evals: AAS 201 is a good course, and Professor Perry is a great lecturer. However, it's a shallow reach into a lot of topics, as you might expect from a survey. Take it as an introduction to African American culture, but don't necessarily expect the deeper analysis higher level courses offer.

Definitely take this course. AAS majors and certificates have to take it anyway, but I would recommend it to anyone who is generally interested. Prof. Perry is phenomenal, and the reading load is super manageable.
Definitely take this course. It's really informative.
Do not rely too much on the precepts.
Do not take this class with Imani Perry. She is brilliant but does not know how to lecture. The class is not structured very well and is more demanding paper wise than you would think.
Do the readings and go to lecture!
Do the readings. Lectures are mandatory but not helpful.
Good intro class. Keep up with readings, and be sure to write good argument strong papers.

Great course, overall. Perry is not the best lecturer, she reads out of the readings a lot and her voice sounds like she wants you to fall asleep. But the information is truly incredible and absolutely necessary for anyone who wants to be anyone in the United States today. Take it, take it. This class has propelled me to take a lot of other AAS classes. Oh, also, the AAS department is great.

I would definitely take this course as soon as possible if you want to pursue an AAS certificate. This is mostly because unless you have never taken an AAS class before, you'll likely recognize most of the material from previous courses in the department. That being said, it's a good course if you want a cultural synthesis of what you have learned in AAS classes. Definitely better suited for someone who has never taken an AAS class before or first year students.
I'm white and this course was my first formal exposure to African American studies. I learned a lot!

If you are interested in getting a certificate or becoming a concentrator in AAS, you are required to take this course. Unfortunately, it will most likely be boring and unhelpful in terms of learning about African American Studies and Cultural Practices. The lectures are dry, and some of the preceptors are very unhelpful. If you can, have you preceptor be Heath Pearson. If you are not getting a certificate or concentrating, take any other course in the department, as they are all fantastic and illuminating. This course is not worth your time otherwise.

If you just want to take an AAS class for general interest, do not take this class. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. It will turn you off to the entire AAS department - and the other classes offered by the department are phenomenal. However, this is a required class for certificates and concentrators - TAKE THIS CLASS. The AAS department is WORTH IT, but be aware that it will be a painful experience for you - dry lectures, readings that are put up untimely, and precepts that are either hit or miss.

If you're not planning on taking this course for the concentration or certificate, I don't think it's worth taking. If you do take it, hopefully you'll get Nyle Fort as a preceptor. He's actually in the field, unlike some of the other preceptors.

Imani Perry is a really good lecturer, and I learned so much from taking this class. If you're interested in getting a broad understanding of the historical development and underpinnings of African American culture, definitely take this class. Also, was a great PDF for my final semester at Princeton.
Not a bad course for those unfamiliar with subject material, lectures can be dull though
Only take this class with Professor Glaude. Professor Perry is amazing, but she is not particularly good at lecturing.
Somewhat boring lecture, not too hard of a class if you're interested.
The workload was very manageable, and taking it as a 5th class would be good idea, but I also didn't get as much out of it.

This course for me turned out to be quite a disappointment. I read about this class in Professor Glaude's "Democracy in Black" and was excited for it to be a rich gateway into the study of African American cultural practices. Instead it turned out to be a disorganized, inconsistent, unengaging and frustrating intro class---the only rewarding part of this class is that it satisfies an AAS certificate requirement.
This is an easy course- not much engagement required. My least favorite so far in the department though.
This was rough...not a heavy workload but material was too broad and disjointed. Only take if you need the certificate.

Took with Imani Perry. Pretty easy course! Papers are not too long and very flexible to your own interests. Lecture can get a little dry but Perry will take attendance if people stop showing up. A good source for little pockets of what AAS is like but so broad.
Would definitely not recommend to take if you're looking for an interesting AAS course. It's not as survey as you would expect. You'll learn just as much and more taking something more specific!
find ways to stay engaged during lectures and be prepared for awful preceptor
take this course if you're interested in culture, though come to this class well-rested as the lecturing style is bound to put you to sleep otherwise
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 150 pages of reading per week.
descrip: As the introductory course required to concentrate or earn a certificate in African American Studies, this course examines the past and present, the doings and the sufferings of Americans of African descent from a multidisciplinary perspective. It highlights the ways in which serious intellectual scrutiny of the agency of black people in the United States help redefine what it means to be American, new world, modern and post modern
title: Introduction to the Study of African American Cultural Practices

evals: I liked this as a survey course. If you can get into the 18th/19th century style of writing, you will enjoy the books. It's interesting to see how prescient some authors were, and how extremely dated other texts seem. Professor Jackson is really likeable and clearly knowledgeable. It's a heavy reading load however, and in my opinion too heavy.
I think the course was good. Some material was repetitive, but if Cassandra Jackson is the teacher, please take!

I would recommend this course only to those who want to immerse themselves in a novel per week and discuss topics such as race. This was my first course on the topic and it opened me up, so I would say that whenever recommending the course to anyone.
I would say try you best to keep up with all the readings, it does get overwhelming.
Take this class. Professor Jackson is an amazing teacher and the material is engaging. I took this for the requirement, but would definitely have taken it by itself.
Take this course! It's interesting and the professor is great!
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Reading 100-150 pages per week. Attendance and participation are mandatory; Two short analytical essays; One in-class final exam; precept assignments.
descrip: This introductory course focuses on black literature and literary culture from the mid-18th century to the early 20th; it will cover the poetry of Phillis Wheatley and Paul L. Dunbar; the political oratory of Sojourner Truth and David Walker; slave narratives by Frederick Douglass and Harriet Jacobs; non-fiction prose by W. E. B. Du Bois and Anna Julia Cooper; and Frances Harper's and James Weldon Johnson's novels. In readings, assignments, and discussions, we will explore the unique cultural contexts, aesthetic debates, and socio-political forces that surround the production of an early African American literary tradition.
title: African American Literature: Origins to 1910

evals: As with any course like this, the key is to do all the reading, but in this course especially it's important to think creatively about each assigned work. Be prepared to ask questions and have criticisms for each author, which will help you both in class and on the written assignments.
Definitely take this course! It will open up a new view of society for all students and its a great introduction to anthropology!
Definitely worth taking. Applying the lens of anthropology on every day life or the things we see on TV or social media is super interesting.
Do the readings if you want to get anything out of this class.
Email the professor for help if one has difficulty analyzing the reading.
Great intro class! Prof Stone is super engaging and material is super applicable to other fields!

I would 100% suggest taking this class if you are interested in re-seeing both how scholars conceptualize the social world and/or re-seeing the social world around you. The readings are challenging but manageable and interesting. I definitely recommend.

I would say to another student taking this course that it is extremely easy, but don't take it if you genuinely want to learn. Only take it if you are not a humanities major or are not interested in anthropology.
Lecturer and preceptor are exceptionally understanding, get there advise for essays and get to know them.
Take it!  You'll read mostly stuff you know you should read anyways at some point (Foucault, Marx, etc).
Take it! I doubt you'd regret it.
Take the class and be prepared to do the work.... doing the readings, participating in class and going to office hours help so much. The class is 100% worth it.
This is a good course for people who have a general interest in anthropology. The lectures are a little dry and the readings can be dense but some is interesting. I would recommend taking it.

This is a good introductory class for anthropology. Professor Stone is incredibly approachable and often a great lecturer. The content matter is often very complex and the readings can be dense but it's a very light workload if you skim the readings. Assignments are very clear and Professor Stone answers any questions. Just know that this class is very philosophic in nature. If you're looking for a more practical review of what anthropology is, don't expect that, but you absolutely will get some foundational philosophy concepts from this course.
otherinfo: Class/Precept participation includes 10% attendance and 10% participation.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Read 70-120 pp. per week. Reading Responses (20%). In-class midterm (30%); 8-10 pp. final paper (30%) due Dean's Date to synthesize a foundational concept learned in class and use it as a lens on a contemporary cultural phenomenon.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to core anthropological modes of inquiry into being human across space and time. Engaging key concepts of culture as lenses on contemporary phenomena, we will explore universalism and variation across societies. How do communities express difference and identity, make meaning, transmit knowledge, circulate objects and power, live, love, wish and dream? Case-studies vary, from women's piety movements in Cairo to the role of mosquitos, germs, and machines in making lives and worlds. We will also consider anthropology's colonial origins, examining intersections between knowledge and domination.
title: Introduction to Anthropology

evals: Always do the readings and come to class prepared if you want to get the most out of it.
Do the readings. Try your best to keep up with Thesis Sem assignments, and enjoy it.
If you're taking this it's most likely for an ANT departmental. Davis is wonderful, take advantage of her office hours!
otherinfo: For administrative reasons, there are two ways of enrolling in ANT 390A/B. ANT 390A is for all students other than seniors in the Anthropology major. ANT 390B is reserved for seniors in the Anthropology major, as it includes enrollment in the Senior Seminar (the ANT 390B "Lab" section). ANT 390A and B are otherwise the same, and meet together.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading: approx 100 pages per week. Papers: 2 short papers at 20% each.
descrip: The course surveys the development of social anthropology by examining the concepts and models used by anthropologists to analyze human diversity and universals, social stability and change, and the relationship between the individual and the group. We explore theoretical debates (evolution, exchange, function, structure, culture, agency, subjectivity, history, power, and globalization) in terms of their capacity to understand human behavior, the social world and modernity.
title: History of Anthropological Theory

grading: Papers - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
prereqs: Although this course is designed for Anthropology graduate students, others may enroll with permission of the instructor.
descrip: First term of a year-long course on sociocultural anthropology, required of first-year graduate students in anthropology and open to graduate students from other disciplines with the permission of the instructor. The seminar focuses on innovations in anthropological theorizing through writings that have historically shaped the field or revealed its shape as a distinctive discipline.
title: Proseminar in Anthropology

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
descrip: Durkheim's concept of social time continues to sustain a broad and varied ethnography; however, it encounters limits in his explicit distinction between social time and the personal experience of time. That disjunction vitiates the potential relevance of temporality as a critical resource - or set of resources - for ethnography. The seminar unsettles that distinction from various angles, and explores the relevance of temporality in current ethnographic writing on law, politics, labor, forms of life beyond the human, and ethnography itself. The purpose of the seminar is to bring new times to ethnographic inquiry.
title: Topics in Social Anthropology - Temporality and Ethnography

evals: A fantastic class for architects and non-architects alike. Professor Rose is a great lecturer and the readings were fascinating. The design project is very time consuming, but it's only a few days out of the semester. The rest of the workload is very manageable with weekly readings totaling ~40 pages and two short papers. Architecture is all around us and you will always be able to apply the lessons of this class to your daily life. Strongly recommend!
Def take as a 5th class, if you need an LA

Definitely take this class. The readings are short and super interesting (if you're interested in different takes on architecture) and the lectures are worth going to, even though they're not necessary to do well in the course.

Doing the readings is essential to being able to get the most out of both the lectures and the precepts. There aren't a lot of assignments and papers due, so it is really up to the student to invest time and effort every week to absorb the information. I would advice people with an interest in architecture to take this class, as the information might be tedious to someone who isn't keen on experimenting in architecture.

I didn't plan on taking this course at the beginning of the semester, but I was convinced after Professor Rose's first lecture, which was terrific (like they all are).  Indeed, it turned out to be an enjoyable, fascinating class that would make me think differently about the buildings I walk through and live in.  This class did more than that, though.  Throughout the course, I began to realize that I was thinking in a profoundly different way than I normally do.  I don't know if I could put a finger on it exactly, but I seemed to be thinking in an artistic way, which as a STEM major I believe I was missing before.  The design assignment is particularly fun.  Anyways, definitely take this course if you want to look up as you walk in cities (or on campus).  It'll make your days more colorful.
I recommend this course if you are interested in learning about the thinking behind architecture and the issues that architecture/architects have faced and continue to face today.

I recommend this course to anyone who may be interested in architecture. The design project gives a little insight into what constructing an architectural model is like, and the other assignments ask very interesting prompts. The course is manageable and interesting!

I took it for the departmental prerequisite... I imagine for non-majors it will be especially cool and inspiring, since architecture is such a complex and engaging topic... but I feel most topics we've barely scratched the surface. I recommend read the readings, take notes, and try to get how they relate to the topic and speak to each other. It would also help to look into building projects introduced in class that seem interesting to you and read more in preparation for papers. Other than that, get a really good cutting knife for the design project!
If you are interested in learning and reading about architectural theory, this is a great class. If you aren't, you will probably be very bored, and find yourself wondering why any of it matters.
If you're interested in the artistic side of architecture and want an lower-workload class, this is definitely a great choice!

Julian Rose is an INCREDIBLE lecturer, would highly recommend this course (plus fulfills LA requirement). Minimal work, only submit questions each week, and two papers. Super inspiring lectures and makes you appreciate architecture even if you may not want to major in it!

Keep up with the readings. Meet with your preceptor and Julian so that you can pass your ideas for your paper through them and so you know what they are looking for. 

participate in precept! It's a big part of your grade and will contribute to your understanding of concepts!

Please do take with Julian. He is one of the best lecturers at Princeton imo. Readings are super light, papers are short. Yet you learn a TON about architecture as a field. It will challenge you to rethink how you experience space.

Some of the readings were boring/way too academic, and some of them were super eye-opening and relevant to things I was learning in other classes. It was more theoretical than I expected (and more philosophical that I was prepared for), so the class is definitely what the title says - architectural THINKING.
Take it!

Take it! It's super interesting. It's not a big time commitment, and not very difficult to learn and succeed. If you show up, do the work (which is not very much) you will learn a lot and get a good grade. And Professor Rose is an amazing lecturer!
Take this class!!!! The lectures are all extremely interesting and enjoyable, there is not too much work and I really learned a lot. I'm not an architecture major but I loved it!
Take this course if you are interested in architecture or looking for an LA distribution. The material is interesting and the papers are fun to write.
Take this course! It is not only for architecture majors

The course was a great introduction to both a general history of architecture and an understanding of what concepts architects grapple with in their work. I learned to see architecture beyond just buildings, as a intellectual discipline full of debate and theory.
This class is very manageable and would definitely recommend it if you have an interest in architecture. The lectures are very helpful, as the lecture slides only have pictures and no descriptions.
This is not an art-history like course. This course brings up debates in the architectural world, and is more helpful if you already know a lot about architecture I think.

This will open up your mind to new approaches and internal debates within architecture. Even if you're more interested in civil/mechanical engineering or art history, this class is extremely relevant! It bridges disciplines and really provides a good foundation with which to approach the architecture around you or to further develop your architectural skills.

Thorough course on the subject matter, Julian Rose is a really engaging instructor. Very appropriate amount of work, papers for midterm and final, assignments are all written - great if you hate in-class tests and quizzes.
take it, get kate as preceptor
otherinfo: Architectural thinking will be explored thematically by focusing upon a series of significant debates (historical and contemporary) about tectonics, program, representation, and urbanism. Debates will include history versus utopia, handcrafted versus machine made, generic versus iconic, form versus program, drawing versus scripting, and image versus surface, among others.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: 60-80 pages of reading a week. Precepts will discuss reading assignments and study individual buildings in depth, linking discussions to lectures. Assignments will include student presentations of readings and buildings in precept, a midterm exam, and a final project consisting of a thorough analysis of a single, significant work of architecture.
descrip: The objective of this course is to provide a broad overview of the discipline of architecture: its history, theories, methodologies; its manners of thinking and working. Rather than a chronological survey, the course will be organized thematically, with examples drawn from a range of historical periods as well as contemporary practice. Through lectures, readings, and discussions every student will acquire a working knowledge of key texts, buildings and architectural concepts.
title: Introduction to Architectural Thinking

evals: (for non-majors): A difficult general interest course/ elective, but incredibly rewarding.

A tough course at times. At first you feel that you don't know anything. Is this a history course? Is this an architectural theory course? How does history of architectural theory merge the two - this is what the course is about. It is more than memorizing names and who said what in their book, but thinking about larger themes of authorship, transfer of knowledge, and how we represent history and theory in the written form and in the physical form of architecture.
I feel that this should be a must take course for any student passing through the PSOA.

I would encourage any architecture major to take it. Lucia is brilliant and engaging and the readings are really good. For non-architecture majors I would not recommend because it is really intended only for people with a strong interest in architectural theory.
I would recommend this course to architecture majors or other students with an interest in architectural theory.
It's a lot of reading and the material is often confusing. But take it if you want to challenge yourself.

Not an intro course! There were lots and lots of readings, and you feel like you won't know anything if you don't read them for lecture/precept. Professor Lucia is very passionate but speaks way too fast. Would not recommend if you don't have time to read and are not interested in anything architecture related. If you are exploring architecture, I would recommend 204 instead.
Take it! it's a lot of work for a 300 level class but well worth it
The lectures are phenomenal. The material is presented quickly, so be prepared to be on your toes the entire time.

This class is essential for students writing or who will write independent work related to architecture and perhaps even aesthetics. Its a rewarding course, but really difficult to keep up with. The workload in terms of reading and writing is a lot, but absolutely will transform your understanding of theory if you put in the effort. Lucia is thoughtful and her opinions will challenge much of what you think you know about the 20th century of architectural history and theory.
otherinfo: Graduate precept will be taught by professor.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 15%, Take Home Final Exam - 50%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading assignments are estimated at 120 pages per week. Weekly reading responses are to be posted on the course website. One in-class presentation, two short writing assignments, one 10/12-page final paper.
prereqs: Course open to undergraduate and graduate students. Of particular interest to art history, history, and architecture students. No prerequisites, but HIS 211, ART 333 and ART 322 are strongly recommended as background..
descrip: This course offers a history of architectural theory, criticism, and historiography from the Renaissance to the present, emphasizing the texts, media and institutions that have supported architecture's claim to modernity since the late 17th Century. Architectural thought is examined in its social and cultural context as it relates both to the Western philosophical tradition and to design method and practice.
title: History of Architectural Theory

evals: An interesting course.

Definitely take this class if you're interested in architecture or construction. As much as you may initially dread the thought of walking all the way down to the arch lab, it's worth it. It's so much fun to just go down and build stuff - for a grade. Bill's great and will help you out the whole way through! This class is really a class where you'll learn a ton without being too stressed about work.
I would suggest planning and beginning the construction of the final project much sooner than the instructors suggest if you want to be finished with it before the end of the semester.
It's a required class.
The class is a requirement for all ARC majors. Take it to fulfill the requirement otherwise I am not sure what one would gain by taking this course.

This class is a bit of a joke. However, it is a requirement for architecture majors. Lectures are boring and are not very helpful. Labs are usually fun, and Bill is a great instructor. You can ask him anything, and he will always answer with a smile. Nat will not give much notice about the midterm bench project, so you should ask him about it before fall break if he doesn't mention anything.
otherinfo: In order to complete the requirements of this course, it is important that students have acquired either technical drawing skills or the ability to draw using CAD software. A final exam (40%), final project (40%), drawing assignments (10%) and lab (10%) comprise the final grade.
grading: Design Project - 40%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: There are weekly reading assignments that dovetail with and compliment the topics introduced during lecture. The readings are mandatory. There is a number of other small drawing assignments issued during the course. There is also a final drawing assignment that constitutes 40% of the course grade. Students should expect to spend about 2 hours a week to complete readings and assignments. The final assignment could include drawing, research, or a small construction project.
prereqs: The material in class requires students to have some experience and understanding of architectural design, drawings and details. It is required that undergraduate students have completed ARC 203, ARC 204 before embarking on this class. Engineering majors earning an architecture certificate should contact the instructor for permission to enroll in the course..
descrip: This course introduces students to the art and science of building. Emphasis will be placed gaining an understanding of construction materials, methods and the process of translating design ideas into built form. Specific topics are introduced each week during the two one-hour lectures. These topics are then further explored, and students gain hands on experience, each week during the two-hour laboratory component of the course.
title: Building Science and Technology: Building Systems

evals: I would definitely recommend this class if you are at all interested in the history of cities, how they work, housing problems, anything of the sort.

Take it if you are interested at all in urban studies. The readings, though long, are actually pretty enjoyable and informational. I decided to pursue a certificate in urban studies after taking this course.

The readings are quite heavy and the professor expects you to know them all very well. Very structured class. The ideas presented are very interesting and definitely changed the way I thought about cities. The manifesto was a very fun project.

Well worth taking, but may be a bit uninteresting if you've already taken an architecture survey, since it largely deals with big-name theorists (Le Corbusier, Wright, Jacobs, Debord, etc.). You will love the manifesto assignment.
otherinfo: The course is open to undergraduate and graduate students, although undergraduates will be given preference in enrollment.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Every student is expected to keep up with readings on a weekly basis. In addition to a discussion of the assigned readings at the weekly meetings, there will be occasional group exercises. Students are expected to be active participants in the class. Students will write a short outline, a draft, and a final term paper of approximately 5,000 words on a topic approved by the instructor. Students will also work in groups on a manifesto which will account for 25% of the grade.
descrip: The seminar will explore theories of urbanism and housing by reading canonical writers who have created distinctive and influential ideas about urbanism and housing from the nineteenth century to the present. The writers are architects, planners, and social scientists. The theories are interdisciplinary. One or two major works will be discussed each week. We will critically evaluate their relevance and significance for architecture now. Topics include: modernism, technological futurism, density, the new urbanism, the networked city, landscape urbanism, and sustainable urbanism.
title: Theories of Housing and Urbanism

evals: Take it with an open mind. A thesis is a year-long endeavor, so it has its limits, but what you can learn from the process can be more important than what you find and produce.
otherinfo: This course is restricted to concentrators in the School of Architecture.
grading: Design Project - 35%, Papers - 45%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: See professor for assignments
descrip: We will consider that a successful thesis entails the meeting of a socio-cultural problematic with a specific disciplinary issue, that the confluence and exchange between these external and internal situations can instigate an original contribution to architectural knowledge and technique. The "newness" of this contribution comes through a particular kind of repetition, a wily swerve within the established canon. The seminar will introduce disciplinary methods and themes through close readings of architectural texts and objects and will provide a workshop for the testing and elaboration of architectural polemics through directed research.
title: Topics in the History and Theory of Architecture

evals: Some students may find the material challenging at first so I encourage them to ask as many questions as possible. Axel is extremely approachable and willing to talk about anything. Just make sure you're prepared and on top of getting work done for the course.. it adds up!

This class, like a lot of studio/design seminars at princeton is what you make of it. You can spend 20 hours a week on assignments if you want to, but you can also get by not doing that. You just won't learn as much. You get to play with a lot of things you might not otherwise have access to (esp as a non-architecture major), like a laser cutter or arduino kit. Plus the instructors are really experienced and helpful. I would definitely recommend to anyone, whether you're a COS major or an architecture major who's never coded before.

This is a really great course to be introduced to various digital tools; the assignments scratch the surface of each tool just enough for you to feel somewhat comfortable, so it's very much an introductory course
otherinfo: No previous computer experience is assumed. The emphasis in the course will be on the implications of the development of computational models for design and fabrication in architecture, and the conceptual and technical understanding required to produce them. Note: the final project in this course is a design project, which will be worth 40% of the final grade.
grading: Design Project - 70%, Programming Assignments - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: There will be three components to the class. The first is a series of weekly and bi-weekly exercises that will be presented in class. Second, there will be discussions of ongoing work in progress linking it to the readings. Finally, there will be a final digital fabrication project due at the end of the term.
prereqs: Open to ARC and CEE - Arch & Engineering students ONLY. If seminar is oversubscribed, enrollment will be based on seniority..
descrip: This course is an introduction to computational design using a range of design concepts from NURBS modeling, simple programming and parametric modeling to basic digital fabrication and electronics. Through a series of computational exercises, presentations, and in-class discussions, we will investigate the evolving relationship between models of design and generative design issues of technology and culture in architecture.
title: Computational Design

evals: I would advise students to have a firm grasp on the current software used in architectural design, namely Rhinocerous and Autocad. Struggling to learn these programs while also trying to design will prove frustrating.
grading: Design Project - 100%
descrip: Design Studio
title: Architecture Design Studio

evals: A challenging studio but Paul is always willing to provide feedback. Expect to learn alot about structures and thermodynamics.
If you're an MArch, you have to take it. Always have drawings printed for Paul so he can sketch over it. You will get more out of it that way.
It's a good studio.
Meet deadlines. Treat it like professional practice.
grading: Design Project - 100%
descrip: Explores architecture as a social art and the spatial organization of the human environment. Projects include a broad range of problem types, including individual buildings, groups of buildings, urban districts, and landscapes.
title: Integrated Building Studios

evals: This is a great course if you are self-driven and independent enough to carry your project.
grading: Design Project - 100%
assgts: Students are assigned design problems of varying scope. Amount of time spent in each subject area varies from critic to critic; typically 20-25% of the time is spent on research and analysis, while the remaining 75-80% of the time is spent on design. Completed projects are reviewed by faculty and invited critics, and clarity of public presentation is stressed.
prereqs: ARC 501, ARC 502, or Advanced Standing. Two Vertical Studio courses are required for all Master of Architecture students..
descrip: The Vertical Design Studio emphasizes site organization, the development of building plans, and the accompanying expression of architectural character in three dimensions.
title: Architecture Design Studio

evals: A great studio for exploring new technologies and constructing real, working prototypes. You will learn many additional skills. Materials for prototyping can get a bit expensive, depending on what you are constructing. The earlier you start prototyping, the better.
The students should start with a simple idea and build on it throughout time because coding gets complex very fast
This studio is worth it youll learn things the belong to our contemporary life.
grading: Design Project - 100%
assgts: Students are assigned design problems of varying scope. Amount of time spent in each subject area varies from critic to critic; typically 20-25% of the time is spent on research and analysis, while the remaining 75-80% of the time is spent on design. Completed projects are reviewed by faculty and invited critics, and clarity of public presentation is stressed.
prereqs: ARC 501, ARC 502, or Advanced Standing, M..Arch. desgree. Two Vertical Studio courses are required for all Master of Architecture students..
descrip: The Vertical Design Studio emphasizes site organization, the development of building plans, and the accompanying expression of architectural character in three dimensions.
title: Architecture Design Studio

evals: Recommend
grading: Design Project - 100%
prereqs: Graduate standing and completion of studio sequence ARC 501-ARC 506..
descrip: The Master of Architecture Thesis is an independent design project on a theme selected by the student, incorporating research, programming, and site definition.
title: Thesis Studio

evals: Buy the textbooks. It's tempting to not do so because they tend to be expensive, but it will save you many hours of work and tears of frustration in the long run.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
descrip: After having taken this class, students are able to: 1) Recognize and explain how external forces (due to people, wind, heat,etc) act upon rigid bodies (eg.a skateboard, bridge, cable and arches, frames, grids and plates, shells and membranes) in the real world, 2) Identify and apply the appropriate analytical approach to quantify how strong such a rigid body is under the applied loading, 3) Write an informed critique about prominent structural designs.
title: Structural Analysis for Architecture

evals: Attend class, do the work.
I think this is an important course. I would urge students to take it more seriously, or at least just show up.
It's a requirement if you haven't done environment before so just try to make the most of it and get something out of it.
otherinfo: Students will be assessed on the quality of their classroom participation, assignments and project work as well as on quiz results. There will be no mid-term or final examinations.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: The course includes classroom instruction, assignments, quizzes and short field trips. Over the two terms, students work in groups of 4 to 6 to design a building that integrates the various building systems with architecture and structure. The projects explore the opportunities provided by climatic conditions and building systems to inform and enrich architectural design, ultimately resulting in a carbon neutral building.
prereqs: All undergraduate students must have permission of the instructor to enroll..
descrip: The first part of a sequence taught over two terms that provides a broad introduction to Building Systems, Environmental Control and Energy Conservation. Sustainable design themes and environmentally responsible practices are stressed throughout and form a backdrop to all the instructional material provided. The fall course focuses on fundamental concepts and provides an introduction to Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing, Lighting, Acoustical and Life Safety systems. ARC 515, taught in the spring, considers the design process and the integration of these systems into buildings.
title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: All undergraduate students must have permission of the instructor to enroll.
grading: Design Project - 33%, Oral Presentation(s) - 33%, Term Paper(s) - 33%, Other (See Instructor) - 1%
assgts: Class sessions will consist of lectures, quizzes, analog drawing labs, several one-week analog drawing exercises and a semester digital drawing project. One research paper and a formal analysis.
prereqs: ARC Graduate Students Only..
descrip: Introduction to the primary projective systems that form the foundations of architectural representation and serve as essential tools of formal analysis and design. Coursework will be derived from a structured examination of key primary sources by Gaspard Monge, Brook Taylor and Girard Desargues.
title: Introduction to Formal Analysis

evals: Course with lots of information, meticulously prepared. Lots of visual representations (as it is about photography), larger historical connections were clearly described. I would reccomend the course to anybody who is interested in architectural representation trough the medium of photography.
If you want to take this course because of the subject, don't take it. The professor is not involved at all and it doesn't have a deep knowledge on the topic
Professor Cohen trusted his extremely interesting life experiences and vast knowledge in architecture not to prepare classes and not to take any risks in the seminars.
n/a
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
descrip: Since the second wave of colonialism, and increasingly after 9/11 and the Global War on Terror, wars have moved to cities and urban areas. The seminar investigates how wars and built environments have intimately shape each other throughout military, architectural, and planning histories. The aim is to explore architecture and urban planning in war zones and examine the strategic design of destructions and constructions of built environments, including fortifications, barricades, bases, borders, bunkers, camps, prisons, towers, tunnels, and walls.
title: Advanced Topics in Modern Architecture - Wars, Architecture and Cities

evals: DO the work, dont hesitate to ask questions. Engage as much as possible.
Do take this seminar, and make sure to complete all the readings to fully engage during class time. Sylvia Lavin is very intellectually engaging
It's easy to be overwhelmed with the research and the amount of materials to cover. The only way to get through it is to narrow down to focus on one thing.
otherinfo: Class will meet every other week for six hours.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Assigned readings, completed before relevant class. Participation in assigned building presentations. Final paper/project.
descrip: This seminar examines the history and theory of exhibition-making in architecture from its origin as a tool in the production of architectural publics in the 18th century to its contemporary aegis as a producer of architectural curators as authors. The history of exhibitions as such will be considered in relation to the auxiliary frameworks that shape, amplify and subtend them, from criticism to installation design, from the catalog to contemporary social media.
title: Topics in Contemporary Architectural Theory - Exhibition Models

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: Undergraduate students are welcome but must have permission of the instructor to enroll.
grading: Quizzes - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: The carrying out of architectural services goes beyond design and involves obligations to the public, to clients, to peers and employees. This course deals with the contracts, specifications, technical documentation, project management, and the construction administration phases of architectural services in designing and constructing buildings. The course is required for the Master of Architecture degree unless you have taken Professional Practice in a 5-year program.
title: Introduction to the Architecture Profession

evals: Take this seminar: challenging, but perfect to develop an independent research
otherinfo: This advanced pro-seminar explores architectural research techniques through collaborative investigation of a specific issue facing the field. Rather than study research methods in the abstract, students are asked to actively carry out detailed research in teams and reflect upon its limits and potentials. The research project of each semester is carried through to realization in the form of a book, a conference, or an exhibition organized by the students in subsequent semesters.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
prereqs: Open to Ph.D. students only.
descrip: Architecture is understood as having a normalizing function, establishing patterns that are stable, predictable, and to some extent standardized. The right angle is called the normal and it is very hard to find in nature. The right angle belongs to culture, to architecture. Architecture sees itself as the caretaker of the normal. But the normal is not normal. It is a kind of artifact, always produced, never found. It is a construction involving a certain violence. Meanwhile there is a hidden tradition in architecture of the transgressive, work that crosses the lines of the normal, complicating these lines, threatening the limit.
title: Research in Architecture - The Supernormal and the Transgressive

evals: If you are looking for a new design approach to architecture and want to delve into new computational design tools to help aid your designs, take this class! Ryan will go above and beyond to help you understand the material and help you realize an amazing final project. Although demanding, this course will change the way you approach the architecture design process.
The final push for the class is extremely intense, but very rewarding. You won't do anything like this anywhere else.
otherinfo: Students will focus on the analysis & construction of sophisticated production pipelines using various high-end software environments, leveraging advances pioneered by studios working in the film & gaming industries. These pipeline prototypes will look ahead to the practice of the very near future by interrogating, gaming & modding the digital media infrastructures that act as dynamic repositories of architectural intelligence.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Students will be asked to design and produce digitally based projects in ways unique to the specific technologies. Coursework will be divided between lecture/demonstrations and work sessions that take place in the computer lab and the digital fabrication studio.
descrip: This course on digital media infrastructure will explore breaking technologies of fabrication, modeling and design based on production pipelines pioneered by the film and gaming industries--pipelines we will author in CATIA, McNeel's Rhino/Grasshopper, and Bentley's Generative Components. A series of formal experiments will be carried out each culminating in the fabrication of rapid prototypes using the CNC mill and the InVision 3D printer, explicitly challenging conventional modes of practice and seeking insight into new forms of organization, techniques and operative procedures.
title: Computing and Imaging in Architecture

evals: Arabic is a challenging but very fun language. Tarek is an amazing teacher and you will definitely learn a lot and have fun in his class. One thing to be aware of is that, as with any language course, in order to be successful you need to be able to devote at least an hour if not more to consistent study each day in order to not feel overwhelmed.

Arabic is hard if you have no prior experience to it or any related language. Take the class seriously. It takes a lot of time outside of the classroom to perform well in Arabic especially at the beginning.

Definitely take the class with Professor Tarek! He is such a great professor and really helps build up a strong Arabic foundation. Also be prepared to have work everyday! It is a time commitment to learn this language well.
Do it.

Frankly, when studied everyday, arabic is not such a hard language ; or at least this class is not that hard.
Take Pr Gregory Bell ! He is fun and teaches well, he always have some anecdotes from when he was living in the Middle East.
Avoid Thomas Hefter though, in drill.
Good introductory class. Ustaadh Tom is a great teacher and the classes are very structured and easy to follow and learn from. I never had an issue with the workload or too difficult subject matter.
I am not sure if classroom time is used effectively.

I would absolutely recommend them to take the course. Although Arabic is often an intimidating language, Professor Bell made it completely approachable, fun, and gratifying. All in all, it is a course that requires a lot of your time and effort, but is all the while worth ti.

I would advise another student to devote as much time into this class as possible because you only get out what you put into this class. If you don't devote a lot of time into this class, you will understand or be able to speak as well as you want to, especially in class and during oral exercises.

I would advise them to do their homework diligently and show up as regularly to class as possible because the class is very well structured and if you follow the structure of the class and the regular assignments, it's easy to follow.
If you feel interested in Arabic, I strongly recommend taking the course. Also Prof. Bell's section is great.

If you want to learn Arabic, it will give you a good base, but it is very slow.  Take it with Tarek, even if it's at 9:00.  He's worth waking up for.
I personally learn best through immersion, so this was not the class for me.  I was often frustrated with my lack of progress for the amount of work I put in, and, because of that, I'm not taking 102.  If you can learn by memorizing words, it should be fine.

If you're interested, go for it! Lots of resources at your disposal. As someone who previously only learned Romance languages/German, Arabic was a huge departure from what I was used to, but it's very worthwhile!

Prepare to actually put forth effort enthusiastically. If there is one thing to understand, it is that you will miss out on immense value and brilliant instruction if you ignore the daily responsibilities of learning a language.

Professor Bell is great. He is very knowledgeable and very kind and understanding. Does his best to teach us and also to be an accommodating professor who actually realizes we are people and not just work machines.Overall there is almost nightly homework that takes about 15-30 minutes. Quizzes and tests are very fair.
Take professor Tarek's class.

Take the course with Greg Bell. He fully explains the material, and he understand some of us are true beginners. He is wonderful! I took this course out of general interest for the language and enjoyed it quite a bit.
Take the course, the material is great.
Tarek Elsayed is the ideal instructor. Class is exciting and he is a native speaker. The course has its flaws, but it is very worth it.
This course is great and provides an excellent introduction to the Arabic language and culture!

This is a great beginning class to Arabic! Greg is definitely the best professor to have. Tip: commit to studying the vocabulary before the night before; you will do so well in the course if you learn your vocabulary correctly!
wonderful class, greg is honestly the best person. his passion is clear and he's a great teacher. get him if you can!
otherinfo: This is the first semester of a two-term language course. Please note that those who arrive late during "shopping period" (the first week of the course) are responsible for making up all work missed. No new students will be allowed into the class after the first full week of classes. Students are required to attend an additional one-hour long drill each week.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Fewer than 50 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: No credit is given for ARA 101 unless it is followed by ARA 102..
descrip: This class develops the basic structures and vocabulary for understanding, speaking, writing and reading Modern Standard Arabic, the shared formal variety of Arabic used throughout the Arab world. Students will also gain some familiarity with both Egyptian and Syrian colloquial dialects. Classroom activities are designed to foster communication and cultural competence through comprehension and grammar exercises, skits, conversation, and the use of a variety of audio-visual materials.
title: Elementary Arabic I

evals: Choose Nancy.
Class is not too bad. Do all the HW, review with the review packets. Tests tend to be fair, only one of three was too hard.
Don't be afraid to ask for help!
Fun class to learn Arabic and practice conversational skills
If you took first year Arabic, the transition to ARA 105 is very natural. Ustaadh Faris is great!
If you want to know Arabic, you can't go wrong with Nancy. She's fantastic.

If you've already taken 101/102, this is no departure from that model. I would recommend taking the class with Faris. Nancy and Greg are amazing, but Faris is a bit stricter in speaking only Arabic during class which I found was helpful.

It's hard trying to learn to languages at once (basically what doing both a dialect and fosha is), so I think no matter how the courses are designed, your learning of Arabic can be spread a bit thin between literary and conversational? but if you're able to coordinate it with things outside the courses, like research in Arabic or regular interactions, it's a very good asset. If you do Arabic, do a lot of Arabic
Take it if willing to commit significant time outside of class.

Take this course! If you're thinking about 2nd year Arabic, chances are you're already in it for the long haul, but anyways, this year's material isn't as difficult as the first year in my opinion, and more time is devoted to focusing on chapters. Really enjoyed the class.  Ustaadh Faris is the best!
The professor is very caring and reachable - she always puts forth the effort to help you understand the language. If you do not understand something, always reach out for extra help and practice.
This course is great like all of the Arabic language courses. It can be frustrating at times because it is a foreign language but I've definitely improved and that's rewarding.
This course is still a lot of work, but your level of Arabic will increase dramatically. There's a big payoff in your ability to speak, read, and write after this semester.

Ustaadth Faris is great. You'll speak a good amount of Arabic and pick up some Shaami here and there as Ustaadth Faris is a native Shaami speaker. Sometimes the grammar learning feels disorganized, but no worse than in any other section.
honestly wouldn't start arabic unless you know you're gonna have a good teacher cause its really really hard
grading: Final Exam - 25%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Students are expected to spend at least 10 hours per week on assignments outside of class. Fewer than 50 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: ARA 102 or permission of the Department..
descrip: This course builds on the skills developed in Elementary Arabic. Students in this course work to improve their proficiency in speaking, listening, reading and writing. We will focus primarily on Modern Standard Arabic in reading and writing, but Levantine and/or Egyptian dialect will be used in informal speaking and listening exercises.
title: Intermediate Arabic I

evals: Amazing professor.
Depends on your desired future use of Arabic. Lots of grammar and feels less useful than the first two years judged on a by-effort basis.
Take this course if you are prepared to take charge of your own learning, put in effort and be passionate about learning the language

This class is very necessary if you want to improve your language skills. It may not seem a lot since the first two years you learn a lot as well but if you want an in-depth understanding of grammar and concepts, this class is necessary. Tarek is phenomenal and makes you want to come to class to learn. Could not recommend having class with him more
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Readings (fewer than 50 pages per week), compositions, listening exercises and other drills. Students can expect to devote 10-12 hours per week on assignments.
descrip: This course will focus almost exclusively on grammar and classical texts. Language of instruction will be English.
title: Advanced Arabic I

otherinfo: Additional readings from primary and secondary sources may be assigned. For department majors, satisfies Group 2 distribution requirement. Enrollment in precepts will be done using SCORE.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Average 40 pages of reading weekly, plus study of photographs; total about 3-4 hours. In addition, students are encouraged to visit the collections of Italian Renaissance painting and sculpture in New York and Philadelphia.
descrip: Lectures will examine the birth, rise and flowering of Italian Renaissance art in Tuscany, Rome and Venice from about 1250 to 1600 A.D., with emphasis on the 15th and 16th centuries. Artists and works of art will be presented, whenever possible and relevant, within their cultural, political, social, technological and/or economic circumstances. Among the major artists to be studied: Giotto, Ghiberti, Donatello, Masaccio, Botticelli, Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Titian.
title: Italian Renaissance Painting and Sculpture

evals: Get starting on Blackboard readings and posts early.
Go to lecture. It's all the finals are based on.

I hadn't taken a single art history course in my life and this one was a great start! It really introduces you to modern art without making you memorize every single piece, its artist, and with what medium it was created. The lectures were interesting, a little slow and sleepy, but I thoroughly enjoyed my time in the class. Generally, this class was also low-stress and low-commitment.
I would say that you should only take this course if you already have a basic knowledge in art history and specifically art theory.
Interesting art history course.
One of the harder lectures out there but Foster is super knowledgeable and presses you to think
Professor Foster is a great lecturer!
Professor Foster is a great lecturer, definitely go to lecture and you will be well prepared.
TAKE THIS COURSE for an easy LA. PDF the course and you can opt out of the final paper at the end of the semester.

Take this course if you're interested in art and serious about learning about modernism. It's not very hard to get an A even if youre not and art major, so long as you take it fairly seriously and have good writing skills.

Take this course! Really interesting even if you're not an Art History major. It can be very abstract and you use a different part of your brain, but it's a unique way to learn about politics/society in the period of the two World Wars.

The art covered at the beginning of the semester was much more interesting for me, but overall a comprehensive course that can decode some of the weirdest modern art works and artists out there. Would recommend it as a PDF course (esp since it exempted me from a long research paper). But only take it if Professor Foster is teaching--he is the one who wrote the textbook and a very well-known figure in the art world today.

This course is SO MUCH WORK. At least two or three times the amount of work compared to other 200-level ART classes. In addition, you will have no contact with Professor Foster at all. Very dogmatic. I'm glad I took it because it made me realize that I didn't like modern art, or at least the way it was taught at Princeton.

This is a class you should definitely consider taking. I feel much more knowledgable about modern art and even conversant about the more esoteric stuff in modern art history. Sometimes the lectures can get a little abstract and over your head, but if anything it's a good opportunity to expand your horizons (if taking as an elective or for general interest)
Very good class to get an understanding of modern art (primarily European, American only got one lecture). Papers and exams are easy. Readings are manageable while informative and compelling.
take it! go to lecture.
otherinfo: For department majors, satisfies Group 3 distribution requirement.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Midterm, term paper, short paper, and final. Approximately 50 pages of reading per week.
descrip: A critical study of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of modernist art from Post-Impressionism to the "Degenerate" art show. Among our topics: primitivism, abstraction, collage, the readymade, machine aesthetics, photographic reproduction, the art of the insane, artists in political revolution, anti-modernism. Two lectures, one preceptorial.
title: Modernist Art: 1900 to 1950

evals: Good course
One of my favorite classes at Princeton - take it!
Take it whether or not you have art history experience. I had never taken an art history class before and found the work manageable while incredibly interesting.

Take this course if you are interested in Japanese arts (as well as culture!) or just for a distribution requirements. Professor Watsky is a captivating lecturer. Go to his office hours if you need help writing the papers! The course load is very manageable.
otherinfo: For department majors, satisfies Group 1 or 2 distribution requirement.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: There will be a mid-term and a final exam, and two papers.
descrip: ART 217 surveys the arts of Japan from the pre-historic period through the present day. Painting, sculpture, and architecture form the core of study, though we will also examine the critical role of other forms, including calligraphy, lacquer, and ceramics. Throughout the course we will take close account of the broader cultural and historical contexts in which art was made. Our topics include the ongoing tension in Japanese art between the foreign and the indigenous, the role of ritual in Japan's visual arts, the re-uses of the past, the changing loci of patronage, and the formats and materials of Japanese art.
title: The Arts of Japan

evals: Start the papers early, especially the term paper.
Take this course if you'd like a good background on photography and famous photographers, and are invested enough in the subject that this background would be worthwhile.

professor really knows her stuff and the class is pretty informative and interesting; not a lot of work, just a longer final paper; only weekly work is attendance; all she wants is for you to take notes during class; readings aren't even that necessary
otherinfo: Some classes will be held in the Photographic Study Room of the Princeton Art Museum. Students will be expected to visit an exhibition (locally or in Philadelphia or New York) in order to write a review for one assignment and to attend lectures by visiting photographers and scholars on campus. For department majors, satisfies Group 3 distribution requirement.
grading: Papers - 45%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 40%
assgts: Readings in primary and secondary sources assigned for each class (ca. 50-100 pp. week); three short papers, including one exhibition review (5 pages); oral presentation; term paper (10 pages)
prereqs: This course does not require a background in art history, although previous coursework in twentieth-century art or history would be helpful..
descrip: By focusing on six major figures, this course examines the ways that photography was transformed from a poor stepchild of the fine arts to a staple of museum exhibitions. Students will consider such topics as the impact of abstraction on photography; the interactions between art photography and the new print and cinematic mass media; and development of photographic collections and criticism. The careers of Stieglitz, Moholy-Nagy, Weston, Walker Evans, Robert Frank, and Cindy Sherman will form springboards for broader discussions of photography's critical importance for twentieth-century thinking about the real and the imaginary.
title: Masters and Movements of 20th-Century Photography

evals: A highly recommended class.

What you get out of this course is very much what you put into it. Professor Barber expects a high level of engagement and insight into what you've read?ALWAYS be prepared to discuss. If you're an undergraduate passionate about art and want to experience what a graduate course may be like, GO FOR IT!
otherinfo: For department majors, satisfies Group 2 distribution requirement. This course is co-taught by Professor Charles Barber and graduate student Katherine L. King through the Collaborative Teaching Initiative.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading: Approximately 100-150 pages per week. Students will write and present a term paper.
descrip: This course will explore the modes and meanings of representations of different types of bodies in the art of the East Roman Empire (ca. 700 to 1453). Weekly meetings will center around a group of readings and images that focus on a particular type of body within the Byzantine world. The course will begin with the imperial body, cover Christ, martyrs, and saints, and conclude with the bodies of Byzantine and modern viewers. The textual and visual material in discussion will prompt students to think critically about the relationship between historical and represented bodies and the kinds of signification the body was and is made to bear.
title: Seminar. Medieval Art - Emperors, Angels, and Martyrs: Bodies in Byzantium

otherinfo: Required for incoming graduate students in the Western program. Students from other departments with methodological interests are also welcome.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: A course designed to inform students in the theoretical foundations of the discipline as well as in the methodological innovations of the last few decades.
title: Proseminar in the History of Art

otherinfo: Juniors and Seniors must email the faculty instructor for permission.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
descrip: Modernism teaches us how to survive civilization, Benjamin once speculated. After the horrors of World War II this project became a necessity. The seminar examines artists and theorists (e.g., Bataille, Dubuffet, Jorn, Oldenburg) who attempted to start again from scratch through different turns to the brut and the brutal, the animal and the outsider. What might this "positive barbarism" teach us about how to respond to emergency in our own time?
title: Seminar in Modernist Art and Theory - Brutal Aesthetics

otherinfo: Classes often meet in the photographic study room of the Princeton University Art Museum to examine prints by Stieglitz and his colleagues. In addition, the class visits the Metropolitan Museum of Art photo study room and the exhibition, "Clarence H. White and His World: The Art and Craft of Photography, 1895-1925," in the Princeton University Art Museum.
grading: Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
descrip: Alfred Stieglitz is one of the mythical heroes of American twentieth-century photography and avant-garde art, largely based on his activities as an artist, gallerist, editor and founder of the Photo-Secession and the Little Galleries at 291 Fifth Avenue. This seminar reconsiders Stieglitz's unedited oeuvre, the marketing of modern art and photography in New York, and the networks of writers, musicians, painters, photographers, social reformers, Jewish philanthropists, patrons, and journalists who shaped his career and contributed to his outsized reputation.
title: Seminar in History of Photography - Alfred Stieglitz & American Photography

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: The seminar examines the diverse arts employed in pre-modern chanoyu, the Japanese secular ritual of tea, including ceramics, paintings, lacquer, calligraphy, and architecture. Special attention is given to period texts written about tea objects. Among the topics considered are the physical and conceptual adaptations of objects (both indigenous and non-Japanese) for the tea context, the aesthetic terms tea practitioners created for chanoyu objects, the practice of bestowing names on objects, and the ensemble use of objects of different mediums. Seminar members may also, if they wish, study objects outside Japanese tea as comparative examples.
title: Seminar in Japanese Art and Archaeology - Japanese Tea and the Visual Arts

evals: Consider taking the graduate class instead.
GR is a must take for any physics major into theory. Attend the lectures and do the psets. You will also learn about the current cool stuff such as gravitational waves, accelerating expansion etc.

GR is hard.  It is a cool topic, but in its current form I would advise against taking AST 301.  Professor Goodman lectured from powerpoint slides which were often hard to follow, and offered little in the way of motivation or explanation for concepts.  If you are dead-set on taking GR, consider taking the physics version.
Go on
Go to office hours!
Interesting course and good material. I would recommend to those who are interested.
Take time to go over the lectures and readings.
The best course I've had at Princeton.

There is a graduate level seminar on General Relativity that's apparently much better taught, and the workload is so much easier. Our TA was taking that seminar and she told us it took her way longer to do our psets for the undergrad class.

This course is billed as "now that you've been exposed to this, you'll understand it a lot better the next time you take it". If you're hoping to fully grasp GR this time around, you probably won't since doing GR properly requires differential geometry - something very rare to have at undergrad level. This means that concepts need to be explained clearly and accessibly by a good instructor. Goodman is not that instructor. He uses slides in lecture and seems to unfailingly skip over the one thing you need to grasp in order to understand the material. Consider the grad-level class if you think you can hack it.
Very interesting, but requires a lot of time and work.
otherinfo: Designed for science and engineering majors. PHY304 or equivalent is desirable but not required.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: One problem set every other week.
prereqs: MAT 201 and 202, OR MAT 203 and 204, OR MAT 217 and 218. Also PHY 203, or 205, or 207..
descrip: An introduction to general relativity and its astrophysical applications, including black holes, cosmological expansion, and gravitational waves.
title: General Relativity

evals: Essays take up a lot of time.
I would recommend reading up on the topics before going to class. I did not do this but would have learnt much more from the lectures if I had.
Read lecture material before coming to lecture. (Otherwise, expect to non-trivial logical steps to be glossed over).
review notes before class
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Theoretical and numerical analysis of the structure of stars and their evolution. Topics include a survey of the physical process important for stellar interiors (equation of state, nuclear reactions, transport phenomena); and the integrated properties of stars and their evolution.
title: Structure of the Stars

evals: I would recommend this course. I do think that a student interested in rigorous derivations should consult Weinberg's text, as the course focuses more on major concepts.
This is a tough course with challenging problem sets, but will really give you a solid foundation in astronomy.
otherinfo: Advanced undergraduates are welcome to enroll, on approval from the instructors.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Additional Reading List: References to current literature and review articles in the journals.
prereqs: Undergraduate Physics and Math.
descrip: This course is an overview of cosmology and extragalactic astronomy at the graduate level, with an emphasis on the connection between theoretical ideas and observational data. The Big Bang model and the standard cosmological model are emphasized, as well as the properties and evolution of galaxies, quasars, and the intergalactic medium.
title: Extragalactic Astronomy

evals: You will learn a lot by attending seminars in this form. Also, trying to describe your own work to other students (rather than a traditional form of seminar that we give talks on things that we are not familiar with) is rather challenging.
prepare two weeks in advance!
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Designed to stimulate students in the pursuit of research. Participants in this seminar discuss critically papers given by seminar members. Ordinarily, several staff members also participate. Often topics are drawn from published data that present unsolved puzzles of interpretation.
title: Seminar in Theoretical Astrophysics

evals: Be careful about the objectives of the course which is to give a thorough, if short, introduction to the subject.

Read through relevant sections in the textbook by Rutherford and Goldston around the time of the lectures and problem sets to reinforce what you're learning. The course doesn't come straight from the textbook, but the textbook compliments a lot of what is covered in a clear manner.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: An introductory course to plasma physics, with sample applications in fusion, space and astrophysics, semiconductor etching, microwave generation, plasma propulsion, high power laser propagation in plasma; characterization of the plasma state, Debye shielding, plasma and cyclotron frequencies, collision rates and mean-free paths, atomic processes, adiabatic invariance, orbit theory, magnetic confinement of single-charged particles, two-fluid description, magnetohydrodynamic waves and instabilities, heat flow, diffusion, kinetic description, and Landau damping. The course may be taken by undergraduates with permission of the instructor.
title: General Plasma Physics I

evals: A great course; strongly recommended. It does take a fair bit of time.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: The course is open to graduate students of Princeton University and constitutes an essential part of the curriculum of the Princeton Program in Plasma Physics..
descrip: Hydrodynamic and kinetic models of nonmagnetized and magnetized plasma dispersion; basic plasma waves and their applications; basic instabilities; mechanisms of collisionless dissipation; geometrics-optics approximation, including ray tracing, field-theoretical description of continuous waves, and ponderomotive effects; conservation laws and transport equations for the wave action, energy, and momentum; mode conversion; quasilinear theory.
title: Plasma Waves and Instabilities

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: Spectroscopy in the visible, ultraviolet, and X-ray wavelengths, scattering of laser light and microwaves, hard X-rays, neutrons, and alpha particles. Fluctuations and transport. Lectures and student presentations.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Introduction to experimental plasma physics, with emphasis on high-temperature plasmas for fusion. Requirements for fusion plasmas: confinement, beta, power and particle exhaust. Discussion of tokamak fusion and alternative magnetic and inertial confinement systems. Status of experimental understanding: what we know and how we know it. Key plasma diagnostic techniques: magnetic measurements, Langmuir probes, microwave techniques, spectroscopic techniques, electron cyclotron emission, Thomson scattering.
title: Fusion Plasmas & Plasma Diagnostics

evals: Needs to be a real class not a seminar.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-termperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.
title: Seminar in Plasma Physics

evals: A good intro mol bio course. Be prepared to do a lot of memorization.
A lot of memorization, the precept problem sets are helpful for test review.
