A lot of the material is familiar if you've taken AP Bio. Doing the readings BEFORE the lectures really helps -- especially if its one of Notterman's lectures.
An interesting (to me as someone with limited high school biology, anyway) and engaging class!
Any interest in MOL? Take this course. It is not an easy A, but it is possible. More importantly, you will learn a lot and hopefully have some fun doing it.
Attend lectures and take good notes because they will be very helpful for studying for exams.

Awesome course to take as an STL or a departmental, made me decide to major in MOL. Lab is a big portion of your grade so come prepared and ready to work. Prepare for the exams by going over the lecture slides (posted online) and pay particular attention to the examples given in class, e.g. signalling pathways, inherited diseases, techniques.
Be prepared to do a lot of readings, because of course no one can hold you accountable for reading the textbook but it definitely will help with understanding the material better.
Be prepared to go to lab office hours so you don't get silly points taken off.
Be prepared to memorize a lot of information
Be sure to attend the lectures and to read the textbook. Both are essential to understanding the material and doing well on the examinations!
Definitely take in the Spring--the course is more interactive and better taught by Professor Gavis and Notterman
Do the readings, before the lecture if you can.

Don't take just for an STL. Full of premeds, most of which have taken AP Bio. Lab isn't too bad but grading rubric is incredibly specific. Material gets more difficult as semester goes on. Likely that you won't do all the readings, but don't stress; do the ones for material that you don't understand. Be ready to put alot of time into the work! Its easy to fall behind bc psets are optional, but try your best to keep up with the material!
Don't take unless required.

Fairly easy, especially if you took AP Bio in high school. Still lots of new details and is a ton of material to study for exams, so definitely keep up. Textbook readings are not always important; use as needed to supplement material from class that you may be unclear on. Try to go over lecture slides once after lecture on your own and make sure you understand the processes outlined. Material can pile up; do not study last minute for exams. P-sets are great! Do them all. Lab sucks. Pretty easy, especially considered to chem, but is just annoying work. The grading for lab reports also seems to be pretty arbitrary, so just try your best on those.
GO TO LECTURE. RECORD THE LECTURES. STUDY THE LECTURE SLIDES. And you will do fine!

GREAT introductory science course. Very well structured and the material is also interesting and spans many areas of biology. Labs are straightforward but interesting (although pre-lab lectures can make you want to pull your hair out) and the lab reports aren't graded harshly. Take for a great science class!!
Go to lecture! Notterman and Gavis are amazing and they make the material really interesting.
Go to lectures, they are very helpful and you learn everything you need to know in lecture. Also study the learning objectives, because they test these concepts most heavily on the exams.
Go to lectures.
Go to office hours for the lab report, rewrite the lecture notes, ask questions on them.

Great and interesting lectures. Just keep in mind that most people taking the course are premed and have taken AP biology before so a lot of people have encountered this material before. Labs aren't too bad but the pre-lab lectures are awful and made the labs run late most of the time. There are also pre-lab quizzes, but the material for the quizzes and the pre-lab lectures make the whole pre-lab experience very redundant and unpleasant.
Great introduction to bio. Lectures are overall interesting and informative, but be ready to spend a large chunk of time on labs.

Highly recommend if you have any interest in biology. Notterman and Gavis are the best lecturers I have had so far at Princeton. Try to get Karin for your preceptor, she is a godsend and knows her stuff.
I advice to do the readings and to go over the lectures right after they happen.
I highly recommend this course if you are at all interested in molecular biology or the medical sciences

I took this course in my senior spring purely out of interest in the subject. For that purpose, this course was a great introduction to the basic ideas of mol bio that someone outside the field would be interested in (ie. the most interesting applications are well stressed in the course material). However, as this class is structured for freshmen and assigns a ridiculous amount of graded work rather than relying on individuals to pace their own studying habits, I found the course needlessly over-burdensome on some occasions.

I would really only suggest this course if you are interested in biology. Try hard on the lab reports because they will help your grade a lot. The course can be a lot of work at times, but overall, you will learn a lot.
I wouldn't go out of my way to take it again, if you really enjoy MOL, however, go for it.
If Liz Wright is the lab director again, be prepared to stay overtime in lab. Decently chill class for the first half of the semester if you did well in AP Bio. Make sure to pay attention in lecture!
If you are interested in biology, it is a good class to take.

If you have taken biology (especially AP) before and done well, you will like this course! Lab is a lot of work/sometimes boring and the TAs vary but the lectures are good and Professor Notterman is great. Not boring even if you have taken AP. Overall not as much work as I thought.

If you loved biology in high school, this is the class for you. Although some of the material is repetitive, the professors to a great job of going in depth. It is a great way of getting to know the molecular biology department through lectures, precepts, and lab. Labs are fun because you work with a partner. The labs are lengthy (they take more than one lab period to complete), but when the experiment is finished, the results are really interesting to analyze.
If you need this course, take it! It's a thorough introduction to molecular biology and you learn a lot.
Interesting, informative class. Not too difficult, however will be time consuming with a problem set and lab report due weekly
It's fairly entertaining and not too much work, lab reports are frequent. I went in without AP bio, learned quite a lot, and didn't have any trouble.
Keep up with readings and go to lecture!
Keep up with the lectures. Don't slack off!
Lecture is really important. Take good notes. Textbook readings are useful but not necessary to understand the material.
Lots of memorization is involved but it's a good course that isn't too hard but also interesting.
Loved this class. You have to pay attention and do a fun lab stuff, but it's a really great class.
Make sure you go through lecture objectives when preparing for exams.

Most people are taking it because they need to. Not terribly exciting unless you love biology. Advice would be to use the textbook, maintain care when doing labs, and try to focus in class, as tired as you may be.
Only take this course if you need to or are really interested in biology. Notterman is an absolutely phenomenal lecturer.

Pretty "alright" class, wouldn't have taken it if I wasn't premed. Lab takes 5ever, lots of idle time; but, you get to do some pretty cool stuff in lab. Lectures are done pretty well, psets are misleading as to what to expect on the exams.
Pretty hard material if you've never taken a biology class before.
Read the book, at least before the exams. There are a lot of details to memorize in biology, so be sure to take notes.

Really interesting class! A lot of people were taking this course as a pre-req, but as far as intro courses go this one was great! The labs were very interesting (if a big long), and Notterdam and Gavis were both great lecturers!
Similar to AP Bio (without the evolutionary and ecology part). Good lectures. Good Lab (except the lab lectures).
Stay on top of the information, as there is a large amount of material covered within every lecture.
Stay on top of the work!!!!!
Students with AP Biology background will find lectures less engaging, but the lectures are generally great.  I loved all the connections to diseases that Notterman made.
Take good notes and review lectures frequently. Make sure you pay attention especially if you don't have a strong foundation in bio.

Take it if you need the pre-req or are interested in mol bio. It doesn't have a huge workload which is nice, the biggest time commitment is the labs that are due about every week. My tip would just be to get a lab partner that you like, it makes the labs so much more fun!
Take the course!! You can definitely succeed and get a good grade by reviewing the lecture slides. Notterman and Gavis are fantastic lecturers!
Take the course, study the lecture slides and youll do great

Take this class if you are trying to decide whether you are interested in pursuing biology/medicine. The lectures are pretty interesting and the labs aren't bad. This class is a big time commitment, but it's doable.
Take this class if you have to or have a general interest in molecular biology. The labs are fun and interesting and you learn a lot of cool things.
Take this course if you have an interest in the subjects.
Take this course if you have to for a pre-req or such, but otherwise you can find a better STL.
Take this course! Great foundation of biology, which is highly relevant to life in general
Take this course.

The lecture half of the course was great! Dr. Notterman was entertaining and easy to understand. He also stimulated my intellectual curiosity and inspired me to pursue a career in medicine! The lab half of the course is very poor. The pre-lab lecture was not helpful and the labs take way too long. Lab is supposed to end at 4:30 but sometimes we would be there until 6. The labs also felt like a waste of time. 50% of lab time was spent sitting around waiting for gels to run. The lab reports were also extremely difficult and there are not many resources for extra help.
The lectures are great and extremely interesting, and the class is very well-structured. The labs are a bit tedious and often very very time consuming though.
The material in the class is very interesting, I would take it if you are considering MOL
This course contains a lot of information. Studying should be done a few days in advance and lecture slides should be thoroughly looked over. Readings can be helpful, although not always necessary.
This course is a really good introduction to biology. The professors genuinely care, give fascinating lectures, and are very supportive!

This course is not the worst pre-med requirement ever. Notterman is really engaging and interesting and the assessments are doable although it is a lot of information. Start your studying early and take advantage of the textbook even though people will tell you not to read it.

This course is probably required for you. Regardless, be prepared for an unorganized, pedantic, and time-consuming laboratory portion if it is run by Professor Wright. Tough it out, and make sure you do everything exactly perfect and you'll only lose maybe 20% of your lab report points on stupid things that were not told to you in the vague descriptions of what you are expected to do. Laboratory work is a monumental waste of time. Work quickly and cut corners and you may actually get out of lab on time.

This course will require a lot of work from you. Yet, if you are genuinely engaged in-class, then you will get the most out of it. I strongly recommend this course to all students interested in the Sciences.
This is a great class to get a good grasp on introduction concepts of molecular biology.
This is a great class. Lab is kind of boring, but lectures are AMAZING. You'll learn a lot about molecular biology, including cellular processes and laboratory techniques.
This is a tough but rewarding course.
This is a tough course that requires a lot of time commitment. Professors are very nice and lab TAs are helpful but you have to really ask for help if you want it because it won't be given freely.
Try to do the readings beforehand. Study a long time in advance also, it is a lot of material but the material itself is not too difficult
Very interesting lectures. Lab is annoying and often runs late.
What you would expect. Get a good preceptor.
Would definitely recommend taking this class. It is very interesting and very well taught.
Would not recommend unless you're premed or mol major and are forced to take it.
You learn a lot and if you study well, it is very possible to do well on exams. Great class!
You probably don't have a choice, so i guess some real advice is to start studying early for exams. And make sure you understand. every. slide.
attend every lecture and review afterwards. don't take it if you don't have to
fairly easy stl to pdf
great class
take it!
this class is very interesting
very detailed course, lots of memorization
otherinfo: This course is required for majors in Molecular Biology and Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Contact Dr. Heather Thieringer (hthierin@princeton.edu) for questions about the course or if lab sections are closed.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 20%, Lab Reports - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%
assgts: Weekly reading assignments in textbook, syllabus, and lab manual. Weekly lab reports.
descrip: Important concepts and elements of molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology are examined in an experimental context. This course fulfills the requirement for students majoring in the biological sciences and satisfies the biology requirement for entrance into medical school.
title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology

evals: Biochemistry isn't the most intriguing class, but Cristea and Greco really tried. I think that they tend to read from the lecture slides a lot, but they do care about how the students feel about the class. Since it's fairly new, I expect that the class will change dramatically, so I doubt I can predict how it will be for future students. My best advice is not to fall behind, especially during the second half, since the sheer volume of information you need to know is pretty challenging. Good luck!
Brutal class. Memorize everything. Ask a lot of questions and start studying for exams really early so you have time to digest and memorize it all.

Cristea isn't as good as the others. Also, if Krystal Lum is doing precept, choose hers. She really cares about her students. Definitely recommend if you want to learn biochemistry, but be ready for a LOT of memorization. Nobody is exaggerating when they say this.

Definitely take this course if you are interested in learning more about Proteins, Membrane dynamics, in addition to the "traditional" material covered in the fall course with Prof. Hughson (e.g. the metabolic pathways). There are slight differences between fall and spring, but Profs Cristea and Greco are truly wonderful to talk to and passionate about the material they're teaching. Would urge students to consider taking it.
Interesting, useful course that gives a good overview of biochemical concepts. Manageable workload. Try to get Krystal as your preceptor!
It's a pretty straightforward class. Lots of memorizing, but nothing out of this world.
Make sure to go to lecture and precepts.

Please take this course in the fall with Professor Hughson. My experience in MOL 345 was among the most miserable I've had at Princeton (and I have not enjoyed it here). Biochemistry is a fascinating subject, but you won't learn very much if you choose to take this course in the spring. The lectures were unhelpful, problem sets too easy, and exams ridiculously hard. Course coverage of biochemical pathways and other fundamental concepts was minimized to make room for discussion of proteomics research which, although interesting, won't help you with the MCAT or most of biology. This course has really shaken my self-confidence and my confidence in my major decision.
Stay on top of everything as you go along. There is far too much to memorize if you get behind. The exams seem to test mastery rather than basic components, so you can't fall behind.
Take it if you have to. Everyone's super dedicated, tons of material, tough course. Teaching not very compelling and can be very biased by the professors' research areas.
Take it in the fall. Lectures are dry recitations of the textbook, so you don't have to go to lecture, except there are graded clicker questions, so you still have to go. It's kinda painful.
This is a biochemistry course and isn't particularly exciting, but you'll learn the material.
Usually there is no option in taking this class. Either you are premed or MOL. Take the course; don't let it's tedium pivot your future. It is interesting if you invest in it.
otherinfo: Offered both fall and spring. Meets during reading period. No course in the biological sciences or other departmental course may be taken Pass/D/Fail by molecular biology concentrators.
grading: Final Exam - 40%, Other Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading from the text, typically 60 pages per week. Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MOL 214/215 and either CHM 304/304B or ISC 335. CHM 304/304B may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Fundamental concepts of biomolecular structure and function will be discussed, with an emphasis on principles of thermodynamics, binding and catalysis. A major portion of the course will focus on metabolism and its logic and regulation.
title: Biochemistry

evals: A lot of time and very dependent on your lab partner, but overall doable and learned a fair amount about working with yeast.

All the reviews you are reading for Fall 2016 will be irrelevant next year, as the instructor will be changing. MOL core lab can be done right -- this hasn't been the case for many years, but I sincerely hope it happens next year. If you are a MOL major you will have to take this course anyways. If you are a CHM major, play it safe and take CHM core lab. The Fall 2016 version of this class was disastrous -- it was poorly organized, arbitrarily graded, and we did not even learn some of the most basic techniques of molecular biology (no Western blots, no immunofluoresence). Again, these criticisms will not (necessarily) apply next year.
Although sometimes this class might be a little confusing, it is absolutely necessary to talk to the professors and the TAs because they will be your lifeline. The experiments are really interesting!
Ask a lot of questions. Split the work evenly between lab-partners.

Be prepared to submit assignments and have absolutely no idea what grade you're going to get. Grading is pretty arbitrary. Lectures are useless. It's an incredible frustrating course, but you have to suffer through if you're a MOL major.
Bruce will not be teaching this course, so it's safe to say it can't be as bad as it was when I took it - good luck!
Didn't get much out of this course, but at least it wasn't too hard.
Don't take it. Talk to department staff about what to do.
Easily the worst class I have taken at Princeton. If you are thinking about majoring in molecular biology, declare something else to avoid this course. I did not learn anything.
I could write a paper about how awful this class is. But it'll probably be changed by next year, so fingers crossed it's even slightly improved. Only take if you absolutely have to of course.
I don't know what to expect for next year because I think the professor is leaving.

I feel like pretty much everyone taking this course is doing so because they have to for MOL major. So just try to ask a lot of questions, you can never ask too many questions. That's the only way you're going to have a firm grasp of what's going on.

I heard this course might be better with a new instructor but this is literally the worst class I've ever taken in my 15  years of schooling. Honestly would be chem right now if I had known that the class was this bad.

I think people really overthink what you need to do to do well in this class (sometimes, myself included). Bruce is by no means the best lecturer I have ever had, rather he can be quite confusing; however, he is incredibly dedicated and just wants you to stop thinking in terms of grades, numbers, and doing the most. Do try hard though and ask a lot of questions!

I wouldn't take this course if I wasn't a departmental. I didn't learn anything new, and have learned so much more form other departmentals like cell developmental. But if you have to take this course, you the lab TAs and Dr. Liz as a resource. And also always ask questions to understand what the goal of everything is.
I'm not sure what feedback is applicable because a new professor is teaching this course next time.

If you are a MOL major, you have to take it. This course was pretty terrible in that it's extremely DISORGANIZED and ARBITRARY. The instructor Bruce did not know what he was doing and often times the instructions given were frequently changed. Deadlines were moved around often until a few days before something is due. The rubrics were vague and arbitrary.
If you gotta do it, you gotta do it. It should be better now that there is a new lead instructor.

If you're considering taking this class for 'fun', don't. Just don't do it. If you have to be in this class, complaining only makes the experience worse. Take advantage of opportunities to get points back and extra credit.

It's a departmental for all MOL majors so there is a lot of moral support from fellow majors.  Make sure you have a good lab partner because they can ruin your grade and spending 7 hours a week with them in lab is awful.
Make sure you know what is going on in the lab that day before going in.
Not sure what advice I can give you besides I am sorry, but you are screwed. An absolute waste of my time, energy, and my parents' money- very happy to be done.

Only take it if you are a MOL major. Hope the next instructor gives clearer and simpler instructions for assignment expectations. I put a lot of effort into this course but many times I fell short in the expectations because the lecturer wasn't clear in conveying them. This course caused me a lot of resentment while doing many of the assignments and going to lab.
Only take this course if you are a MOL major and you have to.
Required course; will probably change in subsequent years, depending on the instructor.
Take it only if you have to or are willing to really stay on top of it
The course is disorganized and confusing, so don't take it unless you have to.
This course has many outside assignments, so be sure to manage your time well and ask questions if the rubric is unclear.
This course was a hot mess - anxiety levels to the extreme. TAs were the best (Xinlei is my favorite person). You're lucky Bruce won't be teaching you. Good luck surviving!

This is a terrible course as taught by Bruce. Someone new will be teaching it for you, so hopefully it will be better, but be prepared for a terrible course just in case. Do not take this course unless you are a MOL major and therefore have to.
Truly the bane of the mol major's existence
Unfortunately, this class is required for MOL. So if you are not graded the way you see fit, make sure to do something about it. It's not your individual problem, it's a systemic problem.

You likely have to take this course. Since the instructor will be different, feedback about the current instructor is not that helpful, since most of my frustrations about this course came from the instructor's antics. Make sure you are prepared for classes, and make sure you set up a schedule with your partner so that you don't end up doing too much or too little work. This class can be fun and fascinating if you approach it with an open mind and a willingness to be prepared, so don't be too disheartened, especially since what you hear about the class is based on how the course has been taught, which will change in 2017.
You should only be taking if required.
this class was painful; lots of time was spent on it and even though aspects were interesting it became stressful
otherinfo: Sophomores seeking to register for the course should send an email to md20@princeton.edu.
grading: Design Project - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Approximately 20 hours of reading and 60 hours to prepare other written and oral work over the course of the semester.
descrip: The purpose of MOL350 is to prepare you to be a contributing member of a research lab and to advance you as a creative, critical thinker and effective communicator. While completing original research, you will employ techniques used by cell and molecular biologists, molecular geneticists, and biochemists. You will discover how and why specific knowledge, skills and techniques are applied to the semester's research topic. In addition, you will practice extracting pertinent information from scientific literature and will generate a research report modeled on the scientific literature.
title: Laboratory in Molecular Biology

evals: Definitely a must take class if you are at all interested in Virology or how the immune system works- the course covers it all and is super interesting. One of my favorite classes I've taken. Make sure to keep up with the lectures and readings, but if you do you will find it to be a super enjoyable class with a manageable workload.

I would strongly recommend taking this course. However, memorization of many facts about various groups of viruses is crucial to success in the course. The amount of material is what makes this class most difficult.

If you are interested in biology and/or medicine this is a great class to take. It is a pretty low work load as long as you stay on top of the material. Study from the lecture slides and use the textbook as supplementary info as needed.

If you took MOL 214, and felt a strong interest during the portions focused on viruses, take this class. Don't take this class if you're just looking for a departmental. And if you take it, please keep up! Do the weekly questions and revise lectures right after. You will not be able to cram the lectures. There is so much material to memorize.
If you're interested in the topic and willing to put in the time to understand the material, definitely take the course. It gives a great intro into the world of viruses.
Interesting material, fair exams, minimal weekly work

One of my favorite classes at Princeton. Low workload. Great professor and preceptor. Incredible material that you end up talking about at lunch constantly. A must take if you've ever wanted to end up a virus fanatic (and after this course you'll realize you've always wanted to be one)

One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. Enquist is extremely good. Very interesting topic covered in extensive detail. Quite a bit of content and memorization. Reviewing lecture videos and "did you get it" questions are essential for exams. Recorded lectures make going to class optional as well, which is very nice. Strongly recommend this class.

Really recommend it. If you don't like memorization, this course may be tough, but Prof. Enquist really focuses on understanding the main concepts so it's mostly ok. You should go in with some mol bio background but not impossible to do well as long as you put in the effort.

Regardless of the grade I end up getting in this class, I am amazed by how much I have learned about viruses, or as the professor calls them "fascinating teachers of molecular biology."  Not only were lectures intriguing in their material and engaging in their presentation, but Enquist himself was also a very approachable professor who cared about how much his students learned. It's remarkable that I was able to talk in person with one of the world leaders in the field of virology! Precept papers were drawn from the scientific literature, and they truly showed how exciting a field virology is today.  I would recommend this course for anyone with an interest in learning more about biology, evolution, ecology, or public health.  Topics covered include how viruses replicate in cells, how they can cause cancer, how they do battle with the immune system, how they cause disease, and much more.
Take it!

Take it, try not to fall behind but honestly even if you do it's not a huge deal.  Really interesting stuff, presented in a really good way, lectures are filmed and posted on Blackboard, and you get good at reading science publications.

Take this course if you're interested in disease or viruses at all!!! Professor Enquist is an amazing lecturer and very friendly. Stay on top of the lecture material and do the did you get it questions and you'll be set for the exams!!

Take this course if you're interested in viruses! It's really fascinating stuff, and Prof. Enquist is one of the virology greats. If you're interested, don't pass up the opportunity to learn from him!!

Take this course!!! It is definitely one of the highlights of my coursework so far. Prof. Enquist is a passionate and engaging lecturer and the material is super fascinating. If you have any interest in viruses, this is the course for you.

Take this course, the learning here really refines and fine-tunes your understanding of molecular biology as a whole - Professor Enquist always comments on how the study of viruses ultimately illuminates the essence of various essential biochemical processes that drive cells and organisms - this is not a lie. You will get one of the most rewarding intellectual experiences if you take this course; Be warned that the amount of information makes it difficult. I made my own Virus Family Chart (and made it very comprehensive); I would fill this up every day for each family for about 15 days before the exams, this strategy was indispensable; Finally, re-listen to the lectures and appreciate Professor Enquist's way of thinking, he assesses things every now and then and forces you to evaluate the importance of pathway X or issue Y. Do the Did you Get it Questions, and check them over with friends and preceptors - this is the kind of course where if you put the time, you will do well ! Amazing learning experience

The most important thing is to constantly be reviewing throughout the semester --- that's how you stay on top of this class. Do the review problems, go to office hours, ask questions. I recommend rewatching the lecture videos before exams in case there was something you missed or are confused about.
This is a challenging class, but it is definitely worth it if you are willing to put in the effort.

Viruses is a great class! The content is very interesting, but be aware that there is a lot to learn. It can creep up on you quickly how much memorization and how many details there are, so stay on top of reviewing lectures. Overall, a really cool class to learn about virology and see how it ties into other fields as well.
prof is sometimes sexist, politically incorrect, and culturally insensitive. no need to go to lecture. he wants you to buy the textbook.
otherinfo: Graduate students will take the midterm written exam, but will write a paper on selected topics in virology in lieu of a final exam. Graduate students also attend a separate preceptorial session led by a postdoctoral fellow where seminal papers in virology are analyzed and discussed.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Assigned readings from literature or selected texts prior to class discussion.
prereqs: MOL214 or equivalent or permission of instructor. No courses in the biological sciences or other departmental courses may be taken Pass/D/Fail by molecular biology concentrators..
descrip: Viruses are unique parasites of living cells and may be the most abundant, highest evolved life forms on the planet. The general strategies encoded by all known viral genomes are discussed using selected viruses as examples. The first half of the course covers the molecular biology (the tactics) inherent in these strategies. The second half introduces the biology of engagement of viruses with host defenses, what happens when viral infection leads to disease, vaccines and antiviral drugs, and the evolution of infectious agents and emergence of new viruses.
title: Viruses: Strategy and Tactics

evals: A wonderful course for anyone interested in biomedicine and social implications for medical practices. Would highly recommend!

As I approached my senior year at Princeton, I was pretty sure that I would never make it into medicine as a non-US citizen. I was ashamed and embarrassed that I would need a post-bac to hopefully work it out. I would have intellectual dilemmas about whether I was actually good at molecular biology - I did amazingly well in MOL 214, Cell Dev, and Core Lab - but the rest....... Simply put, I walked with a pervasive fear that I just did not have what it takes to be a physician - or a MOL student at Princeton. Could I really apply what I supposedly knew and do good? 
But then this course and Dr. Notterman came to my life - and everything has since changed. Let me be clear: the reason why I am still going to put a fight and do whatever it takes to get into a US medical school is because of this course - Dr. Notterman has shown me that I can use molecular biology to solve real life problems, and he has exposed the humane side of medicine to me in the most pristine of ways. I have been revitalized, and I have been reminded about why I want to be a doctor - and why I can be a doctor. This course was so good to me and I will always keep Dr. Notterman in a special place in my heart - I do not know if I will ever make it into a US medical school, but I do know that I will go on with my journey - and this is all thanks to Dr. Notterman. To Dr. Notterman, thank you, thank you, than you, I promise I will be an agent of good in the years to come.
Best course at Princeton. TAKE IT, TAKE IT, TAKE IT. Professor Notterman somehow manages to make learning fun again, not to sound cliche :)
Definitely keep up with the readings/sci. papers - it allows you to be more engaging with the guests and when your classmates present.
Definitely my favorite course at Princeton. Blends together lectures, discussion, and patient visitors to make an engaging and wonderful course.

Definitely take this course! Dr. Notterman is an expert with years of clinical, teaching, and bioethics experience. I learned so much. It was powerful, humbling, and inspiring. I can't wait to be a doctor after taking this course.
Great class for senior year. being a MOL major will help, but if you are not a MOL major it is also great because Dr. Notterman teaches to all kinds of backgrounds.

MOL 460 is maybe the best course I've taken at Princeton. After 6 semesters of being premed here, I really needed something to convince me that I was still interested in pursuing medicine as a career. Professor Notterman did just that. He and this course did just that. He is so motivational and willing to engage in topics that challenge the way you think about healthcare in America. This course was was always interesting. Do not be intimidated by the MOL listing because even as a non-MOL major I can say that I got so much out of this course. The ability to see/ meet/ hear from real people is an educational experience like no other. I can say anyone who wants to be a doctor (or has even thought about it) is missing out by not taking this course.
My favorite class at Princeton, Notterman is incredible, end of discussion.
One of my favorite courses I have ever taken. No question about it: take it.
Take it! Very interesting!
Take it! You'll learn a lot, the work is very spread out and you'll get to hear from actual children   their parents about their experiences with disease.
Take this class!! Prof Notterman is amazing, if you have an interest in this field taking this course is one of the best decisions you will make in your Princeton career.

This course is truly special. It is the only one like it at Princeton, and the closest you can get to a clinical-type course here. Dr. Notterman is a good lecturer who cares about his students and wants to help them become good doctors and thoughtful medical policy makers. If you care about medicine or pediatrics or public policy, consider taking this course. It is thought provoking and offers a real opportunity to see how various diseases affect children and their families.
This course was absolutely amazing. I would recommend it to any student interested in health care. MOL460 was by far the best class I've ever taken at Princeton.
This is a great course! Take it. Stay engaged with lectures and participate. It's easy to just fall in the shadows but the class is better when you're engaging with the material.
otherinfo: Applications are no longer being accepted. Deadline has passed.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Two Lectures: one evening precept. Students expected to read 50 pages per week.
prereqs: MOL214 or MOL215 or equivalent.
descrip: Within a broader context of historical, social, and ethical concerns, a survey of normal childhood development and selected disorders from the perspectives of the physician and the scientist. Emphasis on the complex relationship between genetic and acquired causes of disease, medical practice, social conditions, and cultural values. The course features visits from children with some of the conditions discussed, site visits, and readings from the original medical and scientific literature. Prerequisite: 214 or 215. Two 90-minute classes and an evening 90-minute precept.
title: Diseases in Children: Causes, Costs, and Choices

evals: Don't worry as much ;)
Finish the readings really carefully, and try to be critical about the readings.
I would very much recommend this course.
If you keep up with the work, you'll pass. There is a lot of work to do but the curve is generous. Be prepared to sacrifice some of your winter break for the mini-grant proposal.

This is a very useful class for understanding techniques in molecular biology and biochemistry, and how those are eventually applied to cell biology. It will keep you busy, but will not waste your time or overwhelm you with work.
prepare thoroughly prior to each class in order to get the most out of lectures
senior undergraduates really should take it
otherinfo: Students present 5-minute talks on cell biological methods (assigned in advance). MOL seniors may enroll in this course with permission of instructor.
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Approximately 3-4 scientific articles will be read and discussed each week. These readings will be assigned prior to class discussion.
descrip: This course focuses on the molecules and molecular assemblies that underlie cellular structure and function. Topics include protein structure and folding; ligand binding and enzyme catalysis; membranes, ion channels, and translocation; intracellular trafficking; signal transduction and cell-cell communication; and cytoskeleton assembly, regulation, and function. A major goal of the course is to increase proficiency in parsing and critically discussing papers from the primary literature.
title: Cellular Biochemistry

evals: Talk with the lab members and PIs as much as possible to learn about the lab.
n/a
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 100%
descrip: Students will perform research in the laboratories of two faculty advisers.
title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)

evals: A good introduction if you are interested in Chemistry. Definitely substantial amounts of work (problem sets, lab time, and lab reports) but you get a lot out of it, you learn a lot, and it's worth it if you're interested in STEM/pre-med.

Actually super interesting. just DO THE READINGS BEFORE LECTURE!!!!! 

enjoy
Always do the readings! It helps to reinforce what lecture covered.
Be careful of who you have for precepts and labs. Read the book. And don't let the lectures frustrate you and don't be afraid to reach out for help.

Be prepared to put in a decent amount of effort. The weekly problem sets usually take anywhere from 1-3 hours. There are lots of resources available for help, and the faculty is very approachable. Great class if you think you are interested in chemistry or science in general.
Be sure to read the textbook as the course progresses. It can get confusing if you get behind.
Better than physics
CHM 201 is a hard class, but you will survive.

CHM 201 is a requirement and if you need to fulfill it, do it. It is not a weedout course, you will not fail if you put in some work. I cannot say you will get an A without a lot of work though. As an engineer I chose this over 207 and I highly recommend this if you are on the fence about chemistry. I do not love chemistry and although 207 is more engineering based I am very happy with my decision to be in a more general class.

CHM201 is challenging, but if you have some previous knowledge of chemistry you will be in a good place. If not, you can get a lot out of this course. Really focus while doing your problem sets, as the exam questions will utilize a lot of the concepts you learn in homework. Lab is important - do not neglect it and understand your reports for the lab written exam. And I would recommend doing the readings each week and going over lecture slides - cramming does not work for this class. If you need a lab class, or have an interest in chemistry, I would recommend this class.

Chances are you aren't taking this for fun.  Gen chem is something you have to get through, and it is interesting despite being hard.  Go to McGraw if you need help.  I did not take AP chem and I'm an average student so don't be afraid of it if you don't have a solid foundation in chemistry.

Concepts are hard to learn at first but after learning the basics for every unit, the problems themselves aren't hard to solve. Use the textbook as a resource for problem sets. Lectures are not that useful.
Consistently read the textbook, actively work on problem sets, and closely focus on lectures. Do not underestimate the course as it is not very easy.
DO THE READING, especially if you haven't taken AP chem in HS. stay on top of psets and go to lecture as the demos and explanations of the information are important.
Definitely do the readings.
Definitely read ahead to prepare for lectures. It will make them a lot easier to follow. The material moves somewhat quickly so staying on top of the reading helps.
Definitely read the assigned reading before going to lecture; you understand so much more when the professor describes it that way.
Definitely read the textbook.

Depending on your interest for the material and your willingness to put in a lot of time and effort, I would recommend the class. It was a challenging class to take freshman fall, especially coming from a background of solely  Introductory Chemistry in 10th grade. I would recommend taking AP Chem prior to taking the course.
Do a lot of practice problems and be able to sort them into categories of topics
Do all the work and study really hard for the exams because they generally aren't curved that much.
Do not take this course unless you have to!

Do the problem sets carefully and well! This is not an easy course for people that are new to chemistry, but it is doable if you keep up with the readings and form a study groups. The midterms will shock you, but I think that just comes with it often being most people's first science class.

Do the readings and make notes on the chapters. When doing the homework, attempt it first without notes to enforce memory. Pay attention in lab and during lectures and don't spend too much time writing. When there are demonstrations, watch the entire thing and then write down what happened after. If possible, record the demonstrations for later viewing.
Do the readings in advance and lots of practice problems to become familiarized with the material if you are new to the course.
Do the readings.

Don't rely on the professors to teach you. If you have a good preceptor then that may help. If not, then you're on your own and you'll have to teach yourself the material. The book is actually really helpful once you sit down and force yourself to read it. If you have an AP chem background, then you could do really well, if not - Good luck. If you don't have to take this class then don't do it. Let's face it - most of us are only taking this for pre-med requirements.
Don't slack on the readings.

Don't take if you don't need to. Labs are super annoying (unless you like unnecessarily playing with fire) and there's just so many topics you'll have to learn that don't all really fit in with each other
Don't take it unless you have to. I loved chemistry in high school but people are so intense and it's not very easy to do well in.
Fast-paced intro to chemistry course; take only if genuinely interested in this topic or if distribution requirement.

Find a good preceptor; ask around and make sure they are great at teaching the material. Make use of all the McGraw tutoring sessions, group and individual. I went to them every week, and without them I would not have survived. Overall, CHM 201 is a solid foundation and it is a satisfying course to complete.

Focus on the book. You will learn most from doing careful reading. Lectures will help solidify your knowledge, but they do not stand well by themselves. Lab is enriching. Precept, well, go only if you truly must.
Focus on the computational aspects of chemistry and less of the qualitative stuff because most of the exams test you on the numbers.

GO TO EVERY LECTURE AND (TRY) TO DO ALL THE READINGS. This will make the problem sets straightforward and easy. Also note that the exams tend to be similar in difficulty to your problem sets so use them as a guide when studying.

This course is a great course to take for any major, however it does have a lot of class time (e.g. lab, lecture, precept) so make sure you have time for that if you want to take this class as a distribution requirement.

GO TO OUTSIDE HELP AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE. Many times you will leave lecture feeling like you've retained nothing. See somebody about it and have them explain it to you. Read the textbook and maybe find some videos online to explain the topics so that they really sink it. Also maybe try to ask instructors about how important certain topics are because we may not cover them at all in depth, but yet they might still show up on an exam question.

GO TO THE MCGRAW REVIEW SESSIONS! Form a study group for exam preps. Also study like crazy for the first midterm because it is a lot of information. Finally, read the textbook, especially for the quantum and orbital chapters...it will definitely make a difference in your grade!
Go to Lab TA office hours for help with lab reports. Helps a ton. Also, for the exam just study straight out of the book and do practice problems/tests.
Go to McGraw

Go to McGraw for the problem sets! Even if you can do them on your own, go there once you're done to check answers with other students. Or go there to get help with the actual problems if you need it! Don't tough it out alone like I did at the beginning.
Go to lecture to get to know Professor Hecht and do your best on problem sets.
Good but fast-paced introduction to chemistry. Stay on top of the readings and the problem sets. Textbook is your primary resource for understanding the material.

Good course, but fast paced and a ton of information. There seem to be two paths to succeeding, either going to all the lectures or doing everything from the textbook. Both explain the material very thoroughly. Exams are hard. Most of what Hecht says is intuitive is not.

Good course. I'd say you definitely have to keep up because its easy to fall behind. Start problem sets early and don't study for exams the night before (WILL NOT WORK). If you're really interested in chemistry, I'd recommend.
Hecht tends to teach more background that go in to what he expects of you on the exam. If possible, go to office hours, ask questions, do problems/read textbook

I already had a lot of knowledge of chemistry before I took the course and it was still very challenging. But I loved it!! Lectures are not very exciting but the topics covered are extremely interesting. Make sure to read the textbook thoroughly.

I recommend this class if you have a genuine interest in chemistry or if it is a requirement. Stay on top of homework and attend precept. I encourage you to attend every lecture, but more importantly, do the readings before hand.
I recommend this course to people who are interested in chemistry. Do not take this course if you want to fulfill your STL distribution requirement.

I think it's important to keep in mind that, when you enroll in this class, students' experiences with chemistry will be quite varied. Some people might never have taken a chemistry course, others might have taken AP chemistry, and then there is anything and everything in between. For this reason, aspects of the course might seem like simple review to some students while other students are struggling to grasp the material. With that being said, if you are interested in chemistry, I would encourage you to take the course! There are many resources available to help you improve your understanding, whether that means going to McGraw, attending weekly review sessions, or taking advantage of office/lab hours. Also, I found it more effective to study in groups than to study by myself. You can learn so much from the people around you, and answering others' questions, as well as asking your own, really helps solidify the material. It can also point you to parts of the textbook that you need to spend more time reviewing. I would also highly encourage you to attend review sessions. They provide you with the opportunity not only to ask questions, but to watch the TAs or professors work through example problems that could be similar to the questions on exams. The lectures are also posted on Blackboard, as are the slides that explain how you should construct your lab reports, and these documents are extremely helpful. As a final comment, if you prepare for the labs, you can often leave quite early. Good luck!

I would recommend taking this class if you are interested in chemistry or have to for engineering. The teachers are great and there is a ton of support from them. That said, the class is also very hard and there is a lot of material--so you have to dedicate a good amount of time to learning the material. I would not worry about getting a bad prof or TA though because everyone I met was great.
I would say that they should really consider how much time the course takes if they intend to do well especially if they do not know very much chemistry.
I would tell other students to go to every lecture, and to try to complete each problem set to the best of your ability. Also don't put off readings until the last minute.
I would tell other students to stay on top of their work. To do the problem sets because the more difficult problems could be helpful for the exams.

If you are at all curious about Chemistry this would be a great class to take. Similarly if you are pre med, this class talks frequently about the chemistry behind medicine and biology and might be helpful for you.
If you are interested in Chemistry, don't judge the major by this class. I'm sure future Chemistry classes are great because if they were as bad as this, Princeton would have 0 Chemistry majors.

If you are interested in chemistry, take the class, it's really helpful overall and Professor Hect's enthusiasm for the subject is pretty contagious. Just make sure to stay on top of your work and ask for clarification the moment you need it!
If you don't have to take this class, then I recommend fulfilling your STL requirement with an easier course.

If you don't have to take this course, don't. I took it as an STL, and it was fine. Some parts were interesting. I liked learning about quantum mechanics; however, as a prospective humanities major, I feel that I could have used my STL for a more interesting subject.

If you dont have to take this as a requirement, unless you really like chemistry, I don't really recommend. Not particularly difficult, but extremely time consuming, lecture is helpful but sometimes not worth the time commitment.
If you have not taken AP Chem you will be spending a lot of time studying and independently learning in this course. This is very difficult to do while trying to keep up in other classes.

If you want to do well in this course, you need to both learn how to apply the formulas to problems as well as semi-understand the concepts, because exams test both quantitative and qualitative content. Do the readings and pay attention in lecture.
If you're an engineer, take this instead of CHM 207. It's more straightforward and aligns fairly closely with high school chemistry.

If you're going into this class thinking it is introductory think again. It is very difficult. Read the textbook. Then read it again. If you don't understand, and you have a bad preceptor, listen to the buzz about which preceptor is best and see if you can get help from him or her. If you don't need to take this class then do yourself a favor and just don't.
If you're interested in chemistry, I would take CHM 207.
If you're pre-med you have to take this class and its definitely better than 207 so I recommend it.

If you're premed, then you don't really have a choice about whether or not you want to take chem, but regardless, this course will certainly test your commitment. I am not convinced that the practice exams that they told us were from the year before actually were from the year before, because the actual tests were much much harder.

If you're required to take it for pre-med or BSE, don't worry - you can do well if you pay attention in class and try in lab. Probably not a class you want to take for fun - it's a lot of time for not-very-exciting material. If you're looking for help and the class/precepts aren't enough, there are a ton of resources (your lab/class TAs, McGraw sessions) to help you out.

It's a good intro course compared to others. Don't take it just to fill distribution requirements, but it's a good class laying down the foundations. For me, if you do all the readings, you don't necessarily need to go to the lectures, but do go to lectures to see some sick demonstrations!
It's a hard class and takes a decent amount of time, but it is a very interesting and engaging course.
Keep up with the readings
Know that this course requires a high level of commitment, especially if you have no chemistry background. Work with a study group on problem sets.
Labs are great, Professor Hecht is very engaging, but expect to put in a decent amount of work to be able to understand and do the p-sets. Manageable, though. GO TO PRECEPT.

Lots of time commitment, follow the textbook carefully, understand the lab and how it relates to the material in lecture/precept at the time, complete problem sets to the best of your ability - they are very similar to exam problems.
Make sure to read the textbook before lectures and don't miss class!
Make sure you do the readings. It is absolutely essential. If possible, do them before lecture so that you know what is going on.
Make sure you read the assigned chapters before lecture. It's much easier to follow that way.

Max Watkins is a great preceptor. You really do not have to go to lecture, especially if you took AP Chem. Also, last year's exams may not be representative of what your midterms and finals will look like this year, as my year found out the hard way.

Most people have to take this course so you can't avoid it. The exams are nothing like the psets or the practice so be prepared for a surprise. You NEED to read the textbook to do well, lecture not so much. Do lots of practice, read the textbook, and use google and you can survive.
Must take course. Make sure that you don't miss the lectures and classes since the course only gets harder.
N/A

Not a "weed-out class." If you do the readings/p-sets/practice it is very manageable without any past experience and you will get a grade that well-reflects your work. Just don't take the lab-exam lightly (make sure you have ALL formulas and state things very clearly and simply: avoid even semi- sophisticated word choices because they will downgrade you, for example say purple not lavender even if the flame color is the latter. You will be fine but if you are missing something small you could lose quite a few points)
Not too tough. Stay on top of your work. Love labs.

Only take it if you have to for a requirement; otherwise it's not worth all the time and there are cooler ways to learn about chemistry. Most of the material we covered I had learned in my non-AP chemistry class in high school.
Only take this class if you really are interested in chemistry or it is a department requirement. There have been countless students that dropped the premed track due to this course.
Overall a very manageable course, as long as you kept up with the material and labs and prepped well for the exams.

Overall this is a pretty challenging course, however if you stay on top of the material it is manageable. My advice for students taking this course is to really focus on practice problems instead of going in depth with the weekly reading.
Pay attention to P-sets, don't just look for the answers by having someone quickly explain how to solve the problem, rather read the textbook and really try to understand the concepts.
Picks up after first midterm, stay on top of the material.
Practice problems and taking the time to read the textbook readings on schedule with the lectures are extremely important in solidifying one's understanding of the material covered in this course.
Read and learn from other students.
Read before the lectures to have complete understanding of the material. It isn't a hard class.

Read or at least skim the textbook before going into lecture in order to fully understand the material. Don't do the pset the night before, and check answer or work with others to maximize the percent of correct answers.
Read the book and go to precepts! Lectures do not help. Only take if necessary.
Read the textbook in addition to going to the lectures. Makes a big difference, especially if you're not a math-minded person.
Read the textbook instead of going to lecture.
Reading the book was much more helpful for me than lecture, but thankfully the textbook was very good--recommend reading carefully and taking notes from that.
Reading the textbook and preparing for lectures and labs ahead of time is very important.
Show up to as many lectures as possible, and read the textbook constantly!
Since it's a prerequisite for some distributions, take this course if you need to. Labs were fun.
Stay on top of everything and read the book before classes.
Stay up to date on readings

Straightforward intro chem course. Not too hard to do well but requires engagement with lectures and reading. Psets best done in groups and are helpful for tests. Labs are easy and straightforward. Overall decent class with average amount of work for stl and sometimes is fun.
Study for the finals and midterms. A lot.
Take advantage of all the resources of the people who know what they are doing, i.e. preceptors, professors, past students.
Take if necessary only, 5 Exams, Constant Exams and PSETs, Can never get a break, Lectures Not Helpful at all, Skim over book, Do problems, Go to Lab and Precept only, Seek help

Take it if needed for pre-med, STEM, etc., and be sure to keep on top of readings. Try to utilize office hours or informal conversation opportunities with the lecturer when possible, and use your TA's as much as possible. Not overwhelmingly difficult if you've taken chem before, but it is by no means easy; you will need to devote a considerable amount of time to this class.
Take it if you need it. Find other places for examples. The ones provided do not reflect what you will be working with. Utilize old problem sets and exams.
Take the course, but keep up on the readings before lecture. Otherwise, you are not going to know what's going on.
Take this class instead of CHM 207 if you have to take one or the other.
Take this course if you have to or are seriously interested in pursuing the science, not if you are trying to learn about chemistry for fun.  It is challenging, but also enjoyable.
Take this course.
The chem department tries really hard to make this an enjoyable class. Honestly, its super manageable and pretty good.
The course is challenging and time consuming for most students with no background in chemistry.
The course is fast paced but it is worth it!

The course is time consuming. Precepts vary wildly depending on the preceptor. Some classes had review sheets or worksheets for precept, while others just completely book problems. It is hard to concentrate in lecture because the class size is big and the class length feels too long.
The textbook is your best friend. Do yourself a favor and read it.
This can be a challenging and engaging class, however if you are interested in majoring in Chemistry then it is a good class to take to see early on if it is what interests you.
This course is a solid intro to CHM and requires hard work but is definitely manageable and very interesting. Hecht is the best.
This course is hard, but it's not impossible. If you try hard, and take advantage of the resources you may get and A even if the first midterm scares you MUHAHAHA
This course is high demanding. Stay on top of the readings so you can get the most out of lectures and labs. It is a good course, but it's very dry.
This course is meh.
This course is pretty reasonable and Hecht is a great professor I would recommend that you do the practice exam and time yourself because this was my problem with the exams the timing.

This course is very fair if you do all the readings and understand the homework problems in their entirety. It is possible to get high scores on everything as long as you have done a lot of practice. The exams were fair, but with a lot of questions so the timing was very difficult. You can read the textbook and do the problem sets well to learn everything you need.
This course was basically what you cover in AP Chemistry, so if you have a background in chemistry then the course is fine, but if you had no exposure to chemistry before, you will be kind of lost.

This is a great class to take if you're not sure what you'd like to do. Yeah, you may hate it and drop out but there's also the possibility that you'll see yourself using what you learn in this class in the future, in some way, shape or form. It's tough, no doubt about it, but it's definitely doable. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. Just put in the work and you'll be just fine.
This is a great course. It is, of course, difficult with a tough curve but it is interesting and well run.
This is a great intro course to chem. It is not too difficult as long as you do the readings and stay on top of psets.
This is a very well taught class and really helps you understand chemistry.
Tough, learn quantum numbers otherwise you'll be so lost at the end

Unless you really like Chemistry, don't take this class. It is too hard for an STL and it is very challenging even if you enjoy Chem and are planning to major in a science. Get help early if you can, use your resources and don't get behind! Overall it was a huge challenge but if you're committed to doing well and put a lot of energy and time into this class, it is possible. Good luck.

Will definitely have a time commitment, but will pay off. If you grasp the concepts and know how to solve the problems that come up on problem sets and past exams, you are set! Pay attention in lecture, but sometimes, the textbook is way more helpful.

Yo, read the chapters before you show up to a new unit in class, not as you're getting lectures on the unit. The lectures become confusing and difficult to follow if you haven't read the chapter already.
You will either understand the lectures or not. Make sure to do the psets because those will definitely help you learn the material.
go to precept. that's where you will learn
moves really fast but doable if you have motivation and have time to do textbook readings on your own time
only take if required
only take it if you have to
read the book and you'll pass, lectures don't help much
otherinfo: Contact Dr. Robert L'Esperance (rpl@Princeton/Room A89 Frick Lab) for lab and precept changes after the close of the enrollment period.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 20%, Lab Reports - 20%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: 30-50 pages of reading each week, problem sets, preparation and write-ups for laboratory work.
descrip: CHM 201 (Fall) and CHM 202 (Spring) comprise an overview of Chemistry. This sequence serves as the entry level course for concentrators in Chemistry, and for other sciences requiring General Chemistry as a prerequisite. This sequence is also well suited for premedical students. The goal of General Chemistry is to enhance our understanding of our surroundings through a study of matter at the molecular scale. Topics in CHM 201 include chemical reactions, equilibrium, energy and entropy, quantum theory, atomic structure, and chemical bonding.
title: General Chemistry I

evals: 207 is definitely a difficult course and there will be a lot of work, especially with the p-sets (be prepared to spend an entire day just doing chemistry if the p-set material is difficult). However, you will learn general chemistry well and some things about material chemistry (although that really was not a huge part of the curriculum).

ATTEND ALL PRECEPTS! Precepts help you understand how to tackle P-set and exam questions. READ THE CHAPTERS to understand what the heck is going on in class! GO TO OFFICE HOURS as much as possible to clarify topics you are unsure about, preferably before exams or any other crunch times.
Advice would be to attend lectures and enjoy the course.
Always do the readings, they are invaluable as a supplement to lectures
Always pay attention in lecture! Also, make sure you understand what is happening in lab. That is where I felt the majority of my learning happened.
Be prepared to do some searching outside of class to be able to complete the problem sets.
Despite being called "Advanced Gen. Chem," this is actually easier than 201.
Do all assignments and take advantage of the resources available.
Do not skip lecture, make sure to read the textbook.
Do not take night lab, do not rely on lectures to help you (read the book)
Do the reading! It will help clarify questions you have about lecture and going into precept have questions ready from the problem set so you can learn the concepts behind them .
Do the textbook reading as you do the problem sets or you won't be able to do any problems--the lectures do not teach you how to do problems.
Don't take this class if you do not have to.

Even though this course is commonly a departmental requirement, it shouldn't be a class to be loathed. The lectures are interesting and the professors can be funny. Also the labs aren't that taxing and can be enjoyable.
Form a study group to help learn how to do the types of chem problems. And attend precept!
Go to all precepts since they are very effective.

I took this for B.S.E requirement. The material was interesting. Lectures were also cool with many demonstrations of chemical phenomenons. However, be prepared to learn most things on your own since lectures don't cover textbook and homework material well. Go to precept. The last month of topics can be challenging and we had lectures during reading period which I didn't like. Definitely seems to be more challenging than 201 since acid/base can be annoying and material science can be challening--both of which 201 does not cover. I think it is more interesting than 201. I would recommend 207 over 201 if you like chemistry.

I would advise other students taking this course to read and take notes on the Chapters in advance of all lectures. You'll need to have some type of foundation in order to understand the lectures well.
I would not suggest it for students not studying chemistry or engineers.
I would recommend keeping up with the readings
I would recommend reading the text book and attending all study sessions for examinations and lab reports.
If you don't have an interest in chemistry or don't have to take this as a requirement, I'd say choose another course.
If you have taken chemistry before, you should be fairly well-off, but be sure to do work, as with any class.

If you want to take it because you're interested in materials science, DON'T DO IT. It's not about materials science at all. It's just gen chem. Take 201 instead of 207 and have a better life. If you still want to take 207, try to get Liz as your preceptor. The textbook is your guide.

If you're taking this class it's probably because you're an engineer and don't have a choice. Unless you're great at/super interested in Chem you probably will not enjoy this class but it's a necessity so grit and bear it.

If you've taken AP Chemistry and got a 5, you don't need to take this course (I made that mistake). It's more in depth than AP Chem, but it will be a lot of review for you. Labs were fun and interesting but lectures were often so boring I fell asleep. I probably wouldn't take it again but I don't regret taking it because I ultimately improved my chemistry knowledge.
Make sure you understand a basic knowledge of chemistry
My biggest piece of advice would be to find find the most helpful precept offered and go to that one in addition to or instead of your assigned precept.
N/A
Not too tough. Bocarsly and Cava are pretty good lecturers. Problem sets are good preparation for exams.
Only take if you have to. From what I've heard, it sounds like CHM 201 was taught better so I would take that class instead if you are choosing between the two!

Overall the course is very informative. Definitely would recommend to students not looking to pursue the natural sciences but for whom chemistry is still a requirement because it covers many real-world applications. Doing the weekly reading before lectures will help with understanding the lectures themselves.
Pay close attention to your readings because in lecture they don't elaborate on much of the material covered in the exams.
Read the assigned chapters in the textbook and definitely go for office hours. Oh, and attend all precepts if you can, they really buttress the lectures.
Read the chapter before each lecture.
Read the textbook (before lecture, if you can)! The lectures are great but you get a lot more out of them if you already are familiar with the material.
Solid State Chemistry is actually a minute part of the course.
Take CHM201
Take CHM201 instead of CHM207, it has the same labs but without the CHM207 professors, preceptors, exams and poor organization of material. It was my worst class of the semester by far.
Take this course and get Aubrey Paris as your preceptor if you can! She is great.
Take this course if you're into chem or are a premed or engineer.

The course is definitely better than general chemistry but be weary, you will need prior chemistry knowledge to do well in this course. It is advertised as being equal to general chemistry but this may be a bit of a stretch.
There are a lot of concepts you have to deal with and the labs are a pain (expect to stay late and do more work out of than in lab) but it's not too hard.

This course can be very engaging and rewarding if you want it to be. If you go to all the lectures and make an effort to do all the readings, you'll do very well in the class, and will probably enjoy yourself while doing it. Lectures can be slow sometimes, which is why doing the readings is very important. The professors do lots of fun demos, too, so don't miss lectures! Labs will also help to increase your understanding of the material.

This course is fast pace. Make sure you find the resources that work best for your schedual and use them. If you try to do it alone, you will fail. If you are an athlete, the chemistry office open hours will often not work at all with your schedual between classes and practice. Email Dr.Frances (she's the best), Cava or Bocarsly (not rpl', if you're not a girl he won't be nice to you. I don't think it's intentional on his part, but he's generally a jerk to people and is hard to get along with/ learn anything from.) or another TA of your choice to get your questions answered. You will have plenty of questions, and just going to the lectures and doing the problem sets will not cut it.
This course is great!

This course is very challenging for those without knowledge of chemistry. Lectures are difficult to learn from and assignments can be difficult. However, some of the professors are very entertaining and can make for an enjoyable time.

This course was overall very poorly taught, and there were no weekly notes to guide learning and studying. The main redeeming quality of this course is that the subject matter becomes quite interesting and applicable in the last two weeks. I know that the final two weeks are more interesting than the stuff in CHM 201. Take Aubrey's precept. She is unbelievably helpful and organized. I wish she taught the course.
This is a great introductory chemistry course that I would highly recommend.

This is a self-taught course. It says that no background is needed, but professors do assume some chemistry background. The hardest concepts in the course are just tangentially touched during the lecture and most of it is left to be self taught. If you are interested in chemistry and know some, you will probably find this course nice and easy.  But if you are new and expect to be taught chemistry in a structured effective way, this course will disappoint you. If you do end up taking this course,take Aubrey's precept and Dr Francis' lab

This is an interesting, if disorganized class. Don't be placated by the easy work and fun lectures at the beginning--if you don't stay up with the material at the beginning, it will be painfully confusing later.

Whether you're taking this course for distribution requirements or for fun, this class is enjoyable. You should be prepared to both work hard and enjoy the professors' and TAs humor and teaching. Other than that, just remember to study as any other course.
(P.S. Do not be put off by the Professors' humor and personalities. You'll warm up to them eventually.)
Would recommend this class for a lab credit to any student interested in the subject.
if you want to be engaged it takes effort since it is such a late class. Find a preceptor that teaches in a way you like.
take this course rather than 201. easier and more interesting
otherinfo: Contact Dr. Robert L'Esperance (rpl@Princeton.EDU / Room A89 Frick Lab) for changes in lab and/or class sections after the close of the enrollment period.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 15%, Lab Reports - 25%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Weekly problem sets. Approximately 30 pages of reading each week.
prereqs: Concurrent registration in MAT 103 or equivalent placement is required..
descrip: CHM 207 is an introductory course in chemistry with examples drawn from materials science. The basic concepts of chemistry are introduced: stoichiometry, reaction types, equilibria, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and chemical bonding. These concepts are applied in discussions of the structure, reactions, and properties of technologically important materials: metals, semiconductors, ceramics, and polymers. This course is designed as a one term introduction to chemistry, however it may be coupled with CHM 202 to fulfill medical school requirements in general chemistry.
title: Advanced General Chemistry: Materials Chemistry

evals: Absolutely take this course. It's challenging, but practice makes perfect and you'll get out exactly what you put in.

Although there are no assigned psets, be sure to complete the precept packets and understand everything early on! The course is extremely cumulative so it's very easy to fall behind if you're not careful.
Although you are probably taking it because you must, this class is excellent. Lecture are clear, tests are fair, and professors are helpful and accessible.
Be prepared to put in the effort. Just because the tests are open notes doesn't mean you don't have to learn the material.
Be prepared to self-stud a lot.
Be ready to work if you decide to take this class.

Considering how much people tend to complain about orgo, this is a very good class. The grading is extremely fair, there are so many resources, and it is clear the instructors want students to succeed.
DO NOT THINK THIS WILL BE AN EASY COURSE. THIS IS A CHALLENGE

Definitely recommend if you are interested in chemistry, or organic chemistry specfiically. You will learn a lot and it will challenge you but it will be worth it because it teaches you to think about studies, not just chemistry, in a different way.
Do all available practice problems/exams, do them again, and then again.
Do all of the practice exams and the problem sets. Seek help if you need to brush up on concepts.
Do all the practice tests and psets and go through all your note packets before your midterms and you should be just fine.
Do not take this course for fun. Its very tough and requires a lot of time to work on labs, prob sets and studying for three exams.
Do not take unless absolutely needed. You will definitely be spending a lot of time outside of class studying for the multiple exams that seem never ending.

Do problem sets every week!! ( i regret not doing it) Textbook is actually pretty helpful, but again, most helpful if you read chapters on time. Three midterms make the course a bit overwhelming, and I sometimes dreaded going to lab.

Do the weekly problem sets and make sure you allot yourself enough time to do all (or most of) the practice exams. The textbook problems might be a nice place to start studying but if you know the basics they're not helpful. Focus on the concepts - don't try to memorize - it doesn't work in this class. Make sure to pay attention throughout the course, since concepts introduced earlier never go away.
Doing practice problems is key to succeeding in this course. Old exams from previous years are the best practice.

Don't be afraid of Orgo here! It is without a single doubt the BEST taught course I've ever taken (I'm serious). Although people will tell you the textbook isn't necessary (which it isn't), I would highly recommend you read it because it was so helpful to me in explaining everything. Also, take full advantage of office hours and precept, literally as long as you keep up this course will be fine. It's so fairly graded to give you the best possible score
Don't fall behind. Take practice midterms.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take this class unless you really have to- READ THE TEXTBOOK! lecture is kinda useless.
Don't take unless you are prepared for all of the work!
Don't take unless you have to
