Don't take unless you have to. If you're not an audio learner, spend some time reading the book. Get a tutor if needed. Always go to classes.
Don't underestimate the workload, even though weekly problem sets aren't for grade. Keep up with material and you'll make it through.
Dont take this unless you absolutely have to. Lecture didnt help much at all, might as well sleep in and read the book instead. Pray for a good preceptor
Dont' take.
Focus on understanding the material and not trying to memorize things. Use past exams.

GO TO YOUR PRECEPTS. This is absolutely vital, as you can actively ask questions there and get to see the stuff from lecture put into action. In general the preceptors for this class are also very good, and they will oftentimes clarify what is and is not on the exams. P.S. they also take attendance.
Go to Prof. Semmelhack's office hours! Very helpful!
Go to lecture. Finish the precept problem sets on your own time. Do every practice test. I don't know anyone who did this and didn't get an A.
Go to the lectures and do all of the practice problems.
Great class and Semmelhack is really cool
I mean this class is required for pre-med students. Don't have a choice. It's a lot of time but worth it in the end.

I personally did not use the textbook at all, and still did well. If you like problem-solving and aren't bad at chem, then this course is pretty fun, and not as time-consuming/difficult as it's reputed to be.

For exams, make sure to work on previous exams and ideally study in advance so you can bring your questions/concerns to precept to get them clarified.

I took this course out of general interest (yes, you read that correctly), and I'm really glad I did. I'm an engineer who wanted to take organic chemistry because I really enjoyed general chemistry in high school and wanted to see what upper level chemistry was all about. Don't get me wrong, it is very different from general chemistry (much more qualitative, not really at all quantitative) and it is an extremely challenging course, but even as someone now 3 years removed from general chemistry, I found the material to be very learnable (compared to some of the engineering classes I have to take) if you're willing to dedicate time to prepare for the three midterms and the final, and you will be very satisfied with yourself for completing the course and growing in your knowledge of chemistry. Sadly, the labs are kind of a waste of time, and I tried to look past that when evaluating the overall quality of the course. Just get through the labs. Semmelhack and Gingrich are a really good team and have had years of experience doing this, so you'll have some good teaching. On the whole, I recommend it. If you're pre-med, come in with the attitude that you are ready to engage in learning the material due to academic interest because you have to take it anyway, and if you treat it as a required class and nothing more, you might find yourself disliking the course.
I would highly recommend this if you enjoy chemistry.
If lecture does not help with understanding the concepts, then I highly recommend seeking out an outside resource.
If required, take it, and don't be afraid - you'll be fine. Wouldn't recommend out of interest ... it's a tough, tough course.
If you do not have to take this class, do not.
If you fall behind, try to catch up as soon as you can.

If you're an incoming freshman that has placed into this course, take it. Even though it's a lot of work and probably much harder than the chemistry you have taken in high school, if you put in the work, you'll do well. Orgo is not as scary as everyone says it is, I promise.
If you're just taking this for pre-med requirements, brace yourself.

If you're taking orgo, you are most likely taking it because you don't really have a choice, that being said 830 lecture for me was not as bad as I had thought. Semmelhack is a good lecture, although a little dry. The class is obviously a lot of work (3 midterms), but my preceptors/lab TA's were amazing (Yong Loh and Diana Sun). Hard class, but doable, with lots of opportunities to ask for help
If you're taking this you must be premed.

It is very hard work, but there is no doubt that you learn an extraordinary amount. The professors are good, and you can immediately see their immense knowledge on the topics. Preceptors and lab TAs are hit or miss, but the disparity isn't huge.
It requires a lot of time. Definitely not a class you can cram in one night.
It's a great course. You learn a lot. Lectures are engaging so definitely go; reading are okay but precept and lab are very helpful to solidify concepts.
It's a tough course, but you have to get through it for a lot of majors or tracks.  Utilize the office hours and preceptors; they were by far the most helpful aspect.  It's a lot of work and stress,.

It's doable but not with other huge time-suck courses like COS226. Very time consuming, since you have a midterm practically every 2-3 weeks and a lab report between those periods. Make sure to reach out for help often, study with people, and go to lectures -- even if you're falling asleep at 8:30 AM, having at least some minor exposure to the material will be beneficial when you're looking back at your notes before the exam.

It's not as bad as what people make it to be. The number of exams and the amount of work that you need to put into the class are overwhelming, but I think this is one of the class where the number of hours you put into studying actually pays off. Do all the practice exams!!

It's not impossible to do well in orgo, but it requires a LOT of time and effort. Do all of the practice exams you have access to before the midterms/final, because the gap in difficulty between the problem sets and the exams is really big. Staying on top of the material week to week is a must, because it is really hard to catch up if you fall behind initially and the entire course builds on itself.
Keep on top of material. If you get behind, you'll be lost until the week before when you start cramming for the test.

Keep up with all the material, it is easy to fall behind; and get a really good understanding of early material, since new concepts build off of old ones. Go to the various review sessions offered for exams, and give yourself plenty of time to do practice exams before the actual exam.
Lectures are only important to know what is going on in precept.  Buy the little study guide book by David Klein and try to get into Michael Nech's precept he is amazing.

Make sure that you ask questions early on - the course builds on itself - so if you are uneasy about something early on make sure to get it sorted out, as you will need to understand it well later on!
Make sure that you go to lectures, and that you start doing practice tests well before each exam.
Make sure that you keep up on the material. Try to read the book, because it explains the material, and at the very least it familiarizes you with what will be covered in lecture.
Make sure to take advantage of all the resources that are offered to you.
Make sure you don't fall behind. This class was so difficult for me. You have no choice but to take it if you need it for your concentration or if your'e a pre med.

More enjoyable than I expected, seeing as I was taking this as a premed requirement. Exams need a lot of studying for the week before but it's doable to do well. I never found lectures very helpful- maybe that's just my learning style- but the textbook will sometiems clear things up if you're feeling lost. Doing practice problems (psets, practice exams) is by far the most important part of studying and learning the material. Go to precept, do all of the psets and practice exams, multiple times if necessary, and ask questions until you understand things.
Not as bad as they say.
Only take it if you LOVE organic chemistry or have to take it.  Honestly, if they keep up the same homework policy, pretty easy and interesting pdf class too.
Only take this class if you must. It is a very challenging course often difficult to understand. It can get frustrating at times.
Only take this course if you HAVE to.

Orgo is actually a pretty interesting course, but it's pretty hard and you need to be prepared to put in a lot of work. But the material is interesting, and the tests are open note so it isn't memorization at all. The psets are optional, but that can make a lot of people not study at all until last minute (would not recommend). Go to the review sessions; the TAs are all pretty helpful. Really the largest struggle is the 8:30 am lecture.
Orgo is hard, but also one of my favorite classes I've taken. It's not as bad as people make it out to be.
Orgo is hard. Take it only if you need it for a requirement or if you're really interested in it.
Orgo is just as bad, if not worse as everyone says. The open book policy as well as the grading policy for exams makes the class bearable.

Orgo is not as scary as it may seem as long as you get some practice before the exams. Lectures are only helpful if you don't fall asleep. If you do then the readings and other online material are sufficient for studying as well. Aside from resources on campus for this course, there are countless study guides online and Khan Academy that can get you through it.

Orgo takes up a LOT of time the week before each exam. Make sure you have time in your regular schedule to give up lots of hours to studying orgo, but again just for the week before the exams. Other weeks are relatively light, but I would suggest doing extra practice problems regularly so you really learn the concepts as the course moves instead of waiting until that week before the exam to try and learn everything. Go to office hours with LOTS of questions--the grad students are great. If you don't have questions to ask, you haven't done enough studying, practicing, and thinking through things. There are so many great resources for this course--both on campus and online (online for extra practice problems). Make use of them!
Pay attention in precept. Reading are not necessary, but Khan Academy might be. Do all the psets and practice exams.

Practice! Practice! Practice! Highly suggest getting a copy of David Klein's Organic Chemistry as 2nd language.  It is highly worth the investment and provides the tools necessary for problem solving.  The textbook teaches the materials, but this book teaches you the approach for problems.

Premed student here, this class is very difficult. Get Megan if you can for lab, she's super chill and helpful. If you don't understand the notes, read the textbook and if you don't understand the textbook go online to learn orgo. Also go in for appointments w/ Semmelhack if you don't understand something: he's chill and a friendly guy and will help you out.

Professor Semmelhack is an excellent and dedicated teacher.  Go to the weekly review sessions he holds, which are very helpful.  Nevertheless, the one person who truly made this class not only survivable but also enjoyable was my preceptor: Michael Nechayev ("Nech"). I don't think I've ever met anyone who is as dedicated and effective a teacher, in any subject, as he was.  Nech did so much to help students get through this class.  He made extra practice problems for students, met with students one on one, held multiple review session for exams, and made review sheets.  He gained such a reputation that students from other precepts began going to his office hours/precepts.  He should really get an award for undergraduate teaching.  He deserves it.  Overall, just a really nice, interesting guy too.
Professor Semmelhack is good, but the exams will kill you. Make sure to do the psets and be prepared to study pretty much the entire semester.
Seek out the best preceptor and get on their mailing list/go to their precepts. It makes a big difference.

Significant time requirement, do your best to stay up with the material and practice outside of precept/lecture...if you're thinking about taking it it's most likely because you have to. Good luck! You can do it!
Solve practice exams.

Stay on top of the work in the beginning and develop a study schedule. Try to get Nech as your preceptor, he's amazing! Also, McGraw is super helpful if you have questions or don't understand concepts

Study hard. It's not an easy class and a lot of work. The Organic Chemistry As A Second Language review book is extremely helpful. Also, don't take this class if you don't have to - it's not worth it.
Super, super well-taught. Orgo is cool!
Take Sorensen next semester and do what you can to survive first semester orgo.
Take if you like chemistry or if you have to for a requirement.
Take it if you need to. If not, you're insane, or a genius and need to get a life either way.
Take it seriously, just cause P-Sets arent graded doesnt mean you can slack on them
Take this class only if you have to or are very interested in organic chemistry.  It is extremely challenging and takes a lot of hard work and practice to stay up to par.
Take this course it is amazing and will change the way you think about chemistry and the world, only if you put in the time and effort.
Take this course!!!!! Everyone hypes up organic chemistry, but it's incredibly well taught here and super interesting.
The coarse requires a lot of time to do well in. If you fall behind seek help right away as it can be challenging to catch back up.

The course is required. I took it as a freshman and it wasn't as difficult as I had anticipated. There is a lot of help and the course is designed to help you do as well as possible. Don't skip lectures or precepts and definitely do past exams.

There are plenty of resources to help. The preceptors and lab TAs are all very nice and easy to approach. The problem sets aren't graded, so while there isn't stress at getting everything perfect, you get to do the learning at your own pace.  But with midterms coming around so often, you have to be on top!
This class requires a lot of time. Don't fall too behind or wait to ask someone about confusing topics.
This course demands a lot of work outside the classroom. Whatever you do, don't give up!

This course involves teaching yourself. If you do not find lecture helpful, do not go. Use that time to learn and practice the skills on your own and then copy lecture notes from someone who went to lecture.
This course is extremely well organized and very fair.

This course is not as difficult as people make it seem. many of the concepts themselves are perfectly simple, and with enough time and attention, anyone can get them. If you want to do well, you will need to put in effort into understanding the material by bothering your preceptors or reading the textbooks. If you can finish a pset, it means youre pretty much solid on the material, so try to do those at least before the exams.
This course is very difficult, but there is a lot of resources to help you prepare for exams, so do take advantage of those resources, and CHM 305 may actually be kind of fun!
This is a challenging course and the exams are difficult. However, there are many resources to help you succeed. TRY TO GET A PRECEPT WITH NECH - HE IS GREAT.
This is a great class!
This is a very challenging course. Review the notes and do the Psets. Exams are hard
This is a very demanding class but I learned a lot about organic chemistry.  This class will definitely require a lot of time spent studying outside of class.

This is a very difficult class and your grade will depend on the amount of effort and work you put. DO NOT take this course as a PDF or if you are not set on premed. ONLY take if you are set on chemistry or mol bio.

This is a very organized and well-taught course.  Although it's difficult and requires a significant time commitment, it is not as torturous as people often make it out to be.  If you do review on your own and take time to do lots of practice problems and exams, it's definitely possible to be successful.

This may not be the most exciting course you take, but many people go through it and it's not as scary as people say. Be sure to stay on top of the material, even though the p-sets aren't graded, because it will come back to bite you if you cram for the test.

This will be your most consuming class, you need to always be in orgo mode--- not an easy class especially with the frequent exams but if you put in the effort your outcomes will be great and you'll feel so accomplished. Stay proactive and you'll be fine!
Try to take this class different university over the summer if you can. Save yourself the stress and probably at least six months on your life.

Very challenging course, but if you keep with yours studies, you will be alright. Don't leave the reading and studying for the week before the exam, but study daily/ weekly in small portions. Definitely do all practice exams and read the book, as well as solve all Precept Problem Sets.

While this course is a requirement for several STEM majors and as well is required for the pre-med student, the course material is interesting, and Professor Semmelhack is a great lecturer. One piece of advice I would give is that the textbook truly is a valuable study aid and resource.
You can do it, I did it and I'm not that smart. IT is hard but put in the work and you will be fine.

You need to have a lot of time if you are going to take this course. I would not recommend taking it with challenging courses from other disciplines, especially ones that are time consuming. In order to do well, you need to have hours of free time a week to go over the material and do the readings and finish the problem sets and do practice exams. Also, don't fall behind early because the entire semester builds on what you did in the first unit so if you don't get that you're setting yourself up to struggle.

You will learn a lot of from Orgo when you dedicate your time to it. There is a lot of material to cover and it will take a lot of time to understand it. The concepts you learn from Orgo will be very helpful as you move on to other Biology and Chemistry courses. 
Additionally, reviewing lecture notes will be very helpful each week. Lastly, doing all of the practice exams will be helpful as well. Practicing will help you understand the concepts more and be more aware of what's expected of your for an exam.
You're probably taking this as a requirement, but it's not a bad class. There's a lot of work, but if you keep up with it and don't get overwhelmed, it'll work out.
You're taking it because you have to. Do the problem sets. Practice. Get Organic chemistry as a second language.
dont take unless youre premed or really like organic chemistry
go to lecture, it's really helpful. and do all of the practice exams in prep for the exams
need to put in time along the way to learn the material as you go because it is very cumulative, especially as you approach the final
not really that hard. it's really fun and rewarding when the puzzle works out. lectures and textbook didn't help me.
only take if you need
read before lecture--prep in advance will help you make the best use of your time and will help you be able to follow along very well in lectures.
required
take it if you have to
take it if you have to but make sure that the rest of your schedule is very very simple/easy.
textbook is an understated resource, but extremely useful for later portion of the semester
trash
very good course. Really enjoyed semmelhack's lectures. material is really interesting.
work hard for it!
grading: Final Exam - 40%, Other Exam - 40%, Lab Reports - 20%
assgts: Reading as needed. There is an optional but very important problem set each week.
prereqs: CHM 201 and 202, or CHM 203 (or CHM 207) and 204, or CHM 215. Please contact Patrick Andrae (pandrae@princeton.edu) for all changes in lab and class sections after the completion of registration {OR} to add CHM 303 {OR} to be added to the waiting list for closed lab or class sections..
descrip: This course is designed as the first part of a three-semester sequence, CHM 303/304B and MOL 345 (biochemistry). CHM 303 will introduce the principles of organic chemistry, including the structures, properties, and reactivity of simpler organic compounds. The emphasis will be on the mechanisms of organic reactions, with examples taken from biology when appropriate to illustrate the principles. For a complete presentation of the subject, the course should be followed by CHM 304B in the spring.
title: Organic Chemistry I: Biological Emphasis

evals: I enjoyed it because I got more used to reading mathematical notation and not being intimidated by large equations. Ultimately, you don't really need to know the math very well to succeed in this course.
If you're deciding between 405 and 305, from what I have heard, this is a tad better/easier. It's not incredibly exhilarating, but you'll learn incredibly useful things in an approachable manner.

If you're looking for a mathematically focused course, you should probably pick the other quantum chem class. That being said, this was a generally well-run course. It felt a bit unstructured at times, and there was always some confusion over what would be on the exam. However, it did cover enough basics to understand some of the concepts as they applied to what we'd use in lab, especially spectroscopy.

Jacob and Elliot have done a tremendous job preparing for lectures, precepts, and even additional help sessions. The two are truly passionate about teaching and making the course interesting, though it's a very difficult topic.

The first half with Scholes was super chill, and the first midterm was a joke. The second half with Jacob was difficult and the second midterm was definitely not a joke. But overall it was pretty chill for a quantum class and the profs and TAs are awesome awesome people. Get Elliot as your preceptor if you can!!
You will be confused for a large part of the course. Read and reread the notes, it will start making more sense eventually.
otherinfo: Open to suitably prepared freshmen. This course in combination with CHM 306 provides a two-semester sequence of physical chemistry topics. CHM 305 is not a prerequisite for CHM 306. However, if the full year sequence is not taken, the student will not be eligible to receive professional certification of his/her undergraduate degree, and will not be prepared for graduate work in chemistry. NOTE: This course will have two midterms each worth 25% of the final grade.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: 20-40 pages of reading; Web-based material
descrip: Introduction to quantum mechanics, surveying applications in chemistry, physics, molecular biology, and energy science. A conceptual understanding will be emphasized. Modern examples, including organic solar cells, photosynthesis, nanoscience, quantum computing with diamond, and quantum biology, will be discussed.
title: The Quantum World

evals: A great chemistry departmental. Very straightforward and well taught. I am glad I took it. Some of the problem sets can be tedious and the exams are very long, but nothing was unreasonable.
Go to lecture

I found this course personally difficult as there was a lot of material to cover. Practice is the only way I think one can feel confident about the material, so definitely make time for it! It will help you figure out what you know and don't know.

I personally loved this course, although I know many found it dry. I thought it was so neat to finally learn the why and how behind a lot of chemistry, including spectroscopy, molecular orbitals, and transition metals. Professor VanderKam is incredibly helpful. Go to her office hours!!! Even if you're not quite sure what your questions are. She will  be glad to discuss the concepts with you if you're interested.
Homework took me about 6-8 hours a week depending on the week. Do not start the homework late! 
When studying for the tests there are not practice tests. Go over the powerpoints and be able to explain the concepts (try lecturing to a teddy bear/finger puppet/friend, you'll find out what you don't understand), and make sure to go over problem sets again! And work really quickly on exams. There was way too many questions on all of our exams. So just work as quickly as you can.
I would absolutely not take this course again if it were not required. It is like drinking out of a fire hose. However, it is not bad among chemistry departmentals.

I would recommend this course to everyone who wants to learn inorganic chemistry but be wary that exams are very long and test how fast you can perform the material not necessarily how well you know or understand it.

If you're a chemistry major, you have to take this or 408 or both. What you're getting: 1. Dr. VanderKam, who is a great lecturer and very funny; 2. long and hard problem sets that prepare you for exams; 3. exams that are long but ask fair questions. Also, if you are worried about not liking chemistry because of orgo but you did like 201/2/7, this is probably the class for you.
It's a good course, you get a solid foundation of inorganic chemistry. Start problem sets early, they're long. Work through midterms as quickly as possible, they're very long.
otherinfo: Highly recommended: The purchase of a 1001/Fundamental General Chemistry Set - HGS Polyhedron Molecular Model - Item Number: ASIN B003PM7KL2
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 20%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: 25 pages per week plus weekly problem sets.
prereqs: CHM 303 and 304/304B - OR - equivalent are required..
descrip: Structural principles and bonding theories are discussed for various classes of main group inorganic and transition metal coordination compounds. The topics include an introduction to group theory, vibrational spectroscopy, molecular orbital theory, the electronic structure of d-orbitals and ligand field theory.
title: Inorganic Chemistry: Structure and Bonding

evals: Chem Core Lab definitely lives up to its reputation. I learned a lot of valuable information in this class, but I'm not entirely sure it made up for the torture of the lab reports. Dr. Kelly and Wang do understand the difficulties of this course, and they do try to help us as much as possible, but it's still very challenging to finish everything on time. Our lab TAs this semester, Tomoyuki and Duyu, were amazing, and I don't think I would have survived without them. Since you'll probably have to take some core lab, I'd suggest this if you're more interested in the non-organic side of chem or you want an overview of what you can do for the future... but be prepared to not sleep for the semester. It's a lot of work at the beginning, and the second half of the semester can get frustrating if you don't have an interesting project. Wishing you the best of luck! You can get through it!!

Hello chem majors! You most likely have to take this course and are completely scared-off by the negative course reviews. Well, worry not, it's really not that bad. The labs are fun and teach you a lot - the lab reports will take over your life, but it's a bonding experience! I highly highly highly recommend working together on lab reports, and starting them early. Overall, you learn a lot and get to know other chem majors better.
I mean, you have to. Don't take MSE or MOL core lab, just get it over with and make friends through mutual suffering.

If you are a chem major, you should take this unless you really want to focus on materials or molecular biology. Yes, it takes a lot of time for the first six or seven weeks, but it is worth it. You'll be part of a great community and learn a lot besides. Working with your fellow chem majors throughout the course will be key.

Lab reports actually do take as long as everyone says, especially if you've 1) never used a spreadsheet program for extensive calculations, 2) haven't done this kind of data analysis before, and 3) aren't already intimately familiar with the material, which you probably won't be at this point. Lectures do cover a lot of material, but there's still a huge discrepancy between them and the lab reports, and there weren't really regular office hours, either. If the instructors say the lab report should take "only about 15-20 hours," it will take between 30-60 because you'll either be teaching yourself a lot of material or learning it from other students.
That said, you do learn a lot in this lab, and it's helpful for figuring out what kind of chemistry you'd be most interested in. You'll also really get to know other chem majors. Just be prepared to have less than zero free time every other week for the first half of the semester.
One hell of a class. Will break your soul with uncertainty calculations. But your friends will get you through the class, one way or another.

The only people I can recommend this course to are chemists interested in physical chemistry labwork. This class is frustrating, difficult and intense with almost 0 payoff in the end. Lab reports are mostly p-chem based and take up an incredible amount of time because the material isn't taught well and you'll get them back much later after a TA has shredded them to pieces based on grading standards that were never announced. All this effort is for nothing though when the information never comes up again (unless you go into a p-chem/instrumentation lab). The final independent project is a mess with mainly p-chem projects available, so you'll probably end up working on some project you don't care about or understand for 6 weeks and then have it be 40% of your grade. I hated this class. It was too much work and nothing of value was taught. Take another core lab if you're a chem major as your lab requirement and don't bother with this class. The only saving grace is the community you develop with other kids in the major suffering through the same hell with you. It makes it better and brings you together, but it hardly makes it worth it.
The workload of this class should count as two and a half classes. Very challenging, but you will learn a lot. The independent projects are fun. Don't procrastinate on writing your lab reports.
otherinfo: Laboratory handouts. Reserve books in Chemistry Library. Lecture and either MW or TTh lab sessions must be taken. Please contact the instructors for assistance with enrollment issues.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Final Exam - 10%, Lab Reports - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Four laboratory exercises, including preparation and research notebook write-up. Preparation of one experiment as manuscript for publication. 20-30 pages of reading per week. In lieu of final exam, students complete a special lab project, develop a professional poster of the work, and participate in a poster session.
prereqs: CHM 202, 204 or 215 or equivalent. Concomitant enrollment in either CHM 305 or 407 is strongly advised..
descrip: The purpose of this laboratory course is to teach the principles and practice of modern experimental chemistry, including: data collection, analysis, and interpretation; experimental design; validity of data and meaning of statistical correlation; and theoretical and operational aspects of modern instrumentation. Applications of computers in data analysis and molecular modeling will also be covered.
title: Experimental Chemistry

evals: First half is drug discovery, second half is a more chemical view of biochemistry. The quality of the course is really contingent on the preceptor.

I do not recommend this course. It is not structured well, the problem sets and examinations can exceed what was covered in lecture, and I did not get as much out of it as I wanted to. It is not up to the same quality as other chemistry courses I have taken at Princeton.
I would definitely recommend taking this class. Parts of it were definitely challenging, but it's well worth it if you're at all interested in the material.
Professor Groves is brilliant - do not pass up a chance to take a class with this famous scientist

They say it's story time with Reider, but it's really story time with Groves and Reider. Don't take it if you actively dislike biochem, the second half is all staring at enzymes and a lot of hand-waving.

This class is kind of a mess, but a good one potentially. Lectures are always just Reider/Groves talking/rambling about whatever they want without teaching much, and then you are expected to actually have learned something when it comes time for psets/exams. I recommend this class only because the preceptor (Jeff) was amazing this semester. Only take it if you know the preceptor will make it worthwhile. Don't take this class out of casual interest, it's not worth it unless you intend to use this knowledge.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Reading assignments and problem sets.
prereqs: CHM 301 and CHM 302, or CHM 303 and CHM 304, or equivalent laboratory courses..
descrip: A selection of advanced topics in organic chemistry, including organic synthesis, organic reaction mechanisms, biosynthetic pathways, and elements of modern drug design.
title: Advanced Organic Chemistry

evals: I recommend reading the notes before going to class, since it may take some time to recognize what is written there - they are not the most legible notes.
Make sure you have a strong background in linear algebra and have taken other quantum mechanics courses.
otherinfo: Lectures will follow notes that will be uploaded to Blackboard. Weekly homework problems, a midterm exam, and a final exam. The text (currently out of print), J.M. Anderson, "Introduction to Quantum Mechanics," will be provided as a copy to students. Other background texts will be on reserve in the library.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 10%
prereqs: Successful completion of a quantum mechanics course (at the level of CHM 405) and one semester of linear algebra.
descrip: Basic quantum mechnical concepts at a rigorous level appropriate for graduate students in experimental and theoretical physical chemistry, applied physics and engineering. Topics include (i) mathematical formalism of quantum mechanics and operators in time-independent quantum theory (ii) basic angular momentum theory (iii) exactly soluble systems: harmonic oscillator and hydrogen atom (iv) indistinguishable particles (v) variational theorem (vi) time-independent perturbation theory (vii) time-dependent theory, and (viii) selected applications.
title: Basic Principles of Quantum Mechanics

evals: Anything you get out of this course will come from your own initiative rather than skillful instruction. This is a shame since each of the two instructors are highly respected researchers of the topics at hand.
Do not take this class unless you want to be a theorist.
Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to. Even if you think you should because it will be good for you, don't.

Given my above reviews on the lack of clarity and focus in the course material and the requirement of many hours of additional research to complete the assignments with little feedback I believe that the course title is misleading. This course is interesting as an overview of the field of statistical mechanics and a test of your knowledge in related fields, but is anything but an introduction to the field. The saving grace is that the book serves as a fairly good starting point for beginning to learn the fundamentals of statistical mechanics on your own after the course. With that said I do not recommend this course to a student who wants an introduction to statistical mechanics that clearly lays out the theory in a way that will allow continuation in this field and build interest.
If you major in Chemistry, you should take this course.  It is very useful for people doing theoretical work.
If you want some rigorous knowledge about statistical mechanics, go for it.
Unfortunately, it can be tough for beginners of stat. mech. , but I recommend this course to other students
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Statistical mechanics provides the basis for understanding the equilibrium and nonequilibrium properties of matter in terms of the microscopic details of molecular interactions and structure. The course aims to provide students with working knowledge of the fundamentals and applications of statistical mechanics.
title: Introduction to Statistical Mechanics

evals: Comprehensive introduction to biophysical techniques and chemistry.
If you are interested in applying biophysical techniques to your research, this course was very useful and informative. However, only half of the class was dedicated to learning these techniques.

This is a useful class to take if you are interested in learning about or using biophysical techniques. You definitely get the opportunity to learn about interesting techniques and some really neat applications in biology and chemistry, but sometimes Prof. Carey's biological structure basis lectures are very slow and redundant. It helps with the assignments to be familiar with MATLAB or programming to some degree, but it isn't necessary.
otherinfo: The course is intended for beginning graduate students or advanced undergraduates in chemistry, computer science, mathematics, molecular biology, physics, or engineering. Some basic background in undergraduate chemistry is assumed, but there are no specific prerequisites.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Problem set(s) - 60%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: The 10% "Other" component of the course grading will be the development of a written proposal/outline for the final paper (Final Paper in lieu of Final Exam).
descrip: A quantitative treatment of modern topics at the interface of biology, chemistry, and physics with an emphasis on enzymes.
title: Biophysical Chemistry I

evals: If you have enough time to solve problem sets, this lecture would be nice. However, if you should focus on research, taking this course might be burdensome.
Make sure to take good notes and attend all classes.

Professor Pfennig teaches inorganic chemistry from the fundamentals up and from a physics/mathematics perspective, so this is a great course if you want a deep understanding of inorganic chemistry. However, I would not take this course with Pfennig if you do not enjoy the idea of deriving everything from first principal.

The class taught by Pfennig was frankly awful. His lectures were a mixture of boring and offputting and I feel like I learned very little that wasn't taught in the undergraduate introductory inorganic course. Having said that, I've heard great things about Chirik and his teaching style, so if he is teaching this course, feel free to disregard everything I said.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 33%, Final Exam - 34%, Problem set(s) - 33%
descrip: A detailed examination of bonding and structure in transition metal complexes are undertaken. A variety of modern physical methods are discussed in this context. Chemical reactivity, including ligand substitution reactions, charge transfer reactions and photochemical processes, are investigated based on electronic structure considerations. Examples are drawn from the current literature.
title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry

evals: A good review of synthetic organic chemistry.

The course requires a decent amount of preparation. You should be comfortable writing organic mechanisms and drawing molecular orbitals. It also really helps to familiarize yourself with common and/or named reactions/rearrangements/etc.

This course is good if you already knew the material to begin with. If you are learning the material for the first time then seek other resources in addition to the notes to figure out what is going on.
otherinfo: Source for modeling kit: http://www.maruzen.info/hgs/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=31
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Recommended material will be listed on course syllabus.
descrip: A mechanism-based course on organic synthesis for advanced undergraduates and beginning graduate students who wish to learn chemical synthesis of organic compounds. Course deals with various classical and modern synthetic methodologies. Particular emphasis is placed on understanding scope, limitations, and selectivity based on the mechanism, with the goal to understand fundamental principles underlying each synthetic method. The knowledge and perspective acquired in this course is expected to provide sufficient foundation to understand and use the research literature in organic synthesis.
title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry

evals: Awesome course. It gives you a great understanding of how one can actually probe the ways reactions work and it stimulates you to think about mechanism and trends in organic chemistry. Very reasonable amount of work   Abby&Rob are an amazing duo!

I can't recommend this course enough to other students. The workload was minimal and the lectures were great. Abby and Rob are super helpful whenever you have questions. Just because this is a grad course doesn't mean it's impossible. I found this to be on par with the rest of my undergrad courses. Take this course if you are thinking about grad school and have already taken both semesters of orgo and p chem.

I thought this course was extremely helpful in learning physical organic chemistry. I found the course load manageable, and Rob and Abby are amazing professors!! The exams were fair, I thought, and the problem sets took a bit of time but were biweekly, so that was fair and it was not an unreasonable amount of time. Undergraduates should feel free to take this course if they have the prereqs!!
It's a great course if you want to gain a more rigorous understanding of the qualitative principles we use in organic chemistry day-to-day.
This is a great informative course that I strongly recommend taking.
Very engaging course despite the difficulty - take it if you're really interested in the mechanistic aspects of organic chemistry!

perhaps it would be useful to go to office hours more and ask for assistance with the homeworks, this could lead to finding clear ways to think about the assigned problems the way the professor prefers.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: This course covers the fundamentals of physical organic chemistry to provide the students with a thorough understanding of chemical reactivity. Within the framework of organic reaction mechanisms, the class discusses a number of topics, including the essence of structure and bonding, the nature of reactive intermediates, and the use of kinetic measurements and isotopic labeling studies to decipher chemical mechanisms. Grades are based on problem sets, a mid-term, and a final exam.
title: Mechanistic and Physical Organic Chemistry

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
descrip: This class emphasizes the use of chemical approaches to investigate and manipulate biological processes at the biochemical, the cellular, and the organismal level. The purpose is to provide chemical biologists with modern chemical methods. The class will then discuss how these methods can be applied to study different biological problems, highlighting important questions in biology. Typically a paper from the current literature will be presented and discussed by the students each class. Grades are based on problem sets, a midterm exam, a literature presentation, and a research proposal.
title: Topics in Biological Chemistry - Chemical Tools to Study Biological Systems

evals: If you are interested in learning more about  NMR (especially), MS, and other techniques for chemical identification, take this course. Remember to take good notes because they will be useful during the exam. Don't be afraid to ask questions if you don't understand Istvan. He is very nice, and sometimes his Hungarian accent makes what he is trying to say difficult to understand.
If you don't have enough background of physical chemistry, it will be quite difficult to fully understand the lecture.
Take this course if you are interested in the theory of nmr
enjoyable course, little effort and you learn some cool techniques
grading: Mid Term Exam - 33%, Final Exam - 67%
descrip: This course covers the application of selected analytical instrumentation to modern chemical/biochemical research, including materials science and environmental and medicinal chemistry. Primary emphasis: NMR methods; data processing and spectrum analysis; integration with mass spectrometry; X-ray diffraction; IR, UV, and EPR spectroscopy; chiroptical techniques. Practical problem solving exercises for identification and characterization of molecular structure and dynamics using in-house examples are a significant part of the curriculum. Recommended for graduate students, and junior and senior undergraduates.
title: Introduction to Chemical Instrumentation

evals: A good introduction to Chinese with a consistent but manageable workload.

A highly enriching course and language sequence. I've done two other languages here at Princeton and have had a very long history of language studies. I've come to regard what the Chinese department does to be of high caliber. Do not expect it to be a walk in the park. It should require you 60-90 minutes a day and then 90-120 minutes prior to dictation and the grammar test. You will be surprised on your results if you keep up with it. The faculty is immensely helpful and so kind hearted. Do not do my mistake of not going to language tables.Will go down as one of my favorite courses. It made me love language learning again. 5/5 I say.
A tough, but incredibly well-taught course. Make sure you establish a study routine early on and stick with it throughout the semester.
Don't do a homework all on one day.
Excellent.

If you aren't willing to invest a serious amount of time in this class, you should probably take a different language. That being said, the department has a really effective method of teaching Chinese. I learned a ton this semester. If you're serious about this class, it's so rewarding. But it's not something to throw on as an easy class because it is a lot of work.

It's a lot of work, but well worth it.  Prepare to make tons of flashcards, and use them for a bit each day.  If you put in the work, though, you'll get there.  Also, the instructors are top notch, and go above and beyond every day.
It's a lot of work, especially if you haven't had experience speaking the language before.
Make sure you practice/study everyday because this course is very fast paced.
Only trouble is that if you've never had any Chinese experience before, this can be EXTREMELY difficult for true, true beginners who have never had experience learning another language before.

Overall, this class is a ton of work, but incredibly effective in teaching a language. Every class requires students to speak  and practice, which is an excellent way to practice. I am learning Chinese faster than I would ever learn the language otherwise.
Put in the work and you will do well- the class is very straightfoward
Really recommend taking this class. The teachers and lesson plans are great.

Recommend if you are genuinely interested in learning the language and ready to really put in a lot of work. A lot students who are pretty proficient take the course for whatever reason, so don't be too surprised. You'll be fine if you really work hard.
Simply put, this is the best language class I've ever taken. It will help your Chinese a lot, but is certainly intensive in terms of workload.
Starting a language from scratch? Strongly consider Chinese at Princeton.
Study everyday. This is a very demanding course and even though you can cram the night before the test, you will most likely forget a lot of it by the next week.

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT! This class can be a fair amount of work, but it is super well organized and the quality of teaching is EXCELLENT. You will look forward to going to class every day, and your Chinese skills will improve rapidly.

The memorization of characters is what makes this class potentially more stressful than other languages. But at the end of the day, it isn't really more work than languages like Spanish. If you're really interested, don't be afraid to take this course.
The professors are great and you learn a surprising amount in one semester. It's a decent amount of work but not that much and certainly not excessive or overwhelming in anyway.
There is no better place to learn Chinese than in Princeton. It is a lot of work, but if you diligently keep up, you will see your Chinese gradually get better. You are going to love the teachers!

This class is very, very good.  You need to want to learn Chinese if you take it - it is hard and it can be a lot of work.  However, the teachers will help you understand and the materials are very good.  It is in small sections so you develop a good rapport with your classmates and teachers, all of whom are very knowledgeable and helpful.  Definitely take!

This course is very interesting and you will get a lot out of it as long as you're willing to put the work in. There are weekly tests, recordings and dictations as well as written homework so there is a lot of work that has to be done. If you put the work in the class is excellent.
This is a great course. I totally recommend taking it, but don't do so lightly. It requires a substantial amount of frequent work.
This is the best chance for you to learn chinese before you leave college life. Seriously, this is the place to learn chinese.
While this course is very challenging, especially to true beginners, it's a very rewarding and well taught course. I highly recommend taking it.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Chinese characters will be introduced on a daily basis. There will be weekly written assignment, weekly quiz, and oral exercises. Classroom activities focus on speaking.
prereqs: No credit is given for CHI 101 unless it is followed by CHI 102..
descrip: An intensive introductory course in modern spoken and written Chinese, stressing oral-aural facility and the analysis of structure.
title: Elementary Chinese I

evals: Be prepared to study weekly
Big time commitment but similarly big payoff.

Definitely take this course!! It's one of my favorite courses I've taken at Princeton. The professors are SUPER invested and helpful in teaching you Chinese and meeting with you outside of class time. Textbooks are interesting and workload isn't too too bad (more tedious work than hard work). Curve is a bit harsh though.
I like this class because it's very consistent with both workload and with how you can see yourself improve throughout the semester.
Keep up everyday, do not fall behind.

Moves at a very fast pace and the work is quite heavy compared to other classes, though not terribly difficult. Be prepared to spend a lot of time, lest you fall behind. However, it is incredibly well-taught and rewarding - you will feel at home. Good luck.

Take it if you're interested in learning Chinese and have had a little bit of exposure to it.  Personally, I came in not really knowing how to speak, read, or write Chinese, but since my parents are Chinese I could understand it well.  The teachers are fantastic, but it's a lot of work.  Also, the curve is pretty harsh.
Take this class if you want to learn chinese.

There was a lot of work for the course (daily homework, weekly writing assignments, weekly tests and quizzes), but the expectations are clear, and the workload is basically the same every week. It's not a freebie course and it's pretty hard to get an A, but your Chinese will definitely improve a lot.

They expect you to read the textbook before class so do it! Also, be attentive, on time, and watch for your pronunciation during class, as it all influences your participation grade. The class will improve your Chinese a lot. You just got to put in the time and effort. Out of all my classes, Chinese was the most work even though the actual content wasn't incredibly difficult. Getting an A is difficult.

This course is definitely challenging and time-consuming. Perfecting all the pronunciations and memorizing all the characters are hard and takes a lot of practice, but in the end it pays off. Because it is accumulative, the readings will become easier to understand, and you will gain a lot of confidence in your speaking ability.
This course requires a lot of time commitment and an easy A will not come as easily but the improvement in your Chinese will be noticeable.

This is a fairly time consuming course, but the major upside is that the work is evenly spread out through the semester. The weekly tests and quizzes will keep you on your game so it is pretty hard to fall behind.

This is a great course for "native beginners"! I didn't know how to read or write before this course (and only had a little bit of exposure to spoken mandarin) and I learned a lot from it! Be prepared to put in many hours of work memorizing vocab and reading the textbook. Practice with the study guide! Make sentences with the study guide before the drill.
This is an excellent class! Professors are awesome and your Chinese will improve greatly. Keep on top of readings and make sure you study before the Wednesday and Friday quizzes.
take it
otherreq: CHI 103 not allowed if CHI 101 or 102 taken.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: There will be weekly written assignment, weekly quiz, and oral exercises.Two to three lessons will be covered each week. Students need to prepare for the lessons, listen to audio tapes, and prepare for class discussion about the topics raised in the text. Student will read 4 pages per week.
descrip: Designed for students who already have some familiarity with spoken Mandarin. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills. Students who speak Mandarin with non-standard accents will be trained in standard pronunciation.
title: Intensive Elementary Chinese

evals: Absolutely take this class!  It's a decent bit of work, but you will get so much better!
Always learn the lesson the day before
Always prepare for the work; it's not hard if you're ready but it's nearly impossible if you haven't looked over the material before.
Definitely take Chinese! It is such a useful language and such a great department at Princeton. Classes are fun and very rewarding; workload is consistent but not difficult
Don't take this class for a GPA boost, there is grade deflation.
Get in the habit of practicing characters every day.
I enjoy Chinese, but keep in mind that it is a time commitment, and we have a decent amount of homework, and there is currently grade deflation.

If all you want is to improve your Chinese, then take this course. Be careful, though, of alienating yourself from the language. The approach is one of instruction instead of acquisition; the course can easily turn into another school subject that bombards you with work instead of stimulating your mind.
Keep on top of your work! It all helps you and it's all worth it when you see how much better you've gotten

Make sure you do the pre-reading for the next class every night. If you have the textbook in front of you it may seem easy just to look down at the vocabulary in order to participate in class, but you will stand out and learn much faster if you come to class already ready to engage, instead of to learn the material for the first time.
Note that there is a lot of work to do for this course. Yet, it is extremely worth it.
Stick with Chinese! And practice on your own.    It will pay dividends, you'll take a big step forward in your proficiency.
This course was highly difficult, but simultaneously very rewarding in that you walk away with substantial progress and noticeable improvements.

While the course moves through a large amount of material very quickly, the instructors make class fun and engaging. All aspects of my Chinese have improved significantly after just one semester of Princeton Chinese.
Wonderful course which offers a greater level of Chinese proficiency and understanding.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: There will be weekly written assignment, weekly quiz, and oral exercises.Two lessons will be covered each week. Students need to prepare for the lessons, listen to audio tapes, and prepare for class discussion about the topics raised in the text. Classroom activities focus on speaking. Students will be expected to read 4 pages per week.
prereqs: CHI 101 and CHI 102 or equivalent..
descrip: While reinforcing the knowledge students have acquired thus far, this course will further develop the students' audio-lingual proficiency as well as bring their reading and writing ability to a higher level.
title: Intermediate Chinese I

evals: AAA so this course attracts lots of people who are proficient in chinese, so I would recommend taking it only at 3rd year level or above. The course itself isn't too much work: usually a ~700 word essay per week and a quiz (requires rote memorizing a handful of quotes). The final assessment is a bit more, involving about 3000 written words and an oral presentation of 1000 words.
Highly recommend taking it. Workload isn't too bad. Do the readings and save some time to study for the quizzes and you'll be fine.

If you have studied/know the amount of Chinese required to take this course, then you are probably already interested enough in Chinese language and culture to enjoy it. You'll definitely get exposed to a lot of 'core' philosophies that will inform your understanding of Chinese history and modern culture. It also is a pretty good way to improve or at least retain your Chinese language level. There are some pretty mind-blowing ideas presented in some of the texts, and while Classical Chinese can be a pain at times, it is also incredibly beautiful in its way of expressing certain things. You'll also learn the roots of a lot of cool idioms and even just common words. Zhou is a pretty energizing lecturer as you would expect, and Zou's lectures and individual sessions are really nice, too. Weekly essays are a little annoying but w/e.
It's a great course, very interesting--take it!

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! If you are looking to keep improving your Chinese but don't want to commit to Friday classes, this class is a great way to do it. Also both of the professors are amazing and super helpful and approachable and a lot of times classes are more of a philosophical discussion in Chinese! I absolutely loved it.
Take if you are interested in China in general--understanding classical Chinese is very important for gaining fluency
Take it, we learn a lot of new historical and cultural information about China

Take this class!! The readings in the new textbook are really interesting, and the instructors go through them word-by-word in many cases so that you can completely understand these ancient, classic texts! The teachers also go to great lengths to show how the material is relevant to our daily lives.
The two instructors are amazing. While this course is quite challenging, definitely take it if you are interested in Chinese culture and philosophy!

This course will offer an overview of the philosophical beliefs of ancient Chinese intellectuals and the cultural history of ancient Chinese society.  The concepts felt quite abstract to me so I'm not so sure this course has left a lasting impact on me.

This is a great course to take if you are interested in modern Chinese. Be aware that it is quite challenging to discuss the lofty concepts in class in modern Chinese, especially because you learn only ancient Chinese which is easy to mix up with your spoken Chinese. I would recommend taking this class after taking fourth year Chinese, but it was doable after third year.
not recommended for students < 4th year level I think (hard to produce quality essay given a limited vocabuary and understanding of the language)
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Quizzes - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: There will be weekly written assignments.
prereqs: CHI 107 or CHI 108 or instructor's permission..
descrip: CHI 301 not only provides basic training for students in classical Chinese, but also introduces students to theme-based readings about important cultural aspects of pre-modern China, such as the concept of Dao, life and death, etc. Each theme is consisted of passages selected from Chinese classics and short essays or stories full of wisdom and wit from later dynasties. This course will not only improve your four skills in Chinese language but also enhance your understanding of traditional Chinese philosophy and culture in general.
title: Introduction to Classical Chinese I

evals: Definitely take the course if you are interested in modern Chinese history.  Will help you improve Chinese dramatically.
I would say that one gets out of this course what one puts in. The professors will help if you seek it out, and the reading material is challenging but well worth the effort.
Keeping up with the content is important.
Pay attention in class. Make sure to read the essays. Talk to the professors, they are really nice!
Take it if you are interested in the topic!
Take this course, because it will not only teach you great history, but challenge your thinking and beliefs in ways you never imagined.
only take if you are fluent in chinese and appreciate the language arts history of modern china
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Preparation for class meetings, weekly written exercise, and oral reports.
prereqs: CHI 403, 404, 405 and 406, or Instructor's permission.
descrip: Designed to give students who have had advanced training in modern Chinese an opportunity for directed readings in their own fields. The focus of readings is modern Chinese intellectual history.
title: Readings in Modern Chinese Intellectual History

evals: Absolutely take this class if you have ever been interested in mythology! This course helps you build an understanding of various myths, culture, and values and weaves connections between stories and history. The lectures are engaging, and the work manageable for a third or fourth class.
Definitely take the class if you don't mind a bit of reading.

Definitely take the course if you are interested, but be prepared to be engaging actively and to do the assigned readings. If scheduling allows you, choose Mathura Umachandran as a preceptor, she is amazing.
Do not take this course.
Don't take as an easy class. Actually a decent amount of work and very harsh grading on everything. Don't PDF either.
Fun and interesting
Good class if you are taking PDF. The lectures are very interesting, as Prof. Holmes is a great storyteller. Manageable workload throughout-- only two papers. The final was pretty difficult
Great course to take.

I would not take this course unless you were extremely interested in Classical Mythology. The lectures were hard to get through and the examinations were not a good representation of precept and lecture discussions.
I would recommend this course. Though it has quite a bit of readings, the course is interesting.

I would tell students to stay on top of the readings and take note of characters along the way. The characters/ themes you come across in the readings definitely build up and so it can get a little difficult to keep track of everything. Also, go to lectures because there is material on exams expected beyond readings.
Just don't. If you are PDFing, then be careful because they expect the biggest details from stories. RIP if you are taking this class with Holmes.
More work than in previous semesters, but a good class overall
Not a difficult LA if you need a distribution requirement.  Not the most boring class but not super interesting either.
Only take the course if you truly love reading and trying to comprehend classical mythology. I took it on a general interest whim and missed out on a lot of it
Perfect for a mythology lover who wants to read more into what each myth really means
Professor Holmes is an engaging lecturer.  The readings are reasonable in length and scope.
Readings are relatively interesting, but lectures are overwhelmingly boring. Solid class to PDF
Take this class if you have any interest in classics! It's pretty low time commitment with a high reward.
Take this class. It is rather relaxed, but does allow for a deeper engagement if you wish to have one. Always do the readings ahead of time.
Take this course if you have a desire to expose yourself to another culture that is wildly different from your own. Invest the time to understand and enjoy the myths and you will do fine.
The class is super interesting but actually a fair bit of work even if you PDF.

This course is a fundamental course for students who plan to pursue concentrations or certificates in Classics and may be fun/interesting for anyone who has a basic interest in classical mythology. Otherwise, it can get a little bit heavy if you're not very interested in the subject.
This is a great way to get a distribution requirement and also take a really interesting class, as long as you're prepared to take the time to do the readings.
readings and visuals were great supplements to help learn class material.
very interesting
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Students will read approximately 100 pages per week. Midterm, three short papers, and a final exam.
descrip: An introduction to the classical myths in their cultural context and in their wider application to human concerns (such as creation, sex and gender, identity, transformation, and death). The course will offer a who's who of the ancient imaginative world, study the main ancient sources of well known stories, and introduce modern approaches to analyzing myths.
title: Classical Mythology

evals: All you need to do is go to lectures and precepts and pay attention. The class is really fair, straightforward, and over all really enjoyable. My favorite class at Princeton and I definitely recommend it.
Amazing course, reading (optional), lectures informative and necessary for exams. No papers

Arguably my favorite class at Princeton so far, and I'm taking this as a sophomore, so I've been through quite a few classes already. Professor Shaw is excellent. You should definitely take the class if he is teaching. Try to get Shaw as your preceptor. Caroline Mann is also a very good preceptor. Not too much work, but very enjoyable. Lectures are interesting and exciting, easy to learn from them. The material is focused on the Empire, but we were still introduced to topics from the Republic at the beginning of the course. In addition, the course is well rounded in that it does not only cover battles and conquest but also discusses a variety of topics regarding Roman society. This course has made me strongly consider pursuing as many classics/history courses as possible. Outstanding course.
Being interested in Roman history helps. Expect to learn a lot of dates. Go to lectures. This is a good class.
Come to class - the material is explained well and makes the reading more interesting.
Definitely take if you are remotely interested in history.
Definitely take. Fair amount of reading but exams and quizzes aren't too intense. A good fourth or fifth class. Very interesting material if you like Roman history. Prof. Shaw is great.

Despite the name and advertising, this is not a history of the Empire, but rather its social history. If you expect to leave knowing who ruled in 150, you will be disappointed. Instead this class covers topics such as slavery, architecture, sports, and religion in no particular historical order. That is not a bad thing, but be advised what the class is about.
Do precept readings.

Don't take this if you have no interest in Roman history. This course definitely isn't an easy A and will take a fair amount of effort. With that said,  I didn't do any of the lecture reading and still passed. Doing well in this course is almost entirely based on memorization. Things that come up in lecture that you think are unimportant will most likely come up on the quizzes and exams. Make flashcards or something for every name or Roman term that comes up and you'll do great.
Easy HA, interesting topic
Go to all the lectures, and pay attention carefully to take notes, as this helps for exams.
Good course. Some questions on quizzes and tests get specific so study up. Pretty interesting stuff.
Good intro to Roman history, extremely approachable and Shaw is a great lecturer. If you are interested in Roman history, this is a great first class to take.
I would recommend this course to any incoming freshman regardless of intended major; it's fun, well-taught, and the professor is engaged and interesting.
I would recommend this course to any student looking to take a CLA course or learn about the Roman empire. Shaw is excellent, try to get in his precept as well.
I would strongly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning more about Roman History or needs to satisfy a HA requirement.
If you have an interesting in anything Roman, take this course. It is good for acquiring a base of knowledge and then building upon it.
If you have even the slightest interest in Roman History, take this course. It is excellent and you will not regret it!
If you want to take an intro level classics course this one has a low workload and is very interesting.
Its a chill and fun class on a great subject.
Low stress, low maintenance course. Great lecturer and solid preceptors.
Make sure to keep up with the readings and lecture notes (show up to lectures!) and you should do well in this course.
Make sure to take good notes and do all the readings. Lectures are very important but so are the readings!!
Not a lot of homework,very interesting and well-taught.
Take it!!
Take it, easy class with very interesting lectures!
Take it. The Roman Empire is surprisingly fascinating. And the class is pretty easy...
Take this course. Its amazing.
This course is a definite win. Low intensity workload. Study thoroughly before assessments and you will get a good grade.
Very fun class and not too hard. Take it!
Very informative course.  Not overly demanding and you're guarunteed to learn something.
Would recommend as a fifth course if you're at all interested in the history of Rome.
You may not need to buy the books for this course.
You should definitely take it!
no essays, just a miderm and final: a very good PDF
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 100 pages of reading per week. There will be one 1-hour midterm examination, and one 3-hour final examination.There will be brief precept quizzes. Attendance and participation in the precepts are essential.
prereqs: No knowledge of Greek or Latin necessary. Auditors are welcome..
descrip: To study the Roman Empire at its height; to trace the transformation of government from a republican oligarchy to monarchy; to study the changes wrought by multiculturalism on the old unitary society; to trace the rise of Christianity from persecution to dominance; and to assess Rome's contributions in historical context.
title: The Roman Empire, 31 B.C. to A.D. 337

otherinfo: No research paper is required; there are weekly translation assignments of around 800 lines of verse or 30 pages of prose, quizzes, and a final examination, including sight translation.
grading: Final Exam - 50%, Quizzes - 50%
descrip: An introduction to the major genres of Latin Literature and to the main scholarly issues involved in their study. Also offers intensive practice in reading Latin.
title: Survey of Selected Latin Literature - Roman Literary History

otherinfo: Class presentations; take-home translation exam for grade of Pass, term paper for letter grade. Non-departmental students welcome, with requirements to be adjusted.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: We attempt a synoptic reading of the Oresteia, paying particular attention to the trilogy's structure, staging, and theology. Alongside the text, we consider a selection of critical approaches to Greek tragedy from the nineteenth century to the present, while trying to formulate the critical approaches of the future.
title: Greek Tragedy - The Oresteia and Tragic Criticism

grading: Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
descrip: This seminar is dedicated to the discussion of the natural philosophy and metaphysis of one of the least studied yet major philosophers of antiquity, Philo of Alexandria.
title: Problems in Greek and Roman Philosophy - Philo of Alexandria

otherinfo: The seminar includes a trip to Northern Italy (Milan, Venice, and Ravenna). Students enrolled in the Seminar participate in the Princeton-Oxford Exchange in Princeton during January 2018.
grading: Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
descrip: Relying on material and textual evidence, the seminar explores the cultural history of the Mediterranean World in the Late Antique period by focusing on continuities and transformations in fields such as literate education, transmission of knowledge, religious change, formation of identity, and legal practice. We discuss key concepts such as Romanization, paideia, religious conversion, democratization of culture, centre and periphery from the early Empire to the emergence of post-Roman cultures and societies. Attention is paid to past scholarship as well as to innovative approaches based on new evidence and methods.
title: Problems in Ancient History - Transformations of Culture in Late Antiquity

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Each student gives a 20-minute presentation. Those students taking the course for a grade must write a research paper.
descrip: The title of this course is taken from Saidiya Hartman's pathbreaking investigation into the techniques of psychic control that patterned the master-slave relationship in ante- and postbellum America. This seminar attempts to undertake such an investigation for the Roman world, making use of comparative evidence as necessary. Does Roman culture produce a "doulology" [De Wet]? What about a "hauntology" [h/t Derrida] of enslavement?
title: Problems in Ancient History - Scenes of Subjection

evals: Great class with a reasonable workload. You get to learn many MSE techniques and work with amazing equipment. However, grades are kind of a blackbox where you don't really know how you're doing until the end of the course.
Helpful course for people who are doing a certificate in MSE.
I would recommend taking this class. I heard from one of the professors that a lab involving 3D printing will be involved next year. I am so jealous.
Make sure you begin your reports early, otherwise it's going to be a lot of data analysis at the end. Pay attention. It's all pretty interesting stuff.
Take this course! It was actually amazing. It's not a lot of work and you learn so much in an interesting way.

The Materials Certificate is definitely something that you should consider if you are a chemistry major. Perhaps the problem with the course is that there is no real way to gauge your performance in the course because work is returned pretty late or without grades. But, you learn a lot about different fields in materials science. That being said, don't take this is if you are trying to satisfy your STL, for instance. Also, be forewarned that your reading period will be very heavy
This is a wonderful class. Students perform experiments that are relevant to current research interests in materials science.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Lab Reports - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading per week: 10-20. There will be approximately 10 short laboratory reports. There will also be a final oral presentation based on a literature review.
prereqs: MSE 301 or MAE 324 or CEE 364. Enrollment in this course is restricted with preference given to Certificate candidates. This course is required for students wishing to obtain a Materials Certificate..
descrip: A hands-on introduction to the use of laboratory techniques for the processing and characterization in materials science. Structure-property relations will be explored through experiments in mechanical, optical, biological and electronic properties. The underlying theories and lab techniques will be explained in weekly lectures. The goal of the course is for students to develop a solid understanding of material properties and the common techniques used in research, as well as to gain valuable practice in oral and written presentation.
title: Laboratory Techniques in Materials Science and Engineering

evals: I would absolutely recommend this course to any student with an interest in materials. The workload is reasonable, topics are interesting, lectures are very clear, and you learn a lot.
If you want to know the general content of material science, I highly recommend course.
Other students: this course is great! George is retiring, so unfortunately you'll have to take it from someone else

The current professor will not be teaching this class again, so it is difficult to give advice to anyone taking this class in the future. However, if the next professor teaches the class anywhere near as well as the current one, I would highly recommend this class for anyone interested in materials science.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 45%
descrip: Emphasizes the connection between microstructural features of materials and their properties, and how processing conditions control structure. Topics include atomic bonding, crystal structure, thermodynamics, phase diagrams, defects, microstructure, diffusion, phase transformations, nucleation, coarsening, glasses, elastic and plastic deformation, fracture, sol-gel processing, sintering, and composites.
title: Introduction to Materials

evals: A MUST take class. I feel smarter having taken it, generally light workload, fun class.
A great intro course. I wasn't interested in poetry at all when I started and now I really enjoy it.
A piece of advice: It's going to be more work than you think. Take the class seriously. But if you put the work in, it will improve your writing and understanding of poetry.

Creative writing classes are absolutely wonderful here - a gift!!
