If you're a writer or have had an interested in trying out the art, don't miss out on the opportunity to work with the incredible Lewis Center faculty.  However, if you're taking it just for the P/D/F (please Do Not Do That), I beg that you take the course seriously and put in the appropriate time and energy, out of respect for both your peers and the professor.  You'll get a lot more out of the class if you do that anyway!

Definitely a worthwhile course! You write a poem a week, sometimes with a given structure and sometimes without. Professor Richardson has a wonderful balance of humor, curiosity, and thoughtful commentary when discussing poetry and creates a very comfortable classroom atmosphere to enjoy.
Definitely put some effort into the poems you write each week - you'll get more out of the course that way, and you'll feel more accomplished about your poetry!
Definitely take intro to poetry. Sitting down and writing a poem every week is so soothing to the soul, and very different from the type of work that you probably have to do for other classes.
Definitely take it. Mark Doty is awesome!

Do try to work on your poems before the last minute so that you have time to revisit them before submitting them. Also, make sure you but a lot into your comments on your peers' poems. You'd want them to do the same for you.
Enjoyable if you have a strong interest in the subject; I do NOT recommend for those just looking for a Pass/Fail LA.

Even if you know nothing about poetry and cringe at the thought of sharing your work with anyone - taking a poetry class is thought-provoking and character-building. Tracy Smith is a wonderful professor.
Fantastic first experience with poetry. Get Michael Dickman!
Good course, light workload (about 1 poem written a week) and it's very laid back. I would recommend it if you are interested in poetry or need to fulfill an LA requirement.
Great class to take.
Great course, would highly recommend!

Great course. The professor really knows what she's talking about. Typical poetry workshop. She will tell you what she really thinks and be prepared for it to not always be positive. She is nice though, although sometimes I would appreciate some clearer, more detailed feedback.
Great for students with little background/practice of poetry. Students with heavy background may find this course lax and unfulfilling. Great readings.

Great to relax and think about what matters to you, to be pushed to write regularly. Quality of the class depends a lot on the creativity and experience levels of the other students in it, in terms of how much it will help you become a better writer.
Highly recommend taking creative writing courses, especially poetry. It's light on the work, but it's a lot of fun and can really help improve your writing if you put effort into it.
I loved Professor Richardson's interest in returning comments
I really enjoyed this class as an opportunity to write about subjects I cared about while learning how to express my intentions more clearly.
I took intro to poetry with Craig. Craig is very chill and there wasn't much outside work or readings.
I would say that if they have any interest in poetry this class would provide them with the initial fundamentals of style and structure and spark continued interest in the area.
If you are interested in writing poetry would highly recommend. Very relaxed and fun course.
Must take. Dickman is the best professor I have ever had.
Prof Doty is very accessible and friendly, and provides genuine feedback. His open personality makes him a wonderful teacher.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Dickman is the coolest professor/person I've met at Princeton. its usually an hour and a half once a week and one short poem due per week... that's it!! so simple yet the best 1.5 hours of my week. Great 5th class
TKS is interested in helping you and incredibly sharp; take a course with her if you want to look hard at your poems and try to justify and understand each moment in them.
Take a poetry class while you are here at Princeton! It really is an amazing class and a good break away from all the other things you have to do at Princeton.
Take it with professor Doty!

Take it! And make sure to spend a lot of time on your poems. Yes, this is PDF, but this is one of those classes that you stand to get a lot out of if you put in the time. Most of your classmates will write great poems, so you don't want to be left out!

Take it! Even if you know nothing about poetry and don't think of yourself as a creative person, it's definitely a great learning experience! You can get out of your comfort zone with no worry about grades.
Take it! The Princeton creative writing faculty are brilliant, and it will be a nice refresher to have something open-ended and creative in your schedule.
Take it, if he sticks around for another semester. It made my semester infinitely better, and probably improved my time at Princeton.
Take it, it's a great way to introduce yourself to poetry.
Take this class, put the effort in, and really discover yourself as a poet!
Take this course with Susan!  She is so great and open and funny.  Wish I could take it every term.
Take this course! It is a great way to reflect on your own experiences and really get to know the other  students in the classroom. It is a safe space and you walk away with cool creations!
This is a good class for anyone, regardless if you think you can write poetry or not. Find out more about yourself, learn how to engage in the world.
This is a great course to take, especially if you are interested in Poetry or even curious about it.
Tracy is a lovely person and the class is very lightweight and is a nice break from other classes. Highly recommend taking a creative writing course - great way to fill an LA!
Whether you take poetry seriously or not, Professor Richardson pays exceptional attention to everything you turn in, and you will learn a lot from his comments. Take this class!
You must take a creative writing course at Princeton -- it's a chance to really do something you may not have explored before and it is very worth it.

take this class...if you are a serious creative writer, be warned that there will be people who take it seriously like you and others who take it as a throwaway LA that don't really care. It's hit or miss.
you get what you put into it. try to spend time throughout the week thinking about your writing. don't just do it all in one sitting as an assignment.
otherinfo: Individual conferences are scheduled at intervals during the semester. There are no exams. Students may begin the Creative Writing Sequence with either CWR 201 or 202. Further information is available on the Creative Writing webpage. Other 70%: Workshop Writing Assignments
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 70%
assgts: (1) One manuscript per week. (2) Reading of other students' submissions in advance of workshop in which they are to be discussed. (3) Other assigned readings or exercises. 40 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Students must apply by submitting a writing sample of 3-4 pages of poetry. No prerequisites. Application deadline is April 17, 2017. Accepted students will be able to enroll in TigerHub May 22nd to 26th..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.
title: Creative Writing (Poetry)

evals: Creative writing classes really depend on the quality of the other students in the class. Just keep that in mind if you are thinking of taking it! Also fiction might be more work than you would think.
Definintely take it! I thought I was going to be way out of my league in terms of writing skills, but I think as long as you put in some sort of effort, you'll get a lot out of the class.
Definitely take this course. It's an expected amount of work.
Definitely take this course. Prof. Lahiri is an amazing professor and provides very helpful feedback that will help you hone your writing. Tremendous privilege to have taken this course with her.
Definitely take! It's fun!
Don't be intimidated if you are not a great creative writer because everyone is learning and getting better in the class.
Excellent class whether you're interested in writing or not! Take it with Professor Valdez Quade! She is extraordinary!
Good Intro if you don't have much experience, but not incredible feedback
Great class!
Great class! Fun and interesting

Great class! I will warn you that Mr. White doesn't have that much structure and you mainly just go in a circle talking about each other's work. And there's a value to that, but he's not gonna sit you down and be like, "alright, here's a good technique for good writing." I think I wanted more of that. But anyway, he's a nice guy, and he's lived quite the life and it's just interesting to hear him talk about it and how it's influenced his writing.

Highly recommend courses in the creative writing department, though they seem to vary depending on the professor. This course did not require a lot of weekly work. That being said, I think these courses are a lot about what you put into the class. If you put a lot of work and prep into your stories, you will get more out of the discussions and feedback.
I absolutely loved taking this class with Professor Orringer. Would recommend to anyone interested in fiction (I'm an engineer and found this to be my favorite class this semester).

I found that this was a good class to take as someone who likes to do writing on the side. I really enjoy creative writing so I almost wished we had more writing work (rather than reading) to do sometimes, but overall its a low maintenance and fun class if you like storytelling. Prof Quade is a wonderful woman and writer who made the class very enjoyable and accessible to blooming creative writers.

I took this course to be my fifth course to accompany four very time consuming quantitative/technical courses. I wish I had been able to invest in it more fully--I procrastinated on writing for the course much more than I should have. This is definitely a class that pays off more with greater commitment by the student. I can also definitely recommend Phil Klay--he's funny and interesting to talk to, gives clear, direct, yet kind feedback on your writing, and is a master of selecting and suggesting the perfect readings to demonstrate whatever concept or skill he wants you to learn at any given time.

I would advise another student to go to all the workshops and decide on an instructor who seems to fit their interests as a writer or sparks their curiosity. If you are truly interested in creative writing, take the time to meet with the department and find a workshop that you think you will benefit the most from. Do not just settle because a particular course fits into your schedule at a certain time. Don't take it for granted that this is a PDF, put in your best effort, and be vocal if you think you are not receiving adequate feedback.

I would recommend this course as a very chill, PDF only class if you need a 5th class and are looking for something fun/easy. I had Kirstin and she is super nice. However, I don't recommend this course if you're looking for a course to actually improve your writing. In my class, we only had two stories for the whole semester and I felt like I didn't get much out of the class, besides reading/discussing some interesting stories.
I've already told everyone interested in cwr (and some not) to take a course with Klay. Strong recommendation!
If Phil Klay is teaching this course, take it!!!
Jhumpa is a great instructor. She does present her own idea of writing, but I think she does it really well and allows us to explore the processes that she feels are important to every writer.

Keep up with the readings!  The class is small, and it's way more fun when you've read some cool stuff and can talk about it openly.  Don't be afraid to criticize and be criticized.  It's a workshop.  Everyone's there to improve.
Professor Klay is super nice and approachable. He has a great presence and really knows so many tricks of the trade.

Professor Valdez Quade is a wonderful professor and writer. The feedback you will receive on your work is very productive and specific, as well as encouraging. I would definitely take a course with Professor Valdez Quade.
Start your short stories early and give yourself ample time to let your story develop. Don't ever rush your story.

TAKE THIS. Nice class, chill atmosphere. In White's class, you will submit three short stories (10-20) pages over the semester, which will be critiqued by your classmates. You will also read some short stories and sometimes have a short writing exercise as well. White is calm, but funny and quite charming. He has a lot of life and writing experience that is great to engage with.  There is no real final or midterm. Great class!
Take it if you like creative writing! Easy and enjoyable.
Take it if you love to write, but only if you love to write.
Take it! Professor White is a living legend and the sweetest guy. He also runs a great workshop!
Take it! You won't regret it. I thought I would like it, but didn't expect to really really love it.
Take it!!!
Take it, for sure! But make sure you're fully invested in the assignments for the entire semester, otherwise your fellow students will not be as engaged.
Take this class if you have any interest in writing fiction, especially war fiction.
Take this class! Even if you're not a writer, it will be interesting.
Take this class! Jhumpa is a great writer and It was really interesting to hear her thoughts on writing. However, I do think that there are better teachers in the Creative Writing department.

Take this class! Professor Quade is super nice and really cares about her students. The structure of the class reminded me of writing sem because it was workshop based and we had to write a lot of response letters each week. But other than than, take this course! You will not regret it!!!
Take this course with Professor White! Yes, it's PDF only, which makes it a great fifth course. But Professor White also made it really fun and engaging.

Take this course!!! Classes were great, relaxed, and pretty well-structured. Started with peer-edits for the first half of class, and an important aspect of creative writing (different every class) was deeply explored in the latter half of class. Professor Klay was very encouraging and helpful in all aspects of class. What was incredibly beneficial was how he acted like he was one of us- willing to connect, get personal, and give all of his students respect. He was the very first professor I had at Princeton, and he set a high standard for all professors I'll have in the future. Great class. Great materials. Great professor.
Take this course!!! Professor Klay is awesome!
Take this. Jumpa Lahiri is a great instructor to have for the first intro fiction class. She covers all the basic of how to write a great short story.
Take, take, take this course
The class is a great one, I'm just not necessarily sure that I got the best feedback on my work from the instructor, so it might be good to try to take with someone else.

The workload in Professor White's class is not overwhelming by any means. He is a good professor that will give your pieces individualized attention, but I think you learn the most from your peers based on what they do well and the mistakes they make.
This class is probably pretty professor-dependent, but I really loved it! If you're interested in creative writing, I would 100% recommend it.

This class was a great introduction to creative writing. I struggled with receiving criticism beforehand but now feel much more comfortable with presenting my creative work to others and getting feedback on how it can be made stronger.
This course can be harder or easier depending on how comfortable you are with writing fiction, but it's rewarding if you take your own writing and your own creative ideas seriously.
This course was amazing! One of my favorites at Princeton so far. Try to get Edmund White as your professor -- he's the best!

This is a fantastic, fantastic class. If you are at all interested in writing, you should 100% take this course. Fiona is amazing, and teaches you a lot in a really short amount of time. I could not recommend this class more.
Would recommend. Fun. Pdf.
Yes, if you go in knowing what to expect! This is a fun, creative outlet, which was perfect for me as someone who is not a serious writer or someone who intends to pursue fiction as a career.

You get back what you put in. If you are just taking it to take another class, you'll get a pass on your transcript. If you really want to grow as a writer, you'll have to push yourself within the context of very limited expectations.
You must take a creative writing class. It improves the way you carry yourself throughout the day and opens up your mind.
n/a
recommend
otherinfo: Individual conferences are scheduled at intervals during the semester. There are no exams. Students may begin the Creating Writing sequence with either CWR 203 or 204. Further information is available at the Program Office or on the Creative Writing webpage. Only freshman applications will be accepted in the fall. 70% Other: Workshop Writing Assignments
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 70%
assgts: (1) One manuscript every other week. (2) Reading of other students' submissions in advance of workshop in which they are to be discussed. (3) Other assigned readings or exercises. 60 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information. Application deadline is April 17, 2017. Accepted students will be able to enroll in Tiger Hub May 22nd to 26th..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.
title: Creative Writing (Fiction)

evals: Always take poetry with Michael Dickman!
Do not wait to go to poetry readings. Just don't.
Michael is the best.
Professor Dickman is wonderful! He's really fun to have in class and his comments are always helpful.
Susan Wheeler is AMAZING, take this class!!!!!
Take it with Michael Dickman!! You'll do some weird things, but all the prompts will push you to keep going further and deeper with your writing.
Take it! Take it with Susan Wheeler!

Take this class with Professor Dickman if you can! He's laid back but will give great feedback, and the atmosphere in his class is great. You'll also get to read some very interesting contemporary poetry!
You should have a general interest and commitment to creative writing! This is intrinsic not externally-driven; also forget about your previous preconceived notions of poetry, please.
Your engagement with other students' work and their engagement in turn with yours is essential. The less such engagement occurs, the less - far less - you'll get out of the workshop.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)

evals: A.M. Homes is a fantastic professor. Expect an engaging workshop every class, and definitely take advantage of her offer to meet with you outside of class (and even after the semester has ended!) to discuss writing.
A.M. was great. She's funny and witty and keeps things lively.

Professor Homes is the best creative writing fiction professor I have experienced. Homes really is an inspiring figure, a true adherent of the craft. Take this course if given the chance. I am not sure what else to say about it.
otherinfo: Individual conferences are scheduled at intervals during the semester. There are no exams. Program IV English majors may use two creative writing course at 300 or 400-level as departmentals. Further information is available at the Program Office or on the Creative Writing webpage. 70% Other: Workshop Writing Assignments
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 70%
assgts: (1) One manuscript every other week. (2) Reading of other student's submissions in advance of the workshop in which they are to be discussed. (3) Other assigned readings or exercises. 75 pages of reading per week.

evals: I recommend it if you have an interest in Japanese culture.
I'd recommend this course for anyone interested in Japan! Just keep up with the readings! No prior knowledge required!
If you are a junior or senior who already studies Japan, this course will pretty much just be a review of what you already know, so I recommend taking it as a freshman or sophomore.

If you are interested in the topic, I would definitely recommend this course.  Professor Borovoy definitely knows her stuff and is interested in hearing what students think as well.  The readings are interesting too!
Take this course if you want to learn more about the history of Japanese society and culture. Not much is learned about pop-culture.

Take this if you want a good intro class and if you don't mind a seminar that is mostly lecture- styled. However, if there's another EAS course you might be interested in, especially seminar, I would suggest perhaps looking elsewhere.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 75-100 reading pages per week. 8-10 pages of essay.
descrip: During the decades after World War II, Japan became the world's second largest economy and a highly productive, technologized society. While Americans once regarded Japan as a land of "corporate warriors," today Japan has become known for its popular culture, critiques of environmental destruction, and gentler variety of capitalism. We explore key social issues including gender, labor, affect, sports, media, poplular culture, biopolitics, law, demography and population control.
title: Japanese Society and Culture

evals: Great
otherinfo: Course offered in conjunction with junior paper.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: One midterm paper: 5 pages. One final essay: 5 pages. Weekly reading and writing assignments.
descrip: This seminar teaches the research and writing skills needed to produce a thesis as an East Asian studies major. Through mini-projects and guest lectures, the class introduces the various disciplines and methodologies used to study East Asia, including history, anthropology, political science, history, literature, and media studies. In addition, the class teaches techniques of research and writing: how to formulate a research question, find and use appropriate sources, write a research proposal, craft a compelling introduction and convincing conclusion.
title: Junior Seminar

evals: A great class. No prior knowledge required. The seminars were engaging and rigorous. I felt Prof. Peterson read my papers carefully and provided quite helpful feedback. As a result, my writing skills probably improved more during this class than during writing sem.

If you are interested in learning the fundamentals of ancient Chinese thought, I highly recommend. Be ready to discuss what you think. This is as much a philosophy class as it is a Chinese studies class.

If you are not interested in this subject, the seminar will be boring for you, but I was very interested in the subject matter and this is a class that I look forward to every week.  Class discussion is invigorating and interesting.  In a class of six people, there is a lot of participation opportunity.I love these seminars.  The professor always presents the material in an interesting, methodical way, and I am continuously challenged to think on my own about the intellectual history through open ended paper prompts. Papers are fairly graded but challenging as they are quite open ended. I highly recommend taking this course.  Professor Willard is an expert in this field and an amazing person.

Professor Peterson is always up to hear a challenging argument but he does have very specific ideas and stances on how things should be discussed. His grading is quite harsh and critical. If your argument doesn't conform to what he agrees with or can be convinced of, you're probably screwed. Long papers too.

Professor Peterson is an amazing moderator of discussion and is the ideal professor for a seminar course. Weekly readings were manageable and engaging. There were 3 short papers during the term and 1 final paper, making the work load demanding at times.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 33%, Papers - 34%, Class/Precept Participation - 33%
assgts: Three short papers, 5-6 pages; one final paper, 15-20 pages. Weekly reading assignment: 100-200 pages.
prereqs: A prior course in EAS is desirable but not required..
descrip: Critical consideration of a selection of monumental contributions to early Chinese thought, and the uses to which they were put by later Chinese thinkers. Readings will be from English translations such as: [Analects],[ Lao-tzu], [Chuang-tzu], [Mencius],[ I-ching] and secondary works. All assignments are available on reserve.
title: Intellectual History of China to the Fifth Century

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in history of Chinese thought.
title: Chinese Intellectual History

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Through close readings of original sources, we analyze the anthology of the Verses of Chu (Chuci) in its poetic, historical, and hermeneutic dimensions. Drawing on a wider range of early historical, literary, and philosophical texts, we contextualize the songs in late Warring States and early Han literary and intellectual culture. In addition, we trace the anthology's poetic reception in medieval times as well as its history of scholarship from the Han Dynasty to the present.
title: Chinese Literature - The Verses of Chu (Chuci)

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
descrip: This course surveys Northern Song poetry and prose, focusing on new styles and genres appearing in the 11th century. Genres include: regulated verse; song lyrics; remarks on poetry (shihua); essays; travel writing; funerary texts. Authors include Ouyang Xiu, Mei Yaochen, Su Shi, Huang Tingjian, Yan Shu, Liu Yong, Wang Anshi, Sima Guang. Secondary scholarship in Chinese, Japanese, and English will focus on genres and writers. We consider Song literature in the framework of Chinese literary history, the discursive nature of Song poetry, aesthetics of song lyrics, and new prose styles.
title: Readings in Chinese Literature - Prose and Poetry of the Northern Song

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A study of selected major authors and literary trends in modern Japan, with an emphasis on the Meiji and Taisho periods.
title: Modern Japanese Prose

evals: A good class to pdf. Don't bother attending every single one though.

Be aware that this course is not a course of medieval history (including cultural history), but a course about the great trends of medieval civilization from an humanistic perspective. You might enjoy it a lot or find it completely uninteresting.
Don't take this class unless you have to, you get satisfaction out of doing the readings alone, or there is a different professor than Poor

If Prof. Poor is teaching this, I would recommend avoiding this course (if Jordan or Reimitz are teaching then definitely go for it!). The only real reason to take it is if it is required for your certificate. If you are just generally interested in the medieval period, HIS 211 with Grafton or HIS 344 with Jordan would be much, much better.
Interesting class for a BSE major. The amount of reading is substantial and hard to keep up with, but the class is a nice distribution and easily PDF-able.
Interesting if you do the readings. The discussions can become a bit empty though unless people in your class have a background in Medieval Studies.
Take this course if you want to learn something about the Middle Ages. The reading is fantastic although lecture can be dry.

Take this course if you're interested in medieval studies at all! The grading is not harsh and you'll get a pretty good overview of the time period. Get it out of the way early if you're a potential certificate- I feel like I probably had a better experience as a younger student than the seniors since they had more important things to worry about and were basically forced to. It is meant to be an intro, after all. Extremely chill and the trips were really cool.
otherinfo: This course is required for the Medieval Studies certificate.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 100 pages of primary and secondary readings per week; 2 short papers; midterm exam, take-home final.
descrip: An introduction to medieval culture in Western Europe from the end of the classical world to ca. 1400. The course focuses on themes such as the medieval concepts of self, humanity, and God; nation-building, conquest and crusade; relations among Christians, Jews, and Moslems; literacy, heresy, and the rise of vernacular literature; gender, chivalry, and the medieval court. Material approached through various cultural forms and media; several lectures by invited guest lecturers. Seminar discussion format with some lecturing.
title: The World of the Middle Ages

evals: .Although Kelly is not a very good lecturer, there are several positive aspects of this course. I took this course due to general interest and found it to be both engaging (except for the lectures) and minimally time-intensive. It will allow you to discuss the basics of the financial crisis with some degree of fluency and other topics that come up fairly frequently in conversation (at Princeton, at least). The precepts are generally informative if you pay attention and take good notes, and most of the more mathematical concepts are covered in precept. If Kelly teaches this again, I would recommend the following study methods: print out the lecture slides before class so that you can follow along, then take notes in a separate notebook. Just before you do the problem set, go back and supplement your notes  (add parts you missed during lecture) using the slides. Precise graphs will be the most important thing to get down during lecture because much of the content is on the slides. Try to do the readings before lecture, but if you can't, read them thoroughly after lecture. Take notes on the Economist readings as you go (3-5 bullet points per article). It will save you time during midterm week and reading period. My last piece of advice would be to do the problem sets alone (initially), then discuss with classmates after you have attempted all the problems yourself. If you can take the course at any time I would not recommend taking it with Kelly, but I did it and don't regret it at all.
A decent course if you want to sample econ or want an SA.
Act independently and teach yourself material that isn't covered properly.
Alright class if you have to take it. If you just need a distribution consider Micro instead.
An easy class if you're looking to fulfill a SA requirement.
As with any intro class, there are limitations imposed by class size. Good concepts to understand, even if the instruction could leave a little to be desired. Try to get Dmitry as a preceptor.
Attend all the lectures. They are the backbone of your grade.
Be prepared to teach yourself the concepts for Psets and exams.
Check who is teaching it, make sure you are interested in the material, and then go for it
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH NOONAN

Definitely take this class! The material in macro is MUCH more interesting than the material in micro. Professor Noonan is an incredibly kind and understanding teacher and her biggest concern is that students learn. Although at times she answered questions in a confusing manner, or seemed like she didn't know all the details of what she was explaining in lecture she was still a really great professor. She was a great preceptor and always willing to help us. I think a lot of people taking the class didn't want to give her a chance because she is a new professor, but she was was nice and made the subject interesting and relevant for us.

Depends on the professor I guess. Noonan was a terrible lecturer (I heard she was better in Micro thought). The problem sets were manageable though, and Noonan was an approachable professor. Take it if you need to, but its not the most exciting introduction to macro economics.
Did not have a good experience with Professor Noonan.  She really struggled to teach during lecture and at times it felt like she didn't have a clue what was going on.

Do NOT take this with Kelly Noonan. She doesn't know how to lecture, make problem sets, or teach a course! She is okay in office hours, but during lecture, she is often unprepared and disorganized. She rushes through the lecture slides without explaining concepts well, but somehow still manages to not have enough time to get through all of the necessary material in the powerpoint presentation. Her graphs are unclear, mislabeled, and not explained well. She does not know how to answer questions in lecture. Once, she told us the exact opposite thing occurs (something like the interest rate rising with imports), and only realized her mistake AFTER lecture when somebody emailed her about it... Also, her problem sets have many problems with the wording -- the material itself isn't difficult; the only hard thing is trying to decipher what the problem is asking for since the wording is so unclear. The only thing that got me through this class was precept - try to get Anders Nielsen if possible. The readings are useless, save them until the week before the final. Do not take this course with Noonan!!!
Do not take if Noonan is teaching - you will regret it. She is a terrible teacher. Wait until someone else is teaching macro.

Do not take this class if Kelly Noonan is teaching it. As someone who went to every lecture, completed every problem set days before they were due, and enjoys economics enough to take this class for fun, I was incredibly disappointed. Lectures were disorganized; Professor Noonan struggled to explain difficult topics; problem sets were repetitive and very long. The longest problem set of the semester took me three days to complete and was assigned for and graded the week of midterms. If that doesn't illustrate Professor Noonan's relative aloofness, I don't know what does.
Do not take this course with Professor Noonan. Otherwise, I would recommend it - the subject matter is easy to understand and very applicable to real-world situations.
Do not take with Noonan! Wait for Bogen or at least verify that the instructor is decent.
Do p-sets and you will be fine.
Do the Economist readings, and make sure you keep up with understanding the material in the psets.
Don't take if Professor Noonan teaches
Don't take it if Kelly is teaching. Wait another semester.
Don't take it with Noonan, take it with Bogan!
Don't take this class with Noonan. She has a hard time explaining everything in a clear way and has confusing problem sets and exam questions that use terminology that was not covered in class
Don't take this course unless you have to. i.e. unless you absolutely want to be an econ major.
Don't take this unless you have to and if you do, dont take with this instructor

Don't take with Noonan if at all possible. If you're a prospective economics major, you are going to have to take this course unless you placed out through AP, IB, etc. so you might as well get it out of the way, but be warned that you will be bored, confused, and unengaged if you take it with Noonan. It's not particularly challenging if you take time to read the textbook, but know that it really isn't stimulating, especially compared to Rosen's ECO 100.
Don't take with Noonan.
Don't take with professor Noonan.
Easy A
Go to Professor Noonan's office hours because she would answer any question that you might have.
Go to lectures, but reading the book prior to class would be a great help, given that this professor (K. Noonan) isn't that great and getting a good preceptor is a lottery.

Good material, avoid Noonan
Great course to engage with macroeconomic materials in a technical, theoretical, and overall engaging way.  Moderate workload, interesting, high level of learning, great course to take overall.
I enjoyed ECO 100 so thought I would enjoy this...I was wrong! Don't take it if it's not a pre-req. I'll take more Econ classes but wish I hadn't taken this. Definitely avoid Kelly Noonan.

I think this course is fine to take, especially if you're an economics major and need to learn the basics of macroeconomics!
I would advise another student considering taking this course to do as many of the readings as possible, and to ask as many questions as you feel necessary to either the instructor or the preceptor.

I would not recommend taking this class with Professor Noonan. Unless you have taken macro before, lectures are hard to follow and confusing. If you do have to take it, try to get Anders as a preceptor!
I would recommend the course as a whole, but the way that it was taught was flawed.
I would recommend this course if you're interested in understanding basic concepts in economics, but I wouldn't suggest taking it as a fifth class because the problem sets are time-consuming.
I would suggest taking this course but with a different professor.
I would suggest that they wait until macro is taught by another professor, if possible. I would recommend the class, but would not recommend it if Professor Noonan continues teaching it.

I wouldn't take the course with Professor Noonan. She's not the best lecturer and is easily confused, which makes it really hard to learn from her. Also, she doesn't explain things very well so if you're ever confused, I would go to tutoring or ask a preceptor before asking her. Overall, the class is manageable and the material isn't bad, but I wouldn't recommend taking it unless you have to or are really interested in the material.
If Kelly Noonan is teaching it it's going to be brutal. But if you need to take the class just take it--you'll be fine.
If Professor Noonan is teaching do not take it
If possible check which professor is teaching it.
If you are new to Macroeconomics, READ THE TEXTBOOK to understand what is going on in lecture and in precept. It will save you!
If you go to lecture and read the assigned articles, the class is very manageable.
If you're a very mathematical person you might get bored in this class.
Important class even for non-ECO majors.
Interesting course but pray you get a decent preceptor

Also, make a VERY wise choice of who your preceptor is, as you will probably notice that the preceptors of different sections teach pretty differently, and you might end up with only the information your preceptor covered. Opt for Professor Noonan's precepts, as she is the one who writes the exams. Demand practice exams.
Just read the book.
Lectures are useless except to copy down the graphs. Just read the textbook. Material was interesting though.

Macroeconomics is super interesting, but Professor Noonan is not a good lecturer or teacher at all. Prepare for her constantly mispeaking, powerpoint slides and problem sets riddled with errors, and not getting through all of the material. You teach yourself, basically.
Make sure to do your pSETS
Make sure to keep up with the readings and attend lecture.
Make sure your professor is prepared and the preceptor knows how to portray the correct information, because both were bad. The professor was not good, but the preceptor was terrible.
More work than expected. As a non-major felt I should have PDF'd it, but still pretty time consuming either way.
Mostly you just have to do the problem sets... the exams are multiple choice

Noonan is nice, but she struggles with conveying concepts in more than one way. If someone is confused about something, she can spend up to 45 minutes trying to explain that concept. However, she won't really understand where the confusion is with the student and this actually confuses more people. What you take away depends so much on your preceptor.
Noonan is ok, will probably improve with time. Slightly more work than you'd expect for a 100-level econ class.

Noonan lectures are really, really bad. This class will be fine if not taught by her, information was good, preceptor great, just terrible lectures and this makes the course very difficult to follow and keep up in.
Not a bad Econ class to take to gauge interest in the subject.
Not as engaging as I thought it would be. Interesting material every now and then

Only take this class if you have to. Most of your time will be spent learning the material on your own. Lectures are pointless. Problem sets have several errors in them, making it difficult to get a head start. All of this said, this class is not hard. It is very manageable.

Overall, the course is not too time consuming. I learned a decent amount of concepts, but the lectures were hard to follow (confusing). Lectures were only sort of useful, and if you can do the psets you should be good to go for the exam.
PDF this class if you can.
People are going to hate on Kelly Noonan, but honestly she's not that bad. Also, Anders Nielsen is a great preceptor.

Take if it you need to. The lectures themselves were not all that bad. Professor Noonan is very intelligent and good at explaining ideas, although most people I've talked to seem to think otherwise. The main problem with this course is the fact that the problem sets, lectures, and readings were almost all completely disjoint. The problem sets were quite mathematical and required applying the concepts learned in lecture in abstract ways. Normally this should be fine, but we were never shown worked mathematical examples in class and forced to work it out ourselves. What's worse is that the readings were absolutely useless. There would be much terminology and many equations in the lecture slides that never show up in the entire textbook. The way this class was taught was simply unacceptable.

The material is rather dry, which is to be expected of an intro course. The lectures and psets were particularly poorly-structured this semester -- I often felt that Noonan was unprepared to answer our questions. If you need to take this course, wait for Bogan or another professor to teach this course.

descrip: Economics is the study of the allocation of scarce resources. The subject of this course is microeconomics, which examines the decision making of individuals and firms with regard to consumption, production, and allocation of good and services in a market system. We examine the benchmark "perfectly competitive" market setting as well as market settings that are not perfectly competitive. We discuss the appropriate role of government in addressing these "market failures"
title: Introduction to Microeconomics

Don't take it! Respect yourself. If you do take it, make sure you have taken the intro-level econ classes first (don't like jump from AP Econ to ECO 300). Also, make sure you get Julius as your preceptor, because without him you are nothing. Literally it will be 3 am and you will be sitting in Frist staring at a problem set knowing NOTHING and you will want to scream. Also, find the geniuses and force them to help you understand things. Do whatever it takes; if they hate you for bothering them just write it off as collateral damage. It's you or them! Don't get the textbook; it's not that helpful. If you don't understand the first 3 lectures, you're probably not going to get anything out of the others and you should watch YouTube videos that will help you understand instead. Same advice for if you don't understand the first 3 lecture notes. Go to ALL office hours of your preceptor, and all precepts. Do NOT skip a precept!! You can go to office hours of Tibor too because sometimes he's a little more helpful one-on-one, but honestly if you don't completely understand from one precept, go to a precept with a different instructor as well. This course is about survival. You will not prove your raw intellect, since you will spend half your energy trying to understand what the questions are asking, but you will prove your persistence. There are only really about 7 models and their variations in this course, which are not difficult to grasp once you uncover the explanations shrouding them. However you need to work hard to find good learning materials on the Internet, like on YouTube (there's this great Berkeley professor who explains everything clearly) to get to those models.

I could have never prepared myself to experience ECO 300 taught by Tibor Heumann. This has to be my worst learning experience to date (and I'm a senior). I am still stunned/in awe/ flabbergasted/ incredulous/ disillusioned by how little the ECO and WWS departments must care to allow this man to teach such a core course? I wouldn't even let him precept it. The saddest part is that each preceptor (I know this because if I wanted to learn anything I had to go to preceptor office hours) would've done a MUCH better job teaching the course. This was my most frustrating learning experience ever. Sadly, it was not because of the material, but because I had never encountered a professor so disinterested in teaching their subject/ preparing to students/ proofreading slides/ giving conclusive answers. This professor could easily be the worst this university has to offer and I don't have much more to say of the administrators who could hear half the course complain and do nothing. So few people would even show up to these lectures, and if they did, by the halfway point, half had already decided to leave. Do everything possible to avoid this professor/course. If you must, change majors/ take it a different semester/ go to a different school.

I feel like if another lecturer who had been properly vetted had taught this course, it wouldn't have been so terrible. I found the concepts interesting, but I found it extremely difficult to immerse myself in the subject matter because the lecturer made it apparent this class wasn't his priority. If you, like me, must take this course, especially while Tibor is teaching,  make sure to go to office hours. Buy the book, even if he says not to. Hands down, the worst class I've taken at Princeton.

I have studied with no fewer than twenty-five different professors at Princeton. This professor and this course stands out as the singular worst academic experience I have had at Princeton. Can I get a refund?

I have taken 24 classes so far at Princeton. To call this one the worst would be to draw an insulting comparison with the rest of my transcript. Taking it is my biggest regret. Beyond disorganized, beyond unhelpful, this class demanded much but taught nothing. I now have less respect for my university because it allowed this course to be offered. Both the Economics Department and Princeton University should be ashamed to grant credit for this class. The Econ department has made it clear that they treat students who take this class with a hostile indifference, and I suggest you do the same to them. Instead of taking this course, do literally anything else. Every other class at Princeton would be a better use of the little time you have here.

grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: 50 pages of reading. Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: Prerequisites: ECO 100 and MAT 103..
descrip: This is an intermediate microeconomics course. The general themes are: (1) choices made by individual consumers and firms, (2) equilibrium of the interaction of these choices in markets and (3) the role of government policy in improving economic outcomes. Some new concepts and techniques are developed, especially for studying behavior under uncertainty, and strategic interactions (game theory). The theory of each topic is accompanied by evidence, illustrations, and applications.
title: Microeconomic Theory
