Don't take this course unless you absolutely have to (finance certificate, econ, etc.). The problem sets are nearly impossible unless you go to office hours. If you do take this class, don't bother going to lectures but do go to office hours. If you can help it, just take a different class.

Don't take this course unless you're interested in it as a prerequisite for Economics or a related certificate. Surely confusing, the course is not particularly difficult; however, it is not well presented and very boring.
Focus on the conceptual setup of problems.

Honestly not that much math required (literally all you need to be able to do is take a derivative). If you're on the fence about taking this or 300, go with this. Leonardo explicitly said to us in lecture after the midterm that they deliberately give out higher grades in this course to encourage people to take it, so take advantage! Also, no reading other than reviewing the lecture slides, which is great.
Honestly one of the worst classes I've taken so far at Princeton. Lectures are extremely boring and the professor basically reads off the slides, precepts are useless.

I think there will be a new lecturer next year which is good. Definitely start the problem sets early and go to office hours. Make sure you understand the concepts before you get behind. For ORFE majors, not a terrible departmental if Leo isn't the lecturer.
I would not recommend taking the course unless it is needed for the Finance certificate, since it did not present the material well.
Interesting material, take it for a prerequisite, but lectures might be dry
It is what it is. Learn stuff on your own. Nice curve though. Would recommend as a GPA booster
It was a very good class, but does require a lot of work and if certain concepts do not click, you might fall behind extremely quickly.
It's not a hard class.

Just suck it up and study the material and accept that there probably won't be a particularly engaging professor. As long as you take the time outside of class to do the work to understand the material, it should be fine.
Lectures are boring but it is good economic knowledge to have.
Make sure you have a good preceptor and attend class. Lectures are really helpful and definitely more learning happens in the classroom than from individual decoding of the slides.
Mandatory class. Everybody knows it's bad, but people have to take it, so not much to say.
None
Not as bad as other reviews suggest. It may be boring, but it's not that difficult. Take it as a prereq for more interesting classes in the future.
Not well taught and very difficult problem sets, but super generous curve. Only take if doing Econ or Finance.
Okay difficulty, not too engaging, but really important to understanding how to think like an economist.
Problem sets are extremely tough, so make sure to work together. Overall, very tough and very dry but if you are doing Finance, good luck.
Required for finance certificate. Cool if you're into math and economics, but assessments are brutal.
Study a lot, and go to precept.
TAs are bae
The material is pretty interesting, but not super well-taught

The primary workload is spending time finishing the problem sets and trying to understand concepts. The first few weeks were tough to get through but it gets better later on and the curve is generous. But don't take it unless you have to.
This class isn't as bad as people make it out to be. If you're genuinely interested in economics, you'll find much of the material fairly interesting.

This course has radically changed since the previous semester, for the better. The professor is clearly very open to feedback, and does make efforts to improve the course. If you are interested in applying calculus and logic to various economic scenarios, this is a pretty good course, and very well graded.
This is a great class if you are interested in a slightly more technical approach to microeconomics. If you have to real interest then it will be a grind; however, I loved this class.
Try to avoid taking this course if you aren't an econ major. While difficult, it is doable if you devote some time to it and are comfortable with calculus maximization. Go to Elia's office hours!!!!!
Try to go to Elia's precepts because he is always very prepared and helpful. Lectures are okay if you are willing to read along with the lecture slides.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: 6 problem sets per semester.
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 175 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.
title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach

evals: Good class--the material is interesting and a good way to learn stats (for a non-econ major).
Good course-a departmental but also pretty well taught and enjoyable.

I would loosely recommend this course.  It gets pretty tough in the 2nd half of the semester and when I took it, we had to use Stata a lot for the homeworks.  I wouldn't recommend taking this if the lecture's at 8:30am, cause barely anyone made it.

If you are okay with statistics, take this course. There is no economics, but a lot of statistics. The course staff is always very eager to help (on Piazza, during lectures, during precepts, etc.) and they really facilitate the course. You will not regret it.

Overall amazing course! This course makes all the information learning in ORF245/ECO202 applicable and interesting. You do learn STATA, which is simple/direct and very useful and helps with understanding everything covered. Professor Honore is awesome and Charis is a super helpful preceptor. You can tell they both care a lot.
Take this course if you need it as a stats class. The material is pretty useful, but the classes are boring.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Weekly problem sets, one midterm, one final exam. Students expected to read 40 pages per week.
prereqs: ECO 202 (or ORF 245) and MAT 175 (or 201 and 202). ECO 100 or 101 recommended..
descrip: This course is an introduction to econometrics. Econometrics is a sub-discipline of statistics that provides methods for inferring economic structure from data. This course has two goals. The first goal is to give you means to evaluate an econometric analysis critically and logically. Second, you should be able to analyze a data set methodically and comprehensively using the tools of econometrics.
title: Econometrics: A Mathematical Approach

evals: Different professors mean very different things for this course and its ratings-- fall '15 was definitely a course I'd recommend.
Interesting for econ majors. Good departmental. We had a small class and lectures were engaging.
Make sure to copy all of Myrto's notes.
otherinfo: The book is available in PDF online.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Problem sets every one to two weeks.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 and MAT 102 or MAT 103. Not open to freshmen. Students should be comfortable using basic calculus to solve problems..
descrip: This course studies firms, markets and competition. We will study the theory of industrial organization, focusing on analyzing the way firms make decisions, as well as the impact of those decisions on market outcomes such as market prices, quantities, the type of products offered and social welfare. The goals of the course include the development of intuition for firm strategic behavior, such as pricing, as well as the development of skills for the analysis of formal models.
title: Industrial Organization

evals: Ashenfelter's experience makes the class interesting

Attend lecture! One, this is where the bulk of the course's learning happens, and you shouldn't miss the opportunity to learn from such a well-known and interesting professor as Prof. Ashenfelter. On a more practical note, exams are open note, so having attended lectures consistently thoroughout the semester will be good preparation for exams. Warning: NOT FOR JUNIORS! This is because there is a final assignment for the course that is an empirical paper like the JP. It will be hard for juniors to turn in such an assignment on Dean's Date when you haven't even completed your JIW. Take it senior year and enjoy!
I would highly recommend this course to Economics majors.
I would recommend this course if a student is interested in labor economics.
It is a great course! Professor Ashenfelter is an engaging lecturer with immense knowledge in the field. Definitely consider taking it if you want a more microeconomics focused departmental.
Make sure to read the textbook.
Take if you're interested. Pretty low-key.
Take it. You won't regret it.

Take this class! Ashenfelter is a great lecturer, he always has fun stories and examples to tell along with the material being taught. No weekly psets so super chill during the semester, but there's a final paper AND exam which is annoying.
Take this course if it is offered again.
This was a very relaxed class.
i really like professor ashenfelter so if you have a chance to take a course with him do it.
interesting topic; not a huge workload
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: About 50 pages of reading per week, plus periodic assigned problem sets and/or brief essays.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 302 and MAT 102 or MAT 103..
descrip: To provide a general overview of labor markets. Covering labor force participation, the allocation of time to market work, migration, labor demand, investment in human capital (education, on-the-job training, man-power training), discrimination, unions and unemployment. The course will also examine the impact of government programs (such as unemployment insurance, minimum wages, or a negative income tax) on the labor market.
title: Economics of the Labor Market

evals: A good introduction into finance. Professor was good (Cherkes) and would recommend.
A must if you want to get into finance.
Attend the lectures take the time to understand material in problem sets
Be prepared to do a lot of the work on your own

Cherkes is a good lecturer and keeps it fairly interesting with jokes about russia and beer. The course is pretty disorganized with him, though, and you don't really learn a lot. It's not super hard though
Cherkes is a great and fair professor, if a bit disorganized.
Cherkes is a really interesting professor!
Cherkes is an interesting character.
Disorganized with Cherkes, but professor has a funny character/personality.

Do not take unless you are taking the Finance Certificate. Prof. Cherkes' lectures were unclear and ineffective, and precept seemed totally disconnected. The problem sets were always confusing and were not reasonable in the time allowed to complete them.
Don't take Nico's precept. Take it with Martin only if he uses a mic.
Don't take unless you have to.
Don't take unless you must.

ECO362 (in other years) has been a much better course. Read the other reviews, and discount the ones from Fall 2016 (with Martin Cherkes). The primary issue in this course was the professor, both his lectures/teaching and management of the teaching staff, not the material.
Eh. It doesn't really matter which professor teaches it
Fine class. Stay on top of the lecture slides.
Fine course
Get Nick Butler for precepts if you can, guy is a genius.
Go to class. Professor Cherkes is a great lecturer.
Good course to learn the basics of finance. Will really help you get a sense of fundamental building blocks.
Great course.
I would advise students who want a broad overview of fixed income and equities to take this class for practical purposes and for general knowledge purposes.
If Cherkes is teaching, then it'll be easy but you won't learn as much as you could. I learned a lot, but I mostly learned to use some formulas instead of understanding the concepts.

If you are taking this course with Professor Cherkes, then you will get a hands on treatment of finance; the focus is not on theory but on how to price various financial products (bonds,options,CAPM etc.). Whether you take this class or not really depends on how it fits within your career/life/intellectual goals and the opportunity cost of taking this over some other courses you could be taking during your limited time at Princeton.
If you miss the lectures, at least read the slides.

If you're a finance certificate you have to take it.  If you're not, I would stay away.  The first half of the course is mind-numbingly dull, and although the material picks up during the second half, there are better ways to learn about finance than this course.  Also, the professor and preceptors are extremely unresponsive - they never respond to email or give feedback on the homework or exams, which is annoying because the grading is harsh.  I would stay away unless you like vague assignments and exams.
It is a good class and certainly useful if you intend to purse finance
It was a great course, definitely provided with me a great foundation in finance. Professor Cherkes is funny.
It was much more interesting than I had expected and well taught. Lectures were engaging too.
It's an easy class, but make sure to put some effort in

It's not that the course material is uninteresting -- actually, the theory of options is fascinating in and of itself (if we had covered it in more depth) and much of the material in the course is indeed useful, so it is a useful class if that's what you're looking for. That being said, however, it is NOT a well-taught class, at least not in this semester. Professor Cherkes is brilliant and is a very qualified professor, but I am sorry to say that there has not been a single lecture that I have enjoyed: his accent is too strong that when you finally take the time to comprehend what it is he's trying to say, he's already moved on and then you have no idea where you are. Not that it's a big deal most of the time because the class moves SO SLOWLY. Problem sets are terribly worded and incredibly vague, and it is often a struggle to just interpret the questions the way he wants you to. But the preceptors, oh the preceptors... I didn't think anyone could top Cherkes and his problem sets in being terrible but the preceptors are so useless and incompetent in this class that sometimes I wonder if they aren't taken from another department. They're inaccessible via email, inaccessible at office hours because they have no idea what's going on, and if you manage to hunt them down, it takes years for them to do anything. We're still waiting for the final two problem sets to be graded that were posted more than a month ago. If you're going to take this class, you better have a very, very high tolerance for excruciatingly slow feedback and horrible problem sets. It's not a good time.
MARTIN CHERKES IS THE MAN
Meh.

Not a very difficult econ class. I don't think you really need econ 310 to take it. You should take it regardless of major because it explains to you all sorts of information about the financial instruments and financial world today which is useful to any person.

Not an engaging or high quality course by any means, but take it anyways for the easy-ish departmental. Cherkes doesn't go out of his way to make it interesting, and assumes a basic knowledge of finance. Read the textbook if you are completely lost and need context. The good thing is you can still get by with a decent grade without caring about any of the material.
Only take if you need. you basically need to self study the class
Only take this if you have to for the finance certificate. It was not well taught and did not teach a lot about finance.
Poorly taught, and poorly administered. It's a shame because the content is really interesting but I did most of my learning from the text book.

Prof. Cherkes makes the class fun, but also confusing at times. The problem sets were always manageable, but they were disorganized and poorly worded. That said, the topics themselves were interesting and relatively simple to learn about, regardless of your major.

Professor Cherkes is an engaging lecturer and gives interesting insights into financial investments. I took it with zero-previous experience or knowledge of financial investments and found it easy enough to follow along.
Read the textbook - it is very helpful. Stay on top of the lectures. If you have any questions, the professor and preceptor are willing to help, as there are extensive office hours.
Take ECO 362 if you have to get Finance certificate. Otherwise, it might be better to look through courses list again to find another finance class that better fit your interest.
Take it for finance cert. Prof Cherkes. is pretty funny.
Take it if at all interested in investing!
Take it if interested in finance, not too difficult

Take it if you have to for the finance certificate. Martin is a great guy and funny lecturer, but in terms of actual material, he is not the best in helping you to actually learn. The preceptors are extremely disorganized and I am not exaggerating when I say this is the weirdest, most disorganized course I have taken at Princeton so far. We never knew when homework would be posted, precepts were essentially useless, the preceptors often times didn't even know what was going on in the homework problems...
Take it if you need the certificate. Otherwise steer clear-- especially if Martin Cherkes is teaching.
Take it if you need to take it, but finance for real life could be better learned another way.

Take it with Cherkes. it is a much easier experience than taking it with other professors, because the final is takehome instead of being an actual final. 

Of course, take it if you have interest in financial side of econ too.
Take it. It's interesting.
Take this class if you're interested in the material, but it's not for a casual econ student.
Take this course if you are interested in investments. Fairly good introduction class, but can be confusing at times.
Take this course with Cherkes! It's interesting and gives you a taste of / intro into the very interesting world of finance.  Also not too much work.
Take this if you like finance or want the finance certificate. It's actually pretty interesting.

The course needs better organization, particularly with pset wording/clarity and grading (at one point half the class was missing a grade for a particular assignment). While the professor is fun, there are lots of tangents, so I recommend really learning everything from the slides on your own. Also, even the preceptors would get frustrated with the wording of pset questions, so pray they fix that frustration. 

The work is easy though and only takes a few hours of Excel at most.

The entire course is extremely disorganized - the professor and preceptors are all unhelpful. Questions on the psets are extremely poorly worded, and grades were always delayed or missing. The timing of assignments was also completely random.
The material can be presented so much better; the problem sets are poorly worded and graded; and the course itself is disorganized
This class greatly depends on which professor teaches it. To really learn the concepts, do practice problems and read the textbook in addition to what is offered in the lectures.

This course is a good window into what the finance sector is like and what kind of work is done, and you will learn a lot about bonds, stocks, and derivatives. The professor is really nice, but he can be very confusing during lecture, but he strongly appreciates questions if you are confused. The precepts can be useful depending on your preceptor, but they aren't very helpful in solving homework problems. The homework isn't difficult, but you only get 4 days to do it, which means you should start early and ask questions if you don't understand the wording. Overall, the course is really good and not difficult mathematically.
This course is what you would expect a finance course to be.

This is an interesting course but very poorly run and taught. Professor Cherkes is amusing and easy to get a long with but is not able to teach the material very clearly. You have to be prepared to teach yourself most (if not all) of the material using his lecture slides, which after all are very helpful. The preceptors are great for questions but not for understanding concepts in depth.
Useful knowledge, and if you're in the Finance Certificate program you have to take it any way.
Would recommend taking this if you have any interest in finance or investments.

You actually learn a lot about pricing, financial models and how different financial assets work. Definitely try to take it if Cherkes is teaching it, he's a good lecturer and makes the material manageable.
a decent class, interesting to learn finance terminology/lingo
dont take unless you really want to / are interested--really hard and the curve is brutal
if it is taught by the same professor, do not go to lecture; it is a waste of time. just look at the lecture slides
just don't take it. Learn the stuff from Khan Academy
need to do outside reading - use textbook
read
take if in finance certificate
take the class
won't help with interviews but good course
otherinfo: ECO 202 or equivalent may be taken concurrently, but students would remain responsible for statistical concepts as they arise in ECO 362.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: 50-100 pages of technical materials per week; one problem set, case studies, including computer exercises (typically in Microsoft Excel).
prereqs: MAT 175, ECO 202 and ECO 310. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course surveys the field of investments with special emphasis on the valuation of financial assets. Issues studied include how portfolios of assets should be formed, how to measure and control risk, how to evaluate investment performance and how to test alternative investment strategies and asset pricing models.
title: Financial Investments

evals: Definitely take this class, particularly if you have any interest at all in energy economics. Brunnermeier is consistent and organized and if you pay attention and take notes, the class is very easy. Favorite econ elective I've ever taken

Great course! Great way to fulfill an economics elective or for a Woody Woo course.  It is really well taught and not too heavy of a workload (~4 psets and a final project).  Would definitely recommend this course!

I took this as a WWS student, and was overwhelmed with the Econ. I had taken Eco 100 and WWS 300, and am an enviro certificate student. Class was majority Seniors in the Econ dept and Finance program. Heavy on the econ theory and advanced micro-econ. Ended up PDFing. Interesting mix of Econ applied to environment issues.
Take if you are interested in economic theory as applied to environmental interest but not if you are interested in environmental policy.
The course does what it advertises, and in a pretty interesting way.

This is a great and friendly course for improving your environmental science, econ and public policy knowledge. It covers a large breadth of extremely interesting material. It does not require a huge time commitment, but is thoroughly rewarding.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Approximately 50 pages of reading per week, plus four assignments,mid-term exam and final exam.
prereqs: MAT 103 or equivalent and ECO 300 or equivalent..
descrip: Course introduces use of economics in understanding both the sources of and the remedies to environmental and resource allocation problems. It emphasizes the reoccurrence of economic phenomena like public goods, externalities, market failure and imperfect information. Students learn about the design and evaluation of environmental policy instruments, the political economy of environmental policy, and the valuation of environmental and natural resource services. The concepts are illustrated in a variety of applications from domestic pollution of air, water and land to international issues such as global warming and sustainable development.
title: Environmental Economics

evals: Don't be stupid like me and take this class thinking that it will count as an ORF departmental -- it doesn't.
Great finance elective if you are somewhat familiar with equity and commodity derivatives. Wei was an engaging prof
Just read the textbook.
Take it if the material sounds interesting to you. Overall a pretty interesting course and not that many homeworls

This is an interesting class on options and derivatives that is not too theoretical or mathematical. If you are looking for a deeper and more theoretical understanding of the maths and reasons as to why these concepts work, would suggest taking ORF 335.
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Weekly homework (includes paper-and-pencil problems, numerical work on Excel spreadsheets, and case studies).
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility and more complex contracts. We also devote great attention to discuss the roles played by derivatives in shaping financial markets and the real economy by using commodity markets as a focal point. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.
title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives

evals: Ask questions
Be prepared that this class is not engaging nor is it organized at all. This is the major turnoff. However, the exams were quite fair. I just didn't learn very much from the professor or preceptors.
Do readings by yourself, lecture isn't particularly useful
Don't take unless necessary or definite interest
I would not recommend taking it if you do not need another departmental class.
I would recommend this course if you are thinking of majoring in either economics or Woodrow Wilson School.
It's a great course for learning topic in international monetary economics, and a chance to tackle academic papers as well.
Take it for an easy departmental, but not the best class.
Take it if you have an interest in the topic, if not you'll find it really boring
Very boring, but not too difficult if you attend lectures.
lectures arent essential, but reading the book is a must to master the course
study all topics covered in lecture and readings for the exam. Your effort and time will pay off.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Other Exam - 40%, Papers - 13%, Problem set(s) - 7%
assgts: A chapter a week plus secondary reading.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. Course not required for concentrators.
descrip: This course studies topics in open-economy macroeconomics and international finance. Topics include Exchange Rates,Current Account Imbalances, Inflation, Sovereign Debt, and Open Economy Macroeconomics. The course will include economic theory as well as several applications.
title: International Monetary Economics

evals: Absolutely take this course if you have any interest in law, politics, economics, or law school, or even if you don't. This class will help frame the way you think about everything. Professor Leonard is incredible and his lectures captivating. This was my favorite course at Princeton.
Arguably the best course I have taken at Princeton. Great lectures. Thought-provoking assignments. Well-organized.
Definitely go to office hours or arrange meetings before psets are due to get a good idea of what graders will be looking for on them.
Definitely take this course- This is one of the best econ departmentals and gives you a great insight into the myriad of ways in which economics can be applied

Don't be fooled, the lectures are great and thought-provoking. But unless you have an interest in certain aspects of the law you'll find the readings pretty dry at times. Leonard does his best to make the course interesting, and he's the best part of the course. Be warned, though. The problem sets and takehome midterm and final are very subjectively graded. OK departmental to take, but better if you have an interest in law at all.
Go to lecture. Lectures are very interesting and also needed in order to do well in the course.
Go to lecture. Work on assignments over a long period of time to get all the info in. Do not be surprised if your grade sucks even though you feel like you are keeping up well.
Great class.
Great course. Make sure to go to class.

Interesting application of an economics framework to questions about law.  Great lectures and problem sets aren't too much work / aren't too difficult if you pay attention to lecture, although they're open ended and can be somewhat vague at times.
Make sure you are ready to work on assignments alone and go to all lectures

Professor Leonard is an excellent lecturer. Would defs recommend to take this class. 
Leonard has a tendency to cancel class and then make it up during reading period - an annoying trait, I find.
Professur Leonard is funny and good at explaining what's going on. But lectures are definitely not enough to get a good grade in this class! You absolutely need to do the readings.
Take it if you are interested. P-set are graded harshly and seemingly arbitrary. They weigh a lot, but the price is worth it for the amazing lectures. You will learn a lot and learn to think.
Take the course! Be prepared for a difficult curve, but attend his office hours and most of the answers will be illuminated.
Take this class and attend lectures. Go to office hours for help with psets
Take this course but you have to attend lectures

Take this course! One of the best Econ departmentals as its one of the only Econ courses with actually enjoyable, understandable, and interesting lectures, readings, and assignments. Start the written assignments early (you cannot perform well having only started the night before) and go to office hours to get help if you need - although the preceptors and Professor won't give you the actual answer, they will help you talk through and think about things in a more robust way. Do be prepared for grading that can seem arbitrary and frustrating at times, but you will learn a lot and likely enjoy the course.
The assignments are lengthly. Take a full day or two to complete the midterm and final.
The assignments are tough but it's a great course.
The overall material is great and the lectures are good. Just pay close attention to the lectures.

This course has 4 problem sets and a midterm and a final, which are all essay based. The questions are often vaguely worded and preceptors and the professor do not help clarify the questions that much, making the assignments time-consuming and unnecessarily difficult. Interesting material, but not sure if it is worth the work.

This is a great class, interesting and not hard to follow. No need to do the readings since they are not at all required to understand the lecture or to get good grades for the papers. All exams are prob sets, even the midterm and the final, which is relaxing

This is one of the most interesting and engaging courses I've taken at Princeton. Professor Leonard is extremely energetic and knowledgable and the 80 minute lectures fly by. That being said, don't expect it to be an easy class - the grading for the homework assignments seem very arbitrary and there isn't a lot of clarity on why you would get points off. It seems like you will only get credit if you provide the exact answer that the professor is looking for, so it is extremely important that you attend every single lecture. That being said, if you don't really care about getting an A, this is a very very enjoyable class that I would highly recommend.
go to lecture for sure
really great class if you're interested in the topic, which I was and absolutely loved it
stay on top of the readings because assignments are information-dense
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 24%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 36%
assgts: About 100 pages of reading per week. Four 5-page take-home assignments.
prereqs: ECO 100. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the economics of law. Application of price theory and welfare analysis to problems and actual cases in the common law - property, contracts, torts - and to criminal and constitutional law. Topics include the Coase Theorem, intellectual property, inalienable goods, product liability, crime and punishment, and social choice theory.
title: Law and Economics

otherinfo: Note, the text is an unpublished manuscript.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Students expected to read 50 pages per week.
prereqs: ECO 310, MAT 175 (or MAT 201 & 202), ECO 202 (or equivalent knowledge of probability theory).
descrip: This is an advanced microeconomic theory course. Using the concepts and mathematical techniques developed in ECO 310, the following topics are studied: [1] Theories of choice under uncertainty. [2] Risk aversion and applications to insurance and portfolio choice. [3] Equilibrium under uncertainty with applications to financial markets. [4] Asymmetric information: moral hazard and adverse selection. [5] Applications to the design of incentives and contracts.
title: The Economics of Uncertainty

evals: Attend lectures and go to office hours for help on problem sets
Don't take unless you absolutely must.
Highly highly do not recommend taking this course. Poorly taught and structured, and you can get all the material from other classes
It's not a lot of work, but the lectures are very boring and confusing.
Not an easy course. Only take if really, really, very interesting.
Take it!  The course covers a broad range of important topics you'll learn a lot.  That said, the course title seems misleading - exams and psets are unexpectedly difficult.
Take only if you are genuinely interested in the financial system. High overlap with 362.
Take only if you are truly interested in the technicalities of Banking. It is quite dry throughout.
Take only if you really have a lot of interest in the material.

This class introduces you to highly technical information regarding Monetary Policy conducted by the Federal Reserve. It is a very helpful class if you are a member of the Fed Challenge team at Princeton. If you would like to take this class I would highly recommend pairing it with the information gained from being a part of the Fed Challenge team since part of the goal of this team is to teach you basically everything taught in this class.
not sure...meet with preceptor? hard to say when lectures were unclear and problem sets were unclear and unrelated to lectures
take the class
there are definitely more interesting classes on the financial system and on monetary policy
otherinfo: Last year's syllabus available at: http://www.princeton.edu/~vhaddad/teaching/342/syllabus342_fall2014.pdf
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: One or two papers per week from the reading list. Several problem sets.
prereqs: ECO 300 or 310; ECO 301 or 311. Basic statistics: mean, variance, OLS (there will be a refresher at the beginning of the class).
descrip: This course explores the role that money, financial markets and institutions, and monetary policy play in shaping the economic environment. We investigate why these markets and institutions arise and may lubricate the resource allocation analytically (rather than descriptively), using tools of economic theory.
title: Money and Banking

evals: Definitely take this course if you enjoyed ECO 363 and would like to learn more about corporate finance. Professor Sexton is a very engaging lecturer with a lot of industry knowledge and experience.
Highly recommend - must-take for anyone interested in pursuing a career related to corporate finance

I would definitely recommend the course for students interested in going into banking after school. You need a background in finance to follow the course, but if you have that the work was manageable.
If you have an interest in the subject it'll be worth taking.

Make sure you have a strong interest in financial services or IB. Also, OG is an OG, so I also recommend taking advantage of his office hours. The class is just the right amount of work, and you'll be surrounded by the best econ students in the department. Take it!
Professor Sexton is amazing. If you are thinking about a career in finance or specifically in investment banking, this class is a must take.
Study more for the quizzes than you think you need to.
Super interesting! Somewhat difficult, but very worth it! Almost all assignments are group work, so wouldn't recommend if you hate group projects.
Take this course if interested in investment banking/financial services. Professor Sexton is a legend in the field.
Take this course if you are going into finance. Sexton is incredible and is here teaching for the sole purpose of interacting with his students. Take advantage of this.
Take this course if you are interested in corporate restructuring. Professor Sexton is really good at teaching the material, and you'll learn a lot.
Take this if you're going into financial services or if you just have an interest in corporate structure.
This class is slighty harder than you think. Take time to understand the material.

This course is excellent. If you're even moderately interested in restructuring you should take this course. OG is very knowledgeable and says it how it is. It was very useful going to his office hours and asking questions in class because he understands the industry arguably better than any professor here. One thing students should consider is that probably 80-90% of the class is going into financial services. That means everyone knows their stuff. Assignments and exams are a lot more competitive as a result - albeit everything is graded fairly. The material is easily the most useful stuff I've learned in my courses.
Would take it if you're interesting in the industry, or if you're going into investment banking, he has a lot of valuable insight to pass on
take it
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Readings from assigned texts - 50 pages per week. Four written work assignments will be submitted by groups that will consist of 3-4 students.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310.
descrip: This course applies topics from microeconomics (ECO 310) and corporate finance (ECO 363) to study corporate restructuring. Topics include mergers, acquisitions, joint ventures, divestiture and share repurchases. Each of these is discussed in the context of the relevant economic theory, institutional and regulatory environment, and with a focus on shareholder value.
title: Corporate Restructuring

evals: Be comfortable with at least MAT 215.

Before the midterm, the course is like a math class in style and speed, covering consumer choice and expected utility, with  brief coverage of production and dynamic programming. After the midterm, game theory is less hectic, less formal/theorem-proof-style and heavily overlaps with the undergraduate course, ECO 418, in lectures and problem sets. The course will take up a lot of time; go to office hours for help on problem sets. Good introduction to graduate coursework; take if you are applying to econ PhDs.

For undergrads considering this course: the second half is pretty similar to ECO 418, at least when Abreu is teaching. The first half covers basic choice theory. So if you did well in ECO 418, you can probably do well in this course, but you probably won't learn that much. 

The course mostly covers the mechanics of micro theory, without much discussion of its applications.
worthy
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: First term of a two-term sequence in microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer and producer theory, choice under uncertainty and an introduction to game theory.
title: Microeconomic Theory I

evals: excellent
excellent introduction into graduate level macro
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: First term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include consumption, saving, and investment; real interest rates and asset prices; long-term economic growth; money and inflation; and econometric methods for macroeconomics.
title: Macroeconomic Theory I

evals: If you like it
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduate students must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: Topics vary from year to year reflecting, among other things, current developments and the instructor's interests. Topics covered in past years have included expected and nonexpected utility theory, intertemporal general equilibrium theory, evolutionary game theory, dynamic games, contract theory, theory of organizations, and bounded rationality.
title: Advanced Economic Theory I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: Concepts and methods of time series analysis and their applications to economics. Time series models to be studied include simultaneous stochastic equations, VAR, ARIMA, and state-space models. Methods to analyze trends, second-moment properties via the auto covariance function and the spectral density function, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing and of model selection will be presented. Kalman filter and applications as well as unit roots, cointegration, ARCH, and structural breaks models are also studied.
title: Advanced Econometrics: Time Series Models

evals: The two halves are almost completely unrelated, so your interests may lie solely in one half. Both are worth attending though, imho.
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Problem set(s) - 60%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
descrip: This course will provide a broad treatment of game theory and its applications, particularly in economics. Coverage will include such topics as: common knowledge and rationality, refinements of Nash equilibrium, auctions, bargaining, mechanism design, dynamic games, and reputation. This follows up on the introduction to game theory provided in the microeconomic sequence.
title: Game Theory

evals: It is a rewarding experience!
Not for the faint of heart but an excellent course in mathematical econometrics.
Recommended class for 2nd year master in finance students
Take at least ORF 309
This class won't kill you. If you want to do more econometrics, take it.
excellent
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: A first-year course in the first-year econometrics sequence: it is divided into two parts. The first gives students the necessary background in probability theory and statistics. Topics include definitions and axioms of probability, moments, some univariate distributions, the multivariate normal distribution, sampling distributions, introduction to asymptotic theory, estimation and testing. The second part introduces the linear regression model and develops associated tools. Properties of the ordinary least squares estimator will be studied in detail and a number of tests developed.
title: Econometric Theory I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

grading: Papers - 100%
descrip: Focused on analytical models of political institutions, this course is organized around canonical models and their applications. These include: voting models, menu auctions, models of reputation and cheap talk games. These models are used to explain patterns of participation in elections, institutions of congress, lobbying, payments to special interest groups and other observed phenomena.
title: Economics and Politics

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: Topics vary from year to year, reflecting current developments and the instructor's interests. Topics covered in past years have included methods of numerical analysis and econometric testing of equilibrium business cycle models, the role of monetary and fiscal policy in inflation determination, the nature of optimal monetary policy, dynamic games and time consistency in macroeconomic policy formation, central banking, and the theories of price stickiness.
title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I

evals: Good course for knowing if public finance is a good field for you.
otherinfo: Open to graduate students only. Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: This course provides a microeconomic examination of the role of government in the economy. Topics will include the theory and measurement of excess burden, optimal tax theory, the analysis of tax incidence, and an examination of the effects of taxation on behavior.
title: Public Finance I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: Introduction to asset pricing covering theory in both continuous and discrete time to study dynamic portfolio choice; derivative pricing; the term structure of interest rates; and intertemporal asset-pricing and consumption-based models. Pre-requisites: All required courses in micro, macro and econometrics at the first-year PhD level.
title: Asset Pricing

evals: Professor Dobbie is very helpful to students, so if you're lost at any point, take advantage of his advice.
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 50%
descrip: An examination of the economics of the labor market, especially the forces determining the supply of and demand for labor, the level of unemployment, labor mobility, the structure of relative wages, and the general level of wages.
title: Economics of Labor

evals: I would strongly recommend this class for any student interested in firms dynamics. Even though I was the only macroeconomist in the class, I do believe that for someone who does trade for example, it is a great class.
grading: Problem set(s) - 80%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
descrip: Methods for empirical and theoretical analysis of markets composed of productive enterprises and their customers are studied. Analyses are applied to modern market structures and practices, and public policy towards them. Topics include the roles of technology and information, the structure of firms, modes of interfirm competition, determination of price, quality, and R & D investment, and criteria for government intervention.
title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy

evals: I strongly recommand this class for anyone interested in international trade, international macro or firms dynamics.
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 70%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: The determinants of foreign trade: (1) inter-country differences of factor endowments and technologies and (2) scale economics and imperfect competition are studied. Dynamic comparative advantage; innovation and growth; factor movements and multinational corporations; gains from trade; tariffs and quantitative restrictions on trade and their role in dealing with market failures and oligopolies; the political economy of trade policy; international negotiations on trade policy; and economic integration are studied as well.
title: International Trade I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
descrip: This sequence (with ECO 554) develops core models of international finance and open-economy macroeconomics, and surveys selected current research topics in the field. Topics treated in the first semester include: the intertemporal approach to the current account; the determination of real exchange rates, and purchasing power parity; international CAPM and uncovered interest rate parity; sovereign debt crisis; speculative attacks and liquidity crises; international risk sharing and capital flows, home bias, and the stability of the international financial system.
title: International Monetary Theory and Policy I

evals: Start Professor Rogerson's problem set early because he is very helpful and it's not worth leaving it until the end and rushing.
otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Final Exam - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 50%
descrip: An examination of those areas in the economic analysis of development where there have been recent analytical or empirical advances. Emphasis is given to the formulation of theoretical models and econometric analysis and testing. Topics covered include models of household/farm behavior, savings behavior, equity and efficiency in pricing policy, project evaluation, measurement of poverty and inequality, and the analysis of commodity prices.
title: Economic Development I

evals: Course was rich in content and structured by topic. Student-led discussions and guest speakers especially enjoyable. Perhaps identifying demographic concepts more clearly would be helpful to students.

Definitely take this class (especially if Prof. Goldman is teaching it)! It's a great introduction to demography, and many of the themes covered in this class have interdisciplinary applications to other fields, such as public policy.
Do the reading! Come prepared to participate
Have an open mind and be prepared to read texts that will make you think about your own life and choices you are making. This course will change your perspective on many relevant topics.
It is a rewarding experience!
Set aside a good chunk of time for the readings.
grading: Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
descrip: Survey of past and current trends in the growth of the population of the world and of selected regions. Analysis of the components of growth and their determinants. The social and economic consequences of population change.
title: Survey of Population Problems

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

evals: A great class to take, but make sure to attend the lectures as it is very easy to fall behind in all the information.
Amazing class, highly recommend. Not much work during most weeks, but demanding when it comes to studying for the finals.
An interesting class but make sure that you go to office hours every week to understand what is expected from the reports.
Be prepared to write a lot about the information you learn
DON'T TAKE IT UNLESS YOU HAVE TO.
Definitely take this even if you aren't pre-med. The lectures are interesting (after the first couple weeks) and the labs are fun (you get to race spiders and fight crayfish).
Do not take this course unless it is a necessary departmental or a pre-med requirement.
Do not take this unless you have to.  Lab reports are really annoying so try to make your lab later in the week so they are due later.
Do the readings, it will help you later on. Go to lecture and remember all the biological examples he talks about! They are super important!

It's a good course! The labs are the hardest part of it, and they require lots of critical thinking, but they are very enlightening. You WILL have to put time into the lab reports. I would only take this course if you're interested in biology. Otherwise, the information might be overwhelming.
It's a great lab!

Its a great class but attend EVERY lecture, or record every lecture! Make sure to keep track of what is going on throughout the course. Its fascinating, but you must be on top of the material.

Only take this if you are pre-med or (for some reason) a prospective EEB concentrator. Overall a really informational and fun course. For the sake of your grade in lab, do the reports early and have your TA check over them because the directions are usually unclear.
Put a lot of effort and time into labs, they are a large part of your grade.

Spend a lot of times on the labs and make sure you highlight the key concepts that your instructor talks about in the lab because the grading on this is very hard. Also, rewrite the lecture notes and take notes on the readings.

Take this class! Professor Rubenstein's lectures were great, and the clicker questions made all of us think about the bigger picture. Liana's labs were fantastic and she certainly went out of her way to help us on lab reports and in understanding the material. 10/10 would recommend.

Take this course if you are interested in evolutionary biology (not just for the STL requirement). It's an overall good class, but grading can be arbitrary.
Take this course if you like animals. And if you don't like animals, take this course, cause it will make you like animals.

Take this course! I took it even though I had AP bio credit and I have to say it has been my best decision at Princeton. First of all, it covers way more and different material than AP Bio and Professor Rubenstein is really amazing. The lectures can be a little dry. The labs are relaxing but you need to put some time into the reports. Overall many of the students don't really want to be here. If you have to take it do it. But if you are curious about EEB try to take an ENV or upper level EEB class that is more engaging.

This class can be very frustrating at times, in terms of not understanding what is expected on lab write-ups and tests, and the instructor giving his opinion in a very definitive but ultimately somewhat unsubstantiated manner.

This class is a great introduction if you are interested in ecology and evolutionary biology.  I would recommend reading all the assigned readings and always be looking how to connect lecture, labs and readings because you will be tested on all of the above.
This class is annoying and nitpicky. Be prepared.
This class is quite interesting, the labs are really good and the most fun of the course.
This class was a lot more work than I anticipated but was very do able for not science oriented people.
This class was honestly worse than orgo. You will have absolutely no preparation for the exams, and there is very little guidance in the lab.

This course is a lot of work in the lab, almost zero in the lecture as long as you take wonderful notes. The breadth of info covered is amazing but also means no particular topic could be considered extremely deeply.
This course requires a decent amount of time, but it is a good course to take if you are interested in evolution.

This course was horrible. The material should have been interesting, but instead lectures are boring, lab is completely useless and consists of all busy work and very little explanation of actual concepts, and I felt ill prepared for exams that actually ask you to tie themes together. Lab reports are the worst part of this course- they're not actually lab reports, but a series of short answer style questions that are really vague and often require googling to get an acceptable answer. Plus, you spend all of lab pressing record on a computer or using tape measurers for hours on end, all just to give poor data samples that you are supposed to extrapolate trends from, so there's not much time spent on actually teaching the concepts. Not a difficult class per se, but not an intellectually stimulating or rewarding one at all. Don't take it for fun, because labs are still a big time commitment and a lot of work, and if it's a requirement I'd try to find a different class.

This has beed the most frustrating of the pre-med requirements. The material is very interesting, but the expectations for grading are not very clear. Weekly lab reports are long and tedious, often to prove very intuitive concepts.

This is a great intro biology course. Be ready to work a bit especially on the lab reports. Its really important to be able to connect small details to the big picture concepts in order to do well. If you can understand this from the start you should do very well.
This is an awesome STL for a non-science person I think because it covers so much cool ecology and evolution. Try to really do a good job on lab reports because they will be graded strictly.
To take notes during class and to always start your lab early and have a study/lab group.

Unless they fix the lab portion of this class, there are far better science classes at Princeton. The lab reports are not scientific method based, they are essays with incredibly specific and arbitrary answer keys that you don't have and have to try to figure out by pestering you TA with questions. Yeah, as a freshman, this is pretty much what I expected from a college course. Not many surprises. Labs and lectures are interesting. You can avoid reading the online textbook if you have a firm background in biology - but the four books/readings are much more useful.

i am eeb major. this was a decent broad intro course with highly qualitative lectures and recipe book labs with little creative input from students. not as good as 321 take that class if non-major. you can get basically everything offered here from some decent wikipedia searches.

labs are harshly graded, take if you need to
only take this class if you have to
otherinfo: Two lectures and one laboratory per week. Lectures will be Monday and Wednesday, and design problems and interactive discussions will take place after a break during the latter portion of the 80-minute lecture period. The "hands-on" laboratory component of the course will include multi-week, theme-based open-ended laboratory investigations as well as field trips to local sites in the Princeton area and the American Museum of Natural History in NYC.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 40%
assgts: Weekly reading assignments in textbook and lab manual.
descrip: An examination of how life evolved and how organisms function. Design--'intelligent' and otherwise--will provide a unifying theme. Why do some microbes produce slime and others do not? Why are males brightly colored in some species, but in others females are the showy sex? Why do humans have knees that fail whereas horses and zebras do not? These and other 'why is it so' questions related to the origin and history of life, genetic code, biochemistry, physiology, morphology and body plans, sex and reproduction, cooperation, and ecosystems will be explored. This course is required of all EEB majors and fulfills a requirement for medical school.
title: Life on Earth: Chaos and Clockwork of Biological Design

evals: While the lectures for this class weren't always the most exciting, the topics covered in the course (in particular the readings and precept discussions) were interesting and important. If you are at all considering pursuing environmental policy or conservation, this course should be on your radar, as it is one of the only classes offered by the university that focuses on these subjects.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Approximately 75 pages a week.
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: Students will learn to identify, understand, and (perhaps) reconcile conflicts between human activities such as farming, forestry, industry, and infrastructure development, and the conservation of species and natural ecosystems. We will also explore the role of biodiversity in providing critical ecosystem services to people. We will examine these topics in an interdisciplinary way, with a primary focus on ecology, but also including consideration of the economic and social factors underlying threats to biodiversity. In fall 2017, the course will include a mandatory field trip to Florida for the duration of fall break.
title: Conservation Biology

evals: Allie is a wonderful preceptor. Start studying early for exams so you have time to ask questions. Go through the past exams (though know that the content between years doesn't completely overlap).

As other people have noted,  the class is very good about responding to feedback. Prepping for the tests can be challenging, perhaps visiting the professor for office hours would help with that. Overall, liked the class! especially considering it is one of the few options for an evolution courses.
Don't take it unless you're EEB and have to. Not a bad course but very much memorization based.
Go to lecture and do the textbook reading.
Go to lecture, be engaged, and do and re-do the practice problems from lecture.

Not a bad course to take especially as the evolutionary requirement for EEB majors, but not particularly thrilling either. Not too difficult and all material is easily accessible on the lecture slides.

otherreq: Open to Sophomores and Juniors Only.
otherinfo: Seniors who wish to take this class must get permission of the instructor.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: About 50 pages of reading a week. There will be two midterm exams, each worth 25%.
prereqs: EEB 211 and any course in molecular biology or equivalent (e.g. 214 or 215).
descrip: All life on Earth has, and continues to, evolve. This course will explore evolution within two frameworks: conservation genetics and species interactions. In the first half of the course, we will explore fundamental processes that work together to shape biodiversity and viability, both at the organismal and molecular levels. We then will examine how species interactions can be the driver of change, from sexual selection to predation and pathogens. Overall, this course will provide you with the basic tools to understand how evolution continues to shape contemporary ecological and the phenotypic traits we observe on our planet.
title: Evolutionary Biology

evals: A great, engaged course. so nice to have a prof so engaged in his work and share real time results with you.

As a non-EEB major who didn't take EEB211, this is definitely one of the best classes I've ever taken. Professor Pringle is incredible, engaging, and super interesting. The work and tests are manageable. If you have any interest at all in the subject, 100% take it.
Casual or serious interest in ecology, this is the perfect class.  Best I've taken at Princeton

Definitely take this course if you are EEB. If you are not, and are looking for an STN, or are interested generally in biodiversity and species interactions, this is a good course to take. The professor is awesome as are the lab TAs

Definitely take this course!!!!!!!! This course is incredible, well-taught, and a very interesting look into ecology. Go to every lecture because each one is so interesting, and it never gets boring. The labs are short and sweet, and the exams are reasonable. As an EEB major I absolutely loved it. One of my favorite classes of all time at Princeton.
Definitely take this course. Stay on top of readings, go to lectures. Pringle has a lot to offer
Do the reading when you are confused. Be engaged in the material.

Excellent course, the lectures are great and Pringle is a rock star. The readings are very interesting and relevant, and the guest lecturers are super cool.
Labs are ok, not overly time consuming. Tests are fair.
Great class with a great professor and TAs. Do the readings as much as possible. You can get by without some of them, but you'd be at a loss because they really solidify the lectures.

I took this because it fulfilled both an upper level lab and a ECO for EEB. Honestly, it was not the best time but at least I knocked both of those things out at the same time. Take it if you reaaaally need to. Also I do not understand why people continue to say that this is the "best class they've taken at princeton." I feel like that is a bit unfounded....

If you want to learn practical, real-world conservation strategies, take this class. Study concepts and seek to understand (rather than memorize) and be able to explain reasoning to your friends who aren't taking the class before exams. Labs were for the most part quite fun, and the short lab reports make you think. Lectures are really high quality overall; I wish there hadn't been anything due Dean's Date or for a take-home for this class, because then I would have gone out with so much of a higher opinion of it. The last lecture was *amazing*. It was absolutely incredible, and made me feel really bittersweet but really glad and grateful that I'd taken the class. Be careful taking this class if you have a lot of work due Dean's Date/take-home finals, however. Hopefully they'll make the project report and final paper more enjoyable this year than it was last year, but if not, commiserate with friends and reward yourself with some candy/hot chocolate once you're done. Good luck and hope you enjoy the course!

If you're on the fence - absolutely take the course! The Pringle's lectures were really interesting, the guest lectures will honestly stick with you, and the labs and TAs Matt and Arjun are incredible and super responsive
Interesting class, workload is fair, Pringle is awesome. Choose a partner you work well with for the final project and don't wait until the last minute to do it.
Not that amazing but take for your departmental

TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. The classic exams are very reasonable, the written final is amazing, you learn so much ecology but that isn't even the good part, you are inspired to make a difference in all aspects of the world after this course and are given the tools to do so

TAKE THIS CLASS! Without a doubt, Professor Pringle is a phenomenal lecturer and clearly cares about his students. He gave us hope in moments of despair, and encouraged us to take risks and think about the material in unique ways. After years of book-learning and memorizing facts without being too sure when I'd ever get the chance to apply them, I appreciated learning about challenges and triumphs in the field and actually having the opportunity to engage in fieldwork. Labs with Matt were great, and the research project and presentation served as a satisfying culmination of everything we learned. Oh...and before I forget, there were cupcakes on the last day of lecture, which might go down as one of the best lectures I have ever had here at Princeton, and certainly one I will not forget. The only thing I regret is not being more engaged in lecture because of the opportunities we're given to ask questions, but that might have been my learning style. If you're still uncertain about whether or not you should take this class, take a leap of faith and you will not regret it.
TAKE THIS especially if you like ecology but really everyone should enjoy it - a very good science class, you learn a lot and still have a good time
Take insanely detailed notes. There's no way to predict which minute details will be on the exam
Take it and have your mind blown.
Take it if you like being outside for labs! And if you like meeting really interesting people who saved whole ecosystems across the world.
Take it! Even if you're not in EEB.
Take it. Pringle is the best professor I'll have here
Take this class if you are at all interested in biology. My favorite class so far.
Take this class! You get more out of it than just a grade!
Take this course - by far most interesting at Princeton and Pringle is an incredibly engaging lecturer.

Take this course if you want to learn from a brilliant professor who genuinely cares about your learning and what he's teaching about. This was one of the best courses I've taken in my life, and if you even have a passing interest in the living world you owe it to yourself to give this class a shot.
Take this even if you're not interested in ecology. It's a great class that teaches you to think about the environment and conservation in a different way.

The exams are very straightforward. Study off of the study guide and you will be fine. Maybe you'll miss something here or there but overall, you will be more than prepared. And take advantage of talking to Pringle. He has such a fascinating life.
This class is amazing! definitely take it, Pringle is an amazing lecturer and always keeps class interesting. This is not a typical lab class, labs are more hands on and more qualitative.

This course is amazing! Even if you don't like ecology (which I didn't), you will love this course. Pringle is amazing! Labs are great! Go to lectures and keep up with the readings. You will get the most out of it and you will do well in the class!

This course is great and really adds to not only your science background but also larger education and decency as a human and later a working professional who can meaningfully contribute to the world. Labs are chill but frustrating because it feels like a waste of your time. Also, make sure your group project partners are not slackers because the project is so extended. Attend lecture every time and take notes on even the anecdotes you don't think are relevant. You will be a better person for having taken this course. Pringles rocks. Also he will put guest lecturers on the exams so pay attention during those even when they get a bit repetitive.
This course made me wish I was an EEB major. Professor Pringle is incredible and this course will change your life.

This is a great course! Even if you are not interested in the material, Professor Pringle is a great lecturer and the material is very engaging. He also cares a lot about the students and tries to make the course as enjoyable as possible.

This was an amazing class! It sits right at the nexus of environmental/social activism, a bit of anthropology, and ecology. He's a pretty inspiring professor and genuinely cares about his students as people and wants us to make a difference in this world. If you want to learn more about species interactions and where we as humans fit into the picture, I'd highly recommend this course.
go to lecture, and pay attention. exams are very fair if you do
great course

otherinfo: The details of the course may change, but the spirit and general content are as described.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Lab Reports - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%
assgts: Weekly reading will be assigned both as background for the lectures and as preparation for the laboratories. Laboratories (some of which will be conducted outdoors) will require students to collect and analyze ecological data, deliver oral presentations, and submit written reports; most of this work will be done in small groups.
prereqs: EEB 211 or equivalent is recommended..
descrip: How do wild organisms interact with each other, their physical environments, and human societies? Lectures will examine a series of fundamental topics in ecology--herbivory, predation, competition, mutualism, species invasions, biogeographic patterns, extinction, climate change, and conservation, among others--through the lens of case studies drawn from all over the world. Readings will provide background information necessary to contextualize these case studies and clarify the linkages between them. Laboratories and fieldwork will explore the process of translating observations and data into an understanding of how the natural world works.
title: Ecology: Species Interactions, Biodiversity and Society

grading: Class/Precept Participation - 100%
prereqs: EEB graduate students only..
descrip: Advanced discussions of ecology, evolution, and behavior focus on 50 fundamental papers. Ecological topics include dynamics and structure of populations, communities, ecosystems, and conservation biology. Behavioral topics include instinct and learning, social behavior, physiological ecology, and the evolution of behavior. Evolutionary topics include speciation, evolutionary and quantitative genetics, molecular evolution, evolutionary stable strategies, and evolution of development. (These are core courses)
title: Fundamental Concepts in Ecology, Evolution, and Behavior I

evals: I especially benefitted from hearing different perspectives and advice on how to read academic papers and keep up with the literature. Though papers for discussion sometimes felt distantly related to what I am specifically interested in, it was helpful to get comfortable discussing topics more broadly. I especially enjoyed the second half of the course in which students presented on papers they found particularly inspirational. Pay particular attention to keeping the conversation inclusive, and try to help everyone participate if possible.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 100%
prereqs: Course is limited to graduate students only..
descrip: Systematic reviews of recent literature in areas of ecology, evolution, and animal behavior. The general survey of literature is supplemented with detailed discussion of selected research papers of unusual importance and significance. (This is a core course.)
title: Recent Research in Population Biology

evals: A great way to get to know the EEB community, and engage with top-researchers across the field. The lunch-time discussions are a great opportunity, and free lunch is hard to argue with! I always enjoy this part of the week.
Maybe read related papers before attend the seminars.
otherinfo: With the instructor's permission, undergraduates are welcome to audit, but no credit is given for this course. Pre-Colloquia class 12:00-12:50 M.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 100%
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)
title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations

evals: Although the content of 245 may seem boring, it is clearly necessary for further material in CBE.
CBE 245 is a well-taught departmental that should be fine if you keep up with work.
Definitely do the readings! They help a lot with homework, quizzes, and the exams. Don't be afraid to ask questions during precept/email the preceptors; they're there to help!!

Do Degree-of-Freedom analyses! Always! But also, I highly recommend working on Psets throughout the week and reading sections of the textbook whenever you are stuck. While it may not seem worth it to go to precepts initially, they become lifesaving in the second half of the semester.

Do not base your decision on whether or not to continue with chemical engineering solely on this course. If you are interested in trying different kinds of engineering - would recommend a different course, only take if you have to for chemical engineering.
Dont take this unless you need it
Easy course material as long as you're good at using a calculator accurately. The material is not difficult or challenging, but get ready for some nitpicky grading...
I hope future CBE classes are more interesting. The book is very helpful and the examples help with the homework and quizzes. The preceptors are always responsive.
I think it is important to attend all lectures and read the book (and examples) as well.

If you want to be CBE, you have to take it. It's not the best course, and it's a fair amount of work. Definitely read the chapters because the examples help a lot with the psets. Also try to find a good pset group early on because the psets are so much better in a group.
Kind of slow and not the most interesting, so take it if you have to or you don't mind being bored.
Make sure that you stay on top of the reading!
Not a super difficult class, reading the textbook helps a ton and then just do lots of practice questions

Not as much chemistry and biology as you probably expect. Mostly tedious algebra. I don't know if anyone besides CBE majors take it, so for all CBE majors: it's not a bad course overall (I took it w/ professor Loo and she was a pretty good lecturer). Definitely a good course to determine whether you'll like CBE; I know a lot of people who decided to switch majors because this course was different from their expectations. Do the readings. Precepts aren't super important but go to them if you have time. Really the worst part is 8:30AM lecture and 7:30PM precept.
Probably don't take it unless you have to, i.e. if you're a CBE major. Or I guess if you're just really into process/industrial chem engineering.
Read the textbook before lectures and work through the book examples. The lectures aren't bad, but it can be hard to focus on a Monday morning at 8:30 in the morning.
Take this course only if you are truly sure that you want to do CBE.  It is a required, introductory course, so the material is not very interesting and the instructors seem rather detached.
The course material itself is not very stimulating. However, if you read the textbook and do problem, the material is not hard to master. It is not necessary to attend precepts.
The grading is not very fair sometimes and as an intro course, it is not a good representation of all the CBE department has to offer.

The overall quality of this course is fair. It is required for CBE, but I would not recommend it to other students. Although I wouldn't say this course was very good, it does teach you problem solving technique, which I suppose is the point. My best advice would be to find a good PSET group to work with.

The problem sets are graded extremely hard. Do not attend the precepts as they do not help. The exams are graded fairly. The textbook is helpful. If Nick Davy is teaching or precepting next year, seek him out.

This class is fairly straightforward and not too intense.  If you're taking this class, it's probably because you want to be a CBE major.  Just know that this class isn't anything like chemistry and I don't think that it's an accurate representation of what CBE actually is.
