That being said, it teaches you the fundamentals and has a fairly light workload, which is nice.

This class is not hard, but it is rather tedious and repetitive at times. It often felt like it was testing our algebra skills and patience more than anything else, since the whole class was basically saying input = output about increasingly convoluted systems. However, I would not let this discourage potential CBE majors; from what I've heard this class is just a necessary annoyance to get through before reaching more interesting CBE classes later on.
This course contains simple concepts with very complex applications. Precepts are not helpful. If you take this class, make sure to read the textbook - it's the most helpful thing to learn from.

This course is definitely challenging and time consuming, but worth it in my opinion. Don't let the prospect of it scare you away from CBE. Homework is usually only about four questions but can take 1-2 hours for each question, and is almost impossible to complete alone in my experience. I learned a lot in this class, and the homework was engaging.
This is heavily a course you have to do on your own. I attended all the lectures and I still felt like I learned the most on my own. Do as many practice problems as possible.

This is not the easiest course, but extremely informative and at the end, you really feel like you've learned a lot about the minute and tricky details of mass and energy balances in all kinds of different processes. Psets and exams are hard, but hey, it's an intro-engineering course.

This might sound a little harsh, but I would say that one of the only reasons that I was glad I took this class was because it helped me decide that I did not want to be a CBE major. If  I could do it over again I think I would make sure that I got to know my classmates a little bit more because they are going to be your main source of help on the psets, and I would create some sort of study group to work on the psets because when I did this I was much more successful than when I worked on them alone. I would also recommend reading the textbook religiously, because sometimes there are some very helpful equations and techniques in there that are not really covered in class. I think I would have done much better in this class if I was more proactive about getting help (because it was obvious from almost the beginning that I really struggled with the material).
WARNING: No chemistry involved!

We're almost always allowed either a cheat sheet or open notes in assessments, so it's not memorization-heavy. It's a lot more about strategy and problem-solving, so if you're that type of person you could enjoy this course. Homeworks were 3-6 problems, due once a week so a reasonable load.
take it if you have to
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Other Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: 20 - 40 pages reading per week. 8 - 10 problem sets a week on non-exam weeks. Students are encouraged to go over examples in text and workbooks individually prior to class.
prereqs: CHM 201.
descrip: Introduction to chemical engineering analysis and computations. Course starts with unit conversions and conventions for representing processes and process variables in engineering calculations. Continues with methods for generating flow sheets and analyzing mass balances both with and without chemical reactions. Rules associated with energy conservation and energy balance calculations in non-reacting and reacting systems are also covered. Ultimately, full process calculations, including chemical reactions with energy changes and multiphase systems are covered.
title: Introduction to Chemical and Biochemical Engineering Principles

evals: As far as CBE classes go, Transport is pretty good. That's not to say that it is not challenging, because a lot of the problems require a lot of math. Go to office hours!
Brynildsen is one of the best CBE lecturers I've had and while this course is really tough, it is totally manageable.
Certainly not easy, but this has been my favorite CBE core class so far. The professor clearly cares about the students and the material is interesting.

Come into Transport with an open mind; looking back, I feel like I've learned and accomplished a lot over the course of the semester. Stay calm, review lecture notes and problem sets, and you'll be good.

Course is a relatively good CBE class, not too hard. Nothing incredibly interesting, but definitely a more relaxed class. Would recommend working on the homework with others, as it is definitely a class where more eyes helps doing the problems.
Covered a lot in a short amount of time. problem sets were hard but satisfactory, if that makes sense. Not sure how i feel about having a take home exam.

Difficult and time-consuming, but you really walk out feeling like you've learned something. I enjoyed the material and the way it teaches me to think. Budget plenty of time for the psets to minimize stress and go to office hours.
Even though you probably have to take this course, it's going to be an interesting one if you engage in it!
I really hope Prof Brynildsen teaches you because he explains transport so well, and he is always willing to help.
If you like a challenging course and are interested in CBE, take this course! Quite a workload but you learn a lot
It is very difficult but well taught. If you spend the time to understand the material as you go, it will be a lot easier. The class is very cumulative and builds on stuff you learn.
Make sure to attend class, do the homework at office hours, and take practice exams
Most interesting CBE core class so far. You will wish you had two semesters to finish the course instead of one, but hey that's just Princeton for you. Try your best.

One of the best taught CBE core classes, really organized and Prof. Brynildsen gives great lectures. You may have heard that Prof. Brynildsen generates a random list of people to call on in class, but not to worry, Prof. Brynildsen will help walk you through the question. Just stay on top of doing problem sets (i.e. go to office hours) and you're good to go!
Only take this if your really want to be CBE.
PSETs take a long time, but the take-home exams are around the same difficulty. Make sure to go to office hours if you get stuck.
Pretty math heavy CBE class. Office hours are helpful to solving the questions.

Prof Brynildsen lectures at a very fast pace but he does so off his lecture notes so to avoid falling behind, make sure to read the lecture notes before lecture. I know everyone says to do this for all classes, but I really wish I would've done that more because then I wouldn't have to play catch up as much right before problem sets are due/right before exams. Definitely come in for office hours too. Chou is super approachable and helpful!
Read the lecture notes before and after the lecture (if possible). Go through the derivations slowly to make sure you understand them.
Requied course for CBEs. Quite a difficult course by nature. Go to office hours for the homework. Study hard for exams and stay organized.
Spend time at office hours, work with friends in your class, just make sure you understand concepts as you.re learning them-- don't wait until the exams to realize you're lost.

This class is by far by best CBE class so far (took 245, 246, 250 in freshman and sophomore year). Prof Brynildsen is great and just stay on top of the material. Also, make sure you take the psets seriously as the exams closely follow these. More importantly, make sure you understand you MAE 305 very well as the class is pretty much differential equations applied to solve transport problems (that's it!)...it is easier than thermo but more interesting.

This has been my favorite CBE core class so far. Precepts were ridiculously helpful and for some reason nobody ever went to them after the first month. Find a solid pset group, be generous in office hours (that pset karma comes around, yo), and try to read the lecture notes before class sometimes. At this point it's really too late to back out of CBE anyway, so have fun.

Transport is a very interesting class. Keep up with the material. When Professor Brynildsen says read the lecture notes beforehand, he means it. A lot of the material is logical/rational once you learn it but there is quite a bit to learn and it can get overwhelming if you try to do that 3 days before an exam, so keep up with the class. You will also enjoy/engage with the material more this way. Professor Brynildsen really cares about the students and our TA was amazing too. They made this class great.
Typical CBE course. You know what to expect at this point.

You gotta take it. Keep up with reading lecture notes and read them before class - makes things way easier to understand. Psets are helpful and do the practice midterms he puts out before each midterm. He cold calls in class - so have fun with that (it's not as bad after the first couple weeks). MPB seems really serious and intimidating at first, but really he's a nice guy that invests a lot into your learning. And if Chou is still precepting - TAKE HIS PRECEPT! Also, you must end all your interactions with Chou with "Ciao Chou!" because it makes me giggle every time and he's nice enough to tolerate it
You have to take it, but it's a decently interesting class and though the material is hard, you're prepared pretty fairly through psets and past exams.
You're here because you have to be. Just make sure to go to class and take notes because the stuff he does in class isn't online. Also make sure to go to office hours for homework help.
hard CBE core course, but youll survive
make sure to keep up with the readings and handouts before you go to lecture
otherinfo: An additional class section to be held each week.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Textbook readings and lecture notes. Handouts to supplement classroom lectures.
prereqs: CBE 245, CBE 246, and MAE 305. MAE 305 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Course will survey modeling and solution methods for the transport of fluids, heat and chemical species in response to differences in pressure, temperature and concentration. Both steady state and transient behavior will be examined.Topics include fluid statics; conservation equations for mass, momentum and energy; dimensional analysis; viscous flow at high and low Reynolds number; thermal conduction; convective heat and mass transfer, correlations; diffusion and interphase mass transfer. Working knowledge of calculus, linear algebra, and ordinary differential equations is assumed.
title: Mass, Momentum, and Energy Transport

otherinfo: Limited to a few qualified departmental students.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Student is expected to put in at least 15-20 hours per week on the project, and meet regularly with the project adviser. A final paper of about 20 pages will be due on dean's date. In addition, students will be expected to prepare a 20 minute presentation which will be presented to faculty and peers during reading period.
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, and an oral presentation will be required. Students generally spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.
title: Junior Independent Work

evals: Design project was actually okay. Other than that, this is worst class in every other way possible. Within the span of a week during reading period/finals (while you have other finals and papers to do): PSET due, Poster Presentation, Final Report (on average 30  pages), and 48 hour take home final (worst thing I have ever experienced). No one deserves this kind of treatment.
Don't take this with Yannis. Hopefully they get another professor who is willing to put more time into the course.
Drop CBE
Hopefully you will not have Yannis, but if you do. it will be terrible. The project is interesting and challenging but the material learned in class will have little to no connection.

I can say without hesitation that (largely because of the professor) this is the worst course that I have taken at Princeton. This is the course that is supposed to be the capstone of the CBE core curriculum, but the lack of caring on the part of the professor made it feel like we were being abandoned rather than celebrated for what we have learned in the department. I hope the university can find a better professor than Professor Kevrekidis to teach this course in the future, because most people would have to try in order to do a worse job of it than him. He did not put any effort into the course, refusing to plan out the semester, give effective lectures, stick to his earlier promises about homework and exam dates, or teach us the material that we are expected to know by the end of this course. To the CBE Class of 2018 and beyond, I hope that none of you ever have to suffer through Design in the same way we did. The only way to avoid it is to make sure that Professor Kevrekidis does not teach this course in the future, because I doubt it would get any better next year or in the future.
I hope they figure out this course before you have to take it. Sadly, you do need to take it.

If this class is still being taught by Yannis, protest now while you still can. He does not care one bit for this class, did not bother to teach any part of it (literally missed several weeks of class as well as all of my group's out of class presentations), and made a ridiculously long final exam (which was announced a week before classes ended). This class was a total disaster and a waste of time.

If you have Yannis, don't take it unless you absolutely have to. 
Morris is an absolute champ though, and will soon be teaching the course on his own which is wonderful. The design aspect of the course is quite interesting, but the rest is extraordinarily abysmal.

If you're on this website, it's because you're a rising senior CBE in which case you're required to take this. So good luck. The project is a significant amount of work but you get useful instructions on it and you get the help of Morris (who is fantastic) and the TAs, and I actually learned about Aspen and about design on the project. The rest of the course is a complete shitshow. Lectures are completely useless, and we only had two homeworks, one of which was on econ and the other of which was just a repeat of our seps midterm, number for number. We weren't told until December that there would be a final exam at all, and I still don't know what's going to be on it since we haven't had a homework assignment since September or learned anything at all all year. So I don't know what advice to give you except to hope that it's been re-organized,
Not when Professor. Kevrekidis is teaching it.
Start on the design project early and show up to precepts.
Start the design project early, try to engage as much as you can with the material, this is the last required CBE class!

Terrible. Good luck. Have fun. Pray that it isn't YGK teaching. Maybe Morris might give you a better class. Would be kinda like reactors   core lab combined into one, and actually not that bad, but YGk was just that bad. Make sure you have a full team of 4, with students who can read textbooks well, click on stuff randomly on Aspen and well, and be able to actually do chemical engineering.
Terrible. You have to take this class anyway, but if Yannis somehow manages to teach this class again, consider dropping out.

The worst class I have taken at Princeton. The professor actively hated teaching this class and did not care at all about what we were learning. Massively disorganized. Morris, the ex-industry instructor they pulled in to help lead the project, was the only saving grace of this class. Thank you Morris. I hope that CBE finds a different professor to teach this class because the course was basically useless this year and I feel like our chemE peers at other schools will graduate knowing way more than we do.

This class is basically awful and hopefully it will improve next year since I know that the instructors are talking about how to make it less awful than it was this year. You have to take this course so it is what it is. Don't take it too seriously or you will be even more miserable. Read the book so you actually learn something. Pay attention to the key concepts of the course, which are economic stuff, separation design, heat integration, and optimization (and Aspen and the project) and recognize that everything else is not really that important. Good luck.

This course varies wildly in difficulty and value depending on the instructor.  I personally find the material very interesting.  A good attitude and a drive to learn will make it worth while for you.

This is easily the worst class I've taken at Princeton, and that's including some real gems such as PHY 104 and COS 402. It's oddly fitting that this class is our CBE capstone course, as it was disorganized, uninspiring, tedious, and all things considered, a general waste of a Princeton education. This class made me feel like I haven't learned anything at all from CBE over the past four years. Professor Kevrekidis is a funny guy and generally means well, but it?s amazing how little he cared about this class, which he communicated to us several times in ?joking? fashion at the beginning of the semester. Lectures: Lectures were highly uninspiring. Professor Kevrekidis did not give a good number of lectures, opting for Dr. Morris or industry lecturers instead, and when he did, he was very difficult to follow. Part of this was because it was very difficult to understand why any of the things that were being taught mattered regarding the course objectives. The learning goals were never communicated to us, so the lectures ended up feeling like a random mix of irrelevant topics, which was very disheartening. I don't think I learned, or at least, retained anything at all from the lectures, despite attending a majority of them. Design Project: The main assignment in this class was a capstone design project using Aspen. The problems with and painfulness of this project (buggy software, outdated tutorials, unclear instructions, programs crashing and work lost, many nights spent in the Design Lab, etc.) are well-documented in past course reviews. What made our project uniquely bad was how many times design specifications were changed over the course of the semester. Just about every week, we would receive an email telling us to change something about reaction kinetics, feed flow rates, acid volumes, and so on that would cause fundamental changes to our process design. Furthermore, the deliverables timeline for this project was very unclear, and when finally released, not strictly followed. Finally, were never given instructions about what to include in our poster or final report beyond an outline of one of the TA's undergraduate design projects, so we ended up winging it and imitating the design projects hanging on the walls. Problem Sets: We were supposed to have five problem sets in this class, but we ended up having only three. The first two were an econ problem set and literally one of our past midterms (from CBE 250), which was absurd to begin with, though at least these were assigned at a normal time at the beginning of the semester. From here on out, we never received a problem set again until the last week of class, which consisted of a random set of HEN and optimization questions that we were expected to do over Winter Break because apparently that would be less painful than doing it during a school week. Solutions to the three problem sets were not posted on BlackBoard until the beginning of finals week. Exams: We were supposed to have a single midterm exam, which was then pushed to December before Winter Break, which then became an in-class final, but of course, one cannot simply schedule an in-class final with the Registrar in December, so it became a 48-hour take-home exam, which then became a 72-hour take-home exam, which was ultimately due after the take-home exam deadline. During this entire ordeal, we were never given clear instructions regarding when the exam would be held, if at all; in fact, towards the end of the semester, many of us believed that the exam would simply not happen at all, given that it was already December and no notice was given, and we had not had a problem set in months, so it was entirely unclear what we would be tested on. Of course, in the last week of class, it was announced that we would have a final exam in January. Even then, we did not learn what would be on the exam until a Review  ... [more]

Well CBE majors don't really have a choice, but your life will most certainly be improved if Kevrekidis does not teach this course. Don't expect to learn anything from lectures and don't expect anything to be on time or organized (even with constant reminders and requests to set dates or post homeworks). The preceptors and Dr Smith are great and make the project interesting and enjoyable. But Kevrekidis has no idea what is going on with the project, and that is not really his fault but at the same time he didn't seem at all invested in teaching us what he was mean to, he didn't even finish going over the material he was meant to 'teach' us. As a disclaimer, I have enjoyed all the other CBE courses I have taken, this has been the one exception and what could have been a really interesting synthesis of material and a capstone project was in the end a disappointing experience and a wasted course.
Well you know what you're getting into.
Well, if you're taking this it's because you have to
You are only taking this because you are a senior CBE. Start the project early, ask the preceptors for help. Class is useless.
You have to take this course.  This year, it was very easy because Prof. Kevrekedis did not really care and it was taught poorly.  However, I think things will be different next year.
your experience is mostly determined by your group, teachers sucked
otherinfo: This is the capstone course in the chemical engineering curriculum, offered every fall for seniors in the department.
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Design Project - 50%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Outside work load approximately six hours per week over the whole term, mostly concerned with problem solving. In addition, a major design project, addressed by teams of 3-4 students, runs throughout the semester.
prereqs: CBE 341 and CBE 441..
descrip: Introduction to chemical process design; objectives, conceptualization, and economics. We'll discuss preliminary design (from block flows to PFDs) to detailed process definition, with P&ID's, safety, health, and environmental issues addressed. The course covers costing equipment to overall plant cost estimates. We'll evaluate project costs, and trade-off decisions between upfront investment, and annual operating expenditures. Optimization techniques to improve energy efficiency, conversion, selectivity, and yield, and the cost effects will be covered. A major design project will allow students to apply their skills to a complex process.
title: Design, Synthesis, and Optimization of Chemical Processes

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: See advisor for reading/writing assignments.
descrip: A one semester study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written report required.
title: Senior Independent Work

evals: Be prepared to start really slow and then all of a sudden hit new material and fly through it. Search for other materials because everything that is given is not helpful.

Don't take it if you don't have to. You would probably learn more if you sat in on an undergrad course of Mathematical Methods. If you do choose to take it, heavy outside reading is required to decipher notation and to understand unexplained jumps in reasoning and intuition.

If you have the option, you'd be better off taking a dedicated PDEs course instead. To those who have this as a requirement, try to use outside source material to teach yourself the methods, as the textbook is confusing and incomplete.
It builds a strong foundation on wide range of fundamental topics on Linear Algebra. Its really helpful.
Listen in lecture and ask questions when you are unclear on something. Not asking questions on small misunderstandings just caused more confusion.

Many topics are covered in this course. Lectures focus on providing an introduction to the different methods while often some details about the application may be glossed over. It is highly recommended to review your notes while reviewing the relevant sections of the textbook on a weekly basis to ensure a thorough understanding of the material.
Midterms will be easy, but finals gonna be really difficult
Read the class notes after or during class. They help a lot!
Read.
Review undergraduate linear algebra and differential equation notes.

This course becomes more enjoyable when you realize how all of the topics presented are connected. Try looking for those connections early and think about how you can apply the math you're learning to your research!
This course is required
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Solutions of ordinary differential, partial differential and finite difference equations with emphasis on second order linear partial differential equations and their applications. Topics include special functions, eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, Sturm-Liouville analysis, Green's functions, explicit and implicit finite difference methods, stability analysis, transform methods, asymptotic analysis.
title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II

evals: Don't get discouraged by the exams. Just do your best!
It is a good course to understand thermodynamics and its essentials, however if you look for depth, then this course may not be able to provide you with it. Outside reading will help.
It is very helpful to pre-read lecture notes before class.
Read Shell's book after class and annotate your notes to ensure full understanding of the material presented in each lecture.
Read the Scott Shell book if you have any questions. Go to class.
Read the book to help understand concepts and start homework early.
Read the textbook.
Stay on top of the reading!
You have to take it if you're CBE.  Would recommend to anyone outside the department who is interested in stat mech and thermo topics.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: This course provides an integrated graduate-level introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. Topics covered include: fundamental equations; Legendre transformations; equilibrium, stability, and response of multicomponent systems, including gases, solutions, and solids; statistical ensembles; phase transitions; fluctuations; correlation functions; structure of classical fluids; and computer simulation methods. Applications of these ideas include polymer elasticity and phase separation, electrolyte solutions, colloidal suspensions, ligand binding to proteins, protein folding, nucleation and growth, and surface adsorption.
title: Advanced Thermodynamics

evals: Attend all lectures and ensure you are fully attentive during class, you do not want to miss anything!
Attend all lectures, listen in class, and read the provided course material carefully when working on problem sets.
Don't schedule a class directly after this one--make sure to leave 45 minutes in between!
Even for non-CBEers, this course can be really useful for applying mathematical tools or better understanding random processes in chemical reactions.
The lectures are usually interesting, and the students can learn a lot, but the poor quality of the course notes makes the class more difficult than it should be.
This course is required, so yeah, future students should probably take it.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Stoichiometry. Reaction kinetics and mechanisms. Types of chemical reactors. Steady-state and dynamic behavior of reactors. Mixing and non-ideal reactors. Porous catalysts. Stability and multiplicity. Multiphase reactors.
title: Chemical Reactor Engineering

evals: Be expected to put in a lot of hours for the weekly assignments.

Be prepared to commit a great deal of time to the assignments. Ideally you would be able to carve out substantial blocks of time a few days ahead of the due dates each week, rather than pulling all-nighters (would not recommend). Also, don't be afraid to speak up in lecture to ask a question, no matter how inane it may seem to you. Dr. Dobkin is very receptive to any and all queries and will not make you feel inept if you don't understand something.
Definitely take this course. Be prepared for a good chunk of work each week, but you will learn new things and basic skills which are very important today.
Fine distribution requirement, although expect a fair amount of work. You'll learn things.
It's a good survey course on computers, and will probably help you understand the devices that you use on a regular basis.

It's an easy course and if you put in a bit of effort you can get a lot out of it, things that are really fascinating and relevant!  It'll be really dry and hard to follow if you completely slack off.
Learn java before taking the course.

Not a bad course, but not particularly great either. Weekly labs and psets are relatively easy (if time-consuming) but the midterm was harder because of limited time. Grading isn't too harsh: If you put in the work, you'll get above a B .
Not as easy as it looks, but if you keep up with the assignments and labs you will be fine.
Reasonable for a QR, although the labs will take up more of your time than you expect and can be frustrating. Start early.
Take it!

Take this class if you need a QR, are not a STEM person, and want to gain a basic foundation of knowledge about computers. The work usually isn't too difficult, but it can be time consuming. Also, it would have been nice to know someone in the class to work with on problem sets and labs.
There must be much less painful and much more fair ways to fulfill the QR requirement. Do not take this course unless there are no other options.
This course is good for fulfilling a QR, but more difficult than you would expect, so be prepared to put the time in on the assignments.

This course is the perfect QR requirement, and the content is useful and practical. I would recommend that anyone who takes this course start the labs and problem sets well in advance to prevent last-minute stress.

This is a good course for completing the QR requirement, especially because it teaches both the history of computing as well as practical skills. Give yourself time for the problem sets and labs -- start early, it will be a lot better for you in the long run.
Very easy if you do the work, but a surprising amount of labs and problem sets due over the course of the semester.
lots of time consuming homework
this is a good QR for those of us who are not math-oriented
otherinfo: This course is meant for humanities and social sciences students who want to understand how the technology works and how it affects the world they live in. No prior experience with computers is assumed. 8 self-scheduled lab exercises. If class is full, email instructor to be placed on waiting list.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Midterm exam, final exam, lab reports, and problem sets.
prereqs: Not intended for science/engineering/mathematics students. May not be taken for credit after COS 126 or higher..
descrip: Computers are all around us. How does this affect the world we live in? This course is a broad introduction to computing technology for humanities and social sciences students. Topics will be drawn from current issues and events, and will include discussion of how computers work; what programming is and why it is hard; how the Internet and the Web work; security and privacy.
title: Computers in Our World

evals: A breeze if you have programming/computer science experience. Only go to class meetings if you need to (review sessions, stuck on beginning a project), but go to as many precepts as possible (not required but still go). The lecture videos are slow and tough to get through, but necessary if you have no experience. It's entirely possible to make it through the course without watching any of the lectures.
A great class, but definitely be cognizant of the significant time commitment each week.

A lot of time spent on problem sets, and not a lot of time enjoying them. Go to office hours, go to lab tas, go to friends in 226, but just get through the class. You may not enjoy it by the end because up to 10 hour coding assignments each week might deter you from COS in general, as it did me. Also, don't let the first two weeks fool you, the first assignment is one line of code whereas your final will be around 400.
A lot of work, but immensely rewarding.

Absolutely take this course. The skill set that you obtain from Cos 126 is indispensable. I have learned so much from this course and it is the reason I have decided to pursue the COS certificate. Precepts are crucial and keeping up with the readings/lecture videos will determine how much time you will spend on the assignments.

Absolutely worth taking, even for those not interested in the STEM field. Can be difficult for inexperienced programmers, but this class tends to encourage a way of going about problem solving that can't easily be obtained elsewhere.
Always make sure you ask for help. Don't wait too long asking for help after trying a problem on your own. Try working on a practice program with a friend to understand how to code.

As someone who never took a computer science class, the course is challenging, but there is plenty of resources to do well in the course: Lab TAs, appointments with professors, and piazza. You will feel satisfied after every assignment is sent.

As someone who took CS (but not APCS) in high school, this was still a really fun course to take (although I had to anyway).  Meetings and precept are very attendance-optional, which is great for schedule flexibility, and the coding assignments are super interesting.  Just don't get too behind on the theory lectures towards the end of the year, or studying for the 2nd written exam will be unnecessarily tedious.

Be prepared to teach yourself the material as all lectures are online videos. Weekly assignments are good in ensuring the material is understood. Make sure you study a lot for the exams as this class is not curved.

Before this class, I honestly had a legitimate fear of computers.  I didn't think I would have any interest in them, either.  This class completely changed my way of thinking.  Learning to program was not easy, but it was certainly rewarding, and the theory was quite interesting too.  We live in a computer age, and I feel more confident knowing at least a little about how to program, and about theory.

COS 126 is a fantastic, interesting class that teaches you to code in java from no experience to a point where you can solve complex problems like TSP or estimate avogadros number.
Would highly recommend.
Came into this course with zero coding experience and loved it. Strongly recommend.

Challenging for one who is seeing COS for the first time. No curve so keep up with lectures and precept in order to do well on exams. Written exams harder than programming exams. Study in advance -- many past exams available.

Coding was very enjoyable for me. It felt like solving puzzles, but didn't require too much quantitative reasoning. If you take it, keep up with all the readings and especially theory because it's easy to get behind. The assignments take a long time, so be prepared to start assignments early.
Commit time to the course, it is frustrating through the steep learning curve but you can certainly learn if you dedicate yourself to it
Course is very interesting, but prepare for a significant amount of work.

DON'T be swayed by the positive reviews. While you will probably get a B in the course, that is about the limit for most people.  The problem sets are fair and can be completed in a reasonable amount of time, but the lectures are terribly vague and dull, and the written exam (which is worth 40%) is complete bogus. Even though you are allowed to bring a cheat sheet (front and back) to the exam, the average and median scores were both WELL Below failing. To make things worse, nothing in the course is curved, so everyone fails together, and the students who put in a lot of time just to get that failing grade fail as well.
So, since I probably wont convince you to not take this course if you don't have to, just use this as a warning when you spend days studying and preparing for the exam: Your hard work to get a high grade on this course will most likely not be rewarded. I sincerely hope this course changes direction soon, since the current set up is ridiculous.
Definitely a worthwhile course but a lot of work, especially for beginners. Read the book and use precept efficiently. Donna Gabai is a great novice preceptor.
Definitely take this class to see if you like it! I came in with no prior coding experience, and I may be a COS major as a result!
Definitely take this course if you have any inclination to take it! I hadn't coded before and I really liked it, I learned a lot and it was definitely doable without having any prior experience.

Definitely take this course! It's incredibly well-taught and well-structured and I can't think of a better way to teach this material. Both the assignments and lectures are extremely interesting and introduce you to a lot of thought-provoking concepts both within and outside of computer science. The course is quite well-supported.
The usefulness of precepts will depend on your preceptor--if the precepts don't help you, don't go. Start the assignments early because you never know quite how long they will take you. Do the old exams in preparation for your exams. If you have APCS background, the class will be a lot easier for you. If you are unsure about taking the class, I recommend checking out the website (google cos 126). But I would definitely recommend taking it.
Definitely take this course.  It offers a very good introduction to COS.
Definitely take this regardless of whether you've programmed or not. Obviously if you know Java this will be much easier, but either way you will learn something new.
Don't need to buy a textbook

Don't underestimate the written exams.
Do assignments early so you can ask questions about them in precept or at office hours.

Even though this course is probably a requirement for many students, it's very clear that a lot of work went into this course, and it's very engaging and even fun at times as a result of that. Dan is the best preceptor!

Every student at Princeton should take this course. In general, very fun, engaging intro to programming, though exams are tough (be wary of written especially), grading is harsh, and assignments may take long. This is overall very rewarding and quite well-taught.
Every student should take this course before they graduate.
Expect to have to set aside around seven hours to do the assignments each week, get a head start on each assignment as well.
Fantastic course. Highly recommend
Focus efforts on written exams-- they're very different from past assignments.

For freshmen:
I took this course because I was told everybody takes this course, even people with strong CS backgrounds from high school. So I took it, and it was insanely easy. I never went to a single precept/lecture after the first week, and just did the assignments and exams. I wish I had pushed more to be placed into a higher level class. So the advice I would give is that if you consider yourself anything above an intermediate level programmer, try and see if it it might be too easy; go to the course page from last semester or something (literally search 126 and its one of the first results) and look at the assignments. If they seem way too easy, TRY AND PLACE OUT. Don't make my mistake. Unless all you want is an easy A, in which case, don't I guess.

A lot of my friends who were beginners to programming had trouble in this course, which is understandable given the pace it moves at. If you're in that situation, find yourself a good study group / partner to work on assignments with. Don't share code or anything but I've seen first hand that it is very helpful to have your peers helping you out.

Overall I recommend it but if you think it might be too easy, seriously consider placing into higher classes.
GO TO LAB TAS
Go to precept!
Go to precept, especially if you don't know how to code. It's good because the preceptor can answer questions that you have about the video lecture. Also, utilize lab TAs for help.
Go to the meetings and precepts before written exams for sure.

Great course even for students with zero programming experience, the assignments are always interesting (like creating a guitar that you can actually play with your keyboard), A LOT OF help and support available. both the reading and the class meetings are totally unnecessary, but make sure you watch all the lectures and go to office hours
Great course to take, keep up with readings and lecture videos.

Great course! I get what I put into, and as a humanities student this course is so well-designed  to pique your interest. I almost hope I had more time to do the extra work. Donna's great and will definitely take with her again. I recommend really read the book and watch the videos. If you consider taking the course, go over the material to get a head start - fro saving your time in the semester. It goes fast and it's crucial not to fall behind.
Great course. Assignments are really interesting and fun. Getting a good preceptor is key. Marc Leef was great if you can get him as your preceptor.
Great introduction to Computer Science! If you watch the lecture videos, there's really no point in getting the book.
Highly reccommend for those who have even the slightest interest in computer science.

I feel like everyone should take this course at some point. If you have some interest or no interest at all, the ways that 126 makes you think and operate are incredibly useful and (usually) fairly interesting. Would recommend 100%.

I highly recommend taking this course as it is an excellent introduction to computer science. The assignments are challenging but fun and engaging, and there is always a lot of help available if you are stuck on one of them.
I really enjoyed this course but it was pretty difficult for me
I really recommend this course

I think everyone should have to take this course. As a complete novice in all things computer science, this was indeed a difficult course. However, if I had kept up with the work and readings and sought help when I needed it, I think the course would've been a bit more successful. GET INTO DONNA'S PRECEPT! (I should've listened to previous course evals)

I took it for the general exposure, not for a requirement.  It is a new way of thinking but took up a huge amount of time, which I resented during the semester.  It's supposedly a good experience to have moving forward though.

I would definitely recommend taking this course. Going to precepts/class meetings isn't really necessary unless you feel like you need to catch up. The material is interesting, and the assignments are pretty fun to work through.

I would highly recommend this course for anyone.  I came in with NO programming experience and learned a ton.  They do cover a lot of material, so it's important to keep up.  Definitely take advantage of office hours and Lab TA's.  Study for the exams (especially the written exams which are hard af) and start your assignments early.

I would highly suggest taking this course if you are interested in pursuing any career or major in science. Furthermore, computing is becoming more and more necessary for so many careers and internships. The more programming languages you can learn, the more prepared you are for the world. It is also very well run and taught.
I would recommend that you do the readings.  While the video lectures are great, the readings really go into detail about the content and help with the written exams.

I would take this course in a semester with a bit of a lighter courseload, as it can get incredibly time consuming. If I could redo it, I would have taken it in a 4 class semester instead of 5 to maximize my time studying, watching lectures, and attending precepts and meetings. Definitely got a lot out of the course though!

If you already have a Computer Science background, then this course may be worthwhile. If you need help, try everything (Piazza, office hours, tutor, lab TA, etc.) until something clicks for you. If you absolutely have to take this class (ex. BSE requirement) then try your best at it.

If you already know the basics of programming, try to skip this class and take 226 or another class. If you have some programming experience, you can learn the stuff that you don't know by watching the video lectures online (don't need to take the class). Overall, pretty good intro course, not too hard to get 100% on nearly all the assignments, but the written exams are very hard.

If you any interest in CS, take it! It is a fun but a challenging especially if you are a novice programmer like me. Make sure to watch video lectures in a setting that forces you to pay attention (aka NOT your bed). Also, make sure to use all the available help for this course when you need it.
If you are a novice, make use of the office hours to go over concepts
If you are confused about the material, go to precept. If you are confused about the assignment, go to the lab TAs.

If you do not have any experience with java or programming in general, take this course. It is a great introduction. 

If you already know java or have significant experience programming, stay away and go straight to 226/217. You will be bored, you will end up slacking because the programming assignments/exams will be extremely easy, and you will be screwed by the written exams.

If you don't understand something, ask. Sometimes difficult problems are introduced that you don't really need to understand, and it's okay to not understand them. But you need to understand the basics for the assignments and exams.
If you have any interest in coding, take it. Unless you really struggle with the assignments, don't bother going to lecture.

If you have not had experience with cos before and/or do not have a natural talent for this kind of mindset (think math/science), it will be HARD for you. If you are a social sciences/humanities oriented person, be prepared to PDF if need be. I think it's a good PDF in that you can learn a lot and because of how heavily homework is weighted, you can pass the class. But it's not a good PDF in that you still have to do a lot of work regardless, and if you fall behind on homework you can easily get a D in the class. That being said, computer science is good to have a background in, and some people end up loving it/majoring in it, but just be careful!

If you have some experience with coding, this course will be challenging but manageable. Just be sure to start the assignments relatively early and ask for help when you need it! Sometimes just going to lab TAs is so much more effective than debugging by yourself hours on end and getting nowhere. Make sure to keep up with the video lectures, because it's easy to fall behind. The resources offered for this course are amazing, and the instructors and preceptors are willing to offer as much help as you need.
If you use the resources and are willing to put in the time, you could gain a tremendous amount from this course. Even if you can't give it your all, this course could be fascinating and fun to PDF.

If you're at all interested in programming or computers (which you should be!), then don't be scared off by the name or rigor of this course. It will take up a fair amount of your time, even as a PDF, but I (a humanities major doing my QR requirement) learned so much in a relatively short period. I'm not an expert, but at the end of the course I do feel comfortable writing some simple programs in Java without help (although, as you'll learn, even simple programs can do really complex and interesting things!). If you've never programmed before, definitely try out a novice precept, but if you think you can handle it, then don't be afraid to switch out.
If you're average or better at QR, you shouldn't have a problem with this course. It's very interesting and fun - recommend!

If you're taking this because you're BSE and you have to, you're probably comfortable with solving problems logically and should catch on quickly even if you have no direct programming experience. Just keep up with the lectures and go to precept. If you're a math-adverse person looking for a QR, the course is still doable, interesting, and relevant (given the ubiquity of computers in the modern world), but expect to put in a lot of effort, especially at the beginning. It might not be a good fifth class if you already have a busy schedule.

If you've never programmed, don't take it unless you're willing to put in the effort. It is really challenging but you will be able to understand it if you really do the work and go to office hours and lab TAs. Definitely get Donna as a preceptor but be aware that she can get pretty passive aggressive now and then.
It is a good course. Most enjoyable distribution so far.

It is an alright course to take but the assignments do take time especially if you start them late and get stuck. Ta hours fill up quick around hard assignments. Plus the exams are hard and tricky. They throw so many plot twists in the exams. Finally, precept grading is arbitrarily because some preceptors down grade.
It takes a lot of time (especially as someone with no coding experience), but the course is a great overview of computer science and I really enjoyed it.
It takes a lot of time, but its a good skill to have
It's COS 126. Take it
It's COS126. Take it and die if you must, but sooo necessary.
It's exactly what it says: and intro to cos. Take it, it's p useful.

It's hard. Every week often necessitates a good 5-6 hour block (sometimes more, sometimes less) set aside just to get everything done. But the material is great, and once you start getting the hang of it, it might even be enjoyable.
It's not easy, but take it.  Written exams are hard, so study with lots of practice tests.  Lots of fun and very rewarding.  Get Ibrahim as your preceptor!
It's tough but worthwhile

Just make sure to keep up with video lectures at the very least. I started to fall behind with these towards the end, which made studying for written exams more difficult. The written exams are very hard compared to the rest of the course. Make sure to review video lectures and readings, and get extra help if needed. Practice tests are good for seeing what you don't know, but honestly, I found them to be unhelpful in terms of studying (I did several practice tests before both written exams and did poorly on both).

Mainly just go to precepts especially if you have a good preceptor as that is where you do most of the learning, the video lectures and "class meetings" are not very helpful. The assignments are all very manageable, especially in the first half so save late days for the later ones.
Make sure to keep up with the material because it moves past. But this is definitely a class that I would recommend to take.
Make sure to start assignments before the day they are due!
Manageable, but the exams will get you. Study for tests, and have fun on the programming assignments

No matter what you are thinking about studying, if you have time and are even remotely interested, take this class.  It will open up your eyes to a huge array of applications of computing and give you a really solid understanding of computing and even an introduction to the hardware of a computer.  The assignments are fair, and there are endless resources for getting them done well and in a reasonable amount of time.  Not super strenuous but very rewarding.
Not bad! Take the class.

One of the most well-organized and structured courses you will ever take. Hard at times but there is so much help and all the assignments are super interesting and fun to do. I worked on my COS assignments as a break from other work
Only take if you enjoy coding this class is not joke.
Plan in a lot of time for the assignments, but you will definitely be glad that you took it.
Practice
Prepare to spend some time doing the assignments and preparing for exams, the course is not easy. Wayne is an excellent lecturer!
Prepare well for the written exams, they can be more challenging than expected.
Put in the time and effort and the results are incredibly satisfying.

READ THE BOOK and GO TO PRECEPT. It is actually very helpful. You could probably get away without watching the lecture videos but do the other things. Great course! Would highly recommend! I chose to be a COS major after taking this course.
Really fun class, learn a ton, no need for prior programming experience!!
Really great class! Take if you have the slightest interest in COS!

Really great course but takes a lot of work and gives a false impression that your whole semester will be structured around it. Don't get fooled by the incredible things you can do with the tools this course provides. There are other things that you will be required to do in your other courses. Don't let this course be the only thing you focus on since it is considerably hard to get good grades in it.
Really hard and a lot of work, take only if pdf-ing. It helps if you know how to code ahead of time, if you don't you are thrown into the deep end very quickly.

Recommended if you want to learn about computer science. If you understand Java/coding already (or think you have a good gasp of it), you don't have to attend class/precept. But I definitely recommend going in the last quarter of the semester, when they start going over computer science theory. A heavy part of the final written exam, so it's not all just programming.
STUDY YOU'RE ASS OFF FOR THE WRITTING EXAM.

Schedule your time wisely. This course description isn't joking when it says that this will be a difficult class with a lot of engagement required. Make sure you understand each of the video lectures, attend precepts, go to classes with Tips and Tricks, and allocate enough time for each assignment.
Solid course. You will learn to code and there are boundless resources to get help if you are stuck. It is time consuming. No curve so you get what you work for.

Some may disagree, but I believe everyone at Princeton should take this course. It is already a BSE requirement but it can really add to the marketable skills of any AB student. You learn a lot about coding essentials through Java as well as how computers work in general. Assignments are relevant, interesting, and rewarding. I highly recommend Dan Leyzberg as a preceptor and encourage students to attend Lewis Lab TAs for help.
Somehow do well on the written exams, they are worth a lot and have very low averages.
Start assignment as far out as you can, and stay up to date with the lecture videos. If you follow the guidelines of the course it will be an informative experience.
Start early and start often.
Start the assignments early! And start studying for the written exams early
Start your programs early and study hard for the written exams.
Stay on top of assignments and readings. Do not fall behind in concepts, everything builds off previous concepts.
Stay on top of the lectures, go to precept, and go to Lab TAs
Study a lot for the written exams.
Study for the written exams and get help if necessary.
TAKE THIS CLASS!! I have never learned so much in a semester. It completely changed the way I think about everything!

TAKE THIS COURSE EVEN IF ITS NOT A REQUIREMENT!!!! It's a ton of fun. I did not have any programming experience before taking this course. It was a lot of work, but I did enjoy myself and now I can consider myself a beginner programmer. I highly recommend, even just out of pure interest.
Take

Take advantage of all the help they offer- lab TAs were a godsend. And get Alan Kaplan as your preceptor if you're new to COS. He was so great at explaining things! Overall fun course, but challenging. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on it, and beware the exams.
Take it only if genuinely interested. Has a lot of work.

Take it! I switched to cos after taking this class, and I had absolutely no coding experience prior to cos126. Have Donna Gabai as your preceptor if possible, she is amazing and an absolute sweetheart!
Take it! It will certainly take you some time, but it's worth learning and nothing you run into will be unreasonably difficult.
Take it! It's a lot of fun and super well organized.
Take it, will change your life, hard work though
Take it. Its useful in a multitude of ways.
Take the class! It is challenging but well worth it.
Take the course! Everyone should take this at Princeton. It's not hard, you don't need to be a COS major, and it is so much fun!
Take the course! Realize that your grades might not reflect your mastery of the material. But the course is fun.
Take this class! Really great introduction to computer science. Everyone should try it as you may end up loving COS
Take this class. Really a must for all Princeton students.

Take this course if you are interested at all in coding! As a degree requirement, you just have to get through it, but make sure to stay up to date on theory!! If you don't, the written exams will destroy you. Programming exams are easy as long as you stay calm, however.
Take this course if you are interested in Computer Science, you may really like it. If not, PDF it and don't completely fail the written exams.

Take this course if you are interested in computer science out of curiosity, because you're considering it as a major, or just because computer skills are incredibly useful! The assignments are challenging but there is plenty of support such as office hours, precepts, class meetings, and the textbook. This course does require substantial work and time, but it is very rewarding and a really interesting class.
Take this course! It is an excellent and well-structured introduction to programming, which is an indispensable  skill.
Take this course! It's hard work but totally worth it. You learn a ton. Take advantage of all the help sessions offered!

Take this if you want a solid course on Java programming and some theory of computing. Programming assignments are quite interesting and varied, though other elements of the course are much closer to average.
Take this no matter what department you are in. Extremely useful skills that will develop not only your coding abilities but also problem solving, logic, etc.
The course is great for individuals who are interested in the subject, though can be tough for those just trying o get through.
The course is pretty well taught. DO NOT BUY THE BOOK, YOU WILL BARELY USE IT, instead just use the online lectures and the book site.
The course was a lot of time and was rather difficult, but the programs are rewarding and the information is incredibly useful
The homework assignments were enjoyable and fun to do. The course is taught very well and you will learn a lot. It is time consuming.
The programming assignments requires A LOT of your time, so if you choose to take this then be prepared
This course is a lot of work, but a lot of fun.  If you can, get Professor Alan Kaplan as a preceptor.  He is amazing!

This course is a wonderful introduction to computer science, merging several purposes of such a course into an interdisciplinary approach. Focusing on programming fundamentals in the first half of the course, after the midterm, the course continues with introductions to theoretical computer science and computer construction. Those without computer science may find the course fast paced. With past programming experience, the course is very manageable. Nevertheless, the written exams can be tricky. Allot some time to review and preparation in advance.

This course is interesting and provides a good background into java programming and computer science as a whole. If taking as a grade, a background in program is definitely helpful. Make use of office hours and lab TA hours.
This is a cool class, prepare to work hard and go to lab TAs. The exams are hard, but don't account for as much of your grade as the assignments. Totally a doable class.

This is a great introduction to coding and computer science, the effort put into developing it well shows. Try it out and you'll see if it's for you pretty quickly. If you do need help, use Lab TAs - they're all super helpful!
This is a great introduction to computer science, and the flexibility of online lectures and weekly assignments makes it easy to manage.

This is a really good course. The lecture videos can be kind of boring, but they explain the concepts really well. Class meetings like tips and tricks and precepts were most important to my learning, so make sure to go to those to better understand the material. Overall I enjoyed the course.

This is a really great introduction computer science course.  The class is very well organized, and while assignments are challenging, I would recommend the course to anyone interested in learning how to program very quickly.  While I personally was not a huge fan of the flipped classroom set up, I definitely learned a ton from this class. As someone who had never programmed before, I never felt extremely overwhelmed and there was always a large support system for any questions or help you may need.
This is a very structured course. I personally didn't like that, but other people might love it.
This is an amazing course to take  in which you will learn a lot of very useful and interesting skills and information.
Tough but fun and rewarding. You gotta take it over your time at Princeton
Very fun and engaging class. Figure out early on which parts of the class you plan to attend and use and stick to them
Very much recommend, especially to students new to the subject.
WATCH THE VIDEOS AND READ THE TEXTBOOK. DO PREVIOUS EXAMS. SEEK OUT HELP IMMEDIATELY IF YOU NEED IT.
Watch out for written exams.

While the material may seem daunting at first, don't be afraid to go to lab TAs or schedule meetings with your preceptor for help. It's also important to make sure you keep up with the material because it is incredible cumulative. If you get behind early on, it will be hard to complete assignments.
Worth taking, even if its not a requirement.
Worth taking. Pdf it though

You can't go wrong with this course, but it might just not be for you, so if that's the case, drop it earlier rather than later. But if you can get through the first two weeks it's an amazing skill to learn and it gets way better once you start doing partner projects. Get a partner who won't stress you out - that matters way more than someone who is "smart" or not

You've probably heard it before: everyone should know how to code. Well, yes, but know that this class is about more than just coding. You'll also learn a bunch of theory, which is pretty cool in its own right. Alan Turing is a god (and Sedgewick, we're told, is world-renowned).

aaaa. Regardless of your major, this is a good class to take. Very fun, not too much work or too difficult if you actually try. You come away with a solid set of skills and a decent understanding of comp sci.
enjoy it!
enjoyed, not hard,
good
good course

in my three years here ive learned that most princeton classes are poorly taught and most poorly professors are unengaged - this is absolutely not one of those classes. one of the BEST classes ive taken here and i really wish i had taken it freshmen year
lot of work, but useful skill
no
would recommend! no matter your major! just be prepared to put a lot of time into it and have fun!
otherinfo: No prior programming experience is required. Satisfies the SEAS computing requirement. There are weekly programming assignments plus a final programming project.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Other Exam - 25%, Design Project - 10%, Programming Assignments - 40%
assgts: Weekly Programming Assignments.
descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The course will teach basic principles and practical issues, and will prepare students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis. No prior programming experience required. Video lectures, one or two classes, two precepts
title: Computer Science: An Interdisciplinary Approach

evals:
-This course took me to the next level, and turned me into a "power programmer" as Prof. Gupta would say. You learn an incredible amount of material. I took this at the same time 
as COS226, and the double is definitely doable. Assignments are very fun and satisfying, although time-consuming. Also, Guna is an amazing preceptor who really cares about his students.

A great course. Even greater if Dondero is your preceptor! Know that programming assignments take quite some time and there usually is not a way to avoid having to debug code. However, they are very rewarding. Do not take this course with other courses which have programming assignments and be sure to understand the lecture material for the exams.
AAAAAA In this class you will learn definitively whether or not you like software developing.
Be prepared to do a lot of work, especially for assignments, but you learn a lot along the way.

Definitely take this class if you have even the slightest interest in computer science. The material is really great but it is a lot and precepts cannot cover it fully in the little time they so be prepared to do a lot by yourself.
Definitely take this course if you'd like to know what's happening "under the hood" of today's computers. This course is engaging and interesting, and the experience gained is well worth the work.

Don't take this class unless you're 100% sure that you'll be a cos major. And be prepared to want to change to another major after taking this class. But with that said, if you really need to take the class, take it with Dondero. He is the best person you can find in the COS building.
Expect to put in a lot of time. And get Dandero!

For those that aren't COS majors don't be scared. This class is a lot of work don't get me wrong but they provide a lot of resources and help for everyone. The material is also pretty interesting and its good for everyone who uses a computer regularly to understand what is going on (plus you learn C).

Get Dondero's precept, but expect that he will run 5 minutes overtime every precept (i.e. don't schedule class across campus for 10 minutes afterwards because you will always be late). This was significantly more time than 126 or 226 -- easily 10 hours a week. I found myself spending 15-20 on most of the assignments. The shell assignment brings everything together nicely and really makes you feel like a software engineer, but it will eat up your whole reading period if you take it in the spring -- that assignment can easily be 40 hours. Make sure that you either keep up with the lectures or do the readings; you don't really need to do both, but not doing either will make your life a lot harder.
Get Dr. Dondero for precept.  Expect 10  hour assignments and 30  hour final assignment.  Go to lectures.
Go to Dondero a lot. He's truly incredible. He is so helpful every time I had issues. And extremely responsive to emails.
Go to lectures! You might be able to get by without it, but the material that is presented in lecture is engaging and important. Start the assignments early, especially assembly.

Great class. If you are a COS major, of course you have to take it--if you're getting the certificate and thinking about skipping one of 226 or 217, definitely take 217! It's far more organized and the faculty involved simply seem more competent.

Great course! Different from 226, but much more enjoyable (depends on your interests). The assignments are definitely time consuming (expect 10 hours on for most and 20-30 hours for the longest ones), but the course does give you enough time and heads-up to complete them - so just budget your time wisely. The lectures and precepts are both super helpful and crucial! Amazing course and highly recommend to anyone who is interested in COS.
Great course, a lot of work but worth it if youre interested in cos.
I really liked 217 since it gave me a really different perspective of computer science as a field.  It's really cool to be learning about computers at the low level and a bit about computing history.

I strongly recommend this course with the caveat that you like to code. Liking to code means appreciating that debugging is part of the process. You will spend a lot of time debugging. Like more time than you can imagine. However the course is very rewarding.

If Dondero is holding precept's get it if you can. He, is quite simply, the best preceptor or professor you can get in any class. He is always eager to help you with assignments, and he leads excellent precepts.

If you can, attend lecture; you'll appreciate it once you get to exams. Precepts are absolutely critical (and also mandatory so). Assignments are extremely challenging and tedious; debugging in this class can be an absolute nightmare. I highly recommend that you make use of lab TAs/preceptors if you have small but confusing errors, as this can save you hours. Absolutely do not procrastinate or else the assignments will wreck you.

If you can, get Dondero for precepts -- it is really hard to do poorly in the course if you have him as your preceptor. He usually teaches the first two precepts of the week. The reading is good (especially King) but if you attend lectures and precepts you really don?t need to do it -- there is a lot of overlap and you will just be duplicating work. Start assignments early as sometimes you can spend many many hours debugging. And go to lecture! At times it can be a bit dry but Aarti Gupta is a really great lecturer and really cares about her students.
If you only want to take a single COS course after 126, I would take this one.
If you're not a COS major, don't take it. Take 226 instead. If you're a COS, you're forced to take it. Its tough but not unbelievably tough or a reason to drop the major.

It is a time consuming course for sure. I took COS226 and COS217 at the same time, but I believe it is very doable. Make sure to start ahead of time and you will be doing really well! You learn a lot (and at times, very enjoyable)

Read the textbook if possible. Reread lecture notes. Do practice exams. Never hesitate to go to office hours, ask questions on piazza, or ask questions after lecture. Do practice exams. Try to get Dondero as a preceptor. Start assignments early.
Robert Dondero is amazing. He'd respond to your message always in 5 minutes even if it's midnight! And you can learn so much about what's going under the hood, which lays good foundation for OS

Start the assignments early!! The assignments relate strongly to the course material, so giving yourself time to complete them allows you to 1st complete them and 2nd learn the course material better. Keep in mind the assignments are worth half your grade...

TAKE THIS COURSE! I liked it loads better than 226. Also get Dondero because he is a straight god. Although the assignments are sometimes a pain in the butt, you learn a lot from them and actually feel like you've accomplished something when you finish them. A great course if you are more interested in low-level stuff.
Take it if you need.  Or if you don't, I guess.  That's your business.
Take it!
Take it! I enjoyed it a lot, and it's not as scary as everyone says as long as you manage your time well.
Take it. Precepts with Dondero are fantastic and the course gives a good and thorough overview of systems programming. Be prepared for a good deal of work though.
Take this class if you have time to spend.

Take this class if you want to be a good programmer. COS126 will teach you the basics. COS226 will teach you advanced techniques. But COS217 will teach you how to be a good, sound programmer. You will learn how to code to a standard closer to real-world. ... You will master C. It's not that different from java, but there are some special, difficult features. ... Professor Dondero is the man. Be in his precept if possible. The precepts are key to this class and he is a phenomenal teacher. ... Don't go to lecture. Just read the slides and parts of the book. ... Programming assignments are once every week-and-a-half. Get ready to spend a lot of time doing them. The professor will suggest using emacs text editor; I strongly suggest using something like Sublime. Transferring the files online and offline is a little tedious, but emacs is much more tedious and limiting.
Take this class! Challenging but you'll learn a lot.
Take this course. It can be a lot of work but you will learn a lot.
The assignments can take a long time but are very exciting and intellectually engaging, definitely don't try to rush them and understand what you're doing, or it will come back to bite you.

The course is well done, but whether you will like it depends greatly on whether you like systems. The programming assignments are interesting and fun on higher and more abstract level, but I found most of this fun got drowned out by the tedium of writing in the low-level language of C and the countless hours of debugging.

The first half of the course is about the same time commitment and difficulty as COS 226; the second half is both conceptually more difficult and requires more time for the assignments as well. Precepts are where most of the learning occurs. You will walk out of this course feeling that you learned a lot.

The theory of 217 is much simpler than 226 and maybe even 126, but the assignments will take a while just to debug. I liked learning about the lower-level stuff, so I thought this was a good class, but that might not hold true for everyone.

This course is an awesome introduction to programming systems. It is a fairly demanding course, and I highly recommend starting the programming assignments at least a few days in advance. In particular, if you're taking the course in the spring, budget several days in reading period for the final assignment - contrary to what many say, the final assignment is not terribly difficult, but you should budget at least 24 hours (not in one sitting) to complete it.

This course is devastating for first-time learners. At times, you will wonder "Do I have what it takes to be a COS major? Do I even love COS anymore?". This course is the equivalent of at least three courses mashed into one. I still cannot tell you exactly what the main learning goal was. Was it to learn C? Well, not exactly. If anything, it felt like we were learning how to make programs that just so happened to require C. 

The programming assignments are wholly unreasonable and require a lot of time (sometimes more than 15/20 hours). Avoid any preceptor that is not Dondero. Dondero wrote the assignments and he's been part of this course for a long time. The other preceptors (specifically Guna) do not seems as invested in or as knowledgeable about the course/programming assignments. 

I'm not gonna lie, I'm getting sad just typing this course eval because of the memories that are now returning to me. Let me tell you something: math courses are more reasonable than this course. Yes, you read that right. The math department-- notorious for their unreasonable tests and resulting low scores-- is more reasonable and structured than this course. This course is just too much-- I'm leaving not knowing exactly what I've learned but knowing that I've been traumatized in some way. I'm not sure I'll be able to look at C for the next couple of years. 

Also, start assignments early. I know that you hear this everywhere, but you need to listen to this advice for  this course. When you're working on an assignment due Wednesday/Sunday night, go to your M/T precept and find out the preceptor has already moved on to the next assignment, you're gonna remember this course evaluation-- trust me. 

If you are a COS major: godspeed my friend.  

If you're not a COS major: I highly suggest you find another way to learn C.

Took for interest and found it to be interesting, but very, very difficult (had only taken 126 previously). Assignments are cool but quite time consuming. Not sure I would take it again, given the opportunity for a do-over, due to its difficulty (not departmental for me).

Try to get Professor Dondero as preceptor; his precept was the main reason why I was able to do the assignments. Class picks up substantially in the second half of the semester, and assignments begin to take much longer - be prepared for that.
its kinda boring at times, but cool tie in with ele 206.
otherinfo: COS 217 and 226 can be taken in any order. A student planning to take both can take in the order that fits his or her interests and schedule constraints.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Programming Assignments - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Programming assignment every week or two.
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended), or approval by COS placement officer, Christopher Moretti..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.
title: Introduction to Programming Systems

evals: -- If you're taking this class because you really liked 126 and did well be careful because 226 is a lot harder and more time intensive. This class takes up a lot of time and is difficult.

-- Jeremie, please leave this course. You are ruining it for everyone. Just look at the ratings and you'll see how bad a job you're doing. 226 should be taken before 217 because otherwise, it is too simple and boring. It could be a great course with a good professor UNLIKE JEREMIE. Jeremie is the kind of a guy that lets you know if there is a lecture or not only half an hour before the designated time. He consistently makes mistakes, and argues Maia the Legend. If he leaves though, definitely take this course.
-Great preparation for interviews. Grading can be highly variable though, so beware.

-If you have any interest in coding, and are willing to put in the time (sometimes a lot of time), this course will prepare you for a lot of coding skills that you'll need, regardless of what field you're in. Though challenging at times, I would seriously recommend.

226 is a fine class. Its structured the same as 126 now, but due to the fact that the contents are basically all in the same field and streamlined, it makes more sense than in 126.
