The annoying part is that it is time consuming - you will need at least 3 full days to complete each assignment. Don't take this with a heavy courseload. I feel like cos ability isnt what determines your success in this class - its how much time you have to properly devote to it.

A definitive love/hate relationship with this class. 

Love: the material, certain assignments that were pretty interesting in terms of final product (8 puzzle, autocomplete), how much better I got at coding and COS in general. 

Hate: the rampant disorganization (e.g. extra credit debacle in which they switched extra credit to required 2 days before assignment was due; rarely-on-time grading of exams), the length of the assignments (took me 20 hours to finish deques, holed up in Lewis, one of the worst experiences of my Princeton life).

I personally liked 226 better than 126 but that's because I got used to the course structure from 126, and knew how to prepare for exams better. COS226 also confirmed for me that I would become a COS major whereas after 126 I felt like I was not at all a fit for COS. This class is definitely NOT for everyone; shop it if you're undecided. Keep in mind that it escalates quickly.
A good introduction to the theory of algorithms, well-organized and informative. The exams at the end of the year can be unnecessarily difficult, however.

A great class. If you're a COS major you'll have to take it anyways, but even if you're not it is a very well run, interesting class that teaches you very interesting material, and overall helps you learn how to think and approach problems in a very important and exciting way. A hard class, but one definitely worth taking.

A very good course, especially if you're interested in cos. It was run somewhat haphazardly this year, however, but is worth taking anyway since the assignments and lecture videos are overall quite good and won't chance anyway.

AAA Do NOT take with Jeremie Lumbroso. Lectures were extremely disorganized, sometimes even cancelled 20 minutes before, the exams are taken from previous exams and most questions have errors, don't expect your feedback until a month after, bad BAD BAD! 

However, take if interested in Computer Science.

After the beautifully-crafted COS 126 course, this class is disappointmenting. The content of the course is still good but the class meetings are a waste, the assignments are excessively nit-picky, and the course overall feels very disorganized.

Algorithms (written for this course by Sedgwick) is nationally recognized and used all over the country to teach undergrads data structures. Therefore, 226 at Princeton might just be the best introductory Algorithms course there is! I really really enjoyed the content, and although it is a bit more work than 126 (there are "quizzera" exercises, longer readmes, and the slightly harder assignments, adding maybe 3-4 extra hours per week compared to late-semester 126). Sign up for one of the main precepts if you can so that you can get Maia Ginsberg ? she is great! Anyone who has an interest in discrete problem solving OR computer science should absolutely take this course!
An interesting and very useful course. I enjoyed it a great deal. However it is definitely challenging and time consuming, so be aware of that
As with 126 & 217, the most important part of the class is the assignments. Not nearly as time consuming as 217.
Be prepared to put a lot if work into it. It's all worth it.

Be weary about taking this course if you dont have to (ie. if you are not a COS major). It is overwhelming and very difficult at times, and it can seem like everyone is much smarter than you in the class.

Class is over all fun and the information you learn you will use forever if you're a cos major or if you do any type of programming. David is a really nice guy and makes precept fun. Makes sure to ask if we need clarification and is good at explaining things. Assignments were super interesting and fun and had cool applications, although they were hard and definitely take a lot longer than assignments in 126. Expect to spend a substantial part of your weekend doing them bc assignments are due Sunday night. Make sure you start the assignments early because there aren't as many office hours on the weekend. You still have to study a lot outside of doing the assignments to prepare for the exams. Quizzera exercises super helpful for making sure you understand the algorithms. Exams were super tough. Don't trust the previous exams to give you an estimation of how hard the current exams will be. Make sure you know the algorithms so well you can do them in your sleep. Spend a lot of time on your readme.txt esp the analysis parts bc its easy to lose points on them.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO. If you do take it, take it during a super easy semester. This course contributed to about 90% of my overall stress levels, and I have never genuinely been concerned about failing a class until I took COS226. This is a weed-out class, and the department is actively searching for ways to make sure you have the most frustrating and tiring experience possible. For example, a new, mandatory part was added to the assignment a day before it was due without even sending an e-mail (the assignment specs were simply updated without alerting any of the students). In addition, this class, and the department on the whole, made me really question whether I want to continue majoring in COS. I could honestly go on forever about how much anxiety it caused me and how incredibly discouraging the experience was, but my best advice is to just not take it, unless you have a serious passion for algorithms or you're dead-set on being a COS major.
Dedicate the required time and you'll do great - perhaps not in the design exam though...
Difficult; Uncurved(?); Jeremie won't be teaching it next semester so it might improve
Don't fall behind!
Don't take this if you aren't planning on getting a certificate or concentrating. Its a ton of work, lots of hours of studying, and exams are incredibly difficult.
For a better understanding of how to incorporate considerations of runtime, memory-usage, and data-structures in algorithm design, this is a great course.

For non-COS majors, take this class if you are at all interested in learning how to code efficiently (beyond 126) and simplify a lot of your work regardless of the field you are in. Be warned that it is a lot of work, twice that of any other class, so I would be wary of taking it in a semester with a lot of other science/pset-heavy classes, but I found it manageable in a 5-class semester with only 2 other sciences. You will learn a lot in this class though, so it's worth it!

Get Dave Walker as your preceptor, he's really helpful. Don't expect to get a lot out of class meetings, but do go to the assignment prep sessions, you get useful tips. Get started early on assignments, you don't want to be rushing on Sunday, plus testing and timing can take a looong time.
Get ahead on COS assignments. You can literally watch all the videos in the first couple weeks and be done with the course and stroll through the semester.

Give constructive feedback whenever you wish things could be different, the course staff is super interested in improving the quality of the course which feels great. Most students score very high in all assignments so be aware of where you stand (don't be fooled by what seem like high marks)

Go to lab TAs early and the week since there is never a wait whereas later in the week, the queue can be pretty unbearable. In general, stay on top of all the course materials and assignments. For most people, this will not be a class that you can just give half your effort in. It's tough, but it's very useful and practical.
Go to office hours and lab TAs.
Good class, but also time consuming. make sure to devote enough time to the class
Good class, but the assignments can take a while and the exams are hard.
Good class. A lot of work. This class will tell you if you want to be a CS major. It could be helpful to try to get a headstart on the course and watching the lecture vids ahead of the semester.
Good, useful course. Workload is a bit heavy but worth taking.

Great class. Better than 217 in my opinion. The algorithms are interesting and the assignments are challenging but enjoyable. Less time commitment than 217 but more than 126. Exams can be challenging but are fair. Sergiy is a great preceptor. Use office hours if necessary.
Great course if you have any interest in the subject material, lots of interesting concepts
Great course, would recommend if you enjoy problem solving.
Hard but worth it!
Hard class, make sure to put in a lot of work on lectures and assignments. I thought certain logistical parts of the class were run really poorly. Learned a ton though.
I highly recommend this course even to people who don't have to take it. Go to office hours and ask for help from preceptors for the assignments and exam prep!
I recommend COS 226 because hopefully the administration of this course will be better in the future. I mean, once you hit rock bottom you can only go up.

I thought it was a really interesting course. After taking 217, 226 was so much more interesting, and so much more reasonable in terms of time commitment for the assignments. Having a partner with whom you can easily coordinate times to meet up is important, and the written exams are actually very reasonable as long as you start practicing early and keep up with the lectures. It's a good idea to stay up to date with the video lectures and precepts are really helpful, especially with Kathleen Emerson.

I would advise other students to review all course material in advance, study for a minimum of 2 weeks prior to exams, and go to all office hours every week. If the concepts covered do not come intuitively to you, you will need an extraordinary amount of extra effort in order to be able to do well in this course. I would recommend against taking this course UNLESS you intend to be a COS major or intend on getting the certificate.

I would recommend this course if you liked 126 and have an interest in continuing with computer science. The material is interesting, especially if you like a bit of theory, and in the assignments you design really cool algorithms! Beware, though, that assignments take significantly longer than 126 assignments (maybe 8-10 hours on average). I personally don't think you need to partner for assignments, though many people do. Exams are generally fair, though the programming exam was a bit of a time crunch.

INCREDIBLE course overall. Definitely challenging and programming assignments are rather time consuming, but the quality of instruction, amount of resources available, and support that you receive are incomparable to any other course at Princeton. A must if you're considering a job in the tech world - they even have classes that go over interview tips and interview-style questions. Sergiy is a great preceptor, Lumbroso is a great lecturer. You can tell the profs are in it to help you learn, and that's the kind of class you come to Princeton for!

If you are really interested in Algorithms & Data Structures and want to spend all your waking hours on them take this course. otherwise be prepared for a lot of arduous time spent. I believe it is worth it if you really enjoy the material, but if you don't, don't take this class for fun. Also if you can pay attention to a video lecture for an hour  you will be much better off in this course.

If you enjoyed 126, you will enjoy this class as well. The class format is very similar. I recommend this course to non-COS majors as well; the knowledge from this course is applicable in most other stem fields.

If you enjoyed COS 126 and have any intentions of improving your programming skills, 226 is great. Be prepared to spend some serious time on the assignments, but you will walk away with a much deeper understanding of CS.

If you want to learn programming, take this course. Yes it may be a decent amount of work, and sometimes the lectures are underwhelming, but in the end you really learn data structures and algorithms pretty well. Definitely worth it.
If you want to pursue Computer Science this is course is necessary.  It does a good job of teaching the concepts, although Jeremie Lumbrusio is not a great lecturer.

If you're looking at this class, it's probably not for fun but rather for a requirement. Obviously, if you need to take this course, take it. If you are coming from 126, just know that you won't be able to get by in this class without watching videos on time. There are online problem sets that test you on the videos, and precepts are more about doing practice problems based around the videos than explaining topics covered in the videos. Programming exams were only implemented recently and may change significantly, but they did seem rather easy. Written exams made up most of the grade and definitely sucked; they were very heavy on order of growth/run time analysis of various algorithms and structures, but these analyses were often near impossible to understand or derive on your own (and you'll probably just memorize them) . But unlike 126, the exams were at least curved in a way. Problems that lots of people did poorly on were thrown out, and grading was very lenient as to give partial credit where possible. Overall, I felt that the class taught too many algorithms, and by the end, I had forgotten what most of them were about. But if this is a requirement for you, you'll be able to get by as long as you study and watch the videos on time.
Interesting class. but be prepared to put in a lot of work
Interesting content, can be challenging. Work regularly if you take it.

Interesting course, but be prepared to put in a lot of work. Start early on the assignments (esp. in order to understand the underlying concepts before you start programming!) In the case of the examinations, I can only recommend to study a lot, but I don't know how since clearly I did not do so well, even though I put a ton of hours in the exams.

It's a fantastic class and if you enjoyed 126, is a good next step. Be prepared to put in time though. While you definitely learn a ton, the pace is fast and you have to put in time to keep up. That being said, it's very worth it. Start assignments early, watch the lectures, and go to precept!

It's a step up from 126, but it's got that same, comforting structure of well-organized assignments with a helpful course site.  Lots of neat topics and some tedious ones.  It's a great class to take to figure out if you like COS- in particular the theoretical stuff.  Jeremie has this weird tendency to ask students their grades when they come for help, which can be off-putting if you're struggling, but I think it comes from a genuine desire to give the appropriate advice to each student.
It's a tough course and lots of work, but it's interesting.

It's an alright course. I much prefer COS217 over COS226, even though COS217 is a larger time commitment. The assignments in 226 were interesting, but the FOUR exams really made me pressed for time, and I thought that they barely helped me learn the material. Not too bad, but I think that Jeremie has some learning to do before this course becomes better again.
It's hard.
Material and online lectures are great!

Much harder concepts than 126 and more time-consuming. The material is definitely interesting and worthwhile, but it might burn some students out if they cannot dedicate enough time or are not interested in theoretical aspects. Gets significantly harder toward the end of the semester, particularly the design exam.
Obviously everyone needs to take it, but the structure is bad and isn't conducive to learning the material.
Only take it if you love cos or are majoring in COS.
Overall, not a terrible course. The written exams are doable if you study well, but the design exam will ruin you.
Please, please, please get started on assignments as soon as possible.
Pretty good course overall. All the material can be gained from online lectures. Start early on the assignments and start studying early for the exams.
Pretty interesting class for algorithms! Can get annoying at times because the analysis seems a bit excessive (though justifiably, seems necessary)
Really good class, can be time consuming, but if you watch lectures ahead of time you'll do much better
Really interesting class and a great extension of COS126. If you can, though, wait until Jeremie isn't teaching it.
Really tough course but interesting -- but don't take it unless you would really want to learn more about programming, especially the logic behind coding.
Recommended for students interested in algorithms.

Schedule your video watching times. Otherwise you won't get them done in time and fall behind with the quizzes. Expect to dedicate a LOT of time to this during the whole semester. Rewarding enough I'd say.

Scoring well on written exams is very possible with practice -- many questions are essentially repeated between exams, so look at all the past ones they provide. Design/programming are the harder exams, pay attention to the practice they give you in precept.

Set aside ample time for programming assignments. Pay attention to Piazza - instructors sometimes pin/respond with important answers to questions without sending out a course-wide email to notify students. You truly do need to understand the concepts behind each of the algorithms, particularly for the design exam.

Solid class, you can definitely get by on assignments without really understanding how the data structures work, but it's important to understand them thoroughly for exams (which you should space out studying for since the structure is now that of 126).

Standard CS class. Make sure you do not tank the exams (actually understand everything on the past exams not just glance at them). They programming assignments are graded more harshly than in 126 they take off major points for incorrect read me's and later on for inefficient / not concise code. Surprisingly, only having 10 drop box submissions was not that bad because they give you other ways to test you code (basically training you to use the command line and stuff instead of depending on drop box ; at most I used 8 submissions and this was a desperate attempt from someone who is not a CS maestro). The course is not easy but if you're good (lol not me) than it will not be unbearable.
Start assignments a bit earlier than you think you need to (unless you have late days you are willing to burn)
Start the programming assignments early and use the textbook to study for the exams.
Start your projects early, make sure you watch online lectures before precept.
Stay on top of your stuff and start practicing for the exam weeks in advance.
Take it and sped your time on it. Not easy but not impossible.
Take it! One of the most useful courses at Princeton!
Take it, but be prepared for a lot of work and a fairly difficult class. However, by the end, you can consider yourself to be a pretty good programmer.
Take this class. Not too hard and the assignments are very interesting
Take this course even if you are not a COS major - you learn so much

Take this course if you are interested in COS! It's the most interesting course I've taken at Princeton so far. I learned a lot of stuff. However, expect to put a lot of effort in, as the course is very time consuming (at least 10 hours for each assignment, ~5 hours for watching the lectures, 1 other hour for quizerra).
Take this course if you liked 126 and want to learn about algorithms. You will spend a lot of time on this course but overall a good course.
Take this course with Lumbroso!
Take this course! It will help you understand algorithms and some of the most fundamental theoretical concepts.
Take this course. It is very valuable for interviews. Don't have to go to lecture; I recommend not going if the lecturer is bad.
Take this if you really want to learn about algorithms.

Tedious. They seem to think that it's the only course you're taking sometimes. Exams feel arbitrary and not easy to prepare for. I may be biased though, because I hated the timing analysis and efficiency requirements of this course, which is basically the whole point of this course.
The course is a lot of work, but it's definitely worth it because you learn so much in the process. If you enjoyed 126, definitely take it!

The course is a standard algorithms course though it will be harder than equivalent courses at other universities. I recommend this course overall. The assignments are graded harshly so take your time on them.

The course was somewhat disorganized this year - for example, it took the instructors really long to return our exams for both the midterm and the final. Overall, it's a good class but it requires a LOT of time commitment on the assignments and in general.

The difficulty in this class lies in the amount of time needed to adequately understand all the concepts presented while balancing this with completing the assignments. Allow 10-12 hours to complete each assignment, and start at least four days in advance so you have time to see the lab TAs at a reasonable hour if need be. Understanding the material when it is first presented in each week's lecture is a must - the sheer quantity of exams (4 over the semester) makes advance preparation absolutely necessary so that things are easier the week of the exam. Other than that, you really learn a lot of interesting (and useful) material in this course - just be sure to stay on top of things from the start.
This class takes up so much time. Make sure you only take it if you have a very light course load otherwise.
This course could have been organized a bit better, but it is worth taking if you are into computer science and want to learn more about algorithms.
This course covers great material and will give you a solid introduction to algorithms and data structures. However, it was run in an incompetent fashion this spring.
This course is amazing! It's definitely helpful for every serious programmer, especially if you want to become a developer and get a good job.

This course is definitely more challenging than 126, but is very rewarding when you complete it and its material is very interesting.  If you're interested in COS whatsoever, it is definitely a worthwhile class.

This course is essential if you want basic knowledge of algorithms and data structures in computer science.  The content is great, so stay on top of lecture videos and Quizzera.  However, just know that the course is not well organized.
This course is great, and really useful. It's a lot of time and work, but the material is very manageable and interesting if you're willing to put in the time.
This is a challenging course! Be prepared to spend many hours debugging.
This is a reasonably good introduction to algorithms.  Requires maybe 1.5 to 2 times as much work as COS 126.
This is a well structured and well taught course. It is challenging and time consuming, so I would only take if required or if you loved 126.

This is an amazing course.  If you enjoyed COS126, I think you should take this.  It makes you a much better programmer, and I think it is a very interesting class too.  However, if possible do not take it with Jeremie.  He was very disorganized, but the course was still good.
Though this course can feel a bit disorganized at times, the material is fascinating, the assignments fun, and if you have an interest in computer science it's a great course to take.

Useful and interesting course. Material builds and it can become confusing to keep track of how different data structures, etc. fit together. I'd recommend trying to keep a map/chart throughout the semester, adding to it as you learn new data structures, so as to keep a clear overview of what you're learning in your head. Assignments usually took 10-20 hours for me (closer to 10 in most cases); faster to complete than those for COS217, with much less time spent on debugging.
Very Interesting class, but be careful on programming assignments and exams because they can be very nitpicky.
Very interesting course, with fun assignments and instructors who are friendly, approachable, and knowledgeable!
Warning: it's not PDF-able. Don't be fooled.
Watch the lectures ahead of time.

You basically teach yourself computer science and just go to lecture to get help with the assignments, which are actually pretty fun. Precept is generally a lot more helpful than lecture. Optimization is annoying but necessary. Jeremie is a strange man.
You gain a strong toolkit of skills

You learn so much in this course. However, this course was very disorganized, and the exams were brutal. I would suggest ignoring what grade you get, and just focus on learning the material as well as you can.

tests are ok except design exam will make you want to spontaneously combust. precepts mostly useless but you have to go because participation grade which is the most pointless and stupid thing ever. students are very aggressive with piazza which is occasionally helpful but mostly annoying and as a whole the class is excessively competitive and it is the most frustrating thing ever when you fail a test and hear some people talking about how it was easy. the class makes it really obvious that there is a giant gap between people who come in already knowing everything and people who have only taken cos 126. on the whole it is a useful class and you learn some stuff but if you come in with limited experience prepare to spend 20  hours a week on it to scrape by

~If you are a COS major, just get this course over with and go on to take an interesting class. If you are doing COS for fun, I think 217 was a lot more entertaining, and probably about as useful for a programming amateur.
otherinfo: COS 226 and 217 may be taken in any order. A student planning to take both can do so in the order that best fits his or her interests and schedule constraints.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Programming Assignments - 45%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Exercises covering each lecture; weekly programming assignments focusing on problem solving and understanding properties of algorithms and implementations; two required inclass exams. Approximately 75 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended) or placement by COS Placement Officer. http://www.cs.princeton.edu/ugrad/advisors.
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.
title: Algorithms and Data Structures

evals: A really great course; easil one of the most applicable CS classes offered. But be warned: do not take it with a heavy semester. You will work long hours if you're trying to actually understand what is happening. Project 5 and 6 take a long long long time; start them early.
Assignments are actually fairly straightforward, but you spend a lot of time with sometimes deceptive specifications and debugging.
Be prepared to put in the hours but you learn a LOT
Be prepared to work. Do not take with other COS class.
Disorganized and decent amount of work, but important material as a COS major
EXTREMELY TIME CONSUMING!! Exam was extremely long and pure memorization. Be prepared to get frustrated with the organization of this course.
Expect lots of work but I would consider this a core course for any COS major.

Fantastic lectures. Assignments are long and difficult, but mostly because instructions and grading were unclear. 
However, I gained most of my knowledge in OS from accomplishing the assignments. Highly recommend this class for people interested in firmware, systems, and embedded systems engineering.
Get ready to work hard.
Good luck.  Good material, but structural issues with the class and assignments make it a huge time and stress sink.

I think that anyone with a COS interest should take this course. It's incredibly important to an understanding of computer performance and system design. That being said, in its current form, it sucks. Be prepared to spend hours of your own time trying to understand the material that is glazed over in lecture. Very interesting material though!
I think your experience will depend on how good your preceptors are. I'm glad I learned about OS but it was also one of the most miserable classes I've taken at Princeton.

I was very conflicted whether OS was necessary to take as a computer science major. On one hand, it is a core fundamental field to study. On the other, it is time consuming. Coming out of this semester, I would advise against taking this course unless you are somewhat interested in systems programming (217 is a good indicator). In its current state, the course is too disorganized (difficult to receive the necessary attention during office hours. I did not find it to be a healthy learning environment because everyone was so preoccupied with finishing the assignments and less on learning the material. if you do take it, I strongly advise paying attention during lecture and preparing for the exam (one of my regrets). I also think it is important to have a partner you feel comfortable communicating openly with because assignments are especially crucial in this course.

I would suggest only taking it if you don't mind systems programming. I loved 217 and I enjoyed 318 as well. It can be difficult at times, but I don't think it's as bad as it's reputation makes it out to be. Pretty time consuming though. Also the one exam you have to take will make you feel empty inside.
I'm convinced that the material taught in OS is both absolutely essential to COS majors, and also nearly impossible to teach well. Assignments are about as hard as the rumors say, but not impossible.

IMO, should be required for COS majors. This is one of those courses where you get what you give (just be prepared to give a lot). Yes, the assignments are hard and frustrating -- but they force you to learn to make design choices, understand how to develop in a code base, and practically engage with the material from lecture. You'll come out of this course as a stronger and more independent programmer with an appreciation for the complex engineering and concepts (exceptions! concurrency! virtual memory!) that make your computer work.

If you are taking this class for the systems requirement, don't. If you are taking the course to finish the computer systems requirement, take something else. This course was intentionally designed to be difficult, and unless there is a group of TA's who are genuinely engaged and interested in helping the students succeed, the class will be painful.

If you like exploring stuff in a setting more akin to real life development then this class is for you since the concepts are important anyway. The assignments were notoriously unclear in its guidance and it is actually intended.
It's a difficult class. Take it if you want to learn a lot and grow as both a student a coder. Keep up with readings and materials and start early on assignments!
It's a lot of work. Don't take it just for fun, since it makes you a better programmer at the very high cost of at least 20 hours per assignment. Having two good partners for the class is crucial.
It's super hard
Make sure you are ready to spend a lot of time debugging.  However, if you are interested in systems and the overlap between hardware and software, this is a must take!

NOT AS BAD as people preach. However let's get some thing straight. The EXAM was VERY HARD. I would recommend that you don't fall behind on the readings and also that do some practice questions on each topic so that you don't have to cram for the exam (yes, thank me later on this). 

Projects, this is the order in terms of time-sinks: Project 5 (this is just conceptually difficult and you do a lot of bit fiddling. Just save those 2 weeks for OS), Project 1 (kind of expected since it's the first assignment), Project 6 (not conceptually hard but long), Project 4, 3 and 2.

OS is hard, but it can be really rewarding as well! It just depends on if you are the kind of person who can take a beat down and still get back up. You definitely learn a lot of low-level concepts that are important to know if you are interested in systems at all!
Only take this if you're really interested. I loved because it's what I want to do in life, but the assignments are typically 40 hours.

Please please please please PLEASE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD make sure you have time in your schedule to take your time in this course. Some of the assignments literally take 30  hours to complete if you want to do it well. I'm assuming you're only taking this course because you're interested in the content (if you're not then don't even bother, this class is a commitment), so PLEASE go ahead and take an easy schedule for everything else so you can actually do well here.
Prepare for a lot of coding!

Seriously, don't take this course.  It's incredibly disorganized.  You'd learn more from reading Wikipedia than going to lecture, and would get more out of reading OSDev Wiki than doing the assignments.
Start early on everything!

Start on the assignments early and don't procrastinate on them. Find a partner that you're happy to spend multiple hours with. There's definitely a steep learning curve, but once you get past it things begin looking up. Despite this, you should still expect to spend many many hours working on the projects. But overall great course.
Take the course if you want to learn, a LOT. It's tough and takes a HUGE amount of time, but it makes you stronger and understand your computer better.
Take this class if you are interested in operating systems. I am, so i really enjoyed it. Having said that, it is such a time sink and will take up much of your week.

Take this class if you care about learning what happens behind the scenes on your computer. Some of the assignments are time consuming but they are relatively straightforward if you are interested in this subject and think rationally through problems. The final project was extremely valuable to my growth as an engineer, and I will remember it in the future.

The course covers a lot of very important material for any computer science major and has some really cool and genuinely fun assignments. However, it is very unorganized and frustrating when instructors are all contradicting each other, links are broken all over the site/assignment pages, dates keep changing, there is little input from the professor, etc. Be sure to push on these issues quickly in lecture/Piazza/email to make sure they get attention so the class is more fun/helpful and less frustrating/painful.
The material is interesting, but the class is VERY disorganized, badly taught, and the workload was excruciating.

The rumours are true: this is a very difficult class. Most of the assignments can take a very long time (final project is easily over 1,000 lines of code). You will despair at 3AM, defeated by a bug hidden in hundreds of lines of complicated code. You will feel frustrated, wasting hours of your time just trying to understand what the assignments specs are even saying (someone really needs to revamp the assignments). You will be pitted against a very long and difficult exam. But you will come out of this class having gained absolutely vital knowledge in computer science, and a better programmer less intimidated by big projects. Take it if you're a COS major, but do expect to sink in a lot of time and feeling lost every week.

This course has really important and interesting material and JP is a very good lecturer.  Nonetheless, the TAs are often incredibly confused themselves and therefore ineffective at helping with the assignments.  Also, the early assignments, for some unfathomable reason, require a lot of reading through documentation
This course is difficult, but do not be discourage at the beginning of the semester!

This course seems to suffer from lack of people who care about it. The TAs will answer questions about the assignments, but they don't really seem to want to TA or seem interested in trying to improve the student experience. JP is a good lecturer, but he doesn't really seem interested in trying to overhaul the course to make it better. If you're interested in OS topics/doing work in OS, this class is a necessary evil. If not, I would consider other systems courses.
Very useful material even if you're not interested in pursuing a career in OS. Projects can be very confusing, but they were fun, and JP is a great lecturer
Would not recommend taking this unless you have some interest in operating systems or low-level programming.
You learn a decent amount. But this class blows. Honestly I wouldn't retake it

You learn a lot about systems, but the assignments can feel hopeless and extraordinarily frustrating. Make sure you're prepared to deal with the assignments, and a lot of work that does not necessarily feel fulfilling. The assignments also take over your life somewhat.
You learn some cool low level stuff, would recommend for students interested in systems programming.
otherinfo: Each project will have at least one precept. Last project is a final project. The six projects will build an operating system for a PC.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Design Project - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Six programming projects to build a toy operating system for PC hardware. Weekly reading assignments from the textbook and selected papers. NOTE: Students work in groups for the first 5 projects. Final project is 20% of final grade.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. Audit option only available with instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to operating systems. Emphasis is on the fundamentals of how to design and implement an operating system. Topics include operating system structure, processes, threads, synchronizations, concurrent programming, interprocess communications, virtual memory, I/O device management, and file systems.
title: Operating Systems

evals:
1. Find a good group. You will be spending most of your waking and sleeping hours with them for the second half of the semester so be sure these are people you can trust to be on top of their work and whom you can trust to call you out if you're not on top of your work. Being in a group with two amazing friends who also happened to be amazingly responsible and good at coding made my experience infinitely better than it might have otherwise been. 
2. Don't expect much guidance from the TAs. Most of them don't have any useful experience, and even if they do, it's probably not exactly what you need anyway. The skills you need to complete a project are weirdly specific that you'll probably become an expert on the platforms that you use and nothing else.
3. Don't let your performance fall off towards the end when you have to focus on presenting and writing up a report. This is what the graders will see and this will be their impression of your group, so even if you've created an amazing app but don't present it well, you might not get the best results. Grading seems like a very arbitrary process in this class, unfortunately, so be the best used car salesman you can with your project. 

This class will so annoying at times but you'll probably come out with at least a grudging sense of pride and accomplishment at the end!

Almost all of the value in this class comes from the project. Lectures are useful in the first half of the semester, especially if you have little experience with large software systems and web development, in particular. But other than that, the class is all about the project. You will have to find and learn how to use software tools and frameworks on your own, which is a great experience for the "real world". Also you get experience working with a team, designing/planning a (moderately) large-scale project, and presenting your work to a panel. I would say the course is a must-take for any COS major just for these experiences. I recommend coming into the course with both a group that you are comfortable with (emphasis on being comfortable with the group -- you will have to work with them openly, honestly, and effectively) and a project idea. Or, if you don't have a group, find one early in the semester.

Almost every COS major takes this course anyway, but it's pretty time consuming but also rewarding. Wouldn't necessarily recommend to anyone not COS or not going into software, but a pretty good class as far as the COS department goes.

Amazing class that gives you the chance to turn your crazy ideas into realities. Don't slack on the assignments since they might sneak up on you. As far as the final project goes, do your best, start early. Ask for help and try to research the frameworks and technologies as much as you can. It also helps to come into this class with a group and an idea in mind beforehand.
Amazing class! Gives you a good overview of the most relevant coding languages of today and gives you a taste of what doing industry for COS might be like.

An amazing class that was the highlight of my COS experience so far at Princeton :) I think that every COS student should take this class at some point! It's the most accurate simulation of reality / work in the software industry I've encountered. Of course it's not an easy class, but I think you really get out what you put in, especially with the group project. The group project was a time-sink (and something that was always on the back of my mind for the last 6 weeks of the semester) - BUT - I'm so happy with what I accomplished together with my group, and wouldn't trade that feeling for anything else.

An excellent opportunity to get more experience in group projects. Make sure you pick a group that is interested in the project; ideally get the project idea down before the semester starts, or as early as possible. It is also important you have at least one person experienced and/or very interested in back-end stuff and at least one person experienced and/or very interested in front-end stuff. Unfortunately work on things I wasn't really interested in and didn't gain much technical knowledge, but I'd say the organizational skills and lessons I learned about working collaboratively on large projects made the class worth it by itself.

As you might've heard, this course is truly an amazing experience. Take it for the project -- working on something for a span of 2 months and seeing your idea take shape into a real product is a magical thing!
Assignment during first semester are somewhat challenging but the design project is very fun.

Assignments aren't really useful but force you to deep dive into StackOverflow to understand new programming languages (maybe that's a reflection of the real world?). Final Project is literally the reason you should take this class. Be warned, they not just expect a well designed app but something which is engineeringly complex (which they could be more clear about)
Be proactive with your project and start early.

Beware as a sophomore without much experience?the majority of the lectures went right over my head and the project was obviously more challenging to get started. Kernighan is great. Assignments are pretty good even though grading can be rough if you have bugs you don't know about. Project was cool even though it was pretty stressful for us. Overall worth taking, just ask yourself what you want to get out of it in considering the timing of taking it.

Class becomes much easier and fun once the assignments are over and you start working on your project. One of the easiest COS departmentals out there (which is a good thing because the rest are atrociously time-consuming).

Decent course and a good way to get a systems departmental especially if you're not a systems person (me). I definitely learned a lot. The final project ended up being pretty fun, but that was in large part because I was lucky enough to get a good group. We also started pretty early (take advantage of those breaks!) and so the work was distributed more evenly, rather than all last minute.
Definitely take this class! The project is an immensely useful and fun experience.
Definitely take this class. The big project at the end of the year is really fun.

Definitely take this course, especially when Professor Kernighan is teaching it. He is a great lecturer and an experience you don't want to regret missing out on while at Princeton! The experience of working with a group on a larger-scale project is not really matched in any other course, so definitely worth taking.
Definitely take this course, there is the potential to gain so much, and you will work on a project that you can talk about in Interviews and will gain a lot of relevant skills.

Don't take this class if you already know you don't like web development. You will find the project tedious and stressful even if you are doing it with your friends. The assignments are unenlightenting and do a great job teaching all the ways that working in a software company can be intensely frustrating and unrewarding.

Don't take this class unless you have a lot of software development experiences. If you don't have a lot of experience, just learn those things by yourself, do not bother to take this class. You will not learn anymore than you would have on yourself. If you want to learn making apps, go to udemy buy a course on android or IOS. If you want to do web, go learn that. Do not waste your time in this class.
Don't take this without prior app development experience. Very tough to do well otherwise.
Don't take unless you need a cos systems req.  I've heard awful stories about other cos systems reqs, and this one seems about as good / bad as the others.

Don't wait until the last minute to start the assignments, and go to Lab TAs at the first sign of trouble. Also, start the project as early as possible and keep to your deadlines. Plan ahead and you should be okay.

Everyone tells you to take this course if you are COS and they are right! If you actually have some backbone and aren't convinced by the peer-pressure, here are some reasons to do so: no exams, lecture is optional (but it actually talks about real-world stuff that your lame theory class can't juju on), if your final project isn't excrement you will get a decent grade. Stop wasting time; register for this class now!! (all of this applies to Kernighan   Moretti but I'm sure Dondero will also do a spicy job)

Excellent class. I learned a lot, and feel really proud of my project. Try to find a team that you know will work well together and start early. Establish a good workflow among yourselves and you'll have a good time. One of the best CS departmentals for sure.

Fantastic course for a COS student wanting to work in industry. If you do your final project even vaguely well, it's great resume booster. Try to come with a group and idea, but I had neither and ended up okay. But don't be surprised if you end up pulling dead weight in your group.
Find a good group and a good project. Start early!
Find a good project group and don't slack on the assignments
Find a group of people that are as driven to work on a project as you are!
Find partners! Work with people you can work with! Don't be too ambitious with your project idea!
For me and my friends, the most valuable experience was the final project.

For someone with no industry knowledge, lectures were often helpful in consolidating vast topics of general programming know-how. The assignments were pretty hard for me (not a COS major), but were interesting. The final project was awesome, but could have easily been my worst nightmare without a good group. Kernighan is fun, if not a bit sadistic in his sense of humor about student work. Would recommend to anyone wanting to learn actually useful material at Princeton!
Fun course, but massive workload. Find a project group early and get started ASAP.

Go for story time with Kernighan, he's dope.  (But in all seriousness, he cares a lot about his students and is full of great advice).  Also note that you'll need to get some Unix environment operating on your computer, so rip windows users

Go to office hours for the first half! Lectures don't really discuss things relevant to the assignment, so make sure you can figure out things/make time to go to office hours (but there's a lot of them so that should be fine). Lectures are pretty funny, Kernighan is great, and go if you want to learn a bit about a bunch of different programming languages. When it comes down to it, the only languages you'll actually be using are C, Java, Python, and a tiny bit of Awk. There are also a lot of guest lectures that are kind of hit or miss. 

Really work on the final project during the second half. The last couple weeks are going to heavily reflect how much work you did starting out, and if you don't space things out well, it could be a disaster. Do note that the final presentation/demo/turning in final files can take up a lot of time during reading period so be prepared for that. A lot of the final project will be on you, so don't expect your TA to be of that much help during meetings (mine wasn't helpful at all since he didn't have any experience with the language we were working with).
Great chance to test out skills and get your hands dirty. You will learn how to actually get a real app off the ground in a way that no other class will teach you.
Great class!
Great course, go to office hours for Assignment 5! I feel like I learned a lot from the assignments and the project. Make sure it's your only thing due Friday night!
Great systems requirement. Lectures can be a tad bit boring, but the project is a lot of fun (just don't start at the last second).

I could see how this would be a great class if you have some experience and want to take it further with other smart people with different experiences and specialties. But I expected this to be a structured way to learn how to program things in the real world- instead, it felt like doing a bunch of tutorials and reading stack overflow pages on my own.
I don't think I learned anything.

I overall enjoyed this course, but it's definitely not a course to be taken lightly. The weekly assignments can take a while, and the final project is quite the undertaking. Be sure you find a good group project.
I recommend this course for the hands on experience you'll get working on a large-scale project

I recommend this course to anyone thinking of a career in software development. The final project is fun to work on, and it provides an experience that is similar to what you will do outside of course work. Finding a group that you can get along with, and starting early are extremely important. My project group started having weekly meetings from week two, and we didn't have trouble finishing our project, timewise. Although, I heard that the final project could be painful if a significant portion of the work is left to the last minute.
I would recommend this course, especially to fulfill a COS systems requirement.
I would take the course but be on top of your work.
If you are interested in coding, this class is the best. Kernighan was amazing, and the assignments and project were fun to work on.
If you are not already experienced/interested in software engineering, this course will not bring you any more experience or interest.

If you have little dev experience, you will be doing a lot of self teachings. A very breadth class that is very hands off. Wish there had been more direction. A good class to take to see if you like software dev.

If you haven't really programmed outside of class before, definitely take it for the practical knowledge you'll gain. If you already know topics like JSON, Client-server models, a decent variet of compiled and scripting language, and have worked on projects outside of class, you probably won't learn too much, but the guest lectures are worth it.
If you're a COS major who graduates without taking this course, what are you even doing?
It's 333. Just take it
It's an easy systems, if you hate systems classes this is the one to take.

Learning to do a real project with your friends is the most valuable part of this course. It is super important and is a huge part of the course. Personally I found the technologies talked about in this course to be pretty common and something that a lot of people already knew or could learn from google. Actually using the technologies is the fun part.

Make sure that you are prepared to put a fair amount of time into the course with the weekly assignments during the first half of the course.  That said, the project is a super rewarding, unique and enjoyable experience -- would definitely recommend!
Make sure you have your idea going in, and a good project group. Assignments are not too hard, and there are tons of office hours. Not a difficult course in terms of time commitment or effort.
Overall great course, very applicable to real life

Pick a group that you work well with because you will have to work with them for half a semester. There may be some late nights and bleak periods when nothing works. Also, pick technologies that are established, especially if you don't have a lot of experience.

Potentially an overhyped course. I came in expecting this to be the programming course to rule them all. Unfortunately, the assignments are much more tedious than difficult and you don't learn much that you couldn't outside of school. Even the average software internship gives you much more. 
What's great about this class however is that Kernighan and Moretti are great. The best part was Kernighan's weekly wass appointments that are available, where you can go in and seek general COS career/research advice from the great master himself.
TLDR: take this class if Kernighan is teaching but be aware that the main benefits of this class do not come from course content. Lectures were great, and you also get to hear from guest speakers in industry (eric schmidt, bjarne stroustrup).
Professor Kernighan is a brilliantly devious man. Watch out for his skillful command of that command line. Also, could someone in the future make a better course evaluations website?
Project is very interesting and cool to do, lectures can be boring
Sometimes assignments are frustrating but it's nice to apply programming in a practical way.  Start your final assignment early!
Start the project early, and get a group that you will enjoy working with. If I didn't have a fun group, this would have been a miserable class.
Take it
Take it because it helps you be a better software engineer.
Take it for the group work.

Take it if you dont have an application/major project on your resume, and ESPECIALLY if you havent had a computer science internship yet but want to try out for computer science jobs. it will give you something to talk about in interviews and a sense of what 'real world programming' is like. its also what you make of it so find a good group of people you like but also more importantly work well with! i really like my group as people and we also did a pretty good job of keeping each other honest and on track, so that was helpful. would have sucked if i was working with people who i didnt fit well with for some reason.
Take it if you like intensity. There's atime crunch with the assignments in the beginning, and the project at the end.
Take it if you need to, probably the best systems track course.
Take it if you want to work on a group project, take what you want out of it

Take it only if you're interested in making a project. The first half of the course are 5 mostly uninteresting assignments, and I didn't get very much out of the lectures. The project experience was fantastic though.
Take it to actually learn building a product
Take it!

Take it! As someone who didn't have a lot of experience in a variety of languages and tools, this course really expanded that. I wish I took it sooner. The assignments can be a little frustrating, but you do learn something. The project is the main benefit to this course though. You learn how to do so many new things and finish with a final product you can be proud of.

Take it, but take the project very seriously. Start early, put serious thought into how you organize your work, get user feedback, and don't forget to put effort into making it look professional. The project will always take more time than you think it will!

Take this class as a COS minor if you want coding experience with friends. If this class is taught by Moretti or Kernighan, you are in luck. Take this class with friends and know probably with whom you want to work for the final project, and start early. Enjoy! (You better be looking this up on princetoncourses.com)!

Take this class if you have a light schedule otherwise. It is hard, and assignments and the project will CONSUME your life. Also make sure you have a good group early on, otherwise you will be alone and confused.
Take this class! Doing the project was a lot of fun and I learned more from that than any of my other COS classes here. Definitely helps if you have a good idea and a good team.

Take this class! Find a good project group early on (experience matters less in my opinion than being able to get along well and have a good time with each other). Find a project you're passionate about, and I would suggest starting on the final project early (i.e. before Spring Break). You will thank yourself at the end of the semester.
Take this course and start assignments early. Work on the final project as early as possible.

Take this course! It's quite an experience, and you'll definitely learn many valuable things about teamwork in software development, and general real-life experience for making programming projects happen.

Take this! Excellent course that teaches more practical material. Get a good group, go in with an idea. Even if you love your group members, there WILL be conflict. Also, don't expect there to be too much support in your app. You must be really self-driven, but use this class as an excuse/to force you to build something you've always wanted to. Also: choose the more difficult project idea. It will be more rewarding at the end.

The course is definitely worth taking if not for anything else than the chance to finally have some dedicated time to work on a real, substantial project. Choose a project that you're interested in and really want to work on. Lectures aren't very useful, most people just feel bullied into attending them during the second half of the course due to the randomly selected groups that had to present elevator pitches about their project during every lecture.

The course was enjoyable and I learnt a lot for sure, however, towards the end of the course I was really disappointed by the way we were given feedback on our projects. We received emails with graders' comments, and while no comments that our group received were too derogatory some of my friends received comments that were not constructive in any way, and straight up rude and derogatory. As a student who put in so much effort in not only this class, but all of my classes this semester, I believe that sending out comments and feedback like that shows a complete lack of empathy for the amount of time we have invested in this. I do not know which TAs made these comments but I thought it was extremely unfair for some of my friends to have received the comments and feedback that they did, regardless of what their overall grade was
The lectures are usually pretty interesting, but really you take this course for the project. Get a good group before enrolling, your project group will make or break you.
The reviews speak for themselves. Amazing course, amazing professor, amazing guest lecturers

This class is one of the most hands-on practical COS classes at Princeton. You spend the first half of the semester doing weekly programming assignments, most of which were interesting and force you to work with fairly large codebases. The second half of the semester is dedicated to the course project which can be an incredible learning experience.

This could be a great course, and if you get a good team it can still be a unique, fun experience. However, the organization and teaching make it so much worse than it could be. I'd say that you could go either way on this one. If you want to experience app or web development, go for it, but don't expect much from lectures.

This course has incredible reviews, and I definitely learned a lot. That said, I have to offer a word of caution. If you're coming in with no web design experience, you are WOEFULLY underprepared for the final project. It's doable, but it's exhausting. If you are a senior with a thesis thinking of taking this course, DO NOT unless you have to. I suppose it may be the lesser evil in terms of systems courses, but this is basically more independent work added to your thesis. Otherwise, if you don't have a crazy busy semester, it's worthwhile.
This course is great! Find a group that you enjoy working with and make sure you do something that is interesting. You'll have a lot of fun working on it then.

This course is much more about breadth than it is about depth. Often times it will feel like you are covering random topics/languages and that you don't know much/anything about, and because of the shallow coverage, you will still feel that way at the end of their coverage. The assignments can feel random, but make sure you put in the time because they're worth a hefty amount of the grade, and there's not many of them. Working on the project is very rewarding, but only if you choose something you ACTUALLY care about. When choosing your team, make sure to have people of different backgrounds and specialties, AND START EARLY. It will make things much easier later on.

This course is not as great as everyone says it is. The first half is manageable if you start the assignments a reasonable time. The second half is mostly about the project. If you have an idea you really want to develop, you'll have a great time. Lectures in the second half are kind of useless and unorganized. It was worth it because I had a great team, and it was probably less painful than OS.

This is a course where you learn how to learn new programming languages and tools. I came in with no web development experience and left with a web app that hundreds of Princeton students use every day.

This is a must-take course if you are a COS major. You will learn a ton by working on the group project and come away with highly applicable skills. Kernighan is a good lecturer and brings in several awesome guest speakers. If you're doing things right, it will be quite a bit of work, so go into the course knowing who you want to work with and get started early.
This is a really great course that I think should be required for all COS certificate students. Take it with Kernighan and get to know him!

This is an excellent course if you enjoy technical projects or would like to give it a try. If you start the project early, you can build things that are truely awesome and impactful. Unfortunately the lectures are of relatively little value: you cover many different technical topics in superficial detail. Many students (myself included) simply worked on our assignments or projects on our laptops during the lecture. I would encourage the course staff to re-think the content of the lectures to cover topics that can't simply be easily self-taught by reading the documentation or browsing Stack Overflow. Despite the disappointing lectures, this is an awesome class that I would recommend to all COS majors.
This is the class where you build a project during the second half.  It's barely a systems class.

Try to take this course as early as you can in your Princeton career! It'll cover a ton of material that will help you very much in your future classes and internships. However, as a senior, there isn't a whole lot to gain from it, but I still really enjoyed it and am still glad I experienced this legendary course.
Unbelievable course, start early on the project, build something great
Very cool class. Take it to hear from a legend every week for 3 hours. Assignments are kind of bland but really helpful to get basic knowledge of many languages.
Very good course. Find a good group to do the project with and be invested in your project idea so you can learn a lot. I learned a lot in this course.
You will spend many sleepless nights on the project, but it will be all worth it at the end. It's a semester-long hackathon, and you will really learn to work with your partners.
definitely take but have a group that you enjoy working with.
one of the most applicable courses I've taken. 10/10 would recommend.
otherinfo: This course is NOT open to Continuing Education and Graduate students.
grading: Design Project - 50%, Programming Assignments - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: There will be a number of programming assignments and a term project. The project will be done in groups and will involve creation of a major piece of software, the purpose of which each group will choose.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: This is a course about the practice of programming. Programming is more than just writing code. Programmers must also assess tradeoffs, choose among design alternatives, debug and test, improve performance, and maintain software written by themselves & others. At the same time, they must be concerned with compatibility, robustness, and reliability, while meeting specifications. Students will have the opportunity to develop these skills by working on their own code and in group projects.
title: Advanced Programming Techniques

otherreq: Open to BSE COS Concentrators Only.
otherinfo: The COS department will offer "independent work seminars" this fall. The idea is to allow students and a faculty adviser with shared interests to meet as a group and work on related projects. Please refer to http://www.cs.princeton.edu/ugrad/independent-work for additional information.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: A list of independent research topics including each professor's research area is available at http://www.cs.princeton.edu/ugrad/independent-work/undergraduate-research-topics. No formal assignments, but the student is expected to average at least 10-15 hours per week and to make regular progress reports to the student's faculty advisor. Each student will make a short public presentation of work in progress at mid-semester, participate in a poster session and deliver a final report .
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. Refer to course web page for additional details.
title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)

evals: An interesting course. Professor Mittal is a very nice man but not particularly engaging. He is excited about the material though which is nice. The course had no midterm which I loved and divided work and final fairly.

Easy way to satisfy the applications requirement, especially if you've taken networks or operating systems. The content has the potential to be interesting, but Mittal isn't the most engaging lecturer.
If you want to know basic idea about network security, this is the right course.
Important and relevant area to study, even just for everyday computing. Workload is manageable

Solid high-level introduction to information security. Will help you develop a good intuition about security, but don't expect to get into the cryptographic or systems details involved. First few assignments can be tricky; last few assignments are mostly just design.
Take it if you are at all interested in encryption, security, etc. Not very demanding work-wise.
Take it!! Prateek and the assignments were super engaging!
Take the class if you are interested in security. Try to find a professor that works for you. The class tends to be small in the Spring, so bear that in mind when deciding.
Take this class. Prateek is great.
Take this course. Information security is WAY cooler than it sounds, and learning about this field practically screams that this sector will play a huge role in the near and far futures.

The main drawback of this course was that the TA was extremely unresponsive. A few times, I emailed him a question or posted a question on Piazza a few days before the deadline of an assignment only to receive a reply a few days after the deadline had passed, which was frustrating. 

The assignments were also sometimes vague.

However, overall, the course was very interesting, as were the assignments. Prateek is very passionate about security and is always up to discuss anything and everything security related. I'd recommend this class to everyone, especially to those who have an interest in security.
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Programming Assignments - 65%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: There will be periodic assignments. Some assignments will involve programming, some will involve design of security procedures and protocols, and some will involve critiquing designs and protocols.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Security issues in computing, communications, and electronic commerce. Goals and vulnerabilities; legal and ethical issues; basic cryptology; private and authenticated communication; electronic commerce; software security; viruses and other malicious code; operating system protection; trusted systems design; network security; firewalls; policy, administration and procedures; auditing; physical security; disaster recovery; reliability; content protection; privacy.
title: Information Security

grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Design Project - 45%, Programming Assignments - 35%, Quizzes - 5%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%
assgts: 5 individual assignments and 1 group project that involves the design and implementation of an interactive system.
prereqs: COS 217 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Creating technologies that fit into people's everyday lives involves more than having technically sophisticated algorithms, systems, and infrastructure. It involves understanding how people think and behave and using this info. to design user-facing interfaces that enhance and augment human capabilities. You will be introduced to the field of human-computer interaction and the tools, techniques, and principles that guide research on people. Design and implement user-facing systems that bring joy rather than frustrate the user and put these skills into practice in a semester long group project involving the creation of an interactive system.
title: Human-Computer Interface Technology

evals: As a second theory course, it's not too bad. Definitely go to office hours for help on the psets
Awesome class with an awesome professor, although the assignments are very mathematical / challenging, so if you aren't great with proofs it might be hard.
Bernard Chazelle is a cool guy. The TA's suck.
Better class to take than 423 for theory, some homeworks were near impossible, others were fun to do!
Chazelle is an awesome professor. Tough problem sets, but there are only 4 and a final project.

Comparable to 340, but with more interesting material. Chazelle is a great lecturer, even if some of his lectures went over my head. Not all directly pertinent to the problem sets, however (especially later ones). But, the point of the class seems to be to gain an appreciation for computational geometry as a field, which it was successful in doing. 

Take it for the theory req. It's not a bad option. You'll learn a few cool things.
Definitely a good course to take as a theory course.
Don't take it unless if you have an interest, or if there's really no other possibility for the theory distribution. I did not enjoy this class.

Good class if you are a math genius and can follow Chazelle splashing his brilliant brain onto the board. If you are looking class where lectures, problem sets, and exams are organized, structured, and in sync with each other, this is a not it.

If you need a second theory for a COS departmental and like fun shapes and an entertaining lecturer, I'd definitely recommend. Be warned that you should make friends with math majors because sometimes it requires a decent amount mathematical maturity in proof writing. Though Chazelle tried to make sure that for some questions it was more about critical thinking rather than knowing the exact linear algebra behind some question. Definitely appreciated that. I like this class a lot and Chazelle is the man. So just take it. You know you wanna. Oh, but be warned, lecture notes he puts online aren't informative and don't cover everything. Go to class. It's entertaining, don't worry.
If you need another Theory COS class and you hated 340, take it. It's probably the least bad one out there. But be warned that the lectures almost never coincide with the problem sets.

Make sure you understand what you're signing up for. The class is not categorically bad, but you will not enjoy it terribly if it is very different from what you are expecting (as is the case for all classes).
Not awful for a theory course, but I wouldn't take it unless it's required. The material isn't very interesting, and the problem sets were pretty hard.
Prepare to do a lot of learning outside of class. The final projects look kind of fun though, and a breeze compared to the rest of the assignments.

Prof.Chazelle is bomb. He's super fun, and you will not be disappointed by the course either.
( Although you may not like his style, so sit in to decide if you want to take it)

Professor Chazelle is an incredible lecturer and figure in the field. The topics are always interesting and well presented. Problem sets don't depend too much on lectures and have problems of various difficulties, so they're challenging to complete without taking too long overall.
Such a fun class with such a fantastic professor (take it with Chazelle!), but the problem sets are also really hard. 10/10 would recommend taking.

TAKE IT if you need a theory departmental. I hated 340. This was much more manageable. There is much less work than 340, and the final project can be interesting if you want it to be. Chazelle is also entertaining during lecture.

TAKE IT! probably the easiest theory for COS. I say this not having taken 340. Chazelle is funny and always willing to answer pset questions. although most lectures went over my head and I spent significant time working on the psets.
Take it for Chazelle's lectures.
Take the course if you can; it's not offered every year.
The course is fairly challenging, although there are not as many psets.

This course was the only theory class offered my senior fall so I took it. Professor Chazelle is eccentric and engaging, made the lectures very enjoyable. There were 4 problem sets, which were very time consuming and a final project. Not an easy theory class, but would still recommend it. The problems can be reasoned about visually which is nice for a theory class.
This is a good and interesting theory course to take. Chazelle is really the best and most entertainning CS professor you will find

Work in groups - unless you're some sort of math genius, the problems are far too difficult to complete on your own. You can probably get by in the class without going to lectures (the questions often had nothing to do with the lecture material), but if you actually want to understand computational geometry, you should go to class as often as possible.
You really don't need a lot of background. The amount of work is very fair. And you will have a great time if you like math.
really worthwhile theory. hard but not too hard and chazelle is awesome
grading: Programming Assignments - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Several problem sets and programming assignments, plus final project.
prereqs: COS 226 and COS 340..
descrip: This course introduces the basic concepts of geometric computing, illustrating the importance of this field for a variety of applications areas, such as computer graphics, solid modeling, robotics, database, pattern recognition, and statistical analysis. Algorithms are presented and analyzed for a large number of geometric problems, and an array of fundamental techniques are discussed (e.g., convex hulls, Voronoi diagrams, intersection problems, multidimensional searching).
title: Computational Geometry

evals: Full of math majors. Take another course for your theory requirement if you're a COS major.
Good theory course overall, not too much work, problem sets are challenging but doable .
Interesting class and not too bad of a workload

It's a really cool theory course about computability and complexity. The problem sets generally weren't too difficult. You have definitely have to put work into them though, because  they're your whole grade (each one is 20%). Tarjan is brilliant, though he can be kind of intimidating.
Not too bad of a theory course for COS if you need it. Read the textbook!!!
Not too much work and really interesting material!
Take it if you need a departmental
Take it if you're interested in theory.
Take this course if you want a good course in theoretical CS.

Tarjan is a really nice professor who gives relatively little work consisting of fair questions that he sometimes solves for you in lecture. His lectures are all you've heard, but you can learn something if you pay attention.
The course if fair and not too work-intensive. I did not personally find it very interesting, but if you're interested in computational complexity, it's a pretty standard course.

This class is a good theory departmental for COS. The course staff really wanted us to learn and we learned a lot without going at the ridiculous pace of 340. The only problem with the course is that some of the proof details get glossed over frequently so it's difficult to learn to write really solid, complete proofs.
This isn't an easy course by any means, and problem sets can be graded harshly. Only take if you feel confident in your proofs

Very interesting material, and very important if you want to understand complexity theory. 
Definitely take if you are interested in either CS or math. 
The course was really well-run. There was not too much work, and was very manageable.
Very theoretical, interesting material. Tarjan's not the most interesting lecturer, but he knows the material well. Problem sets were all natural extensions of class material and were not too hard.
You probably will be better off self-studying the material.
grading: Problem set(s) - 70%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: 5-6 problem sets during the term. Final assignment in lieu of exam, worth 30%
prereqs: COS 340 or equivalent mathematical maturity. (Basically the ability to do proofs).
descrip: Introduction to computability and complexity theory. Topics will include models of computation such as automata, and Turing machines; decidability and decidability; computational complexity; P, NP, and NP completeness; others.
title: Theory of Computation

otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
