otherinfo: Books under "Sample Reading" are available online through the Princeton University library.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 15%, Design Project - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Approximately 6 homework assignments. Some may involve programming. Reading assignments will be textbook chapters or sections and conference/journal papers.
prereqs: COS 226 and some experience with linear algebra..
descrip: Complex networks arise through the analysis of complex systems in many areas of study. Well known areas include social network analysis (e.g. Facebook friends), text citation analysis (e.g. Wikipedia) and biological network analysis (e.g. protein-protein interactions). Complex networks can be distinguished from random networks and from regular networks, such as grids, which are often created by design for applications such as interconnecting computers. This course examines methods of analysis of complex networks and how this analysis can be applied to enhance our understanding of real-world systems.
title: Special Topics in Computer Science - Complex Networks - Analysis and Applications

otherreq: Open to BSE COS Concentrators Only.
otherinfo: The COS department will offer "independent work seminars" this fall. The idea is to allow students and a faculty adviser with shared interests to meet as a group and work on related projects. Please refer to http://www.cs.princeton.edu/ugrad/independent-work for additional information.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: A list of independent research topics including each professor's research area is available at: http://www.cs.princeton.edu/ugrad/independent-work/undergraduate-research-topics. No formal assignments, but the student is expected to average at least 10-15 hours per week and to make regular progress reports to the student's faculty advisor. Each student will make a short public presentation of work in progress at mid-semester, participate in a poster session and deliver a final report.
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.
title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)

evals: As a COS major with an interest in theoretical CS, this was one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. Prof. Arora and Prof. Kothari are both amazing lecturers, and keep the lectures very engaging and interesting. Both of them tried very hard and succeeded at really providing intuition and insight into the material. The lectures were light when it came to computation and calculations, and focused more on exposing the student to the variety of topics presented. The homework's really tested understanding of the material, and for most of the part, very hard ( >40 hrs/pset). This course is definitely hard, but also really well taught. Definitely would recommend to anyone who has an interest in CS theory and the necessary background!
Go to office hours. Problem sets will take a lot of work. Use past years' notes if the current year's notes are not up on the website.
Go to office hours. Set aside time to learn the proofs you go over in class.
I would highly recommend taking this course! Pravesh and Sanjeev are fantastic lecturers, and the material is very, very interesting.

If you're lost, ask *immediately* in class. It will not become more clear if you wait, you will only get more lost.

Work in teams. Solving the homework on your own is nearly impossible if you don't have a strong theory background.

Make sure you are sufficiently well versed in linear algebra. Having taken a related class 3  years ago is not sufficiently well versed. Prepare to sink 10-20 hours into each problem set. There are 4-5 of these.

This course covers a wide range of many useful advanced algorithms. The instructors do a great job of motivating the topics and explaining them succinctly. Highly recommend this course.
Be warned that the assignments could get be very challenging

This is a great course with amazing lecture quality (clear, giving a lot of intuition).
Problem sets can go beyond what's covered in lecture and take a considerable amount of time, so make sure you have the time to invest in them. Extremely helpful TA.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Advanced methods of algorithmic design and analysis: data structures, network flows, and linear programming. Solution of linear programs: Karmarkar and Ellipsoid algorithms. Probabilistic techniques. A selection of topics from on-line computation, approximation algorithms for NP-hard problems, number theoretic algorithms, geometric algorithms, and parallel computation.
title: Advanced Algorithm Design

evals: Anastasia was the best and most clear lecturer. Overall the class would have been great, but the AIs greatly reduced the quality and experience of the class. However, I still learned a lot by doing the problem sets, even though the instructions could be vague at times.

Are you a CS student? Turn around. Don't waste your time.

Are you a biology student? Do you think you need an entire class to learn how to make pretty pictures? You should take this class. If you think you don't need an entire class to learn to make pretty pictures, spend your time somewhere more useful.
I recommend this to anyone that wants to get a broad overview of genomics and would like to learn a little bit about the programming involved in doing high-level analysis of *omics datasets.
The material is interesting, but the class was disorganized, and getting help on problem sets can be a pain.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Introduction to basic computational methods used for problems arising in molecular biology. Topics include computational approaches to: sequence similarity and alignment, phylogenic inference, gene recognition, gene expression analysis, structure prediction, and whole- and cross-genome analysis.
title: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Prerequisites: Strong knowledge of algorithm design and analysis (eg COS423 or COS521) and theoretical ML (e.g., COS511)..
descrip: This advanced seminar explores how to develop rigorous and interpretable ways of thinking about recent practical advances in ML. Along the way we make excursions into deep learning, optimization theory, statistics, bayesian modeling, natural language processing, vision, reinforcement learning, etc. The instructor gives 2/3rds of the lectures, and the remaining lectures are devoted to student presentations, discussions, etc.
title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - New directions in theoretical machine learning

evals: Be prepared to put time into it. However it is a more interesting theory than any other theory, in my opinion.
Definitely take this course, even if you have satisfied your theory requirement. It is an appropriate amount of work, and you will learn a lot about formal verification.
Depends. If the topic is related to their research they should take it.
Dope theory course. Not too much work
Great course if you are looking to satisfy your theory department or if interesting in formal software verification techniques.

Great way to fulfill COS theory requirement. Reasonable workload and professor is very passionate about the material. Office hours are very helpful. Lectures are a bit confusing/dense, but not as intense as some other theory classes.

I strongly recommend this course to other students. You will learn a lot of interesting things in this course, from a great instructor, that are not only intellectually stimulating and interesting by themselves, but also can be applied to many other areas.

I would strongly recommend this course, as program verification is an area of major research and one becoming increasingly important in simply the act of programming--many companies use automated verification tools to check for common errors in performance-critical code. It's simply an important topic to know about. Prof. Aarti Gupta is also very accessible and eager to talk to students, so the course is doubly worth taking if she is teaching it.
It is worth taking, especially for covering the department requirement.
It's an interesting introduction to and overview of the current state of formal verification.

Take if for your second theory! It's less abstract than COS 340. It is challenging, but very rewarding. There is a lot of support from the professor. Also, the material is very interesting and relevant.
Take it!
Very good introduction to related fields.  Schedules and assignments were flexible and the course was great.
otherinfo: Course available to COS graduates. Grads outside department and undergrads to take it with instructor approval. If you need approval to enter the course, please contact the instructor
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course covers recent developments in distributed systems. The main component of the course is reading recent papers from top systems conference (e.g., SOSP, OSDI, NSDI) and discussing them in class. We cover papers on a variety of topics within distributed systems to give students a broad view of where the field is moving. In addition, students dive deep into one subarea to produce a short survey paper that compares several recent papers and then identifies the most promising directions within that subarea for future research.
title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Recent Developments in Distributed Systems

evals: I strongly recommend this course.

If you are interested in art, game design and music, this course is for you to develop something beautiful and playful. You also get to meet some leading researchers in the field of interactive illustrations.
It's very self-paced; you get what you put in.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
descrip: This seminar explores recent developments in image processing, manipulation, analysis, and synthesis, including data-driven and deep-learning-based methods.
title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Advances in Image Processing

evals: This course does an excellent job at presenting algorithmic methods that have been created to reason about concurrent systems/programs.
nothing
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The seminar focuses on proving lower bounds for various computational models. In particular, we focus on Boolean circuit complexity, communication complexity, arithmetic circuit complexity, and recent time-space tradeoff lower bounds for learning. The seminar is mainly intended for graduate students in theoretical computer science or math, as well as for undergraduate students with a very strong mathematical background. The last few lectures are devoted to student presentations.
title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Lower Bounds for Computational Models

evals: I would suggest taking this course if a student is interested in security.
If you are interested in hardware or computing system, it's a good class for you to take.
grading: Programming Assignments - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
descrip: Machine learning discovers and reproduces patterns in existing data. Thus, unthinking application of machine learning risks perpetuating societal biases including racial and gender bias. This seminar studies the emerging science of fairness in machine learning. Readings cover: sources of bias in machine learning; methods for detecting, measuring, and mitigating bias; individual fairness, group fairness, and the tension between them; connections between fairness and privacy; bias in algorithmic decision making; bias in unsupervised machine learning. Students take on hands-on empirical projects of their choosing.
title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Fairness in Machine Learning

evals:
Be prepared to do a lot of reading and self teaching in this course. Thermodynamics itself is not a terribly complicated subject, but Dan makes it harder than it needs to be. 
The exam questions are nothing like the HW psets, so try your best to do well on the earlier midterms since the content is not challenging at that time. Dan is a terrible lecturer. He expects a lot on the lectures, yet has very little guidelines. You have to  hunt him down if you want the information. 
Other than that, don't take it if not required. Life will be much easier.
DO NOT take this course unless you have to for MAE requirements. You will not have a good time.
Even if it takes a while, do the readings in the book. Everything is covered much better in the book and you will feel like a boss.
Expect to spend the majority of your time on this course. Work load is intense, labs take a long time (>3 hours), and lab reports are intensive.

Hello student. Let me start off by saying congratulations on choosing MAE, it's a great major. Now, let me say I'm sorry. I'm very sorry that you have to take this class with Dan Steingart. This is the worst class I have ever taken and it'll probably be the worst for you too for one simple reason: Dan Steingart. Dan is a very bad lecturer. He teaches nothing in his lectures and yet expects a high amount of work from you. Do yourself a favor and don't go to a single one of the lecture; read the book and find a good youtube series to teach you thermodynamics because Dan sure isn't. 
Now I know what you're thinking, "I've had professors who can't teach." Sure you had. But Dan not only doesn't teach, but he expects you to know very obscure things on the exams and psets that you've never heard of before. He makes them very hard and you're expected to know everything. The labs are fun, but put aside ~15 hours for each lab report if you want a passing grade. Take advantage of the way homeworks set up to teach yourself the material. And for Dean's date and reading period, try not take too many classes with finals because the amount of work given for this class for Deans date prevents you from studying for any other finals. We had a design project (45 hours to completion working with 8 people), a take home lab (15 hours to completion with 4 people), two lab regrades (15 hours) a midterm due on Tuesday (with material I've never seen before), and a final on Thursday. The amount of work we had for this one class on Dean's date is more than 50% of student's have for all their classes combined. This class caused very significant stress and anxiety and I can't emphasize enough how bad of a teacher Dan is. In summary, put aside 20 hours a week for this class, and about 100 hours over reading period. Good luck.
Honestly I considered dropping mechanical and aerospace engineering solely because of this class, so I would likely not give any advice other than to take the class only if Dan was not teaching it.
I loved the class content and the professor and TA's, but when it came to exams and workload, thermo took over my life. Get ready to focus a great deal of your time on this class.
I think most students leave MAE because of this class; avoid it if you can (the LAB TA's are fantastic though; the lab parts of the lab are much better than the 103-104 labs)
I wouldn't really recommend this course if you aren't and MAE. It's important for MAE's and very interesting if that is your path, but its very involved.

I'd recommend not taking this unless you're really into thermo or you're required to. It has the potential to be a great course, and Prof. Steingart is working on it (and it's improving!), but there are still lots of problems, primarily with the disjoint between lectures, problem sets, and exams. Learn to teach yourself from the book, and generally you'll do fine. Otherwise, Steingart is a great guy to hang out with and talk about batteries/engineering in general.
If you must take it, do so. Make sure to stay on top of homework and concepts - it can get pretty tough!
If you're MAE you have to take it.  The material is not too hard but many students find that the class is disorganized.  If you feel lost in the class ever make sure you go to the professor.
If you're taking this course it is likely because it is a requirement. Dan is a fair and reasonable professor, but make sure to ask questions if his lectures aren't apparent at first
It's hard. Keep ahead from the first day.
Learn how to program python.  The labs and homework do require you do know how to code.
Lectures don't teach you very much, labs are a bit haphazard, and overall course seems to be a bit disjointed. Workload heavily skewed towards a ton of stuff all due on deans date.
Let me just say this. The class should not be called MAE 221: Thermodynamics. It should be called COS 221: Introduction to Pithy. If you are bad at coding or struggled in COS 126, then the course

Never take this class until they replace Dan Steingart as professor.  He is literally the worse professor at Princeton.  He is nice, the guy just can't teach and he will ruin you winter break with all of the end-of-term work.
Nice professor, bad class, but this shouldn't really matter to you if you're considering this class.
Only take it if you have to. It's a pretty rough course.
Only take this course if you have to, or if there is another professor.

Only take this if you're MAE. The readings are so much more important than the lectures. In fact, if you spend each hour of lecture reading the textbook instead, you will probably learn a lot more in the course. Do a good job on your cheat sheets for exams, they will come in handy.
Only take unless you have to. Awful course.
Take it if you're MAE

Take only if you are an MAE major. Read the textbook.
Be prepared for a lot of work. Go to prof. Steingart's office hours if you need help.

Take this course if you would like to learn how work and heat and energy come together to power the world.  This is strictly a course for MAE majors but it is not the worst investment of time even if you are not.  The material is interesting though it may not be obvious from the textbook or lab.

The course is interesting and you really learn a lot, but it sure is demanding. With 3 deans date assignments and a final, it is a bit excessive, but you sure learn a lot. Make sure to read the book, because lectures are a lot more theoretical, and to gain a more practical understanding of the material, you really have to read the book. You also really need coding experience to take this class.
The instruction makes the course difficult to appreciate, but the subject matter is interesting.
This class factored into my decision to drop out of MAE. It's far more trouble than its worth.

This course is probably more work than it should be, as it can take some time to gain any kind of intuition with the subject material. If you have to take it, stay on top of any readings, and take the time to solve problems by yourself

This is an awful course. This is probably the worst class I have ever taken. First you don't learn anything in lecture. Be prepared to teach yourself 100% of the material. But wait, there is more. You also have weekly labs and lab reports that take 15 hours to complete. They are so meticulous and time-consuming that you will literally spend 100% of your weekend typing up the report. You also have a final independent lab and final design project that take up so much effort that you might as well skip Christmas break and just lock yourself in your dorm room. Do not take this class.

Very easy to fall behind and be completely lost in the subject matter, make sure you keep up. Dan will often mention important things/announcements in lecture that don't show up on trello or blackboard, so if you miss class make sure you talk to someone who was there. Also make sure you don't spray yourself with boiling water in lab.
You have to take if for MAE, so too bad. Read lecture notes, don't bother with lectures or with the textbook.
You probably have to take it lol
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Design Project - 15%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Weekly reading assignments and problem sets, about 9 hours per week.
prereqs: PHY 103 and MAT 201. MAT 201 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Heat and work in physical systems. Concepts of energy conversion and entropy, primarily from a macroscopic viewpoint. Efficiency of different thermodynamic cycles, with applications to everyday life including both renewable and classical energy sources. In the laboratory, students will carry out experiments in the fields of analog electronics and thermodynamics.
title: Thermodynamics

evals: A reasonable class, but lectures are particularly hard to understand. Make sure you read the textbook.

Be prepared for the lectures to be utterly boring. However, Yannis is a nice guy (even though some people have issues with him being disorganized) and can be helpful if you go to his OHs. Take it if you want lighter workload than the fall semester and are okay self-teaching yourself.

Be prepared to attend all precepts because the TAs are the only reason why I can say I understand some of the material. Be prepared to work a good amount independent of scheduled instruction, because chances are you won't get much out of lecture.
Course was pretty disorganized. Yannis is leaving, so maybe he had less motivation. If you saw our piazza, you would find many angry rants. The psets were pretty annoying to do at times.

Differential equations is the most important math class I have ever taken in Princeton. Even if you are a physics major, and think you know all about diff eq., seeing it in a mathematical structure makes a very big difference.
Do not take this class with Professor Kevrekidis. It is complete and utter misery.

Do not take this course with Yannis. He cannot teach effectively at all. He makes simple concepts far more complicated than they need to be. If you skip every single lecture, and I mean EVERY lecture, you will learn the material far faster and at a greater depth. Plus, you will never get your exam grades back in a timely manner and will end up wondering what your midterm grade was during the finals period.
Don't take it.
Don't take unless you have to. Not tangible enough to be interesting, and it takes a fair amount of work to keep up with/do psets even if you are a math specialist.

Follow the textbook because the lectures are hard to follow and difficult to understand. If you read through the textbook, you'll be fine. Do the psets in Office Hours because some problems are really challenging. If you actually want to understand Diffeq with a strong conceptual background, take it in the fall with Professor Stone (will be more difficult, but you will properly learn the material).
Go to precepts if nothing else. Jeffrey is so brilliant as is everyone else.
Good class if you know how to self study. AIs are useful
Great course; do take!
I can't really complain about Kevrekidis, but he's not going to make you very fired up about differential equations. I've heard Stone is better but I'm not sure.

I honestly do not think I've had a worse course experience than this one at Princeton. Yannis's lectures are among the worst at Princeton (apparently he's leaving though so take this with a grain of salt), and I think the rest would follow suit from improvements there. The preceptors deserve more credit, as all three of them (Jeffrey, Wendy, Sravya) were fantastic and taught the material extremely well during precepts. I always dreaded precepts where Yannis would teach instead of the preceptors, don't go to those they're useless.
I love calculus and all its applications, especially to differential equations. However, this class is not a good use of your time. Take a different math class and learn this material on your own.

I took this assuming it would be easier than the Stone course in the Fall. THAT WAS DEAD WRONG. Not only do you get some of the same problems (Kevrekidis reuses Stone's), the lectures are so absolutely terrible that you can't possibly hope to succede without immense google-fu and getting answers in office hours. 11/10 do not recommend, just suck it up and take Stone if you need this course. Other ORFE's, get the fuck out of here.
I would only recommend if you must take it for your major.

I would recommend taking this course in the fall with Stone instead of the spring with Kevrikidis. The class is really difficult regardless of the semester, but it is way more rewarding to take it and understand it, since it has a lot of relevant applications.
If you can get yourself to feel excited about differential equations, this class will be a lot more fun for you. The exams were a bit long, but the questions were fair.
If you have Yannis, strap in
If you show up to class and pay attention, you'll do fine-- don't worry
If you want a more rigorous course, you should take it in the fall.
It's a math course what do you expect. Its better than most others I've taken.
It's a tough course. While the homework and exams are doable, learning the concepts can be quite difficult because the lectures are kind of confusing, but the textbook and precepts are very good.
It's probably easier than diff eq with Stone, but at the cost of not really understanding as much.
JUST DON'T DO IT! Wait to take it with Stone in the fall because Yannis is HORRIBLE HORRIBLE
Just take it if you need to take it. Other departmentals for ORFE are more interesting.
No longer and ORFE requirement. I would not take it as an ORFE major

Not too bad in terms of difficulty and amount of work. Lectures were tedious and not worth going to, while precepts were more concise and covered the same stuff. Although these reviews won't be that applicable in the future, since Yannis isn't teaching this course next spring.

Overall, this course (when taken with Prof. Kevrekidis) isn't too hard. If you find yourself still going to lectures late into the semester and learning alot in lecture then kudos to you. If not, then the book turns out to be a handy resource. The AI's for this course were great too. Their weekly review-sessions greatly summarized the concepts covered that week, and they devoted a lot of time to helping students on Psets duing their office hours. Basically, if you're not gaining much out of lecture, then 1-Read the book, 2- Go to the weekly review session(s) 3- Go to office hours, and you should do well in this edition of the course (if Yannis is still teaching it...)

Professor Kevrekidis is a great guy however, he is not a great instructor. If you don't have to take this course, DONT. It is the least organized course that I have ever seen which makes it frustrating. The material is not bad but you get assigned late and expected to finish everything by unreasonable deadlines. The Ads have no idea what the professor is up to. They are trying to be helpful but they seem to be also suffering from lack of planning for the course. This shouldn't be one of the 36 courses that you wanna take in Princeton.
Stay caught up with the reading!
Take it in the fall if you want to learn more. Otherwise decent class.
Take it with Stone, not Kevrekidis.
Take this class in the fall.
This class is probably much easier in the spring than in the fall. If you take it with Yannis and don't go to lecture and only read the book (but go to precept), you can do fine.
This is a pretty good course, it really just takes a bit of effort outside of lectures to unravel the different kinds of differential equations/processes.

This was a terribly taught class. It was also very poorly organized. The first midterm took 5 weeks to grade. There were times where we were "given" two weeks to complete assignments, but after the first week, the assignment hadn't been posted. The review sessions run by the TAs were good though.

Yannis and the AIs tried their best to teach this course well, and their effort was good. But there were too many structural flaws for the course:. Yes, an overall easy course, but it didn't teach us the important parts of differential equations adequately. We didn't cover Laplaces, we covered PDEs only minimally, but we spent weeks reviewing linear. Just model the course off similar courses at UT Austin or whatever and this course would be exponentially better.

Yannis is a pretty crappy teacher. The AIs and the professor are never on the same page, and things just get delegated around, and it takes a long time to get something done. 
Pretty poor course overall.
You probably have to take it, but you might want to wait until Stone is teaching.
You still learn something about ODEs, Fourier, dynamical systems, and separation of variables I guess.
don't take it unless you have to but who would take differential equations unless they had to
dope class, luved it bruh, dont let the haterz tell u its not a grate clas bruh. 18/17 snails wood nevur take agen
the actual material is pretty interesting and very doable. the final was extremely hard though and some of the p sets take ages and are due on fridays so don't take if u value thursday nights highly.
otherinfo: Two midterm exams will be administered accounting for 35% of final grade.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 45%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Reading about one chapter per week and 10 - 15 homework problems.
prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 and MAT 202 or MAT 204. Open to freshmen with instructor's permission only..
descrip: A treatment of the theory and applications of ordinary differential equations with an introduction to partial differential equations. The objective is to provide the student with an ability to solve standard problems in this field.
title: Mathematics in Engineering I

evals: Ask Glenn and Al questions, get as much experience as you can!
Budget a lot of time in midterm and reading period time.
Do the tutorials carefully, that information will be needed later for the design part and you'll most likely have to go back to the tutorials for reference.
Don't save the design project till the last minute!
Focus on the lab and choose a good group for your design project.  Will be a lot of work in the second half of the semester.
For the final project, be prepared to put in a lot of work. Communication is also really important. Ask Glenn if you have any questions on anything, he could be your lifeline for this course.
Glenn and Al are amazing and you'll come out of this course with the confidence to make anything you'd ever need for MAE.

Glenn and Al know their stuff, you just have to ask a lot of questions to get to it (Glenn will skip over stuff thinking you already know it). Lectures are a waste of time, but it's fun to get to use the machine shop. Get a good group for the project; it lasts all semester.
Glenn is a fantastic source of information in the lab. He tends to skip large amounts of material in lecture, however, and does not have a very organized layout for the course.

Glenn is extremely helpful and nice (though doesn't always explain all the expectations), so just ask him if you're stuck. The final design project takes forever, so account for that. Creo tutorials are a pain, but necessary.

Glenn is the best! You are taking this because you have to, but don't worry because it is the most fun I have had in an academic setting thus far. Get to know Al and Glenn because they are both super helpful and knowledgeable, and working with them is the best way to do well on your design. I wasn't planning on it before, but now I'm really excited to take 322!
Great class. Highly recommend even for non MAEs. Al and Glenn are amazing.
Great course. Doesn't take too much time during the semester, but it takes a lot at the end. It provides the fundamentals of machining which are crucial.

How the class goes for you will depend on who the professor is. Hopefully that professor will teach you about how to gain intuition in the shop and about various concepts in mechanical design. That did not happen very well this semester. In addition, make sure you understand all of the details about the projects completely and make sure you know when the shop is available. That was also not distributed well this semester.
I would definitely recommend this course if for nothing else than the lab component.
If you are MAE you have to take it so make sure you get started on the assignments early and order in your parts/build early because there is always something that goes wrong while building.
If you're MAE, you're probably required to take this class, but I took it when Glenn taught the lectures AND labs, and it was great. First MAE class where you get to use the machine shop.
Machine shop is awesome, but the time it takes to do the projects = as long as you think it will times pi

Not just for MAEs, I think any BSE or experimentally-minded science student could get a lot out of this.

please find yourself a reliable group, I was stuck with a bunch of leeches and it made my midterms and reading period hell
Shop is great, learn as much as you can. Start the final project as early as possible.
Take it! You won't regret it!
Take it, learn how to build things!
Take this if Glenn is the one teaching. He was fantastic. Not a lot of work, but a ton of time spent in the shop machining and CADing. If that's your thing, you're going to love this class.
This course is so awesome, that even non-MAE's want to (and do) take it!

This is a departmental for MAE so it has to be taken. It is a very good course if you are in it to just learn how to machine and spend a lot of time hands on. The class does not have much structure, so you never know what to expect.

This is a distinctively MAE class; you get your hands dirty in the shop drilling holes in metal for hours. You learn how to work in teams to design and build something. You don't even know that you're not AB until you've taken this class.

This is a fun course. You don't necessarily need to be an MAE major, and if Glenn is teaching it, I feel that you would really enjoy it. You learn a lot, and are exposed to the machine shop, which I found to be very fun.
This is a pretty good course. The labs are great, but the lectures are less interesting/helpful.
This is a required course. That being said it was easily one of my favorite courses at Princeton.
Worth taking and very helpful if you have any interest in doing any projects in the machine shop
You have to take it, but with Glenn it is an awesome course.
You have to take this class regardless if you're MAE, but this was probably the funnest class I've taken here.
You're probably taking this as an MAE requirement, but enjoy the labs and all of the help that Glenn and Al provide.  They are really great and make the labs fun.
great course for learning the basics of machining and manufacturing
grading: Design Project - 70%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Reading from references and notes. One major project. Lab reports and problem sets. Mid-term exam. The project will involve design concepts, component and system design, construction and device fabrication.
prereqs: MAE 206, 221 and 222, and CEE 205 or MAE 223.
descrip: This course introduces the technical foundations and basic processes of Mechanical Design, which are appropriate for the design of both mechanical systems, and components. The emphasis is on designing for the complete product life-cycle. Topics in parametric design and design optimization are also presented. Basic techniques in Computer Aided Design (CAD) and Manufacturing (CAM) are first introduced in the classroom, and then reinforced and expanded in the laboratory.
title: Engineering Design

evals: A rather enjoyable MAE class. Make full use of the help sessions, and this will be an easy class.

A solid course. Although most people taking this are probably taking it because they have to, it's completely doable with a good foundation in basic mechanics, and Prof. Kosmrlj is a very good professor. Go to problem sessions/office hours each week (or just work with other people), it will cut the time you spend on the problem set down nearly by half (so yes, the walk to the equad at night will be well worth it).
A super smooth course that doesn't require you to do anything special to succeed
Andrej Kosmrlj is a great lecturer! You will learn a lot and enjoy the course without ever feeling overwhelmed. Psets are just 2 hours/week and very helpful.

Andrej is a good human being. The problem sets, tests, quizzes, and book are extremely straightforward. You may occasionally find yourself lost in lecture or not present in lecture. I feel like time in lecture could have been used better. In my opinion,This would be a good class to used the flipped classroom method, with problem solving groups. The reading is very logical and the material isn't too broad.
Andrej is a great guy and it really is a super reasonable class.

Ask questions if you have any! The professor is very nice and happy to answer whatever you want to ask. This class was one of my favorite classes since the material is very interesting and the class is very well taught.
Definitely go to office hours and review sessions -> They are constructive and friendly!
Definitely take this course. Not only a very interesting topic, but Andrej does an unimaginable job in breaking it down into bite-size pieces. Highly, highly recommend to all intersted
Even though it's required for MAE, this wasn't a bad class! Professor Kosmrlj is a great guy and professor. He does some cool research too!
Excel in all homeworks, quizzes, exams. The curve is high.
Fairly easy, sensible course
Go to the TA run Monday night review sessions. It makes the problem sets much easier to do, and helps you know exactly what you need do and do not need to know for the course.
Good class, interesting and applicable.
Good class.
Good course. Very fair exams and good lectures. Make sure you do the psets as they are key to making sure you get everything and help you on the exams.
Great course!  Very interesting material and Prof Kosmrlj is good at teaching it.
Great course, but I don't know why you would take it if you are not an engineer.
I highly recommend this class if you need to take it or even if you don't.  Kosmrlj is an amazing lecturer but make sure you have a study group!
If you want to learn Solid Mechanics, take the course. Workload is reasonable, lectures are good, grading is fair, and you'll learn a lot.
If you're MAE, you have to take it. If it's still Kosmrlj, he does a good job keeping lectures interesting even if the topics themselves aren't super compelling.
It's a great extension of mechanics, and isn't super difficult. Would recommend to anyone meeting the physics prereqs
Keep on top of it, there are five pop quizzes
Kosmrlj is exceptional. His lectures are well-prepared, and he takes time to answer questions if you have them. His office hours are helpful as well.

Lectures were great! Very practical, thorough methodology for solving problems. Kosmrlj always gave us an opportunity at the end of lecture to submit papers with requests for clarification - if one part of the lecture was not clear to students. He would tailor his lectures based on these requests! He's also a very cool guy. Finals, midterms, and quizzes are very fair. Office hours and help sessions were very helpful. 
Some parts are a bit math intensive, so make sure to brush up on old skills.
Make sure you understand the concepts, and you'll do fine. Prof Kosmrlj is super friendly and approachable, and makes the 90 minute lectures almost bearable.
Organized, Lectures at a reasonable pace, Office hours helpful
Pay attention in class and go to the problem set sessions. The problem sets are directly based off lectures and the exams are based off problem sets so there will be no surprises.
Required for MAE anyway. But Professor Kosmrlj is the nicest and you will enjoy having him
Take this course! Andrej is great!
The course is fairly straightforward with the way everything is presented and not unnecessarily difficult as long as a bit of time is put in.

This can be a tough and time consuming course. However, if you are willing to put in the effort, you will see that Andrej, the professor, and the AI's are excellent at helping the students in this course. It is a very well taught course, and perhaps one of the best scientific courses I have taken here at Princeton.
This is a very well taught class. It's fun, as it's the first class that you'll take as a sophomore MAE that actually feels like engineering

This is great course! It is challenging but very rewarding. Andrej Kosmrlj is fantastic! He breaks down each concept really well and helps you build intuition for applying them. The problem sets are often very difficult (I recommend you go to TAs) and take up a lot of time but they truly enable you to learn the material in great detail. A great class to take!
Very well taught, professor is really nice and helpful. Go to class and keep up with psets and you'll do fine. Recommend!
otherinfo: This is an important course for anyone interested in structures.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 5%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly homework assignments, accounts for 30% of the final grade. Occasional quizzes, accounts for 5% of the final grade.
prereqs: MAT 104 and PHY 103.
descrip: Fundamental principles of solid mechanics: equilibrium equations, reactions, internal forces, stress, strain, Hooke's law, torsion, beam bending and deflection, and analysis of stress and deformation in simple structures. Integrates aspects of solid mechanics that have applications to mechanical and aerospace structures (engines and wings), as well as to microelectronic and biomedical devices (thin films and artificial hearts). Topics include stress concentration, fracture, plasticity, and thermal expansion. The course synthesizes descriptive observations, mathematical theories, and engineering consequences.
title: Modern Solid Mechanics

evals: Awesome class, definitely take it. Even if you're not MAE and looking for something to take as a sort of neat techy elective, consider this class - I found the material really interesting, and Arnold is a great lecturer (and go to his office hours and hang out with him!). Problem sets aren't too much work compared to other engineering classes.
Craig Arnold is an exceptional lecturer. The problem sets reflect the lectures and the tests reflect the psets, so it's really easy to follow.

Craig is extremely passionate about the material and wants you to be too. The man has an incredible street creds. The material itself, you will find to be quite wide-ranging as compared to a more straightforward class like MAE 223. You will learn many things and at the same time realize that you don't know anything about the field of materials.
Exams are hard, so make sure you study for them. The scope of the material is such that your second midterm will feel like a time-crunched final. That aside, TAs and Professor Arnold are great.
Good introduction.
Great course, especially if Arnold is teaching it! He is an amazing professor! Great fundamentals into the field of MS.

I recommend taking this course. Professor Arnold is great and a very engaged professor. I strongly recommend going to office hours when the material is confusing or if you just want to chat. Great class.

I thought it was quite hard, mostly because of the amount of material that the course covers, which you'll realize when you sit down to study for the final. Keep up with the work!! Arnold is an engaging professor.
I would recommend taking this course if you are an MAE major.
My favorite class this semester.  Take this over MSE 301 because professor Arnold is an amazing guy.  Lots of work, but Arnold and the preceptors will get you through it.
Professor Arnold is a fun professor, which makes this class worth taking.
Required anyway. Not an easy course but interesting contents.

So if you are thinking about taking this class, you fall into one of 3 categories. First, you are an MAE student. You gotta take it. If you are not chemistry minded, it will be a stretch, especially in the first few weeks. But at the end, you will learn a ton from this class! Second, you are a Chemistry student. This class will be easy for you. Third, you are a chemical engineering CBE student. It will also be easy for you. But, both should still take it! In fact, every one should take this class because Craig Arnold is the prof. The dude is a materials science genius and will leave you with a full materials science background and with enthusiasm for the subject matter. Have fun!
Take it with Arnold! This is one of the best-taught classes at Princeton!
Take it! It is better than the one offered in the spring!.
Take it!! Prof. Arnold is a very good lecturer, and the assignments are all very doable. Just make sure to keep up with the pace!
Take this course, learn why everything is the way it is!

Take this if you like, inorganic chemistry or building things. Not because you'll be actually doing either of these things, but because you'll understand applications of inorganic and a bit of the theory behind the building.
This class is challenging, but you can really enjoy it if you pay attention and talk to Arnold outside of classes, as he is really passionate about his work and wants to see students succeed.

This course teaches important material for anyone who ever builds anything! Try to give yourself plenty of time with psets/studying and ask questions because you will get useful responses/conversations.
Would be difficult to take without a background in math/science but Arnold is a great lecturer and professor.

Would recommend! The class is fun and a reasonable amount of work. Professor Arnold is a really engaging lecturer, and he knows his stuff. It's a very hands-on class if you learn well that way. He's always passing models and samples around the classroom to demonstrate what we're learning in class.
good course. if you have to take it its not too bad just make sure you keep up on the material
grading: Final Exam - 35%, Other Exam - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and reading in reference texts. Students are expected to read one chapter per week.
prereqs: It is expected all students will have completed the BSE freshman requirements of chemistry, physics, and math or their equivalent. MAE 221 recommended but may be taken concurrently. Audit option available only for non-departmental students..
descrip: Relates to the structures, properties, processing and performance of different materials including metals, alloys, polymers, composites, and ceramics. This course also discusses how to select materials for engineering applications. This course satisfies the MAE departmental requirement in materials as well as the MSE certificate core requirement.
title: Structure and Properties of Materials

evals: 8:30am lectures are challenging! But it's worth it to make it.
Be prepared for early lectuers... It is less than ideal but if you are aero you need to take this.

Besides the occasional problem on the problem set that made me want to curse and switch to an english major, this was a great course. If you get stuck, make sure to talk to your peers. Teamwork was almost a necessity to do well on the problem sets (which are heavily weighed) . The material was fascinating though , and I felt the instructors did it justice.
Compared with other required MAE courses this one is pretty good.

Don't take this class as long as Professor Nosenchuck is teaching. I'd say switch to ME to avoid it, but then you'd have to take heat transfer...

Go to precepts and TA office hours, read the textbook, and try to make it through the lectures.
Go to precept and class, take notes, you'll learn, Nosenchuck is great.
Going to office hours is helpful for really understanding the problem sets, especially since exam questions can be modeled after the more unusual or difficult problem set problems.

I really liked this course. Still on the theory side of things as far as upper level MAE courses go, but very interesting. I haven't taken heat transfer, so I don't know how it compares, but if you liked fluid mechanics or like airplanes, you'll probably like this.
I would not take this course unless you have to.

If you are considering taking this course, you're probably MAE and have to take it as a departmental. That being said, fluids is not too bad. Nosenchuck's lectures can be dry, especially at 8:30 AM, but definitely go to precept and office hours. They help alot.
It can be a lot of time, but it's worth it. Read the textbook, it's actually one of the better ones and pretty good at explaining the material.
Make sure you understand the Psets and go to precept because lecture might not be too helpful.

The material is really interesting. Lectures aren't terrible but aren't great either. Probably take it if you have to but not otherwise. Average workload for MAE, maybe slightly above average in terms of pset difficulty (like, harder than fluids 1 but not even close to Stone's diff eq).
The textbook by Anderson is great!
This course is not easy, but it is quite interesting and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

This course is very thorough and you will be learning a lot about high speed, compressible flows. This is a far better class than MAE 222, and your performance or opinion on that class should have bearing on this one. The problem sets are relatively time consuming (8 hours) and can be open ended and unclear at times. The exams require utmost preparation as well.
You need to go to office hours to do well on problem sets
a good course, but difficult. make sure you keep up
wish I would have taken heat transfer instead
otherinfo: This is a required course for Aerospace concentrators.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Reading 30-40 pages of text. Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or Permission Of Instructor. MAT 202 is strongly recommended as background for enrollment..
descrip: The course is focused on compressible and incompressible inviscid fluid flow. Compressible subsonic and supersonic flows are studied in the first half of the course. The remaining portion of the semester addresses low-speed, incompressible fluid flows and aerodynamics of two and three-dimensional wings and bodies. Concepts of thrust, lift and drag are introduced and applied.
title: Fluid Dynamics

otherinfo: One hour class meetings will be scheduled as needed. Students are encouraged to attend. Requirements/Grading for Final Paper: 50% of grade is Advisor; 25% of grade is Reader.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 75%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
assgts: Written report and poster session due at end of semester
prereqs: This course will not fulfill the department's independent work/thesis requirement. This course is restricted to MAE concentrators. Non-concentrators may seek the approval of the MAE department to enroll..
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and oral presentation at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.
title: Independent Work

otherinfo: One hour class meetings will be scheduled as needed. Students are encouraged to attend. Requirements/Grading for Final Paper: 50% of grade is Advisor; 25% of grade is Reader.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 75%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
assgts: Written report and poster session due at end of semester
prereqs: This course will not fulfill the department's independent work/thesis requirement. This course is restricted to MAE concentrators. Non-concentrators may seek the approval of the MAE department to enroll..
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principal difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principals of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and oral presentation at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.
title: Independent Work with Design

evals: A challenging course with advanced material that is probably inaccessible unless you are very well-versed in MAE, ELE, dynamics, etc. Good for people who are quick learners, self-starters, and can engage with very technical topics. Problem sets are maybe ten hours a week on average. The learning you get out of it is very worthwhile.

Don't worry if you don't understand the technical details of every topic covered in class. There's a lot of material covered, so it would be almost impossible to gain a deep understanding of it all in a single semester. As long as you understand the big ideas and how topics relate, you'll do fine on the assignments.
I'd advise against taking it. Professor Stengel is such a kind man but he is too smart to teach.

It will be a lot of work. The lectures may get boring at times, but the knowledge you will take out of this course will astound you.

Though I do not think this is a perfect replacement for a dedicated controls course, like 433. But hey, that's why 433 exists.

It's a pretty great course. There are no exams, which lets you sort of ignore what you're not interested in and focus on what you are. Expect around COS-level amounts of work each week in technical and theory assignments where you're paired with other students randomly. The open-ended final project was surprisingly inspiring and had me doing some of the coolest independent work I've ever attempted. The class if more theory based and less actual building robots, but I still found it really useful. Seriously consider taking this class.

Lectures are extremely fast based, but provide a great overview of all of the possible techniques/methods you could use for projects. Also goes in depth in some areas. Projects were excellent! Definitely recommend!
Take this class if you are interested in robotics! It's not that much work and the lectures are kind of interesting.

This course currently satisfies the controls requirements of the Robotics and Intelligence Systems certificate. However, it is difficult to learn very much from the course because the material is presented with a lot of mathematics. It is also a lot of work - there are biweekly "problem sets" which are the length of small projects. These projects involve technical write-ups which often span several thousand words; by the end of the course, I suspect that you will have exceeded 10,000 words written for all the reports you do for the course. As for the content, here is a good way to gauge whether you will be interested: Look up the previous year's lecture slides and find the most interesting topic that you can. Every topic does not depend on the previous ones as a prerequisite, which means that the level of understanding and interest you have in reading the lecture slide now will virtually be the same when you're taking the course. So read the slides, gauge how much you understand them, and gauge how interesting they really are. That will be how you feel as the professor presents them in class.
Very cool class!  Takes some serious work, but it's worth it.

You're not building robots. You're not programming robots, either. Cool if you want to learn a lot of different topics in a short amount of time, but everything goes really fast and it's not terribly fun. Assignments can take a long time too. If you want to sort of delve into an introduction to robotics and intelligent system, go for it, but considering using your time on something else.
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: This course is open to graduate students from all departments.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Reading, 50 pages per week, plus 3 - 5 computer based assignments during the term.
prereqs: MAT 202 or MAT 204 and COS 126. Additional prerequisites: For AB students, science and technology requirement must be met. For BSE students, freshman science requirement must be met..
descrip: This course provides students with a working knowledge of methods for design and analysis of robotic and intelligent systems. Particular attention is given to modeling dynamic systems, measuring and controlling their behavior, and making decisions about future courses of action. Topics include system modeling and control, principles of decision-making, Monte Carlo evaluation, genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, neural networks, and expert systems.
title: Robotics and Intelligent Systems

evals: Be aware that the final project will extend far beyond Dean's Date. Plan and study accordingly. Otherwise, highly recommended

Definitely attend the lectures in the first half of the semester. Attend any lectures in the second half that explain how the test-stand and train system itself work as well. It can be hard to understand at first but it'll save you lots of time while working on the final project when you understand how all the pieces fall together. Pick a project that is manageable and partners who have a similar goal in mind. You can make the project into whatever you want so if you all have the same idea and enthusiasm, you can build a really awesome project. Expect to spend lots of time in the lab towards the midterm and final periods. You're going to learn tons but it'll cost you a few sleepless nights.

Fantastic course! It's definitely a lot of work for the final project, but very rewarding at the end and you come away with such an in-depth knowledge of microprocessors (and model trains). I came into the course with basically no useful knowledge at all - I could barely build a circuit - and came out with an array of skills I am proud of.
Final project is a LOT of work. It also runs past Dean's Date, so be advised that it may interfere with your exam schedule.

Great class, not a lot of work for most of the semester. Be prepared to sink a significant amount of time into the final project, and make sure that you don't get too ambitious. Even the "simple" projects tend to be quite complicated, and there are a million things that can go wrong for no apparent reason and make your project a miserable experience. Professor Littman and John Prevost are quite helpful in the lab and can usually sort out any problem you may have. Definitely a class worth taking because it really exposes you to electronics and sensors in a way no other MAE class will.

Highly recommend this class. Lots of fun on the final project and labs are good too, but it does take up all of reading period. (This is fair though since there aren't lab reports during the semester). Take some time early on to explore the course website. All the info you need is there, but can a little tough to find sometimes.

Make your project as simple as possible. Don't use motors. Don't try to interface your arduino and ACIA, it is tricky and you won't really be able to get much help on figuring it out since apparently no one has really done it before.

No psets and only labs which is awesome but the final project is super long. My project was extremely difficult because my group chose to make it challenging but I learned a lot and really enjoyed it.

One of MAE's best courses. I would strongly recommend it over Mech Design, especially if you're dual Mech/Aero. Littman's a great professor, and the labs are well-structured. It's all too easy to put in more than 100 hours of work on the final project during reading period, so get as much as you can done before winter break. Even if that means coming in outside of lab, do it - you'll thank yourself later.

Overall, this course is a good experience - though not always fun. Work for this course comes in waves. Stay on top of things before the midterm. Don't be ambitious about the final project - even the simplest projects on paper can take a lot of time debugging and testing to make work. You'll learn to respect the fickleness of electronic components and the mind-numbing frustration of debugging hardware and software at multiple levels.
Really time consuming, but you learn a lot. If you think your project is "too simple", it's probably not. Lots of things can still go wrong. Plan accordingly.
START YOUR FINAL PROJECT EARLY. Just 3 extra hours a week with Jon's help will save you so much time.
Take it, really helps MAE students have a broad understanding of engineering as a whole.
Take it. Start working on your project as early as possible

The midterm and especially final project are going to take A LOT of time. Other than that there isn't much out of class work throughout the semester. It is an interesting class and you learn quite a bit of useful skills. However I cannot stress how long that final project will take you, it's a beast.

This is a class that is a lot of fun but the ramp up in course load can catch people off guard.  The class starts off fairly light in terms of work, with very little time outside of lab being needed to complete the work.  But when you get to the final project, a HUGE amount of time outside of lab will be needed. The earlier you can get started on the final project and the more time you can put in early, the smoother your reading period will be.  Also, make sure you unit test everything.  Having ways to physically test each circuit and code to test each action the project is designed to perform will be invaluable in finding the problem when something stops working as it is supposed to.
Try to get involved in as many aspects of the projects and labs as possible. The more you actively do, the more you'll get out of the course.
Very frustrating class. Anything can stop working all of a sudden, very finicky stuff. Only take if you need it. Professor Littman is phenomenal, however the class can drive you up the walls
otherinfo: MAE Juniors and non MAE Seniors may enroll with permission of the instructor.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Design Project - 55%, Lab Reports - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%
assgts: 4-6 hours weekly assignments in the form of laboratory projects.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 224, or introductory knowledge of analog and digital electronics.
descrip: Introduction to microcomputers for measurement and control. This is a hardware course in the area of electro mechanical systems. Students design and build microcomputer controllers and apply them to the automation of various aspects of a model railroad.
title: Microprocessors for Measurement and Control

evals: Cool topics and reasonable problem sets...until the final project which takes many, many hours, and requires coding (probs MATLAB). Nosenchuck is very nice and helpful. Plus we got to have dinner at his house so that's awesome.
Go to class and office hours. If you are confused read the textbook.
Great course!  The last couple weeks are very challenging once you begin numerical simulations with the final project.  Start the final project very early!
I recommend showing up to classes because the lectures and explanations are very useful. I personally chose this over the alternative required class and I'm glad I did.

I would recommend for you to take the class. This class is a little more chill in the regular semester as compared to fluids. But at the end of the regular semester and in reading period, the class ramps up the intensity tremendously as compared to fluids due to the final project of the class. Be prepared for that project. Please DO IT IN A GROUP. Also make sure one of your group members has a powerful computer because that is needed to work on the project efficiently, even if professor tells you otherwise. Finally, make sure to figure out all of the small details that professor leaves out in lecture about the project. Also be ready to meet with professor or the TA at odd hours in the day to potentially get your questions answered.
You definitely learn about the three methods of heat transfer, and also a lot about fluid dynamics. Be ready to extensively matlab code!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly problem sets. Six hours estimated weekly preparation time.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will cover fundamentals of heat transfer and applications to practical problems in energy conversion and conservation, electronics, and biological systems. Emphasis will be on developing a physical and analytical understanding of conductive, convective, and radiative heat transfer, as well as design of heat exchangers and heat transfer systems involving phase change in process and energy applications. Students will develop an ability to apply governing principles and physical intuition to solve multi-mode heat transfer problems.
title: Heat Transfer

evals: Absolutely take this class, even if it's not required.  Rowley is an absolutely amazing lecturer, and he should honestly teach every MAE course.  He makes the material interesting and understandable.  One of my favorite classes I've taken.

Attend lectures and keep up as well as you can. The labs are relatively straightforward but lectures will start to emphasize more complex topics toward the end of the year, so try to stay on top of the content.
Controls is a fantastic and rewarding class, and I highly recommend it. Make sure to read the textbook and find a group to do psets with - they tend to be long but interesting.
Controls is a subject that you worship. You will never truly understand it, but it works in the labs and is really goddamn cool. Rowley is a good lecturer.
Controls is pretty dope.

Couldn't recommend enough. Thought I would hate it because math but it actually wasn't that mathy at all. The labs and problem sets were often very satisfying. Don't take Thursday lab because it makes turning the psets in a struggle.
Go to lecture, read the notes, ask questions when you don't understand. Great MAE class.
Great course to take. Highly recommend, especially if Rowley is teaching.
Great course! Make sure to get a book of the notes and keep it handy for the psets. The course has a decent difficulty level to challenge you but not leave you stumped.
Great course. Read the lecture notes and go to lecture.

I took this course for "fun" because I am not in MAE. Professor Rowley is a star in every sense of the word. He is one of the best technical professors I have had here. The labs are done completely in the lab time which is good because there is no work outside of class. The problem sets are the biggest weakness in this class because they are pretty long and time consuming. The exams are amazingly fair and they test you on exactly what you should know as opposed to absurd questions. The curve seems tough but the learning is great so I would strongly recommend for people who really want to learn and understand the basics of control.
If you liked Stone's diff eq class, definitely take Controls with Rowley!
TAKE IT, one of the best courses I've taken as an MAE. Challenging, but really engaging -- don't miss Rowley's lectures since they're great and really help with understanding the material.
Take it! Super well-taught and interesting! Go to lecture, read the book, use office hours if you need it.  Well worth it!

Take it. You'll never have a more organized course, and Rowley is engaging and extremely intelligent without being condescending. The self-contained labs really are self-contained in the sense that you don't need to do any outside work or prep for them, but they are very useful for getting physical insights to the material being covered in lecture that week.
Take this course. This is one of the best courses I've taken here at Princeton.
This is a bit funny that the prompt is asking for feedback. If you really want feedback, you should take the course. You'll learn a lot about it and I would highly recommend it.
This is an amazing class. Clancy is an incredible lecturer and makes the subject very enjoyable. Difficult, but favorite class at Princeton so far.
This was one of my favorite classes at Princeton! Challenging but well organized, clear, and very helpful professor/TAs.
Well, this is the right course to learn about feedback.
take it!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 5%, Lab Reports - 15%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Twenty pages of reading per week in lecture notes. Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and to gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems in a laboratory setting.
title: Automatic Control Systems

evals: As an undergraduate, if you are interested in fluids, this is a brilliant follow-up to 222 and 335. It's essentially a combination of those two, with a more fundamental treatment of the material. Don't be turned off by the "graduate course" label. Be prepared to work hard, but if you do, you'll be just fine. Prof. Smits is extremely helpful and accessible, and presents the material in a really wonderful manner.
Lex is an incredible teacher. Take a class from him at any chance you get.
Strongly recommended
The lecturer gives very clear lectures and is very humorous.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 40%
descrip: An introduction to fluid mechanics. The course explores the development of basic conservation laws in integral and differential form; one-dimensional compressible flows, shocks and expansion waves; effects of energy addition and friction; unsteady and two-dimensional flows and method of characteristics. Reviews classical incompressible flow concepts, including vorticity, circulation, and potential flows. Introduces viscous and diffusive phenomena.
title: Fluid Mechanics

evals: If you are interested in knowing about turbulent flows, I suggest you take this class. The professor wants the students to have a general idea about this field of research, without going into too many details.
Take this course if you're interested in higher level fluid mechanics. The courseload is too much and the lectures are great.
The class is really good and the lecturer is very nice.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 25%
descrip: Physical and statistical descriptions of turbulence, and a critical review of phenomenological theories for turbulent flows. The course examines scales of motion; correlations and spectra; homogeneous turbulent flows; inhomogeneous shear flows; turbulent flows in pipes and channels; turbulent boundary layers; calculation methods for turbulent flows (Reynolds stress equations, LES, DNS); and current directions in turbulence research. This course is offered in alternate years.
title: Turbulent Flow

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: An introduction to principles of lasers. Topics include propagation theory, interaction of light and matter, Fourier optics, and a description of operational characteristics of lasers, light scattering, and nonlinear optics.
title: Optics and Lasers

evals: Even if your research is not directly related, consider taking this course because you will learn a lot and it will give you a great foundation in dynamics which is useful for any engineer.

If you have taken a class with Kasdin before, this is very similar to his other courses in format.  Lectures are very linear and problem sets are demanding but fair.  If you want to learn about dynamics beyond the Newtonian version this is a good way to do that.

This is class is a lot of difficult work, but Prof. Kasdin is clear, and you will get help if you ask. You learn methods that make certain classes of problems a lot easier. The subject material is beautiful. Speaking from the perspective of a non-MAE engineer who didn't have prior exposure to dynamics but did take PHY 105/6.
This is the best course on Dynamics I have followed. Highly recommendable if this is your field. High workload.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 35%
descrip: Principles and methods for formulating and analyzing mathematical models of physical systems; Newtonian, Lagrangian, and Hamiltonian formulations of particle and rigid and elastic body dynamics; canonical transformations, Hamilton-Jacobi theory; and integrable and nonintegrable systems. Additional topics are explored at the discretion of the instructor.
title: Advanced Dynamics

evals: Read the books carefully and completely
Read the textbooks multiple times. Dwell on the material, and make sure you can see and explain the logical thread implicit within these readings.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Physical and chemical topics of basic importance in modern fluid mechanics, plasma dynamics, and combustion science: statistical calculations of thermodynamic properties of gases; physical equilibria; quantum mechanical analysis of atomic and molecular structure including rotational and vibrational transitions; atomic-scale collision phenomena and excitation and ionization; emission, absorption, and propagation of radiation. Analyses of major greenhouse gases from point of view of molecular absorption and emission properties; discussion of effect of greenhouse gases concentration and disribution on climate equilibria.
title: Physics of Gases

evals: Take it if you are going to make Combustion your life and your passion.  Otherwise, take something that doesn't require so much of your life.
Take this class if you like combustion.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, oxidation of hydrogen, hydrocarbons and alternate fuels, pollutant chemistry and control, transport phenomena, laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames, turbulent flames, ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena, flame stabilization and blowoff, detonation and blast waves, droplet, spray and coal particle combustion, principles of engine operation.
title: Combustion

evals: Very good
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.
title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

evals: A fun but not time-consuming course, starts simple but by the end you make a simple processor, that's pretty cool.
A must take for anyone who has ever wondered how computers work from a hardware perspective. A good intro to the subject!

A solid systems COS departmental. Works well in tandem with (or after) COS 217. Lectures are a little dry, but Professor Malik is a great guy and (blessedly) posts screencasts and recordings of all of his lectures on Blackboard. Labs are easy, excluding the final two, which both made me want to tear my hair out and eat it. Psets are unclear at times; would definitely recommend consulting Piazza. Overall, well organized, if occasionally frustrating.
AAA THIS CLASS DOES NOT ACTUALLY HAVE LABS WHICH MEET. your 'labs' are just coding assignments. it literally does not matter which lab you choose for your schedule.
Amazing, most organized course I've ever taken at Princeton. Professor Malik is an incredible lecturer and great teacher.

COS major, took this class because I heard it aligns well with 217. Definitely regret that decision. Not super interesting and lowkey a lot of work - problem sets and programming assignments every week, and then major programming projects at the end of the semester. If you're a COS major take something else for your systems requirement.

Certainly take this  course with Professor Malik! The computer is possibly the coolest piece of technology ever built, and it is surprisingly easy to understand how it actually works when it is spelled out so clearly by Prof. Malik.
Definitely take this class if you're interested in hardware design/computer architecture! An amazing class to take simultaneously with COS 217!

Don't get me wrong, this course is hard and work-intensive. But, it is absolutely worth it. I have never learned so much in a class before. I know that the skills I developed in Verilog and in logic design will help me in my future for many years to come.

ELE 206 does a very good job at capturing the different levels of abstraction present in electrical engineering. It teaches you how transistor level design (the material you cover in ELE208) is abstracted to logic level design (sequential and combinational logic), which is abstracted to RTL design (the level where you make a microprocessor) and finally how it leads to software (this is the level that COS226 covers). I am very happy to have taken this class and I believe it is a very useful topic even for non COS and ELE majors to take. In a nutshell, this class helps you see how you make electrical brains (i.e. a computer) starting with pieces of metal and semiconductors.

ELE majors are required to take this, but that is fortunate for them! The course is very helpful and a great introduction to the material, and probably makes COS 126 easier afterwards. COS majors - the programming in this course will be very easy, it is one of the easier Systems departmentals. It is not a prereq for 375 / Architecture and should not be considered as such if you have COS prerequesites.
Go to lecture unless you absolutely can't help it. Professor Malik tries to keep everyone engaged and will make sure you understand what you're going over thoroughly.
Goes great with COS 217! I learned a lot about logic design. Picking a time for the lab section isn't important, you can go to any one of them. Start the last two labs early
Good way for COS majors to get a systems requirement. Try as hard as you can to pay attention in lecture.
Great COS departmental
Great Class.
Great course and well taught. Go to every lecture and take notes. Buy the book and read that as well --- it's very well written and explains a lot of the concepts better than in lecture.
Great course. Definitely take it if COS or ELE

Great course. Make sure to take with Malik. I wouldn't say it is necessarily easy, but it is worth it if you are interested. It is really cool how you can go from transistors all the way to a processor.

Great course. Sharad Malik is amazing. AMAZING. If you think you'd be into logic design, take it. The last to labs can be a HUGE time sink though (depends on your luck with debugging), plan accordingly.
