I am neutral about this class. Lab work is sometimes exciting but also frustrating (debugging Verilog is very difficult and different). Midterm and final are challenging. But the course does introduce you to interesting concepts that are "Under the hood."

I did really well in 217 and I liked the stuff taught in that class, so I thought I would like ELE 206 as well, but I really hated this class. So much weekly work, and you get destroyed in the exams anyway. I felt like studying didn't really help, unless you're ELE already and are taking a higher level ELE course. Think twice if you think this is going to be an "easy" class. I wouldn't say the material is that hard, but the exams aren't exactly what you see in the textbook, and requires a lot of weekly work.
I think this class isn't too hard, but there's a lot of tedious work involved in labs, and Prof. Malik goes pretty slow in lecture.  Definitely start the last two labs early.
I think this is a very interesting class to take because it teaches you so much. But you definitely need to put in the work.

I took it as a COS major, and found it to be the easiest departmental I've taken. Part of this is thanks to the interesting material and the superb quality of the course. Prof. Malik is a fantastic lecturer and really goes out of his way to make learning as easy and relaxed as possible. Lots of resources and short assignments to make sure you keep up with the material, so that when exam times comes you're probably already ready.  I've learned a lot and it was very cool to play with hardware for once. Definitely consider taking this course!

I took this as a COS major; you'll definitely learn new things, and the difficulty level of the course isn't particularly high. A lot of the assignments are just moderately difficult; you just have to take a bit of time to do them. The later labs are similarly time-consuming, but besides debugging Verilog, there isn't anything that is so hard to wrap your mind around. Malik is a great lecturer. If you go, make sure to pay attention because he asks questions. Course staff are excellent. The material is usually pretty interesting; if you are a COS major it will give you a new perspective (the things going on under the hood aren't as 'clean' as you would think!).

I took this class fall of senior year, as a humanities major cos certificate student. I had enjoyed 217 and I enjoyed 206 in similar ways. Note that there are weeks when there are both p-sets and labs due, and are both long.

I took this course with three other COS departmentals, and it turned out to be probably both the most conceptually simple of them and the most time-consuming. Almost all of the problem sets boiled down to busywork that forced you to invest effort into them way beyond the amount of learning you were getting in return. That being said, the Verilog programming assignments were useful exercises and you really do get to see how to build up a hierarchy starting from low-level transistors and going all the way up to creating a programmable processor. This course isn't hard--but it can be frustratingly time-consuming.
I would highly recommend this class if you would like to know a bit more about what happens within your computer and the underlying logic. It is also a very good class in conjunction with COS 217.

I would highly recommend this course to any students vaguely interested in the topic. Professor Malik does a great job conveying the material and he explains almost all of the readings through the lectures.

I would recommend this course if you are a COS major and want to learn more about how circuits work. The logic design allows you to practice logic/design skills in a different setting, and while it is not completely relevant to COS, its a great, doable systems class for those of you who do not want to die in OS.
I would recommend this course, though be prepared to sit through some fairly boring lectures. The material is very interesting though.

I'm a COS senior who took this for his systems requirement. I strongly regret not taking this course as a sophomore. In particular I recommend taking this class with COS217 as their material complements each other very well (processors, assembly language, etc). 
The class is taught extremely well on all fronts. Malik is extremely clear and interesting. He explains everything completely and from first principles before moving on. Some might find his lecture style a bit slow but I thought it was great. Better to master something the first time round than to gloss over it and relearn it for the midterm/final. The homework assignments were great. They took a decent amount of time, but none of them were unreasonably difficult and the Piazza support for this class was a huge help. (shoutouts to Justin Patel the GOAT).

If you are COS -- TAKE THIS CLASS WITH 217. They good great together. Also, get a good lab partner, you'll be spending a lot of time together near the end of the semester. Malik really cares about his students, so get to know him. He's honestly the best.
If you are ele major, you have to take it.

If you try it and don't like it, just drop the course. If you PDF you still have to do the assignments. unless you have a partner for the last two projects who is also PDFing or willing to halfass things, you'll still end up putting way too much time into it.

If you're ELE, you have to take it. This class will also help you decide whether to stay ELE or switch out. If you're COS, maybe you could find a better systems course? Felt like this class was a lot of work: labs take up a lot of time, psets are ok, and key idea assignments (short reflection after every class) are ok but something you have to do.

If you're a CS major looking to fulfill a Systems req, this isn't a bad choice. It's not super easy but won't take up as much time as some of the other options. Tests can be brutal but there is a redeeming curve (I may be speaking too soon because I haven't taken the final yet). Be warned - the last lab will take longer than you think, so start early and don't wait until the last minute. This advice holds for all of the labs.

If you're not a huge fan of Systems, like I'm not, this class is a great way of getting the requirement. The psets, labs, and exams are well-designed to give you a good understanding of the subject, and I didn't find the workload too stressful.
It helps to have taken 217 before or concurrently... but there's no need to take it concurrently. Not especially mind-blowing, but an interesting systems course.
Keep up with readings. Slowly work through psets and labs in order to fully understand the material as you go. Will pay off.
Learned a lot and it's a super well-organized course!
Make sure you keep up with the lectures and reading material. It's easy to get left behind if you aren't on top of the material.
Not a bad class, but don't fall behind on labs.

Not too difficult as a systems course, but quite a lot of busy work that you have to keep up with every week. The workload and conceptual difficulty during the first half of the semester are ok, but both pick up after midterms. The exams are usually more difficult than psets and lecture material, so be prepared to get consistently good grades during the semester but not be able to do as well as you'd expect on the exams.
Pay attention in lecture. Do all the work and do not use your late days early.

Poorly sturctured labs.  The last two labs have little support, which means the bulk of the learning lands on the students.  There are little references for verilog from the course and online.  A good lecture series.

Pretty good course. Be prepared for interesting exams; just make sure to take the practice exams so you know what sort of questions to expect. Also be prepared to spend a good amount of time during winter break or reading period on the final project.

Professor Malik is incredible--he's helpful, informative, and most importantly puts in an immense amount of time ensuring that the course is as fair as possible (e.g., he has TAs take the exams to test for timing, gives generous partial credit on exams when you've displayed that you understand most of the tested concept, allows students to schedule extra time with him if they're not understanding certain concepts). The course of the material is moderately interesting, and for most people this class is required. But Professor Malik made the course worthwhile!
Really good course, I'd totally recommend it for anyone who wants to get a better understanding of how computers work at the logic level.
Really interesting, gave me a new perspective on COS. The book is super super helpful (as in, you can read the book instead of going most lectures...)
Sharad Malik is an awesome prof. The course is quite a bit of work but a good intro as a COS major.

Skim through someone's old textbook to see if you are interested in the material; it is difficult to describe it in words (on the course webpage).... Don't go to lecture. It's a waste of time. Just read carefully in the book.... Early labs are easy. The last two (after midterms), Simon and PUnC, are super cool but hard. Get an early jump on debugging.... Also, the labs don't meet during their registrar-given sections. You have to sign up for one, but you only have to go to lab to demo (and for help) and you can go at any section.
Solid systems course. A good amount of COS majors take this with COS 217 and the rest are ELE majors. The material in ELE isn't that helpful for 217 but nevertheless not a bad idea to take with 217.
Start early on labs and get lots of help if you need it for them. Try to pay attention in lecture even though they are way too long.
Start the labs early.

Start the last two projects (Simon and PuNC) can be very difficult to debug, so start these early. The class isn't super challenging, but the exams often are quite difficult. If you aren't someone who learns well from lectures, reading the textbook provides pretty much the same material.
Study for midterm
TAKE IT
TAKE IT! Even if you aren't ELE or COS, Prof Malik is amazing. Take it for him.
Take
Take if interesting in logic. No knowledge needed going in, but you will learn a lot.
Take it as a COS major. great systems course and helps you learn to think logically.
Take it for an easy COS systems course and/or an STL.
Take it only if you have to. Work really builds up in the second half of the semester. The midterm was very brutal and intuition-based.
Take it, it's fun and an easy A!

Take it--the pace is not too fast, the work is fine if you share it equally with a good partner, and Professor Malik is a likable and engaging lecturer. I initially had zero interest in the subject matter, and expected I wouldn't like it at all. However, I enjoyed going to lecture, the work did not kill me, and I came out feeling like I actually learned something. Will not forget this class.
Take it. It is an interesting course and a good departmental.

Take this class if you have taken / plan on taking COS 217. They work really well together and you understand so much more about how a computer works (you get to make your own processor). Class is well structured and there is lots of support. Problem sets and labs take a decent amount of time, but there are late days and other flexible polices.

Take this course if you have interest in low level design. It's slightly cool but not extremely cool to be taken alongside 217. Be prepared for the course to go from 0 to 100 SUPER suddenly. The first couple labs/psets are not very hard but suddenly psets take a super long time and the last two labs take an insane amount of time. Definitely start work early.
Take this course if you're a COS student who needs a Systems course.
That's a good class and it's not too time-consuming.
The class moves really slowly. Malik is a good lecturer, but I found the material pretty boring. Not too hard, especially for a systems class.
The material covered in this class is very fun and useful. Definitely take it!

This class is a little on the difficult side, in the sense that the material is somewhat challenging.  It could be done in a 5-class semester, but not without some difficulty.  It's graded against 1/2 ELE and 1/2 COS majors, the latter of which just want to meet a systems requirement.  Class is mostly underclassmen, but the majors involved make the curve somewhat tough.  Sharad is an okay-to-good lecturer, who does his best with the material he's given.  If you're COS and need a systems req, I'd take this, but not otherwise.
This class really doesn't have to be hard. Going to lecture is extremely helpful, and just work on the problem sets and labs early and you'll be fine.

This class was fantastic, however, a bit tedious at times so be prepared to put the work in. Nonetheless, the class is well organized and well taught. It's easy to get help and I think that was a large component in why this course was successful. Get a good partner for the projects.

This course has heavy workload with one pset and one lab per week in addition to two lectures (and a short key idea assignment for each lecture). The exams were a lot more difficult compared to homework and labs and were difficult to prepare for. Would not recommend for COS majors needing a departmental.
This course is very well-run.

This is a really good course to take alongside COS 217, and is an easy systems requirement. You don't have to go to all the lectures, but be careful of the last two labs: they can be quite time consuming.
This is a really great course! Malik is an engaging lecturer and the course is very well structured. Labs can be a pain if you don't get started early, but overall, the workload is very manageable.
This is a very good course; great lecturer, interesting material, not an overwhelming amount of work.
This is a very time consuming class and is harder if you are COS than ELE. Be prepared to spend alot more time than you think on this class.
This is an interesting but challenging class.  If you stay on top of the work then you have time to appreciate it for what it is.
This is my favorite COS class so far at Princeton. Professor Malik is an excellent lecturer and the class is very well-structured!

Unless they make some changes to this course's labs, I do not recommend.  The material is interesting, but there are not enough lab TAs to help you if you need help and it's overall a waste of time to take if you want to take it just out of interest.
VERY EASY. Take it!

Very interesting course that was made even better because of Sharad Malik! There are quite a few assignments over the course of the semester, so be prepared for that. Great class if you liked COS 217, or if you just want to see how what was covered in COS 217 connects to the hardware side of things.
While it's not Professor Malik's goal for you to come to lecture, go to lecture.

You're going to have to stay motivated and organized if you want to keep on top of the readings, labs, problem sets, and key ideas assignments. The work is worth it, though -- it's an interesting class.
it's not the most interesting class, but it's manageable. there's help if you look for it, and professor malik cares a lot about his students. i wouldn't take if if you're not ELE or COS
its a great lab for a cos ab major. also its a nice way to try ele even if its not your major.
just be prepared tbh
take if you are generally interested in circuits or need a cos departmental
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 20%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Weekly problem set and lab assignments. 20 pages of reading per week
descrip: Introduction to the basic concepts in logic design that form the basis of computation and communication circuits. Logic gates and memeory elements. Timing methodologies. Finite state systems. Programmable logic. Basic computer organization.
title: Contemporary Logic Design

evals: A very interesting class that teaches you about electronic devices. Would definitely reccomend.

As an ELE sophomore who took this and 206 at the same time, I liked 208 better (it's also much less work, with only weekly quizzes). Claire is the best! although I don't think she's teaching this course next year :( Also it's ok if you don't really understand understand the material; eventually things will start to click. 

Also try not to get Monday afternoon lab (we frequently finished late)

At the very fundamental level, all your electronic devices are chunks of semiconductors and metals. It is really quite miraculous how these common materials come together to make something as complex as your computer. If you want to get a qualitative approach as to how this all happens: this class (accompanied by ELE206) is for you.
Attend ALL the lectures, and take detailed notes!
Be prepared for labs; you'd better understand what you're doing and why you're doing it, or writing about it for your projects will suck.
Decent class. Interesting enough and combines together knowledge from other classes that makes it a useful ELE class to take.
Do past years' homework to prepare for quizzes and ask Claire questions whenever you are confused. Do the practice exams to study for exams, and make a good cheat sheet.
Go to class. What Claire says is what she wants you to know.

I recommend this course for any student vaguely interested in the topic. Claire is very helpful and very nice. She really wants her students to do well, and she is always a great resource to go to. She knows the material very well so any questions you have will be answered if you approach her.
I think everyone, electrical engineer or not, should take this course. Prof. Gmachl is an incredible teacher and the subject matter is fascinating.
I would recommend this course, though you likely don't have a choice.

If you take this course, go to class, take good notes and go to office hours early and often to figure out what is going on in the class and what you should be doing outside of class to learn the material. The labs are cool.
It's a fun course. Take it if you want an STL but you want to do work and are ok with listening to lectures that you might not understand. Labs are very cool
Maybe read up on this kind of material outside of class to understand what is going on in lectures more.
Not enough math to fully understand the concepts - read yourself!
Not structured the best, but the concepts are interesting. Go to all lectures --- it is basically your sole source of understanding the material. Labs are interesting.

Not sure what this class is going to be like since Prof. Gmachl mentioned she would not be teaching it anymore. She is super nice, incredibly helpful, and really wants to make sure you are able to develop intuitions for problems and can approach them conceptually without needed a deep math or physics background.

Pretty much just ELE students who take this, although it would be an interesting class to take if you were interested in the chemistry/physics behind transistors and other electrical devices. A very qualitative class all things considered, which is nice.

Take it! If the course description interests you even slightly, take it! It's not a very time-consuming class, but I still learned so much, and it inspired me to pursue semi-conductor research (and the labs give a fairly good idea of what experimental semiconductor research is like, since we fabricate solar cells and transistors and lasers   LEDs and get to write lab abstracts analyzing some of their properties). It truly gives you necessary lab skills that will help in related research, and just genuine lab experience in general. And Prof. Gmachl is very kind! I didn't always find her explanations clear, so Piazza was sometimes more helpful to clear up doubts, but she really cares about her students and you should take the time to talk to her about your questions and just talk to her about all things ELE - I wish I had. Well worth the time!
Take only for ELE req

The class will likely be very different in future years, but this year it was very chill. If you pay attention in lab and lecture, the midterm/final are easy. Weekly quizzes may sometimes seem really confusing/difficult, but don't worry about them too much.
The lectures suck. I wouldn't bother going. Find a textbook and read that instead. The labs are great! Work hard in them and don't mess up.

This class had no homework this semester and honestly took up very little of my time. The only problem was that we didn't really have to work with the material that much so you have to motivate yourself to solidify it.

This course is pretty easy.... Labs are super cool (have you ever been in a Clean Room?) and not difficult. There are two tiny lab reports (really just abstracts) and basically no other work for lab. You can miss a lab or two and get a "free pass" if you really can't make it. But go to lab, because it really helps with understanding the material.... Claire is really nice, and a lenient grader. She is a brilliant person and a fantastic lecturer.... Don't worry if all of the mathematical explanations for the phenomena you study go way over your head. This course is introductory and about 99% qualitative.... This is an easy and interesting STL even if you are not ELE, and there are plenty of people (probably 15% of the class) who take this without being ELE.

This is required if your are an ELE major so there is no choice.  If you are not an ELE major, I wouldn't recommend the course.  It is not well-structured and very unrigorous.  If you are interested in the physics side of devices, perhaps you could take an upper-level or graduate ELE devices course after you take PHY 208.

Unfortunately future ELEs won't have the privilege of Claire teaching this class (with her very instructive chocolate teaching aids), but the material is not too difficult, the work is relatively light, and the labs, though long and tedious, have rewarding results in the form of your very own (hopefully) working transistors, solar cells, LEDs, and even lasers!

Watch the lecture slides and do the readings!
Take it if you want to understand the inner workings of the important electronic and photonic devices at the quantum level.
You might have a hard time understanding the material covered in the class, but the exams are definitely doable.
You probably have to take it, but it's a great course to take anyway! Love Claire!!!
You should take this if you want an easy lab class.
You will finally understand what a transistor is and how it works.
otherinfo: Free online textbook: https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~hu/Book-Chapters-and-Lecture-Slides-download.html
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Lab Reports - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Weekly homework, 2-4 laboratory reports over the term.
prereqs: MAT 103-104 and PHY 103-104. Contact instructor for questions. Pass/Fail not available to ELE majors..
descrip: Introduction to semiconductor devices centered around modern devices and technologies. Explores the physical basis of complex technologies from the perspective of solid state physics, electricity and magnetism, statistical mechanics, and quantum mechanics. Applications to be discussed include lighting, displays, computing, energy harvesting, sensing and imaging. Laboratory: fundamentals of micro- and nano-fabrication, fabrication of integrated circuits and optoelectronic devices.
title: Electronic and Photonic Devices

evals: Class was decent. Not the best ELE class, but required.
Either get really smart friends or go to office hours because lectures wont be that helpful
I mean if you're ELE there's not really a choice...

I will not say this class was all bad. That would be unfair. The labs were decent and the TAs were good. However, overall this class was very disorganized and one of my least favorite classes. The lectures were horrible.alf the class did not understand what was going on half the time. When we would stop Wysocki to ask questions, he would give more reasoning behind it. However, most of the time, we did not understand what we should be gaining from the lecture. He would move between topics without giving an explanation or motivation for the topic, which would confuse us more. We wondered what the build up he was doing for one topic had to do with the current one. It was overall fairly horrible.
I would recommend studying more than you think you have to for the exams, and starting on the problem sets fairly early in case something is unclear, because it can be hard to puzzle out by yourself.
If you want to learn controls, probably take the MAE version...if you're ELE, well this is mandatory...kind of confusing/disorganized but check out Youtube for some good controls stuff

If you're taking this class, you probably have to anyway. That said, I would follow along with topics in the textbook in addition to lectures. There aren't many psets so one can fall behind without something to solidify the things gone over in lecture.
Not a lot of work in the 1st half, but picks up pretty quick close to the midterm.
Only take it if you're ELE, there's little reason to otherwise.
Read the notes for the first half of the semester. Try to stay awake and take notes the second half of the semester.
Take it if you have too.
Take it if you're ELE

The concepts and labs are cool. The lectures and details can get a little complicated, so it's easy to lose sight of the overarching concepts. Exams are very math-heavy, but overall, the concepts are definitely worth learning
The information was interesting, lectures were difficult to follow, labs were good.

The material for this course is somewhat interesting, but not the most cohesive. As of right now, Professor Wysocki is a really nice guy but probably one of the worst lecturers I've had. He doesn't really explain what he's doing or justify why he's doing it, he just jumps in and starts doing it, making everyone in the class look around at each other with confused faces. Even the smartest students in the class often came away saying they didn't know what Wysocki was doing or why it was necessary for a given problem.

The material is interesting, even if the lectures aren't. Then again, if you're not forced to take this through ELE, you probably won't find the material too interesting and should probably stay away.
Try to stay awake in class!
You gotta take it.  Just suck it up and do it.  Also, don't space out for every single lecture because that leaves you with a lot to make up later
You need to stay on top of material; if you don't, or you miss one or two lectures, it's incredibly painful to catch back up.
You're taking this class because you have to, because you're ELE.  It's better than 201, but a lot of the same topics.  Ask the TA's for help!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Lab Reports - 25%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Weekly homework assignments and 5-40 pages of reading per week. Weekly labs include computing and simulation exercises using Matlab, sensor design, and system control.
prereqs: ELE 201 and ELE 203.
descrip: This course focuses on the science, engineering, and design of the highly integrated systems that dominate many of today's devices. Analysis of systems, sub-systems, and basic principles will be covered, with an emphasis on hardware-software optimization, sampling and digitization, signal and noise, feedback and control, and communication.
title: Designing Real Systems

evals: Great class. Professor Rand is a really nice guy and knows the material very well!

Most people wait to make their cheat sheet until right before the exam.  I would honestly keep one on at all times.  It would make the homework easier and also give you a timeline for the equations and formulas you learn.
Take it to get the math of 208!

This class will give you a very nice sampling of the properties of semiconductors, and how solid-state devices operate. The work load is very manageable, but you really need to stay engaged in lecture. Assignments are not particularly difficult conceptually, but can get a little tedious because of their plug-and-chug nature. Professor Rand really cares about students learning the material and is very open with his office hours. Overall I highly recommend the class if ELE208 left you wanting a more in-depth explanation behind device operation.
This course is excellent, especially as a followup for ELE 208. I would recommend this course to anyone with any interest into how electronic components actually work.
otherinfo: Preparation and presentation of a 25 minute seminar is an important part of the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: One problem set (about 4 problems) per week. 10-15 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: ELE 208 or equivalent..
descrip: The physics and technology of solid state devices. Review of electronic structure of semiconductors, energy bands and doping, followed by discussion of carrier transport by drift and diffusion and recombination/generation. Detailed analysis of p-n junctions, bipolar transistors and field effect transistors. Survey of a wide range of devices, including photodetectors, solar cells, light-emitting diodes and semiconductor lasers, highlighting contemporary concepts such as thin film electronics and 2D semiconductors.
title: Solid-State Devices

otherinfo: Grading is done by individual project advisors, a second reader and an oral committee. A grade for ELE 397 is given at the end of the fall semester even if the project continues in the spring semester. Three graded elements: Detailed proposal and literature review- 10%, Oral presentation - 25%, Final report - 65%
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: No formal assignments, but the student is expected to average at least six to ten hours per week and to make regular progress reports. An oral presentation as well as a final written report is required.
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.
title: Junior Independent Work

evals: I'd definitely recommend it with Professor Shayegan
Lots of work, but you learn a lot.
Study regularly and practice all the materials provided. Class was very helpful, should attend all of them.
This course will take up the majority of your time due to the weekly problem sets, but all of the problems were very helpful in understanding the core concepts covered in the class.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly reading and homework assignments.
prereqs: ELE 342 or PHY 208 and PHY 305 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the properties of solids. Theory of free electrons--classical and quantum. Crystal structure and methods of determination. Electron energy levels in a crystal: weak potential and tight-binding limits. Classification of solids--metals, semiconductors and insulators. Types of bonding and cohesion in crystals. Lattice dynamics, phonon spectra and thermal properties of harmonic crystals.
title: Solid-State Physics I

evals: Pay attention, read the notes and do the work and the class will be both interesting and doable.
Study regularly and practice all the materials provided. Class was very helpful, should attend all of them.

This course has a lot of theory and math involved and so can be a little overwhelming if you're out of practice. Problem sets were bi-weekly and never took more than a handful of hours to complete, but your mileage may vary depending on past experience.
Would only recommend taking the course with a solid background in E&M. Otherwise, quality course.
needs very good backgrounds in Vector Calculus, Maxwell Equations, Schrodinger Equations.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 60%
assgts: Weekly problem sets (5-10 pages).
descrip: Fundmentals of light-matter interactions, waveguides and resonators, nonlinear optics and lasers.
title: Optical Electronics

evals: I think this class provides a good primer for anyone interested in optical systems and photonics. The lectures strike a good balance between math and theory, and Professor Prucnal is great about making sure everyone understands the topics before moving on.

I will strongly recommend them to take the class if they are interested in photonics and optical communications. In the class, you will not only learn the basic knowledge of optical communications. Through the research projects and the talks given by graduate students and post-doc, you will know the state-of-the-art photonic technology.

This is an interesting course, and the Professor is one of the best in the field. Definitely take if you are interested! Very manageable workload, and although 8:30AM may seem tough, it really isn't that bad. There was significantly better 1-on-1 time with the professor.

Worth taking if you are interested in fiber optics, but be prepared to be extremely frustrated by problem sets and unhelpful TAs. Get a study group together to do homework and spend a decent amount of effort on the lab project since it's such a big component of your grade. This year our labs only met for half the semester and we had problem sets during the other half. I think this might be changed in the future, so you may want to check with Professor Prucnal about course expectations outside of lecture attendance.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Problem set(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Problem Sets; Research Paper.
descrip: This course provides a working knowledge of the components comprising fiber-optic networks, which form the backbone of today's communication networks, including the global internet, 4G wireless, home access and data center networks. The operation of lasers, fiber optics and optical routers will be discussed, as will current applications such as fiber to the home, the broadband wireless-optical interface, all-optical switching, signal processing and computing, and security in fibers. The course will also provide lab demonstrations and visits to the Lightwave Communications Research Lab.
title: Photonics and Light Wave Communications

evals: A difficult course for undergraduates - ELE 206, ELE 375, and ELE 304 all provide valuable background as preparation for taking this course, but it could be done, and many have done it, with only the 200-level ELE classes. First problem set is the most difficult, then it slowly levels off.
Fantastic class and best lectures - probably one of the best but hardest courses I've taken. Take this as a 4-class semester and give it time
The rumors are true. You'll learn a boatload, but it's gonna take a boatload of work. If you're interested in VLSI, and can handle the workload, absolutely worth it.
Verma is very generous with office hours and general availability. The material is quite difficult so take advantage of this!

You will have all the information and warning you need beforehand.

Start problem sets early. Start the project early. Be prepared for a lot of work. Ask a lot of questions.

Good luck!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 20%, Design Project - 35%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Approximately 25 pages of reading per week
descrip: Analysis and design of digital integrated circuits using deep sub-micron CMOS technologies as well as emerging and post-CMOS technologies (Si finFETs, III-V, carbon). Emphasis on design, including synthesis, simulation, layout and post-layout verification.Analysis of energy, power, performance, area of logic-gates, interconnect and signaling structures.
title: Design of Very Large-Scale Integrated (VLSI) Systems

evals: A good course. If you can, you should probably take it. We studied interesting, engaging cases each class and drew lessons from them. The class relied too much on student content for my liking: the airtime in the class was probably 80% students talking and 20% Professor Kuenne talking. I think I would have learnt more if Professor Kuenne talked more. The 30% participation grade made the class feel very competitive; there is a constant pressure to say things, even if you don't have anything very valuable to add. I believe this causes the quality of student contributions to be lower than they would otherwise be if participation was a less-important part of the grade. If you have not taken any entrepreneurship courses before, I would recommend taking EGR 201 (with the excellent Prof. Kasdin) instead of EGR 491 because the class environment is less high-pressured and I felt I learned more from that class.
Be prepared to make and listen to hollow comments made just for a grade.

By applying for this course, you are not just applying for the opportunity to learn valuable life and business skills - you are applying to become part of an inclusive, diverse and generous community. Strongly recommended for anyone who doesn't dread teamwork and collaboration.
Do the readings. Participate. Enjoy
Do the readings; a bit of Googling about each case before class goes a long way too.
Every response in class matters. Focus on the quality of responses as much as the quantity.

Excellent course?overlaps with many of the other EGR courses with an added look at marketing. Far and away the best in terms of structure and quality. BEWARE?PARTICIPATION FORMAT IS TERRIBLE. 33% of your grade is dependent on you talking out of your ass every class and results in everyone repeating the same thing over and over.
I highly highly recommend this class for any students interested in business.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to think about their passions and discover new areas in the full time career space that may not be obvious.

I would recommend this class if you are looking for something less academic and more applicable to the real world. I was worried about having no tech background when taking the class, but it's not really something you should be concerned about. The class definitely made me interested in entrepreneurship.
I'd recommend this course. Very different from a typical Princeton course, very refreshing
If you are interested in entrepreneurship, you have to take this class.

Kuenne is the MAN! The guy is an incredible professor and mentor: humble, wise, genuinely cares about the students (I'm sure you've heard this for a number of classes, but out of all the ones I've taken, Kuenne is the most caring and down-to-earth prof). A friend once remarked that Kuenne just knows how to make you feel special, and indeed, I felt like not letting him down became another reason to work hard in the class. Great for learning about entrepreneurship frameworks and success and failure stories. THAT SAID, while the prof is incredible and first rate, I found the class and content did not live up to their lofty reviews. I left the class feeling I didn't TRULY learn that much - if you really want good entrepreneurship advice, read the lean startup - and the people in the class were annoyingly tryhard. Because the class is 90% discussion, you get a LOT of people raising their hands all the time with very little to say, and Kuenne is too nice to not entertain low-quality comments, which makes the class move rather slowly and in a cringe-worthy way at times.
Participate as much as you can.
Some people say this is the best course at Princeton. I don't know if I would go that far, but it definitely a good one. Sometimes discussions could drag on, but overall the content is high quality.
TAKE IT!! It is a life changing course. It reminds you why you came to Princeton. Professor Kuenne is an amazing person to listen to and talk to.

TAKE THIS CLASS.  This class is the by far the best class that I have taken at Princeton so far.  Extremely interesting material that really gets you thinking beyond the orange bubble and the trials/joys of starting one's own business.  One word of warning though don't think you can just coast through.  You need to thoughtfully do all the case study readings as participation can be competitive (and you are graded on it).
Take it!
Take this class! Very interesting and highly recommend. Grading can be a little difficult, but the class is rewarding in itself.
Take this course! It is awesome and by far one of the best courses at Princeton. All of the readings are so interesting and fun to read.

This class is great and one of a kind, mostly due to Professor Kuenne. I would highly recommend. NOTE: This class is fairly high commitment, attendance and participation closely tracked. Additionally, the assignments are quite involved, particularly contacting other companies/startups for projects. It's likely that your company will not be as great as others, so expect a challenge getting an A-range grade.
This class is very participation-heavy and the students are generally very intense, but the content is interesting and Professor Kuenne is absolutely amazing

This is a must-take class for anyone remotely interested in entrepreneurship, technology, or business in general. This class was nothing like any other course I've taken at Princeton and I can truly say that it is one of the defining classes of my Princeton experience thus-far. A word of warning; it's a good deal of work, but you get as much out of the class as you put into it. Only take this if you're willing to devote a significant amount of time to unpacking each of the case studies and developing your own points/arguments for discussion. Also, don't be intimidated by the discussion format - some people like to talk a lot, but speaking sparingly and making deeper points is definitely what Prof. Kuenne prefers.
This was the most engaging class I've taken at Princeton--and the one I've learned the most in. Take it!
What they say is true - best class so far at Princeton.
You do learn a lot, but don't take it expecting an easy A. The class is definitely pretty competitive.
take
otherinfo: The course includes lecture/discussion sessions, readings from articles, classroom discussions of "cases" describing real entrepreneurial situations, and a few visits to class by entrepreneurs to provide current "real world" guidance.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 35%, Term Paper(s) - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Students must read a case study for each class, plus supplemental readings that lay out key frameworks, totaling 30-65 pages per week. Participation grades are awarded for insightful analysis and fact-based recommendations. For the midterm and final assignments, students select a start-up and interview the founder. The midterm paper is a written analysis of the company, whereas for the final presentation, students must develop a growth initiative and pitch it as if seeking financing.
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application bit.ly/ELE491App, deadline is April 18..
descrip: This hands-on course introduces students to analysis and actions required to launch and commercialize a tech company, through the use of Harvard Business School cases, visits from entrepreneurs, and two "field assignments". You will learn conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques for evaluating technologies, markets, and commercialization strategies. Additionally, you will learn how to attract and motivate the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners and venture capital), prepare business plans, structure relationships, refine product-market fit, and create and grow enterprise value.
title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship

otherinfo: Grading is done by individual project advisers and the second reader.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: The student is expected to average at least six to ten hours per week on the project and make regular progress reports to the adviser.
prereqs: For each project the structural deadlines and evaluations are set in consultation with the faculty advisor. A poster session during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and written midterm report will be required submission to both the adviser and second reader, the due date determined by adviser. A senior thesis presentation will be held at the end of spring. The unbound senior thesis must be turned in to the ELE Undergraduate Office on the University's established senior thesis submission deadline..
descrip: Senior Thesis Course. The student has the opportunity to do a self driven project by proposing a topic and finding a faculty member willing to supervise the work, or, the student may do a project in conjunction with a faculty member's research. A second reader will be required for both the midterm report and final thesis report. Students will be required to enroll in ELE 498 in the spring.
title: Senior Independent Work

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
prereqs: Students taking this course should have a prior course in applied probability at the undergraduate level..
descrip: Fundamentals of probability and random processes relevant to information sciences and systems: radon-nikodym derivatives lebesgue integrals; laws of large numbers, central limit theorems, large deviations, marron chains, poisson point processes, measure concentration.
title: Random Processes in Information Systems

evals:
AAAAA. 

I claim that this is the best Machine Learning course at Princeton for anyone who desires the mathematical derivation behind *why* Machine Learning concepts work the way they do. 

I have taken COS 402 (AI), COS 495 (Deep Learning), ORF309 (Probability), ORF 363 (Optimization). I have sat in on lectures for COS 424 (Fundamentals of Machine Learning), ORF 350 (Big Data). I have read over lecture notes for COS 511 (Theoretical Machine Learning).

I honestly believe ELE 535 with Prof. Ramadge is the gold mine. The intuition behind the concepts: PCA, Regression, MLE, Sparsity, SVM, Kernels, Deep Learning in this class have enlightened me far more than in any of my previous classes. 

I gained more insight from his one hour lecture on Deep Learning than I did from the entirety of COS 402 or COS 495.

I will recommend ORF 363 as a pre-requisite (a great class with Prof. Ahmadi) as a solid understanding of linear algebra and convexity are important. For those of you who can handle your own with Linear Algebra and proofs (of the ORF 363 flavor). I cannot recommend this class enough.

I realized that the ELE department has many graduate-level classes that cover what is fundamental to Machine Learning and that many COS majors and ORF majors have overlooked this. 

If you are dissatisfied with classes that throw Machine Learning algorithms at you adhoc out-of-the-blue (Here's a Random Forest, plug it in!) and come out of them still confused, then look no further. ELE 535 has the answers that you seek. (You should be comfortable with math, though.)

As an ELE senior, I found this class to be very mathematically rigorous and challenging, but definitely rewarding. The class is based on the theory behind many machine learning techniques, but be aware it doesn't cover the recent hotness of neural nets and deep learning in very much detail. However, it is a must-take for students interested in understanding and engaging with ML. It is useful to have taken ORF309, ORF363, and ORF350 before this class. Prof. Ramadge's ELE488 is also a solid introduction to elements of this class. Definitely take if you are serious about pursuing machine learning in research or industry, and especially if Ramadge is teaching!
Be ready for a challenging class that requires a strong background in linear algebra.
Do not hesitate to take this.  Excellent course and a very good introduction to the subject.  One of the best courses I have taken here.
Fantastic course! Well organized
Great class if you're interested in a very quantitative view of ML. Deriving the material in the notes by hand is the best way to prep for exams.
Great course with a great professor! Challenging but worth it
Great lectures and materials, will consume a lot of time, rigorous covering of core topics in machine learning

I would strongly recommend this course for anyone interested in Machine Learning. The lectures are well structured, well delivered and extremely useful. The assignments (theory and programming) are well designed to challenge students as well as help learn the content better
I would tell another student to plan on spending a lot of time working on homework assignments for the class but ultimately learn a lot.
It's a difficult course and math-heavy (especially linear algebra), but if you're at all interested in machine learning, you should definitely take it! Professor Ramadge is awesome.
Read the notes and have a very solid understanding of linear algebra.
Strongly recommend. This course is very mathematical.

TAKE IT! The material is fascinating and very thoroughly presented. Ramadge is a first-rate lecturer. This class is one of the most challenging I've taken at Princeton, but the workload is actually very reasonable. If you want to learn the material super thoroughly though, you have to do more than just the problem sets. I felt that I could have gotten more out of the class if I had put more time and effort into it. My background - senior ORFE student who took ORF 350 and ORF 363. This class is MUCH better than ORF 350, but 350 was helpful in exposing me to much of the material first. ORF 363 was very helpful in the exposure to convexity, optimization, and some practical linear algebra.
Take this class, and take it with some prior background as the class moves quite fast. Linear Algebra background is absolutely indispensable.

Take this course if you are interested in machine learning. Professor Ramadge is a great lecturer and you will learn a lot. Course has lots of theory and will have an extensive revision of linear algebra in the first lectures. Assignments nearly every week with part of coding in python and maths proofs. Proofs part can be challenging and this is definitely not an easy workload course but definitely take if you are ready to put in the hours.

Take this course if you are interested in the mathematical aspects of some aspects of machine learning. Note that the course does not cover popular topics such as graphical models or Bayesian inference.
Take this course! Professor Ramadge is an excellent lecturer, and the problem sets do a good job of helping students understand the material.
This course is interesting, but very labor-intensive! Only take if you're willing to put in a lot of time.

This is a fantastic class to take if you are interested in machine learning and want a more rigorous, mathematical approach to it, in contrast to the very hand-wavy approach adopted in most introductory machine learning classes. After this class, you will really solidly understand key concepts behind principal component analysis, least squares regression, sparse regression, minimum mean squared estimators, support vector machines, and kernels. And you will be able to give sketches of their proofs and understand how to extend them. Be warned though, this class involves a lot of linear algebra and it would be good to brush up beforehand.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Problem set and a lab report.
descrip: The course is an introduction to the theoretical foundations of machine learning and pattern recognition. A variety of classical and recent results in machine learning and statistical pattern classification are discussed. Topics include Bayesian classification, regression, regularization, maximum margin classification, kernels, neural networks and stochastic approximation.
title: Machine Learning and Pattern Recognition

evals: Good overview of Information Security. By the end of the course you will be able to read/understand current research in the area.
Highly recommend taking this course..
Take it if interested. You wont regret it. But keep in mind that a general IT knowledge is required throughout the course.
grading: Design Project - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: This course focuses on secure communication built on information theory, which does not assume that an adversary has computational limitations. We begin with classic results on secrecy systems by Shannon and Wyner, paving the way for a study of modern research on physical-layer security, secret key agreement, etc. We consider distortion guarantee as a metric for partial secrecy and compare to the more traditional use of equivocation. The course also touches on other aspects of secure communication, such as authentication. Related topics such as digital watermarking and information embedding is also discussed.
title: Special Topics in Information Sciences and Systems - Information Theoretic Security

evals: Classes were very helpful, learned a lot from them.
For those students with a previous background in devices, it is really not necessary to take this course.
Good for students with real interests.
Recommended for students who never learned electronic devices.
otherinfo: Text Book is optional, other references will be given in class.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: Introduction to principles of electron behavior in semiconductors and applications to device physics. Band diagrams, Metal-semiconductor contacts, Schottky barriers, p-n junctions. MOS electronics, FET's, bipolar transistors, solar cells, optical detectors, LED.
title: Electronic Devices

evals: Attend all of the classes.
Definitely take this class (aside from it being required) to aid in selecting a research advisor
It is required for graduate student in EE anyway.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Introduction to the topics and methods of research in electronic materials and devices, providing an overview of current research of the faculty in electronic materials and devices, and in optical and optoelectronic engineering.
title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Advanced Topics in Electronic and Optoelectronic Materials and Devices

evals: A good formal introduction to the English Department. The readings and discussions were the highlights of the course and the professor's penchant to call upon people at random to respond at times helped to ease people into discussion while still holding the class to the standard of having prepared all of the material.

Do the readings and use the prompts to spur your thinking about the readings before class.  It's helpful to come to class with already formulated ideas/questions about the readings.  Even if you don't get to bring them up, the process of coming up with ideas/questions will help you to better engage with the readings and the in-class discussion.
Do the readings well ahead of time; some of them can be quite time-consuming, especially if you're a slow reader.
Do the readings, show up to class ready to participate, make appointments with the professor if you have questions on anything.
Good seminar to choose.

I thought that this Junior Sem topic was very interesting, it just felt a little truncated. It felt like every week was a new class, and I wish that the texts and themes were more linked week-to-week.
If you can get this seminar, definitely take it.

Professor Anderson is a thoughtful, kind and incredibly clever teacher.  She works to make sure that every student is working with material that engages him or her on a personal level, and somehow manages to provide incredible insight regardless of the student's chosen area of study.  She demands an intense level of academic engagement, but in a manner that is encouraging rather than intimidating.  She offered me an entirely new perspective on feminist writing and I'm so glad that I had the chance to work with her.
Professor Wills is a great, I'd take it if you're interested in violence.
Professor Wills is a really good advisor!
Start the assignments early!

Start the memos a week in advance as opposed to the night before because shorter essays are a lot harder to do well on. You can't BS for three pages if you're only turning in one. Also, practice your speaking skills.
Study! Do the readings! Participate!
Take it if you want a background in protest lit.
When choosing your junior seminar, evaluate the material, but also the professor above all else.
do not take this course.
n/a
otherinfo: Seminar assignments will be posted outside the English office.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: This course consists of several unique seminars. The reading and writing assignments will be determined by each professor for his or her seminar.
descrip: Students learn to write clear and persuasive criticism in a workshop setting while becoming familiar with a variety of critical practices and research methods. The course culminates in the writing of a junior paper. Each section will pursue its own topic: students are assigned according to choices made during sophomore sign-ins. Required of all English majors.
title: Junior Seminar in Critical Writing

evals: Cole is a nice guy, but the CT is kind of hard to engage with without more context about Chaucer's time.  Thus I didn't really enjoy doing the readings.
Cole is a phenomenal lecturer.
I would recommend this course! Not too much reading, but you'll get much more out of the course if you put in the time to do all the reading thoroughly.

I would suggest this course to get a British lit requirement out of the way for English majors. And there were also plenty of non-English majors who were very engaged in the course so if the subject matter interests you, then go for it. The class is what you make of it.
It's a 300-level English course but many non-English majors take it-- this can be nice or not-so-nice depending on the balance of the class and the level of engagement overall.
Solid course; Cole leads a great seminar and you learn a ton about Chaucer and analyzing texts in general.  Not too much work, papers are graded someone stringently though.
Take it!
Take it!!
Take this class! Prof Cole is wonderful and hilarious. It's not too much reading and the reading is fun!
Take this if you have taken previous English classes at Princeton. It is extremely interesting, but seems to be more for English majors.

This is a great class, taught by a professor who really knows his stuff and is serious about his subject, but likes to keep things lighthearted and fun. If you can handle a couple of readings a week, and a paper about every month, you should definitely treat yourself.
Very cool course.  Light work load and fascinating material.  Professor Cole is also very enthusiastic when giving lectures and discussing Chaucer in general.  Would definitely recommend.
otherinfo: Department Distribution: British Foundations.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Approximately one Tale for each class, plus some secondary reading. Three (7-page) papers. Reading quizzes and short in-class brainstorming assignments, counting as participation.
descrip: Look up Geoffrey Chaucer in the Urban Dictionary, and you will find an entry describing him as the original urban dictionary, a "medieval poet" whose Canterbury Tales "is a collection of stories filled with plenty of swearing, slang, and fart jokes." In this course we will read and discuss that Chaucer--the brilliant, hilarious, dirty poet of the Canterbury Tales. We will enjoy this fun, often moving text while learning about the poet's artistry, both the literary traditions he so deftly works over, and the sexual, political, and religious issues he so astutely figures and, as is so often the case, perverts.
title: Chaucer

evals: A great way to get into Shakespeare.
Definitely take this course if Professor Dolven is offering it.  He is a very good lecturer, whether you are deeply interested in Shakespeare or not.
Definitely take this course! I wish I could take Shakespeare II in the spring.

Definitely take this! It could help you decide whether or not the English department is for you, or is just great if you have a general interest in Shakespeare. When else in your life will you get the opportunity to read such a big portion of his work?
Don't take it if you hate Shakespeare, but aside from that, the course has everything to recommend it.
I definitely recommend taking this course even if one is not interested in pursuing English as their major. The subject matter is excellent and the lectures and precepts are insightful and enjoyable.
Read each play! They are actually quite fun to complete.
Take it if you're interested in Shakespeare or if you want to improve in your writing.
Take it!
Take it--SO well taught. & make sure you do the readings so it doesn't come back and haunt you when you take the final (!)
Take this course if you are interested in Shakespeare! It's not a lot of work, and Professor Dolven is a fantastic lecturer.
Take this course if you're remotely interested in Shakespeare (you should be).

This is a great look at Shakespeare. I loved Dan and Professor Dolven always gave great lectures (even at 10am!). However, the written assignments really add up and will take a lot of time. Be ready for a lot of reading and writing!!

To any English major who has an interest in Shakespeare, definitely take this course. However, be aware that you read 1 play a week for the most part, so don't fall behind on the reading, which can be fairly intense when this course is taken in conjunction with 3 or 4 other courses.
otherinfo: Department Distribution: British Foundation
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Usually one play per week, two papers, a midterm, a final exercise.
descrip: The first half of Shakespeare's career, with a focus on the great comedies and histories of the 1590s.
title: Shakespeare I

evals: 100% recommend if you enjoy Jane Austin. Extremely engaging and fun class!

An excellent English course at Princeton.  I would highly recommend to anyone who likes Austen and would challenge those who don't to take it and see if it changes their minds.  The volume of reading is high unless you've read the books before, so I'd advise reading in advance over the summer.

Everyone should really know Jane Austen beyond Pride & Prejudice. Prof. Johnson is a big name in Austen scholars, so you can't miss this! As an English major though, I warn off those who don't want to put in the work and contribute thoughtfully to precept.
Fantastic.

If you like Jane Austen, take this course! IF you don't know if you like Jane Austen, take this course! If you haven't heard of Jane Austen, take this course! Professor Johnson knows so much about her and gives really good lectures. I cannot recommend highly enough!!!!
If you like Jane Austen, you should take it.  Although, I hope that would be self-explanatory.
Like Austen? Never read her? Take it.
Read the novels. Attend lectures. Participate in precept.
Really great course that gives an excellent beginning for a deep understanding of one of our best authors.
Super engaging and insightful class. I never expected Austen's novels to be so insanely thought-provoking.
TAKE IT.
Take if you love Austen.
Take it if you love Austen. You don't have to be an English major! The amount of reading is extensive, so I'd recommend finishing maybe 2 or 3 Austen novels before the course.
Take it!
Take it, whether for a departmental or an interest in Austen. I was hesitant to spoil my love of Austen by studying her, but Professor Johnson's lectures did just the opposite.
Take it. Take the course. If you have even the slightest interest in Jane Austen, take it. Professor Johnson will make you love her.
Take this class! Professor Johnson is an incredible lecturer, and you'll leave the class having learned a lot.
The class was a great opportunity to gain insight on aspects you never noticed before. Even if you have only read one Austen novel, the class is still interesting and worthwhile.

The readings are naturally very substantial. As such, it is useful to have read *most* of the books in advance. This will allow you to really focus on subtext rather than on plot and to engage in the more subtle aspects of Austen's writing. The course makes you rethink your preconceived notions about Austen's meanings and to question conventional interpretations. Overall, very enlightening for those who have an appreciation for Austen's art.
There is a lot of reading, and you can't get through the course without doing all of it. The books are a pleasure to read, though, so it's worth it.

This course was fantastic. Prof. Johnson's lectures were wonderful, and everyone was engaged in the precepts. Rosalind was a great preceptor, and I would highly recommend it if she precepts again next time.
Try to engage with all the texts and always start the papers early to ensure you have enough time to receive feedback.
Would absolutely recommend! Engaging, fun class where your homework is to read about Mr. Darcy. Doesn't get better than that.
interesting class if you want to take a relaxing English class
otherinfo: This course is co-taught by Professor Claudia Johnson and graduate student Hope Rogers through the Collaborative Teaching Initiative. Distribution Requirement: British
grading: Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: 150 pages of reading per week; approximately 300 pages of reading every two weeks, in addition to critical essays and required viewings; two 10-12pp essays; and blackboard postings (20%).
descrip: This class will consider Jane Austen not only the inventor of the classic novel but also as an inspiring author who is--thanks to a steady stream of adaptations spinoffs and sequels--our contemporary. Pairing each novel with recent movies, vlogs or tv shows, we will show how Austen is perpetually current in her treatment of love, violence, sisterhood, sex and gender, and we will also ponder how modern texts speak back to her. Exploring Austen's modernity and her difference, we will learn as much about ourselves as about her novels.
title: Topics in 18th-Century Literature - Jane Austen Then and Now

evals: AAA TAKE THIS COURSE ? if you graduate Princeton without having taken a course with Jeff, you have not lived. His lectures are legendary. This has been my favorite course of all time. Do yourself a favor and take this class. You will have no regrets.
Awesome class. Not hard, definitely the easiest PDF possible. So much fun, take it.

Excellent choice for a more relaxed literature class. Preceptor, Matt Kumar, was superb quality in that he led a good discussion (albeit a bit slow sometimes), gave needed reminders, put lots of effort into feedback, and showed a genuine investment in complementing the lectures.
Prof. Nunokawa can be a bit overwhelming, but displays true literary genius. If a student is looking to learn about literature, to truly enjoy novels throughout the semester, to build on a love of reading, to look at literature in a new light, this class is the best for it. Learned a lot about literature, and that's all I came for. (Some kids might get a little obsessed with the class/professor, but it's best to just treat it as a more entertaining than usual English class - focus on the books and what you learn.)
Go to all the lectures. And try to read as much as you can. You don't have to read everything to write good papers.

Great course and great books! The 19th century is so foreign and so real all at the same time. Jeff takes some getting used to, so warning, but he's an amazing experience. Make sure you read at least 2 books so you can write a decent paper, but of course try to read all of them.
I can confirm it's a great class.
Lots of reading but great class!
One hundred percent I recommend this course, it is amazing!!!! Lectures are fantastic and you will learn a ton. Read at least one novel (I suggest Middlemarch) before the semester!!
Reading load builds up very quickly, but they are all great books.  The course will benefit from better organization.

TAKE IT!!! You will be missing an incredible opportunity if you do not take a class with Jeff Nunokawa at Princeton. Make the time to read the books, go to all the lectures (not because you have to, but because they are amazing) and you will learn so much about HUMAN BEINGS not just 19th century fiction.
TAKE THIS CLASS -- lectures are engaging and fascinating, and papers are short and not a lot of work. This is one of the best classes I've taken here.
Take it for Jeff
Take it!
Take it!!! Amazing English class, Jeff is amazing
Take this class, you will not regret it. Try to get a head start on the readings because they really do sneak up on you. This class is phenomenal.
Take this course only if you want to read the novels. Jeff is overhyped as a lecturer.

Take this course, especially if you DON'T currently have an appreciation for Victorian literature. Jeff made me realize how much it has to teach us about empathy and understanding the human condition, and his lectures are very engaging.
Take this course, it is a lot of reading but not too much work apart from that. The lectures are really entertaining and interesting.

The quality of the course was excellent. Jeff knows how to keep students engaged in both lectures and precept. I took this as a student considering the English major and a lover of 19th Century Fiction, so other students may experience this class differently. If considering this course, make sure you are able to devote at least an hour a day to reading. There is roughly 300-400 pages of reading a week. But you the lectures go in depth enough and the books are well enough known/read that it is not necessary to complete all of the readings; you can still learn from the course and succeed without reading everything.
This class is amazing!!! The books are very long but intersting.

This course is a gift to the world--don't walk away from Princeton if you haven't availed yourself of this opportunity. I don't care if you think Jane Austen is silly or George Eliot is a bore. If you give Jeff a chance, he will change your mind. With all his panting in lectures, he seems to blow the dust off these old novels. He makes their sentiments, which are actually timeless, accessible to "you young people." These books as well as his lectures are powerful, and it's not likely that you'll find any class anywhere else that comes close. Quintessential Princeton. Don't pass it up.

This is a  really fun, fascinating class. I learned a lot about what 19th century fiction can say and teach us about the world, and Jeff has a lot of really fascinating takes on it. The lectures are amazing (and even more amazing if you do the readings for them), ,but there's a TON of reading. If you take this class, definitely start the reading early! But take it, it's so much fun and you learn a lot.
You must learn under the sweaty wings of Jeff Nunokawa at least once before you graduate. Every lecture is a revelation. It's just a sight to behold.
Your loss if you don't.
highly recommend if you're willing to do a lot of reading b/c Jeff puts his whole soul in the lectures and presents ideas that will feel central to your life
who cares this is my last course, I'm graduating, LATER FELLAS
otherinfo: Departmental Distribution: Modernity
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: A novel every week or two weeks.
descrip: This course will acquaint students with the distinctive features of the nineteenth century novel, from Austen to Hardy. Lectures will seek to illuminate relations between social and aesthetic dimensions of the texts we read. We will consider how these fictional imaginings of things like love, sex, money, class, and race help shape the ways we live now.
title: 19th-Century Fiction

evals: It's an interesting English course to take, reading load is manageable and enjoyable.

Prof Sandberg is an amazing professor and the class is very discussion oriented.  I took it even though I didn't really have time for it (so I PDFed) and I still did almost all of the reading because it was so fun.
Prof. Sandberg is one of Princeton's best teachers. Take it!
Professor Sandberg is a great teacher. The class is a fair amount of reading but Bob is very supportive and always willing to talk outside of class about the texts. It's a lot of fun.
Take this course! Sandberg is kind, engaging, and knowledgeable. The workload is not particularly heavy (only two papers), so you will get out of reading and discussion what you put in.

The highlight of my semester - Professor Sandberg is a one-of-a-kind professor who makes every text exciting and relevant. Class discussions were lively and enlightening and frequently hilarious, and the texts you cover are varied and fascinating. I cannot recommend this course highly enough. Take it.
otherinfo: When possible, we will attend relevant productions and watch videos to better appreciate the fact that a play is a form of literature written to be performed. Department Distribution: Modernity
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: Two plays per week. Other 35% = Short papers in the format of Blackboard posts and responses.
descrip: A study of major plays by Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekov, Pirandello, Brecht, Beckett and others. Artists who revolutionized the stage by transforming it into a venue for avant-garde social, political, psychological, artistic and metaphysical thought, creating the theatre we know today.
title: Modern Drama I

evals: Definitely take this class if you can!  The authors are interesting, and Mitchell does an excellent job working with the material and making sure that class is dynamic, engaging, and thought-provoking.  One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton, by far.
Definitely take this course. Lee Mitchell is incredible and it is an extremely manageable workload.
Don't be overwhelmed by the reading. They're far from easy reads, but Professor Mitchell does a good job of walking the class through them.
Enjoy it
Incredible-- one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Take it! Lee Mitchell is an inspiration, and his lectures are incredible...
Mitchell is a great lecturer. The Faulkner readings were particularly good. Overall an enjoyable class with loads of reading.

Professor Mitchell is a truly amazing teacher. He encourages students to engage with dense texts with a critical eye and a conscientious mind. This is a must take if you are interested in Henry James and/or William Faulkner! Strongly recommended!
Take this course!
otherinfo: Department Distribution: American Foundation
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 250 pages of reading per week, midterm paper (5 pp).
descrip: This course examines the careers of two of America's most accomplished novelists. Manifest differences aside, both authors were obsessed with the ensnaring effects of plot, prompting both to imagine fictional realms that are as much "designs" on the reader as on characters.
title: Topics in American Literature - Henry James and William Faulkner

evals: Absolutely take this!
Start the poetry books early, don't read the entire thing the night before class begins.
TAKE IT
Take it if you enjoy poetry or are afraid of it but want to learn how to appreciate it better
Take it. I promise you will learn tons and will absolutely think of it as your favorite class (and this is coming from an engineering major)

Take it. I was a non-humanities person who took this course on a whim, and it was one of my favorites at Princeton. You'll learn a lot about poetry. Writing reviews is hard, but they force you to engage with texts in ways papers don't. You'll learn how to approach poetry from many ways, and better yet, you'll learn how to put your thoughts about poems into words. I knew very little about poetry going into this course, and now reading poetry excites me. Kotin is very nice and great a facilitating discussion. It is also cool to meet a lot of the poets whose work you are reading through guest seminars.
This is without a doubt the best course I've taken at Princeton.

Yes, absolutely. Professor Kotin in twelve weeks has changed the way that I read poetry. I now am eager to embrace the bewilderment attendant to each interaction with a new poet/poem/book of poems. Poetry by its nature always at first destabilizes and befuddles its readers, and this class has made me marvel at the fact that we can be confused by language so constantly and utterly.
otherinfo: Distribution Requirement: Modernity
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 15%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Students will write six reviews, ranging from one to eight pages.
descrip: This seminar focuses exclusively on books of poetry published in 2017. We will read work by established and emerging poets, and attend poetry readings in Princeton (and possibly New York and Philadelphia). Poets will also visit the class to discuss their work and/or the work of writers they admire. Students will write reviews, rather than essays, and, in the process, learn about (and contribute to) the institutions that support and promote contemporary writing.
title: Topics in Poetry - Contemporary Poetry

evals: As an English Major, I was not a huge fan of this course. The quality of the readings is inconsistent and lectures seldom engaged with any specifics on a meaningful level. I suppose the course would be fairly accessible for non-majors though.
Great teacher and really interesting class. It's some work but nothing horrific.

Lectures are important to go to for the notes handed out, but kinda torturous. If you're the kind of person who aces attendance, this class is for you. Material is 100% worth reading, it just won't get discussed very well unless they change this to seminar format, which I hope they do.
Simon is great! He is one of the most engaging lecturers. Imagine Mussolini with a Kenyan accent.

Take this class. Gikandi is an amazing lecturer and I loved every bit of it. It really makes you think about literature and evil in a different way. It is definitely the best class I've ever taken at Princeton.

Take this course! The professor is awesome and the course material is super interesting. Professor Gikandi is one of the premier people in his field when it comes to talking about ethical issues of evil.

This class is more of a lecture in which you ask the professor questions than a discussion in which everyone's opinion might be correct.
