However, the topics of the class did allow me to consider important questions such as the role of literature in a suffering and often evil world as well as how or if art should depict and discuss radical evil. I would suggest writing down points or questions to make before lecture and precept and not being afraid to disagree with the professor or with anyone.
This course was one of my favourite English classes I've taken at Princeton. The texts and lectures were extremely engaging and I never looked at the clock in this class.
This is a challenging course, but definitely worth taking. All the books are books I would read for fun and the lectures are  engaging and enhance the material.

aa: Please take this course! It is my favorite course so far at Princeton, and that says a lot considering that I've loved all of my courses. Professor Gikandi has so many interesting things to say, and the readings are very doable and interesting. I learned more about myself, my friends, my family, and the world from this class.
otherinfo: Distribution Requirement: Theory/Criticism and Diaspora
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Readings: 150 pages of reading per week, oral presentations, short response papers, midterm paper, and one research paper
descrip: This is a course on the problem of evil in the modern world as it is represented in works of literature and film. What is the nature of evil and how is it imagined? How can the noble ideas that define the modern world--justice and human rights, for example--be reconciled with the terrible events of the twentieth century: genocide, racial violence, and war? Why do good people do terrible things to others? What can reading books on evil in distant places teach us about ourselves? The course will explore how evil functions as a form of deep ethical violation and challenges how we understand the world and our relationship to others.
title: Topics in Literature and Ethics - Modern Evil

otherinfo: The course will examine artworks ranging from ancient Egypt to nineteenth-century Europe in the Princeton University Art Museum, where most classes will convene. Assignments will include a study of one of the objects.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course has three aims: 1) to disprove Hegel's claim that Africa has no history, particularly in the domain of philosophy; 2) to trace the legacy of medieval institutions and political theology in the formation of the colony and the postcolonial state; 3) to explore the institutional formation, and the silences, of postcolonial theory itself as the legacy of the forgetting of the European and African medieval. Readings come from the domains of medieval philosophy, theology, and literature; African historiography; contemporary African writing; postcolonial theory.
title: Special Studies in Medieval Literature - Medievalizing Africa

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A survey of Shakespeare's linguistic resources, from several standpoints: the history of the language, the art of rhetoric, problems of attribution (including the potentials of computational stylometrics), and poetics. Over the course of the semester we study six plays, including Comedy of Errors, Hamlet, and The Winter's Tale. There are weekly exercises in stylistic description and imitation. Our questions: how does Shakespeare sound like himself? (Does he sound like himself?) How does he sound like others, like his age, like his readers? And his characters - can we ask the same questions of them?
title: Renaissance Drama - Shakespeare's Language

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 60%
descrip: What is Enlightenment? And when, if at all, did Enlightenment happen? In this course we approach these familiar and crucial questions with an eye to literary forms and fabulae, tracing how poetry, tragedy, and novels participate in the work of biblical exegesis, theology, natural philosophy, and emancipatory political though--that is, the common terrain of Enlightenment philosophy and administration. We examine inventive investigations of enthusiasm and priestcraft, speculative anthropologies that posit worlds before Adam and Eden, and philosophical works that traverse genres, exacting new and exciting forms of fiction.
title: Special Studies in the 18th Century - Literature and the Early Enlightenment, 1650-1760

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: "What shocks the virtuous philosopher, delights the camelion poet," wrote Keats, while Byron declared that "there's a sure market for imposture." Even as the Romantics cultivated the posture of poetic authenticity, they also invented avatars, disguises, doppelgangers, shape-shifters and shameless frauds. In readings of Wordsworth, Byron, Keats, Hemans, Robinson, Equiano, Hogg, and Scott, we explore the dialectic between posture and imposture in the Romantic age as an allegory of form, a theater of the self, and a triumph of Romantic irony. Discussion frequently focuses on approaches to teaching these texts.
title: The Romantic Period - Chameleon Poets: Posture and Imposture in the Romantic Age

otherinfo: Excerpts from Buffon, Rousseau, Herder, Kant, Lamarck, Geoffroy Saint Hilaire, Robert Chambers, G.H. Lewes, et al will be provided in a course reader, along with relevant secondary readings
grading: Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 60%
descrip: The seminar explores the interaction between nineteenth-century fiction and an ascendant "natural history of man," from late-Enlightenment philosophical anthropology through early transformist biology to Charles Darwin. Topics include: the Romantic invention of new novelistic forms, the Bildungsroman and historical novel, in light of a new form of human subject; the scientific basis (in pre-Darwinian evolutionism) of Dickens's challenge to the codes of realism; reconfiguration of the relation between lyric and narrative in long poetic forms (Tennyson); George Eliot's address to the ongoing revolutions in the natural and human sciences.
title: Special Studies in the Nineteenth Century - Realism, Evolution, and the "Natural History of Man"

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The leading ambition is to track a variety of ways in which poetry tries to capture felt and pressing realities. The course starts with Pope at his most sweeping ("Essay on Man," "Essay on Criticism"), and take up the relationship among psalms, metrical psalms, blank verse, Anna Laetitia Barbauld's metrical prose, and hymns before proceeding to georgics and conversation poems. It concludes with a discussion of first-person lyric and memoir.
title: Poetics - Poetic Realism: Episodes, 18th Century to the Present

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 80%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
descrip: How is our political moment in line with a series of cultural and political shifts since WWII, in global practices of impunity? How may we reconsider postcolonial texts from the vantage point of questions about accountability, redress, and the production of subjects who can or cannot be punished? We explore economic, legal, psychological, and aesthetic dimensions of impunity, ranging across a series of global sites, from Indonesia to the U.S. Course topics include decolonization, state violence, populism, and aesthetic autonomy. Readings include Adorno, Arendt, Balibar, Brown, Butler, Fanon, Kristeva, Marx, Nietzsche, Spivak.
title: Criticism and Theory - Impunity

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: How do critics, writers, and readers approach the work of the present moment? This seminar has two main foci: first, the field of 21st century literature and culture in English, and second, the contemporary role of critique in both academic and popular culture. We read and watch primary texts that undertake their own projects of social, political, and formal critique, alongside experiments in critical and theoretical writing from writers both in and outside of the academy. We take up questions that animate discussions about the role of the humanities in our present moment: who are we writing for? What forms can that writing take?
title: Literature and Society - The Present Moment: Contemporary Literature

evals: A good introduction to French, and not very difficult if you study grammar and vocabulary consistently and as you go.

Be sure to start learning the vocabulary at the beginning of the module instead of waiting until a few days before the test to start cramming the vocabulary. As long as you keep up with the coursework on a day to day basis (30 to 45 minutes daily), you'll be fine.
Do more exercises than the homework for more practice, and learn new words just to learn them. It expands your vocabulary and will help you with the listening and writing.
Focus on nailing down vocab and grammar.
I really feel like this wasn't an introductory course. The people who succeeded in this class did so because of prior knowledge of french. The language test placement system does not work.

I would definitely recommend this course to people that are looking for and interesting class or are trying to fulfill a language requirement. My 101 professor Sophie was fantastic and It really peaked my interest in learning another language.

I would recommend taking the course if you are considering learning French. It is a great introduction that goes at a pace that is easy yet still up to university standards (as long as you keep up with your work). Overall, I worked hard and had great success. Furthermore, I feel like I can actually carry out simple conversations in French because of how much practice we received inside and outside of class.

I would recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in French. One thing to keep in mind is in order for this course to count, FRE 102 also has to be taken. This course moves at a manageable pace but you definitely learn a lot. If you do a little but of studying outside of class, you come out of this course knowing basic french (enough to communicate at a basic level). It is taught by grad students, which is not necessarily a bad thing since this gives you leniency and a more friendly relationship with your teacher.
I would strongly recommend this course.

If you aren't interested in French and just need to fill a language requirement, don't take this- it is a lot of work and is a huge commitment. However, if you are interested in French definitely take it.
If you took SPanish in higj shool, dont start a new languae
It is an interesting class if you would like to learn more about the French Language
Just buckle down and do it. It'll get easier.

Make sure to study the language EVERY NIGHT for a few hours. This means reviewing verbs, nouns with their respective gender, accents and speaking the language out loud. Also take the course with Johnny Laforet! There is not a better option!

Make sure you are always reading your textbook and memorizing the lists of terms found in the back of each chapter, as you will be required to know these on the exam but will not necessarily cover them in class or even on homework assignments.
Rely on the coursepacket for test and quiz preparation - the tips it gives are very relevant to the expectations on examinations.
Study 30 minutes to an hour daily. Cramming isn't effective especially in language classes. Participate in class. Don't make small spelling/grammar mistakes on the exam! they add up
Study more than you think you need to
Take Johnny's. He is so warm and helpful.

The class is straightforward and simple to do well in, as long as you actually spend time on the class. Do not put this class on the back-burner in favor of other classes. It'll be difficult to catch up, and your grade may not turn out as high as you would like it to be.

This course is not too hard if you're looking to start a new language but I do wish that I had spent more time within the first few weeks working on pronunciation and vocabulary because at times I found that I let myself off the hook and did poorly on tests despite finding class itself relatively easy.
This is a good beginners class to take for anybody who wants to switch to a different language than high school.
This is a pretty standard introductory language course. Anyone who keeps up with the vocab and does the homework can/will succeed.
To make sure to study 15 minutes everyday.
Very good intro course...pace is fast for students just learning French but do able...assessments are very fair...all the hw...will help a lot
You have to take a language, if you know some of a certain language, go with that.
enjoy the class and you will get more out of it
great course. your hard work will pay off
its an intro language class, pretty straightforward
otherinfo: Offered every Fall term. Classes are conducted in French. PLEASE NOTE: C01A (9:00 a.m.) and C04A (12:30 p.m.) classes are recommended for students with absolutely no previous knowledge of French, and C05 is limited to Graduate Students.
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Approximately one lesson per week, including practice with workbook, written exercises, brief reading assignments and role plays. Interviews with instructor in lieu of midterm. Three exams, weekly written assignments, periodic quizzes, final oral presentation, and final exercise.
prereqs: Students having studied French previously must take the Princeton French Language placement test. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless it is followed by FRE 102. The afternoon section of FRE 101 (C05) will focus on reading skills, in addition to oral communication, and is limited to graduate students..
descrip: This class develops the basic structures and vocabulary for understanding, speaking, writing, and reading in French. Classroom activities foster communication and cultural competence through comprehension and grammar exercises, skits, conversation and the use of a variety of audio-visual materials.
title: Beginner's French I

evals: Great intro to French but stay on top of the assignments and readings because the tests will prove difficult otherwise.

I would recommend graduate students take this course pass-fail, especially if taking as a fifth course, because it is quite intensive.  While Fanny gives her students everything they need to succeed in the class, the amount of work outside of class that is required is quite intense.  I am glad I did not stress about my grade, but was instead able to focus on learning at my own pace, and just passing the course.

I would recommend that students be prepared to spend significant amounts of time on this course, in order to reap the most benefits from it. I believe that such an investment would be rewarded richly.

If you just did french in high school, consider taking 101 and 102. I don't understand spoken french very well, but I can do written french well, so I got into 103, but had lots of trouble understanding the professor - who will constantly be speaking rapid french.
Study extensively for the written exams, as these will be most of your grade, there's no curve, and it's easy to do badly if you don't prepare well. You will be pressed for time, as you have 50 minutes to answer listening, read a passage answer questions, do a lot of grammar questions, and write an essay.
Keep up with homework and readings.
otherreq: FRE 103 not allowed if FRE 101 or 102 taken.
otherinfo: All classes are conducted in French.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Other Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 2 chapters per week, including practice with workbook, written exercises, and reading assignments. Students should be prepared for rapid pace of course. Three tests, three compositions, midterm interview, and final oral presentation.
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.
title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French

evals: Definitely a great course to take if you struggle with gramma in french. The professor is great too!
Do not leave compositions until the night before; treat them as an essay you would write in any other core academic class.  Prepare for interviews multiple days in advance.
Do the readings before class and don't be afraid to mess up if speaking

I found this course interesting, and the workload was manageable. Meghan is engaging and funny, and there are plenty of opportunities to receive feedback about your language skills and ways to improve.
I would take this course if you are an advanced student that didn't fulfill the language requirement through AP. It is very rewarding and the professor is excellent!

If you feel even relatively comfortable with your level of French, take this course! Meghan is a very supportive, understanding, and overall great professor. Make sure you do the readings before class so you are able to discuss and that you speak with Meghan personally about how to improve your speaking/writing skills in order to get the most out of the class.

Make sure to do all assignments, whether they are checked or not, because they help in class and on quizzes. Writing assignments have a lot of freedom and are interesting to write. Tests and quizzes are fine as long as the course material is thoroughly gone over.

Meghan is great, and this is a great intermediate French course.  She's very willing to talk, and rewards participation.  You can skimp on grammar assignments without penalty (she doesn't check), but I wish I had done more of them.
Meghan is very kind, and the course is not too intensive or stressful. Participate in class and keep up with readings.
Put effort into the homework!
Take it.
Take this course to fulfill the requirement.                                      Keep up with the readings, because they pile up fast.
Take time to really practice your french, the homework assignments are very easy to skim through and never take long but the more time you spend on them the better you will be.
The class is a good class, but make sure you study, even when a test isn't coming up, or else you'll find that you haven't really learned the language.
Very good course. Make sure you complete all of the grammar exercises since it will be very useful for tests and quizzes.
otherinfo: All classes are conducted in French.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Other Exam - 25%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Course packet, online material and film series.
prereqs: Typically two to five years of high school French. Appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test, or special permission of the Placement Officer..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while allowing you to strengthen your knowledge of contemporary French society and culture. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a wide range of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material. The course aims at building your confidence in French, while giving you a foundation for the understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures and exposing you to their rich literary and artistic productions. A wide range of authentic material will be offered, including films.
title: Intermediate French

evals: A good mix of French grammar/literature
A very good French class; Prof. Hart was very engaging and it was overall a very good course.
Choose the time of your class wisely. Taking a class five days a week is difficult if it is at a time which is not convenient for you.
Definitely take this course, you probably have to because of your language requirement, but if you can take it with Mdm. Hart.
Great class! Very well designed. You learn not only the language but also weekly units on cultural materials. You'll get all your expectations met. Rachel's an awesome teacher!
I honestly dislike French and was only in 107 to finish up the AB language requirement, but I still really enjoyed this course! TAKE IT WITH MACS IF POSSIBLE, BEST INSTRUCTOR EVER
I know it's likely a requirement but you can't go wrong with Rachel Hart!  Great enthusiasm about French but is a native English speaker so she gets it!
I would advise people to do the readings and participate every day in order to get the most out of the class.
If Macs is teaching, take this 100000%. He is the best professor in the dept. by a ton.

If you can, try to get Madame Hart as your professor. She loves what she teaches and it definitely rings through in the class. Keep up with your homework and CP assignments - I promise you that you won't feel like doing them when your quiz rolls around, but then when you take the quiz you'll wish you had done them. Speak in class, be really engaged, always ask questions. It'll definitely be a good time.
Keep up with the assignments and readings!
Madame Hart is a delight: so understanding and energetic. Highly recommended to all.
Madame Hart is an amazing teacher. I would love to take another class with her. She is such a genuine person and has so much energy. Try to get her as the teacher and you will love this class
Make sure to keep up on the assignments and you'll do fine.

Quality really depends on who you get, but in general the grad students in French are super attentive and talented at teaching, especially since most of them are not native Francophones and understand what it's like to learn French as a non-native speaker. Classes aren't super difficult, but they're informative, and they take the time to teach you about cultural aspects--like the dynamic in la banlieue/les HLM, among other things. I loved it!
Speak up in class; it is the only way to improve your language skills!
TAKE THIS COURSE WITH PROF. HART!
Take it if you have to and if you like french, not a super interesting course
Take this class with Rachel Hart if at all possible. She's a stellar instructor, leagues ahead of most of the others.
Take this course! French is great and so is Macs.
This course is challenging but will help you make rapid progress in learning French. The teaching quality is very high, and the course is well planned out.
This is a really great class! The films are fascinating and wonderful, and so was the book we read. Madame Hart is a really engaging teacher, and you'll learn a ton about the French culture!

Try to actually enjoy the class! Listen to everyone, but also push yourself to participate in discussions, even if you're self-conscious about stumbling over words and whatnot. You'll only get better as the year goes on!
otherinfo: All work and instruction in FRE 107 will be done in French. Not open to Freshmen in Fall only.
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Daily grammar, reading and writing assignments. Three in-class exams and three compositions during the course of the semester. Final: oral presentation.
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103, or special permission..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of cultural units chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material.
title: Intermediate/Advanced French

evals: Honestly, this class if fine (and will probably be boring) if you have a strong French background but are bad at taking tests. That being said, there are enough readings and projects to keep it bearable. I would definitely recommend to fulfill a language requirement, but if you are considering between this and just taking a higher-level course, go for FRE 207.

I have no complaints about this course. While Professor Gottschall is leaving, the class structure is great and conducive to learning the language, even if you have trouble with the grammar concepts or vocabulary. It is not much work either. If you stay on top of the grammar homework, the three tests you have are very straightforward. Also, you have the chance to watch a few interesting movies in French and then talk about them. This class has done wonders for my listening and speaking skills and I came out of it feeling incredibly comfortable with the language. If you want to know French, I definitely recommend this course.

I learned more French in one semester at Princeton than I'd learned in four years of high school French. This class provides you with a great understanding of intermediate French grammar topics as long as you do your part by reading the relevant textbook chapters and participating in class discussions. The workload is very manageable: there aren't any major projects or long papers, but generally a short reading or some course packet exercises due each class. Take it for the AB foreign language requirement, but also know that it's great preparation for future departmental classes and study abroad opportunities!
It is much tougher than 105, many readings, subject matter is geared more towards french history.
It's a great class.
It's a pretty fair amount of work. The curriculum is well-organized and a seamless continuation from FRE105.
Just because you get two shots per composition doesn't mean you don't need  to take the first draft seriously. The first draft determines your grade!
Make sure you do practice grammar exercises from the course pack and textbook to prepare for the tests.

Overall this is a good course. Some of the topics discussed weren't that interesting, but it's a pretty manageable course in terms of workload. If you keep up with the readings and work to understand the grammar as you go along the exams are manageable as well.
Take the course, but be aware of your knowledge in French, because it may be more work than you're previously used to

This class is definitely more challenging than FRE 105; I found the assessments significantly more difficult. It focuses mainly on grammar, but the readings and films are relatively interesting. The seminar format is helpful for building conversational skills.

This class really improves your French. Do the grammar exercises as they're assigned instead of all at once right before the test. Push back on the fact that this course only focuses on France - there are so many other places where French is spoken and they're entirely ignored in this curriculum.
This course is very chill. Not very difficult.

This course is very good for improving French speaking, reading and writing skills, although there is more of an emphasis on reading and writing. The course is very doable and takes up as much time as a regular Princeton course. Madame Gottschall is very helpful and understanding while teaching the subject matter very well.

This is a great course to fulfill your language requirement, or for anyone who wants to improve his/her French! Unfortunately Meghan is leaving, so the course won't be quite the same, but I think the curriculum would be successful even with a less successful professor.

Very similar to FRE 105 (but harder and more interesting). Definitely study for tests and do the readings before class. Very doable if you put in the constant effort to keep up and study daily--I think I learned a lot in terms of written and spoken language.
fair class
otherinfo: Offered both semesters. Classes in French. NOTE: FRE 108 also helps in preparation for applying to our study abroad programs.
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Weekly assignments include: 15 pages of reading from text, quiz or composition or grammar review.
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Director of French Language Program..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. We'll take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates: national identity, immigration, relationships with the Francophone world and former colonies, the role of the State in the shaping of the nation, etc. We have selected a variety of authentic materials (films, videos, music, newspapers articles and literary texts) and carefully incorporated them into our curriculum so you'll develop your ability to communicate in French.
title: Advanced French

evals: Definitely take it to improve your French! You'll also learn a lot about literature analysis, and the theme of the fantastic! You'll grow a lot as a thinker.
Fun course, not too difficult! Interesting readings and Florent is great.
Good course, improve your French, a bit more time commitment than 107, but not too much more.

I definitely feel like my reading and writing abilities improved during the course. Would recommend simply with the warning that the material is not always the most engaging or interesting (but I think that they might be changing them). Rachel and Charlotte are great teachers. They are very dedicated to their students, and are always willing to help and meet with them
It's gonna be a lot of reading work; take this if you're interested in analyzing things in French, rather than in actually improving your ability to speak.
Make sure to keep up with the grammar even if the concepts aren't covered in depth during class.
Take it with Charlotte and always go for her office hours!
The class was helpful in my overall ability to feel comfortable expressing myself in French, both through speaking and writing. There is little emphasis on grammar.
This course is a good mixture of grammar and literature; if you need a grammar boost, but still want a literature class, take it. Teachers are great.

This course takes more effort than the earlier courses because you'll be learning the majority of the grammar outside of class. If you come from 107, you might have to learn some new concepts. It was a fun class though, more discussion, less grammar.
otherinfo: Offered both semesters. Classes are conducted in French.
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Weekly assignments include: 10-15 pages of reading; grammar and style exercises. There will be two in-class oral exposés per term and there will be 3 tests and 3 short papers.
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion of literary texts and films. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.
title: Studies in French Language and Style

evals: I highly recommend this course. It helped me with my French immensely and covered very engaging, interesting material.

I would highly recommend doing every reading thoroughly. By doing so you will see that not only do your contributions in the classroom get better, but your language abilities will enhance. Madame Sagnier knows what she is doing. Trust her. She works wonders and she cares so much about her students. She really believes in taking care of them and teaching them.
If you are looking to learn more about why French society and culture is the way it is today, this is the perfect course! Madame Sagnier is fantastic and the course covers a variety of topics.
If you like French, you will like everything this class has to offer.
If you want to speak french take this course. It is fantastic.
Keep up with all readings and be prepared to discuss in class.  You will get more out of the class if you do extra work outside of class and make a specific effort to memorize new vocab.
Prof. Sagnier is excellent and energetic. The readings and films are interesting, and the course will definitely make you feel more prepared to live/work in France.
Prof. Sagnier is the best but do all the readings and participate lots because it is a small class and you will have to talk!

Take this class. It is so interesting and Professor Sagnier is a fantastic teacher. If you want to engage in intellectual and cultural discussions about relevant social topics, take it, do the readings, watch the films, and come to class prepared for great discussions. It is so worth it.
Take this course if you are interested in politics and need to use the language in the future. This is a great alternative to generic literature-type classes.
otherinfo: This course is excellent preparation for Princeton-in-France internships or Sciences-Po semester.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Weekly assignments, short papers, and a final research project on a topic chosen by the student.
prereqs: FRE 207 or equivalent..
descrip: This course is designed to develop students' linguistic skills and broaden their knowledge of contemporary French society. Discussions and essays will cover a wide range of topics drawn from economic, political, social and cultural aspects of France and the francophone world. Current affairs will be discussed in class on a regular basis. The course will provide intensive language practice and students will improve their communication skills by completing a research project, to be presented orally and in writing, on a topic of their choice. Excellent preparation for Princeton-in-France internships or Sciences-Po semester.
title: France Today: Culture, Politics, and Society

evals: Do it!
I would highly recommend this class for someone interested in French literature or hoping to improve their reading, writing and speaking skills. It was enjoyable and challenging at the same time.
Professor Chenoweth is wonderfully enthusiastic and brings great energy to the class. Take it if you can.

Take this class! A very fun approach to the literature that exposes you to a good variety of eras and types of works - very discussion based which helps you with speaking and lets you enjoy the readings more! I highly recommend this course!

This is a good survey of French literature. Kind of language-heavy for a 200-level French class, but it all depends on the level of students. So take this class! Or anything with Katie Chenoweth. She's wonderful :)
grading: Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: 50-100 pages per week (less for poetry). Since this is an introduction to literature course, the length of the assignments is limited, and the quality of preparation stressed. Three 4-5 page papers, as well as a variety of shorter writing assignments.
prereqs: FRE 107 or FRE 108 or permission of instructor. Course conducted entirely in French..
descrip: This course is meant to introduce students to great works of French literature from a range of historical periods and to provide them with methods for literary interpretation through close reading of these texts. The course syllabus is organized around common themes and generic categories. This course is invaluable preparation for more advanced and specialized 300-level courses. Classroom discussion, free exchange encouraged.
title: French Literature: Approaches to the Language of Literary Texts

evals: Definitely take this class if you want to get better at writing in French - I feel like I've improved so much thanks to this class. Madame Perrier was also great, super helpful and fun!

Great course. Professor Perrier is super nice and really focuses on having everyone in the class learn the material well. Definitely more material than 207, but the writing assignments really help you solidify the grammar points.
Highly recommended. Professor Perrier is an excellent teacher.

I think this is a good class to take before other 300-level French classes if you're nervous about writing papers in French.  However, if you've already taken 300-level classes, you might not get as much out of it as you expected.

If you are at a fairly advanced level in French, please take this course with Professor Perrier. The assignments are reasonably doled out and Professor Perrier is an extremely understanding and engaging teacher. I guarantee that your level will improve as well under her guidance.
Madame Perrier is great and will always be very well prepared. Very good class to take if you want to work on your writing. Work isn't that intensive, but it's more writing than you might be used to.

Mixed feelings about this course. The essays were really fun to write, the films were great, and Professor Perrier is very smart and nice. On the other hand, I didn't feel very comfortable speaking in class, even though I have a solid background in French. Also, classes were kind of long and dry.

Not a terrible amount of work with Murielle--a few short essays, plus revisions, and some short readings. Very enjoyable course, lots of in class discussion and the grading seemed to focus more on grammar than content, which I wouldn't complain about. Definitely helped me understand how to write in French a bit better.

Take this course! Your written and spoken French will be greatly improved. As long as you engage in the readings, participate in conversation, and pay close attention to the essays assigned (start them early to give yourself time to edit, especially because there aren't very many of them), you will do well in this course.

Take this course!!! Madame Perrier is amazing and I would absolutely recommend this course. There's hardly any work except for a paper ever 3 weeks or so. Discussions are fun, and it's a great way to keep your French up.

There is a fair bit of writing but it is broken up into small chunks. It could be easy to hide in this course and not get much out, but if you meet with the professor, your writing will really improve. Readings are very short so close reading is possible, which makes for better class discussion.
This course helps improve your French, but it can be tedious at times

This is not a class for someone who doesn't want to work to better their French. However, it is manageable and very helpful, and the instructor is fantastic.  I have taken two classes with her and am enrolled for a third.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: One short paper due every other week.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through attentive study of French grammatical and syntactic structures and rhetorical styles, with a variety of creative, analytical and practical writing exercises, and reading of literary and non-literary texts.
title: Advanced French Language and Style

otherinfo: Course is taught in English, with French texts available in the original and in translation
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: Through theories of realism and examples of realist fiction, this course poses the following questions: What happens to realism in the post-truth era? Do we really suffer from what David Shields has called 'reality hunger' or some other literary affliction? What has happened to realism since the 19th century? Other topics include: naturalism, socialist and capitalist realism, the role of journalism and the social sciences in changing the texture of realism, the seepage between life and literature.
title: 20th-Century French Narrative Prose - Realism and (Post-)Truth

otherinfo: Course Packet Required.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 60%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: A study of Marcel Proust's works and "imaginaire", some of his most remarkable readings, along with readings of/by some of his most remarkable readers (writers, philosophers, critics, artists, and film makers).
title: Seminar in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature - Reading Proust

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: Classic theories of Imperialism (Marx, Lenin, Hobson, Arendt, Fanon), and the relation of the critique of imperialism to decolonization. Focus on the francophone Caribbean and Africa. Attention as well to contemporary critiques of Imperialism that draw on this legacy. Readings and discussion in English.
title: Francophone Literature and Culture Outside of France - Imperialism and Decolonization in the Francophone World

evals: Dr. Keller is absolutely amazing. It's an intimate small class but the material is also quite technical.

Great course! Gerta is absolutely fantastic and very funny. You'll learn a lot and the field trip is amazing, but very tiring. You'll want to go back to Morocco for actual touristing as you won't be doing much of it while you are there.

I found Gerta's lectures to be fascinating (didnt get boring! shes a character), and the field trip was AMAZING. Was helpful to have some background on the material however. Made me think about the earth in completely new way.

If you are planning on taking this course just for the field trip, you're doing it for the wrong reason. While the field trip was a very good learning (and life experience) opportunity, it also required substantial work both during and after the trip. Professor Keller is one of the best lecturers that I've had the opportunity to learn from, and the work is not too bad if you keep up with the readings. Overall a great course, but don't take it just for the trip. If you do, you might have a bad time if you're not actually interested in the material. One of the best classes that I have taken.

Take this class if you get the chance to! The field trip to Morocco was amazing and is probably why most people take this course. The course itself is very good -- it feels much more like a history class than a geosciences course (ie all readings, no problem sets) and it was so interesting to learn about the 5 mass extinctions of earth's history and about the 6th mass extinction we are currently in. Additionally, Professor Keller has amazing and fun powerpoints with her 90's era rainbow captions and crazy dinosaur pictures.

This is a great class though space is limited. Do NOT take it for the trip alone because you will not being doing the subject matter the justice it deserves. Worthwhile learning experience if you are willing to put the time in. Four scientific papers a week with quizzes every week. Must give two presentations over the course of the semester. Put the work in, it is worth it.
otherinfo: Mandatory field trip provides hands-on learning experience during Fall break week. Field trip destination will be Morocco.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Problem sets, oral presentation. Reading material will be provided by instructor each week.
prereqs: One 200-level GEO course or Geosciences Freshman Seminar..
descrip: This course introduces students to the evolution of life and mass extinction's based on a broad survey of major events in Earth history as revealed by the fossil record. Concepts and techniques of paleontology are applied to all aspects, including colonization of the oceans, invasion of land, mass extinction's and evolutionary radiation's. The roles of major catastrophes in the history of life are evaluated, including meteorite impacts, volcanism, climate change, and oceanic anoxia.
title: Evolution and Catastrophes

evals: Interesting course where you'll learn a lot but be prepared for a workload on the heavy side.
Lots of work. If you've taken Petrology, this class becomes a lot easier, if you haven't it could be a baptism of fire.
Take Rocks (Petrology) before you take Structural Geology.  Blair is great.
This course can be somewhat time-consuming, but the field trip is really fun and the class itself is really interesting.
You'll get more out of this class if you've taken classes like sedimentology and petrology.
otherinfo: Two 1 day weekend field trips (Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New York) + break fieldtrip.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 15%, Lab Reports - 40%, Papers - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Student is expected to read per week 30 pages.
prereqs: One semester of college-level calculus, one semester of college-level physics, and one semester of college level geoscience are required. Open to freshman with permission of instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the physics and geometry of brittle and ductile deformation in Earth's crust. Deformation is considered at scales from atomic to continental, in the context of mountain building, rifting, and the origin of topography.
title: Structural Geology

evals: A good course to take that covers a wide range of chemical environmental issues. Difficult with a small chem background (lots of chem heavy majors take the class), but Satish is pretty great at asking and checking that everyone is following.

BE CAREFUL. Only take if you're really interested. This class is heavily dominated by GEO/natural science majors, so if you're not one of those, I would recommend against taking it. The course gets a lot harder in the second half, so be careful about that. It's a lot of self-learning because there's no textbook; you only have your own notes to go off of, so write down everything Satish says.
I had no chem background and I made it through somehow, although not without difficulty
I'm mixed on this class. While I did learn from it, it was also poorly structured and hard to know what was expected. Lecturer was enjoyable, but lectures were often not.
If you have an understanding of chemistry you will be thrilled and love every lecture. If not, there will be a gap in your knowledge that prevents you from immersing yourself.

Take chemistry first if you want to get more out of this course. It is pretty unstructured so if you like that, take it. Satish will teach and help you outside of the class. You would learn a lot that could affect your everyday life.
Take this course if you are interested in geoscience that is applicable to real life. Not a lot of work, and exams are extremely reasonable.

The class is very lecture-focused, so make sure to get the most out of them. While I went to office hours only a couple of times, honestly I think not going more was the biggest regret of the course because the preceptor and Prof. Myneni were really great to talk to. And helpful.

This course was great. Don't freak out about this course, it's perfectly fine if you're a sophomore going in, but do brush up on your chemistry during and beforehand. Satish is very helpful and great at making you *think* in a way that no other professor here has succeeded in making me do. Psets were very interesting and mostly tested application of the concepts taught in lecture. Definitely go to office hours for those, I remember for one of the last ones there were like 10 of us in Danielle's office at the same time lol, it was great. Satish really emphasizes conceptual knowledge over memorization and application of knowledge, so do attend the review sessions before the midterm and final but don't stress about memorization, rather try to _understand_ what's been taught. The group project was fun and a really interesting way to dig deeper into a topic that was mentioned in lecture but not necessarily delved into in depth. I hope they keep the final before break, it helps make reading week less stressful (though you do have the project report [very short] group presentation then). All in all, a wonderful class; although I already knew I was going to be a GEO major, this class made me even more certain haha. Don't stress out too much, pay attention during lecture, and enjoy!

This is a generally interesting course. I was able to use my background in the natural sciences to understand chemical reactions that shape the environment in which we live. I find myself telling my friends "fun facts" that I learned in this course about everyday things that we all experience (including the effects of different toothpastes on our teeth, how different soil affects plant growth, why magazines are often heavy and have shiny pages, and about how building materials cause buildings to disintegrate differently over time). I think this course is really cool!

This is a great course if you're interested in a general overview of geological chemistry. Professor Satish is a great lecturer, and I really enjoyed the wide variety of topics that we covered. I'd take this if you're interested in the geology over the chemistry, since the chemistry was fairly straightforward and not that in depth.
Very interesting course. Highly recommend!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Other Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 10%, Problem set(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: There will be regular classroom teaching on the topics mentioned, there will be at least 3 field trips, 5-6 problem sets, 5-6 quizzes, and group presentations during the reading period. Field trips are optional.
prereqs: Introductory chemistry (CHM 201 or AP chemistry).
descrip: Covers topics including origin of elements; formation of the Earth; evolution of the atmosphere and oceans; atomic theory and chemical bonding; crystal chemistry and ionic substitution in crystals; reaction equilibria and kinetics in aqueous and biological systems; chemistry of high-temperature melts and crystallization process; and chemistry of the atmosphere, soil, marine and riverine environments. The biogeochemistry of contaminants and their influence on the environment will also be discussed.
title: Environmental Geochemistry: Chemistry of the Natural Systems

evals: Absolutely attend lectures and don't pass on the reading. If you don't understand something in lecture, stop and ask questions until you understand. All the material in this course is cumulative, so if you do not understand something early on, you have no hope of understanding increasingly complex systems studied later on in the course.
Good class for those who interested in aqueous chemistry.

If you are interested in understanding the chemistry of natural waters (lakes, rivers, oceans) and learning a specific approach to deal with the complicated chemistry of these systems, this course is for you.  A background in chemistry will make this course much more approachable. This course involves a lot of calculations.
Take the time every day to keep up with the readings and notes, otherwise you will fall far behind very quickly. Go to class! It is much more useful than the textbook.

This course provides a good foundation in understanding chemical reactions in natural waters. You learn to solve the problems by hand (no use of computers) and the material can seem challenging until all the pieces click. Give yourself plenty of time to do the problem sets, as they can take a while and require a large number of computations. I would certainly suggest having a good handle on equilibrium (acid-base, redox) chemistry before starting the course, but you certainly can review/pick up the pieces as you go. Tests are timed and in class.
This was a great course with Anne Morel-Kraepiel.  She did a great job in lecture and was good at clarifying the material in the text.  Her pace was more clear than Francois'.

This was one of the most challenging courses I've taken. If you are interested in the subject, you will really grow as a student & learn plenty of useful things, but you should only take it if genuinely interested since it's very difficult. You'll enjoy it and do well if you put the time in.
take it if you are interested in chemistry in real water systems!
otherinfo: This course is intended for seniors and first year graduate students with interest in environmental chemistry.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Semi-weekly problem sets.
prereqs: One year of college chemistry required. Previous or concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 306 recommended..
descrip: Application of quantitative chemical principles to the study of natural waters. Includes equilibrium computations, carbonate system, gas exchange, precipitation/dissolution of minerals, coordination of trace metals, redox reactions in water and sediments.
title: Environmental Aqueous Geochemistry

evals: I really enjoyed this class, you should definitely take it if you're thinking about it! The problem sets, at least for me, seemed to start out rather difficult and get easier, so don't be discouraged in the beginning.

I would really recommend this class.  It's not easy, but the material is engaging and lecture is truly enjoyable.  If you enjoy math and are interested in physical oceanography, definitely take this class!!

If you're interested in physics or climate, take it. If you're not sure if you are interested in physics or climate, take it & it'll probably make you interested. Go to Vecchi's office hours, print out the powerpoints before each class & take notes on them. The problem sets are way hard without asking questions.
Pay attention in class, look over your notes and the slideshow right after class, ask questions in class, and try to understand the assumptions (and maybe the derivations) behind the formulae.
This course is interesting, and its a really nice GEO departmental if you want a non-lab course. The problem sets can be somewhat time-consuming but they are only assigned every couple of weeks.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Three to four problems every two weeks.
prereqs: MAT 201 or MAE 305 or equivalent..
descrip: The study of the oceans as a major influence on the atmosphere and the world environment. The contrasts between the properties of the upper and deep oceans; the effects of stratification; the effect of rotation; the wind-driven gyres; the thermohaline circulation.
title: Introduction to Ocean Physics for Climate

grading: Other Exam - 100%
descrip: The course critically examines current literature and recent developments in the study of materials under extreme conditions of pressure and temperature. Both static and dynamic compression techniques are covered. The course focuses on technique developments as well as forefront scientific applications and results. An emphasis is placed on materials of geological interest including ceramics, minerals, and iron alloys.
title: Topics in Mineralogy and Mineral Physics - Current Research in Mineral Physics and Materials Science

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Application of fracture mechanics to a wide range of geologic processes, including dike and hydrofracture propagation, fault and joint growth and earthquake rupture. Topics include engineering fracture mechanics, analytic solutions for cracks in elastic media, numerical boundary element methods, and applications to geologic examples including observed fracture paths and patterns, small-scale structures associated with faults and dikes, and interpretation of geodetic data and seismological data.
title: Rock Fracture

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: See Instructor for Complete List
descrip: Geophysical applications of the principles of continuum mechanics; conservation laws and constitutive relations and tensor analysis; acoustic, elastic, and gravity wave propagation are studied.
title: Theoretical Geophysics

evals: A fast-pased class - definitely do the homework.

Absolutely take German! If you are looking for a class to fulfill the language requirement, this is a fantastic option! I took Spanish to complete the university requirements and can say that the German program is much more structured and you will learn more. There's not a lot of busy work like other languages and the instructors are fabulous. Rankin takes such a genuine interest in his students and is the best instructor I've had at Princeton. Definitely recommend for language requirement or general interest!
Absolutely worth taking, though for graduate students, unless your schedule is really straightforward you will have to make a lot of compromises early on
Be prepared to speak German sometimes to practice and keep up with the vocabulary.

Definitely take German 101! Stay on top of the der die das homework, or catch up on the weekends as necessary. All of the tests are really fair. Going to class every day is the best way to practice what you are learning.
Do the assignments and learn vocab. Then you're cruising.

GER 101 is a great course if you want to learn German. It does, however, require a lot of work on the student's part. The staff and the online textbook are really wonderful, but the student needs to be really engaged and interested in order to effectively learn the language

GER 101 is a very well organized course, and I was surprised by how comfortable I felt with the language by the end. I wouldn't be able to sit down and read a newspaper, but I can have real conversations with friends and communicate most of the ideas I want to. The online textbook, Der/Die/Das is very good, and as long as you regularly study your vocabulary the class is quite manageable.
German is so fun do it

I come from the British education system, where I can say with certainty that the language teaching is nowhere near as good as what the German Department can offer. I was super pleased to find that after just one semester of classes we were covering relatively complex grammar and were capable of having substantial conversations with each other.
I loved it and if you've never taken German before or have little experience, it is a great place to start. If you put in the work you will succeed.

I think the German department conducts these classes really well. All of the people I know across the sections have really enjoyed their classes. The class is entirely conducted in German though so I would recommend maybe prepping a little bit with duolingo ahead of time so that you have some exposure.

I took German all throughout high school, and even with that background this class challenged me. It's very fast paced and to stay on top of it you really have to study each day. It's time consuming but truly a worthwhile class if you want to take German. This class helped me more than anything else to solidify my understandings of German grammar and to improve my vocabulary. Elaine is incredibly nice and helpful, I would suggest taking it with her if you can.

I would say, take this course, absolutely. It will be a positive influence in your life, and will take you out of the hyper-competitive, oppressively pedantic average Princeton classroom and place you in an openly intellectual space for an hour each day.
If you want to learn German, take this course.
If you want to learn German, where else would you go? Also, Herr Rankin is a great professor.

If you're interested in the language and are willing to put in the work, you'll have a great time. The German dept. is incredible and supportive. DDD (the online textbook) is great and focuses on teaching you essentials. I spend about 60-90 minutes on studying everyday, and German's really not an easy language, but it's worth it. You'll be surprised at how much German you can speak after just a semester.

If you're just interested in fulfilling a language requirement, and you absolutely detest grammar structure and inflection, then don't take German. The language can be quite complex, and there are exceptions to exceptions abound, so you should really be taking this if you are truly interested in doing so, in which case, you should enjoy it.
It is a lot of work.. but is worth it if you want to learn a language well, and quickly.

It's a lot of work to learn a new language, so don't sign up for an intro language course and expect it to be light. On the contrary, I think an intro language course is just as demanding as a high school AP language, since it's constant memorization and rereading to make sure you haven't forgotten what you just learned. Everything builds on itself. That said, the multimedia teaching model of German 101 is great?it reinforces past concepts and introduces new grammatical constructions in conjunction with fun cultural lessons. As long as you devote a fair chunk of time each day to this class, it'll be hugely rewarding.
It's pretty intense so make sure you'll be able to set aside a good hour for daily homework, with more in the days leading up to the biweekly exams.
Keep up with the vocab, as long as you do that you will find the classes enjoyable with Prof. Rankin!
Lots of work, but worth it.
Please take this course! The language software used is incredibly efficient and you really won't have a hard time speaking german very soon.

Prepare for class time with the online exercises; make sure to be relatively comfortable with vocab and grammar

Don't be afraid to ask questions
Princeton's German department knows what it's doing in terms of teaching new speakers German. Take it!

Rankin is probably the most pedagogically gifted professor that I've encountered to date at Princeton. His dedication and zeal are unmatched. The course textbook (that he created) makes learning German easy and pleasurable. A great language course that is very rewarding in terms of how well you can communicate after a relatively short amount of time. Not only is German useful, the department is quite rigorous at Princeton and a nice complement to many courses of study. Would definitely recommend!
Sehr gut!
Stay on top of the vocabulary and grammar every week. Strongly recommend making flashcards and going to office hours for help.
TAKE GERMAN - ALL OF THE PROFESSORS ARE FANTASTIC AND THE TEXTBOOK IS FUN
Take it!
Take the course with a native speaker/graduate student if possible.

Take this class with Jamie Rankin! Extraordinarily accessible texts, appropriately challenging tests, not that much work per night, and you'll learn tons of German (as well as tons of interesting tidbits about history, society, culture in German-speaking countries.) Don't be afraid to take the class with no experience, either -- he will be glad to work closely with you no matter your level, and will listen attentively even if you're struggling to form sentences. STRONGLY recommend.
Take this class! It is a large time commitment but absolutely worth it.
Take this if you really want to learn a lot of German. Rankin is an amazing professor, and the course is very well-run. Keep up with the vocab and do the online hw.

The class was wonderful and I enjoyed it immensely.  The new online textbook makes learning the information enjoyable and Professor Rankin is a fantastic professor.  He is by far the best language teacher I have had the pleasure of learning from and I hope to continue learning German under his tutelage! If you are at all interested in taking German I would 100% recommend taking this class (and hopefully getting Professor Rankin as your teacher!)

The course is rather intensive: there is a lot of vocabulary learned in a short amount of time, and there are also many online exercises to be completed each night. However, this practice is very effective in learning German, and I prefer it this way to other ways that foreign languages have been taught.

This course is very fast paced! Make sure you keep-up with the homework everyday, otherwise it is incredibly easy to fall behind. I would also take good notes from the homework to reference during class. However, keep in mind that this course is also really enjoyable! It encourages discussion and understanding of the German culture, which makes it interesting and engaging.
This has been my favorite class! I have learned so much German in a short time. Great class especially if you have Jamie Rankin.
This is a great course and anybody considering it should try to practice their German as much as often outside of class.

To any student considering if they should start a new language here at Princeton, I would say go for it! I have taken French for six years in high school and was a little skeptical about my choice to start afresh with German, but I haven't been happier. The language department here is truly amazing and the German department especially has allowed me to form close bonds with the professors and other German students. 10/10 would recommend!
really practice speaking outside of class if you can. that's the most important thing.

would highly recommend taking, the German department is very robust and supportive. excellent professors and grad students teach the classes. i personally find languages harder to learn, for me it takes a lot effort and practice, but certainly well rewarded.
grading: Final Exam - 10%, Other Exam - 75%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Daily online assignments, with emphasis on vocabulary acquisition. Several short written assignments each week.
prereqs: Normally no credit given for GER 101 unless followed by GER 102. All participants, including graduate students, must be fully enrolled in the course..
descrip: The course lays a foundation for functional acquisition of German. Class time is devoted to language tasks that will foster communicative and cultural competence and will emphasize listening and reading strategies, vocabulary acquisition, authentic input, and oral production. Conducted in German.
title: Beginner's German I

evals: A good mix of review and new material - a good balance of grammar and cultural/historical topics

A lot easier that 101 and 102. Much less emphasis on grammar and more on literature and films (which you go through together in class anyway, so it doesn't even matter if you don't take any of it in when you do them).
Definitely take it. Learning another language is extremely valuable and this is a great language and instructor t do it with.
Definitely take this course! German 105 is really the first inroad to German literature after 101 and 102, and it was really great to get to read plays and poems and watch films in the native German.

German is a difficult language to learn, but the German department (and Carolina especially!) does a great job making sure you get the help you need and teaching about relevant cultural ideas. I never felt like I was learning phrases and words that were useless, or doing pointless assignments. That being said, I'm sure there are easier languages to take to fulfill the language requirement, but I still very much enjoyed German and feel like I'm learning a lot.
I suppose if one wanted to take GER 107 and did not either take 1025 or go to Munich then there'd be reason to take this course. Otherwise I would advise against taking it.
I would highly recommend this class. Be sure to keep up with the homework and to study the vocab.
I would say take it with Carolina! She is so much fun and played a huge role in making this class so enjoyable for me.
It helps me to improve German, especially the grammar
Much easier than 101 and 102.
Recommend. You cover a bunch of interesting topics in a thorough way. Helped me improve as a German communicator. Also the feedback you get on your essays is great !
Take this course!
Take this course.

The readings and films are very interesting and worth paying attention too because they make learning German easier. That being said, I did well in the class without finishing much of the required readings or films. Jon is a very clear, helpful instructor, and you'll become a better writer and reader of German.

This is by far the worse course I have taken at Princeton. It is basically a far less intelligently designed version of German 101. Having already taken 101, it amounted to a complete waste of time for everybody. I am shocked that the two courses were created by the same department. I think my German has actually gotten worse through my time in German 105. Had I known just how poor this course would be, I would have run, not walked to take 1025. Do not waste this credit!
This level of german is where the next step towards proficiency is taken.  It is a great course and I recommend it.
You might feel a little bit lost at the beginning of the semester, but as such progresses, your skill and confidence will constantly go up.
go to class!!

stay on top of your reading, go to office hours to flesh our ideas for essays, continue to review vocabulary and grammar independently (with flashcards, best for me). Study material and grammar for tests - watch TV in German or go to German table at a Res Coll. Review your essays many times before the initial submission to catch grammar mistakes.
otherinfo: Four unit tests (40%)
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Quizzes - 15%, Papers - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Short stories, online media, and a full-length filmscript; 3-4 short essays
prereqs: GER 102 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Develops deeper proficiency in all areas (cultural understanding, production skills, and receptive skills), using a combination of language-oriented work and cultural/historical content, including film and texts.
title: Intermediate German

evals: As a course to finish the language requirement, it was pretty high quality. Pretty much the same as 105 but with slightly harder texts (Die Verwandlung was most of the second half of the semester, so get used to Kafka). Grading is pretty lax since you probably have an intuitive sense for German grammar by now (I never studied for any of the exams, apart from learning vocab), and the analysis questions are easy to BS. Do it to finish the requirement, but know that you probably won't feel actually proficient in German until you go to Germany or take a bunch of upper level courses.
Awful. Terrible. Never ever take it. Worst course as Princeton. Spend 2 weeks in Germany, and then place out of it.
Definitely take this course! The instructors for German are amazing, and if Carolina is teaching again, make sure you take the class with her, she's wonderful!
Excellent

German is challenging, but the course is also a very great way to discuss ideas that I otherwise wouldn't discuss, especially as a STEM major. It's hard having not learned any German before I started 101 here, but I learned a lot. And the German department is amazing.
Highly recommended. 107 is not as difficult as the beginning courses, so take it!
If you are interested in German, take it ! You really improve your comprehension skills, especially speaking. This course I'd say has mostly German reading, not so much German culture.
If you like the German language, and are interested in German culture at all, I would recommend it. The readings can be very difficult, but it is a really phenomenal class.
If you want to just do okay/fulfill the language requirement, then average difficulty and time commitment. However, to get an A- or better, will require a lot of work.
TAKE THIS CLASS WITH JONATHAN
TAKE THIS COURSE WITH CAROLINA

Take it; be engaged. The more you put in, the more you put out. German is a very cool language, and the neat thing about the department is just how far you can get and where it can take you when you dedicate the time.
Take the written work seriously and you will be greatly rewarded! Great class to improve your German in all aspects.
Take this class if you want to solidify your basic German skills. Full engagement in class is a must in order to get all you can out of this course.
Take this class!
Take this course with Carolina!
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Grammar exercises. About 20 - 30 pages of reading per week. Four essays of increasing length.
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using texts, online media, and other sources as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included. Conducted in German.
title: Advanced German

evals: Angi is one of my favourite Professors. He genuinely cares about his students and is more concerned with helping you improve your German than with grades. I recommend you do the readings and the homework, as it will definitely help improve your written German.
Definitely take if you want to continue German!  Angi is the best, and your German will certainly get better over the course.  Workload is not stressful.
Take the course if you want to work on your German reading ability or if you are interested in the theme. But really take it with Angi if you can. As I said before, he made this course.

This course is a MUST for all German students interested in a 200 level course. Prof. Arya is absolutely fantastic and makes the course relevant to everyday life as well. The readings are also really interesting. You'll never be bored. You could probably get by in this class without doing a lot of the readings, but you'd really be missing out. Take this class and engage with it as much as you can.
This is a very good course.  Would recommend if you are looking to read interesting German texts and improve your German writing/speaking/reading abilities.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 20-40 pages of reading per week, two short essays, a class presentation, and a final paper.
prereqs: GER 107 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course will tackle exemplary works of modern German society and culture, including literature, art, film, essays, speeches, and autobiographies. It offers an introduction to the most important events and issues from the first half of the century: the foundation of the German state, Berlin as a modern metropolis, World War I, the rise of National Socialism. Intensive practice in spoken and written German with an emphasis on vocabulary acquisition and complex syntactical forms.
title: Studies in German Language and Style: Society, Politics, and Culture in Germany, 1890-1945

evals: Great class with a great professor. You get a survey of modern German literature and a healthy dose of Marxist commentary. Hard not to love.
Great class--challenging but interesting and very worth it if you're interested in German.
Professor Jennings is amazing--if he teaches this course, do not think twice about taking it. It was such a fun class.

Professor Jennings is excellent at stimulating good class discussions that really make you think in deeply about the stories. He somehow makes the class sessions deep despite the difficulty of German.
Professor Jennings is one of the best professors I've had. I would take any class he teaches. He is very excited about the material and really helps you to understand it and want to be interested.
Reading are difficult, but usually pretty doable. There's a decent amount of philosophy discussed in the course, so take it if that interests you.
Readings can be difficult, but put the time in and it's pretty rewarding.  Prof. Jennings is extremely fair and you can get a lot out of this class if you take it seriously.

This class will push you to read challenging material and engage with it at nearly the level you would in an English-language course. You should be prepared to devote time to the readings and papers to get a lot out of them.
otherinfo: Intended for students who have just completed GER 107, a 200-level course, or the equivalent.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 50 pp. per week. Three essays of increasing length, ranging from 4-8 pp.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: This course has four goals: 1) to introduce students to key authors, genres, and movements in German literary history between 1770 and the present; 2) to provide an opportunity to deepen interpretive skills through reading and discussion of representative texts; 3) to encourage students to explore theoretical approaches to cultural material; and 4) to provide intensive practice in spoken and written German.
title: Introduction to German Literature after 1700

evals: Absolutely take this course! Professor Jennings is one of a kind. Even with little experience in the subject, you have much to gain.

As an auditor who did not have to keep up with the rigorous assignments, I lack an insider's perspective on the experience of the class, but its seems students in the course made significant progress in their appreciation of Benjamin and conversancy in his thought. This was extremely difficult material and not for the faint of heart, but class discussion made these texts noticeably more navigable. I recommend the class for this reason to anyone looking for a better understanding of this most unapproachable theorist.

Content wise, this is the hardest course I've taken at Princeton. But Professor Jennings is great, so as long as you put in the time and demonstrate interest, he will patiently work with you through the difficult material.
Great class if you're open minded enough to let some very esoteric and often unbelievable thought influence your own.

Highly recommend for anyone interested in critical theory, media theory, or just plain 'ol theory. Any course with Professor Jennings is bound to blow your mind and leave you super confused about the world, in the best way possible.
Highly recommend.  Not too much work, but not worth taking unless you're really interested in the topic.

It's an incredible class, with an incredible professor. Just do not take it if you feel that being interrupted or dominated in the classroom bothers you. In other words, the style of this class best suits either contentedly passive listeners or aggressive discussion warriors. That said, I fall into the second category, and I absolutely loved this stimulating, wide-ranging, energetic class.

Professor Jennings is terrific! He provides a different way of thinking about many well-known texts, and also introduces many lesser-known texts that are essential to understanding all the others. This is a wonderful course about Professor Jennings' life work, and it was exciting to see his love for the material in each seminar.
Re-read the texts, and don't be afraid to speak/ ask questions in seminar.
Take it.

Take this course. Walter Benjamin was one of the greatest minds of the twentieth century, but that said, his works are often impenetrable, especially when glossed over as a secondary reading in a survey course. With Jenning's guidance through the semester, you will become a confident reader of Benjamin (while simultaneously acknowledging the text's difficulty!).

The course opens a world of Benjaminian texts, which are extremely dense, but very interesting.
