The seminars are extremely important to understanding the material, however, do not completely cover everything, as there is only a limited time for class. However, professor Jennings hosts office hours, in which you can ask any question about the content, theory, or just plain confusion regarding the texts.
Would recommend - hard material but a pretty manageable amount of reading (~50 pages / week) and writing (2 10-page papers). Incredibly interesting material.
otherinfo: Course taught in German.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 30-50 pages of reading per week; two short papers (4-6 pages each) and one final paper (10-12 pages).
descrip: What mechanisms of exclusion accompanied the constitution of modern reason in the eighteenth century? Are the universalist ideals of the Enlightenment inherently flawed, or can they be recuperated by a more inclusive universalism? This course interrogates Enlightenment universalism by reading canonical eighteenth-century works together with texts that highlight the occult, gendered, and racialized undersides of Enlightened reason. In conversation with recent attempts to reclaim, revise, or refute the Enlightenment project, we will also explore the complex legacy of Enlightenment universalism in contemporary political and theoretical debates.
title: German Intellectual History - Margins of Enlightenment

evals: Definitely take the course and do the readings to get the most out of the experience.
Don't be afraid to push the envelope. Joel is really open to unorthodox interpretations, as long as your observations are firmly rooted in the text itself!
Great class if you really want to participate in class. Be ready to bring your perspectives to the table.
Joel is an awesome professor. Take any course taught by him.
Take a class with Professor Lande!  This is a great way to get exposure to important texts in the German tradition.
Take this class. Joel is a great teacher and the material is interesting and challenging.
otherinfo: All readings and discussion in German.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Papers - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 20-40 pages of challenging reading per week; 4 page paper in lieu of midterm, 5 page paper in lieu of final, three 2-page response papers.
prereqs: Prior completion of either GER 207, 208 or 209 or adequate proficiency in German as determined by the instructor..
descrip: Going back at least as far as Immanuel Kant's landmark 1795 "Towards Perpetual Peace," German thinkers and writers have been preoccupied with the concept-figure of war. Reading authors from Kant, Kleist, and Clausewitz to Freud and Schmitt, we'll pursue some of the following questions: Is war a necessary component of human history and experience? Can there be a science of war? What is the relation of war to politics? What problems does war pose to aesthetic representation and how does art help us understand war? Subtopics include: the sublime; Napoleonic invasion and French-German rivalry; war and media.
title: Topics in German Culture and Society - War in German Philosophy and Lit. around 1800 and beyond

evals: Great course to take if you want to watch phenomenal movies and learn how to talk about them.

I recommend this class if you have some background in media theory of some sort. Without that background I think much of the content will be difficult to follow, although certainly still comprehensible with effort. Even if you have no real interest in film, this course will change the way you think about cinema on a deep level, and the films you watch in class are a good enough reason to take this course.
If you are open to thinking about cinema in new ways, and viewing lots of experimentation with the film medium, take the class.
It's not an easy course--the material can be difficult and long--but it's a really good one.
Just take the course! Why wouldn't you take this course?

Levin is one of those professors whose classes you just have to take. You will never watch a movie in the same way after taking this course. Prof. Levin is extremely accessible and friendly, and offers guidance on any topic. If you, like me, are constantly struggling to find film studies courses at Princeton, this course is a light in the darkness.
Professor Levin is one of the best professors here; take this course!!
This course takes a lot of patience to understand the material but is very rewarding.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 70-100 pages of historical, theoretical and/or critical readings plus one mandatory (evening) film screening per week; 4-6 page mid-term paper, class presentation, and final term paper. Readings and class discussions will be in English; films will be shown in original-language copies with subtitles. Attendance at screenings and subsequent discussions is mandatory.
prereqs: German-language competence and/or prior background in film history or theory, while highly desirable, are not required. Due to the interdisciplinary character of the course (which will also consider film in relation to theater, painting, photography and sound arts), it is of special interest to students in literature, visual arts, art history, music, architecture, history and sociology..
descrip: Is film ideological? What is propaganda? How do mass media structure values and desires? Is there a politics of narration? These deeply contemporary questions will inform this interdisciplinary seminar in film history and theory and its interrogation of key works of expressionist, documentary, proletarian, avant-garde, queer, horror, and paranoid-thriller cinema from the Weimar Republic (1919-1933). Films and texts will be subject to socio-political, media-historical, and film theoretical analysis.
title: Topics in German Film History and Theory - Regimes of Spectacle in Weimar Cinema

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 50%
prereqs: Open to graduate students only..
descrip: Readings and discussion in classroom application of SLA theory. Focus on quantitative as well as interpretive analysis. Primary audience is the current teaching staff of GER 101. In English.
title: Second Language Acquisition and Pedagogy

otherinfo: Seminar will be conducted in German.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 150-200 pages of reading per week. Writing will consist of a short 5-page midterm paper and a longer 15-20 page seminar paper.
descrip: An exploration of the importance of socio-historical structures in the production and circulation of literature: combines theoretical texts on collaborative writing, cultural techniques, and epistolary culture with close readings of selected works from German literature. In this context, authors such as J.M.R. Lenz and Karl Philipp Moritz are particularly interesting: since their works have served as testimony to the autonomous revolt of the supposedly "bürgerlich" hero against exploitative patron-client-relationships, they hold great promise for a discussion of the intricate correlation between modern authorship and patronage.
title: German Literature in the 18th Century - Patronage und deutsche Literatur im 18. Jahrhundert

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 60%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading 150 - 200 pp. per week
descrip: "Good proletarian art is usually Covert Pastoral," wrote the critic William Empson in 1935. This seminar examines the rebirth of pastoral in the avant-garde literature, film and photography of Germany and Soviet Union, exploring topics such as: the revolutionary intelligentsia and the countryside; the return of Naturalism and landscape genres; poetic archaism and narodnost'; modernization and the agricultural mode of production. The seminar concludes with contemporary reflections on the pastoral project, including its relationship to the politics of ecologism and to the geological turn in media theory.
title: Modernism and Modernity - The Avant-Garde and the Pastoral Drive

otherinfo: Course taught in English based on German readings (although all novels are available in translation).
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 75%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
assgts: One novel every two weeks. One seminar paper.
descrip: This seminar examines a series of narratological and political issues in German-language novels from the period 1959-1977. This period, which begins with the first serious novelistic attempts to confront the legacy of fascism and ends with the "German autumn," produced a series of novel notable for their narrative innovation and their political engagement. The seminar combines readings of the novels with an introduction to narratological theory.
title: German Literature after 1945 - The Politics of Narration: The Post War Novel

evals: Great course if you have taken Latin and already understand concepts like indirect statement and participles and know how to quickly memorize endings.  Professor Ford tends to move quickly through these ideas, so having that basis really helped me.  Because he tends to move quickly through the last couple chapters, practicing outside of class is essential.  Memorize vocab with flashcards or Quizlet.  Write out verb and noun forms until you get sick of them, then keep going. Translate the sentences and passages not done in class.  This class was very informative, not just about Greek, but about the history of the Greek language as well.
Take this course if you want to learn Classical Greek. It is a lot of fun. It does require daily homework but not excessive.
Unless you think you have a pretty large stockpile of interest and motivation, this class will be a grind. If, however, you really want to learn greek, this could easily be your favorite class.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Short written assigments most nights. About two hours of preparation per class session.
prereqs: Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year a short Platonic dialogue or comparable text will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.
title: Beginner's Greek: Greek Grammar

evals: Go ahead and try it out.

If you enjoyed Greek before, then you should take this class without a doubt! You'll definitely love it. It's a good mix of grammar and translation, so you get to read a fair amount of an original Greek text and your knowledge of the language will improve a lot.
If you love Greek, take this course! It's a great opportunity to immerse yourself in the ancients and to form bonds with a tight community of students.
Review your grammar beforehand and keep on top of the translation and grammar review!
Take it if you're a Classics major.
Take this course if you want a reading knowledge of Ancient Greek and are interested in the dialogue. You should be fairly self-motivated for this course to be enjoyable.

This course is the most work that I have ever done for a Princeton class, and it will likely be my lowest grade. If you can take it with Professor Wildberg, I recommend it; he's wonderful. But for the love of god, take the vocabulary list he gives at the beginning and learn it by heart, otherwise you will spend the entire semester looking up dictionary entries.
This was a good class, especially after 103, for helping to go back over concepts for a second time and really learn them, as well as apply grammar knowledge to a real text.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: On average, 2 pages of Greek per week, plus intensive study of Greek grammar.
prereqs: CLG 102 or CLG 104 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: In this class we will read from Plato's Republic and the Ion in order to understand his highly influential critique of poetry and the enduring contest he inaugurated between philosophy and literature. The course aims at an in-depth study of Greek grammar and syntax.
title: Socrates

evals: Be prepared to work, but it's quite manageable.

Review grammar! Sophocles is difficult and there isn't really room for error on exams as far as grammar goes. Staying on top of principal parts is key! Otherwise, I would say do all the secondary readings and take a step back from the details of translation at the end of every assignment and enjoy the content. This play is fascinating and its themes are timeless!

TAKE IT! Prof. Holmes is an amazing prof- she really helped us through the Greek and assigned thought-provoking secondary sources that gave me a more nuanced understanding of the play. Of course, it's Sophocles, so it's difficult by nature, but this is definitely a course worth taking.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Passages of Greek varying in length according to difficulty, averaging 250 lines per week. Some secondary reading in English. Short paper.
prereqs: CLG 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A close reading of Greek tragedy (one play to be read in full, with supplementary readings in Greek) plays.
title: Tragic Drama - Euripides' Helen

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 500 lines of the
prereqs: CLG 108 or permission of instructor..
descrip: The aim of this course is to gain close familiarity with the imagination and artistry of Homer's Odyssey. We will read a substantial amount in Greek, the rest in English translation, with attention to the epic language, structure, themes, conventions and values of the entire poem. Selected secondary readings in Homeric criticism and other relevant materials.
title: Homer and the Epic Tradition

evals: If you are interested in learning hebrew, I think it presents an exciting challenge.
Small class was very good and the professor was extremely helpful.
otherinfo: Course offered every fall. Every week, there will be a Hebrew Table at the Center for Jewish Life. "Other" in Requirements/Grading comprises written homework assignments and exercise sheets.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Reading/writing load entailed consists of 5-10 pages a week.
prereqs: No credit is given for HEB 101 unless it is followed by HEB 102..
descrip: This course is designed for students with little or no previous exposure to modern Hebrew. Over the fall semester, students will become familiar with the Hebrew alphabet, and acquire rudimentary skills in reading, writing, speaking and comprehending modern Hebrew. By the end of the semester, students will be able to read short texts, construct normative sentences, and conduct simple conversations. In addition, a wide range of audiovisual materials will provide the students with an immersive environment, contextualize their knowledge of the language, and help them gain an understanding of life and culture in Israel.
title: Elementary Hebrew I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: Course offered every fall. Every week, there will be a Hebrew Table at the Center for Jewish Life. "Other" in Requirements/Grading comprises written homework assignments and exercise sheets.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Reading/writing load entailed consists of 10-18 pages a week.
prereqs: HEB 102 or Placement Test..
descrip: This course is designed for students who have completed basic modern Hebrew language courses, and aims at further developing reading, writing, speaking and comprehending skills. Emphasis will be placed on grammar and syntax, on conversational skills, and on creative writing. By the end of the Fall term students will be able to read and analyze literary texts, respond to and discuss contemporary media contents (films, journal and newspaper articles, blogs), to give class presentations and write short essays.
title: Intermediate Hebrew I

evals: Changes the way you approach history, no more binging and purging of information.
Definitely take this course. The professor is excellent and you will learn so much.
Great course. Interesting topics with great guidance.

I did not like the platform of the class online. The lectures were too broad. The entire class is too broad. I understand that it is the history of the world, but themes are made more important than events/people/places etc. Do not recommend if you do not have a strong historical background. If you don't, you also can't really participate in precept, and even when you do.
I would advise you to take the course because you learn about interesting main themes and paradoxes in history.

I would take this course if you are not a history major and are looking for an HA that gives you a very good idea about general trends in global history over the past 7 or so centuries. Adelman is an excellent lecturer, the workload is quite manageable (you probably will not find another history class with such a minimal reading load), and the information is broadly applicable and highly relevant to the present. However, this is not a course to take if you are frustrated by group work, can't stand flipped lectures, etc. Just know what you are getting into before you sign up.

If you want to be a part of an interactive and engaging class setting, definitely consider taking this class. The professor is clearly knowledgable and passionate about the material and interested in helping students succeed in becoming better critical thinkers. You should be aware though, that it requires a lot of work outside the classroom. You will need to watch lectures online, analyze sources & case studies before precept, and collaborate with other students on weekly online presentations.
If you're willing to take the time to learn how to use the online software, you'll have an advantage
Interesting course but lots of reading and student should be caught up with lectures and pace of class
It's not really worth it. Don't expect an easy peasy A, you'll have to work a good amount for it.

Keep up with the general reading. Make notes on what you learned from precept readings and about what shocked/surprised/interested you. Learn to watch the lectures by identifying the date, historical context and significance of each historical event discussed, to help you with class discussion.
Make sure you know the concepts very well and practice narrative mapping.
Take it if possible. The workload is very flexible and manageable. The lectures aren't too biased. All in all its a good opener into history. Great freshman class.
Take it! Professor Adelman will teach you to think about history from a global perspective and you will learn to love the subject if you don't already.
Take it, it's a great overview and you'll learn themes from history that are still relevant today. If you aren't a potential history major, PDF it.
Take this course because the professors are great, but you will be challenged to learn a lot of material on your own. If you have a good memory, I recommend this course.
This class has potential, but the way it is presented is too complicated to be useful or worth taking.

This class is very gimmick-y and has a weird set up. It is a large time commitment and no two people learn the same things because everything is split into team work. The tests are not bad if you are ok with doing the readings and watching all the lectures outside of class. I wouldn't recommend this class for non-history majors.

This is not your typical history class. Interesting if you like to look at a lot of material in a long span of history. There is a lot of group work in your precept, however, you are expected to know a lot.
Very general history course and a lot of memorization.
otherinfo: Students will be required to view two lectures online per week. There will also be one live town hall forum per week with Prof. Adelman, and one precept per week.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 20%, Design Project - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Approximately 100 pages of reading per week of primary and secondary works. Students will work collaboratively on "historical case studies" in world history based on lectures, readings, weekly forum discussions with the professor, and interactive communications with students elsewhere in the world; they will present group projects every week online.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the history of the modern world, this course traces the global processes that connected regions with each other from the time of Genghis Khan to the present. The major themes of the course include the environmental impact of human development, the role of wars and empires in shaping world power, and the transformations of global trade, finance, and migration.
title: A History of the World

evals: Absolutely take this course. If you're looking to fulfill your pre-modern req for the History department or if you're simply interested in learning a bit more about Latin America--Candiani's course is the one for you. Professor Candiani helped me to challenge the way I saw and interpreted history as a set of moral decisions and refocused this interpretation as a simply interplay of cause and effect. Every lecture, precept and reading was deeply engaging and thought-provoking. Not many lecture classes will hold your attention or keep you awake like this one.
Difficult, but take it for an important perspective on colonialism.
Great course! There is a lot of material to get through, so be prepared to work hard. Professor Candiani is a interesting and funny lecturer!

I loved this course, especially lectures! I would say to make sure you're genuinely interested in the topic before taking it as you may just feel bogged down by readings if you aren't. I took this because I had never learned much about Latin America, and I'm glad that I did. I highly recommend
I would not recommend this course. Even if you are interested in colonial Latin America, I think it'd behoove you to look elsewhere before this class.
If you have to take this for a requirement then do so but if not, don't. Important for class success are going to lectures and doing readings, there's no way around it.
You need alot of time because examinations of difficult. If you are a history major, you will enjoy it; otherwise, the course will be a struggle.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 100-200 pages of reading per week. Two papers; two take-home exams.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course begins with the origins and consolidation of the Aztec, Inca and Iberian polities and ends with the severance of colonial ties. It combines an overview of the political economy of the region over three centuries with a study of how social groups interacted among themselves and with imperial rule over time through accommodation and conflict. We pay special attention to comparisons and contrasts -- centers and frontiers of settlement, urban and rural life, indigenous and African populations, religion and transgression, Portuguese and Spanish models of rule -- and to long-term processes and implications of environmental change.
title: Colonial Latin America to 1810

evals: I would take this class with the expectation that you will not really walk out with any answers. Just more questions.
Take it if you're really interested in the subject matter, but otherwise you could find a better course. Easy grading, and not too much work.
Take the course! You will enjoy it and learn more about African history.
The message of this course is one that isn't often repeated elsewhere. The course itself is interesting and well-taught, so I'd definitely recommend taking it.
^ see above comment
take it!
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings consist of 150-200 pages drawn from both primary and secondary sources.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: The course explores the rich history of the African continent before colonial occupation during the 19th century. It concentrates on people and civilizations indigenous to Africa, focusing on ancient civilizations as well as on the expanse of Islam and the Atlantic slave trade. Travelers' accounts, epics, and archaeological evidence reveal diversity of African culture.
title: Precolonial Africa

evals: After taking this class I know I will ask Reimitz to be my thesis advisor. Its a great class with a great professor.
Definitely get used to doing a lot of reading! Go to lectures; they are great!
Definitely take this course whether or not you are particularly interested in history - Interesting and engaging with a great professor.
For a history major interested in this period, highly recommend.
Go to class and get something out of the lectures.
Highly recommend!
I loved this course! Take it!
Pay more attention to the readings than the lectures.
Read all the material even if there is a lot of it. It's really worth it.
Take it especially if you're interested in late Roman history and the middle ages. Professor Reimitz is an awesome guy.
Take this course! The professor is amazing and the reading is so interesting.
Take this course; weird area of history, that the Professors sheds light upon
definitely worth taking!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Readings will average 100 pages per week (secondary literature and translated original sources).
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course will survey the "Dark Ages" from the end of the Roman Empire to the end of the first millennium (ca. 400-1000 AD), often seen as a time of cultural and political decline, recently even labelled as the "end of civilization". The complex political and social landscape of the Roman Empire, however, had more to offer than just to end. This course will outline how early medieval people(s) in the successor states of the Roman Empire used its resources to form new communities and will suggest to understand the "Dark Ages" as a time of lively social and cultural experimentation, that created the social and political frameworks of Europe.
title: The Civilization of the Early Middle Ages

evals: A decent amount of reading, but if you come to class engaged and interested, it's worth it and you can get away with skimming or not doing all of the readings. Professor Dweck is one of the best professors I've had.
Be prepared to do all the readings and actively participate in class. And go to office hours. The professor is always happy to answer questions
Dweck is great?he'll definitely keep you on your toes with questions, not necessarily for everyone, but knows a ton, and lectures were always engaging and interesting. Very manageable workload.

If you have a strong foundation in Jewish history/culture, definitely take this course!  If you do not know much about Jewish history but are willing to work hard/learn, you will love the course.  Professor Dweck gives amazing lectures and he will not disappoint!
If you have any interest in modern Jewish history whatsoever take it. Professor Dweck is a great lecturer.
Prof. Dweck is a phenomenal lecturer and class is fun and interesting. Take this class! There is a decent amount of reading but not too much writing. You will thoroughly enjoy it.

Prof. Dweck is a very dynamic lecturer. Workload is quite manageable, but do the readings - you'll be expected to participate in lecture, which can be awkward when you haven't read. Overall, take the course.
Take it if you want to participate in interesting discussions. The professor is clear and captivating.
Take this class! Professor Dweck is an incredible lecturer. He will challenge you to think like a historian, and you will learn a ton.

Take this class. Do the readings and come with questions for Professor Dweck. Don't be offended by his rambunctious personality, it's never personal! But if you take things super personally maybe don't take this class. But you should take this class, it's super awesome and fascinating and secretly teaches a bunch of world history wrapped up in Jewish history.
The readings are hard and long, so make sure you put the time into doing them. They help a lot in lecture discussions, and they are also just super interesting
it's a very broad overview
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading assignments consist of approximately 150-200 pages per week.
descrip: This course surveys the breadth of Jewish experience from the era of the Enlightenment to the contemporary period. Tracing the development of Jewish cultures and communities in Europe, the Middle East, and the United States against the background of general history, the lectures focus on themes such as the transformation of Jewish identity, the creation of modern Jewish politics, the impact of anti-semitism, and the founding of the State of Israel.
title: Modern Jewish History: 1750-Present

evals: A very good class if you're interested in learning about Russian history. If you go to all the classes and do the reading, the midterm isn't too bad
Don't take it.

I would recommend HIS 360 if you like Russian History. But the way the class is structured now, you will probably get the most enjoyment out of reading the textbook and doing the supplemental readings, i.e. on your own. If you do take the class, definitely visit Prof. Pravilova's office hours- I went once to discuss the final paper, and my only regret is that I hadn't gone more times during the class. She is a wealth of information.
I would suggest doing all readings and being extra-prepared for precepts.
If you are interested in Russian history take the class.
Lectures communicate interesting information but do not have unifying themes that tie it all together. Reasonable midterm and a final paper with an open topic makes graded parts not too bad.
Make sure you go to lecture and do at least some of the reading for precept. Be ready to put a lot of time into writing the final paper.

Take this course if you want to learn more about Russian history! Get Pravilova as your preceptor. Precept readings are often literature-based which gives a different and more nuanced approach to historical events, which was great! Lectures were a bit dry but interesting nonetheless.

This course has a LOT of reading, but most of it is interesting. This class consumed a lot of my time for the first part of the semester, but the work load drastically dips after the midterm. The midterm itself was fairly standard?some multiple choice and two essays. Pravilova is a great instructor and is very knowledgeable about the content.
This is a thorough class if you are at all interested in Russian history.  It covers a lot of information in an easily digestible manner.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading varies from 150-200 pages of reading a week. Students can expect a midterm exam, in-class essays, and multiple choice quizzes.
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators. No prior knowledge of Russian history or the Russian language required or necessary..
descrip: This course is a survey of Russian history from the late 1600s to the fall of the Romanov dynasty in 1917. During this period Russia emerged as one of the greatest powers in Europe and Asia. In 1917, it collapsed, and the first socialist state grew up on the debris of the former Empire. In this course we'll analyze the causes of Russia's enormous territorial growth and the reasons for its backwardness; explore why the Russian monarchy outlived other European monarchies and escaped the turmoil of the 19th century revolutions; and pay attention to the development of Russian art, culture, and intellectual life.
title: The Russian Empire: From Peter the Great to Nicholas II

evals: A great early American history course!
Absolutely take it, but be prepared to do deep reading
Enjoyed the course and learned a lot. Would recommend the course, particularly to people interested in political/economic history.

Fantastic class - Professor Wilentz is an amazing lecturer, and is very supportive, although a very tough grader. However, he is always available to give advice and answer questions during office hours, as well as just have very engaging conversations about history.
If you are interested in the early history of the United States, take this course. Professor Wilentz does an incredible job and makes the class very interesting. Go to his office hours!!!
Prof Wilentz is a legend and a truly attentive and brilliant professor. Challenging but worth it!!!!
Professor Wilentz is one of the best professors around. He knows his shit and he's really helpful and available.

THE best class I have taken at Princeton.  The class is small and Professor Wilentz will challenge you in lecture and precept.  You will have to fight harder for a good grade than in any other History class I have taken, but that being said you will also learn more of the details and truly understand the period in question.  Professor Wilentz can be intimidating but is extremely caring about his students, and he takes note of who goes to office hours and puts in time outside the classroom. Take after 372 for the most comprehensive history of early America - these classes should both be requirements for American History majors.
Take this class. Wilentz is an amazing, attentive prof. The primary sources are rich and engaging.

Take this course! If you're at all interested in American history, it provides a look at an era that was more impactful than many realize. I'm BSE and was intimidated at first by all the history majors but it is definitely manageable for anyone.

This course is really a survey of early U.S. history. (There's no particular focus on democracy or slavery--they just come up a lot.) But if you're interested in American history, take this class! Wilentz is a great lecturer, and an extraordinary preceptor. When you come well-prepared, you will be challenged, and you will learn a lot.

This is a great course. The topic is interesting and the primary source readings give a clear idea of how historians interpret events in the early republic and why. Take it if you're interested in early American history or want to try out a history class.
This is truly the best course I've taken at Princeton so far. Wilentz is an incredible teacher, the course is graded fairly, and you will learn a ton about how to write. Not easy!
take this!
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 200 pages of reading per week. Brief weekly writing assignments (10%); take-home midterm.
descrip: An interpretive history of the United States from the ratification of the Constitution to the coming of the Civil War. The course will cover politics and social development, while emphasizing focused reading of primary documents. Topics will include the debate over the Federal Constitution, the presidency of Thomas Jefferson, the rise of cotton slavery, Jacksonian democracy and the growth of political parties, antislavery and reform, westward expansion, and the growing social and political divisions between North and South.
title: Democracy and Slavery in the New Nation

evals: 100% take

A course you will never forget. Professor Fronczak is up there with other Princeton legends and this is an absolute must take course! The material was extremely fascinating and I was able to learn a lot in a short span of time. Even though all major events are not covered (and cannot physically be), most big issues were covered and weaved together seamlessly. Readings could sometimes be really dense. BUT TAKE THIS COURSE.

A phenomenal course in U.S. foreign relations history. A bit of a background in U.S. history would be helpful, as there are inevitably certain events the professor can't address due to time constraints. The assessments are very fair and the lectures are extremely enjoyable. Would definitely recommend!

Definitely take the course if you are interested in learning about aspects of US foreign affairs history that you may not have known much about before. Incredibly well structured lectures, readings not too overwhelming.
Fronczak is a good lecturer? if you think history is normally boring take him since he makes it full of anecdotes and fun tid bits.

Fronczak is a wonderful lecturer. As a senior, I can really say he is one of the top three I've had at Princeton. Readings are really interesting - there are a good amount, though. Great distribution or PDF class for those looking for it.

Fronzcak takes on a massive task; all of American Foreign History in one semester, including combating some of the most pervasive myths of American identity. I would not confuse this class with a "cold war" class; this is a class about the very foundations of this country, its particular brand of imperialism, and interventions. Even if you disagree with some of the conclusions, its worth to take the class to see if you can.
Go to lecture. The readings are helpful for precept and understanding nuances but the lectures are easily the most important part.
Great class

Great class but very much a history class. I was expected it to be similar to POL/WWS classes that I had taken in the past, and Professor Fronczak is very serious about using a historical approach. However, if you are interested in analyzing primary sources, it is a great class and Fronczak is a great teacher!

Great class! Professor is really engaging, tests are not particularly hard, and essays are short. Interesting perspective on American history that you definitely didn't get in high school. I would recommend it!
Great history course.

I love this course. Professor Fronczak is a champ at story telling. My preceptor was Ronny - who was good too! But I don't recommend this as your first history class ever unless you are pretty familiar with historical writing and American history. There's a lot of content to cover!

I would absolutely recommend this class to another state. My advice would be to read the readings thoroughly and go to lecture! Also, go to Fronczak for help- he really is good at clarifying confusing concepts.
I would take this class again. Go to lecture and keep a timeline of all the deets.
If you are interested in present day diplomacy or interested in US history from an international perspective, definitely take this course. Take a precept with Ronny Regev.

If you attend the lectures and do some or most of the readings, you will do fine in this class. It is definitely an easy class to take for a HA requirement, but as someone who is considering being a history major it felt a bit like a waste of my time because it was such a survey course.
It wasn't as good as I thought it would be - readings were pretty dry. Relatively low commitment but still learnt lots
It's ok. I was underwhelmed, but it has pretty light workload and some interesting points. Having a US history background can be helpful but not necessary.
Keep up with the readings and attend lectures.
Lectures are very important to attend.
Loved this course. Absolutely take it.
Pay attention in class, take good notes, and engage well in precepts.

Professor Fronczak is an amazing lecturer--I'm so glad I took this course! A lot of reading, but the reading actually works with the lectures so it often feels worthwhile. This was definitely one of my favorite classes at Princeton so far.

Professor Fronczak is one of the best lecturers at Princeton (and that is saying a lot).  He is funny, engaging, insightful, and precise in his delivery.  Furthermore, you will learn so much from the readings, which are mostly primary documents.  If you put in the effort, you will learn so much.  The history of our country's foreign relations is much more complicated than you might believe.

Professor Fronczak is the best lecturer that I have had at Princeton. Every single lecture was engaging and fascinating. The reading can be dry, but most of the time, the documents assigned are vital to U.S. history and very worthy of close examination
Read all of the readings. Take careful notes. Read the readings again. Take an active part in class discussions.

Really great quality course!  Prof. presented the information so well and in a manner that would help the listener stay engaged.  There were clear connections between themes and topics so that was very helpful.  I definitely learned a lot from his lectures which were clear and easy to follow!  TAKE THIS COURSE. YOU LEARN SO MUCH.
TAKE THIS CLASS. This is the best class I've ever taken and made me completely reevaluate history. Extremely worthwhile. Why are you still even reading this? TAKE IT.

Take it if you like reading about history. I considered myself a history person but upon going through weekly readings i sometimes wondered why I took this course because I didn't find them particularly interesting except for a few. Lectures are chill and its not necessary to attend all the time, just get notes from a friend if you miss and idk about other preceptors but Prof. Fronczak was a great one
Take it! Even if auditing, you won't regret going to lecture, they're all so interesting, and you're not bound to the readings like other courses.
Take it! It is fair, and very interesting.
Take it! You'll learn a lot and look at US history from a different perspective. Ronny is a great preceptor.
Take the class! It's interesting, you'll learn a lot, and grading is very fair.
Take this class if you're interested in learning more than just US history but rather how the US interacts with everyone else.

Take this class!! JMF is an amazing lecturer!! you'll learn new things even if you've taken APUSH and were really good at it. you'll look at things in a new way, and the papers/exams are not too bad. i didn't think the expectations were that different from a high school history class, so even though it's a 300 level course, don't fret it

Take this class. Professor Fronczak is an amazing lecturer and will make you love what he's teaching. There are a lot of readings, but they're generally really interesting and are all contributing to the course in a significant way. Definitely go to all the lectures, they are the most valuable thing you'll get out of this class.

Take this course if you want a comprehensive overview of the history of U.S. Foreign Relations. Keep in mind that it is a history course, not WWS, so there is less attention paid to evaluating policy paradigms or major international events that did not directly influence the United States. In all, it is still an instructive course for anyone interested in the field or who have previously heard good things about Professor Fronczak - he is extremely engaging as a professor and lecturer!
Take this course!

Take this course! It is challenging but you will learn a lot and will come away with a better, more nuanced perspective of the role of the U.S. in global politics. Ronny is a great preceptor - she provides detailed feedback on papers, and makes precept an engaging time. Fronczak is a really nice guy and his lectures are great (he likes to insert puns as well).
This class was amazing. Fronczak was an incredible lecturer and the subject was really engaging. It was like he was telling a story every lecture. Definitely take

This course was an excellent choice as a prospective WWS major. As an international student, I learned so much about American history, while also learning about U.S. foreign policy. There are more readings than I was able to complete each week, but I felt like attending all lectures allowed me to get a lot out of the class nonetheless.
Very solid course.

Would recommend if you would enjoy reading many primary source documents in their original context. Preceptors could have been more engaging but a great survey course of U.S history and a good introduction to the history department.
You have to go to lecture, but the lectures are awesome.  Super PDFable if that's what you're looking for.

You should take this course if you like US history -- it looks at the same history you know in a different way. It's not the easiest history course, but it's also not hard, and Fronczak is an amazing lecturer
if you've taken apush, you won't learn that much that is new, but you'll also be in much better shape for exams. Fronczak is a good lecturer.
otherinfo: Joseph Fronczak received his Ph.D. in History from Yale in 2014. He comes to Princeton from Harvard, where he studied violence and nonviolence in war as a Mellon Postdoctoral Fellow. He specializes in international history and has written about geopolitics and protest in the journal Diplomatic History.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 125-150 pages per week.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course covers the history of US foreign relations from the American revolution to the present day. Lectures take up questions of diplomacy, foreign policy, ideology and culture, empire and anti-imperialism, and revolution and counterrevolution. Precepts emphasize primary sources, from the writings of Tom Paine, George Washington, William Jennings Bryan, Ho Chi Minh, Phyllis Schlafly, Elaine Scarry, and more.
title: U.S. Foreign Relations

evals: 100% take this. It was one of my favorite Princeton classes so far.
5 Stars! If you're looking for an easier HA with a great lecturer, take this course! Kruse is awesome and the content is really interesting.

A great course overall, the lectures were particularly good in relation to some other lectures you'll have here at Princeton.  A very interesting class and the professor does a great job of telling history like a story and not just telling us facts or other things to memorize.

A great course with a brilliant professor. Take it if you are interested and are willing to do the readings. I came into it not knowing anything about American history and it was challenging, but rewarding in the end once I got the hang of it. Take it!!
Attend all lectures! Do the readings. Skim if necessary.
Attend lectures! That's the best part of the course.
Best class I have taken at Princeton. Kruse's lectures were so interesting. Try to have precept with Richard Anderson--Amazing!
Best class ever! Definitely get David Walsh as your preceptor--he is fantastic!
Cool lectures and readings, granted the readings take a lot of time to do (especially if you're a BSE trying to get the HA distro). Grading seems kinda arbitrary.

Definitely recommend, especially for people that are not history majors and want to take a good history course before they graduate!  Will Schultz was a great preceptor--you should really try to get him!
Definitely take it
Definitely take it. Just attend lecture and fill out the essay prompts beforehand.

Definitely take the course. Great information presented, especially concerning all the different presidencies in the United States from 1920-1974. Very interesting course and excellent teaching, led by lecturer Kevin Kruse. Definitely take to learn more about American history, which is really important for being an informed citizen.
Definitely take this as an HA or just out of general interest - learned about US history in a whole new light.
Definitely take this class if you're interested in US History. If you're planning on PDFing, I would not recommend.
Definitely take this class if you're interested in learning more about US history! Professor Kruse is an amazing lecturer.
Definitely take this course! Professor Kruse is an amazing lecturer and it is an eye opening course with not an insane amount of work.
Definitely take this course. Professor Kruse is amazing and the subject matter is important, interesting, and well-delivered. The workload is decent and certainly worth it.
Definitely take this couse
Definitely take this. Prof. Kruse is an excellent lecturer and this course is well-designed and very organized.
Definitely take! Really opened my eyes about US history in a relevant way. Great lectures. He doesn't let you take notes with computers but he is an amazing lecturer.
Do take it, it's an easy HA and Kruse is an excellent lecturer.
Do the readings, and start your Short Paper early - it sneaks up on you.  Prepare you essays for the exams, and study the critical terms.  ENJOY every lecture!!

Dont assume this class is easy. It is a very popular course and Professor Kruse and the preceptors were awesome because they make the material very interesting, however the grading is pretty difficult.

Fantastic course - Kruse's lectures are fascinating and gripping. Readings are well selected as well, with some pretty cool topics covered. Just DON'T get Sean as your preceptor. His grading is arbitrary, his standards are unreasonably high, he's stubborn without a cause, and he is just way harder than the other preceptors for no reason. It seems that he prides himself on making history class more difficult than it needs to be, and will ruin the experience of this course.
Go to lecture! The course isn't hard as long as you organize your notes well for the exams.
Go to lecture, but most importantly do the readings and go to precept to gain the best understanding of course materials.
Good class, but didn't live up to the hype for me. Interesting lectures and pretty light workload, but precepts were kind of rushed.
Great background on an important time in American history! Take for a better understanding about the United States
Great class to PDF for HA requirement - really interesting material
Great class!
Great class, Professor Kruse is awesome but be prepared to do a lot of reading if you want to do well in the class
Great class, especially alongside Zelizer's U.S. History from 1974-present
Great class. Lectures were really interesting. Definitely take it.

Great course even if you aren't interested in history. The course presents material that everyone should at least have a general idea of.  PDF unless you are a history major.  The exams are very tough.
Great course! Kruse's lectures are always really interesting, and the reading isn't too heavy!
Great course! Not too tough but very interesting. Will need to study for the exams but it's very manageable.
Great course. Kruse is a great lecturer, and Schultz is a fantastic preceptor.
Great course. Take it
Great lectures and interesting readings!
Highly recommend!
Honestly, take this course if you took, did well, or enjoyed AP US History in high school. The readings are not too helpful for exams or precepts, so GO TO EVERY LECTURE and take notes.
I stronly recommend this class to anyone looking for a great HA, or anyone interested in American history. Lectures are engaging and reaadings are not overwhelming.

I took this course as a freshman, so I found it to be pretty difficult. I didn't realize how hard Princeton history courses would be. That having been said, Kruse gave some really amazing lectures that always kept the class engaged, and I found myself wishing that I didn't have to take furious notes the whole time so I could just sit back and listen to him recount history. I'd recommend it, but be ready for a good amount of work.
I would advise other students to certainly take this tremendous course and to embrace the import of the course's subject matter.
I would definitely recommend taking this class to other students, especially humanities and social science majors, as there is a lot of reading.
I would definitely recommend, so long as Professor Kruse is lecturing--he is incredible.
I would definitely take this course.

I would not recommend if you lack a solid base in US History. I am an international student and found some of the information difficult to internalize (compared to my peers). A good amount of reading each week but its not too difficult if you start early.
I would recommend to anyone no matter their interest in history.
I would strongly recommend. It covers a lot of material and really delves further into the historical landscape of the US socially, politically, and economically over the specified time period.
I would take this course, especially if you have any interest in American history. Professor Kruse is an amazing lecturer. He is on the Bogan level.
If you are looking for an amazing history class, look no further. This was one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.

If you are taking this course non-PDF, I would strongly suggest doing all the readings over an extended period of time. There is no way to cram the material in the night before or skim; doing the readings in full, highlighting, and making little summary notes, are the only way to stay on top of things and really engage critically with each source. This will also help you participate in precept and give you talking points. Additionally, I would start in the weeks coming up to the midterm and final, making flashcards or a comprehensive study guide. Professor Kruse has notes on blackboard that are to serve as a general guide, but as a student, its important to summarize for yourself, what you've learned and how you would explain things to another student.
Incredible class. Kruze is a legend, readings are interesting, manageable coursework. I'm not a history major, but this was one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Kruse is a great lecturer and even better preceptor. I recommend trying to get him as a preceptor. The class is very interesting, not very difficult, and I highly recommend it.
Make sure to go to all the lectures and do the readings! Also, do not think that Professor Kruse cannot hear you from the far back of the lecture hall. He will know and call you out on it in public.

Make sure to go to every lecture and take notes. The lectures are very interesting and it is not worth taking the class if you don't want to attend them. This being said, be ready to be furiously taking notes.
Make sure to keep up with the readings and ask questions.

Most evaluations will tell you this class has great lectures and is a must-take. It does have pretty entertaining lectures but most won't delve into issues much beyond what you got in AP US. I'd tell people to look around for something else unless they just want something to PDF for the HA requirement.
Not a 'joke' class at all - material is interesting, but grading is quite strict. Either do the readings, or PDF it.
Not as hyped as course reviews make it out to be, but a good course if you've never taken American history before. If you have, it's not going to be too different from high school history.

One of my favorite classes at Princeton. I learned so much--Kruse is an amazing lecturer, and if Ray is precepting again, he's awesome. It was an awesome class. Only qualm is that I wished there were less lectures from preceptors in the second half and more from Kruse. The readings were also interesting (heavily primary-source based) and not too taxing. I'd never really been interested in learning more about American history until I took this class.

One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Prof. Kruse is an incredible lecturer and Richard is an amazing preceptor. You can see the foundation of the modern American political system develop as the course progresses, with particular focus on the New Deal and Civil Rights Movement. TAKE IT!
Over-hyped. If you've taken US history before it won't be particularly engaging but it also won't be a guaranteed A due to somewhat arbitrary grading standards.

Personally found it worth it just for the lectures. The readings are essentially regurgitated more in depth in the lectures, but even then it's still worth going. I missed one lecture and actually still regret it. Finding a reading group early on to split up the reading is helpful, and will help when reviewing. There are a ton of readings tho. Also, it doesn't really seem like it would be an easy PDF, so definitely consider that when deciding to choose this class or not.

Prof. Kruse is a great lecturer, and makes US History interesting. However, the readings are long, and the grading is hard. It's not a free A by any stretch, but would be a great PDF. Take it as a interesting HA or if you don't want to be bored in a lecture class.
Read the primary readings especially, even more than the secondary ones (but read those too).

Reading the course reviews, I came into this course with the impression that it would blow my mind, and it didn't. Maybe that's because I'm not a US History fanatic, but it was a survey course and not much more interesting than that. If you enjoy American History, you will LOVE this class. But for someone like me, who is not in love with learning about American History, don't expect this course to be outstanding - it will be a normal, survey, US history course.
Recommend as elective or departmental.
Shouldn't have PDFed if I wanted to enjoy the course.
Strongly recommend, but be aware that this is a class that doesn't always focus on what most people would consider the most "exciting" events of this period.
TAKE IT, this is a time period of US history that one should know--I didn't before, but with Prof. Kruse's amazing lectures, I can now say I do.
TAKE THIS CLASS

TAKE THIS CLASS! Kevin Kruse is an amazing lecturer. Even if you already know most of US history from this time period, you will learn more and more every lecture. If possible, get precept with Will Schultz. Try to do all of the readings and be active in precept discussions to get the most out of this class.

TAKE THIS COURSE! If you were to only take one course at Princeton, it would have to be this one. Lectures with Kruse are amazing - the one on Jim Crow is especially moving - he is the best lecturer I have had in 4 years at Princeton. Try to get into his precept if you can (don't worry about the pressure of being with the Professor - he is very chill and I can guarantee that it will lead to a much better class conversation than that of the other precepts. I got to go once and ended up really regretting not originally choosing that option).
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
TAKE. Best lectures and precepts. Lots of readings, but if you get in a reading group it's totally manageable.
Take it
Take it and be ready to write fast in lectures
Take it!
Take it! Good HA, very informative.
Take it! It is amazing.
Take it! It is so important to know this stuff.
Take it! Kevin Kruse is one of the best lecturers and Princeton, and the content is important for anyone who wants to understand the current state of US politics and culture.
Take it! Really interesting stuff. Also try to get Will as your preceptor- he's awesome- super smart and low-key really funny
Take it!!!! The lectures are incredible and Professor Kruse is great. A really chill departmental if you're a history major, and great for general interest too.
Take it!. It has a much lighter workload compared to other history classes and Professor Kruse is an amazing lecturer.
Take it, but PDF it. Be ready to put in a lot of time each week in order to do well.
Take it, it's worth it.
Take it, pretty interesting
Take it. Most gripping lecturer at Princeton. Emotionally jarring at times but a must if want to have any understanding of how America came to be the way it is today. Not easy, but do the readings.
Take the course and do the readings.
Take this class but dont expect to learn so much more than you already do if you took US history in high school.
Take this class for Kruse's lectures. Skim the readings, the lectures cover a lot of the same material. The exams are not too hard and the paper assignment is fun.
Take this class for the simple fact that Kruse is the best lecturer I've ever had. Engaging portrayal of history.
Take this class!
Take this class! It's super interesting and very fun for an HA.
Take this class! My best at Princeton so far.

Take this class! Professor Kruse is a great lecturer and the readings are actually pretty interesting.  As someone who had not enjoyed history courses in the past, I was pleasantly surprised by how engaged I was both in lecture and precept.  It's a great class to fulfill a requirement even without PDFing it.
Take this class!!! Do the readings and go to class because you'll learn so much
Take this class.
Take this class. Provides a great background of US History and presents things that have lasting legacies to today.
Take this course if interested in the material. Easy and light workload, and Professor Kruse is a great lecturer, clearly passionate about what he teaches.
Take this course if you can take reading and are interested in the subject -- it will be very good
Take this course if you don't mind extremely large lectures and in class examinations.
Take this course!
Take this course! Even if you aren't a history major, Professor Kruse is incredibly engaging during lecture.

Take this course! I learned an incredible amount of information about the United States that your basic U.S. History course in high school never covered. Professor Kruse is an amazing professor; really engaging and makes the information you learn in class relevant.
Take this course! Kruse is incredibly and stands up to his reputation as one of the best lecturers at Princeton. Lectures, precepts, and assignments were all very interesting and stimulating.

Take this course!! My favorite Princeton course I've taken. Kruse is a fantastic lecturer. GO to lecture, though, because a lot of the information he gives will be on the exams. Exams were very fair and expectations were always made clear well in advance. I learned so much about American history.
Take this course, the lectures are good and it is very entertaining.
Take this course. Do the readings (they are fascinating). Lectures are fantastic (best at Princeton). Take it and put the effort in and you will learn a lot.
Take this of a distribution requirement. Professor Kruse doesn't use any powerpoints
The reading with Kruse is great!
This class is SUPER fun and I learned so much! Kevin Kruse is a great lecturer but he reads from his slides so that can be a bit awkward.

This class is a great look at American History, but it is pretty difficult if you haven't learned about the material before. For a lot of it, Professor Kruse expects you to know at least the basics of what he's lecturing about, but your preceptors can help when you're lost.

This class is amazing! Kevin Kruse has to be one of the best lecturers at Princeton, as he turns everything into a hypnotizing story that you simply need to hear more of. Combined with his daily doses of music at the beginning and end of class and a relatively easy Dean's Date assignment, it's a great distribution req and even if you don't need it, it's a very enlightening course, as it made me look at current events a lot differently. If you get Hamilton as your preceptor, be prepared to work hard for a good precept grade as she expects tons of participation and at least one week where you prepare the class notes based on the readings.

This course is Really well done. The Lectures were so interesting and fun due to Professor Kruse's broad knowledge and dramatic flair. The readings tended to be interesting but I feel behind by mid semester (benefits of PDFing). The tests were fair but the midterm was really Short and hard to finish so write fast! Overall, great course- it was very interesting, fun and very easy to PDF.

This is a great class! Kevin Kruse is an amazing lecturer. Definitely try to take this if you can! Kruse is very engaging, the readings are interesting, the grading is more than fair, and the material really broadens your understanding of American history. Highly recommend!

This is a very interesting course to take and important information for all Americans to know and other students should definitely take it!  The information is laid out very nicely and is clear to understand.

This is an amazing class! One of the best lecturers at Princeton. I was hesitant because I felt like i had learned so much American history already but the way the facts are taught around the greater themes in this course make it unique and valuable experience. It truly is a study of the history of America as it has led us to where we are today. Beware of the essays on the exams, talk to your preceptors about their expectations beforehand. Get Richard as your preceptor if you can he is AMAZING!
Very interesting lectures, Professor Kruse is phenomenal. Get a good preceptor.

Very interesting lectures, readings can be kind of a pain and they are necessary for understanding. One dean's date paper that is only 5 pages. Definitely go to lecture because it is hard to get back missed material. Professor Kruse is amazing but don't mistake this for an easy-grade class.
You have to stay on top of readings and go to lecture and take notes. Be careful who you select for a preceptor.
definitely take this course for kruse but would recommend pdfing.
enjoyable and interesting course, but fairly strict grading when it comes to exams and papers

good HA. Probably hard to find another one as good as this (don't waste your time with bridges... you actually want to learn something). Kruse is left of center, if that is a concern, but as somebody who is very conservative on certain issues, I did not find it to be dogmatic. He's a great lecturer and is savage af. Don't talk or use your phone in class; he will call you out
good history course if you need to take an american history to graduate
interesting course but material becomes tedious and repetitive
really fair. important part of history. take it! kruse is a cool guy and lectures are like american story time
take if you want to read a lot about this period in history. also you learn a lot if you invest in the course
take it

take it! I PDFed it, and wouldn't necessarily suggest that this would be a class to PDF because there is a dean's date assignment and a final, but the readings were manageable. Professor Kruse is AMAZING
take it, very good course
take it.

this isn't a particularly challenging course, and kruse is an amazing lecturer. if you get a good preceptor you'll overall love this course, which i did. the only negative id say is its easy to get by without doing the readings. then youll get to the final/paper and be a bit behind.
yes
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 150-200 pages of reading per week, midterm exam, final exam, short paper.
prereqs: PDF option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: The history of modern America, with particular focus on domestic political and social changes. Topics include the Roaring 20s; the Great Depression and the New Deal; the homefront of World War II and the Cold War; the civil rights movement and the Great Society; the Vietnam War; the sexual revolution; the Silent Majority, the Nixon administration, and Watergate.
title: The United States, 1920-1974

grading: Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
assgts: Source materials and readings prepared by the instructor.
descrip: This course offers an opportunity to explore the social and cultural meanings of legal texts. The focus is on methodology: on how to locate cases, statutes, treatises, trial records, and legal lives in their historical contexts, and on the differing ways historians have used legal texts as historical artifacts. In the course of this course, students will be exposed to a number of differing and contending perspectives on American legal history. It should offer students an opportunity to think broadly about the role of law in the wider culture and to try their hand at doing legal history.
title: The Role of Law in American Society

evals: Be ready to read, but be ready to also gain a new lens on not only African American history but American History.
Do the readings and go to office hours.

Fantastic course--one of my favorites so far. Prof. Guild's lecture style will not appeal to everyone, though. Try to stay on top of the readings as much as possible and the papers shouldn't be a problem.

I highly recommend taking this course, especially if you are at all interested in American history. This course helps you understand a critical story to the progress of America and to the America we live today. If you take this course, make sure to do all the readings before the lectures because it enhances your understandings of the lectures. Also, in writing papers it's crucial that you have a thorough understanding of the readings for context and general understanding of the coursework.
I would advise other students to stay on top of the readings because it is a lot to get through.

If you take it, make sure to actually spend a good amount of time reading. All of the readings that Professor Guild assigns are amazing, so make sure to read them while you have the chance to critically engage with them.
Really enjoyed this course
TAKE IT.  The material is absolutely fascinating and NECESSARY for any American or anyone interested in American history or contemporary politics.
Take it regardless of background. Best class I've taken at Princeton. Guild is a gift.
Take this course. It should be a requirement for all history majors.
This is an excellent course - take it! Be prepared for a lot of reading, however
take it!
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Papers - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Approximately 150 pp. reading per week, plus several documentary films. Assignments include a short paper, take home midterm, and final paper.
descrip: An analysis of the social, political, legal, and cultural dimensions of the African American experience in the United States throughout critical historical moments such as Reconstruction, suffrage, the Great Migration, war, the Great Depression, the New Deal, the Civil Rights era, the black power movement, and contemporary racial politics. Two lectures, one preceptorial.
title: African American History Since Emancipation

evals: A very interesting class that completely changed how I viewed Churchill in relation to Europe and the United States. Explored his life before and after WW2, which I had never learned about before.

Always try to keep up with the research and writing process until the very end.  Take advantage of individual meetings with your instructor/adviser because they're really insightful and clarifying.  Prof. Williams did a great job with that aspect--assessing where we were and providing advice to help us get where we wanted/needed to be in the process.
Amazing professor. Super interesting time period. Churchill was an incredible person and  wrote so much/so much was written about him so there are many directions for your JP!

As far as the junior seminars go, I think this was an above average one. Interesting material, Professor Colley is great. But, the American Revolution is not a great JP topic because of it s breadth and so much has already been written about it
Be wary that everything will fall on you
Definitely take this seminar! Ronny is awesome, the topic is super interesting! Great class discussions!
Do the readings, and start your papers early!
Get an early start on drafting!
Great junior sem! Professor Cannadine is very interesting and extremely knowledgeable and nice! Be prepared to do A TON of reading!
Gross is very nice and helpful. He enjoys talking and the seminar can feel a bit long/conversationless.

I imagine taking a Professor Gross lecture course would be great, but he doesn't seem to care too much about the students he's advising, as far as that goes. He seems like a very nice person and he's obviously very smart, but I'm not convinced he knew my name and he didn't seem to be that encouraging. Hard to get a solid read on the guy overall.
I would highly suggest the course - even if the time period is not particularly interesting to you. The material, instruction, and discussion makes it very exciting, informative, and worthwhile.
I would recommend another seminar if you want an interesting topic, but Professor Cannadine is extremely knowledgable, helpful, nice, and makes sure you get on the right track with your Junior Paper.
It's great!
Loved this seminar! Professor Fronczak is great and all the work we did throughout the semester was to get us one step closer to writing our JPs, which was so helpful. Invaluable resource.
Professor Candiani is great and makes writing a JP (which is not fun) a little bit more manageable.
Professor Colley can be a bit intimidating but she's really helpful and you'll learn a lot!
Professor Colley is a genius, do you readings.
Start your JP as early as possible; it's worth it.
Start your JP early, and DO NOT PROCRASTINATE.
TAKE THIS COURSE

Take HIS 400 with Professor Fronczak if it is offered. The course moves very smoothly. There are assignments each week, which is more than some other HIS 400 seminars, however they give you a clear idea of what his expectations are for the JP. More importantly, they put you in a great position to be able to write the JP at the term's end.
Take if you are interested in how normal people interacted with political/social issues, or are just looking for a bit of a different History class.

Take this course!!!!! Couldn't have imagined a better JP adviser than Professor Fronzcak. Seriously was so grateful to have had such a wonderful adviser. He will help you every step of the way. He's friendly and approachable and really a smart and thoughtful Professor who will do everything he can and go out of his way to help you on your paper.
Take this course. Professor Cannadine is great and the course material is really interesting.
Take this course. Professor Fronczak is awesome and teaches so much about writing. I was so scared of writing my JP but Professor Fronczak made it seem so manageable.
Take this seminar if you can! The topic is amazing and a great foundation for a JP.
Take this seminar if you really want to learn how to craft an interesting and well-written JP!!! Professor Candiani is amazing!!!
The professor is good, but there isn't much guidance.

There is no course I would recommend more highly than this. In addition to being a fantastic lecturer and one of the world's leading authorities on Churchill (he's also an editor of the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography), Prof. Cannadine is an extremely friendly and witty man. He strikes the perfect balance of direct instruction and facilitation of discussion. Even if Churchill/WWII in general is not your main historical area of interest, I would recommend taking this course solely for the professor.

This class is not economic history heavy, which was what I was expecting coming in. The assigned readings, however, are great, great foundations for whatever you will go on to write out about for your JP: music, economics, cultural history, fascism, whatever. There's a lot of freedom in this class.

This course was quite unique. I particularly enjoyed learning with Prof. Colley which has been an incredibly rewarding educational experience. The course brought together a number of different topics and themes in order to gain a greater understanding of the American Revolution. The use of different source types and perspectives also helped achieve the course's mission of more deeply understanding the Revolution as a whole.
Would recommend.
You don't really have a choice in taking these courses, but professor Candiani is a great advisor to have.
You lost out on Ronny. Other seminars field a lot of complaints, but hers was great.
otherinfo: View descriptions of the seminars at http://www.princeton.edu/history/undergraduate/info-for-sophomores/. One's instructor in the 400 Seminar will advise the Fall Junior Paper on a subject connected with the Junior Seminar. The Junior Paper and the Junior Seminar receive separate grades. Direct all questions to the History undergraduate administrator at etta@princeton.edu.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Varies. Up to 250 pages of reading per week. Assignments include essays and exercises related to the seminar topic. The course culminates with the production of the Fall Junior Paper.
prereqs: Compulsory course for departmental majors in the fall of their junior year..
descrip: The Junior Seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This course is compulsory for departmental majors and is taken in the fall of the junior year. Students may choose from a range of topics. Seminar topics will tend to be cross-national and comparative.
title: Junior Seminars

grading: Papers - 35%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 150-200 pages of reading per week; weekly written response to readings; two papers.
descrip: This seminar will examine how the territorial footprint of the People's Republic of China was created, by exploring the history of its frontier regions. Through units on Tibet, Xinjiang, Taiwan, Manchuria, and the Southwest, we will interrogate concepts of ethnic identity, nationalism, culture, and religion, as well as contested historical claims over territory and sovereignty. Some basic knowledge of modern Chinese history is helpful but not required.
title: China's Frontiers

evals: Be open to reflect on the moral and ethical underpinnings of the historical discipline.
Go all in -- those who view HIS 500 as a requirement and not an opportunity get less out of the course.

History students obviously don't have a choice about whether to take this class or not, but I found it really enjoyable and helpful and hope that it continues to be co-taught with smaller discussion groups. Great introduction to themes within the discipline and a safe space to discuss big problems.

I have had students in my department ask for my advice, and it depends on the student.
