For those dealing with medieval history or later, its definitely necessary to have training in historical theory, and be able to "speak the same language" as it were with historians studying other regions and time periods. For my peers studying bronze age China, I do not think it has much value at all.
I would advise reading a basic textbook on historiography prior to taking the course.
Read diligently and participate earnestly.
You have to take this course, so make the best of it.
grading: Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
descrip: A colloquium to introduce the beginning graduate student to the great traditions in historical writing, a variety of techniques and analytical tools recently developed by historians, and the nature of history as a profession.
title: Introduction to the Professional Study of History

grading: Papers - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Participants write a number of discussion papers.
descrip: Covers the history, historiography and theory of Latin America's early modernity. Readings offer a vehicle to discuss questions such as why some types of historical questions seem more urgent than others at different times and what are the origins and meanings of historiographical shifts over the evolution of the field. To explore such questions and find out what problems of past historiographical traditions remain unsolved and deserve a new look, both classic texts and more recent works that display new approaches are read, often in counterpoint. Students of early modernity, colonial empires and world history will profit from the course.
title: Colonial Latin America to 1810

otherinfo: Some Spanish is highly recommended. See instructor for more details.
grading: Papers - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
descrip: Course examines interactions between states and citizens since Latin American independence with an additional consideration of the region's integration into global economic and political systems.
title: Modern Latin American History Since 1810

otherinfo: Undergraduates may enroll with the permission of the instructor.
grading: Papers - 75%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
descrip: Topics include the relationship between society and warfare in pre-modern and modern Africa, the impact of violence on society (for example, population displacement, disease, and genocide) and post-conflict recovery (i.e. demobilization, return and resettlement of internally displaced persons and refugees, the transition from emergency aid to development aid) and reconciliation (for example, truth- and/or reconciliation commissions and war crimes/humanitarian courts) as well as the memorialisation of the violence and peace-building.
title: Modern African History: Society, Violence, Displacement, and Memory

evals: If your work concerns either gender or science, or you have a general interest in the topic, this is definitely a course worth taking.
Take the course.
This is great course that will help you to think through some interesting and important issues in the history of science.
This was a great course and I highly recommend it to others.
Yes, take this course!
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: The seminar begins by exploring classic scholarship centered on four historical periods, each posited as important moments in the origin of gendered science: medieval Christianity, the scientific revolution, the professionalization of scientists in the late-19th century, and 20th-century second-wave feminism. We then turn to a series of well-developed analytical tools employed by historians of science and gender, and finally to recent scholarship. In all cases, we will analyze the imbricated processes by which science as a social enterprise has been fundamentally gendered and the implicit gendering of the sciences of sex and sexuality.
title: Topics in the History of Sex and Gender - Gender and Science

evals: If you have any interest in Tokugawa history, or even if you are looking for a course that will challenge some of your ideas about history, I thoroughly recommend it.

The theoretical questions applicable to early modernity are intelligible, I think, to both classicists or medievalists and modernists, in a way that those aren't always accessible to each other. Tokugawa Japan is a rich, well-documented example of early modernity, so if you're at all interested in theoretical questions, this is a great way to dip your toes in.

This course was a very good look at historiography, but an excellent prod to consider the teaching dimensions of the topic. Prof. Marcon will ask you many times to think about how you would teach this which, really, contains within it at the same time the question of how you would write about it for other historians, and you eventually come up with your own Tokugawa undergrad syllabus. I would tell you to grab on to this chance to work on pedagogical things in a way that is actually built into a class from the beginning.
grading: Papers - 100%
descrip: A survey of major issues in the historiography of early modern Japan and Meiji Japan (1600-1890).
title: Readings in Early Modern Japanese History

evals: A very rigorous introduction to the Soviet Union and in some respects to the practice of history in general. It is overwhelming but entirely worthwhile.

Even if you are not a history graduate student (and I do think this grad-level course should not be taken by undergrads), consider seriously taking this course. It will stretch you in ways you cannot imagine, from learning that you can in fact read as much as he asks to thinking about the world in a whole new way.

If you're willing to do the readings, and willing to be challenged, take the course.  You won't regret being in the same classroom as Professor Kotkin.  It goes without saying, but conversely, this is not a course you can "skate by" on.   You've got to work hard at it and be willing to participate, even if you're not completely  sure of every concept.
Take the course. But be invested. The course can consume your entire semester, so you need to be disciplined. But Kotkin will blow your mind every single week.
This course is extraordinarily good, but, be advised, it is also a lot of work.
grading: Papers - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
descrip: This seminar covers the history of the Soviet Union from inception until dissolution and slightly beyond. The readings are exhaustive and comprehensive, with particular attention paid to institutions, empire, the cultural foundations of politics, and the world context.
title: The Soviet Empire and Successor States

otherinfo: In the first half of the course, we examine sets of documents in conjunction with related notable works of historiography. In the second half, students explore selected documents in more depth, writing a 20-page paper. Later class meetings focus on formulating research questions, organizing research and writing, and developing arguments.
grading: Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
descrip: This research and writing course introduces students to working with archival documents. It is designed to expose students to a variety of early modern archival materials, especially manuscript (letters, state papers, parish registers, criminal proceedings, account books, legal depositions, etc.) and to explore how historians use different materials.
title: Topics in English History - Working with Early Modern Documents

grading: Papers - 80%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the historiography of early North America and the Caribbean. Discussions of Native American history, comparative colonialism, labor, violence, race, slavery, and more.
title: Readings in Early American History

evals: Absolutely recommend taking this class, especially if you were interested in the HUM sequence but wanted something a little less intense. You read one book per week, which can be daunting at first but you get used to it by the middle of the semester. Lectures are always great - Professor Barkan's lifelong passion for the subject matter always shows. There are some obvious limitations on how in depth we can study the texts with just 2 lectures and 1 precept per week, but that's what the papers are for, I suppose. Only 3 papers, fairly graded.

An interesting class, but it probably wouldn't be enjoyable for someone looking for a distribution requirement or fun/easy class. The amount of coursework wasn't too bad, there are only three papers. However, you read a book each week. You can get by with sparknotes but it's much better to actually read the book, which might take up a lot of time.

As a science person, I'm not sure I'd recommend a non-humanities person take this course if you're hoping to get a good grade. Papers are tough if you don't have the gift of thinking cool things about books. Nonetheless, it's really cool to read the great books and learn all the important information about them.

If you are afraid of taking the HUM sequence, COM 205 is a painless alternative. One book a week and very interesting, thoughtful lectures by Professor Barkan, who is an absolute gem of a human being. Andrea Placidi is also an incredible preceptor, so there are no losses to be had. Would highly recommend if you want a basic background of Western literature!
Prof. Barkan is a thought-provoking lecturer! Great books and reading in a classroom setting gives guidance to thinking about them critically.
The readings take a long time, but I would recommend in general

This is a terrific course for anyone interested in literature. Professor Barkan is deeply passionate and knowledgeable about this material, and he does a wonderful job of allowing students to discover for themselves the joys of the material. I highly recommend this course.
grading: Papers - 65%, Class/Precept Participation - 35%
assgts: An average of approximately 250 pages of reading per week. Three papers.
descrip: A reading of some of the greatest works of literature in the Western tradition from Homer to the Renaissance. The course is also designed as an introduction to Comparative Literature -- that is, a reading of literary works across the boundaries of time, geography, and language. All works taught in English.
title: The Classical Roots of Western Literature

evals: Be prepared for a large amount of reading.
Definitely take this class because it's a hidden gem! Professor Wood has tons of ideas to bring to the table, and he is always willing to explore students' interests.

Professor Wood is an extraordinary professor, knowledgeable, easygoing, very insightful, and kind and approachable. I would definitely recommend taking the course with him, and of course the readings can't be beat.

This course deserves the attention of any Princeton student. Professor Wood is the best teacher I've ever had - funny, engaging, laid-back, hugely influential in his field and a man of significant intellect, he's the perfect guide for this tour of Europe's greatest works of literature.
This course was one of my favorite ones at Princeton - I highly recommend it. Professor Wood is amazing and the books read, and the discussions about them, are extremely interesting.
This is a great survey course for people of all majors and disciplines; you don't have to be a comp lit major to truly enjoy this class. That said, if you are, you'll also have lots of fun.

You really need to do the readings in order to get anything out of the course, so if you can't do that, it's probably not worth it. On the other hand, don't let the page numbers scare you, because there isn't much other work. Professor Wood is very nice, but the lectures and precepts are very different from the readings so they might not actually help with your understanding of the texts.
grading: Papers - 65%, Class/Precept Participation - 35%
assgts: About 250-300 pages of reading a week, on one occasion (Dostoevsky) a little more. Weekly responses on Blackboard and two papers, one short (around 5 pages), one long (around 10).
descrip: In this course we will examine the major forms and themes of European literature since the Renaissance, concentrating on drama, prose fiction and lyric poetry. Significant works originally written in English, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Russian and Spanish will be read (in English) for their intrinsic interest as well as for what they tell us about what a masterwork might be, and how the concept may change over time.
title: Masterworks of European Literature

evals: A lot of work. But you are also learning from 6 professors. Amazing precepts--heated discussions, high participation rates. People actually take precepts seriously. Also you will learn to skim. Go get help before you write your papers. Hardest class but also my favorite class at Princeton.

Be committed to the readings and discussions. Approach the class eager to engage your cohort and professors. If you are a sophomore, consider how it will feel to be a full part of a freshman-dominated friend-forming community. If this does not deter you, go for it.
Be prepared for a whole lot of reading every single week and harshly (but fairly) graded papers. It's a lot of work, but an immensely rewarding course that every first-year should consider taking.
Be ready for amazing lectures, but a lot of reading.

DO NOTE that it is possible to attend lectures WITHOUT enrolling in HUM - those interested in learning the material but lack the writing skills should consider popping into a few lectures here and there - be certain before committing.
Do the reading.

Don't be intimidated by the long list of reading. Remember, this is weighted as two classes, so it makes sense that there is a lot of work. But it is so rewarding. If you have the slightest interest in this course, take it!
Don't let the readings scare you! This course is absolutely fantastic, and will really make a difference in your academic life, and perhaps life in general. Take it!
GO TO THE OFFICE HOURS OF YOUR GRADERS AND ALL THE OTHER PROFESSORS!

HUM is fantastic--I can't recommend it enough. Yes, there are a lot of readings, but, considering it counts for two classes, it really is manageable. The professors--particularly Baraz and Morison--are phenomenal. All of the lectures and precepts were

HUM is hard. However, there're tons of people to help you and the professors are really nice! If you ever need help, just talk to someone and they'll be happy to. Also, I can't stress strongly enough how important it is to get your papers peer reviewed-- If fewer than four people have read your paper, it's probably not ready to turn in. Find people from precepts or friends or even good writers who aren't in the class and ask them for help.

HUM is not for everyone. As someone who absolutely loves literature and history, this class pushed even me to my breaking point. The faculty is amazing, the books are astounding, but I couldn't physically find the time to keep up in the course and give all of the readings the attention they deserve. I didn't have the best precept group and I felt that as wonderful as the class could be, it just wasn't right for me.
If you are interested in taking it, and end up taking it, give it your all, because you can learn so much from this curriculum.

If you only kind of like reading and literature, you might want to consider very carefully before taking this course. It's very intense and requires a LOT of reading, but it's not as terrifying as everybody seems to think. I was able to balance lots of extracurriculars and the work of other courses.

If you're on the fence about HUM, take it- it was a really formative experience for me this semester, and I'm so glad I did. While it is demanding, it's not as bad as its reputation makes it out to be for sure. You get so much academic support, and there's a great community that comes up around all the students (inside jokes abound). That being said, you get out of this course what you put into it, and since all you're learning is the literature, if you don't plan on reading all the books (at some point- I caught up on a lot of reading on breaks), I wouldn't waste your time with this class. Also note that this is a primarily literary class, and you examine all the works from a more literary/philosophical perspective; if you're just interested in history or philosophy and not literature, I would possibly recommend another class.
Invest your time and energy into it. Take advantage of office hours, especially in preparation for essays.
It is a life-changing course that will change the way that you look at the world
It's a lot of work, as you probably have heard, but actually more manageable than you might think. Mainly an exercise in time management, honestly.

It's definitely more fast-paced than other courses and really intense, but I enjoyed it. 

The professors were always willing to answer questions and were a treasure trove of knowledge in their subjects. They're really nice and love talking to you, so don't be afraid to go to office hours (should've done this) and just ask them general advice and direction!
Make time in your schedule for reading! Otherwise you will not get it done.
Only take HUM if you're okay with reading three books or more per week and talking about the greatest books of the early European literature for a very short time only.
Read three books a week. If it sounds game, then do it. But remember that this will be intense and stressful if you want to do well.

Recommending this course is difficult because on the one hand, the readings were killer and the essays were ill-planned (I had to write them all over holidays and breaks where there was little assistance until the night before the essay was due).  One the other hand, I did learn and my perceptions of literature are different now, though in unexpected ways.  Now see, I did all the readings.  Like literally all the readings, so listen to me when I say if you do this, then you will not have a life.  It is not possible to have both; they are mutually-exclusive.  Not that it isn't possible to have a life and take HUM, because technically it is.  Technically, but if you do all the readings, it is not.  Anyway, so I did all the readings, but that is how I learned from this course.  I read all of Aristotle's philosophy and reason works, and now I literally hear and read things differently because I understand what logic is.  I remember proofs from Euclid's Geometry, which actually comes in handy sometimes.  I know stories from the Bible now, which let's be real, is super helpful for living in America.  I know how much the plague in Athens sucked, which doesn't really help me in life, but I read about it in at least six different pieces, so it's gotta be important somehow, right?  Anyway, I learned things, but those things were not necessarily how to write a textual analysis essay, because I never fully grasped that, or how to glean the important parts of a text, because let's be real, I didn't.  Take this course if you like Classics, ancient history, language, humanity, logic, philosophy, literature, dying, or not having a life.  Or don't take it, and listen to all the kids who do take Hum whine about their lives, and laugh.  I will say that Hum compelled me to think about humanity in ways I never have before, and that's kinda cool, though kind of unrelated to the course because that wasn't really the point of the course.
Take it, and make sure you get better at quick reading

Take notes during the lectures; they are helpful during exam time. Don't skip out on the precepts; they are more fun than they let on in the beginning. Work hard, but don't give yourself a heart attack.
There are a lot of things wrong with the class -- talk to upperclassmen who both liked it and didn't like it before you choose to take it.
This course is good if one is willing to do the readings fully. If not, one might struggle with the precepts.
This is obvious but... take only if you enjoy reading. Stay a week ahead of readings (this must be started before classes start). The community is great

This is such an interesting course. Lots of readings though, and you will be discouraged at times by how fast you're forced to move, which disallows you from really analyzing some of the more interesting texts as much as you would like.
Those who struggle with writing, beware! I found the essays a real struggle. The readings are almost always wonderful, but it's very easy to fall behind.
otherinfo: In the fall, students must enroll in both 216 and 217, which together include a thrice weekly 50-minute lecture and a twice weekly 80-minute class. In the spring, students may continue on to HUM 218-219, which covers the Renaissance through the modern period.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 200-400 pages of reading per week. Five papers.
prereqs: The course is designed for first-year students and sophomores. Interested students should consult the HUM Sequence website for information and instructions on how to reserve a seat in the course: https://humstudies.princeton.edu/humanities-sequence/ . Seats are available first come, first served, but department sign-up is required. The year-long double-credit course fulfills the prerequisite requirement and two courses for the Certificate in Humanistic Studies https://humstudies.princeton.edu/certificate/..
descrip: Humanistic Studies 216-219 is an intensive yearlong exploration of the landmark achievements of the Western intellectual tradition. With a team of faculty drawn from across the humanities and social sciences, students examine pivotal texts, events, and artifacts of European civilization from antiquity forward. The course is enhanced by guest lectures from preeminent scholars and by excursions to museums and performances. Our themes are the great ones, ethics, politics, beauty, truth, and--in a year when Princeton will make a formal reckoning with its historical debts to slavery--European legacies of bondage and freedom.
title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture I: Literature and the Arts

evals: Come to precept prepared to participate and engage with other people's ideas. Be ready to read and learn A LOT. You will leave feeling so much more equipped to do almost anything.
Do not take this unless you are willing to devote 80% of your time to this course. Lectures can be boring and your precept will probably not be conducive to actual understanding of the texts.
Do the readings. Go to lectures. This course will profoundly change the way you think.
Don't expect to go too in-depth with the readings, but I did like that it gave me exposure (however brief it may have been) to works that I wouldn't have read otherwise.

HUM is excessively brutal, which is exactly why you should take it. The professors recognize the struggle and are therefore willing to provide their time, expertise, and brainpower to assist your intellectual and personal progression in any way possible. Steel yourself for a painful year, and prepare to be inspired.

I would recommend anyone who really has a lot of patience and curiosity to take this course. Although everyone should read the texts we read, to take this course in an academic setting is definitely demanding in a different sense. Students considering this course has to be able to pace themselves well, while also enjoying every single word.

If you don't mind reading and want to learn where important ideas originated, then I wholeheartedly recommend this course. If tons of reading is a roadblock and not something you would enjoy, then this course is not for you. But learning about the origins Western Civilization is an incredibly rich an informative experience.

Lots of people absolutely love the course, but it's not for everyone.  I personally want to major in the humanities and found these types of readings fascinating, but even so, I was one of the people that it just didn't work for. The course flies through tons of material in a short amount of time, so if you prefer to depth over breadth, I would reconsider. Also, even though it counts for two classes, 200-400 pages a week does not sound nearly as grueling as it really is, so be prepared and willing to dedicate a lot of time to the class. All this being said, many people have an amazing time in the course and find it incredibly rewarding, so give it a chance if you think you might like it.

Only take this course if you really love this material. I enjoy the humanities but am not super passionate about them and found myself quite bored by the readings, lectures and precepts. The course provides a great scope of works, and I do feel like I have a good foundation because of it, but the pace of the class means skimming the surface of the works without exploring them at a deeper level. The writing assignments are based on close readings of passages which I found painful to write, and since there are 5 a semester it didn't feel worth it to me. Don't let the workload deter you from taking this course, there are a lot of readings but it's manageable, but do consider how interesting you find the material before taking this class. Some students really love it and some don't. And since it's such a big commitment make sure you're invested before you commit to it.

Precepts: It certainly helps to read the assigned passages. :p But more seriously, try to read ahead, especially in December, because Dante is a huge block of text lol. But if you can't read it all (we feel you on Lucretius), at least skim it, and write down questions/reactions you have to the text. They don't have to be dignified or anything, my comments on Lucretius were so sassy I'm almost embarrassed to read them again. But you'll be interacting with the text, and so you'll be able to contribute in precepts.
It's not just about the contribution, though. Everyone in HUM has something influential or cool or insightful to say. Often it's more enjoyable to simply listen and understand what they have to say. But with a good professor (as will be the case in HUM), you can work together with your peers to draw deeper meanings from the text and get closer to the truth, which is one of the most rewarding aspects of the course. Also, you'll probably form study groups for the final this way, which is very beneficial. :p
As for the final, the papers prepare you for the commentary portion. For the quotes portion, honestly rereading through the texts was much better than Sparknotes. Go back through your lecture/precept notes to see which passages the professor emphasized. Look back through sections that struck you and that you commented on/highlighted. Get together with other HUMies to see what they thought key parts were, to precisely determine the style and idiosyncracies of the authors, and quiz each other beforehand. The final is ultimately a chance to show just how much you've learned in the course. It's pretty incredible to see. So to all the future HUMies, congrats. You're going to learn and do amazing things. Godspeed.
Stay on top of your readings!

The humanities sequence is an incredible--overwhelming, at times--journey through Western civilization and culture. You must keep your mind malleable and constantly open to the influence of ancient and medieval authors as well as your professors and classmates. This is a great chance to appreciate and join a conversation that has been taking place for centuries.

This course is unlike any I have ever taken. If you are willing to think critically, take intellectual risks, maintain an open perspective, and invest time into the study and appreciation of literature, then you will find the course to be transformative. Do not take HUM simply to fulfill a distribution requirement. Take it if you are inspired by the storytelling process and are committed to joining an enduring conversation about pivotal works from the past. The dedicated team of professors is a reason in itself to take the course. I walked away from every lecture and precept overflowing with new convictions, questions, ideas, and passions that will continue to resonate with me long after my time at Princeton.
This is the best class I have ever taken with some of the most intelligent, wonderful professors I have met.
n/a; duplicate to evaluation just submitted
same advice as 216 evaluation.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: For information on assignments and requirements, please see the description for HUM 216.
prereqs: See HUM 216..
descrip: In combination with HUM 216, this course explores the landmark achievements of European civilization from antiquity to the middle ages. Students must enroll in both 216 and 217, which constitute a double-credit course. The lecture component for HUM 217 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 216. There are no separate meeting times for HUM 217.
title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture I: History, Philosophy, and Religion

evals: Don't play yourself, take it. Take it and learn from everyone you interact with. Relish in it.

If you are lucky enough to be accepted into this course with John McPhee, do not hesitate, and take it 100%. It is a life-changing course, especially if you are considering writing as a career. It's not a workshop - writing feedback takes place during one-on-one conferences - and the seminars are fascinating. Professor McPhee is an unbelievable teacher, and his seminar guests are equally interesting to speak with. Apply for it, and take it. You'll never regret it.
If you get in to this class, do not hesitate. A Princeton highlight.

If you have the opportunity, take this class. John McPhee is not only a master of nonfiction, but also a totally kind and supportive teacher who devotes hours every week to each student's writing. He has perfected the structure of this course over decades, and if you give your time to the class, you will come away with clear, definite, and widely applicable techniques that will improve any piece of writing. If you don't have the chance to take the course, I highly recommend John McPhee's recent New Yorker series about writing. (Also, look out for a forthcoming book!) Besides being a joy to read, they will teach you all of the major themes of the course. Keep reading nonfiction, and keep writing!

In this course, everyone will take your writing seriously, but you won't have the added stress that can inhibit creativity. John McPhee is one of the best professors here, because of the deep and apparent interest he takes in each one of his students. You won't find a more inspiring or nurturing environment.
Obviously you should apply.

Please take this course, even if you are unsure about creative writing. It will open your mind to a new genre of writing. The assignments are very flexible, allowing you to take whatever approach and angle you'd like. Writing the stories was by far the best part of the class, not to mention the one-on-one meetings with McPhee. He is an excellent professor and friend who really, really cares about this course. The guest speakers are very engaging and eye-opening--do the readings before they come to class! Definitely apply to this course--it was my favorite class I've ever taken at Princeton, and I think the things I have learned in it will stick for a while.

Take this class if you get in - you won't regret it. John McPhee is so extraordinarily nice, funny, and hard-working. I come from a STEM background, and this class made me want to be a writer. The three hour seminars can get a bit boring, but the guests are extraordinary (New Yorker writers, editors/publishers, former students, etc.). Don't think twice about it - just take the class.
This course is the best I've ever taken, here or anywhere, and if you have the opportunity, take it! McPhee is a living legend and a wonderfully humble person. His writing advice is precious.
This is a life-changing class that will stay with you forever.
otherinfo: Suki Kim is an investigative journalist, a novelist, and the only writer ever to have lived undercover in North Korea. She is the author of the New York Times best seller Without You, There Is No Us: Undercover Among the Sons of North Korea's Elite and the novel The Interpreter, which was a finalist for the PEN/Hemingway award. A contributing editor at The New Republic, Kim's investigative reporting and non-fiction have appeared in Harper's, NYTimes, and The New York Review of Books.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of reading, reporting, and writing. Throughout the semester students will work on a single, long-form project due at end of term. Drafts will be due on staggered deadlines every two to three weeks. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required.
descrip: This seminar will focus on journalism as an art form, especially as it regards social issues. Literary, investigative non-fiction came to flourish in the 1960s and continued; this course will explore that tradition with essays and articles. The class will operate like a magazine newsroom in which student writers will produce a high-quality story that goes through a deep editorial process. Narrative arc, storytelling, and thorough reporting will be emphasized, and themes might include race, class, and culture. Students will work on a single, long-form project throughout the semester.
title: Creative Non-Fiction

evals: Absolutely take, especially if you have any interest in learning the Bible. For the religious-minded, both lecturer and preceptors are incredibly fair and don't take any cheap shots; your faith will grow if you take this class. If you're not of a religious background, there is still an incredible amount to be learned, and an understanding of the Bible will lend greater understanding to other works, I'm sure. Definitely take!
Highly recommended. The work load is flexible. Great lectures. Most weeks you could participate in an engaging precept just by attending lecture.
I really liked the class, great PDF and not too hard to do well in either. Professor Vance Smith has a wealth of knowledge about the Bible and is very approachable. Take it!

If people are interested in fulfilling a LA distribution requirement, this is a good course to take because it focuses on one book comprised of many other books inside.  It is also a good course for people who want a deeper understanding of the Hebrew and Christian teachings.
If you're good at essays and moderately interested I say go for it
It's not an unmissable class but it's certainly fun and not too hard.
Not as good of a course as I expected. Great if you want to learn about the Bible

One of my favorite courses at Princeton - definitely take this class!! If you've read the Bible before, whether Christian or not, this class will give you a different and interesting perspective on it - and it'll equip you to read it better on your own! And if you have never read it, this is the course to get yourself started!

Take it! This course is engaging, challenging in the best ways, and generally fun. 
Professor Smith is absolutely excellent, and I'd recommend seeking him out to chat outside of class as well. I also had the privilege of sitting in on one of Professor Schor's classes while I was Previewing, and that lecture was fascinating too! You can't go wrong with either.
Take it!!! You won't regret it. I wasn't too familiar with the bible and it was accessible to me!

Take this class and get Carl Adair as your preceptor if he does it again. Lectures were boring and honestly not that important to do well in the class, D Vance has a tendency to talk about stuff that isn't necessarily relevant to what the papers will be on, but precepts were incredible, and the class was easy as long as you participate and pay attention in precept. If you have a decent knowledge of the Bible already the readings aren't even that important. Strongly Recommend

Take this course even if you don't think you're that interested in Judaism or Christianity. Approach it as a literary analysis of a sacred text and you will be amazed how rich and dramatic the Bible appears under this new light.

The class is very interesting and the workload is very low. Lectures are pretty abstract, but precept is very interesting. Definitely go to precept and try to skim the reading to get the most out of the discussion.
The lectures by Professor Smith are really awesome. I typically enjoy lectures, but I think his are especially insightful, well organized, and clearly he knows what he's talking about.
it's an easy LA, especially if you want to PDF it. if you have knowledge of bible its not too bad
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately two Biblical books per week; assigned secondary reading; two written essays.
descrip: This course will study what it means to read the Bible in a literary way: what literary devices does it contain, and how has it influenced the way we read literature today? What new patterns and meanings emerge? This course will examine the structures and modes of the Biblical books; the formation of the canon and the history of the apocryphal or deuterocanonical books; questions authorship; its literary genres; histories of exegesis, interpretation, and commentary; the redaction, division, and ordering of biblical texts; the cultural, political, and intellectual worlds within which these texts were written.
title: The Bible as Literature

evals: Definitely take it.
Do it. You won't regret it.
I don't know if this will ever be offered again, but it was amazing. Richard Just is the best, you will learn so much, and it's an unforgettable experience.
If you are interested in long form journalism in the US, this course is very helpful.
If you have any interest whatsoever in journalism, this course is 100% worth taking.
It's a bummer that Richard won't be back teaching this class, because he was by far the best.
TAKE THIS COURSE. If you ever are so lucky to take a course with Richard Just--do it! He is such an amazing teacher and excellent human being and kind person.
Will be more useful if you intend to be a journalist, but an interesting course nonetheless.
otherinfo: Rebecca Mead is a staff writer at The New Yorker. She has profiled many subjects and written more than a hundred Talk of the Town stories. The author of My Life in Middlemarch and One Perfect Day: The Selling of the American Wedding, she previously worked as a journalist for New York magazine and The Sunday Times of London.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of reading, reporting, and writing. Short- to medium-length writing assignments (500 to 800 words) due every one to two weeks. One long-form final project due at end of term. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required.
descrip: This seminar will focus on the profile, the multi-thousand-word portrait of an individual, which remains a mainstay of magazine journalism. In this course students will develop their skills as practitioners and critics of the form by reading and writing some of the best--and, occasionally, some of the worst--examples. We will read, analyze, and write long-form profiles, consider the advantages and drawbacks of access, and look at writing about the famous and the unknown. Interview techniques, research methods, structure, and language will be explored with the goal of understanding what separates an ordinary profile from an enduring portrait.
title: The McGraw Seminar in Writing - The Art of the Profile

evals: 0 This is a spectacular course. The instruction is incredible and the material is interesting. You will be exposed to new ideas and styles and you will be better for it.

For those interested in long-form journalism, this is an excellent course to take. Students often become fully invested in the course because they are asked to report on what they care about. Reporting sometimes takes longer than expected, but that is the nature of journalism.

Great class. Schmidle was a little disorganized since he also had a job and family along with this class and hadn't taught before, but he was great nonetheless. time consuming, but worth it--you'll want to spend time on this class.

Great course. The speakers, the writers, the writing that you do. This is what I wish writing sem was, since it's so much more understandable and relatable than the academic pedagogical stuff taught in writing sem.
TAKE THIS COURSE. It is so awesome.
Take it
Take the course, but just know that there will be a lot of work involved!

This class with Nick Schmidle was incredible -- we met David Remnick, Mark Bowden and so many other great writers and journalists. If you're interested in understanding why investigative journalism matters -- especially now -- I recommend this class.
This course was amazing. Balanced workload, diverse discussion, and fascinating readings.

This is one of my favorite courses I have taken at Princeton. Whether you're considering a career in journalism or you just want to take the class for kicks, this class will make you a more critical consumer of media and a much much more incisive writer. Nick is approachable and truly has students' best interest in mind, plus we got to experience a star-studded panel of guest speakers (some of the best journalists of our time) and take a field trip to the New Yorker offices to meet David Remnick. Be aware that this course does require a significant amount of work and time, and the writing assignments can be daunting, but it's 100% worth it. I can't recommend this course highly enough!
otherinfo: Joe Stephens, Ferris Professor of Journalism in Residence, is a veteran investigative reporter for The Washington Post who has reported and conducted journalism training in the U.S., Asia, Africa, Europe, and Latin America. He has won many journalism honors, including three George Polk Memorial Awards. He also is a three-time finalist for the Pulitzer Prize.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of reading, reporting, and writing. Short assignments due every week. One long-form final project due at end of term. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required. Course may include a trip to The Washington Post or another major news organization.
descrip: In this seminar students will learn the sophisticated reporting, research, and writing techniques that investigative reporters use to root out corruption in public and private institutions. While learning to produce compelling news pieces, students will discover how these tools can be used to advantage in other fields and in everyday life. In addition to exploring new models of journalism (crowd sourcing, social networking, etc.), we will meet with some of the nation's most successful investigative journalists.
title: Investigative Journalism - Accountability Reporting

evals: Absolutely take this course! We went on a field trip, met with incredible people, and learned a lot about media coverage of a tricky election year.
Definitely take a class with Professor McCleery - I loved it!
Definitely take this course! It is one of the most relevant classes you could take at Princeton.
I would highly recommend this course!! Incredibly interesting material and it makes you really consider choosing journalism for a career. Absolute must-take!
If you get the chance to take a class of this nature, that follows some crazy ongoing in society, take advantage of the opportunity!
Professor McCleery is engaging, supremely intelligent, well-read, and full of experience. I would highly recommend this course

Take this course if it is ever available again!  It is undoubtedly the best course I have ever taken at Princeton!  Also, any course that Professor McCleery teaches is a must!  It may not be as relevant to academic work but focuses more on real life which I think should be priority since we are going to college to get job in the first place!  This class gets an A
Take this course.
Would highly recommend, very interesting and current.
otherinfo: Bob Davis is a senior editor who covers economic issues out of The Wall Street Journal's Washington bureau. He is a 34-year veteran of the WSJ, having previously reported from Beijing and served as bureau chief in Latin America and Brussels. In 1999 Davis was part of the team of WSJ reporters that won a Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for coverage of the Asian and Russian financial crises.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of reading, reporting, and writing. Short- to medium-length writing assignments (500 to 700 words) due every one to two weeks. One long-form final project (2,000 words) due at end of term. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required.
descrip: This seminar will focus on writing about the intersection between Washington and economics. Storytelling--the heart of journalism--will be stressed. Starting with the basics of covering economics, the course will branch out to include political subjects as diverse as income inequality, the new presidential administration, China, and immigration. We will identify local controversies that illuminate national issues. Students will learn how to find and report precise, compelling stories about domestic and international political economics by using curiosity, lively writing, and successive edits. The goal is to produce a long-form final project.
title: Politics and the Media - Writing about Washington and the Economy

evals: A must-take! Princeton's journalism classes are amazing - we got to visit the Times headquarters, had a ton of superstar guest speakers, and had really awesome writing assignments.
Amazing class- great opportunity to learn from NYT writer with loads of experience. SO many incredible guest lecturers and a sick trip at the end. 100% recommend

Definitely take it if Tara is teaching. But you can't go wrong with any journalism professor. I found my passion through this class. Come in with an open mind and a hunger eagerness to learn! Be ready to write differently than writing sem though.

If Tara is teaching, definitely take it! She's incredibly articulate, brought in fun speakers, and kept things very interesting. We got to meet incredible reporters working in areas from health to politics to international relations. We toured the New York Times, and I learned so much about writing. Cannot emphasize enough that this is a great course if Tara is teaching. Take it.

If you love writing and are interested in science, take this class. You get what you put into the class. The guest speakers are amazing and inspirational. Working closely with Tara is a great experience as well. You'll get interview some amazing people for your final project.
It's a must take. I loved it. Makes you a much better writer. Fantastic speakers. Tara really cares and spends hours workshopping with you 1:1.
Take it if journalism really interests you!
Take this class if interested in scientific journalism.

This course changed the way I thought about journalism. You get to meet absolutely incredible guest speakers, and Tara herself is so nice and helpful and brilliant. One of my favorite courses at Princeton.

Though this course and the professor aren't usually set in stone in the Registrar, I would highly recommend taking this. It takes more outside-of-class time than you think, but what you learn about sci journalism is well-worth it.
otherinfo: Tanzina Vega is CNNMoney's national reporter for race and inequality in America. Prior to working at CNN Vega was a staff reporter for The New York Times, where she created and covered a beat on race and ethnicity for the national desk and reported for the business desk and metro section. Also a skilled multimedia producer, Vega has won various awards for her multimedia work, including an Emmy.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of reading, reporting, writing, and watching news. Short- to medium-length writing assignments (500 to 1,000 words) due every one to two weeks. One long-form final project due at end of term. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required.
descrip: This seminar will focus on how the evolution of media and technology has shaped the way America looks at race and enabled the creation of social movements, like #BlackLivesMatter and the alt-right, that in turn shape national policy agendas. The course will explore how the democratization of media allows people to lead the conversation, and how legacy media have changed their tactics to engage directly with audiences in the age of Twitter. Students will learn about non-traditional forms of reporting as they cover issues including diversity, racial demographics, bias, cultural appropriation, and race in the 2016 presidential election.
title: The Media and Social Issues - Reporting on Race in America Today

evals: A great way to practice your public performance skills and very fulfilling! Jane and Monica are fabulous instructors and show a genuine interest in helping you and improving your performance experience.  Also, a great class if you are balancing a heavy workload and want something less paper-assignment heavy.
Definitely take this class if you're interested in art making, theater, people, the way we see the world, psychology, urbanism, presentation, or sociology.
I wish this course was happening again, unfortunately for those who weren't able to take it, it's not.
If this course is ever offered again/anything with Jane and/or Monica, TAKE IT!
Take it. It's so much fun and you'll learn a lot by experimenting and creating and get to be part of an experience.
They won't be able to take it.
This class was okay. I would not highly recommend, but I would not discourage you from taking it either. The workload is pretty low, but sometimes, the teachers change things last minute

This course will never be offered again, I'm sure, so I'm sorry to you, prospective class-taker, but Ateliers are great and Jane Cox and Monica Bill Barnes are amazing and kind and inspired, so there's that for the record.
otherinfo: Please e-mail Michael Counts at michaelcounts@mac.com and Jayce Ogren at jayceogren@me.com if you're interested in enrolling in this course. Note that we'll be taking a class field trip to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in October to see Michael Counts' collaboration with Bang on a Can, celebrating their 30th anniversary. Grading: 80% Other = final public performance.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 80%
assgts: Listening assignments include Mozart's Symphony #40 in G minor, excerpts from his operas Don Giovanni and Le Nozze di Figaro, and applicable examples from the pop and contemporary classical genres. We'll watch video of theatrical productions such as Robert Wilson's Deafman Glance, and read excerpts from books such as Anton Ehrenzweig's The Hidden Order of Art, Nikolaus Harnoncourt's The Musical Dialogue and Richard Kostelanetz's Conversing with Cage.
prereqs: We welcome students from a broad range of backgrounds, interests and talents. An open mind, willingness to collaborate, and love for the creative process are the most desirable traits of students interested in this course. Though expertise in a particular field is unnecessary, we're especially interested in individuals with experience in visual art, lighting, scenic and installation design, theater, dance, music composition and music performance. Additional rehearsal time outside of class will be necessary in the week before the final performance..
descrip: Theatrical designer/stage director Michael Counts and conductor/composer Jayce Ogren will explore the innermost workings of Mozart's Symphony #40. Class sessions will focus on creating an immersive experience inspired by the structure and content of Mozart's masterpiece, utilizing visual art, lighting, scenic and installation design as well as movement and musical performance. The class will culminate with a public performance/showing of the work.
title: Princeton Atelier - Reimagining a Masterpiece: Mozart's Symphony #40

evals: Ateliers are one of the best things you can do for yourself here. Find one with a topic that interests you - or even more importantly, instructors you admire, enroll, then quickly let go of any expectations you have for the class. Things always change, and the class is more rewarding if you roll along with it rather than complain that it isn't what you thought you were signing up for.
Great teachers from a professional background any student of theatre would love to learn from.
If Fiasco comes to teach again, take it! Make sure you do the assignments and you'll have a fun, stimulating time.

If you're interested in very close analysis of theatrical text, as well as getting practical tools for making theatre, this would be a good class for you. Fiasco is so interesting, and I definitely got a lot out of the class, even as a non-actor.
It won't be back in this form, but I ALWAYS recommend taking Atelier courses. They're some of the best courses offered at Princeton for working with professionals at the top of their game.
NA
Noah and Ben are really lovely, and the coursework was quite light. Just show up to class; you will get the most out of the course that way.
Take this course to meet these people, but there isn't a lot of music-creation involved, if that's what you think it'll be by the course description.
otherinfo: Course instructors are composer/lyricist Peter Mills '95 and director / writer Cara Reichel '96, founding artists from NYC's critically-acclaimed Prospect Theater Company, a non-profit organization dedicated to the development and production of new musical theater. Together, Mills and Reichel have created a dozen new musical theater works, many inspired by research into historic events, and have premiered their work both Off-Broadway and internationally.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 80%
assgts: Students will engage with primary source materials from the research of the Princeton and Slavery Project as the basis for the original theatrical pieces they create. Secondary reading assignments will concern racial representation, theater, and the craft of musical theater writing. Additional shorter writing exercises to build craft may be assigned. The major writing assignment will be students' final creative project, a collaborative 10-15 minute original music theater work.
prereqs: There are no formal prerequisites for the course. This course is open enrollment. We are seeking a diverse group of students who bring a variety of skills and perspectives to the table: playwrights, composers, lyricists, musicians, singers, actors, designers, dramaturgs. Course participants will be assigned collaborative teams with the necessary skill sets to create a musical theater piece. 80% Other: Final project.
descrip: This course will take the form of an inter-disciplinary, creative investigation of a rarely-discussed chapter of Princeton's past: the university's history as it relates to the institution of slavery in America. Composer/lyricist Peter Mills '95 and director Cara Reichel '96 (founding members of NYC's critically-acclaimed Prospect Theater Company) will guide students in a collaboration to create and present original, short music theater pieces based on the research of the Princeton and Slavery Project.
title: Princeton Atelier - Who Owns A Song?: A Theatrical Investigation of Princeton and Slavery

evals: Amazing course with Professors Dossena and Teardo. They're really enthusiastic and kind and supportive, the work is super manageable, and they make it really fun and un-stressful to come to class. You're held accountable for your work throughout the term and move at a really reasonable pace while still learning a lot as an intro course. Would 100% recommend to take for a language requirement or extra course just for fun.
Daily commitment required
Definitely take it if you want to learn Italian.
Do the assignments on myItalianLab because they are are very good practice.
Do the online assignments daily, as you can resubmit them until you get a perfect score. They really help with highlighting the in class material.
Excellent!
Go in for office hours if you are unclear about anything. Anna is very helpful.
Good class, challenging if you don't have experience with a romance language
Great teachers. Very helpful and willing to meet. Stay up to date on my italian lab and do the homework each night. Will benefit you in the long run
I would advise not to take this course in conjunction with another romance language immediately beforehand! The similarities between the two languages may get confusing.
I would highly recommend taking this course. It made the process of learning Italian exciting.
I would recommend all students to take this course. Overall, I throughly enjoyed the course and was able to make strong relationships with both my professors and the other students in the class.
If you're planning to start a new language, Italian is a great language. Not only is the language fairly easy to learn from scratch, but the professors are absolutely amazing.
Its definitely worth it

Just a disclaimer, I already speak Spanish and French (two languages related to Italian) so that influences my feedback. This has to be the easiest course I have taken so far in my Princeton career. The pace is really casual, the assignments are easy and most homework takes 5 minutes on average, and the tests are not unreasonable. You will learn a lot in this class in a short period of time, but there really is not much pressure or stress from it. The only thing that I really don't like is that we meet 5 times a week and it doesn't even feel like the extra time helps. I also wish we took the final before Christmas break like some other language classes. But overall, this was a really fun, light, and engaging class. Professor Teardo really knows her stuff and really wants to see you succeed.
Make sure not to fall behind on My Italian lab, otherwise you get bombarded before tests. Go to class and enjoy the language!
Practice on most - if not every - night and do the practice/online exercises and this course should be enjoyable.
Sara Teardo is the best and ITA 101 is very fun and not very stressful. Highly recommend as a language requirement or for fun.
Study the vocabulary and try and get Professor Dossena.
TEARDO IS AMAZING!!! She actually cares about her students' success and will take the time to meet you outside of class and answer any questions. Definitely take it!!!
Take Italian!!! Get Anna Cellinese if you can!!
Take it! Amazing department!
Take it. The teachers are awesome. Great interactive not too hard class
The Italian Department is amazing!
The faculty in the Italian department is so kind, and the language is beautiful. Take this class! And take Professor Teardo!!! You will not be disappointed!!
This course is an excellent introduction to the Italian language and culture. It teaches a great deal of useful information over the span of a short semester.

This is a great class! Very engaging, a lot of fun, and very reasonable to do well. You learn so much in such a short time. Professor Teardo is AMAZING! So nice and energetic. Try to get her if you can!
Very good course overall. Highly recommended.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Weekly assignments include: one grammar chapter from book, oral drills, written exercises, compositions; and one-hour test every other week.
prereqs: No credit given for ITA 101 unless followed by ITA 102..
descrip: To develop the skills of speaking, understanding, reading and writing Italian. The main emphasis is on oral drill and conversation in the classroom. Aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.
title: Beginner's Italian I

evals: Definitely take this class because it is very fun and entertaining without a lot of pressure academically. The language is beautiful.
Do the homework, review often. Not a difficult class if you just do the work.

Get Daniele if you can, he's wonderful and will make class a bunch of fun. The grammar exercises are a bit of a pain, but if you can knock them out during little weird snippets of time like at lunch or in between your last class and practice then it's not so bad. Quizzes were fair but have much more writing out complete thoughts than 'choose the write word to put in this sentence' style. Make the papers seem fun to write and you'll enjoy it a lot more. Hopefully they'll have better prompts for the group oral projects next year, but be warned that those were during Reading Period this year, so if that's the same they'll make you work over break.
Otherwise, do try to speak Italian for as much of class as possible, and have a blast with Daniele!
Great for fulfilling language requirement. Not too overwhelming but definitely helps improve your skills in the language. It's a fun class but it's also very enriching! Professors are great.
I highly recommend all classes with Daniele De Feo and with the Italian department.
If anything is every unclear, never hesitate to ask for extra help; the professor is more than willing to meet with you and he helps so much.
If you want to learn a language in an engaging and rigorous way, this course is perfect. If you can place into it, it's definitely worth doing.
Just stay on top of the work. If you fall behind it's difficult to catch up
Take an ITA course with Daniele! You will not regret it.
Take this class, try and get Professor De Feo. He is the best language teacher here.
Take this course! you learn a lot about culture and improve language a lot. I looked forward to this class each day.
The best course I've taken at Princeton. The course is very organized, and Daniele is THE BEST: kind, encouraging, and fun. The class isn't intimidating at all.

The oral presentations should be before Winter break-- it makes it so much harder on the students when it is after going home for three weeks. The course is great and the teachers are even better, but they just try to plan way too much in the last few weeks.
This course is not very hard, and pretty fun!

This course is very helpful if you want to review grammar and improve your speaking skills. But if you also enjoy reading and want to improve your writing skills, this course might not be the perfect fit.

This is a great course which covers all of the useful grammatical tenses throughout the semester. Great for grammar practice, but reading practice is best done on your own, while conversation practice is best done at the Italian Conversation Tables.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Grammar exercises, brief compositions, and quizzes.
prereqs: ITA 102 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is designed to help the student who already has some background in Italian to develop greater facility in speaking and writing Italian on an advanced level. Principally oral approach. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.
title: Advanced Italian

otherinfo: Precept meets for 2 hours.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: About 50-80 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200- level Italian course or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will explore the ways in which national identity was imagined and implemented within Italian literature, culture, and cinema before, during, and after the period of Italian unification in the mid-XIX century. Examples are drawn from a wide range of literary, artistic and cultural media.
title: Topics in 19th-Century Italian Literature - Risorgimento, Opera, Film

evals: A little bit heavy load class. May expect to spend more time than usual classes.
Get a head start on hiragana and katakana before starting the course.
Go to office hours if you have questions or just want to practice!
Go to office hours regularly whenever you're available, even if you don't think you need it. Watch out because the course is very fast paced, so stay on track.
I would but I would help them understand how much work this class is compared to other language classes.
If you are interested in learning Japanese, this is a good start.
If you are interested in learning Japanese, you should definitely take this course.

If you wanted to learn a new language in a rigorous but extremely fun environment take this course! Although this is Japanese 101, the students in the class come from so many different backgrounds and levels of proficiency, and it's just a great time all around.

If you're even remotely interested in studying Japanese, please take this course!! All of the professors are awesome and really helpful! It should be noted that it can be time-consuming and difficult at times. I would suggest studying a bit every day; that's what I did, and it helped so much in the long-run. Put in the work, and you'll see the results!

Japanese can be a little intimidating, but it is so rewarding. The professors are all so engaging and fun. Though I don't look forward to going to class everyday, I'm always really happy by the end of it. I really enjoyed learning the language even though the work load is kinda intense. You barely learn any kanji at this point, but getting the sentence structures and hiragana/katakana down is going to be difficult enough in one semester.
Know that Japanese will be one of your hardest classes, and you will dedicated much time and energy to learning this language. You must be dedicated and motivated.
Of course.
Take it! I joined the Japanese language classes as a sophomore and it was very welcoming.

This class is a lot of work, but if you are interested in learning Japanese it is great. The teachers are very helpful and the course is a lot of fun as long as you are willing to put in work and go to class everyday.

This course takes a lot of time. I probably spent 10 hours a week on it on average (5 hours of class, 5 hours of homework). Fortunately the amount of homework is pretty consistent in both difficulty and quantity, so unlike in other classes you won't randomly get shrekt by random bursts of work.
Sato sensee is honestly an amazing teacher. He is clear and concise and uses great examples to illustrate his points. Shibata sensee and Tokumasu sensee also reinforce his lessons very well. 
If you put in the work - and you pretty much have to since there's class and homework pretty much every day - you will definitely learn a lot. Keep in mind that you are expected to participate heavily in class. I'm a pretty introverted guy so normally I don't like doing this, but the teachers of this class do a great job keeping the environment friendly and nonjudgmental, so I felt pretty comfortable.

Try to review the textbook/do the homework in advance so you can ask the instructor for questions before turning it in!
The more you put in the more you get out! 
Write on your blog often--it helps to strengthen your writing, grammar, and vocabulary skills!!
Take take take this class! One of the best language learning environments and classes I've been (and I've been going to language program classes for Chinese since I was 5).
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 20%, Design Project - 20%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: The course covers chapters 1 thru 8 of the textbook "Nakama". Each chapter includes about 40 pgs. of reading, 15 pgs. of listening assignments, 15 pgs. of grammar homework, 10 pgs. of kanji homework.
prereqs: No credit is given for JPN 101 unless it is followed by JPN 102..
descrip: An intensive introduction to modern Japanese stressing oral-aural facility, but including an introduction to written Japanese.
title: Elementary Japanese I

evals: Focus on the vocab, and also go in for office hours whenever you can
Learn passive and causative form.
Take it! Japanese is a fun language to learn, even if you're not very good at it, and both of the professors are great.
Take it!! It's amazing! It's PERFECT!
good class!
otherinfo: Offered every year in the Fall term.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Other Exam - 15%, Quizzes - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Preparation for lessons to be covered in class, and homework.
descrip: This course aims to give a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese (Tokyo speech) by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points and more advanced vocabulary and grammar. Students will reinforce four major skills by speaking - listening drills, readings, and written exercises.
title: Intermediate Japanese I

evals: If you are serious in continuing your Japanese-language education, then by all means take this class. It will take a lot of memorization and effort on your part to do well however.
Really awesome course, awesome professors, too. Takes a lot of your time though, so keep that in mind.
Take it if you need it

The class and instructors are very chill, but the way that the material is taught becomes a little redundant. (We tend to go over the readings that we did for homework during class.) That being said, it is a fun class and I'd recommend taking it if your schedule allows.
otherinfo: Class will be conducted entirely in Japanese. This course is offered every Fall. Requirements & Grading: Other includes homework (10%) and a semester project (15%).
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Other Exam - 15%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Short composition based on readings and video materials. Approximately 15 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: JPN 107. Students should have completed Intermediate (second-year) Japanese or equivalent as a prerequisite to admission in JPN 301..
descrip: This course is designed to further students' reading ability. Students will have ample opportunity to hear and use increasingly more sophisticated vocabulary and grammatical constructions through discussion and composition. Japanese video will also be incorporated into the course. Reading materials include "Tobira" and selected readings from works in the original language.
title: Advanced Japanese I

evals: Do it!!!
Great class if you want to brush up on japanese or continue studying it- great way to think about Japan and its culture in the context of other cultures and ethnicities.
If you're at a sufficient level of Japanese to take this course, you definitely should! The work load is very fair, and the senseis really want everyone to do well!
Take this course!! Sometimes time-consuming, but Shibata sensei is the bee's knees.
grading: Design Project - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 10%, Papers - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 5-10 pages of reading and 2 page of composition per week.
prereqs: JPN302 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, listening and speaking. Reading materials include novels, essays, etc. Video materials are also used to enhance listening skills. The goal of this course is "advanced" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.
title: Integrative Advanced Japanese I

evals: Be aware that there are a lot of components to this class. JPN 401 is very structured, and there is a deceiving amount of work you need to do to stay on top of everything.
Take it if you have a solid reason to do so (e.g. major, strong desire for fluency, etc).  Don't take it out of casual interest--the workload is too much for this to be that kind of class.
Very solid course.
otherinfo: Sample Reading List: selected reading and videos.
grading: Design Project - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: 5-10 pages of reading and 1 page of compostition per week. 1 hour of watching drama/movie per week.
prereqs: JPN 306 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is targeted to students whose Japanese proficiency is at an advanced or superior level. In this class students will (1) discuss various issues in international relations focusing on Asian nations, using dramas, short novels and editorials, and (2) learn Japanese business manners and speak and write business Japanese. Through these activities, students will develop critical thinking skills as well as Japanese language skills.
title: Readings in Modern Japanese I

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
assgts: There will be selected readings weekly.
prereqs: Two years of modern Japanese..
descrip: Introduction to the fundamentals of classical Japanese grammar. This course trains students to read premodern Japanese historical and literary texts. Texts: Makura no Soshi, Taketori Monogatari, Ujishui Monogatari, Hyakunin Isshu, etc.
title: Introduction to Classical Japanese

evals: Definitely take this course.
Do the chapter readings. Don't get behind on vocabulary, because everything snowballs. Take the course.

I definitely recommend 101 with Kaster. Be prepared to put in more work than you might think for a language course?? usually about 1.5-2 hrs per day just to complete the assignments without studying. There is a short quiz every Monday which is usually straightforward if you've been studying what you're supposed to. Latin is a difficult language, and don't think that knowing a Romance language coming in is going to be a huge advantage. The verb tenses of Latin are much more complex than that of Spanish or French, and godspeed when you learn your declensions.

I took this class on a whim after a full year of Spanish and HUM. If you have any interest in understanding the fundamentals of any Romance language more intensively or just want to try something new, this class demands a good deal of time (often a couple hours a day) but is very much worth the effort. I could not be more impressed with the consistency and thoroughness of Kaster's instruction. Take it!
If you are at all interested in Latin, this course was fun, interesting, and challenging. Professor Kaster is very good at what he does
Make sure they keep up with the readings and learning things on their own when they need to
Memorise declensions and conjugations. Study the vocab. Do your homework. Pay close attention to in-class discussions.
TAKE LATIN!!!! Don't listen to people who say it's not worth it, because it's a dead language. It's intellectually stimulating and the faculty genuinely wants you to appreciate the language.
The pace of the course is quicker than that of a high school language course, so it's easy to fall behind on vocab and word forms unless you put a good deal of effort into keeping up.
Unfortunately, this is Kaster's last time teaching 101, so you'll have to take it from someone less good. Latin's a great language and not too hard to learn.
Would definitely recommend to other students.
decent
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Daily study and written exercises.
prereqs: No credit is given for LAT 101 unless it is followed by LAT 102..
descrip: An introduction to the basic grammar, syntax, and vocabulary of Latin designed to enable students to read and understand simple Latin prose and verse.
title: Beginner's Latin

evals: A great course, translation based so class basically consists of translating lines at home and them coming to class to go over the homework. Very straight forward, which is exactly the kind of class I like.

A very good class to take if you have the fundamental knowledge of Latin grammar and have some experience reading Latin texts, as this will advance your ability for grammatical analysis as well as translation.
Be sure to prepare for class daily. Overall, it is really enjoyable class.
I really liked Catullus; the poems were neat.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in continuing studying Latin. There is a sizable focus on grammar in this course, so a strong grammar background would be helpful; however, it is definitely not impossible to do well without a strong background. I had a great instructor who helped us tackle a lot of grammar; I highly recommend Brahm Kleinman! This course is a manageable amount of work and definitely not overwhelming. For the translations, I would recommend printing them out and annotating them as you go through the translation in class.
If you need this for a Latin language requirement, while the material doesn't disqualify the course, be prepared for some boring reading.
It's a well-taught course, and you'll get out of it what you put into it. It's fairly easy to coast to a B, and it won't be the most enrapturing class you'll take, but it's fine.
My reading ability improved and it was nice to be able to read actual writing and not just contrived examples.

Pay attention to the grammar notes you are given in class. Make them legible and easy to look back at. Shortcuts aren't worth it; save yourself the effort during exam time, and carefully learn the first time.
Review every night and dont wait until the last minute to study. If you really don't understand something, office hours are really valuable.
Take it with a grad student. They'll probably be more helpful with actually learning the language as opposed to approaching the class from a classicist's perspective.

Take this course! Do the homework, and put in a little extra time before the quizzes and you will be fine. Also attend office hours as much as you can, it makes the coursework seem a lot more manageable.
Take this course.  The readings are interesting and the Latin is fairly straightforward provided you have a good grasp on your mechanics from the first two semesters of latin.
This course is fantastic. Not too difficult, but allows for a lot of growth. Brahm was one of the best Latin instructors I've ever had, so if it's ever possible to take a class with him, do so!

This course is not graded harshly, but it does require that you keep up with homework day to day and come to class willing to translate. If you consistently put in effort, you should be fine, and the class will be more pleasant. Daniela sometimes seems to demand too much grammatical knowledge, but she is kind and understanding when writing and grading exams.
This is a good course for continuing Latin studies.
You will engage in-depth with the text, focusing on the grammar and vocabulary as well as the historical context of the text.
don't be that person that hasn't done the translation and then asks other people to repeat theirs 3 times.
good course
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Students are expected to read approximately 3 pages of Latin per week.
prereqs: LAT 102 or departmental permission based on Latin Placement..
