descrip: This course aims at increasing facility in reading Latin prose and poetry and introduces students to the literary culture of Republican Rome. We shall read selections from two important authors of the late Roman Republic, Caesar and Catullus.
title: Intermediate Latin: Catullus and His Age

evals: Be prepared to work in this class by translating latin almost everyday before class. Granted the content is interesting and the professor is really great, it is a lot of work, and it can be really intimidating to participate in class.
I suggest that you read ahead of the syllabus and study in groups.
It's a nice, chill Latin class where you read texts you might not otherwise. Recommend.
LAT 210 offers a very good translation based class for anyone looking to practice and further develop their translation skills.
Super manageable workload and Kaster is great.  Highly recommend for anyone interested in Latin.
Take this class if you're interested in the subject or language, otherwise it'll be easy to fall behind and disengage from course content.
The readings are awesome, but there is no guidance on grammar/structure, you need to prepare and analyze the translations on your own before coming into class.
There is a lot of Latin to read, and the readings do get harder throughout the semester. However, if you are comfortable in your skills to read Latin, you should take this course.

This class is a lot of fun. You'll read a lot of irreverent, sexual, and funny texts. Kaster is a great Latin professor. For the quizzes, if you've done the homework you'll be absolutely fine. One thing you should know is that you're expected to participate in class.
This course has a fair amount of reading, but it's quite interesting and Professor Kaster is great.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Assignments will range from 3 to 5 pages a week, depending on author and difficulty.
prereqs: LAT 108 or equivalent.
descrip: This course aims to build skills in reading literary Latin in a variety of genres, both poetry and prose, while introducing students to an important social function shared by many kinds of texts: Winning status and prestige by slandering a rival. The kind of insult that wins over an audience tells us much about Roman values in various realms of public and personal behavior.
title: Invective, Slander, and Insult in Latin Literature

evals: Great course! Professor Baraz is fantastic. Plus, we had a trip to Rome, which was incredible (though you lose spring break for doing work for other classes). It does expect a lot of you, so don't just take it for a free Rome trip if you barely know latin.
I would suggest to keep up with your readings. Additionally, not only do you need to translate, but also scan poetry lines.
If you like Latin, I would take this course. The professors are amazing, the conversation was amazing, and the text is amazing. Also, you get to go to Rome!

PLEASE DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Prof. Baraz is amazing and although you'll have to put a lot of work in (doing Latin readings, English readings, and research), you'll get a lot out of it!
Professor Baraz is such a delight both inside and outside of the classroom.  She demands excellence from her students, so be ready to do the work, but it will be worth it!
Students should take this class but be prepared for long readings. Baraz is a wonderful spirit and has a great way of leading discussions.
TAKE THIS COURSE. You will learn a ton about the Aeneid and about material culture. Baraz is wonderful. And, let's be real here, you get to go to Rome. Take the course.
Take any class with Professor Baraz
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Reading: 200 to 300 lines of Latin per week.
prereqs: LAT 203 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will develop an understanding of Virgil's poetic and stylistic techniques (metre, allusion, structure, word order), together with an understanding of Roman history and identity at the end of the Republic.
title: Vergil's Aeneid

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 15%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately 15 pages of Latin per week.
prereqs: LAT 200-level course or permission of instructor..
descrip: From accounts of the emperor Claudius as mortal (Suetonius' biography, Tacitus Annales XI), we will progress to satire of Claudius as divinity (Seneca, Apocolocyntosis). Emphasis will be on gaining familiarity with the prose styles of imperial historiography and with the genre-bending medley of Menippean satire.
title: Roman Historians of the Empire

evals: Be creative with the essays! Only two pages long and you can write about pretty much anything, so if there's a book/play/text you love that you read in another class or your free time, go for it!

Go into this class with a good attitude and you'll enjoy it!  It's a great way to get experience in the field and read outside of your comfort zone.  Your professor/grad student are also great resources for independent research advice!
Prepare to eat many breakfast pastries.
Professor Reeves gives fantastic comments. A fun way to get to know the department.

Take your time writing the papers even though they are short, and read ahead of time to make sure you are prepared to speak and write about the texts. Take notes as you go along, because that will really help for the final exam.
The best thing is to do the readings as they come and actually pay attention during class discussions -- that way, the final will not be very stressful to prepare for.

The material was often somewhat jargony humanities speak, but you're going to have to endure your share of that if you're in COM--and maybe you enjoy that sort of thing. The papers are helpful for honing your writing skills, and the novels weren't bad.
You have to take it if you're in COM.
otherinfo: This seminar will also address general questions about independent work and the senior comprehensive examinations in Comparative Literature.
grading: Final Exam - 33%, Papers - 33%, Class/Precept Participation - 34%
assgts: Approximately 150 pages reading per week.
descrip: The Junior Seminar will investigate the literal and figurative meanings of the phrase "the place of literature." How relevant is geography to literature? How do we distinguish between imagination, invention, and falsehood when considering a literary setting? How well, far, and fast do texts travel? How do contemporary texts convey the particulars of transient populations and non-native speakers? What does an individual text disclose about its origins and potential destinations? What does it mean to map a text? We will discuss these and related questions in the context of both literary and theoretical works.
title: Junior Seminar: Introduction to Comparative Literature

otherinfo: Other authors who may be read include Albert the Great, Anselm of Canterbury, Austin, Benveniste, Béroul, Chrétien de Troyes, and Peter Lombard.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Attendance, preparation, and active participation in seminars. Short writing assignments, midterm paper, and final paper. Writing assignments will consist of literary analyses of short passages. The midterm paper will be a close reading of a literary text. The final paper will take the form of a close reading of two or three related works.
descrip: An introduction to medieval literature and the question of performative language in literature, linguistics, philosophy and theology. Works to be read include romance and lyric poetry from the French, German and English traditions, as well as selections from Scholastic philosophy, grammar and theology. We will also study some twentieth-century philosophical and linguistic accounts of speech acts. Topics to be discussed include lies, promises, oaths, baptisms, ritual speech and the structure of sacraments. All texts will be read in translation, though study of the originals will be encouraged whenever possible.
title: The Literature of Medieval Europe

otherinfo: Mandatory day trip(s) to local museum(s). Other 20% = Museum Project Guangchen CHEN is a new Fellow in the Society of Fellows and Lecturer in Comp Lit. Dr. Chen's training, interests and research are interdisciplinary, in literature and music, as well as intellectual history. He holds an undergraduate degree in English from the Beijing Language Univ., an A.M. in Comparative and World Lit from Peking Univ, and a Ph.D. in Comp Lit from Harvard Univ.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading assignments 100-120 pages per week. One class presentation (15 minutes). One research project analyzing a collection at the Princeton Art Museum or a university library of your choice. One midterm paper (4-6 pages), and one final paper (6-8 pages).
descrip: Why do people collect objects? What desires motivate this obsession across cultures? How does a collection reflect and shape our relationship with objects? It is no accident that many writers are fascinated by the collector: Balzac, Eco, James, Pamuk and Proust all devoted significant creative energy to this figure. In this course, we will consider collecting as a serious mode of thinking. Analysis of key literary works will be combined with hands-on study of museum collections in Princeton and beyond. You will develop your own approach to the humanities that combines methodologies in archaeology, art, literature, intellectual history.
title: Topics in Comparative Literature - On Collecting: Anatomy of an Obsession

otherinfo: Class is open to advanced undergraduates with the instructor's permission.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
descrip: We take Jacques Derrida's "Of Grammatology" as a historical and theoretical primer for the discipline of Comparative Literature. The class reads "OG" in its entirety along with the works read there by Derrida (Saussure, Lévi-Strauss, Rousseau, Leroi-Gourhan, Hegel). Topics covered include ethnocentrism, Eurocentrism, globality, theories of the sign, writing and speech, translation, comparison, reading, institutions, ethics and politics of education.
title: Introduction to Comparative Literature

otherinfo: Other works that to be studied may include Old Icelandic outlaw sagas, Jean d'Arras'
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This year's seminar explores the varieties of medieval personhood, with particular attention to limit cases: sovereigns, outcasts and outlaws, saints, monsters and hybrid creatures, the civilly and the truly dead, and ghosts. All texts are read in translation, though close study of the originals is encouraged wherever possible.
title: Topics in Medieval Literature - Medieval Personhood

PLease read your textbook and do all the practice tests.
Pay attention in class and read the textbook.  It is not too challenging of a class if you keep up with the material.  Otis Chodosh was an excellent instructor, so get him if you can!

Prep yourself for those quizzes and exams.  I got cocky on the midterm after doing well on the first quiz, and boy that was a mistake.  Exams != book problems or class problems.  Do the practice exams, understand the old exams, and you'll be good.
Read the book and go to office hours.
Read the book, and do problem quizzes/tests
Read the textbook before precepts, it will help you understand so much more in the class.
Read the textbook thoroughly to understand the proofs of concepts, and write down everything that the instructor writes on the board.
Read the textbook. Don't be fooled by the first few chapters, because it definitely gets harder as you go along.
Read through the textbook for the relevant sections before class!! It'll help you keep up with what they're saying during class. AND DON'T FALL BEHIND YOU WILL REGRET IT.

Same level of difficulty as 201, but very different mathematical concepts/way of thinking. It was only much harder for me because linear algebra didn't come to me as easily as multi. Take only if you have to.
Seek out help when you need it!

Start the problem sets early- they're sometimes very long and tedious. There's not much time for examples during class, but there are weekly review sessions that might be helpful for some people. Otherwise, the class isn't too bad, and though the content is quite different from multi, if you study the theory you'll be able to grasp it.
Stay on top of the homework. Nothing really makes sense until the last two weeks of class. Learn how to do true or false.
Stay on top of the material, use McGraw tutors for problem sets.
Study for the exams, even more than you think you need to. They are hard, and there aren't very many of them.
Study from Adrian Banner review videos.
Take advantage of office hours when you don't understand something.
Take if you need to. Don't get behind. Adrian Banner videos are really useful.
Take it if it's a requirement. Do all the practice exams.

Take it if you have an interest in learning various ways of solving data problems, as the matrix-solving ideas are very applicable to real-life data analysis. If you're an engineer you have to take it anyway
Take it if you like math or have to. Don't fall behind, study, try not to use your drops, and look for a preceptor who suits your needs.
Take it if you must.
Take it if you really like math or if you have to

Take it only if its required. Classes aren't really that well taught and there's a lot of self-studying. And you have to hope you get a good professor. But put in enough outside studying and you'll do fine.
Take it only if you have to
Take it with Nicolas, if you can. He's a fantastic instructor and a really good guy. He makes the material intuitive, whatever your skill level.
Take it, be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to it, and hope that you get as an amazing professor as I did.
Take it. Much easier than 201 in my opinion.
Take this after 201.
Take this class if you have to
The class is incredibly difficult and is very difficult to conceptualize. Only take it if it is a requirement for you.

The course definitely picks up after the midterm and the second half covers material that's a lot less immediately understood. Staying on top of the second half of the course is really key; don't relax just because you've done well in the first half
The course itself is interesting but rigorous. Take this if you need the pre-req, but be careful choosing preceptors.
The material is interesting and the class well organized but the course is tough.

The material is very different from any of the algebra most people are used to it helps to go to class to first be exposed to it, then going through the textbook before doing the homework to really familiarize yourself with the concepts. Be ready for a lot of memorization of theorems.
Think twice about taking this course if you don't have to.

This class is a lot more theoretical than MAT 201. Be prepared to do proofs and answer lots of true/false questions (with justification). The problem sets are a pain. I personally liked MAT 201 a lot better and think MAT 202 is far harder. It's a much different way of thinking. Try to understand the material geometrically if you can. 
It's a pretty useful topic, but not a super interesting class. Take it with Otis if you can.

This class is absolute trash. The textbook is even worse than the class itself, which I never thought was possible. If you can, just take it over the summer at another college because honestly thats what a lot of people do for math classes in the university. It is not better than multi.

This course is WAY better than MAT 201; linear algebra is so much more useful and it is actually reasonable when it comes to the exams. PSets are a little long so start them early but are reasonable and help you study for exams. Most of the 202 professors are also pretty good so don't stress about getting into a specific section. Exams are tough but not impossible, study hard and you'll do well. Great math class to take even if you don't need a math!
This course is a good introduction to linear algebra, although rigorous at times (expected for Princeton math). Take it if it is a distribution requirement, although you don't really have a choice

This course is really hard, but Linear has awesome applications. While the course may not seem interesting at times, its introduction to what Linear can possibly do is interesting. However, the suffering this course entails is not necessary.
This course is very difficult. Do not take it unless you have to.
This is a good course, and I had Michael Jemison, who was a great preceptor. However, the material is always going to be dry unless you're into linear algebra.
This is a good course, students interested in math should take it.

This is a great course, but to do well you have to stay engaged with the material throughout the semester. It gets difficult very quickly, but there is plenty of help with office hours, review sessions and McGraw.
This is a well-taught and organized course, and the material covered is very useful.  Don't get behind--it's very hard to get caught up.
This is very hard. Careful, even if you are good at calculus
Time consuming course, much more concept based than MAT 201. Make sure you understand concepts throughout the semester and as right away if you have questions.
Tough and very abstract. Buckle down for this one
Try to get into Adam Levine's section.

Try to keep up minimally with concepts (at least remember formulas) so you don't have to cram it in before finals which can be tough. Do practice quizzes and exams. Try to understand deeper concepts behind formulas bc that will help you going forward on the exams.

Unless you got a respectable grade in 201, probably one to avoid unless you really need it. Concepts were very abstract and difficult to understand for me personally, so unless you're one of those people who just 'gets' that sort of stuff, set aside time to spend scratching your head and doing practice problem after practice problem.
Unless you have a particular interest or the course is required for your curriculum, I wouldn't take it.
Use the textbook to review. Don't take notes in class because it's all in the textbook. Just focus in class.

Very solid class to take. Hard if you don't follow along the lectures because everything aggressively cumulates, so FOLLOW ALONG! I liked it better than MAT 201 and if you like systems of equations then you'll like this class. I took it because of distribution requirements so I didn't put in enough effort but it's definitely not a bad class.
Very useful concepts. Reasonable exams.

WATCH KHANACADEMY VIDEOS. literally the only reason I survived the final. They are so helpful. I guess you should also read the textbook? Sometimes it makes sense, but sometimes its just more confusing. I only took this course because it's required--wouldn't recommend if it's not a required class. If it is, luck be with you. I thought this was much harder than MAT 201.

You have to take it if you're BSE. As long as you pay attention, read the book, do the problem sets, and take practice exams you should be in good shape to get a decent grade. Some problem sets will throw you for a loop, but the professors are pretty good about providing help. You can go to any of their office hours, so take advantage of that.
You just have to pass so it's fine you'll survive.

You must take if BSE. Personally, better than 201 but still challenging. Try to do readings before precepts and do attend precepts! Homework needed to solidify examples. Office hours are great. Try to get Professor Menezes if possible.
You should take it! It's a good course.

You're most likely taking this if you have to; not sure if this is the best QR if you need a distribution requirement. I found this course significantly more interesting and intuitive than MAT 201. The class will seem like a joke up until section 3.4. Then, it gets a lot more challenging. Go to office hours and review sessions! Do a lot of practice tests before quizzes and finals! Try your best not to fall behind, as, like other math courses, concepts really building off each other.
easy to fall behind. despite what you think, you can't learn a whole semester's worth of material during reading week. Difficulty ramps up in the last few weeks.
just because you did well in previous math courses doesn't mean you'll do well in this
ok
probably no need to go to class if you read the textbook and go to office hours
take it if you need it. Nothing special, not too hard.
why?
otherreq: Students may receive credit for no more than two courses from MAT 200, (201 or 203), (202 or 204).
otherinfo: MAT201 and MAT202 can be taken in either order, although most students take MAT201 first.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 20%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and readings from the textbook; quizzes as determined by instructor.
prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.
title: Linear Algebra with Applications

evals: Definitely not for everyone. Professor Diao is amazing, and taking it might be worth it just to have him, but... the exams are really hard. Even if you understand the basic concepts, it will be a challenge.
Do every single old quiz/exam that gets posted to Blackboard. If a problem or its solution stumps you, go to office hours. Even if you know all the answers, go to office hours anyway.
Do it if you like applied mathematics or physics. Be warned - it's a lot of computation!
Do the problem sets with friends and do the textbook problems soon after the relevant lecture.
Don't take this unless you're good at competition math.
Easily manageable if you keep up with the problem sets and study before quizzes. You don't even need to go to lectures.
I definitely recommend this course. The material is really interesting, and while the course is difficult, it is very much worth it.

I would warn that proficiency in high school mathematics is not a good enough indicator of preparation for this course. If one is interested in majors such as Physics, the difficulty is worth it, but for those that are just looking for this course to fill a requirement, the 201 course will be pleasantly difficult.
I'd only really take it if you took multivariable calculus in high school. Professor is fantastic though.

If you already know multivariable calculus and are in a rush to move forward in math, then take whatever math class you are planning on taking. HOWEVER: This is a good, rewarding course that will strengthen your skills in mathematics. It's not just plug-n-chug; there are plenty of "tricky" things that you will encounter here.

If you are extremely mathematically inclined, and are very good at mathematical proofs, or have had an exposure to such a class, by all means take it. But if you are here for the sake of fulfilling requirements, and if it would make no difference to you to take math 201, then moving down to math 201 would be recommended. Many people, including myself, found the course to be very overwhelming and really only catering to the top few who seemed to truly understand everything.

If you like a challenge, I recommend that you take this course. For context, I took this course along with 4 others (for a total of 5): PHY105, Writing Sem, COS 126, and a very workload intensive freshman seminar. With the exception of maybe COS, all of these courses were very workload intensive, so if you plan on taking this class with 3 others, or 4 (one of which is a relatively easier course), you should probably be able to manage (if not, you can always drop down to 201). As for the course itself, the material is challenging and the problem sets/examinations are brutal, but not such that anyone with a solid mathematics background (5 on BC calc, decent SAT II math scores) will completely fail to understand. The best part of this course, however, is not the material, but the professor: Hansheng Diao makes this course worth it on his own. If he is still teaching it (which I hope he is), I really encourage that you take 203 over 201!

It is a challenging course, but I had a lot of fun taking it.  Go to the homework help sessions; there is a direct correlation between me going (or my roommate going and telling me what happened) and my p-set grade.
It is a very challenging course, but if you work hard and go to office hours and homework help sessions, you can survive.
It's a difficult class that will take most of your time.
It's not easy, it's a very hard course but all the work done pays off in the end and I think it's much more interesting that a normal math 201.
Make sure to collaborate on homework.
Note that the tests are pretty hard

Take practice tests and do Psets well before the due date. Tests and Supplemental problems are hard, but generally speaking, not impossible! Last, if you are ever stuck with a problem or topic, go to office hours or the weekly review sessions and someone will be able to help you.

Take this class only if you've had prior exposure/background in multivariable calc and want to learn it thoroughly again.  If you haven't taken multivariable calc before then this course will probably seem very fast paced.  You will come out of this course with a very solid foundation in multivariable calc.  Psets take a fairly long time to do but aren't unreasonable in length, quizzes and exams are harder but if you study well you will do fine.

Take this course (over MAT 201) if you have previous experience with math competitions or mathematical proof.  It offers a comprehensive overview of vector calculus.  The lectures are fast-paced and the problem sets and exams are difficult, but help is available and you should seek it.
Take this over 201! Super rewarding, and if you're at all interested in giving theoretical math a shot, good intro. Worth the time.
The course is certainly challenging, but Professor Diao is very helpful. Take it but only if have deeper interest than fulfilling requirements.
This class is very hard but well-taught; be prepared to work hard but definitely take it if you enjoy a challenge.

This course is very challenging. Be prepared to commit a lot of time to problem sets and studying for quizzes and exams. Working with your peers and going to McGraw tutoring will help a lot. It may also help if you've taken multivariable calculus before, but it's definitely not necessary.

This course is very challenging. Weekly problem set sessions are pretty much mandatory, and exams are tough. I'd recommend taking it as a PDF if possible. However, if you engage with the course you will get a deep understanding of the material.
Very difficult course, be prepared for a lot of work every week and impossible exams.
Very very tough course. Sign up if you want a challenge and be prepared to dedicate a ton of time to it. Not to be mistaken, a very rewarding and exciting class if you like math.
otherreq: Students may receive credit for no more than two courses from MAT 200, (201 or 203), (202 or 204).
otherinfo: MAT203 and MAT204 are recommended for mathematically inclined science and engineering students, and math students interested in applied mathematics. MAT203 and MAT204 may be taken in either order, however MAT 203 is offered only in the fall and MAT 204 is offered only in the spring.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 20%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and readings from the textbook; quizzes as determined by instructor.
prereqs: MAT 104 or MAT 215, or equivalent..
descrip: Vector spaces, limits, derivatives of vector-valued functions, Taylor's formula, Lagrange multipliers, double and triple integrals, change of coordinates, surface and line integrals, generalizations of the fundamental theorem of calculus to higher dimensions. More abstract than 201 but more concrete than 218. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics.
title: Advanced Vector Calculus

evals: I think this was an odd semester for MAT 215. Not the normal prof, and the course was poorly run, despite the interesting material. Be sure to shop and leave other options open if you are thinking of taking the plunge in to the math deep end.

Probably just take it in the fall. No good resources in the spring, and if no one knows what they're doing then we can't really help each other through it. A good intro to analysis but it's tough enough that it might dissuade you from doing more math here, which is sad because math is cool.
This is definitely a tough class but if you are interested in learning mathematics and looking at it as mathematicians consider taking it. Professor Elgindi's explanation of the material is clear
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly reading and problem sets.
descrip: An introduction to the mathematical discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Riemann integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.
title: Honors Analysis (Single Variable)

evals:
GO TO OFFICE HOURS. You can get a lot of help there and you'll probably need it .

Thankfully psets are only due once every two weeks. None of the problems are trivial and they get progressively harder. Combo doesn't build on previous theory like analysis might, but is more of an exploration of many topics

If you have done serious competition math, you will already know everything. If you haven't (like me), then there's a ton of interesting topics covered. However, be warned that the curve is exceptionally harsh and the problem sets take a long time. They are hard because he basically takes named theorems and tells you to prove them (with a hint if you're lucky), which in my opinion is kind of a lazy way to assign homework. The professor was also not very approachable. Grading and problem sets were pretty frustrating/poor, but Prof Liu is a very good lecturer and the material is very interesting. I would recommend if you have a PDF saved and some extra time.

Since the final exam was open book, the course was rather relaxed, not much pressure to understand everything in detail. You get to see some cool gems of problem-solving type mathematics. You should not expect to learn deep theory and general theorems like in some other courses. Instead, each problem requires its own smart solution.
The class is difficult, but knowing combinatorics is interesting and useful. Take it for the subject, but not for the lecturing or the course itself.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: There will be bi-weekly homework problem sets.
prereqs: MAT202 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to combinatorics, a fundamental mathematical discipline as well as an essential component of many mathematical areas. While in the past many of the basic combinatorial results were at first obtained by ingenuity and detailed reasoning, modern theory has grown out of this early stage and often relies on deep, well-developed tools. Topics include Ramsey Theory, Turan Theorem and Extremal Graph Theory, Probabilistic Argument, Algebraic Methods and Spectral Techniques. Showcases the gems of modern combinatorics.
title: Combinatorial Mathematics

evals: Alright class for real -- a bit scattered and difficult though. Probably would not recommend if you're a math major though

Generally the material is useful, but if you're used to organized classes, this may come as a bit of a shock to the system. That's not to say I'd recommend against it -- but if you don't think you could work with fluid assignments and deadlines, this probably isn't a course you'd enjoy.

Prof. Elgindi was a very clear lecturer, and also very kind about extending assignments sometimes. Assignments took on average 10 hours, possibly more in some cases.
I have a solid grasp of Real Analysis now.
Don't let the disorganization of the class fool you, the exams are graded pretty harshly.
Tarek is a good lecturer, but the class is not currently run all that well, problem sets are difficult and vary greatly in length

This class was the hardest class I have ever taken at Princeton and honestly if I take a harder class here I will die. So know that. But I learned so much from the problem sets, the exams, and the presentation. I think I understand real analysis fairly well now, and have some notion of functional analysis, which is nice, and I'm super proud of that, and you can be too! I thought the material was really useful and this class taught me how to approach proofs more quickly than I did before. Lots of skimming and selective reading? The professor is nice and tried hard to cover a lot, which he did, and I was glad I could reach out to him for help when I needed to. If it's a different prof I'm sure it will be a class worth taking too. We needed to have taken MAT215 before this. Idk how it will be next semester but you will have a much much better time regardless if you do.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 25%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MAT 201 and 202 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to real analysis, including the theory of Lebesgue measure and integration on the line and n-dimensional space, and the theory of Fourier series and Hilbert spaces.
title: Introduction to Real Analysis

evals: A good class. Szabo is a nice teacher and you should email him/go to office hours if you can.
Definitely a great math class -- Zoltan's the best that ever was. Problem sets aren't too bad, but the midterm's pretty hard, and the final may potentially completely wreck you.
Final is scary. otherwise, an easy course and a must-take for the professor and your math major requirements.
First half is not bad. Second half is ok. Final is hard.
Great course. I honestly don't think I will get a good grade but I learned a lot doing problem sets.
Highly recommend taking with Szabo.  Material was very interesting, and presented well.

I hesitate to recommend this class. From beginning to end, topology was always a struggle; I had problems finding intuition in different topologies, I didn't know how to prove spaces were compact, and fundamental groups were truly the bane of my existence. I dreaded the problem sets every week, trying to prove second countable or normal or you-name-it, and the midterm was a 40-hour endeavor that took some of my soul with it when I handed it in. That being said, there was something incredibly gratifying in being able to slowly piece together everything we learned in topology: how topological spaces relate to each other, how to construct homeomorphisms, how to construct fundamental groups -- and even if it was a struggle during the semester, I do think that topology is useful for any serious student of mathematics. Take this class. Professor Szabo will take you on a magical journey through the world of mathematics far larger than you could have imagined.
If Szabo is teaching it, take it. The class gets a bit worse at the end, but overall it is very good.
If you like math, take it.

Professor Szabo is a really chill guy who truly cares about the topic and making sure his students understand it. The book, Munkres, is pretty readable, and the exam problems can be very hard but they can also be quite beautiful
Szabo is a great lecturer and gives a lot of intuition for things. Problem sets are easy, but be warned the final exam is a lot harder than the rest of the course.
Take it!
Tough but good class.
Zoltan is one of the best teachers I've ever had!
its a good, fair class
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MAT202 or 204 or 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to point-set topology, the fundamental group, covering spaces, methods of calculation and applications.
title: Topology

evals: Complex analysis is a beautiful branch of mathematics, and the course does a good job of teaching the subject.
Definitely take this if you're a math major - the material both challenging and interesting too. Probably the hardest 300-level class, but worth it.
Good course, take it if you like analysis. Problem sets weren't too hard usually.
I would recommend taking this course if you are a dedicated math or physics major. It is very challenging and requires a deep background in proof-based mathematics.
If you are a math or physics major, I highly recommend this course.

Ionescu is pretty good. I hear Stein is great and Rodnianski is horrible. If you're a math major deciding which year you should take this class, I recommend taking it the first year you can when Rodnianski is not teaching it, to minimize the probability that you'll get stuck with him.

It's amazing taking this course after Analysis 1  because complex analysis is so different from real analysis (though it's told that these two classes may be taken in any order, I think that taking them in order is a lot better).
It's hard as hell.
It's hard, but interesting
Take this class if you are a math major but beware of the exams; there is significant time pressure. Super interesting topic, but not very engaging lectures.

The course is well-taught and it's an important/interesting area of math you have to be familiar with as a math major. Just stay on top of the work, and pay close attention to the psets. The grading can be a bit harsh relative to the other departmentals I took.
Tough, but worth it.

Try to read the book a bit in the summer, it will help. Very interesting and useful, but quite difficult. P-sets take a lot of time so start early, do the readings. Ionescu is a good lecturer.   (From a physics major).
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Final Exam - 20%, Problem set(s) - 70%
assgts: 70% of grade will be based on performance on weekly problems sets.
prereqs: MAT215 or MAT 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Study of functions of a complex variable, with emphasis on interrelations with other parts of mathematics. Cauchy's theorems, singularities, contour integration, power series, infinite products. The gamma and zeta functions and the prime number theorem. Elliptic functions, theta functions, Jacobi's triple product and combinatorics. This course is the second semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.
title: Analysis II: Complex Analysis

evals: DO NOT TAKE THE COURSE IF SINAI TEACHES IT, HE CANNOT LECTURE FOR LIFE.
Sinai is awesome. That being said, be very careful. The oral exam is really strange and tricky, with highly arbitrary grading.
Think long and hard before taking this course.
You learn a lot - it does feel kinda hard to understand/communicate with Sinai but he knows what he's doing.
otherinfo: Not open to freshman without department permission.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Rigorous weekly problem sets will account for 50% of the grade
prereqs: MAT 203, 218 or instructor's permission.
descrip: An introduction to probability theory. The course begins with the measure theoretic foundations of probability theory, expectation, distributions and limit theorems. Further topics include concentration of measure, Markov chains and martingales.
title: Probability Theory

evals: A lot of work, but it is an awesome class!
Best and (most time-intensive) math class I've taken at Princeton, take it and be prepared for it to take up the time of 2 or 3 standard math classes.
It is challenging but as long as you work hard and think hard it pays off. It is the best math course I've had at Princeton.
Take it!

The most difficult and stressful class I've taken by far, but also the most productive. I really felt that this class has made me better at math, not just more knowledgeable, something I didn't expect. The work load for this class was more than all the work for all of my other classes combined.

This is by far the hardest course that I have taken in Princeton, but I would still strongly recommend it to students with a solid background in algebra. The subject is truly fascinating, and professor Morel is amazing. Start the problem sets early, they will take more time than all of your other classes combined. Go to every class and take notes, you will need them.
otherinfo: Freshman who wish to enroll in upper level math courses must have departmental permission. Please see Junior Adviser Tasho Kaletha or Robert Gunning (MAT215 instructor).
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 70%
assgts: Weekly reading and problem sets.
prereqs: MAT345 or MAT346..
descrip: An introduction to representation theory of Lie groups and Lie algebras. The goal is to cover roughly the first half of Knapp's book.
title: Topics in Algebra - Representation Theory

grading: Other Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly reading and problem sets.
descrip: Elements of smooth manifold theory, tensors, and differential forms; Riemannian metrics, connection and curvature; selected applications to Hodge theory, curvature in topology and general relativity.
title: Topics in Geometry - Semi-Riemannian Geometry & Geometric Analysis

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: We address how the h-cobordism theorem extends to h-cobordisms between smooth 4-manifolds. In particular, we discuss the cork theorem of Curtis-Freedman-Hsiang-Stong, Matveyeev and attempt to explain the disc theorem of Freedman.
title: Topics in Topology - Topology of 4-manifolds

evals: A decent EC to take if you're interested in language!
A solid course. Not too much work. I liked professor Kalin.

As an upperclassmen with major decided, it's probably the best EC.
As a freshmen, you should take it if you have any sliver of interest in language.
Basically no work if you PDF. Probably not much more if you don't.

Class was great with Prof. Kalin. Highly recommend if she is teaching it again. The iClicker questions made it mandatory to show up to lecture, which was slightly annoying, but worth it anyways because you enjoy hearing Prof. Kalin talk.
Clicker attendance. Interesting material, not difficult to understand. Good EC requirement.
Do a lot of practice problems.
Do take it if you want to learn more about language. Prof. Kalin can help you a lot.
Easy class for a fifth class. Not too difficult if you put in some effort. Generally very interesting material.

Easy enough PDF, but a little harder than I expected. Definitely will need to attend precept and pay attention (sometimes even read the book), but the professor has plenty of office hours and is always willing to help (Kalin).
Excellent but not an easy class.

For BSE kiddos afraid of anything remotely humanities this is your time to shine. It's like half-technical, half-iffy-humanities-stuff put together. So don't be afraid!!! Also you'll never write an essay in this class
Fun, easy EC. I actually learned a lot. Take this course!
Good class, well taught, and generally interested.  If language interests you, then take it.
Good distribution requirement and not much work.
Great course!
Great course, interesting and valuable knowledge without too much effort.
Honestly, this class was a lot better than I expected, it seemed very well structured and the workload wasn't very high. If you go to lectures and precepts you don't have to do much reading.
I liked it. Not the hardest, which is good for an EC. Prof Kalin is a good approachable/clear/knowledgeable lecturer. I repeat: not very hard.
I liked this course. It was pretty easy and Prof. Kalin did a good job explaining the material.

I think this is a great EC requirement. Get Rachel as a preceptor if she does it again! Really fun and engaging class and not too difficult. Only four psets the whole semester which is great for a engineering who gets slammed with psets every week.

I took this for an "easy" EC but ended up really enjoying it. It doesn't take much work (psets are only a few hours/wk and not every week has a pset) and the subject matter is also fairly interesting. Lecture/precept examples were often quite similar to pset/exam questions. Prof. Kalin was also a great, engaging lecturer!

If linguistics sounds even remotely interesting to you, take it! (And especially take it if Kalin is teaching - she's amazing.) It's not a lot of work (easy PDF if you're looking for that), it'll show you a really interesting way of looking at language, and it'll give you an appreciation for everything that goes on in our heads when we speak a language. Highly recommended!

If you are interested in linguistics, but you don't know what field you want to pursue, then this is a good class to get a sample of many of them.  If you are interested in linguistics and you already know what field you want to pursue, I would not recommend this class.  The information is all surface level, and you may already know much of what will be taught.  Professor Kalin is great, though!  She's always willing to answer any questions you have that may go beyond the material of the course.  She is a pure, kind, wonderful person, and a very helpful professor.  If you are just looking for an EC, I think this class is good for that, if you are even remotely interested in language.

If you are looking for an easy PDF, then fine take this class. If you are looking for an easy A, then you have no chance here. The grading is hard, the class is annoying, they CARE ABOUT ATTENDANCE, so really I take that back. Even for PDF stay away. Really just stay away.

If you have an extra couple of hours per week to commit to this course, then it will not be difficult to get an A - I did not have those hours, which sucked because I really could have used an easy A this semester
If you're a non-STEM AB major, don't take this class for an easy A under Prof. Kalin. PDF it if you do bad on midterm.
Interesting course that's not very hard. Readings were easily doable and problem sets were fun/easy.

Interesting enough in the beginning, and certainly pdfable. This was Professor Kalin's first semester teaching, and it showed in her diligent efforts in her lectures. However, I lost interest midway as the lectures moved on to semantics and grammatical areas, which I don't think is the professor's fault but my own waning interest in linguistics. If anyone wants to learn linguistics for fun, I would recommend pdfing, but with Professor Kalin, I would like to say that this class is NOT an easy A at all.
It is a decent class for an EC. It has like no work and the exam is so short.
It's a fun course. Take it!
It's a good course to fill a distribution requirement.

It's a lot harder than people think. I'm pretty sure this course has gotten harder than in recent years. The tests and problem sets are, in the words of the teacher, "graded extremely harshly." It's a good PDF to get your EC requirement, but it's not the easy A it used to be.
It's super easy so take it, but I hated the material, personally
Must have a passion for it. Cannot take and not try and expect to get a P
Next spring, when Prof Kalin teaches it again, don't miss your chance!

Not a bad course to take as an EC, but know that the exams are by no means easy. If you are planning to take for a grade, be prepared to put in a bit of extra work outside of what is required to really understand the concepts and skills they are teaching you. Skim the readings. If you don't know if you will be interested in linguistics yet but hope you will, you probably won't.
Not a lot of work and pretty interesting but some parts of the exams and problem sets are not straight forward and have a lot of gray area in terms of possible answers. Great pdf class.
Not as bad as you think, though its incredibly tough to find motivation to study this subject. Quite dry.
Not nearly as easy as everyone says it is. The class is pretty interesting, but be prepared to do a decent amount of work.
Not the easy PDF it once was, but if you stay up with the material you can do well in it.

One of my favorite courses at Princeton. The subject matter can be polarizing (some find it interesting while others find it very dry) but I think everyone can agree that Professor Kalin is an incredible professor. I would highly recommend any course taught by Kalin.
One of the easiest EMs, you also learn some stuff about language that I had never thought about before.
Pretty easy EC, you'll probably learn more and have a more interesting experience with Kalin but it will be more work and definitely not a guaranteed A.
Prof Kalin and the preceptors are all very welcoming to questions and helping out whenever possible.

Professor Kalin is a very good instructor, and the preceptors are all engaging.  Just make sure to keep up with the work, and study hard for the midterm and final, and this will be a great class selection.
Relatively minimal workload and decently interesting.
Strongly recommended only if you're willing to do the work and are interested in logical thinking, engaging with the class is worth
Take it

Take it for a distribution requirement. Kalin is a fun lecturer, the assignments are easy and infrequent and the general atmosphere is pretty chill. Go to the lectures, though, they're a nice break from hard work and they cover most of the material in the readings, which you can then skim.
Take it if Laura Kalin is teaching. Good EC. Not an easy A though.
Take it if you have any interest at all in languages/linguistics.

Take it if you want a REALLY EASY LA.  Collaboration on psets is a godsend.  Lectures move EXTREMELY SLOWLY, so I'd recommend you don't pay attention in class (lectures are mandatory so you have to at least show up) and skim through the lectures slides on your own time (takes like 10 minutes for a 50 minute lecture). Skimming the readings is a good idea if you think you don't understand something.
Take it if you're at all interested
Take it with Kalin! She's great.

Take it, especially it it's with Prof. Kalin! Not as easy as some people claim (there are lots of finnicky details you need to remember), but incredibly interesting and somehow profound as you learn not just about how language works but about how humans think about language and what makes it universal. It's well organized and clearly presented and not too much work.
Take this class! It's a good EC too.
Take this course for an EC. Prof Kalin is an engaging lecture and you'll learn some interesting things about language that you do unconsciously but aren't typically aware of.
Take this course if you are really passionate about languages. It is really eye-opening and interesting.
Take this course! It is a relatively easy EC. Lectures are engaging and material is not too hard.

Take this if you have a genuine interest in linguistics and you'll enjoy it, especially with Professor Kalin, who is amazing. Without that general interest, you'll find that the classes will really drag
The course has gotten challenging since recent years, but is a decently interesting course.
The problem sets are worth a lot of your course grade, so take them seriously.
The readings help greatly when understanding the concepts. Really interesting class that will have you thinking about things that you've most likely never thought before or never questioned.
This class helped me think differently about language and I am glad I took it, however it is not as straightforward as you might think.
This class isn't too hard, but lecture and precept attendance are mandatory. For the most part, course material is interesting.
This course is great for proving a foundational knowledge of linguistics such as morphology, syntax, phonology and semantics.
This course is interesting and does a good job of presenting an introduction to linguistics. Graded fairly and lectures are actually pretty engaging.
This is a great course! Linguistics is super fascinating and this is a great way to learn about it. Take it in the spring, Prof. Kalin is great!
This is a great course. If you've ever wanted to learn about "the science of language," definitely give it a try. Critical thinking skills are recommended.
This is a very solid distribution requirement. It's not much work, and Professor Kalin is a great lecturer if you're at all interested in linguistics.
This is an excellent intro course with a low workload and very interesting material. Great fifth course and a good overview to see if you would be interested in studying more linguistics.
This is an interesting course, probably more work than you are expecting though.

This was a really fun class! Professor Kalin is very engaged and enthusiastic and she makes the classes interesting by doing things in an out of the box way. 
The work load is not bad at all with 4 homework assignments spread out over the semester. I really liked that we were allowed to collaborate on the homeworks. My roommate took the class in the Spring with Prof. Felbaum and they were not allowed any collaboration. I personally didn't do all of the readings and I was able to understand and keep up just fine.
Great class with a light workload. Definitely recommend
Try to get Cory as a preceptor. Great preceptor.
Try to get a good preceptor for the precept. I got a grad student that was kindof awkward so we spent a good third of every precept in silence. Otherwise, study a bit and you should get an A
Very awesome course. Will take more classes with Kalin and in linguistics. Good choice for a distribution.
Very interesting course, learnt a lot from it! Precepts are very useful, and overall not a lot of work.
Very manageable course and not terribly boring. Good as a fifth course or distribution requirement.
really boring class, don't buy the textbook somewhat chill pdf.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Approximately 40 pp reading/ week. 4 problem sets.
descrip: An introduction to the scientific analysis of the structure and uses of language. Core areas covered include phonetics and phonology, morphology, the lexicon, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with data from a wide range of languages. Topics include the biological basis of language, language and cognition, the neurology of language and language disorders, and first and second language acquisition.
title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics

evals: Although the professor is not good at promptness with grades and assignments, he's very good to talk to and thoughtful ? very good at teaching, less with organization, but then again very enthusiastic and cares a lot
Byron is great and this class is fun if you're interested in syntax. You bond with your classmates over the problem sets. Byron consistently returned problem sets and quizzes very late.
Don't expect to get grades or feedback on time
If you want to learn about Syntax, this is a great class.  If you want to be stressed because your professor doesn't make assignments, due dates, and grades clear, this is also a great class.
The course is very technical, which could be fun or overwhelming, depending on your interests.

This is a great course, but Byron is not well organized -- be prepared to wait a long time to get grades back. That being said, Byron is so obviously passionate about the subject, so he presents the material in an engaging way.

Though the course was a bit disorganized and things were often posted very late, the course was very engaging. Overall, I really enjoyed this course. Byron was very passionate about what he taught and this made the course very interesting. I am able to look at language differently now and do think that this course benefitted me and my knowledge of how language really works.
lectures are great, otherwise not very well organised but I have a feeling it's just a temporary thing going on. Byron is a great prof and lecturer but communication could be better.

professor often failed to reply to students' questions or post material on time (for a problem set, for example). he didn't get back feedback or even grades for psets until very late (and made a lot of false promises about posting, which stressed everyone out). I loved lectures, but don't take if you don't have much interest and would get anxious if you didn't have an idea where you were standing in a class.
otherinfo: Open to freshmen.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 35%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: 20 pages of reading per week; 10 short assignments; 5 problem sets.
prereqs: LIN 201 or 212, or with instructor's approval..
descrip: Syntax is the aspect of human language involved in building phrases out of words. How do words combine - like beads on a string? Are words the smallest building blocks of phrases? How can we make predictions about what is possible and impossible in these structures? This course aims to answer these questions while focusing on the methods linguists use to analyze natural language expressions. Explorations of some universal properties of language structures, as well as the ways in which those structures can vary. Strong emphasis on building and testing hypotheses on the basis of both language data and foundational principles of the field.
title: Syntax

evals: A good alternative to taking 201.

Definitely take this class. A lot of similar material to LIN 201 but in a vastly more interesting way. Kalin was phenomenal and you'll probably meet a lot of people you would never have another class with

Definitely take this if you are at all interested in understanding language on a deeper level. This basically summarizes the most important parts of intro linguistics 201 while also providing an application of the concepts to a specific and extremely contemporary field of linguistics. You can get the EC done with this instead of 201 and be in a smaller more engaging class atmosphere if that is what you prefer.
Excellent course. Prof. Kalin is highly engaging and cares deeply about helping her students learn the material.

Good introduction to the technicalities of linguistics, and really interesting study of language universals. The exciting stuff comes later in the course (universals), but is only possible to understand in light of the first half (typology). Prof. Kalin is a fantastic educator, who lectures clearly, is excited about the material, and is responsive and accessible to students.
If Prof. Kalin is teaching the class, I highly recommend it. It is a good introduction to linguistics. There is very little work, but the class is very rewarding.

Professor Kalin is an amazing teacher. She really really cares about the course and her students and puts effort into getting to know them through organized lunches in small groups, etc. This isn't really a class where you can avoid going to lectures, but her enthusiasm throughout the class makes up for that. The material is pretty interesting, too. It's cool to learn about the underpinnings of languages. I'd recommend.
Professor Kalin is great and presents the material really well. There's a lot of material covered and pretty interesting!
Professor Kalin is great! She cares a lot about her students and is glad to answer questions.
Take this class if you are interested in Linguistics.
Take this class you won't regret it!

Take this course instead of LIN 201! It teaches you everything LIN 201 covers with fun data and there are loads more interesting questions you'll find yourself asking. However, this course is also a technical way of reasoning about language, so don't take it if you're more interested in literary/cultural aspects of language.

This class isn't what I expected it to be. I thought it would be a more sociological and anthropological approach to language diversity, with some focus on technicalities. This course is very technical and heavy on linguistic concepts. I enjoyed the first part of the course because the discussions still went into the big picture on language diversity sometimes. Later in the semester, things got too tedious. If you're into that, you'll like it.

This course is really great! Even as an intro to linguistics. You don't need prior knowledge of linguistics and yet you'll leave with extensive introductory knowledge. You'll get to work hands-on with a grammar, which is really cool. And Professor Kalin super great!

This is a fun and interesting course in linguistics.  There are several presentations, but they are not overly challenging, and serve to help you understand the language grammar you chose to study.  I would recommend this course to anyone interested in linguistics, or looking to fulfill a requirement.  It is not necessary to take an introductory linguistics course before this one.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 16%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 24%
assgts: 40-60 pp. reading a week. Other (24%): A series of small assignments throughout the semester that involve (i) critically thinking about course material, (ii) preparing for in-class language work, or (iii) writing short language reports. The assigned paper should be 5-7 pages in length.
descrip: This course is a hands-on exploration of language typology. Each student will work with a different endangered language to help us, as a class, answer typological questions across various domains of language (sounds, words, sentences, etc.). Along what lines do languages vary? How much can languages differ from each other? Are any linguistic properties shared across all human languages, and if so, how do we explain them? How do signed languages fit into this picture, and what's all that buzz about Pirahã? Through answering these questions, we will build up and engage with various models and theories of language variation.
title: Linguistic Universals and Language Diversity

evals: --Pretty easy course; low workload.  Don't need much musical background to do well.  If you want a really good grade, then do the readings.  Otherwise, it's not hard to get an A- without doing any readings, which basically means doing almost nothing the whole semester except for listening to music.  Great choice for LA distribution.

A must-take survey course on music history - it's nice to have a greater understanding of the background and the stylistic elements of major compositions from the pre-medieval era to the 21st century. Morrison is also one of the best lecturers at Princeton.

ABSOLUTELY FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, OUR COUNTRY, AND YOUR FUTURE CHILDREN DO NOT TAKE THIS BS COURSE. IT IS HARD, DIRECTIONLESS, POINTLESS, YOU WILL LEARN NOTHING, AND IT IS A WASTE OF A COURSE. JUST NO NO NO NO NO NO NO NO.
Do not expect an easy PDF, let alone an easy A.

Do not take the course with Simon Morrison. He does not seem to care about the students, going as far as making up random first names when calling on people with questions. 

The exams are difficult, all over the place, and graded unequally. I was told by a friend who heard from his Dean that 40% of students had an F or a D at the midterm. I do not recommend this course for anyone.

Do not take this class if you expect to take it as an easy A. The midterm and final requires an enormous amount of memorization from composition dates, musical features, random facts during lecture, etc. That being sad, it is not a difficult course. If you put in the time and keep up with the listenings you will be fine.
Do the listenings and be able to recognize the songs. Go to the review sessions. Not too much work. Have fun! Great class.

Do the readings and listenings and study for the exams. There are a lot of random historical questions that you either know or don't and you just have to memorize the info. Attend lectures - they're so fun and interesting.

EXCELLENT MUSIC COURSE. Super easy, with very light reading and only 1 final paper. Especially if you have any kind of musical background listenings and lectures and fun. It will introduce you to a bunch of different genres of music throughout history. Professor Morrison is wonderful, and I am now looking to take more of his music classes next semester.
Easy LA PDF, maybe not as much of a graded course since the curve is not great.
Easy LA, especially if you PDF. Broad but shallow overview of the history of Western music. Good way to become slightly more cultured with minimal effort. Only one major assignment, which was nice.
Easy course, though you won't gain much deep knowledge of music. You'll get a rough overview which is all you should expect from a class like this.
Engaging class taught by a talented professor.

Even if you don't know anything about music, take this course. It's easy, relaxing (lecture is just listening to music), and by the end of it you'll be able to hold an intelligent dinner conversation about concertos and such.
Fun, interesting course. Took PDF and was very little work. Was instead able to just sit back and listen and learn some interesting things! Definitely take!
Good course for getting an overview of music history. Lectures are boring and unfocused however. Be prepared to memorize a lot of dates!
Great PDF, but be aware that you have to know a pretty substantial amount for the midterm and final.

Great course, especially with Morrison teaching it. This course was probably the easiest class with the least amount of work (for most weeks, you just show up to lecture and precepts). That being said, the content is really interesting and you get to do listening instead of reading. Definitely take it!

I heard that DON'T take it with Morrison. However, it's NOT EASY at all. Definitely the worse class I have taken here. The who thing of memorizing music, specific dates and terms doesn't make sense. We all forget about these after the exam.  Also, when they grade they look for specific words and not concepts; this was a bit weird given that people like me think in terms of concepts and associations of the concepts and not in terms of certain specific terms.
I would definitely recommend this course to all students. It is very important to have a basic understanding of the history of music.
I would recommend this course to people who are already interested in music or have some experience playing an instrument.
I would recommend this course. I would say to take this course if you have prior experience in music or music history. Otherwise it is harder than expected.
I wouldn't do it again

I'm not exactly sure why people call this course, "clapping for credit". It is a legitimate music history course with very detailed exams. I know smart people who had to pdf the course. Do not expect a free A. There is a LOT to memorize and the exams are very trivia-based at times. Which means, read the book, study the operas, pay close attention in lecture. I have had substantial musical background, but all of that is mainly irrelevant in this course since it is NOT a music theory course. There is a listening recognition section on exams, but the professor chooses the easiest excerpts that everyone in the class will recognize. 
TLDR: being a musician doesn't give you that much of an advantage, course is a lot of memorization, not a free A. But if you put in the work, enjoy the rewards.
I've never had a course like it but feel myself learning a lot about genres/composers I had only a base level understanding of. If you appreciate music, I recommend the class.

If Professor Morrison is the lecturer then without a doubt take this class! He is an amazing lecturer and will make the material very interesting. It was a great class; however, don't expect an easy class. To do well on the midterm and final you must study a lot.
If you are interested in music or getting a background on the development and progression of classical music, this is a great introduction that isn't particularly demanding.

If you really want to learn about music I don't think this course is for you. I felt like I was learning about a random collection of people and dates rather than a cohesive whole. On the other hand some of what we learned was interesting. Don't take it unless you're very interested. There's not much day-to-day work though so if you need an easy class this one is probably for you.

If you're looking for an easy LA, this is the perfect class for you. There is only one written assignment, and two exams. Morrison is an extremely interesting lecture if you have any interest in music history. Exams require some memorization (especially the final) but aren't hard as long as you put in some time.
Interesting class with reasonable work load, consider taking it!
It is not an easy class, despite what you may have heard.  Take it with Morrison if you get the chance.  He is a phenomenal professor.
It's a great class to take, even with no musical experience.
It's a music history course. Very little work
Make sure that you listen to the pieces, or you will be scrambling to memorize them before the tests.
Midterm and Final are a lot of work. Have to study a lot. Take a different LA.
More work than I expected, which was an easy PDF class. Fair amount of memorization required for exams.
Morrison is a great lecturer. Light workload until exams.
N/A
Not a bad 5th course/easy LA/both if you need. Extremely easy if you pdf
Not an easy class. A lot to memorize.
Not as easy as they say, but interesting for a general view on the evolution of music.
Not much work at all if you PDF. But also probably not too hard to get an A.

Pay close attention to lecture and do the readings. Keep up with the listening assignments. Manageable workload just put in some efforts for exam preparation. Overall a helpful overview of western music history.
People sometimes write off this course as "clapping for credit," but Simon Morrison makes it a wonderful journey through music history.  His lectures are not to miss.
Prof. Morrison is a wonderful lecturer.

Professor Morrison is a great professor and really funny. If you're interested in music history take the class. However, at times I did feel like a lot of the weeks were learning about music that I wasn't that interested in (Gregorian chants, atonal creepy music, etc.) but it is a part of history.

Professor Morrison is a masterful lecturer. Also the class is more or less zero work (other than going to lecture because it's great) if you're taking it P/D/F.

The textbook is not really necessary.
Read the textbook. Listen to readings. Pay attention to conceptual information rather than specific aspects of pieces.

Really a pretty good course if you're willing to take the time and learn from the professor and preceptors. If you get the chance to dive in and ask questions and really think about the music, you could probably gain a lot.

If you're just taking it for an easy class and don't invest the time, you'll get frustrated with why you're memorizing so many things.
Relatively good course. Study for the exam and you should be good.
Take it for distribution requirement if you're interested in music/music history

Take it if you want a laid back PDF for most of the year. You don't have to keep up with the course as it goes along (readings/listenings are pretty light, but you still don't need to do them or go to lecture necessarily if you're PDF'ing). THAT SAID, the midterm and final exams are pretty hard so make sure you study up for them.
Take it if you're willing to put in a bit of work, even for PDF.
Take it only if you are really in to classical music and music history otherwise steer clear. It isn't as easy as you would expect and ended up being a giant pain even for a PDF
Take it only if you have musical background and take Professor Morrison's precept.
Take it!

Take it! Great class, great way to fill your LA requirement, very chill, no work essentially outside of class except listening to the required listenings (but I often did that by playing a MUS103 spotify playlist that I made while walking around on campus).

Take it! It's a very easy LA requirement if you already have a bit of music background, whether it be in performing or theory. I wouldn't even think it's necessary to PDF the course. Besides the midterm and final exam there is one very short concert review paper. You get very good preparation for the exams from the preceptor and Professor Morrison. My advice is to attend the review session taught by the professor at the end of the semester. If you have any interest in music history, I recommend taking the course. It's fun and easy, but you still learn a lot!
Take it. Do the the listening and keep up with the readings. The course load is not too much but it is easy to fall behind and this could be costly when the exam comes around.
Take the course for music history. Not much work, but a lot of assigned listenings.

Take this class if you have any interest in music! As a science major who has had no substantial prior music knowledge, I was admittedly a little worried at first, but the class is great in walking you through everything. Professor Morrison's lectures were interesting and definitely worth going to, and Julia was a fantastic preceptor!

This class is great if you want more exposure to classical music. Don't be fooled by the "Clapping for Credit" moniker. While the material is not conceptually difficult, there's a lot of memorization involved, including dates.
This class is neither particularly easy nor particularly interesting. I'm not sure who it is geared toward. You are definitely expected to have some music knowledge.
This class is not an easy A.  However, it's not much work at all, and is perfect to PDF.  It is pretty boring though.
This course was much harder than it seemed- unreasonably so. Only take if you have a background in music and take everything very seriously.

This course will give you a solid grasp on the progression of Western music. Lectures are interesting, and no one really does the readings, so the class has a minimal time commitment. As far as effort put in vs. reward, the class fairs well. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for an LA or who wants to learn about the history of Western music.
This is a course that is very memorization-heavy, and mostly talks about history rather than music theory.
This is a great LA to take. You definitely do not need a musical background to do well or feel engaged by the course material.
This is a hard class and it requires lots of memorization. Also it is helpful if you have some background in music.

This is a relatively easy class with minimal work throughout the semester that fulfills the LA distribution. I like lectures and found them pretty enjoyable. Put some effort into learning listenings and material for exams.
This is an interesting course, but be careful if you want to PDF because there is more work than you think (but it is interesting work).
This is not an intro to music in the sense of structures and the music it self, focused a lot more on the history of classical-esque era musiciains
Very easy class (almost no work), but the material is very interesting. It teaches the basic knowledge everyone should have about music.
Very good course if you're interested in learning more about Western music. You should take it, especially if Simon Morrison is teaching!
Would not recommend unless the structure of the course significantly changes
good PDF - bare minimum. but pretty boring and the selection of music towards the end is hard to relate to
yes
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 1-2 hours of reading and listening per week; one short writing assignment.
descrip: Music 103 is an introduction to Western Art Music (works from 1100 to the present). The course defines the basic elements of music - pitch, rhythm, melody, harmony, and form - and the historically significant styles and genres of composition. Emphasis is placed on significant premiere performances, music and politics, and music and the other arts (film, dance, literature).
title: Introduction to Music

evals: Awesome class! Take it. Super interesting. Professor Dennehy is great.
Course material might be too simple if you come from an already strong musical background. Good opportunity to get motivated to work on compositions if you haven't before, however.
Definitely take this course if you have an interest in music theory and are looking for a fun class to fulfill the LA distribution requirement.

Definitely take this course if you have any interest in music whatsoever! It's really cool to see the basic music fundamentals and then use them to make your own song! Professor Dennehy is also super fun and engaging. Probably one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Don't fall behind, because the quizzes can be tough. Interesting!
Fun course. It does pick up in the second half of the semester, and make sure to take care with the composition portion of the class if you want to do very well. The quiz/theory part is very easy.

Go to lectures, and precepts. Give yourself enough time to work on the compositions, because it's really fun to write music, but if you're like me than you'll probably end up scrapping a few ideas before settling on something. Don't be afraid of the sight-singing; my precept was never forced to sight-sing alone, and there was never judgment or mean-spiritedness. Have fun, and don't take yourself too seriously.
Go to precepts!!! They kept me engaged and on top of things. Lectures can be skipped once in a while but they do handout the homework and notes in lecture.
Great course. Prior exprience in
Having a good grasp on music or a solid amount of free time to work with would allow one to get the most from this course.
I would advise people to pay attention in precept and make sure that they understand the basics of music theory because the level of the class ramps up very quick over the course of the semester.

If Professor Dennehy is teaching this course, I would highly recommend it. I came in knowing how to read music but not much else about theory, and learned a lot.

If you have a chance to have Professor Dennehy as a preceptor, I'd highly encourage that as well; he was extremely nice and encouraging, and really understood that he had all levels of experience in his precept and accommodated accordingly. I started off the semester feeling a little nervous about singing in front of other people and answering questions on the board, but my confidence grew in large part because of how reassuring he is.

If you are interested in learning some basic music theory, I strongly recommend this course! Those with music experience (i.d. those who play instruments or sing) will find the first half or so relatively straight-forward, however the second half may present some new information! The projects are quite a lot of fun, and the workload is not very heavy at all.
