If you can play the piano, take this course. But do not kid yourself, this course is more difficult than you think. I don't have great natural musical abilities and because of that I suffered. Also, basically everyone in the class (including me) had prior experience with music, usually by means of playing an instrument.
If you have some theory background, this class will be a breeze. And fun too.

If you like music and want to learn the basics of song writing, definitely take this class. It will be easier if you are familiar with music theory, but if not, the class starts out with the basics. It's a fun class and the assignments are very manageable.  Also, Professor Dennehy is a great lecturer.
It's a pretty easy course, just make sure to start early on the composition projects.

Make sure you allow ample time for the homework, because it can be more time consuming than expected. Otherwise, this is a fairly easy class that will allow you to begin writing your own music if you have no formal training beforehand.
Not as easy as it seems at first.  Rewarding and fun.
Not too difficult of a class, and a good introduction to the subject.
Please take it. It's super fun and easy to enjoy, even if you're not an aspiring musician, though who knows, by the end of the course, you might be.
Study the notes closely for the quizzes.
TAKE IT. Awesome quick introduction to music theory. Fast-paced and you learn a ton.
Take it but bear in mind the fact that if you have no musical background this class will be VERY time-consuming.
Take it if you want to do some music theory without doing the much more serious 105/106 sequence.

Take it if you want to learn more about music. But also make sure you know how to read sheet music before you take the class, while it does go over how to read sheet music in the first few lectures, it goes over it very quickly and assumes that most people have had prior experience with it.
Take it, it's very fun and interesting
Take this class if you have any background in music, it is very fun and you feel very rewarded by writing a song to finish.
Take this class. You will learn so much, and it  is not difficult at all to do fairly well in it. An amazing PDF as well.

Take this course, kids. Donnacha is a great enthusiastic and funny teacher. Certainly helps if you have some experience reading music or playing an instrument. Other than that, the class is great and not too hard. 10/10 would recommend to a friend.
Take, its interesting and different from all your other math and science classes.
The course will be more fun if you apply the concepts you are learning to your own work, or even just your own listening to music.

This class is incredible. If you have any interest in pop song composition, this is the class for you. If you're deciding between this and 105, I've been told the biggest difference is that in 105 you focus on classical composition whereas in this class it is mostly pop. You should definitively take it if you love music and want to understand it better. It is also easy if you have any musical experience at all, especially piano.

This course is an amazing pick for anyone with an enthusiasm for music.  This course really opened my eyes to the logic behind musical progression and allowed me to understand and put names to so many chords and musical modes that I had only been able to describe as "cool-sounding" before.  Experience with an instrument helps, especially in terms of reading music, but you certainly don't need to be professionally proficient, so don't let anxiety about that deter you from taking the class.  (To provide perspective to my advice, I am a chemistry major with major singing experience, including the Glee Club, and had some piano lessons, but I never even understood that all the scales I was learning how to play sounded the same because the spacing between the notes was the same.)
This is a great course for non-music majors who are interested in writing their own music and learning the proper techniques
This would be a great course for anyone who wants to learn more about the fundamentals of music theory and some composition.
Very good introduction to music theory. Probably don't need to take if you have had any previous experience with music theory.

Very light workload but sometimes the assignments are a little tedious. On the other hand, composing your own pieces is fun. I'd say only take this course if you're actually into music theory (although if that's the case, you should really be taking 105).
You should have some familiarity with reading sheet music before taking the class--otherwise the learning curve is rather steep.

easy PDF, but not easy to get an A in. 
will take work. 
composition is fun, but grading is tough.
go to lectures, try to have fun with the projects
otherinfo: Students should have rudimentary skills in reading music.
grading: Design Project - 45%, Quizzes - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Most assignments will involve listening to, and writing music.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of music theory through exercises in melody, harmony, composition, ear-training, transcription, instrumentation and analysis. A variety of music will be studied. The main emphasis in the course will be on the practical and creative application of these skills in small composition and songwriting assignments.
title: When Music Is Made

evals: Be in Viet's precept -- he's incredible. He'll actually teach you the material. Go to lectures in case there's a pop quiz or something that happens to be interesting that day, but they're largely unfocused and not about the material. They are fun, though. Overall, definitely take this class -- your musicianship will improve greatly and it's a really fun class. It gets much easier after the first few weeks -- don't be discouraged by the beginning. It's not a huge amount of work, but I wouldn't recommend it as a fifth course unless you took AP theory in high school or already know quite a bit of theory.
Good class for theory and some exposure to composition.
I would not take this course unless you are sure that you want to pursue a certificate or major in music.
If you sing or play an instrument, this course will enrich the way you think about music while listening and the way you engage with your hobby

If you think you're capable of switching out, do it even if the professor tells you not to. I felt like this semester was a waste of my time, as I knew the material and aced the class without attending any lectures or precepts. The point of taking classes is to actually challenge yourself and to learn new material, and all I felt like this class did was give me a GPA boost, which shouldn't be the case.

If you've studied little to no music theory in the past, then this course might be interesting to you. However, be warned, this course takes up five hours of weekly class time, so only take it if you have a very strong interest in theory. On the other hand, if you've taken AP Music Theory and scored well on the exam, DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. If you are planning to get a certificate in Musical Performance, you will unfortunately have to take MUS105, but otherwise, don't waste your time. You will most likely find lectures to be extremely slow, and won't learn anything. Possibly the only redeeming quality about MUS105 for students who have already taken theory is that it may help you get into more exclusive, higher-level courses in the music department (e.g. MUS 212/CWR 211). But other than that and the certificate program, any student who scored a 5 on the AP Music Theory exam has no reason to take this course other than to get an easy A, albeit at the expense of a lot of wasted time.

In this course, the textbook is your professor.  The only point in going to lecture is to not miss the pop quizzes. Prepare to PDF if you're in the minority of people that haven't played a classical instrument all their lives. The only saving grace of this class is Viet.

Learn voice leading really well and you should be fine. Good course for learning theory and completing the requirement for the music performance certificate, but definitely not just a casual music course.
Make sure you keep up with assignments because they help you learn the material.
Make sure you understand things thoroughly and refer to the textbook if you're confused!
Read the book and do the assignments on time.
Take it if you want to learn music theory. Let's hope that Dimitri will teach it again soon!
Take it with Viet! If you did well in AP Music Theory this should be really easy. Just go to class so you don't miss quizzes.
Take the course, but be ready to spend a lot of time on psets in order to do them well.

The course starts off pretty quick with an expectation that the students are pretty comfortable with reading music. I wasn't very comfortable reading music going into the course, but if you have the drive to learn how to compose, you'll do very well in the course.

This course does an excellent job at teaching the basics of music theory. I was a bit surprised at the prior music knowledge that students were expected to have at the beginning of the course, but as the course progressed it wound up not making a huge difference as I thought it might.
This course may not be helpful if you want a good introduction to music theory.

This professor is kind of nuts. You'll be able to learn the material on your own and from Viet, but lectures are not helpful.  Many people just wouldn't go.  Overall, this is a good course to take if you want to move ahead into counterpoint and gain an understanding of voice leading rules.  Take it with friends and you'll be fine.  The work is very manageable.
Viet is an absolutely amazing preceptor; if at all possible make sure you have him.
avoid prof. white if she's teaching...unless you have to take this class
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Problem set(s) - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Weekly assignments.
prereqs: The ability to read music in treble and bass clef. Basic familiarity with some instrument. Some prior exposure to music theory is helpful. Students who are nervous about their prior experience should contact the instructor and consider 104. A placement test is available for advanced students..
descrip: Music 105 is the first of a two-semester course on introductory music theory of Western classical music. We will study various ways a diatonic scale is used to structure melodic and harmonic directions, and further, to govern phrases and musical forms. After an in-depth review of the rudiments-- scales, intervals, chords--we will proceed to examining counterpoint, harmonic function, and phrase structure. The course is designed to help you develop your understanding of music, analyze existing musical works, and compose your own.
title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition

evals: A fantastic class! Steve Mackey is a great teacher, and 16th century choral music is fun to compose and listen to.
Definitely take this class

Don't wait until the day before an assignment is due to start it! The assignments are not extremely difficult, but they take time, and they often take longer to complete than you think they will. Also, since a lot of the class is dedicated to learning a set of rules for composing, make sure to leave time to check over your work, as you can lose a lot of points for careless mistakes.

If you don't like listening to 16th style choral music, you're going to have a rough time. Take it if you need to or if you actually want to compose this style of music. Otherwise, it's no fun. All the composition track music majors will make it look easy, but guaranteed even they will be having a hard time.

Take this course! Even if you're not a music major/certificate, it's well worth your while and when you end up writing a whole mass movement as part of your final project, you'll feel really proud of yourself. If you want to get an A, be prepared to put in a lot of work, though--silly mistakes on the problem sets can be killer! (beware the parallel fifths...)
This is a fantastic course! I highly recommend it.
counterpoint is beautiful. not easy, but certainly manageable
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 60%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Two counterpoint assignments per week.
prereqs: MUS 106 or permission of instructor.
descrip: To lay the foundations for a thorough understanding of the principles of linear structure and voice-leading through the study of species counterpoint. Twice weekly exercises will lead to a complete 4-5 voice Mass Movement as a final project.
title: Species Counterpoint

evals: A great course to learn more about music 1900-1945. We covered such a wide variety of music that I really learned a lot. You won't love all the music, but you'll probably discover some new things you like, and there will be some enjoyable classics too (Stravinsky, Shostakovich, etc.) Do be aware that you'll have listening sections on the exams, so be thinking about that during the course of the semester when you decide that you don't have to do the listening assignments. In general though this is a class that's not a ton of work during the semester until midterm/final time, so it's nice in that regard.
A very interesting class, with a hilarious and esoteric professor. It requires minimal work, and you learn a lot about the music of the modernist period.
Attend all lectures, take all notes with your computer; Morrison speaks very quickly.
Be warned about the listening portion of the exam, but otherwise this is a pretty chill class.
Definitely take this class. Fairly low time commitment and incredibly interesting if you want to learn more about the time period and gain an appreciation for modernist music.
Great breadth, not so much depth.
Great course! I learned a lot, and Morrison is an incredible lecturer. A background in music theory is not necessary.
I recommend the course but stay on top of the listenings each week because that will make preparation for the exams much easier. It is also helpful to have a little bit of background in music.

I strongly recommend this course to anyone with an interest in music, the modernist period, or general artistic movements. I was enthralled from the first to the last lecture by just about everything was given to interpret. Additionally, Morrison is an excellent lecturer, my favorite up to date.

If you're interested in music history and want to listen to some interesting works, this is the course to take. Professor Morrison is a bit full of himself, but he also is a great lecturer and has the resume and experience to back his self-assuredness up. You can do well if you really pay attention to lectures and have an interest in the subject matter.
Just take it. (Unless you are not interested in modern music. Even then, you would probably still enjoy it)
Lectures are excellent, and it's very interesting material.
Lectures are very interesting - but you need to go to all of them to understand the material required for this course! Also requires basic memorization of dates and pieces.

Notice there is a final paper AND a final exam for this class. Writing the final paper helps you intimately study something from the course in particular, but the end of the semester for this class is hard. The final exam usually falls on the day after Deans Date. otherwise, this class is super interesting and super informative and Simon is an excellent lecturer. Don't miss the lectures and you'll be fine in the class.
Only take this class if you have the time to really dig in deep into the recordings and readings. Highly not recommended to PDF unless you already have a background in classical music.
Study a lot for the exams!
Super amazing lectures and not too much work throughout the semester. Hard paper. Get guidance on it early.

TAKE IT!!!!!!! This class is the best course I've ever taken at Princeton. Prof Morrison is an amazing lecturer and you'll learn a lot without being stressed. Low workload, low stress, super interesting, and very fairly graded. I skip a lot of classes but I never skipped MUS 240. Also try to get Megan as your preceptor.
Take it if you are interested in the material or need it, but don't if you are not. Would be an easy PDF, though.
Take this class if you have experience with music or want to get a new perspective or want to listen to a lot of great pieces of music.

Take this class! It is not too much work, and you learn soooo much! Morrison is a great lecturer, he is hilarious and makes class a joy. And if Megan Sarno is precepting GET HER she is the best preceptor I have had ever.

Take this course! Prof. Morrison and the preceptors are awesome! Prof. Morrison has knowledge that you won't read in any book (yet - he's commisioned to write them) and is so kind and funny. You really can't lose with this course.
Take this course! The lectures are great, there isn't that much work, and it's really interesting.
Take this course. Morrison is a must have at Princeton - he's a great professor and is super knowledgeable and funny in lecture. Worth showing up to class for.

The professor is excellent and the subject matter interesting - take it! BUT - if you have no musical knowledge DO NOT TAKE IT they pretend that it isn't required but the course is extremely difficult without it, it requires listening IDs and reading scores etc.
listen
should take if interested in musical history
otherinfo: Students may find it useful to have some prior experience with classical music, whether as listeners or performers. Ability to read music not required.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: About 3 hours of listening and reading each week
descrip: This course is an overview of modernism in European and Euro-American art music, including movements such as symbolism, expressionism, and neoclassicism. We will listen to music of-among others-Bartók, Berg, Copland, Debussy, Ives, Mahler, Milhaud, Satie, Schoenberg, Scriabin, Stravinsky, and Varèse. Topics will include introduction to a wide variety of musical languages and forms, as well as different cultural contexts for music making (music and ethnicity, music's relation to other art forms such as dance and visual art, music and politics).
title: Musical Modernism 1890-1945

evals: A must-take for all instrumentalists that enjoy collaboration.
Definitely a worthwhile course to take if you can get a dedicated group together.
Excellent class. If you are keen on playing chamber music, you should take this class.
I would recommend this course to any musician.
Take it twice if you can!
otherinfo: The instructors are TBD. Auditions to be held TBA.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
assgts: Students are guided through a given work with the goal of performing it in a concert at the end of the semester. Sources used in this course are pieces from the chamber music literature.
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.
title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music

otherinfo: Midterm and final projects (20%) will be creative and collaborative in nature.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Working from high-resolution, color facsimiles, students approach major works from the Middle Ages and Renaissance through the notations and formats in which they were originally recorded, and gain fluency in a variety of notational systems. Twice over the course of the semester, experts in the field of historically informed performance lead students in a masterclass as they prepare for the final concert that culminates the course.
prereqs: The ability to read modern music notation comfortably..
descrip: A hands-on introduction to the notation of Western music, c. 900 to 1600. Students will become familiar with representative pieces while learning to read notations in which they are preserved. Material covered includes plainchant, sacred and secular polyphony, and notational puzzles and games. Classes are split between singing and discussions of notation as it relates to style, composition, performance and culture. Students gain hands-on practice with the art and mechanics of early notations, and will have the opportunity to use historical tools and techniques to notate their own quires of songs, to be displayed in the Mendel Music Library.
title: Medieval and Renaissance Music from Original Notation

evals: Be prepared to work hard every week on your project, since you'll often want to revise it based on the comments you get from others during the seminar. Don't wait until the last minute to finish it.
Dmitri was surprisingly chill. no homework, just work on your composition. take if you want to compose

I would heavily recommend this course to anyone who wishes to improve musical composition skills. Not only does this class facilitate those skills, it also opens up intellectual discussion related to other composers, and it provides an intimate atmosphere for discussion.
If you see that Dmitri is offering it, don't be intimidated by him. He is very understanding and honest, and truly a good teacher.
Like composition? ... Well?

Only take this course if you want to spend the semester writing one piece of music, mostly on your own. The feedback from class is generally pretty superficial, given that these are not composition lessons but discussions in a group setting. Professor Tymoczko is very smart, however, so, if he is teaching, you might want to consider it.

You'll have feedback from all of your classmates and your instructor every week, which is a very valuable resource for any composer. Three hours of listening to each other's pieces can be somewhat draining, but the class is often broken up with discussions of famous composers' works that pertain to broader discussions of form, tonality, etc. I mostly appreciated this class for pushing me to write a piece during the semester when I easily could have avoided doing so.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 80%
assgts: Steady progress every week, leading to the completion of a substantial composition.
prereqs: Some previous compositional experience. Pick up application in Woolworth Room 310..
descrip: A composition course for independent, self-directed composers working in any style. The primary requirement is to compose a substantial piece and present it at our class concert at the end of the semester. Each week students will present drafts of their works in progress in a workshop format. In addition, we will consider a range of music, which may be accompanied with small assignments to provoke the creative process.
title: Advanced Workshop in Musical Composition

evals: Actually learn the visual programming language (Max/MSP). People in the class tend to make crazy things and with frequent presentations, it's easy to feel inadequate compared to them. Try to keep up in the class because lectures go by really quickly.

As a COS major I found this course very light on the programming side. It uses two music-specific programming environments that don't have the same flexibility as traditional programming languages. It is an interesting course, but consider it a music course that requires some programming experience, not the other way around.
Be prepared to do a lot of self-study in terms of the programming languages!
I loved this class. You get out what you put in, and the projects can sometimes be work-intensive, but I don't think it was more work than any other COS departmental.
If you can, take it.
If you have any computer and music background, this course is basically a must-take. One of the best classes I've ever taken.

It's a good course. If you're interesting in both COS and music then you should have a good time. Be aware that the course is less about things like the digital representation of sound, digital-to-analog conversion, etc. and more about electronic music (its history, techniques for creating it, etc.)
Seriously fun and great regardless if you have musical talent.
So much fun, and it's a pretty laid back course. Would recommend.
So much fun. You'll never want to take another COS or MUS class that doesn't combine the two disciplines (but you will, because that's how it works)
Sometimes it feels as if there are too many assignments, but if you like music and you can code you better not miss out on this course!
TAKE IT. Definitely one of the best COS classes I've taken at Princeton. Extremely well taught and a lot of fun.
Take it! Jeff is amazing and this class is a great way to explore music and programming as an art.
Take it!! Fun and relatively low workload, but you get to create some very cool work and can take the course in whatever creative direction you want, by how you approach the assignments.

Take this course! The assignments are fun and not at all frustrating the way other CS courses are; this is not the course where your program breaks/needs hours and hours of debugging. As soon as you start programming, you get results. In class, we learned a cool few programs and got to follow along on our own computers, which made lectures engaging. Jeff Snyder is also a very cool person and will broaden your horizons with the listening assignments. A must-take for anyone who wants a hands-on course.

This course can be very fun and rewarding, and you will likely produce things that you are proud of. But, depending on how much you want to dedicate, the assignments can take a lot of time and effort!
This is a truly wonderful class that man COS majors at this school should take.  I did not know any music theory or science but was still able to make good projects and have a creative outlet.
This is an amazing course and you have an opportunity to compose new pieces each week and present in class. Make sure you choose a good partner!

Very practical - lots of fun assignments. Not the best if you're really interested in diving into the theory behind electronic music and sound representation in computers. Basically a wide survey of getting your feet wet in a number of electronic music approaches.
great course - Jeff is the bomb-diggity
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Programming Assignments - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Weekly programming and project assignments.
prereqs: Enrollment in course by instructor's permission. Application available in the Music Dept. office, or music.princeton.edu/Mus314/application due April 14, 2017..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer and electronic music. The music and sound programming language ChucK, developed here at Princeton, will be used in conjunction with Max/MSP, another digital audio language, to study procedural programming, digital signal processing and synthesis, networking, and human-computer interfacing.
title: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Explores the golden age of polyphony in the 13th c., with particular attention to the many historical mysteries surrounding the repertoire.
title: Topics in Medieval Music - Anonymous 4 and the Riddle of the Magnus Liber Organi

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
assgts: Six hours of listening/viewing, six hours of score study, and six hours of reading each week.
prereqs: Not open to Undergraduate students..
descrip: This course explores the career of Pyotr Tchaikovsky, from his first civic-minded compositions and salon songs through to his first ballet Swan Lake, the operas Eugene Onegin and Mazeppa, the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Symphonies, his liturgical music, and the works that he was planning to compose before his premature death. The course considers recent Russian-and English-language scholarship on the composer, both technical and cultural-historical, with accent on his service to the Russian imperial court.
title: Topics in 19th- and Early 20th-Century Music - Tchaikovsky

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This seminar examines the origins of opera in Italy from the late sixteenth century until the inception of public opera in Venice in 1637. Offered in conjunction with the PU Opera Theater production of Monteverdi's L'Orfeo (1607) in January 2018, the seminar considers the cultural and intellectual context for Monteverdi's opera and others produced in Rome, Florence, and Mantua, considering the relevant literary and musical sources, questions of aesthetics, networks of patrons, performance practice, with special attention to the problems of producing baroque opera today.
title: Topics in the History of Opera - The Origins of Opera

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Emphasis is placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.
title: Composition

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The topic of this course is interdisciplinary collaboration. The motivations that are precursors to, the products resulting from, and the strategies and processes one might use to develop collaborative work are explored.
title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: We examine the music of the late British composer Jonathan Harvey (1939-2012). His writings on musical inspiration and Buddhist philosophy show that he thought of composition as an act of compassion. We discuss his unique approach to serialism, self-similar structure, aleatory, and melodic chains; and examine how and why the warmth of his lyricism is infiltrated by complex textures.
title: Points of Focus in 20th-Century Music

evals: If you have any investment in the history of science as a discipline, this course will provide an indispensable orientation.

It's an excellent introduction to the historiography of science and to science studies more broadly. I would recommend it highly to any humanities graduate student with an interest in that literature.

This is a great course to take because you will not only learn about central issues in contemporary historiography, but you will also gain an understanding of the ideas that created history of science, philosophy of sciene, and SSS.
enjoy!
grading: Papers - 75%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
descrip: This course is designed to introduce beginning graduate students to the central problems and principle literature of the history of science from the Enlightenment into the 20th century.
title: Introduction to Historiography of Science

evals: Great class.  Take it, but be careful with your preceptor selection - that is what will make or break it
Great intro NES class! Schayegh is hilarious and everything you need is in the Pequod
Highly recommend. Great information that will make you more well-rounded in the current events and history of the Middle East.
I definitely think this is a great class to take and would highly recommend it.
It doesn't take too much effort. Easy 5th class.

It's a good course! Workload is tolerable though readings can be long, and watch out for the pop quiz (if he still keeps it). It's nice that there is no final exam and just a pretty short paper. Cyrus is also a great lecturer--try to get him as your preceptor!
Take if you are interested but be prepared to only get a very broad overview
Take it! So interesting and very well-taught.

Take this course if you're at all interested in the Middle East. By the end, you'll have a comprehensive view of the entire region with specific focuses in some of the most prominent countries of the region. Professor Schayegh is a great lecturer, and classes always tell an interesting story.

Take this for an easy HA on a subject many people, especially Americans, don't often bother to educate themselves properly about. It's soft and squishy in the beginning but picks up later. The end of the course gives you valuable knowledge of and insights into the Arab Spring, which I would never have been able to reach on my own. Pretty good class all around and I would do it again.

This class is more difficult than the syllabus makes it seem. It tries to cover more material than is really feasible, and becomes annoying because of that fact. I think there are other better HAs to take if you need to take an HA. Even if you are interested in the Middle East, I would recommend taking a different course with a smaller scope.

This class is too fast paced. If there were separate classes on the modern middle east and premodern, that would be great. As of now, there is way too much info being presented in one semester and I'm coming out with no better idea about the middle east than I went in with.

This course is not only about the Modern Middle East. It's good for people looking for exactly what the title says, an introduction to the history of the empires that existed all the way to the current states and conflicts seen today. I would recommend to people looking for that.

This is a great introductory class. Professor Schayegh is one of the best lecturers around, his lectures are always easy to follow and incredibly clear and informative. There is hardly a question about the Middle East he can't answer. Workload is fairly light although some readings are significantly longer than others. Subject matter is VERY much a survey and I wish we could have gone more in depth with some historical aspects of the Middle East. You will absolutely walk away with a solid understanding of some of the major Middle Eastern philosophies of the 20th century and the movements that have made the Middle East what it is today.

Took it because I wanted to learn more about the Middle East and thought it would be an easy class.  Turned out to be more difficult than I expected.  Ton of overly hard working freshmen (I'm a senior)- would rethink if you think this class is a layup.
Very interesting, luck of the draw with preceptors.

You will learn interesting material, it's a lot more focused on older history of the Middle East as opposed to modern history which was a little less exciting for many in the class. It's not a lot of work at all, a decently easy midterm and very easy dean's date paper, just one tough quiz.
n/a
recommend
otherinfo: There will be background reading, but the main focus will be on close study of short primary-source texts; these are to be read the way historians read them.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Circa 80 pages of reading a week. Writing: (1) midterm exam; (2) quiz; (3) final exam.
prereqs: Freshmen are encouraged to enroll..
descrip: A sweep through Middle Eastern history, globally contextualized. Weeks 1-6 treat the rise of Islam, the Caliphate, the Ottoman Empire, 19th-century reforms, European imperialism, and globalization in the region. Weeks 7-12 focus on state-society relations, ideologies and cultures, and foreign actors in the 20th/21st centuries. You will come away with a basic grasp of the region's past and present and its mix of idiosyncrasies and global links.
title: Introduction to the Middle East

otherinfo: Final paper.
grading: Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
descrip: A colloquium primarily intended to introduce graduate students to major scholarly trends and debates in the various disciplines and methodologies of Middle East and Islamic Studies.
title: Introduction to the Professional Study of the Near East

otherinfo: Final paper.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 80%
descrip: The course offers a hands-on introduction to such basic genres of medieval scholarship as biography, history, tradition, and Koranic exegesis, taught through the intensive reading of texts, mostly in Arabic. The syllabus varies according to the interests of the students and the instructor.
title: An Introduction to the Islamic Scholarly Tradition

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
prereqs: Knowledge of Modern Turkish is required. Course is open to undergraduate students with permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to the writing system and grammar of Ottoman Turkish through close reading of graded selections taken from school books, newspapers, short stories, and travelogues printed in the late Ottoman and early Republican era.
title: Introduction to Ottoman Turkish

otherinfo: Requirements: Seminar paper and oral reports in seminars. Reading knowledge of Arabic is required. Final Paper.
descrip: This course focuses on reading texts that are illustrative of various issues in Muslim religious thought. The texts are selected according to students' needs.
title: Studies in Islamic Religion and Thought

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
descrip: This course aims to survey a variety of historical and religious texts in Arabic. Students must have mastery of advanced Arabic. Some of the texts that will be studied have been edited and published, others remain in manuscript form.
title: Studies in Modern Arab History - Readings in Islamic Revivalism, Islamist Politics and Law

evals: If you are at all considering Persian, DO IT! Amineh Khonum is a wonderful, intelligent, kind, compassionate, and helpful woman, and a fantastic teacher. Coming to Persian every day will feel like a treat, not a chore, and you learn so quickly in this class!
If you seek to learn Persian, Amineh is your resource!
Stay on top of your homework and be diligent in studying your vocab. This class moves relatively quickly and it is easy to feel left behind or hold up the class.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Amineh is among the best profs you will ever have. She is kind, reasonable, and amenable (in a good way). She will teach you so much in a short time, and you will enjoy the process. She works as hard as, if not harder than, you in the class. You will NOT regret it.
Take it! Try something new: I promise you will not regret it!

This class was a wonderful experience where you learn a lot about the language and the culture. Amineh is really helpful so it is alway good to ask her for advice. It will be very time-demanding as is every language course but it is an awesome experience and very eye-opening.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Preparation of one lesson or more from the text. Written exercises, oral drills and language lab.
prereqs: No credit is given for PER 101 unless it is followed by PER 102..
descrip: The focus of this elementary course is on sounds, letters and basic grammar of Persian language. The students will be exposed to the Persian culture through selected prose, daily news and class discussions.
title: Elementary Persian I

evals: Professor Amineh is great; the class structure can be repetitive at times but my reading/writing/speaking skills have improved a lot over the last three semesters
Take it!! Amineh is amazing
Take this class!
highly recommend.
otherinfo: If necessary, the schedule will be adjusted to accommodate both graduate and undergraduate students.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading materials will be provided in class, available in xerox copies. Ten-twelve pages of reading, drill and excercises.
prereqs: PER 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: PER 105 is designed to introduce students to intermediate level Persian. It stresses oral fluency, written expression, and reading comprehension. It will help the students to read texts of intermediate level difficulty communicate and converse in Persian in everyday situations write intermediate narrative style paragraphs coherently with reasonable accuracy.
title: Intermediate Persian I

evals: As an introductory course, this class goes at a pretty fast pace, but it is very manageable. The professors are always there for help, and the classes are very helpful.

Definitely take this class! However, I will say that if you aren't very interested in Korean culture (i.e dramas, kpop, family, friends, or some personal reason)/ haven't been interested in Korean culture for a while, then the amount of homework and tests may be a bit overwhelming. The instructors are very fun and helpful, and drill sessions are generally small. The first two weeks can feel a little awkward, but it's more than worth it to stay in the class if you're really interested in Korean!
Good for if you want to learn Korean.
Great class, but be prepared to put in some time to do homework.
Great class. The professors are helpful and quite funny. I've really improved in my language ability and I can't wait to continue with 102

If you have an interest in Korean, then absolutely take this course. If you have experience in Chinese, its really fun to see the link between the two languages. For native English speakers, it is probably a little bit more difficult than the other languages offered at Princeton, but the tradeoff is that basically everone in the class has an investment in learning the language. Most of all, the teachers are very kind people and are truly passionate about sharing their language and culture with you!

If you have space in your schedule and wish to learn another language, take this class!! It's a very entertaining course and the workload is not that much. Also, the professors are amazing and offer you many resources for extra help.

Only take if you have prior experience with Korean or a tremendous passion for the language. It was difficult to keep up with because some students were already fluent and there was so much new material to learn from scratch. It can be a wonderful course, but the huge workload and difficulty of learning a new language should be  taken seriously.
TAKE !
Take this class if you are at all interested. Learning a language is always fun but learning a language with great instructors is even better!
Take this, if you want to learn Korean. And don't worry, they do not grade on a curve
The Korean professors are amazingly kind, patient, and funny. I not only learned a lot but had fun doing it. Would highly recommend!
The professors are so kind and understanding; if you have any questions or concerns don't hesitate to talk to them about it!

You have to be very interested and motivated to learn Korean. It is a hard language to learn if English is your first language. The professors are amazing and push you to practice and speak in front of your classmates.
take it for the culture
take it if you have an interest in learning korean! it's super fun
otherinfo: Workbook assignments will account for 20% of the final grade.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Weekly assignments in the workbook.
prereqs: No credit is given for KOR 101 unless it is followed by KOR 102. This is a 5 day/week course..
descrip: Elementary Korean is designed for beginning students who intend to build a solid foundation for further study in the Korean language. The course provides four balanced language skills - listening, speaking, reading, and writing - needed for basic communication. It emphasizes the ability to use Korean appropriately and introduces students to useful information concerning culture and daily life in Korea.
title: Elementary Korean I

evals: If you take it, be prepared to put in daily work, that isn't too mentally taxing but can be a bit of a time drain. The class is well-taught and well-organized, so if you put in the work, you'll be fine. The professors are also really fun and amazing!
Overall a good course. I found it harder than KOR102.
Professors are really kind and great.
Take this course if you want to learn Korean!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Weekly assignments in the workbook/Journal writing
prereqs: KOR 101 and KOR 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Intermediate Korean is designed for students who have learned the basics of the Korean language and want to improve their competence to a higher level. Complex sentences and grammar are covered while the basics are reviewed. Balancing four language skills -- listening, speaking, reading, and writing -- is emphasized.
title: Intermediate Korean I

evals: Do all the assignments, listen to the instructor, and prep for the quizzes; it will help in the long run.

If you really want to continue improving your Korean I would recommend it! Prof. Choi is very friendly and willing to help you at all times. The writing assignments are fairly time-consuming and the vocab is a little harder to learn but overall it was fine.
Korean is the best dept ever
Take this class if you want to continue learning Korean!
This is an excellent fun course that is not too challenging, and you learn a lot too. Professor Choi is great!
Useful training in giving presentations in Korean. Good textbook.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: One short essay and preparation for weekly readings.
prereqs: KOR 107, KOR 108 or placement test. This is a 3 day/week course..
descrip: Advanced Korean is designed to develop fluency in both oral and literary skills. Expansion of vocabulary, practice in reading comprehension as well as active skills of conversation and writing are stressed through short readings and class discussion. Readings include different styles of writings on various topics including Korean culture, society, and history.
title: Advanced Korean I

evals: A really great & well-taught course. Interesting material and not too much work at all. Gideon's lectures were amazing! He took some tough material and made it very understandable/accessible.

Absolutely do take this course! It is a perfect introduction to philosophy, and philosophical thinking. It is interesting, and the lecture are very engaging. The readings are not too long, but they are substantial, and really do teach you interesting arguments. The essays are well spaced out, and not too challenging, yet they help you to think critically about the arguments. You will learn, be challenged, but also have a very strong chance of achieving a high grade; exactly how a course should be.

All the papers can be about any topic covered so far in the readings, so I recommend writing down any ideas you have for papers when you think of them and then consulting your list when you have to write each paper.
An excellent introduction to philosophy. Covers a wide variety of topics and a reasonable amount of work.
Attend the lectures because they are interesting and ask your preceptors about any looming questions.

Awesome course - interesting material with a broad range of topics. Not difficult to get a good grade as long as you're a decent writer and can think logically/creatively. Prof Rosen is a great lecturer, attend as many as you can!

Be prepared to write philosophy papers with no help or guidance, unless you seek it out. A philosophy paper is very different from an english, or any other paper, so be careful. Also, it is not necessary to read all the texts? Rosen's lectures basically covers all of the readings. However, they will be necessary for the papers. Overall, the workload is manageable.
Cool class, don't expect an A. Really its about the work you're willing to put into it. You definitely can skip lecture always.
Definitely take this course! It is super interesting and enjoyable, and not very time consuming at all.

Definitely take this course. It will change the way you look at philosophy, yourself, and the world. There is no one better than professor Gideon to guide you through the difficult readings involved in metaphysics.
Definitely worth taking just to hear Professor Rosen speak - really interesting and engaging lectures.
Didn't really try.  It's an easy PDF.
Easy B
Easy class.
Easy class. You don't need to do the readings, just pay attention in lecture, and decide what you want to write about early. Then read relevant info
Enjoyable and manageable. A nice introduction to philosophy.

Everyone at Princeton should take this course. It's super interesting regardless of your major AND had a bonus of fulfilling a distribution requirement. Rosen is a  really engaging lecturer and the material is interesting so definitely go to lecture. Also try and get Colin Bradley as your preceptor if you can, he's great!
Excellent enough
Fantastic course, as an engineer I found this course to be very interesting and eye-opening, and it has definitely broadened my perspective on a variety of topics. Also Sam is the absolute bomb.
Follow the readings and have fun with the material.
Get a good preceptor and always go to lecture - it's worth it just to sit there with a coffee and listen to some really cool philosophy.
Go to lecture, as it helps clarify the confusing readings.
Good EC, interesting readings, nothing too difficult. Would recommend if you want to take a philosophy class and don't want something too rigorous.
Good elective, light workload. Rosen's lecture slides are great.
Great PDF.

Great class. Interesting material, extremely reasonable workload (4 papers total, 2 of them very short). Readings generally not necessary unless for a paper topic (just go to lecture). Can make of it what you want.
Great course overall. Low workload. You don't have to do the readings if you go to lecture and vice versa.
Great distribution requirement and PDF option. Limited workload and fairly interesting.
Great overview of philosophical problems, and easy pdf for an EC. Rosen is great- he brings life and energy to complicated topics.

I loved this class personally, but if you're not a philosophy person you may get tired of it. Still, it's a fascinating introduction to philosophical questions and a pretty easy EC for those of you who aren't really into PHI.
I strongly recommend this class, especially if you need an EC requirement.

I would advise students with a real interest in philosophy and some experience to take a different, non-introductory course; they might find the scope of this class too limited. For others, it is a good course to take.
I would highly recommend this course. It's really fascinating and Gideon Rosen is an awesome lecturer. It's also not too difficult.
I would recommend if you are interested in taking philosophy or possibly majoring in it.
I would recommend the course for anyone interested to see how philosophy is done. Also, Rosen is a great lecturer.
I would recommend this class for those interested in this topic. Professor Rosen does a great job in presenting his information during lecture and the preceptors can help with the papers.

I would recommend this course not only as a distribution requirement, but also as a thought provoking course to take if a student has an interest in philosophy. Really, the course and what you get out of it is truly how much effort you put in; if you do the readings, show up to the lectures, and keep up conversation with peers and preceptors, the course is extremely valuable as an experience in training your brain to think both creatively and logically.

If you are taking this as a distribution requirement, this is a great course to PDF, since there is not that much of a workload besides the readings and the papers. If you are taking this course for general interest, this is a great introduction to epistemology and metaphysics and exposes you to interesting problems.
If you have an interest in philosophy, you should take this course. It won't teach you too much on one topic, but you will have an overview of the important problems in Epistemology and Metaphysics.
If you have any interest in philosophy, this is a great introductory course to take. It is taught very well and provides a good stepping stone into other courses.

If you like the subject matter, lectures will be entertaining and precepts are a place to develop a strong curiosity for the material. HOWEVER, your experience in the course is very much dependent upon the preceptor and the nature of the precept.
If you need an EC, the workload is pretty light. Try to stay on top of readings, because it will make writing essays so much easier.
If you put in any amount of effort at all you'll get a B.
If you're going to take this course, don't half-ass it because this class can snowball in to a lot of work. Do the readings, attend the lectures, befriend your preceptor.

If you're interested in philosophy, this is an amazing (and easy) introductory course. It isn't hard to get a B /A- if you focus in lecture and dedicate time to your writings. Phenomenal choice for a pdf -- definitely take the course just to hear Rosen's amazing lectures.
Interesting but hard to do well unless you know how to write philosophy papers.
Interesting class, very light work load.  Take it!

Interesting course if you are interesting in Philosophy. If not it may be a little rough. The writing for philosophy is very different and requires that you think in a different way than most writing assignments
Interesting course, not too taxing timewise
Interesting topics with very low work load.  However, you will not get that much out of it and grading can be quite subjective.
It's a good class! It's one of the those classes where if you put in the effort, you will get a good grade. The lecturer is also very good.
Keep a running list of essay topic ideas as you do the readings.

Make sure to attend lectures (or at least read the ppts) because they clear up the readings a lot. Gideon Rosen is also a great lecturer. Make use of preceptor's office hours because they'll really help you with developing/writing your essay, and they'll be the ones grading it.
Material has something to interest everyone.
None
Not a hard PDF class to fulfill the distribution requirement but could get boring at times. Pick a good preceptor if you really want to engage in the class.

PDF it... super easy if you do that. Probably not very hard if you want to take it for a grade but in my opinion Philosophy is a brutal subject. I didnt enjoy it but its an excellent PDF. Never need to go to lecture.

PDFing this course is a great choice. You can just sit back and chill/listen with only a little bit of work commitment over the semester. This is a great intro into philosophy if you're not interested in taking more than one PHI class
Pretty good course to take to fulfill a requirement. Not particularly work heavy. It is worth it to become engaged in the readings
Prof. Rosen's lectures are very engaging and clear. If you nail down how to write a good philosophy paper early on, you're all set.

Professor Rosen's lectures are engaging and interesting but mainly a summary of the arguments in the readings. The only work apart from readings are the short papers, so just attend lecture and only do the readings you need to for the paper (you get to pick your topic). Don't even need to take notes during lecture, just download the lecture slides after class. Patrick is a great preceptor.
Put time into the papers... lectures will seem repetitive if you do the readings.
Rosen is a really good lecturer. Get a preceptor who seems chill. Overall a pretty good course.
Speaking as someone who never thought they would like a philosophy course, this course was incredible. The topics are interesting and it is really well taught.
Start the essay assignments early. Even if it's just coming up with an outline a week before the due date. Coming up with the topic is the hardest part of writing the papers

TAKE IT. Rosen rocks as a lecturer, the material is super interesting, and it is not a super time consuming or super difficult course. Highly recommend for anyone regardless of what you study. I am a philosophy major and my best friend also in the class is an engineer and we both loved it.
TAKE IT. Very light workload, readings optional, lectures super interesting, precepts are fun. A great course for strengthening critical thinking, logic, and argument skills.
Take if you want an easy distribution requirement, not if you want to be super engaged.
Take it for EC

Take it if need EC. Not too demanding and will make you think - if you want it to. Having said that, take a higher level PHI course if you really want to think deeply about issues rather than quickly skirt over them.
Take it if you like philosophy - expect some subjective teaching.

Take it! This class will challenge you and change the way you think in the best way. 
*Make sure* to meet with your preceptor before writing papers to confirm topics and refine arguments.
Take it!!! Really interesting class. Fun and not a lot of work.
Take it.
Take it. It's a pretty easy A without that much of a time commitment. Pretty interesting stuff, to boot.
Take the course!! it's a fantastic introduction if you're interested in philosophy, and take patrick's precept (or prof. rosen's i'm assuming), you can't go wrong.

Take this class, the readings are helpful but not required. I would nevertheless recommend you at least skim them each weak so you understand the though Prof. Rosen has put in between reading the text and presenting you the information

Take this class. Take time to do the readings (a 10 page paper will take way more than 30 minutes to read and digest). Get help on the exams early on, and find a preceptor who improves the quality of the paper.

Take this course if you have an interest in or want to see what a philosophy course is like. There's no grades except for the few papers you turn in. You don't need to do the readings as long as you pay attention to the lectures (I would, they're really interesting). **Note: If you need to have concrete answers to complex questions, do NOT take this course.
Take this course! Great intro to philosophy and you don't have to attend all the lectures to get a lot out of it.
Take this course, maybe as a 5th class. It's pretty easy, very interesting, and well-taught.
Take with Rosen - great prof, great course.
The course is very fascinating, and I would recommend it to anyone interested in philosophy.
The lectures are fantastic. Your world will be turned upside down, but in a good way.

The lectures are very clear and interesting, and even if you miss some, you can get a clear powerpoint version on blackboard.  Prof. Rosen is amazingly smart and knowledgeable, is very accommodating with due dates and anything that comes up, and is interested in what your opinion is.  If you can get him as your preceptor, even better.  The papers are not bad and the grading is pretty lenient.  If you want a good intro to philosophy, choose this class.

The workload for this class is pretty manageable but you do need to do that reading so that you have things to write your papers about. If you understand the readings on your own you don't necessary need to go to lecture. But Professor Rosen is super engaging. Would recommend.
This class provided a good overview of big philosophical problems. The class was pretty easy, but it wasn't the most engaging.

This course changes a little depending on who teaches it, but it's always fantastic when Prof. Rosen is the lecturer. He's a really engaging lecturer, and I think he chose topics that were the most interesting given the reach of an introductory course (existence of God, personal identity, free will, etc.). The textbook is also really good, and definitely something I'd read in my free time to learn more. The course is also very light on workload, so take it!

This course discussed a broad range of really interesting topics and I feel like a I understand the world better for having taken it.  Rosen is a super capable and enthusiastic lecturer.  Workload is quite light
This course is a great introduction to a wide range of topics in philosophy.  The lectures are great and the essays are very open for interpretation.  Definitely take it!

This course is pretty interesting, but not the most riveting ever. However, it is run very fairly and does not require a lot of work, and what work you have is spread out nicely over the semester. If you need an EC I would highly recommend.
This is a good intro to philosophy class and not too much work

This is a good introduction to philosophy, but I'd only recommend it if you're already interested in the discipline. The material can be frustratingly abstract unless you really work with it, but Rosen is a good lecturer, and the papers help you better understand the issues in the course.

This is a great course. Do the readings because they really are interesting. The more you put into this course, the more you get out of it. Professor Rosen is a great lecturer so do go to lectures for your own benefit.
This is an interesting, intriguing course which is a good fourth or fifth class option.  Also, there is not a whole lot of time commitment with the P/D/F option.

This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton, if not my favorite. The material is SO interesting and really makes you think about the big questions in life. The assignments were really cool because you got to choose your own topic, meaning you didn't have to fully understand everything, but just be interested in a few things. The lectures were phenomenal. Professor Rosen presents both sides of topics so you can choose what you want to believe. Brett was a really good preceptor and really knows his stuff. Office hours are an absolute must for writing your papers. TAKE THIS COURSE.
Very good course! Pretty easy, just reading and 4 papers, but still very interesting
Would really recommend for distribution requirement. Rosen is awesome and interesting and the work is not that demanding.
go to all the lectures, esp. if you don't understand the readings
go to lecture
ok class to take for EC
take if you want a philosophy course!
otherinfo: Course open to freshmen.
grading: Papers - 60%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Two short papers (1-2 pp), two essays (3-5 pp) and a term paper (12-15 pp). Students are expected to read 100 pages per week.
descrip: An introduction to central questions of philosophy. Topics include: The rationality of religious belief, our knowledge of the external world, freedom of the will and the identity of persons over time.
title: Introduction to Metaphysics and Epistemology

evals: Absolutely take this course if given the chance. Professor Nehamas is incredible, and so is Nietzsche. The course is challenging but so worthwhile.
Definitely take it if you have interest in philosophy.  You don't have to do the readings to get a lot out of the class.  Just make sure you pay close attention in lectures and read some Spark notes.

Definitely take. Prof. Nehamas is an amazing lecturer and preceptor. Nietzsche's works are incredibly intriguing. If you like philosophy or have any interest in Nietzsche, definitely take. One of the best I've taken at Princeton.
Even if you are not a philosophy major, this is an important class to take for personal development and understanding of the world!
Excellent course to take if seeking to expand your lines of argumentation--eliminate dogmatism and other constraints of the mind

For the first few weeks, I was taking the course just because I loved Professor Nehamas (you should certainly enroll just for him), even though Nietzsche's philosophy didn't interest me that much. Now I know how important a good professor can be: I came to love studying Nietzsche, though especially as a Christian I don't agree with much of what he says, and I enjoyed discovering the beauty, complexity and appeal of ideas that at first seemed completely contrary to reason. This class is important for you as a human being. These major views by Nietzsche that revolutionized Western culture will probably change how you live and see yourself. Dare to explore!
Highly recommended. Will change the way you think about how to live your life (in a positive way, of course).
If you are even considering this course, take it.
Nehamas is an incredible lecturer, the work load is very manageable, and love him or hate him Nietzsche will make you think

Nietzsche has some ridiculously interesting ideas but can be challenging to impossible to understand his work. Go to lecture and look up summaries to keep up in this course and you'll do fine. Nehamas is one of the most engaging lecturers I've had at Princeton so this isn't a course to miss out on if you have any interest in philosophy.

Nietzsche is a very important author in my opinion. The class is superbly taught by Nehamas. This class attracts motivated students so be willing and able to put in the work. It is very worth it though.

Take it!  Nietzsche is one of the most interesting figures in philosophy, and Professor Nehamas is an engaging lecturer, and truly an expert on Nietzsche.  It is a privilege to get to read such great writing and interesting philosophical ideas, and discuss them with a professor as knowledgeable and down-to-earth as Professor Nehamas.  Highly recommended.
Take it! Especially if you're interested in philosophy, but don't like analytic approaches.
Take the course and do not look back...
Take this class if you are a person.

This class provides a comprehensive and thoroughly engaging to one of the most thought-provoking and artful philosophers in history. For those whom the name "Nietzsche" inspires vague confusion or apprehension, rest assured that Prof. Nehamas is strikingly clear in explaining difficult concepts; and for those already well-acquainted with Nietzsche, Nehamas' interpretation of him will shed new light.

This is a very good philosophy course. It appeals to a broad range of interests, from how to live a good life to metaphysics to getting to know some impressive literature. Professor Nehamas is very engaging, even though or rather because he often has pretty controversial ideas about the material. Challenge him in your papers and go to his office hours. Definitely a great philosophy class to take if you are willing to be open to some pretty cool worldviews.

This was one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. I highly recommend. Take this course and do the readings, because they're valuable. Make sure to go to office hours if you have problems. Nehamas is very friendly and responsive, and perhaps the best lecturer I've had.

While the other reviews of this class being "life-changing" may of course be hyperbole, its not hard to see why some would describe it as that. While this class is not for anyone, if you even have a passing interest in your place in the universe as an individual, whether in line or in opposition to Nietzsche's ideas, do take this course.

i don't know if nehamas is ever going to teach this course again in the future but if he does, take it without a doubt. i convinced a handful of people who were on the fence about it to take it with me, and they enjoyed it almost more than i did. people have said this course changed their lives (from woody woo majors, econ majors, etc.), and it's well worth the repeated existential crises to learn what one man thinks about life and the things we do. by far the best class i've taken at princeton thus far.
otherinfo: At least one course in philosophy is strongly recommended. Three papers, each counting for 30% of the final grade. Participation in precept, 10% of final grade.
grading: Papers - 90%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading: about 50-75 pages per week. Writing: three papers, two during term, one due at the end of term.
prereqs: At least one Philosophy course-not elementary logic. Freshmen admitted only after interview. Please contact Prof. Nehamas for an appointment..
descrip: An examination of Nietzsche's central views, including the role of tragedy, the place of science, the eternal recurrence, the will to power, and the primacy of the individual. We will also examine Nietzsche's ambiguous attitude toward philosophy and his influence on literature and criticism.
title: Nietzsche

evals: An interesting course - friendly to students new to philosophy.
Definitely take this class! It gives a great overview of epistemology and Prof. Kelly is a great lecturer and generally not too strict.
Do not take this class unless you know you will PDF, even then you probably won't get anything out of it.
Do you enjoy masochism? Then take this course. You won't learn about masochism (or anything tbh) but you'll sure as hell be hating yourself.
Good intro philosophy course
Great course as a foundation for doing philosophy in general. It's so important to understand epistemology and Prof. Kelly does a great job at it. Cannot recommend highly enough.
Great course! Kelly is a wonderful professor, and the material is very interesting - some of the most important issues in philosophy.

Great introduction to the theory of knowledge that covers all the bases. A very solid philosophy course, even if perhaps not the most exciting one if you just want to sample one philosophy class. It will help you with analytic thinking, and the subject matter is fun. TK's lectures are very good.
If Kelly is teaching this class, TAKE IT! He is phenomenal.

If you are interested in philosophy and want a good introduction on how to write and read contemporary philosophy, this is a great class (especially if you don't feel like sitting in a huge moral philosophy lecture). If you're interested in epistemology, even better! Not too hard (workload = barely anything), but the reading is really interesting. If you're a philosophy major, this would be a good easier second philosophy class during the semester (especially recommended if you aren't super familiar with epistemology).

If you're interested in epistemology, take the class. It's a little slow at first, but it picks up after a while. Professor Kelly is really helpful, and is super dedicated to his classes and his students.
Kelly is amazing, but unless you are particularly interested in a mostly conceptual/linguistic analysis of "knowledge" as a category/term, it can be a pretty boring course.
Loved this course.
Note that TK will not be teaching this in the fall, and the class will likely be pretty different.
Professor Kelly is a great lecturer; very clear and helpful.  The material is fascinating, and Professor Kelly is a great preceptor as well.

Professor Kelly is great. Go into office hours and talk to him to learn more cool stuff that we don't get to in class. Definitely go into office hours before papers.

The topic is pretty specific to philosophy, so if you're not that into studying questions like "how do I REALLY know," then you might not find it that engaging. At the same time, if you are interested in these questions, there definitely is room to explore practical applications if you look for them.
Solid course on epistemology. Tom Kelly is good at covering the general area and very thorough. Also a foundational area for philosophy, modern or otherwise.
Take it if you are interested in the material.

Take this course if Kelly is teaching! Whether or not you're a philosophy major, whether or not you think you care about knowledge (I didn't), you'll be surprised at how interesting and well-taught it is.
The level of this course makes it a good intro even for non-philosophy majors. I had never taken a philosophy course (in college) and found it very manageable.
This class is nothing like IB TOK. Make sure you have interest in the class before you take it; otherwise, the class might be hard to get through.
take it!! So interesting and well-taught
otherinfo: Students will be introduced to "argument mapping", a method for visually representing arguments. Drawing maps of arguments is difficult but rewarding--for philosophy, but also for any task that involves close analysis of argumentation,.
grading: Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 55%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Readings: approximately one difficult philosophy paper per lecture. Problem sets will be a mixture of writing and "argument mapping" assignments. There will be a term paper
prereqs: A previous philosophy course is recommended..
descrip: What justifies your confidence that the sun will rise tomorrow, or that you are not living in a computer simulation? Is it ever reasonable to believe something just because believing it will have good consequences for you? Is it possible to decide to believe something? Is the apparently fine-tuned nature of the physical constants evidence that there are multiple universes? Should you reduce your confidence in your political views if you find out that you would have taken contrary views had you been raised by different parents? Can two people with the same evidence rationally disagree?
title: Theory of Knowledge

evals: Chill class, I enjoyed group discussions and meeting directly with the professor
Harman is a great person and a great professor. The class isn't very much work but very interesting and forces you to face many relevant moral issues.
I definitely recommend this course. It was interesting and not that difficult. Attend lecture and precept and you should do fine.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students.
Interesting course to take. Professor Harman is a good professor and very helpful!

Prof. Harman is very old and mentally unreliable. With every sincerity, his unreliable mental behavior (e.g. forgetting what he was talking about during conversations/lectures) is indicative of Alzheimer's disease. In addition to being a poor lecturer and preceptor, he does not teach how to structure a philosophical argument.
Take it if you need the distribution requirement.

Take this! Professor Harman is amazing. Very nice and helpful and is always willing to talk about the material, paper topics or whatever you want to discuss. The topics covered are usually easy to have an opinion on, and it's interesting to read about other people's views on them because they often differ from your own. Great class!

This course offers a broad range of topics concerning ethics, and the papers are all open-ended. Do not expect a lesson on how to construct arguments, but take this class if the course description is interesting to you.

This course usually changes its textbook, and the professor himself said that this semester's readings were a bit too much for philosophy, so not much was discussed in depth. Otherwise the professor is a nice guy, and he encourages discussion. The course covers a broad range of topics including patriotism, terrorism, freedom of speech and animal rights, just to name a few. From what I've heard about Peter Singer's class, this class covers similar topics too. I would take this class, because I do think on the most part this class covers interesting topics, and future classes will probably go into more depth about the readings compared to what we did. The professor, even though he has his beliefs, is pretty open-minded about our beliefs and he is not biased by what we believe, and grades the assignments pretty fairly. He is also very quick to respond to any drafts that you send him.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 50-80 pages of reading per week.
descrip: Normative ethics is the systematic study of what is morally right or wrong, good or bad, and why. In Part 1 of this course, we will examine a number of rival moral theories that provide answers to these questions. We will contrast consequentialist moral theories with various non-consequentialist alternatives, and investigate their respective strengths and weaknesses. In Part 2, we will look at a number of practical issues, often connected to the broader theoretical debates examined in Part 1. These will include: liberty and paternalism; the value of distributive equality; the ethics of risk imposition; and the moral status of future persons.
title: Normative Ethics

evals: A good course. Perhaps a little meta in the first half, but not so much that it's impossible to follow even without a philosophy background. Make sure to read the readings carefully and multiple times, attend lectures, and read the lecture notes the profs provide.
Be prepared to read. This is a worthwhile course, but the readings take so long to understand, and if you dont do them, then youre lost.
Beyond the thought-provoking subject matter, the professors are really what make this class as amazing as it is. Take it!

DISCLAIMER: This is a course on decision theory and action theory! It isn't about "values" or "ethics" in traditional understandings of those terms.Take if you are okay with exploring a very narrow topic. A huge plus is that the professors require you to submit drafts and give other students feedback on draft assignments before submitting a final graded copy. They even let us submit rewrites for the midterm. This is awesome becasue it forces you to submit better quality work in the end. I love that Smith and McGeer value quality writing and the writing process as much as they do your comprehension of course materials. Also Smith's precepts are awesome, because they are exclusively breaking up into pairs/small groups to answer course questions and learn from fellow students.

Definitely take it! I was not such a big fan during the first half of the class because everything seemed too confusing and abstract, but I realized when I wrote the midterm paper that all the set-up was necessary to understanding the main issues, and once I completed that assignment I finally knew what was going on. From there the class became intensely fascinating every day. Explaining Values takes you into wonderful discussions about deep questions regarding why we do what we do. Professors Smith and McGeer are excellent lecturers and very approachable. Overall, this was one of the hardest but most rewarding philosophy classes I've taken. To grapple with the nuanced materials, set aside around 50% more time than usual for your papers, and get ready to have a blast learning about moral psychology!
Difficult class. Hard to follow a lot of times.
Do the readings.
Great course if you stay on top of the material.

I absolutely loved this class! That being said, it was such a struggle, taking this as my first philosophy class. Professor Smith's lectures were incredibly engaging (or at least what I could understand of them) and Kyle was an amazing preceptor.

I recommend taking this course. It is very insightful and makes you re-evaluate your actions as a human being and actions of others. The readings and course material is usually interesting and the paper topics are good. Make sure to keep up with the readings.
If you're interested in why people do what they do, take this course. It's amazing. Not a lot of work but a lot of fun.
Pay attention in class, and engage in precepts.
Really interesting course if you can grasp the difficult starting material.

Solid course. Take this course if you really will engage in readings and go into depth with them. Otherwise it probably won't be very interesting or fulfilling for you - and for others if you won't engage in conversation.
