Take it if you are interested! Fantastic lectures. Quite challenging but in a good way.

Take it. More and more each day I believe it is important for people to learn about value theory and normative ethics. They can really improve one's quality of life and understanding of other people, and help one worry less about understanding the outcomes of one's behavior, etc.

Take this course only if you have a solid background in philosophy. If you do not, you might end up getting bored or lost in supposedly trivial details (of course the details are never trivial in philosophy).

The first few weeks are a bit of a slog but entirely worth it for the back two-thirds; lectures are engaging, precepts are a toss-up; read everything carefully (readings are short, you can/ should do them twice) and come prepared with questions to get the most out of the experience.
The first week is the hardest?the readings are much more interesting after that.

The material is challenging but rewarding if you really try to make sense of it. Smith and McGeer's lecturers are very helpful in showing how the wide variety of concepts discussed in the course all relate to one another.

This course is complex and intimidating, which makes it a wonderful challenge for those who are unafraid of office hours and are eager to work hard. Plus, Prof. Smith has a delightful Australian accent.

This course is pretty difficult- I wouldn't take it as a first philosophy class- but very interesting and rewarding. Even as a pre-philosophy major, I spent the first half of the semester being pretty lost, but Professor Smith is great and very willing to meet with you to go over the material and clarify things. Once I reread all of the readings and met with him a couple times, I went from being completely unprepared to being very well prepared for my paper and ended up doing pretty well. That being said, he is so knowledgeable about philosophy that it can be easy to get left behind, so it's important to speak up when you don't understand something, even if he has to reformulate his explanations a couple of times. Both he and Professor McGreer are really nice people and good lecturers.
take for department, beware its hard
take it if you're interested in the material aka the material is super fun and makes you think about all the decisions you make in your regular life and how akratic you are on a regular basis
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 40%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Weekly preparation: Reading = 2-3 articles, one mid-term paper and one final paper, each preceded by a drafting and comments exercise.
prereqs: One other course in Philosophy or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course will examine the way in which evaluations permeate our understanding of human action, agency, and responsibility, and what exactly such evaluations amount to. We will approach these issues primarily from a philosophical perspective, but where appropriate this will be augmented by scientific and social scientific perspectives. Topics to be covered include self-control, addiction, weakness of the will, and obedience to authority.
title: Explaining Values

otherinfo: Non-Philosophy students taking this seminar must contact the Registrar directly (either in person or by e-mail) if they wish to receive a grade.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: An exploration of Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics book V, with special attention to the theory of justice that emerges in that book.
title: The Philosophy of Aristotle - Nicomachean Ethics Book V

otherinfo: Harvey Lederman (PHI assistant professor as of July 1, 2017) will be the instructor for this course.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course presents recent work on the logic & metaphysics of opacity. The first half discusses theories of quantification & identity in the presence of opacity (5 sessions). We then consider the application of these approaches to the philosophy of vagueness (2 sessions). The second half of the course turns to the question of whether opacity is relevant to the problem of logical omniscience. We begin with issues in the metaphysics of propositions (3 sessions) and then turn to issues about the logical closure of belief (3 sessions). We will likely read recent work by Bacon, Russell, Goodman, Caie, Dorr, Yablo, Yalcin.
title: Philosophical Problems in Logic - Opacity

otherinfo: Non-Philosophy students taking this seminar must contact the Registrar directly (either in person or by e-mail) if they wish to receive a grade.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Recent work on mind-body problems.
title: Philosophy of Mind - Recent Work on the Mind-Body Problem

otherinfo: Non-Philosophy students should ask for instructor permission in order to take this seminar.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: An examination of select issues in the Theory of Knowledge.
title: Theory of Knowledge - Knowledge and Rationality

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in the research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students will make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It will meet for two hours each week throughout the academic year.
title: Dissertation Seminar

evals: Look over each lesson before coming to class - when I had the time to do that it helped immensely.
Study the day's vocabulary every night!
Take Modern Greek if you have any interest in Greece or Greek culture. It is an amazingly expressive language, and it is a great challenge for English speakers.
Take it. Be ready for lots of personal attention and tons of learning.
otherinfo: This course is the first part of the Modern Greek language sequence HLS 101-102, 105-107 regularly offered every year. No credit is given for HLS 101 unless it is followed by HLS 102. HLS 107 or its equivalent is a requirement for Plan A (modern Greek language and literature) and highly recommended for Plan B (modern Greek studies) and Plan C (Hellenic tradition) concentrators in the Hellenic Studies Program.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Daily assigned texts (readings and grammar) from the textbook, with all accompanying drills and exercises from the workbook; Language lab attendance will be required to reinforce pronunciation and syntactical patterns through practice; daily written exercises.
descrip: To set the foundations for acquiring a command of spoken and written Modern Greek. Equal emphasis will be given to speaking, reading, and writing.
title: Elementary Modern Greek I

otherinfo: This course is the third part of the Modern Greek language sequence HLS 101-102, 105-107 offered every year. HLS 107 or its equivalent is a requirement for Plan A (modern Greek language and literature) and highly recommended for Plan B (modern Greek studies) and Plan C (Hellenic tradition) concentrators in the Hellenic Studies Program.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Textbook, CD & Workbook - Web-based assignments. Daily assigned texts (readings and grammar) from textbook, with all accompanying exercises and drills from Workbook; language lab practice; daily written exercises; occasional written compositions and oral presentations.
prereqs: HLS 102 or permission of instructor.
descrip: To improve the students' oral and written skills and introduce them to themes in the Hellenic tradition through readings in Modern Greek literature.
title: Intermediate Modern Greek

evals: A great introduction to physics, very accessible to students without much math.
A lot of learning in this class is through the textbook. Read/skim the textbook when you're unclear on topics/need equations. Also, attend lectures! You get to see some really cool demos!

Class is interesting and a solid intro to Physics. Requires students to try and grapple with the content. Don't be too concerned at first, you'll get into the groove soon, but come in prepared to read and chase people up for answers
Do a lot of extra practice problems. Being in class and studying does not cut it. Don't take it unless you have to.
Do as many practice problems as possible!

Do not take this course unless you have to. It is so much class time and so much of that class time is ridiculously unnecessary. Lectures are actually pointless but you're forced to go because of clicker questions. All Visnjic does is demos and derive equations. She does not actually teach any physics. Precepts are a little better but you do a lot of pointless handouts and still no one really teaches you physics. The students that did well in the class seemed to have taken physics before. Avoid if you can.
Do the homework, go to office hours.
Do the readings and go to the study halls for the problem sets.

Don't let rumors of this class stop you from taking it. It is a lot of work but the professors and preceptors are willing to work with you at anytime to help you through it. If you stay on top of your work and keep up with the class, you will be ok.

Don't rely only on yourself to get things done, it's okay to get help from other people. Also go to office hours - you can save your grades through that.
Don't take this for fun because it is a lot of busywork.

Just hope you study the right things for the exams, because there is a lot of material and they can only choose a few arbitrary concepts to test on.

For me it was very similar to high school physics - not a lot of work if you've taken physics before even with the p sets and weekly quizzes because you don't have to really study.  It's definitely more work if you haven't taken physics, but should be doable.
Go to lectures because they're really fun.
Go to office hours and study hall
Go to office hours! Don't leave everything until the last minute. Use the summaries of the chapter at the end of every chapter if you don't want to read the book.
Go to office hours.

Go to the McGraw Study sessions! Doing homework there will mean it gets done faster, more accurately and you'll learn more. 
Great intro class. Demos are really cool.
Going to McGraw is helpful. Additionally, going over p-sets with friends will be helpful as well. Honestly, if you have a friend who knows Physics, please ask for help.

Great class--very straightforward. Highly recommend. Difficult material, but they're not trying to trick you. Lectures are great--super engaging. Do your best on the problem sets--they're ensure that you understand the material for quizzes and exams.

Honestly, I hate physics. But if you're pre-med or a bio major and don't have a choice (sigh), quietly sit your butt down in office hours and do the reading. If Peter Meyers teaches next year, fight hell and high waters to get into his precept. If not his, then try Prof Vijnisics.

I always disliked physics. But this class made me grow an appreciation for the  course. Physics really does apply everywhere, and thats super cool! As long as you read the book, and go to office hours, and do practice problems (including HW and other book problems) this class is manageable.

If you have the time to take 103/104 do it. The course is easy but it feels like you are back in middle school and the tediousness of the course is usually painful.

If you take this course for whatever reason, be prepared to work hard. I wouldn't take it if you're looking for an interesting physics course, but if you need it for a requirement of some sort, it's doable.
If you're taking this you probably have to, but honestly it wasn't too hard, Professor V is awesome, and I learned a little bit. Try to get precept with Professor V

It's a large pre-req for several departments, so don't expect it to be that engaging.  It's one of those courses you have to get through and do the best you can; but it won't be that interesting unless you love physics.  Professor Visjnic is really great though!
It's physics 101 so it isn't too hard or too easy, but it does get the requirement out of the way if you're MOL, so just do it if you need to.

Make sure to start the homework early, close to when it is made available online.

Make sure you do the textbook readings before you tackle the problem sets; your life will be a whole lot easier. Also, go to the McGraw study halls if you need help, and establish a good study group that will help you a lot in terms of figuring out problems and learning the material.

otherinfo: The examinations and weekly quizzes consist of problems. Course meets premedical and science requirements. Class and Laboratory sections may be selected in any pairings without special permission.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 20%, Lab Reports - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 2%, Problem set(s) - 3%
assgts: Textbook reading 20-30 pages per week. About 7 problems per week assigned; other problems taken from the learning guide, and additional exercises from the textbook. Estimated preparation time about 8 hours per week.
prereqs: Completion of laboratory experiments is mandatory. A working knowledge of algebra (up to quadratic equations) and trigonometry (solving triangles, vector projection) is required..
descrip: The course is concerned with an introduction to the fundamental laws underlying physics and having general application to other areas of science. The treatment is complete and detailed; however, less mathematical preparation is assumed than for PHY 103-104. Mechanics and thermodynamics are treated quantitatively with a special emphasis on problem solving. In the spring semester PHY 102 covers electricity and magnetism, optics and relativity using the topics treated in PHY 101.
title: Introductory Physics I

Great course, labs were awful though. P-sets are very reasonable and nice, while still being very helpful for understanding. I wish my other classes were more like this one, with the exception of the labs.
I have found that resources within Blackboard, specifically the past assessments, are the best way to succeed in this class.

I would definitely attend McGraw study sessions and those held by TAs in Jadwin. They helped tremendously with final, midterm, and weekly homework assignments, and were also a good way to meet fellow BSE students. I am so grateful for all the help I received at the study sessions this semester.

I would highly recommend reading the textbook sections before lecture - not only is the material very clear, it will also help you with the iclicker quizzes. I would also recommend doing the past practice quizzes and exams, they are extremely helpful for preparing.

I would only recommend that a student take this class to fulfill a departmental requirement or if they have a genuine interest in physics. This is a generic physics course; do not expect too much from it. The classes can be dry sometimes.
I would only recommend this course if you need to take physics or are interested in it. There are probably better STL's out there. The lectures were good, but labs were not enjoyable.
I would say it is important to stay on top of the assignments, since there is a weekly quiz.

If this course is not required, do not take. Better to spend time on other courses than prerequisites. Course does very good job of keeping focus in physics by giving good amount of work to keep you busy.

If you already took AP physics in high school, you are off to a good start. If you have weak physics background or have never taken physics before, do supplemental problems and old quizzes every week to prepare for the weekly quiz. Also, do the reading before lecture.

If you are considering this course for the sole purpose of fulfilling a distribution requirement, you may want to be aware of the time commitment. There are 7 hours just of class/lecture/lab time per week, plus time you have to spend on your own doing homework, preparing for quizzes, etc. You get a pretty good overview of Physics (material is similar to AP Physics C: Mechanics), and much of your learning will occur in precept. The weekly lectures are not too useful.
If you genuinely like physics, I would recommend this course.
If you have a choice in preceptor, pick Ali Yazdani
If you have a question, clarify it earlier rather than later because concepts are cumulative. Also, the homework is misleadingly easy, and the examinations are quite a bit more difficult.
If you took physics in high school and excelled, then this physics course will be a slightly greater challenge. The workload is not that bad, but the course does move quickly in terms of topics.

If you took physics in high school, this class will be a breeze. I chose to take it instead of 105, which I heard was a lot of work, and I appreciated having one relaxing class. Definitely try to get Kasey Wagoner, he is the best.
If you're a premed choosing between 101 and 103 I would honestly take 103. The professors are excellent and the course is very well organized.
If you're interested in physics you should take this class.
It all depends on what preceptor you have. Actively try to get a good one like Wagoner, and you will have a much better experience.
It is an awesome course but not an easy grade by any means.

It was just okay. People who like physics probably like it. I was forced to take it and didn't enjoy the two problem sets a week or the graded clicker questions during lecture. Try to get the pests out of the way as early as possible so you can focus on preparing for the quizzes, which are worth more.
Labs are boring and frequently off topic. The rest of the class isn't exactly stellar, but it's useful information.
Lectures are interesting, but labs are quite annoying and confusing.
Lectures are poorly taught.  But go to precept and office hours to learn the material.
Lectures aren't super necessary but precept can be very helpful
Lectures have great demos that are fun to watch. Definitely go to precept, even if you don't want to, because your professor can be really helpful in answering questions
Make sure to do supplemental problem sets and study previous exams in preparation for quizzes and examinations.
Make sure to go to precept to learn the material and do all the practice exams before the exams.
Make sure to have a solid conceptual understanding of each topic.

Make sure to stay on top of the psets and adequately prepare for the labs, and them you'll be set. Also, I would recommend working with classmates on the psets because its much easier when you can bounce ideas off of each other.
Make sure to use online past quizzes to study for quizzes, use McGraw with problem sets
Make sure you do plenty of practice problems.
Make use of McGraw group and individual tutoring! Those were the things that helped me survive this course. It was a good foundational course for me and very satisfying to complete.
N/A
Not too bad. Take practice tests. Learn concept by doing practice problems. There's no alternative to doing well in physics.
Not too difficult to stay above water.
Pay attention in precept.
Pay close attention during lecture, definitely take if you are being introduced to physics.
Practice problems and participation in precept are, in my opinion, the two most important actions one can take in trying to succeed in this course.

Practice textbook problems, go to precepts and work on past exams before tests. Don't let stuff accumulate, and go to office hours/help sessions - that can be very helpful. Once you get used to everything, you'll be fine.

Pretty good course overall, no too hard, probably not as in depth as 105 but if you can take it to that type of level of understanding there's no way you won't succeed. Also, get Kasey Wagoner if you can; he's an amazing professor!

Prof. Staggs is great for precept. She's clear, accessible, and just generally fantastic/kind. Go to the McGraw help sessions, whether for psets or for exam review. They're really helpful, and even if not, working on the physics in a room with everyone else makes it much easier to focus.
Read the textbook. Do ExpertTA on time, don't leave it to the last minute, and work in groups.
Sometimes enjoyable, sometimes annoying because there are so many things to do that all add up to your grade. Also, go to lecture even though it is not helpful because of the IClicker.
Stay on top of the quizzes

Take advantage of office hours! these instructors are awesome and they will inspire you to learn about physics while at the same time answering your questions! Don't try to hole yourself up in your room and tough it out. You'll just end up bitter about physics and with a bad grade. Go to the McGraw help session, they help a ton.
Take if necessary
Take it if you really like physics or if you have to
Take it if youd like
Take it only if you have to.
Take it with Dan Marlow!

Take this course! It is a breeze if you have taken AP Physics Mechanics in high school. Lectures are interesting but repetitive (and you have to go), and homework is pretty simple. Get Galbiati as your preceptor he is great! Weekly quizzes are pretty easy but don't take exams lightly, they are pretty hard.

Take with Wagoner, he's awesome! Go to lecture, the demos are cool, but do the readings beforehand, otherwise you might get lost sometimes. Don't worry about the iclickers that much. Do past quizzes and exams, some questions are used again!
The course gives a good understanding of mechanics. If you have good prior knowledge of physics, try 105 and then maybe switch in the worst case. Expect to do more problems, and less proofs.
The course was helpful in reviewing the basic principles of physics
The homework is fairly easy, so make sure you understand the material well so you won't get freaked out by the difficulty of the exams.
The lectures are really cool, and I would consider taking this course just for seeing all of the experiments in lecture.
The only reason you should be taking this is if you're BSE and doing it for a pre-req.
The textbook should only be read if you haven't taken a similar physics class before. Go to precept for the real meat of the class.

This class is a lot of work with four classes, a lab, prelab problems, two problem sets, and a quiz every week. Be aware that you will spend a lot of time preparing for quizzes and doing problems, and seek help from the McGraw study halls.

This class is definitely a sizable amount of work if you did not have a solid understanding of physics already. It can be very confusing at times. I would make sure to do everything recommended including the learning guides if you're especially worried. Be sure to practice many different kinds of problems. Also lab TA's in Jadwin are extremely helpful!
This class is very interesting and is a great basis if you don't have experience with physics.
This course is helpful, but make sure you make study groups because they really help. Peer to peer help is very important.

This course is very straightforward. If you attend lecture, precept, and take notes, you are fairly set. Personally, I took physics before and found this course to be a bit boring, so if you are looking for a physics challenge I would not recommend it. However, it is a solid introductory course, and if you do what you're supposed to it will not be a problem.
This course is well-taught and informative.
This course was intuitive, problem sets and practice exams are very helpful.
This is not as hard of a course as other people say.

To those who are considering PHY 103 to fulfill STL: Take this course if you know you like physics and genuinely want to learn about it. Your intellectual interest is the only thing that will keep you going in this course.
Tough Labs, Tough Tests, Time Consuming, Take only if requirement
Try and get Kasey Wagoner as a class instructor!!
Try not to get too annoyed at this class.
Try to read the textbook before lecture if you can, that way you might actually understand what he is talking about if you didn't know physics before taking the course.
USE THE LEARNING GUIDES!
Understand the labs before you do them. It is easy to make mistakes.
Well structured course

When possible, do the extra problems(such as the learning guides and the supplemental problems). Give the lab a decent amount of thought before getting there as this can allow you to finish the lab at nearly half the time.
When studying for midterms, DO PRACTICE EXAMS.
Working together with other students on problem sets and trying to understand concepts together are very helpful! Ask for help if you need, it can help you in the long run.

You need this class for a lot of things and it helps to have knowledge of the physical world. My advice is to read the chapter, do practice problems, and ask your preceptor lots of questions. Make sure you set time apart for this class because it is time consuming.
You'll either love or hate labs depending on the partner you get, and it's a decent amount of work but it's not too terrible

You're reading this because you have to take it. This is a time sink because of all the annoying weekly things you have to do. They expect you to learn everything on your own by reading the textbook, and force you to go to lectures even though they're completely useless. Just an unimaginably poorly taught course, definitely not what you paid for when coming to Princeton. But oh well, you have to, so just do it. I feel like they tried to make the course easier this year: the prof put questions from past exams on the midterm and final, and the exams are just significantly easier than they were 3 or 4 years ago. Don't be scared or anything; it's not hard at all, just frustratingly bad.
alright for an intro to physics. not particularly great. make sure to read the textbook and do all the practice quizzes
choose your group wisely for labs
manageable STL, go to precepts
not great- take if you love physics or as a req
stay on top of the material by studying for weekly quizzes
take as an STL even though many people don't like physics, i greatly enjoyed it
youre taking it because you have to
otherinfo: Classes C03 & C04 form the core of PHY 105 - an advanced course to be formed 3 weeks into the term on the basis of a placement test. Only students with strong Physics and Calculus backgrounds should enroll in these sections. PHY105 students should not enroll in Monday evening labs.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Lab Reports - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: In-class problems, and four tests during the semester. Total number of pages students are expected to read per week - 10-20 pages.
prereqs: Some prior preparation in physics and calculus is desirable..
descrip: To understand the basic physics needed for further study in science and engineering. Logical, quantitative approach to problem solving. Applying fundamental concepts to idealized, practical problems.
title: General Physics I

evals: Be warned: This course is both engaging and difficult. If you are planning to become an engineer or have no experience with physics, I would recommend 103 over this simply because most of the students in this course have taken high school physics courses. For the engineers, this course is much more theoretical than application based learning, so beware. Your head may spin like mine. A suggestion to all students taking this course: Practice PSet problems and textbook problems over and over. It's the only way.

Difficult introduction to mechanics. Take it if you did well in AP Phy in high school--it will be challenging but rewarding. Labs are not good. Psets are fairly tough, but there are problem sessions. Midterms are hard but curved well. Good professors/preceptors.

Do not take if you have only a passing interest in physics. This class is taught a significantly higher level than 105, and it will really make you think. The instructors were great, and I would recommend it for serious students.
Don't fall behind. Go to office hours or problem sessions to avoid getting lost, as the class moves quickly.

I strongly recommend taking this class if you like physics. It will give you deep understanding of physics concepts and present a wonderful intellectual challenge. Keep up with readings and be prepared to commit fair amount of time to the course.
I took mechanics in high school, but I think this course really gave me a firm grasp on things I was iffy about before.
I would recommend this course for students pursuing a high-level and abstract understanding of fundamental physics.

I would recommend this course if you really enjoy physics. Be aware that it is very math-heavy and might be a lot more abstract than other physics course, thereby making it harder to grasp. But if you're sure you're going to be a physics major or you're sure you enjoy physics, it's a great intro course.
I'm pretty sure this class killed me several times, but I came back to life because physics has no mercy.

If you have to take physics OR you want to continue to take any future physics classes (it's pretty much impossible to place into sophomore courses out of high school), I cannot recommend this course enough!!!!! PHY105 is a fantastic course whereas PHY 103 is an abysmal, patronizing mess. I entered 105 having already taken mechanics at the AP level in high school (although there were kids in the class who did not have such a strong physics background) and yet I still learned a TON of new material (tensors, thermodynamics, special relatively, etc). Lyman Page, the head professor, is an incredible lecturer and has a passion for the course material that is so deep that it is all but contagious. Additionally, I strongly recommend Professor Pufu for precept (if available), as he did an amazing job at presenting the precept material in a clear manner and reinforcing material from the main class with Page (note: this 105 does not have full sized "lectures" due to the smaller class size, which is really awesome). Also, Pufu's Sunday office hours were a godsend whenever I was stuck on a pset problem. If there is one downside to 105, it would have to be the labs (tedious and poorly run), but they are combined with 103 so you are getting them either way. Finally, in terms of homework load, the problem sets a certainly more challenging than those in 103, but whereas 103 has two per week, 105 just has one, and if you have group of friends to work with, you can usually bang them out in a couple hours.
If you like physics and think you'd like a challenge, definitely give this course a shot.

If you truly enjoy physics, take 105. Remember that, for the first two weeks, you can switch between 103 and 105, so take a risk and just try it. If you don't like what you find, then there's no harm in having done it, and if you do enjoy it, then you're in the right place.

If you're sure you're interested in physics, definitely try this course. I think that despite having taken a couple physics classes in high school, my level of preparation was not entirely adequate to totally knock the course material out of the park. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed challenging myself with the practice sets and lecture content. No matter where you end up in the sciences, your investment in this course will definitely pay off.

If you're thinking about majoring in physics, or you're really interested in hard STEM stuff/have aptitude for it then definitely take this course!  It will be well worth your time and you truly gain so much in physics knowledge by the end of the course.  Material can get challenging but all the professors are really helpful about helping you understand, and exams are fairly reasonable in difficulty.
Interesting class; GREAT professors.
It is a very good course. If you are interested in physics you should take. Even if you are not going to be a physics major, this course has a lot of important stuff for life.
Read K&K from beforehand, at least the first few chapters so that you're emotionally prepared to dive head first into the material. If you are serious in doing physics as your major, take the class.

Show up to class, take good notes, do the problem sets, and you'll be fine. On the midterm, of the three questions, one problem is literally a pset problem and one is a problem from precept, so you'll get an automatic 67% as long as you stay engaged.

Take this course if you are interested in physics. Even if you aren't thinking of majoring you'll get a very good foundation. If you manage to do well in this class you won't forget what you've learned because it's explained so well.

Take this course if you think you can devote the proper time to it. If not, 103 might be the better choice. Also, find a group to work with or attend the weekly problem sessions--physics is a lot more fun when you can share it with other people!

The best strategy for succeeding in this course is to do lots of problems! Going into an exam, make sure you know how to do all the precept and problem set problems; if you have any questions, go to office hours. (Even if it's a minor question, go anyway; it might lead to a discussion of another problem you hadn't thought to ask about!)

The course description for this course recommends being in MAT104 or higher; I would not recommend this course for anyone who is not currently in MAT201 or higher, and even that may be a stretch.  If you've never had calc-based physics before, this class will be challenging, but not impossible.

This class is significantly more difficult than PHY 103; however, it is significantly more exciting and fascinating. Dr. Page is a wonderful lecturer. I would strongly encourage anyone with interest to take the course.

This course is incredible for those who are interested in physics. It is a difficult course so be ready for lots of time poured into it, but I believe that if you want to be involved heavily in physics at Princeton then this course is very worth it.
This course is interesting and engaging, but it is difficult and will require time-commitment and effort. A standard concentration-track course.
This course is tough, but if you have a strong background in physics, then this is definitely worth the work.
This course will eat up all of your time so be prepared. Don't bother with unless you are majoring in physics. If you are majoring in physics, TAKE IT it is very useful.

This is a challenging but very rewarding class. The material presented covered topics more quickly and in depth than I had ever done before, but is also incredibly interesting. If you're choosing between this and 103, be prepared to sacrifice a bit of your GPA for lots of intellectual stimulation.
Tough class, but worth the effort.

Try your best to be ahead of the schedule so that you can make it to to problem sessions. Otherwise have good partners to work on Psets as I did. You should take this course if you can handle the level and you enjoy spending time for physics.
Very interesting and stimulating, but challenging.
Work with other people on the problem sets.
hard course! Make sure you're invested in physics
take this if you would like to study physics
otherinfo: Class, Lecture and Laboratory sections may be selected in any pairings without special permission. Weekly problem sessions on Thursday evenings. We will have classes during Reading Period.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 10%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: The reading assignment is typically one chapter per week. Weekly problem sets. Class notes provided on Blackboard.
prereqs: Good mathematical aptitude required - students should be taking MAT 104 or higher concurrently. Students do NOT preregister for PHY 105. Instead, sign up for PHY 103 and select C03 or C04. There is a weekly problem session on Wednesday evenings, 7:30-10pm. Do not schedule your lab section for PHY 105 or any other courses during this time slot..
descrip: PHY 105 is an advanced first year course in classical mechanics, taught at a more sophisticated level than PHY 103. However, care is taken to make the course mathematically self contained, and accessible to the motivated physics student who may not have had exposure to an introductory college level physics course. The approach of PHY105 is that of an upper-division physics course, with more emphasis on derivation and the underlying formal structure of physics than PHY103, including an introduction to modern variational methods (Lagrangian & Hamiltonian dynamics), with challenging problem sets due each week.
title: Advanced Physics (Mechanics)

evals: As long as you understand the concepts well and don't make too many algebra mistakes, the homework and tests are not so difficult
Comparable difficulty to PHY 105.

Death mech is amazing: the unification of many fields of physics with the use of Lagrangians and Hamiltonians is quite simply beautiful. If you are planning to be a physics major or want to study solid state physics in another department, definitely take this course. It is a lot of work but definitely worth it. Also, the theoretical stuff is not nearly as hard as the name Dathmech suggests. Don't let what other people say scare you off!
Don't give up, even if it's difficult!
Great class, especially if Giombi is teaching

I didn't find the material particularly interesting, though many did, so this course is a hit or miss in regards to interest. That being said, this course is important in teaching problem-solving strategies for problems too difficult to solve with regular Newtonian mechanics, and establishes the formalism needed for quantum mechanics (where Hamiltonians apparently come into play big time, as does the wave equation). Read through the examples in the book - Giombi's lectures tend to be rushed, and he usually covers examples that are found in the book anyways. Make sure you understand what's going on, and take the problem sets seriously - they're difficult, but if you truly understand them, then you should be well-prepared for the exams.
I wouldn't rule out taking this class even if you are not a physics major. It does take a fair amount of time, but it's taught well.

If you are considering becoming a physics major, take this course. Giombi is an excellent lecturer and the material is very interesting (in my opinion). That said, expect to spend 15-20 hours of work per week to fully understand the material and complete the problem sets. Because of that, don't take too many other hard courses in addition to this course when you take it.

If you are generally interested in physics maybe you should take 207 instead because this class is very high-level and very very fast-paced. Despite not being a physics major I really enjoyed the material, but I wasn't a fan of the group dynamics - a lot of really intense and aggressive people will take this class and make you feel like you don't fit in (especially if you are female and/or not physics). There's no way to avoid it, but if you can tolerate that then you should be fine.

If you took 105 and liked it, you will probably like 205. It's a bit more mathematically involved, but is full of interesting material. You'll need to invest some time into the course, but it is rewarding.

If you're a physics major, I recommend taking this class rather than PHY 207, because it really does introduce you to the formal way of thinking about physics.  Sometimes it is a bit dry if you aren't particularly interested in mathematical formalism.  It may be hard to have a truly deep understanding of the material, but the problem sets are often procedural.  Overall difficulty level is probably comparable to PHY 105.

It's a fundamental physics course for those who want to be challenged (not to mention that it's required to be a physics major). 

I found some of the topics boring and others incredibly exciting - so it has its ups and downs. The problem sets for this class can take a long time, but I recommend working with friends.
It's definitely not easy, but if you put in the work, there's no reason you can't do well in the class.
Not as bad as the name "death mech" makes it out to be
Please take it if you are thinking about becoming a physics major. It is a very good class and you will enjoy it.

Read the textbook, and especially Giombi's notes ... I preferred just trying to understand class, not copying down everything. And start p-sets somewhat early, but don't try to do it all on your own - check in with others early and often.
Take it over 207. Giombi is an excellent lecturer.
Take it! PHY 205 isn't that hard, and it's a very fun course that's particularly well taught. There really isn't a good reason not to take it. Highly recommend.

Take this course with Giombi! If you are a physics major, duh. If not, still well worth your while. The Lagrangian approach is so beautiful and useful and will give you new insight into problems in classical mechanics. If you have any interest in physics, you must take this course. Useful for people of any major. And Giombi is a fantastic and engaging lecturer. Absolutely a must take!!!
Take this over 207. Giombi is such a good lecturer! The problem sets are gruelling but you will learn physics like you've never learned before.
The problem sets were extremely time-consuming, but you learn a lot.
This course is hard.

This is an amazing course that will give you insight into mechanics and how the physical world works. Take this over 207; while challenging, you will learn more and appreciate physics at a more nuanced level, and will be able to deal with difficult problems and tackle them accordingly.

This is such a fascinating course! I loved this course and managed to keep up despite coming from the Physics 103-4 track. The problem sets are tough, but very manageable and interesting if you work with classmates and TA's (take this opportunity to meet your fellow physics majors!). This course is also a great way to decide if you really want to be a physics or astro major.
This probably won't live up to the name "Death Mech." Hard but reasonable.
otherinfo: This course is very demanding and will require at least 10 hours of preparation per week. PHY 207 provides an equivalent background for PHY 208 and subsequent courses.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Read assigned material before class. Do assigned homework problems.
prereqs: (PHY 103 and 104) or (PHY 105 and 106); one 200-level math course; or instructor's permission..
descrip: Classical Mechanics with emphasis on the Lagrangian method. The underlying physics is Newtonian, but with more sophisticated mathematics introduced as needed to understand more complex phenomena. Topics include the formalism of Lagrangian mechanics, central force motion and scattering, rigid body motion and non-inertial forces, small and coupled oscillations and Hamiltonian chaos. The course is intensive but rewarding.
title: Classical Mechanics

evals: Don't worry if you don't completely understand the concepts after lecture. Tully will happily help you during labs, and the more questions you ask the more you will get out of the course.

If you are at all interested in physics, programming, or electronics, take this course! I would recommend this to any physics major as an introduction to must-have skills and a taste of the world of high energy experiment.
otherreq: Open to Freshmen and Sophomores Only.
grading: Programming Assignments - 70%, Lab Reports - 30%
assgts: Weekly lab reports. One larger final programming project due on Dean's Date.
prereqs: Juniors and seniors will be considered on request, please email Karen Kelly (kkaras@princeton.edu). No programming experience is required. The programming projects are chosen to have interesting physics and to be open-ended. It should be possible for newcomers to achieve the main goals each week, while experts also get to explore more sophisticated, optional extensions. Each lab group will participate in a weekly 80 min. precept scheduled according to group member availability..
descrip: Introduction to modern data analysis using computational statistical tools for separating signals from background. The labs will involve experimental data collection, processing and visualization in Python using the Raspberry Pi interfaced to sensors. Multivariable discriminators and confidence levels for hypothesis testing will be applied to data samples from a range of different sources. Labs are drawn from measurements with sensor data, such as accelerometers and photodetectors and external sources including a radio-astronomy telescope, XRF analysis of Art Museum paintings, cosmic rays, LHC data, wind generators and other sources.
title: Computational Physics Seminar

evals: An interesting yet challenging course. Would recommend.
Bialek is a very entertaining lecturer, even if the course feels disjointed. His lecture notes are incredibly helpful, and the homework load is very manageable.
Bialek is one of the better professors in the physics department, so if he's teaching, you should take the class. It's the only physics class that didn't completely waste my time.
Bill's the man.

Boring subject. Prof had an enthusiastic tone during lectures, but personally it was hard to follow. Derivations were introduced without giving an introduction on what was being derived. Only recommend taking if you are a physics major.
Go to Professor Bialek's office hours and go to every lecture!

Go to his lectures. He is super awesome and great at explaining everything and deriving in a way that makes sense to most of the majors in the class. Probably wouldn't want to take it if it's not a requirement for your major though.

If Bialek is teaching, take it even if you're not a physics major. You will learn not just statistical mechanics and its impact on our understanding of the world (Bialek loves "mic drop" lecture endings where he blows everyone's minds with how amazing physics is) but also how it connects with areas like information theory, thermodynamics, maximal entropy probability distributions, etc.

Although Bialek is a theorist, he has a firm philosophy of experimentally motivated physics (rather than "just math on a board") and emphasizes a tight connection with the real world. If you're lucky and the Nobel prize winners in your year are related to statistical mechanics in some way, he might also deviate to discussing some of the work that won them the Nobel prize.
If you think physics is beautiful, take this course as soon as you possibly can. You will be entranced and awed. You also do some fun math and coding.

If you're a physics major, you have to take this. If not, but you're interested in physics and/or statistics, definitely consider this course! The workload is relatively light, and Professor Bialek's lectures are really unique and great!
It's an interesting course if you are stem focused.
Overall this is a good course that I would take again.
Physics majors are required to take this. I cannot think of a reason for anyone else to take this, however.

TAKE :) Bialek knows what he's doing. You walk away with a deep understanding of the statistical mechanics taught. He starts with the big picture so you understand where all the equations and physical arguments come from. This way, when we start going into the nitty gritty, it makes sense what direction we are talking and the final result makes sense! The only  draw back was we didn't get our midterms back :/
Take it! Cool physics with a great professor
Take it, it's fun
Take this class! Bialek is absolutely the best professor I've ever had. You will love this course because he is teaching it.
Take this class. Bialek is great.
Very interesting material plus Professor Bialek actually cares if you understand what's going on...which sometimes makes for rather slow lectures but is still a nice idea.

Very interesting, and Bialek's lectures are wonderful for explaining various subtleties in the subject. Problem sets are relevant for the most part, but it seemed like there was too much focus on the Ising model that never appeared on exams.

With a little working knowledge of probability and quantum mechanics, the course is not as difficult or as much work as some other physics courses. However, this class provides a rather insightful and profound introduction to thermal physics, touching on everything from thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, to information theory and renormalization. Professor Bialek has some rather interesting points to make in his notes and lectures, providing a nice twist on more straightforward thermal physics courses of study (i.e. Kittel and Kroemer).
You have to take this as a physics major, but if you're interested in upper level science this is a great one.
work with others and you will be fine.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 35%
assgts: Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: PHY 104 or 106; PHY 208.
descrip: A unified introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, both classical and quantum. Topics include heat engines, kinetic theory, black-body radiation, ideal Fermi and Bose gases and phase transitions.
title: Thermal Physics

evals: Always look at Sondhi. Don't blink too much, check the time, or do anything else. YOU WILL GET LOST. His handwriting is absolute bs. It looks like chicken scratch written in poop. He is condescending af. Like bruh lol. I like quantum mechanics, but screw Sondhi like high key. Only go to lectures to get a general idea of what you are covering. Read Townsend and some Sakurai for the majority of the course. Read Gottfried for group theory stuff. Suck it up. F the course.

Be prepared to sink a lot of time into this class, and be prepared to stay in lecture and focus for the full time, because leaving or not paying attention for even a few minutes can make things very difficult to understand.

DO NOT TAKE UNLESS YOU TRYNA TO DIE LMAO
bruh if you gotta take this class, Imma pray to every deity I know and you still be struck.
This the only class I ever took where you check the time on the clock and the professor already been filled up the chalkboard and started a new chapter in the book If you look at your notes when you write you gonna get lost because he write so fast, its like you gotta keep your eyes on the check 24/7 or you lose it.
This the only class I ever took where the pset took longer than my jp, like I coulda been doing things with my life but no smh... what type of problem you start at 6 am on a Saturday and you aint finish til 1 the next morning working nonstop and eating only twice. Bruh, ONE PROBLEM OUT OF TEN!
This the only class where I lowkey took out a whole forest wit all the paper I turned in, I fr used a whole package of printer paper on my homework. What kind of man you know let all the squirrels go endangered for his class?
This the only class where I needed Rosetta Stone to read that man handwriting like this man write and speak in hieroglyphics and don't want to translate for us. Half the time I ain't get no notes because them things on the board was unreadable you better have that 20/20 eyesight if you want to see.
This the only class I ever took where the professor ask you if you got that and pretend he dont see eeryone shaking they heads and saying no.
I dont know what they tryna to teach us in the physics department because I'm leaving this field I had enough of this. This the most disappointing class I ever taken wish I could have my whole semester back cuz I fr had to drop everything to keep up with this od class and I probably failed lmao
Don't take this class, unless you are a physics major, or are really really interested in quantum. In the latter case, it is probably better to read the book instead.
Don't take this course unless you have to

For non-majors: take only if you really really (really) want to. Approx. half of the material is dedicated to a more fundamental and theoretical treatment of QM (and introductory quantum field theory), and the other half is dedicated to various approximation methods (time-(in)dependent perturbation theory, variational method, WKB approximation).

Problem sets have traditionally ramped up especially towards the 3/4 mark of the semester (e.g. the worst problem set, over Thanksgiving no less, bludgeons everyone rather thoroughly - the page count varied between 10 and 40 pages for this particular problem set)

Go to the problem sessions because the TA's help a lot. Make sure you know the core principles because you will flounder later on if you do not. Get really good at integrals because you will be doing a ton.
If you're a physics major, you have to take this! Quite a lot of fun, but also a lot of work - if you've done PHY 208, this course will help unlock a better understanding of quantum mechanics!

It takes a lot of time and lectures are hard to follow, but jf you're thinking about taking it you probably have to! If you can grind through it you will learn lots of useful approximation techniques if nothing else.
Miserable course, but easy midterm. Only take if you are a physics major.

Overall, I enjoyed this course a lot even though it is quite difficult. If you're a physics major you have to take it... otherwise I guess you can take it if you're really interested in the subject material.
Sondhi's not the greatest teacher, but if your physics you're taking it so just read Townsend and Griffiths carefully and do all the examples.
Take it because you probably have to. If you don't, it might be a good idea to just read the rest of Griffiths.
Take it if you have to, don't if you don't.

The first half the class reviews PHY208 but focuses on a linear algebra approach to QM (using Townsend) instead of a calculus-based approach. The second half is applications of perturbation theory (Griffiths) and is significantly messier. Be prepared for problem sets of extravagant length in the second half of the course and some really nasty math. It's not pleasant, but unfortunately required if you are a physics major. Prof. Sondhi moves very quickly, so be prepared for some major scribbling. He's accommodating if you can't come to his normal office hours but can be difficult to follow in lecture at times.
Worth taking.
You'll learn a lot of quantum if you keep up with the material and think about it on your own time. Don't expect lectures to make everything super clear.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: One problem set consisting of 4-5 problems per week.
prereqs: PHY 208.
descrip: This course is a continuation of PHY 208. We will continue to develop the formalism of quantum mechanics and to explore its basis. We will apply our methods to phenomena from atomic, high energy, and condensed matter physics.
title: Introduction to the Quantum Theory

otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Approximately 30 pages of reading, along with about 5 problems.
prereqs: PHY 208, PHY 301 and PHY 305.
descrip: This survey course applies concepts from quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics to the properties of electrons in solids. Topics include phonons and lattice dynamics, electronic band structure, the tight-binding approximation, origin of exchange and magnetism, spin waves, Ginzburg Landau theory of phase transitions, and the BCS theory of superconductivity.
title: Modern Physics I: Condensed-Matter Physics

evals: Be ready to put in a lot of work. QFT requires serious reading on a weekly basis to keep up, and if you fall behind, the topics will get very difficult. The later topics in the course use every single earlier topic, which is somewhat of a different story from most other upper level physics classes at Princeton. Perhaps that is just the nature of QFT.
Take it

This is a very hard class, but super interesting! Keep up with the reading, and try to understand what Peskin and Schroder are saying, though sometimes it's hard. Verlinde isn't the clearest of teachers, but he's great if you have questions for him.
it's quite time-consuming, but you learn a lot from it
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Canonical and path integral quantization of quantum fields, Feynman diagrams, gauge symmetry, elementary processes in quantum electro dynamics, applications to condensed matter theory
title: Quantum Field Theory

evals: Don't slack off and put effort to learn the basic differential geometry covered at the beginning since having a good foundation on that makes deriving and analyzing the physical situations later in the course more streamline. The homeworks are not hard but can take a while to complete so don't start too late on them.
GR is a gorgeous theory, so definitely worth learning. Just be careful in that the course may not let you off easy on it.
Great course. The lectures are dry but informative. The textbook by Carroll is very easy to read, but doesn't follow the class perfectly.
Great first graduate class.

If there is any section of the course to really learn well, it is the first section on the math needed for GR. Without a solid understanding and ability to work with tensors, it will be hard to follow any of the applications in the rest of the course.

It's not too challenging for a physics grad course. If you have time before you take it, try to work your way through chapter 3 in Carroll, since the intuition in those sections is pretty challenging.

Take the course if you want an introduction to GR, but for a full complete introduction you will be required to read and research many things outside the realm of the course outline. Don't stick to Carroll as much as the course may suggest.
take it
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course gives an introduction to Einstein's theory of general relativity. No prior knowledge of general relativity will be assumed, and an overview of the differential geometry needed to understand the field equations and spacetime geometries will be given. Beyond this, topics covered will include black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmological spacetimes.
title: Introduction to Relativity

evals: I would recommend this class but note that it is a hard course with many hours of commitment required outside of class, so consider the intensity of other classes before deciding on taking this one.
TAKE THIS COURSE with Dr. Huse. He definitely knows the material and has much to offer beyond the topics in the course. Always willing to meet with you in his office.

The course was challenging but rewarding. I would recommend trying hard to keep up with understanding the concepts because I felt that this course moved quickly and builds on previous concepts more so than other physics courses I have taken.

This course gave me a very solid understanding of the big topics in condensed matter physics. The homework was very difficult, but often times was useful to help understand the material and highlight important results. I was debating between this and the 2-semester sequence offered by the EE department. With my background of 1 solid state class under my belt before I took this class, I think I made the right choice.

This course is loads of work and very difficult, but you certainly learn lots for all your effort. Huse is a good lecturer and the problem sets are rewarding, but they will take a loooong time. A strong background in quantum mechanics is necessary, and the final exam was extremely difficult.

Would definitely recommend. Prof. Huse gave helpful lectures and really good (if long) assignments. The class is paced very fast, but you'll get introduced to some pretty interesting and modern topics at the end of the course.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Electronic structure of crystals, phonons, transport and magnetic properties, screening in metals, and superconductivity.
title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Discussion of the old and new methods of quantum field theory with applications to statistical mechanics, turbulence, black holes, dS-space.
title: Selected Topics in Theoretical High-Energy Physics - Strings, Black Holes and Gauge Theories

evals: Awesome course. Norm will teach you so many super useful circuits and design techniques in a low stress class environment.
Excellent overview of basic circuits needed for any experimental physicist.  Taking this early in your career can save you hours in the lab by giving you the tools needed to make useful circuits.
Take it! Almost no work, an easy PDF, but I learned so, so much. It's a great course for the future, and you'll learn how to design and really apply circuits. Zero reason not to take.
Take this class early--your effort will save you in the future, whether you're building electronics for research or just need to understand what circuits can be capable of.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course is targeted for graduate students from all departments and undergraduate physics majors. It introduces students to the basic techniques used to design, build, analyze and test analog circuits as would be used in laboratory experiments. The course assumes a basic understanding of electromagnetism at the undergraduate freshman level. Emphasis is placed on building, testing and analyzing actual circuits during the weekly lab sessions.
title: Electronic Methods in Experimental Physics

evals:
American politics is not an average introductory course in the POL department. Having Prof. Staszak and Prof. McCarty teach the course simultaneously was a pleasure, but it also made lectures feel disjointed. Individually, the topics were interesting, but I found it hard to piece them together into a coherent argument or approach to the study of politics in the United States.

The readings were often interesting, but dense. As a result of the Constitutional Convention, it was difficult to get much clarification in precept (which was largely consumed by individual projects and debate, rather than discussion of lecture/precept).

Lastly, the expectations for assignments and exams for the course were often vague and ambiguous, making it difficult to succeed. In hindsight, I wish they had made it clear what to expect for the work in the course earlier than they did.

I really want to recommend the course, because I learned a lot about different aspects  of American politics but it was often disjointed and I think my experience could have been even better if the readings and lecture had been more thoroughly integrated into the course.
Awesome course! Not a lot of work, but you get out what you put in.
Be able to summarize the main points of each reading in a few sentences, since those speaking points will be discussed in precept and may show up on written examinations.
Be ready for a ton of readings!
Be sure to stay on top of your readings!

Decent course to take if you have to take it.  If it's just for fun, I might suggest taking a different class.  Nothing bad about it at all, just nothing amazing either.  Some interesting information covered, but not always delivered in the best way possible.

Definitely take this if you have any interest in what goes on politically in the US. Also, this course is also listed as WWS but really it is more politics so I don't think you need to take it before diving into a policy class in the Woodrow Wilson School. Don't skip lectures because they are good! Make sure you have the main points of all the readings because they are important for precept and exams.
Do not be afraid to talk up in precept! I was afraid sometimes because of other students who took the discussion over. But what you have to say is important, even if you think it may be wrong.
Do not take.
Do not take. A boring politics course.
Do the readings and attend the lectures.
Don't do all the readings. Only do the readings which the professors reference in lecture.
Don't take this class unless you have to. Lectures are very boring, readings are long and you finish the class feeling like you havent learned anything.

Don't take this. The lectures are terrible, the readings are way too numerous, and I found there was nothing to motivate me to stay engaged. If you like having no written assignments except the midterm, final, and dean's date paper, though, you might like this course.
Follow the reading and know the consititution.
Get a group together to share the readings, and relate the notes and lectures to the "Great Debates".
Good course to have, but not a good introduction to the politics department

I didn't hate the course, although there are definitely people who did. Don't take this course unless you're actually interested in the material. The readings suck and there are a lot of them. The assignments aren't that bad though.

I knew very little about politics coming in, so I found this class useful! It's not always the most interesting material (a lot of it is pretty fundamental), but the readings do go deeper into theory.
I went into this course as a perspective politics major. I left this course determined to never take another politics class. Don't take this course.
I would recommend the course as a good early departmental for a freshman or sophomore interested in majoring in politics.
I would strongly recommend this class if you even have a passing interest in American politics.
I would suggest this course to any prospective politics major or anyone interested in learning the basics of policy and politics within America.
If you already like american politics or its a departmental then go for it. Probably wouldn't take it randomly.

If you are going to take this course, pick and choose two topics from each week to focus on and only do the readings for those. There is simply too much reading to accomplish while taking 3 - 4 other courses.
If you want to learn introductory facts about american politics, definitely take!
If you want to understand the basic dynamics of politics in our country, I would definitely recommend taking this course.
If you're a politics major or thinking about it, take a more interesting course
Interesting if you like to learn about politics.
It was quite a bit of work, especially around midterms and deans date with a deans date and a final

It's very easy to get by in this course without doing any of the readings, but the readings are the most important part of the experience. Look for connections between the perspectives touched on in the readings from week to week and incorporate this into your midterm and final exam and you will be golden!
Make sure you take the key concepts from the readings, but you can get most of your info from lecture, so go to it. The strength of your writing is important to grading on papers and exams.
Not a bad way to fulfill the Woody Woo core requirement. Professor Staszak is significantly better than Professor McCarty and they share the lectures.

Not a huge time commitment if you neglect the readings. Add the readings in, and you've got a considerably time-consuming class on your hands. The material is interesting, no doubt, and the professors are great, but I would be cautious in recommending this class to anyone who is taking this as a distribution (especially engineering) as keeping up with readings can be remarkably difficult amidst already busy schedules. Having a strong understanding of American politics before taking this class would be extremely helpful.
Not the hardest course, not the easiest. Definitely one of the least engaging.
Only take if truly interested in the subject. The lectures are boring
POL 220 is a great course. Just be prepared to do a lot of reading.
Read the news
Readings are unnecessary. Nonetheless, they are always really interesting and definitely enhance the course experience. Do them if you have time.
Take another, more interesting POL class.

Take if you need to, it's not too bad. Lectures can be a bit dry at times as can readings, but I found a good amount of them interesting.  Loved Professor Staszak. Try to take notes on the readings (you can skip some unimportant ones) because you'll need to remember them for the exams.
Take if you want a very basic course on American politics.
Take it if you want a basic background in american politics.
Take it!
Take it- readings were interesting and you learn a lot about how to think about American Politics in different ways. Workload is very manageable.

Take this as a departmental course.  Not just a repeat of high school politics/am gov. course, but rather, surveys some of the political science literature on voting preferences and Congressional representation, the branches of governments, etc.  Lectures are not riveting however.
Take this class if it's relevant to your major. My only complaint is that lectures and readings were dry and hard to keep up with, which makes studying for the final difficult.
Take this class if you are at all interested in politics.

Take this course if it's a prerequisite or departmental. It's a good course. Stay on top of the readings because they can be 200  pages a week. But it does a good job of engaging students anywhere on a continuum from being well versed in politics or beginners.
Take this course if you are not sure whether or not you want to go into Politics. This could be indicative of your interest in a class like this. Midterm is take home, final is in class.
Take this course if you need to. Or take it p/d/f if you don't need it. This way you don't have to do as many readings - the readings are dry.
Take this course if you'd like to receive information on American politics, but beware - there are lots of readings each week. Both professors were very good lecturers!

Take this course, but be prepared to do readings, to take notes on readings, and to work hard. It is not as easy as its generalised title suggests. You will learn a lot, but if will not feel like you learn a lot. Much of what you learn will come in the last days before the finals, when you actually sit down and engage with all of the readings at once. If you can do this over time, during the semester, the course will be much more rewarding for you.

Take this course. It is pretty cool and always relevant -- you will always end up relating what they're teaching to things that are happening with our government today. There is almost zero workload as readings are not at all essential for precept success, and the take-home midterm is a walk in the park. Highly recommend.
The Constitutional Convention is an enjoyable alternative to heavy paper assessment throughout the semester.

The class is not too interesting, but is somewhat easy.  Slides are online so you don't have to go to all of the lectures.  Precepts aren't great, but Constitutional Convention at the end is interesting. Easy take home midterm and fair final.
The readings for this course are absolutely necessary to understanding the history of Politics in America, as well as they are crucial for the midterm and final.

This class is not difficult and includes some interesting concepts; however, lectures are not engaging. This course is good for freshmen and sophomores, but I would hesitate to recommend that a junior or senior take it because there are more intellectually stimulating courses out there.
This course can be a little boring at times but it's overall pretty easy. If you don't have a strong background in politics, then this would be a great course to take.

This course is very "meh"- not the best, not the worst. It's very very dry, but not particularly difficult. There are far more interesting courses at Princeton. I'd strongly encourage you to take another course if you can.

This is a decent class to take to fulfill as a distribution requirement, even without PDFing.  Readings and lectures are a bit dry but the material is not too difficult to understand.  There is very little week to week work aside from readings which makes it very manageable to take as an easy 5th class.
Try to split the readings with others. This is an especially helpful method for the upcoming exams.
Unless you're a diehard political person I would look to other POL courses.

Very similar to an AP Gov course. Not particularly difficult, even without having done any reading. You might want to take something else if you're familiar with the subject and looking to learn something new
Would not recommend because lectures were boring and seemed unnecessary. Nothing seemed cohesive and structured.
precept wasn't great but the course was interesting
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 150 pages of reading per week; one short paper.
descrip: An introduction to the institutions and political processes of American government and democracy. Topics will include the Constitution and American political tradition, federalism, political institutions, elections and representation, interest groups and social movements, civil rights and liberties, and the politics of public policy
title: American Politics

evals: A lot more intensive of a course than expected; reading difficult and different from many other pol theory courses. At times felt like it was a bit more "classics" than "pol theory" but learned a ton

A pretty good course if you're interested in the subject. If you take it, I would definitely try to get Professor Lane as a preceptor; she's a great lecturer and the one time she conducted my precept she was awesome.
An excellent class for reading the classics of Western political thought. Do not take if you do not have time for a ridiculous amount of reading, though.
Engaging, with a lot of reading. Professor Lane will help you with what you need help with. She knows her subject very well.
Enjoyed this course a lot - as always, you'll get more out of it if you do the reading!
Essential information for any person who wants to pursue or contemplate the "good life". Great syllabus and incredible lectures. It will take work, but the work is well worth it.

Gabby Girgis is a wonderful preceptor, and Prof. Lane's lectures are absolutely phenomenal. Her ability to connect classical, canonical thinkers to modern debates in the political realm today is illuminating, refreshing to say the least. Lane is incredible as a lecturer.

I took this course because I love politics and needed to fulfill my EM requirement. I was extremely bored and uninterested with the course material. Everything in the course is primary reading (and a lot of it) and all the lectures center on the primary readings.

If you're interested in the development of political thought, you need to take this course. It will provide an incredible foundation. However, you need to be willing to devote the time and effort to giving each author their due.
LOTS of reading, and a little frustrating if you're more pragmatic than theoretical (it is after all a theory class). Overall not a bad EM, and Professor Lane really cares about her students.

Prof. Lane is magnificent in lecture and gives extensive and valuable feedback on papers. She really goes above and beyond in helping you improve your writing and thought processes. All in all, it's a great course. That being said, be ready to work. There is a lot of difficult reading, and papers are held to high but fair standards. The final is take-home and open-book, but it's timed, so be sure to take very detailed reading notes that include page numbers (seriously, use lots of page numbers. During the exam, you won't have time to flip through the books to find that one crucial quote in your notes). You'll learn a lot about the material, but this is not a class you should take unless you're very interested in the subject and are willing to put a lot of time into it. Having a background in political theory, philosophy, or classics is useful. Not a good idea to take it only because you want an EM or need something to fill your schedule. It's a difficult class, but you'll get a lot out of it.
Students absolutely must complete each reading as they are the foundation of the course. Attending every lecture and precept will definitely allow the student to understand the material better.
Take it!
Take it. Its interesting, and it will help you determine whether political theory is your thing. Do not take for fun. It is not easy.
Take the course.

Take this class! Fair warning that it is pretty difficult and getting a good grade will be tough, but Prof. Lane is a great lecturer and really knows how to make the material engaging. Beyond the material itself (which is essential for getting a good background in early political thought), there is a lot of writing and helpful feedback, so your writing ability will improve greatly if you put in the effort.

Take this course if you are interested in pursuing something relevant to political theory. It isn't a course you would want to take simply out of general interest. It was the course I dedicated most of my time to this semester, so see it as a time commitment. There is a LOT of reading involved, but I found them all to be very relevant and engaging. All of that being said, Professor Lane is an amazing professor and you will most certainly learn a lot from her. This course taught me a lot and helped me see some of these texts we studied in an entirely different light.
Take this course! You get a fantastic overview of the greatest political thinkers and how they have addressed some of humanity's most important questions.
This course is a must for anyone interested in political theory!

This has been a life-changing course for me. Having never really studied the classics before, and being quite full of prejudice (particularly scorn for the middle ages and christians) I was amazed by how much I learned in this course. Professor Lane is truly a gem, as she not only has immense expertise in this field, but also a real gift for teaching. She puts in a huge amount of effort, structuring the course in a way that makes it very easy for students to follow (lecture notes broken down by section handed out in lecture and also posted on blackboard with bullet points covering the discussion, reading guides with questions you can fill out for your learning pleasure and guide your study, mandatory office hours appointments to discuss all paper proposals before writing the finals). Professor Lane is also a simply fantastic lecturer. She really brings out the best of these thinkers; when you speak to people who studied them elsewhere, you will be stunned by how many of the key arguments they missed that you got because you had Professor Lane to guide you.
