Be thankful to have this unbelievable opportunity and leap for it.
This is an excellent class, with an excellent professor.  In my very humble opinion this class should be required of all undergraduates.
take it take it melissa lane is a fantastic prof
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 200-250 pages of reading per week. Two papers of 2000 words each are required, as well as a take-home final examination. There may be additional / brief writing assignments in precepts.
descrip: A study of the great works of political theory in four periods: ancient Greece, including Athenian democracy, Thucydides, Plato and Aristotle; ancient Rome from republic to empire, including Polybius, Cicero, Seneca, and Marcus Aurelius; medieval Christian political thought in Augustine, Aquinas, Marsilius, and others; and a brief survey of Renaissance meditations on classical themes. Fundamental topics are examined, including nature and convention; constitutional analysis, including democracy, oligarchy, tyranny, kingship, and the mixed constitution; property, virtue, law, and republicanism; church and state; consent and representation.
title: Ancient and Medieval Political Theory

evals: A must take, especially if you have any interest in going to law school. Great, thought-provoking lectures.

As a science major, I'd say that this was the best course I've taken at Princeton, but probably also one of the hardest. The level of discussion is incredibly high, the material is fascinating, and you will be trained to think in a slightly new way. I could not recommend a course more!

Awesome pdf. Readings essentially become optional if you pdf and minimal effort is required on the 3 papers you write throughout. Bobby George is a ride or die legend and will blow your mind with some of his Con Law/American history knowledge
Be careful of the preceptor you pick. Work hard and fast to learn how to write the papers for this course in the way they're supposed to be written.
Be sure to do all of the reading.

Choose your preceptor wisely and understand that the course is taught by a conservative professors and a team of largely conservative preceptors. There is more reading than logistically possible to adequately prepare. If you have the time, I'd recommend fitting in a few semesters in law school before taking the course as I'm sure that would've helped me immensely!

Definitely take if it sounds interesting. Tougher POL departmental but very intellectually stimulating. Makes you think about the constitution in a new way and Professor George and the preceptors (who are all lawyers) are fantastic. Lives up to the hype for sure.

Despite the hype, this class is perhaps not a "must-take" as has been advertised unless one is especially interested in constitutional law or Supreme Court cases. Nonetheless, Professor George is a phenomenal professor, and his lectures are worth sitting in on even if you aren't taking the class for credit. Tough but rewarding.
Do all the readings and attend all the lectures. If you miss a lecture, you really are missing out.
Do not take this if you do not have extensive knowledge of judicial theory. If you don't then you should PDF-MAKE SURE GEORGE ISNT YOUR PRECEPTOR!!!!
Do the readings, be engaged, and work hard!
Do the readings.  This isn't a class you can take passively if you want to learn.
Excellent, intellectually stimulating course with unnecessarily excessive grade deflation
Great course. All citizens - or residents - should take to understand the Constitution under which we live.
I would only advise students interested in studying constitutional law after graduation to take this course on a graded basis.
I would recommend this course to anyone, whether they be interested in law or not, and whether they are a Politics major or not.
If you need an SA and aren't afraid to PDF a class that's decently hard then take this course. It's very interesting and relevant. Everyone should have some knowledge of how our government works.

If you want to understand American government. If you want to have to think very hard about controvertial issues that you would usually just support without even questioning, take this class. Lots of work but I am better because of it, and no bias in the course at all.
If you're interested in law or American politics at all this class is a must-take.  It's famous for a reason.
If you're pre-law, politics, or liberal and haven't felt your views challenged by someone smarter than you in a while, take this class. Otherwise...
If youre willing to do all the reading, its a must take. A lot of work, but very fulfilling!
Incredible, thought-provoking lectures. Grading can be very harsh and inconsistent though. Looking back, I might have been much happier had I PDF'd.

Just take it (Come prepared to every lecture such that you could answer his questions--and put yourself and there and try to!)--as for the essays, make sure that YOU ALWAYS ENGAGE WITH THE BEST OPPOSING ARGUMENT--you'll get a B at max otherwise, and the reason the course is so engaging anyway is that it forces you to realize there are super good reasons for adopting positions entirely counter to your own.
Learned a lot! The readings are very interesting and Prof. George is an incredible lecturer. The grading is harsh but the material is worth studying even if you don't get the A.
Leave your political views at the door and think about the theory alone (not that you can ever fully separate those). Get Darren as your preceptor.

Lectures are well-done, but the real learning happens in precept--and Con Interp precept counts among my best Princeton academic experiences. Dr. Madigan moderated so well, motivating us to carry the conversation almost all the time, and I had the pleasure of listening to my brilliant classmates--a couple of strong conservatives, a couple of strong liberals, and a few in between--present strong defenses of varying positions on controversial issues from abortion to affirmative action to marriage, all of which hinge on what the role of the Supreme Court is and should be, the central question of the course. Having read and discussed all sides of these important topics I had never before considered carefully, I am walking out of Con Interp with my own convictions built on the evidence we encountered, a better citizen for life. Perhaps the diversity of viewpoints represented in my precept was a rare blessing, but in any case that panorama of perspectives strengthened my critical thinking phenomenally, and I would urge you to enroll in Con Interp to, hopefully, experience the kind of magic that we came to this school seeking.

Look for repeating patterns in arguments throughout the cases you read that exemplify each side's positions, the precepts should help with this but actively doing it on your own should help understanding. If you have any interest in how the Constitution works and why the Supreme Court has decided the way it has (and are willing to read, think, and work a lot), take this class.
Only take this class if you want to be a lawyer or are blindly in love with American institutions

Prof. George will make you question everything. This class is legendary, and with good reason. And if you've never understood conservatives, this is a great place to start (turns out they're actually kinda smart).

Readings are fascinating. Grading quite hard. Learn a lot about legal reading, some legal debate/arguing, little about legal writing. Unfortunately, grade is 80%-90% based on your legal writing. 

George is solid, not spectacular. Impressive delivering lectures with no notes. Lofty rhetoric often trumps fine-tuned points, but when he focuses in on legal particulars, is quite engaging and provocative. 

Would recommend to PDF; grading is tricky given prep they give for what you are graded on.
Really opens you to seeing Constitutional issues from more than one viewpoint (a priority of George's). Take this course if you want to be challenged in a meaningful way.
Strongly recommended. Just be prepared for lots of readings and long writing assignments. But if you read, pay attention in lecture and so on you should do fine. Grading is very fair.
TAKE IT.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! And do everything you can to get into Professor George's precept!!!! This is an amazing course and is a once in a lifetime experience!  If you want to go to Law School, if you want to know more about the US government, if you just want to learn from an amazing scholar TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!
Take it early. Don't wait until senior year. Dedicate time to it and you will do well.
Take it if constitutional law is your interest. Seemed a little overwhelming for some other people in the class who didn't have as much previous exposure.
Take it if you are interested in law at all! If you PDF it, it'll be very manageable and rewarding still.
Take it!
Take it! And do the readings, otherwise there's no point.

Take it! It's not an easy A (and I'm not expecting an A-range grade in general), but if any course is worth the GPA drop, it's this one. Professor George is a REMARKABLE lecturer, amazingly neutral (and this is coming from me, someone who's read his books and found them quite infuriating), and he presents the material in an engaging, thought-provoking way that forces you to think about issues in a more nuanced light. Put effort into papers, because those really force you to think about the core issues more deeply than you do in precept, and regardless of the grade you get, they're definitely worth engaging in just for the intellectual exercise (coming from a STEM major who took 6 classes, and who admittedly didn't really prioritize all the readings for this course). I mean it - and now that the class is PDFable, there's even less reason not to take it!
Take it. I've never looked forward to attending another class more. If you manage your time well and don't do all the readings the night before precept, it's really not a lot of work.
Takes work, grading is harsh. It will be easier if you have interest in the subject matter.

The only reason I liked this class was because of my personal interest in constitutional law. I found George to be a horrible lecturer, and Nieli was not a coherent preceptor. But the textbook is really good and papers were great in allowing one to apply what they had learned. Still, without an interest, I'm sure anyone taking this class would have hated it.

These were among the most interesting and nuanced lectures that I have experienced at princeton. Professor George is of the highest caliber of instructors I have came across. I highly recommend taking this course despite it not being an easy A, which I am typically quite fond of.
This class is hard work, but the subject matter is timely, intellectually stimulating, and very relevant.
This class isn't as much work as people say. The cases are amazing to read and the chance to read both sides of so many issues is way important.

This class lives up to the hype. Professor George is legendary for a reason - he really inspires you to think. There is a challenging but reasonable workload. If you get a chance to take this course, even if it is PDF or audit, do it.

This course is honestly one of my favorite that I've taken at Princeton. I pretty much disagree with all of Prof George's opinions which made the course all the more stimulating and interesting. Take it!!! Yes, it's challenging but completely worth it.

This course will fundamentally change and deeply inform the way in which you view our Constitution. The content, course readings, and paper prompts are all excellent. Furthermore, the culture of the class is such that students often discuss the course outside of class (and in the best of ways). However, a word of caution, I found the course to be intentionally deflated grade-wise. Nevertheless, I found the course to be extremely rewarding, and if you're willing to put in the time necessary to engage with the material I'm sure you will as well.

This is an amazing class that will teach you about and force you to think about the major issues in the American constitutional traditions. I highly recommend it for anyone at all interested in American politics and institutions. Do know, however, that it is a very difficulty graded class and requires polished, detailed writing to succeed. Read all of the cases and take notes on their main points so you can keep them straight.
Very harsh grading. Also very biased presentation of material. I did not think it lived up to the hype, and honestly made me very mad a lot of the time.

You will think at a high level about methods in Constitutional Interpretation, but always through the lens of a very specific read on the Constitutional tradition that I often found ahistorical. Its a great way to read the important cases though, which every American should do.
don't be intimidated by the reading load! definitely doable.

t was a good introduction to some of the very difficult issues surrounding constitutional interpretations. It requires you to think hard and pay attention to details, and while the lectures can be a bit tedious at the end you do get a sense for what's going on with the constitution
this is a great but difficult course. a lot depends on your preceptor too, so try and get a good one. don't take this course and expect an a, you might get it but its tough to do
otherinfo: (1) Please note that precepts will meet once a week, for an hour and fifty minutes. (2) Students who receive permission to audit the course MUST attend precepts.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Papers - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Cases and articles; one or two short paperbacks. About 150 pages per week, but must read very carefully--mostly opinions by U.S. Supreme Court.
descrip: A study of the structure of the American constitutional system and of the meaning of key constitutional provisions. Students will critically evaluate competing theories of, and approaches to, constitutional interpretation.
title: Constitutional Interpretation

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: About 200 pages of reading per week. Students will also be expected to read a major newspaper regularly.
descrip: Topics to be covered include the origin, nature, uses and limits of presidential power; the presidential selection process; the relationship between the President and other significant political actors--Congress, the Press, executive branch agencies, and the public; presidential accountability and the importance of presidential personality.
title: The Presidency and Executive Power

evals: Absolute must-take if you have any interest in China! Material is well-organized, clearly presented and highly engaging, and Prof Truex is very kind and approachable. Do bear in mind that half the course is modern Chinese history (late 19th-20th century) so you might find it repetitive if you already have a background in that, but the context is important and once the course delves into present-day politics it's extremely fascinating and gives you lots of insights you won't just get from reading the news (in fact, it teaches you to question a lot of what media/politicians speculate China will do).

Always attend lecture!  Professor Truex covers the material in-depth and presents important, new information that isn't represented in the readings. 
The readings are not light, but are full of interesting material.  

TAKE THE CLASS
Chinese politics is a fascinating and topical subject matter. Everyone should take this course and gain a better understanding of how and why China's politics is the way it is.
Definitely take it! Really interesting and important, and not a hard course.
Definitely take this class!!
Definitely take this.

I cannot recommend this class more highly. It is an absolutely necessary area to study, taught by an excellent and engaging professor who, having gone here for undergrad, has an excellent understanding of student life and what is fair and unfair for him to ask of us.
I really enjoyed this class! Definitely take it if you have any interest in Chinese politics. Professor Truex is amazing. One of my favorite classes at Princeton.

I would definitely take this course!! Professor Truex is great, and I learned a lot. I still enjoy IR more than domestic politics, but it was very interesting. I would highly recommend it if you're interested in China, politics, etc.

I would highly recommend taking Chinese Politics. Even if you don't have any particular interest in China, it's very useful to learn about the workings of authoritarian systems, not to mention all of the the theoretical frameworks that political scientists use to analyze them.

If you have any interest in contemporary China and its internal politics, take this course! Prof. Truex is an extremely engaging and approachable professor, and you will learn a lot from this course. Even if you know nothing about China (or a lot), the course is designed in a way that everyone can benefit.
If you're interested, take this class for sure.
It is an awesome course and you will learn so much about China and its history/politics. Take it!
It's one of the best courses you will ever take in Princeton. And Prof. Truex is one of the most engaging, interesting, and friendly prof you will ever have!

Make sure you read the news on China to keep up with what's going on. It will help you put what you learn into perspective. Come in knowing that this is a course that focuses very much on research frameworks and specific research designs more than Chinese politics per se. If this doesn't sound appealing to you, you'll learn more from a Chinese history class and from keeping up with the news.
Not too hard of a class and super engaging material. Truex is young and fun and presents material well. Readings and workload are generally light but critical for course.
Not worth the time or effort and can only be made slightly more bearable if you PDF the course.

Professor Truex is an amazing lecturer - very organised, engaging, and funny. TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN. Response papers are not that much work at all and there's a lot of freedom in choosing what you write, however in order to do well on the midterm you have to finish all readings
Sure but not as good as spring 2015 from what I hear. Also there are a lot of tryhards in this class, and a lot of PDFs so its really easy to get average but like to do well its eh

TAKE IT! Best course to take if you have a reasonable workload and arguably a doable 4th/5th class. If you're on the fence - go to the first lecture and I assure you that your hesitation will be changed within minutes.
TAKE THIS CLASS NOW.  IF YOU NEVER LEARNED ABOUT CHINA BEFORE TAKE THIS CLASS - CHINA IS IMPORTANT. PROFESSOR TRUEX IS AMAZING

TAKE THIS CLASS! Even if you don't even think you're interested in China -- take this class! Professor Truex will convince you to become interested in China and learn about its complexities. Brilliant class.
Take it and don't look back
Take it if you're interested.
Take it! Learn about China and get to know Rory, who is truly a fantastic professor and an even cooler dude.

Take it.  Super interesting course.  Truex is an amazing lecturer.  The readings are really interesting.  Make sure to read the studies as you go along and get good notes on them in precept, otherwise it will come back to bite you in the final
Take it. Truex is awesome
Take notes on the readings and try to bring the different ideas together.
Take the class if you're interested! Prof Truex is a great guy and it'll only make the class better if you have him as your preceptor!

Take this class for sure. Lots of native Chinese hurt the class because they wreck the curve (48/50 gets you 2nd quartile on the midterm), but if you study hard and stay up to date on chinese politics, you'll be fine.
Take this class! It is interesting and not an overwhelming amount of work.

The actual grades in the class are based more off your ability to make an argument than the material itself. The readings are necessary to truly succeed in this class, but you can skim by with little effort

This class has a lot of reading and, at times, can be pretty challenging. However, I learned so much from this class -- not only about the subject matter (Chinese politics), but also about academic research and evaluating research (more than I've been taught during any other class at Princeton). The professor is an amazing lecturer and really tries to connect with the students. Would definitely recommend taking this class.

This course is excellent. I had very high expectations for this course, and this course certainly exceeded them. Professor Truex is an absolute gem at this school. Lectures were very crisp, and the slides were very well-organized and comprehensive. Precepts were engaging and not super stressful. Readings were interesting and manageable.

Definitely go to office hours, and try to get to know Professor Truex. He is very young, and can relate to students much more so than older professors. The grading is not super easy, but this class is totally worth it.

This course is hands down the best organized course I've ever taken at Princeton. Clear instruction from Prof and preceptor, clear expectations, intriguing materials, broad range of topic covered about historical and contemporary China in a critical yet unbiased fashion. Highly recommend all students to take Prof. Truex's class!

This is a very good course and Truex is really a unique, special professor at Princeton. Get to know him well--go to office hours--and engage with the material. Definitely a great course for freshman or sophomores interested in possibly majoring in Woody Woo or Politics. A lighter class for upperclassmen with a heavy course load.
This is an amazing course. Take it.
This was by far my favorite class that I've taken over 7 semesters at Princeton! If you have any interest at all in the subject matter (or even if you don't), you should really consider taking it!
Tough course, professor is great though
Very gentle politics class for non politics students.
definitely take this class if you have any interest at all. also try not to get behind on the readings.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: The reading assignments will total about 150 pages per week. You will also be expected to stay up to date on developments in Chinese politics. You will write three short, two-page response papers over the course of the semester to facilitate precept discussion. There will be also be a midterm and final exam.
prereqs: All students interested in China are welcome. No previous knowledge of China/Chinese is required..
descrip: This course provides an overview of China's political system. We will begin with a brief historical overview of China's political development from 1949 to the present. The remainder of the course will examine the key challenges facing the current generation of CCP leadership, focusing on prospects for democratization and political reform. Among other topics, we will examine: factionalism and political purges; corruption; avenues for political participation; village elections; public opinion; protest movements and dissidents; co-optation of the business class; and media and internet control.
title: Chinese Politics

evals: A good course for anyone interested in political economy from a more political standpoint (as opposed to a purely economic one). The readings really are essential to a solid understanding of the course content, but if you do them in a reasonable timeframe, the lectures are quite worthwhile. Professor Ahmed is really knowledgable in his field, so ask questions! Prepare to think critically. Memorizing the models and reciting information won't get you very far in this class, but it's worth your time to put in the effort.
A good course with good readings, recommended for politics major, not for economics ones.

I would recommend this course anyone interested in international economics and international economic policy. The course is engaging and provides a great opportunity to develop a good understanding of economic concepts.
Interesting course. Manageable workload

This course grounds your knowledge about things you really ought to know, and are presumed to know when reading newspapers. Lectures a bit dry, but the lecture slides are great.
You learn the major debates in international trade and finance, and wrestle with evaluating the effects of globalization. 
Xander is a really approachable preceptor. And Prof Ahmed is a wonderful person -- would recommend getting to know him personally.
Would recommend to economics majors and politics majors.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Approximately 100-150 pages of reading per week; one paper; in-class midterm exam; and a take-home final exam.
descrip: This course examines how politics affects the international economy and vice-versa. The course will apply theories and tools of political economy to explore some of the following questions: who wins and loses from international trade and finance? How does globalization affect domestic politics (e.g., the 2016 election, regulations, inequality, environment) in developed and developing countries? Who sets the 'rules' under which the global economy operates? How influential are international organizations like the WTO and the IMF? These issues are explored with reference to economic and political theories, history, and contemporary events.
title: International Political Economy

evals: Absolutely take a course with Gary Bass!!!!. He's an outstanding lecturer and person. If you can, be in his precept. He's brutally honest, but you will learn so much. He cared about each student and really tried to make sure the precept catered to the students interests. If you are in his course, go to office hours. He gives great advice and is very open to talking to students. I absolutely recommend this course, for humanities and science majors alike. I took this Freshman Fall, and it wasn't too hard or unmanageable. It was a challenge, but that made it all the more worth it. The lectures do go over a lot of the reading, so while there is a lot of reading, it's fascinating and the broad background reading isn't 100% necessary to read.
Absolutely take this course. Prof. Bass is a complete beast.

Aside from all the implied advice for success in this course (attendance, reading, etc.) it is essential that students remain up-to-date on current events as they take up a decent portion of our quiz and test.
BEST CLASS EVER. TAKE IT.

Bass does a great job at bringing the theoretical and tangible aspects of war together. He's a dramatic lecturer and the readings are a pleasure to read! Strongly recommend, there's not too much work.

Bass is a fabulous lecturer and the content of this class is very interesting. He emphasizes current events along with doing very in depth analysis of case studies. Fabulous IR class, take if you have any interest in foreign policy. (p.s. I'm not a pol major)

Bass is an engaging, authoritative lecturer. The course definitely has some rigor to it, but don't be shy if politics isn't your field -- I did fine as a science major, and this is stuff all informed citizens should know about. Know your current events/leaders of the world before tests. The essay(s) are all about having a strong argument -- even if you could argue either way, they really want you to pick a side and go with it.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Bass is an amazing lecturer, super funny, interesting, and knowledgeable! I had no previous experience in international relations courses, but I really enjoyed this. Like any upper level politics class, there is a decent amount of reading but most of it is pretty interesting. Definitely would recommend.

Definitely take this, even if you're not into politics. This class gives a really good insight into the status of the world today, is VERY relevant to current issues, and helps you be a better citizen of the world. Professor Bass is an amazing lecturer whose sassy quips and awesome stories keep everybody engaged. Loved it!
Do the Readings!
Do the readings and attend lecture.
Do the readings! Stay on top of them, or else it's easy to get behind.
Do the readings. Work with your preceptor on the paper - start very early. Enjoy the lectures.
Excellent class for POL concentrators, even if you haven't taken the introductory course for international relations.
Gary Bass gives excellent lectures, but avoid Nhung Bui as a preceptor. Simply the worst I had in my four years at Princeton.
Good but not great. Bass's Human Rights class is way better in terms of lectures and readings.
Good class. Do the work. Can really clear things up on how the world works.
Great and important class to take. Useful information to know, great readings, good lectures, good precept debates, and stuff is graded pretty favorably.
Highly recommend. Take it! Will broaden your perspective and make you a "world citizen," (or at least send you on your way).

I would greatly recommend this class. For anyone considering Woody Woo or Politics, it's an excellent exploration of conflicts, wars and their origins- an integral part of our history. But also for anyone who is simply interested in trying something new, this would be a great class for interesting lectures, helpful readings, and a knowledge of a subject matter that is valuable to have regardless of major or field.

I would highly recommend taking this course.  It is highly informative, and can really alter your worldview, but is also highly objective from a political point of view, which can sometimes be difficult to find in humanities courses.

If you are interested in the field of IR and war theories, this course is must.
This course will give you the whole view of the theories and analytical tool for conflicts and crisis throughout the history.
It is a good class.  Lectures are great, but be aware that Professor Bass is a little full of himself, and that sometimes annoyed me, so it might annoy you as well.

Keep up with the news as you will be able to see the concepts you are learning play out quite intricately. Attend all lectures because Gary Bass is awesome and go to your precepts not only for your participation mark but also to have fun and be inspired.
Know your concepts and go to lecture: it's worth it.
Make sure to actively engage in precepts.
Pro tip: go to every lecture because Gary Bass is a freaking gem. Also, because lectures cover a good chunk of the obscene amount of readings he assigns, so you can do some triage with your time.
Professor Bass is a fantastic lecturer who is incredibly engaging and inspiring, explains the material very well, and has interesting side stories and digressions. One of my absolute favorites.
Professor Bass is a great lecturer. Lectures are awesome- definitely the most enjoyable part of the class. There is a lot of reading, so make sure you try to keep on it.
Quite good. A bit heavy on the theory the first half, but Bass is excellent. Readings can be heavy too - I would suggest trimming them a little bit.

Spectacular course with a spectacular professor. Bass is a stellar lecturer and preceptor; he's engaging, organized, hilarious, and gives off just the right amount of that sassy/arrogant academic vibe. Unless you really hate reading (there's a lot of it), it's an easy (but time-consuming) course. The concepts are intuitive and fascinating, and the readings are mostly straightforward and interesting. You can definitely get by with skimming historical case studies. The exam was very fair, and the only real danger is a 15-page research paper on a war of your choice. All in all, there's not much of a reason not to take this class. It's a fairly easy SA that's great for POL and HIS majors. The workload is certainly manageable if you don't fall behind on reading.

TAKE THIS CLASS RIGHT NOW. I learned so much and loved Professor Bass so much I signed up for his course the next semester right away.  Absolutely imperative for anyone who wants to learn about conflict resolution, politics, and history.

TAKE THIS CLASS! Gary Bass is a phenomenal lecturer, and he makes the already interesting subject material even more fascinating by being such a great lecturer. Yes there are high expectations and a good amount of work with long readings, the research paper, quiz, etc., but these are all totally worth it for how great the class is. I am a much more informed person after having taken this and feel this is honestly one of the more useful classes I've taken at Princeton because you learn so many important theories that help you understand international relations and foreign policy. Take it!

TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Bass is an incredible lecturer--the workload is standard for a politics course. Writing the research paper, though tedious, was an thought-provoking experience, especially for underclassmen who may be writing their first real paper of college. The readings are helpful and interesting, precepts are extremely well run, and tests are fair. Professor Bass will leave you with goosebumps every time you leave a lecture. Excellent class.
TAKE THIS COURSE. Lectures and readings are excellent, exams and papers are fair.
Take it if you think you'll put the work into doing the readings most of the time and the paper.
Take it! Gary Bass is an amazing teacher, its a well designed class, and you'll learn a lot of crucial information about our world.
Take it, the more work you put into it, the more you'll get out of it
Take it. He is a life changing professor. The course is a lot of reading and it is difficult, but if you put in the effort, you learn things that will stay with you for life.

Take it. It's important material for everyone (I'm an engineer); a class likes this makes you a better citizen. Gary Bass is a great lecturer, precepts are actually productive and not just re-hashing of the readings, and everything is very interesting and relevant to today. Part of the required reading is keeping up-to-date with the New York Times. It's also not a very hard class to do well in if you do the readings and pay attention in class, but if you want to get the most out of it, you ought to put in some effort. It's not an "easy A" class, but you could probably get a B without a lot of effort.
Take it. Lectures will have you really thinking and really laughing. The reading is a lot but it's doable if you stay on top of them. 8.5/10 would recommend.
Take it. Whether you're a foreign-policy person or just want to be aware of what's going on in the world this class is worth it. Amazing lectures
Take notes
Take this class. Bass is the best.
Take this course! Do the reading, participate in precept, and go to lecture. Professor Bass is incredible!  You will not regret taking this course.
Take this course.  It is a lot of work, but it is worth the work and you will learn a lot of interesting material.
The course is a good amount of work, but very rewarding. It will challenge you, but if you like a fair challenge, it will motivate you and you can get an A.
The topics are extremely interesting. Be caught up on current events.
This class is amazing! You learn a lot. You gain an understanding of IR, history, and politics all with an incredible professor
This course is a lot of work. The readings are complex and you must keep up with the NY Times throughout the entire semester.

This course offers the most valuable information that I've come across in my four years at Princeton and it made me feel prepared and knowledgeable about the world around me more than any other course. Lectures are actually enjoyable, which is quite high praise for such a heavy and substantive topic. You'll learn a lot of things you really need to know as a Princeton graduate. Highly, highly recommend.

This course was actually pretty great. I took it because I want a Political Economy Cert and was looking for an interesting Pol class. I didn't do the readings and it all has turned out fine. Just find friends in the course which can summarize the big points for you. Bass is a good lecturer too. Take precept with Tyler if you can.

This is a great course to take, very interesting lectures, a lot of reading. If you don't want to spend too much time on this course, highly recommend a taking it pass/fail. The lectures are great, the precepts not great, the tests are long and hard. If you take it definitely ask someone who has taken the course before for tips.

This is a must take course, and I highly recommend it for anyone with even the remotest interest in international affairs or war. Professor Bass is amazing and does such a great job lecturing and making the material relevant. Do the reading if you want to do well on the quiz and final, and start the paper early in order to do enough research. Also, read the NYT or Economist to do well on the current events questions.
This is a really good POL course if you're at all interested in war.
This is an interesting and engaging course.  However, if you are taking the course because of Professor Bass, I would recommend taking Human Rights instead because the lectures are better.
Very interesting! you learn a ton! im very glad i took it. Expect it to be hard and requires a lot of work, but overall worth taking

Would definitely recommend if you're able. I'm a COS major and was planning to PDF it but I liked the material so much that I ended up going to every lecture and doing most of the readings, so I didn't PDF. You won't regret taking it.

Would highly recommend this course!! Go to every lecture and try to do the readings as much as you can, just because they are interesting. Most importantly, though, READ the New York Times!! It definitely left me with a new habit that is good for the mind and soul.

You should absolutely take this course! Prof. Bass is a great professor and totally changed my intended major.

The readings are not overwhelming and he covers mostly everything important in class. There is only one real essay and it's not due until after fall break rather than before during midterms. Don't let yourself miss taking this class because of fears over the workload.

I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in international relations, politics, war, or what it means to be a voter.
amazing PDF and very little work to worry about. readings are not vital just skim
amazing lectures, definitely worth taking for Professor Bass
take - you should learn about this topic and read the news in general
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 10%, Papers - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 200 pages of reading per week.
descrip: Why do states and peoples go to war? Conversely, how can war be avoided? This course surveys some of the most important explanations--including human nature, the anarchic international system, domestic politics, economics, technology, nationalism and terrorism--and evaluates them in light of historical wars, and of crises resolved short of war. Cases include the Peloponnesian War, the Napoleonic Wars, World War I, World War II, the Cuban missile crisis, ex-Yugoslavia's wars, and September 11.
title: Causes of War

evals: Definitely take it if interested. Prof. Achen is great and grades nicely.
Definitely take this course! It's very exciting to learn about the Tea Party during this time, and Prof. Achen is awesome!
I think the most valuable resource of the entire course is Professor Achen himself. I enjoyed hearing his thoughts more than anything else.

Take this class! It's a lot of reading but its enjoyable. Professor Achen really makes you think, but you will come out of it with a better understanding of the Republican Party and the political landscape in general.
Take this course.  Professor Achen is great.

The course material is interesting but the seminars can be kind of boring. If you're interested in learning about movements outside of the Tea Party, the populists and the abolitionists, this may not be the right course.
not a hard course, and interesting topics
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Four short papers. One final paper.
descrip: Why do political cleavages often divide along lines of race and ethnicity? Does human psychology tend towards 'groupism'? How do government institutions like schools, police and elections increase or decrease the salience of various ethnic and religious boundaries? This course investigates the relationship between identity, groups and politics in the U.S. and around the world. We will consider theories of group identity development; assess empirical approaches to the study of racial and ethnic groups in politics and look at how politically relevant aspects of identity can be measured for conducting original research (JPs or Senior Theses).
title: Seminar in American Politics - Race and Ethnicity in Comparative Context

evals: Do the readings and go to office hours. Great course to learn more about IR.

If you are IR/international politics major, and deepen your knowledge and analytical skill on the subject, this course is for you. 
Professor Gowa is super helpful. Go to her office hour and you can deepen your understanding even more. 
You can sharpen and make your knowledge on the subject more sophisticated throughout discussions and presentations.

I think although the level of lecture is not super high (basic game theory etc), keeping up with the  reading, discussion and presentation is tough and demand your basic understanding on IR.
Such a great course.  More rigorous/in depth than the introductory IR courses.  Professor Gowa is incredibly knowledgeable and a wonderful teacher.
This is a good course if you have background knowledge in the area and want to go into more depth!
otherinfo: This seminar is not open to students who have previously taken POL 381.
grading: Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 40%
assgts: Approximately 200 pages of reading per week; Two quizzes, a final exam, two short papers (about 8-10 pps)
descrip: This course is an introduction to conflict and cooperation in international politics. It emphasizes the impact of the anarchic international system on patterns of conflict and cooperation across nations, issues, and time. It spends roughly equal amounts of time on war and trade. It also considers the role of domestic factors in international politics, but it privileges the role of the system in explaining outcomes. Students will be introduced to elementary game theory, the use of quantitative data, and trade theory.
title: Seminar in International Relations - Conflict and Cooperation in International Politics- Security and Trade

grading: Papers - 100%
descrip: This seminar investigates ideas of individual and collective self-determination in modern political thought.The first part of the course investigates individual self-determination in the thought of Kant and J.S. Mill, then turns to the theories of autonomy put forward more recently by Joseph Raz and other contemporary philosophers. The second part looks at collective self-determination, where we will study the work of Jean Jacques Rousseau, as well as contemporary defenders of nationalism and democracy.
title: Problems in Political Theory - Self-Determination

grading: Papers - 75%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: A general introduction to the field of comparative politics, with an emphasis on principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories.
title: The Study of Comparative Politics

otherinfo: WWS PhD students may also register. Contact jgeorgiana@princeton.edu to receive the permission.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 50%, Papers - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: A general introduction to the field of international relations, with an emphasis on the principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories in the field. Students emerge from the course with an ability to situate theories and empirical claims in the broader historical, conceptual and empirical context of debates and literatures.
title: Seminar in International Politics

otherinfo: In the past, talented undergraduates intending to pursue graduate work have also benefited greatly from taking the sequence. The typical background for an undergraduate student with interests in political science who would take this course would be to first enroll in Politics 345 and 346, and then to start the graduate sequence, beginning with Politics 571.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: This is the gateway for the graduate methods sequence in Politics, it moves quickly to provide the foundation in probability theory that students will need in the methods sequence. The course assumes students are well versed in univariate calculus, and while a previous background in statistics is not required for graduate students taking the course, it is highly desirable.
title: Quantitative Analysis I

grading: Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Problem set(s) - 40%
prereqs: POL 575.
descrip: This course builds on POL 575, to further develop the analytical foundations for examining problems in collective choice. Topics include vote buying, multilateral bargaining, strategic information transmission, strategic voting with incomplete information, career concerns, and strategic experimentation. Readings combine textbooks and research literature.
title: Formal Political Analysis II

grading: Papers - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
descrip: This course examines psychological perspectives on politics. Themes include human limitation vs. human capacity, how institutions shape or interact with individual opinion and behavior, discussion and deliberation, and the role of groups. We will also discuss methodological issues.
title: Political Psychology

grading: Papers - 100%
descrip: During the third semester, each student writes a research paper under the direction of a faculty member.
title: Directed Research

evals: Great course even if you don't need a language. You learn a lot in the semester
It's a good class. It's taught family well.

Read the book! Since you already know Spanish most of the material will be easy to understand, however, reading the book helps you differentiate between both languages. Also, go  to the language tables! It might seem intimidating at first, but it really helps with the pronunciation of the language.

Such a great course. Though for native Spanish speakers, know that, at least for me, most of my class was people who learned Spanish, but weren't native speakers, so the class might not be as intense for you as you might imagine. If you're a native Spanish speaker, I perhaps recommend 110 (though I didn't take it).
Such a great, fun course. You learn a lot in this one semester and being class feels like a treat
Take this class!  The department is amazing, the workload is not bad at all yet you leave with a solid command of conversational Portuguese.

Take this class! The Portuguese professors are lovely, kind, caring and loving as well (something that is rare at Princeton). Daiane in particular is a warm and engaging professor who will actually teach you Portuguese through fun and exciting activities.
Take this class--Daiane is amazing, and you won't regret it! I wasn't really interested in Portuguese at all before this class, and now I'm considering study abroad in Brazil.
The coursework is doable but definitely time consuming.

This is definitely one of the best classes that I've taken here at Princeton. All of the professors in the Portuguese department here are so nice and they really care about their students. Although the class can be a lot of work at times, it's so worth it. You'd be surprised how much Portuguese you can learn in just one semester.
would recommend if interested in learning a new language; not too difficult especially if you like languages
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Paper in lieu of Final - 10%, Other Exam - 10%, Quizzes - 15%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Emphasis will be on oral communication in class. We will learn about the cultures of the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. There will be daily homework assignments, short compositions, a midterm, oral presentations and grammar testing.
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.
title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers

evals: A decent introduction to psych. Find a way to read the textbook efficiently and you might have a chance.
Always keep up with the homework
Anyone who has not taken a psychology class should take PSYCH 101! This is the perfect STL, and I will never forget all the fascinating, practical information I learned this semester.
Easy enough, fulfills the STL requirement without p-sets and gruesome labs. Interesting intro if looking into psych.
Great choice for STL.

Great intro course for psych. Go to lectures if you can, but generally slides are posted (although some material is in videos or discussed in lecture, so you don't want to miss that). Labs are "fun" and make sure you are engaged in them.
I definitely recommend taking this course if you are interested in Psychology. It will set the foundation for your understanding of this field in a well-paced and well-designed fashion.
I would advice students not to procrastinate on reading each chapter assigned because it will definitely come all at once when midterms and finals come
I would recommend that students take this course if they wish to fulfill an STL requirement. It is not a writing intensive class, but it does require a lot of reading so brace yourself.

I would recommend this class if you have a general interest in Psych, because it gives you a very nice surface understanding of a view really interesting things in the discipline. Take lab with Professor Junge because he is extremely chill and interesting to interact with. The midterm was annoyingly difficult even though the content itself is easy.
I would suggest this course if you think Psych is cool, if you don't it will be hard to stay engaged.

If you are planning on taking this course to fulfill your lab requirement or just out of personal interest, I would suggest doing it. Psychology in general is interesting, and I found many concepts to be applicable outside of just this class.
If you like psychology, you'll learn a lot, but you'll also do a lot of work between textbook readings, exam studying, and labs. If you're just looking for an easy STL, look elsewhere.
If you want to cover a wide range of topics in psychology this is definitely a good intro class. It isn't a difficult lab either.

If you're taking this class just to fulfill a STL requirement, I wouldn't recommend it. Although it has a reputation for being one of the easier classes for non-science majors to take in order to fulfill their STL requirement, this isn't really true.
It is quite a bit of teaching yourself from the book because it is such a big course and has so much content that he cannot go through everything in lecture. It was interesting!
It's a good STL if you're not a science person because the labs are just like long precepts and it's a very tangible subject.
It's a very interesting course. Lectures and labs are both engaging. Take it!
Keep up on the readings and outline them because its a lot to reread for the midterm and final and outlines help a lot
Keep up on the readings, and go to lecture.
Make sure you keep up with your reading. The course is very interesting. Very easy STL
Make sure you pay attention when learning statistics in lab. You will need it for every subsequent activity in lab.
Not at all a bad choice if you're just trying to fulfill your STL.
Not too hard of a lab. Readings are really long and actually needed to do well on the midterm/final.

Professor Cooper is an awesome professor! I have met several people who've told me that they or someone they knew were inspired to study psychology by Professor Cooper. Having taken this class now, I can definitely see how that could be the case. He is a very engaging speaker and really does a good job of presenting the material in a lucid and interesting fashion.
Sit in the front and don't save all the readings till the last night.
Stay on top of readings.

Take this class for your STL! The labs are overall pretty easy compared to other classes and Professor Cooper is extremely kind and makes lectures fun. Even though the readings can feel really long and boring at times it's important to make sure you keep up with it because when it comes time for the exams you don't have to spend hours upon hours studying.

Take this class! Lectures are very good and although it is not a requirement for psychology major it helped expose me to different areas of research that I might be interested in. Study a lot for the midterm and final.

Take this course if you are looking for an STL with a ridiculously easy/joke lab where you don't really do anything for 3 hours. This is a SURVEY course, meaning you'll cover like a new topic every week. It is mildly interesting, the main thing is that as a human being you already know all this stuff; you're just putting a name to it. Do not be fooled; the exams are not easy, but if you study hard and memorize a lot an A is definitely attainable. If you aren't taking it for STL or prereq or have taken AP Psychology before, don't take this course. There are many more interesting courses.
Take this course! Not only is it interesting, but it's also perfect for those just wanting to fulfill a requirement.
Take this course! Really interesting and useful information, and you can fulfill an STL requirement without doing an intense hard science type of lab.
Take this for an STL or if you're interested in psychology--Cooper is pretty engaging as a lecturer and labs are very reasonable. Be sure to keep up with the textbook reading, though
This class can be fun and informative for those interested in psychology.

This course is a relatively easy STL compared to others offered at Princeton, however it is not enjoyable. If you have taken AP Psychology, then you will easily pass this course, but as a person who came into PSY 101 with little experience in the field, I struggled. Assessment is all based on memorization, and content is presented in a dull manner.
This is a basic psychology course. Take it for distribution or STL requirement.
This is a good class to take in order to fulfill your STL.
This is an excellent intro course with an engaging lecturer.  Make sure to read the textbook to be prepared for exams.
Very good stl, would definately advise taking for an AB student with limited math/science ability

Whether you want to fulfill your lab requirement or you are simply interested in psychology, I can strongly recommend this class. You get a great overview of the various aspects of psychology and you can apply much of your knowledge in a practical way during lab.
Would recommend this course. It's a good STL and it is also not that difficult.
the course was interesting
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 40%
assgts: Approximately 100 pp per week.
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course can be used to satisfy the science and technology with laboratory general education requirement.
title: Introduction to Psychology

evals: Definitely take it if you're interested in clinical psychology. Fairly easy.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest.
Definitely take this course! Not too much work and the tests are not cumulative for a final! Only 2 midterm exams
Do the textbook readings!!!!! That is very important to understanding the material from this course.
Don't take unless you're prepared to strap yourself in and set aside time just to go over the material. If you can't do that, you probably won't do well on the exams.

Easy PDF if you just listen to lectures. However, I must say that I wasn't a huge fan of how the lectures were taught. The course got gradually less engaging throughout the semester, as every lecture was pretty much in the same format and a little dry. Exams are hard if you don't read the textbook, and require a lot of memorization. If you have general interest in the material, you can take it. But keep in mind that you can also read about the material in your spare time if you want to learn more.
Easy distribution requirement if you find this interesting. Minimal workload.
Good PDF class. Lectures just reiterate textbook readings. Precept readings are the most important for the final paper. Take it if you want to learn more about the subject matter.
Good, low stress class to take. Do the textbook readings, and you will be fine.
Great course!!! Lectures are really interesting and the reading is interesting and not too demanding.  Professor Spokas is great
I would recommend this course if the material interests you. If you don't think you would find explanations of and treatments for mental illnesses interesting, don't take the course.

I'd recommend taking this class if you have an interest in psychological disorders... It can be a monotonous course at times, but the content overall is interesting and it's definitely not very much work. Try to have Aaron as a preceptor!
I'd recommend taking this course. It isn't too difficult but is very fascinating

If you do all the readings and show up to lectures you will probably get an A. If you skim or read through the chapters at the last second then you'll probably get a B. Pretty good class for being in season.
If you're interesting in the subject matter it is good. The readings are very interesting but lecture is boring and dry.
It is a good course, if you are looking for new insight into common diseases/psychological dysfunctions then this is not the course to take
It's decent. not to much work, but not all that interesting. easy PDF, tricky blackboard exams, so not that easy to get an A.
Laid-back, good class
Make sure you have enough time to read the book in addition to the lectures. Much of the exam is based on information from the book.
Not too hard, the lectures are basically a summary of the textbook readings. You can do well even if you don't attend lecture, but lectures are still helpful to go to.
Read the textbook VERY closely in order to prepare for the exams.
Really interesting course if you want to learn about different psychological disorders. Not too much work.
Really interesting course. Would definitely recommend. A lot of memorization though but most of it you can get if you just pay attention in lectures.

Really nice, relaxed course. Take if you are interested to make sure you attend lectures, as lecture material is really the crux of the exams. Precept articles also were decently interesting and low-work, so a great fifth course too if you like the material!
Solid, well-run course. Material is interesting, but isn't always presented in engaging ways.
Take good notes on lectures (record too!) and read the textbook chapters bc that what the exams test. I
Take it!

Take this class!! The material is so interesting, and the debate-style precepts make learning the material more fun. The workload is very doable- just weekly readings and a blackboard post. The lectures aren't always so interesting, but the material is cool.

Take this course for an engaging and manageable social analysis requirement. The material is pretty fascinating and Professor Spokas is extremely clear in letting you know exactly what to expect on exams. I strongly recommend this class!
Take this course if you are genuinely interested in the topic, or like reading a textbook.
Take this course it is really really interesting and the tests are fair and the work is easy. I loved learning.
Take this course, and study hard for midterms. Highly recommend.
The course is boring and the exams are only based on readings, not lecture

The readings provide clear explanations of disorders in relation to each model (behavioral/psychodynamic/biological, etc.), as well as symptoms. Attending lecture, precept and reading the textbook should give you a clear understanding of each topic.
This is a simple class as long as you do all of the textbook readings. Take it if you are a potential psychology major!
This is not a super easy SA unless you PDF and actually study. Exams require memorization of minute details in the textbook, which is not very well written.
Unless you're interested in mental illnesses and other aspects of abnormal psychology, other departmental options might be better. Exams were difficult
While the readings may not seem like a lot, they are very helpful to keep up with, especially for the exams.
Would not recommend this course. The material is not engaging and the tests just require you memorizing the textbook.
You don't need to go to class. Just do the textbook readings before the exam and you'll do fine.
good class, all of it is in the textbook
its not very good but since we don't have any other psychopathology courses here...options are limited. won't ruin the subject for you. decently interesting course, and not so hard
take it. important and interesting stuff to learn.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Other Exam - 35%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%
assgts: Approximately 70 pages of reading per week.
descrip: Survey of different types of abnormal behaviors and different models of explanation. Students will come to understand the conflicting viewpoints and treatment approaches that characterize the clinical field, and will understand what is presently known and not known about abnormal functioning.
title: Psychopathology

evals: "Common sense 101 and dating advice"  - w/ Prof. Shelton.

100% recommend this course. If you're at all interested in the subject, you'll find this class to be fun and engaging. If you're not, it's still a relatively easy pdf, though you will need to attend all the lectures.
A great class! More on the easy side with not that much work, and very enjoyable lectures. You don't need to read the textbook chapters unless she specifically mentions a chapter.
A lot of work but not hard
A well-organized course, very engaging, and you get to help an organization with a pertinent social problem!
Absolutely DO NOT take this class. Lectures were okay, but not comprehensive. Precepts are a waste of your time and the CBLI project takes you back to 5th grade science fair.
Absolutely take this course! One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Lectures are clear and engaging and clearly applicable to the real world.
Attend lecture! Exam will sometimes ask questions you can only answer if you've been to lecture.
Class is pretty non-rigorous. Very low workload; you might learn something if it's your first introduction to the field. If you have any psych/neuro background, I would not recommend.
Course topics are highly interesting and not much work on a weekly basis, recommend!

DO NOT  take this course, unless you're a Psych major and mindlessly memorizing a LOT of things is what you want to spend your tuition money, time and Princeton education on. 
Maybe take it when Prof. Tamir is teaching??
This course is a REALLY INTRO course that, if you're reasonably smart or used to reading scientific papers, you will find it extremely frustrating and boring ie You will get penalized for not explaining simple things in a scientific paper that are not explained in usual professional papers. 
There should be more TAs, bc feedback on assignments is really lagged that you will get feedback for an important document for your presentation on the day of your presentation. And you will schedule meetings for going thru your presentation when the precept presentation is already done.

Definitely take this class! Dr. Shelton is an amazing lecturer, and all of the lectures were fascinating and stimulating. I found the material to be really relevant. There is not much outside work other than the weekly precept readings.

Definitely take this class. There is not too much work besides weekly precept readings and comments. The CBLI project at the end of the semester can require some time, but the course does a good job of spreading the work out over the course of the whole semester. Attend the lectures since most of the tested material comes straight from Professor Shelton!
Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in the material or want to knock out a distribution requirement. Course is fair overall and definitely worth your time.
Definitely take this course if you are interested. Consider PDFing if there is an additional project, otherwise the workload is very reasonable.
Difficult midterm. Prof. Shelton's lectures are amazing though!

Do the readings and please go to lecture! 
The MC exams are difficult....
Do your best to prepare for the midterm because it's pretty tough
Fairly easy psychology class.
Go to lecture and start working on the project early.
Go to lecture and study for the exams
Go to lecture, take careful notes, read precept readings (questions come up on exam).
Go to lecture.
Go to lecture. Study principles. Make sure the project gets done well and on time.
Good course. Do the work and stay engaged. Everything seems extremely simple to remember, but the midterm will get you if you don't study hard!
Good intro to psych course! Also presents a lot of fascinating concepts that help you understand why people do the things they do.
Good introductory psychology course - not that much work and a good senior year class.
Great PDF course. Great course normally too! You'll learn a lot of the basic concepts in social psych in a digestible manner

Great course with interesting material, would highly recommend you to take it. Easy distribution requirement if that's what you're looking for, but I also enjoyed the content despite having little interest in the non-engineering fields.
Great course, fascinating material, exams are very specific and difficult so don't take for a grade unless you plan to really put in the time

I really enjoyed doing the CBLI project, and learning about the psychology of my everyday life. However, if you're looking for something really stimulating, this class is pretty basic and never requires you to do much in-depth analysis or reading.

I really enjoyed this course; Prof. Shelton is a fun and relatable lecturer and the material is very fundamentally interesting and understandable, so I did not find it to be too difficult. I would definitely recommend taking it, but I found that my preceptor was lacking in providing us with information/feedback so definitely try to make sure you get a good preceptor.
I thought the lectures and material were interesting. I wish precepts were a little more interactive. CBLI is more work than you might think.

I would recommend taking this course, it's engaging and the material isn't boring. The professor (Shelton) is great and makes the lectures interesting. There is a lot of reading but it is interesting.
I would recommend this course for those who have a general curiosity for how and why people behave socially in the manner that they do

I would take this class if you are a freshmen or sophomore who wants to improve research and writing skills. I would not recommend the class if you are a junior or a senior unless social psychology is a life interest or something because the class is strongly oriented toward teaching underclassmen how to do research and writing. If you already know these things, it is still a lot of work (especially if you get a freshmen partner for the group and end up having to do most of the work yourself) but you won't get much out of it, especially if you took intro to psych or other classes of that sourt.
If you are considering being a PSY major, take it! If you are interested at all in PSY or people in general, take it!

If you are interested in why we are the way we are and social relationships, definitely take this course. Lectures are pretty interesting, but if you miss them you aren't missing terribly much. Precepts aren't the most interesting, but they aren't that much work. There are a few papers and projects throughout the semester, but it is pretty interesting overall. You will also have to participate in a few experiments yourself over the course of the year. Overall, this class is interesting but not terribly engaging.
If you are looking to take this course for fun, PDF it. There is a lot of busy work and tests are pretty difficult. The material is super interesting though so if you interested try it out!
If you are thinking about majoring in psych, take this course since it is a prerequisite. If you are just looking for a introductory psych course you may be better off with PSY101
If you have interest in social psychology, take the course, as you learn a lot and learn to see the world in a different way.

If you have to take this class because you are considering majoring in psych, it is completely manageable and Professor Shelton is a great lecturer. I was hoping the class would go into certain topics more in depth instead of just reviewing many topics at surface level.

If you love psychology, take this course. If not, consider that it is a lot of work. Basically three classes in one: lecture, precept, and the CBLI project. They're manageable, but be prepared for unnecessary work.

If you're interested in social psych, this is a nice introduction to the topic, and really a very painless class. The workload is very manageable but do keep in mind that it sometimes feels like busy work, which led to the class ultimately not feeling as satisfactory or worthwhile as I would have liked.
Information is interesting but class is very poorly run. Lots of work for the final but not much otherwise.
Interesting class but expect work and studying.

It's a decent course and will give you a better understanding of social psychology. Not the best course out there. Shelton is a wonderful lecturer. Precept was a joke, hopefully she will change it up for next time.
It's a great course if you care about psychology even in the slightest.
It's interesting and valuable material that I really enjoyed, but it's a lot more work than I anticipated.

It's not difficult to stay on top of course material for this class, but go to lectures to get a solid foundation of concepts in the textbook (and to avoid having to study a lot for exams). Don't put off the CBLI project until the last minute!

Make flash cards as you go through the chapter because otherwise the midterm is really harsh. You can pretty much get through the discussion board posts for precept without doing the readings and you won't need to know these for the tests. You really should go to lecture and read the textbook if you want to do well though.
Make sure to keep up with the readings and go to lectures.
Make sure you like sociology if you take this class.
Mildly time-consuming elective. I am an engineer and it actually demands time occasionally, and that may be at moments you'd really rather not deal with it.
Not a terrible SA course. It changed a lot compared to past years, just be prepared to dedicate time to the group project throughout the semester. 6-7/10 recommend.

Not an interesting course. A big portion of this class consisted of giving formal definitions to ideas/concepts that were already intuitive. On the other hand, the workload was very very light, so that was good.

Not too hard most of the time, but the research project is stressful and requires a good bit of work at times during the semester.  Interesting subject, but not the most engaging or well organized course.

Not worth it if you're looking for an easy distribution course or even PDF (midterm, final, research participation hours, dean's date paper, and mandatory presentation fair thing). Very broad survey course but exams require knowledge of specific terms. Do not get Tasha as a preceptor if at all possible.
Pay attention to what Dr. Shelton recommends for you to read from the textbook. Lectures are very engaging and relevant.
Read the textbook and go to lecture. The CBLI portion could be difficult if you do not start it earlier
Read the textbook and precept readings and go to lecture.
Recommend! Interesting, and not too difficult.

Shelton is a great lecturer and Holden is also a great preceptor. Be warned that the CBLI project is a bit time consuming and tedious but not too difficult. Also, this may have been a one time incident but the midterm had way too many questions for the allotted 50 minutes. Besides that I would recommend this course to anyone who needs a distribution requirement.
Social psychology is an interesting course. It wasn't very challenging.

Social psychology is so great to study because it's interesting and relevant to everyone's lives. The midterm content is almost entirely covered in lecture, and Prof Shelton is great, so go and take notes. You can get away with doing barely any of the precept readings.

Super chill class! If you are taking it for a grade, go to lecture and pay attention to the studies she talks about. It's an easy A if you just take good notes and memorize them really well. The textbook is completely unnecessary to read. A bit slow and boring sometimes, but a lot of good information for life!
TAKE THIS CLASS - it's been my favorite class in my time here. It's applicable to almost any field and teaches some great material!
Take it for an easy and interesting psych course, that's applicable to your everyday life! Also a good one to take if you want to see your ideas applied to real life through the CBLI project.
Take it if you have to. Lectures are interesting, but precepts are awful, and the CBLI final project is a pain.
Take it if you have to; it's fairly enjoyable.
Take it only if you have to for a distribution or STN.
Take it take it take it!!! The material is most interesting and having Prof. Shelton is a must before graduating.
Take it to learn more about why people act they do.
Take it, but go to lecture! Shelton is great, and make sure to stay up to date on the final project as your life will be easier in the long run.

Take the course if you're interested in analyzing and understanding social factors in your daily life but don't take it if you're trying to take it as a general knowledge course because it's definitely more psych-oriented.

Take this class! Interesting lectures and she posts outlines of the lectures afterwards which is super useful to go off of when studying for midterm or final. Weekly precept reading posts were easy and so was the CBLI project, because once we got into CBLI, we stopped having to do weekly posts and just focused on the project. Material is easy to understand and Shelton is super fun. Don't really need to use the textbook. If you're on the fence about this class, I'd say give it a try, I really enjoyed it.
Take this course!
Take this course! Absolutely great to teach students a relevant and engaging topic about social interactions.
Take this course! Professor Shelton is amazing and course content has many useful social implications.

Take this course! Very fun, really engaging. If Social psychology or psychology in general is even kind of interesting to you, you will love this class! Tasha is a great preceptor and Prof. Shelton is great!
Take this course, its very easy and not a big time commitment. The lectures are super interesting and the exams not very hard. Its honestly a great class.

The class is deceptively challenging--while the lectures essentially repeat the textbook verbatim, the exams find a way to test the most trivial detail--including obscure lines from precept readings and even numbers that are "stressed" in lecture. If you decide to take this class for a grade, go to the lectures and study for the exam; if you take it too lightly at first, you will be unhappy with your midterm grade.

The lectures are fairly engaging, but be warned that the slides are not posted after lecture and the lecture outlines posted on blackboard are very incomplete. A large portion of the information is given out verbally in lecture. The midterm examination was very unexpected and difficult, and I feel that we weren't given adequate preparation for what kind of questions to expect (the sample exam items were deceivingly easy). Material discussed in precepts was somewhat inconsistent across different precepts, this may have negatively impacted precept-related questions on the exams.

The midterm exam is so petty.  It doesn't even really test you on whether you know the concepts or not.  It's more of like can you remember every unimportant minute detail... Literally most poorly written exam I've ever taken.
The subject matter is definitely very interesting, the precept readings, not so much. I did not like it as much as I thought I would.
There is A LOT of work involved. The CBLI project is a huge commitment and you have to be on top of everything because the organization and communication isn't great.
There is a lot of reading, so give yourself enough time for that. The lectures are very interesting. Go to lecture because the most important content is given in lecture.

This class is great, very interesting, and really helps you to think about yourself and others and why you do the things you do. Highly recommended, also isn't particularly difficult. Great for a 5th class or PDF course.
This course requires A LOT of work, way more than I expected and should be expected of a class. I would choose any other Psychology course over this one if I had to do it again.
This course was very interesting because of the real life examples.  The work was very manageable especially because the lectures covered everything that we needed to know from the reading.

This is a great PSY class. Shelton is a really engaging lecturer and pretty funny. The lecture content is interesting and makes you think about everyday psychological phenomena. CBLI component of the course is sort of a pain but great class recommend
This is a great introductory psych course. If you can take it with Professor Shelton, she's great!

This is a very interesting and fulfilling class to take. While the readings might seem easy and obvious, make sure to do them in order to build your knowledge. Approach the class as a life skills class, and you'll be pleasantly surprised!
This is a very interesting class! I highly recommend taking it! Advice that I have include taking good notes during lecture and using the textbook as a valuable study aid and reference.
This is definitely a really interesting class, but also not easy. Put in the work.
Worthwhile to know the material, not impossible, but probably as useful just to audit lecture
