You should absolutely take this class, especially if you are a first-year student. Incredibly interesting material that will stay relevant to you far beyond the class.
You will talk about this class with everyone. It's so applicable and interesting to everyday life.
do take.
honestly, too much work if you're not taking it as a distribution requirement
interesting class
it's more work than you'd expect, not because of the amount of work (which is very little) but because of how pointless the work feels. professor shelton is great though.
take
take this if you are interested in psychology! it is an easy class and very interesting, professor shelton is a great lecturer- i never dozed off, topic was always interesting and relevant
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: 60-80 pages of readings; 7-8 hours of preparation.
descrip: The scientific study of social behavior, with an emphasis on social interaction and group influence. Topics covered will include social perception, the formation of attitudes and prejudice, attraction, conformity and obedience, altruism and aggression, and group dynamics.
title: Social Psychology

evals: A great professor and very interesting material.
A pretty easy class if you're good at memorizing facts and taking exams. Lectures weren't really necessary to grasp the material. Material is also very interesting
Attend both lecture and precept! You'll get mostly similar but slightly different and critical information for the exams from both.
Avoid taking this class as it is right now. It's not hard, and there's some interesting material, but you can learn it pretty well from the textbook, and the lectures are not particularly inspiring.
Awesome class on how the brain works. Alice is a solid preceptor and taking notes from lectures is all you need to do well in the course.
DO NOT TAKE IT AND SAVE YOURSELF

Definitely consider taking this class if you are interested in neuroscience, its also good way to fulfill STN. It does assume some prior biology knowledge, but definitely still manageable. Fairly light workload.
Discussing material with others helped me to understand.

Do all the readings and make sure you actually understand them and you're golden. I found taking detailed notes while I was reading very helpful when preparing for exams. Also Professor Witten has tremendously improved this course, so it is not as bad as people might make it out to seem.

Don't be afraid to reach out to Professor Witten and your preceptors during office hours and Piazza! They are so receptive/welcoming to your feedback and are always willing to answer questions. Definitely a great introductory class with a manageable workload and homework problems that will prepare you sufficiently for the quizzes.
Don't take it unless you have to.

Don't take this class. If you're not already well versed in neuroscience, this is a confusing run through the park, where you'll spend a lot of time on arbitrary principles without a lot of nontechnical explanation. If you do take this course, get a better textbook or set of readings to do on your own time, because the book would spark more as tinder than as text.
Examinations are based on the intersection between lectures and textbooks. When studying, it is helpful to cross reference lecture slides, notes and the corresponding sections of the textbook.
Follow lectures and read lecture notes
Go to all the lectures!

Go to lectures and keep up with the textbook (keeping in mind that the book goes into considerable depths that won't be tested). Do not take if you have no interest in learning the basic mechanisms of neuroscience, which will make up the bulk of the semester. How those mechanisms tie into our general brain function and dysfunction won't come until late into the course.
Go to lectures and you won't have to do much outside of class. A great class to take if you want to confirm your interest in neuro as a major.
Go to lectures! Textbook readings aren't as important.
Go to lectures, Prof. Witten in awesome and covers the material much better than the book
Great course! If you like molecular biology, you will probably like neuro 201. Exams can be challenging, so make sure to keep up with textbook readings.
Great course. Very interesting. Not that complicated of topics, very little homework that is not very time consuming

Having heard a lot of negative reviews about this course, and being hesitant to take a very "technical" class, I was very pleasantly surprised by NEU201 - I really enjoyed the material and learning how everything came together in lectures. If you don't like the material, it probably won't be for you, because there's a lot and it can get dry, but if you think you might, definitely give it a shot. Professor Witten's lectures started off fairly dry and intense but she's dedicated to improving the experience for the class and I thought they got better over the semester. Alice is also a very sweet and helpful preceptor!

I learned a lot and have found it very engaging? testing is pretty stressful though, and exams still seem to be geared towards being a good multiple choice test-taker than on knowing the material really well. It's very interesting, too, and there's a great set of people teaching
I read the reviews and I thought it would be different because neuroscience is cool. I was wrong. Don't take this class unless you absolutely had to. The lectures will put you to sleep

I really enjoyed this class. Professor Witten does a good job of explaining the concepts and the class is not difficult by any means. I think some students find the class dull though because they go in expecting neuroscience to be a fluff science, which it's not. Be ready to learn about the nitty gritty details of how the brain works on a molecular level. If that sounds interesting to you, then absolutely take it!
I really liked this class! The quizzes are hard, but the material is really interesting.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in neuroscience. I came in as a prospective MOL major but I discovered that I really enjoyed neuroscience and wanted to study it further. 

The homeworks are not very demanding and the exams are multiple choice. Most of my studying for the course was attending the lectures and taking notes on the lecture slides because I found that they didn't have enough information for me to study solely off them.

I'd recommend this class to people who are interested in the biology part neuroscience. Witten's lectures can be dry, but the content (especially in the latter portion of the course) is interesting. The quizzes are fair and mostly based on memorization.
If you are interested in neuroscience I would recommend taking this course.

If you are planning on studying Neuroscience, there really is no way to avoid this class.  Although the materials are truly interesting and seem to set a good foundation for the topic, the course as a whole leaves a lot to be desired.  Lectures and precepts are not the best, so I would recommend clarifying topics by using the textbooks and figuring the materials out for yourself.  While not ideal, it is most definitely possible.
If you can get through biological structures, the first half of the class will be okay and the second half will be very interesting.

If you love neuroscience/genuinely appreciate the subject and do not rely on engaging lectures to develop your interest, this is the perfect course for you. The lectures were a bit dry and monotonous and at times, saturated with information. However, if you dedicate time to learn the concepts, memorization will not be a difficult barricade to surmount. I really enjoyed this course.

It is very helpful to have some background in biology (e.g. AP Bio), but it is not necessary. If you are interested in the subject matter and willing to put in the time studying, this course will be very enjoyable for you.
Make sure you have a solid biology background before taking this course (AP Bio or equivalent).
Only take this course if you want to major in Neuroscience.

Only take this course if you're planning to be a neuroscience major. If you just want a neuro course to take to gauge your interest, take another one (probably 202). I would only take this one to fulfill the prerequisite requirement.

Prof. Witten is nice, and a decent lecturer if people don't interrupt with pointless questions, which they always do. If you're interested take it, but also take an upper level NEU course alongside to get a better taste of what NEU is like.
Review what you learn each week, it will stack up on you.
Small things are important.
Take for requirement. For enjoyment?-- it's a lot of work, so be careful.
Take if you need to or are interested in Neuroscience
Take if you're interested in neuroscience. If you go to lecture and do the problem sets, you can do well in this class. Lectures can very dry, be warned,
Take it if Witten is teaching! Lecture is all you need to do well.
Take it! One of the most fun courses I've taken at Princeton. Prof. Witten's lectures will keep you interested.
Take the course only if you need it. It's difficult with a lot of memorization.
Take this class only if you are interested in the topic. I really liked this class, but it is probably not a class to take just for the fun of it.
Take this class!!!! Super interesting, not super technical science class, wish there was a lab for it
Take this instead of 175, easy
The course is very manageable if you make sure to read a few chapters per night and stay on top of the material covered in lecture.
The lectures are not as clear as they could be. Making an active effort (going to office hours and supplementing lectures with reading) makes the course very manageable.

The material is really cool so I would recommend taking the course. However, the material is challenging and lectures are unclear, so you will spend a lot of time teaching yourself to get a decent grade.
This class isn't a very engaging introduction to neuroscience. The instructors DO NOT make clear what will be assessed on quizzes.

This course is exactly what is advertised. It is a good, thorough introduction to neuroscience. It is nice to have the semester broken down into units with evaluations after each, not adding to midterms week stress. However, this means there will be three midterm-like tests that can sometimes be inconveniently scheduled.
This is a course all students should take for general/useful knowledge purposes. Highly recommend if you're looking for an engaging high level science course.

This is a great class but you have to go to lecture and do the homework. The exams do require at least 4 hours of studying though so don't try to BS through them. Ultimately not hard to get at least a B

This is an excellent introductory neuroscience course that presents a wide variety of topics in appropriate biological context. It caused me to change my major and will likely play a part in my thesis research. Take it out of general interest - it's well-taught, fairly easy, low commitment, and intellectually rewarding.

Very manageable course -- read the textbook for better understanding of the material, it's one of the only courses that I would vouch for the textbook. Also, use lectures as a guide for quizzes and exams.
Work load is not too high and the material is very very interesting.  However, a lot of young very diligent students take this course, leading to a relatively tough curve.

Would recommend the class! There was a good variety of prior-knowledge on the subject in terms of students, but Ilana definitely did a good job explaining concepts/answering questions. Lectures could be a little unorganized but were generally well-done.
go to lecture. read if you want more in-depth understanding, but it isn't necessary for tests.
reading the textbook along with the powerpoint slides is helpful
super fascinating. if you're afraid of the technical stuff, don't be. ilana is an amazing teacher!
otherinfo: NEU 201 and NEU 175 cover overlapping material and cannot both be taken for credit.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 50%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: 60 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Recommended background: high school psychology, biology, and chemistry. NEU 201 and NEU 202 are a two-term sequence which may be taken out of order, and are prerequisites for entering the NEU concentration. Students who do not intend to pursue NEU concentration and are seeking to fulfill STN requirements may consider NEU 175 (Introduction to Neuroscience) as a potentially appropriate alternative. NEU 201 has been substantially redesigned for 2017, including a new textbook and different instructor than previous years..
descrip: An intensive introduction to fundamental topics in neuroscience, including neuronal excitability, synaptic physiology, neural networks, and circuits that mediate perception, action, emotion, and memory. We will examine neuroscience at scales ranging from single neurons, to the activity of small sets of neurons, to the organization of brain and behavior. The course will address broad questions including: How does information enter the brain? What neural pathways transmit these signals? How is information processed and used to construct an internal model of reality? How does the brain choose and execute the correct behavioral response?
title: Fundamentals of Neuroscience

evals: ABSOLUTELY take this course. Prof Lew-Williams is awesome, lectures are fun and interesting, and you will learn so much you didn't know that will be useful later in life.
Be sure to go to class often, keep up with the readings, and take notes on the things that are said in lecture more than what is just on the slides
Casey Lew-Williams was an awesome professor and definitely improved the class for me.
Casey gives AWESOME lectures.
Casey is a fantastic lecturer. Definitely take this class if you have any interest in learning about how children develop.

Casey is a great professor and lecturer (although he can be disorganized and speak too quickly to follow along sometimes). However, I would not recommend taking this class unless the grading/assignments are changed. There are a lot of useless busywork assignments and you'll find yourself spending days memorizing irrelevant "key terms" never mentioned in lecture for the exam. Lectures are irrelevant to the exam.
Casey is an incredible professor. Definitely take this class

Casey is great, precepts are totally fine, the expectations aren't terribly high so it's a solid class to PDF but if you do well on the midterm I would just take it for a grade anyway and you can probably get an A of some sort.

Definitely go to each lecture and take notes on what Casey says (his slides normally are just a skeleton of the lecture).  Be engaged in the class and you will definitely enjoy it!  Read all the textbook assignments and journal articles.

Definitely take it if you like babies or anything of the sort. Professor Casey is a wonderful professor and the preceptors are all super fun as well. You won't have a dull moment in this class, that I assure you of!

Definitely take it! Casey Lew-Williams is a great professor who makes every class really enjoyable and fun. The workload is not too difficult, but it can get tedious. Overall, though, a great class to take.
Definitely take it, especially if Casey is teaching it.
Definitely take this class even if you aren't generally interested in Psychology - Lew-Williams is amazing and lectures are awesome!!
Definitely take this class for the EC distribution requirement.  Great lecturer, very little work during the semester, and a class that I actually enjoyed taking.
Definitely take this class, but be prepared to do the textbook readings for the exams!

Definitely take this course! Professor Lew-Williams was an incredible lecturer and, as a non-psych major, I thought the material was really interesting and accessible. Perfect for anyone, regardless of background in psych. Also, there were a few major assignments but overall not a huge workload.
Do the readings and you will be fine for the exams.
Don't underestimate the amount of work you have to put in this class.
Easy 5th class. Not much much work but definitely not the easiest to get an A in. Great choice to PDF and is very interesting.
Easy and fun EC, why not?
Favorite class. Take it if you're interested in the material
Go to Casey's office hours and be sure to do readings.
Go to all the lectures, but skim the book as well for important keywords.

Go to lecture, take notes. Participate in precept. Do the readings and don't blow off studying. The midterm had some tricky questions and was not that easy! Relevant, interesting material and kind, passionate professor.
Go to lectures. Make sure you're reading from the textbook, because there are a lot of exam questions from it. Get coffee with Casey.
Good course.  Needs a lot of organizational help.  Would have loved to just audit the course.
Great class to PDF. Very interesting but the midterm was fairly difficult, so if you do not want to invest the time in memorizing all the terms but want to learn the material, definitely PDF.
Great class! Lectures are awesome and you really learn a lot. Good for an EC, as well as interesting. Don't take precept from Michael though.
Great class, Professor Lew-Williams is awesome, and you should definitely take this class if you have the chance.

Great course where you learn a lot about a wide range of topics. Good amount of opportunities to do well. Caters to a wide range of skill sets. Professor Lew-Williams is great. Only issue is exams are hard and he doesn't curve them
Highly recommend this course!! It was amazing: challenging but not dishearteningly so, interesting, stimulating, engaging, and all around great.
I definitely recommend this class for anyone looking to take an interesting psychology class. The lectures are entertaining and the subject itself is fascinating.
I would recommend this course, mostly because the lectures are so great.
I would strongly advise students to take this course if they are interested in understanding how children develop, in every possible aspect.

If you are interested in dev psych, take it! Prof. Casey is very enthusiastic and approachable, and it's a good fifth class to take. There are a few projects scattered here and there, but they don't take up too much time.

If you can only pick one psych course, pick this one. Casey is one of the best professors here on this campus and he surely reminds you what professors should be like and how we should be learning in college.
If you have any interest in the material, kids, or psychology in general, definitely take this course.

If you've never taken a psychology class before (or even if you have), this is a great choice!  Prof. Lew-Williams is one of the best lecturers I've had at Princeton.  As a BSE student taking 4 other classes, I felt that this was a manageable workload and I learned a lot.  Do the readings and go to lecture, as the two are not interchangeable.
If your interested in development or videos of babies its a great course. There is a lot of reading though and you have to keep up. Overall a very interesting course
Interesting class and Casey is a great lecturer. Definitely take if you like psych.  However, dont expect an easy PDF.  Theres a lot of busy work invovled in the class.
Interesting class to take. I had to take for a departmental but it's not a bad class to take for fun. The workload is not too bad.
It's a good course if you're really interested in development. A little too much work for PDF, there are better courses if you're just looking for something easy.
It's a good distribution requirement but the exams are pretty difficult so I'd maybe recommend another course to fulfill an EC.

It's a well structured course taught by a great professor. That said, be prepared to do the readings and attend the lectures; the exams can get pretty specific to detail. Overall, workload is completely manageable, but some of the content was pretty intuitive. In terms of grades, you get as much as you put into this class.

It's not chill or an easy 'A'. Chances are you will probably start to prioritize your other classes over this, and then the midterm and final will sneak up on you. Take very very good lecture notes (record in case you miss something), participate in precept, and READ the book (know your keywords). Also, there is a Dean's Date assignment for this course, which is an extra added stress. But lectures were fun and entertaining, Casey is great. Take it as a fun but challenging (in some way) distributional requirement.
Its a lot more memorization then I expected.
Keep up with the readings and participate in lecture and precept! Be engaged with the material so you can get the most out of the course.
Love this class. A little hard but so worth it.
Not an easy class! Fun though.
Not much work outside of class, easy PDF.

Not necessarily as easy as everyone says, unless maybe you're PDFing. Still incredibly important to attend lecture AND read the book as both emphasize slightly different concepts while the exam covers content from both equally.
Not the most thrilling course, exams are tough
Note that while the material is easy, the grading is pretty harsh. It's not a lot of work and Casey is a great professor, so you should take it!

Pretty interesting subject matter.  You can put as little or as much into it as you want, however much you do corresponds with how much you learn.  Prof Lew-Williams is a great guy and always tries to keep students engaged in lectures.  recommend for anyone who wants to try a psychology class or has an interest in child psychology.
Professor Lew-Williams is an incredible engaging and relatable lecturer.  He makes the material fun with media clips in powerpoints and anecdotes from his own life and experiments.

Read the textbook and start your final paper in december before break so you can get feedback from your preceptor. Also, go to lectures. The powerpoints are mostly pictures which makes it harder to understand what was discussed if you didn't hear the lecture.
Recommend if interested child development
Small details from the textbook come on the exam that never was mentioned in lecture so the tests do get a bit annoying.
Study hard and memorize the process of development.

TAKE THIS COURSE (if): you want to work with kids, you want to have kids, or you were ever a kid. 

Basically, take it! Professor & preceptors are great. It's definitely a worthwhile investment. You also learn so much about parenting. (And the workload is not bad at all, although the exam might be a little more specific than you expect - that being said, study the terms carefully.)
Take it for your EC but be careful because it is not a gut class.
Take it if interested, hopefully grading is easier again in the future
Take it if you need an interesting EC, but don't expect it to be an easy flat A.
Take it!! Go to every lecture and make sure you memorize all the vocabulary.
Take the class
Take this class because you'll learn things you'll never forget.
Take this class! Interesting lectures throughout the semester.  An easy EC for science majors.
Take this class! The material is fascinating and Prof. Lew-Williams is a great lecturer!
Take this class. It is amazing and fairly easy if you go to lecture and do the readings.
Take this course if you are looking for an interesting lecture.

Take this course if you wish to attend lectures given by a passionate, intelligent, entertaining professor and to learn more and more about yourself on a weekly basis. However, if you're coming into this class in search of an easy A or an easy PDF, be forewarned--the exams are much harder than you'd think!
Take this course with Casey Lew-Williams! He is an amazing lecturer, so interesting and engaging!

Take this course! It's run very well. (The lectures, assignments, readings, precepts...everything is great.) The material is also interesting, and Prof. Lew-Williams will keep you engaged through the semester.
Take this course. It is more work than expected and was graded harder than I thought it would be, but it is possible to get a decent grade if you try.

Take this!!! Casey (Lew-Williams) is an absolutely great professor.  And the material is really, really interesting.  I'm a completely unrelated major, and I loved it.  It's also not particularly difficult; just do the readings.
The course is fun and engaging. Casey basically presents the material from the textbook, but in a much more fun way, and lecture is definitely worth it.
The course material was very accessible, and the workload manageable too. The concepts from this course were thought-provoking and shaped my perspective on human development.
The course moves fast because there's a lot to cover. Notes in lecture and very necessary, and precept readings helps a lot.
There's really no reason for you not to take this class.
This class is extremely interesting and not very hard. The lectures are great and the work load is very manageable.
This class is interesting, intuitive, and a good EC!  I enjoy the lectures and the readings and tests are very manageable with reasonable effort.
This class is more work than it seems, with both a final paper and exam and difficult midterm/exam. But there is very interesting material and it is taught well.
This class was pretty great and Lew-Williams is a great lecturer, would recommend if you're interested in child development. Be cautious on the exams because they can be very specific.

This course has a wonderful lecturer, Casey, and has a lot of material that is absolutely crucial to know if you will ever interact with children, or want to eventually become a parent. I highly recommend this course, and highly recommend PDFing it since the exams are really difficult to study for, but it's such a good class.
This course is awesome and so interesting. You won't regret it!
This course isn't too difficult and is very interesting. I highly recommend it
This is a good course if you want a very broad introduction to an interesting field.
This is a great class overall. Casey is a FANTASTIC lecturer, keeping everyone engaged with pictures and videos.  The subject itself is interesting, and the exams are very reasonable.
This was a very interesting course and not difficult to do well. A decent amount of work to pdf, but the paper assignment is extremely easy and the tests are non cumulative.
Whether you are a Psych major or not, take this course.

Would highly recommend this course! I learned a lot of things about kids that changes the way I think about learning and parenting. It's a really fun class, fairly low stress, and very applicable to daily life. Plus, Casey is a super fun professor to listen to.
definitely take it if interested in psychology
everyone should take this, period

if you need an EC it is not the easiest option out there but mildly interesting, go to most lectures and study for midterm and final and you'll be fine.. written work and projects are very feasible and interesting
know that it will be mostly about babies. this wasn't super obvious to me when I signed up for this course.
one of the best classes I've taken at princeton. Casey is an amazing lecturer and the subject matter is important to know.
the exams are a bit difficult, keep up to date with readings and terms*** and
very relevant
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Two exams, one paper.
descrip: Babies, who look like helpless blobs, are capable of impressive feats of learning. 3-year-olds, who can't cross the street alone, know an astounding amount of information about their environments. We will focus on landmark studies that elucidate how children's biology, cognition, language, and social experiences interact to set the stage for what we do and who we are. Is the baby's world a 'blooming, buzzing confusion', or do babies enter the world prepared to make sense of their environments? How can we understand the collaboration between nature and nurture during development?
title: Developmental Psychology

evals: Definitely an enjoyable class, but make sure you have enough time in your schedule to do the readings - they are and will be important for any future teacher.

Do not underestimate the amount of work that this class requires: a midterm paper and a final paper, 12 hours of observations at schools   3 response papers (this adds up), plus weekly mini-essay assignments. 

That being said, this is an absolutely incredible course and you will learn a lot. Prof. Glat certainly rewards for effort, and is very chill and understanding about deadlines. The clinical emphasis in this course on how educational psychology can be practically applied was especially appreciated.
For those in TPP or have a general interest in this field, I really strongly recommend this course. It is a lot of work but definitely worth it
It is an enjoyable course, but I did not learn as much as I would have liked. At the same time, Professor Glat is very kind and thoughtful and the material is interesting.

It's a great course - Prof Glat is awesome, tried to make the class topics interesting and relevant to his students' interests and listens to suggestions for how things can be improved.  Definitely a ton of work between classroom observations, weekly response papers, a presentation, and midterm and final papers, but if you're interested in it - I say definitely go for it!
Make sure you start papers and schedule observation hours early!!
Manage your time well, as there is a lot of work. However, Professor Glat is very accommodating and willing to work with you if you ever need extensions, and the class is very interesting.
Start readings as early as possible - they take a while!

This course is lit. It is full of dank memes waiting to happen. Take it if you are at all interested in studying education/education policy or ever becoming a teacher. Will also change the way you think about yourself as a student.

This is solid course, but I am not sure I would recommend unless you need it for teacher prep. The mash-up of education and psychology can be confusing if you don't have a strong background in psych. But it is a great way to hear about some cool concepts and discuss education.
otherinfo: Each student - alone or with a partner - will assume responsibility for conducting one class session.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Average of 6-hour reading per class. Students are required to submit written reflections weekly, on readings assigned. Students will also be required to observe in a local classroom for a total of 12 hours during the semester.
prereqs: This course is open to juniors and seniors who are concentrating in Psychology. It is also required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Others may enroll with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.
title: Educational Psychology

evals: A good class to take if you are extremely interested in linguistics and genuinely excited to stay up to date on course work, or alternatively if you want a class with only take home assignments and work that can pretty much be ignored on a day to day bais.

An interesting course and subject in general -- really makes you think about the ways that we learn, use, and understand language in our daily lives. Lectures are engaging and the workload is relatively light.

Be sure to go to lecture. There isn't much work and the exams are take-home, but if you don't learn the material, they're still really difficult. Plus, they're pretty lengthy and you don't want to spend your entire day reading up on the material so that you can do well on the tests. Try to stay engaged during class, but fair warning, they can be dry at times. Some topics are better than others, but overall the material is pretty fascinating. More psychology than linguistics in my opinion, but there definitely is a mix.
Go to classes and enjoy the course!

It's an easy, engaging, relevant, interesting course. Homework and exams are open-everything, don't have to participate in precepts, etc. makes it very chill. Take it and listen to every single word in lectures and precepts.
Pretty easy workload but super interesting and informative. I don't know why anyone wouldn't go to the lectures they're interesting and engaging!
Strongly recommend to linguistics students, great way to understand other side of Universal Grammar and other debates from a psychology perspective. Great course for LIN certificate.
Take it
Take it!!!! Professor Adele is amazing, lectures are always interesting and the readings are very comprehendible. Even if you haven't taken 201 before, the class is accessible! A great 5th class!
This course is both fun and informative.
This is an AMAZING course. Adele is a wonderful person and teacher, and you will learn so much, even if you have no prior experience with linguistics or psychology.
adele's an awesome professor, you'd be lucky to have her!
great
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Approximately 50 pages and one or two short articles
descrip: The cognitive processes underlying the use and understanding of language, and in learning to speak. Topics include speech production and perception, grammar and meaning, knowledge and words, and pragmatic aspects of language.
title: Psychology of Language

evals: I would recommend this seminar.
If you are interested to acquire a broad view of state-of-the-art neuroscience studies in various fields, I highly recommend this seminar course!
No comments worthy of note.
n/a
otherinfo: Princeton Neuroscience Institute graduate students are required to participate in the neuroscience departmental colloquium. The grading is either Pass or Fail based on attendance. The seminar is open to the entire research community at Princeton. Students from other programs do not need to sign up for the course.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.
title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior

otherinfo: Designed for Psychology graduate students. Others require Instructor's Permission.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 100%
descrip: Current research and issues in cognition, perception, and learning. Seminar participants present ongoing research and discuss current topics of interest in the literature.
title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 100%
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.
title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research

evals: I would definitely recommend taking this class if you are interested in the idea of hormonally active pollutants and endocrine disruptors. Work load is manageable, but engaging and informative
Only take this course if you need it for an EEB departmental.
This class is honestly very easy and the workload is low (one 1.5-2pg easy summary write-up each week and an easy final paper).  The material is also very interesting. For sure take it.

Would highly recommend this class. Professor Ruderman is great and the material is very interesting and relevant to your life. The weekly short papers are very manageable and it is not hard to excel in this class.
take it! I think someone without any knowledge of endocrine disrupting chemicals especially has a lot to learn!
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Other Exam - 20%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Students will read approximately 200 pages per week; two take-home exams, and a term paper.
descrip: Americans have built and preserved an astounding variety of environments. The course examines the evolving complex of incentives and regulations that drove the choices of where and how places developed. It focuses on the emergence of land-use and environmental planning as a way to encourage or discourage growth and to mitigate or intensify its environmental, social, and economic effects.We will examine the latest tools for building and protecting the American landscape. Case studies include Southern California, New Haven, the American Great Plains, and others. Analysis will be from historical, policy-oriented, and predictive perspectives.
title: Topics in Environmental Studies - Building American Style: Land-Use Policies and Rules

evals: A great way to fulfill HA with interesting readings. Totally manageable amount of work.
Absolutely loved this class. Not a lot of work, and learned a lot
Attend all lectures as Professor Stone is great. Also try and understand the key ideas of emptiness and non-duality because they do a lot when understanding everything else.

Buddhism is a profound world religion. So you should probably know something about it. This class is a very good overview of many kinds of Buddhisms and how its developed over history and even affected society. It's not too demanding. There is a good chunk of reading, but you can normally get away with doing a bit of it only. Lectures are where I learned the most and they were quite fascinating. I'd reccomend it!
Decently low commitment, but may be difficult to completely grasp concepts and obtain A's on the papers
Definitely take the course if you have an interest in learning about a world view that differs immensely from yours. Professor Stone is excellent in this course.
Do the readings and ALL the blackboard responses. Don't forget to comment on other student's blackboard responses
Don't go to lecture if you do the reading, it's almost unbearable. However, the course materials and readings are quite good

Easy HA. Weekly blackboard posts, take home midterm and final. They graded the midterm kinda harshly but they said they wouldn't grade the final as harshly. If you're lazy like me, a typical week was: skip lecture, post on blackboard doing minimal amount of readings, try and make it look like I did more of the readings in precept, take notes during precept (very helpful), repeat. Use past blackboard posts as starting point when doing take home exams. Easy fifth class.
Good overview of Buddhism, not life changing but definitely gives a new perspective to see things

I can't recommend this course enough. The material was very interesting. The workload was very reasonable, and Prof. Stone is a great lecturer, if a bit eccentric. I took this as a distribution requirement and planned on PDFing, but I found it interesting enough that I took it for a grade.

Side note: If you don't have time to do all of the readings each week, just read the primary sources. The secondary sources give nice background information, but aren't necessary for precept discussion or papers.
If at all interested, take it. Professor Stone is wonderful and you'll come out feeling like you got your tuition's worth of learning.

If you're interested in learning more about Buddhism from a historical and doctrinal standpoint, take this class. It's not a mind-blowing class in the philosophy of Buddhism but it was very informational on background of Buddhism.
Interesting and relatively laid-back course, but a little disappointing in terms of the depth in which we explored the material.
It's an interesting class, but the take home midterm and final are horrible.
Not the most interesting course I've taken, but it's a great HA with a small workload.
Pretty light class with light homework and take-home exams.  Still pretty thought-provoking and cleared up a lot of my misconceptions about Buddhism.  Definitely recommend for a fifth class.
Some of the readings are hard to grasp so make sure to understand the material before going to precept.

TAKE THIS COURSE if you're interested at all in eastern religion, it's taught VERY well and is really not that much work (you can get by doing a few readings a week) and the take-homes are definitely manageable!  Really interesting course.
Take it - Prof. Stone is really good and summarises the readings in her lectures. If you PDF it's almost impossible to fail as long as you go to precept.
Take it as a pdf or out of interest. It does require some work, though.

Take it! Don't worry about your prior background in Buddhism, nothing is assumed. I had never taken a Buddhism (or Religion) course, but all of the material was completely approachable. It's a great HA.
Take this class if you are even vaguely interested in religion, Buddhism or ancient cultures!

Take this class! Buddhism is so fascinating to learn about, and Professor Stone is so sweet and a wonderful teacher (and we had such interesting discussions in her precept). Not too much work, compelling subject matter, and great professor!

Take this course if you are even a little interested in Buddhism. The material is interesting and manageable. Professor Stone is a great lecturer who is passionate the material; she is also a great preceptor. Overall, I highly recommend this course.
Take this course if you want to learn about buddhism and religion.
Take this, expand your mind

The course will give you a rough overview of Buddhism but it makes you think about many aspects of life differently and learning about Buddhist philosophy is very interesting. Not to mention the class is not much work beyond readings and blackboard posts.
This course is interesting and enjoyable. Professor Stone is super nice and a great lecturer.
This course was really excellent, you learn a lot and Professor Stone is an interesting lecturer.

This is a fairly easy class, especially when comparing it to others.  It's not too difficult to get a decent grade.  Professor Stone and the preceptors really care about you learning the material and improving.  I would strongly recommend this if you have a free class.
This is an interesting class if you would like to learn about Buddhism. It's not particularly demanding. The readings are interesting.
Very interesting class! Definitely recommended.
other, better classes out there. Super easy pdf but not fun to take for a grade as its a little dry.
pretty boring if you don't care about really theoretical religious beliefs. not really much history for your HA; a few somewhat interesting fictional stories.
take it if you are curious about Buddhism
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 35%, Take Home Final Exam - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 100+ pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course surveys the development of Buddhism from its beginnings in India through some of its later forms in East Asia, Tibet, and the West. Attention will be given to continuity and diversity within Buddhism, its modes of self-definition as a religious tradition, the interplay of its practical and trans-worldly concerns, and its transformations in specific historical and cultural settings.
title: The Buddhist World of Thought and Practice

evals: An interesting course to take, but can be disorganized at times. Deceptive amount of reading--what it lacks in page length it makes up for in obscurity.
Best class I've taken at Princeton. If Meshel is teaching, this course is a must for anyone with an interest in religion.

Definitely consider taking this course.  Professor Meshel is brilliant, not to mention quite witty, and you will learn a lot about the bible.  The course was a bit scattered, attempting to cover a vast amount of material in a short time, so be prepared for that, but you will still learn a lot .  Also, though it is not a requirement to know the bible pretty well beforehand (I didn't), it is certainly a big advantage.  This is also not an easy HA, so be prepared to do the readings and participate in class.

Definitely recommend for anyone interested in studying the Bible!! The course with Professor Meshel is one of the best I've taken in Princeton, and it really challenges you to think about the Bible very differently. He's a wonderful and engaging professor who really cares about teaching the material.
Definitely take this class.
I would probably recommend this course to students with background knowledge on this type of material, and not to students who are not interested in the concentration.
If Professor Meshel is teaching, take this course. He is an absolute riot and you'll learn a ton.
If you are at all interested in the material, then you will find this course easy to work with. Stay on top of readings and give yourself time to reflect on them before attending lecture.

If you have some familiarity with the Hebrew Bible but want a professor who will provide interesting perspectives and great conversations (that continue throughout the semester), take it! If you don't have any familiarity, unless you are willing to put in a pretty good deal of work, be cautious.
It's a fun class. Take it. There will we a lot of people who have a lot of experience with the material though.

Its a highly interesting class.  Professor Meshel is really smart and nice but you 100% have to do the readings because he will call on you out of the blue no matter how much you try to hide!  Good though, not too bad of a workload

Sadly Prof. Meshel will be leaving after this year, so any feedback means little. However, I did really enjoy the course. Meshel is one of the most brilliant professors I've ever had, and I learned a surprising amount, despite the class being somewhat disorganized. If by some miracle Meshel ever returns, I'd highly recommend taking a course with him.
Take it if you have any interest in seeing the Bible in a new/different way!
Take it! It doesn't take too much time out of your day and Prof Meshel is fantastic. He's enthusiastic, engaging and you can tell he's excited about sharing the subject with his students.
Take it. Meshel is great. He expects a good amount from you, but the class is worth it.
read a lot.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 70 pages of reading per week; short one-page bi-weekly essays; midterm exam; take home final exam.
descrip: The course will introduce students to the Hebrew Bible ("Old Testament") in its ancient Near Eastern setting. Key concepts often associated with the Hebrew Bible, such as God, damnation, sin, and history, will be scrutinized through a careful reading of a selection of Biblical texts including the Creation and Garden of Eden narratives in Genesis, the laws of Leviticus, the prophecies of Ezekiel and the poetry of Song of Songs. Particular attention will be paid to the transformations that the texts underwent through a continuous process of transmission and interpretation.
title: Who Wrote the Bible

evals: A fantastic course. A wonderful engaging professor. An interesting approach to meaty subject matter. Great class to PDF. Highly Recommend.
Always do the readings -- always.

As a Christian, this course forced me to really think through some presuppositions I had about the Bible. Pagels presents some provocative questions, but if you are willing to make the effort to look at all sides of the issue, the class can be SO enriching. However, if you want to take it as an easy HA, be warned that you will likely come out with an extremely skewed perception of Christianity. Pagels is just an amazing professor and thinker, so you should totally take her class, but if she's not teaching it, I would think twice.
Do the reading
Do the readings and look up definitions on words you don't know.
I strongly encourage all students to take this course, regardless of their concentration.  It was perhaps the most pleasant challenge I have encountered during my time at Princeton so far.

Prepare to allocate a lot of time to the readings each week, and really focus on the message and importance each reading is trying to express. It will greatly help with the short papers and written exams.

Professor Pagels is a top scholar in her field for a reason. She is very knowledgeable, and she genuinely loves the subject and loves teaching it. Pick the research paper over the take-home final because even though they're both difficult, the research paper will be more interesting because you pick your own topic. The grading system is a little unclear though.
Take it, it's interesting. Not too bad, you don't really need to do all the readings.
Take it. Prof Pagels knows her stuff. The level of reading is fair and the papers throughout the semester were the easiest ones I've ever had to write.

Take this class whether you are a Christian or not. This class will give you a new knowledge not only about history but also about faith. It was one of the most important classes that I have taken at Princeton
This is a really interesting course. Consider taking it.
This is an amazing course, take it if you have the chance!
Use a lot of primary sources in the papers.
You learn so much. Really enlightening course.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Approximately 75-100 pages of reading per week; take-home midterm; leading precept discussion one week on topic of your choice; active participation in precepts; your choice of take-home final or research paper.
descrip: Who was Jesus of Nazareth, and how do we know about him? Why did some interpretations of truth -- and his message -- win out over others? How have these particular ways of thinking influenced western culture, shaping our views of politics, race and ethnicity, sexuality and gender, civil and human rights even now? To answer questions like these, we'll investigate the earliest gospels, letters, Jewish and Roman sources, prison diaries and martyr accounts -- as well as how artists, filmmakers, musicians and theologians interpret them. Regardless of religious background, or none, you will learn a lot, and be able to contribute.
title: Jesus: How Christianity Began

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A critical introduction to developments in social theory that have influenced the academic study of religion, including the classic contributions of Marx, Durkheim, and Weber as well as more recent debates in anthropology and cultural theory. Required of, and designed for, first- and second-year graduate students in religion; others must receive the instructor's permission to enroll.
title: Religion and the Tradition of Social Theory

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The goal of this course is to introduce a significant part of the literature of the Jews of Palestine and Egypt in the period from Alexander to the destruction of the Second Temple, together with a sampling of some recent scholarship on these works. The introduction is necessarily selective, and it thus reflects to some degree my interests and reoccupations, but I make an effort to give you some sense of the range of Jewish texts in the period. I hope that this breadth of coverage provides the background you need for your own work.
title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - Introduction to Judaism in the Greco-Roman World

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: In this course we engage questions of approach, method, periodization, and scope in the study of religion in America through the Civil War. Texts consist of secondary literature with both classic and contemporary importance to the field, along with brief primary sources selected and presented by students.
title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - Religion in America to 1865

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The number of people who claim to be "atheist" or who claim no religion or religious affiliation has grown tremendously in the last half century. Although "atheism" has been a part of American history since the Colonial era, more Americans from among a vast cross section of society now claim to be "God-less." This course examines this trend as an aspect of American historical and religious studies. We pay particular attention to the writings of the "New Atheists," who have done the most to articulate the perspectives of this group and to reveal it as a crucial and increasingly important aspect of American society.
title: Special Topics in the Study of Religion - "God-less": The History of Atheism in America

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course introduces students to the tools of the discipline of papyrology. The two main components are 1. how to write history with ancient papyrus documents and 2. the material history of books (new philology). We work with a broad range of papyri, mainly in Greek, so strong knowledge of Greek is required.
title: Special Topics in the Study of Religion - Papyrology and Late Antique History

evals: A great course, but if you are taking for Italian credit make sure you are ready linguistically, because it is difficult to compete in exams and papers alongside your peers who will be taking the course in English.
Fantastic course. Marchesi is amazing. Maybe try to read at least a summary of The Aeneid beforehand.
I would say to really take the time to make sure you understand what you are reading before you go to class.

If you are very interested in Dante (and Virgil!), take this course! I have really enjoyed it, but I think it would be a difficult course if you are not invested in the subject matter. Do the reading each week very carefully. If you neglect that throughout the semester, studying for the exams will be very difficult.

If you're genuinely interested in learning about Italian literature, history, and culture, take this class! It's a fantastic opportunity to learn about The Inferno, and from one of the leading experts in the world. Be careful to read closely, however, and constantly keep in mind potential topics for your final paper.

Studying Dante at Princeton is a must!  The tradition here is so strong, and the interdisciplinary nature of the poem means you can apply your expert knowledge from any field and come to a variety of new thoughts and conclusions.
TAKE THIS COURSE! It is easily one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton and is worth every person (not just humanities majors) taking it.
Take it if you want to learn more about The Inferno, which means you will be learning a bit about everything.
Take it, especially if you speak Italian. I imagine you'll get more out of the course if you can read the text in its original language.
Take this class!

Take this course. Everyone should study Dante's work, one of the greatest references in world literature. Professor Marchesi is exceptional - creative, enthusiastic, funny, clear. It's also a great opportunity for an in-depth analysis of a literature work.
Take this course. Princeton is rightly seen as one of the greatest places to study Dante. Prof. Hollander's legacy lives on in Prof. Marchesi.
otherinfo: Course will take advantage of the wide array of resources available on campus to Dante students, from Firestone's holdings to the web-based Princeton Dante Project. Section P01 will be conducted in English, P99 will be conducted in Italian.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: The weekly readings are short in length (ca. 25 pages), but demand a great deal of intensive work (a minimum of 5-6 hours would seem necessary).
descrip: Intensive study of the "Inferno", with major attention paid to poetic elements such as structure, allegory, narrative technique, and relation to earlier literature, principally the Latin classics. Course conducted in English with highly interactive classes and preceptorials. An Italian precept will be offered.
title: Dante's "Inferno"

evals: Definitely take this course if you're interested in Russian.  It is difficult but well taught.

Do not take this course unless you are seriously interested in devoting a large amount of time to learning the Russian language. The course moves very quickly, and it necessitates a lot of work outside of the classroom. This is not a class to take "for fun;" that being said, you will learn a lot. Also be advised that 3/5th of the course is taught by a graduate student.

Drill vocabulary and conjugations every single night; it is not, in fact, possible to learn significant portions of a language the night before tests, even if it is possible to memorize material for other subjects on that time frame.
For those who want to learn Russian, I definitely suggest taking this course.
I was happy with the other students' participation.

If you want to learn Russian, this class will definitely be your best chance. I learned more Russian in one semester than I did high school German in 5 years. The professor was very helpful and I recommend this class to anyone who is thinking of taking it. Just be aware that, as you may tell by my comparison is my German, it moves at an IMMENSE pace to begin with. Be prepared to be shocked at how quickly it moves. However, it definitely slowed down at the end of the semester as I felt the initial speed made me learn very very quickly.

Keep up with the textbook and study vocab/concepts for at least a little as often as you can. This will save you so much time and stress when preparing for exams since there is a huge amount of information to go through. You will definitely learn a lot though.

Make sure you take the time to seriously review the material each night. The course can seem very overwhelming at times if you have not encountered the language before, but if you can stay on top of the work and not be afraid to ask for help when you are confused, the course is quite rewarding.

Mark does a good job in teaching you the basics of Russian, which is a very hard language.  Mark's style of teaching is not the best so make sure you have a good preceptor.  David is the best and then Massimo, idk about other preceptors.  The hw is easy, it just takes forever and is mind-numbing.  If you want to do well in this course you should try and review on your own time (the hw doesn't count).  Because the hw is not graded, I think it more beneficial to review on your own than do the hw.
Prof. Pettus is a wonderful teacher.
Russian is a difficult language -- there are very few cognates with English to help you; however, it is a very intriguing language taught by a very good professor.
Russian is a sick language and everyone in the department is rad. The course is run like a well oiled machine.
Russian takes a lot of time commitment for someone with no experience but its really a fascinating language and culture.
Take the course but be prepared to study a lot and often. Make sure you study outside of the worksheets!
Take this class if you love learning languages! Russian is honesty not that hard if you put some effort into it plus this class is taught pretty well
Take this course if you have any interest in Russian. Pettus is a great professor and the course is well designed to give you a strong foundation of Russian grammar and vocabulary.
strongly recommended
otherinfo: This course will be offered each fall term, followed by RUS102, taught by the same instructors. No credit is given for RUS 101 unless it is followed by RUS 102.
grading: Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Various types of written and oral exercises from the textbook/workbook.
descrip: After learning the Russian alphabet and handwriting in just a few days, we'll continue with daily lessons using original materials - each day covering a basic aspect of Russian grammar and building incrementally. Special emphasis will be placed on learning to express your own feelings and ideas in natural, idiomatic Russian, preparing you to engage with Russian speakers and real Russian texts, and delving into Russian culture, history, music, and literature as we go, learning the language in its own unique and incredibly rich cultural context. The year will end with a sampling of Soviet prose and poetry in the original.
title: Beginner's Russian I

evals: I would suggest making time to speak Russian, either w the instructor or at the weekly speaking groups.
If you want to continue Russian, then I already know that you will take this course.

Mark is very knowledgeable about the language and culture and guides you through his books well. Class is, for the most part, being guided through the books. They're fine books, by the way. Your Russian grammar will improve for sure. However, if you want to improve at speaking Russian, there is no other way but to speak Russian outside of class. Go to Russian table at least. Mark is very accommodating with attendance and I've always felt like the goal of the class was learning and not studying to a test.
if you've already taken two semesters why would you stop now
grading: Final Exam - 15%, Quizzes - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Written work on and oral discussions. Daily written assignments and short compositions on new vocabulary topics.
prereqs: RUS 102 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Using original textbooks that focus on the Imperial period of Russian culture by incorporating literature and paintings from the period, we will look at more advanced grammar topics, such as prefixed verbs of motion and de-verbal forms (verbal adjectives, adverbs and nouns), that are essential for reading literary Russian. Later in the semester, we will read a selection of classical Russian poetry and prose, from such authors as Pushkin, Lermontov, Chekhov, Nekrasov, and Tolstoy. All readings will be done in the original, with extensive vocabulary and notes provided.
title: Intermediate Russian I

evals: I liked the oral presentations, they were on interesting topics. We spent a lot of time on ??? though. I would have preferred spending that time teaching the concepts in the textbook instead of just doing homework activities on them and assuming we know them.

I would seriously recommend against taking this class unless you absolutely have to. Unfortunately, in many cases (like if you want any certificate), you absolutely have to. That said, my level of Russian did not improve at all through this class, except for by work I did on my own outside of class. You should be at a level where self-study is possible by the time you can enroll in this class. Do that instead. Seriously, if you know your cases even kind of (not asking that much of you after TWO YEARS of Russian), then this class will be not only a complete waste of time, but also actively horrible. For those of you that have to take this class, I'm sorry.
Keep up with your readings and make sure you understand what you are reading/writing down.
This is a good way to keep the level of Russian steady, but to improve, the student needs to put in their own effort.
otherinfo: Other 20% is homework and oral presentations.
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Short texts, grammar exercises, oral presentations.
prereqs: RUS 107 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A literature/language course designed to further develop speaking and reading proficiency, comprehension and writing skills through substantial expansion of vocabulary, work on sentence structure, review of selected grammar topics, discussion of the literary texts, and work with a movie.
title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation I

grading: Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 25%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Average 3000 words of reading per week. Three quizzes and a final.
prereqs: SLA 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: All readings are in Russian. This course traces the development of the Russian short story from the 1830's to 1930's. The entire course is conducted in Russian and special emphasis is placed on active use of the language.
title: The Russian Short Story

evals: Great class.  Professor Hasty really makes the material engaging and the performance at the end of the year is a lot of fun.
I would tell them it's a good course. If you are interested in Russian, this is an opportunity to improve your skills in a fun way.
Take this class if you want to practice your Russian in a fun way by reading aloud famous Russian plays and discussing them. Great class!

This is the best course for anyone interested in Russian language/culture/literature! It promotes lots of discussions, enhances writing, reading, and pronunciation skills, and teaches to interpret what meaning the great Russian dramatists tried to convey in their great works.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Reading: Approximately 20 pp of Russian text per week. Writing: Two short essays (2-3pp), one longer essay (5-8pp) in Russian.
prereqs: RUS 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is devoted to the reading and discussion of masterpieces of 19th and 20th century Russian drama. It will also provide students with an opportunity to develop aural, oral, and written language skills. Classes are conducted entirely in Russian and all readings are to be done in the original. Students will participate in a performance project at the end of the term.
title: Russian Drama

evals: A great introduction to Russian literature. Professor Vinitsky is a little quirky but very passionate about the material.
Do the readings! They're super fun so it won't really seem like a chore.

If Vinitsky teaches this again as a seminar I would recommend it. The readings were all fabulous and I loved hearing him talk about the history and biographies of people involved in the literature scene at the time. This semester it seemed like people weren't very-engaged which led to some lackluster class participation.
If you are interested in Russian literature, this is a great introductory class! Definitely take it with prof. Vinitsky!

Professor Vinitsky is an amazing professor who genuinely cares about the material. The course felt like it was less geared towards testing us on the material and more towards actually teaching us the material. He took the pressure off from grades to help us enjoy and actually learn the material. I really highly recommend this course!
Professor Vinitsky is the best! Def get to know him personally by talking to him after class, going to his office hours, etc.

The readings are about 50-100 pages per week in the beginning of the semester and grow to about 150-200 pages per week towards the end. If you don't do the readings, it's not worth taking the class. If you do the readings, the rest of the class is pretty easy.
otherinfo: Open to Freshmen.
grading: Quizzes - 15%, Papers - 60%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: One short paper (about 5 pages), one longer paper (10-12 pages).
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not required..
descrip: A study in English of masterpieces of Russian literature from the late eighteenth to the mid-nineteenth century. The focus of the course is on close readings of individual works. At the same time, we will pay close attention to the way a distinctively Russian national tradition is created, in which writers consciously respond to the works of their predecessors. No previous knowledge of Russian language, history, or culture is expected.
title: Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky: Introduction to the Great Russian Novel

evals: Attend lectures and precepts

Be sure to attend lectures. Realistically, if you attend lectures, you do not have to do much to prepare for exams outside of reviewing lecture notes. This class is very manageable and very insightful, providing differing perspectives on a number of issues that I think everyone should have some exposure to in their college careers.
DO THE READINGS! they were very helpful
Definitely take this course. Very interesting and great introduction to sociology.

Do not take this course unless you have to. Also, do not take this course if you have already taken an upper level SOC class. You WILL be bored. Also, be prepared to be happy with your midterm and final grade, as you will never be able to talk to your preceptor or professor about it, and you wont really know how you are doing in the course until you get your grade at the end of the year.
Do take it!
Doesn't seem that necessary tbh, it's more of just a reading list that one could learn in a few weeks, but take it if you like, if it sounds interesting, it probably is.
Easy course and interesting but only take if you are planning to study Sociology.
Go to precept
Good class, do the majority of the readings, as the exam is based almost entirely on your understanding of those.
Great course to take for distribution requirement or if just for general interest. This will be one of your favorite classes.

Great intro. Professor Duneier is very enjoyable to listen to, in my opinion. So go to lecture! The readings are often long, but usually relevant and easy to understand. Other than readings, workload is light- just a paragraph memo on the readings every week.
Have fun
I recommend this class to upcoming students.

I take it to familiarize myself with social issues in the US and am generally satisfied with it. I was not interested in all of the topics, but I am confident talking about some of them that I felt relatable. Now I can say I improved my understanding of sociology, but not necessarily how to move on from here. I'd say read the readings and take notes and use them in preparation for the exams.
I would definitely recommend this course. The material is engaging and fairly simple although lectures can become a little boring at times.

I would not take this class unless you have to for SOC because other SOC classes get more deep into things and you learn more from them. If you are the type to do all your readings even if long and boring, you can easily get an A in this class. if you slack off like me, maybe not!
I would recommend at least skimming every reading before its corresponding lecture, because lecture is harder to follow if you read afterwards.

I would recommend this course for anyone with an interest in sociology, who has never taken a sociology course before, or who would like an additional course that is not too much work or pressure but that is very interesting. It allows you to think about certain things-both in the world and here at Princeton-in a much different way, something that I think is valuable and very applicable to our daily lives. Duneier is fantastic and funny and very engaging. Go to lecture because you will not regret one moment!

I wouldn't take this class again. The readings were very interesting, but I didn't do any of them until the last few weeks before the final because he would assign such an absurd amount of reading for one or two nights that it became so overwhelming and I didn't do any of them (literally he would assign like 100-400 pages each night).
If Mitch is teaching it, take it.

If Prof Duneier is teaching, take this course regardless of your major--you will learn such relevant topics that will help you better understand the world you live in and it will make you a more thoughtful, better person. Readings are fascinating (would want to read on my own time) and Duneier is funny and engaging in lecture.

If you have to take it, it's not horrible but it's not a typical 101 class.  Don't expect to actually learn anything theoretical or concrete about sociology.  Everything you get out of this class will be what Mitch decides you do through the readings he assigns.
If you're going to take this class, take it with Mitch Duneier! I recommend it to anyone who wants a better understanding of topics including race, gender, class, etc.
Interesting class for kids who are interested in sociology.

Intersting course. I took it as an easy 5th class, and it really isn't too much work. All you really have to do are the readings, but I would recommend going to lecture as they are usually interesting. Duneier is a really good professor in my opinion.

Keep up with readings and attend lectures. Duneier is great!

Never be afraid to talk in lecture, and make sure you go to lecture! Even if you do not talk in lecture, the information that professor says is very helpful to understanding the materials.
Pay attention in lecture
Professor Duneier is the best! Take this course with him if you can
Stay on top of all the readings. They aren't long or dense, but learning them well is important for the midterm and final.

TAKE IT! You won't have any other courses at Princeton that help you to learn more about yourself, the school, the people around you, the society around you, and the world around you like this one will. Mitch is probably one of the best professors at this school and it's a absolute joy to be sitting in on his lectures, especially when he shares his life stories (which are amazing). A must-take if you're choosing between this and some other introductory course. I can honestly say that if I had taken this course freshmen year, I would have been a SOC major.

Take it if you're interested in learning more about what sociology is, especially if you're thinking about concentrating. But if you're just interested in SOC, I highly recommend one of the other more in-depth classes in the department, as they are much more interesting and the same level of difficulty, generally.
Take it only if interested. Professor Duneier is the best dressed Professor at the school.
Take it!
Take it! It is an interesting course with a lot great discussion. Professor Duneier is also a phenomenal lecturer!
Take it, especially if just seeing what sociology is all about! Interesting material and weekly memo assignments.
Take it, especially if you have an interest in sociology!!
Take notes on the readings so you don't have to reread them before the exam.

Take this class with Duneier, although if you're conservative politically be ready to have your blood boiling in lecture. Easy class, but a lot of students get to talk during the lectures, and most of them are pretty liberal and make their comments seem as if they attack conservatives, although it's still a great class to have if you don't let that bother you
Take this class! Great way to get an idea of what sociology is all about.
Take this class! Prof. Duneier wants his students to learn the material and do well.
Take this class, you won't regret it.

Take this course if you are interested in Sociology. Work is not too hard or difficult. Everything is reasonable, and you just learn a lot of things that are relevant in your life in general. Recommend!

Take this course! Professor Duneier is a really great professor and goes over what was in the reading really clearly. As long as you pay attention in lecture and follow along with the readings, you can definitely get an A.
Take this course! The concepts are fascinating and this is the perfect challenge as an introductory sociology course.
Taking notes as you read the material throughout the year will make studying for the exams much easier.

The readings are genuinely interesting and it is important to keep up with them although no one will push you to do so.

This is an amazing intro course for anyone with an interest in sociology or just looking to fulfill the requirements.  If you pay attention and take notes in the lectures, you could do quite well in this course and the exams without doing the readings at all.  This class is challenging enough to be interesting, without being overwhelming.  If you're considering taking it, do it.
Understand big picture of readings and how different readings relate to each other
You should definitely take this course. It asks you to think about sociology as it applies to the real world, and it's a completely non-pressured environment in terms of grading. Duneier is amazing
definitely take it! easy and enjoyable!
great
keep up with the readings, they're actually interesting
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately 200 pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course introduces sociology as a subject with a key role to play in modern intellectual culture and a central place within the social sciences. A range of topics such as race, class, gender, deviance, ethnocentrism, crime, families, urban life, social interaction, and social inequality will be covered. Lectures are intended to inspire students to draw on their sociological imagination to become more publicly involved and directly engaged in the real world.
title: Introduction to Sociology

evals: A lot of readings, redundant and disorganized lectures, but all the while relatively easy!
At times it will feel pointless, but it's pretty easy and interesting at some points.
Definitely go ahead and take it, do the readings because they are interesting
Definitely take the class! Professor PFK is very engaging and nice.
Do most of the readings, at least so you can talk in precepts. PFK is a great lecturer (and sometimes takes random attendance) so I wouldn't miss her lectures :)
Don't take this class unless you're super interested in the topic or absolutely need to. It is really boring. And there is a lot of writing.
Go to lectures and participate in precepts
Good class, easy PDF.

If one is interested in the study of city development in terms of sociology, you should take the course.

Get in PFK's precept and participate, and make sure you get to know her. She is way more interested in you understanding the topic than necessarily being the best student, which makes it a very enriching class and good for your overall knowledge.
If you're cool being sermonized at by a bleeding-heart liberal twice a week, then take for an easy class with material that can be interesting/relevant.
