Make sure already know a good amount of Spanish when you take this course, especially since the first day she talks in Spanish a bunch

Make sure to take notes on all of the Aprendo activities that you are assigned, complete unassigned Aprendo activities, and learn as much of the vocabulary as you can and try to incorporate those words/phrases in your writing and speaking.
Overall, an easy class to take as long as you complete all the assigned assignments on time. Finish your aprendo assignment for each night as the next class will be based on homework.
Plenty of work, but definitely engaging and definitely an effective way to learn Spanish.
Prepare for a lot of homework, but you'll definitely enjoy the professors in the Spanish department

Profesora Alsina is the best hands down. Very very fair grader. As long as you put in the effort you will get an A. Make sure to triple check work. I can almost guarantee that you perhaps used the wrong article or adjective.

Speak Spanish outside of class and try to take some of the learning into your own hands. You're learning a language, not just content--treat it as such, and you'll both enjoy the course and do well in it.
Stay on top of the activities and review the grammar carefully!! It will really help when the time comes for the tests.
Study for tests and work hard on the writing work. Solid class overall, but the Aprendo homework is terrible.
Take this class if you can!
Take this course with Le Anne. She is the most helpful professor that I have ever seen.
The course is a big time commitment, but you'll learn a lot very quickly.
The most important part of this class is to practice outside of the class, either with your classmates or with Spanish-speaking friends of yours.
This course is a great course. I advise to always make sure you do the homework because it will prepare you for class the next day. Also, give yourself plenty of time for the projects.
This course was manageable and very interesting!
This is a good course to take and Spanish is widely used around the world.  This Spanish course in particular made me feel more comfortable speaking.
This is a great course! The projects and homework are all interesting. Though there are a lot of assignments, the workload isn't too bad as long as you manage your time.

This is a very fun class. It does not move so fast that it becomes hard to keep up with the material but it also does not move so slow that it becomes a boring class. All of the professors are great about being approachable and are awesome teachers. This class is an excellent way to meet your language requirements.

Unlike high school, this class is more discussion and orally based. The content is interesting, and having taken 3 years of Spanish in high school, SPA 103 is a really good refresher class and a class that will teach you some new grammar topics. Get Professor Naudi! She is the sweetest teacher!
Watch for attendances and be sure you are participating in all of the group activities.
You get out what you put in to the course.
otherreq: SPA 103 not allowed if SPA 101 or 102 taken.
otherinfo: Offered only in the fall term. Followed by SPA 107 to complete the language requirement.
grading: Quizzes - 25%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Approximately two lessons per week. Weekly assignments include: online exercises, brief reading and writing assignments, conversation activities, audiovisual assignments, several quizzes, and a final project.
prereqs: A satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: SPA 103 is an intensive course that covers the most relevant structures and vocabulary from SPA 101 and SPA 102 in one term. Designed for students who have previously studied Spanish at elementary levels. Language is presented in a cultural context in order to develop the skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing.
title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate Spanish

evals: Be prepared for the overload of projects and assessments in the last month.
Classic SPA 105

Definitely take this class and take it seriously. Put the time and effort into your homework and you will reap the rewards on the tests. It is easy to be complacent, but if you put in the effort, you will do well.
Do the grammar and readings without falling behind. This class with Prof. Goncalves is fun and entertaining as well as useful for building Spanish skills.
Do the homework, all of it, every time. Contribute as much as humanly possible.

Don't be scared of taking 105 instead of 103. It is totally worth it. Besides the benefit of only having class 3x a week, the content is pretty straightforward if you read the textbook and pay attention during grammar lessons.
Great course!
Great course. The work is worth the effort.
Great if you have L. Goncalves.
Highly recommend this class because you have to take it at some point if you want to continue speaking Spanish and it's a very fun class.

I highly recommend taking this class with Andie. During my class, we spoke a lot in Spanish and I definitely feel like my language abilities flourished. Compositions are graded pretty harshly, but if you ask for help with office hours and revise a few times, you will definitely do better them. Homework assignments are very time-consuming, but they are really interesting and thought-provoking. Exams aren't that difficult. Highly recommend taking this class!

I highly recommend this course for anyone looking to fulfill the language requirement or just to improve Spanish ability! Profesora Andie is AMAZING and I highly recommend her. The coursework is not bad at all, and it is very doable as long as you give it the time it deserves (which is not a lot of time).

I recommend taking this course, not only because it allows you to fulfill the language requirement, but because it serves as a good review of previously-learned Spanish language skills and teaches interesting themes of Spanish culture. Additionally, it helps improve speaking, reading, and writing skills.
I think this course did take up a significant amount of my workload, and while I'm glad I took it, I think the experience is very dependent on the professor.
I would definitely recommend this course because it was challenging, but not impossible. I think my Spanish definitely improved as well!
I would highly encourage students to participate in Spanish language tables.  These are very helpful, likely the most important practice for learning a language.
If you take this class, make sure that you are interested in history and do not mind studying grammar. The work load is pretty manageable but gets a little repetitive.
It is far more challenging than language classes you've taken in high school! It is a class that you have to really pay engage with on a daily basis--not for a good grade, but simply to enjoy it.
Its an easy course, take it to fill your distribution requirement.
Just be sure to comprehend the readings, give effort on the papers, and study the grammar text and you should be more than fine.
Monserrat is the best! She makes the class fun and will always help you if you're struggling. Don't be afraid to ask for her help. In general, the class is manageable and about more than grammar.

Nadia is an effective communicator and seems passionate about the subject matter of the class. She has a warm sense of humor. There is homework every night, however, so staying on top of your work and actually understanding what you're doing is crucial.
None
Not the most challenging class but good for the language requirement.
Note: If you're taking this not for the language requirement, having homework every other day will bog you down.

One of the tougher courses I took my first semester. Papers were graded on the harder side and the first draft constitutes the majority of your grade so make sure you try to focus on fixing all mistakes before you hand in your first draft. Exams are fair and classes provide stimulating content.
Professor Goncalves is a very chill professor, and classes are pretty relaxed and easy-going. This is a good intermediate Spanish course and the workload is not too bad.

Solid intermediate course; a lot of the assignments feel like busywork but if you're looking to get more comfortable with the language and brush up on some trickier grammar this is the course for you.
Stay on top of homework and readings, especially grammar. Don't be afraid to talk during class, it's the main way a student improves without penalty.
Study a little bit every day. It is not especially difficult if you stay on top of work. Take Goncalves! He is an amazing professor.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! Enough work to make you learn, but all of it is manageable and not very stressful. Andie is THE BEST!!
Take advantage of the many opportunities to participate because it will improve your speaking. Go to office hours to get feedback on your writing. Great class!
Take the course if you're serious about pursuing Spanish past 108.
Take the time to do the homework properly - it'll save you when it comes time for the exams. Put effort into the class and you'll do great, there's nothing hard about it its just time-consuming.
Take this course if you really enjoy language and are up for a challenge.

Take this course! Andie is super helpful and really makes the class enjoyable. Her first language is English, so she understands there's a learning curve, and is never degrading if some of your skills are a little below average.

Take with Andrea Faber. Helpful and knowledgeable, understands the struggles of a non-native speaker.
Humorous, energetic, peppy, interactive, and available to help. Caring for students. Really great at clarifying and describing concepts in memorable and concise ways.
Take with Paloma, she is both nice and well-informed
The course has a decently large work load, but it is manageable.
The more you are committed to learning the material  and speaking up in class the more you get out of it.

This class reviews most of the important grammar structures that you may have already learned in previous Spanish classes although it does so mainly through homework assignments and brief class lectures. The homework is a good way to use the grammar and improve your reading comprehension and writing.
This is worth taking if you are deciding between Spanish and another language, and if the other course meets five times a week, it is even more worth it, because this one meets three times a week.
Try on homework to build skills.
Unless you're a native speaker, don't expect to enjoy the course. Lots of work involved.
Valles was a great instructor. The workload is at times heavy, but overall, this class was enjoyable and improved my Spanish. I would recommend it.
While the course will be a challenge and you can't fall behind in your work, it's rewarding for anyone who wants to become fluent and learn a lot about the culture.
Wonderful opportunity to improve you spanish in a safe, encouraging environment. The workload is manageable and very worthwhile.
You will not be reminded about compositions and tests, so be sure to be on top of the syllabus. Besides that, it is a wonderful class and I believe has brought me much closer to fluency.
You're being forced to take this course. Sucks.
otherinfo: Offered only in the fall semester. Followed by SPA 108 to complete the language requirement.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 10%, Other Exam - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading/audiovisual activities (based on short stories, films, podcasts, speeches, commercials, music videos, newspaper articles, etc.) and grammar exercises in preparation for each class. Four compositions (including the final composition); two in-class exams, two presentations, one oral interview, and one group project.
prereqs: A satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: An intermediate language course that focuses on oral and written communication and the consolidation of listening and reading skills. In this course students will enhance their linguistic skills through the analysis and discussion of various types of texts (literature, film, visual culture, music, interviews, etc.) that focus on global and cross-cultural aspects of Spain and Latin America. In particular, the course will familiarize students with the concept of neocolonialism as a way to bridge language learning with the context in which cultural values and meanings are produced. SPA 105 prepares students for SPA 108.
title: Intermediate Spanish

evals: Aardvark. Now that I'm the first on course evaluations, this was a fine course--you have to get through it. Jeannie Byrne was a great teacher, super kind, and grading wasnt so bad. Theres a big liberal bias to all these Spanish courses--all they talk about is emotions and illegal immigration but nothing to do about that!
Always stay on top of Aprendo activities and be present and engage in class discussion.
Anais is amazing please take her class. Fun and easy to stay on top of as long as you hold yourself accountable to doing the daily homework!

Avoid Nadia Cervantes Perez, as she makes the classroom very serious and strict, plays favorites, and is very critical. If you get into her class, I strongly recommend trying to switch out to one of the other teachers of this course.
Be as engaged and speak as often as you can in class. Have an opened mind.
Be engaging in class and ask the professor for help if you do not understand certain topic.
DO NOT TAKE WITH JEANNIE BYRNE, switch around your schedule to take it with another teacher, Jeannie is literally the harshest grader I've ever had.
Definitely take the course with Anais if you can, it's absolutely phenomenal.
Do Aprendo before class, make sure to speak up.
Do the Aprendo, and study for the exams by going over the Aprendo - it will really help.
Even if you're just fulfilling the requirement, make the most of this course and you'll enjoy it.
Even if you're shy, speak up in class. You'll improve a lot more! Don't be afraid to make mistakes.

For this course it depends on the professor you get. Mine was relatively easy and as long as you did your work and tried hard then he was pretty lenient with grading, but I heard that some of the other professors are much more strict. Generally it is a good class though.

Great way to finish the language requirement. Professor Byrne is amazing and so sweet, definitely take it with her. Much less work than 103, but more interesting in my opinion. My speaking and comprehension improved immensely after taking this course, and I enjoyed going to class everyday. Take it!

Great way to fulfill the language requirement! Extremely interactive course so be prepared to speak everyday. But don't fret, this actually really helps you to learn the language. Also, for you 103 folks, not more mini proyectos yay! However this means that your Aprendo assignments and compositions and exams will be weighted more heavily. Also expect to give a few in-class presentations on a 'research project'. Don't worry, the project isn't too bad.
I highly recommend Professor Holdago-Lage if you want to have the best experience in 107, but regardless of who you have, the class is fantastic.
I would advise another student considering taking this course to try to participate as much as possible in class, and to try to make connections between the material and the modern world.
I would recommend this course to people with a solid base in Spanish.
If you like Spanish at all, take it! Even though, it is an intro level class you learn about a lot of important issues such as immigration. I really enjoyed this class!

It is much more boring than SPA103, but unfortunately you have to take it for your foreign language requirement. Try not to get Nadia, too uptight and boring. Try to get Anais, super fun, and her class is much more laid back.
Lighter workload than 103. Be prepared for the group project at the end though...there are two oral presentations that you don't have much time to prepare for.

Loved the class. Thought-provoking, engaging, informative material that is taught well by amazing professors. Great, chill class. Would totally recommend even as a fifth class. Not a ton of work, not too stressful. Just requires some time, but nothing too demanding.

Most people take this course because it's required, but I would take it regardless. It's a really great way to learn about Spanish language and culture at the same time in that it isn't as centered around mechanics and basic techniques as some of the beginner courses.
Profesora Byrne is great!!!

READ THE GRAMMAR SECTIONS ON APRENDO. Please just do this, it might take some time at the moment but you're going to need to know the rules eventually. Other than that, just show up to class and try to speak when you can.

SPA 107 is a fine class. Take it to satisfy the language requirement if you need to. My only suggestion would be to drop the class or switch sections immediately if you get Professor Cervantes Perez as your teacher. This professor is by far the worst professor I have had at Princeton and she made my experience in this class miserable. She played favorites, was extremely unhelpful when I asked questions to her after class, didn't prepare the class well for tests and compositions and was just a nightmare to deal with in class everyday for an entire semester. While this might seem harsh, about half of the students in her class felt exactly the same way. My experience in this class was terrible because I had Professor Cervantes Perez as my teacher.

Stay on top of your assignments, from Aprendo to the compositions. The course is not difficult if you ask for help from your professor or from your peers and get all of your work done on time. Try to participate as often as possible, as it truly is the best way to ensure that you truly learn the language and how to utilize it effectively.
Take Anais.
Take it with Yasmina!
Take this course with Anais!
Take with Jeannie she is super sweet and helpful I loved her.
Take your time with Aprendo assignments and with the "redacciones".
Talk to the professor to she exactly what she wants - it's hard to tell sometimes.

This class is extremely interesting and helpful for improving your Spanish skills. The discussions are interesting and help to advance one's ability to speak the language. Yasmina is a great teacher! Some of the content is carried over from 103. Also, most of the grammar is a review from stuff previously learned.
This is a good course with daily interactive power point presentations. Attendance is mandatory and affects your grade!
Try not to get Jeannie as your professor if you are concerned about your grade. However, she is a very good teacher so you will definitely learn a lot.
Would be a good course if I did not have Nadia Cervantes Perez.  Good reading and visuals.  Only issue is her.
You may not understand everything the professor says and that's OK! You'll get there!!
You should take this course. Your Spanish language skills will improve immensely.
anais is amazing
be prepared for fun
take it
take this course, especially with anais
otherinfo: Offered both semesters. Students who complete SPA 107 will be qualified to take a 200-level Spanish course under SPA 210.
grading: Other Exam - 10%, Quizzes - 25%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: There will be reading, listening, grammar and/or writing activities on a daily basis. There are also three compositions.
descrip: An intermediate/advanced language course that consolidates and expands the skills acquired in beginner's Spanish. Students will continue to develop their ability to comprehend and communicate in Spanish while using the four basic skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. The course's linguistic goals are achieved in the context of examining the history, cultural production, practices, language, and current reality of the U.S. Latino community. Materials include oral, written and audiovisual texts. By the end of the course, students will be able to express more complex ideas, orally and in writing, with greater grammatical accuracy.
title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish

evals: Always do the homework and remain engaged and talkative during class.

Definitely take this course and try to get Monserrat as your instructor. It is an excellent course full of interesting cultural content. If you particularly want to develop your speaking ability definitely take this class.
Defintely take Monserrat's section.
Do the homework and readings as they are essential to each class. Definitely a manageable amount of work and interesting subject matter.
Go for office hours midterm advice with the head of the department (because they can tell you what is on it), or do your best to study the grammar GRADUALLy for the exam
Good course but workload can be a bit heavy at times.
Good course if you get a good teacher. Do your homework and go to office hours with questions when you can.
Great Spanish class! Good readings and great films. Take it with Monserrat - she makes class enjoyable!

Great course, that I would recommend if you are trying to fulfill the language requirement or just to improve your language skills. As a premed Neuroscience major, my semester was science heavy and having this language course was a great way to counterbalance that.
I enjoyed it a lot more than 105, and I think the course is interesting as it allows us to discuss social issues like gentrification, sexism, and immigration policy.

I pity you, because you're definitely in the class because you got a 4 on your AP. Sucks. 
Bite the bullet and stick it out. And also take it with Luis if you can - he might be the only way you get out of this class and remain cheery.
I really enjoyed this Spanish class, and Monserrat was a great professor. Overall, be prepared to do work but it is very interesting and you're Spanish will improve dramatically.
I would recommend they really focus on grammar on their own and not push the assignments off to the side because the professor does not talk about it much in class.

I would recommend this course as long as it is a requirement and/or you are interested in Spanish and some of the higher level courses as well. I will, however, warn that the Spanish taught is very structured and strays from what is actually spoken in some countries.
If you are interested in Spanish/ want to improve, you should take this course. Try to get into Monserrat's classes because she is very engaging and helpful.
If you have to take 108, Monserrat is great. She's not easy, but you'll learn Spanish and she's super nice.
If you have to take this class, Professor Goncalves is the guy you want.
Language is great and Monserrat is such an engaged and wonderful teacher! MUST TAKE
Learn grammar when first assigned on your own because it will never be taught
Learn the grammar structures well, as these are what you will be tested on.  Start compositions early, and consult with your teacher for things you aren't sure about.

Loved this course!!!! Noticeably harder than SPA 105 (presentations and papers graded more harshly and the grammatical topics are more nuanced), but the cultural materials and films (especially Made in LA) are very engaging. Also, take with Profesora Bores if you can because she created the course, cares deeply about it, and is also just sassy and fun to be around in class.
Luis is the best!
Make sure you understand the readings before class because the more prepared you are, the better you are able to contribute to the discussions.

Moderately large time commitment but not tremendously difficult.  Very consistent/predictable workload.  Your Spanish writing, reading, and speaking abilities will likely improve throughout this course.
Monserrat is great, take it with her.

Not a terrible class to fulfill the language requirement, but also not the most exciting class either. The small class setting is great though, and very helpful for actually building relationships with the other students in the class and the professor. A lot of the homework seems like busy work, but the class as a whole does improve your Spanish reading and writing skills.
Not bad- take it if you have to. Just a lot of busy work.
Olander is nice and she is very flexible to meet for office hours. If you're struggling, GO TO OFFICE HOURS. It will help your grade a lot and professors like to see that you actually care.
SPA 108 is a strong conclusion to many students study of another language at the university. It's a pleasure that it has such great teaching staff who are dedicated to the success of the students.

Spanish is pretty awful so you're probably only going to be taking this class because you have to. If you actually want to learn Spanish out of interest or something, probably just do it on your own, because you won't really learn it here. It's a lot of busy work. Theres also a lot of range in the harshness of the teachers. Conclaves is by far the easiest and will be very nice to you. Monserrat and the other teachers are much more difficult.

TAKE WITH DANIELA. She was AMAZING. She was always amazingly engaging and made the material super interesting to discuss and learn about. Even through the boring grammar portions of the course, she made the class interesting and fun.
Take Luis Goncalves if he's teaching this. Very laid back and chill.
Take it if you need to fulfill a language requirement or want to get to higher level spanish classes (those are much more interesting).
Take it with Luis.
Take this class with Prof. Monserrat Bores to really develop your language abilities. Not an easy A, but you will get better at reading, writing, and speaking if you put in the time.
Take this course for foreign language requirement.
Take this course with Professor Bores. She is wonderful!!!
Take with Bores, especially if you're interested in improving your speaking skills.

This class definitely requires quite some time and verbal practice of the language outside of class in order to keep up. The cultural elements such as movies, readings, stories, and videos that are part of the curriculum are so interesting, and have inspired me to take Princeton in Spain over the summer and study this language abroad. Daniela is a great professor and is simultaneously super chill but also on top of everything. She makes you work hard, but the improvement in your Spanish at the end of the semester is so evident. Take this class!

This class requires a lot of work. If you are taking it, it's probably because you want to complete the language requirement, so you'll just have to deal with it. Daniela was a great professor, though.

This course isn't awful, but it is difficult to get an A or A-. Their standard is very high. The volume of work is tough sometimes as there are many projects and little writing assignments, but it is overall doable.
Very good course. take it
You probably have to take it, sorry
Your Spanish will definitely improve through this course, but it is a lot of work, assignments are graded very hard, and you'll get very annoyed by the hw assignments due every other day.
moderate work load.
take it with daniela salcedo, she rocks
take this course!!
otherinfo: SPA 108 is offered both semesters. Students who complete SPA 108 will be qualified to take a 200-level Spanish language course under SPA 210.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 10%, Other Exam - 20%, Papers - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Readings include short texts (press articles, short stories, essays, etc.) and visual and audiovisual sources (paintings, graffiti, interviews, animation, documentaries, films), providing opportunities for students to engage with social and cultural issues related to Mexico City and Los Angeles. Writing assignments include three blog entries, a critical response to artwork, and a review. Readings and writing assignments progress from personal to more formal and abstract genres.
prereqs: SPA 105 or satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test. SPA 108 is offered both semesters..
descrip: SPA 108 develops fluency and accuracy in speaking and writing by focusing on functional language in context. It aims to strengthen and consolidate comprehension and production of oral and written Spanish with an emphasis on cultural awareness and cross-cultural communication. Through a series of current and thought-provoking texts, images, films, paintings, and related activities, this course enhances linguistic proficiency and language performance while reflecting on important aspects of the history, art, society, language and cultural identity of two of the largest Spanish-speaking urban communities: Mexico City and Los Angeles.
title: Advanced Spanish

evals: 207 is a good jump from 107, so get ready if you did the 101-102-107 sequence; it wasn't easy. Not sure how much my Spanish actually improved after this course but if you put effort into it then you should come out a stronger speaker. You don't learn too much new vocab or go over grammar a lot, so its more watching videos in Spanish and doing (short) readings and then talking about them in class. Also get Mariana if you can, she's a sweetheart!
Definitely take it, very manageable. Try and take it with Gorka, he's awesome
Don't go through the motions on the homework-- you'll get out of the course what you put in.
Gorka is fun, educational, enthusiastic. All positives for this course.
I advice that you take notes during the lessons, since they go a bit fast and it is easy to forget what was said.

Mariana is an incredibly kind professor. This course is especially helpful for students who wish to have another semester of speaking and writing (at a low level of intensity) before moving on to higher level coursework. However, if you are looking for extensive grammar education or an intensive focus on writing (as the course name suggests), this may not be the course you are looking for.
Really great way to advance your Spanish in a class that has a pretty consistent workload but is very fair. Gorka is a fantastic professor who runs interesting discussions.
Take it with Gorka! He is so nice and really funny and will keep you laughing. He's also really understanding and he makes it very clear what he expects.
Take it with Mariana! Great teacher, great class.

The workload is not too heavy. The class is not grammar-intensive. It's a good class to keep your Spanish skills sharp and practice reading, writing, and speaking. You also learn about the culture/history of different Spanish-speaking regions of the world.
This class is fun and Mariana is great! Most of the work is in the second half and there is lots of group work.
This course is ok if you are solid in your language skills, but not the most interesting.
This is a great class to further develop your spanish writing and overall language skills! Mariana is a great teacher!
keep up with the homework and you'll learn
otherinfo: Offered both semesters.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 15%, Other Exam - 15%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Includes fictional and non-fictional texts (short stories, poems, essays, press articles) and film/visual media. Improving students' ability to express complex ideas in writing is an essential goal of the course. Writing assignments cover different genres, including narrative, expository and argumentative texts.
prereqs: SPA 107 or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed the Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score..
descrip: An advanced language course designed to increase students' fluency and accuracy in Spanish with an integrated approach to content: classes and assignments draw on various types of texts (literature, film, visual media) that focus on Madrid and Buenos Aires. Students hone their linguistic skills by engaging in discussions about the urban environment, and its cultural and artistic productions. The course aims to raise intercultural awareness and to explore the contexts in which cultural values and meanings are created. Reading and writing assignments cover different genres, and verbal interaction and personal production are actively encouraged.
title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style

evals: A good class, I liked it for the most part given the emphasis on literature/film/photography. My speaking and writing improved to a certain extent given the chances to participate in class and the weekly commentaries. One thing I would say that I didn't love was that my professor had a very specific viewpoint on each piece of material, and we would often spend the class period trying to articulate his understanding of the text/movie/photo. While his interpretations were undeniably excellent, I sometimes wished he could've been a little more open-minded to other ideas.
Good Spanish course.
I wouldn't advise taking this course unless you're considering Spanish as a concentration or certificate.

Many of the readings are great.  Beautiful, disturbing, thought-provoking, or all three.  Sometimes the classes got monotonous, and it seemed like Prof. Loureiro assumed he had the "right" answers.  (Maybe he did... but the discussions seemed a little too structured and forced toward his interpretation.)  This was also reflected in the commentary grading.  If you hit the ideas he wanted, you could get a good grade with just decent analysis.  If your conclusions were different from his, he would pick apart your analysis more.
Take the course in order to gain an introduction into analyzing Spanish literature. It is really beneficial, especially if you plan on taking upper-level course work in the Spanish department.
Take, but be cautious.

This is probably the best 200-level Spanish offered at Princeton. It's a good amount of work (but still less than most higher level language classes) and the professor can at times be very exacting. However, this class exposes students to a wide range of material and provides a good transition into higher level languages courses. If you're going to study Spanish seriously at Princeton you need to take this class.
otherinfo: At least one of the classes will be held in the Princeton University Art Museum to examine some of the museum's holdings of Latin American photographs. Any student unable to register for the course, please contact Prof. Loureiro, loureiro@princeton.edu.
grading: Papers - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 45%
assgts: About 20 pages per week and/or viewing one film outside class time. Literary readings will be in Spanish; theory readings, in English. Films will be in Spanish with English subtitles. Six 500 word commentaries on the assigned readings or films. Two longer commentaries, 1,500 words each (5-6 pages) on the works listed in the syllabus for the weeks they are due. Shorter commentaries will count for 45% of grade; the two 1,500 word commentaries for 45%.
prereqs: Another SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to the analysis of contemporary cultural texts (narrative, poetry, film, photography) from Latin America and Spain, with the support of various theoretical ideas. The course's main objective is to provide students with a set of strong conceptual, analytical and linguistic skills, which will be of great help in 300-level literature/culture courses.
title: Hispanic Studies: Introduction to Cultural Analysis

evals: A great class to take for the SPA 307 certificate! Mariana is an awesome teacher who allows every student to improve his or her Spanish speaking, reading, and writing. Highly recommend. Plus the workload is actually better than SPA 207!
Good Spanish class to take for the certificate. The workload is extremely manageable and the content is relatively interesting. Mariana Bono is a wonderful teacher and a great grader!
Great Spanish course if you want to practice speaking and writing! Steady course load, not really any big projects so everything you do counts for a little part of the grade.
I enjoyed this class and it was fairly manageable, but I still gained valuable information and skills that transferred to all my other humanities classes.
I would highly recommend Sylvia and 307 for a Spanish course because the topics are very interesting and it was a fun upper level course.
I would highly recommend taking this course with Bono. She is a passionate instructor and is always enthusiastic to engage with students. The work felt totally fair and certainly not overwhelming.
If you are thinking about concentrating or getting a certificate in Spanish,  you should take this class.

Overall, this is a good course if you're looking for a class that will keep your Spanish from getting rusty. The material itself isn't the most interesting, but the class as a whole was enjoyable and the professor (Zetterstrand) was great.
Take advantage of the small class size to really practice your Spanish and get to know the professor--definitely worth it!
Take this course if you want to improve your Spanish/work towards the certificate/concentration. You will be more than fine taking it coming out of 207. Also, Professor Bono is the best!

Take this course! Super interesting and discusses topics that are very much engaging to the students (think anything from Spanglish to the modern-day Latino community). Mariana is an awesome teacher who cares a lot about this course and her students, and she does go out of her way to make sure everyone understand everything and enjoys her class. One of the best Spanish classes I've taken at Princeton.

Very good class, especially if you are interested more in the purely linguistic side of Spanish and/or the nuances of Spanish-speaking cultures.  The class covers a nice variety of topics, but do not expect to improve your grammar skills.  Otherwise, the workload is not bad and the class is well taught.
Very light workload and pretty interesting material.
Would recommend if you just want to maintain or improve Spanish, but the class is very abstract and you don't learn much material wise
otherinfo: Offered both semesters.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Other Exam - 15%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: 50-75 pages reading per week. Primary texts such as news, advertisements, movie clips, fragments of conversations, blogs, tweets, text messages, academic articles, narratives and poetry. Secondary texts on linguistic theory and language use. Daily discussion boards on course readings. Two oral presentations. One writing assignment and a final essay.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course. Students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course with instructor's permission..
descrip: SPA 307 is an advanced language course. Its main purpose is to develop and reinforce accuracy and fluency in both writing and speaking Spanish. Students will also learn to identify linguistic features that characterize different genres, as well as social and cultural factors that aid in the interpretation and understanding of different texts and types of speech. More specifically, the course aims at providing the tools for discourse analysis, raising awareness of the social and ideological values that permeate discursive practices, and developing autonomy and proficiency as an advanced learner of Spanish language.
title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style

otherinfo: Course taught in Spanish.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Approximately 100 pages reading per week; short paper; midterm paper; term paper; oral presentation; weekly Blackboard postings.
prereqs: A 300-level SPA course; or fluency in Spanish; or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course examines recent literature and film from Latin America (~ past ten years). The course focuses on novels, essays and poems that address various issues across divergent regions, nations, movements, and experiences, including precarious life in the wake of widely implemented neo-liberal economic policies, environmental challenges, border culture, new forms of auto-fiction, young authors' reflections on a prior generations' politics, etc.
title: Topics in Latin American Modernity - Latin American Literature after Latin America

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 60%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
descrip: This course explores the originary discourses and cultural parameters of Iberian literary expression in Medieval and Early Modern texts. Works to be considered include the Cid, the Libro de Buen Amor, Celestina and Don Quijote, as well as the poetry of Garcilaso and Quevedo. Special attention is given to questions of generic innovation, self-representation, mimesis, realism, and social contexts.
title: Seminar in Medieval Spanish Literature - Foundational Fictions

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Programming Assignments - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
descrip: Through fiction, poetry, film, painting, comics, music, etc, the course has repression and resistance as its main thread. Among the topics to be covered are: the memory of the Civil War, internal dissent within Francoism, exile, economic development, the country and the city, immigration and emigration, tourism, forms of indoctrination, social unrest, construction of gender, and the role of religion in both repression and resistance
title: Seminar in Modern Spanish Literature - Repression and resistance in Spain, 1950-1975

evals: Highly recommended -- innovative approach to analyzing literature.

Parcel out the reading for some weeks accordingly, as some of the texts are rather long. Take some time to think about the overarching questions of the course on your own, and try to construct a hypothesis that can be proven or disproven; otherwise, it may be easy to get lost in very abstract questions
This course is a good place to think and discuss from different backgrounds. The materials are interesting and accessible. Moreover, Professor Price is a good teacher and well debate conductor
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
descrip: This course provides an overview of Cuban cultural history from the Ten Years War to the present (1868-2017). Reading widely across historiography, cultural studies, literature, ethnomusicology, and art history, the course also examines primary documents ranging from constitutions to poetry, ethnography, novels, film, and essays. Topics include black political activism in the Republic; women's participation in pre-revolutionary movements, essays and films from the 1960s; post-Special Period genres, etc.
title: Narrative Prose in Latin America - Cuban Cultural History 1868-2017

evals: 10/10 TAKE THIS COURSE! Macedo is an engaging and all around fantastic lecturer, and this course will change the way you see and understand the intersection of ethics and policy. Best class I have ever taken at Princeton!!!
Decent amount of reading, but very helpful for beginners. Odd examinations, best check with previous students to ensure you are comfortable with exam styles.

Definitely not a bad course for a WWS ethics course.  If you already have a good base in Rawls, Nozick, Walzer, or other contemporary political theory, this will probably be pretty dry.  But it provides a good overview and a balanced view of some contemporary debates in ethics (torture, marriage)

Definitely take it!!! This course is hard, not because of the readings or the concepts, but because it will challenge your moral views and force you to justify them with persuasive reasoning. It will definitely build your critical thinking skills and force you to re-examine your beliefs. Ultimately you will come out able to face controversial issues and back your opinions with just and sound reasons. Precept was also very engaging and fun (we have lively debates and discussions every session). Toni is by far the best preceptor I've had in my two years here.

Fun and interesting course. Lots of reading, which you'll want to keep up with so the exams aren't hellish. Almost all grading is based on writing (essays and exams), so be cautious if that's not your favorite thing!
Great class
Great class and offers questions/arguments that everyone should think about. Get Toni as preceptor - best preceptor I've had in my princeton career
Great course overall. Would highly recommend.
Great course! You will really enjoy it if you engage in the course. Prof. Macedo is an engaging lecturer and very open to student input.
Great introduction to moral issues in policy. It covers several topics that may spark an interest in you.
I would recommend taking the course, especially if one is interested in policy.

I would recommend this course if you need a Woody Woo departmental or are genuinely interested in ethics. No need to take if you are interested in public policy; there are by far better courses for that. By no means an easy A, although it has the feel of a survey course/intro course. The underlying theme of this course was Rawls' Theory of Justice, and it felt like much of the class was applying this work to different policy issues. If this is a dealbreaker, don't take the course.
Interesting class. Be prepared to hear Macedo's point of view a lot of the time.

It is what you make it. Engage with the ideas and the reading and this course has the potential to really challenge your thinking. I thought I knew what I believed about a lot of these issues already and didn't expect my perspective to change but it did.
Keep up on the readings and the lectures/precepts will be WAY better. Also, go to office hours - don't play yourself, because Macedo is such a great dude.
Keep up with readings! Spend a good amount of time developing your paper! Go to office hours!

Lecture is not integral and often boring. Office Hours absolutely are beyond question the best thing you can do for yourself in this course. Pay attention because essays require a pretty consistent synthesis of some fairly complex material and arguments. Ben Hoffman is a pretty damn good preceptor. The class is a survey course with its fingers in many different pies, but I would recommend this class on its introduction of Rawls and handling of property and utilitarianism alone; its the closest I've yet found to normative economics here. A solid EM or ethics requirement.
Meet with preceptors as much as possible if you are not grasping the concepts as easily as you'd like. There are plenty of abstract concepts that may overwhelm you if you are not adequately prepared.
NA
Only if you have to.
Probably don't need to read everything. Many of the articles are repetitive.
Strongly recommend this course. Interesting lectures, gets you to think more deeply about challenging issues. Workload is average for a Woody Woo class.
Subject material feels very relevant and engaging. Has philosophical aspects that feel practical in their application.
Take advantage of the prof's and preceptor's willingness to help. Go to office hours and make sure your arguments are rigorous.
Take if interested but otherwise do something else with your life
Take it if you're a WoodyWoo major
Take it if your interested in ethics and how it applies to public policy. Title of class is self-explanatory but its also interesting and Macedo is great. Good WWS departmental.
Take it!  Find a study partner or two!  Read for basic concepts and use the extra materials to clarify your understanding (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy).  Rough curve, but you learn a ton.
Take it! Made me think about a lot of tough issues I wouldn't otherwise have made time to think about (but always wanted to), like marriage, torture, and immigration.
Take it! Not too difficult and interesting material. Lots of reading and try not to fall behind.
Take it. Great course. Relevant and engaging. Prof Macedo is excellent.
Take it. It's hard at some times but overall very manageable.
Take separate notes on blank pieces of paper while you're doing the readings. You will understand it 100% times better. Trust me

Take the course, do the readings, attend lectures. It will be great for learning and it will be fun. Precepts are heavily discussion-based, but you learn a lot and are forced to think about a lot of issues that are deeply important.
Take this class! I took it only as a requirement and was quickly surprised by how great of a professor Macedo was and how challenged I was in this course to formulate opinions on tricky topics
Take this class! It's a lot of work but totally worth it!
Take this class. It is both interesting and manageable. The lecture notes are very helpful.
Take this course if you are willingly to put work into the readings and papers. The topic is super interesting and talks about relevant world issues
Take this course if you must fulfill a requirement or really like philosophy mixed with some public policy.
Take this course if you need it as a core for WWS. It's hard, but the material is super interesting and the preceptors are all pretty helpful.
Take this course! It's not easy, but is extremely timely and forces you to consider some really important questions. Macedo is very approachable, and the workload is manageable.
This class is actually super interesting. Macedo is great! I liked it a lot.
This course is amazing - take it! Professor Macedo is one of the best lecturers I have ever had, and the course covers a wide range of relevant moral issues. Made me look at many things in new ways!
This course is very interesting. Sometimes the readings are a bit excessive, but you don't always have to do all of them.
This is a definitely doable course but you have to really want it and put the work in, definitely go into office hours!

This is an excellent ethics course for WWS concentrators. Absolutely easier than Global Justice, which is another popular WWS ethics requirement. Particularly, preparation for examinations is low stress. Macedo tells you on which authors to focus for the midterm, and he pre-releases the final prompts and IDs. There are two papers, which do take a bit of time if you haven't written an ethics paper before. Macedo and his preceptors make themselves abundantly available for help with papers. Macedo focuses very heavily on Rawls, so if you've read him before you probably shouldn't take the class. If you're VPL with a genuine interest in ethics, this probably isn't the class for you either. It's sort of like the lite version of ethics.
This was a great course. Fun to take with friends especially
Would definitely recommend (it's a departmental anyway) but don't get bogged down in the readings
otherinfo: Students should select the P99 option to enroll in the course. Final precept selection will take place during the first week of classes.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 150 pages of reading per week; the quantity depends on the sort of material covered. Weekly intensive participation in precepts required to develop skills of analysis and deliberation. Short paper, midterm; longer paper; final exam.
descrip: The course examines major moral controversies in public life and differing conceptions of justice and the common good. It seeks to help students develop the skills required for thinking and writing about the ethical considerations that ought to shape public institutions, guide public authorities, and inform the public's judgments. The course will focus on issues that are particularly challenging for advanced, pluralist democracies such as the USA, including justice in war, terrorism and torture, paternalism, markets and distributive justice, immigration, and refugees and the place, if any, of religious arguments in politics.
title: Ethics and Public Policy

evals: A lot of time put into reading but manageable and interesting
Absolutely take this course, it is interesting and Bogan is an excellent lecturer. The readings are so fascinating and definitely worth investing time in.
Bogan is awesome! Take the class!!
Definitely take this course--Professor Bogan is awesome!! Really interesting course with important/relevant info that all people should know.  Great way to fulfill an economics elective.
Do the readings, go to lectures. Problem sets are not that bad and neither are the exams. That's about it
I came out of this class a much better informed citizen.

I would strongly recommend this course to any econ student. The class is very relevant to political issues today, Professor Bogan presents a balanced view of conservative and liberal arguments for/against policies. you'll learn a lot in this course and she is the most involved professor in the econ department that I have taken a class with. Highly recommend!
If you love Professor Bogan then you should take this class.

If you're interested in a practical application of economics, this course is perfect. The readings, which are many, are interesting and go deep into presenting economic issues as well as proposed solutions.
My favorite class at Princeton so far! Professor Bogan is the best

PHENOMENAL COURSE. Lots of readings that are really great, but you can totally get by with just going through the slides and memorizing them verbatim for the tests. One of the few classes in the economics department where you genuinely learn super useful, practical things. Only bad part is the tests that Bogan makes are tricky because of her multiple choice, but that's not a good reason to not take the course.
Really great policy overview for anyone!!
Really interesting, very relevant to current politics, Bogan's really good about presenting every side of an issue, though she'll definitely give you her opinion!
Take it if you like Bogan, the material is interesting and the readings are short and to the point. There's a lot of breadth to the course, not as much depth, which I kept me engaged throughout.
Take the class. Bogan is a very passionate teacher and I love her noble effort to pursue the truth.
Take this course. Straightforward and relevant. You will actually walk away understanding prevalent societal issues. Also, manageable workload that is an easy enough A.
Take this course?it will give you the insight you need to understand how public policies can affect your daily life. It's engaging, and well worth the work you will have to put in. DO THE READINGS.

This is a great course! If you're interested at all in healthcare, education, crime, etc., definitely take it. Very heavy on reading, but pretty chill otherwise. The preceptors are both great as well.

This is a must take at Princeton. Professor Bogan is the best lecturer and at Princeton and has such interesting and impassioned lectures that you stay engaged for every minute. Grading is also very fair.

Whether you are an Econ major looking for a great elective or simply a student with a general interest in Economics and Public Policy, TAKE THIS COURSE. Prof. Bogan is easily one of my favorite professors at the University, and the material is manageable and engaging (just make sure to stay on top of the readings, and review her lecture slides).
You learn a lot in this course and the material is up-to-date and really interesting. I'd recommend this course to anyone, not just econ or policy people.
do not save all the readings to do before the exam, keep up with them
take this course! i'm a CBE major and loved it! bogan's lectures are great and really educates you about topics that are super relevant to our society
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Typical weekly assignment includes 75 pages of reading and a problem set.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101.
descrip: The role of government in promoting efficiency and equity in the U.S. economy. Conditions when markets fail to be efficient. Problems with government allocation of resources. Economic analysis and public policies regarding health care, education, poverty, the environment, financial regulations and other important issues.
title: Public Economics

evals: A solid course. You'll learn very interesting things coming out of this class ? might lead you to look at the world in a new way.
Definitely take this as a WWS/ECO departmental - both interesting and applicable.
Definitely take this class if you're interested in it! If not, then it won't be as enjoyable.
Do not take this course.
Do the readings ahead of time so you aren't stuck doing it all right before the test.
Do the readings. All of them. For your own good.

Don't listen to the negative reviews here. 90% of the class are Woody Woo majors who spent every lecture on Facebook. Many of my friends said they learned nothing from this class, but that's probably because they didn't pay attention or attend class. This class has a ton amount of information to offer. It is interesting and important. But it requires the students to remember that they are Princeton students. It requires active engagement. It requires attention. You will learn from this course if you are a good student. So don't be afraid to take this course if you take school seriously. If you're looking for an easy psych course where you can text your friends during lecture, this is not the course for you. Neuroscience majors and Psychology majors should especially consider taking this course. They will get a lot more out of it than their Woody Woo counterparts. My only major complaint is that there are an overwhelming amount of readings. Finding a study group is necessary to tackle them.
Don't take it unless you have to- there are other more fair classes that you will enjoy better

Focus on the readings for both midterm and final. Organize concepts and examples around it. There is some repetition throughout the course so don't necessarily digest the information chronologically but by concept.
Great course. It's as good as you heard it was. Keep up with the readings.
Great topic but really hard class to take

I have mixed feelings about this class. It is definitely overhyped, and a lot of the course can just be gained from reading books like Nudge or Thinking Fast and Slow. That being said, it is still quite interesting as the material is good. The lectures are ok, and the exams are bad, as you basically have to memorize all the readings done in the class, which is stupid but Im told thats how all Psych class are, so...

I very much regretted taking this course. It's sad because the material is actually interesting, but the structure, readings and grading absolutely ruin it. The exams are sheer luck of whether you remember tiny details from readings.
I would recommend the course but you could probably read Kahneman's books and be able to have a similar level of understanding of behavioral economics.

I would take this course only if the material interests you; if it doesn't, it will be extremely difficult to make it through vast numbers of readings and difficult exams. Professor Shafir wants students who are invested in the material, not students looking to fulfill a requirement.

If you can take another PSY/SOC course that fulfills the Woody Woo requirement, do that one instead because this one is not as simple as you might think and actually requires much more amounts of work than you might like.
If you have to take it for WWS, take it, but I would also explore other options (even if everyone seems to be taking this course!)
If you're actually interested in learning about social psychology and behavioral economics, take another course on this subject. The readings are boring and the lectures aren't well put together.
Interesting course. Difficult to do well... Grading is arbitrary and most people failed the midterm.. so this class may not help your GPA..
Interesting in the beginning, but felt like topics were repeated and just applied in different ways in the end. Did not take for a requirement, but felt like most people in the class did.
Interesting material but not to be taken as a "fun" course. Lots of work.
Interesting, very much helps to be passionate about psychology
It's not the worst class to take, but it isn't the greatest.
MAKE SURE YOU DO THE READINGS!!! The exams include a lot of questions about the readings. This class is interesting and useful. It is not particularly easy though.

One of the hardest classes to get into at Princeton and worth the hype. Super interesting, but do put in the work to do readings, etc. It might be a bit time-consuming, but it's well-worth it, both in terms of grading and intellectual curiosity.
Only take this class if absolutely necessary. The lectures are repetitive and slightly boring, but the exams are difficult.

RECOMMEND WITH RESERVATIONS. Unlike 99% of ppl in the class who take it for a departmental, certificate, or one of the other 309112 requirements this class fulfills, I took it out of interest. It's quite a shame really that the mass of disinterested people + the horrifically long reading list somewhat dull the allure of this class. That said, the pros do make it worthwhile: 1) Shafir is INCREDIBLE! The man commands a stage like the best of them at Princeton. Lectures are engaging, thought-provoking, and delivered well. 2) The content is remarkable. Some of the conclusions and findings of behavioral economics are incredible. Going through this class really will change your life, make you a more informed decision-maker, and better equipped to deal with the vagaries of life. DO YOUR FUTURE ADULT SELF A FAVOR AND TAKE THIS CLASS. You'll make better decisions, save yourself money, and all around be a more capable person.
Readings are the only thing tested.
Really interesting class. There is a lot of material but its all good things to know! And the professor is very engaging.
Really read the material, and attend all the lectures. If doing this for a WWS requirement, make sure to give it your all and do not slack.

Shafir is a really good lecturer and the class is pretty interesting (albeit somewhat repetitive). Grading of assignments and exams is frustratingly arbitrary. The exams test details about the readings, so doing the readings and knowing them well is necessary to do well. Not sure if there is a better class out there to satisfy this WWS requirement.
Super fun and interesting course! I would highly recommend taking it!
Survey of theories around decision making, a lot of makes intuitive sense
Take it for WWS psych requirement or just if you have a general interest in the subject matter

Take the course if you're interested in decision making, but some of the things may be a bit repetitive, especially if you've taken social psychology before. Lots of readings as well, so don't take if you don't like to read.
Take this class if you are willing to put in a lot of work to do the readings. Really interesting with a lot of real-world application.
Take this class! Prof. Shafir is wonderful and the learnings can be applied across disciplines.
Take this course! You'll learn a lot. (The midterm is quite difficult though.)

The content of this class is really interesting, as are many of the readings, both of which would made it a must-take class if it weren't for the exams.

Shafir says at the very beginning of the class that he doesn't like people who are just taking the course to fulfill a requirement (aka most of the students as it is an EC and fulfills WWS, PSY, and Engineering requirements) - he seems to make it extra difficult just for that purpose.

If there was ever a reason to not take this class, it would be the exams. The questions are in no way clear, and Shafir/the preceptors DID NOT do a good job of explaining the format/what information needed to be studied, so you could study basically everything and still not do well because they, for example, referred to a specific study by its authors (which they said they wouldn't do) rather than the experiment/concept at hand. The range of grades was brutal, from 22/100 to 98/100 (with a mean of 63 or something). Additionally, they wouldn't let us keep our graded exams or even give us an answer key so we could LEARN FROM OUR MISTAKES (and seemed surprised when we asked for that for that purpose) - they said this was due to some kind of University policy, but no other class I have taken has ever done that, so I think it's just them being difficult.

If they fix the exam formats, then take the course, because it IS super interesting.

The course can be confusing and a decent amount of work. I think to do well, it's important to do the readings and know the concepts / understand them as specific concepts. Overall, important and interesting topic.
The material in this class is fascinating - you just need to be willing to put in a lot of work in terms of reading and paying attention in lecture.
The subject matter for this course is incredibly interesting but at times confusing. The tests were extremely hard but if you are willing to put in the work I highly recommend this course.

This class is a good way to do the Woody Woo requirement. The lectures are super interesting. it's kind of hard to be super engaged in the readings I found. The exams are super detailed on the readings so beware of that.

This course is incredibly interesting and actually taught me things that I'll remember for the rest of my life. That being said, the course was a lot of work, and I wasn't prepared for that. The exams are also very difficult. Make sure you put in the effort if you're going to take this class. If you do, you'll gain some really cool insights.

This is a great course and lectures and precepts are really interesting! Make sure that you know the differences between similar concepts and can provide examples of each psychological phenomenon because that will be important for the exams!

This is a really good and interesting class, even (maybe especially) if you haven't taken a psych class before. Do ALL the readings because the midterm includes readings you won't talk about during precept/lecture.
This is a very interesting and fun class but with Professor Shafir you have to DO ALL THE READINGS (or at least get a group together to do all the readings)
Very hard midterm and readings. Lectures are great.
Very interesting class that fulfills a wide variety of requirements (EC, WWS and ECO departmental). It is challenging and a lot of material, but it's worth it.

WWS doesn't really give options to fulfill the soc/psy requirement if you're interested in psychology, so this is definitely the course to take. If you've taken a psych course before that covers social/behavioral psychology, you will be covering quite a bit of familiar material (nudges, Shafir's famous work, etc.)
The grading system was simple and fair, in my opinion, so it's easy to do well in the class.
I didn't think the reading is technical, which makes the course accessible to all majors.
So, the only real drawback is for those who already have some degree of a psych background already.
You HAVE to do all the readings and take notes of them. Going to lecture helps you understand them better but doing the readings is really the most important thing I think.
don't take unless you're prepared for a killer exam
great course. exams were kind of way too difficult given the impossible amount of material but great class otherwise
interesting class! really good information to know to be an informed citizen -- particularly one that wants to go into/understand policy. hard exams. Study hard!
take
take it! really interesting material. graded harshly so do all the readings.
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: WWS course online waitlist form - http://wws.princeton.edu/intranet/student-program-offices/undergraduate/forms/course-waitlist-request
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: 60-80 pages a week, and weekly assignments (short papers, problem sets)
prereqs: Introductory statistics for social science or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to the logic and research findings underlying decision-making and judgment under uncertainty. The focus is on the contrast between the normative theory of judgment and choice, and the psychological principles that guide decision behavior, often producing biases and errors. Among other topics, we will consider political, medical, and financial decision-making, poverty, negotiations, and the law, along with the implications of the findings for the rational agent model typically assumed in economics, throughout the social sciences, and in policy making.
title: The Psychology of Decision Making and Judgment

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: 100-150 pages per week
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to WWS concentrators and certificate students. The course is required for concentrators, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. Junior concentrators are automatically signed up for the policy task force as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 401. WWS juniors who are certificate students must enroll. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy task forces, students work in groups of 8 to 10, first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.
title: Policy Seminars

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

grading: Papers - 45%, Other (See Instructor) - 55%
descrip: An analysis of the forces that shape the behavior of public organizations and individuals in organizational settings. The emphasis is on the workings of U.S. governmental agencies. Special attention is given to writing skills as they apply to the roles of advisers and decision makers in public-sector organizations.

descrip: This course applies management concepts and approaches to nonprofit organizations. The course emphasizes the challenges faced by managers of nonprofit organizations in this period of resource scarcity. It also examines the impact that the increasingly blurred boundaries between the nonprofit, public, and for-profit sectors are having on the management of nonprofits. Course materials integrate both theoretical and applied research and writing on this topic with cases based on the real world experience of managers.
title: Management of Non-Profit Organizations

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

descrip: Statistical analysis with applications to public policy, begins with an introduction to probability theory followed by discussion of statistical methods for estimating the quantitative effects of changes in policy variables. Regression methods appropriate for the analysis of observational data and data from randomized controlled experiments are stressed. By the end of the course students are able to do their own empirical analysis using statistical software package, interpret regression results and competently assess the work of others. The course assumes a fluency in high school algebra.
title: Quantitative Analysis for Policymakers

grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: Statistical analysis with applications to public policy, begins with an introduction to probability theory followed by discussion of statistical methods for estimating the quantitative effects of changes in policy variables. Regression methods appropriate for the analysis of observational data & data from randomized controlled experiments are stressed. By course end, students are able to do their own empirical analysis using statistical software package & interpret regression results from the professional literature. The course assumes fluency in calculus, which is necessary for rigorous mathematical analysis of probability & statistics.
title: Quantitative Analysis for Policymakers (Advanced)

evals: Be ready to commit about 10 hours to each PSet. You will learn from it, but if you don't think you'll use this level of stats it may not be worthwhile, except that it's interesting.
Broad coverage of statistical techniques. Problem sets are practical and a highlight of the course.
Good if you want to dive a bit deeper into regression analysis.  Quite math-heavy.
I highly recommend that students read the notes before each lecture to take full advantage of it.
I recommend it. Great professor.
I would recommend it with the caveat of it being very challenging.
I would suggest taking this course if you want a more applied statistics course. The material isn't as theoretical as some of the courses offered in the sociology and politics departments.

If you came out of 507 and 508 feeling confident, don't take 509 unless you're extremely enthusiastic about it or see it as a core skill for your job prospects. If you want a little extra exposure to solidify your knowledge, 509 is a good option, but will be a challenge if you haven't got a strong background in this stuff. Most of those who take the course are quite strong in statistics, so be prepared for the grade distribution to have shifted. I chose not to Pass/Fail because I knew I needed to really go through all the exercises to get what I needed out of it, but I also didn't do as well in this course as I have in most others. Make sure you know what you want to get out of it, and decide accordingly.
Lectures are not nearly as important as the practice exams and problem sets.  Even the notes offered in class are rarely touched upon.

Take the course! This is one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. If you enjoyed Vogl's 508c course, definitely take this class, as it feels like a logical continuation of that and expands upon some ideas that aren't touched on in 508c.

This is a top quality course and German is a top quality instructor; you will feel as though you are learning from a true statistical Guru. A moderately strong background in mathematics and statistics will be necessary as the course is quite rigorous. It is also an excellent opportunity to gain experience with statistical software (R or Stata). The best thing about this course is that all the material is available from German's website: http://data.princeton.edu/wws509
If you are considering taking the course I suggest browsing the website to get an idea of the material covered.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 40%
descrip: The analysis of survey data using generalized linear statistical models. The course begins with a review of linear models for continuous responses and then considers logistic regression models for binary data and log-linear models for count data, including rates and contingency tables and hazard models for duration data. Attention is given to the logical and mathematical foundations of the techniques, but the main emphasis is on the applications, including computer usage. The course assumes prior exposure to statistics at the level of WWS507c and familiarity with matrix algebra and calculus.
title: Generalized Linear Statistical Models

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

prereqs: A working knowledge of calculus and ease with algebraic manipulation are prerequisites of the course..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the use of microeconomics for the analysis of public policy on an advanced level. The emphasis is on both the intuitive and formal logic of economic principles, a deeper perspective on the impacts of typical policy measures, and an introduction to the use of professional microeconomic tools to assess and weigh these policy impacts. One goal is to move students towards the ability to read professional microeconomic literature with appreciation of both its contributions and foibles.
title: Microeconomic Analysis for Policymakers (Advanced)

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

descrip: An introduction to the political analysis of policy making in the American setting. The course includes theoretical and empirical analyses of political institutions, including executives, legislatures, and bureaucracies. It also examines the political environment in which these institutions operate, with special attention given to the role of public opinion, interest groups, and elections.
title: Domestic Politics

descrip: Examines a series of major issues of policy designed to illustrate and develop skills in particularly important applications of microeconomics. Topics will include education and training, the minimum wage, mandated benefits, affirmative action, the theory of public goods and externalities, and the basic theory of taxation. Prerequisite: 511b.
title: Microeconomic Analysis of Domestic Policy

otherinfo: Master of Finance students should contact Melanie Heaney-Scott to register. Economics Undergraduates students should contact Noelina Hall to register. All other interested students should contact Regina Burke to register.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: WWS 512C, or equivalent..
descrip: This course is about the economics and some of the politics of central banking, especially monetary policy. Special emphasis is given to central banks as unique policymaking institutions and, especially, to the Federal Reserve System, although other central banks are mentioned frequently. Since the focus is on monetary policy, the course presupposes a working knowledge of the relevant macroeconomics, but particular aspects thereof are taught in the course. Attention is paid to the causes, consequences, and central bank behavior during and since the recent financial crisis.
title: Advanced Macroeconomics: Domestic Policy Issues

descrip: In this course, we analyze examples of development strategies in the United States, Europe and Asia, at the urban and regional levels, with a focus on the practical role of city government leaders and strategists, and how to make their role more effective. This course is taught primarily through case studies. Most of the classes focus on economic development, but we also spend some time discussing related issues (such as sustainability and income inequality).
title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Implementing Urban Economic Development

otherinfo: For more information on WWS Graduate Course, please see our WWS website: http://wws.princeton.edu/grad/course_offerings/.
grading: Papers - 50%, Term Paper(s) - 50%
descrip: This course introduces a set of concepts and tools that are widely used in the practice of urban and regional planning. The focus is on developing an operational understanding of the models, techniques and data used in such applications as regional economic and demographic projections, cost-benefit analysis, and land use analysis. Emphasis is also placed on the limitations of the methods.
title: Planning Methods

Course presents current theories regarding the ecological and social structure of urban areas, and how urban social organization affects the behavior and well-being of human beings who live and work in cities.
