evals: Be prepared before class having read the readings.
Don't take it if you don't need to.
Don't take it unless you have to. The only learning you will do in this course is how to be an environmental consultant. You won't learn any new scientific or engineering tools or concepts.

I wouldn't take this class (as it is) unless required. Rubbed me the wrong way. Expectations for assignments are not communicated and grading is arbitrary. Workload is very unevenly distributed throughout the semester (periods of no work, then too much work). Projects require little understanding (learning) of the material, felt more like trial and error. Has the potential to be a good course, but current execution of instruction and assignments is poor. If you are not a GEO/ENV-track CEE, there are several better courses to use as departmental electives.
If you are interested in improving sustainability (particularly energy efficiency) in buildings, this is the class to take.

If you're reading this, then you're probably an env. track CEE and it's too late. If this doesn't apply to you and you're taking the class out of interest, then you're a fool. Best to stay away. Song drones on in class, 80 minute lectures are sleep-inducing, not many participate in class, the instruction is haphazard and low-quality, and everyone pretty much just crams the readings to do the projects before the deadline. It's one of those lazy ass senior year classes that the CEEs have to take. Really empathize with the 2 ppl in class this year who didn't have to go through this. Feel like I really didn't learn much, and cranking out the projects was mostly one big cram session - figuring things out on your own, sending the prof and TA a bunch of emails, skimming through the readings. Lectures are a huge waste of time. STAY AWAY!!

It was a helpful course because you apply basic engineering concepts like thermodynamics to real world applications that make the science more tangible and relevant. (It's kind of like an intro to being an environmental consultant course). A nice contrast with a lot of the more theoretical CEE courses

Take into account Prof. Song's feedback after the first presentations, and take the presentations as learning experiences for future improvement. Consult him if you have any questions - he is very kind, friendly, and extremely generous with his time!
Take it if you're interested in environmental consulting work or the technicalities of energy efficient building
This class rubbed me the wrong way
This course only covers sustainable design in the context of sustainable buildings. The projects are fairly straightforward and the instructors are always available for help.
This is a pretty good course and more practical than most CEE classes. Most of the grade is assessed based on group projects.
Will teach you a lot about the field of sustainable environmental consulting.
grading: Design Project - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: From text and selected articles from the literature: final class design report and several smaller class assignments. The student is expected to read 20 page per week.
prereqs: CEE 207 or equivalent with instructor's permission. Open to Seniors and Graduate students only..
descrip: Students will design several features of a LEED-certified building project. Features that will be considered include ground source heat pumps; ventilation; photovoltaics (PV); insulation; glazing; green materials; and storm water management systems, including a green roof, and rainwater harvesting. Ventilation will be designed considering the potential for vapor emissions from building materials. Energy software will be used to determine the carbon footprint and energy costs of alternative designs.
title: Engineering Design for Sustainable Development

otherinfo: The Graduate Independent Study form can be filled out by either a PhD or Master student.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Minmin Fan in E-211..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.
title: Independent Study I

otherinfo: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by advisor and DGS. The form can be filed out by either a Phd or Masters student. Bring signed form to Minmin Fan in E-211.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.
title: Independent Study II

evals: A great start to research! Will depend heavily on your advisor and research topic, as expected.
Make sure you get started on your research ASAP.
The course is good for a first year student to learn to do research.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.
title: Directed Research

evals: Be rigorous and don't save everything for the last minute
If you are in the hydrology field take this class, it was very useful for me to understand the current challenges and opportunities in the field.
Push yourself.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: 510 requires an extended abstract (3 to 5 pages) to be handed in a week before the oral presentation.
descrip: This is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course is based 10% on oral presentation and written "poster" communication skills and 90% based on advisors evaluation of the semester's work.
title: Research Seminar

evals: It is a very big time commitment, but you'll definitely learn from this class. Warning that homeworks are really long in comparison to typical classes. Coding is a big component, and you will definitely learn MATLAB, which is something to be excited for. Lectures were somewhat unclear, but precepts cleared things up and allowed completion of the homeworks and understanding the practical application of theories taught in class. Take this course if you have a good amount of time to devote to it. Also, make sure to practice very very hard and continuously drill for the exams since there is a lot to do in very little time.
Read the notes on blackboard right away and review linear algebra.
This course is very helpful in teaching you about finite element and how to do it, but be prepared to spend 10-15 hours a week just doing the homework.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 15%, Design Project - 30%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Homework assignments consist of a mixture of theory as well as computational exercises.
descrip: The course introduces basic concepts of primal finite element methods. It begins with an overview of finite element methods for a one-dimensional model problem including the weak, Galerkin and matrix forms. Extension of the finite element to multiple dimensions are carried for second order scalar and vector valued equations. Applications in heat transfer, fluid and solid mechanics will be discussed. The course then concludes with the Cº approach to plates and beams. Element formulation, data structures, isoparametric interpolations, locking, analysis of error and convergence, constraints as well as variational crimes are all discussed.
title: Introduction to Finite-element Methods

evals: Don't be afraid to take the course even if you don't have much background in chemistry.
Good course to learn fundamental chemistry theories. Easy to follow, professor is very generous with her time.

The readings and assignments are essential for confirming one's understanding of the course and for succeeding on the exam.  Take advantage of Professor Peters' office hours if you have questions, as she is the best resource for clarifying questions concerning problem sets, material or the final project.
Yes, recommend.
otherinfo: The course is appropriate for graduate students in environmental engineering, water resources, chemical engineering, geology, chemistry, or other related fields. Undergraduates are welcome with permission from the instructor.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: In this course, environmental chemistry serves as a vehicle for study of chemical thermodynamics. Students will gain an understanding of Gibbs free energy, chemical potential, and fugacity, and the universal applicability of thermodynamics to environmentally relevant topics such as equilibrium phase partitioning and oxidation of organic chemicals. There will be a focus on toxic organics and their chemical properties. Assignments will be based on chemical property estimation methods and on simple mass balance models that link chemical properties with pollutant transport, fate, and reactivity in the environment.
title: Environmental Chemistry

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Fundamental physics of fluid flow and contaminant transport in porous media; derivation of governing equations; analytical solutions for simplified equations, with applications to well hydraulics, contaminant transport, and parameter estimation; and development of simple numerical methods with applications to field problems. The course also covers flow and transport in unsaturated soils and provides an introduction to multiphase flow systems.
title: Theory of Groundwater Flow

evals: I strongly recommend those who are interested in MD simulation, interfacial water, surface science and material science/chemistry in general to consider this course.
N.A.
Need good foundation in physical chemistry and molecular dynamics.
Very interesting class if you are interested in MD simulations and interfaces. Would recommend.
grading: Papers - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: A significant portion of the course is student-led design and execution of hyper-resolution modeling projects that result in simulations at scales ranging from 30m to 250m depending on the domains.
prereqs: CEE586 (Physical Hydrology) or equivalent graduate hydrology course. Advanced computer programming skills (python, high-level programming language, scripting, parallel processing experience)..
descrip: This is a seminar/project based special topics course focusing on hyper-resolution hydrological & remote sensing modeling. Recently available land surface global data sets that include topography, land cover, & soil properties are used to simulate the terrestrial water and energy cycles at scales as fine as 30m - often referred to as `hyper-resolution' scales. In this course, we discuss recent papers in hyper-resolution & algorithms behind the models, including their use with remote sensing data. Strong programming skills in an advanced language, experience using Python and scripting, and experience using large data bases are necessary.
title: Special Topics in Environmental Engineering and Water Resources - Advanced Hydrological Modeling and Terrestrial Remote Sensing

evals: --Take it in the fall with Fan instead, it's easier. A lot of Samory's problems made absolutely no sense and grading was very arbitrary.

A Samory is the best instructor ever! He is very helpful in lecture and office hours, and he does a very good job at delivering his lecture materials, despite a lot of students asking distracting questions all the time. The programming assignments were the best part of the course and I really enjoyed all of them. This course is a MUST TAKE with Samory and I will be very sad when I am no longer a member of Samory's class. Go SAMORY!

A course so terrible you'll laugh at the thought that this is being taught at Princeton. Don't waste your time bothering to attempt psets or preparing for the midterm/final because Samory won't be releasing any practice tests anyway. Skip this course and just view the videos on KhanAcademy which is 200x a better teacher.

Be aware this is generally not an easy class (especially in the spring). That being said, you will learn a lot about statistics and the math underlying it. Generally, it is a very useful course that teaches the "what" and "why" of the topic. Start problem sets early and push for organized help sessions on programming in R. Otherwise, you will have to learn it yourself.
Course is not well taught although material is very interesting and useful.
Do not take it if you don't have to! And this course's structure depends highly on the professor, if Samory is teaching...STAY AWAY FROM IT!
Do not take it unless necessary

Don't take it if for your Woody Woo stats requirement, at least not with Samory. This was much more proof-focused than I anticipated, and Samory makes this class much more difficult than it was in the fall with a different professor.
Don't take it unless you have to!
Don't take it unless you really have to. Otherwise you in for a really rough ride. Take other stats courses if possible
Don't take this course unless necessary. At least try not to take in a semester where Samory is teaching
Don't take this course unless you have to. Not hard but a waste of time.
Go to office hours for the psets- they are incredibly helpful!
Good accessible course for an intro into statistics.
Great introduction to statistics. A good amount of work but very applied.
Harder than other stats class, but you come out with a much better and more intuitive understanding of statistics.
I liked Samory. He's pretty straightforward.
I recommend this class if you are interested in statistics. Samory is a great lecturer! The problem sets can be pretty challenging.
I though I liked stats... until I took this class. I learned a lot but it kinda turned me off from this subject. Useful stuff tho for engineers, but it could have been much better taught.

If you have taken AP Stats, this course has very similar concepts although goes much more into depth and is much more rigorous.  It was not too terrible already having some knowledge of statistics, although I think I would have struggled a lot more without having any prior knowledge as often it is assumed that you have this knowledge.

If you take this with Professor Samory, it is pretty difficult but EXTREMELY useful for later ORF classes. I took the later ORF classes before taking this and realized that it would have been much better to have taken this first.
If you're mathematically inclined, take this as your stat course.  If not, stay away.  With Samory, the exams are hard but the curve is generous.
Keep up with the reading, it helps a lot even though it is not emphasized a lot in class
Make sure you put a lot of time into the homeworks, they are worth a lot and it's where you do the most learning in this course

Not a great course but not terrible. Take it if you want a basic understanding of stats. People say it's a joke class - idk if someone new taught it, but I found it took some thought/work (which is fine; just be aware it's not no work).
Not a great course, but if you're thinking about taking it you probably don't have a choice and it could be much worse.
Not as bad as you think. A good intro to stats, and you also learn R. But after haven taken ORF 309 and AP Stats, I was bored for most of the semester.
Not terrible if you stay on top of things.
Pay attention in lecture and go to office hours if you get stuck on the P-Sets.

Pay close attention in lecture because Samory teaches at a very fast pace and if you aren't 100% focused you will miss something and will be lost for the rest of the lecture. Precepts, however, are mostly optional, first few are important as you learn some basic R programming but afterwards it's mostly example problems and helping you get comfortable with using the theories you learn.
Probably your best option for a stats class, particularly if you enjoy math and/or programming. If you don't have any programming experience, prepare to struggle on the programming assignments.
Review course notes and work with others on the psets. Go to office hours to check your understanding on fuzzy points from lecture

Samory is a really great professor and cares about how much you learn from the class! Really glad I chose to take this class! Bachir is also hands down the best preceptor. Office hours are really helpful too (except with Jeff, Jeff just leaves me feeling stupid and more confused than I was before)

Samory is great, but this course is very theoretical and 'mathy'. No practice exams are provided which makes the exams particularly difficult and Samory does not give you a midterm grade, so you don't really know how you're doing in the class. However, I would say I learned a LOT and this class gives you a solid foundation in statistics.

TL;DR: Boring, but useful stuff. If you are considering this course, it's probably because you have to take it. Regardless, this course actually does a good job in teaching you basic R and statistics. Pay attention, even if the class may be dull at times.
Take in the fall
Take it with Samory!!!
Take only if required or inclined to learn statistics. The workload each week is a fair amount, and Samory is a fine lecturer.
Take this course even if you have had probability and statistics before, because even though the first 6 weeks will be easy, the second half covers interesting material when Samory teaches it.
Take this course if you're curious, it's not that hard for anyone who has already taken MAT 201 and COS 126. It can be challenging if you take it as a freshman though.

Take this course only if you need to. I'm a math major, and I think that the course is not super interesting honestly... most of the stuff is just plug into formulas. The first half is a little bit better, as you learn about probability theory, but the second is just about statistics, which I found pretty boring.
Teaches a critical manner of interpreting information. Stats should be required for all STEM and social science majors.

Terrible class with Samory. If you know how to code (took 126 or more) the precepts are worthless and the programming assignments are trivial. Statistics at the introductory level is a pretty simple and intuitive subject, but every lecture, problem set, and textbook reading seemed hell-bent on making it as hard to understand as possible. Psets with problems from the professor were ridiculously hard and took forever, the lectures made everything more confusing, and you canstudy the textbook all you want, but the midterm and final will still beat you up because the hard parts aren't concepts but the problems--they either require tricky math or weird understandings of the concepts that wouldn't be too bad if someone taught them to us, but you're expected to come up with them on the spot. Take another stats class if you can. This was a miserable joke. It's embarrassing that this is considered educational. Watch khan academy and read lectures from other schools, and things will make sense.

This class is hard if you don't follow along and the psets are HARD so work together in groups. I don't remember which precept I'm in because I went like twice but you'll turn out okay in the class because the material is pretty gosh darn interesting.

This course is definitely not for those who just want to take any statistics course; DO NOT take it just because. That being said, it really isn't as bad as many people make it out to be. It will seem like that in the beginning, but after you're done you will realized how much you learned and how high of a level you were taught at (this would probably be a 300 or 400 level course somewhere else). Come in knowing how to program or you'll struggle on the programming assignments (there is no instruction on R). Challenging, but worth it in the end.
Unless necessary, I would recommend taking a different statistics course.
Very hard with Samory but you learn a lot.
Worth the work especially for last three weeks of the semester, when everything comes together. But know that Samory can be a solid lecturer and STILL give 16 psets in 12 weeks of the semester.
Would not recommend, Samory wasn't a great instructor and he did not make the material interesting or understandable.

You're probably taking it because you have to, but just try and get through it. It's not terrible, but everything sometimes just feels like "why am I doing this?" The programming assignments have nothing to do with the course, so just go to McGraw and have them help you figure it out.
go to McGraw tutoring for R assignments, since they pretty much don't teach R. Don't take unless you're trying to be ORF or something similar. Take a diff stats course
tough. wouldn't take unless you need to
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: This course satisfies WWS quantitative analysis requirement.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Reading per week: 30-40 pages; Weekly problem sets (3-5 hours each); Weekly precept/lab report (3-4 hours each)
prereqs: MAT 201 concurrent or equivalent or approved by instructor.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression and classification. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated using a variety of modern real world data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R.
title: Fundamentals of Statistics

evals: A great course in probability. Lectures with Ramon are excellent, move at a good pace, and entertaining (as much as a probability course can be). The problem sets were interesting and a reasonable time commitment. Exams were also of a reasonable difficulty.

A really difficult but rewarding class. Probably one of the best taught courses at Princeton, though-- don't miss a second of Ramon's lectures!! Be sure to go to office hours, the preceptors are very helpful in helping solve homework problems.
Absolutely AVOID this class at all costs
Amazing class. Difficult, yes, but a very fun class (especially with Ramon as a lecturer). It starts out fairly light but ramps up quickly, especially after the midterm.

Amazing course. Do take with Ramon Von Handel and with Nana Kobby Aboagye as preceptor (or Koushiki Bose!) Ramon is indeed the best technical lecturer at Princeton. Every lecture was engaging and entertaining. Advice I would give someone taking this class: (1) You must have a mastery of the concepts calculus (especially integration), as well as discrete maths like sums, counting, sets. (2) Start problem sets early and use them as preparation for exams. Results from problem sets are assumed knowledge after they are done. (3)Try to build up from the axioms provided and construct a tree of knowledge about probability and what questions can be answered by various processes (Bernoulli, Poisson, Brownian Motion etc). Make sure to dedicate a lot time to the course. Put in as much as you want to get out. Re: Exams, they will be difficult but much of the rewards of this class comes from the process (mind the pun) and not from the end result/ grade.

As this might be the last time Ramon teaches it, I do feel a bit sorry for the students taking this course after me. That being said, the lecture notes and material should still make the class pretty interesting--plus I heard the other lecturer is pretty good, too. If you prefer rigorous proofs you might be disappointed, but this class helps you build excellent intuition behind probability.
Course is good, but very tough.

Dear COS majors like myself, if you have taken COS 340 then you should be prepared for this course to go from easy and review to difficult new material around the fifth or sixth week. Plan your time appropriately. If you are a strong math student you will be OK but be aware that your ability to do math fast will be tested by the exams.
Definitely a tough course, but not as bad as everyone makes it out to be. Challenging, but rewarding. Definitely make use of office hours.
Definitely take this course! von Handel is an amazing lecturer and the preceptors are super helpful. The course is extremely well taught and organized

Don't kid yourself; this is a hard and demanding course. But you will learn so much and probability theory is such an applicable field. Make sure you have the time to put into this course and you will reap the benefits. Ramon is the best but sadly he won't be teaching in 2017-2018 because of his newborn baby. Shyolnikov is great tho too!!

Don't take unless you are really interested in the course. The beginning isn't bad but it picks up significantly. Problem sets can be impossible and the exams are difficult, half the class will fail the exams.

Even if you think you know about probability, take this course because there's so much to learn beyond the basic stuff taught in a high school course! Very work heavy, and make sure you know people in the class because collaboration is a must on the psets. However, if you took ORF245, the first half of the class is basically a repeat of that.

Excellent course and prof. is great. It won't be particularly awe inspiring, but you will learn a LOT. The approaches to problems you will learn here are super useful. That said, the course definitely isn't easy, but it is manageable.
Good higher level math class. Problem sets are bad and take about 10-15 hours to do well. You can avoid going to lecture by reading the notes.

Great class! Not an ORF major, but took some math classes and thought this was the best taught math related class i've taken at princeton. Super manageable, really well taught. Really a pleasure to take.
Great course! It is very difficult but probability is an immensely useful field. Highly recommend.
Great course, decent amount of work. Would take it and figure out the rest of your schedule around it.
Great course, difficult exams.
Great course.

Highly recommend to ORFE and engineering students who are interested in probability. Prof. van Handel explains hard concepts in a way that you can easily understand. Problem sets are well designed. Detailed lecture notes are provided. Exam is fair.

I loved this class! Ramon was an excellent professor and Kobby's precept was probably my favorite one hour of class in the week. He's a great preceptor who cares about his students and is very approachable. I found the material really interesting, though I definitely believe that this is the kind of class you can only really enjoy or appreciate if you can give it the time it deserves, so make sure you allocate enough time in your week to understand the material. I am not the best test taker so I did not do as well as I wanted to on the tests, but I think that regardless of whatever grade someone comes out of this class with, its a great learning experience.  I'd definitely recommend it to anyone considering it.

I think this is a very good stats class. It's definitely heavy on math but you should expect that since it is cross listed. I honestly would not understand why anyone who does not like math would take it. Otherwise, it's great! I learned a lot!

I've read a lot of reviews saying that the problem sets are impossible and you need a study group and have to be really smart to do them. That's not true at all. Though some questions are indeed difficult, the problems are for the most part doable and just require some critical thinking occasionally. 

Overall, this course was amazing. Ramon is a great lecturer and he really makes difficult concepts easy to understand while still somehow being rigorous. Unfortunately, he won't be teaching the course next year but I'm sure if the next Professor follows his examples and his notes, they will do great.

Precepts were useful, depending on the preceptor. Kobby is the man, though it also seems he will be gone.

Exams are fair, though time is a bit limited on the midterms.
If Ramon teaches it, just take it. Period.
If it's with Ramon, take it. He is one of the best lecturers I've had. The course covers a whole lot of material that is relevant to COS majors and should definitely be taken as a COS major.

If you have a strong math background, then I would highly recommend this course.  However, a lot of people with strong math backgrounds take this course, so if you don't have one, the curve will be pretty tough.  No matter what, you'll learn a lot though.
Interesting and fun material, a decent amount of work but you learn a lot of cool topics
It's very difficult but good if you put in the time

Loved this course. I wish all courses were taught in this fashion. Every lecture made sense as to why we were doing what we did and exciting to see our models extend to the real world problems. Great class

Probability is not like any previous levels of math you may have taken especially you have not been exposed to it before. Your knowledge in previous math classes may not transfer well and even though I've done well in most math classes, it is not the case for this class. Don't take it for a grade if you're taking it just for interest, I made that mistake. If you have to take it and you're not interested, I'll have to say I'm very sorry. It's an excellent class and now I have a much better understanding of probability. But it is hard to say if it's worth dropping your GPA down significantly...

Probably take this course. If you're a math major or strong at stem things, it won't be hard and you'll get a good understanding of practical probability problem-solving along with some decent theory. If you aren't strong at these things, this is a super important skill so very worth the time and effort.
Ramon is bae

Really interesting course taught by knowledgeable staff. Definitely worth taking, but keep in mind that it's a lot of hard work (for most people). Good: lectures, precepts, material. Not good: the curve, my grade.

Recommend.
If you are considering math, then I feel that this (along with real and Fourier analysis / Galios) is really something that everyone needs to take.
Take it if you like math (I'm a COS major). It's not easy, but it's very well organized, and there's always help if you need it.
Take it if you want a solid understanding of probability. The first half is easier if you've already taken a course like COS 340, the first quarter is easier if you've already taken ORF 245.
Take it if you'd like a background in probability; Ramon is a great lecturer
Take it, Ramon is a great lecturer.
Take the course if you're interested in probability.
Take this course. Probability is super useful
Take with van Handel he is very very good.
Take!
The homeworks are hard. Be prepared to spend a lot (~4-5 hrs) of time on them!
This course is difficult, but it's very rewarding. If you do all the problem sets and take time to read the lecture notes/go to lecture, you will learn a lot.

This course is hard. It is very hard to pull anything in the A range and Bs are tough without effort. However if you are even remotely interested in math or probability, this is an amazing course. One of the best courses I've taken on this campus. Ramon is a great lecturer and you will know everything just by going to lecture. HW are hard but not as hard as the exam and are designed to make you think. They may take a long time to complete.
This course isn't easy (not even close), but you'll learn so much! Go for it!
This is a fantastic course for an introduction to probability.  It will be useful for a variety of different disciplines and application areas.
This is a tough one. find a study group early and stay on top of the problem sets and materials. Must take if ORFE, don't know about others.

This is a very hard and time-intensive course, but quite worth it. I'd recommend taking it in the spring so you don't have to do the big problem set, and certainly take it with Ramon. It's the only way to really learn about probability!
This is an excellent course; great lectures and great lecture notes

This is the best intro course in Probability possible! Take it with Ramon when he returns! Definitely take it, although it will take a lot of time to complete the homework. However, office hours are extremely helpful, especially Kobby's, Danny's and Kaizheng's. Kobby is the best head AI!
Very hard course and extremely exam-focused, unfortunately. But you learn a lot in the end.
Would highly recommend taking this course. I found the material to be really interesting and well-taught, but problem sets get pretty difficult and exams can be challenging as well.
hard but worth taking

evals: An interesting course if you want an overview of different approaches to using financial data and a chance to try some of them out for yourself. Be prepared to do reading in the textbook to clarify difficult parts of the material.
Be prepared for work, but it's worth it!
DONT, if you don't have to
Difficult but good ORFE class. If you're looking, you probably have to take it, but don't worry about it.
Don't take it if you have a choice
Don't take it unless the school will absolutely not let you graduate without it. Or if you are a genius
Don't take it unless you need the departmental. It's not a great class, and it's just stress inducing at times.
Don't take unless you have to.
Easy class but you have to do a lot of self-learning. Be sure to understand the theory properly before any exam or the final assignment.
Go to lectures and start problem sets early.
Good class with Carmona, not too hard and useful for many applications.

I am extremely confident that no one would take this course if it was not mandatory for ORFE majors. This course not only is organized poorly, but has a professor that openly isn't concerned with the quality of his course. Here are a variety of reasons that this course should undergo significant revision before it is taught again.

1) Professor Carmona is not engaged with the course whatsoever. During the course of the semester, the logistics and details regarding the final exam were not disclosed until reading period, despite frequent requests and emails by myself and my fellow students. During the two midterm exams, I exited the room to ask Professor Carmona to clarify a certain problem. His response both times: "The question is clear enough." I know that several of my friends had the same confusion, but received the same response from the professor. The day after the midterms, we discussed the exams in the class, and both times students raised concerns regarding the clarity of the exams. Despite these issues being vocalized, confusion remained the theme of the semester.

2) If we had any questions regarding any aspect of the course, we had no outlets to get these questions answered. Professor Carmona was unresponsive to emails, and because Junwei was the only person operating the course Piazza, we were unable to get answers to logistical questions. Junwei was a massive help to the course but he could not answer every single question. In fact, many of the responses to the questions on Piazza were "Ask Prof Carmona," but Professor Carmona was largely unreachable. 

3) The material in this course is interesting and relevant, but it is presented in a very mechanical way. The entire course is spent regurgitating R commands and formulas, and thus becomes a course in memorizing rather than a course in modeling. 

If you are not an ORFE major and do not have to take this class, I would recommend taking ECO 312 to learn this same material in a practical setting. If you are an ORFE major, I would recommend reading Carmona's textbook as the exams are largely problems taken directly from the book.
I mean you learn a lot of monte carlo simulations - it's pretty comparable to every upper level orfe class
I would not advise anyone who does not have to take this course for ORFE to do so (not that anyone does to my knowledge).

I would only recommend you take this course if you are an ORF major, or if you want to definitely go into quant research in finance. The concepts you learn in this class are pretty relevant to those aspects, but the material is pretty tough.
If one would like to master how to use R, then take this; if one is not really into statistics, don't take it for fun.
If you have taken an econometrics course, I'm not sure what you'll get out of this class.

If you're ORF you have to take this class.  Otherwise, especially if Carmona is teaching, I would probably not take it.  The grading was very disorganized on one of the midterms and the final "project" was rescheduled at the last minute, which I found very unfair to people who had studied in advance and planned ahead.
It's not that bad, not that interesting either.  You won't die in the class, it's not that much work, and it's not horribly difficult, but it's not terribly fun either.

Only take it if you have to (ORFE major). It's interesting material and not too difficult, but dealing with Carmona is annoying. His lectures are not bad, but he doesn't take feedback and has unrealistic expectations about how fast students can learn.

Only take this course if it is required. Carmona is a very good teacher if you pay attention and take notes, and the problems sets are quite fair. The exams were very harsh. This was one of the better ORFE courses
Recommend it --> very practical
Since there is a lot of work involved, I would not suggest taking it unless you are truly interested in the subject, and unless you actually have to.

Steer clear of this course unless you have to take it for ORFE. If you are not in ORFE, please do not waste your time in this class. It's awful and not relevant to anything. I honestly don't really know what we learned in this class. If you are one of the people who has to take this course, be prepared to be confused in lecture/precept and to teach everything to yourself from a very dense textbook.
Take it if you have to, otherwise there are other courses you will probably enjoy more.
Take it, ORFE requirement

This course provides a good coverage of various statistical techniques like fitting distributions to data, joint distributions of random variables, various regression techniques as well as time series. Although, the course presents financial applications, the concepts are useful beyond finance. Professor Carmona has a lot of experience in this area and really wants his students to develop a good statistical intuition.
otherinfo: There will be TWO in class midterm examinations
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Design Project - 40%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Homework: Approximately four hours/week
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Regression: linear, nonlinear, nonparametric. Quantile regression. Time series: classical linear models, univariate and multivariate; elements of spectral analysis; stochastic volatility models (ARCH, GARCH, ....); dynamic factor models
title: Regression and Applied Time Series

evals: Good course overall.
Not a particularly fun course. Take if you want.
Take it if you are interested in finance at all.
Take this if you are ORFE and doing the finance certificate
This is an interesting class and if you need to take another ORFE class to complete a certificate then I would recommend this one.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: In lieu of a final exam, students will complete a final project (worth 30% of the final grade), to be submitted on Dean¿s Date.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: 30-40 pages
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 335 or ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment okay) or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include portfolio optimization in the mean-variance and expected utility sense, interest rate risk, credit risk, risk measures, systemic risk. Algorithms from machine learning are introduced and linked to the stochastic planning models.
title: Financial Risk Management

evals: If you are looking for an ORF departmental elective, I would definitely recommend this course. But be prepared: this class is not the "easy" departmental elective that has been advertised from previous years. It is an extremely interesting topic, and I liked the open-ended nature of the projects/assignments but be prepared to sometimes put in entire weekends to complete the work for this course. Another surprise for me was how much coding we did. You can use any language/coding environment you want when completing the assignments, but be warned that there is a lot of coding in this course, and you might be at a disadvantage if you and your team members for the group projects don't have a lot of coding experience, as a fair amount of knowledge is assumed in this area. Overall, the class is rewarding, as the projects are in many ways like doing original research analyzing large trip data sets. Great guest lecturers are an additional plus to this course.
Kornhauser is a must-take ORF professor
Not really that recommended unless you are interested specifically in the subject matter.
Only take this class if you are truly interested in transportation. Kornhauser has an extremely interesting personality.
Pretty easy orf course as they come. professor kornhauser is knowledgeable but not always on topic. You can learn a lot of interesting things, but not necessarily applicable things.
Professor Kornhauser is a funny guy. The class is not a lot of work apart from the final project.

The course material is interesting. Pretty laid-back class for the first few weeks, but then pretty quickly ramps up. The projects are cool, but definitely time-consuming, and having a partner whom you get along with and is reliable is important.

This class is poorly taught and you won't really learn much -- do not take unless you are  good at coding and sincerely interested in studying transit patterns across the nations with little guidance.

This is a great course. The final project is an amazing experience as you contribute to pioneering research. I definitely recommend it to anyone interested in self-driving cars or the future of transportation more broadly.

This is an unusual course unlike any other. Kornhauser is really into driverless cars so it's cool to hear what he has to say, plus it's a hot topic rn and generally just cool. It's not a ton of work, and it's never super well defined exactly what you have to do, but none of it is terribly hard or uninteresting. Overall would recommend if you like messing around in matlab and learning about driverless cars

This is the worst class I've ever taken. Going to lectures is pointless, and assignments will take a long time and will seem extremely random. Kornhauser loves to talk over students and rant about autonomous cars. The only 2 times I actually learned were when guest speakers came, so you might as well not take the class and show up to these if you're interested in transportation.

Unless you're really interested in the subject, probably best to pick another departmental. Interesting topic, but class structure is vexing, lectures are often repeated, and projects are tedious, frustrating, and time-consuming.

You need to take this if you're an ORFE major or if you just love Kornhauser. He's a great and entertaining professor. The final project especially is where you expand upon previous research by previous classes. Learning how to code in Python or  Matlab will help.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Design Project - 30%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Problem sets, chapters of final report documenting findings of the class project.
prereqs: ORF 245 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Studied is the transportation sector of the economy from a technology and policy planning perspective. The focus is on the methodologies and analytical tools that underpin policy formulation, capital and operations planning, and real-time operational decision making within the transportation industry. Case studies of innovative concepts such as "value" pricing, real-time fleet management and control, GPS-based route guidance systems, automated transit systems and autonomous vehicles will provide a practical focus for the methodologies. Class project in lieu of final exam focused on major issue in Transportation Systems Analysis.
title: Transportation Systems Analysis

grading: Papers - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 50%
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research is normally taken during the first year of study.
title: Directed Research I

evals: A good introduction course of Probability.
Everything is fine.

Good probability theory class, entirely proof-based like a math class. Ovidiu Calin was a good lecturer, but Mark Cerenzia was too harsh on grading problem sets. The material is not too difficult if you've done proof-based math before, particularly real analysis and measure theory. Make sure you know the material very well for the exams - problem sets definitely help.

Highly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning probability from a theoretical perspective. It is possible to take this course without any background in real analysis or elementary probability theory, but make sure you have had practice with proof-based mathematics at an intermediate-to-advanced level.
I strongly recommend this course to other students.
If Ovidiu Calin is teaching, you should take it! Not only the subject is interesting, but you can really learn it deeply and ask questions. This professor is very dedicated.
No.
Take it!
The textbook is recommended.

evals: Everything is fine.
I strongly recommend this course to other students. This is a basic course that every student who wants to specialize in optimization should take.
Mengdi is a really good teacher. She covers basics as well as some interesting applications. I recommend this class for all who want to get the overview of optimization.
No.
Read more related materials after class.
Strongly recommended. Excellent course.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 60%, Problem set(s) - 40%
descrip: Topics discussed include: the simplex method and its complexity, degeneracy, duality, the revised simplex method, linear programming in game theory, primal-dual interior point methods, nonlinear optimality conditions, KKT conditions, first order and Newton's methods for nonlinear optimization, dynamic programming. A broad spectrum of applications are presented.
title: Linear and Nonlinear Optimization

evals: I highly recommend it, I think this is the best way to teach an art history class.
I highly recommend taking the course.

This course will change significantly from year to year, based on who is teaching it.  This year, we benefited from a fabulous instructor, formerly at the National Gallery of Art, who led us through an exploration of the works of Pieter Bruegel.
please do
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: Maryan Ainsworth, Curator of Early Netherlandish, French, and German Paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will teach the course. For department majors, satisfies Group 2 distribution requirement. Graduate students should contact Maryan Ainsworth for permission to enroll.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: There will be required readings for each class, a mid-term take home essay, and a final paper (c. 20 pages, plus notes, bibliography, illustrations) due at the end of the course. Paper topic is reached through consultation with the professor. Rough draft for review required. All students will give class presentations.
descrip: Once the realm of a small group of connoisseurs, object-based art history has been transformed over the last century through the technical examination of works of art. Researchers from the fields of art history, conservation, and conservation science are working together in an interdisciplinary manner to evaluate art objects in a field now called technical art history. This course entails a holistic approach to the study of Northern Renaissance paintings that aims to unite art historical concerns with in-depth technical examination of works of art in the Princeton Art Museum and The Metropolitan Museum of Art.
title: Seminar. Renaissance Art

evals: Be prepared to work hard and learn a lot.
Make sure to go to Professor Bou-Zeid's office hours to ask him about the math and theory of environmental fluid mechanics.
Start the problem sets early, and always read the notes after lecture! The notes make everything make (more) sense.
Take it if you think you'll be modeling any environmental fluids.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Students will read various scientific works related to the topic of the course, other than the textbooks.
descrip: The course starts by introducing the conservation principles and related concepts used to describe fluids and their behavior. Mass conservation is addressed first, with a focus on its application to pollutant transport problems in environmental media. Momentum conservation, including the effects of buoyancy and earth's rotation, is then presented. Fundamentals of heat transfer are then combined with the first law of thermodynamics to understand the coupling between heat and momentum transport. We then proceed to apply these laws to study air and water flows in various environmental systems, with a focus on the atmospheric boundary layer.
title: Environmental Fluid Mechanics

evals: A lot of work and not easy, but if you're into space-related engineering you'll love it.

As a disclaimer, I'm one of those people who is fascinated by everything related to space exploration and spacecraft. If you're also one of those people, then my review is most relevant to you. I had been interested in this class since I arrived at Princeton, and years later it truly delivered. The material is challenging, but not at all prohibitively so, Professor Kasdin is enthusiastic, organized, and helpful, and you literally get to learn rocket science. If you're considering Aerospace, take this class. Do it.
Ask questions since the TA and professor are approachable. Kasdin is incredibly knowledgeable and a great resource.

Awesome class on orbital mechanics and space-related dynamics. Draws heavily on MAE 206, especially towards the end. Definitely take it, even if you're not doing the Aero track - Kasdin is a very good lecturer and you'll learn a lot.

Class teaches orbital mechanics which is a cool topic.  Problem sets are not too bad (similar to Dynamics if both are taken with Kasdin).  For the group problem, if you are not presenting don't stress if things aren't working out.  Some of the problems didn't actually work this year.
Definitely take the class! The material was well-taught and the problem sets/exams were very fair. It was fun to have a final project of our own design!

Good class for an intro to orbital mechanics. Interesting material, but it will consume a good chunk of time. Being familiar with Matlab or some similar software would be very helpful, as you will use it for calculations.

If you take it with Professor Kasdin, he really knows what he's talking about and he's super passionate. Go to all the lectures - the lectures are super helpful. And, the assignments aren't too bad and not terribly time-consuming, and you get to solve really cool problems.
If you're interested on space travel then take this course but its not an easy course so dont do it if you dont need to or really want to.
Interesting but hard.
It's a fun class
Learn a lot about satellites and interplanetary travel as well. Very interesting (plus I've heard negative things about aircraft)

Make sure to attend all the lectures and take good notes. The problem sets and exams will often rely on small elements covered in lecture which didn't quite seem important at first. The beginning is tough since there are lots of derivations but it builds a good understanding for the later material.

My advice would be to skip the first few pages of chapter 1 of the text book and read chapters 1 and 2 and get a good grasp for those chapters in the first week. This is the basic core of the material that came up most often so understanding it early was crucial. Try to write down a table of contents organizing the information that was taught in class on any day to the chapter it corresponds to in the book or the various notes online.
Not too challenging, great class for a PHY or AST major looking for something cool to learn about

Read Professor Choueiri's notes on blackboard - they're extremely helpful. Cross reference their material with your notes from class, that'll help keep you fully immersed in material. If you're weak with your dynamics, brush up on them - the last three weeks of lecture is very dynamics heavy. Keeping Kasdin's book by your side isn't a bad idea. If you're confused about anything in the first three weeks of lecture, get it clarified immediately in office hours - the material for the rest of the semester builds off of the introduction (orbital elements, angular momentum, frames, etc.).
Read the textbook if you have time. Make sure you fully understand the problem sets.
Take this course if you are even vaguely interested in space (or even if you're not). One of the best and coolest classes I have taken at Princeton!
There are going to be a lot of things you'll need to look up and learn yourself. The precepts are more like office hours and not a lot of help is always given.
This course is very math-heavy. Interesting in its own right, but you should also take space design. The final project - planning your own mission - is pretty cool as well.
You are probably taking this course for a requirement. If so, don't worry and enjoy it. If you are interested in space flight, this is a good class; don't be afraid to take it.
otherinfo: Grading Information (other): Homework accounts for 20% of the final grade; Final Project accounts for 20% of the grade.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Weekly assignments consist of carrying out realistic analyses, solving quantitative problems and using an advanced software package to simulate and study complex space missions.
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course addresses the various concepts that form the basis of modern space flight and astronautics. The focus is on space flight analysis and planning and not hardware or spacecraft design. The topics include space flight history, orbital mechanics, orbit perturbations, near-Earth and interplanetary mission analysis, orbit determination and satellite tracking, spacecraft maneuvers and attitude control, launch and entry dynamics. Use of advanced software for the planning and analysis of space missions.
title: Space Flight

evals: Definitely take this course! The work level is manageable and the intellectual rigor is exciting. The readings are fantastic and the professor is really invested in his students.
Hard to take on top of JP! But definitely makes you think and prepares you for independent work.
I think it is a very interesting course to follow and Professor Katz is definitely a wonderful reason to take it! The readings are interesting and the topics you cover are wide and thought-provoking.

I would not suggest taking this seminar if you have a Junior paper that is also due at the end of the semester. It will be like writing two junior papers since the term paper is most of your grade for the course. Only take this if you are interested in civil society, or in what Professor Katz studies. He is an amazing professor and very attentive. I only regret not having enough time to commit myself as much as i would have liked. Would be a good class for sophomore to prepare for junior year independent work. If you do take it as a junior or senior, take his offer and break up the term paper into smaller assignments.
I would very much recommend taking the course. Definitely meet with Professor Katz during office hours. His feedback on the final paper and just in general is very helpful.

I'm not sure I would wholeheartedly recommend the course unless you'd like to learn from the readings by self study. The discussion and seminar aspect was not particularly engaging or true to the description of the course. But Professor Katz is really nice and easy to get along with.

Katz is the best! He's so knowledgeable about the topics discussed. This class isn't a lot of work, and the readings are pretty good. We talk a lot about current political events. Totally would recommend for anyone interested in how civil society interacts with government and the market and how to view the idea of civil society in general.
Not too much work overall, but time and effort into your final paper!
Prof. Katz is great, lectures sometimes boring but you do learn  lot
Professor Katz is a phenomenal professor, who really wants you to learn. Meet with him individually about writing the term paper and start writing it early!!

Professor Katz is very sweet and very impressive, and he taught me a lot about civil society. The seminar is a good one to take if you don't want to do all the readings or have to participate a lot; conversely, it means only a few people talk much or else only Professor Katz talks so it can get boring. It can also be intimidating to talk if you're not a Woody Woo major/someone really knowledgeable about politics. Really interesting topic though and an easy way to learn about it.
Take advantage of Prof. Katz's vast knowledge and experience! He is amazing.
Take it. Professor Katz will make you excited about learning.
Take this class! Professor Katz is amazing. Course is alot of reading and discussions, but it is all relevant, interesting, and super helpful in understanding our history and world of society!
Take this class! Professor Katz is one of the best professors at Princeton!
The entire grade is the final paper. Go to officer hours and submit drafts.
do the readings, stay engaged in the discussion
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 20-page research paper.
descrip: Civil society is the arena of voluntary organizations (churches, social welfare organizations, sporting clubs) and communal activity. Scholars now tell us that such voluntary and cooperative activities create "social capital" -- a stock of mutual trust that forms the glue that holds society together. The course will be devoted to the study of the history of these concepts, and to the analysis of their application to the United States and other societies. This will be an interdisciplinary effort, embracing history, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, and other disciplines.
title: Civil Society and Public Policy

evals: Branko is great

Go to lectures, make sure to take notes on everything he says that aren't on the slides. There is a lot of critical thinking - for most answers on homework, you can get most of the credit with a wrong answer if you justify your thinking.

highly recommend. one of the best classes i took since i learned a lot in a low stress environment. he is patient and always lets you ask as many questions as you can so its a really good starting point for classes.
otherinfo: Not Open to Freshmen
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: See instructor for complete list
descrip: Structural Health Monitoring is a relatively new, interdisciplinary branch of engineering. This course introduces the topic with basic definitions of measurement and monitoring, monitoring activities and entities, and with various available and emerging monitoring technologies. The fundamental criteria for applications on concrete, steel and composite materials are elaborated, and the basics on data interpretation and analysis for both static and dynamic monitoring are presented. Finally methods applicable to large spectrum of civil structures, such as bridges, buildings, geo structures, and large structures are developed.
title: Special Topics in MMS - Structural Health Monitoring

descrip: Applications of numerical methods to problems of engineering and scientific significance.
title: Numerical Methods for Engineers

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 100%
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.
title: Master's Project I

evals: A decent course overall, subject material is presented in a straightforward way and Widner's precepts are good to clarify things from readings/lecture. However, don't expect much feedback at all on papers; myself and much of the class didn't get grades on the first or second one (submitted September) until the last paper was due in January.
Definitely take it! Professor Widner is a great lecturer! Readings are very interesting, especially in the second half of the course.

Fair WWS Departmental; however, do not expect any discussion on culture or colonialism, even though this is a class on developing countries (and many examples referred to countries in Africa). 
Also, be very proactive in asking for your paper grades/responses! (I almost handed in my third paper of the semester not knowing my grades on the first two papers)

I liked it. Widner seems like a fair grader, and her precepts are intellectually engaging. Keep in mind that this is a politics course, so sometimes the focus is a bit much on theories that are kind of fuzzy and subjective, but overall the balance between theory and real-world examples is really nice.

I would recommend this course if you're interested in learning about a wide range of political and developmental issues in developing countries. Professor Widner is definitely very knowledgable about the topic.
If you're interested in a broad understanding of the challenges of POL development, take this course.

Make sure to a plan a schedule for your papers a the beginning of the class, but don't expect to get them back in a timely fashion. It's a fine class to take as a Woody Woo departmental but wouldn't say that it was incredibly interesting.
Strongly recommend this class. Not an excessive amount of reading. The hardest part is waking up for lecture, but if you can do that, then absolutely take it.
Take American Politics instead (for WoodyWoo distribution).

Take advantage of office hours and go back to the readings after lecture as well (assuming that readings are done before lectures first :)) since lectures/precepts give greater clarity. Then you can catch the details in the readings more effectively.
Take good notes! Topic is interesting.

Take this class. Prof. Widner is really passionate about what she's teaching, and you'll learn so much! development politics is really interesting, and with Prof. Widner, it gets even more intimate and personal. You'll love her style of lecturing. Only criticism is the intensity of the papers. There are three papers one the course of the semester, and they all expect a lot, intellectually, from students. And there is also a final. Nonetheless, you'll enjoy writing the papers, and if she's your grader, you'll laugh at some of the comments she puts on the side. Take the class.

A word about Sharan: There were two options for preceptors, Widner and Sharan. Get Sharan as your preceptor. Lectures are already preceptorial in nature, so there's a lot to gain by stretching your time over the two pedagogues anyways. That is, of course, if both of them ever teach it together again. Great class, great precept, great support. They're both amazing!
Take! You will learn so much.

This class is great! I had no knowledge of international development before, and felt like I learnt a substantial amount through taking this class. It also very much helped guide my future career choices.
This is a great class to expand your background if you've had a mostly US-centric education in history and politics.

This is a solid and well-designed course. I didn't know much about the politics of development and I felt that taking this course helped me build on other areas I've studied (international relations, colonialism, etc.). The essays have multiple options for topics and due dates, which is really nice if you plan ahead because you can choose to schedule the essays around your other commitments.
Try to engage yourself in the content to get the most out of the course.

Very abstract class. If you have the chance to take a different politics class, do. The disjoint between lectures, precepts, readings, and paper assignments was frustrating. I don't know that I learned much.

You learn a lot about efforts that have worked (and not worked) in development and some interesting political theories underlying the problems of development. However, this course is a LOT of work. There are three papers-- one 5 page and two 8 page in 1.5 spacing. There is also a long take home exam (that is timed). This is a lot of work for one class, and the feedback on the papers can be very late (literally over three months to get one graded assignment back). Take this if you are seriously interested in pursuing a career in economic development-- not out of general interest or just for fun. You learn a lot, but the workload (and lack of feedback from the professor) can be overwhelming.
if you genuinely enjoy the readings, take it. you will not get much from lecture
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Approximately 150 pages of reading per week. Two 8-page papers and one team analysis of data.
descrip: This course investigates the key political drivers of economic development and human welfare. It explores the effects of geography, historical legacies, policy, incentive design, and institutional capacity on standards of living, including vulnerability to disease and climate risk. Uses theory, comparison, and case studies to motivate discussion.
title: The Politics of Development

evals: If you've taken enough Persian at Princeton to get to this level, you already know that Prof. Amineh is great. This class is a good way to improve your reading and writing skills and to practice new vocabulary. It's much more self-directed than earlier classes, so you get out of it what you put into it.
work with Professor Mahallati any chance you get.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Programming Assignments - 10%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Photocopied Persian texts on a variety of topics. Students are also expected to write essays in Persian during the course of the semester.
prereqs: Two years of Persian or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course is designed to improve the student's proficiency in the reading and comprehension of Persian texts. The emphasis is on reading and understanding and translating modern and classical prose. In the Advanced Persian course students are also expected to write essays in Persian during the course of the semester. Advanced Persian Reading class will be conducted in Persian.
title: Advanced Persian Reading I

evals: Difficult class, but interesting introduction to measure theory and Lebesgue integration. Take it for the continuation of the Stein sequence.
Fun course - finally delving into justifying things taken for granted like interchanging order of integration, fundamental theorem of calculus, etc.

How can you not know real analysis: measure theory, the Lebesgue integral, Hilbert spaces, and L^2 / fourier theory?!?!? Anyone interested in analysis should take this course.

Mihaela Ignatova was a very nice professor and made the material attainable.

If you are considering taking this course, it is probably because you have taken Analysis I and/or Analysis II. If this is the case, you have enough to be able to handle this course, and you should definitely take it. We use Stein's Analysis III book, which is simply the flagship book in the introduction to Measure and Integration Theory texts. Problem sets will be hard, sometimes very hard, but never impossibly hard. Go for it!
Memorize all the proofs. Find people to work with. Ask questions.
Solid class, I think Prof. Ignatova made it easier than usual but then curved it more harshly.
Take it.
Take this class if you want to learn Measure Theory and Lebesgue Integration! Otherwise, you will be bored.

Take. Critical stuff to know as a math major, especially if you're interested in analysis. Don't know who will teach it in the future, but Prof. Ignatova was good.
Stein's book is also an absolute pleasure to read.
The material is pretty interesting, but nothing fascinating. The psets were on the easy side for a math class, but be warned that Ignatova's grading curve is pretty harsh.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of Lebesgue integration in n-dimensional space. Differentiation theory. Hilbert space theory and applications to Fourier Transforms, and partial differential equations. Introduction to fractals. This course is the third semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.
title: Analysis III: Integration Theory and Hilbert Spaces

evals: Burnham is captivating lecturer. Just take the class. I promise it will be worth it.
Burnham is fantastic and enthusiastic lecturer, take this if you're remotely interested in classical music.
Definitely take this course, whether or not you are a music major. Enjoy the lectures of Professor Burnham and learn to share in his passion for the music.
Enjoyable, and not too time consuming.
Go to all the lectures!
Go to lectures, because they're very interesting, and you'll definitely learn something.  Do the readings; it may be a struggle, but you'll be a better person for having done it.

If you like classical music and want to look at it from a critical perspective and learn its history, this is a good course for that. Professor Burnham's lectures are really engaging and he knows the pieces well enough to point you to the interesting bits.
Please take this course. It will be an eye opening experience as you will hear classical music differently.

Pretty easy class. Prof Burnham is super nice but not the most inspiring lecturer. Make sure you like the classical period b/c there are listening exams and if all those alberti bass sound the same to you, you could be in trouble.
Take it with Scott Burnham!
Take it! Definitely take a class with professor Burnham
Take it.
Take this course for Burnham. If you must take one music class, take this one.
Take this, or anything that Prof. Burnham, teaches. And if you are interested in the Classical Period especially, he's the one you want to learn it from.

This class was a really enjoyable experience. It transformed my engaged but uninformed appreciation of classical music to one which is more refined, subtle, and enduring. I'd highly recommend it, especially if Scott Burnham is teaching it!
You can take this class even if you have no classical music training but if you take it you should try to make yourself listen to a lot of classical music because the more you listen the better.
You don't really have to go to lecture, but it's just so entertaining! Also really helpful for the listening quizzes...otherwise pretty light work load.

take it if you have any interest in spending a few hours of class every week listening to classical music. burnham is a great lecturer and tells all sorts of fun stories. the class was never too stressful, and the workload is very manageable
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Listening assignments and readings. Several brief written assignments, as well as, midterm and final essays. Periodic listening quizzes.
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the historical, aesthetic, and stylistic issues of the music of the Viennese Classical period. Class discussions will focus on the critical analysis of selected musical works by Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven, as well as on the cultural context of the music.
title: Music of the Classical Period

evals: Be prepared to do research outside your comfort zone
Good
It will be a great course if you are concentrated in this field.

Recommend for those who already have taken MAE's viscous flow. It's an very good extension of the contents of that course and even allow you to dig into your interest to develop a project of your own.
This was an excellent class. I would highly recommend it to anyone studying some aspect of low-Reynolds-number hydrodynamics, or who likes to think about fluid mechanics.
grading: Papers - 45%, Oral Presentation(s) - 45%, Problem set(s) - 10%
descrip: Survey of low Reynolds number flows and various applications with complex fluids. The theoretical structure of these flows is presented, including integral equation descriptions. Applications to be given for particle motions, suspensions, bubble and droplets, thin films, fluid-structure interactions, etc.
title: Advanced Topics in Fluid Mechanics I - Low Reynolds Number Flows

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class meets from 11/6/2017 to 12/15/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course evaluates fiscal policies that governments will likely consider in the 21st century. Recent economic developments--technological change, rise of robots, and geographic sorting--present many challenges. The course assesses likely policy responses: taxing capital and top-income earners, the safety net and redistribution, and place-based policies that aim to address spatial disparities in opportunity. The goal is to discuss potential market failures operating in these settings, to critique methods of government intervention, and to discuss pros/cons of alternative policies.
title: Policy Analysis: Selected Topics (Half-Term) - The Future of Fiscal Policy in the US

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/28/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course will provide an overview of the issues relevant to designing and delivering basic education services in low and middle income countries. The focus will be basic education, with discussion of early childhood education/care, and particular emphasis on improving access to and quality of education. We will review the ongoing debates at global and national levels about the successes and shortcomings of recent interventions for improving basic education in low and middle income countries.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Basic Education in Low and Middle Income Countries
