evals: I think the course is very useful to give you a general idea of all the diversity of the research carried out in the geoscience field.
This course is required, but a great opportunity to get to know the department. It is certainly the kind of course that you will benefit from it proportionally to the effort you put into it.
otherinfo: Course is taught by 6 different professors, each taking a 2 week term. The final is a combination of all their class work compiled together.
grading: Other Exam - 100%
descrip: A survey of fundamental papers in the Geosciences. Topics include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. This is the core geosciences graduate course.
title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences II

otherinfo: Please submit written request (with internal transcript) to take course to Melanie Heaney-Scott (mheaney@princeton.edu). Final Exam will consist of a Final Paper
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Quizzes - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: This course applies topics from microeconomics (ECO 305) and corporate finance (ECO 318) to study corporate restructuring. Topics include mergers, acquisitions, joint ventures, divestiture and share repurchases. Each of these is discussed in the context of the relevant economic theory, institutional and regulatory environment, and with a focus on shareholder value. Meets concurrently with ECO464.
title: Corporate Restructuring, Mergers and Acquisitions

evals: Good for a general overview of the topic but I didn't learn a lot of technical skills.
Strongly recommend to other students who are interested in finance areas.
otherinfo: More advanced topics such as stochastic programs will also be introduced. Course will be taught with ORF 435.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include portfolio optimization (mean variance approach and expected utility), interest rate risk, indifference pricing, risk measures, systemic risk. Algorithms from machine learning are introduced and linked to stochastic planning models.
title: Financial Risk Management

evals: Attend lectures if you can sit through 50 minutes of Professor Benziger reading the slides to you. If you do the readings, or at least most of them, you should be more than able to write the 3 page essays required of you.
Do it.
Do the readings for the midterm! Also participated in precept!
Easy EM distribution - do all the readings and you will perform well. A good chunk of the course is structured around current ethical dilemmas so you'll have more things to talk about during dinner.
Good course - lectures slightly unengaging
I think you get what you put into it in terms of interesting material. Fairly light workload and provokes some interesting conversation.

If you are planning on becoming an engineer: it's important for every engineer to engage with the questions this course brings up at some point in his/her career. On the other hand, there are other EM courses that likely have more engaging lectures.
It is a great EM class to take if you are an engineer. The work load and grading is very reasonable.
It is a terrible course. The professor never communicates and grades are never returned promptly; however, it is easy and the curve is favorable.

It's a fairly doable course if you need a distribution requirement for EM, especially for people looking for a lighter fifth course. Lectures were a little dry, but the material was pretty interesting. It's ok if you don't get through all the readings for that week, but don't forget to go to precept as participation counts towards your grade.
Lectures are tough to get through, assignments are not clear, not well organized. Maybe PDF.

Not terribly difficult and the material is actually somewhat interesting for an engineer. The lectures are not exactly riveting, and you'll have to monitor yourself to be sure you actually do the readings and go to class (or, as most people did by midterm time, stop doing both entirely)...
Pretty easy distribution requirement for BSE students, also you learn some interesting historical stuff about engineering and think a little more about how you approach problems.
Take it for an easy A and an easy EM. Prof Benzinger is boring but the content is very interesting.
Take it for easy EM.
Take it. It's not demanding and you have a lot of interesting discussions in precepts. It's really relevant if you're an engineer.
Take this class. It is the class that everyone is looking for when searching through course selections. Cool professor, no work, easy.
The course was overall pretty boring, and the midterm was much more specific and difficult than was needed. About 40% of the midterm grade came down to about two slides throughout all of lectures.
The precepts are interesting, although the lectures can be a little dry. Overall, the course is easy.

This is a bad class.  The lectures are random and Benziger is a terrible lecturer.  Lots of questions are asked, none are answered.  This course could be really interesting, but they need to find a better professor.
This is a good 5th class for engineers who are interested in learning about the impacts that engineering can have on the world.
This is a good EM geared towards engineering students of all types. Lectures with Benziger can be dry, but precept readings and videos are quite interesting. Pretty easy PDF.
This is not a difficult class and the subject matter is very interesting, but it was taught at a very slow pace and sometimes uncomfortable as a non-engineer.

This was a really interesting and enjoyable class. I would highly recommend to everyone, particularly engineers looking to understand how to make ethical decisions about the effects of the products they build on the world around us.
Topic material is interesting but class fails to delve into the material deeply enough to satisfy genuine interest
Very easy course, take it with four others.
take this course if you want an easy EM but also are interested in engineering ethics. don't have to do the readings or attend lecture. just participate in precept and make sure your papers are good
otherinfo: There will be movies relevant to technology development, e.g. "Who Killed the Electric Car", "The Day After Trinity", "China Syndrome". These will be available for viewing on Blackboard.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Weekly readings of 4-5 articles. Weekly precepts will be student led. Three short papers (2-3 pages) based on precept material. In the second half of the term, students will carry out an independent analysis of a technology and examine the ethical issues facing engineers in implementing the technology (topics include energy, environmental, automotive and other technologies). Oral presentations and annotated bibliographies will be presented on these analyses.
descrip: This course examines engineering as a profession and the responsibilities of that profession to society. Professional responsibilities of engineers are compared to those of lawyers, doctors, scientists and business leaders. Ethical theories are introduced as frameworks to guide decisions of technology implementation. Simple quantitative decision making concepts, including risk-benefit analysis, are introduced as a method for engineers to make ethically optimal choices.
title: Ethics and Technology: Engineering in the Real World

evals: Its tough but you learn to solve a bunch of cool number theory questions!
Only take this class if you have a real passion for theoretical set theory. A good class to determine whether or not you want to be a math major (in my case it showed me I wasn't).
Pretty bland course with occasionally hard psets that will stress you out. Wouldn't recommend

This is not a true introduction to higher mathematical analysis as I would only recommend this class to people who have experience with proofs and quite abstract mathematical concepts beyond the fundamental High School level.
otherinfo: This course is an alternative to MAT 215 as an introduction to rigorous mathematics and mathematical proofs for prospective Math majors. It can be followed by MAT203/204 or MAT215/217.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly reading and problem sets.
descrip: An introduction to classical number theory, to prepare for higher-level courses in the department. Topics include Pythagorean triples and sums of squares, unique factorization, Chinese remainder theorem, arithmetic of Gaussian integers, finite fields and cryptography, arithmetic functions and quadratic reciprocity. There will be a topic, chosen by the instructor, from more advanced or more applied number theory: possibilities include p-adic numbers, cryptography, and Fermat's Last Theorem. This course is suitable both for students preparing to enter the Mathematics Department and for non-majors interested in exposure to higher mathematics.
title: Numbers, Equations, and Proofs

evals: Be prepared to sweat! Readings are fun and light, and Mama Dy is amazing!
Don't be afraid if you have never danced in your life. Just take it and you will love it
Great class. Lots of studio time so you'll really get to experience the music and the dance forms. Mama Dy is a great teacher and a lovely personality
If you are an outgoing/energetic person, take this class. Very, very enjoyable.

It's a totally new experience beyond the academic setting and so I would recommend it to those who are interested in dancing. Don't think of it as the easiest class you'll ever take, because the class itself teaches you so much more than just dance, but it is a fun experience.

TAKE IT! Mama Dy is awesome and the class is fun and a great work out. And if you don't get in right away, email her and go to the first day of class especially if you are a senior- she let a lot more people in!
Take it! So much fun and I learned a lot.
Take this course it's very fun!
Take this course! It's so much fun and you get to dance for two hours twice a week! There are not a lot of written assignments.
Take this course! Mama Dy is amazing and you'll have such a good time!
The Best. Come prepared to sweat, to be confused, and to improve. Don't worry if you've never danced before- Mama Dy will meet you where you're at and you'll be so glad you took the class.
This course was the perfect way to take me outside my comfort zone and teach me to learn and think in a different way. It broke up the monotony of the lecture/precept cycle.
This is a fun class and a great way to get out of the normal Princeton class environment.
This is an amazing class whether or not you have prior experience in dance. Dyane is really an amazing instructor and person, and she will definitely make sure everyone is learning and having fun!
solid
otherinfo: This course is primarily an experiential studio course. Its intent is to focus the first half of the semester on African dance aesthetics and relevant movement practices and the second, on several contemporary American choreographers whose work has been influenced to various degrees by these traditions.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
assgts: Mid-term paper (4-5 pages). Final paper (5-6 pages). Two final dance studies. Readings: 50-100 pages per week. Dance studies every other week. Video viewings every other week.
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.
title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This seminar explores the relationship (or dissonance) between legal and social categories in the context of late Medieval Muslim societies. Some of the topics that we will cover in this context will be gender, slavery, religious minorities, ethnicity and hybridity, communal violence and concepts of transgression. Readings will include scholarly literature and Medieval Arabic texts.
title: Studies in the History of Islam - Legal Categories and Social Realities

grading: Problem set(s) - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 60%
prereqs: Prerequisite: POL 572..
descrip: Second course in applied statistical methods for social scientists, building on the materials covered in POL 572 or its equivalent. Course covers a variety of statistical methods including models for longitudinal data and survival data. Material covered corresponds to the quantitative part of the General Exam in Formal and Quantitative Analysis at Level II.
title: Quantitative Analysis III

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: On the Move

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Miniatures

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Miniatures

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Big Apple, The

evals: If you are interested in learning about the literature, history, and culture of France during the time window in the course title, take this class.  Even if you are not particularly interested in this, take it if you enjoy discussing literature with peers in French.

If you are interested in the history of print and media culture in its early stages, this is a fascinating class. Prof. Chenoweth is a passionate and dedicated teacher who really cares about her students and wants to see them do well. While some of the readings can be dense, the workload is relatively light and the subjects are quite interesting.
Professor Chenoweth is amazing?really engaging classes and it's clear she was passionate about her work. Definitely recommend this course.

Take it! Professor Chenoweth is the best, and the stuff you get to read and write about is very cool. However, if you feel like you need more grammar support, this is not the class for you, and maybe take 207 instead.
Take this class if you're actually interested in the subjects in the reading. if you're only looking to practice your french, look elsewhere.

This class sounds dreadful on paper, but Chenoweth made it so engaging and fascinating. Went from being my most dreaded class when signing up to my favorite class of the semester. Chenoweth is one of the best professors at Princeton.
This course is a comfortable step forward for pursuing 200-level French. You will enjoy learning from Prof. Chenoweth.

This course is very interesting and engaging.  A decent level of French ability is required or else it will be very difficult.  There is a lot of reading involved but my ability to read french increased by leaps and bounds because of the necessity in this class.  That being said, you definitely need to be able to communicate fully in French as there is almost no English involved besides a few readings and those are then discussed in French in class.

This isn't a history class and you won't be going in chronological order. It'll focus on big movements in French culture and history, but in no particular order. Readings are dense, long but worthwhile. Workload is relatively light to compensate for the readings. Definitely recommend taking this class, especially if Prof Chenoweth continues to teach it.

To take this course, I would recommend a high level of ability in French speaking and reading. While the assessment is not particularly difficult in terms of content, being able to know and engage with the readings is absolutely essential. This is a great course, and has diverse content, so you should be able to focus on historical issues that interest you. 10/10 would recommend.
Well taught, fair course. Professor Chenoweth is one of the best at Princeton.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 50-75 pages of reading per week. Two short papers and one mid-term essay, in French. A final take-home exercise will be on the historical, cultural, and literary material covered in the course.
prereqs: Prerequisites: FRE 107, FRE 108, or equivalent, or permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course examines French culture during the Ancien Régime (i.e., from the Middle Ages to the Revolution) through a series of key figures, events, and social phenomena. We will study primary documents alongside modern representations in film and historiography in order to better understand this period and its legacy. Topics include: the trial of Joan of Arc, the printing revolution, French colonies in the New World, Renaissance self-fashioning, Versailles court culture, and Marie Antoinette.
title: The Rise of France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from the Beginnings to 1789

evals: A great look at game theory and its uses in economics, with many interesting examples. Challenging and makes you think but not overwhelming.
If really interested then yes
It's a really interesting subject but can be difficult. Abreu is a good professor. Take it if interested and willing to put in effort.

Lectures are somewhat slow, which is nice, but they are also somewhat dull, and sometimes they feel like a scattering of unrelated examples rather than a coherent series. Problem sets can get very tedious, and although the preceptor Franz is definitely very knowledgeable, precepts just go over the problem set solutions, which are posted online anyway. Textbook was barely used. Nonetheless, the material is not too difficult, and Professor Abreu is a nice guy. Good theoretical-ish ECO departmental - no formal proofs per se, but not just computation either. Good for general interest or grad school.
Only take if you are a proof-math based student (math major, etc.), or are EXTREMELY interested in game theory.
Take it, it's fun.
There is actually a lot you have to put in the class. Be careful at the grading system. The lectures are very important yet they are not very engaging
This class covers difficult material. Be ready to invest some time and to go to office hours. Professor Abreu is an excellent lecturer. I highly recommend studying game theory with him.

This is a great course for those wishing to better understand game theory and the role of information in economics. There are some aspects of the course that do feel computational at times, but the course overall becomes more rewarding over time.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: One Problem Set per week.
prereqs: MAT 175 or MAT 201 or equivalent.
descrip: Explores basic themes in modern game theory and information economics. Non-cooperative solution concepts for games will be developed and applied in a variety of contexts including auctions, bargaining, repeated games dynamic interaction in oligopolistic industries, and reputation formation.
title: Strategy and Information

otherinfo: This course will have an emphasis on qualitative methods in international relations. WWS PhD students please contact jgeorgiana@princeton.edu for enrollment permission.
grading: Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
descrip: This seminar provides a broad introduction to research design and analysis for political scientists interested in qualitative research and mixed-method research. The emphasis is on systematic measurement and inferential strategies when considering a few cases in-depth. Topics covered include case selection, periodization, comparative-historical analysis, the integration of qualitative and statistical methods, the design and implementation of field research, in-depth interviewing, and archival research. The class critically practices the implementation of various techniques.
title: Qualitative Methods

evals: Ask lots of questions and do the practice problems

For students considering acquiring a basic training in some techniques in data analysis this course is good, professor Ovidiu certainly does a good job. But it's not for people seeking advanced training.
Great subject. If there is Ovidiu Calin as a teacher, take it!
Highly recommended. You learn a lot and all of it is relevant. Take a class with Ovidiu while he's here.
If you want to understand applied stats in finance , it is really helpful for those who want to be asset managers or quants.
Ovidiu Calin is very organised, well prepared and clear in his teaching. Not a very demanding course, but is useful. No background in R needed.
Recommend this professor!
Take this class!!
Teacher was great and I think it changes thing a lot. Material is basic statistics but it's really mandatory for bank and hedge fund.
This class offers great introduction to statistical ideas and makes them closely related to our study of quantitative finance. Highly recommended.
Very useful and practical subjects are reviewed in this class.
You cannot avoid taking it.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Homework consisting of a problem set and some reading. Approximately four hours work.
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Heavy tailed distributions and copulas. Simple and multiple linear regressions. Nonlinear regression. Nonparametricegression and classification. Time series analysis: stationarity and classical linear models (AR, MA, ARMA, ..). Nonlinear and nonstationary time series models. State space systems, hidden Markov models and filtering.
title: Statistical Analysis of Financial Data

grading: Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: 100 - 150 pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course examines the oulines of Islamic family law in gender issues, sexual ethics, family structure, family planning, marriage and divorce, parenthood, child guardianship and custody, etc. The course starts with a general survey of Islamic legal system: its history and developments, structure and spirit, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to terms with the challenge of time.
title: Islamic Family Law

evals: Don't take it, if you can get away with it, or unless there's a proper revamp of the course.
I would not recommend this course but it is a requirement.

If it's not a required course for you, I would suggest against taking this course. The lecture notes and assignment does not make sense, we (not I alone, also fellow students) found it hard to understand the way in which the course approaches the problem.

It is a core so you cannot escape from it. My advise is that you don't need to attend the class or precept since they don't help you understand better. Sit with your classmates and discuss among yourself. That may be better.
Make sure to read both the notes and the slides. If you think you are misunderstanding something there may be a typo or inconsistent notation being used. With this in mind, the course isn't too bad.
Read the slides and notes for the class. They are probably the most helpful resources for the course.
The course material is very useful but the professor is not good at teaching

This is a core for MFin students. But I find this class not worth taking AT ALL. This class is very theoretical and abstract. It builds up the big picture of financial theories but rarely touches the applied skills. Given the time constraint of our master program, I do think this is a waste of time to take this course. If possible, BCF should consider to remove it from core and make it a List 1 course.
Very general pricing asset methodology, too theoretical to be used in real life finance. For a career in Finance, maybe not the most important class to take.
You should read the notes (not the slides) before each class.
otherinfo: Problem sets can enhance grade. ECON undergrad majors may enroll in course with permission of the instructor.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Final Exam - 60%
descrip: An introduction to the modern theory of asset pricing. Topics include: No arbitrage, Arrow-Debreu prices and equivalent martingale measure; security structure and market completeness; mean-variance analysis, Beta-Pricing, CAPM; and introduction to derivative pricing.
title: Asset Pricing I: Pricing Models and Derivatives

evals: I love this class! Mwalimu Mahiri really cares about all of us and tries to make sure we all feel as comfortable as possible with the language while also making the class fun.
I would highly encourage you to take Swahili: it's a manageable workload, a fun language, an unusual skill, and a generally great learning experience. And Mahiri is awesome!

Swahili is awesome! I've taken other intro language courses offered by the University prior to taking SWA101, and this class was by far the least work-intensive. Even though we didn't have much homework, we did plenty of learning exercises within class time. Professor Mwita is super fun and he is a native of East Africa so he can tell you tons of stories about growing up in Kenya that make the process of learning swhaili much more meaningful.
Take this class instead of spanish.
This is a great class to fulfill your language requirement. Mahiri is excellent!
otherinfo: This is the first course in a four-term sequence which will fulfill the University language requirement. No credit is given for SWA 101 unless it is followed by SWA 102.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Weekly language lessons, including reading, audio practice, conversation and role-plays, and written exercises. Language lab drills. Quizzes and presentations.
descrip: An introduction to Kiswahili language and culture for students who have no prior knowledge of the language. The course is taught in Kiswahili and focuses on acquiring novice-level skills to perform basic communication functions in the culture of Swahili speakers. Instruction is through performance of cultural themes and experiential activities that enhance the four components of speaking, writing, listening, and reading. At the end of the course, students are expected to acquire simple grammatical skills to perform day-to-day interactions in the language and gain some insight into the culture of East Africa.
title: Elementary Swahili I

evals: A decent class for fulfilling historical analysis requirement. May be of particular interest for engineering students, as engineering is the focus of the course.

As an engineer I would say definitely take if you are interested in the topic.  I was really interested and loved the topic so I enjoyed it but others that I know said the topic was not as interesting to them and would have preferred to take a different class for an HA

Be engaged with the material and listen with open ears because the course material is actually very interesting and many of the social/scientific/symbolic concepts are relevant even today. Professor Littman is AMAZING. Very knowledgable and passionate in many fields. Actually try hard in the course and you will be rewarded.
Definitely a great course. Interesting, work is fairly evenly spread out and doable. Exams are fine.

Definitely take the class, not just because you heard its an easy HA, but because the material is actually very interesting. The homework takes around an hour to do, and the readings are not very dense which is nice. There are separate readings for the precepts, so make sure to do those because that's what's going to count for your participation grade. Try to get Andrew Rock's precept, he is great, and he gives good feedback on essays, other work.
Do not wait until the last day to start the problem sets. It is important to do the readings because you will need to know the information for the precept discussions.
Easier course for an HA requirement. Would recommend it, but make sure to study and have knowledge of your inventors and inventions for the midterm/final.
Go to class and do the readings and you'll be fine.
Good for history distribution. Don't procrastinate on term paper.

Highly, highly recommend this class. This is a wonderful class. The work is extremely manageable, especially if you are at all interested in engineering and/or interesting origin stories. Even as an engineer, I found myself procrastinating my other engineering classes' homework to do the readings from this class because they were a nice break and were always interesting.
I think this course was very interesting and I'd recommend it to everyone interested in engineering history.
I took this for an easy HA. I regret it.
I would recommend NOT taking this class unless you need to for a departmental. It is a fine class, just not very engaging and there are better ways to spend your time.
I would recommend reading and taking notes/making flashcards for every chapter. It pays off when you have to remember all of the engineers/scientists/innovators' names.
I would recommend this course because I can see that it is well-structured and well taught, even though I personally did not find the material interesting.

If you want this to be an easy fifth class, be ready to PDF it. Doing the PSETs will feel like a waste of time because they are. Doing the papers will feel like BS because they are. However, the lectures really are enjoyable and you learn a bit.
If you're looking for an easy HA I would recommend looking somewhere else. Unreasonable amount of work for a 100 level class. The material is cool but I didn't like the way it was taught at all.
Interesting to learn about the way engineering has progressed through history
It's an easy 5th class
Keep up with the readings, go to lecture, and be prepared for precept!
More work than you would expect  if you are taking it as an HA(From weekly problem sets to Final paper due dean's date AND the final exam).

Not a particularly challenging course, but definitely interesting. Don't expect to learn anything particularly useful, however. Personally, I learnt better just reading from the course book than going to lectures, although the lectures can be interesting.
Solid HA. Good if you want to learn more about engineering history. Beware, there are problem sets and weekly readings so balance your schedule accordingly.

Take as a relatively easy distribution requirement; however, be aware that there is a good amount of work that you'll have to do. Apart from p-sets you'll have to turn in papers as well as a term presentation at the end of the semester (if you're taking as STN).
Take it if you're interested in *history* of engineering. Easy P. Not an easy A.

Take it. It may seem like extra busy work with all the psets you have to do, but it makes a difference. You walk away having learned a lot of information.
They should make this a requirement for engineers.
Take this course if you are interested in learning about all the works of engineering that have shaped our world and also want to satisfy the HA requirement.
The course presents interesting material and is accessible for any background.

The exams and problem sets are very easy. The precept readings aren't too bad and you can skim. Read the textbook up to the midterm and go to all the lectures. You could get an A- with very little effort.

This class is more work than expected but interesting and fair. Lecture is fast-paced and you really should go--partly because it is interesting and partly because you need the information presented verbally.

This course is very well-taught and engaging.  It is very refreshing to take a step back from strictly technical education and see how and why engineering developed as it did throughout the course of history.
Time-wise material is not totally trivial amount. CEE 262A has some really interesting material as well.

Very interesting content- great for history, sociology, econ majors who don't necessarily want to understand the complex inner workings of inventions, but enjoy exploring the social and cultural effects of the major inventions on society.
aaa. I only went to a few lectures and found it difficult to stay awake.  If you're looking for an HA there are so many better ones out there.  Not an easy A.
take the HA version
take this class if you want to pdf it. Precepts are really stupid/complete waste of time
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 14%, Problem set(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 6%
assgts: This section of CEE102 has approximately 30 pages to read out of the course text(s) each week, along with an additional 20 pages of special readings for precept each week. Students also complete a set of homework problems every other week.
descrip: Lectures and readings focus on bridges, railroads, power plants, steamboats, telegraph, highways, automobiles, aircraft, computers, and the microchip. Historical analysis provides a basis for studying societal impact by focusing on scientific, political, ethical, and aesthetic aspects in the evolution of engineering over the past two and a half centuries. The precepts and the papers will focus historically on engineering ideas including the social and political issues raised by these innovations and how they were shaped by society as well as how they helped shape culture.
title: Engineering in the Modern World

evals: Definitely go to lectures! they are important because some of the problem sets contain facts that are not on the slides. Also, the demonstrations are usefully and neat.
Definitely take it if you need an easy lab requirement!
Even if you're in the lab section, do the readings each week
Fairly easy lab class. Not too time consuming.

Good class for a distribution requirement. It's not too time consuming or difficult, and the material is fairly interesting. You don't need to buy the books because the readings and the lectures cover roughly the same material, and the exams are drawn only from the lectures.
Great STL to PDF, don't really need to go to lecture as long as you do well on the lab reports and psets.
Great course to take for distribution requirement. It is fun and not too demanding.
Great course! If you're remotely interested in architecture or engineering this is a really fun class to take and not too difficult. The readings are fun, though covered quite thoroughly in lecture.

I waited until senior fall to fulfill my STL, which I'll admit was stupid, BUT I don't regret it for a second because this semester of Bridges was so much fun! If you are Humanities-minded like me, you'll especially appreciate the connections forged between engineering and the arts. You get to look at paintings and read excerpts of literature while also learning new formulas and scientific concepts. Professor Littman is a delight. Definitely take it.
I would definitely recommend it for someone that doesn't have a science background but needs to fill a requirement.

I would defintiely recommend this course! I loved the balance of history and engineering. Professor Littman is awesome and a good lecturer. I thought the exams and psets were very fair.  

 I did not find the problem sets to be overwhelming?do them with a friend! Definitely start them early go to office hours if you have questions. 

The lab portion is pretty fun, in my opinion. The labs and reports are valuable without being too time consuming, which I really appreciated
I would possibly recommend a different STL class if someone needed a distribution requirement.
If you're a humanities/social science student, I strongly recommend this course. If you're a math major (like me) looking for easy STL, I strongly recommend ELE 208A.
Interesting class, definitely worth it if you need the STL. More work then I had realized, and a lot of physical time spent in class, so take that into account.
It's fine, take it for your lab science course.

Lectures aren't the best, often gets sidetracked or doesn't put enough information on the slides so tough to keep up with what he is saying. Labs are very good, lab AIs are generally great and the content is very interesting.
PDF this course. If you actually like science don't take this course.
Take for an easy STL
Take it
Take it. Easy.

Take this course for your STL, but don't expect it to be a breeze. The labs are really interesting and the professor is really passionate about the subject matter. However,  the examinations seem to have gotten harder compared to last year (from what I've heard from friends) and you do have to be on top of the readings/go to lecture in order to succeed.

This course gives many opportunities for hands-on learning. Labs are straightforward and give you a good look at how basic components of engineering actually function. Great course for humanities students looking for an interesting STL!

This course is a doable, while interesting engineering course that balances experiments with historical and social information. I would recommend this course for anyone trying to fulfill their STL distribution requirement, but to keep in mind that the laboratories are still a commitment.
This course is excellent, especially if you want to fulfill the STL requirement.
This is a great course if you're looking for the STL distribution requirement and are planning to PDF. You can put in minimal effort and still pass with relative ease.

With the psets and labs, the workload is not light but fair. Also never stayed for lab for more than 2 hours! Take it if you want to get an STL out of the way, but doesn't mean you won't be doing work for it.

You should take this class for a distribution requirement (STL/STN). The material was really interesting and engaging and I learned a lot even though I ended up PDFing the class. Taking the class for a grade is very possible, but one would have to really work quickly on the exams, which are very fast paced. The labs were also interesting and I surprisingly enjoyed them. Overall one of the better taught courses at Princeton.
You will learn absolutely nothing.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Lab Reports - 36%, Class/Precept Participation - 14%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: This section of CEE102 has approximately 30 pages to read out of the course text(s) each week. In addition, students complete a set of homework problems every other week, and complete 5 experimental labs with lab reports during the semester to meet their STL requirement.
descrip: Lectures and readings focus on bridges, railroads, power plants, steamboats, telegraph, highways, automobiles, aircraft, computers, and the microchip. We study some of the most important engineering innovations since the Industrial Revolution. The laboratory centers on technical analysis that is the foundation for design of these major innovations. The experiments are modeled after those carried out by the innovators themselves, whose ideas are explored in the light of the social environment within which they worked.
title: Engineering in the Modern World

evals: A bit demanding on the math part but well worth it
A bit hard if you have no stochastic calculus background before.
Be comfortable with stochastic calculus, maybe read notes ahead of time (for Professor Ait-Sahalia's lectures)
First half is not very useful, and takes a lot of time especially if you lack a background in stochastic calculus, but intellectually enjoyable. Second half is more useful.
This class is amazing and gives an edge in recruiting when you are able to speak in depth about fixed income.
Very time consuming and very hard but it's a good class as we learn a lot and we get to actually think a lot.
it can help you for interviews the content of this class is often asked in interviews
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: There will be approximately 5 problem set assignments.
prereqs: ECO 362 (or FIN 501) and ECO 465.
descrip: A study of models for the term structure of interest rates, bond prices and other contracts such as forwards and futures, swaps and options. The course develops the theory of arbitrage-free pricing of financial assets in continuous time, as well as special models that can be used to price and hedge fixed income securities
title: Fixed Income: Models and Applications

otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Five homework assignments
prereqs: ECO 362 or FIN 501, ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment is acceptable) Multivariate Calculus, Introduction Probability/Statistics.
descrip: This course will deal with no-arbitrage models of contracts based on interest rates including bonds, forward and future contracts, swaps, options and other derivatives. We will develop the theory of arbitrage-free pricing of financial assets in discrete and continuous time, as well as many special models that can be used to price and hedge fixed income securities.
title: Fixed Income: Models and Applications

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA

descrip: Cognitive Proseminar: Introduction to graduate level cognitive psychology and cognitive neuroscience for first year graduate students in psychology. Course serves as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.
title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Cognitive Psychology
