evals: A lot of work but still fun and relaxing. If you want to learn photography and photoshop skills definitely take it! Much of the work is on computers.
As with many art courses, they vary depending on the particular teacher so make sure you know which teacher you are signing up for.

Fia has a tendency to send out instructions and clarifications on assignments very late... if you're not clear about something, be proactive in clarifying with her! Also, I would suggest having some basic knowledge of camera usage--the class doesn't teach much about the practical side of photography. A bit too theoretical for me, but might be enjoyed by others.

Fun course and you learn a good amount about photography as an art and photoshopping. If you use class time well, the course involves very little work outside of class besides taking photos and creating contact sheets. The one downside to this course is that a lot of time there is a lot of pressure to do what Fia wants and likes in a effort to get a good grade rather than staying true to what you want as an artist.
Great course, very fun, and just moderate workload. Very doable with any schedule.

I really liked this course. The workload is far from overwhelming, but it does take some time outside of class. Having never done digital photography before or used Camera Raw or Photoshop, I learned a lot in this class and I'm glad I took it.
I think that you should try to take this course with specific professors. Ask different students which profs they had. From there decide on the teaching style you prefer.

I took this course having 0 experience in photography aside from taking pictures on my iPhone. Honestly, this course was a lot of work, so don't just take it expecting to be an easy 5th or easy LA; it requires a substantial amount of time and energy to actually do well in. Ultimately, I learned a ton about photography and have improved my photographic skills and artistic palette considerably, but I don't think I'd take the class again given how much work it was and how unclear the assignments/expectations often were. Also beware that you'll probably be in class with VIS majors and kids who already have a lot of experience in photography, so the learning curve will be steep at times. TL;dr very rewarding class but a lot of work for someone with minimal experience.
If you have any interest in photography, I would recommend this course.  At times it can be boring, but overall, it is a fun, low stress class.
If you want to improve at photography, I would recommend taking Deana's class

It's probably a good idea to use the free Lynda account you get as a Princeton student and taking the Photoshop Essential Training course before the first class. You'll be able to get so much more when you already have a working knowledge of photoshop. Also Fia is great :)

Not hard but quite time consuming. Is a good reason to get out of a library or your room, do something when you are not sitting. Take it with Jeff!! It is very important to require feedback on your photos as sometimes you can be doing something wrong and you will be told about it only at the end. Put some effort into the final project to get something that you are proud of.

Take the course if you are interested in photography. Not the best course to take just for the distributional if you don't like photography, because it is a bit of a time commitment. But if you like it take it, not too bad grading.
Take this course if your want to take better artistic photos. Jeff Whetstone is a great professor.
Take this course with Jeff. It's a great class and he's super interesting. You get out as much as you put in.
This class is more work than you think, but it is also a lot of fun. I highly recommend as a fifth class. Have fun with it.

This is a good course to get introduced to photography. Whether you have some experience or none at all, you'll gain valuable practice with photography and editing. Keep in mind, though, that the grading can be very subjective, by nature of the course, but that if you put a lot of effort into your project, you will be rewarded.
grading: Design Project - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: 20 pages per week. 20% Other: Digital Workshops and Technical Proficiency; which will be class time spent working with the instructor and/or the digital lab technician learning and demonstrating file management, scanning, photoshop, print management, etc.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to aesthetic and theoretical implications of digital photography. Studio emphasis is on mastering digital equipment and techniques, managing print quality, and generally becoming familiar with all aspects of the digital workspace. Popular media, found photographs, and the "life" of digital images will also be investigated. Slide lectures, readings and class discussions of student work in critique format will augment visual skills with critical and conceptual understandings of contemporary photography.
title: Digital Photography

evals: 1st half of semester had more molecular/microscopic focus than I was used to so I felt less engaged, 2nd half of semester meshed well with ORFE requirement material. Good to pay attention in lecture and ask a lot of questions if confused (I regret not asking more often about where an equation came from or why certain things were how they were). Labs did not take too much time, only a few ended late whereas most ended quite early, and workload was light (1 lab report per week due, no psets)
Be aware, this class doesn't have much week to week work, lab reports don't take long at all. It's the exams that are the killers as they tend to be difficult, and no work makes you lazy.
Do not take this course. Mol214 is easier and a better course especially if you're CBE
Go to office hrs for lab reports. The lab reports are ridiculously easy so even if you make a small error you get major points off.
Great course! Definitely recommend over 214 if you want more of a quantitative understanding of everything. Make sure you come to lectures.
Hard. Only take if Mol, CBE major or pre-med.

I felt that the course was pretty poorly designed; not much relationship between lectures and lab, and it's very unclear what you need to know for exams. Not as much quantitative focus as I expected from the course description.
I would not suggest to take this unless you have taken AP bio.  Has elements of Mat 104 and 202.  Tests are very difficult if you can not find related math practice problems.

If you don't like memorization, take this class. If you enjoy math, perhaps this is not the course for you. The quantitative side of the course material deals largely with rudimentary mathematical ideals that can be introduced in a few lectures. The scientific papers are interesting but as work ramps up you simply won't read all of them...

If youre good at physics and stats and math, this is the better course to take. For CBE kids - a lot of us this year took CBE250/MAE305/MOL215/CHM303   1 course as a schedule. Most of us regretted it - this is a super hard schedule to manage. Youre best off taking either MAE over the summer i youre bad at math, or putting this class off till later if bio is not your strong suit. Of those four core classes, I found this one the easiest. others would disagree.

It's a pretty interesting course if you want to do math relating to biology. The course can be a bit disorganized sometimes (grading takes a while), and the material is definitely difficult. AP bio knowledge recommended, but not necessary. If you want to do well, you will most likely have to put in a lot of work unless you're a biology master. But the material is interesting, and while I have not taken MOL 214, it seems that MOL 215 is a bit less of memorization, probably due to the quantitative stuff that doesn't require memorizing (they gave us a formula sheet).

Jared and Alexei are both great professors! I had a blast in this class, it being my first biology course ever, and it gave me some fascinating insights into biology from a quantitative perspective. The mathematics is really cool, and it synthesizes principles from calculus and probability. Reading the textbook helps supplement understanding the lectures, so it was definitely a useful resource. I wish there was a follow-up course to this one!

Memorize the powerpoint slides and how to do the math for the exams. Don't be intimidated by the papers, (or spend tons of time going carefully through every single one), the important parts will be highlighted in lecture. It's a really interesting class, and a little easier than a lot of the other BSE prerequisites
Only take this class if you have a solid math background and are okay with getting relatively random lectures. This is not your typical bio course.
Pay attention and ask questions. Read the book for the tests.
Reading the textbook is necessary to supplement the lectures. Mostly well taught course, and take if you have a strong interest in more hands-on biology. Difficult, but rewarding.

Relatively easy course load week to week (only short, informal lab questions, no pset) compared to other STEM courses but takes noticeably more effort than MOL 214. It was Prof Toettcher's first time teaching but he was a great lecturer and will surely make the second half of the course exciting for his upcoming semesters too!
Save yourself from taking this monstrosity of a course by taking mol 214 instead.

Since the material is very new and does not align with traditional biological courses, the textbook did not align with the lectures very much. Thus, in order to do well, you must attend every lecture and understand everything both professors say. Take very very detailed notes. The lectures are incredibly captivating, but just make sure you pay attention well. Also note that grading wise this course is more challenging than MOL 214 but definitely manageable if you put the effort it. Highly recommend!!
Take MOL 214 unless you're sure you want to go into quantitative biology. Even so, I think the quantitative aspects of this course were appended, rather than integrated.

Take this course if you want to look at bio with quantitative rigor using principles from physics and chemistry. Definitely proves that bio is not all memorization but rather highly problem-solving based, and the content is very interesting. We covered things like cell dev, Michaelis-Menten, diffusion, Turing patterns, stochastic processes and even some neurobiology, which aren't things that you do in 214.
That said, the course is disorganized because fewer people take it, so be prepared for that. At the end, you get a really nice integrated view of biological principles.

Take this course! Profesors are super kind and the lectures are really interesting. Didn't have APBio background but I felt like I learned a lot and have more of an understanding of the systems that govern our body functions, instead of purely memorizing.

The mathematical concepts are tough as nails, especially if you're like me and want to really understand what's going on. If you want an A, don't bank on the tests only. Make sure you're getting high marks on the lab reports so you're not stressing yourself to pull out a rabbit from a magic hat during the exam... The information is cool, but it's gonna take more than just sitting through lecture to understand it. Go to office hours, ask questions, and put more focus on trying to understand the math concepts taught in lecture because most of them, if not all of them, are not in the textbook.

This class is a literal dumpster fire. Try it if you think you're too good for MOL214, but tbh you'll regret it. I would consider taking it only if they completely reorganized it and Alexei wasn't teaching
This course is definitely more tightly knit than any other intro course. But the lab reports are sometimes confusing. There is quite a bit of quantitative stuff!
This course is more interesting but WAY more difficult than MOL214. The exams are very difficult and help in this class is limited. Study groups are mandatory

This is a good way to satisfy the biology requirement for CBE, since there are some quantitative aspects of the course. The exams are tough and ask about details that aren't covered in detail during class. The workload is relatively light, but there is a lot of material taught during each lecture.

Would recommend taking this course if you are interested in biological research and how research has advanced to provide us with the understanding of molecular biology that we have today, or if you are interested in the applied math/statistics of molecular biology.  Stay on top of it though!  Make sure you understand each lecture slide and the important concepts.
don't take it unless you have to, but don't be upset if you do have to, it is a good class. Don't be scared away by the math: the qualitative emphasis is less emphatic than you might think
otherinfo: This course is motivated by the observation that molecular biology and other physical and engineering sciences increasingly interact, and that this can be reflected in how introductory courses are taught. MOL 215 will therefore cover the basic principles of cell and molecular biology as an introduction to the discipline, but will also emphasize wherever possible insights available from engineering, physics, chemistry, and computer science. Students cannot take both 214 and 215.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 30%
assgts: Approximately one text chapter each week and one or two original research papers chosen either as founding papers in an area, or because of an insight into how to think about a field or discipline. In the project laboratory students will amplify and sequence their DNA and use the sequence to study the organization of the human genome; build a simple circuit illustrating feed-back principles; and construct a simple microscope to study unanswered questions in cell biology.
prereqs: AP Biology, Physics, Calculus..
descrip: Central concepts and experiments in cellular, molecular, and developmental biology with an emphasis on underlying physical and engineering principles. Topics include important insights into the genetic code; energetics and cellular organization; communication, feeding, and signaling between cells; ideas about feedback loops and cellular organization; problems and solutions in development; and the organization of large cellular systems, such as the nervous and immune systems. Satisfies the requirement for entrance into the Department and the requirement for entrance into medical school.
title: Quantitative Principles in Cell and Molecular Biology

evals: A super fun class to take whether you're a seasoned vocalist or just want to get over you stage fright. Not a lot of work to prepare for classes; had to learn one or two songs for each class and compose a song for a final project.
Absolutely take it. Be brave. Try scatting. You do need to write a song, but she helps you come up with it. TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
Learn the songs well!  Knowing ten  jazz songs by heart is the most meaningful take away from this class.

PHENOMENAL COURSE for anyone with jazz background.  Learned 1-2 standards for each class and spent most of class working on improv (after discussing theory behind the piece).  Great way to build up rep.  At the end of the semester each student writes their own song and performs at a concert.  PDF only, and only homework is practicing (which you'd probably be doing anyway), so fits great in busy schedule.  Dr. Trineice is FANTASTIC.  Incredibly friendly, amazing singer, provides very helpful feedback.  TAKE TAKE TAKE!!!!!!!
Super chill. Take it!
This class is great if you want to learn and perform jazz and improvise. You can expect to have lots of fun!

This was my favorite class of the semester. The professor is awesome, the class is really chill, and you learn so much. I would highly recommend taking it if you can, but be aware that it's helpful to have at least minimal background in theory and/or jazz to be successful in the class. Regardless of level, your improvisational skills will improve tremendously.
otherinfo: Preparation of repertoire, music listening assignments, and extended projects in jazz performance. Students are also expected to participate in peer performance observations and to provide critiques of in-class presentations. This course may be repeated for credit with a different topic. Final Recital 25%, Class/Precept Performance Assignments 50%, and Class/Precept Performance Evaluations 25%
grading: Other Exam - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
assgts: Students will be presented with a variety of performance assignments related to the theme of the semester's course. Students will be expected to present material for in-class performances and a final public recital.
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition. Auditions TBD..
descrip: A performance course that focuses on the development of style, concept, and repertoire in the jazz idiom. Students are coached by faculty in extended projects in performance.
title: Projects in Jazz Performance

evals: Aight course, you be fine. Come to class. go to office hours, its a fun time.
Better than thermo. learned more about thermo than I did while taking thermo
Definitely a lot easier that thermo, just make sure you come to lectures and pay attention. Good notes are the key to this class.
Difficult final exam but the course is interesting and well taught

First of all, don't believe everything you hear about this class. Professor Link is a great lecturer, his notes(on the board) are clear and include everything you need to learn in this class. He is also a good professor, go to office hours so that you can get to know him more personally. He really cares about the students, and wants everyone to be present and attentive, if you judge him negatively for that then I can't say much there because that is all I expect of my professors. Be attentive, be polite, and genuinely work on your problem sets to learn. And beware, the finals are much harder than anything you have ever done in this class.
For a CBE core class, this is doable. Take some time on psets. study for exams and go to class!
Go to lecture, since notes present the information in a form that is easier to understand than the textbook does.
Go to lectures. Go to office hours for problems sets. Try problem sets on your own first, then if you need help try working in a group.

I had Prof Link - The homeworks for the bio separations units are often hard to complete without working with other people/going to office hours. Make sure to attend lecture because Link's lectures are really clear and the presentation is very organized - covers all the important things you need to know.
It's not as bad as the other CBE departmentals...and the end of the course is a bit more interesting and relevant
Keep up on office hours/psets and ask questions in class.
Link is petty af. If you miss his class, he'll hold it against you. Having said that, you shouldn't miss his class, but still. Attend his lectures and participate somehow and you will be fine.
Link is the best cbe lecturer I have had so far. The material is also very interesting. Link is a bit petty in terms of exam questions.
Listen in Lecture, and he really does take attendance in the morning by looking. If you're not there he'll notice, he's also a very nice guy so endeavor to be engaged in class.
Make sure to attend class and write good notes!
Much, much better then Thermo. Comparable to 245. Make sure to take notes on the material properly so you can study for the final more easily. Second half has an emphasis on bio which is nice.
Only take this is you are sure you want to be a CBE major.
Pretty decent course. Give yourself time to study for exams and you should be fine.
Prof Link is great.
Prof. Link is a great lecturer and seems to genuinely enjoy teaching. Rereading notes from class is more helpful than reading the textbook.
Solid CBE class. I enjoyed it. Go to office hours.
Take careful notes during lecture and you will have no problem on homework and exams. I think that Link does a good job as a lecturer.

This is a required course for CBE, and it is a practical course that deals with similar concepts in CBE 245. You learn the nuts and bolts of chemical engineering techniques, and it is a fascinating class with a lot of practical applications.
While seps can be a bit dry, if you stay on top of it the class will be interesting and not a huge burden. Also you probably have to take it anyway, so just do that.

You have to take it if you are CBE and it's easier than thermo. Do not take this course for general interest! There are dozens of other courses way more interesting than this in the similar discipline.
You have to take it lol. GO TO CLASS! He does a really good job organizing the material in lecture and having your notes from class really helps out when doing the psets
make sure to take notes on what the professor says, not just what is written on the board
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: 1-2 chapters from textbooks per week, weekly problem sets.
prereqs: CBE 245 and CBE 246. MAE 305 and CHM 303 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: This course covers the theory and practice of separations technologies used in the chemical and biochemical industry. Both equilibrium and rate-based separations will be discussed including distillation and chromatography as the primary examples. The first two-thirds of the course will focus on traditional chemical separations while the remainder of the course will be devoted to bioseparations.
title: Separations in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology

otherinfo: This is the third couse in a four-term sequence which will fulfill the university language requirement.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Weekly language lessons, including reading and composing texts, audio practice, conversation and role-plays, and numerous written exercises, language lab assignments, quizzes and class presentations.
prereqs: SWA 101 and 102 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This second year Swahili course focuses on enhancing the communicative skills acquired in the first year. Instruction is done through reading, writing, speaking and listening activities on cultural content that review and consolidate already acquired language skills. The course infuses cultural and socio-political aspects of life in East Africa with more complex grammatical concepts such as the subjunctive, grammar infixes, and relative clauses. Students are also introduced to intermediate-level reading and writing in Kiswahili.
title: Intermediate Swahili I

grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Basic mathematical concepts essential for formal and quantitative analysis in political science research. Course prepares students for advanced courses offered in the Department, e.g., POL 573-576. Topics will include calculus, linear algebra, and probability theory. Some applications to political science will be introduced. The course is aimed for both students with little exposure to mathematics and those who have taken some but wish to gain a more solid foundation. No prerequisite.
title: Mathematics for Political Science

otherinfo: The course is first open to students who deferred taking it in fall 2016-17 and will be open by application to others as space permits, with priority for Politics graduate students. Contact jgambach@princeton.edu if you are interested in enrolling in this course.
grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: A seminar on survey design and analysis and a practicum on analyzing survey data. Each student writes a paper based on his or her analysis of previously collected survey data or on original survey data collected by the student. Does not prepare for the General Exam in Formal and Quantitative Analysis.
title: Survey Analysis

evals: Attend lectures and precepts and easy A-B
Definitely a very useful class to take if you want to be a more informed human being. PFK is great, too. Take it!!

Definitely take! PFK really comes through in this class with smart lectures and sass. So, lectures are a check - but, be warned, they're mandatory! Readings are super easy to keep up with, but at some points could feel like very very short Writing Seminar essays. Still good though! The exams were not bad AT ALL. A good class to take in addition to a heavier course load if you want to engage with the material but not die under massive amounts of work.
Do all of the readings! The readings are super interesting and were you will get the most information. PFK makes great points though lectures do tend to get repetitive.

Do the readings and summarize for the memos as you read them. It makes the memos easier to manage and time. And the memos make the exams easier to complete by using your summaries from them along with your notes from lecture. Also go and talk to Professor Fernandez-Kelly during office hours! She is so awesome and nice and the conversations that I have had with her have been very engaging and enjoyable. She's also very willing to help with course material and writing style help!
Do the readings.
Easy B, you can get an A if you do the readings. TAKE THIS COURSE.
Easy to pass if you're PDFing but I did not get that much out of it without having done the readings thoroughly

Good class overall and not a crazy amount of work.  There will be a decent amount of readings, plus 4 memos.  Be careful on the memos and ask your preceptor as to what they want to see in them, because they are less reflection pieces and more mini essays (with an argument).  PFK is good though and very knowledgeable and does her best to keep class interesting.  Would recommend.
Good class to take for PDF- pretty interesting.
Good course! A fair amount of work for a PDF though. Some weeks, they would assign 150  pages of reading.
Great PDF class. PFK is an interesting lecturer and a fun preceptor.
Great course. Work load is flexible, lecture is great, and precepts are interesting.
Great source material, easy final, easy midterm. TAKE IT.
Great!

I would definitely take this course if you are new to studying race and especially to people who have never had to think about/notice their race before. However, if you are more experienced with studying race already, it may seem a bit repetitive.
I would recommend everybody to take this course.
If the topics of race and ethnicity are often on your mind, and you wonder about the history and future of all these social relations, then this course is for you.

If you already know a lot about race and ethnicity, this course probably won't offer much additional knowledge. However, it does offer a social scientific approach to the way we think and understand the terms.
Interesting and important topic but you could find better courses in other departments.
Interesting subject matter but can be hard to take seriously
It is a good course to take if you wish to learn more about the subject.

It's a decent class. PFK is very passionate about the material, but to be honest nothing that was covered in the class was particularly groundbreaking. Take this class if you're looking for an easy fifth class and don't particularly care if you learn much or not. If you're looking to learn something crazy and groundbreaking this is definitely not the class for you.
Lecture is often repetitive and boring. The workload isn't too bad. Overall an alright distribution if you need it.
Make sure you attend all the lectures! You'll get a lot more out of the course if you do...and get to know PFK :)
PFK is a great lecturer, and the content is interesting. There are, however, a lot of readings.

PFK is an entertaining professor. Difficult to hear in the classroom we were assigned. She says she doesn't care about grades and she will grade you like she doesn't think you should care about grades either. Which is unrealistic. I took this class out of interest and I still would rather have a structure to the class that allows me to learn better. She doesn't allow laptops because she prefers to feel appreciated for preparing her lectures and she will call you out in lecture for yawning or losing focus. So prepare for a bit of self-importance. And she's always saying messed up things about slavery (eg "We need to give more credit to the "nice" slaveowners" and "There were many loving relationships between slaves and slaveowners" - in reference to slave women being raped by white men. I don't think I need to say that such a relationship cannot be consensual).

I really appreciated that this course covers more than African-American/European American race and history. I know more about that topic than any of the others we covered in the class. Which really makes me wonder what else she's teaching that is problematic and false. I hated this class which really was disappointing. There is a lot of good ideas in the reading but PFK is just not a good professor. 

I would strongly advise against taking this course.
Possibly the worst class I've taken here. Do not take it.
Premed student here, this is a great course for exploring the history and issues surrounding race. Took this at first because of the sociology requirement for premed, stayed for PFK. Awesome prof.
Start on the memos early, and think over your arguments and how you'll structure them. This will make writing them without much of a guidance much easier.
Students have control over how much work they put in and professor and preceptor (Linsey) are very understanding.

Take it if you want to be more knowledgable about race and its formation, especially in America. Just be warned that due to the content of the course it may be perceived as "liberalization," and PFK is very liberal.
Take it only if you are interested. Not an easy fifth. PFK is a great professor though.
Take it, I suppose, but the readings are kind of too much. Memos are okay, but if you have Mon/Tues precept, you're going to be ahead in the readings for like 2 weeks.
Take this course because it is interesting, and the subject matter will be relatable to some extent. Participate in lectures/precepts.
Take this course! It presents a great opportunity to question one's pre-conceived notions about race and ethnicity and to expand on one's knowledge of such concepts.
The lectures are really fun, the professor is great! Definitely take this class!

This is a good solid class to take. Not that much work, and the lectures are generally interesting. Be sure you come to lecture because they take attendance in class with Google Forms. But overall, this was one of my favorite classes this semester! Do take it.

Though lecture may seem chill, put your whole effort into memos/exams. Grading is not chill.
4 memos/semester doesn't seem too bad, but I found it hard to come up with good, arguable theses for memos. It's a very peculiar type of assignment, but a good training, I guess.
Attend precept and lecture, your grade depends on it.
read material be open minded to multiple aspects of the class
grading: Other Exam - 20%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 40%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%
assgts: Approximately 80 pages per week.
descrip: Our goal in this course is (a) to understand various definitions of race and ethnicity from a theoretical perspective and in a plurality of contexts and (b) to account for the rise of ethnicity and race as political and cultural forces in the age of globalization. Why are ethnic and racial delimitations expanding in areas of the world where such distinctions were formerly muted? Is race and racial discrimination all the same regardless of geographical region? What are the main theories and methodologies now available for the study of race and ethnicity from a comparative point of view? These are among the questions our course aims to answer.
title: Race and Ethnicity

evals: A very good intro to asset pricing and securities markets.
Good introduction to derivatives markets.
Great introductory course to financial derivatives. Recommend this professor!
Take it and you will not regret for it.
Take this course for a very good introduction to options theory. It could be a bit boring for those who have previous exposure to derivatives.

This is the first derivatives class you should take. It talks about forwards, futures, options, and swaps. If you want to know the fundamental pricing models of derivatives, you should take this class.
otherinfo: This course meets concurrently with ECO 465.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly homework (includes paper-and-pencil problems, numerical work on Excel spreadsheets, and case studies).
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility and more complex contracts. We also devote great attention to discuss the roles played by derivatives in shaping financial markets and the real economy by using commodity markets as a focal point. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.
title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives

evals: DEFINITELY take this class as a SOC major (well you are required to, but still). It was super helpful to have a class geared towards guiding us through different sections of our JP.
Do the readings and get started early! Also go to office hours; Professor Ferguson is amazing and very helpful.
If you're considering this course, you're probably a SOC major so you have to take it.  But its a good class!! Not hard at all, little reading, and will help prepare you for your JP so much.

If you're taking this course, be sure to complete all the readings and get to know Professor Ferguson. She is extremely helpful, but your experience with the class will only be worthwhile if you keep up with the readings she assigns.
It's for SOC majors. Go to class and have fun while you can! READ. PAY ATTENTION!

The course is very heavily backloaded, which made for a very unpleasant winter break-- both in terms of having to complete a lot of work and not being on campus to meet with advisors for guidance. Emails during this time (and frankly for the semester at large) were frequently ignored or answered very late by preceptor/professor. Feedback needed for assignments was also given back extremely late: a large problem when the assignments scaffold off one another. As a course created to ease students in to Princeton's heavily stressed independent work, communication and advising were heavily deficient.

This class is great. However, Prof. Ferguson seems to pick favorites, mostly athletes and some of those in her precept. Make sure you turn in your IRB application if you need one ASAP. And make sure to follow up with Prof. Ferguson about it quickly to make sure it is actually getting submitted and reviewed. That whole process was a train wreck for me.
This class is historically known as boring, but Professor Rachael Ferguson is a one-of-a-kind professor, so if she is teaching it you should definitely sign-up!

This course is a requirement for SOC majors. Take it seriously because if you do, you will likely make a lot of progress on your JP and prevent a lot of stress when the April deadline approaches. There is plenty of guidance when it comes to the various research methods. Professor Ferguson is a great lecturer who is open to helping her students. Don't be afraid to ask for help.
This course is very manageable as long as you stay on top of lectures and use office hours and other resources available.

This is a great research course for sociology students, so there is definitely much to look forward to in SOC300. Just be sure to complete readings early and leave time in your schedule to complete written assignments.
This is a required course, so take it. Take the assignments seriously because they will help you for your JP
you'll only be taking this if you are a junior in sociology dep, but its very helpful
otherinfo: Students are required to attend class and precepts. Written assignments are due on Tuesday at the beginning of class.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 35%
assgts: Assigned reading will average approximately 100-130 pages per week. Readings will entail a mix of methodological primers and exemplary/cautionary research studies. When it comes to methods, small details are important: 'Skip or skim at your peril'. There will be five short assignments throughout the semester, which will culminate in a final paper. These assignments will help you create a blueprint for your junior paper.
prereqs: SOC 101 or another 200-level sociology course.
descrip: This is a course on the logic and practice of social research. We explore how sociologists apply a specific approach of inquiry we call 'science' to explain social behavior. Students will learn to formulate tractable research questions and answer them using various combinations of theory, methods, and data. Topics include macro-comparative analysis, field experiments, text analysis, structured interviews, decomposition, simulation, and event studies. We will also grapple with conceptual issues including levels of analysis, causality, respondent reliability, model sensitivity, scope conditions, and inductive vs deductive modes of inquiry.
title: Claims and Evidence in Sociology

evals: If you get a chance, take studio with Frank and Regine
grading: Design Project - 100%
assgts: Students are assigned design problems of varying scope. Amount of time spent in each subject area varies from critic to critic; typically 20-25% of the time is spent on research and analysis, while the remaining 75-80% of the time is spent on design. Completed projects are reviewed by faculty and invited critics, and clarity of public presentation is stressed.
prereqs: ARC 501, ARC 502, or Advanced Standing. Two Vertical Studio courses are required for all Master of Architecture students..
descrip: The Vertical Design Studio emphasizes site organization, the development of building plans, and the accompanying expression of architectural character in three dimensions. It explores architecture as a social art and the spatial organization of the human environment. Projects include a broad range of problem types, including individual buildings, groups of buildings, urban districts, and landscapes.
title: Architecture Design Studio

evals: A fantastic follow-up to 204 but also generally interesting and useful. I would especially recommend to people interested in math that isn't purely theoretical or entirely proof-based.

Exceptionally well-taught course that exposes you to some interesting theory and algorithms and gives you an appreciation for the math that drives your Matlab code. Will be kind of painful if proofs aren't your cup of tea, so I'd recommend prior experience with some kind of proof-based class.
Prof. Boumal is really kind and helpful. Take it with him if he teaches this next year. The workload was ok. Some interesting ideas that comes into union in the end.
Take it! Don't be scared by the problem sets.  Well worth the struggle.
Take this course if you're interested in the PACM certificiate. Highly recommended if Boumal continues to teach it.

This course is good if you want to learn how to implement efficient numerical algorithms and some of the homework problems illuminate how benefiting this efficiency is. It's essential to know these things if you're thinking of studying applied math in the future. The class is not hard and barely requires any math background to understand the entirety of it, however some working knowledge of (basic) linear algebra and normed vector spaces would help. As far as coding is concerned, if you've ever taken an introductory course to programming or have done any kind of programming before you'll be fine.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: This is an introductory course designed for upper class undergraduates and beginning grad students in fields related to applied math and engineering. Special attention is paid to numerical analysis and algorithm development. Students are expected to accumulate hands-on experience by programming and running numerical simulations assigned as homework problems. A substantial amount of time in class is dedicated to mathematical analysis of numerical methods, with proofs.
grading: Final Exam - 35%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Homework assignments in the course consist of both theoretical and computational work. For the computational component, students should use MATLAB.
prereqs: MAT201 and 202, or MAT203 and 204, or equivalent. Some prior programming experience is helpful..
descrip: Introduction to numerical methods with emphasis on algorithms, applications and numerical analysis. Topics covered include solution of nonlinear equations; numerical differentiation, integration, and interpolation; direct and iterative methods for solving linear systems; computation of eigenvectors and eigenvalues; and approximation theory. Lectures include mathematical proofs where they provide insight and are supplemented with numerical demos using MATLAB.
title: Numerical Methods

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Representing Difference

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class will meet from 11/6/2017 to 12/15/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This half-term course provides students with some of the basics of a legal education, focusing on the most relevant areas for public policy work. Topics include constitutional law, administrative law (with a focus on agency rulemaking), and statutory interpretation. Course is not open to students who are pursuing or already have a J.D.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Legal Skills for Policymakers

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: This class will meet from 11/6/2017 to 12/15/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course is designed as a practical introduction to the use of computer mapping (Geographic Information systems) for policy analysis and decision-making. Students learn ArcGIS through examples of map applications. Students are expected to complete exercises and a final project applying GIS to a policy issue.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - GIS for Public Policy

otherinfo: Qualified undergraduates must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics.
title: Behavioral Economics Workshop

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: How We Learn

otherinfo: Qualified undergraduate students must receive written permission from the instructor to register for the course.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.
title: Political Economy Workshop

evals: Course difficulty will depend on how much you learned in 108.

Daiane and Andrea are both amazing professors that make learning a wonderful and rewarding experience, so it doesn't matter who you take it with.  They really want you to learn and succeed and they do a wonderful job in doing so.  They will become more than just your professor, they will be a friend.
Excellent course. Daiane is extremely good at teaching and makes sure the workload is not overbearing. You will learn a lot. Definitely take it if you took 108.

I highly recommend this for anyone's who's taken 108 and is on the fence about continuing Portuguese. I almost didn't do another semester after 108 because I felt like there wasn't anything interesting I could talk or read about with beginning Portuguese, but in 109 there were so many engaging topics and issues beyond just the language instruction.

TAKE PORTUGUESE. IT WILL CHANGE YOUR LIFE. ANDREA IS THE MOST WONDERFUL PERSON. PORTUGUESE IS THE MOST BEAUTIFUL LANGUAGE. MUSIC AND DANCE AND CULTURE AND POLITICS--THIS IS MORE THAN A LANGUAGE COURSE. EXPAND YOUR WORLD. FOR SPANISH SPEAKERS, IT'S ONLY A LITTLE WAYS AWAY. BE KIND AND TAKE TAKE TAKE IT!
Take this course with Andrea!

Take this course! It's fun, not much work, and will make you pretty fluent. If you can, take it with Daiane. She's tough in terms of corrections/grading, but she's the nicest person ever, helps you with everything, and going through a semester with her will ensure that you'll walk away with full proficiency. I wish I had taken 108 with her, so I could've come into 109 with a more solid foundation, but she helped me through all of it!
The workload is much heavier than POR 108 so be prepared to put in that extra time.
You will enjoy this class: it is a lot of fun and students learned a lot. Take it with Andrea!

profs.name: Andréa de Castro Melloni, Course Head

grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Paper in lieu of Final - 10%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Weekly assignments will include grammar review, compositions and readings. There will be four tests, four short papers, presentation(s), a midterm, a final exercise, and a final paper.
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.
title: Intermediate Portuguese

evals: Great if you want to read more in Portuguese. Not too much work and Nicola is great.

It's basically a less-intense version of Writing Seminar for Portuguese.  You'll learn a lot, but, if you're politically-minded like me, you won't particularly enjoy the readings, which focus on metaphors and such.

Take it if you'd like to practice Portuguese! The course material is a mix of movies, songs, and short story readings. Reflection on the material is required through two-page essays and in-class discussion. Professor Nicola is a great professor!
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 15%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Grammar and composition, discussions of current affairs, literary readings and textual analysis, music and films. We will read and discuss short 'crônicas' and articles from the Portuguese language press and analyze short stories ('contos') from across the globe. Students will be responsible for leading class discussions, writing weekly response papers, and giving oral presentations. There will also be a final paper.
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.
title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture

evals: Great course to learn about a field of psychology in-depth. It's unlikely that most of the actual material will have much consequence in most students' educations, but I thought it was a great class for learning how to read and analyze research articles, discuss them in a scholarly setting, and present findings to a relatively unscientific audience.

Interesting course, manageable workload, great professor who makes the topic interesting and wants to see his students succeed. Would recommend to a psych major with some background in research methods.
It was a better fit than I expected. Reasonable workload and interesting material.

Professor Todorov is great, and the class is really interesting if you are interested in face perception! Has a lot of applications for politics, clinical psychology, developmental psychology, computer science, etc. Definitely was worth it. Pretty light assignment and exam schedule as well. We also took a few "field trips" to the MRI lab and the art museum, which were great.

Take this course if you have even a small interest for faces and first impressions. It starts pretty slow and goes over notions that you probably already have if you are a Psych/Neuro Major. The second part of the semester is when the course becomes truly interesting and detailed. Material is great. Workload is completely doable (40 pages a week) and you can easily be a part of the conversation even if you have not done every reading. Professor Todorov is always trying to engage with his students. Great stuff
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Requirements for the class will be two papers. The first paper will be a short paper on a specific model or research program. The second paper will be a synthesis of work relevant to a broader topic in the area of face perception that is addressed by multiple disciplines.
prereqs: Students should have some background in cognitive psychology, cognitive-neuroscience, or equivalent background in related fields relevant to face perception..
descrip: This course will be an upper level seminar that will attempt to synthesize research from multiple disciplines on how faces are represented in cognitive, computational, and neural systems. The material covered will include work on the role played by face perception in social cognition. The methods used in the research to be discussed include cognitive-behavioral measures, functional brain imaging, electro- and magnetoencephalography, single cell recording, lesion studies, and computer vision. The reading will include review articles and research reports.
title: Psychology of Face Perception

evals: Awesome class if you're interested in neural networks, computer vision, Kaggle-type classification problems etc. The class is especially good in giving you a deeper understanding of neural nets compared to the "black box" interpretation that is very popular on the web now.

BEWARE. The first assignment was a disproportionately large amount of work, though I really felt that I learned from it. After that, the assignments really became a mess. They were released late (sometimes weeks late) and had multiple bugs in the provided code that students then had to discover and fix. The instructors basically wrote all the code for the assignment and then erased lines here and there and had us fill them in. I learned very little from doing that. There was also next to no support for almost the entire semester. The professors would not reply to the dozens of student questions on Piazza, and the TAs would always reply "I don't know, email the professor." I think towards the end of the semester, enough students emailed the professor that he started answering questions on Piazza. However, that was short-lived, and feedback disappeared quickly. After we submitted our proposals for our Dean's date project before winter break, we received zero feedback. Then, the day before we were supposed to have our final presentations, the professor suddenly emails us saying that he's canceling final presentations. The class was horribly run this semester. With the lack of feedback throughout, I actually feel that I got worse at coding.
Be wary if you are actually interested in computer vision, because it will be really hard to follow along. However there are only four assignments.

Cool topic, but fairly disorganized class. Be ready to spend a couple hours figuring out the assignment specs. If they add more structure next semester, definitely take it. Otherwise it is a bit too much of a headache to manage.
Disorganized assignments, but interesting material. Unfortunately you might not get as much out of the course as you would want

Do NOT take this course. You may hear that it's easy, and that is true: the material is not challenging. The assignments were delayed and delayed and delayed until they piled up (read that: were not even released so you could get started until December). You don't need this stress in your life.
Do not take unless they get some organization. Arbitrarily graded and vague assignments (posted over a month late), unclear lectures, and hard to get help.

Do not take, professors don't answer Piazza questions and are slow to respond to emails. TAs are pretty useless on Piazza and in office hours. Assignments were very difficult and time consuming. Overall very unorganized course. Would not recommend
Don't take it if Andras is a guest lecturer.
Don't take it, the course was not handled very well at all.
Don't take the class yet -- hopefully it will get better soon. It's a messy world out there

I don't know if it is always like this, but in F2016 this class was an unorganized mess. Assignments would be released late (one assignment was released over a month late) and due dates would constantly and unexpectedly change.

I would advise taking this course only if you are particularly interested in learning more about computer vision. I enjoyed the lectures, but the problem sets are not very well-organized and not particularly helpful in contributing to your understanding of the material.
I would be prepared to have very little guidance and help for the assignments.

I would recommend taking it with a different professor. The subject matter is very interesting and the assignments were enjoyable, but the class was very disorganized and the TA's were not very helpful on Piazza.
I'd recommend this course if Professor Rusinkiewicz is teaching -- he explains the concepts really well.

Interesting survey course that will help you figure out whether you're interested in the specifics of Computer Vision at all.  For me, it was a useful look at machine learning in the context of vision (this was discussed near the end of the course), and while I probably won't go heavily into other aspects of vision in the future, it did help me to discover that particular thing.  There were also only four assignments and the final project was (to me) more useful than a final, so that was a good set up as well.  Recommended if you don't know much about the field of computer vision in general and would like to know more, but it won't make you an expert on anything.
It's a great intro course to learning about the subject. The lectures can be dry.
It's awesome!! Challenging but worth the work in bursts
Its an easy course because there is no final or midterm, but expect to struggle through assignments as the assignment specs are never clear.
Lectures are not very interesting, and the assignments don't really help you learn. You come out of the course with a lot of half-baked knowledge. Would not recommend.

Lectures can be superficial (especially if Prof Simmons-Elder is lecturing) and there are only 4 assignments from which there wasn't much to learn. Overall course with little workload and covering interesting material, although not taught well.
Not the greatest course but would still recommend if you have a particular interest in CV.
Not too large of a work load, but not very well structured in its current form. If you actually want to learn computer vision, I'd recommend finding a quality online course rather than taking this.

Start all assignments early as you may run into issues that may take a long time to resolve, given that the professor did not answer piazza questions, only the TAs. The TAs often didn't know the answer to the questions.
Take it if you're interested in the topic, but be prepared to learn a bit on your own.

The course was good and interesting but disorganized. I learned stuff about computer vision, I learned stuff about dealing with professors dropping inconvenient assignments on you and needing to deal with it. Both were valuable.
The information is very interesting, and Szymon is a good lecturer. Assignments were poorly organized, but hopefully this will improve in the future.

The organization was pretty poor for this course. Going in, I was really interested about the material, but the lack of clarity in the assignments and the fact that the third assignment got pushed back nearly a month (which then caused assignment 4 to be released even before the due date for assignment 3) was very inconvenient. The lectures are okay, but after assignment 1, it's hard to really learn anything from the assignments. Would not recommend.

The topics the course covers are very interesting and the lectures were engaging. However, the class was very disorganized and we got very limited feedback on our work. Also, although we were supposed to receive the third assignment in early November, we only received it in December, forcing us to do both the third and fourth assignments in the last week of classes. However, if Szymon teaches this class again it should be more organized now that the assignments are created. He wanted to revamp the curriculum from previous years that did not include much coding to make it more rigorous. I would recommend this course if you are a COS major or getting a COS certificate and are interested in the topic. You get to learn lots of cool things and the assignments are fun. I was just offput by the lack of organization, but that should hopefully be fixed.

This class failed in so many regards. The assignments were poorly designed and the support from the professor was basically non existent. 
The assignments were not well designed either. The fourth assignment in particular was so poorly organized. There were dependencies required for running the code given to us and it was not made clear at all. Students had to try and figure out what was wrong with the given code and debug it ourselves. This is ridiculous. To give an analogy, it's like having a math class where the problems they give you state: "2 2=5" and you have to figure out why it does not work. The majority of the students I spoke to had no idea what we were supposed to be implementing and there was no support from the lecturer or even any attempts made by Syzmon to clear up assignment questions. The support from Piazza was laughable at best. Almost all the responses from the TA's can be summarized in one sentence, "I'm not sure, you should ask the professor." I can honestly say I and many of my peers that I spoke to took away nothing from the assignments and I am very disappointed with them.

In addition to this, the third assignment was released 3 weeks after it was actually due. This led to use having to complete assignment 3 and 4 in the span of 1 week. When asked about assignment 3 on Piazza, the supposed means of communication with the professor, the professor just never responded. Overall a horrible experience.
Attempts to reach the professor by email were never returned. In fact, this course is the reason I am no longer interested in taking COS 429 next semester, simply because Syzmon is teaching it. Honestly, if Syzmon is teaching this course again, stay away.
This class is great, and so interesting.  Would recommend highly!

This class was not difficult because there are only 4 assignments and 1 final project. It's not graded harshly and you can figure out how to do them just by the lecture slides. However, this class was extremely disorganized when it came to the assignments and deadlines were moved around. There was also no transparency about grading so you never knew why you got points off. If you actually want to learn computer vision, go to lectures, but this class is definitely possible to do the bare minimum and still do well.
This course was super interesting. This semester it was pretty disorganized and involved self-learning but overall a good course

This course went wrong for me in two ways. First, the course grade is 70% assignments, yet assignment #3 was posted about a month late. That meant people had to do the last 2 assignments in the last 2 weeks of class. I had to work for the first week of winter break. This course was also unexpectedly bland, but that's just because of my personal taste. I found the assignments frustrating because they took a long time to run and test. I also found the applications of the course too specific, though that's not the course's problem. I was generally VERY unmotivated by this course.

Very interesting material covered in this course - would recommend if you have an interest in machine learning/neural networks/cool applications of computer science. Be prepared for challenging assignments and not a TON of guidance - help is there but you have to work hard to get it. I enjoyed this course and learned a lot from it but definitely experienced some frustration in the lack of organization.

WORST DECISION I'VE EVER MADE AT PRINCETON. You have been warned. The class is the most disorganized class I have ever taken. Nobody knew what was going on. The lecturers were impossible to follow and the assignments were so poorly explained and guided. I tried to follow in lecturer but evetnualy stopped going because I just could not understand. The professor just assumed everyone already had the relevant math knowledge, which isn't true. Only about 5 people (grad students) follow in class maybe, and most of the time I was just lost.There was hardly any support for class materials and assignments. Moreover, for one assignment, the professor released the assignment a month after it was supposedly due. Overall, the professor didn't seem to care about the class and the TAs had no idea what was going on. The professor had to cancel the final project presentation because everything was so last minute. Overall, just the worst experience ever and extremely disappointed.
easy class but poorly organized; you probably won't learn too much about vision
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: Design project in lieu of a final exam.
grading: Design Project - 20%, Quizzes - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Readings will be assigned (approximately 1 chapter per week) and/or classic research papers (1-2 papers per week). Programming assignments will be due every 2-3 weeks.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. The course will require programming (in C, C++, and/or Matlab), as well as some background in data structures, linear algebra and probability. Experience with computer graphics is useful, but not necessary..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the concepts of 2D and 3D computer vision. It surveys a wide range of topics from level-level vision to high-level recognition. We will discuss concepts such as filtering and edge detection; cameras and shape reconstruction; segmentation and clustering; optical flow and tracking; object recognition; motion recognition; statistical modeling of visual data, etc. Throughout the course, there will also be examination of aspects of human vision and perception that guide and inspire computer vision techniques.
title: Computer Vision

evals: A very helpful course for those interested in derivatives pricing and creating Excel formulae. I would recommend it especially to those interested in trading and structuring.
Course is interesting, but more focused on mathematical finance than C  .
Great course.
Great lectures and assignments! Take it!
Take this course if you like programming/comp finance and if you want to become a quant.
This is an AMAZING class that you shouldn't miss, especially if Prof. Sotiropoulos is teaching it.
Very good if you want to see what quants actually do
Very useful for those students who want to have an industry-standard (finance) training in C  .
use the Cplusplus website tutorials
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Programming Assignments - 60%
assgts: There will be no midterm, and the final grade will be computed as follows: 60% Homework and 40% final project. Assignments will be posted due in a week.
prereqs: Basic knowledge of C++ programming and Microsoft Excel usage. Junior & Senior enrollment by Instructor permission only--must contact instructor PRIOR to signing up..
descrip: The intent of this course is to introduce the student to the technical and algorithmic aspects of a wide spectrum of computer applications currently used in the financial industry, and to prepare the student for the development of new applications. The student will be introduced to C++, the weekly homework will involve writing C++ code, and the final project will also involve programming in the same environment.
title: Computational Finance in C++

evals: I loved the class and the discussion was great. the professors clearly like to teach it. easy grading for the most part as long as you participate and show youre interested and willing to learn

If you're interested in the subject of civ-mil relations or just the military in general, and want a very relevant course on decision making when it comes to foreign interventions, definitely take the course.
Participate, read the news
Take it if you can! The reading load seems intimidating at first but the teachers as a duo are phenomenal.
Take it!  It is very interesting, and make sure to engage in the discussions very often.
Take this course if you're prepared to put in legwork engaging with the material

This course is not too much work, but it is not like a typical Politics departmental. The readings are not typical political science readings, and class discussion can become tangential at times. The papers and presentations also do not come with much guidance. Still, it was a fun course.
This course requires a large time commitment if you want to do a good job. Read/skim as much as you can. Put time into the outline and presentation.
otherinfo: Classroom participation will be quite important.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Final 10-15 page paper due on Dean's Date. Presentation of final paper outline and comment on classmates' outlines.
descrip: This course examines the role of the military in the formulation and implementation of foreign policy. The course will cover the theory of civil-military relations and how the military influences foreign policy decision-making. We will investigate theories of conflict, nuclear war and deterrence, diverse forms of warfare, the efficacy of war termination strategies, and what future trends in warfare portends for the military instrument of foreign policy. The aim of the course is to help acquaint students with role of the military in the formulation and implementation of foreign policy and in the functioning of the international system.
title: Seminar in International Relations - The Military Instrument of Foreign Policy

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Politics of Nostalgia, The

evals: Always do the readings
Be prepared to be involved and do the work, but it is very interesting.
Engage in the conversation, which is one of the more rewarding aspects of this course.
If you are interested in Religion, Media, Advertisement, Persuasion, Social Movements, or anthropology take this course.

If you want the experience of being in a small seminar without the three hour long period, then this class is awesome. Professor Rouse will introduce texts and commentary that will challenge how you think about the role of religion, which has become an increasingly relevant topic in contemporary news. The readings are manageable, and I highly encourage you to go to Prof. Rouse's office hours if you want to get more out of the course.
Keep track of overarching themes across readings to stay oriented.
Participate in class and do the readings.
Take it. Read! and do a creative media project!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: 120 pages of reading per week. Weekly précis 20%, mid-term exam 20%, media assignment 20%, final paper 30%, participation 10%
descrip: This course explores how media shapes cultural and social identities. From televangelism to political talk radio, the mass marketing of faith and political ideologies is contributing to how people understand themselves as gendered, raced, and classed subjects. But are these programs helping to sustain a fragile consensus within our nation-state, or is this media threatening radical disunity? This course examines what is at stake culturally in this religious and ideological war of symbols generated within mediascapes.
title: Religion, Ideology, and Media

evals: Good manageable econ departmental especially if you're at all interested in Europe.

Great material, lectures are a bit dry, but overall the written assignments and presentations are relevant. Go to her office hours for help on problem sets! Make sure to try to attend class even if it is early because she often says more than on her slides.

I thought the class was overall pretty interesting, and very relevant to world affairs right now, with Brexit and other EU-related events. I do think that there was too much information at times (especially when trying to study for the final), but Prof. Weyerbrock explains it in a way that is easy to understand. Good departmental for Econ majors!
I would highly recommend attending all lectures and doing the packet readings as that is the most important asset to the class.
I'd definitely recommend taking this course even if you're not an econ major for a better understanding of the economic situation in Europe!
Interesting mix of economics and politics.
Know your micro and macro

Lectures were pretty dry. Prof does everything on the board so you have to go to class and take notes. Take for Econ departmental if you are interested in the logistics of the EU. Felt like a history course since the final was mostly memorization and regurgitation
Not sure.
Professor Weyerbrock is super nice and helpful. This class is very interesting, but be aware that you do have to learn trade models that are a bit dry.
Take it if you need another econ elective
Take it! Silvia is an excellent professor.
Take this class if you need a departmental. Lectures aren't always engaging but there are some applicable macro theories taught.

This class if great! Professor Weyerbrock is very sweet and clearly explains the topics in her lectures. She was also very understanding of our lack of enthusiasm at times since the class was at 8:30 AM. She answered any and all questions we had and was very helpful in office hours. Overall, Silvia and her lectures were very pleasant.The three problem sets were great at applying topics taught in lecture. The third one was a bit challenging and long, but office hours were great for clarifying any problems we had. I really enjoyed the paper we wrote in lieu of a midterm exam. I thought it was an effective way to learn about the EU and the presentations were interesting to watch. The EU readers that Silvia would compile were very helpful. At times I thought the textbook readings were a bit superfluous but were easy to skim through to find the most relevant information. The textbook was especially helpful if you needed some minor clarification on a specific topic. Overall, I'm very happy that i took this course. It was taught well and was very interesting.
Try your best to go to all the lectures.

Would suggest reading the readers and making sure that they completely understand the problem sets, which cover the material well.  And take this class!  Professor Weyerbrock is an excellent lecturer and makes herself very accessible to her students.
interesting and relatively low-work class; prof weyerbrock is great
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 18%, Final Exam - 45%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 22%
assgts: One to three articles or book chapters per week. Three problem sets. One presentation. Short paper.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101.
descrip: Europe is at a crossroads. Political and economic integration in the European Union (EU) exceeds levels reached in the rest of the world. Economic integration not only affects trade but also migration, agriculture, competition, regions, energy, and money. Most euro area economies have been struggling with interlocking crises involving debt, banking and growth. The EU is facing a migration crisis. The UK voted for Brexit, and other countries may follow. This course studies economic integration and the ongoing crises. It uses economic analysis to study policy issues.
title: Economics of Europe

evals: A good course for EC.

Chapters 1,2 and 5 are quite accessible and there are easily available resources on the web. Chapters 3 and 4 are somewhat more challanging if you do not find the manner in which the book presents them very helpful.
Interesting course, but very difficult if you do not have a strong background in logic or proofs.
Probably don't take it. The course goes over five different logical systems, not very much in depth, and the lectures aren't all that good. If Kezia is one of the preceptors, avoid her precept(s)!

Seriously only take if you are already well into mathematics or classical logic. You need a very strong understanding of at least one to make sense of the course. It's really assuming very good knowledge of classical logic before going into the somewhat more esoteric or alternate logics. You will need to do a lot of work on your own to make any sense of the stuff.
otherinfo: Students should not register for the course unless they will be free to attend precept at one of the listed times.
grading: Other Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 60%
assgts: Bi-weekly exercises. About 10-20 per week of dense material
prereqs: PHI 201 or instructor's permission.
descrip: An introduction to non-classical formal logics: temporal, modal, conditional, relevantistic, intuitionistic.
title: Philosophical Logic

evals:
- I really enjoyed this course! 
- It particularly targets Spanish speaking, rather than reading or writing. At least half of the class time is spent presenting (and presentations account for half of your grade in the course). There is minimal instruction on grammar, and almost none on vocabulary (with the exception of cinematic jargon). 
- The course is well-organized & unambiguous. On Blackboard there are super clear instructions, as well as a straightforward & detailed grading rubric, for every assignment throughout the semester. This made grading transparent and accountable. 
- I'd recommend taking the course with Profesora Nadia if she's teaching it--she's the best!

AAH The movies for this class are great. The Spanish level is very high so be cautious if you aren't at least nearly fluent. Gorka has a tendency to give you the same grade all semester too so watch out for that.
Be ready to come in shy and not look forward to the 5 required presentations but by the end you'll be a pro.

Despite the fact that it's only a 200 level course, it requires being actually fluent in Spanish. If you still struggle with grammar or speaking (lots of presentations and short writing assignments), you'll lack the preparation needed for the course and might not enjoy it as much as you'd like to. But if your Spanish skills are solid, you'll completely enjoy having conversations about the films! Most of them were amazing, and I felt the course was a breath of fresh air. It changed the way I look at film and made me appreciate this art much more than I did before. Strongly recommend with Nadia!
Don't wait until the last minute to watch the movies and write the tableros. The 8pm Saturday deadlines sneak up on you.
Great class, but a lot more work than expected. Still take it just be prepared, also Gorka is kind of a tough grader as far as the department goes
I really enjoyed this course and would highly recommend it to anyone looking to improve their Spanish.

If you are looking for an enjoyable and engaging way to continue practicing Spanish, this is the course for you. It consists of a manageable workload, and I would consider it a viable 5th class for a heavier semester.
Professor Cervantes is great and the class is chill, you should take it
Professor is very good! Not a big focus on grammar, much bigger focus on making presentations and class discussion. The movies we watched are great.

Start on work early and don't watch it pile up. In this course you may have 2 weeks completely work-free and then a week of constant Spanish if you don't plan accordingly. Lots of presentations which is good for your speaking development. It is fun though! Enjoy the excuse to critically examine movies and be entertained by them!
Take this class as a fifth class, as a 200 level pre rec, or if you want to improve your speaking and listening abilities.  Nadia is great!
Take this class if you can. Gorka is amazing, the movies are cool and interesting, and it is a very low stress class. Very rewarding, and very chill.
Take this course! It's great. Movies are excellent, Gorka is excellent, this course is a must-take for anyone interested in Spanish

This is a very enjoyable course, that will also force you to come to terms with your language speaking abilities, and is thus both useful and fun. The film analysis is pretty basic because its more about learning to speak, but you will enjoy it anyway.
This is definitely one of my favourite courses at Princeton! Great movies, my Spanish got so much better, and Gorka is incredible. Take it!
Watch the movies carefully.
You cannot skim a movie. This class is a lot of work.
