You will be required to talk in Spanish a lot!

You're going to be working really hard just to get an A-, but the movies for the class are all really great. There are a TON of presentations for this class. For non-native speakers, these will probably take a while to prepare, as you're mostly graded on grammar--both correctness and the level of complexity you use. Same applies to the weekly Bb posts--you'll get slammed for any and all grammatical mistakes. Make sure to schedule your presentations wisely and in accordance with other classes you're taking, since you do get to choose which weeks you present.
take this class, even if you're not a big movie person. your spanish skills will improve tremendously
otherinfo: Offered both semesters.
grading: Papers - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 55%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Students will watch a film every week. These films will be available on Blackboard and on reserve in Firestone Library. After viewing the movie, students will be required to post a blog comment on Blackboard's discussion board, which will later be the subject of discussion in class. Additionally, there will be 10-15 pages of readings per week. During the semester, there will be one composition, five oral presentations and one final critical video review.
prereqs: SPA 107 with instructor's permission or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: A course designed to improve speaking abilities while learning about Hispanic cultures and cinema in context. The course aims to provide the students with lexical and grammatical tools to allow them to engage in formal and informal discussion on a variety of topics informed by the films provided. Additionally, there will be several writing exercises throughout the semester that will help students improve their writing abilities. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of all linguistic skills, especially listening comprehension, fluency and accuracy in their speech.
title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema

evals: Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the projects, and don't put them off until the last minute. Don't be afraid to go to office hours -- Prof. Mueller is very helpful.
Don't wait until the last minute to start the projects.
Even if you're an undergrad, this a must take course!
Good course, lots of work

I highly recommend this course for someone who is interested in gaining a deep understanding of different numerical methods for modeling fluid flows. The assignments for the courses are very time- and coding- intensive, so this is not a course that can be taken casually. It is, however, one that is very well taught by Professor Mueller, and very rewarding.

I highly recommend this course. It surveys a  broad range of methods for solving the Navier Stokes with a computer. Mueller is a great professor and the assignments really help you learn skills which will be useful for research.
Significant amount of coding required, and the amount of work that has been contributed is huge and can hardly be reflected without proper writeup.
Stay up-to-date on the lecture material and start the projects early.
Very good CFD course.
Very interesting course, but not recommended to first-year students with no previous knowledge on CFD. To take if you are interested in computational work, as programming is heavily required.
While there are a lot of recommended prerequisites, hard work is a good substitution if one approaches the material with the will to succeed.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: The required coursework includes short programming assignments for simple fluid flows. The course culminates with a final project of the student's choosing.
descrip: Overview and fundamentals of numerical algorithms and models for computational fluid dynamics. Numerical approaches discussed include finite difference, finite volume, finite element, and spectral methods on both structured and unstructured grids. Coverage includes asymptotically zero Mach number (incompressible), low-speed compressible, and high-speed compressible flows. Introduction to modeling of multi-phase flows.
title: Simulation and Modeling of Fluid Flows

evals: A good course for the beginner, especially for whom have not yet a clear mind of what statistics concerns about.
Everything is fine.
Good.
I strongly recommend to take this course.
I would recommend this class to all who are interested in statistics and data science.
Learn more after class!
Take this course if you are interested in Statistical Theory, not in applications. It is very hard, but you will learn a lot.

The course is a good intro to mathematical statistical theory. The last quarter of the course (non-parametric regression) is pretty interesting. The first 1/2-3/4 of the course is less interesting, but still good to know to understand the foundations of statistics.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 15%, Problem set(s) - 70%
descrip: A graduate-level introduction to statistical theory and methods and some of the most important and commonly-used principles of statistical inference. Covers the statistical theory and methods for point estimation, confidence intervals (including modern bootstrapping), and hypothesis testing. These topics will be covered in both nonparametric and parametric settings, and from asymptotic and non-asymtoptotic viewpoints. Basic ideas from measure-concentration and notions of capacity of functional classes (e.g. VC, covering and bracketting numbers) will be covered as needed to support the theory.
title: Statistical Theory and Methods

evals: 100% take it!!

If you want a course that helps you improve your Portuguese without grueling amounts of reading, this is a good choice!  There is definitely a stronger focus on music rather than literature, which is fantastic if that matches your interests.
More philosophical than I expected. My language skills were not quite up to the task.

Pedro is incredibly nice, but I did not love this class. Helps with Portuguese, but somewhat unstructured and not as much about Brazilian lit and music as I would've hoped (lots of philosophy and ethnomusicology readings); discussions could be difficult to follow at times.
Pedro's great! If you like Brazilian music and literature, I recommend this course. If music really isn't your thing, you might not find it all that engaging.
otherinfo: This course is co-taught by Professor Pedro Meira Monteiro and graduate student Charlie Hankin through the Collaborative Teaching Initiative. Music by Caetano Veloso, José Miguel Wisnik, Arnaldo Antunes, Os Mutantes, Tom Zé, Anitta, Valesca Popozuda, João Gilberto, Racionais MC's, Seu Jorge, Milton Nascimento, Karina Buhr, Fernanda Abreu, among many others.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Readings will be in Portuguese and English, an average of 100 pages per week. Classes will be taught in Portuguese. According to their interests, students will produce their own sound archives throughout the course, which will be discussed in the classroom, classified and posted to a digital platform for ongoing public consultation. A midterm and a final research paper will be required. Digital archival research will account for 40% of the final grade,
prereqs: POR 208 or POR 207S or instructor's permission..
descrip: What happens when sound and sense meet? Do silent letters provoke sound and movement? Is sound political and does it have a grammar? We will explore how the distinction between music and mere noise informs our understanding of politics and history. In a journey through sound events, composition, performance, fiction, poetry and journalism, with a special focus on Brazil from the birth of the Republic (1889) to the present, this seminar explores the points at which the aural, the corporeal and the linguistic become entangled. Musical genres we will study include funk, tecnobrega, hip hop, samba, club music, bossa nova and more.
title: Topics in Brazilian Cultural and Social History - Sound and Sense

otherinfo: Students pursuing a certificate in Spanish will be required to complete all written work/exams in Spanish.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading: 80-100 pages per week. Writing assignments: a take-home midterm and a take-home final exam.
descrip: Since 1605, Don Quixote has been an icon of idealistic and misguided desire. This course explores quixotic desire and its representation (from the psychoanalytic to the cultural issues it raises) in Cervantes seminal text, Flaubert's daring update, 'Madame Bovary', Mann's 'Death in Venice', Kafka's 'Metamorphosis', Nabokov's 'Lolita', and Kathy Acker's post-feminist post-punk 'Don Quixote'. Films inspired by this topic (by Welles, Visconti, Chabrol and Kubrick) will also be considered.
title: Quixotic Desires

evals: A lot of people are usually on the fence about taking this course. If you have any doubts, you should definitely go for it. The first two weeks will give you a good indication of what the rest of the semester will feel like. If it's not your cup of tea, it's a piece of cake to switch into different courses. My roommate dropped after two weeks and he had no problem transitioning into his new classes. Just don't stay on the fence for too long and start dropping half way into the semester. As for the course itself, there is a real emphasis on developing the intuition and skill to solve problems, rather than just memorizing a set of formulas to apply in different cases. I highly recommend this course if you are up for the challenge.

A most excellent course. If you've ever thought something in physics was fascinating and beautiful, and if you have any interest in more than one field of science, take this class. It is really really hard but I never felt oppressed, because the work is so interesting. It is basically Biophysics: The Course, so if that's what you want to do, then it is especially perfect for you.

ANYONE WITH AN INTEREST IN SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH SHOULD TAKE THIS CLASS.

That being said, this class is very hard. It lives up to its reputation--you probably have never worked as hard at something before. However, if you're willing to put in the work, this class is probably one of the most rewarding things you'll do in your time at college. The strong mathematical basis developed and used throughout the course should be a welcome relief to anyone who's used to high school science classes that focus on qualitative knowledge or the memorization of formulas. The problem solving skills I developed in just the first semester have revolutionized the way I think and approach any problem (not just ones found in science classes). You'll be exposed to fantastic professors and amazing labs that are hard to find in any other intro class--all with a fairly small group of close and dedicated people.

Even if you have fulfilled the requirements that ISC satisfies with AP/IB credits, you should still consider taking this class. It will only build on the standard AP curriculum, while adding things you most likely have not encountered before (statistical mechanics). Furthermore, the integration of computer science into ISC gives you an edge over others by developing computational and analytical skills much earlier than you otherwise would--simply put, this is invaluable in the 21st century.

All of that being said, do not take this simply to fulfill requirements. You must have a real passion for science (or an incredibly strong willpower). If you are looking to fill the 6 requirements ISC gives you, it would most likely be much easier to take them all separately. ISC would kill you without a passion for what you're doing.
Be prepared to work hard, but do take it. The course is really intellectually stimulating in ways normal intro science courses are not.

Do all the problem sets, and try to stay on top of reading the lecture notes before lecture. This course is probably at least 30 hours a week of productive, distraction-free work, but it is completely worth it if you are interested in science. As someone more interested in biology, this course includes more physics and chemistry than I would ideally enjoy, but the applications of physics and chemistry explored are really cool and not topics you would get in regular physics and chemistry classes.
Do it if you think you truly like science.
Familiarize yourself with solving first-order linear differential equations before starting the class.

I highly recommend this course to any students interested in the sciences. Although it is a lot of work, the material is presented in a way that will make you think differently about the problems. It is difficult, but extremely rewarding. The professors are really good, and you will get to work with and likely become friends with a tightly knit group of freshmen that share your academic interests.

I highly recommend this course. It takes a great deal of time, and means sacrificing sleep sometimes, but you learn so much about the different sciences, and about working in labs. Seeing how the sciences share certain mathematical frameworks really broadens one's understanding of each science individually as well, and of  processes which can be used in many different contexts.

I would highly recommend this class to anyone who has a love for biology and physics. Warning though, it is a lot of work. You need to be prepared to devote a large part of your life to it. The community that is built throughout the semester is huge and a large part of how I survived the class. We build our own little ISC family!
If you are curious, take this class. It is intense but incredibly rewarding on a personal level.

It's either totally worth it or not worth it at all, depending on personality and goals; I'd say to try out the class and give it a shot! Oh, and the basketball shouldn't scare you away. Try the class and the basketball! If you're the type who would enjoy it, it will be the most rewarding thing you've ever done.
Only take if you're prepared to suffer through an intense work load, but want to make friends for life who will help you along the way.

READ LECTURE NOTES BEFORE CLASS. This will make understanding class material much better and allow you to ask meaningful questions. START PSETS EARLY. They take a very long time and will ruin your Thursday nights if you don't manage your time well. RE-DO OLD PSETS TO PREPARE FOR EXAMS. I found that this is the best way to study. BE PREPARED TO COMMIT A LOT OF TIME. Work ranges from 10-20 hours per week not including class/lab time.

Take if you like cool ideas and are interested in science esp. from a less conventional perspective.  ISC has great labs and you learn MATLAB. Many of the problems on the pset will make you realise things and be happy. You will probably make a lot of friends in the class. Be prepared for a large workload, periods of confusion, and working things out yourself. However the class misses a lot of concepts covered in traditional routes i.e. intro physics and bio classes - make sure you have seen these somehow if that is your major. (But ISC covers some things you won't see in those classes too). There is very minimal chemistry. Overall the class exposes you to interesting ideas and can be lots of fun.

The class will review some concepts from high school biology/physics courses although it will also assume that you will be able to apply them into problems. The way the material is presented is very interesting.

The course is amazing if you can handle it.  This class will take over your life: long hours working on Psets and with other classmates in Icahn, painfully long lab reports, hours reading lecture notes to understand the material.  But you'll also get professors who really care about teaching the next generation an in-depth, integrated view of science, a unique education into all disciplines in science, and amazing labs in which you'll build a solar cell and experimentally calculate mutation rates and Avogadro's Number.  Take it if you love science and are willing to work hard.

This course is extremely time consuming and challenging, but you gain an incredible group of friends and learn a ton. I would strongly recommend this course to anyone willing to put in the time required to enjoy it.

This course is strongly based on math and physics. If you like interdisciplinary approaches to science and have a strong math background, this is the course for you. Don't take this course just for requirements. To complete the amount of work in the course, you will need dedication.
This course teaches all the sciences through the lens of (and with an emphasis on) mathematics. The problem sets and lab write-ups are challenging but worthwhile.
Very interesting but at times soul-sucking. You can only have two (max) out of ISC, sleep, and extracurriculars. Choose wisely you must, young padawan.
otherreq: Open to Freshmen and Sophomores Only.
otherinfo: Students must enroll in both ISC231 and ISC232, and must sign up for both an experimental lab (231) and a computer lab (232) each week. Students must also sign up for the Wednesday evening problem session (231 Class). Meets with COS126 on T/TH for the first 6 weeks. The full sequence, ISC 231-234, is alternative to the combination of PHY 103/104, CHM 201/202, COS126, and MOL214. For more information, visit http://lsi.princeton.edu/integratedscience/education/curriculum/freshman-year.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Lab Reports - 30%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Reading, problem sets and lab reports totaling 10-15 hours each week will be assigned. Readings for Fall 231 & 232 will be based primarily on lecture notes, which will be available through Blackboard. In addition, students should follow the readings for COS126 in the first half of the semester.
prereqs: Familiarity with the calculus at the level of MAT103/4 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics, chemistry, molecular biology, and computer science. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: C. Callan, J. Shaevitz (PHY); S. Shvartsman (CBE); H. Yang (CHM); P. Andolfatto (EEB); E. Wieschaus (MOL); O. Troyanskaya (COS); J. Gadd, B. Machta, A. Nourmohammad, Q. Wang (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.
title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences I

evals: Answered in 231
Familiarize yourself with solving first-order linear differential equations before starting the class.
If you are curious, take this class. It is intense but incredibly rewarding on a personal level.

Really, I suspect most of the reviews that you should read are over on the ISC 231 side, but still YOU SHOULD TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU HAVE ANY INTEREST IN QUANTITATIVE SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH!

There is no substitute for the quality of this class--you learn so, so much! It does more than just teach you scientific material, it teaches you a way of thinking that is so important. That being said, it is very difficult! Don't let that intimidate you, though. You should still try it--advisers and teachers will work with you if you need to drop it. And don't let anyone tell you that you don't belong in the course--make your own way.
See 231 eval

The course is amazing if you can handle it.  This class will take over your life: long hours working on Psets and with other classmates in Icahn, painfully long lab reports, hours reading lecture notes to understand the material.  But you'll also get professors who really care about teaching the next generation an in-depth, integrated view of science, a unique education into all disciplines in science, and amazing labs in which you'll build a solar cell and experimentally calculate mutation rates and Avogadro's Number.  Take it if you love science and are willing to work hard.
The psets are a good way to understand the material although the workload is a lot to manage with other classes.
otherreq: Open to Freshmen and Sophomores Only.
otherinfo: Students must enroll in both ISC231 and ISC232, and must sign up for both an experimental lab (231) and a computer lab (232) each week. Students must also sign up for the Wednesday evening problem session (231 Class). Meets with COS126 on T/TH for the first 6 weeks. The full sequence, ISC 231-234, is alternative to the combination of PHY 103/104, CHM 201/202, COS126, and MOL214. For more information, visit http://lsi.princeton.edu/integratedscience/education/curriculum/freshman-year.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 20%, Lab Reports - 30%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Reading, problem sets and lab reports totaling 10-15 hours each week will be assigned. Readings for Fall 231 & 232 will be based primarily on lecture notes, which will be available through Blackboard. In addition, students should follow the readings for COS126 in the first half of the semester.
prereqs: Familiarity with the calculus at the level of MAT 103/4 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics, chemistry, molecular biology, and computer science. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: C. Callan, J. Shaevitz (PHY); S. Shvartsman (CBE); H. Yang (CHM); P. Andolfatto (EEB); E. Wieschaus (MOL); O. Troyanskaya (COS); J. Gadd, B. Machta, A. Nourmohammad, Q. Wang (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.
title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences I

evals: A good intro fiction class!
Definitely take this course! Chihaya picks amazing books, and Ian Davis is an awesome preceptor! LOVED the books
Do the readings, engage in lecture, and you will have a great time in the course.
Great books and precepts are awesome.

If you are an ENG major looking for a 200 level course, take this. 
If you are not an ENG major and just looking for an interesting course, take this. 
This class is really well run, taught, and thought out. The book choices are incredibly thoughtful and aim to teach and guide rather than instate. Chihaya is a great lecturer with interesting ideas and makes you want to be a better reader yourself.
If you want to read really cool books and learn how to really read well, this class is wonderful. You get to investigate fiction, and Chihaya is wonderful.
Please take a class with Professor Chihaya. She is wonderful. Keep up with readings! Talk to your preceptor...discussions will be more enjoyable if you participate.
Read the novels! You'll get so much more out of lectures, and they're really good books.
Really great material! Devote a lot of time to the course, but worthwhile if you put in effort
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT! Professor Chihaya is amazing and this is a good opportunity to read and study great books! Try to get into her precept if possible.
Take the course! Chihaya is amazing and the readings are varied and really interesting.
Take this course even if you are not an English major. It's a really fun course. If you don't mind the book-a-week format, then I definitely would recommend. Professor Chihaya is great.

The novels in this course and the ideas we study are truly incredible. This class was SO intellectually stimulating if you do the reading. Don't let the title or the fact that it's a requirement for English majors turn you off. Professor Chihaya is a great lecturer and really wants her students to feel good about the class. Same with Ian the preceptor I had.
You'll be reading one book per week so if you anticipate having a strong workload in other classes, be ready to be behind on readings.
otherinfo: First-Year Students Welcome. This course will have two lectures, and one one-hour precept.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: About 250pp. of reading per week.
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take ENG 200 and one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208, 209..
descrip: The making and interpretation of fictions are among our everyday activities, whether or not we realize it; however, we don't always consider what "fiction" is, or what it means. This course will introduce students to the diverse and specific forms fiction takes in literature, with emphasis on the novel and film. We will interrogate the act of creating fictions, and the impact a fictional world can make on a reader. Along the way, we will continually consider two deceptively simple questions: what does fiction do to us? What can fiction do for us?
title: Reading Literature: Fiction

evals: Definitely take this course if you like to read and are interested in diverse, politically relevant topics. You get to watch lots of awesome plays and meet many of the playwrights.
Great professor. Will do justice in reading plays. Come prepared.
I would just do all the readings.  There are some cool playwright visits and Professor Sandberg is a pretty cool guy.

If you have an interest in plays and drama, take this course (there were a lot of actors in the course). However, be prepared to do the work the professor's way--this means paying attention to terminology (i.e. climax, inciting incident, etc) and using the professor's definitions, and completing assignments that often have very specific requirements.
It was probably my favorite class of the semester, and I'm not an English major. Professor Sandberg is a great professor and can really relate the course material to your life.
Robert Sandberg is a great professor and you should take this class because it opens up a new world in literature.
Take this class! Readings were not too heavy, and Professor Sandberg is great0-- I really enjoyed it.
This course is amazing and the professor is sincerely great and always available to talk outside of class. Take this course!
This course is very interesting and engaging.  It opened my eyes to new plays that I had never heard of before, and Professor Sandberg's knowledge of each play is incredible.
otherinfo: First-Year students welcome. Prospective concentrators should take this course or ENG 205, or ENG 206, 208, 209, and ENG 200. Some theatre going will be required.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Two - three short exercises, two 5-8 page papers. One play per week and some video viewing.
descrip: This course is designed to teach students how to read plays as literature written for performance. Key assumptions are that every act of reading is an act of interpretation, that a good reader of dramatic literature engages in an activity nearly identical to that of a good director or actor or designer, and that a reader might learn from theater practitioners how to make critical choices based on close reading and a knowledge of theatre history.
title: Reading Literature: Drama

evals: A sometimes awkward mix of theory and applications that doesnt seem to reach far enough in either direction. Regardless, a fine way of getting an EM.

A very useful and interesting class for anyone planning on further study in fields relating to politics, philosophy or ethics, but wouldn't necessarily recommend to anyone studying the topic casually--it's up to you to do the readings, of which there are a fair few, but the material is introductory and while not simple, easy to understand after a little consideration.
Be prepared to  pay attention in lecture. Great class. Interesting material-- good way to get rid of EM and Woody Woo's ethics requirement

Beitz is an excellent professor and extremely supportive towards his students; I strongly recommend his preceptor. The readings are difficult as it is political theory, but it's a great foundational class for Woody Woo and POL concentrators.
Definitely take it if you need a decently easy EM or to fill the WWS core req. Beitz is a pretty cool guy and a good lecturer
Do the readings, because you'll be prepared for the problem essays, and because they're fascinating in of themselves.

Global Justice is a truly fantastic course. The course is separated into two sections: justice in war, and justice in peacetime. Both topics were full of thought-provoking questions. Lectures were clear and organized, readings were a very reasonable length and well-chosen, and assignments were useful for grappling with the material. I couldn't recommend this course more highly.
Go to lecture. Always.
Go to lectures and take notes of important concepts. Discuss your essay outlines with preceptors.
Good ethics requirement.
Great class, interesting material
Great course, would highly recommend, the lectures were absolutely amazing, the readings extremely engaging, and the general structure fair and well-organized.
Hard but useful.
I am neutral on this course--take it if you like theory, but otherwise, don't take it.
I would recommend this course for anyone with an interest in the theoretical aspect of international relations.
It was interesting. Do the readings to get the most out of it.
Pretty good class without too, too much work. Prof Beitz is a very good lecturer, and I loved having David as a preceptor!

Someone else called this 'pie in the sky', which is definitely very accurate. Problem essays really are graded harshly, and final exam was a bit harder than I thought it would be. However, you do learn a lot about global justice from a professor who is very well-known in the field.
Start the problem essays earlier rather than later and take full advantage of precept and professor office hours. Go to lecture!

TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Beitz does an amazing job of summarizing material and also making you think for yourself about it. The readings are amazing if you have time to do them, and if you miss a few he does a great job summarizing. Not an insane workload and incredibly interesting. One of my favorite classes here. David is a great preceptor!

Take it you have to. It's a pretty painless way of getting rid of your ethics requirement if you're WWS, and if you have any interest in ethics at all you probably will find it interesting. But maybe don't take it otherwise.
Take it. Beitz is a very traditional lecturer but he is incredibly insightful and so smart and I loved it. Take it.

Take this class!! Beitz is a great lecturer and the material is fascinating - though sometimes it can be dense, the preceptors are always welcome to discuss anything you might be confused about. Highly recommend taking this if you are unsure about your interest in International Relations, or if you are interested in majoring in Politics but aren't sure what the department looks like at its best.
Take this if you're looking for an interesting course in political philosophy!
There is not a great deal of work in this course besides the two short essays and readings. What you learn here is very valuable and you should take it!
There's a lot of reading, so don't take other reading intensive courses unless you know you can handle the quantity.
This course does an excellent job of stimulating critical thinking on difficult issues.  Participating in precept will help you get the most out of the course.

This course is about international political theory. The first half focuses on 'justice in war', the second on 'justice in peace'. If you're interested in the ethics of war, trade, human rights and morality beyond the state I highly recommend this course.

This is a fantastic class. It's intimidating at first if you've never taken any kind of philosophy or political theory, but it definitely becomes easier and more natural as you go along. For anyone interested in international relations, this offers a totally different perspective on familiar issues, and an important perspective--the one of morality and justice.
This is an awesome class! I would definitely recommend taking it.
This is an interesting class that seems to combine philosophy and politics. The lectures were very clear and interesting and the reading was reasonable.

definitely recommend having a good grasp of politics and current events, very helpful in precept discussion. readings are very dense but interesting and class is very productive. if you're interested, definitely take it. professor beitz is a fantastic lecturer - clear and very thought provoking and provides helpful lecture outlines to more easily follow along
have some experience with the material
poses interesting, philosophical questions- take
take it but a lot of work
grading: Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: 100-150 pages per week. Two or three writing assignments totaling about 4,000-5,000 words; possibly short reaction papers in precepts; final exam during exam period; and regular informed participation in precept.
descrip: What, if any, norms of justice apply to the institutions and practice of world politics? Topics may include "political realism" and skepticism about global morality; just wars and justice in warfare; ethics of humanitarian intervention; the nature and basis of human rights; world poverty and global distributive justice; climate change; democracy and accountability in global institutions. Readings chosen from recent works in political philosophy.
title: Global Justice

evals: 100% recommend this class. Ed Wong is really invested in helping students, be it providing feedback or helping with future plans. The work is really rewarding and the reading is excellent. Take it.
Definitely take this course. Professor Wong is great.
Everyone should try to take at least one journalism course here.
Fantastic course. Take the readings seriously and put a lot of effort into all of the writing assignments; you'll get a lot out of this class if you do these things.

If you're at all interested in international affairs, take this class. The readings/films cover a lot of material, and are some of the best pieces of journalism to date. Professor Wong won't be teaching this course again because he is a visiting professor, but the material should be similar.
Manage your time adequately for the readings and written work assignments, but take the course because it is incredibly penetrative.

Professor Wong puts an incredible amount of effort into scheduling guest speakers, assembling a canon of great journalistic works for class readings, and giving personalized feedback and guidance on each assignment. Take this course.

The professor changes every semester, and the focus along with it, but journalism classes at Princeton are amazing, and I can't recommend them enough. You get to hear from such amazing speakers, take a field trip (we went to the New York Times!), and have a lot of flexibility in the writing assignments to focus on what interests you.

This class is interesting only if you have a really strong interest in journalism, Iraq, or Beijing. The readings assigned are superfluous and take way longer than the suggested amount of time posted on the course description. However, Professor Wong is an incredibly knowledgable professor with a wonderful world view, great connections, and has great guest lecturers come in.

This course was incredible -- a ton of work, but super rewarding. It's a shame Professor Wong only taught one semester. Take a journalism course in general -- just not in a semester with too much other work, because you will need to be in contact for interviews and stay on top of your work.
You must take this course!!!
otherinfo: Deborah Amos covers the Middle East for NPR News. Her reports can be heard on NPR's award-winning Morning Edition, All Things Considered, and Weekend Edition. Amos has traveled extensively across the Middle East covering a range of stories, including the Syrian uprising. She now covers the migration crisis with a focus on Syrian refugees in the United States.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of reading, reporting, and writing. Short- to medium-length writing assignments (500 to 1,000 words) due every one to two weeks. Six short multimedia assignments due during semester. One long-form final project due at end of term. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required. Mandatory travel to Canada during fall break (four days, TBD) and to Connecticut in early December (three days, Friday to Sunday), all trip costs covered.
descrip: This seminar will focus on journalism and the global migration crisis, as more than 65 million people are on the move, with forced displacements at a record high. At the same time, refugee resettlement in the United States is contentious. We will examine journalism's approach to the crisis in photos, text, and radio, considering the conflict between national security, international responsibility, and America's historic role in resettlement. Students will visit ethnic and refugee communities, write stories on topics as diverse as social media, education, and entrepreneurship, and produce multimedia assignments and a long-form final project.
title: International News - Migration Reporting

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows. Note: REL 521 (fall) and REL 522 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.
title: Religion and Culture Workshop

evals: I would recommend, but Hindi is hard to learn. Keep that in mind.
If you want to learn a different and really interesting language, take Hindi. Once you understand the script and sounds, it is not very difficult to follow along.

Robert is really chill and makes Hindi fun even if you don't have any real exposure to the language. Learning a new script can be a challenge but you get a lot of practice early on. Overall it's not too hard and I would recommend to anyone who's looking for a unique class to fulfill a language requirement.
Take it. Go out on a limb. It's fun and not too difficult.
Work hard and pay attention!
Yes! It's a really fun, low-key class. Work is pretty minimal and Robert-ji is great!
otherinfo: Grading: 30% Other = 10% homework, 10% skit; 10% class participation. Final project in lieu of final exam.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Grammar and vocabulary drills, writing, reading, listening and speaking assignments.
prereqs: This is the first course in a four-term sequence that fulfills the university language requirement. No credit is given for HIN/URD 101 unless it is followed by HIN/URD 102..
descrip: This introductory proficiency-based course in Hindi and Urdu allows students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Students will learn to communicate in a variety of everyday situations. Hindi and Urdu share a basic grammar and core vocabulary but differ in terms of scripts and some cultural markers. There will be equal emphasis on both scripts and cultures; parallel written materials will be provided in both scripts. Students are expected to develop proficiency in one script of their choice, and are encouraged to learn both. Classes will be interactive.
title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu I

evals: A bit disorganized at times, but definitely very engaging and a great introduction into the wealth of research possibilities in the field of astrobiology. Professor Turner and Professor Chyba's lectures are extraordinary and are not to be missed! Make sure to go to all the lectures because the information is truly fascinating and worth learning.

A somewhat interesting survey of life in the universe that isn't much work at all. However, lectures are not very engaging and the course had some organizational problems this semester. Be prepared to do a modest level of astrophysics work and a bit of statistics.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS
Don't need to buy the textbook. Lecture is interesting but unnecessary.
Go to office hours for the psets! Make sure you're comfortable with your grasp on humanity otherwise you'll have at least six existential crises in class the first few weeks.
Great STN, not too much work, but generally really interesting.
I don't think I would recommend this class unless you are a non science major who needs an STN and are interested in space.
I think it is a great course, especially for people that just want to learn and not do too much work.

If you are very interested in the prospects for life outside of the Earth, then I would recommend this class. I thought that I learned a fair amount, but that the information could have been presented in a better way.
Interesting subject, but the class is extremely unorganized. It would also be helpful to have one or two basic CHM / MOL / GEO / AST courses under your belt, although it's not absolutely essential.
Not that much work, but you probably need a science background if you want an A
Only take if you are extremely interested. Disorganized and poor lecturing.
Take only if you like space/want the certificate. An easy PDF but I can't help but think I'd enjoy other classes more than this.

Take this class! I came into this course with a general interest in astrobiology, but I was blown away by how interconnected all of these fields are in understanding life as we know it. The professors, and especially Professor Onstott, are certainly passionate about what they teach. Even though they're some of the biggest names in their fields, they're always available to answer questions and help further a deeper understanding of the material. I came into the class not really knowing what to expect because I don't have a strong astrology background, but I came out with the desire to pursue the Planets and Life certificate!
Take this course if you'd like an introduction to astrobiology, but understand that it is certainly a broad, high-level introduction.

This class might be really easy for you if you have background in astrophysics, biology, and chemistry.  If not, note that the material is presented quicker than you could ever absorb it because there is so much.  It could become frustratingly difficult.

This course is very interesting and I would highly recommend it however it's not as easy as some people make it sound. A very wide breadth of material is covered in relatively little time, which may seem daunting at first. However, you are not required to understand absolutely everything to the level the professors teach it. Certainly stick with it if you find the first half a bit tough, because I found the second half of the course much more interesting than the first as it deals more with space missions and exploration rather than theory.

This course was organized very poorly. There were so many logistical issues in this course. It was very clear throughout that the instructors did not communicate well with each other. I did not understand how the lectures were meant to build on each other-- it was difficult to understand the connections between each one. Definitely not a course that is friendly for non-science majors.

This is an easy course for science majors. The information from your discipline will be trivial, and the lectures from others either too in-depth for you to understand and care, or a nice overview of another field.
The psets are easy, you don't need to read, and the midterm is open-note. If you want the certificate or an easy (but frustrating) course take this.
It is an interesting concept on a fascinating topic that needs some serious refinement.

While this course is not that difficult, it definitely does require you to put some effort in to be successful on the midterm, term paper, and Mars project. However, the material is interesting and is definitely something that's fun to know about, even if you don't want to get the Planets and Life certificate. Just know that it is a "real" science class and you do need to know a little bit of science (especially chemistry) to really grasp all the lectures.
good
take it if you want

take this course if you are interested in the subject matter.  Lectures are long and could be dull for a non-science person, but for a science person this class is super interesting and I recommend you go to all lectures
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: About 60 pages of reading will be assigned weekly. Four problem sets. Please refer to http://www.blackboard.princeton.edu for additional information.
prereqs: At least one course (but two are recommended) in Astrophysics, Biology, Chemistry, Physics or Geology is required. In the case of freshmen, an advanced placement score of 4 or 5 in Chemistry, Biology or Physics is required..
descrip: This course introduces students to a new field, Astrobiology, where scientists trained in biology, chemistry, astronomy and geology combine their skills to discover life's origins and to seek extraterrestrial life. Topics include: the origin of life on Earth; the prospects of life on Mars, Europa, Enceladus and extra-solar planets. Students will also compete in class to select landing sites and payloads for the next robotic missions to Mars and Europa. 255A is the core course for the Planets and Life certificate.
title: Life in the Universe

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 80 pages per week
prereqs: FRE 207 or Instructor's permission.
descrip: The eighteenth-century, the age of Enlightenment, gave rise to the proliferation of utopian ideas. Philosophes examined the concept of individual liberty while opposing it to moral, religious, and political values, with a specific goal: societal betterment. This course takes a multidisciplinary and comparative approach, drawing various examples from: eighteenth-century arts, architecture, treatises, and novels, in order to call into question the possibility and/or the limits of the creation of a utopian society, through the notion of power, passion and ideology.
title: Power, Passion, and Ideology

evals: An excellent course for people who want to learn to engage with biological literature in a more systematic way. I thought most of the readings were interesting and reasonable in terms of the time required. The assignments were fun, but might have been less so without a quantitative background.
DEFINITELY TAKE IT. Ned is absolutely amazing, and this class will teach you a lot no matter what your background is. Take it as soon as possible, in fact.

Excellent topics/papers course in quantitative biology. A bit of relevant experience in math (probability, diff eqs) and programming (python or MATLAB) is helpful when doing problem sets. You couldn't ask for a better instructor than Ned. He explains concepts clearly, leads engaging discussions, and always looks out for the well-being of his students.

I would definitely recommend taking this course for anyone who is interested in quantitative biology. This course helps develop critical reading skills for scientific writing. Prof. Wingreen is an amazing teacher, definitely take a course with him if you can!

I would highly recommend this course for science students who are looking to learn a lot and willing to invest a moderate amount of effort. The Problem Sets do take some time (especially if you don't know much of the math and need to learn a lot of things on your own). However, the class is extremely rewarding. This is the perhaps the best class I have ever taken at Princeton. 

Most of all, I really appreciate how this course got me much more comfortable dealing with equations and seeing things I used to understand qualitatively, quantitatively. Loved this!
If you haven't taken differential equations (like me), start on the homework early, email the TA for help, or ask some friends.  Don't wait for the TA help session.
Make sure to do the readings and participate in class discussion.
More than strongly recommend.
Read the papers thoroughly, and take time to discuss them with other class members or other people who are knowledgeable in the subject before the in-class discussion.

Sometimes a bit basic to cater to people from all disciplines, but overall of good difficulty.
Very good explanations of experimental/scientific logic by Ned. Students were encouraged to share their ideas in class, and Ned provided good feedback for these ideas.
TAKE THE COURSE. Though if you don't have a computer science background, have some friends who know how to code take the course with you so you can learn from them.

Take this class! Professor Wingreen is great. Make sure you do the readings every week thoroughly. The weekly quiz isn't too bad but still requires you to know what you are talking about in a broad sense.

This class is fantastic. If you have any interest in doing anything quantitative with biology, you must take this class. Professor Wingreen is amazing and charismatic and your classmates will be motivated and knowledgeable. The problem sets are significant time investments, but they are also pretty cool and fun.

This is a fantastic course and Ned is an amazing teacher. I am a PhD student from a background in biology with very little experience in differential equations, so a few of the assignments were very challenging, but I could collaborate with my classmates and from the TA who have different backgrounds to get the help I needed. I highly recommend this course.
otherinfo: This course is intended for graduate students interested in quantitative/computational biology. Undergraduates may enroll only with prior approval from one of the instructors.
grading: Quizzes - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
prereqs: Prior knowledge of calculus (differential equations) and linear algebra..
descrip: Close reading of published papers illustrating the principles, achievements, and difficulties that lie at the interface of theory and experiment in biology. Two important papers, read in advance by all students, will be considered each week; the emphasis will be on discussion with students as opposed to formal lectures. Topics include: cooperativity, robust adaptation, kinetic proofreading, sequence analysis, clustering, phylogenetics, analysis of fluctuations, and maximum likelihood methods. A general tutorial on Matlab and specific tutorials for the four homework assignments will be available.
title: Method and Logic in Quantitative Biology

evals: Ask questions, challenge, debate, engage. Taking a course with Dr. Greenhouse is a true treat, make sure you take advantage of it.
DO THE READINGS
Do as much of the reading as possible and contribute in seminar - and don't hesitate to visit professor Greenhouse with any help understanding the class.

I would definitely recommend this course! I think it is extremely interesting class and gives students a nice sampling of what anthropology has to offer (examples of what ethnographic field work can yield, anthropological theory and "everything" in between!) Do the readings! They are interesting and having done them makes the seminars much more interesting.
I would recommend it for anyone with an interest in anthropology, or someone who is simply trying to get requirements out of the way.
I would say that other students should be prepared for class and actively ask questions while reading and of their classmates' points.
Professor Greenhouse is truly brilliant. Interesting course
Take it; take it; take it. You won't regret. Greenhouse gives a great introduction into Anthropology.
Take this course if you are interested in law and the way in which social forces shape our lives.

This class is good for students familiar in anthropology, and also those who want an exposure to the field. Professor Greenhouse is great - be sure to make use of her office hours and your class experience will be even better!

This course is amazing! Professor Greenhouse speaks poetry, truly cares about the students, and teaches brilliantly. You will think about yourself, society, and things like the interaction between work and family in totally new ways. There's not too much of a workload, and the readings are really interesting.
definitely take a course with professor Greenhouse if you get the opportunity!
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Reading: 50-100 pages per week. The seminar's workshop format emphasizes experimentation with interpretive possibilities through active discussion. Oral presentations give everyone the opportunity to lead the discussion from the standpoint of their own interests and critical engagements with key sources. Short papers are designed to highlight comparative issues. The final exam covers the course as a whole as applied to independent reading.
descrip: This seminar takes up the connection between authority and obligation as a cultural question. We draw on diverse sources (anthropology, case studies, social theory, literature, public documents, art, etc.) to probe conceptual and real-life gray zones between individual and community, liberty and constraint, state and private sector. We consider formal and informal institutions (e.g., courts, legislatures, police, workplaces, families) and a range of formal and informal norms (from court rulings to common sense). Authority and obligation emerge as complex social relations that shape and are shaped within and across cultural contexts.
title: Social Lives, Social Forces

evals: A very well-organized, well-structured, and interesting class. Take if interested in the interaction of politics and economics. A solid politics elective or economics cognate.
Definitively take the course. Thomas Romer is an amazing lecturer. You will have to go to the lectures. Do problem sets on your own and you will do very good in the class.
Difficult but good course.
Difficult course. Take for certificate/departmental but avoid otherwise.
Mathematical study of politics. Fair and useful for independent work. Recommended for those who struggle with studying politics in the abstract and like math.

Really great course! This course will be a great introduction to formal modelling in the the social sciences. Good treatment of game theory as well. 
Manageable work load. Korhan is a great preceptor too. 

Grading is weirdly harsh sometimes ...

Romer is a great professor, but I do not think you should be taking this as an elective. Most of the students were pursuing certificates in the Political Economy program. If you are a politics major, you may have to do more work than econ majors to understand the math. parts.

TAKE THIS COURSE. My favorite class for my major so far. If you think you like economics applied in policy, this class is for you. Fairly simple math for a economics major applied to interesting topics.

This class is incredibly technical and proof-based, more in line with ORFE classes than Econ/Politics. Lectures are quite dry, and more focused on theory than a practical understanding of political economy. Do not take unless you have to for certificate.

a good foundational class if you're interested in political economy as an underclassman and would definitely recommend. as an upperclassmen in the department, you've probably learned most of the stuff already so it can be a bit boring
otherinfo: Course recommended for those in the Political Economy program.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Approximately 75-100 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101, MAT 103.
descrip: Examines the role of political institutions in facilitating or hindering economic prosperity. We start with the basic tools of political economy - collective action, elections, and delegation. These tools are then applied to the problems of controlling rulers, and the persistence of inefficiency.
title: Political Economy

evals: A very interesting survey of contemporary Cuban literary and visual culture. Collect your thoughts before you speak, but also don't be afraid to speak up -- everyone has their own language barriers.
Definitely take this class. Professor Price is very understanding and the material is fascinating if you have any interest at all in Cuba.
Do at least half of the readings every week, so that you can contribute in class.
Great course, interesting material. Great professor. Be prepared for the 3 hour time block. Otherwise, take this course.
It gives you a much greater understanding of the complexities of Cuba
Need to find a way to engage
Take the class if you are interested in learning about Cuban society through the lens of art via multiple mediums.
This is a really interesting class and Professor Price is great! Take if you want to learn more about Cuba.

This is a solid class with an interesting subject matter. My Spanish isn't amazing, and I'm not sure if I would recommend this class if yours isn't. That being said, if your language skills are very strong, this is a good class- the films are interesting, and Cuba is an interesting country to study. You may also benefit from doing some background research into Cuba and its history since 1959 if you want to take this course- just knowing the basic history is okay, but if you don't know that, you may want to change that before/while you take this course, since it will help you to get context for the literature and films.
Very interesting course

You have to put in considerable effort and speak up in class to get much out of this course. A lot of reading. I don't think my Spanish improved much, but we discussed some interesting themes and a few of the readings/movies were fascinating. Not the best class I've taken but Prof. Price is nice and I definitely learned more about contemporary Cuba.
otherinfo: Course will be taught in Spanish.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately100 pages per week. One oral presentation, two 4-5 page papers in Spanish, one midterm take home written exercise in English; 10-page final paper in Spanish.
prereqs: One or more 200 level SPA courses above 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: What is nature? How is it perceived, modified, destroyed, and represented in history and culture? This course explores these questions in relation to the location of Latin American nature in modernity, through travelogues, literature, photography, and film. Focusing on legendary Patagonia and the Tropics, we'll examine the interplay between the two opposite images that have dominated modern perceptions of 'extreme' nature (and the peoples associated with it): the idea of nature as a monstrous being that has to be tamed for the sake of progress, and the idea of nature as the lost object of modern nostalgia and environmental ethos.
title: Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies - Spectacles of Nature: Patagonia and the Tropics

evals: A newly restructured course that is an interesting and thorough qualitative introduction to solid earth sciences. While I think that it could benefit from having more stringent math and physics prerequisites so that we could cover more material, I think that if the department wants to be more inclusive for freshmen and non-STEM majors, that is fine too. Professor Irving is very fair and engaging. The field trip, though time-consuming, is enjoyable. I would definitely recommend this course for any potential geosciences major. It really transforms your understanding of the Earth.

Definitely a great way to get a really solid foundation in your understanding of the earth. If you are remotely interested take it. Problem sets make you think, the lectures are well done, and it may change your perspective of the planet.
Don't struggle through problem sets; instead, try to get help and actually understand them, as some of the most valuable lessons from the course lie within.
Don't take this course unless you are required to. The geoscience department has courses that are a lot more engaging than this one.

I would recommend this class to anyone who is trying to complete a STL requirement or a geosciences nature. It includes a fun field trip to the Appalachian Mountains that shows how this science is applied to the "real world."

If you're CEE and taking it for the bio requirement it's definitely the best option to fulfill that but be warned that you are not going to be interested at all in the material. Also be wary of annoying field trips that will colonize your weekends. Look forward to pretty decent naps during lecture.

If you're a freshman, maybe wait to take this class. Everyone else will have more experience in science, math, and doing psets. Wait til your soph or junior yr maybe. If you're GEO, I think it's better to take 203 and go through some busy work and hard long psets but still have a life than to take 201 and not have a life. [If you're not GEO, take the course if you like rocks I guess? lol.] The people in the course are great, as you'll discover on the field trips. The field trips, in-class/precept activities, and the last ~3 wks of class were the highlights of this course for me. Psets-sometimes too long and have some busy work, but graded nicely and have lots of interesting questions. (Alternatively, you could let yourself not care too much.) Exams-you'll have to memorize some equations; also, every single lecture activity, including one that some people spent ~10 minutes on while you were getting a snack, can be on the exam (darn meteorites! lol). However. The final went much better (and was much fairer, imo) than the midterm, so I'm thinking you guys will have better luck on the midterm next year. Make study groups to work on psets/for exams and don't panic! Finally, it's really cool to see how far you've come from the beginning of the semester at the end. Enjoy the class!
Knowledge of basic calculus and Matlab is required. Otherwise, a great intro class for anyone interested in geo - and the field trips are excellent.
Professor Irving is great! A good grasp of calculus and prior knowledge of MatLab would be helpful.
Take it to gauge your general interest for GEO.
Take it! Great course to learn foundation of many areas in geoscience, astro, etc. Jessica is enthusiastic and thorough. Field trips are fun.
The field trip is fun if you like camping and generally being outdoors, takes up a weekend, but it's worth it! Pay attention in lectures, esp. to the class activities
The field trips are cool, the lectures are solid (good snacks), but the problem sets can sometimes be weirdly challenging. Probably a fun PDF, or not too bad of a regular DR.
This class is really hard. Expect to spend a lot of time on the problem sets. It's an intro class, but it is not for beginners at all.
otherinfo: The course has 2 required field trips: one overnight trip near the beginning of term and one day trip to the Museum of Natural History in New York.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and a related precept.
prereqs: Single variable calculus is a prerequisite, and the course also introduces basic multivariate calculus, simple matrix algebra, and elementary tensor calculus. The course serves as a prerequisite for several upper-level GEO and CEE courses..
descrip: A quantitative introduction to Solid Earth system science, focusing on the underlying physical and chemical processes and their geological and geophysical expression. Through the course we investigate the Earth starting from its basic constituents and continue though its accretion, differentiation and evolution and discuss how these processes create and sustain habitable conditions on Earth's surface. Topics include nucleosynthesis, planetary thermodynamics, plate tectonics, seismology, geomagnetism, petrology, sedimentology and the global carbon cycle. Two field trips included.
title: Fundamentals of Solid Earth Science

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 100%
assgts: Readings in current scholarship as dictated by student interest.
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with the opportunity to talk to an editor from a university press). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.
title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar

otherinfo: For PACM Certificate students, the course can provide a vehicle to launch independent work.
grading: Other Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 60%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: There will be approximately six take-home problem assignments, a substantial final paper on an independent project, and class participation.
prereqs: Multivariable Calculus and linear algebra at the level of MAT201-202 or similar, plus some knowledge of ordinary differential equations (MAT350/APC350 or MOL410), or permission of instructor. Some programming experience is helpful but not required..
descrip: This course will introduce some key mathematical tools used in modeling and analyzing problems and data in neuroscience. It will also provide sufficient background in neuroscience that those with little knowledge in the are can appreciate how mathematical models are constructed. The course combines modeling techniques with mathematical methods, including differential equations and elementary stochastic dynamical systems. The course will also include topics such as Hopfield-Grossberg type neural nets, leaky accumulator and drift-diffusion models of human decision making, and probabilistic approaches to the analysis of neural spike trains.
title: Topics in Mathematical Modeling - Mathematical Neuroscience

evals: Commit to a certain amount of time every day to do Hindi. Use that time to do homework, but if there is no homework or you finish early, take the initiative to do your own practice or reading in Hindi to fill that time.
Great course! I'd suggest you stay on top of all the assignments and readings during the course of the semester though. It's tempting to fall behind, but you'll learn a lot more if you keep up.

Robert-ji is very supportive and passionate about Hindi, and is willing to help students of all levels. Hindi is also a relatively simple language to pick up - I took 105 without 101/102 (having some spoken Hindi background) and was able to survive. Only take if you have the time to commit an hour a day to studying - if you cannot, you will not get that much out of this class or any other language class.
Robertji is a great Hindi professor! He is always very helpful and kind; go to him with any help you need!
Robertji is great. Take the course!
otherinfo: Grading: Other = 20% Homework
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 15%, Quizzes - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading assignments will consist of fiction and non-fiction materials from a wide range of genres and topics. Writing assignments will focus on comprehension, exposition, narration, and description.
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 and 102 (Elementary Hindi-Urdu I and II) or the instructor's permission..
descrip: This course continues training in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Students will learn to read and understand texts in Hindi on familiar topics, to speak confidently and effectively in a wide range of common situations, to write concise texts expressing their thoughts and views, and to acquire general familiarity with the cultural context in which Hindi is used. Students will engage in interactive and collaborative task-based activities in the classroom.
title: Intermediate Hindi I

evals: Do the readings, and don't be intimidated by the philosophy.
Don't take it unless you want a crash course in white feminism and a tired, inept engagement with Beauvoir.
I would absolutely recommend this course or any course with Professor Salamon. I think it worked very well as a small seminar, particularly because students came prepared and willing to contribute.
Loved this course, loved The Second Sex, learned so much.
Take it - Salamon is *brilliant*, the conversations titillating.

This was the best seminar experience I've had at Princeton! Take this course if you're interested in the origins of contemporary feminism and willing to grapple with some difficult philosophical concepts.
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Response papers, 2 pages, due intermittently. Midterm essay, 5-7 pages, due week six. Final essay, 10-12 pages, due on Dean's Date
prereqs: GSS 201 or equivalent..
descrip: One is not born, but becomes, woman. So writes Simone deBeauvoir in her landmark work of feminism, The Second Sex. But how do we become women, anyway? In this course we will read The Second Sex in its entirety, exploring Beauvoir's ideas, along with our current ones, about childhood, coming of age, the family, sexuality, relationships, work, the social order, and the philosophical imaginary. We will read Beauvoir alongside the work of her primary interlocutors as well as contemporary theory, memoir, and fiction considering the question of what it means to become a woman--or not--in contemporary culture.
title: Contemporary Theories of Gender and Sexuality

evals: Annie has a great energy and is an amazing studio professor. Our project was engaging and I thoroughly enjoyed my studio with her this past semester.
Best luck!
grading: Design Project - 85%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Readings will be tailored each year to the specific topic of the design studio.
descrip: The Advanced Design Studio examines architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. A specific problem or topic area will be set by each studio critic, and may include a broad range of building types, urban districts or regional landscapes, questions of sustainability, building materials or building performance. Studio work will include research and data gathering, analysis and program definition. Students are expected to master a full range of design media, including drawing, model-making and computer-aided design.
title: Advanced Design Studio

evals: Definitely take this course if you are interested in physics.  Top to bottom great professors and TAs
Fine to satisfy STL requirement. Don't expect it too be an excellent experience though.
Good STL if you're looking for one. Not too challenging.

I would highly recommend taking this class if you have even the slightest interest in physics. However, be aware that you'll be doing a good amount of work. The class is not very difficult but it definitely isn't easy; be prepared to work for a good grade.
Take this class if you have an interest in physics.
The course material and work were easily manageable.
otherinfo: PHY 115B is designed for those who want an introduction to the basic concepts combined with a laboratory that further explores the ideas. For those who want an introduction to the basic concepts combined with experience in quantitative reasoning, please see 115A. Reading: Text available on-line.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Lab Reports - 20%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: The weekly assignments are: reading (1-2 hours); homework (1-2 hours) and labs including writeups (3 hours).
prereqs: Math skills at the level of high school algebra are assumed. No prior classes in physics or astronomy are necessary..
descrip: What do future leaders of our society need to know about physics and technology? The course is designed for non-scientists who will someday become our influential citizens and decision-makers. Whatever the field of endeavor, they will be faced with important decisions in which physics and technology play an important role. The purpose of this course is to present the key principles and the basic physical reasoning needed to interpret scientific and technical information and to make the best decisions. Topics include energy and power, atomic and subatomic matter, wave-like phenomena and light, and Einstein's theory of relativity.
title: Physics for Future Leaders

evals: A good course to take for non science majors.
Attend every lecture, as they are helpful, necessary, and very interesting. Rare is the course that makes students feel like they have actually missed out on something when they do not attend.
Make sure you keep up with the homework.
Must take if you are trying to fulfill STN/STL.
Study a lot for the midterm and final. Very good course if you want to learn about quantum physics and stuff.

This class is not an easy STN. It is difficult to understand the material presented at such a basic level and you rely on the internet and google for answering all problem set questions which can be tedious.

This class started off slow and I felt I was doing just fine. Then the lectures made a huge jump from calculating heat energy (plugging numbers into an equation) to special relativity and quantum mechanics which is just a little more difficult to wrap my head around. The professor and TAs are helpful in their review sessions but its not just an easy way to get a science requirement out of the way. The lectures and demonstrations are interesting though sometimes I didn't completely understand the scientific principles behind them. Take notes on all the demonstrations.
take it, easy class and you get a prereq out of the way.
take this for a STN
otherinfo: PHY 115A is designed for those who want an introduction to the basic concepts combined with experience in quantitative reasoning. This version of 115 has no laboratory. For those who want an introduction to the basic concepts combined with a laboratory that further explores the ideas, please see PHY 115B. Reading: Text available on-line.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: The weekly assignments are: reading (1-2 hours) and homework (2-4 hours).
prereqs: Math skills at the level of high school algebra are assumed. No prior classes in physics or astronomy are necessary..
descrip: What do future leaders of our society need to know about physics and technology? The course is designed for non-scientists who will someday become our influential citizens and decision-makers. Whatever the field of endeavor, they will be faced with important decisions in which physics and technology play an important role. The purpose of this course is to present the key principles and the basic physical reasoning needed to interpret scientific and technical information and to make the best decisions. Topics include energy and power, atomic and subatomic matter, wave-like phenomena and light, and Einstein's theory of relativity.
title: Physics for Future Leaders

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: For more information on WWS Graduate Course, please see our WWS website: http://wws.princeton.edu/grad/course_offerings/
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.
title: Program and Policy Evaluation

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Nature of Landscape, The

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Global City, The

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Global City, The

evals: A good alternative to PHY 103 :)
A great course to take if you are interested in the engineering field! The rocket lab is a lot of fun!
A rewarding course, and much better than taking MAT 201 and PHY 103 separately. You get to know classmates better and also the lab is fun.
Definitely consider taking this course in junction with math 192 as a freshman because it allows you to meet other freshman also interested in engineering.
Do all the work assigned and collaborate with people.
Do not take this course
Do not take this course just for the "Rocket Lab". Only take if you are an aspiring engineer who wants a challenge.
Do the readings and do your problem sets at least a day in advanced so that you understand the content rather then just trying to get it done. I know its cliche but just do it.
Do the work. Stay in school

Do you want to do a fun lab about rockets while satisfying your kinematic physics requirement? Take this course: nothing in it is tangibly much harder than PHY 103, and you will probably appreciate the smaller class sizes and different lab.

EMP is definitely a good class and I'd recommend that you take it.  You grow really close with the other students which is nice and it's not too hard of a workload.  Just have a realistic expectation for the lab.
Go to class and read the book beforehand. You'll get a lot more out of it.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS CLASS.  Be prepared to put in the work though, or you won't benefit much from it.  Dr. Olsen is an AMAZING professor and you'll learn a LOT from him (ask him about his research!).  The labs are quite interesting. Dr. Olsen's demonstrations during lecture are really cool.  I came into the class as an engineering concentrator and left a physics major.  That's a testament to the greatness of this class.

I can't speak to what PHY103 was like but I heard the labs were time intensive and boring; the rocket lab was neither.  Also Professor Olsen was a great lecturer/preceptor and I heard that Bakr was very good as a preceptor as well.
