If you can take this course I would-- homework is very manageable, quizzes are straightforward, and it's as interesting as an intro mechanics class can get.
I liked the course but the math part was too difficult
I would highly recommend this class.  The lab is fun and it's nice to have a slightly smaller class.

If anything, take this course over PHY 103 just for the labs. In lab, you learn to use MatLab, which will be helpful in future courses, and you get to build accelerometers and other cool stuff. Lab work is challenging and very time-consuming, but also very rewarding. For the course itself, even if they don't require the supplementary Tipler readings and problems, use them if you have the time. The regular homework for this course (the Learning Guides) are very unhelpful, and don't really help you learn how to solve challenging problems.

If you are BSE and need to take physics and math, EMP is a great course. Since everyone in your class is also in the same math class, it's very easy to form study groups and crank out p-sets. The rocket lab can be a bit slow at times, but its definitely rewarding, and from what I hear far superior to other physics labs. It was challenging, but definitely doable, even for a person with a terrible physics background (like me).
If you are going to take this course, be prepared to commit yourself to reading the textbook. The class can be confusing in terms of logistics, so be prepared for that.
If you are trying to decide whether to do EMP, I think EMP physics is about the same as PHY103, but the rocket lab makes EMP worth it.

If you enjoyed your AP Physics and Calculus classes in High School and feel like you can move at an accelerated pace during first semester of freshman year, definitely take EMP.  The professors are great and the students you meet are very driven and easy to work with (which will help with problem sets throughout the year).
If you take this class, go to office hours as much as possible, do the readings, and do your best to start your homework early.
If you want to learn anything about physics, do not take this course (if Professor Olsen is teaching). You will get nothing out of it unless you teach yourself.
If you're taking this you're probably taking it because you have to. Don't worry though, it's a pretty nice class. Just make sure to stay on top of things and to ask for help if you get stuck!

It's a lot of work, but you'll gain a better understanding of physics because you read about it, are taught it, and have to apply it so it really gets ingrained in your mind. Combined with the math, you will never not understand a topic because you don't know the math. Be ready to do the work that's assigned and you'll be ok.
Lab is interesting

Lectures have interesting demonstrations, and precepts are very useful for learning how to do problems that will be on the homework.  There is little structure for lab, but the rocket lab is enjoyable (though writing the report is very tedious).
Make sure to thoroughly do the problem sets. The lab and lectures are interesting.
Make sure you know how to code in Matlab or the lab will stress you out.
Not the most exciting course but it is introductory physics. You will learn the material but the rocket lab is much more fun than the other physics labs.
Not too much harder than PHY 103, interesting lab too.

Poorly taught by Olsen, but the lab almost makes up for it. The lab was very enjoyable, though occasionally a serious time commitment (and consequent learning experience). In general the small community of students adds a lot to the class. Take this course if you're at all interested, especially because the lab is so cool, but don't be in Olsen's precept.

Take this course. It is better than PHY103. Go to every lecture, each is truly special. Go to  every precept, this will help you know how to do problems. Work on the lab with classmates. Do the learning guides by challenging yourself first, then look at helping questions and answers.
The only reason to take this class rather than 103 is if you're interested in interacting with other engineering students, making circuit boards, and launching bottle rockets.

The precepts and lectures have great demonstrations, the problem sets are understandable and you can check your answers which really helps. The rocket lab is cool--but the MATLABs can be tricky and difficult. There is little instruction with the MATLAB (coding) so working with classmates is the best bet. I would choose EMP if you are ready for something more rigorous, but more rewarding!

This class is very similar to PHY103, but the lab sets it apart. The lab is interesting and fun, but can be very difficult. The weekly quizzes on the material are generally homework problems from that week. If you have taken AP Physics (even without calculus) the class should be very manageable and not that much work.
This course is a good course, just be sure to study and work early on the labs! Do the readings and the problem sets and you should be alright. Labs are way cooler than in normal physics!

This course is definitely easier if you have taken physics before. If you are unlucky like me and physics doesn't just click for you, you will definitely have to seek extra help, and even that might be unsatisfactory sometimes. That being said, others in the class seemed to understand the material better, so I may just be an outlier.
This course is great if you enjoy having a group of 60 other people with whom to collaborate and commiserate.

This course, as well as EGR192, will teach you more and to a deeper level than MAT201 and PHY103 but prepare to strap in and accept the consequences of your decisions. The little extra you get requires a 10-fold increase in workload.

This is a fantastic alternative to the regular PHY103 physics. The instructors are very good. Although the readings can be confusing, the lectures and precepts definitely help clarify concepts so I would highly recommend attending as consistently as you can.
This is a great class. The smaller class size is definitely a plus. The lab is fun, but at times complicated and confusing. Still, you build a great sense of community.

While the rocket lab was an enticing feature of this class, in my personal opinion, it wasn't worth it. It was a lot of extra work, which involved coding (via MATLAB) and physical construction. If you have experience with code or building small projects this may be the class for you, but if you're looking for a straight physics class for requirement, you may be better with basic 103.
take advantage of office hours, enjoy the lab
otherinfo: Students enroll in both EGR/MAT/PHY 191 and 192 concurrently in the fall semester. Term project will account for 10% of the final grade.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 15%, Lab Reports - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Reading 20 pages from the textbooks listed.
prereqs: All first-year engineering students who have placement into multivariable calculus on the basis of a score of 5 on the BC calculus exam (or equivalent) are eligible to enroll..
descrip: Taken concurrently with EGR/MAT/PHY 192, this course offers an integrated presentation of the material from PHY 103 (General Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics) and MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) with an emphasis on applications to engineering. Physics topics include: mechanics with applications to fluid mechanics; wave phenomena; and thermodynamics.
title: An Integrated Introduction to Engineering, Mathematics, Physics

evals: Although it is advertised to be so, this class does not take an "integrated approach" to math and physics. This course is basically MAT 201 with longer problem sets and a harsher curve. I am glad I took the course, simply because of how unnecessarily demanding it was. I feel it prepared me well for future math courses at Princeton, which can all be very difficult.

Be prepared to work and bond over some very confusing Pset problems. You need to go to problem sessions and office hours. On the plus side, Dr. Taylor (if she's still teaching it) is very knowledgable and will happily explain things quite clearly if you ask during lecture/office hours. If you're BSE and want to do something in between the difficulty levels of 201 and 203, this is your class.

Definitely take this course. It can be quite challenging, but is definitely worth it, especially as an alternative to MAT201 for engineering students. My best advice is to go to office hours and problem sessions - although it sounds cliche, office hours are so so so helpful, and working in groups to bounce ideas is way more efficient and more fun than working alone.
Definitely would recommend as a good alternative to 201, but keep up on lecture notes and book reading.

Depending on the professor, this can be a very difficult course (especially if you have no background in multi, as a large number of the students in this course, excluding me, came in having already taken multi). The math is definitely closer to 203 than 201, but it's gonna suck any way you take it, so you might as well take this just for the easy physics lab.

Do more textbook problems than the ones assigned, for practice. It's nice having a smaller class, compared to MAT201. Professor Taylor makes class interesting and is very good at answering questions. Go to all the problem sessions and occasionally office hours if possible.
Don't be alarmed at the pace initially; it is incredibly fast, but 1) you get used to it and 2) Professor Taylor is more than willing to slow down and answer your questions if you have them

EMP math is definitely a struggle, but Professor Taylor is very dedicated and helpful during office hours.  I found this course to be significantly harder than Math 201, but there are plenty of resources (i.e. problem sessions and office hours) which make it doable.  Also it's really easy to make friends in EMP because it's really hard and since the class is so small, everyone wants to work together to figure out what is going on.
Excellent enough
Fast-paced course where collaboration is needed. Don't be afraid to struggle, you won't be the only one. Absolutely attend all classes and problem sessions.

Form a study group with which to work on problem sets. Study well-ahead of time for assessments. Attend office hours to cover any holes in understanding. Also be ready to have a very fast-paced lecture.
Go to office hours and use the textbook to fully understand course material. Try hard to understand underlying concepts not just formulas.
Good class, well-taught and pretty low workload. Doesn't go too in depth however, so don't expect to master multivar after only this course.

Great way to meet fellow engineers as a freshman but just aheads up math at Princeton is very challenging and this class is no different. Also I would highly encourage you to take multivariable before this class - I wish someone had told me this.
Harder than 201, definitely doable though, with problem sessions and office hours.
I would only take this course if you are already very good at math and want a challenge.

I would strongly recommend this if you have already taken multi but do not want to start off in a higher level course; There is new material (diffeq) and it moves at a pretty quick pace so one is never bored from repetition.  On the other hand I could see this being very fast paced to someone coming from BC calc.  However there are really great problem sessions held regularly and as long as you have a pretty good work ethic I'm sure it will turn out fine.  Not an easy course, but I don't think multi ever would be.  If anything take this for the physics course.  EGR192>PHY103 (or so I've heard).

If you are trying to decide whether to take EMP, EMP math is harder than MAT201 and the problem sets have more challenging problems, but I think the rocket lab made EMP worth it and sometimes EMP is taught better than larger lecture courses.
If you struggle, reach out to Professor Taylor, she is more than happy to help if you ask. It is very hard but a good introduction to Princeton math.
If you take this course, make sure you go to office hours as much as you can, and you use help sessions to their greatest potential.

One of my favorite classes; Professor Taylor is extremely intelligent and does a great job of thoroughly explaining the material (although it can be fast sometimes).  Recommend for anybody looking to study engineering or math.
Prof. Taylor is super kind and helpful but the class and the material is very very tough. Requires a lot of time and effort.
Start on problem sets early!
Take MAT 201
Take this class. It is very challenging but you will learn a ton and make some very good friends.
Take this course!! I think it's really similar to MAT 201 but with smaller classes and precept taught by the professor, so you just get a lot of attention and help.  Would highly recommend.
Taylor is an extremely effective professor and would reccomend taking this class if you have a strong mathematical background.

The Psets are very hard, but in conjunction with the rigor of physics its not as bad a balance as it may seem. They want you to read the textbook beforehand, which timewise is not feasible, but before doing the problems from that part of the chapter, the examples can be very very helpful for the book problems. The quizzes and exams are very hard, but don't worry because the majority of the class will not do well on them. If you are considering EMP vs regular, the EMP math is hard, with manageable EMP physics and the regular math is manageable with regular physics being hard. So take your pick!
The course is very challenging, but also rewarding.  Problem sessions were essential and really the only way to complete problem sets, but you get very close with the people you collaborate with.

The course is very fast-paced, so be prepared. Definitely read the book, attend class and office hours (or make an appointment if you can't attend), and go to the problem sessions. Overall the professor is great and willing to help you!

The material isn't too bad but to succeed on exams, you'll need to know the small intricacies of the concepts which is hard to achieve because the homework does not prepare you very well. Make use of offered problem sessions and read definitions for the theorems taught. Having a study group with friends also helps.

This class is definitely challenging, especially the problem sets. However, partly because of the weekly problem sessions where students from the class work on the psets together, there was definitely a sense of comradery within the class, which made taking a harder class worth it for me.

This course is great if you enjoy having a group of 60 other people with whom to collaborate and commiserate.

Don't be discouraged by the reputation of Princeton math classes as difficult and demoralizing.

This course is not easy, but it is very doable. GO TO THE PROBLEM SESSIONS, but make sure you have done what you can on your own. They will save you a ton of time and really help you understand the concepts. The first quiz will likely go pretty badly, but it gets significantly better once you get the hang of things.

This course is taught in a different order than most multivariable calculus classes, but that didn't seem to make it any harder. It has one more chapter than MAT201. It is taught very well, and the homework and exams are difficult, but fair once the curves are in place.

This course will certainly give you a deeper learning experience than MAT201. However, for that bit extra you are getting, your workload will increase drastically. 

For example, the homework consist of approx. 40 questions from the textbook and 2-4 harder questions added in by the professor. The textbook questions are the hardest questions there but can be completed simply by reading the chapter. The 2-4 other questions however is what sets this course apart. They are much more complicated and often take at least double the time the 40 textbook questions take. They require you to build upon the basics you learn in the textbook and create methods of solving the problems yourself. This stimulates a student to understand the material to a much more fundamental level and will make them truly problem-solve, rather than just applying what they read in the textbook. They will however take many hours and often make you want to rip out your hair and cry out in frustration.

In short, this course will give you more than MAT201 and will push you to your limits but will also take a huge chunk of your time. I guess it depends on what you're looking for.
This is a great class, but in order to survive you must be on your game. There are tons of resources available, so it is up to the student to take advantage of them in order to succeed.

This is a very good course, and I would recommend it were it not paired with the awful physics course. Professor Taylor is an extremely good teacher. Do not try to take notes in her lectures/precepts--her notes will be posted online, and if you do try to take notes you will not be able to keep up with the pace at which she goes and therefore will be frantically copying without gaining any understanding.

Very difficult, but very well organized. Professor Taylor gives you all the tools you need to succeed: relevant and challenging problem sets, relatively detailed lecture notes, practice exams etc. I would only ask that lectures and precepts move more slowly. If you do this course half-heartedly, and are not a math genius, it will be very difficult to do well. Also, the course is not really structurally integrated with physics or engineering.

You need to go to office hours. Christine is amazing in office hours and will clarify everything. Even if you're so lost that you don't know what questions you need to ask -- just go and listen to other peoples questions or ask her to explain concepts again.

start putting in 100% effort from the first week on; if you don't fundamentally understand the first few concepts and units the remainder of the course will be very challenging because you will struggle to understand it conceptually
take advantage of office hours and problem sessions
otherinfo: Students enroll in both EGR/MAT/PHY 191 and 192 concurrently in the fall semester.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 20%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Reading 20 pages from Thomas' Calculus.
prereqs: All first-year engineering students who have placement into multivariable calculus on the basis of a score of 5 on the BC calculus exam (or equivalent) are eligible to enroll..
descrip: Taken concurrently with EGR/MAT/PHY 191, this course offers an integrated presentation of the material from PHY 103 (General Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics) and MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) with an emphasis on applications to engineering. Math topics include: vector calculus; partial derivatives and matrices; line integrals; simple differential equations; surface and volume integrals; and Green's, Stokes', and divergence theorems.
title: An Integrated Introduction to Engineering, Mathematics, Physics

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Madness and Culture

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Madness and Culture

grading: Papers - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 50%
descrip: The course concerns Japan studies in the context of theories of capitalism, personhood, democracy, gender, and modernity. We discuss issues of fieldwork as method and "area" as a unit of analysis. We also consider the pace of Japan in American social thought. One thematic focus is on medicine and biotechnology and their engagement with social and historical processes.
title: Japan Anthropology in Historical Perspective

evals: Don't try to read an entire dissertation in one day.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Prerequisites: POP 501 and POP 502, or instructor's permission.
descrip: Course is designed for doctoral students in their third year of a specialization in demography. One objective of the course is to examine critically how researchers tackle demographic research questions. A second related goal is to explore the construction of a dissertation and a research paper.
title: Evaluation of Demographic Research

otherinfo: In addition to lectures and precepts, there will be film screenings (mostly projected DVD or VHS). Some of the films we will study are: Almodóvar, "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown"; Bizet/von Karajan, "Carmen"; Dreyer, "The Passion of Joan of Arc"; Gibson, "The Passion of the Christ"; Kushner/Nichols, "Angels in America"; Shinoda, "Double Suicide"; Zhang, "Ju Dou".
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: The primary focus of the course will be the films chosen for viewing. In addition, there will be approximately 100 pages of reading per week. Students will complete 4 short papers.
descrip: Passion is a common word with a long, complicated history; the diverse meanings we associate with it engage our experience on the most ethereal and abstract as well as the most visceral and profane levels. In this course we will study a range of films from the past eight decades with the aim of understanding how the films situate their subjects, how they narrate and illustrate passion, and how they engage personal, social, and political issues in particular aesthetic contexts.
title: Passion

evals: Absolutely take this course! Professor Zeitlin is a fantastic professor and the material is all extremely intellectually stimulating and engaging!
Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading and watching films, but it's worth it. Do the work and worry less about the grades (they're not too hard)--focus more on the content and meaning.
Emotionally rigorous, but highly recommend if you have any interest in the subject matter. Professor Zeitlin is sweet and HILARIOUS.
I think that it is a good course to take. Professor Zeitlin is no longer teaching (or that is my understanding) so I cannot recommend based on the teaching! The subject is fascinating though.

I would definitely recommend this course. Professor Zeitlin is a gem and really fun to take a class with. The class is interesting and the topic is important. Readings and films are for the most part pretty engaging. Admittedly there is quite a lot of weekly reading, but you don't necessarily need to do it all thoroughly.
If you don't take this class, you will be missing out on an essential part of the Princeton experience as well as cheating yourself out of being a compassionate human being.

Professor Zeitlin and her course are two gems on Princeton's campus. If you have the opportunity to enroll in her class, take it! Be warned: the workload is VERY heavy, but every reading is well curated and demonstrates thought and care on the instructor's part. No prior experience with Comp-Lit necessary. Froma makes everything really accessible and the course is more like a hybrid of comp-lit, history and sociology. She goes out of her way to help students and always provides ample guidance and feedback, if you ask.
TAKE IT EVEN IF YOU'RE JUST REMOTELY CONSIDERING IT
Take it if you are willing to learn about really emotional stuff, and willing to challenge yourself to write about it.
Take this class but be prepared to do a lot of reading
Take this course if you really enjoy the subject. Not a class to take for the sake of taking, you should be engaged with it.

This class was really fascinating. A new perspective that I had never used before to approach the Holocuast - the perspective of children. But, just need to keep in mind that it's a ton of hours per week (reading a novel or memoir and watching a movie).
This course is incredibly enriching and the content is captivating. You won't be able to stop thinking about it.
You need to take this class!
otherinfo: Anne Frank (Dutch) and Elie Wiesel (Hungarian), two 16-year olds in 1944, are probably the best-known adolescents of this time. But our reading introduces a host of other remarkable voices that attest to the creative power of the word to grapple with the extraordinary and often unspeakable. Films have their own role to play and include contributions from Japan, Russia, Poland, Hungary, France, Germany, Czechoslovakia, China, Israel and Italy.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: Reading averages 200-250 pages per week (occasionally more or less). Attendance at weekly evening films. Brief written weekly responses for discussion (15%). Short midterm essay, film journal (35%), and final paper. Open choice of essay topics, in accordance with students' individual interests.
prereqs: Attendance at seminars and films..
descrip: COM 362 examines the gendered experiences of childhood and adolescence under the Nazis in World War II as witnessed, remembered, and represented in texts and images through a variety of genres and different nationalities. We include historical studies, diaries, testimonies, memoirs, fiction (semi-autobiographical or otherwise), photos, and film (documentary and feature) of 1st and 2nd generations. While we focus on struggles for survival and their traumatic aftereffects among Jewish youth, who were specific targets of genocidal policy, not just unintended victims, we will also attend to the experiences of others in the occupied countries.
title: Stolen Years: Youth under the Nazis in World War II

evals: Great intro to a complex and often confusing language. You won't be able to read the Bible after one semester, but it'll set up the groundwork you need to do so. Not too much work and quite enjoyable overall.
I had no Hebrew experience before this class. It is definitely an accessible intro to Biblical Hebrew.

I loved this class! It is a very small class, so each students receives a lot of individual instruction and attention. The professor is very patient and helpful, and he truly cares for his students. The workload is very light, but the course demands a lot of memorization. However, you will learn a lot!

I really enjoyed this class! Though this semester focuses very heavily on grammar/verb conjugations, you leave with the ability to translate/read simple passages of the Bible in Hebrew.  The required workload is quite light compared to most Princeton classes, but you get out what you put into it. Also, Yehuda really cares about his students and tries his best to help you learn. Overall, I would highly recommend!
Take it with Kraut, he's the man. It's well-taught, interesting, and graded leniently. 10/10 would recommend.

This course gives you the grammatical groundwork (i.e. parsing verbs and sentence structures) to read the biblical text. However, with the first semester you will still need an English translation alongside to understand the text, as there is not much emphasis on vocabulary.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%
assgts: Approximately two chapters of textbook reading and various exercises per week, regular in-class quizzing on vocabulary and verbal forms, and preparation for in-class reading of Biblical text.
prereqs: Class meets two times per week..
descrip: Students will achieve a basic ability to read the Hebrew Bible in the original language. During the semester, students will learn the script and the grammar, develop a working vocabulary, and read a selection of Biblical passages. The course is designed for beginners with little or no previous knowledge of the language. Students with extensive experience in the language should contact the instructor about course alternatives.
title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew I

evals: Algebra is a fascinating subject. It's very different from the other branches of mathematics, and even from linear algebra. I say take this course, take it even if you're not a math major, take it because you want to learn about group theory and think in groups and group structures, take it because math in general excites you, take it for character-building, whatever. Jerry's class is probably easier than previous years, but the material is still just as interesting, and it is incredibly useful to have taken this class (or taking it concurrently) if you are also taking topology (you will need algebra for algebraic topology in the second half!). Love group theory, breathe in isomorphisms, see the symmetric groups when you close your eyes, I promise it'll be worth it. Also, if this gives you any incentive, Jerry did say that there is probably an injection from the students of our class into the set {A, B, C, D, F} where the set represents our grades, and the image of the function is {A}.
Although I probably did quite poorly on problem sets and exams relative to other students, I learned a lot.
Assumes at least basic knowledge of linear algebra, so make sure you have that before you take the course.

Definitely take it if Jerry Wang is teaching it. We had 4 assignments the whole semester, and although the first and last one were very long, the class wasn't very stressful. As with any other math class here, working with a group really helps. The midterm was a take-home, but the final is going to be in class. Jerry initially was planning on having us give presentations instead of a final, but the class was too big to do that.
Do take! It's a beautiful topic and Professor Wang has some really nice course notes.
Don't think the class is too difficult for non-math majors - the class doesn't move very fast and doesn't require a lot of background.
Hard and very fast-paced but enjoyable and a fun professor. Took it to see if I might wanna be a math major and decided nah..
If you are a math major, take it.
It's a required course.
Jerry is a great instructor - take it with him if possible! The subject itself is not too hard, though does ramp up near the end.
Make sure you have enough time for this class. Just like every other math class, this class is very time-consuming.

Not well, many people failed the uncurved final examination, even though most went into the final with an A.  The instructor was misleading, and could insult students if they did not quite understand. Only take it if required.

Obviously algebra is required for math majors, and the style of course completely depends on the teacher. This may be the minority opinion, but I did not enjoy taking the class with Jerry that much. His psets were very bashy, and I found the lectures kind of dry. He was very reasonable and clear, though. Take if you're a math major. There are more interesting math courses if you're not a math major.
Take it because you can. It's great to have the abstract background even as a COS major.
Take it with Jerry. He is great.
Take it with Xiao Heng.
Take this class if you think you are prepared for difficult algebra
The year I took this course it was fantastic!! But that was largely a function of Jerry Wang, the professor who was teaching it. Since he's leaving, not sure how it will be in the future.
This class moved pretty slowly and the lectures were boring. If it's taught by Jerry again, you won't learn much.
This course was well-taught, but I found it difficult to be excited by the lectures or the material.

This is a fun course. The proofs are cute. However, you can probably skip it if you know some of the very basic material and you're willing to spend a week reading through, and doing problems from, the Artin textbook.

You learn a lot of material in just this one course--it's definitely a good, in-depth introduction to group theory, and will give you a good idea of whether you lean more towards algebra or analysis. As with any math class, keep up with the material, and if you do not understand something, ask, because it is probably important.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly readings and problem sets to be determined by instructor.
descrip: This course will be devoted to Galois theory, developing the necessary group theory, including the Sylow theorems, and algebra from scratch.
title: Algebra I

evals: Take this class. The content is very practical and the trading simulations are really engaging.
The external reading materials can be very helpful supplements. The most important part is to understand the intuition behind all the models.
otherinfo: 30% of grading will be based on problem sets and trading simulations.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: The course involves trading simulations that are based on recently developed trading software, and approximately 50 pages of reading per week. There is no comprehensive book for the course. Reading material will be provided via blackboard.
prereqs: Introductory Asset Pricing Class (ECO 363/FIN 501) or Derivatives Pricing Class (ECO 465/ FIN 522)..
descrip: This course covers important theoretical concepts and recent developments in asset pricing under asymmetric information, financial intermediation, behavioral finance and market microstructure. Topics include market efficiency, liquidity crises, asset price bubbles, herding, risk management, market design and financial regulation. The course examines these concepts theoretically as well as via a simulation software, whereby classic decision-making settings are realistically revisited in a competitive classroom environment.
title: Institutional Finance, Trading, and Markets

evals:
An excellent class overall. Prof. Houck is an amazing lecturer. The lectures are laid back, and you can ask any questions, and he will always try to explain even the most unintuitive or difficult aspects.
The assignments are always instructive, and help to understand the material, and are never tedious. .

Definitely take this class if you are interested in quantum computing! Some background in quantum mechanics would be helpful, but not absolutely necessary. Go to the weekly problem sessions to talk to the TAs even if you think you understand the material- it's still good to take advantage of them as a resource to address any questions or confusions you might have from lectures.

If you are: a physicist looking for a fun way to make QM relevant and clear; a mathematician looking for a fun way to apply algebraic techniques; or an engineer looking for a glimpse into the weird quantum world, take this class! Not a huge time commitment, and a really high payoff.

If you're interested in quantum computers, you should definitely consider this course! If you've taken PHY 208 and/or PHY 305, the first third or so will be very straightforward (and it will help later as well).
If you're interested, take it. The problem sets are challenging, but the material is really cool and Houck is awesome.
It is a hard course, you need to put a lot of work in it, only take it when you want to do something with quantum computing
It isn't a huge amount of work and Professor Houck is awesome.

Prof Houck is a leader in the field. He goes very fast in lecture. Psets aren't long at all but really test your understanding. Would recommend taking some quantum beforehand, but it's not really required.

Professor Houck is amazing, and quantum computing is super interesting. This is a great look at the field, though it is a reasonable (though not too bad) amount of work.

(I'm a COS engineer senior)
Take it! Prof. Houck is an excellent lecturer and very helpful in explaining concepts. The class, while unintuitive at times, isn't exceptionally hard either.
Take it, it is interesting and it does not require too much background in either quantum physics or math.
Take this class! You will learn a lot and the material is interesting.
Take this course if Prof. Houck is teaching it. Quantum computing is a fascinating subject, and it's hard not to become excited by it in this class.
Take this course if it's with Houck. He is an amazing lecturer, has great notes. It might be my favorite class so far at princeton.

Take this course if you already know some quantum mechanics and want to learn a huge amount about the field of quantum computing. If you don't know any quantum mechanics, this course is significantly more challenging.
Take this course! It's a lot of fun.
Would recommend to any math, physics, CS, or ELE major.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly problem sets
prereqs: A previous quantum mechanics course will not be required. Requires sophomore linear algebra at the level of MAT 202, 204, 217 or the equivalent..
descrip: This course will introduce the matrix form of quantum mechanics and discuss the concepts underlying the theory of quantum information. Some of the important algorithms will be discussed, as well as physical systems which have been suggested for quantum computing.
title: Introduction to Quantum Computing

evals: Great introductory course in trading and understanding market making
Interesting class. Not very useful for banking in real life but nice topics and trading simulation are cool.
Intuitive models for thinking about banking and trading behaviour. Medium workload.

Professor Stephen has done an awesome job in introducing the materials. For anyone interested in taking this course I would suggest going over the materials briefly and determine if you actually need to learn these-course may be too theoretical and tends to focus too much on the models.
Recommended.

This class is pretty theoretical. The models are pretty abstract. Sometimes I feel it's more about mathematical manipulations and creations rather than real world understanding. But as a theoretical class, it's pretty good. If you are a MFin interested in quantitative finance, I recommend you not to take this course.

Very important and interesting material for understanding markets, but pitched a bit low for graduate level students and lectures could be delivered more engagingly - lack of relation to real world scenarios.
While the course is not pitched as a technical course, it is fairly math-heavy.
it is very helpful for interviews in trading.
otherinfo: This course involves student presentations and most likely trading simulations that are based on recently developed trading software.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: The course involves trading simulations that are based on recently developed trading software, and approximately 50 pages of reading per week. There is no comprehensive book for the course. Reading material will be provided via blackboard.
prereqs: introductory asset pricing class (ECO 363/FIN 501) or derivatives pricing class (ECO 465 / FIN 522).
descrip: This course covers important theoretical concepts and recent developments in asset pricing under asymmetric information, financial intermediation, behavioral finance and market microstructure. Topics include market efficiency, liquidity crises, asset price bubbles, herding, risk management, market design and financial regulation. The course examines these concepts theoretically as well as via a simulation software, whereby classic decision-making settings are realistically revisited in a competitive classroom environment.
title: Institutional Finance,Trading and Markets

evals: If you're at all interested in war (regardless of an interest in the Middle East) I would 100% recommend taking this course. This was hands down the BEST seminar I've taken at Princeton. Reynolds definitely challenges you in a way that most professors don't, but you end up with such a solid understanding of Clausewitz, Creveld, and several wars. The seminar discussions are pretty dynamic and the readings are great, albeit the papers are tough. Take it, you won't regret it.
Take it, do the reading.

Take it. Professor Reynolds is a superb professor. His tangents were entertaining and fun to hear about. The readings are interesting if you are interested in warfare, strategic thought, and the Middle East.
Take this course if you're interested in wars in the Middle East.
You should definitely consider taking this course. It discusses many important conflicts within the Near East while also raising important questions about warfare in general.
take it!
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Students will write two 5 page papers during the semester and a 10-15 page final paper. The course is reading intensive (approximately 300 pp/week) and students will be expected to demonstrate command of the reading material in weekly meetings.
prereqs: Although exposure to strategic thought and/or Middle Eastern history may be useful, there are no prerequisites..
descrip: Drawing on case studies of Middle Eastern wars, this course examines the changing nature of warfare from the second half of the twentieth century through the present day. The course begins with Clausewitz's theory of war and examples of conventional state warfare in the Middle East. It then moves on to cases of insurgency and so called fourth generation warfare and uses them to test Clausewitz's ideas and less state-centric alternatives. The goal of the course is to compel students to think seriously and critically about war and the ways in which it is and is not changing in the twenty-first century.
title: War and Politics in the Modern Middle East

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A practical course intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets every week for 2 hours, or less often depending on the need and pace of the participants. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.
title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Reading Minds

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Reading Minds

otherinfo: Additional departmental required
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Reports due dean's dates and end of term
descrip: Students conduct a one-semester project. Topics chosen by students with approval of the faculty. A written report is required at the end of the term.
title: Senior Project

evals: A great survey class - interesting lectures and light workload.
Attend lectures and engage in precept, it will make everything much easier for you in the long run.
Be prepared to memorize.
Be sure to do the readings and study for the exams.
Definitely go to precept, some of the exam materials involve objects from the PUAM. This is just a good course to take if you want to be a generally cultured person.
Definitely take the course! Great LA without a lot of work. Lectures were very interesting and stimulating, and I really enjoyed precept in the art museum.
Definitely take this class
Definitely take this!
Don't take it. Lecture is horrifically boring and a waste of time.
Go to lecture. Be proactive on the papers.

Good LA distribution requirement. The lectures can sometimes be boring but the precepts are cool because you get to be in the museum. Definitely go to class because there is a different lecturer/topic each day so if you miss something it is hard to make it up. Seems like a lot of reading but it's not necessary. 2 five page papers. Final and midterm are all memorization.
Good course to take if you have a genuine interest in art.
Great course. Not much work except for having to memorize a lot of art for midterms and final. Precepts are great and the papers are easy.

I thought this course was amazing and a great first introduction to Art History here at Princeton. I thoroughly enjoyed the lectures--they were engaging and a nice way to start my morning. Each one was taught by a different Professor/Lecturer in the department whose expertise is on that period/type of art. They were very knowledgable and their PowerPoints were very good. I also liked how the PP were later posted on BB, which was helpful when studying for exams.The two writing assignments weren't that difficult and helped hone important skills in visual analysis that were necessary for precept discussion and the exams. I also really liked how precept was held in the PUAM since we were able to actually observe and learn from actual works of art. I also thought the exams were easy as long as you can memorize facts well, which isn't difficult. The only negative I have to say is that the reading are a bit unnecessary and purely supplemental--totally do not need to do them to get an A in the class. Overall, great course!
I would only recommend this course to those who have to take it.

I would recommend any student to take the course. In addition, I would advise that the student attend every lecture possible (something required in the syllabus) and that they take profuse notes to ensure the most effective study conditions for exams.
I would take it as a low stress pdf.
I would take this course if you are interested in ART.

If you are interested in learning about art history, take it! Precepts take place in the art museum, and you walk around the museum, talking about pieces that are examples of that week's lectures. The workload isn't bad: two papers per semester, and two exams.
If you do the readings and go to the class you will do well.

If you have any interest in art or history take this course. You get a world history course from the perspective of an artist, a refreshing perspective instead of historians/politicians. Exam is easy without much work. Papers are all about observation of detail, nothing tricky about them. A really easy class.
Interesting and fun - not too hard.
Interesting course, light workload, readings not necessary!!
It is an okay class. If you want a basic understanding of art, take it.
Lectures can get dry when the speaker is not engaged with the audience. Overall, an interesting class if you commit yourself to it.
Make sure to keep up with all the readings, and definitely reach out to the instructors when you need help.
Not a tough class, good PDF option.
Not too much work and pretty interesting

Perhaps take this if looking for a 4th class and willing to consistently go to lecture. You should have a genuine interest in art and understand that not all the lectures will be good. I don't think this is a good PDF because you have to memorize a huge object list for an exam regardless

Some lectures will be great, and others will go right over your head. It's awesome to have so many different professors in the department give a lecture, but it is thus difficult to string together a coherent narrative. An easy class to PDF. Memorizing is annoying as ever, but having precepts in the museum was cool because now I can say something intelligent about at least one thing in every room. A good course for general education.

TAKE IT!!! This is a great class to take! I would highly recommend as a fun class, whether you have taken art history or not! Papers are really fun to write and the precepts in the museum are the best! Good for all students of all disciplines!
Take it if you want a survey of art history. It gives a nice overview of art, to the point where you feel like you could hold a conversation about it.
Take it! I like the 2nd half much better than the first one.

Take it! It's a very easy PDF course if you need the LA requirement and you can also learn a lot while having fun. All of the precepts are held in the art museum and you learn about many works in there. If you are PDFing the course it's not necessary to do the readings. Just take good notes in lecture and precept and you will be prepared for the big, general ideas which are tested on the exam. The essays are also very short (3-5 pages). If you are even remotely interested in art history, take this course! I'm glad I did! And you can tour your friends or your date around the art museum afterwards ;)
Take it; it's a good overview of art history. And make sure to take good notes in lecture.
Take this class!

Take this class!! There's always a waiting list because its easy and actually enjoyable (and everybody should know something about art history). Lectures are interesting; you just get to sit back and have pretty pieces of art described to you. And precept each week is like a guided tour of the art museum. Everyone would love this course.
Take this class, great PDF class and v interesting.
Take this course!

The class covers a broad range of topics and art genres, which is a good intro class for art history. As someone who has never learned art history before, this class was pretty useful and informative. However, since there was a different lecturer each time, sometimes it could get super boring. Moreover, there wasn't a good place to look over the stuff we covered in lecture, because there was a different lecturer each time and they all have their own slides and some just never put up their slides on Blackboard.

There are lots of readings, but they don't come up on the tests which rely mainly on memorization of several pieces of art (50 for the midterm). Two short papers were no problem. Lecture quality varies--some of them were incomprehensible. Precepts are held in the Art Museum and are great. Take for a workable LA.
This is easy, interesting, and extremely worthwhile if you're thinking about majoring or pursuing a certificate in A&A. Precepts in the art museum and lectures with the whole department are cool too.
While reading the out of class readings may help, they aren't essential for the class.

You should definitely take this course if you are interested in Art History. The workload is manageable and the precepts are interesting since you walk around the art museum. The only times this class can get overwhelming are the couple of days before midterms.
easy. readings arent necessary.
otherinfo: Most precepts take place in the Princeton University Art Museum.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Weekly readings in the textbook will be supplemented by short precept readings. A selection of digital study images will be made available for review of lecture material. Two short papers plus midterm and final exams.
descrip: Introduction to the history of art and to the discipline of art history. Not a comprehensive survey but a sampling of arts -- painting, sculpture, architecture, photography and prints -- and artistic practices from diverse historical periods, regions, and cultures. The course balances consideration of historical developments with attention to individual works of art. Faculty members of the Department of Art and Archaeology lecture in their fields of expertise; all precepts are held in the Princeton University Art Museum to facilitate direct engagement with works of art.
title: An Introduction to the History of Art: Meanings in the Visual Arts

evals: 10/10 take this course!!!!!!!! The teachers (Gong, Huang, Xie) are rock stars, so good at what they do and really fun and engaging. I started at CHI 105, and I've found 303 to have the most interesting and thought-provoking material yet. LOVE THIS COURSE <3
8  hour commitment outside of class weekly.
A lot more challenging than 2nd year. You know what to expect by now and how to do well in the class.
As it is for the other Chinese classes, the workload is tough, but it is great that you can actually feel that your level of conversation is constantly improving.
If you are a BSE/ QR heavy major, and taking chinese as general interest... it's less interesting than 101 102 107 108
If you're this far in Chinese, you know what to expect with level of difficulty. It's an amazing class that you should absolutely take.
It's a big time commitment, but your Chinese will definitely improve.
Take it, as long as you don't have 5  other classes.
Take the course!

Take this class if you are interested in improving your Chinese to talk more specifically about social, economic, and political issues. The teachers are amazing, but you also have to dedicate a certain amount of time every week to study and learn vocabulary, so be prepared for that.
The Chinese department is as strong as ever. In this course, be prepared to start using more formal written Chinese. The emphasis is on being able to discuss and write about social issues.

The course is work heavy. There is not necessarily one point where the work load spikes, but it is a constant deluge of vocab and grammar. It gets tiring, and if you've taken first and second year chinese, becomes monotonous. Nevertheless, absolutely take if you want to maintain a degree of chinese proficiency.
chinese is really intense, only take this class if you're serious about the language.
make flashcards and review the study guides.
grading: Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: One to two lessons will be covered each week. Students will listen to audio tapes, and prepare for class discussion about the topics raised in the text. There will be weekly written assignment, weekly quiz and oral exercises. Classroom activities focus on speaking. The student is expected to read four pages per week.
prereqs: CHI 107 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Designed to further develop the student's overall language skills through reading and discussion of contemporary affairs published in Chinese newspapers.
title: Third-Year Modern Chinese I

evals: I will totally recommend this course.  It is rigorous, but your Chinese will improve a great deal.  The professors are super helpful in the feedback they give and are very encouraging.

It is definitely a lot of work - expect to dedicate around an hour or two to Chinese every day, but in the end it is so absolutely fruitful. The bonds you make with other students and the teachers is just indescribable - and your Mandarin speaking/writing/reading skills will improve immensely.
Take it!
Take this if you're interested in continuing Chinese, but be aware that the lessons are much more dense (vocab and grammar structures).
The grading is harsh, but the class is extremely well-taught and very well-prepared. Extremely helpful for learning Chinese, especially higher-level topics.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 35%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: Preparation for class meetings, weekly quizzes, written exercises, and some oral exercises. Students are expected to read 4 page per week.
prereqs: CHI 103, 108, or instructors' permission..
descrip: Designed to further develop student's overall language skills through readings and discussion of contemporary affairs published in Chinese newspapers.
title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese I

evals: Be prepared to talk about the same topics as 2nd and 3rd year, but with higher vocabulary.
Good class. Lower time commitment than earlier chinese classes but also harder units

I would definitely recommend this course, even for people who are not doing it for their major or a certificate. Do not be afraid that it is one of the most rigorous languages (or courses in general), because it is 100% worth it. It is taught extremely well and if you keep up with the daily work is not overwhelming in the slightest.
It takes a lot of every day work. If you want to keep learning Chinese, continue, but it can be tedious at times.
It's definitely a step up for third year. Just stay on top of your work.

Like all the other Chinese classes, it's a lot of work and the tests every Friday can be annoying.  But also like every other level, it's extremely well-organized and well-taught.  And the teachers are great.
Memorize vocab and grammar before lecture to promote participation and help solidify your knowledge.
Readings were dated, but instruction was overall pretty good. Not a super heavy workload, but grading is always on the harder side for Chinese
Standard four year Chinese course. It's exactly what you would expect.
Take it. The Chinese department is one of the best language departments at Princeton. You're language really improves over the years.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 15%, Quizzes - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: One to two lessons will be covered each week. Students need to prepare for the lessons, listen to audio tapes, and prepare for class discussion about the topics raised in the text. There will be weekly written assignment, weekly quiz, and oral exercises. Classroom activities focus on speaking. The student is expected to read 4-5 pages per week.
prereqs: CHI 303-304 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion of selections from Chinese and newspapers on contemporary Chinese political, economic, and social issues.
title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I

evals: Definitely memorize your scene early on. Overall, it's a fun course to take.

Florent is really a theater person, a diva if you will. If you don't mind that he is a bit disorganized when it comes to posting readings and assignments in a timely manner and seems to plan his classes on the spot, it's fine. He really cares about theater and improving your acting and diction skills, he just isn't your typical uptight and organized Princeton professor. If you're like me, you might find that acting really isn't your thing, but this class has a lot of potential to be fun either way.
Go to class and read the plays and pay attention because Prof. Masse does tend to randomly call on people sometimes.
I would take the course if you are interested in acting and have a conversational level of French.

In general courses tend to be somewhere along the fun-informative scale. This class however manages to be at both ends. Although enjoyable at all times, you will learn and gain a huge amount from it. It has drastically improved all aspects of my french, my acting and my confidence both on stage and speaking off-stage.

Take it, it's fun - but recognize that it's a MUCH bigger time commitment than you might think it is. 4hrs of class a week, plus extra things you have to go to often (e.g. 3hr plays etc) and ~2 pgs of short responses per week
This is a fun class to take, especially if you want to avoid dealing with a grammar heavy course. You will have to deal with homework being posted right before it's due, but overall would recommend.

This is a good class to take if you're looking to improve your French speaking skills.  This is not just a breezy class though and you will have to do a decent amount of work, not over the top but it's also not just a easy class to take.  However it is fun and engaging and is a nice break from the format of other courses.
otherinfo: Two class sessions supplemented by one weekly one-hour private rehearsal and supervised attendance of theater plays and events. Film screenings of French plays and documentaries on French theater will be scheduled and weekly readings in the course packet will focus on overviews of French theater.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Graded assignments will include the two page critical reviews of plays, performance work, as well as a 3-4 page paper on the works and playwrights explored by students.
prereqs: FRE 108, or equivalent. FRE 207 recommended as a co-requisite. Course is conducted entirely in French. Interested students must contact the instructor: fmasse@Princeton.EDU to apply and schedule an interview. Course is open to Freshmen..
descrip: L'Avant-Scène will offer students the opportunity to put their language skills in motion by discovering French theater in general and by acting in French, in particular. The course will introduce students to acting techniques while allowing them to discover the richness of the French dramatic canon. Particular emphasis will be placed on improving students' oral skills through pronunciation and diction exercises. At the end of the semester, the course will culminate in the performance of the students' work.
title: French Theater Workshop

otherinfo: This class will meet from 11/7/2017 to 12/12/2017 during the second half of the fall semester.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Examination of issues in the responsible conduct of scientific research, including the definition of scientific misconduct, mentoring, authorship, peer review, grant practices, use of humans and of animals as subjects, ownership of data, and conflict of interest. Class will consist primarily of the discussion of cases. Required of all first year graduate students in the Department of Psychology. Open to other graduate students.
title: Responsible Conduct of Research (Half-Term)

evals: ART400 is a great experience and department students who are able to take it are certainly lucky! Professor Alsdorf was a fantastic instructor and gave great feedback on written assignments, while also being a reasonable grader and understanding students' perspectives on the course material.
Engaging, great introduction to art historical methodologies.
I felt that the course was very well-managed and informative, and genuinely enjoyable despite being a requirement.
Very writing intensive but very rewarding. Alsdorf really makes this class bearable and fun. a heads up that there isn't a ton of help with the fall JP in this class.
work hard!
otherinfo: Open to junior majors in the Department of Art and Archaeology and to senior majors who were unable to complete the course during the junior year. For Program 1 and 3 majors, satisfies the junior seminar requirement.
grading: Papers - 75%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Student is expected to read 150-200 pages per week. There will be several short papers.
descrip: An introduction to a range of art-historical approaches and to the writings of key figures in the history of the discipline. Attention is also given to research and writing skills specific to the history of art.
title: Junior Seminar

evals: Chinese 405 is beyond the distribution requirements, so please take this course only if you are really interested in Chinese and are willing to put in the work, or else you will struggle in this class.

Ding Laoshi and Dong Laoshi are excellent teachers. The class can be a fair deal of work, but they are really committed to helping you succeed. If you're serious about improving your Chinese, you should definitely take it.

I would advise other students to spend a lot of time at the beginning of the course figuring out the best way to study--I struggled because I wasn't clear on the structure of the class at first. If you are looking for high-level Chinese with a lot of discussions about literature and current issues in China.

TAKE IT! This course is a lot of work, but your Chinese will improve so much. One word of caution - I didn't have the option of taking it earlier because I started studying Chinese at Princeton from 101, but the workload is intense. If you have a choice, take it as a freshman or sophomore, before you have JP/thesis to deal with.
They would need to work hard and put in a lot of hours.

This class is intensive, but it will help you improve your Chinese skills. The topics discussed are often controversial. Be aware that this course is team-taught: even when teaching the same course, different instructors sometimes have different expectations. The head instructors change every year.

Towards the end of the semester the course speeds up a lot more; be prepared for this.

In addition, the course is graded on a curve so be wary.
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Two lessons will be covered each week. Students are expected to read 6 pages per week. There will be weekly written assignments, weekly quiz, and oral exercises. Classroom activities focus on speaking.
prereqs: CHI 305, CHI 306 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion based on Chinese scholarly journals, popular essays, and newspaper articles. Students are exposed to a variety of modern Chinese literary genres, as well as some of the major substantive issues that modern Chinese intellectuals have faced.
title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I

evals: Easy course if you don't mind visual arts (sitting and drawing for extensive periods of time trying to get something to look perfect)
Great class especially if you're interested in figures. Kurt is an amazing professor

If you're interested in drawing, have some experience AND you can do so for at least 4 hours in one chunk per week, then I'd highly recommend this class. Live models are great and you get to experiment with a variety of materials.
this is a great course, and I definitely imporved technically as an artist
otherinfo: GRADING: Homework - 10%.
grading: Other Exam - 20%, Design Project - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Studio work in class, plus readings. Occasional visits to museums and galleries in New York. This is a studio course requiring a final presentation and appraisal of work.
prereqs: Introductory Drawing, or Introductory Painting, or Introductory Sculpture, or Introductory Photo, or Introductory Video..
descrip: This course is designed to teach students the skills necessary for drawing human figures as volumetric structures in clearly defined, illusionistic space. Exercises will investigate the dynamics of human bodies, light and shadow, tonal drawing, and hatchure. While our focus will be on depicting human figures, our approach will also help students gain mastery of a wide range of pictorial ideas - illusionistic form, space, flatness, opacity, transparency - that lead conceptual clarity and material complexity to all art. Students will also be encouraged to develop ideas and techniques that derive form personal experience and cultural affinities.
title: Advanced Drawing: The Figure

evals: A great class to take, especially if Professor Rexford is teaching.

Definitely take it to gain experience working on a moderately sized systems project wherein you'll get to create an actual thing at the end of the semester, regardless of your background or your interest area. I found that although I had a background in both networks specifically and systems in general, and despite the fact the I wasn't interested in either for the future, that I did learn a few tangible tools, and the final project definitely was useful in creating something that although wasn't the most difficult, still was important in being able to have the feeling of "building something from the ground up".
Great course to take if you like networks. Course particularly focuses on backbone protocols (BGP) as opposed to intra-domain protocols like OSPF and SNMP.

Great course. I had taken networking classes before as an undergrad and came to this class to learn more recent and advanced concepts and got exactly what I wanted. I learned a lot from presentations and all the discussions in the class. Also, Jen is a great instructor, she is very passionate, knowledgeable and respectful. 
I strongly recommend this course

Great for people with or without a background in networks. Lectures are easy to follow but still make you think. Workload is on the lighter side, which is great. I haven't received my grade yet but I think this class is more lenient than many others.
I would highly recommend this course. Don't need to have taken an undergrad level networks class. The lectures are heavily discussion based. Workload is fair.
If you are a CS PhD student and want to fulfill the Systems Breadth Requirement, this is an excellent choice! The course is very interesting and has a research bent.

If you have even a general interest in networking, I would take it. I am an undergraduate taking it and found it no more challenging than other CS classes at Princeton, though I did take 461 before this.
If you want to learn about networking without working yourself to death, take this one.

If you want to learn more about networking, this is the class to take. You will cover important papers that marked some of the foundations of networking, as well as discover brand new technologies and ideas that are appearing within the world of networking.
It is better to attend with background like 461.
Jen is an excellent instructor and the course is incredibly accessible even to those without a networks background. I would highly recommend taking this course
Prof. Rexford is excellent, and if you liked what you saw in COS461 and want a less intensive but more in-depth version, take this class!
Read all the papers and participate in discussions.
Should have some background in network
Straight forward seminar course. Take if you've never taken a networks course before, there's more content in 461.
Strongly recommend this course, also tell them try to learn some basics before class.

This is a great class, but what you get out of it is what you put in. Most of the learning is from reading papers and engaging in discussion, which isn't proportional to the grading. So make sure to read the papers, always, even though it's easy to slip.
This is an awesome class, I think anyone interested in network should take it.
This was one of the best courses I've taken in the department.  The professor makes everything approachable, and you read a lot of interesting papers.
Very good for a "systems requirement". Not much work.
You will learn more if you spend more time in reading the papers.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Survey of computer networks covering end-to-end principle, multiplexing, virtualization, packet switching vs. circuit switching, router design, network protocols, congestion control, internet routing architecture, network measurement, network management, and overlay networks. Survey of research papers from classic literature through contemporary research.
title: Advanced Computer Networks

evals:
If you are an astrophysics major, definitely take this course, if for no other reason than simply because it will give you a crash course on observational astronomy in various branches from radio astronomy, which involves interferometry, to stellar astronomy. There is a fair bit of plotting, manipulating, and analyzing spectra, for instance. This course confirmed for me that I did not enjoy observational astronomy (which itself is a valuable lesson, especially if you are a sophomore who is considering JP possibilities!), while I heard some other sophomore friends say "this stuff is cool", so I'm sure it did not unfairly kill anyone's love of observational astronomy, but rather gave a realistic idea of how interesting / boring it is. 

That being said, this can be a frustrating course at times, because a significant portion of this course involves coding in Python, but we never learn anything but complete basics, and are thrown into the water for the rest. The lectures focus entirely on the concepts of the astronomy topics, with the equations thrown in, but the profs don't go through worked-out examples in lecture the way physics lecturers do, which might have helped. My friend who didn't know python coming in managed to pick up the skills, but basically anyone who had not done a JP / thesis was fairly out of his/her depth at various points. 

Our class had to write mock JWST proposals for the first time, which I thought was cool, but I think we could have had more guidance on that as well. Partly because there were no templates for JWST-specific proposals, and partly because the class proposal expectations were different, the example proposals didn't help either, and it was confusing at times the level of sophistication expected from the technical calculations, but hopefully things will be better for future classes since our proposals will be available as examples.

If you want an idea of what astronomy research is like, this is the class. It helps if you are already interested in/have a little background in astronomy. As a final project, you have to write a mock proposal for the James Webb Space Telescope. Start your calculations early and get the help you need. It will take you a lot longer than you think it will to get everything done.

It's a good course, and if you're an astro major you probably have to take it (or else you should, because it's a lot easier than some of the other departmentals). However, it wasn't the best class I've taken, and especially as a senior I felt like I knew most of the material - it's probably better for juniors or even sophomores.

Michael and Jenny are awesome, enthusiastic, and dedicated professors who are so happy to share their knowledge, expertise, and experiences with students. They are totally open to any and all questions, and are a super helpful resources when working on problem sets. 

Be aware of a couple things: firstly, the problem sets do not really reflect what was taught in class, and depending on your level of experience, there can be a huge learning curve. The best way to deal with this is to get a study group together and work on problem sets as early as you can, and to ask the professors questions. Otherwise, the problem sets are nearly impossible to do on your own. 

Secondly, you'll learn a lot of information that you won't need for problem sets, exams (there are none) or anything, so it's really tempting to forget that information. The point of this course is to become a practical, well-informed astronomer, so forgetting all of this information defeats the purpose of the course. 

The final JWST project was an attempt by the professors to be fun and relevant, but it just made everyone unnecessarily stressed because we felt so unprepared, and no one really got that much out of it. The professors suggested that they may have more intermediate deadlines throughout the semester for the project, which I think would be helpful.

My favorite course at Princeton so far! Gave me a great flavor of the astro department! Jenny and Michael are amazing -- both really passionate about the material and willing to help students with the problem sets. The small size of the class made it feel really collaborative. Best learning experience here at Pton. Fair warning -- the psets are time-consuming (but there are no exams in the class either).
Problem sets take a long time, so start early. This is a good class for astrophysics majors. It is nice that it doesn't have a midterm or a final so you can focus more on your exams in other classes.
Take it, you will learn a lot.
This class takes a lot of learning on your own and the p sets can be challenging, but the lectures are really cool and Micheal and Jenny always want to help!
This is a very interesting class! It's great for engineers and physics majors.

This is a wonderful course. Take it before senior year so it can help you on your thesis. The professors are excellent at explaining the wide range of topics and their excitement for astro is infectious. Work with your classmates for the psets (this is a great chance to meet your fellow astro majors!) and go to problem sessions and the problems will be manageable if you start early. I had never programmed before, but was still able to complete the Python assignments.
WORK WITH OTHERS. You won't survive if you don't.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 60%
assgts: Weekly problem sets. Final oral or written presentation
prereqs: PHY103/104 OR PHY 105/106, and MAT 103/104, or consent of instructor. Background in computer programming is helpful, but not required..
descrip: How do we observe and model the universe? We discuss the wide range of observational tools available to the modern astronomer: from space-based gamma ray telescopes, to globe-spanning radio interferometry, to optical telescopes and particle detectors. We review basic statistics and introduce students to techniques used in analysis and interpretation of modern data sets containing millions of galaxies, quasars and stars, as well as the numerical methods used by theoretical astrophysicists to model these data. The course is problem-set-based and aims to provide students with tools needed for independent research in astrophysics.
title: Modeling and Observing the Universe: Research Methods in Astrophysics

evals: All in all a pretty good introduction to genomic techniques. I wish we would have gotten a bit more in depth to the actual algorithms -- the assignments were mostly assessing whether we can implement pre-existing packages, not whether we can implement any algorithms ourselves. Nevertheless, a pretty good class with reasonable work load.

Be ready to do a lot of your own learning in this course! You need to be really proactive with trying your best to reach out to preceptors if you aren't sure about certain topics, and even then, they might not always be available to help, so come in with the expectation that the course doesn't have too much support built in for the students, so you'll have to be ready to do with a lot of self-study and research.

Definitely take this course if you have an interest in computational biology. It's pretty challenging if you don't have any background in cos or in biology, but definitely doable. Be prepared to work hard on homework assignments and the final project. You will learn a lot and if you have an interest it is definitely worthwhile!

Do not take this course unless the TA's aren't Andrew, Francine, and Ugne. These are the 3 worst TA's I've encountered in my time at Princeton by a long shot. For example, one of their policies was to not answer questions about assignments 24 hours before a due date. This class has interesting lectures and material that is completely derailed by the dysfunctional out-of-classroom assistance. Precepts are useless. The TA's never had anything prepared for instructional material. Interesting and engaging assignments become exercises in tedium due to the lack of a Piazza or access to helpful office hours. The final assignment is the worst assignment. It takes about 3-4 times as long as a normal Dean's date assignment. You can expect minimal to no help, arbitrary grading (no feedback, no rubric, you can't even find out why you lost points if you ask). The class expects you to replicate a publication, but it does not give you the toolset you need to complete the assignment and does not provide any instructional support for the assignment. This assignment might be reasonable if assigned to groups or partners. There is also no standardization across the multiple papers to choose from. Some students will have all the data provided to them, others will have to search for hours for data because it is no longer hosted where it is listed. This course has so much potential and great lecturers. But I cannot recommend it unless there is a serious overhaul with the way assignments and the TA's are handled.
Do not take this course. The subject matter is interesting, but the assignments will make you miserable as the professors and TAs are extremely reluctant to offer help even when asked.
Don't take it without a lot of background. I only knowing COS, put hours and hours into this course and did absolutely terribly.
