Good course. Everyone will be bored at some point because they'll either have a lot of background in biology or in computer science, but everyone will also learn something new on the other side. It is more of an introductory survey course but I also got to learn R and learn about interesting techniques and an emerging field.

Great course, but get started on the projects early. As computer science courses go, this one is less intense but can still be time-consuming. If you're a COS major, be aware that the course requires a pretty good understanding of molecular biology.

Great course, can be time consuming, but you learn how to deal with genomic data and can tackle any related project in your lab after taking this course. Can be a little slow if you already know all the biology, but otherwise, good pace and fun teaching team.

I didn't learn too much from this course. It's one of the easier COS departmental courses.

But be warned: if you're not a COS major or don't have experience with R, you're going to have a bad time.

I think I went into this class with a good attitude -- I thought this would be my favorite course at Princeton. Lectures were interesting but the problem sets were tedious and long and our preceptors were unhelpful. I've never recommended against taking a course before, but, unless they make a concerted effort to find better TAs or revamp the problem sets, I recommend against this course.

I took this class because i thought it would be an easy course departmental and that i would learn more something about bioinformatics. tbh the assignments helped me learn concepts a lot, but it was pretty unorganized and the feedback on assignments are not extensive. i really like the final assignment because we kind of got to do research, but i did not like the class overall.

If you are a COS major, find a BIO student that can explain to you the random R libraries you need and the random bio databases and terms you need to use because the lectures don't do that on  micro level.....

One of my favorite courses at Princeton. A great course if you like both biology and computation. You really only need a basic understanding of biology and programming, but a background in R is very helpful. The assignments are not a lot of work, but the final project can take a while (you have to replicate a major genomics publication).
Take this class! the final project is pretty cool and the problem sets are related to the lectures each week. Not a typical COS class, and adding biology to the content is really cool.
Take this if you're really looking for a ride in R

The class was too basic on both CS and Biology fronts, especially given that this is a QCB graduate course. But if you have strength in one of the two fronts, this might be a chill class.
However, no matter how good you are at either, this class will waste a lot of your time. A lot of the problem sets were busy work -- just figuring out how to use packages, rather than learning algorithms and their implementations. They should either have us implement basic algorithms or give us instructions on how to use the packages. Wasting time figuring out how to use packages is not very instructive. Be wary of this.

The content is really interesting and great for giving an overview of the material, but the problem sets definitely need to be updated. You don't learn a lot from them but they are pretty tedious. Overall, though, the workload isn't super high.
The course covers an important topic, and you learn a lot. Problem sets take a bit of time, but there are only four.
The preceptors aren't going to help you with anything. Really challenging assignments and final project. Overall good class.
The problem sets ramp up really quickly and go to the preceptors!

The upside: lectures in this course are very interesting. All three lecturers are really good. The downside: the written work is really hard (especially if you have no experience in R) and the TAs are not helpful with written work. Lecture is engaging, but you have to do a bunch of problem sets on your own without any help or guidance. The course is still worth it, but the work gets hard as the semester progresses and there is little support. Definitely work in a group and go to Baryshnikova's office hours.

This course goes a bit slowly if you are already familiar with some parts of computational biology. However, it is a good survey to get a basic understanding of many different areas. The final project is a big step up in difficulty from the psets, so leave plenty of time for it over break and during reading period.

This course is best taken if you have a strong interest and some background in biology. The material got too specific and niche for me. Also you should really have experience in R. The assignments were painstakingly long mainly because I had to look up how to download, format, and compute things in R. As a computer science major, this was some of the least interesting programming I've done.
Tough but worth it.

What I have noticed is that the topic sounds really interesting, yet for many students it ends up being a burden. The first part of the course with Michael Levine is deceiving, as the course will continue in a completely different direction. It is not a hard class, but you need to put some effort into it.

cool lectures, AWFUL BORING CONFUSING assignments. busy work with a lot of magic r functions you just had to google until you found them. maybe bio students had an easier time/were used to the tools and R. If you are used to coding in python/java/even c you will find R to be really annoying and non-intuitive, but you have to use if you want partial credit on assignments  

They also would stop answering questions 24 hours before the deadline which was awful if you had a last minute problem and expected your preceptors to help you. 

dont take this class tbh
watch out for pop quizzes!
grading: Other Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 60%
assgts: In addition to regular homework exercises, students will be asked to design and carry out projects in groups of 3-4 students. Students will present their projects in an oral presentation and will describe their findings in a final paper formatted as a journal article.
prereqs: COS126 or equivalent preparation.
descrip: The course will provide a detailed overview of experimental and computational approaches used to study molecular systems. We will focus on modern technologies used to generate and analyze "omics" data, such as genome sequences, gene expression, transcriptional and post-transcriptional modification, proteomics and mass spectrometry, molecular interaction networks and chemical genomics. We will also discuss and apply fundamental statistical concepts relevant to genomics (data evaluation,estimation of true and false positives, significance testing, multiple testing correction) and learn basic programming tools.
title: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology

otherinfo: Applications may be picked up in the ELE Graduate Studies Office, B-209 Equad or by contacting the ELE Graduate Administrator at cconrad@princeton.edu.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.
title: Extramural Research Internship

evals: Don't take this if you are already perfectly fluent because I don't want this to be a trol class. The teacher really cares about you so don't let her efforts go in shame.
Remember to actually learn and retain vocabulary, instead of just on quizzes. What you get out is what you put in. Definitely recommend taking this course with Professor Yun.
Take this class!!! You won't regret it! Seriously one of the best classes you could take!
Take this course if you can!! Funnest class I've taken, and will take at Princeton.
otherinfo: Students are required to attend a 50-minute drill session, which will be scheduled after students are enrolled in the course.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 15%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Approximately 10 pages of reading/week; bi-weekly short response essays; oral presentations; bi-weekly quizzes
prereqs: KOR 302 or permission of instructor..
descrip: The fifth-year language course is designed to accelerate students' proficiency to the high-advanced level and 5th-level to promote a deeper level of understanding of contemporary Korea and its people. A wide range of social, cultural and economic issues are covered through the use of various media resources (e.g., dramas, films, songs, commercials, newspapers, websites) as well as short essays. Classroom discussion are conducted in Korean.
title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture I

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.
title: Extramural Research Internship

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course
