otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/28/2017.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 65%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
descrip: Examines budgeting and finance at the state and local level of government. Topics include: budget structure and process; decision makers within the political and economic environment; debt, capital planning and bond financing; revenue structures supporting expenditures. Tax policy and associated tradeoffs between tax equity and efficiency and spending and program needs are also examined. Two case studies are utilized---one related to state and local tax policy and one related to budgetary decision-making.
title: Policy Analysis: Selected Topics (Half-Term) - State and Local Finance

evals: Great course for your certificate!
If you need to grow as a choreographer, take this.
This class was very helpful for preparing for choreographing my dance thesis.
otherinfo: Students will perform in the Princeton Dance Festival at the Berlind Theater, December 1-3, 2017 (mandatory). Preparations require four additional rehearsals, several costume fittings, as well as a final technical and dress rehearsal the week of the performance. Grading: 30% Other = Final Project
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Ongoing choreographic assignments (approx. 2 hours outside class/week); reading and viewing live and videotaped performances (approx. 2 hours outside classes/week); mandatory trip to NYC to view live performance; several short papers analyzing choreography and discussing dance based on readings and class work; and participation in an end of semester showing. Number of pages of expected reading per week 10-20
prereqs: DAN 419A or equivalent experience. To secure your place in the appropriate class, email Prof. Lazier (rlazier@) between April 10-21, 2017, and list previous composition experience at Princeton. This course MUST be taken in conjunction, and in the same semester, with DAN 319B, DAN 320B, DAN 419B or DAN 420B (Dance Performance Workshop courses, additional two 2-hour classes weekly). A mandatory placement class for these Dance Performance Workshop sections will take place on Tuesday, September 12, 2017, at 3:00 p.m., location tbd..
descrip: Students workshop their senior thesis performance. Classes delve deeply into a specific choreographic process and performance approach in preparation for Senior Thesis Production in Dance Theater. Required for seniors pursuing a Certificate in Dance.
title: Choreography Workshop IV

evals: Definitely not an easy course, but very rewarding as a student in the sciences for independent work
Definitely worthwhile if you're interested in statistics or modeling, but be prepared for a lot of math.
Excellent lecture experience with Freddy. Take this class!
Frederik gives awesome engaging lectures.  Make sure you start labs early so you can iron out any technical issues you run into.

Good if you have some statistics background and are comfortable in a class with very unclear expectations.  Definitely what you make of it.  Probably not a great class grade-wise.  And Ben is an amazing TA!
Good intro to statistics and signal processing. Also a good introduction to dealing with Matlab.

I can't say I learned much, but I did manage to get through the whole semester while being utterly confused.  So it's not so difficult that one would need to drop it if you feel confused, but do expect to feel confused the whole semester.
If you are really interested in statistics and having a robust understanding of how it works I recommend this class.

If you're looking to learn basic statistics, take this course.  It's much more relaxed and there's a lot more individual attention in this class than in something like ORF 245.  Frederik is hilarious and very good at explaining things, and the TA, Ben, is really helpful with the problem sets.  It definitely helps to have some math and programming background (roughly at the level of COS 126 and Math 201/202) and I was surprised to find that a basic knowledge of probability from PHY 208 and 301 also went a long way in helping me follow along, especially at the beginning.

It's mostly GEO-related upperclassmen and some grad students. That said, it's very useful if you're going to be doing science in the future, and a good way to learn (or improve) with MATLAB. If you're a newcomer to it like I was, you'll have to work hard, but you won't be alone and help is readily available. Assignments are weirdly structured -- 5 problem sets in the semester for your whole grade basically. But you'll come out of the course having learned valuable stuff.
Take it!  Anyone interested in applied math or statistics should definitely take this course.
Take it! Push yourself creatively on the problem sets and you'll get more out of them.

The course did not live up to my expectations based on prior experience with Frederik and the previous reviews. It was not particularly well organized or structured, and it covered surprisingly little material outside of a typical linear algebra course.The workload is pretty light, but I actually wish there would have been a bit more work to really delve into data analysis and modeling. Nevertheless, Frederik is a very engaging lecturer and the course gives a decent introduction to regression and spectral analysis (especially if you're new to modeling).
The course is interesting and worthwhile, but if you don't have a lot of experiencing programming, especially in MATLAB, the problem sets can be pretty time consuming.

This class gives an excellent exposure to a number of techniques used in data analysis and modeling.  It moves through a lot of material fast, but emphasized the application of these techniques and gives you time and flexibility to work through and process the problem sets. The problem sets are also excellent and you will get a lot of practice with Matlab (I learned to use Matlab in the course). Frederik is primarily motivated by helping everyone really get the material and he is willing to help you at whatever level you are coming into the class. That said, I HIGHLY recommend reviewing and feeling solid with the concepts of matrix algebra and basic statistics and probability going into the course.  The course uses a lot of mathematics and while you can probably gain a good amount from the class without fully understanding the theory, you will benefit a great deal more if you feel comfortable with the mathematics.
Useful course, not too much workload compared to other classes.
Very useful in interested in statistics and inverse modeling as applied to scientific data.
Would not recommend for anyone with a poor math background.

You may not appreciate what is going on during the lecture initially, but the pieces start to fall into place when you start on the first set of MATLAB exercises. Professor Simons is a wealth of knowledge and has great insight about how to analyze data in a meaningful way.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Programming Assignments - 10%, Lab Reports - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: The classroom component alternates approximately weekly, between blackboard lectures on mathematical theory and hands-on MATLAB programming sessions devoted to practical data analysis problems. The final problem set is the most involved and requires a report written on an in-depth analysis of data in the context of the methods, concepts and techniques taught in this course.
prereqs: MAT 201 (multivariable calculus) and MAT 202 (linear algebra, can be taken concurrently) . Prior experience with MATLAB is not expected; however, it is helpful. A first course in statistics is sometimes helpful, but not required..
descrip: No more being puzzled by dots on a graph! This course is for those who want to turn observations into models and subsequently evaluate their uniqueness and uncertainty. Three main topics are elementary inferential statistics, heuristic time series analysis, and model parameter estimation via matrix inverse methods. While the instructor's and textbook examples will be derived mostly from the physical sciences, students are encouraged to bring their own data sets for classroom discussion. Problem sets and MATLAB computer programming exercises form integral parts of the course. Prior programming experience is helpful but not required
title: Data, Models, and Uncertainty in the Natural Sciences

evals: Great lightweight class. Take it (K-12 mentors) if you want to help spread the goodness of computer science to schools in New Jersey. You tend to learn a lot when you are in the role of teacher.
I recommend taking it if you have the time in your schedule.

The K-12 CS mentors group is wonderful! If you have an interest in education and want to burst the orange bubble a bit, take this! It's a very low time commitment (maybe 3 hours per week) and also rewarding.
otherinfo: Please enroll into B01 for "Time" team, B02 for "Design for Developing World" team, B03 for "K-12 CS Mentors".
grading: Design Project - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Each project team will complete mid-semester and end-of semester oral and written project reports. These will include background on the team's project partners in the community, a description of all aspects of the design project being carried out for the partner, a status report on the project, plans for the future, and any other material specified by the faculty advisor(s) for the team. Reading material and other requirements will be determined by the faculty advisor(s) for each team.
prereqs: EGR 250 is the first course which students interested in EPICS need to enroll into. EGR 251 required in the next semester in order to get credit and receive a PDF grade..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.
title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit

evals: Highly recommended. As long as your project is serious AND accomplishable, you can do it. But it's only as good as the work you put in, and it's embarrassing if you have nothing to show for a semester of work. Don't take this just to slack off? take it as a personal project with no homework!
have an idea for a project
otherinfo: Please enroll into B01 for "Time" team, B02 for "Design for Developing World" team, B03 for "K-12 CS Mentors".
grading: Design Project - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Each project team will complete mid-semester and end-of semester oral and written project reports. These will include background on the team's project partners in the community, a description of all aspects of the design project being carried out for the partner, a status report on the project, plans for the future, and any other material specified by the faculty advisor(s) for the team. Reading material and other requirements will be determined by the faculty advisor(s) for each team.
prereqs: Completion of EGR 251. Students will need to take EGR 351 in the subsequent semester in order to receive grade and credit..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.
title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit

evals: Definitely take it! Mike Hepler is a great resource and really great TA.
Definitely take this course. Not stressful but still productive.
Only take this if you really like to work on things and get excited about little projects that you essentially do for fun.
otherinfo: Please enroll into B01 for "Time" team, B02 for "Design for Developing World" team, B03 for "K-12 CS Mentors".
grading: Design Project - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Each project team will complete mid-semester and end-of semester oral and written project reports. These will include background on the team's project partners in the community, a description of all aspects of the design project being carried out for the partner, a status report on the project, plans for the future, and any other material specified by the faculty advisor(s) for the team. Reading material and other requirements will be determined by the faculty advisor(s) for each team.
prereqs: Completion of EGR 351. Students will need to take EGR 451 in the subsequent semester in order to receive grade and credit..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.
title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit

evals: Be on top of the coursework, as it is easy to fall behind, but take it if you really want to improve your Spanish speaking skills while learning about an interesting topic.

Great class! German is awesome and the materials are really interesting and provide good fodder for class discussion. A bit overwhelming/challenging at times, but ultimately very rewarding and interesting.
If you are interested in Spain as a nation today, take this class. Profesor Labrador is an amazing professor and makes you analyze better.
It really is a lot of work. Multiple movies a week plus time consuming questions, but it's a good class. So...take your pick.

REALLY good course material and well-taught. Heavy preparation for each class, so don't schedule a precept or another demanding class on the same day as this one. You'll need the evening before it to prep for Spanish.
Take this course! It is a lot of work, but I learned a ton and feel like it was totally worth it.

There is a lot of homework for each class- both watching movies and reading articles and answering questions about them. BUt the class is very interesting because it is mainly about current events in Spain.
This course is intense, but if you're interested by the topic and looking to learn about Spain, I would highly recommend.
otherinfo: The course will be taught in Spanish. Films are intended for an adult audience.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 40-50 pages reading per week and/or viewing of 1-2 films; written commentaries before each class; two oral presentations; one five-page midterm paper (2,000 words); one five-page final paper (2,000 words).
prereqs: SPA 207 or 209, or instructor's permission. Freshmen are welcome. Interested students with a language Advanced Placement Examination score of 5, and/or heritage speakers, please contact labrador@princeton.edu..
descrip: What is happening in Spain today? How did culture, society and politics get affected by the 2008 financial turmoil and by the European debt crisis? Using films and documentaries (and various materials: newspaper articles, YouTube clips, graffiti, etc), we will study topics such as urban struggles, social movements, global crisis, historical memory, emigration, multiculturalism, gender identities, urban cultures, collective fictions and digital cultures. Those who are planning to apply for the Princeton-in-Spain program and/or pursue a certificate in Spanish or concentration in the Department will find this course to be a fantastic passport.
title: Contemporary Issues in Spain

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Readings will be assigned weekly. Thorough study of readings in advance of class meetings is required. Weekly readings, class discussions, and presentations. Students will write weekly response papers on the texts, one short paper for midterm evaluation (6 page minimum), and one final paper (10-15 pages) due on Dean's Date.
descrip: Although the novel is the youngest genre in the Swahili critical tradition, it has experienced some of the most revolutionary and innovative experimentations since it gained mainstream prominence in Swahili literature, mainly during the post-colonial/independence literary revolution. This course is a reading of the Kiswahili novel with a critical analysis of the socio-political and critical trends in the literary world that have influenced the writings of contemporary Swahili novelists. The colonial/independence and post independence experience in east Africa are some of the motifs that inform the course readings and class discourse.
title: Kiswahili Novel

grading: Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Materials to be provided.
descrip: This is the first course in a four-semester Polish language sequence. After beginning with the basics of Polish spelling and pronunciation, we'll continue to explore all of the basics of Polish grammar, including all major verb forms, noun and adjective cases, consonant mutations, and case usage. As we progress, we'll also learn about Polish culture, and history; by the end of the spring semester, we'll even read a sampling of Polish prose and poetry in the original.
title: Beginning Polish I

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Short grammar exercises or compositions, and 30-40 pages of reading each week.
descrip: After a thorough review of the basics of Czech grammar, we will continue to explore more advanced topics (word formation, verb aspect, syntax, etc.) while reading challenging but rewarding works of Czech literature, both prose and poetry, and watching Czech films. Added emphasis will be placed on speaking and writing about these works (and other topics) in Czech.
title: Intermediate Czech I

evals: Fairly easy class, could be done in a 5-class semester, mostly graded against upperclass ORF majors.  Material is interesting, but presented very dryly.  Overall, would weakly recommend.
Good course if you want to learn simulation methods.
Good way to practice Python in a easy environment (before doing crazy Python in crazy classes).
I would strongly recommend this class.  It's a good combination of probability, math, and coding.  And Professor Massey has a really clear, easy-to-follow way of lecturing.

It seems that this class is mostly filled with grad students, and attendance is low overall. But I still think that the professor is clear and explains things well (he also did try to engage the class and make some jokes). The work wasn't that difficult for me, but I had a coding background beforehand (though I had never learned Python, but it's easy to pick up). I think it'd be harder if you had zero coding experience before this course.
Make sure you attend all lectures in the second half. The first half is a lot of probability review, etc. but the second half is where the material really picks up.
Read the textbook carefully, and don't procrastinate on the assignments! They take forever

This course allows you to learn some interesting concepts in Monte Carlo simulations and allows you to learn and become better at programming in Python. But overall, the lectures and explanations/guidances for help could have been better and material could have been presented in a more engaging manner.

This is a broad introduction to simulation, covering techniques for simulating from different distributions of random variables as well as using simulations to provide computational answers to stochastic models that are too difficult to analyze analytically. 
It is of interest to you if you would like to see how you can do probability computationally rather than analytically like you did in ORF 309.
Useful and good but you will not learn a ton of Python.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Problem sets.
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309..
descrip: An introduction to the uses of simulation and computation for analyzing stochastic models and interpreting real phenomena. Topics covered include generating discrete and continuous random variables, stochastic ordering, the statistical analysis of simulated data, variance reduction techniques, statistical validation techniques, nonstationary Markov chains, and Markov chain Monte Carlo methods. Applications are drawn from problems in finance, manufacturing, and communication networks. Students will be encouraged to program in Python. Office hours will be offered for students unfamiliar with the language.
title: Introduction to Monte Carlo Simulation

otherinfo: This course meets from 3/29/17 to 5/3/17. Non-Sociology graduate students wishing to receive a grade for this course must submit a completed Graduate Student Enrollment Change Form located at the following URL: https://gradschool.princeton.edu/sites/gradschool/files/Enrollment%20Form%20Revised_1.pdf
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Introduction to a gendered analysis of economic processes and institutions. Course investigates when, why, and in what ways gender shapes production, consumption, distribution, and transfer of assets. After a general discussion of gender theories, it surveys how gender works in a variety of settings and activities, such as labor markets, intimate economies, and caring labor. We end with an overview of strategies aimed at reducing gendered economic inequalities. Overall, the course attempts to strengthen intellectual bridges between economic sociology and gender scholarship.
title: Topics in Economic and Organizational Sociology (Half-Term) - Gender and Economic Activity

evals: Good course. I recommend taking it.

Having graduated from the physics 105/106 track, I can say this class is a bit more relaxed in terms of difficulty and expectations. Problem sets are challenging but manageable; focus is more on examples than on formal proofs. Considering that you are probably deciding between this and PHY205, I will say that this class is definitely easier BUT I have heard the lectures are not as good. Prof. Romalis is sometimes hard to follow in lectures; the textbook for the course is really good and proved a reliable resource for clearing up any confusion from lecture.
I doubt many of you would take this class for fun, but it's really interesting and Romalis is a reasonable guy

I took 105 two years ago, and this is definitely a giant step down from the difficulty of that class (or maybe it was because I was a freshman then). Take for an easy fifth class. Heavy math skills not required, just basic knowledge of taking partial derivatives. Exams are very doable and so are homeworks.
SENIORS: DO NOT TAKE! YOU WILL BE DISTRACTED FROM YOUR THESIS!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: PHY103 and PHY104 or PHY105 and PHY106; one 200-level math course; or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course covers wave phenomena, both classical and quantum, and it also includes an account of special relativity and introductory aspects of statistical physics. Topics include: special relativity, Lagrangians, small oscillations, coupled oscillations and waves, wave-packets and the Schrodinger equations, and elements of statistical mechanics. Mathematical methods will be developed as appropriate, in parallel to physical concepts.
title: Mechanics and Waves

otherinfo: Other 40% = Homework (grammar exercises, essays)
grading: Final Exam - 10%, Quizzes - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Daily written and/or reading assignments and weekly short compositions.
descrip: This course is intended for students who have spoken Russian at home and seek to achieve proficiency in the language. Topics will include an intensive introduction to the Russian writing system and grammar, focusing on exciting materials and examples drawn from classic and contemporary Russian culture and social life. Successful completion of this course and its continuation in the spring (RUS 108) fulfills the University language requirement.
title: Russian for Heritage Speakers

evals: If you want to start translation, this is a good class.
It is time consuming because there is a translation due every other week.
It was a good and interesting course. If you're fluent in Spanish, it is light and interesting.
It's good to have on your transcript and it's pretty low-commitment
Must take if you want to learn about translation and spanish.

Sylvia is the best. Take this course just for her. You won't learn a lot of Spanish, but there's not a ton of work, the translations are pretty interesting, and it's a very practical and relevant skill. A lot of what you do is pretty instinctive (ie there's not magic bullet to suddenly become a great translator) but just having the opportunity to think about the process and work through it is very helpful.
Take it!!!
You should take this! Not too difficult, and an interesting class for those that want a different Spanish learning environment.
otherinfo: Offered only in the fall.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Readings in English and Spanish (30 pages per week). Weekly Spanish into English translation assignments and/or translation related activities. Two collaborative translation projects. One class presentation. Final translation of a text not previously translated.
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to translation practice for the Spanish-English language pair, focusing primarily on the task of translating from Spanish into English. The course is conducted in Spanish and follows a communicative approach to translation, with a good balance between theory and praxis. Materials are drawn from a range of disciplines, such as humanities, social sciences, popular culture, and the media. Students are encouraged to think critically and creatively about language, and will heighten their awareness of the linguistic, textual and cultural differences between English and Spanish.
title: Introduction to Spanish-English Translation

evals: A good course. I took this as a distribution requirement (I'm BSE) and I PDFed the course. Easy workload and some interesting content. Topics very relevant to modern life. There are around 75-150 pages of readings each week, but you don't actually need to read them all ? just read a few pages here and there and you'll get enough to get through the precepts and the weekly 1.5 page reflection papers.
As an engineer, take this class for an EM. GREAT LECTURES. Professor Zaman in amazing. Get a good preceptor.
Choose a good preceptor that fits your needs. If grades are important to you, make sure you look at who your preceptor is.

Definitely take this class if you want to learn more about the historical context of the emergence of Islam, as well as the relevance of Islam in the modern world. If you're just looking for an easy A without interest in the topic, then I wouldn't recommend it. If you do take it though, try to get in Dana's precept. She is great!
Definitely take this class, but be prepared to do a lot of reading if you are not planning to PDF it.
Don't take this as an 'easy' 4th or 5th course. It is pretty easy, but its a ton of work, and the responses are not graded very lightly. You'll learn alot.

Don't take this class. There is an illusion that this class is a great introduction to Islam, but it is very rigid, and Zaman does not like to engage the students into one conversation. The workload is not a lot, but if you have some basic knowledge of Islam, this class is incredibly redundant.

Easy EM and PDF - weekly reading responses are very chill and easily done in an hour or two. Otherwise, the midterm and final are just two 1000-word essay questions, and an afternoon's work should be enough for a solid P. Lectures and precepts themselves are not bad and worth going in their own right.
Excellent class if interested in subject matter. A lot of work though (100  pages of reading plus 1.5 pages response paper a week)
Generally good but, as goes with all classes, your preceptor can make or break the class. Generally better than the other NES classes though
Go to lecture.
Great EM, though heavier workload.
Great class. Definitely take it if you have any interest in the Middle East.
Great class. Maybe shouldn't have taken pdf given the weekly reading responses.
Honestly, really disappointing, not what I expected. Grading is a little harsh. But workload is light.
I learned a lot about Islam and it was a very chill class
I took it pdf and enjoyed it. not very difficult, but interesting lectures and readings. take for distribution requirement or good pdf.
I would recommend this course! My perspective of Islam certainly expanded.

I would suggest this class if you have a general interest in Islam. The readings are interesting for the most part and the midterm and final are take home, which give you sufficient time to lay out your ideas. Professor Zaman is a good lecturer; he presented the material in a clear and engaging manner. Overall, this was a very good course in my opinion.
I'm really glad I took this for my Islam requirement in the Religion department. Would recommend to Religion majors who want a survey of Islam that will stick with them past the semester.

If you don't know anything about Islam, this is a great place to start--students who are familiar with theology might find it a little slow/easy otherwise. Also preceptors grade weekly response papers pretty harshly, so if you don't want to spend the time then definitely PDF
If you want a general introduction into Islam this is a good course to take. The reading is not too heavy and the preceptors are excellent.

If you want a relatively light EM, this is a good course. The course is really designed for people who know very little or nothing about Islam, so take that into account. If you really want to focus on modern Islamic militant terrorism though, this is not the right class for you. Modern questions such as war and sexuality are reserved for the end and really only compose about 20% of the course. The rest is about history and basic tenets of the religion.
If you want an easy PDF, this is the class. Two take home exams, just a short response to turn in each week. Go to precept and do the work and you'll be fine.

If you're not a fan of philosophy, this is a good EM class to take. The preceptors are really great and Professor Zaman is an interesting lecturer. You do have to at least skim the readings to do the weekly assignments though.
It is a great class to take for general knowledge on Islam, if you aren't too familiar with the subject it definitely opens your eyes to other belief systems around you!
Not the best PDF course out there for an EM requirement, but do take it if you're interested in the topic. If you have time to do the readings, they're actually quite amazing.
Take for a good intro to Islam. However, this class will be a little repetitive for someone coming into the class with significant knowledge of Islam already.
Take if you don't know much about Islam and would like to know more. Provides a good overview of Islamic history and beliefs. Content can get a bit dry at times, but otherwise a pretty good class.
Take this class! But be prepared to work hard.
Take this course for an interesting EM with light to moderate amounts of work.
Take this course. Professor Zaman is brilliant and the class will give you many perspectives on Islam and its place in the world.

Take this if you want a good introduction to Islam. Be prepared to actually do the readings if you want to get more out of the class besides the lectures. The weekly responses can be frustrating and how harshly they are graded depends on your preceptor, so choose wisely.
The topic is engaging and important to understand considering Trump just banned all Muslim immigrants from entering the country. It is graded fairly.

This is a great course and a lot of fun. Its about 100 pages of reading a week, which for me as a STEM major was a lot (sometimes too much), and often the readings were on the boring side, but everything else was really well done. Take this class!
This is such an interesting class definitely take it. The readings are long and hard but is worth it because you learn a lot and gain a better understanding of a very important topic.

Very useful for gaining a basic understanding of Islam. Lectures not totally necessary. Readings were often dense and dry...
If you are in Professor Zaman's precept: the discussion is great, and he's very knowledgeable, but it was more expanding on the material than just clarifying it. Was easy to feel lost. And be ready for him to throw your question back at you!
Zaman makes this course everything it is.  And that's a good thing.  He's the man.
Zamman is a very good lecturer. Kate is a very good preceptor. I enjoyed this course, even though the amount of readings was a bit too much for a BSE student.
take! interesting course!
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading: About 100 pages per week. Writing: Two take-home exams: the first at mid-semester, the second at the end of the semester.
descrip: A broad-ranging introduction to pre-modern, modern, and contemporary Islam in light of how Muslims have approached their foundational religious text, the Qur'an. Topics include: Muhammad and the emergence of Islam; theology, law and ethics; war and peace; mysticism; women and gender; and modern debates on Islamic reform. We shall examine the varied contexts in which Muslims have interpreted their sacred text, their agreements and disagreements on what it means and, more broadly, their often competing understandings of Islam and of what it is to be a Muslim.
title: Muslims and the Qur'an

evals: Definitely take this if you want a hands-on class where speaking is the focus
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Quizzes - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Preparation for this course will require a minimum of 4-5 hours per week with less than 50 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or the equivalent..
descrip: In this course, students will develop their skills in reading and listening to Arabic news media, including newspapers, magazines, websites, radio and satellite TV broadcasts (including BBC and al-Jazeera, among others). Attention will also be given to informal discussion of current news, and we will also take a brief look at political cartoons. Language of instruction will be primarily Arabic.
title: Media Arabic I

evals: 10/10 would recommend Ran Raz as the professor and Dr. Petras as the preceptor. I was never confident in math courses ever since I took 104 and 202, but I was really surprised by how much I learned after this class. It's important to find a good partner for the problem sets. I did go to all the lectures and took notes, and I think that helped me following the different concepts in the class. Also helped me review for the midterms and finals.

340 was very well done this semester imo. Raz gave great lectures. 
340 precepts with Petras should be the gold standard for engineering math courses.
Students are given a handout at beginning of precept with relevant problems and their step-by-step solutions, so you don't need to take notes and can always refer to the packet in the future. Petras then goes over each problem in detail.

A great many COS upperclassmen told me this class is unforgiving in terms of workload. Thankfully, this is no longer the case. Allegedly, in the past, psets would take 10  hours to solve, and 6 hours to latex (NB all psets are PROOFS and they must be LATEX'ED (both of which turn out to be awesome)), but not, the solving only takes about 1-2 hours. Additionally, Ran Raz has scaled the pace of the course back a bit to focus more on the fundamentals (expected value, probability theory, etc). I strongly recommend that any prospective COS major (no COS 226 or MAT 202 necessarily required) take this class as soon as possible in case it gets absurdly difficult again! Plus, when the workload is manageable, content is actually quite enjoyable. Math majors will probably be bored until week 8.

A lot of you may have heard horror stories about this class, but that just seems to be Princeton's knee-jerk reaction to seeing any kind of math for some reason. I think it's a pretty unfounded reaction because if you do the readings and follow along with lecture and precept, the psets shouldn't be too bad, especially if you have a group to work with. This semester the lectures were really great with Ran Raz, and precept with Petras was (as expected) clear and helpful. Overall you might not learn too much that is mindblowingly new, since the course doesn't go too far in depth for any one topic, but it's definitely something you need to move forward in COS theory.
A this course is a joke! The lectures, precepts and problem sets are extremely easy and cover material learnt mostly in high school. Take it for a very very easy A !

ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS COURSE! Ran Raz is one of the most charming, down-to-earth, and brilliant people I've ever met (it's an incredibly rare combination). I loved every single minute of this course, and I always looked forward to going to lecture. Ran Raz is one of the world's leading experts in computational complexity theory, and his passion for theoretical computer science shines at every single moment in the course. His lectures are crystal clear, and he's always happy to stop and answer questions from the students in the lecture hall. If you opt not to attend the lectures in this course, then I promise you that you're missing out on hearing one of the coolest people on the face of the planet speak passionately about the foundations of theoretical computer science. The problem set questions are not too difficult, and most of them permit collaboration in groups of 3 students. The course is immensely rewarding, both in material covered and in terms of the professor's lecture style, and I certainly want to take another course with Ran Raz just to experience his awesome lectures for another semester. If I could uncountably infinitely strongly recommend this course, I would do so in a heartbeat because I loved it so much. A 5.00 review for this course underestimates how incredible it is!
Attend lectures and/or do readings and you should be fine on the problem sets.  Office hours and Lab TA hours are very helpful.

COS 340 has a reputation in the COS department as a very hard and scary course for the less mathematically-inclined COS majors that have to take it. As a BSE COS major, I came into the course with this reputation in mind and not much past proof-based math experience, and I ended up loving the course more than any other course I have taken at Princeton. The psets are challenging but much more doable then they were > 2 years ago. If you are interested in taking a proof-based math course, are passionate about mathematical problem solving, do not have a Princeton-level rigorous background in math, and are afraid you'll get eaten alive trying to take MAT 215 or the like, and are looking for a challenging and fun proof-based math course at Princeton, take it.

COS 340 is an excellent intro theory class. It used to be balls-hard but now it's at a difficulty that is appropriate for most students. Definitely take if you don't have extensive background in proofs; you'll learn a lot. If you're a math major please don't take this course and do us non-math majors a favor :P Seriously. There were at least 5 IMO kids in 340 this spring and they really should've been in COS 423 or 487.
COS majors, take this class! Not the worst class, workload-wise.

Definitely take this course if you are interested in CS theory at all (and if you're a CS major ? it may as well be a requirement). Ran Raz taught the class very well and the material itself is very interesting ? a formal introduction to the course's topics is rarely seen elsewhere in such an enjoyable manner.
Excellent class, material is pretty cool, only downside is that curve is bad. Raz is a good lecturer, but goes very slowly. Petras is a great preceptor.
Foundation course to CS.
Go to Lab TAs for help on the problem sets. Actually do the readings, even though for most classes the readings do not help much.
Go to lab tas, class, and office hours and you should be able to do well on the assignments. Make sure to take good notes and they will help with the exams.
Great course, very interesting. Could be challenging if you don't have a good background in math. The readings are good, and Petras is great.
Great introduction to the theory behind algorithms!
Hard class, especially if you don't have any probability background knowledge going in.
I highly suggest for anyone interested in the topic to take it. If Professor Raz is teaching it,  you have to take it! He's amazing at explaining things and gives great lectures.

I loved this course because I loved the topics involved, but even if you don't like math, its a good theory course and gives a solid understanding of some important concepts for computer science. Definitely recommend!
I thought this class was going to be a disaster but in the end it worked out well.  I think that it is definitely a hard course but the material could be pretty interesting.
If you are a COS major, you probably need to take this class. It's not as bad as people say it is. Try to find a good group to work on the problem sets with

If you don't have an extensive math background, be ready to grind. Read the book before the lecture so that you get the material twice. Make use of lab TAs and office hours. Lastly, make sure that you find a good team that you can depend on when the problem sets get tough. You can make it through this class, I believe in you!

It's a good course and Raz is a good professor. You really don't need to go to lecture, but if you're like me and are not a genius math major, you should. The curve in the class is pretty much non-existent and the math majors don't help that, but it's a good course. COS majors like me have to take it, but I really think you do learn a lot of important and valuable skills. Some classes, you leave with no real sense of accomplishment or sense of what you learned, but that's not the case with this class.
It's not as bad as people say !

It's not as terrible as all the horror stories that I've heard about 340, but it definetly made me realize CS theory is not my cup of tea. If you're someone who shudders at the idea of proofs, take this class only if you have to.

It's okay. It's a requirement. I think people overhype how hard this class is. I did all problem sets by myself because I don't like working with other people. I'm not very good at math and was able to work through most problems by going to lab TAs. Was fairly frustrating that the median score on most PSets was a perfect score and mine were, well, less than perfect, but so it goes. 

You probably have to take it, try not to put it in a super stressful semester, but it won't kill you.
Keep up with the material, especially in the second half of the course. Don't give up; stuff might seem hard but you just have to keep at it!

Perhaps it's just this semester, but COS 340 was quite easy in my opinion (I found MAT 104 and MAT 202 to be significantly harder). The assignments can be tricky, but most of the time is spent on typing the answers in Latex. Prof. Raz is a great lecturer. I found him to be rather slow-paced, but that's great because I'm not a very math-y person so I wouldn't have been able to follow along if it went faster. The midterm was ridiculously easy, but it was balanced by what I thought was a hard final. Overall, I learned a lot, and I loved the course even though I won't be getting as high a grade as I'd like. Do NOT be scared to take it; enjoy learning some super important material!
Pretty cool class; I've heard it's much easier now than it used to be. Get Iasonas as a preceptor. He knows his stuff and is willing to go the extra mile if you reach out
Ran Paz is pretty good and I anticipate the ratings of this class to be relatively high.

Ran Raz is a wonderful person and a great lecturer, though the lectures are overall unnecessary since the book is so great. Problem sets were very manageable (3-5 hours per week) with lots of help available. That being said the average on all the problem sets and tests was very high because they weren't terribly challenging, so be prepared to fight over the A's with a bunch of r/nosleep COS department lunatics. I took it out of interest, very satisfied.
Ran Raz is an absolutely amazing professor, the COS department needs to hire more people like him. Definitely take if he is teaching.

Ran Raz is really great. Workload is reasonable, though no practice exams made the exams difficult for me. Precept problems significantly harder than lecture or even problem sets sometimes, which made it sometimes hard to follow. Pretty interesting material.
Take it if you have to
Take it if you have to, it's not that bad of a class as long as you are willing to go to office hours.
Take this course for COS departmental, very interesting and Professor Raz is great.
Take this if you want a basic CS theory course. As someone who had never written a proof before this class, it's time consuming, but not terrible.
Take this with Ran Raz. He's makes hard topics very accessible and is the best professor I've had so far at Princeton.

The problems sets aren't the toughest but do take a considerable amount of time to work through. Overall, a good intro to proofs and not as hard as it seems. The course is basically a must take for CS majors but I also recommend it for any math inclined students.

This class is what it is. Take it because you need to for Theory distribution. Ran Raz wasn't particularly difficult compared to prior semesters, so taking it with him is not a bad move. Petras is the best preceptor, and find yourself a good problem set group!!!

This is a pretty good course, I would give it a moderately strong recommendation.  Professor Raz is sometimes a bit difficult to understand in lecture, but he's always willing to help or talk about the material outside of class.  And Nikunj is a great preceptor - get him if he's still precepting this class!  The material is really fascinating stuff - it starts with discrete math topics and then moves into graph theory, and finally into theoretical computer science topics.  They've been pretty tight-lipped about grading, but I doubt the curve is very generous - the median on the homework is nearly 100 and the median on the midterm was 90.  The final was a little bit tricky, though, so we'll see.
This is so much easier than ORF 309. It may have been less time-consuming that MAT 201/202. But you skim over a bunch of topics and don't really learn any of them deeply.

This was actually a fun course, and more similar to the math in high school (no linear, or calculus) which I really enjoyed. It definitively isn't as difficult or scary as people make it out to be, and completely doable even if you don't have the background. However, it's definitively not very COS heavy so people might be disappointed in that.
Try hard in each and every problem set. I really recommend not slacking off for even just one cause it builds up.
Unless you have an interest in introductory Computer Science theory, or have to fill a distribution requirement, I would not recommend taking the course.

You'll have to take this course if you're COS. But Ran Raz is the man and Iasonas Petras is a good preceptor. The TA's are the best resource for psets (go to them weekly, put it into your schedule). Stay on top of the concepts and you'll be fine.
very interesting, I myself was not fantastic at it but found it super engaging
otherinfo: This course replaces COS 341.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Problem sets.
prereqs: COS 126 and 226 (or sufficient mathematical background), and MAT 202 or 204 or MAT217 (students entering Princeton before fall 2015 may use MAT 175). COS 226 can be taken along with COS 340 in the same term. Please contact the professor directly with any questions you may have..
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics, probability and graph theory will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.
title: Reasoning about Computation

evals: A lot of reading, but good for a general reading into translation and what it is and what it's for.
Definitely take it!  The nature and topic of this course allows for so many different perspectives that it is always interesting.

For someone interested in translation, this is a great class-- interesting, a wide variety of different kinds of readings on the subject, and Professor Emmerich is wonderful. I would recommend taking any class with her.

I took this course knowing nothing about translation, and completely fell in love with it. I was apprehensive about it at first, thinking that I would hate translating or be really bad at it. I found the class to be an environment in which I could openly contribute and take intellectual risks. I am a French concentrator. Because of this course, I will be pursuing the Translation and Intercultural Communication Certificate and plan to incorporate translation into my independent work. 

This course is appropriately challenging for a 200-level, but not overwhelming or stressful, in my experience. It felt balanced. Readings are relevant, and there are many guest lecturers, which makes the course very interesting.
I would encourage anyone with even a slight interest in the topic to consider this course.

I'd definitely recommend this intro course if the THEORY of translation and the academic discourse around it interests you. It's less about actually producing translations (though we did a little of that with Karen)
Professor Emmerich is an inspiring educator -- do not pass up a chance to take a class with her.

Professor Emmerich was an amazing professor. I've learned a lot about translation theory. The readings can be dense at times, but there's a wide variety that can be interesting to read. The guest lecturers also provide different sides of translation that people don't normally think about it. Overall though, I don't think I would have enjoyed the class as much if Professor Emmerich was not teaching.
otherinfo: Open to all students interested in the topic. Required course for Certificate in Translation and Intercultural Communication.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Reading in English 50 pages per week. Take-home mid-term 5-7 pages. No final exam. Final paper 15 pages. Brief weekly postings on Blackboard.
descrip: What is translation? What is a language? So essential and widespread is translation today that it has become a central analytic term for the contact of cultures, and a paradigm for studying many different aspects of our multilingual world. This course will consider translation as it appeared in the past, but especially as it constructs everyday life in the contemporary world. It will look at issues of anthropology, artificial intelligence, diplomacy, film, law and literature that involve interlingual and intercultural communication. Students should acquire an understanding of the problems and practices of modern translation.
title: Thinking Translation: Language Transfer and Cultural Communication

evals: DO NOT TAKE if you know thermo / science even moderately well. I'm MAE, took this because it fit my schedule better than 328, and it was so boring and general. If you're an engineer, do 328 so at least you'll be interested.

Easy course, very low work. Midterm is easy, and no final (final debate project instead). Lectures are pretty boring - lots of good info that if compressed into 20-30 minutes would make for awesome lectures, but the 80 minute classes really drag.

If you're doing the sustainable energy certificate, you have to take this. It's not that interesting or that much work, although also not that easy to get an A since the expectations are so unclear and variable.
It was a relatively straightforward class. Topic was interesting.

It's a chill class compared to other engineering requirements. The psets don't take more than 2/3 hours usually and precept discussions can be interesting. Lectures are often not very engaging. The material can be interesting, though I would have liked to see more alternative sources of energy and less conventional fossil fuel technologies. Chill midterm and fun final debates
Only take if interest in sustainable energy; relatively disorganized and confusing class
Take it if you need it for a certificate. Relatively low-commitment.

The course should be better organized - it often felt somewhat disconnected from wider perspective. Also, visits to the PPPL and CoGen plant did not happen. We did have a couple guest speakers that were interesting. The lectures are generally dry, but they do give a good overview of today's energy field. Precepts on Friday are generally more interesting-the floor is open to questions, or a student will lead the precept. Debates emerge and participation is high. The final debate is also a very good way to replace a final- students learn from each other and get to practice a skill that is very important in a field with controversy.

This class is a solid introduction to the topic of energy overall. You'll learn something. (Workload and exams are more than manageable/very light as well This class doesn't demand a lot.) Just very disorganized at some points and dry (in terms of lectures)  for a subject that has so much potential to be engaging.
This is a good course if you are interested. Gets boring.
otherinfo: Field trips to fusion research laboratory (PPPL), co-generation coal power plant, and energy research labs on campus will be arranged. This course is one of the core courses for the Certificate Program in Sustainable Energy.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Other Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Group projects and presentations to analyze regional and global energy sustainability and their impact on the environment using engineering analysis of conversion technology, efficiency, regulations, and cost.
prereqs: This course is offered for both engineering and non-engineering students. (Calculus or Thermodynamics are NOT requirements)..
descrip: This course will deal with issues of regional and global energy demands, sources, carriers, storage, current and future technologies and costs for energy conversion, and their impact on climate and the environment. Students will learn to perform objective cost-efficiency and environmental impact analyses from source to end-user on both fossil fuels (oil, coal, and natural gas), and alternative energy sources (bio-fuels, solar energy, wind, batteries, and nuclear). We will also pay particular attention to energy sources, technologies, emissions, and regulations for transportation. The course will also include tours to energy research labs.
title: Energy Technologies in the 21st Century

otherinfo: Undergraduates must receive permission from Professor to enroll.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics. Note: REL 518 (fall) and REL 519 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.
title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop

evals: Definitely take it.
Professor Homes is great. If you care about literature and/or politics at all (and you damn well better, for everything is political and a lot is literary), then take this course.

She is a character in the best possible way. She wants you to develop as a writer and will go to great lengths to help you do so. She is open, approachable, and honest. My favorite professor I've had at Princeton.
Take it. its fun, and its PDF only.
Take this class, you won't regret it!
otherinfo: Individual conferences are scheduled at intervals during the semester. There are no exams. Grading: Attendance is mandatory.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: During the semester each student will write either one long autobiographical piece or three shorter ones
prereqs: Interested students should complete an application (arts.princeton.edu/cwr-app) and include a writing sample of 3-4 pages of prose. Prerequisite: One 200-level fiction course. Application deadline is April 17, 2017. Accepted students will be able to enroll in Tigerhub May 22nd to 26th..
descrip: In this course students will read autobiographical fragments that reveal a whole gamut of possibilities, from carefully documented memories to novelistic elaboration to wholescale invention. The real work of the course, however, will be creative. Students will explore their own lives through various devices and discover that the truth is never elemental but can be released through literary strategies. During the semester each student will write either one long autobiographical piece or three shorter ones.
title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - Writing Autobiography

evals: A good class for people with interest in East Asian history. Professors clearly knew their stuff and classes were engaging. Not that much work for a HUM class though the readings could be heavy.

Do the readings! This should go without saying, but the readings are short enough that you should always be able to make time for them. The quality of the discussions can't shine through unless you already have some ideas that you can hone in debate.

I would highly recommend this course. It provides an interesting approach to East Asian literary works that I've never experienced in a Humanities course. The readings are mostly excerpts, so the coursel oad isn't challenging, and it allows you to focus in on key themes in the work, which I think provides a more holistic view on this big topic.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the general field. And if not, I'd recommend it anyway; the class is relatively low stress and you'll learn something from it.
If you are interested in East Asia, you might consider taking this course.
Learn about the professors for this class, i can see there being variance in the quality of the course based on what professor is teaching it.

TO ANYONE COMING FROM THE HUM SEQUENCE: this course is a nice complement and I found it worthwhile, but it might not be what you expect. The papers are not close readings, they're much shorter. And there are projects that make you think about the material in a non-traditional way. Again I liked it, but it's not the same format of the HUM sequence.
The lectures are really interesting and engaging. It is an enjoyable class to take.
otherinfo: Fulfills a requirement for the certificate in Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities. Other 30% = group projects on specific topics.
grading: Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: 100-150 pages of reading per week. Written assignments consist of short articles, annotations of primary texts and images provided on the website, and a group project. All written assignments will be integrated with the course materials discussed in class and will be posted on the website (accessible only to those registered for the course). Oral presentations and class participation will also be assessed accordingly.
prereqs: No knowledge of East Asian languages or history is required. No prior knowledge of working with digital media is required. Freshmen are welcome.
descrip: An introduction to the literature, art, religion and philosophy of China, Japan and Korea from antiquity to ca. 1400. Readings focus on primary texts in translation, complemented by museum visits and supplementary materials on the course website. The course aims to allow students to explore the unique aspects of East Asian civilizations and the connections between them through an interactive web-based platform, in which assignments are integrated with the texts and media on the website. No prior knowledge of working with digital media is required.
title: East Asian Humanities I: The Classical Foundations

evals: If you take this course, you have to make sure you take on the responsibility of writing your screenplay and developing your story. It is only then that you can get feedback on your work.

Screenwriting gives you a wonderful new perspective on creative writing, even if your interests lie in other genres. For those not interested in creative writing, screenwriting gives you a new appreciation for movies and the way they tell stories.
See the professor during office hours. It is an excellent way to further your screenplay along and ask specific questions about your piece which would be more difficult to do in class.

Take it. It's much chiller than other CWR classes because you have no readings outside of class, just writing your own work. Lazaridi is a very talented and engaging professor who can teach you a lot, but be sure to follow her rules about developing a story. I struggled with this, and as a result the workshops were very repetitive for me (i.e. we just went over the same 10 questions every time).
Take this class if you're interested.  It's not a very large commitment but it's worth it and Lazaridi is both an amazing writer and teacher.
Take this course if Professor Lazaridi is teaching!
Take this course, even (especially!) if you have never done screenwriting before! Super fun, manageable, and engaging. You should challenge yourself to write pieces you're proud of!
professor lazaridi is laid-back, the course is as hard or easy as you want it to be. also it's fun. 10/10 recommend
grading: Papers - 85%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Weekly writing assignments. 60 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Interested students complete a creative writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they would like to take the course, and optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Please note this course cannot be audited. Application deadline is April 17, 2017. Accepted students will be able to enroll in Tiger Hub May 22nd to 26th..
descrip: This course will introduce students to core screenwriting principles and techniques. Questions of thematic cohesiveness, plot construction, logical cause and effect, character behavior, dialogue, genre consistency and pace will be explored as students gain confidence in the form by completing a number of short screenplays. The course will illustrate and analyze the power of visual storytelling to communicate a story to an audience, and will guide students to create texts that serve as "blueprints" for emotionally powerful and immersive visual experiences. Final portfolio will include one short exercise and two short screenplays.
title: Introduction to Screenwriting: Writing the Short Film

evals: Give it a try. If it ends up not being your thing, you will at least gain some valuable lessons and knowledge from a great instructor.
If you are at all interested in learning how to write screenplays, this, or any class offered by Prof. Lazaridi, is a great place to start.
Take it. Take it. If you haven't already selected it, what are you doing? Take it. Now. Go.
take it if you're working on being a better writer, thinker, or movie-appreciator!
otherinfo: This course is open to both advanced and beginning students of screenwriting. All students should purchase or have access to Final Draft or equivalent screenwriting software.
grading: Papers - 85%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Weekly participation in table-top readings and critiques of peer materials. Active participation in film clip and screenplay text analyses. Completion of first screenplay. Completion and revision of final short screenplay (20-30 minutes). 60 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Interested students complete a creative writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and, optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Application deadline is April 17, 2017. Accepted students will be able to enroll in Tiger Hub May 22nd to 26th..
descrip: This course will introduce students to Screenwriting Adaptation techniques, focusing primarily on the challenges of adapting "true stories" pulled from various non-fiction sources. The class will address the ethics of adaptation, questions and techniques surrounding the need to fictionalize truth for dramatic purposes, as well as touching on the differences between fictional and nonfictional original materials. Students will be exposed to various contemporary non-fiction adaptations, and will write a short film (under 15 pages) and one longer project (30 pages).
title: Introduction to Screenwriting: Adaptation

evals: AAAAAAh Choose a good project!!!!!!
Come in with your own project ideas.
Definitely take this class.
Excellent! Go in with a group and an idea and you will learn whatever you want to with the help of great teachers!
Great class if you decide on a project early. You can make some cool stuff it's a lot of fun
LOVED THIS CLASS
NA
Rewarding to get out of the bubble and help out high school students. Make sure your group's schedules line up!
Take CS Mentors with Dan!
Take it
Take this course if interested in applicable engineering
Take this course if you want to actually work on building/repairing some kind of machine.
Take this if you want to be inspired by children and teens learning computer science!
Very rewarding experience if you are into it and put in just a few hours of good work each week.
You will get nothing out of taking this, would much rather have PDFed an interesting class than taken this.
recommend
take
otherinfo: Please enroll into B01 for "Time" team, B02 for "Design for Developing World" team, B03 for "K-12 CS Mentors".
grading: Design Project - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Each project team will complete mid-semester and end-of semester oral and written project reports. These will include background on the team's project partners in the community, a description of all aspects of the design project being carried out for the partner, a status report on the project, plans for the future, and any other material specified by the faculty advisor(s) for the team. Reading material and other requirements will be determined by the faculty advisor(s) for each team.
prereqs: EGR 250 is the prerequisite; Please note that EGR 251is P/D/F only course. After completing EGR 251 you can continue in EPICS by taking EGR 350-351 ( fully graded course).
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.
title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)

evals: Take this course if you have a project you're willing to dedicate yourself to. Some kids slack off and miss class/just show up. This is a low-time commitment each week, has no homework or exams, and lets you craft your plan for the year. It's a chance to do something you're passionate about!
build a good good relationship with your TA
otherinfo: Please enroll into B01 for "Time" team, B02 for "Design for Developing World" team, B03 for "K-12 CS Mentors".
grading: Design Project - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Each project team will complete mid-semester and end-of semester oral and written project reports. These will include background on the team's project partners in the community, a description of all aspects of the design project being carried out for the partner, a status report on the project, plans for the future, and any other material specified by the faculty advisor(s) for the team. Reading material and other requirements will be determined by the faculty advisor(s) for each team.
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.
title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/28/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Economics is centrally concerned with models of human capital development, educational attainment, labor market dynamics, unemployment, labor turnover, job duration, wage setting institutions, the role of unions, human capital formation, the relationship between economic status and other aspects of well-being (including health). Economists are essential partners in the behavioral study of preferences and decision making, mobility and redistribution, and the institutions of industrial relations that govern the labor market.
title: Economic Perspectives on Inequality (Half-Term)

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: This class will meet from 11/6/2017 to 12/15/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Two major areas of psychology make important contributions to the study of social policy and inequality. The first is social psychology, which focuses on inter-group relations, interpersonal perception, stereotyping, racism, aggression, justice and fairness. These are the micro-level building blocks of structural inequalities and processes that are shaped by the larger context of race, ethnic and gender relations. The second domain involves the fields of social-cognition, judgment and decision making, areas of research that study human information processing in a way that is not about individual differences, and often not social.
title: Psychological Studies of Inequality (Half-Term)

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. The workshop is designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.
title: Religion in the Americas Workshop

otherinfo: Graduate students will take the midterm written exam, but will write a paper on selected topics in virology in lieu of a final exam. Graduate students will also attend a separate preceptorial session lead by a postdoctoral fellow where seminal papers in virology are analyzed and discussed.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Other Exam - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Assigned readings from literature or selected texts prior to class discussion
descrip: Viruses are unique parasites of living cells and may be the most abundant, highest evolved life forms on the planet. The general strategies encoded by all known viral genomes are discussed using selected viruses as examples. The first half of the course covers the molecular biology (the tactics) inherent in these strategies. The second half introduces the biology of engagement of viruses with host defenses, what happens when viral infection leads to disease, vaccines and antiviral drugs, and the evolution of infectious agents and emergence of new viruses.
title: Viruses: Strategy and Tactics

evals: A great course to learn all the grammar basics Portuguese in a semester. This course is best for those who have a strong knowledge of Spanish that won't be too confused by Portuguese. There is a lot of work (frequent compositions, quizzes, daily homework, a presentation, a midterm and final), but it is worth it if you really want to learn Portuguese! I improved so much over the course of the semester from where I started with no knowledge in speaking, writing, or listening. Andrea is also a great professor who is super nice and very willing to help you if you need it -- all you have to do is ask her. If you're up for the time commitment and have a desire to learn Portuguese, I highly recommend this course!
Andrea is an amazing teacher and makes of your introduction to Portuguese an exciting and interesting journey.

If you are a Spanish native speaker or have already taken advanced Spanish courses, this is an extremely intense and extremely gratifying course you will definitely enjoy. Although it requires a good deal of work out of the classroom, it is completely worth it. Portuguese is a beautiful language and, most of all, a great gateway to the incredible Lusophone world. You won't regret it.
Take the course. You will learn Portuguese very quickly and efficiently. Andrea de Castro will be the best professor you will take a course with at Princeton. I guarantee it.

The best professor I have ever had. The best class at Princeton. Funny, intelligent, challenging. I do not have enough words to say how grateful I am with her. Every class with her was an amazing rollercoast, always stimulating. THANKS, ANDREA!
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Emphasis will be on oral communication in class. Students must commit to daily preparation of grammar to ensure efficient use of class time.
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.
title: Intensive Portuguese

evals: Definitely take this class!  Professor Schwalm is one of the best professors I have ever had.  She is really good at explaining concepts, is willing to meet and help students outside of class, and is a fair grader.  She doesn't really try to trick you and is really just committed to helping you learn a lot and become more interested in biology.  She definitely did that for me.  Therefore isn't too much work so it is definitely manageable and the material is fascinating.
Go to lecture and office hours to make sure you're understanding the most important parts.
Great course. Really interesting and informational. Take if at all interested in disease and things like that.
I strongly recommend this course if you are interested in medicine. The subject material is very interesting and we go into detail about many interesting diseases.
If you have an interest in viruses or bacteria and their medical implications, take this course.

It's a really great course! You learn about the mechanisms of how the common pathogens (e.g. TB, malaria, ebola, HIV) are associated with the particular symptoms they cause and how antibiotics work. Very up to date with current events.
Just pay attention during lectures and you'll be fine.
One of the easier upper-level MOL classes, taking it as a MOL major can be tedious since it's just a broad overview of stuff we've already learned
