Pretty easy and pretty interesting.
Take it - it's an awesome course! The material is really interesting and not a lot of work.
Take it if you are extremely interested in the subject matter. It requires a significant amount of studying for the midterm and final, and a lot of attention during lectures.
Take it if you're motivated to learn a lot, attend every lecture 3 times a week, and engage in discussion.

Take it! Make sure to go to lecture - taking notes on the slides is probably a good way to go about it - and review each week as you're doing the problem sets, and you won't need to spend too much time cramming for the exam! Professor Schwalm is great!

Unless they change this course, I wouldn't recommend it. The topic of material is just way too broad to go into any significant depth in any topic. It ends up just being memorization of basic principles of a variety of topics. This could be an interesting class if they tweaked it a little bit or if you are interested in a very broad shallow course.
interesting and manageable class
probably shouldnt take it.. especailly if you're MOL you wont find it very satisfying
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Readings will be assigned from selected texts, 10-20 pages per week. Primary research literature will be assigned as relevant to course topics over the course of the semester.
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215, ISC 231-234, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Microbiology is a broad subject that encompasses medicine, the earth's environment, and industry. This course will investigate the evolution of microbes, their requirements for growth, and aspects of their metabolism. The importance of microbes in industry, recombinant engineering, and genomics will also be addressed. On the medical front, we depend on microbes for our survival but also must content with deadly pathogens. Topics will include the study of microorganisms in selected areas of infectious disease, with a focus on viral, bacterial, and parasitic modes of action.
title: Modern Microbiology and Disease

evals: Do the readings because you'll love them. They're actually super exciting and you'll be really proud of yourself at the end of the semester. Students are self-selecting in this course and that's really gratifying in the discussion and it is only enhanced when you really have appreciated the readings.
Take this course if you have any interest whatsoever!
Take this course! Professor Weisenfeld is an excellent professor and the material is very interesting and relevant. It is a lot of reading but on the whole the course is manageable.
Take this! Professor Weisenfeld is wonderful, and it will be composed of a self selecting group of interesting, thoughtful students
There are a lot of readings, so please do not take this course lightly. It will be fully worth it, though.
This has been my favorite seminar at Princeton. It's a lot of reading, but worth the work.
there is quite a bit of reading that you have to be accountable for but the course is really enjoyable!!
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 150-200 pages of reading per week, mid-term paper, final research paper and in-class presentation.
descrip: In this seminar we examine the tangled and shifting relationship between religion and race in American history. In doing so, we explore a broad landscape of racial construction, identity, and experience and consider such topics as American interpretations of race in the Bible, religion and racial slavery, race and missions, religion, race, and science, popular culture representations of racialized religion, and religiously-grounded resistance to racial hierarchy.
title: Race and Religion in America

evals: A very interesting course on personal identity, raising many metaphysical and moral issues. Mark Johnston is very capable of explaining the material and his own papers are excellent. Some of the readings are very technical, however. And the lectures can sometimes sway far off-topic.
If you take this class, meet with Johnston for office hours - he's fun to talk to and also great at further explaining the material.
Interesting course, but know going in that the content will be very specific to Professor Johnston's work. It is not a general introduction to Personal Identity, but it will get you thinking

Johnston focuses on his own contributions to the topic more than he probably should, but the class is still definitely worthwhile if you're interested in learning about personal identity, and he sometimes brings in interesting arguments from other areas in philosophy (mind, ontology) as well, which is nice.

Johnston is an expert on the subject and passionate about teaching it to students which is a great mix. Oddly enough, he really struggles to directly answer questions which can be frustrating. Word of caution- though grading is not very harsh the material is very advanced so I would recommend having some solid exposure to philosophy before taking it
Take it! This course is fantastic and will likely change your views on identity and what matters

Take this if you're interested in metaphysics! If you don't care at all about metaphysics, stay away as this class is not for the faint of heart. It gets quite metaphysically technical, but would be interesting to metaphysically minded philosophy majors (or people with adequate philosophy experience).
grading: Other Exam - 50%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately 30 pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course will focus on the conditions for personal identity over time, with implications for the beginning and end of life. We will investigate what it is rational to care about in caring about survival or continued existence, and whether our account of what it is rational to care about should change if we discover either that (1) there is no human soul or (2) no self or subject behind our various conscious acts.
title: Personal Identity

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%
assgts: Student is expected to read 20-40 pages/week (occasionally a little more)
prereqs: One philosophy course or permission of instructor..
descrip: The course will explore various kinds of relativism: cultural relativism about beliefs concerning matters of fact; conceptual relativism, deriving from claims about the existence of distinct and, perhaps, incompatible conceptual schemes; something called "epistemic relativism"; and moral relativism of various kinds. We will look for the common structure of the various relativisms--if there is one--and explore whether relativism in any of these domains is plausible.
title: Relativism

evals: Be prepared for a lot of reading, but definitely take the course; the discussions are consistently high-quality.

Do the readings and watch the films. They are some of the most interesting materials you'll encounter here. Otherwise, Professor Borneman always has something interesting to say, so participate in discussion too.
Only take if you are interested in the material, otherwise the readings are dense and uninteresting.
Take it! Stay on top of the reading and have fun with it.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 100-150 pp. of reading per week. Students will write 6 abstracts (3 pp. each) during the semester. The seminar will be discussion-driven. Final grade will be based on abstracts and participation in discussion, take-home midterm, and a final research paper of 10 pp. on a subject of student's choice (approved by Instructor) related to a seminar theme, due on Dean's Date.
descrip: We focus on how humans deal with traumatic loss through three major approaches to memory: psychoanalysis (Freud), social organization (Halbwachs), associative temporalities (Sebald). We examine genres in which the memory of loss is retained or displaced. How is a traumatic past experienced individually and collectively? We consider memory from different cultural landscapes and theoretical perspectives. A better understanding of the memory of loss, and the social forms and histories in which this memory remains active, will improve our approaches to cultural observation, documentation, analysis, and interpretation.
title: Memory, Trauma, Accountability

evals: I think environmental science and policy are some of the most important topics of this century, so I definitely recommend others to take it

I would recommend this course for anyone who wants a broad introduction to environmental challenges, and the technology and policy focused on mitigating them. The in-class discussions are great, although the problem set are a little uninteresting.

I would recommend this course with reservation. On the one hand, Professor Mauzerall is an incredible source of information. Her work on the co-benefits of climate change and air quality is very unique, from my experience, and she knows a ton and is very dedicated to environmental issues. The class also covers a TON of information. THAT SAID, the negatives are rather numerous as well - hour and a half PPT slides can be long and boring; discussions will either be too simple or hopelessly complex depending on if you're an engineer or a woody woo major (and the class is an even balance between the two); psets are generally long, onerous, and unnecessarily time-consuming; a final presentation, paper, and test is likewise excessive and unnecessary; sometimes it feels like the prof asks discussion questions with a very specific answer in mind. But at the same time, you do learn a ton! Take if you know you're interested in environmental issues; definitely not for those seeking to initially explore these topics.

Maybe not the best choice for WWS science policy as it stands. If you take it, it's manageable, but be careful to leave lots of time for the Psets because its hard to predict how long it will take to complete them.
Not great, take if required.
Professor Mauzerall is an extremely resourceful and friendly professor with a ton of insight. Participate in class discussions and you will learn a lot while enjoying your time in the class.
Take it if you can, this is an extremely good class.
Take it! It's a great class with a good balance between lecture and discussion. Problem sets and assignments were fair.
Take this course! Seminar discussion is interesting and material is relevant to environmental issues facing the world today.

Unless this is a required departmental, I would not recommend taking this course. Problem sets take way too long and we never got grades back. Way too much work for a fall semester senior in my opinion.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Approximately 50-75 pages of reading per week. Mid-term and final papers.
prereqs: AP Chemistry, CHM 201, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines a set of global environmental issues including population growth, ozone layer depletion, climate change, air pollution, the environmental consequences of energy supply and demand decisions and sustainable development. It provides an overview of the scientific basis for these problems and examines past, present and possible future policy responses. Individual projects, presentations, and problem sets are included.
title: Global Environmental Issues

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
prereqs: WWS 507 and 511. Please see instructor to apply for enrollment..
descrip: About well-being throughout the world, with focus on income and health. Explores what happened to poverty, inequality, and health, in the US, and internationally. Discusses conceptual foundations of national and global measures of inequality, poverty, and health; construction of measures, and extent to which they can be trusted; relationship between globalization, poverty, and health, historically and currently. Examines links between health and income, why poor people are less healthy and live less long than rich people.
title: Poverty, Inequality and Health in the World

evals: Professor Bellos is a delight, and if you're interested in translation, this is a great class that'll help you think about it from a lot of different angles. If you're perhaps put off by a less-than-stellar experience in TRA 200, know that this class is very different, not least because the professor is probably different.
Unfortunately it's a requirement for the certificate course, but you'll get through it.
You'll enjoy this course if you have an interest in learning about the broad field of Translation studies!
otherinfo: Open to Sophomores, Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings (approximately 100 pages). Weekly presentations by students. Two papers (a shorter paper in lieu of a midterm and a longer essay in lieu of a final exam)
prereqs: Prerequisite: TRA 200 or (for graduate students) an equivalent.
descrip: A required course for students taking the certificate in Translation and Intercultural Communication but open to all who are interested in translation or any of its aspects, that is in movements between languages of any sort. Readings will focus on recent contributions to the emerging disciplines of translation studies across a wide spectrum of thematic fields (science, law, anthropology, literature, etc.). The seminar will incorporate the individual experiences of the students in their contact with different disciplines and idioms and, where relevant, in developing their senior theses. One three-hour seminar.
title: Senior Seminar in Translation and Intercultural Communication

evals: Absolutely avoid. Take MAE 328: Energy for  a Greenhouse-Constrained World for a reasonable, well-defined introduction to renewable energy technologies. When Wagner taught this class, the lecture material looked pretty good, but all of the assignments were unrelated, ill-conceived, and a poor use of everyone's time.
Anyone interested in energy and renewables MUST take this course.

I highly recommend this course as a survey of renewable energy concepts, and covers basic realms of power generation as well as the basic scientific principles and challenges behind each one. The lectures are interesting, and Professor Wagner knows a lot about renewable energy, particularly Solar PV. When considering this course, it might be useful to know the following:

? The problem sets require a lot of thought and time, but are not computationally difficult. They are largely open ended questions about estimating different aspects of implementing new technologies.
? Labs are not difficult, and are flexibly timed.
? There is very little numerical feedback on grading, although problem sets receive specific and general qualitative feedback.
If you like renewable energy, take this class
If you're at all interested in energy, take this course. Work load is what you make it, could be easy could be hard. Great professor and great attention.
otherinfo: This course fulfills a requirement for the Technology & Society: Energy Track and Sustainable Energy certificate programs.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: Six homework assignment problem sets, one-hour midterm examination, a final project and presentation (35%). Weekly reading assignment of 25 pages of textbook or web content, or review articles.
descrip: Principles and design of solar energy conversion systems. Quantity and availability of solar energy. Physics and chemistry of solar energy conversion: solar optics, optical excitation, capture of excited energy, and transport of excitations or electronic charge. Conversion methods: thermal, wind, photoelectric, photoelectrochemical, photosynthetic, biomass. Solar energy systems: low and high temperature conversion, photovoltaics. Storage of solar energy. Conversion efficiency, systems cost, and lifecycle considerations.
title: Solar Energy Conversion

evals: Great class
If you started Italian at Princeton, this course will be challenging. But the professors are very nice and understanding. Your language abilities will grow if you put in effort.
This course is very diverse and will give anyone his or her first experience with Italian academic work.

definitely take this course if you have any interest in italian culture/literature/history! Marchesi and Marrone-Puglia are both amazing and encourage you to think deeply about the readings. 3hrs seem very short with the engaging discussion.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%
assgts: Approx. 40 pages of reading per week; 4 short papers; mid-term and final.
prereqs: Italian 107 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is designed to give an overview of pivotal moments in Italian culture, such as the relationship between Church and Empire in the Middle Ages, Machiavelli's political theory during the Renaissance, and the rise and fall of Fascism in the 20th century. Through the examination of the most relevant intellectual, historic, and artistic movements and their main geographical venues, students will be able to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the development of Italian history and civilization.
title: Italian Civilization Through the Centuries

evals: A very open-ended class that the more you put in, the more you'll get out of it.  Come to class having done the reading, and you'll learn a lot.  Not too high a workload either.

Read a few scholarly scientific articles before signing up to make sure you enjoy the assignments. If you do, this is a great class for you. Also, it helps if you know a decent amount of biology before taking the class.
Read the papers, prepare well for your presentation
Take it. Awesome class.
Take it. It's a great discussion class, and learning about Biophysics is a great idea. Some of the concepts will blow your mind.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 40%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: One problem set every three weeks.
prereqs: Introductory Physics (PHY 103/104, PHY 105/106, ISC 231-234).
descrip: Biological Physics is one of the fastest growing areas of physics. This course focuses on both experimental and theoretical physics approaches to understanding biological molecules, cells, and tissues. We will start with an overview of the forces present within a cell that govern the activity of enzymes and the motion of molecular motors and the cytoskeleton. We then move on to discuss physical processes on the cellular level that give rise to motility, tissue development and differentiation. Emphasis will be placed on both techniques and scientific concepts. Classes will be a combination of lectures and student presentations.
title: Biological Physics

evals: Create a group to split up the readings because it's impossible to do it all on your own. Go to lecture during guest speakers - they're really interesting and offer so much to the course/your critical perspective on global health.

Definitely don't quit GHP based on this course. Pick what you are passionate about out of the many topics discussed and run with it for your final paper - there are so many amazing things to explore, and though the lectures can be dishearteningly dry, global health is important enough that the class is worth it.
Definitly take time to breakdown and understand the texts. Thats where most of the information for the course will be and they should definitely be understood to a deeper extent.

Don't take this class unless Professor Biehl is teaching it. Unfortunately, he was on sabbatical and couldn't teach it this semester but his one guest lecture was the ONLY one I enjoyed. It's a very relevant course with so much potential, but the material is presented poorly to the point where everyone is either asleep/doing other work.
Dont take unless Prof. Biehl is the professor.
Go to preceptor office hours and seek their advice on how to best approach discussion posts and papers!
Great course to take! Prepared to read a lot every week, especially between Monday and Wednesday. Don't be afraid to participate during lecture!
I didn't really feel like I gained anything major from this class that I wouldn't have been able to learn on my own. It wasn't a hard class, but it also wasn't as rewarding as I expected.

I have mixed feelings about this course -- I very much enjoyed learning about global health, but at the same time I feel like the class was a bit too critical. I now know what will make a global health endeavor fail, but not what will make it succeed. The course also felt a bit repetitive at times. Nevertheless, the class gives you some valuable perspectives on global health.
I obviously recommend the class if you are getting the certificate. Hopefully Professor Biel will be back because he is a dynamic lecturer. Overall, you get out of it what you put into it.
I wish I had the opportunity to take this with Professor Biehl. Overall, though, the course introduces you to a lot of great concepts, and if you're interested in GHP, you should definitely take it.

I would definitely encourage anyone with an interest in this area to take this class. It touches on several relevant and important topics that are both fascinating and that challenge our understanding of health nationally and internationally.

If Professor Biehl is taking it, definitely take it! If not, it's still worth it (even if you're not doing the GHP program) if you are really interested in global health and want to broaden your perspectives.

If you have to take this class, you have to take it. It's basically a survey course so you will talk about everything but nothing in depth. The basic themes are "The WHO sucks" and "here are all the problems we have with the world but can't fix". You don't really need to attend lecture, but you do need to the readings up to the midterm. Guest lecturers are usually pretty good and they are amazing field workers that have incredible perspectives (wouldn't miss those classes). Overall, I wouldn't take this class for fun; there are other GHP courses that are much more narrow in topic and much more interesting.
Interesting and a probably requirement, not super interesting if Joao's not teaching it though
Interesting subject matter. boring (yet required) lectures that could easily be 50 minutes.  The guest lecturers are amazing though (and thankfully the majority of the course)!
Intro course. Good readings.
It's a core course for GHP, so you kind of have to take it. I heard that Professor Biehl is amazing, and I think he's teaching it next year.
Just hammer through the course and make sure you secure your grade with the midterm and final. From what I understand, the instruction changes more often than one would anticipate.
Keep up with readings for your own personal benefit, you learn about a lot of really interesting topics you may not have had much exposure to before
Keep up with the readings for each lecture and begin discussion posts early!
Only take it if you have to, and don't try to do all the readings, impossible and unnecessary. Very boring class, both in terms of lectures, and in terms of content.
Only take this if you have to.
Pick the relevant readings. Don't need to read 5 articles with the same message/point. Recommend if Biehl is teaching.
Spread readings through out the week as there are a lot of readings! Lecture notes are useful for studying for midterms.
Take it if you need it!
Take it! Lectures can be a bit dry, but you will get the most out of this course by doing all the readings!

Take it, but make sure Professor Biehl is doing it. Careful with the fact its non-pdf. If you have the luxury to explore global health (as in you have a free floating spot or a class when it happens to be taught) and don't want to do the certificate then definitely consider it.
Take this class in a year when Professor Biehl is teaching it. Still interesting otherwise, but lectures quite boring without Professor Biehl.

Take this class! Everyone needs to learn and be challenged by the history of western medicine and their imposition over the world. Great critical environment and readings whether you are in the certificate or not.
Take this only if you have to. Make sure you have Joao Biehl otherwise it is really really boring and you won't learn that much

The readings can be super dense, try to have a study group to review them together. Basically pick two-three that you want to write your discussion post on and read in depth. Participate in precept for sure.

There's a ton of reading in this course, but the content of the reading is very interesting. Writing assignments aren't too bad: weekly discussions posts (1 page each), take-home midterm (2 short essays), and a final paper (10-12 pages). As long as you don't fall behind with the readings, you should be fine.

This course is definitely interesting, especially if you haven't participated in any formal study of global health. However, this year's lecturers were not the most engaging and many students would leave halfway through lecture.. They did try hard so hopefully next year will be better or with a different professor.
This is a fair introduction to global health. You'll know if you GHP after the first two readings. Expect a lot of reading and writing.

This is a great course. It provides a great introduction to global health issues and is very informative in learning relevant topics. Even if you have to take this for a requirement, it really is a well-run, engaging course!
This is an interesting course that you should take if interested in global medicine.
You'll need to take it for GHP certificate, but it was not as engaging as I was expecting, but that could be because the original lecturer was not available this year.
interesting, but the amount you get out of it really depends on the amount of time you are willing to spend
keep up with the weekly readings. find specific case studies that interest you from the start.
otherinfo: This course is required for GHP certificate students.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: A weekly 1-page summary of questions and comments that arise during readings (average 200 pp/week). A research paper (10-12 pg) on a well-defined topic of global health policy in consultation with instructors.
descrip: Global health brings together a vast array of actors working to address urgent health issues worldwide with unprecedented financial and technological resources. This course is a critical analysis of the cultural, social, political and economic processes related to this expanding medical and humanitarian field. As we scrutinize the evidence-making practices, agendas and value systems informing global health, we will place current interventions in historical perspective and gauge their benefits and unintended consequences. Students are encouraged to find new and collaborative ways to understand and act in and through the field of global health.
title: Critical Perspectives in Global Health

otherinfo: Precept meets for 2 hours.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: About 50-80 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level Italian course or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will explore the ways in which national identity was imagined and implemented within Italian literature, culture, and cinema before, during, and after the period of Italian unification in the mid-XIX century. Examples are drawn from a wide range of literary, artistic and cultural media.
title: Risorgimento, Opera, Film

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A course required for and limited to students in the Joint Degree program in Social Policy. Papers drafted in the year-long course WWS 590a,b,c,d must be revised and submitted to the workshop leader by August 20. Papers will be provided to an expert reader outside of the Princeton faculty, who is invited to join the seminar for sessions devoted to each student paper. Each student will present his/her own paper and simultaneously contribute written critiques of one another's papers. By the end of the term, students will be required to submit their papers for publication to a leading journal.
title: Workshop in Social Policy

otherinfo: This class will meet from 09/13/17 to 10/27/17. To apply, visit http://writing.princeton.edu/wse/graduate-writing-courses/wri-503
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Each week, students will write a new section of a research article on their own work. Reading assignments will include examples of published research articles and drafts of articles composed by members of the class.
prereqs: Course is open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.
title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering

evals: If you're interested in the Middle East or literature then you should take this course!
Take it for the amazing books and the interesting (though somewhat unstructured) discussions. Prof Levy is quite knowledgeable and the class is rewarding.

The readings are phenomenal.  If you are interested in learning more about the Middle East and reading some very interesting (mostly contemporary) novels, take it.  Professor Levy really knows the material.
This is an amazing class.  Professor Levy is wonderful and the literature you read really provides a glimpse into the past and present realities of Middle Eastern life.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Programming Assignments - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%
assgts: In addition to novels, a number of critical articles will be assigned. There will be a midterm and a final paper. 200 - 250 pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course examines how Arab writers and filmmakers represent social and political issues such as the aftermath of colonization, labor migration, civil war, authoritarianism, and women's rights. It covers novels and film from Egypt, the Sudan, Lebanon, Palestine, Libya, Algeria, Syria, and Iraq, on the Syrian civil war, the Arab Spring, the Lebanese Civil War, the Palestinian struggle, Islamic fundamentalism, and Ba'athist Iraq. The course will also address the role of Arabic literature and film as social and political critique. All readings and films are in English translation.
title: Politics and Society in the Arabic Novel and Film

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 150 pages per week of reading; one 5-6 page paper.
descrip: This course considers the role of both mass media and social media in American politics and the influence of the media on Americans' political attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors. We will examine the nature of news and news-making organizations, the role of the news media in electoral campaigns, how the media shape the behavior of politicians once in office, political advertising, and the ability of social media to facilitate collective action.
title: Mass Media, Social Media, and American Politics

evals: A rare chance to study and develop meditation practice in a Princeton classroom.  Could save your life!  Course work is not difficult if you're paying attention, and for once is considered secondary to gaining useful knowledge and practical experience.  Who'd have thunk!

An interesting class where you'll learn a lot. I wouldn't take it if you're looking for an easy A because theres a significant amount of reading and the responses are occasionally pretty tough.  Professor Gold is very knowledgable but often seems rather disorganized.

I honestly took this course only because it looked like the most interesting EC, but it turned out to be one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Princeton. Professor Gold is awesome and the seminars flew by so fast. The meditation component was also really interesting.
Prof Gold is wonderful! But if you're only taking this course because of the practical meditation component you might be disappointed because the seminars are more analytical.

Prof. Gold is very thoughtful about his structure for the course, and simply hearing him talk about his research and his interests in the field of Buddhist Studies is worthwhile. Good for those who already know something about meditation and for those who don't.

Take this class! Extremely interesting and taught by a great professor. Prof. Gold is reasonable, approachable/helpful, and has a fun sense of humor that makes for an enjoyable class dynamic. The subject of Buddhism is really interesting and it's especially cool to see how mindfulness and meditation has seeped into our everyday culture.
Very interesting course. Only take it if you are willing to put in the work and do the reading.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately 100-150 pages of reading per week, regular participation in the seminar, weekly written responses to readings, regular meditation practice log and journal, oral presentation, one 12-page paper due on Dean's date.
descrip: This course examines the philosophy, history, and methods of Buddhist meditation. Primary readings will be Buddhist works on the nature of the mind and the role of meditation on the path to liberation (nirvana). We will ask how traditional Buddhist views have been reshaped by modern teachers, and we will interrogate the significance of current research on meditation in the fields of neuroscience, psychology and the philosophy of mind. In addition to other coursework, students will be practicing meditation and keeping a log and journal. Some coursework in Philosophy or Religion is expected.
title: Mind and Meditation

evals: An amazing course. I gained so much from this course, Saki is an incredible preceptor, work is well taught, exams are fair, so much to learn!

As a non-quantitative humanities person, I took this course to challenge myself and step outside of my comfort zone. Although I PDF'd it, I thought it was a well-taught course with a great round of interesting lecturers. Saki was awesome! Make sure to get her as a preceptor, especially if you're not familiar with R and/or have trouble grasping the math concepts.

Definitely take this class if you are interested in disease ecology at all, even if you don't have a science background. The quantitative stuff is very manageable and you learn some skills that you can apply to other research environments in the social sciences. Really interesting, with fair grading and assessments.
Don't do the readings unless you don't understand the graphics in the lecture slides.
Engaging STN that educates about contemporary issues. Possibly political.
Go to all the lectures and precepts and don't be afraid to ask questions!

I would strongly recommend this course. From the perspective of a WWS major, the science is accessible and none of the assignments are too demanding. The problems presented are important ones, and both Professor Grenfell and the many guest lecturers are engaging teachers.
If you're EEB/GHP/WW take this course! Opens your mind to disease dynamics.

If you're interested in public health. If you're a premed who is interested in policy....do it.

Even if it's not you're primary interest, it's super interesting to just learn about.

There is some math required. I think it was very helpful for me to already have had exposure to disease modeling and R.
Pay attention to the derivations, if you don't understand ask questions! The whole course keeps revisiting them, so make sure you have a solid grasp on them.

Take this class, you will not regret it! I know that a lot of students were Woody Woo, so this is only from an EEB perspective: I was blown away by this class. The material Professor Grenfell teaches can be challenging to wrap your mind around, especially the modelling bits, but the most redeeming moment was in a guest lecturer who spoke about the practical applications across the world in the form of smallpox eradication and cholera treatment. Although there is math and modelling involved, Saki does a phenomenal job of going through the material during precept. (That being said, if Saki is still precepting, take her section!) Overall, I loved the course and feel that the poster project was a very satisfying way to synthesize all of the material in the semester. I definitely came out with a better understanding of diseases, and you will too.
Take this course if you are interested in learning about health policy or want an easy introduction to disease modeling and dynamics.

Take this course if you are interested in the content. It is very relevant to today and is something anyone interested in the bigger picture and the intersection of disease ecology, economics and policy.

Take this course! Probably one of the best classes I've taken here! Lectures can be a little dry (powerpoint based), but the content is always fascinating and professor Grenfell does a good job of breaking up the monotony by interspersing activities between slides. The professor is extremely kind, and the assignments are easily doable if you pay attention during class and precept.
Take this course! Professor Grenfell is amazing, and you learn so many cool things!

This course is challenging at times, but it is rewarding and interesting. Professors Grenfell, Laxminarayan, and Metcalf are absolutely fantastic lecturers. I would recommend taking this if you're an EEB major looking for a class that integrates mathematical modeling with policy. Fair warning though, there is a substantial amount of modeling involved.

This is a good course. However, you might not get so much out of it if you're getting the GHP certificate and have already taken those classes. The economics portion was interesting, but the rest was kind of boring, because it was information I had already learned once or twice before in other lectures.
Worth taking if you have interest in disease on the global scale. Interesting although the lectures drag on. Not too difficult.
a good course but a lot of work!
not a ton of Econ concepts but pretty good
otherinfo: Other 45% = graded weekly journal assignments (20%), and a poster presentation at the end of the semester (25%).
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 45%
assgts: Students will read assignments from primary journals (approx. 30 pages per week). Students will be assigned a paper to present in class. During the second half of the course, students will present draft versions of their term paper in class.
prereqs: Calculus is required. Moreover, you should be comfortable with differential equations and algebraic manipulation..
descrip: The dynamics of the emergence and spread of disease arise from a complex interplay between disease ecology, economics, and human behavior. Lectures will provide an introduction to complementarities between economic and epidemiological approaches to understanding the emergence, spread, and control of infectious diseases. The course will cover topics such as drug-resistance in bacterial and parasitic infections, individual incentives to vaccinate, the role of information in the transmission of infectious diseases, and the evolution of social norms in healthcare practices.
title: Disease Ecology, Economics, and Policy

evals: Barbara changed the format of the course from the traditional lecture style to a project-based course. You don't learn as much this way.
Basically a project course, with weekly presentations. Take it for hands-on experience, to see what people are doing in ML in practice.

Get started early thinking about what you want your project to look like; you will be working on it all semester. Barbara is very helpful and available, and is flexible about the questions that you want to answer in your project.
If the course is anything like this year's, be ready to spend a lot of time. You get what you put in. Still a cool course.
Prepare to spend a lot of time working on the class project; lots of unexpected issues arise when working with real data.
Read the abstracts of the papers listed in the syllabus to decide if you'll be able to use this class.
The class is quite helpful, and the project is fun. Make sure to spend time thinking about the readings if you want to get things out of the class meetings.

This course is mostly "do a project" - if you want to do a project, it's excellent! If you want a more traditional class, look for something else, though I hear the next version of this course may be taught differently (in the style of the 2010 version of this course).

This course is very project-based. I recommend going into it with a good idea of the kind of data analysis you want to do and some idea how to do it; otherwise it's easy to waste time figuring out how.

This is an excellent course if you have already familiar with Bayesian inferences. Warning to die-hard deep learning guys: consider again before taking this course because we are going to be serious about generative models. Also if you have an interesting data analysis/mining idea but haven't got the chance or tool to explore. This class will guide you though it.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: Probabilistic modeling is essential for modern data analysis, providing essential tools for analyzing the vast amount of data that have become available in science, scholarship, and everyday life. This course will cover the mathematical and algorithmic foundations of probabilistic statistical models, as well as methods underlying the current state of the art models.
title: Foundations of Probabilistic Modeling

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A survey of recent work on the nature of moral responsibility and related matters.
title: Ethics - Recent Work on Responsibility

otherinfo: Course will meet from 09/14/17 to 10/27/17. To apply, visit http://writing.princeton.edu/wse/graduate-writing-courses/wri-501
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Two to three research articles will be assigned as readings each week. Writing assignments will include weekly informal responses of 2-3 pages and a 1200-to 1500-word literature review in the student's area of research.
prereqs: Course is open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.
title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science & Engineering

evals: Best PDF ever; moderately hard to get a good grade; almost no work.
Definitely take it if you are interested in the process of drug discovery. Prof Reider will give you a great primer to the whole industry.
Don't take this course if you don't already have a background. It's not worth it.
Exams are kind of luck dependent since you may not understand the wording and get screwed over. But the content is new and interesting if you have had no drug discovery classes before.
Great class! Definitely take this - very little work, but is still very interesting and engaging
Great course, perfect for anyone who has a general interest in drug discovery and development
Having more knowledge of organic chemistry would probably be helpful, as most of the teachers come from that field.
Horribly disappointing, yes it isn't any work but the grading is arbitrary. Don't expect to get an A, but you probably won't get anything lower than a B .

I liked the lectures! paul has a lot of cool stories to tell. its different than most science lectures, but in my opinion, it's much more understandable and you get a lot out of it. not too much, but i highly recommend

If you need an upper level chemistry class for premed, go for it. Good insight into the pharmaceutical industry. Be aware though you are not guaranteed an A, because grading can be harsh on small mistakes.
It's a good course if you're interested at all in the pharmaceutical industry.
Offered for the last time in Fall 2017 so sorry to those who missed out.
Take it! I learned a lot about the drug discovery process and the stories were interesting.

Take this class. Yes I am sure you have heard that it is easy, but please value your time with professor Reider. This is a man who has done so, so much for humanity and there is so much that he can teach you about chemistry, drug discovery, and life in general. Take the class, enjoy it, and do not stress out about learning every little thing or bugging preceptors about what is going to be on the exam. Take enjoy the class, take good notes, and enjoy it.
Take this course! I learned more from Prof Reider's lectures than I have in most other courses. The course info is relevant and important, even if you don't plan to work in pharma.
Take this if you're interested in learning about the drug discovery industry, how science is done, and how decisions are made.

The amount of time I spent on this course was 3 hours a week. That's the number of lecture hours per week. It's very little work, but you don't get too much out of it, either. Interesting stories about HIV protease drug, though.
The best part of the class is Dr. Reider. Get to know him as a human being, because he's the biggest asset.
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Readings from the current literature.
prereqs: Two semesters of organic chemistry (CHM 301 & 302 OR CHM 303 & 304/304B) or the equivalent..
descrip: A detailed review of recent successes and failures in the discovery of new drugs. Therapeutic areas to be discussed include: HIV, oncology, asthma, Alzheimer's Disease, antibiotics, diabetes, and neglected diseases (malaria, TB, human African Trypaonosomiasis). Case studies presented by leading pharmaceutical scientists will complement discussions of the functional steps required to select a target, indentify a new chemical entity, and get it to patients. The course will emphasize the integration of the molecular sciences and the role of chemistry in inventing and producing important new medicines.
title: Drug Discovery in the Genomics Era

evals: Fairly interesting course that has a different lecturer each week and precept afterwards with the class professor. Not much consistency between each week so each lecture can be looked at in isolation.
I believe you should take if you are interested in Europe and want to learn more about the continent's culture.

I would recommend taking this course earlier in your Princeton career so that, after gaining exposure to the range of topics and thinkers that the it covers, you have time to take other courses that offer a more in-depth focus on the ones you most enjoyed.

It is an interesting course covering a very wide range of topics in European culture and politics? I expected it to be entirely focused on culture, but it is important to note that there are many readings that are focused more on political theory (Marx, etc.)  The seminar itself is very laid back, as it is a guest lecturer each week, followed by a precept discussion, but students are responsible for reading ~1 book each week to prepare for this lecture by writing a short "journal entry."
Take it, and do all the readings. Even if they're long sometimes, I guarantee it's worth it. Ask lots of questions.
The readings are very interesting, but take a lot of deep analysis to fully grasp.

This course gives you a smattering of knowledge about various important figures in European history, but I would not recommend it unless you have to take it for either the ECS and/or EPS certificates. You would be much better off taking a course on one of the figures. I felt shortchanged when I finished this course because I felt that I did not gain enough in-depth knowledge about any figure or time period in particular.
This is a tolerable class if you must take it for the certificate, though probably the worst possible venue in which to read the text's at hand.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Weekly reading or viewing assignments; mid-term paper; paper in lieu of final exam.
descrip: Co-taught by Professors Spyros Papapetros (Architecture) and Eileen Reeves (Comparative Literature), and drawing on the expertise of distinguished Princeton faculty and visitors, this seminar aims to provide a broad, multidisciplinary perspective on turning points in European culture from the early modern period to the present. It serves as the core course for the Program in European Cultural Studies (ECS) and the Program in Contemporary European Politics and Society (EPS).
title: Turning Points in European Culture

evals: A good STN to PDF: an interesting subject with a dynamic lecturer that isn't too difficult, and meant for non-experts. Readings aren't required to pass--only regular lecture attendance and diligent note-taking.
A good class to take for science distributions; very little work and interesting/important subject material.
A good course. Super super relevant to the future. I'd definitely take it as and STL or STN.

A majority of the course is only based off the of the lectures, therefore the reading from the textbook is not that important. Also, give yourself a lot of time for the quizzes because it can take a lot of time to find the information in the lecture slides. Make sure you are interested in the topic before taking the course!

A really interesting PDF for a non-science major looking to do a STN.  Not too demanding, great lectures, and you'll become informed about climate to an extent that you can seriously understand policy and policy implications.
Actually go to lecture, review only the important graphs, diagrams and points from week-to-week and the class is a cakewalk. Don't do that and you will regret it.

Be sure to COME TO CLASS. This seems to be an issue among a lot of the people taking this course for the sake of the distribution, but the in-class assignments and explanations from Professor Sigman were definitely necessities.
DO NOT take this course. It's very, very, very dull. Take another STN, any other one.
Decent course to PDF for a distribution requirement and does teach you a good amount about climate change.
Definitely a good choice for a fairly easy STN

Definitely take it if you're looking to fulfill a STN (didn't take as STL, so don't know if that's as good.) I took it as a STN to PDF, but decided not to later on. The professors are very willing to help you succeed, as long as you put in the effort. It's a really self-explanatory class!
Definitely take this class if you're planning on pdfing.

Dont underestimate it and realize how important the course is. Unfortunately the material is not the easiest to get, but in the next 4 years it is important that young people care more about Earth's climate.
Easy PDF but a lot of work. Quizzes are hard. Don't get the book.
Easy PDF or A. Quizzes and homework assignments can be tricky, but the average is low enough to easily get curved up to a good grade.
Easy enough STN but takes work to synthesize all of the material.
Fun and interesting course and not too much work at all.
Go to lecture and listen! If you do, this class is totally manageable for an STN requirement.
Go to lecture and pay attention.
Good option for STN but watch out for the final! Get good grades on the quizzes as you go so that if you do poorly on the final, you'll be okay.
Good, really easy pdf.
Great
Great STN. Relatively easy and interesting. Definitely take it.

Honestly, this class is fine for an STN- I don't know if there are better options- but it's one of my least favorite classes I've taken at Princeton. It's not really the professors' fault, though, and you'll get through it with a P (probably) without too much strife.
I would recommend taking the course if you are interested in climate change at a generic level. While some of the concepts are confusing overtime it all begins to make sense.
I would recommend this to another student looking to satisfy an STL or a thirst for climate-related knowledge.
I would say you have to keep up with the content.
If you need STN requirement filled, take this class it is really interesting and gives us a better understanding of earths climate

If you need an STN, this course is not too hard. I didn't end up even needing to PDF it. Lectures are posted online too so you don't even have to go except for that participation grade. Also, the quizes are open book with no time limit, which is pretty nice.

If you need to fulfill a science requirement, take this over any other class! Daniel and Catherine are super cool and the stuff you learn in class applies to a lot of relevant conversations going on in the real world.
If you would like a digestible intro to climate science/climate change, this is a good course to take.
Interesting course and overall not too difficult. If the subject interests you, go for it!
It will be a lot easier if you attend lecture and take some notes!
It's a great class to learn about simple earth science and Prof Sigman is great!
It's good way to fulfill a requirement, but not the most stimulating course--I'm glad I took it, as the professors were very much behind the students and their successful completion of the course.

Keep up with the readings to fully understand the lectures. It is a wonderful course to take, especially if you are interested in climate/weather/environmental policy. It's detailed science, but not overwhelmingly so.
Make sure to pay attention in lectures, which are pretty important in this course especially.
Not the worst STN to take if you need one, especially if you're PDFing. Everyone should know at least a little bit about the climate, and you'll definitely get that in this class.
Only take this course if you are genuinely interested in climate change and are ready to spend hours reviewing concepts that were taught quickly in lecture.
PDF the class if you can, but an A is very achievable if not. Go to lecture and pay attention, because it will make revision and assignments extremely easys.

Pretty easy STN. However, keep in mind that if you're not taking the lab section, since you are only attending two huge lectures a week, it is hard to feel connected to the class, especially if you don't find the subject matter interesting at all (like I did).
Probably the least painful way to PDF your STN.
Prof Sigman is hype and makes the class a lot more interesting than expected.

Really great STN. Well-organized course that's also pretty interesting (even for a humanities student). The instructors are fantastic. Professor Sigman tries really hard and his lectures are always super informative. Catherine is the nicest person ever and her office hours are super helpful!!!
Really read the lecture slides and pay attention in lecture - that's basically all you need to be successful in the course.

Really well-organized course.  The professors don't want you to fail, so they try to make each assignment as doable as possible.  Professor Sigman is so super nice and enthusiastic about his topic, which makes it a lot easier to sit through a long lecture.  I would recommend it if you need an STN or STL.
Take as STN and pdf
Take it if you have to. You'll learn something about climate change, which is important. It will also be, in general, a waste of your valuable time--but not more so than other STNs.
Take the course

Take the course! Also join me in getting further involved with local politics because the environmental future is extremely grim and I only learned more reasons that humanity's future will be challenged!
Take this class as an easy STN. Easy PDF
Take this class if you're interested in climate change in the past, and how that might affect the future. Lectures are entertaining, and overall, it's a fairly easy class if you show up.

Take this class! It will transform the way you think about the climate and the earth. You will be able to view reports about the climate with a new critical eye and hopefully also change other people's perspectives about the urgency of climate action.
Take this course for your STN/STL while learning about the environment in depth!

The class was well organized and the materials were interesting and well explained. As long as you pay attention in lecture there is not a lot of work outside of class. I've learned a lot about climate. The professors were amazing at explaining and making sure that students understand the materials.

This class gave me a sense of awe at the bigness of the universe. Professor Sigman is an amazing lecturer, and I wish I had gone to office hours with anyone earlier to clarify more of my questions. Also not too much work!

This class is a good PDF but definitely more work than it would seem. This course is very detail-oriented and takes a lot of detours in discussing climate change. It's really about climate as a whole with climate as a theme.
This class is well-organized, not difficult, and occasionally even interesting. Good ST distribution.

This is a dope class. Sometimes it gets bogged down in some technical science stuff but for the most part very interesting. The math is incredibly easy unless you had a hard time in middle school. Learning about glaciers was sick. Plus now you can tell your relatives why they're stupid or whatever
This is a great STN. Interesting if you attend lecture but not a necessity.
This is a great class to PDF for a distribution requirement. I would not take it otherwise.
This is an excellent course. I took it as an STN and learned a lot about the climate and the Earth in general. Go to lectures -- they are great.
This is an excellent intro class into climate change.  Paying attention to the lectures is key.  Take advantage of the office hours;  the teaching team is readily available.
Try your best to attend all of the lectures and attend office hours if you need additional help.

Very easy STN; you don't need the textbook or to go to lecture, really, though they are fairly painless to sit through. Professor Sigman is funny. The class is climate, not climate change, so be ready to learn about all the various topics that determine climate, and be warned that they are not especially fascinating, for the most part.
Very little coursework, but long and often dry lectures.
Was super excited to take this class and was disappointed. Not engaging and lectures were boring
a fine STN to PDF. don't have to go to class or do anything to get a P
fine for an STN to pdf
good class
yes
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Weekly readings will complement the lecture material. Four open-book online quizzes and two short assignments will reinforce key points.
descrip: Which human activities are changing our climate, and does climate change constitute a significant problem? We will investigate these questions through an introduction to climate processes and an exploration of climate from the distant past to today. We will also consider the implications of climate change for the global environment and humans. Intended to be accessible to students not concentrating in science or engineering.
title: Climate: Past, Present, and Future

evals: Do not take this course. Do any other course. If you do, take with the lab so that the pressure falls off the tests and stuff.
Easy PDF, but don't skip all the lectures. It's a pain trying to catch up.
Easy STL but long/boring lectures w participation marks for being there

Every first year should take this course! It is an easy way to satisfy your STL requirement, which if you don't do now can become an inconvenience later, and with a moderate amount of effort it is possible to get a good grade in this class. Although the lectures and labs can be uninteresting or tedious at times, this course informs you of the scientific mechanisms and theories responsible for global climate change so that you can effectively and intelligently convince people of the threat of global climate change. One warning: DO NOT TAKE AS STN?you will be lost in the class and probably earn a lower grade.
Great class to take as an STL - the labs are really fun.  The lectures are easy listening, and you don't need to do any of the readings.
I highly recommend this class as an easy STL. The labs are manageable and the lab TAs are incredibly helpful. The material of the course isn't difficult, but lectures can be really boring.

I took this to get my STL out of the way and I think it was a good decision. I'm pretty terrible at science in general, but the labs in this class were really doable and, in my opinion, were actually more informative than the lectures and readings. Would recommend to any non-sciencey people who are struggling to find a STL.

I would only suggest taking this course if you have a genuine interest in the topic. And by genuine, I don't mean "I acknowledge that climate change is a real and serious problem," I mean "I want to know why climate change is happening and what sets this change apart from any change that's happened before in Earth's history and what the future is set to look like if we continue doing what we've been doing." If THAT sounds like something you're genuinely interested in, then I'm sure you'll find this course to be intriguing and informative. If not, there are other ways for you to fulfill a distribution requirement. (Still, if you do enroll, here's my one big takeaway: Read the textbook! It's super helpful.)
I would recommend they take the lab with the lecture, attend office hours, and connect with other people in the class to talk through ideas in the course.

I'd recommend it for a STL. Not a bad course, I wouldn't say that every single lecture was super exciting for me (being a humanities person) but as the class went on I got the hang of the concepts and assignments. Lab is long, of course, but it gives you more things to be graded on, so the midterm and stuff aren't counted quite as much.
If you go to lecture, you will learn a lot and do well.
If you put in just the tiniest bit of effort, you will do well, especially if you take the lab version of this class.

If you're looking for an STL, take GEO. Professor Sigman is very funny and this class definitely can't be construed as a hard STL out to get you. The labs, of course, are time consuming, but if you go to lecture and really pay attention to the quizzes, it's theoretically feasible to pass.
Interesting class, great lab work

It is possible to do well in this class while paying ZERO attention in lecture. The labs are cute. Worked well for me as a social science concentrator, but I would not recommend this for any reason other than to fulfill the lab requirement.
It's not necessarily "Rocks for Jocks" as advertised. Some level of reading and attention is needed.

Really a great course. Lots of different components that play into the final grade so its really easy to get a good overall grade. Tons of help available - Professor Sigman, Catherine, and Danielle are awesome!

Take if you need a fairly easy STL, but don't take as an STN because the lab helps a lot with synthesizing the course material. It's not the most engaging class, but overall pretty interesting if you want to learn more about a highly relevant topic.
Take it for a distribution. Worth it.
Take it for your STL!!!!!!
Take it if you need STN/STL; labs are tedious but not that challenging, lecture is pretty boring but TAs are helpful
Take the course, Can get and A if you try or can pdf pretty easily. Taking the lab helps to understand the classes.

Take the lab. It isn't that much extra work, in fact it saves you work. The lab assignments give a good overview of all the topics you learn in class and allow you to look at the more complex topics in more detail. Because of the labs I only studied the day before the midterm and was able to get a B . Besides, it's a good way to get rid of your STL.
Take this class with the lab! It really helped me understand the lecture material! Students taking it as a STL had an advantage over the STN.
Take this class, not hard and interesting stuff about climate change. I learned a good amount.

Take this course - seriously (esp. to fulfill an STL requirement). It is so relevant and will equip you with the knowledge to understand and discuss climate change and the world around you. Profs are awesome, geo department is awesome, course is awesome!
Take this for an easy STL- take it with the lab though (if you do the labs they will most likely bring up your grade).
The course deals with a really interesting and important subject in a way that's totally accessible for nonscientists. Taking the lab really helps clarify lecture material, but means more work.
They should roll this course out online and make the world take it.

This course we be good as a distribution requirement, or if you are interested in geosciences. However, there is a lot of information presented, often very quickly, so I'd recommend doing it as a PDF.

This is a great course to take if you want to get the distribution requirement out of the way. I'm not a science person, but I enjoyed the course a lot. The lectures were generally engaging, and the work load outside of lectures is very manageable. The labs also helped to reinforce lecture content. Take this course!

This is a great lab course to take. Don't underestimate it though and I would recommend taking it as an STL instead of an STN if you are debating. You don't need to do the readings but do focus on the assignments and quizzes to maintain your grade.

Took this to fulfill my STL and overall enjoyed it and came away with a better understanding of climate science, which is especially crucial in this day and age. The 80 minute biweekly lectures are definitely a drag in terms of time commitment though, and I didn't think the amount of material justified the extended lecture. If you do take this, I REALLY recommend that you take it with the lab, which is genuinely lots of fun, fairly easy, and helps solidify concepts discussed in lecture.
Would recommend to someone like me who does not necessarily enjoy science but wants a new and unique take.
go to lecture

great STL or STN. If you take the lab you will be forced to learn the concepts so you will do well on the quizzes midterm and final so you don't even need to pdf. Also climate is a very important topic that is great to learn about while fulfilling your stl.
pretty painless stl!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 15%, Lab Reports - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Weekly readings will complement the lecture material. Four open-book online quizzes and two short assignments will reinforce key points.
descrip: Which human activities are changing our climate, and does climate change constitute a significant problem? We will investigate these questions through an introduction to climate processes and an exploration of climate from the distant past to today. We will also consider the implications of climate change for the global environment and humans. Intended to be accessible to students not concentrating in science or engineering.
title: Climate: Past, Present, and Future

evals: A very quantitative and challenging overview of the earth's atmosphere. Professor Fueglistaler is both considerate and knowledgeable. Though I think the course could benefit from offering a midterm and weekly problem sets, it is a fantastic course. Take this if you are interested in really understanding the physical processes that govern the atmosphere. I would recommend taking MAT 201, some computer science, and some physics before taking this course.
Def take it! Stephan is great and the workload is VERY manageable
If you have any interest in the subject you should definitely take it! Interesting class with a light workload.
If you want to learn more about the atmosphere and its scientific problems, this course will give you that. If you're interested in it in a climate change context, you'll probably be happy.

Take it! A great introductory course on the physical and mathematical equations governing Earth's atmosphere. Stephan is a great lecturer and is very helpful to go to during office hours. Make sure you start problem sets early to fully grasp what the questions are asking.
otherinfo: The main goal of the course is to demonstrate how interplay between measurements and a hierarchy of models (that starts with the highly idealized and gradually becomes more elaborate) can lead to an understanding of very complex phenomena such as weather and climate.
grading: Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Readings from texts and journals. Bi-weekly problem sets
prereqs: MAT 201, PHY 104 or equivalent.
descrip: This course discusses the processes that control Earth's climate - and as such the habitability of Earth - with a focus on the atmosphere and the global hydrological cycle. The course balances overview lectures (also covering topics that have high media coverage like the 'Ozone hole' and 'Global warming', and the impact of volcanoes on climate) with selected in-depth analyses. The lectures are complemented with homework based on real data, demonstrating basic data analysis techniques employed in climate sciences.
title: Earth's Atmosphere

otherinfo: Graduate Students from English and other language and literature departments who are teaching literature for the first time at Princeton are eligible for enrollment with the instructor's permission.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Teaching practicum required of departmental PhD students and open only to those concurrently teaching in their first course at Princeton. A wide range of topics is discussed, based primarily upon the needs and experience of participants. These typically include: facilitating discussions, delivering lectures, grading papers, designing course syllabi, teaching with translations, using technology in the classroom, developing a statement of teaching philosophy, and preparing a teaching portfolio. Course leads to partial fulfillment of the McGraw Teaching Transcript.
title: Comparative Literature Graduate Pedagogy Seminar

evals: Definitely take this class if you want a sophisticated review of current research efforts in the field of quantum information. Some background in quantum mechanics and quantum computing as well as some research experience in the field would be wise to have as it will help you make even more out of the class.
For undergraduates: it is a difficult course, a fire-hose of knowledge. But it is worth it: a great follow-up to 396 for anybody interested in applied physics.
Great course - regardless of interest in quantum computing. Applies your physics knowledge to understanding various cool experiments and devices.

I would recommend this course to any students interested in understanding the different physical implementation platforms of quantum information or doing research topics related to quantum information.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone willing to get a broad overview of different routes towards building a quantum computer.

This course is a fantastic way to learn about experimental quantum computing. I am walking away feeling confident I can understand papers on almost any implementation of quantum computing. As a first year grad student I found the course to be exactly hard enough where I am learning quite a bit but not banging my head over problem sets too often.
This is a great (also ambitious) course for getting formally introduced to, as the name suggests, implementation of quantum information.

Thompson is a great lecturer. He is extremely engaging and receptive to the level of understanding that students in the class have of the subject, and he can quickly come up with intuitive examples to explain a concept if you are confused. He also draws broad connections across topics in quantum information that would be harder to see if you self studied the material of this course.
Would highly recommend, was definitely my favorite class of the semester.
otherinfo: This course assumes knowledge of quantum mechanics at an undergraduate level. A course in quantum algorithms, such as ELE 396, may be helpful, but is certainly not required.
grading: Quizzes - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Problem set(s) - 40%
descrip: This course provides an overview of experimental approaches to quantum information processing and quantum computing. We discuss the basic principles of quantum computing to understand the physical requirements, and then survey current research on implementing quantum information processing in various physical systems, in part by reading recent experimental literature. Specific topics covered include gate-based and adiabatic quantum computing, topologically protected quantum architectures, as well as several physical qubit systems: trapped ions/atoms, superconducting circuits, and electron and nuclear spins in solids.
title: Implementations of Quantum Information

otherinfo: This is a full term course. It is open to undergraduates. Non-Sociology graduate students wishing to receive a grade for this course must submit a completed Graduate Student Enrollment Change Form located at the following URL: https://gradschool.princeton.edu/sites/gradschool/files/Enrollment%20Form%20Revised_1.pdf
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Weekly problem sets, midterm and final exams.
descrip: An introduction to basic concepts in probability and statistics with applications to social research. We cover descriptive statistics, sampling distributions, statistical inference for means and proportions (including point estimation, confidence intervals and tests of hypotheses), the comparison of two or more groups, and an introduction to analysis of variance and linear regression. Throughout the course we use the open-source statistical package R to illustrate and apply the techniques. The course is intended to prepare students to take Advanced Social Statistics the following term.
title: Applied Social Statistics

otherinfo: This is a year-long course that must be enrolled in both semesters. Professor Paul Starr will teach the fall semester, and Professor Viviana Zelizer will teach the spring semester. Open to graduate students in their second year or later. Non-Sociology graduate students wishing to receive a grade for this course must submit a completed Graduate Student Enrollment Change Form located at URL: https://gradschool.princeton.edu/sites/gradschool/files/Enrollment%20Form%20Revised_1.pdf
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Students enrolled for credit will be required to present their work at least once over the course of the year, as noted above; to lead discussions of readings at least once (and perhaps twice, depending upon enrollment); and to post weekly essays of at least 500 words on the workshop discussion board, as well as to post a comment on at least one other essay each week, in advance of the workshop meeting.
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work lies in the fields of economic sociology, organizational sociology, institutional analysis (including historical institutionalism), and social network analysis. The workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.
title: Workshop on Social Organization

evals: 8:30am is rough, but Prof. Graham is a great lecturer, enthusiastic and very organized. This is not a traditional immunology class memorizing a ton of molecules and names but more of an evolutionary class talking about how the molecular immunology stuff translates to the population level. There were a lot of interesting topics related to infectious diseases, immunopathology, vaccines, etc. There are two short "creative" papers, a final paper on any topic you choose, a take-home midterm, and take-home final.
A good EEB if you need one. Provides a very useful framework for thinking about immunology and medicine. Professor Graham is great.
A great class. Be warned: it has two finals, one due a few days before Deans Date and one due a few days after.

Although the lecture slides are extremely good and you will probably be fine not going to lectures, you should still go because the lectures are so good. Easily the best lectures I attended, even though I missed some because they were at 8:30 am.
Class gives a great broad look at immune systems. It's pretty low key but you learn a lot.
Definitely take this class! Really interesting, great professor, and not too much work.
Definitely take this course. The professor is great and the material is really interesting

Despite the early time, this class is definitely worth taking! Prof. Graham is a wonderful lecturer who can keep you engaged at 8:30am. This class presents a nice combination of EEB and MOL concepts, but it seems that EEB majors tend to enjoy it more.
