Even if you're not EEB or MOL, this class doesn't make too many assumptions about your background in bio and should be fairly accessible.

Engage in precepts! Makes it much more enjoyable. Also, go to all the lectures. The powerpoints online give you all the information you need but hearing professor graham lecture really gives you a better understanding of the material and how it all fits together. She is the one who makes all the themes work together in your head.
Go to lectures--they will deepen your understanding and will help you lots on the midterm/final.
Go to office hours and make sure you understand the concepts earlier on so you aren't scrambling to figure out everything when the exams come around.
Good for EEB students, as a MOL student sort of wish I took the other immnology class.  Lots of writing, also wish there was more substantive exams that were not writing based.

I thought this class was extremely overhyped. It doesn't matter if they bring granola bars, if you are not a morning person you WILL start drifting off to sleep as the lectures are fairly boring, and she uploads slides later anyway. The lecture material wasn't presented in an organized or logical order, and the big picture got lost in the very small details far too often.
I would recommend them taking it if they need an EEB class or another science class.

If you are more interested in the molecular side of immunology, don't take this class: it focuses on the evolution of immune systems and the history of that for the most part, as well as a few other topics related to that. Do the readings and be a good thinker for the essays and you will be completely fine.

If you have a strong interest in the immune system and don't want to have to memorize the nitty gritty details like most classes, I would definitely recommend this course. Don't be deterred from the 8:30 time slot because she provides granola bars every class!

If you need another MOL departmental, this class is pretty easy, but a little infuriating sometimes. It's a pretty good class - apparently better than MOL Immunology - and it's nice to pair with something like MOL Virology (which is a better class).

If you want a solid understanding of the immune system, mol immunology is a better choice. The evolutionary aspects of this class were interesting but I don't feel like it gave me a solid understanding of how the immune system works.

Interesting material taught by a very passionate, helpful, and engaging professor. Precepts not that helpful. EEB majors will probably enjoy this class more than MOL majors. Know that this class if focusing on EVOLUTIONARY immunology. If you want to learn more about the molecular details (the nuts and bolts) of immunology and memorize information, take the MOL immunology course. EEB 327 is more focused on critical and analytical thinking on broad processes but know that this is still a new field and there still needs to be more evidence to support the theories in this field. Recommend this course!
Review lectures after class, ask for specific examples, engage as much as possible.
Study as you go and go to office hours when you can.
TAKE IT. Easy grading - really entertaining.
Take it! It's a great class!
Take it.
Take this class if you are like me and hate focusing on only the molecular level of things.  It is fun to try to think of the broader implications of the minute details of biology.

Take this course! It will challenge you to approach this subject in a creative and engaging way. Assignments tend to be fun and Professor Graham is a great lecturer. I had a lot more fun in this course than my friends over in MOL immunology did, and it stimulates a lot of great questions about evolution as well. It feels very relevant because sickness is something we all deal with.
The course was good overall, and some of the material was very interesting, but the underlying concepts became redundant pretty quickly and the exam questions were somewhat vague.

The material got much less interesting after the midterm. It is a cool class, but the molecular side was not entirely clear so I would recommend taking a molecular immune course prior to this one. It was a class that encouraged creative thinking, but it was a bit too much at the end with both a final and paper.
The midterm and final will probably take longer than they suggest, but its take home so you should have enough time. Dont regret taking it at all though, really cool class. I'd recommend it

This class is quite a bit of writing. It has a few interesting salient themes but gets quite repetitive. If you're a MOL major who is more interested in mechanism and really understanding why things happen, this class can be frustrating. A lot of the content seemed rather speculative or hand wavy but it was also at times interesting to get the "molecules to population" perspective of immunology.

This course is very interesting and a great alternative to just focusing on molecules. However, it is deceptively easy and little work until the end of the semester when you have to write the term paper and the take home exam. Try as hard as possible to take detailed notes in every lecture and really pay attention even if it's 8:30 in the morning. The take home exams also take much longer than she says, even if you've studied.

This definitely was a great and interesting class. Only problem is it's so early and that definitely impeded my learning. If you can get over the 8:30am class and make sure you actually attend class, take it!
This is an excellent class! Lectures are amazing (even though they are at 8:30 AM)!

This is by far the best course I have taken at Princeton. Lectures were packed with so much information and made you think broadly about vaccines and immunity. Course examples were always interesting. Fantastic class. Definitely worth the 8:30am time slot. Definitely recommend. TAKE IT if you are at all interested.
super interesting stuff. if molecular memorization of MOL immunology doesn't seem appealing to you this is the way to go.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Approximately 50 pages of reading per week. Two short "thinking outside the box" assignments. One term paper.
prereqs: EEB 211 and MOL 214..
descrip: How do immune systems work, and why do they work as they do? Why is there so much immunological polymorphism in animal populations? To address these questions, students will examine immunology across multiple biological scales. At the molecular and cellular scales, students will learn mechanisms by which animals recognize and kill parasites. At the population scale, students will investigate causes of the tremendous immunological heterogeneity exhibited by animals. Both the clinical relevance and the evolutionary basis of polymorphisms will be emphasized.
title: Immune Systems: From Molecules to Populations

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Decoding Dress

evals:
Absolutely take this course! This class is easily one of the best I've taken at Princeton, if not the best. I really learned about Egypt and gained a significant amount of confidence in my Arabic abilities.

Prof. Elsayed is the best! His energy and approach to the material are ideal for learning the material in a fun but practical way. You won't find another professor like him anywhere.
I think students who are interested in learning colloquial Arabic must take this course!
Take this class if Tarek is teaching it!
Take this course! Tarek is great, and the ability to speak a dialect (as well as Fusha) is super useful!
Tarek has a lot of energy and will expect you to as well. A sense of humor is necessary. Learn all the vocab!
Tarek is the last native Arab standing in the Arabic department, and his genuine love of teaching shows in this class. This class is chill and light on workload, heavy on fun. Do it!
take it!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Assignments will focus on reading (fewer than 50 pages per week) and reviewing materials developed by the instructor as well as watching a variety of Egyptian colloquial materials on the internet.
prereqs: A minimum of two years study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107) or NES permission..
descrip: An introduction to the spoken dialects of Egypt, particularly of Cairo. Students in this course are assumed to have a functional, working knowledge of classical Arabic, and the course will focus on developing the ability to use conversational language in common, everyday situations.
title: Egyptian Colloquial Arabic

evals: If you are graduate student starting research in  Neuroscience, I would recommend it. Also it is part of the neuroscience certificate program.
It's a great way to understand what the PNI professors are working on, and to give yourself an excuse to read a textbook. But it's way more on you to get something out of it.
Start the assignments early. They will always take longer than expected.
Take the summer math bootcamp before this course because background in coding is a must.  Homework assignments are demanding and take days to finish.  Work with classmates.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format combining theoretical and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include cellular neurophysiology, neuroanatomy, neural circuits and dynamics, neural development and plasticity, sensory systems, genetic model systems, and molecular neuroscience. This is one-half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.
title: Neuroscience: from molecules to systems to behavior

evals: Don't be overambitious when designing the final project. You have a rotation waiting for you on the other end of the coursework.

Great course. I had barely learned how to program in python and this course allowed me to explore analyses in python in preparation for my rotations. If you use matlab there are some scripts available to help guide you. Overall, great learning experience.
Very VERY time consuming course, but excellent nevertheless.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This laboratory course complements NEU 501A and introduces students to the variety of techniques and concepts used in modern neuroscience, from the point of view of experimental and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include synaptic transmission and plasticity, two-photon imaging, central neuron activity patterns, optogenetic methods to control neural activity and student-designed special projects. In-lab lectures give students the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs but the emphasis is on the laboratory work. Second half of a double-credit core course required of all NEU Ph.D. students.
title: Neuroscience: from molecules to systems to behavior

evals: Definitely take this course! Assignments are well-designed and Alice consistently provides great feedback, both conceptual and formal, in group critiques. She challenges students but is also very realistic. You'll have to learn InDesign on your own if you're not familiar with it already, but it's easy to do through the assignments. Super rewarding class!!
Definitely would recommend. Can be a lot of work, but it is very interesting and engaging.
Enjoyable but time consuming. You will never look at typefaces (the right word is "typefaces" not "fonts"!) the same way!
If you're actually interested in the subject matter, definitely take this!!!!
grading: Design Project - 65%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Six studio assignments (one every other week); two published pamphlets or books (one at midterm, one at the end of term); four publicity campaigns (post card, leaflet, poster, email blast or performance).
descrip: This studio course will introduce students to the essential aspects and skills of graphic design, and will analyze and discuss the increasingly vital role that non-verbal, graphic information plays in all areas of professional life, from fine art and book design to social networking and the Internet. Students in the course will explore visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, type design, and image. Hands on production will include an array of do-it-yourself printing and distribution technologies, from letterpress and mimeograph to photocopying and websites.
title: Graphic Design

evals: Portuguese is a dynamic course that engages you into a community. The professors are willing to meet with you outside of the classroom and the sense of community is very strong.
Take it! It's so much fun and all the professors in the Portuguese department are super nice!
This is a must take class. The Portuguese department is amazing. Just be prepared to invest so you are taking full advantage of the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Paper in lieu of Final - 10%, Other Exam - 10%, Quizzes - 15%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Emphasis will be on oral communication in class. There will be daily homework assignments, grammar exercises and quizzes, short compositions, a midterm, an oral presentation, and final paper.
prereqs: No credit is given for POR 101 unless POR 102 is taken..
descrip: Students will be taught the fundamental skills of oral comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and the music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa.
title: Introduction to Portuguese I

evals: Have fun and engage with your fellow artists.
You literally can't not take this class, enjoy it, show up, take the time for helpful criticism, as well as listen to other people's perspective.
otherinfo: Enrolled students are also required to attend 4 - 5 visiting artist lectures on campus over the course of the semester, as well as participate in a day-long field trip to visit exhibitions and/or artists' studios with the enrolled students in VIS 392 Issues in Contemporary Art.
grading: Design Project - 10%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
assgts: Weekly readings, visiting artist research, and presentation and discussion of initial concepts for each student's Spring thesis exhibition. Two substantial writing assignments in the form of interviews will be undertaken, one as interviewer and one as interviewee.
prereqs: Open to senior Program 2 students in Art and Archaeology and VIS certificate students..
descrip: This seminar provides senior ART Program 2 and VIS certificate students a context for investigating and discussing contemporary art exhibition practices. Over the course of the semester, students will develop a greater understanding of their art, their influences, and their aesthetic underpinnings by considering them alongside readings, visiting artist lectures, writing assignments, and field trips to current exhibitions. Approaches to exhibition design, publicity, and audience will also be addressed. Assigned readings will challenge received ideas of what art is and what the form and content of an exhibition might entail.
title: Exhibition Issues and Methods

otherinfo: Undergraduates must receive permission from Professor to enroll.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion. Note: REL 525 (fall) and REL 526 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.
title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This seminar provides an intensive introduction to Japanese Religions past and present and examine key issues in scholarship. It is designed for those planning to take general exams, teach, or simply acquire a background in this field. Topics may include interactions of Buddhism with local religious culture; the emergence of Shinto; lay and monastic Buddhist practice; doctrinal issues; modern transformations of Buddhism; and religion-state relations. Readings are chiefly in English, supplemented by Japanese for those with sufficient language skills. Some topics may be chosen to accommodate participant research interests.
title: Studies in Japanese Religions - Issues in Scholarship

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on attendance at all course meetings and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on attendance at all course meetings and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.
title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)

evals: All engineers who have spent their careers just doing written math-y problem sets should take this.  It is extremely useful and very challenging

An excellent choice for anyone who will heavily use programming in their PhD and wants to do it in a neat and professional way.

Caveat selector! It will take a lot of time. (To give you a sense. I took two courses; was teaching an undergraduate course; and doing some research. This was almost certainly too much. If I did the semester again, I would probably do only three of the four, but this course would certainly be on the list).
Assignments takes a long time, but are mostly very worthwhile to do. I learned a lot.
Be advised that the final project for the class requires some work over winter break

Expect to be challenged by the assignments if you have not use a compiled language before. Go to lectures with the expectation of learning about possibilities and tools that are available, not of learning specifically how to code in every language. Take if you want to explore new languages and try out development tools that you've never had the chance/excuse to use.

From suggestions of people who took this class before I was expecting much more from this course, but turns out that for some of the classes read the slides was much more useful than attend classes. Homeworks assignments are quite demanding, but you learn a lot from them.
If you want to become a better programmer and write code that you can still use five years from now then I would highly recommend taking this course and applying its principles in your research.
It will be tough but you will come a long way over the course of the semester. definitely taking it a-f made me focus more on details which was good for learning.
Make sure to download the lecture notes before going to classes.

Start early on the homework. The first couple are manageable, but the later ones take a bit of time and you don't want to get stuck on the tail end of the timeframe. You will learn a lot if you apply the material to the homework and the project.
Take this class!

The homework projects and final projects provide a great chance to practice implementing good software development. Lectures are decent, especially in the beginning, but not all of the later ones are useful for everyone.
This course is very well designed to teach you practical skills and tools for software engineering. The final project lets you put these into practice. Highly recommend!

This is very challenging if you are not an advanced programmer. That said, the course will provide you with an outstanding jumpstart to software development if you are willing to put in the time and effort to do things right.
You will learn the most from the HWs. Make sure to put effort into them and talk to the TAs.
grading: Design Project - 50%, Programming Assignments - 50%
assgts: Approximately five programming assignments, plus a final project. The project will be undertaken in groups, and will involve creating a major piece of software related to scientific computing.
descrip: The goal of this course is to teach basic tools and principles of writing good code, in the context of scientific computing. Specific topics include an overview of relevant compiled and interpreted languages, build tools and source managers, design patterns, design of interfaces, debugging and testing, profiling and improving performance, portability, and an introduction to parallel computing in both shared memory and distributed memory environments. The focus is on writing code that is easy to maintain and share with others. Students will develop these skills through a series of programming assignments and a group project.
title: Software Engineering for Scientific Computing

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/28/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This half-term course is designed to hone students' ability to write effectively for policymakers and for public audiences. Students have the opportunity to improve their memo-writing skills and gain experience drafting other frequently-used materials, such as fact sheets, talking points, Q&A documents, speeches, and press releases. This course is particularly useful for students interested in working with elected officials, either from a position in the non-profit sector or directly in government.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Writing for Policymakers and the Public

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/28/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: In the 1949 Housing Act, Congress established the goal of 'a decent home in a suitable living environment for every American family.' Despite a plethora of federal, state, local, nonprofit, and private sector initiatives, achieving that goal remains elusive. This seminar explores supply-side approaches to addressing this pervasive housing crisis and examines current policies, challenges, and practice of developing new, income-restricted affordable housing, both single-family and multi-family, for sale and rental. We assess the impacts of building affordable housing on residents and communities, including issues of race and class.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Affordable Housing

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Art of Adventure, The

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Princeton Ethnographically

evals: Go to all the lectures and take careful, as they are both interesting and necessary to succeeding in the class. Be selective and consistent about how much reading you will do each week, and mark interesting segments of each book for use in precept or exams.

I really recommend this course, especially if you have an interest in thinking about history and the built environment. Professor Isenberg is a very dedicated teacher. The lectures are more fluid so it may take a while to get used to the organization of the course, but this fluidity also helps to powerfully capture historical dynamics across time. As a history major, this was also a great pre-20th century American history course.
I would definitely take this class if you want your mind expanded about the city and the agency that we each have within our cultural landscape.
Maybe you would like this course if you are open to it, but don't expect too much.

This is one of the worst classes I have taken at Princeton. The lectures are disorganized, filled with incoherent tangents, and poorly supported arguments. Don't take this class. Find another history class if you want to try out history.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 20%, Papers - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 250 pages of reading per week; two five-page research papers; brief writing assignments.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: For centuries cities have embodied U.S. hopes and fears, symbolizing ideals of democratic melting pots and cultural innovation, as well as urban "problems" and crisis. Urban life distilled extremes like rich and poor; parks and skyscrapers; philanthropy and greed; racial and ethnic divides; violence and hope; center and suburb. By producing contrasts and conflicts, cities brokered transformation, rebellion and renewal. Course covers social life, politics, economy, revolutionary ideologies, culture, race, gender, and the built environment--from the colonial era to the present.
title: Unrest and Renewal in Urban America

evals: Definitely take it! Be prepared for a lot of the work to come at the end, but it's an interesting class that will expose you to something new, regardless of your prior Jewish education if any.
If you are interested in Judaic studies this is a really interesting course with a great professor. The readings are short doable and interesting and the papers are not too demanding.

In regards to essays, just do as Prof. Himmelfarb says and do really close readings of the text. Takes time, but that's what you're supposed to do, and if you do that it's not too hard to get a good grade.
Only take this class if you are really interested in the subject matter.
Only take this course if you are VERY interested in reading ancient Jewish texts.
Talk to professor Himmelfarb when you have questions.
This course is a great summary of ancient Jewish history, but very historical (a lot of facts and historical analysis) so make sure you like that!

This course is all about close reading of scripture.  It was a great introduction into judaic studies for me, though other people in the class came in with a lot more background in the subject than I did. A great way to do history based in text.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Brief secondary readings (approximately 50 pages a week) to allow more time to focus on primary readings, which are also brief but require careful attention. Participation, two papers, and a take-home final exercise.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the development of ancient Judaism during the eventful millennium from the establishment of the Torah as the constitution of the Jewish people in the fifth century BCE--an event that some have seen as marking the transition from biblical religion to Judaism--to the completion of the other great canonical Jewish document, the Babylonian Talmud, in perhaps the sixth century CE.
title: Ancient Judaism from Alexander to the Rise of Islam

evals: Be ready to read A LOT. But as long as you can fit it into your workload, this course is not to be missed.
The reading load for this course is notoriously heavy. Your other classes will likely suffer. But it's amazing.
This course is rich on empirical studies but Kotkin also provides powerful conceptual frameworks to think about history in general. He is extremely rigorous but not rigid. Take it!
This is a challenging course, but well worth the effort if you are willing to put in some late nights.

This is an outstanding course that is particularly well suited as an introductory course. It offers an excellent introduction into global history and the discipline of history at large. It is very demanding, though; so only take it if you are willing to do the work.
grading: Papers - 33%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 17%
descrip: This seminar offers a history of global interactions roughly since the 1850s, combining an analytical framework with an overarching narrative. It singles out geopolitics, political economy, empire, networks and exchange, warfare and welfare, and oil. Key themes include the Anglo-German antagonism, the U.S.-Japan clash, the rise and fall of global communism, the German story and the European Union, the fall and rise of China, and America's global predominance and partnerships.
title: Global History (1850s - Present)

evals: I took this course because of the stellar course reviews, and I was not disappointed. Prof. Brangwynne is so passionate about the topic and knowledgeable about current research in the field. Lectures are a joy to listen to. Just remember to start early on the final paper so you have time to send an outline to Prof. Brangwynne and ask questions before you start writing.
I would definitely take this course if you are in CBE, MOL, CHM, PHY. The class was so worth it.

Requires a good amount of time (comes in waves). Interesting class - the field has a lot of unanswered questions, which makes for good discussions. Professor approachable and friendly. Go to office hours.
Take it!! Great CBE course and really interesting. If you like biology or material science you'll like this course. Recommend to all CBEs and MOL majors.
Take this course! It's very interesting. Make sure to attend all lectures, participate in class, and go to office hours if you need help.
Take this course!! It opens your eyes to a world of soft living matter that you never knew existed! I am now interested in doing related work in grad school.
Take this if you want a taste of what research is like as a grad student.

This course is extremely well-taught and well-organized. Most people will be much more familiar with either the materials science side or the biology side of the course, but regardless of your prior knowledge you will learn a lot and be able to get a lot out of this course.
Very fun, low-stress course for anyone interested in biophysics, including non-CBE majors.
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Weekly reading 20-30 pages and problem sets.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.
title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter

otherinfo: This class meets 10/25/2017 to 12/13/2017. It will meet six times on Wednesday evenings, starting on 10/25/2017 (before fall break)
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 60%
assgts: The success of the seminar depends on your commitment to complete all required readings for each session, write and post weekly précis, help lead a session, and participate actively in discussions. Grading is based on collection of précis, participation, and class presentation (60%) and a final book review essay (40%).
descrip: This seminar explores the unfinishedness of human subjects and lifeworlds, advancing the conceptual terrain of an anthropology of becoming. People's plasticity trouble and exceed ways of knowing and acting, opening new channels for research, creative expression, and critical theory. As we consider the array of affects, ideas, forces, and objects that shape contemporary modes of existence and dissect present-day regimes of veridiction and falsification, we explore how ethnographic subjects can become alternative figures of thought and restore a sense of movement, surprise, and possibility to ethics and political practice.
title: Topics in Theory & Practice (Half-Term) - Peopling Critical Theory

otherinfo: For department majors, satisfies group 1 (Ancient) distribution requirement. For Archaeology certificate students, this course satisfies the Ancient Art course requirement.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Quizzes - 5%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Geography quiz, midterm, final take-home exam, two short writing assignments, oral presentation.
descrip: A survey of the material culture of the Greek world, from the Persian invasions until the death of Alexander the Great (ca. 500-323 BC). Works analyzed in their social, political, and archaeological contexts. Topics include: urbanism and the Greek house; the concept of the artist in antiquity; the archaeology of death; the divine image. Study of monuments, artifacts, and sites integrated with the reading of primary literary sources. Frequent hands-on experience with artifacts in the Princeton University Art Museum.
title: Greek Archaeology: The Classical Period

evals: A fascinating survey of various topics about social, economic, and technological networks. The problem sets typically involved programming simulations and "translating math into code", which I thought was a great way to solidify the material.

A pretty easy COS class at the 300 level; good for anyone trying to fill the ApC certificate requirements. Content is really relevant to everyday technology that we use and the course really does try and tailor to current events and pressing issues. Prof Andrews has a great British accent

A relatively easy course (you do have to put in time on the psets though) but I also found it to be really interesting. I'm glad I took it. Having no coding experience beforehand might make it harder, but the coding was generally quite easy for anyone with any background.
Attend lecture. Don't be too ambitious with your project.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in digital services and the networking/finance/social aspects behind them.
Definitely take this, even if you're not ELE. Make sure you brush up on math
Do it but be prepared for more mathematical content than you would expect.
Don't take it unless the original professor, Mung Chiang is teaching it. Definitely not worth it.

Don't take this if you don't have to. Taught poorly, you don't learn much...

It's such a brief overview of different topics, that you don't understand enough on how to really leverage any of them.

You use one of the topics for the final presentation, but I don't think ....
Expect a lot of math, especially probability and linear algebra. The psets are a good way to learn Numpy, but don't really connect to the exams.
Good one! Lots of solid topics.
Have a strong math foundation. The material is interesting but the exams are quite difficult.
I definitely recommend taking this class if you want a cursory overview of how networks work and some more in-depth real life examples.
I would recommend. It's a lot of work but it's very interesting if this stuff interests you
If you are really interested in networks maybe take it, otherwise do not take it
If you wanna know how the internet works and how math is incorporated into how tech companies make money, take this course. It really is interesting, but is not very technical

If you're looking for a relatively chill class, then I'd recommend this. It's pretty interesting without being that much work. That being said, you probably won't learn a whole lot and certainly won't learn it to any deep level of understanding.

It was unlike any other Princeton course I've taken.  There was far more emphasis on the practical applications of the theory, rather than just straight theory like usual.  Enjoyable and worth taking.  However, keep in mind that your Dean's Date will be packed if you add this to it
It's random and jumps around a lot!

Prof. Andrews wont be teaching this next year, so likely to be different. Focus on applications and creating basic models over theory. Homeworks a good opportunity to get comfortable with Python, and final project a great opportunity to explore any topic interesting to you. Would recommend if you want a broad overview of how the internet, cellular communications, and social networks work.

Professor Andrews is such a nice man. HE is a little out of touch with expectations for a course. The final project and the exam were a lot of work. The exams were SUPER annoying and didn't test what we learned in class but rather your fast computation skills. The material is interesting, especially the first half of the course and it is just a shame that the course felt so ruined for me by the exams. I don't know if Professor Andrews will be teaching any more so this all may no be relevant.

TAKE IT. VERY EASY and answers some of the questions that you probably asked yourself and didn't find technical solutions to. Also, READ the book. To do well, all you need is differentiation and linear algebra
Take it if you love stats.
Take it if you're interested in how things work. Expect demanding reading and finals period with a demanding project and a final exam.
Take it! It's fun, very broad coverage of interesting topics, short (4-8 hour) psets each week, somewhat difficult exams, fun project at the end.
Take it! Prof. Ramadge's lectures are extremely clear, and his problem sets help solidify understanding of concepts.

Take this class! It's one of the few classes that teaches practical knowledge and the material is super interesting too. Be prepared to do a lot of work though; there are weekly psets, periodic blog posts, a final project, AND final exam.

The course is surprisingly math-oriented and assumes decent understanding of probability, expectation and other stuff. If you are comfortable with some math, then its a pretty nice course. Its very broad and informative in nature, and the psets are not too much work (at least if you go to office hours). The exams are generally too long to complete, but everybody feels that way, so its ok. Also, they are open book so one doesnt need to study too much for them, as long as youve paid attention in lecture. I would highly recommend it as an easier ELE/COS class, but not one AB people can take without having some math background...

The course was not very good. We learned pretty interesting things, but the problem sets only slightly related to the lectures. The midterm was unnecessarily difficult and almost no one got more than a 60% on it.

This class is much more work and much more difficult than advertised. Probability should be a pre-req (like COS 340, ORF 309). Moreover, there's so many assessments: Psets, midterms, blog posts, design project and a final. We covered too many topics in not enough depth. I would opt for a more focused class or better, just buy the book and read it. Prof Andrews did his best and his TAs, esp Abe were solid, but I felt that this class wasn't worth it overall.

This class isn't as hard as other COS/ELE classes. That said, I am only saying it relatively and it can still be a pretty tough class. If you don't have to take it, I advise you learn it from Coursera, since the pace they go with here is ridiculous.

This course is super interesting and really fills you in on the way vastly impactful technology works in our lives today. The quickly rotating material keeps things fresh, and there are topics of great interest to everyone. Try to take it with a couple friends so that you have a group for the final project, but besides that, it's definitely recommended, especially as a departmental!
This is a good class to take for COS majors and certificates. It's a lot of work especially with the weekly problem sets, but it is manageable and interesting.

This is a great course because it touches on so many different subjects related to computer science and networks. It is a survey course that also goes quite in depth into a number of fascinating problems without much prerequisite knowledge.

This is a really cool class. You learn a lot about the inner workings of a lot of popular websites and apps, as well has how exactly the internet, cellphones, etc. actually work. Would highly recommend taking this class as an interesting, engaging, fun elective.

This is about as close as you can get to an engineering survey course. Topics range from Google's PageRank to Uber's price determinations to cellphone networks. Problem sets are mostly simulations of whatever models we are looking at, which I found to be a lot of fun.
You should take this course, should the professor ever teach again.
great course with a very passionate professor, and the subject matter/group project are both super interesting
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Design Project - 30%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Homework assignments, a midterm, and final examination.
prereqs: Knowledge of calculus and linear algebra..
descrip: This course is oriented around 20 practical questions in the social, economic, and technological networks in our daily lives. How does Google sell ad spaces and rank webpages? How does Netflix recommend movies and Amazon rank products? How do I influence people on Facebook and Twitter? Why doesn't the Internet collapse under congestion, and does it have an Achilles heel? Why does each gigabyte of mobile data cost $10, but Skype is free? How come WiFi is slower at hotspots than at home, and what is inside the cloud of iCloud? In formulating and addressing these questions, we introduce the fundamental concepts behind the networking industry.
title: Networks: Friends, Money and Bytes

evals: Absolutely dont take it with Nikhil as a preceptor!

Do not take this course if you're not interested in the course material. Alicia is a super nice professor but her slides have grammatical mistakes that affect the clarity of the material she presents. Also if Nikhil Gupta is the preceptor, stay away! He made the experience uniquely terrible.
Easy but dont take it

Easy course with only 4 problem sets. Very little math and very simple, especially if you've taken some Econ already and are familiar with basic concepts & graphs, but still easy even if you haven't. I took it for the topic and for Nikhil and was not disappointed -- I would advise the same for other students, because if you're not interested in the topic, it's not worth it. Lectures aren't amazing or necessary, and I mostly read the textbook & did the readings & relied on precept.
I thought we would be talking about international development challenges but it stressed economic models. Only 20% of the class or less showed up to lectures.

I was super interested in this topic but I ended up PDFing it because it wasn't what I expected. The course is disorganized and grading is not fair. There is a reason why the course has low ratings. Don't take it.
I would recommend this course only if you are committed to always going to lecture and precept and doing most of the reading.

I'd say take it if you're an Econ major. Very little in the class is too difficult, ultimately not very much work, and exams weren't too bad. Only reservation would be it seems like it's hard to get an A. Also, the class is pretty theoretical which might be off-putting for those who want to know what can actually be done for international development.
If you think this is an easy Economics departmental, it probably is but because it's so boring, it literally isn't worth it.
Neutral on recommending; was interesting in the context of political economy, but lacked the same mathematical rigor that many other PE classes have.
Nikhil is an amazing preceptor!
Problem sets and tests are very difficult, professor hard to understand because of her thick accent
Psets are graded really hard and so much attention to detail. Lecture is decently helpful. Thought the readings were interesting and topics were good to think about but nothing life changing.

Take this class if you are interested in development and are willing to either PDF or take a GPA hit. The material is really interesting and you learn a lot of models that aren't covered in regular economics classes, but the tests/problem sets are very difficult.
Take this course if you are interested in the subject, or if you can understand econ concepts easily.

This is a great course if you are interested in international development - you learn a lot of core concepts. BUT don't take it if you're expecting an easy A. You have to put in the work to really succeed in the class.
it's a meh class. much more quantitative than you would expect for a wws crosslist.
ok course not that tough. inconsistent grading though
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: The class will use basic economic concepts: ECO 100 and ECO 101 are recommended.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 60%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Approximately 100-120 pages of reading per week are expected. Policy note will account for 30% of the final grade.
descrip: This course will focus on less developed countries and will consider topics such as economic growth and personal well-being; economic inequality and poverty; strategies (particularly of farmers) for dealing with risk; trade policy; public economics when both markets and governments fail with health policy as a case study. The course will tackle these issues both theoretically and empirically.
title: International Development

grading: Final Exam - 100%
prereqs: Prerequisites: PhD-level microeconomics and econometrics..
descrip: Examines health issues in both developed and developing countries. Specific topics include the evolution of health over the life course; the fetal origins hypothesis; the two-way links between socioeconomic status and health; the impact of social safety nets on health outcomes; environmental threats to children's health and development; health insurance and its effects on health; the industrial organization of health care delivery; and the relationship between health and economic growth.
title: Health Economics I

evals: For those who are interested in surface science or material science and nanotechnology in general should consider this course.
I reccommend, particularlyly if you are doing research in this area, or have an interest in this area.

I think that this course provides a comprehensive and accessible introduction to the area of surface science by presenting the fundamentals of the theory without requiring prior knowledge in this or related fields. I felt that I not only gained working and theoretical knowledge in the area of surface science, but also a better appreciation of how surface science interacts with other fields. As such, I would strongly recommend this course to anyone working on projects dealing with or related to surfaces regardless of your field. (as long as it is in the sciences/engineering)
If you want to know about surface science, this is THE course to take.
Pay attention to lecture! An interesting and fair class
Very useful class taught at a fast pace. Important to have a strong chemistry background.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 10%, Problem set(s) - 45%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and reading in reference texts. Students are expected to write one term paper and present the paper orally in class.
prereqs: It is expected all students will have some familiarity with kinetics and thermodynamics..
descrip: An introduction to processes at surfaces and interfaces. Experimental methods of surface science. Electron spectroscopy, ion scattering, and scanning probe microscopy. Atomic structure of surfaces and adsorbed layers. Thermodynamics of surface processes. Adsorption and molecular dynamics of gas-surface reactions. Kinetics of adsorption, desorption, diffusion, and reactions. Liquid interfaces. Heterogeneous catalysts. Etching. Film growth and epitaxy. Applications to energy and environmental science and technology.
title: Surface Science: Processes and Probes

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course focuses on various types of Japanese kanbun, including waka kanbun (Japanese vernacular kanbun) from Nara to Meiji era. Basic knowledge of classical Japanese grammar and kanbun kundoku reading is required.
title: Readings in Kanbun

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The two-semester course is designed for students in Chinese studies, who already possess reading fluency in Chinese. Its goal is to train these students in reading the particular style of Japanese academic writing; at the end of the year, students will be able to independently read modern Japanese scholarship on China. Students take this course after at least one year of modern Japanese (JPN 101/102). The course does not train all four skills of reading, writing, speaking, and listening; instead it is devoted entirely to rapidly develop the necessary reading skills in Japanese academic style. The course is conducted in English.
title: Readings in Japanese Academic Style

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

grading: Papers - 70%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
descrip: Course uses the lens of history to evaluate why some individuals are considered most effective as elected, bureaucratic, and appointed officials in American history. Course evaluates social scientific models of leadership, then delves into the historical record to discover any patterns. Careful consideration is given to the distinct challenges posed by different institutional settings. A wide range of influential leaders, including Gifford Pinchot at the Dept of Agriculture, Lyndon Johnson in the Senate, Wilbur Cohen at the Social Security Administration and George Schultz at State, will be examined.
title: Great Leadership in Historical Perspective

evals: A little different than what you might think, but good dist requirement.
AMAZING CLASS. It was a lot of work but ultimately very rewarding. Take it if you have an interest in constitutional law or American history.
An extremely interesting topic. So neat to learn about the executive from all different angles. Can be work at times but it is interesting.
Depends on the subject and professor, POL 332 changes around.
Do all the reading

I love Professor Forte, he is one of the best professors I've ever had. He is incredibly kind and intelligent, and worked to connect with each student in his class. The material of the course was incredibly interesting and relevant to today's society and I would recommend him and the course to anyone.
I would suggest starting the Term Paper as early as possible, because it can prove to be very demanding. However, I would definitely recommend the course.
Take the course.

There isn't a lot of work, but the class is not very related to the course description. Its mostly about the development of the Constitution and political theory, not practical or contemporary issues in presidencies.
Very interesting American/theory politics class.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Reading assignments in assigned texts and recommended readings. A mid-term and final examination. A paper (10-12 pages).
descrip: Course will examine the political development, constitutional principles and practice of Abraham Lincoln, and especially grass-roots politics in the 19th century Republic, the international context of liberal democracy in the 19th century, the war powers of the presidency, the contest of Whig and Democratic political ideas, the relation of the executive branch to the legislative and judicial branches, diplomacy, and the presidential cabinet.
title: Topics in American Statesmanship - Abraham Lincoln

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
otherinfo: This class meets from 11/6/2017 to 12/15/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course examines international peace processes and mediation in a variety of conflicts, from Syria to Northern Ireland to South Sudan. It confronts technical and political questions that arise in international negotiations. What ingredients are necessary for a peace process to succeed? We examine the role of mediators, types and principles of mediation, mediation architecture, mandates and supporting institutions, the interests of 'stakeholders', and the political, moral and economic dilemmas faced in arresting violent conflict and facilitating transitions to sustainable peace.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - International Negotiation and Mediation

otherinfo: POL PhD students may also register. Contact regina@princeton.edu to receive the permission.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The field of Security Studies is distinguished by its focus on a clearly delineated set of intellectual and practical problems. This course will serve as the required gateway for all students entering the Woodrow Wilson School.
title: PhD Gateway in Security Studies

grading: Papers - 90%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: TBA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.
title: Decoding Dress

evals: Definitely take it!  It's a really interesting subject and Erica will challenge you to do your best while also creating a fun and engaging environment.
Erica is one of the best teachers I've had at Princeton and this is one of the best (and probably the most life-changing) class I've taken. TAKE IT.
Honestly, a wonderful class. Do take even if you don't understand what Community Based Performance is.
If you like small theater theory classes, give it a whirl.
Take it.
otherinfo: Students will research foundational artists and companies engaged in Community-based performance with a particular emphasis on performances in which professional actors perform alongside community members. Students will work closely with artists from McCarter Theatre Center to help develop and implement new community-integrated initiatives with partners such as HomeFront, OnStage Seniors, and local environmental advocacy groups.
grading: Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: Reading:100 pages per week. Writing: 20-25 pages over the course of the semester. Some weeks will require out-of-class engagement or activities
prereqs: Enrollment in this course is by permission of the instructor. Please email Professor Erica Nagel to state your interest in the course at: enagel@mccarter.org.
descrip: This hands-on seminar will explore contemporary theories and practices of community-based performance, investigating contemporary theatre, dance, and music groups that use these methods. The course will also interrogate the sometimes fraught politics of community-based performance, including questions of authorship, authority, authenticity, and artistry. Offered in partnership with the Community-Based Learning Initiative, this course will offer hands-on experience in the process of creating community-based performance projects, and facilitate opportunities to build artistic relationships with local community organizations.
title: Community-Based Performance

evals: Amazing distribution, and Professor Hamera makes the material really engaging and she is so genuinely interested in the topic.  You also get to learn a different dance from a trained instructor every other week, which is a really valuable addition to the class.  Would definitely recommend for a distribution.

Such an amazing class! We got to learn about dances from so many different cultures, and the studio sessions were so much fun, so non-judgmental, and such great sites for learning through moving. Professor Hamera is incredibly articulate, thoughtful, understanding, and just genuinely wants you to learn.

Take this class! Prof. Hamera is so kind and knowledgeable about dance as a form of cultural transmission. If you have any interest in understanding the greater stakes within performance, this is the course for you!

Take this course because Professor Hamera is amazing, but don't take it during your senior spring because it is a lot of work and in order to be engaged enough to really take advantage of all of the nuanced greatness of the course, you should not be in a senior spring mindset.

Take this course if you need an LA or to fulfill your certificate requirement, or just for pure interest. Studio sessions are fun and relaxed, and seminars are rather engaging. Not too difficult in terms of readings or courseload. Three field notes and one final paper (on a princeton dance group). This is more of an ethnography class than a dance history class, but you definitely get both. Professor Hamera is truly skilled and a great seminar teacher. If you participate actively you will likely get an A

This course is an absolute must. Whereas the bulk of the courses at Princeton seem to deny the value of oneself as a resource, DAN 215 privileges it. Don't be deterred by the non PDF; field notes can be edited and resubmitted, and Professor Hamera is thoroughly invested in her students. My advice is to do the readings and to throw yourself into the dance instruction, though not forgetting to acknowledge how you feel while learning the movements.
otherinfo: "Other" in Grading 20%: Performance based on fieldwork
grading: Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Total number of pages the Student is expected to read per week: 75 -100. Each student will conduct a 3-visit participant observation of a Princeton University dance company or community company and discuss the results of this fieldwork using the vocabulary from the class. Three field notes will contribute to the final paper.
prereqs: No prior dance experience is necessary to succeed in this course..
descrip: Bharatanatyam, butoh, hip hop, and salsa are some of the dances that will have us travel from temples and courtyards to clubs, streets, and stages around the world. Through studio sessions, readings and viewings, field research, and discussions, this seminar will introduce students to dance across cultures with special attention to issues of migration, cultural appropriation, gender and sexuality, and spiritual and religious expression. Students will also learn basic elements of participant observation research. Guest artists will teach different dance forms. No prior dance experience is necessary.
title: Introduction to Dance Across Cultures

evals: Although Professor Scheppele presents interesting arguments in this class, I would recommend going to her public lectures rather than taking a graded course with her. Engaging participation is minimal, the exams are confusing and extensive outside knowledge of global constitutionalism is needed to meet her expectations.

Do not hesitate to take a class with Prof. Scheppele. You will be challenged and learn more than you thought one course could offer. Prof. Scheppele is the most engaged professor I have ever had, and you'll be lucky to spend a semester with her.

Prof. Scheppele is extremely knowledgeable and friendly, and she truly cares about her students. She certainly has her (very liberal) opinions, but she's exceptionally fair to everyone. If you disagree with her views, as I do, you should definitely take this class because she'll challenge you and teach you quite a lot. Overall, it's a great and interesting class that offers insight into a fairly specialized field that you've probably never been exposed to before. It mostly focuses on European and Commonwealth law. There's a little bit of Latin American law, but don't expect anything on Asia or Africa. Because readings are pretty technical be sure that you're genuinely interested in the material. Familiarity with American constitutional law is helpful. My only real complaint is that lectures can get kind of dry. This is not a discussion-based class.
TAKE IT! The reading is above average but all necessary. The course covers a broad range of topics in the subject, so there is something for everyone. Best course I've take at Princeton!
Take this course if you are interested in learning more about the constitutions of various countries but not if you want to engage and talk in precept.
Take this course if you are interested in the subject matter, but be prepared to do the work.

Take this course! If you have any interest in international law and how other countries approach human rights issues within their constitutional frameworks, you will enjoy this class. Professor Scheppele is an engaging professor and the class gives a comprehensive overview of constitutional systems and different rights. Each lecture is fascinating.

This class goes over a lot of material, leading to a very broad but meaningful introduction to the field of comparative constitutional law. Prof. Scheppele is accomplished, intelligent, and also incredibly down to earth - I cannot recommend this course or another taught by her highly enough. If you have an interest in law, you'll appreciate this course!

This is a fairly technical course that might take a bit of getting used to for non-majors, but if you have the chance to take a course with Professor Scheppele, you should absolutely take it. She goes above and beyond for her students and is brilliant. Definitely not my highest grade in a Princeton course, but well worth the time and effort.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 40%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 100-200 pages of reading per week; essay-based take-home midterm and final. The readings will include both court cases and secondary sources. Students will be expected to read assignments before class and to participate in discussions.
descrip: This course will introduce students to the variety of forms of constitutional government and the way that human rights are understood and enforced by courts around the world. We will trace the emergence of a global constitutional culture and explore the constitutions of South Africa, India, Germany, France, the UK, the Netherlands, Hungary, Colombia and Canada. We will give primary emphasis to the rights provisions in national constitutions but will also consider transnational regimes through examining decisions of the European Court of Justice, the European Court of Human Rights and the Inter-American Court of Human Rights.
title: Comparative Constitutional Law

grading: Final Exam - 50%, Papers - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: This class is an entry-level graduate study of US political institutions. As such, the seminar provides an overview of the field and, perhaps more importantly, a foundation upon which students can begin to teach themselves additional works in this literature. In addition, through brief assignments and class presentations, we build students' ability to conduct scholarly research, evaluate others' scholarship, and serve as discussants and reviewers.
title: American Political Institutions

evals: Definitely take this course if you are interested in African American art history, black studies, or another related academic area of interest. This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton - learned a lot about/became even more interested in the lineage of African American art, without feeling overwhelmed by information and assignments. I genuinely enjoyed class time.
Do the readings because they provide very interesting historical context for the class and prepare you well for the lectures.
If you're a person who learns through class participation and engagement, don't take this class.
Take it if interested in the subject.
Take it if you can. The class was very good.
Take this course!  Dr. Okeke-Agulu is a great professor and genuinely cares that his students are learning the material and are grasping key concepts.
Take this course.  You will learn a lot about a subject that is not learned enough.

This is a pretty good LA that isn't too stressful. It helps if you have experience analyzing or creating art because it is first and foremost an art class that requires that you be able to understand artwork as well as aspects of style, form, etc. The readings are interesting but are most necessary to review for the midterm and final when they can help you better understand the art, the artists, and the time period.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: 60-100 pages per week; One short paper (7-10 pages) on an artist, group of artists or on a theme
descrip: This course surveys important moments in 20th-Century African American art from the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920s to the 1960s Black Arts movement. Our close studies of the work of major artists will be accompanied by examination of influential theories and ideologies of blackness during two key moments of black racial consciousness in the United States. We shall cover canonical artists and writers such as Aaron Douglas, James van der Zee, William H. Johnson, Jacob Lawrence, Romare Bearden, Faith Ringgold, Betye Saar, W. E. B. Du Bois, Alain Locke, James Porter and Jeff Donaldson.
title: Harlem Renaissance and Black Arts Movements

evals: Definitely take this class if you have an interest in biotechnology but be prepared to come to each class having spent ~45 minutes reading the day before the readings. But it is worth it. You learn so much and gain so much from it.
Definitely take this course! Probably the best class I've taken at Princeton so far.
Read the papers and the general review papers for every class so you actually can participated in class. I would recommend participating often since it is a part of the class grade.
Take this course!
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Reading: 3 to 4 papers and 1 to 3 news-type articles per week. Writing: 3 short papers/proposals during the semester; final paper.
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345, or permission of the Instructor.
descrip: This course will consider the principles, development, outcomes and future directions of therapeutic applications of biotechnology, with particular emphasis on the interplay between basic research and clinical experience. Topics to be discussed include production of hormones and other therapeutic proteins, gene therapy, oncolytic viruses, and stem cells. Reading will be from the primary literature.
title: Biotechnology

otherinfo: Open to graduate students in the humanities at any stage of the writing process. Participants are not required to attend every session of the colloquium, but regular attendance is encouraged. Sessions are every other Tuesday. Lunch will be provided
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: OPTIONAL READING: Wendy Belcher, "Writing Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks"
descrip: The Writing and Dissertation Colloquium is a biweekly forum for graduate students in Comparative Literature to share works in progress with other graduate students. The seminar welcomes drafts of your prospectus, article, dissertation chapter, conference paper, exam statement and grant or fellowship proposal. Work is pre-circulated. The 90 minute sessions, done in conjunction with a rotating COM faculty member, are designed to offer written and oral feedback.
title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Writing and Dissertation Colloquium

grading: Term Paper(s) - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: This seminar offers a comparative study of the political, intellectual, religious, and cultural transformations of societies of the Near East and Eurasia from the late seventeenth to the early twentieth centuries. The course investigates the common geopolitical, economic, and intellectual challenges that Western Europe posed to the societies of the Near East and Eurasia. It seeks to understand the responses of the latter on their own terms, and to relate them to each other. The course aims to stimulate students to move beyond regional particularities and think outside the models and assumptions provided by European historiography.
title: Comparative Transformations in the Near East and Eurasia

evals: A generally excellent class with some very concrete foundational teachings, and a general tendency to force you to think long and hard about how you want to lead.

Amazing course on leadership, building and growing a company and ultimately knowing yourself. This class takes serious time. Be prepared to prioritize it and take readings and assignments seriously for your own sake, but also for the sake of your group members. Come in with an open mind (many students stay in the class and complain that it's BS, but tbh you need to engage with the material in order for it to have an effect on you) and you'll learn many useful and important things about leading people and creating change in the world. Prof Lidow is great guy, but an okay lecturer, so most of the meaning drawn from the class will be implicit and only bare fruit toward the end. If you wna learn how to align your ducks, take this class. 

In short, the class content will help you become a better person. It will hurt, but it's worth it.
An excellent introduction to entrepreneurship and business in general, Lidow's framework seems obvious once you've taken this course but you are unlikely to reach it through your own experience.
Be prepared to participate in every class and have time to set up meetings with groups every week for the assignments. Derek has a vast experience with leadership and the guest speakers are great.
Definitely take it

Definitely take this course if you can fit it in your schedule. You owe it to yourself to learn about yourself and about how to interact with others in the most efficient way possible.  The entrepreneurial exposure is also super valuable and realistic.
Do not take this course, you may put in a lot of work and learn a lot from the intense group projects but your grade is fairly dependent on whether the professor likes you.
Go to lecture and do the readings. It's an active class.
Great class for learning about self and for the training the assignments give you. Last assignment is really insightful
I am quite sure that this is the course I really will remember from my time at Princeton. It has thought me so many important concepts that I am already applying in my professional life.

I would recommend this class with reservations. I signed up cuz the reviews looked really good, only to be slammed with a long pre-first-class questionnaire and assigned seats (!!). Seriously considered dropping right then and there, but I stuck around for the first class and it seemed promising. Overall I believe this to be the right call. The pros: Lidow has a lot of experience and wisdom. These gems of wisdom, while rare, make the class worth it. Group work twice a week, while a bitch to organize, has been a valuable experience and will be really useful post-grad. And in general, Lidow's framework for thinking about startups is correct and productive. THAT SAID, the cons: 80-minute Q&A sessions drag on. Grading with pluses and checks is completely arbitrary, until you get slammed at the end with a bad grade. A lot of people will raise a super-specific question, not at all relevant for the class, seemingly for the participation grade, and Lidow will entertain these bullshit comments. A lot of work for an EGR class. All in all it's a lot of bullshit with real substance underneath. The ratio isn't favorable, but the good stuff makes it all worth it.

If you enjoy being preached at for 1.5 hours twice a week every week and stroking a professor's ego for credit, then this is the class for you. Otherwise, take a class where the prof does not say that his class will "change your life" and not deliver. The class's saving grace is the third segment where you get to work in a team to develop a company. But you have to go through several weeks of mundanity and irritation to get there. Best of Luck.

Lidow takes himself way too seriously -- definitely some interesting material, but it ends up being a bunch of kids trying to score participation points by making dumb comments. Participation is graded on a curve, which is ridiculous, and there's an absurd amount of busy work. Also 4000 word Dean's Date assignment. Not an easy A, nor interesting enough to take outside of your major

Overall, I would recommend this course but I also recognize that is flawed. Some of the lessons learned about leadership are invaluable, as is the groupwork (p.s. there's a ton of groupwork so don't take this class if you don't like working in groups). Other parts of the course are unstructured and much less useful. Take it if you plan on working in a small organization at some point.

Overall, you get lots of really good frameworks to think about leadership and skills and such, and learn how to work with people of different types and such. Definitely read the readings and take part in the group exercises. Lectures, however, can be a bit dry, repetitive, and irrelevant (since most of the learnings and points do come from the readings themselves).
Solid.

Students should take entrepreneurship classes before they graduate. This class can be as little to no work as you want it to be. I took it quite seriously so I was at times spending the majority of my time on this class. The readings are very manageable but students should be aware of the 2 mandatory group meetings that need to occur each week. It's a great way to meet other people but it is quite time-consuming. Nevertheless, if you want to leave Princeton with a good idea of how to run a meeting professionally and how to work effectively in a team, this is a great class.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! The skills you learn are relevant in anything you do in life, not only if you want to be an entrepreneur. It really teaches you self-awareness and how to work in teams as leader and member. It's made me 1000% more effective and productive in all parts of my life. One of my favorite classes in Princeton!!!
Take it and do the readings.
Take it in your senior year. You won't regret it

Take it! This class really structures and codifies the fuzzy world of leadership. There are so many theories, ideas and suggestions floating around the business academia, so it is really important to be able to gain insight about entrepreneurial leadership in a clear and consistent fashion. I learned so much about myself in this class and I will use these lessons for the rest of my career and life!
Take this class if you plan to start a company, it will be quite helpful. Leadership is an often underappreciated quality and developing it in a class is a great opportunity.

The team projects taught me a lot about myself and leadership in general. (Make sure to budget in 1.5-5 hours/week for team meetings.) However, be prepared to sit through 3 hours/week of really unhelpful Q&A style lectures. In hindsight, I would not have taken this course.

Things to watch out for: In class quizzes on reading, group work, lots of talking.

I loved the course, but its def not for everyone.
This is one of those Princeton classes that could change your life. Take it.
excellent
otherinfo: Goal is to provide an experiential learning opportunity showing how engineers, together with scientists and other professionals, really build companies.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Design Project - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: The class uses the Case Study Method, supplemented with reading from articles and books, and includes team assignments designed to practice the skills discussed in actual situations. Approximately 7 hours of homework per week, including team assignments.
prereqs: Interest/passion in discovering how an idea can become a real company.This course is not open to students who took EGR 495 Special Topics in Entrepreneurship: Entrepreneurial Leadership..
descrip: The mission of the class is to enable students to successfully create and lead enterprises by teaching the basic skills required to be a successful entrepreneurial leader. This class compliments EGR 491 "High Tech Entrepreneurship" which focuses on 'giving birth to a company', by focusing instead on enterprise 'early child rearing'. The basic skills taught fall into three major categories: how to create and manage powerful relationships, how to know and manage yourself, in addition to understanding how organizations work as they evolve from the idea stage to become value producing, self-sustaining enterprises.
title: Entrepreneurial Leadership

evals: A bit harder than expected
A fun STL. A LOT of material. Not especially easy. If you don't have a mind of physics but don't like that stop you. but you will have to work harder. Qualitative material was really interesting.

As a STEM major, this course did not emphasize the quantitative aspect of astrophysics enough for me. That said, it was a great fifth class that I took out of general interest. My advice would be to not put off the "observations" portion of the course. If you put in the time early on, it can be extremely rewarding to use the telescopes and cameras!

As a physics major, I found some of the concepts in this course, like how solar systems form to be very interesting. On the other hand, while the math and physics on the problem sets was easy, they were still fairly time consuming and not particularly interesting. If you're studying math or physics, I'd recommend taking another more rigorous astronomy course instead.
