Attend the lectures when possible, but definitely read the textbook! Also, attend the star parties, they were fun. This course was challenging but not impossible (as someone who only took one year of high school physics and didn't do that well)
BAKOS IS AMAZING. BEST COURSE EVER.

Definitely easier STNs out there, but this one is doable if you put in some effort. If you're good at physics, that'll help a lot. If not try to find people who are for psets (there are 5 but most are long, tedious, and difficult). Lots of the grade is group work, so find a good group (or take class with friends) and go observing early before it gets freezing. In terms of PDFing, an A/B  is doable with effort and studying, but still many people do PDF and the curve as a result is nice. Lectures often put me to sleep but Professor Bakos is a very likable and genuine guy. No precepts is a nice plus. Definitely don't take if you're not interested in astro.

Do not take this course unless you have a solid background in math and physics. It was described to me as a fun class that taught about the title (Planets in the Universe) and incorporated physics. Lectures are entirely centered on planets, the universe, and abstract concepts, with only a very few physics principles scattered in. Problem sets were straight up physics that we had never been taught. You're expected to know basic physics principles and learn the rest from reading the book and asking questions or visiting office hours/help sessions. Not a class for someone looking to fill a distribution requirement. However, if you are in the department, Professor Barkos is very understanding and quite funny. This might be a good fit for someone who excels at the material.
Don't take this course unless you want to be an astrophysicist
Fun course; lectures can get a little stale even if you have interest in astronomy. Worth taking though. Easy if you have a physics background. You get grades for looking at stars!
Go to lecture!
Go to lecture, Prof. Bakos is a great lecturer. Go observing! It's really fun!
Go to office hours!
Great class. Very manageable workload while still learning quite a bit. The exams emphasize qualitative concepts (in case the physics might scare you off) while the hws tend to be more quantitative.
I enjoyed the course! It was new and different and I felt like it was a good course to take if interested in introductory astrophysics and planet exploration

I strongly recommend that everyone takes this course. If you're not a STEM person, you'll learn lots about space and astronomy. If you're a space enthusiast and have a solid background, you'll still learn more about exoplanets and the current methods used to detect and analyze them. Attend the lectures; they're not only important but the material is interesting and Professor Bakos tries to keep them engaging. Start the p-sets early, they can be time consuming sometimes. Attend lots of star-parties; they're lots of fun and you'll start to recognize different stars and constellations which is a fun skill to share with friends and family.

I would not recommend taking this course if you do not consider yourself a "math-minded" person. I had a lot of trouble understanding the quantitative concepts, which makes the class very difficult. So if you are a non-science/math major looking for a distribution requirement, just know that it will take a lot of work to understand the math. The qualitative portion of the class is very interesting, though, and the observing portion of the class is really rewarding!!!

I'm BSE COS and I found the mathematical (physics) parts of the course very easy. Beware that there ends up being a lot of qualitative material. Also, it says STN, but there's actually about 1/2 a lab (you have to go star/sky observing over the course of the semester).

I've always been interested in space so I took the course because I wanted to learn more about it. The material is interesting but the class may seem a little boring at first. Professor Bakos is awesome and definitely go to the star parties!
If you are interested in the subject definitely take this course. There is a lot of material. Not an easy A.

If you're interested in planets and astronomy, I'd really recommend this course. Bakos is a fantastic lecturer. However, the course load is heavier than expected. Be prepared to spend a good amount of time doing assignments, journals, and observation sessions.

If you're planning to take it as your STN, know that it requires way more effort than what you're probably thinking. Problem sets are long and complicated, observing sessions can get freezing cold! But professor is kind and engaging.
Interesting class, not too hard, great lecturer!

It is integral that students attend the lectures frequently as the majority of exams are filled with questions related to the lectures. Studying for exams would be extremely difficult without attending lecture as the course covers a ton of material. I would also recommend reaching out to instructors for help on problem sets as they make the difficult material much clearer.

It's a pretty cool class! If you go to lecture, you don't really have to read the book (but having the book can help with problem sets). Going to observing sessions will probably take up more of your time than you'd expect, but I thought that they were actually pretty fun!
Professor Bakos is an amazing lecturer. If you have any interest in astronomy take the class. Problem sets are doable with any background in high school physics.

Start observing early in the semester! I had assumed we would go over telescopic observing techniques and astrophotography in class, which is why I waited. All the information you need is online, so start observing while it's still warm out!

TAKE THIS, especially if you are looking for an interesting STN. Professor Bakos is amazing - so engaging, caring, and funny, he makes the already interesting material so intellectually stimulating. It is not a walk in the park, but definitely not too challenging (even for non-STEM people) if you pay attention and take notes in lecture. I didn't read the textbook at all and still did well in the class. Also star parties are fun!!
Take the course, Prof Bakos was amazing, and all the work in the course is well worth it.

Take this class if you have a relatively strong background in physics. I did not and struggled very much with psets (very much physics heavy). Professor Bakos is an amazing lecturer and is very engaging and nice!

The class isn't super hard. I put in almost no work and am passing with a low B. Even without putting in extra work, the homeworks are long and rigorous. Also, the lectures are dull and everything can be found online; consider them fully optional.
The lectures are great, the problem sets almost kill the class by frequently going too far from what we actually learn, especially for a class advertised as being for non-STEM majors
The observing and journaling takes time.
The tests include far more problems than you can finish. Do the ones you know.

There is no requirement to have taken physics before this class, but there should be. The problem sets were incredibly hard and would take me hours, both because there was so much physics that I didn't know and because there were so many things that we were never taught in class. Don't just take it for a fun class, it's more work than you'd think.
This is a great course.

This is not 'Stars for Stoners,' but still a great class, mainly because Gaspar is awesome! He is super funny and makes lecture engaging. A lot of the class were non-science people, which was nice. The course is a lot of work though due to there being problems sets and observations. Make sure you complete the telescopic observations and astrophotography in a timely manner and don't wait until reading period to try and finish them (which happened to a lot of groups). You also need to post current events in the group journal once a week, which just another thing you have to keep in mind. In total, this group journal work with observations counts for 30% of your grade, while to final is only 25%, so its super important. The problem sets were a bit difficult. Overall, I was glad I took the class and got my STN requirement out of the way.

This was an incredible class, and if you put effort into it you will have a great experience. I would recommend starting and doing the problem sets early, and attend office hours as Professor Bakos is extremely helpful. Also, attend the star parties as they are very helpful for learning how to observe the sky.

as far as taking this as a PDF STN: don't get this mixed up with stars for stoners - it's pretty tough in that it requires time observing, doing psets, and writing journal entries. the curve is amazing though so take it if you want
otherinfo: Students will be involved in telescopic observations and astrophotography. Some of these will be during selected lectures (in the daytime, e.g.observing the Sun and Venus), and others will be in the evenings (e.g. Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune). OTHER: group activities: observing. Participation on at least one star party required for passing the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Approximately 42 pages per week. Five homework assignments through the semester.
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This is an introductory course in astronomy focusing on planets in our Solar System, and around other stars (exoplanets). First we review the formation, evolution and properties of the Solar system. Following an introduction to stars, we then discuss the exciting new field of exoplanets; discovery methods, earth-like planets, and extraterrestrial life. Core values of the course are quantitative analysis and hands-on experience, including telescopic observations. This STN course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. See www.astro.princeton.edu/planets for important changes
title: Planets in the Universe

evals: A fun course -- especially if you're looking for an English course that isn't so "English"-y.
A very easy LA. Might be frustrating for English majors.

A very fun class -- take it with friends!  If you watch all the movies and put effort into the essays, it'll be a higher time commitment than other fun classes, but definitely worth it! Professor Fuss' lectures are very insightful, and made me think a lot more deeply about the movies we watched, and cinema in general.
ABSOLUTELY.
Absolutely take it. Makes you look at cinema and all films in a different way.
Absolutely take this course.
Actually go to lecture, take thorough notes, meet with your preceptor, and watch ALL the movies.
All you really have to do is watch the movies and go to lecture. Take good notes.

Always watch the movies before lecture - not worth going if you didn't watch. And even if you've watched one of the movies prior to the course, watch it again...you'll see things you missed the first time.
Analyze the film beyond just what you think, look into a new perspective and a new mindset
Attend lecture! It's fantastic!
Avoid Kira's precept.

Be careful with your preceptor.  Make sure it's a veteran on whom there are reviews.  

Frankly, it would be better just to watch these movies on your own with Wikipedia open.
Definitely take it
Definitely take it, big class so be prepared for pros and cons that come with it
Definitely take the course as it allows you to watch a great series of movies guilt free.
Definitely take the course if you are interested in popular movies/even American history. The course definitely causes you to look at movies (even non-syllabus ones) in a new light
Definitely take the course. It is very interesting and you get to watch some great movies that you should definitely watch at some point in your life.
Definitely take this class! Diana is the best, most friendliest teacher in the world. You won't regret it. And take it with friends its so much fun.
Definitely take this class. It's not too much work and it's worth it. Also go to lectures, it's not that long and it's worth it.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in film, anything ranging from film analysis to casual moviegoing.
Definitely take this course, Professor Fuss is fantastic and the movies are all worth watching regardless of whether or not you have to.
Definitely take this course, if you work hard at papers you can get good grades and the movies are all great
Definitely take this course.  Watch all the movies and start to think of every movie different because of it.
Definitely take this course. It will change the way you view films as well as develop your ability to speak intelligently about films.
Don't be afraid to think out of the box, it's hard to be wrong
Don't take this course for an easy A grade or an easy LA requirement. Take it for personal interest (it is well worth it!)
Enjoy
Excellent.
Films are fantastic, grading is kind of arbitrary. Your experience depends on your TA, but its an easy class overall that's fun to be in.
Fun easy LA if you need it
Fun, though not particularly special or fascinating
Go for it.
Go to lectures if you actually care to learn about the movies! They teach you so much more than you learn by just watching the movies alone.
Go to office hours for the paper
Go to your preceptor with your paper drafts just so they know you're working hard on it.

Good selection of movies and not a big work load. But beware: Most of the students are not taking the class seriously, which makes it hard to get anything out discussion. The lectures are pretty engaging, but not terribly helpful for the papers and some claims are a bit ridiculous.
Great PDF option tough A.
Great and relatively easy LA course. Awesome movies and well taught critiques.
Great class! Go to lectures and watch the movies! Its fun and watching movies is a good way to productively procrastinate!
Great course with a relatively fun/light work load. Definitely take if you love watching movies like me!

Great course. It's incredibly easy and fairly enjoyable ? not just to slip by with a B, but to fully engage. Workload is two movies a week, two short papers (midterm and final), and exam, all fairly enjoyable and not very time consuming. And the movies are great. Take it.
I hated the papers and the grading. I am not an English person, don't know why I thought I could take this class as my "easy class".
I recommend this course to any student--regardless of their major. The classwork, written work, and films were all enjoyable and reflected the course's level of organization.
I strongly recommend taking this course: so interesting and fun!

I took this course because I wanted to learn how to get more out of movies beyond aesthetic enjoyment. I watched all the films, attended all the precepts, attended almost all the lectures. It's worth taking this class just to watch the movies. It could be so much better though. Professor Fuss is an ok lecturer. I felt like quite a few times, she was really grasping at straws -- maybe she's just a really postmodernist reader who is trying to create meaning, but I think if she was trying to interpret what the director intended, it sometimes seemed far-fetched. That being said, it made me think more critically about movies in general, so I liked that. My preceptor, Kira, is a very very very sweet person. That being said, she was not a good preceptor. The main issue was that every time she asked a question, no one really knew what she meant. I didn't end up getting anything out of the precept, which is a shame because I really liked the other ENG precept that I had.
I would recommend it.
I would recommend this course to someone looking for an introduction to film studies.

If you are comfortable with a class that lacks focus and isn't clear about what's expected from you, and you just want to watch movies and hear semi-interesting observations about them in lecture, then I would say go for the class. If you want to be serious about film analysis, the class doesn't analyze films closely enough, and if you want to talk about the films in a social context, the class is too stretched to adequately address that as well. 

Professor Fuss is well meaning and I've heard that her precept is pretty good, but she is not that engaging and the overarching focus of the lectures is not clear and does not match her original, stated intentions from the opening lecture. 

Be ready for precepts that include students who don't care and preceptors who don't know what they're doing.
If you're an English major, definitely take this for the theory & criticism requirement. This class is a lot of fun, there's no secondary readings. It's just watching movies.

If you're interested in film at all, take this class. Professor Fuss is an excellent lecturer and the workload is relatively light. Also, the movies are fun to watch and I really think I learned something about them.
It will make you dislike movies you once liked.
It's a good class to get an overview of major films.
It's really easy.

Its a great course, but definitely don't skip lectures as the notes she gives can be very helpful on the final. Don't skip precepts either, and incorporate your ideas and get comments on them from classmates and preceptors, which will be very helpful for writing your papers.

Lectures were really boring for someone with some film background. Professor makes "insights" that can really just be found on Wikipedia or film review sites. Don't take it if you are really into movies -- you've prob already have seen the Hollywood flicks on the syllabus, and you won't learn anything new.
Look for a preceptor you like, Because they control your grade in the class.
Make sure you go to lecture, take notes, and watch the movies.

Not a bad class, but watch out for the no-PDF option! This would be a great class to PDF, but unfortunately it's hard to get a high grade without since. There are only four grades in the class - two papers, precept participation, and the final exam, so if you don't do well on all those things, you're screwed.
Not an easy class if you want to do well.
Not as easy as people say it is...
Not worth taking if you just want an easy blow-off class. Preceptor was harsh and critical, and I do not feel like I learned much from the class.
One of the best classes I have ever taken in Princeton! Great break from problem set classes.

Pretty cool class. I wish that the syllabus was a little more widespread however, with less emphasis on Shia Labeouf and his career. I understand he is a great American actor, but it seems pretty restrictive to only watch movies with him in it
Really enjoyed watching the films for this class. Still, the lectures were pretty unimpressive and the precepts an absolute waste of time.

Relatively easy, but way less interesting than you think it'll be. Professor Fuss' lectures are not interesting and her analyses are often pretty dumb and irrelevant. My high school film class was 10x better. Still easy though and nice to watch movies for homework
Remember its npdf
Requires a degree of self-engagement but a fairly low commitment class.
Stay on top of all the films
Super interesting! Easy homework to just watch movies.

TAKE IT! I absolutely loved this class! It's great if you love watching movies and want to to see them from a more academic perspective. Aside from her crazy puns, Professor Fuss comes up with some pretty interesting ideas in lecture. The workload is fairly light - mostly just watching films which is fun and only a few really easy readings. There are two papers and a final but if you get a good preceptor than you should do just fine.
TAKE THIS COURSE - especially for a 5th class.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!!!!! One of my favorite that I've taken at Princeton so far. You will not regret it!!!
TAKE THIS. Professor Fuss is the best professor and gives the best lectures I have had here at Princeton.
Take it
Take it as a 5th class.  Pay attention in lectures and everything will come easy.
Take it if you want an easy class and are interested in watching the movies.
Take it if you want to catch up on your American movies.
Take it if you want very little work during the semester.
Take it seriously - some people don't realize the class is no PDF.

Take it simply for the reason that you don't know as much about the American film industry as you might think. But expect to get lower grades on the papers than you like if you don't watch every movie or learn how to write a  paper about film.
Take it!
Take it! But don't expect it to be a walk in the park if you're just looking to get rid of an LA. It's possible to get an A, but the class isn't a joke so take it seriously.
Take it! Great films and if you're at all a decent writer the assignments are pretty easy
Take it! It's an easy and interesting LA, and probably my favorite course of the semester.
Take it! It's awesome to 'have to' watch movies as homework. I wish there were more classes like this at Princeton.

Take it! It's fun, a lot of your friends will be in it, papers are fun, and learning about American cinema is such a useful skill that will influence the way I watch movies and think about culture for the rest of my life!
Take it, you won't regret it
Take it.
Take it. 100%.
Take it. not too much work.
Take the class to watch the movies.  It is fun even for just that reason.
Take the course. It is a good way to get rid of a LA requirement
Take this class!
Take this class!! It's awesome, and it's a great excuse to watch cool movies in the name of doing homework.
Take this course and watch all the movies.
Take this course if you want to think about films in new critical ways.
Take this course!
Take this course!  Lectures are decent and precepts are great.  All you have to do is watch Hollywood blockbusters!

Take this course! If you are concerned about the grade you might get on your paper, talk to your preceptor early in the writing process. Aside from that, this course is officially my favorite non-science class.
Take this course! Whether you're a film buff re-watching these movies for new insights, or you're watching them for the first time, American Cinema is a blast!
Take this course. It is very enjoyable and a great opportunity to watch films you've always wanted to see but haven't had the time to. Professor Fuss' lectures are insightful and thought-provoking.
Take this. Great class on cinema, inspiring and insightful lectures. Made me watch movies in new ways.
The movies are good to watch, the topics are straightforward, and the workload is light.

The movies are good, but her lectures are so, so bad. She thinks that every sentence is like the most important revelation in the world - her voice pitch goes up in a sort of "A-Ha!" type reaction. Took a lot of energy to convince myself to go to lecture everyday. That being said, it is pretty easy, and all your friends will take it, so take it.

This course is great and a light workload. Don't stress about readings. Try to watch the movies and attend lecture, but overall your grade depends on your papers and the final. Talk to your preceptor about your argument on your papers beforehand, they will often give you great evidence or warn you against weak arguments. Plus they are grading you so it helps to be on the same page.

This course is really fun and almost no work, but I'm an English major and I don't expect to get an A in this class. Everyone I talked to did poorly on the first paper, but if you need an LA with almost no work, this is the way to go. Everyone should watch these films at some point. Don't take it if you don't like hearing weird theories/opinions on films stated as facts. There is little room for your own interpretation/argument with the interpretations given, as far as this course is concerned.

This is a great course. Please don't take this course because you're looking for something that you think will be easy. Yes, it is an easy class to pass, but it certainly isn't easy to write good essays. Instead, take this course because you love film. Having a couple of favorite movies isn't enough (like the 6 people in my precept who only wanted to talk about Mean Girls). You really need to be open to accept film as a form of literature/art. Many people in the course can't do this, and they spend most of their time during lecture scoffing at Professor Fuss's excellent analysis because they think she's reading too far into these movies. Do everything you can to watch all of the movies before precept. They are all excellent and worth your time. Also, don't skip the reading. It's very short and helpful. If you love movies, this is the best class at Princeton for you.
This is great course, take it!

This is not an "easy" class in terms of workload or materials - you will have to write papers and take exams which require a serious analysis of film. However, the work is often very enjoyable and fun, because we study popular American movies. I'd recommend it if you're looking for an entertaining class to complement a hard schedule.
Try to get Professor Fuss as your preceptor.
Watch all of the movies, even if they don't seem interesting at first.
Watch all the movies and attend every single lecture. Seriously, you'll regret it if you don't and it's the best way to get the most out of the course.
Watch all the movies and go to the lectures. They are actually pretty interesting. The second half of the semester was really interesting.
Watch all the movies.

Watch as many of the movies as you can! Some people only watched half of them and I think it really takes away from the overarching themes of the course. 

Also, take the time OVER THE WEEKEND and watch both--don't try to do it during the week, unless your schedule is really free on certain days.  It's much harder to find two 2-3 hour chunks of time during the week than it is on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday.
Watch the films before precept.
Watch the films.
Watch the movies before lecture and pay close attention to them. What you get out of the class is very dependent on how engaged you and your classmates in precept choose to be.
Watch the movies before lecture!
Watch the movies on time
Watch the movies.
While this class is about movies, don't take it lightly. I know other people who did so and didn't do as well as they hoped.
Yes
You get to watch movies for homework. its awesome.
You have to like watching all kinds of movies.

You only need to go to the lectures you are going to write papers on, so really only need to go to two lectures all semester then bum notes off a friend who actually went. The theories proposed are laughable. She is grasping at thin straws. But that also means all you need to do to write good papers is come up with the most incredibly unbelievable idea possible and you will get a good grade for originality and deep thought.
You'll watch cool movies, but don't expect this to be just a walk in the park.
Your homework is watching movies and writing two papers. This class is fun and the subject matter is not very complex. Everyone can get involved.
fun class
great class to get rid of your LA, very easy
highly recommend
not a difficult course, but know that watching the movies might be more of a burden than a fun break because many of them are boring/hard to follow
not too much work and the movies were good, i would recommend it
take it
take it - papers are easy, movies are good.
take it if you like movies!
take it!

this class is tempting because it seems easy and you get to watch movies. The latter part is true--your reading is just watching good movies, and that's fun. But as long as Prof. Fuss is lecturing, you might want to think again about taking this course because she sucks. Sucks sucks sucks. All the lectures were about the same things (the holy trinity of raceclassgender) and she speaks like a 12 year old. Lectures were supremely boring and useless for any and all writing you'll do. My preceptor (kira) also sucked--mean and unhelpful, facilitating the most awkward precept possible, full of bizarre questions, awkward silences and irrelevant asides. I know some preceptors are better, but regardless, think twice about taking this class.
watch the movies
otherinfo: Department Distribution: Theory and Criticism/Modernity
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: In addition to the films, students will read Ed Sikov's book "Film Studies: An Introduction" as a guide.
descrip: This film genre course addresses the cultural heritage of our national cinema. How has cinema shaped American culture, and how has American culture shaped cinema? We will focus on iconic figures in American film: robbers, tycoons, immigrants, cowboys, gangsters, detectives, lovers, monsters, cyborgs, survivors. Each week will pair an early film with a later one to trace a given genre's evolution; for example, the week on westerns might pair John Ford's "The Searchers" (1956) with Ang Lee's "Brokeback Mountain" (2005). The course studies commercial Hollywood films that serve as important barometers of their times.
title: American Cinema

evals: Overall, course was structured about as well as it could have been. A relatively light workload and auto P/D/F made it much easier to focus on knocking out the first of two JPs. Baraz is great and it's also nice to meet other profs in the dept
Take advantage of the fact that professors in all different areas of Classics are coming in to speak with you! It's a special opportunity!

There is little point in me recommending this class: If you aren't a classics major, you can't; if you are, you have to. 

Nevertheless if it weren't such a class, I would strongly recommend it. The visiting professors were fascinating, the discussions a lot of fun, and the papers (Jps) were excellent.

This was a waaaaaaay more interesting required Junior Sem. than I thought it would be. I looked forward to doing the readings and going to class more than for many of my graded classes. Professor Baraz is wonderful!
you have to take it if you are a classics major soooo
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Short exercises in literary and historical methodologies.
descrip: This course will introduce concentrators to the study of classical antiquity. Students will become acquainted with different fields of study within the Department, including literature, ancient history, linguistics, and the long reception of antiquity in the middle ages and modernity in order to acquire an understanding of the history of the discipline and its place in the twenty-first century. Sessions will involve guest visits from members of the faculty. Particular attention will be paid to acquiring the skills necessary to pursue independent research for the spring Junior Paper.
title: Junior Seminar: Introduction to Classics

evals: As long as you regularly go to class and do the p-sets, it is fairly easy to do well in the class. However, make sure to study hard for the final. It is unexpectedly harder than remaining of the assignments in the class.
Be prepared for a very hard final
Definitely take it if you want a doable QR or need it for either Econ/Political Economy. Totally manageable workload
Dr. Schmoyer is amazing! Best math course I've taken at Princeton.
Dr. Schmoyer is an awesome teacher. Quizzes are not too hard and homework only takes about 2 hours a week.
Easiest math course I have ever taken.
Go to lecture, and read the book.  Complete the problem sets to the best of your ability and study them for exams and quizzes!
Good course, would recommend. But don't take it too lightly because it can get challenging if you get behind.
Great math class, not demanding, if you attend class and do the suggested practice problems it can be as easy A.

I advise people to take this class because its straightforward and fairly easy to understand if you put the work in. The problem sets help prepare you for quizzes, and going to class gives you a leg up compared some other students in the class.
I heard the person that's not Francesc is better
I loved this class and would recommend to all students interested.
I recommend taking this if math isn't your favorite class in the world. It could change your mind.
I would recommend this course.

If you were decent at Calculus in high school, you should honestly consider trying 201 and 202 instead. While this class was well-taught, I found that it was a little too easy, and I felt like I sold myself short by not learning more valuable skills through 201 and 202. If you were decent at Calc AB/BC, this class should be no trouble at all.

If you're stuck between 201 and 175, take 175! The exams and quizzes are manageable and the problem sets aren't too difficult. Dr. Schmoyer is a great professor and the handouts that she gives out in class makes studying for the class so much easier. Definitely the best math class I've taken here.
It is a doable class compared to other more difficult math classes.
Pick Susan!
Read the book along with the lectures and do lots of practice problems
Really well taught course and easier than 103 in my opinion. Definitely take this over 201 if you can.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! With Professor Susan Schmoyer, she is nice and amazing and not too hard. Overall, this class was great in that it taught the basics that I wanted to learn but was not challenging at all (arguably too easy); you learn some solid math without much effort (and can get a high grade. I spent around 30 min to 1.5 hours each week on problem sets. Caution: if you want a challenging class (on par or harder than AP BC calculus, MAT 103/104, etc) or really like/are good at math, this is NOT the class to take. But if you want a super chill math class with an amazing prof and learn some basic MV, this is where it's at.
Take it
Take only if you're sure you need it. It's not bad, and it's a good shortcut for econ /finance certificate.

Take this class if you want a math class that's easy to understand and very fair in terms of exams and homework assignments. Prof Schmoyer is really good at explaining concepts and topics and I really enioyed this class.
Take this course! It's very good and Dr. Schmoyer is a very engaging teacher.
Take this over math 104! However, you will need to put in the work and go to office hours!

The class had a very manageable pace; I was nervous about taking my first math class at Princeton, and I'm really happy I chose 175 over 103/104. Definitely keep up with the suggested practice problems, attend review sessions, and study well for the midterm. Professor Castella is a concise lecturer, and always available for help after lecture.
The lectures were copied from the textbook. Professor Castella copied the textbook pretty much word for word. He is not interested in the topic.
The midterm is pretty chill as are the psets and quizzes. Final is a lot harder.
This class is generally not terrible. The final is harder than any of the other assessments. The problem sets are very manageable, and a lot of resources are given to you so that you can do well.
This course isn't too bad. It gets a little confusing at times, homework is really easy, but make sure you study for the quizzes because they are not like the homework.
This is a solid course that will teach you the fundamentals of 3D calculus. If you can, take it with Prof. Schmoyer - she's amazing and enthusiastic and made the class more fun.

This is a very fair and well-taught math course. I ended up PDFing because I decided against majoring in econ and was taking 4 other classes, but if you study and do the work (which was never excessive) you will do fine. I was initially worried about the amount of calc knowledge needed before taking this class (I took an AP calc class in senior yr of high school and took this in my soph spring and was worried bc I felt I forgot all my calc), and if this is you then don't worry about it. the first week is all review of the calc you need to know, and you'll never have to do a limit, derivation, or integration that is insanely difficult or complicated; you just need to know the basics.
Yes please take it! It was awesome
good class for econ majors
if you need it take it.
only if professor schmoyer is teaching
yes
otherinfo: MAT201/202 is strongly recommended for finance and math track economics. Students who complete 175 can continue in 202 if they wish.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 20%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and readings from the textbook; quizzes as determined by instructor.
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent. MAT175 not allowed if MAT201 taken.
descrip: Survey of topics from multivariable calculus as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, vectors, partial derivatives, gradient, optimization of multivariable functions, and constrained optimization with Lagrange multipliers.
title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences

evals: A general understanding of functional programming is very useful in other parts of CS, but having said that, I think we covered everything relevant in the first half of the course. Moretti is great.
A must take for any and all COS students. Not an easy class in terms of amount of work but a very important and interesting subject. Well taught by Prof. Walker. .
Be prepared to dedicate some time to the course. The time dedicated is well worth it, functional programming changes the way you think about programming.

DEFINITELY take this class -- you will not regret it. It's definitely a hard class to take, but you should make room for it especially if Walker or Moretti are teaching it -- they're super enthusiastic about the class and teaching

Definitely take the course, especially if Walker is teaching it! It was a great experience and the material taught really changes how you think about programming. The paradigm is very different from what you are traditionally used to (and very useful to learn)!
Difficult, but worth taking.
Do it, functional is a fun sort of programming.

Extremely fun class. I've learned a ton and have really been amazed by OCaml!

I would recommend this class even though it's just as hard as everyone says. I probably won't be getting the grade I want in a COS departmental, but I still don't regret taking it at all!

Functional is surprisingly widely-applicable - I was learning ReactJS just recently, and it turns out functional programming concepts are worming their way into many aspects of web development. I found the challenges of the assignments to be very satisfying--it pushes you to solve problems and think in ways that you probably don't have much cause to in routine software development. The course is also extremely well organized--on par with 126/226/217.

Functional programming is very interesting and is becoming more and more useful in the software industry especially start-ups. Everyone should take this course! The second half gets more theoretical, but at least stick around for the first half. The course isn't too much time.
Great COS class.
Great class. Well structured, well taught.
Great course for COS majors - learn a new way to program. Beware, the latter-half of the assignments are quite difficult, though (so find a good partner!).

I don't know how the class is with Appel, but with Walker/Moretti, it was fantastic. This is one of my favorite CS classes in the department. The lectures are a little too soothing, but he presents the material very well. Moretti (lead preceptor) does an amazing job at answering Piazza questions and being overall SO helpful - go to his office hours and get to know him! His precepts were also great - I went to a couple others a few times and his definitely stand out both in terms of his knowledge of the material as well as general engagement. I highly recommend - you have to keep up with the material, but it's a wonderful class.

I think is a critical course in developing students programming problem solving skills. 

We are forced to learn how to step back from complicated problems, relax the constraints, abstract the procedures, and discover the cleanest approach. We learn how to write much better code as a result.

Many COS326 reviews only talk about recursion and proofs. They leave out the fact that COS326 also covers parallel programming and the fundamental ideas behind it (e.g. Map-Reduce). If you are unsure of the practicality of this class, then consider this another important reason for why you should learn what COS326 has to offer.

I took this class because everyone always said that functional programming was something that you had to do as a programmer.  They said that it would improve my recursive reasoning.  But I'm almost to the end of the class with one more assignment to go and I don't know if I feel like I'm better at coding.  This leads me to the following conclusion: I spent a lot of time studying and working on these assignments for little payoff.  Now, this might be because I'm measuring my improvement in terms of my imperative language coding skills, and that's a fair criticism of my criticism.  I'm probably decent at functional language programming now.

If you're considering this class because you think that somehow this class will make you better as a programmer somehow, it's not going to make you good enough to justify all the hours.  Probably better to just spend time on LeetCode or something.  However, there's one bright spot to this class: it also functions as an introduction to PL theory and PL proofs.  I found that kind of interesting.  

Basically, take this class only if you have a strong reason to, since it is a lot of work.  Also I wish this class taught Haskell instead of Ocaml since the former is more widely used.  But it's not that big of a deal since functional languages are pretty similar to each other anyway.

If you are looking to fulfill an applications departmental for COS, look no further than this course. I think this should be essential for all COS majors. Functional programming is incredibly interesting and exposes you to a new way of programming (and even thinking about programs) that you have not been exposed to before with just imperative programming. Professor Walker is a great professor and explains things very clearly. The problem sets are also well-done and help contribute to your understanding of the material, although they can sometimes be quite long, so start them early. However, you can probably skip the precepts; they were not very helpful for me and your time would be best spent reviewing the lecture/precept materials on your own.

It's a different way of thinking and you'll probably find it strange at first, but you learn a lot! While OCaml might not seem "useful" outside of places like Jane Street, the class helps you understand programming languages and the design and reasoning behind them. Assignments are not that bad - the first half is mainly fill in the function exercises (be warned, they might take quite some thinking) and/or proofs while the second half is longer but not necessarily more difficult.
It's a good course and mostly well-organized. If you like recursion and/or proofs, you'll probably enjoy it. Chris Moretti is amazing if you can get him as a preceptor.

It's a solid course. People say it's very math-intensive but I don't think that's as true as others say. If you math skills aren't strong then it shouldn't deter you from taking the class. A lot of time will be spent learning the conventions of OCaml though, rather than why functional programming as a discipline is interesting.
It's cool stuff, but it's so hard! I didn't expect this course to be so difficult, as I've taken a lot of other courses. But I feel so much cooler now that I know OCaml.
It's hard for a sophomore taking 217 at the same time, but it's definitely a great class and I think it's worth it.
Make sure you have enough time for this class. Easily one of the most interesting but also challenging COS classes. I loved it.
OCaml is a blast - especially with D Walker

OCaml is a very interesting language and functional programming is a really cool way to approach programming. However these lectures and precepts were often boring and slow, and could be hard to follow. Some assignments are extremely long. I would recommend going to office hours, reviewing slides after each lecture, and doing the exercises to practice for the assignments.

Overall, I am really glad I took this class because I have learned a lot. As a COS major, functional programming opened my eyes to a different way of thinking, that's recursive and fundamentally different from the traditional Object Oriented Programming that I was used to. Walker is a great lecturer and Moretti is super helpful. I would recommend anyone who's interested in exploring a new way of thinking as a programmer and also a more theoretical approach to programming.

Pretty good.
If you are into MAT-COS then I recommend it. Maybe taking a look at some Category Theory before could be interesting. 
A rather interesting topic that definitely touches some beautiful math things that I wish that Java and C had.
Really cool concept of programming. So much simpler than imperative programming! I want to learn more! Nice introduction to parallel programming as well.
Really interesting class, turns programming paradigm on its head. Careful, it is a proof heavy class with a lot of mathematical focus. Assignments take a good amount of time each, so plan ahead.
Really interesting course that opens you up to a framework of coding besides object-oriented design. Strong resources that are able to help often
Start assignments early.
Study hard for Midterms and Finals. Make sure you go to lectures.

Take it if you want to learn another paradigm for coding,  It is a wonderful learning experience. Reach out and get help from the professors and TAs when you need it, Attend lectures as much as possible since they are useful.

Take this class if you want to learn. It teaches a more mathematical philosophy of computer science, instead of an engineering philosophy of computer science like in 217, and this gives you a lot of perspective. Also, it is very fun if you like correctness, and has a lot of really great succinct puzzles in the assignments.

Take this course if you're interested in a new way of thinking about programming. Not required, but would recommend also taking 217 before it as a solid computer background will really help you out here.

The assignments can be tricky, especially as you're getting used to how FP works. Give yourself plenty of time to complete them. Prof. Walker's lecture slides are also crazy helpful for learning & for reviewing. Prof. Walker and Chris Morretti are great at explaining things in office hours, so do not be afraid to go talk to them! I can't speak for other preceptors.

The class is well taught and well organized (at least with Walker), but know that the assignments are quite involved (think 226/217 and possibly more). The class is one of the most conceptually difficult COS classes I've taken, especially if you have a more limited COS/math background. There are proofs in the class, but most of them were manageable for non-math majors. It did teach me to think about programming in a different way which was cool, but think carefully about whether that's a worthwhile tradeoff for you.

This class forces you to code with a lot of limitations in order to make your code easier to reason/write proofs about. Instead of loops you write recursive functions, or even just calls to map/reduce, instead of mutating data structures you create new ones. As a more practical programmer (does this do good?) I found these limitations to be frustrating.

This course is not for everyone, but if you like abstract mathematics and elegance, and/or want to discover something completely different from all other languages you've likely learnt, take it. Start the assignments early, they are very long.

This is a very interesting, worthwhile course! The workload varies; it can be a lot in the first half of the semester, but things get more spread out in the second half. The exams are hard (though I think they've been getting better over the years), though.
This is an amazing course that teaches you a completely different way of thinking about programming. Although at times it may be difficult, it is definitely very rewarding. Highly recommend!
This is an interesting course, but make sure you have a good partner for the later assignments (don't try and do them alone!).
none
take it if you like studying programming languages and proofs
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Programming Assignments - 60%
assgts: Weekly or bi-weekly assignments.
prereqs: COS 226 or with permission of the instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the principles of typed functional programming. Programming recursive functions over structured data types and informal reasoning by induction about the correctness of those functions. Functional algorithms and data structures. Principles of modular programming, type abstraction, representation invariants and representation independence. Parallel functional programming, algorithms and applications.
title: Functional Programming

evals: Definitely take this if you are not sure if you are ready for Calculus. I dropped Calc I last year because I didn't have the basic understanding provided in this course.
I would recommend this class.

If you want reinforcement in your foundational math knowledge then take this class. If you have already taken higher level math you will find this course redundant but Prof. Howard is a very effective communicator so if you have concerns about taking calculus or feel less than good about your basic math skills, take this class.
Make sure you are getting A's on all the problem sets.
Take if you want to try a Princeton level math course, but do not have much past experience in advanced math.
Take this class! It is a fun class and challenging while capable of receiving a good grade.
This course is very helpful for students who aren't ready to jump right into Math 103. Don't be ashamed to take this class.
This is a fine course. Tatiana is an invested professor, but can often move quickly.
be ready for a fast paced class and get help and go to problem sessions
otherreq: MAT 100 not allowed if advanced MAT course previously taken.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Quizzes - 25%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and readings from the textbook; quizzes as determined by instructor.
descrip: An intensive and rigorous treatment of algebra and trigonometry as preparation for further courses in calculus or statistics. Topics include functions and their graphs, equations involving polynomial and rational functions, exponentials, logarithms and trigonometry.
title: Precalculus/Prestatistics

evals: Take it! This is a great class, but very fast pace. It's recommended you take this class knowing some basic Korean ahead of time.

Take this class if you want to improve your Korean and can understand fairly well but lack  speaking, reading, and writing skills. At times the class can be a bit dry, but classes are extremely well organized and you will learn a lot. Professor Ji is very good at explaining material clearly and making sure everybody participates so you have a chance to practice speaking. The course load isn't overwhelming, especially because the material you learn in class is exactly what shows up on homework assignments and quizzes. Make sure you study thoroughly for quizzes though because they can be a tad challenging. Overall, not a super challenging class and if you are genuinely interested in learning Korean, a pretty fun class.

This class is great for students that can speak Korean but have little experience in writing/reading. The class is quick paced but still manageable. It made me realize I enjoy learning Korean and might consider taking more classes beyond the language requirement.
otherreq: KOR 103 not allowed if KOR 101 or 102 taken.
otherinfo: Students are required to attend an 80-minute drill session which will be scheduled after students are enrolled in the course.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Grammar, reading, listening and writing activities from the Workbook. Other supplementary reading materials. A minimum of two journal entries every week.
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. The credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing 2-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: The first part of Intensive Korean is designed for heritage students who have already had considerable amount of exposure to the Korean language and culture but have not received any formal instruction before their arriving at Princeton. It covers the Elementary Korean material focusing on vocabulary building, grammar, reading and writing.
title: Intensive Korean I

evals: Awesome class! It's a lot of fun. Don't be nervous at all if you don't have any experience  with dance.
Each studio session is a bit long, but it is so much fun, and worth it for any level of dancer.
If you want to learn about ballet without any prior experience, and enjoy the process, this is the class for you.

If you want to learn about ballet, if you want to get some movement and exercise into your day, if you want to get more flexible, if you want to take a fun and stress-free class...then take this class! It's amazing, fun, and I gained so much appreciation for ballet.
Take it!!
Take this class!! Perfect LA and you really learn a lot of ballet.  Every class is almost all dancing and students really grow to love it
Take this class.
This course was so much fun! I loved learning something new, and Tina is wonderful.
This was an incredible class, and is a must take if you can. Professor Fehlandt is wonderful and it was a joy to learn from her. Take this class seriously and you will get so much out of it.
You should take it. It's very low work but really interesting and fun.
yes.
otherinfo: DAN 207 is designed for students with little or no dance experience and meets twice a week. ATTENDANCE: Attendance in all classes and completion of all work required including: creative projects, papers and participation in final demonstration is required to pass the course. All unused reserved seats will be released to all class years for further enrollment during the Add/ Drop period. 30% Other: Creative Assignments
grading: Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Ongoing creative assignments (approx. 1 hour outside class/week); reading and viewing live and videotaped performances (approx. 3 hours outside classes/week); mandatory trip to NYC to view live performance; several short papers analyzing ballet and discussing dance based on readings and class work.
prereqs: Application required, deadline Monday, April 17, 2017. Apply at arts.princeton.edu/courses. Students will receive notification by Friday, April 21, 2017..
descrip: From grand plié to grand jeté, Introduction to Ballet is for students with a curiosity for the study of classical ballet. No prior dance experience necessary and beginners are welcome. In this studio course students will learn the fundamentals of ballet, gaining an understanding of its physicality, artistry, and principles of alignment. Students will examine the historical origins of ballet and its absorption of cultural influences. Live music will be featured in this class and key in exploring the inextricable link between music and dance.
title: Introduction to Ballet

evals: Do all the readings.

I strongly recommend this seminar if you have an interest in finance and want to learn more about the history behind the financial instruments and institutions you have learned about in other classes.
Not the hardest or most engaging class... But, man, it is super boring.
Pretty easy class that covers a lot of material that pertains to issues today. Definitely take, James is awesome.
Stay up to date on the readings and make a list of key terms and you will have no problems.
Take it if you're interested, but only if you plan to participate actively and do the readings, otherwise it's really a waste of time for you.
definitely take it!
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 200 pages of reading a week. Two papers
descrip: The course examines the history of financial innovation and its consequences. It examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, and securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader development? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility? How is resulting conflict and instability managed, on both a national and international level?
title: Financial History

evals: Good course, excellent professor but it requires a lot of time and effort.
I would try to better understand the grammar techniques as well as continue to grow your vocabulary.
If you're interested in learning Urdu take Prof. Farooqui's class. You will learn a lot of Urdu and enjoy the experience.
Should definitely take this - wonderful instructor and a wonderful language to learn.
Take Professor Fauzia's help whenever you can, she really care about you and your learning!
Take it, she's a lovely professor, and will listen to your feedback if you need help or need really anything.

Take this class! Take any class with Fauziaji! She is a phenominal teacher, and a lovely person to know! You will really learn urdu. Make sure you come to this class with some understanding of the skript.

Take this course because Professor Fauzia is an amazing teacher and you improve your urdu so much! She always tries to do whatever she could to help you and is super understanding about whatever you're struggling with.

Take this course! Fauzia-ji is a very good and warm professor, and she is able to quickly gauge what your limitations are when it comes to the language (in other words, where you can grow). Just put in effort, and the class will definitely help your Urdu skills. Also, you don't need to know the script before going in.
otherinfo: Grading: Other = 10% homework; 10% skit; 10% class participation. Final Project in lieu of final exam.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Writing weekly journals; grammar and vocabulary drills; reading, listening and speaking assignments.
prereqs: HIN/URD 102 or equivalent proficiency in either language.
descrip: This course is a continuation of HIN-URD 102, concentrating on Urdu. Students beginning with intermediate proficiency in either Urdu or Hindi will be brought to an advanced level in Urdu in all four skills. The Urdu script will be introduced and an emphasis will be placed on strengthening literacy skills. After completing the course, students will be able to read or comprehend through listening, a variety of authentic Urdu texts and media materials. Various aspects of the target culture will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.
title: Intermediate Urdu I

evals: Do your readings, otherwise you won't get much out of the discussions or the seminar in general.

I mean, if you're an NES major, you have to take this class. Prepare for more reading than most of your other classes, circular and repetitive discussions, and rather unclear prompts. However, Professor Gribbetz is very good at what he does, and will prepare you thoroughly for a thoughtful career as an NES student. He never "takes a side" in a discussion, and is always looking for ways to make his students think more deeply about their topics.

If you're an NES major, you have to take this class, and you will enjoy it! Professor Gribetz is super smart and helpful and understanding and the readings and class discussions are interesting. It is also really helpful for independent work.
If you're not an NES concentrator, some of the elements of the class might not be directly relevant to you, but the class is still worth taking if you want to understand the scholarly field of NES and, more broadly, how different academic disciplines fit into 'area studies' departments.

If you're interested in a career in academia, this course will be a great way to see if you want to become a professor or go to graduate school, as a lot of NES professors visit the class to talk about their research. I gained a greater appreciation for what it means to be in an interdisciplinary department. I feel much more prepared to write my Junior Paper and Thesis, as we learned a lot about academic writing and different methodologies to formulate an argument. You also get exposed to a lot of famous works that NES majors will be expected to know about, like Said's Orientalism and Ibn Khaldun. If you put a lot of work into this course, you will write a much stronger Junior Paper.

Professor Gribetz is amazing. Take this class only if you are an NES concentrator. This class has a heavy workload but is a great introduction to various fields in the NES department. Professor Gribetz makes it very easy to follow the material, and he is an absolute delight to have as an adviser and professor in class.
Use it to the best of your ability to work towards your JP.
You will enjoy this course if you put in the effort to do readings and think thoughtfully. Gribetz does not disappoint!!
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: 100-200 pages of reading per week. Two papers: a critical literature review (5 pages) and a final research project (10 pages). Weekly responses to practical research questions related to the week's readings (1-2 pages each).
descrip: Introduces NES majors to the sources, tools, and methods used in Near Eastern Studies, and to central questions and debates that have informed the region's study in varying disciplines (history, comparative literature, religious studies, political science, and anthropology). Also covers the nuts and bolts of academic research and writing: how to design a research project, find and make sense of relevant primary and secondary sources, develop an argument, and write a compelling scholarly paper. Includes guest lectures and visits to Firestone Library and its Islamic manuscripts collection.
title: Seminar in Research Methods

evals: A very interesting course with excellent professors. Manageable coursework and fair assessments.
Great class to take, especially with Professor Tilghman and Professor Wailoo!!!
Great class. 10/10 would definitely recommend.

If you're interested in science, ethics, and policy, you should definitely take this course! Prof. Wailoo and Tilghman are amazing teachers. You will get so much out of this course, whether you have a strong science or policy background. Take it!

Must take! Even if only remotely interested in bioethics, it's an incredible opportunities to hear from two professors who are particularly established in their fields teach a course that is present in a variety of hot topics today.

Overall, the material and discussions in this class are important, engaging, and relevant. There's something for everyone, regardless of major- science, policy, social sciences, etc. 

This isn't a traditional seminar so keep that in mind. It has 2 great professors and there is a high demand for the class which means the class is also larger than most seminars.
TAKE IT. Best class I've taken at Princeton.
TAKE THIS CLASS. Tilghman and Wailoo are AMAZING professors/lecturers, and are even better together - their teaching dynamic is great. Readings are extremely manageable.
Take it! It's amazing, and probably one of my favorite courses at Princeton.
Take it, do all the readings, engage in class. Very interesting subject that will have a huge effect on society in the future.

Take this class!! Definitely be prepared to work hard, but it is worth the time. Professor Tilghman and Wailoo are very talented professors, and they are very helpful and willing to provide assistance if you ask!
Take this course. Professors Wailoo and Tilghman are two of the best profs I've had at Princeton. The course is extremely interesting and thought provoking. Very light workload.
stay on top of the readings and meet with preceptors before the final and midterm papers
take the class!
take this class! two incredibly passionate and knowledgeable professors. interesting stuff to know on such a current topic.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 35%
assgts: Students will be expected to write two policy papers in this course. One 5-7 page paper due at mid-term and a 15-18 page paper at the end of the course.
descrip: Examines modern genetics' implications for public policy focusing on health, law, consumer products, and criminal justice. Topics include: eugenics; gene patenting; gene therapy; FDA consumer regulations of genetic testing; genetic discrimination; forensic use of DNA; and genome editing. Explores social, political, and philosophical problems that modern genetics pose in areas such as the changing conceptions of the self; genetic enhancement vs. therapy; genetic nature of race; new theories of gene action in epigenetics; genetically modified plants and animals; and genetic privacy.
title: Modern Genetics and Public Policy

evals: Either you have to take this course (i.e. you're a WWS concentrator) or you're not eligible (everyone else). If the former, I liked Prof. Lockheed's seminar on education policy. Seminars themselves were sort of dry, but readings were very good and if the subject matter interests you, it's a good one to write your JP on. (Also the weekly assignments are pretty easy compared to what I've heard about some of the other seminars.) In the labs, take advantage of the preceptors, because they can make or break your JP. Writing a quantitative JP was painful for me (I had virtually no stats background; WWS 200 was a joke) but I think I'll be glad I did it later; it's good experience. (If you take Prof. Lockheed's seminar, you have no choice between qualitative and quantitative; you will be writing a quantitative JP.)
Enjoy it
Go to office hours for help on STATA/R. It will be a life-saver

Highly recommend taking your policy research seminar with Prof. Armstrong. I learned a whole lot about the policy area of maternal and child health and found the JP process easier to handle with her advice than the people I know in other seminars did.
I learned a tremendous amount from Professor Mody. Take this class! And be prepared to work hard!
I loved this course. Professor Boix is very relaxed though I would have liked closer guidance with my independent work.
If you are interested in economics and have some basic understanding of statistical software, take it!

If you are looking for an interesting research seminar with a great professor/advisor, TAKE THIS COURSE. The readings are manageable/engaging, and Prof. Armstrong is a phenomenal professor and research advisor for your JP. Prof. Armstrong really cares, and I truly believe that my JP experience would have been suffered had I taken a different course.
Lab isn't going to be fun, so choose a seminar you're interested in.
Nail your junior paper topic down as quickly as you can. The earlier the better.
Prof. Armstrong's seminar was probably the best one. In a completely unbiased way. Take it, and be prepared to have your mind blown on so many levels.

Prof. Boix is pretty laid back in his advising (not necessarily a good or bad thing). You'll need to make your own schedule and be strict with yourself to meet personal deadlines. If you need to, make periodic appointments with the Writing Center, Steve Frakt, or Will Lowe (if doing quant.) - have them check your work and let that guide development of your research proposal, drafts, and final paper.

Professor Tienda's research seminar was awesome! She is super knowledgeable about the material and a phenomenal teacher. She will challenge you to improve your writing and critical thinking skills and will be willing to work with you to make sure your JP is in as good shape as you're willing to make it. The research methods lab has a lot of issues, but you're stuck with it so hopefully WWS can fix it by the time you take it.
Take Professor Tienda's seminar if you can!
Take if you have an interest in the judiciary system.
Take it if interested in the subject.

Take the quantitative lab even if you are bad at statistics and know nothing of R. It was excellent. Dr. Lowe's lectures were extremely helpful; he also had a crash course in R session for beginners like me. The quantitative component pushed me significantly out of my comfort zone, and in doing so, it greatly expanded the kinds of research I am able to conduct. Probably among the most formative and most useful courses I have taken here. My professor for class was Dr. Cameron. He was easygoing, almost to a fault. I wish he had been a little more strict about readings and due dates, but because his laxity allowed my project to thrive, I must also speak to the significant benefits of his approach. He has great explanations for all the papers and research designs, just make sure to read the syllabus (he won't be mad if you don't, and that's the dangerous part). He brings his dog Xander to class every night, so that's always a treat!
Take this class or any class with Armstrong! She is a very challenging but uplifting professor who has a lot to teach and is readily available to the students

This is definitely one of the more challenging policy research seminars, but so worth it - you will find yourself understanding economics more than you thought possible and the research process is very rewarding!
You have to take it so just put time and effort into it because it's a requirement.
You have to take it.  Just make sure you think of a JP question that actually interests you
You just have to power through it.
the office hours were much more helpful and relevant to our projects, but the lessons of each lab were indeed beneficial.
otherinfo: The instructor in the policy research seminar will advise the junior paper of students in the seminar and provide instruction in research methods in the seminar; the seminar will be accompanied by a methods laboratory in which students further refine and apply quantitative research methods (including sampling, hypothesis testing and causal inference) and qualitative research methods (including interview design, ethnographic methods). The methods lab will constitute 40% of the grade.
grading: Design Project - 60%, Lab Reports - 40%
assgts: 150 pages a week. Students will do research design projects and lab project reports.
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.
title: Policy Research Seminar

evals: A great course if you really like documentaries and want to learn more about making them - but you definitely get out of the class what you put into it and it's worth putting in the effort to get the results and actually learn a lot.

Definitely take if you're interested in filmmaking at all. It will be time consuming, since you have to actually shoot and edit a documentary, but if you think you'll enjoy it and also like watching documentary films, it will be worth it. You get access to cool equipment, and you'll learn a lot especially if you're a camera/editing beginner. You get out what you put in.
It's a great course to learn about documentary film-making. I recommend coming into the course with a particular idea of what kind of documentary you want to be making in the course.

This was a great course, Su is #1!! The material of the course is engaging and very hands-on.

Don't take if you want an easy PDF only. Yes, you'll probably pass, but Su is wonderful and you shouldn't waste her time (or your classmates') just to have an easy class, when someone else might actually contribute and learn more. Don't be that kid who sleeps in this class when it's less than 10 people and we all depend on each other to shape the mood of the class.

However, do take this class if you're interested in either or all: film, documentary, and film-making (with an emphasis on editing), and just want to learn all the basics, and more, about the whole process. Some say this is a time-consuming class, which it definitely is if you genuinely care, but for me it was so worth it, and I'd take it all over again.

There's another teacher who teaches the same class in the fall, but I'd wait for the spring and take it with Su - she's an adventure, and worth knowing!
Work hard.
i mean you learn premiere... not sure if it's worthing taking. not life changing.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Design Project - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Five short films (recorded, directed, and edited by the student). 3-5 hours of watching films each week. And six journal entries written in response to these films (each entry should be two pages long).
descrip: In the real world, what relationships have the necessary friction to generate compelling films? Documentary Filmmaking will introduce you to the craft, history and theory behind attempts to answer this question. Through production assignments, screenings, and seminar discussions, you will take your first steps into the world of non-fiction filmmaking. Further, as films are often vessels for their directors' preoccupations, the course will also push you to examine the formal, social, and political concerns that animate your life.
title: Documentary Filmmaking

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor..
descrip: After an introductory discussion of the Navier-Stokes equation, the course goes carefully through the proof of the classical Cafarelli-Kohn-Nirenberg theorem, which is still the best partial result known on global existence and smoothness of solutions to Navier-Stokes.
title: Topics in Analysis - Fluid dynamics and related equations

otherinfo: This is a six week course that will meet from 10/25/17 - 12/13/17. Non-Sociology graduate students wishing to receive a grade for this course must submit a completed Graduate Student Enrollment Change Form located at the following URL: https://gradschool.princeton.edu/sites/gradschool/files/Enrollment%20Form%20Revised_1.pdf
grading: Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
assgts: Two 5-10 page papers. 200 pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course is concerned with the professional obligations of social science researchers. Topics covered include teaching and mentoring relationships, human subjects protections, professional codes of ethics, data management, peer review, collaboration, scientific misconduct (fraud, fabrication and plagiarism), conflicts of interest, and scientific agenda-setting. The course is intended for graduate students in Sociology and the Office of Population Research.
title: Research Ethics & Scientific Integrity (Half-Term)

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Problem set(s) - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Notes distributed by instructor.
prereqs: Introduction to Real Analysis (MAT320) or equivalent, or consent of instructor..
descrip: The course is an introduction to partial differential equations, problems associated to them and methods of their analysis. Topics may include: basic properties of elliptic equations, wave equation, heat equation, Schr\"{o}dinger equation, hyperbolic conservation laws, Fokker-Planck equation, basic function spaces and inequalities, regularity theory for linear PDE, De Giorgi method, basic harmonic analysis methods, existence results and long time behavior for classes of nonlinear PDE including the Navier-Stokes equations.
title: Introduction to PDE

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Geometry. Specific topic details provided when course is offered.
title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry

evals: Great course covering a wide range of topics on all aspects of the development of cities. Lectures are consistently interesting. Students should think about topics for their final paper early in the semester in order to receive adequate feedback.
Recommend
if they are interested in learning a comprehensive history of europe, they should take the class
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 85%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
descrip: The class introduces students to the branch of the philosophy of history that specializes in cities. Cities are social entities that exist at an intermediate scale between the micro-level of individuals and the macro-level of society as a whole. Social science has tended to focus at those two extremes, while the intermediate meso-level has been neglected. The philosophy of urban history aims at remedying this situation, stressing not only the role of cities as historical actors, but also the role of other meso-level social entities from local communities and institutional organizations to urban regions and provinces.
title: The Philosophy of Urban History

evals: 110% take this seminar.  There is a ton of reading- just split it up with other kids.  Seminar was something I looked forward to each week.  Admiral Mullen is an incredibly interesting man with an equally interesting career, getting to interact and learn from him weekly was an honor.

Absolutely take this class if you get into it. Adm. Mullen is an incredible individual and many of his lessons in the course are deeply informative to life after the course/Princeton. This is a fantastic class on the mix of hard-power/military with other aspects of foreign policy, and how they should best be used in combination. Also a strong focus on governance processes and how the sausage gets made, which was fascinating. Highly recommend.
Definitely worth taking it. But remember that it's not an easy class, and you have to be prepared. But it's Admiral Mullen. If you are interested in the subject, take it.
Pick topics for your papers that you know a lot about.
Take it if you can. Great class, interesting topic and excellent professor.
Take this class to be with Admiral Mullen and not the grade, since the grading is very arbitrary. I would also recommend splitting up the reading since it is a lot.
