Take this course for Admiral Mullen. He has incredible insight and perspective. Readings are good as well. While class discussion and papers leave something to be desired (80% of your grade is based on papers, for which instructions can be somewhat unclear), this class is worth it.
Take this course! The grading is tough though.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Two short papers; one final paper
descrip: This seminar will review concepts of military strategy, national security policy, U.S. diplomatic relations with other global power centers, and efforts to transform international institutions to address emerging global security threats.
title: U.S. Military and National and International Diplomacy

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in combinatorial optimization: More specific topic details are provided when the course is offered.
title: Topics in Combinatorial Optimization

otherinfo: Not open to students who were enrolled in the fall 2016 "Princeton Slavery and Historical Memory" freshman seminar. Work in conjunction with the Princeton and Slavery symposium and related tours will account for 15% of the final grade.
grading: Papers - 55%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: All students will do extensive research in University and online archives, and create content for the Princeton and Slavery website by writing short essays and developing online exhibitions.
descrip: Research seminar focused on Princeton University's historical connections to the institution of slavery. The class will contribute to a website that details this history and assist with the scholarly events related to the public launch of the Princeton and Slavery Project. Class will meet in Mudd Library.
title: Princeton and Slavery

evals: I can highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in empirical or quantitative questions in macro.
grading: Programming Assignments - 33%, Papers - 34%, Problem set(s) - 33%
assgts: Course assignments are based on (i) Data exercises, (ii) Replication/Extension exercises, and (iii) a paper related to the broad theme of the course.
descrip: This course is geared towards (i) understanding how finance and the macro economy interact with each other, and (ii) introducing micro-empirical techniques and data sets for answering traditional macro questions. The focus of the class is empirical but we begin each topic with a discussion of its theoretical foundation.
title: Topics in Empirical Macroeconomics

evals: A great class to take before conducting ethnographic research, as you will closely examine types of methods and analysis that do and don't work, and you will gain experience practicing some of these yourself. A great way to learn about different types of schooling. Class is somewhat disorganized, and Prof. Klugman didn't return any work to us, but was also very fair and understanding in working around our busy schedules and difficulties with managing workload.

If you are the kind of student who has a messy class and thinks "all right, this is easy!", that's great. However if you're like most Princeton students and will feel confused and resentful and like your time is being wasted, I wouldn't recommend it.

If you decide to take this course, make sure that you give yourself enough time to reflect about your school visits (spread them out), figure out what you are going to write and possibly meet with him about it as well.

If you have any interest in education, take this course. Ethnography is a really unique and valuable window into the world of education.  Professor Klugman is fantastic and this has been my favorite course at Princeton thus far. Not only did it further stimulate my interest in education, it introduced me to the field of anthropology, in which I am now planning to major.

If you're more interested in policy, take a policy course instead. Otherwise, this class is a great opportunity to study schools through a more intimate perspective. Pay attention during observations for the mini school ethnography!
It's interesting even if you don't have a background in anthro.
Take this class. The workload is manageable and the material is always interesting. Dr. Klugman is also a great source of information.

course is the most enjoyable seminar you will take at princeton-- klugman is a master educator, not just a researcher like so many other professors at princeton. you get to see pedagogy in action, instead of just learning about it. course is more about culture and systems that surround schooling, rather than pedagogy proper. seminar is extremely varied in nature, lots of small group discussions, presenting to each other, interactive, learning about each other's education backgrounds.
otherinfo: This discussion and fieldwork-oriented course is designed for students who have a general interest in education, urban education, teaching, education reform and the social sciences. Students with serious interest in teacher preparation, Teach for America or similar ventures are encouraged to enroll. As part of the course, students will conduct 10 hours of field work in local schools.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Approximately 100-150 pages of reading per week; Weekly Reading Response Papers (250 words); Personal Educational History and Commentary (4-6 pages); Book Review/Presentation (3-4 pages); Mini School Ethnography based on field observations and class discussions (15-20 page paper -- final project in lieu of exam)
prereqs: Students should have a background (coursework or other experience) in Anthropology, Sociology, Education or related fields..
descrip: Social scientists use ethnographic methods to describe and analyze the range and variation of daily interactions in schools. Ethnographic study allows researchers the opportunity to examine power dynamics that influence the daily life of students, teachers, administrators and parents. Vivid, critical ethnography helps us discover how cultural traditions, expectations, and opportunities are passed down to the next generation and how they impact school outcomes. This class will explore educational ethnography and students will complete observations hours in local schools and prepare a descriptive, mini-ethnography of a school community.
title: Ethnography of Schools and Schooling

evals: A very enjoyable class with two phenomenal professors whose interaction with each other and the students was academically stimulating and a pleasure to watch. Moreover, the materials covered in class were diverse and interesting for the constructing a theoretical understanding about the development of both literature as a general concept and individual literary movements.
Aaay, this course will get you to think about literature in a new, fulfilling way. The
If it is offered again, take it. Professors Lande and Feeney are some of the best I've had at Princeton.

Prepare to be challenged?and always come prepared and ready to engage at a very high level. Understanding the texts is not enough. You will have to draw theoretical connections between them and confront very abstract questions about the nature and role of literature in societies across the world.
take the class
grading: Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 100-150 pages of reading per week.
descrip: This course explores the emergence of history as a field of knowledge in the ancient Mediterranean and in East Asia. It will guide students to investigate the cultural presuppositions for historiography, comparing two cultures that created their own indigenous tradition, China and Greece, and two that borrowed and adapted foreign traditions, Japan and Rome. We will discuss the specific nature of historiography, comparing it with other ways of transmitting and/or constructing memories of past events, and reflect on the respective historical and cultural implications of these different ways of dealing with the past.
title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - How the Past Became History - East Asia and the Ancient Mediterranean

evals: Amazing class. Robert is great at what he does and he teaches us what we need to know. He is very honest and direct so I really appreciated the opportunity to  learn more about radio!

Don't hesitate, just take it. It'll teach you to be curious in a pointed way, and how to have so much fun doing it. Take it even if you find podcast stuffy and annoying. You'll learn so much about journalism, multimedia, the world, talking to people. Just take it.
Great intro to radio producing and audio journalism!
If this class is ever offered again, take it. It is a lot of work. I cannot promise that you will do well. But you will learn so much and it will be so so fun.
If you get the chance, take this. Unbelievable course and so different from every other class at Princeton.

If you have any interest in radio and audio journalism, you must take this course whenever it is available.  I hope that Robert Smith can teach it again-- idk who could be a more effective guide or who could offer a more exciting and realistic perspective on the world of audio journalism.
If you're willing to struggle and be frustrated, then take this course, you will not regret it in the slightest. It's the most innovative course I've taken here.
It was so cool to pair reporting work with the technical challenge of audio editing

This was my first journalism course and I highly recommend it. It's a unique course offering and really well-organized class with exercises in event coverage, storytelling, and sound. Really hands-on and lots of fun, especially if you like listening to podcasts already.
otherinfo: Joe Richman is founder and executive producer of Radio Diaries, a not-for-profit radio production company that has won every major award in broadcast journalism. He is a Peabody Award-winning producer and reporter whose pioneering series Teenage Diaries brought teenage voices to a national audience on NPR's All Things Considered. He has also worked on NPR's Weekend Edition and Car Talk.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 6-8 hours of preparation per week, consisting of listening, reading, reporting, and writing. Bi-weekly individual meetings with professor required.
descrip: This seminar will focus on journalism in the form of audio storytelling, as a good radio story can do much more than just convey information. We will explore the sensibilities and skills needed for narrative storytelling to capture listeners' imaginations. Students will do advanced writing, interviewing, sound-gathering, and multi-layered audio production to create broadcast-caliber radio documentaries. Students will produce an audio postcard, a profile, and a final documentary--through frequent rewrites and intensive editing--and a class podcast of their work. The best stories will be pitched to WYNC, NPR, and other outlets.
title: Audio Journalism - Storytelling for Radio Documentaries and Podcasts

evals: -- It's not as good as people say it is. There is A LOT OF material. We had SEVEN late days and it was barely enough. This is a very demanding, very difficult, and overcomplicated course that is so theoretical you probably won't be able to apply most things you learned. BE CAREFUL, THINK A LOT, AND CHOOSE WISELY.
:) Good class

A great class (although unsure now that Han Liu might not be teaching it). You will learn so much about Big Data in both the theory and applications. The problem sets are engaging and provide insights into Big Data beyond the class, and the lecture summaries show that Professor Liu really cares that you learn the material. Yes, this class essentially forces you to learn the material completely, or lets you fail otherwise. Be warned - this class has hands down been the hardest class I have taken at Princeton (as someone who typically takes 5 quantitative math/cos/orfe classes per semester). The problem sets take much longer than the time they give you to do them and require strong proof abilities, coding abilities, and interpretive abilities. However, if you survive the class, you will probably get an A. Overall a great class (although overhyped a bit tbh).
Absolutely take the course, but make sure you have time in your schedule for it. It's quite time consuming.
As everyone else is probably mentioning, Han Liu made the class. It might be different without him. But the material is incredibly useful for every field.
Best class I've taken at this school.

Best statistics/machine learning course I've taken at Princeton. You go really in depth about the theory underlying the statistical methods you think you understand, and learn lots of new methods of data analysis. Problem sets can be kind of time-consuming, so start early!

DO NOT TAKE! Disclaimer: I would write 2 paragraphs about how Han Liu is one of the best profs I've had here - complete mastery of the subject matter, cares about the students, humorous in his own quirky way (he never tries to be), and as humble a prof as you'll find here - and how Big Data, while really challenging, was my most rewarding class here and teaches a super useful life and career skill..........but Han's not going to be teaching 350 anymore. LOOK ELSEWHERE. DO NOT take this class with another prof, it will be greatly diminished, the material has the potential to be completely inscrutable, and it seems like a disaster waiting to happen. Find whatever class Han may be teaching and take that instead!
Definitely take it but you do need a little bit of Linear Algebra.
Excellent course! I think Professor Liu is leaving though, and the course was great because Professor Liu explained things very clearly and seemed to put a lot of care into the course.

Great introduction to *statistics* (and in part, machine learning). Heavy emphasis on statistical approaches to data analytics, but forms a great foundation for more advanced machine learning classes.

I don't know how this course will change without Han Liu. I can say that Han Liu was a god in the lecture hall. I especially loved his focus on machine learning intuition, which was eye opening. This is probably one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.

I have learned so much from this class. Even though it was really hard sometimes, and the assignments could take really really long, I'm still really glad that I have taken this class, because it is the best there is to learn about machine learning and statistics. This course teaches the theory behind machine learning concepts and statistical models, and really made me better understand the algorithms that I have used in other classes. The math could sometimes be daunting, but it is worth it to really understand it, and it feels amazing when you finally get it! The professor and the TA's also really care about the class. I really want to thank a TA, Jason Ge for answering all the Piazza questions and helping me understand the materials. The course staff really put in a ton of effort to help people understand. I would totally recommend this class!
I would recommend this course to any student interested in big data/machine learning. It is pretty heavy on the math/theory side, which is important however to understand no matter what.
If Han Liu is teaching take it. He is a flexible, responsive, professor who highlights important philosophical distinctions in the field.

In my opinion, this course takes a more fundamental perspective than many other course in the realm of data analysis / ML. The course teaches you many fundamental foundational topics (you will relearn regressions, clustering, and classification). The work load is on the larger side but also manageable.

It is very easy in ORF to fall in the trap of doing 1 question on the pset yourself and asking help from friends and TAs on the remaining questions. Many times its unavoidable but try your best to understand things yourself first. 
COS 424 is too little theory. ORF 350 is too much theory. Decide which side you want to be on.

One of the best classes I took at Princeton! The problem sets in the first half of the semester are not too bad, but then they go full throttle afterwards. Get a good group of friends to work on the problem sets with. They're a rather large time commitment.

Otherwise, Professor Liu gives a generous curve. He recognizes that this class is hard, and he knows you deserve top marks for surviving it. He's also an upstanding gentlemen who's invested in making sure you succeed. I learned so much through his lectures.

Outstanding course that forces you to be engaged. Problems sets are a bit long but not too hard; there's lots of guidance. Plus you're rewarded with a great percentage of A's. Builds strong foundation in stats/ML.
Probably the most useful class you could take at Princeton.
START PSETS EARLY!!! This is a great class and has interesting (and also lots of theory based) material and proofs, but problem sets should be started early.
Take it with Han Liu!

Take it! You learn a lot of practical skills used in data science. The problem sets took a long time but there are 7 late days. This year, the midterm was canceled, so in addition to problem sets, there was only a take home final to determine our grade.

Take it, but make it your main class for the semester. Make no mistake, this class is HARD. Pros: 1) Extremely clear and precise presentation of very complex subject matter. I understand all of stats (not just ML) better thanks to Han Liu. 2) It's good to get the theoretical foundations of ML down before going into applications (e.g. COS 424), and this class focuses on that. 3) Final is a take-home so you'll be done a couple days after Dean's Date. Cons: Problem sets are VERY LONG (upwards of 20 hrs/ week). A quarter of the class is comprised of genius MAT/COS majors. Useful prereqs: ORF 309 (critical), ORF 245, MAT 202
Take this class, although Han Liu won't be teaching it next year. But the material is interesting and very useful.

The problem sets do take a lot of time, however, you certainly learn a lot in class, especially if you take as much time as you need to read through notes after lectures, maybe while doing the homework.
There is a fair amount of work for this course but you will learn a lot.

This class teaches a lot of interesting material that is worth learning (and very applicable in real life). At the start of the semester, problem sets are light, but they become progressively more difficult and time-consuming towards the end of the semester, both because of the material but also because of tedious problems. Prof. Liu made us submit lecture summaries after every lecture to enforce attendance and help you retain the material, which was helpful but annoying.

This course has a reputation for being somewhat time consuming and difficult, but it is very rewarding. Han is a fantastic lecturer and will make everything you cover very intuitive and understandable. The psets are what gives this class a reputation; they are pretty time consuming, but Han is very generous with late days, and the psets are never "unfair"; you can always do them with what you learn in class.
This is a great course, but be prepared for this to be a huge time sink. The problem sets take forever, but reallly help you learn the material.

This is a hard course and you will need to put in a lot of time (15  hours a week when there are problem sets, but only 6 assignments throughout the semester. Han requires students to write lecture summaries of each lecture so this really helps you reinforce what you learn. Attend every lecture and soak in every bit of wisdom that Han has to give. Although I heard Han might be leaving for industry so if that's the case hopefully the new teacher is just as good. There is no better intro machine learning course on campus (COS 424 is hands on python package type stuff). If you want a really really rigorous treatment of ML, try ELE 535 with Ramadge (but ORF 350 is pretty rigorous). You should probably take an optimization course before taking ORF 350 even though it's not an official prequisite. Real analysis also helps but not required. Brush up on your linear algebra before the course starts

This is an excellent course--lectures are fantastic and the problem sets are very useful.  Start early and work with other people.  Also, linear algebra was not listed as a prerequisite, but it's really important to know.

Unfortunately, Han Liu is leaving after this semester, so I don't know how this course will be for future semesters.  But I found the material pretty interesting, so if you have an interest in big data/ machine learning, try it out.   Be warned though, the PSETS are really long.  Also, I think this class gives out a ridiculously high amount of A's.
Very rigorous course, but worth it. Prof. Liu is a very good professor who cares about students learning the material well.
Very very challenging course but you learn a lot. Take it if you actually are interested in the subject
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: R programming.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Take Home Final Exam - 10%, Programming Assignments - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Programming assignments
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 309.
descrip: The amount of data in our world has been exploding, and analyzing large data sets is becoming a central problem in our society. This course introduces the statistical principles and computational tools for analyzing big data: the process of exploring and predicting large datasets to find hidden patterns and gain deeper understanding, and of communicating the obtained results for maximal impact. Topics include massively parallel data management and data processing, model selection and regularization, statistical modeling and inference, scalable computational algorithms, descriptive and predictive analysis, and exploratory analysis.
title: Analysis of Big Data

evals: Couldn't recommend this course any more highly!

Engage as much as possible with the professors, because if you speak up they will provide so much guidance for you! Also, take initiative and get excite for your film--it will be so much more amazing if you do!

Fantastic course, definitely take it if offered again! Be prepared for a heavy workload, but Professor Isenberg and Purcell are both fantastic instructors and they offer ample guidance and constructive feedback for assignments. Class discussions are also interesting and substantive and they make learning a fun, enriching experience.

I'd say take it if the topic the course is engaging means a lot to you and if you are interested in making a film and engaging the Trenton community-but prepare for a lot of work especially if it is co-taught again.

Really think again about taking this course. The topic seems interesting, but for all this class made us do, I questioned many times whether all this work was worth it. I think the Professors are well studied, but I think that this class is not structured well, because there is a ton of interesting readings that often are overlooked by the Prof in lecture. Also note that the final projects paper and film are due around the same time so this makes things very challenging, and stressful. I personally would not do it again, but am proud I learned how to make a film, and write a JP-like paper.
Take it if you have the time/are interested in the topics of the course.

Take this course! Both Professor Isenberg and Professor Carson are very intelligent and compassionate and really committed to their students' learning process. You really learn how to edit film, which is an awesome skill to gain, and you get to learn about Trenton and engage with the world outside the orange bubble.
The film project and the paper are very rewarding assignments. I highly recommend the class, especially if you're interested in the histories of Trenton and Princeton.
otherinfo: Selected feature and short documentaries will also be a part of the reading list. This course participates in the Community-Based Learning Initiative and involves a commitment to fieldwork in Trenton outside of class.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Grades will be based on: participation (20%), short response papers to films and readings (10%), final research paper (30%), other: a final short video (40%).
prereqs: Students should be prepared to conduct fieldwork with documentary subjects, collaborate with fellow students, shoot and edit video. This course teaches the fundamentals of video editing; prior experience is not required. Seniors by permission; please contact instructor(s)..
descrip: This hands-on urban studies seminar in documentary film making and history focuses on Trenton's unrest of April 1968, when a black college student, Harlan Joseph, was shot and killed by a white police officer. The course works outward from these events to examine the 1960's, race, region, economy, memory, and media representation. Students produce their own short films and related research papers using their own field work and shared archives sources. Collaborative assignments will contribute to works of scholarship and a documentary produced by the professors. Includes public screening of student work. See www.thetrentonproject.com.
title: Documentary Film and the City

evals: Cool class. A bit more on the abstract than the practical end of the spectrum.
David won't be here next semester but will be coming back later (I think). If you're interested in graphic design, take it with him!
Go for Graphic Design, rather than Visual Form.

If you are interested in the subject, you can't go wrong with this course. But don't take it if you just think it will be easy (you won't have fun and there are plenty of other students who actually want to take this course). David is a great instructor and provides great feedback. Prepare to work independently and get out what you put in.
Take it for sure!!

Take this class! It changed how I approach all sorts of creative work for the better. David is absolutely amazing. You could probably get by without doing the readings, but you should do them because they're really good.
Take this class. You will learn about Illustrator and Indesign, but most of all, you will learn about design thinking. Also, David is great. Just take it - you won't regret it.

This class is DEFINITELY not what you expect. It focuses a lot more on psychological concepts than it does on technical art at all. I do not feel as though I have become a better artist through this class, but I have become more knowledgable about many artistic standards instead.

This course was great and David is an awesome teacher. But it was not as technical as I expected and a lot of class critiques were too intuitive - i was hoping that i would learn principles of design (eg. this looks good because it is this ratio etc.) instead of just receiving subjective feedback (eg. this looks good because i feel like it is).
otherinfo: Studio work will be supplemented by critiques, readings and guest lectures as described in the syllabus. All work will be ongoing with periodic reviews, and a complete portfolio is due at the end of class.
grading: Design Project - 65%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Studio Assignments (one every two to three weeks, overlapping) 2 in-class exercises (one at midterm, one at final)
descrip: This course introduces students to techniques for decoding and creating graphic messages in a variety of media, and delves into issues related to visual literacy through the hands-on making and analysis of graphic form. Graphic design relies on mastering the subtle manipulation of abstract shapes and developing sensitivity to the relationships between them. Students are exposed to graphics from the late 19th-century to the present in slide lectures. Studio assignments and group critique will foster an individual ability to realize sophisticated forms and motivate these towards carrying specific meanings.
title: Graphic Design: Visual Form

otherinfo: This course is open to Visual Arts Concentrators
grading: Design Project - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Grading 10% Other: Weekly work in writing, planning, filming and/or editing
descrip: This course will focus on the three major phases of cinematic storytelling: story development, principal photography, and post-production. Through class exercises, workshops, guest speakers, and critical evaluations of ongoing projects, students will learn the importance of the script, visual design, subtext, the staging of action, and the value of collaboration, with the goal of developing a more nuanced approach to the nuts and bolts of the entire film production process.
title: Narrative Filmmaking

evals: Very useful, interesting course; pay attention in lectures!
highly recommend this course to the students who want to know x-ray diffraction and crystallography
otherinfo: This course is the first term of a one-year sequence on materials chemistry. Students who sign up for this course should take CHM 507 in the Spring term. Open to graduate students only.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 40%
descrip: Topics in the solid state chemistry and crystal structures of non-molecular solids. Point group and space group symmetry and the International Tables for Crystallography. Introduction to X-ray, Neutron and Electron diffraction. Introduction to the most common non-molecular structures. Electronic band structure, lattice vibrations, dieletric and optical properties.
title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Solid State Chemistry

grading: Papers - 70%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Course packet is assembled by instructor.
descrip: This course explores global geochemical cycles through the use of simple numerical models. Topics covered range from box models of the geologic carbon and oxygen cycles, planetary thermostats, and atmospheric oxygenation, to box models of Cenozoic seawater chemistry (Mg and Ca), to 1D diffusion-reaction modes of the dynamics of carbon and oxygen in sedimentary systems. Previous coursework in differential equations and MATLAB are highly desirable but not absolutely necessary.
title: Geological Constraints on the Global Carbon Cycle

evals: Complete the readings and engage fully in the discussions.

Don't be afraid! Financial history as a discipline is often seen--quite unfairly--as number crunching, dead white guyism, a relic of now old-fashioned historiographical schools. Nothing can be further from the truth! And in any event, anyone interested in the history of capitalism NEEDS to take this course, both to understand finance and capital and to be able to more effectively critique a protean field.
Even if you are intimidated by finance/economics, this is a wonderful course. Writing assignments are tailored to your interests within the syllabus.
grading: Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
descrip: The course examines financial innovation and its consequences from the early modern period to present: it examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader processes of economic development and to state formation? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility?
title: International Financial History

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course covers current topics in Arithmetic Geometry. Specific topic information provided when course is offered.
title: Topics in Arithmetic Geometry - Arithmetic Gan-Gross-Prasad Conjecture

otherinfo: Undergraduate must obtain permission of the instructor.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: The course will assume familiarity with basic differential topology and Morse theory..
descrip: This course covers symplectic methods in low-dimensional topology, with a special emphasis on Heegaard Floer homology. Topics may include grid diagrams and corresponding knot invariants, Heegaard Floer homology for closed three-manifolds, and bordered Floer homology.
title: Topics in Low Dimensional Topology - Symplectic techniques in low-dimensional topology

I would recommend this course.

evals: Absolutely take this course! Dr. J is a fantastic professor and the readings are varied and incredibly interesting.
Dr. J offers a course that is relatively light on work with lectures and readings that are interesting to perhaps a few. Helps if you're interested in the topic.
Good to take PDF or for a grade, and Vertesi is just a really fun person, so the overall experience will be good even if you aren't interested in the material.
Great class on organizational sociology, not that hard but very interesting and engaging.
Great class- interesting, not too difficult. Find an easier way to get through the readings, though- half of them are very dull theory pieces if you're not a soc major.
It's a good senior year course for someone in a different major. Provides an interesting analysis of the tech industry for students looking to join it.
Take it, especially if you've never taken a SOC class and you're interested in management and technology!
This class wasn't for me, but maybe it will be for you. Be prepared to do a LOT of work to prepare for the exams and on the group project. Given the choice I would not take this class again.
This course presents some interesting theories of organizational sociology and makes good connections between theory and real examples!
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: Credit for Technology & Society Certificate, Information Technology track.
grading: Final Exam - 30%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 100 pages of reading per week for lecture and precept participation. Take-home midterm exam with written component. Term paper due on assigned question.
prereqs: Freshmen and sophomores need instructor's permission to enroll..
descrip: What kinds of social forms do we organize ourselves into, what makes these forms endure, and where does change come from? In this course, we will explore classic and contemporary theories of organization with a special focus on technology in organizations. We'll discuss engineering cultures, skilled work, entrepreneurship, innovation, risk and failure in the context of such cases as the dot com boom, the rise of Silicon Valley, and the imprint of office technologies in the workplace. As companies pick up, produce, or respond to technological change, we'll witness and discuss some of the great questions and theories of social organization.
title: Sociology of the Cubicle: Work, Technology, and Organization

evals: A great help for psychology independent work.
An extremely engaging and useful course!!!
Be prepared to work!
Choose a final project topic that is interesting to you; that makes up for the rest of the course, which is quite dry.
Do the work and go to class!

Don't be intimidated by the class but do expect a reasonable amount of work each week. The final research project can also be fun if you choose an interesting topic. Wouldn't recommend for non-psych majors.

Don't be intimidated y the syllabus. The professors do an AMAZING job of organizing the syllabus so that the work does get done and do a wonderful job os teaching the information and being there for extra help if needed. The first 2 weeks are the hardest

If you are a psych major, you do not currently have a choice in taking it. (If you are not a psych major, do not take this course.) The readings are not long and they are informative so I recommend you do them. Lecture attendance is crucial. Just be careful of pacing in terms of the final project: group projects can be challenging so be sure to stay on top of deadlines.
If you're in this then you have to be in this most likely! Take it it's great!
Make sure to use all of the resources available to you, from asking the professors to going to R tutoring hours, to get the most out of the course.
Must take if you're a psych junior

Professors give you so much feedback that it is quite hard to do poorly in the class. Just show up and go to labs and you will do fine. There are many days were you don't have lecture which is nice and the class overall feels more like a giant study hall for independent work and projects than an actual lecture and lab.
Take it- interesting and helpful
Take the course only if it is required. Go to lecture and most of the information will be covered there.
The project is worth a lot

The work for this course is very manageable. There are only a few psets in the beginning of the semester, and once you're assigned to a group, you only have to work on your final project. The midterm was fair (if you review the lecture slides and practice questions, you should be fine). Above all, make sure you don't take on too much for your final research project. You don't get extra points for being super ambitious, so it's better to focus on one or two interesting/simple research questions with as few variables as possible.
This is a great class, much more laidback than I'd expected in terms of lectures and the labs were really engaging and worth the work you put in.
This is an awesome course take it!! Even though you are required to haha

You are probably taking this course because you must -- embrace it! What I found to be the most rewarding part of this course was getting to know others in my department, whether it be professors or peers. You really do get to build a sense of camaraderie, especially with your assigned teammates. Be prepared to do work and participate, both in lecture and lab; the learning curve can be steep in the beginning of this course if you have little experience in R.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: The readings for the course will be available in the textbook specified in class. Reading and Writing assignments for each week will be posted in Blackboard.
prereqs: Offered to PSY concentrators only, is offered every fall term. Students who are unable to take the course in the fall of their junior year (e.g., study abroad students) must take the course in their senior year or fulfill the requirement by another course at Princeton or at another university (subject to approval by the Dept. Rep.). Early concentrators will be permitted to take the course as long as they have satisfied the prerequisite for the course (PSY 251 or the equivalent)..
descrip: This course will give students the foundational knowledge and analytic tools that they need for their independent research in Psychology. The first half of the class will address issues pertinent to all areas of psychological research through lectures and hands-on research projects, and will survey the methods used by different subsets of Psychology through guest lectures. In the second half of the course, students will apply these principles to their own research ideas, realized in small groups. The semester will end with a conference of student projects and a corresponding final paper written in APA journal style.
title: Research Methods in Psychology

evals: If you are into LA classes or if you need an LA I would very very much recommend this (but my recommendation only holds if it is with Sarah Anderson).

Sarah Anderson is an absolute joy, and I couldn't recommend her courses more highly. For those with any interest in the Middle Ages, any one of her courses is a must-take. She tackles the complexities of medieval material bravely, with immense knowledge, imagination, generosity, and love for what she does. No professor cares more for her students: Professor Anderson is always eager to support, accommodate, and encourage. Beowulf offered a particularly interesting and rare opportunity to engage very deeply with a text that is relatively small (in terms of length, not of power!). To spend so long with Beowulf meant that we were able to develop especially complex lines of inquiry during seminar, to explore the larger scholarly conversation surrounding the poem, and to approach the poem from a number of cultural, critical, and creative angles.
Take it! It is an amazing course that is very interesting, and professor Anderson is a really great professor.
Take it.

This is a fabulous course and I cannot recommend the professor enough! Beowulf is a fascinating subject and this class provides a myriad of historical, linguistic, and literary (perhaps more literary than philological) approaches to the poem. Some knowledge of Old English is useful, but as discussion is often, to some degree, tailored to the abilities and interests of the students in the class, it is not necessary. I'd encourage you to take this and/or other courses from the same professor regardless of your department or primary academic interests.
This was one of the most incredible courses I have taken at Princeton. Take a class with Sarah Anderson before you leave, regardless of your major or interests. She is truly an incredible individual.
otherinfo: Any knowledge of Old English or of the early Middle Ages in the West will be helpful, but is not required. During the first few weeks of the term, I will conduct a workshop introducing the language as we work with the poem. Textual and historical problems will be part of class discussion each week. Distribution Requirement: British Foundation
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Twenty-five pages of reading per week. We will focus on learning
descrip: How does Beowulf work as a poem? In this course, we aim to find out, learning Beowulf through close study of its manuscript context and of its literary and historical milieux. Topics emphasized include the poem's genre; its sources, analogues, and afterlives; its place in theories of oral performance; its aesthetics; and its troubled relationship to the culture(s) that wrote it and to the modern cultural investment in it. Tune up your harp, sharpen your wits, and get set to explore a startling and crucial text.
title: Beowulf

evals: Definitely take this class

Definitely take this class! Professor Strigl is a great lecturer and there is a lot to be learned from his leadership experiences. It's a great class to take senior year- not too heavy of a workload, but you will definitely still get something out of it that is applicable to life after college.
Fantastic course!
Go to lecture.

I wanted to like this class more than I did. I wanted it to challenge what I already knew, but all this course did was tell me things I knew in a different format. It was interesting learning from Professor Strigl though, even if I disagree with his (very clear) political views and his old school approach towards consumer behavior. Take this if you want to hear his comments/opinions/experiences, but I think you'd be better off with a different course if you're looking to learn about leadership.
I would recommend this for people who want to develop their business and public speaking skills.
If you are interested in leadership qualities, the class is perfect.
Mehn
One of the most practical classes I've taken at Princeton. Highly recommended. Prof. Strigl cares and engages with his students. Love him

Perfect senior spring course, works well as a PDF.  Not the most engaging entrepreneurship class offered at Princeton. Readings and guest speakers are the best part.  Much of what is taught seems intuitive already.
Really nice class. It was good to learn from someone with such an amazing background.
Take it
Take it if interested in going into the business world as an aspiring manager
Take it.
Take it. Prof. Strigl is one of the best professors at Princeton. Everyone loves him. Great practical life lessons if you want to go into the business world.
Take this class and make the most of Professor Strigl, he's amazing.
Take this class if you have any interest in genuine leadership.
Take this! Professor Strigl is incredibly experienced and wants to help you become a better leader.

This is a useful course for understanding the business sector and how to be a leader in it; there are a lot of guest speakers that come in and talk about leading their companies, and Professor Strigl also has useful advice from his days in business. The workload is pretty light, so I think the ratio of work put in to what you get out of the course is actually quite high! This is also an extremely practical course; don't come in expecting theoretical perspectives on management methods but rather case studies of how people have led and how their leadership styles have shaped their companies.
This is one of the best classes at Princeton. You?ll get to learn a lot of useful skills that can be applied in the workplace and learn from Professor Strigl?s experiences as a Fortune 500 CEO.
Would definitely recommend.

i would definitely take this course. professor strigl is so intelligent and kind and you'll learn and absorb more than you know out the course simply by attending class. i think the case studies you read are also super interesting too which supplements class discussion.
jkjk
take this class because it has very valuable lessons and can actually change how you think about leadership, if you let it.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Reading assignments approximately 40 pages per week. Group presentation and written report will account for 25% of the final grade.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The Leadership Development for Business course deals with the strategic, organizational and leadership challenges that global corporations face. The course provides students with a unique perspective on leadership vision, and how leaders recognize and capitalize on opportunities. We will focus on how leaders achieve results and make things happen working with and through others. This course presents innovative, practical and field tested methods used by successful business leaders to achieve sustained results. Classes will consist of a mix of classroom lecture, case study discussions and guest speakers.
title: Leadership Development for Business

otherinfo: Course offered in French. This course is sponsored by the Princeton University Art Museum's Andrew W. Mellon initiative "Activating the Collections". A significant number of classes will take place at the Museum.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: 70-100 pp. / week
prereqs: FRE 224 or higher, or by permission/interview with Professor..
descrip: Perhaps the greatness of works of art and literature -- and of one's life -- can be gauged by the importance they confer to things of no obvious significance: anecdotes, anonymous people, ephemeral characters, trivial details gleaned from daily life. Through readings of texts and film, as well as artworks from Princeton University Art Museum's collections, we will question, far beyond the concerns of minimalism, what is at stake in the possibility of the sublime within the banal. At the crossings of ethics and aesthetics, be raised the questions of what it means to not mean much, and, yet, be absolutely indispensable.
title: The Art of Insignificance

evals: I found it to be much more rewarding when I had an instrument to play (that was not the piano). If you can't play an instrument, don't completely avoid the course if you still are interested, but also know that it definitely enhances your experience to do so. And please please please don't get caught up in how well you play your instrument and chicken out because you haven't picked up your flute in 7 years or something! Trust me, that doesn't matter!

I would recommend taking this class if only for the professor.  John is renowned and wonderful.  If you do not play an instrument, this class will definitely not be as fun or practically enriching for you.
If you are willing to apply yourself for at least 4 hours a week to learning from a genius and creating something beautiful then take this course!
If you like theater and/or music, you will like this course.  It is unlike anything else you've ever taken.
Take it! But don't take it if you're shy.
Take it! John Doyle is very kind and actor-musicianship is really fascinating. Ask lots of questions!

Take this class! John Doyle is wonderful. Even if you don't play an instrument or haven't played your instrument since elementary school, you can still get a lot out of it and he will adapt things for you.
This class really opened my mind to what theater can be and what performers can do.  John Doyle is a wonderful teacher. Take it!
otherinfo: John Doyle received a Tony Award in 2006 for his innovative direction of SWEENEY TODD and continues to reinvent musicals, plays and operas around the world. He is the artistic director of Classic Stage Company, where he directed a new revival of Stephen Sondheim's Pacific Overtures in Spring 2017. 30% Other: Creative Projects
grading: Design Project - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Students will read at least one play or musical a week, and prepare performance work for weekly presentations.
prereqs: For admission, please complete an application on the Music Theater Program website. This course CANNOT be audited..
descrip: A practical class. This is a workshop based class for those interested in multi-skilled performance and in how performance skills can illuminate new forms of theatre making. Ideally participants should have musical skills and be able to bring an instrument to work with. A lack of instrument would not preclude somebody from participating. It is helpful, but not necessary if students can read music. The course is also open to those interested in directing or other aspects of storytelling. It is also available to music students who are interested in all aspects of performance.
title: Development of the Multi-Skilled Performer

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 150-200 pages a week of reading; Four response papers, due before precept; Two essay reviews, each of a major secondary source
prereqs: There is a required 80-minute precept. Additional precepts will be scheduled only if enrollment warrants..
descrip: This course surveys American legal thought and the practices of American lawyers. Along the way, it questions the notion of distinctive "schools," as well as the distinctive legality and the distinctive Americanness of legal thought. It offers an intellectual history of 20th century American law, with an emphasis on core controversies and debates.
title: American Legal Thought

evals: Definitely take it with Professor Johnson

I would not recommend taking this class out of general interest in anthropology. The class is suited for students in Anthropology, ETH, or who have a specific interest in the evolution of anthropological thought over time.
Make sure you're keeping tabs on the readings each week because they're very relevant to (and helpful for) the papers, which don't require much, if any, outside reading.
Take this course to get a good overview of strands of anthropological thought. As long as you are on top of the readings and active in class, you should be fine!
otherinfo: For administrative reasons, there are two ways of enrolling in ANT300A/B. ANT 300A is for all students other than juniors in the Anthropology major. ANT 300B is reserved for juniors in the Anthropology major, as it includes enrollment in the Junior Seminar (the ANT 300B "Lab" section). ANT 300A and B are otherwise the same, and meet together.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 75-100 pp/week. Oral: participation in class and on Blackboard in the form of discussions of the assigned reading and of students' field journals (30% of the course grade). Written: weekly one-paragraph abstracts and discussion questions (10% of grade); weekly 250-500 word journal entries (first half of journal due at midterm for 15% of the course grade, second half due last day of class for 20% of the course grade). Final Dean's Date paper: 3000 words (25% of course grade).
prereqs: This course assumes basic knowledge of sociocultural anthropology or another ethnographic tradition. Students lacking such preparation may take any concurrent 200-level anthropology course, or consult the instructor for advice. ANT301 (the spring term fieldwork methods course) and ANT300 may be taken separately and in different academic years. However, the two courses do complement one another and together prepare students for Independent Work involving ethnographic fieldwork in the US and abroad..
descrip: This course connects ethnographic theory (e.g., about culture, relationality, context, and interpretation) to everyday experience and vice versa. Readings from academic and media sources align with weekly journal writing to cultivate students' ethnographic awareness of their own and others' embodied knowledge and the ethics, politics, and ritual dimensions of relationships, language, and more. Throughout we scrutinize how "experience" becomes ethnographic "evidence" and how the immediacies of participant-observation fieldwork bear on wide-angle questions about power/value hierarchies, historical and cultural context, and societal dynamics.
title: Ethnography, Evidence and Experience

evals: Great professor, low workload, nice to see a different side of structural engineering. I recommend it.

I would recommend this course for any civil major who would like to see the format of a graduate level course or just an upper level civil course.  Professor Glisic provides so much support to the undergrads and honestly since the subject is not widely taught often the graduates and undergraduates have about the same amount of background knowledge.  The workload and grading are very fair and Professor Glisic will work with you on any aspect of the course!
This class is pretty easy and not too much work, but there isn't a lot of guidance in the psets
Use Branko as a resource! Go to office hours and talk through things with him. He is one of the best professors at Princeton, so take advantage of having him as your professor.
otherinfo: The course is oriented to upper classman (juniors and seniors). A fair knowledge in Construction Materials, Structural Analysis, and Engineering Mathematics is expected from participants.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
assgts: Each lecture of the course is illustrated with examples taken from the practice, and the hands-on through active participation in the Streicker Bridge project and other real projects. Reading and writing will be assigned through the lectures.
prereqs: CEE 205 or CEE 312 or CEE 361.
descrip: This course introduces the topics with basic definitions of measurement and monitoring, monitoring activities and entities, and with various available and emerging monitoring technologies. The fundamental criteria for applications on concrete, steel and composite materials are elaborated, and basics on data interpretation and analysis for both static and dynamic monitoring are presented. Finally, methods applicable to large spectrum of civil structures, such as bridges, buildings, geo-structures, and large structures are developed.
title: Structural Health Monitoring

evals: Best is a bit extra lol, but he's great and he knows his stuff! Beware of the midterm! You'll need to know names, DATES, and even some pretty obscure quotations. This truly is a great class though, and you'll learn a lot.
Definitely take this class. Professor Best is amazing and it is easy to build a close relationship with him. He was so passionate and willing to help his students.

I would encourage students to complete the readings for the course. Professor Best is very knowledgeable about the material, but you'll find the course worthwhile if you are able to engage with the text he assigns.
Take it!
Take this class! Professor Best is one of the kindest professors I have had yet at Princeton. His lectures are a joy to attend, and you will learn so much about this subject!

This is an excellent course for anyone interested in African American history or religion. I would consider it a must for all religion and AAS majors! Professor Best is such a great resource -- he really listens to students and gives them opportunities to shape their own learning experiences. I highly recommend it!
Wallace Best is a great professor. Take this class; it's important.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 100-150 pages of reading per week, participation, weekly response paper (1 pg), mid term exam, final paper (10-15 pgs).
descrip: This course will trace the origins and historical development of African American Religion in the United States in all its various forms, beginning with the Colonial period and ending with the era of Civil Rights in the late 1950s and early 1960s. "Slave Religion" and its impact on the subsequent cultural, theological, and material expressions of black religion will serve as the theoretical centerpiece of the course. We will also analyze and discuss the predominance of "urban religion" and the rise of New Religious Movements such as the Black Hebrews and the Nation of Islam after the First World War and during the Great Migration.
title: African American Religious History

evals: Don't be afraid to introduce yourself to EE faculty and propose an idea, or just see if they have a project in mind.
Fun, easy A, good way to make connections within ELE department
It was fun to get an idea of what research is like. It's pretty open ended in considering how much you can/want to do, so make sure you meet with advisor often to determine your next steps.
otherinfo: Grading is done by individual project advisors and an oral committee. A grade for ELE 297 is given at the end of the fall semester even if the project continues in the spring semester. Three graded elements: Detailed proposal and literature review- 10%; Oral presentation - 20%; Actual independent work and final report - 70%.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: No formal assignments, but the student is expected to average at least nine to ten hours per week and to make regular progress reports. An oral presentation as well as a final written report is required.
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a state-of-the-art project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.
title: Sophomore Independent Work

evals: A very well taught, organized and engaging class- though relatively small and intimate for a lecture course. Professor Thompson is a MacArthur Fellow and her knowledge of musical history and the phonograph is second to none. Her lectures are well organized, methodical and it's really fun when she brings old phonograph equipment to class. She and Joppan the preceptor are both engaging instructors, extremely helpful and go out of their way to make your learning experience challenging, but fun. Lectures sometimes can get a little dry, but overall, it's a great class. Would highly recommend if you are a musician or at all interested in American music or musical history during the 20th century.
Definitely take this for a fun history course, and if you have any interest at all in music technology history over the past century in the U.S.
Do the readings and take good notes in lecture, not too tough of a class.
If you are interested in learning about the history of music and how it was invented, then 100% take this course
If you are interested in the subject, it is a solid class. Not terribly difficult.
It's a pretty niche class, but I think it's worth it if you really think you'd be interested. I enjoyed it.
Take it! The course works really well and is a great introduction to the history of American culture and technology in general, in addition to musical innovations.
Take this class. It is very interesting while also having the perfect amount of coursework. Readings are long but the topics are interesting.
Take this course if you are a history major or if you are generally interested in music and technology.

This class is really interesting and I actually wanted to attend every lecture because I was worried I would miss something really cool. Would highly recommend to anyone with an interest in music and history!

This course is easy. Reading is supplementary to lecture material. Exams and paper requirements are minimal. relatively easy, but very specific. Hard to really engage in the material if you do not have a particular interest in music.
This is an awesome course, especially for music lovers!
Try to stay on top of the readings and be sure to stay on top of remembering important names when studying for the finals! It is an exciting and captivating course and I warmly recommend it!
Very enjoyable class. A fairly chill history class with interesting readings. Exams were mostly dependent on lecure slides.

Yoooooo take this class if you want a passionate professor and care about how the music industry came about! dang i learned so much! Prof Thompson is a really great lecturer and really cares about this class! :)
do the rreadings! itll come in handy for all of the assignments
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Final Exam - 15%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Reading assignments will average 125 pages per week. Essay assignments will require students to integrate ideas, themes, and information across several weeks of reading/lecture to articulate an argument about some aspect of the relationship between phonographic technology and culture. Students will also develop skills of careful, historically-informed listening.
descrip: When Thomas Edison invented the phonograph in 1877, no one, including Edison, knew what to do with the device. Over the next century Americans would engage in an ongoing dialogue with this talking machine, defining and redefining its purpose. This course will track that trajectory, from business tool to scientific instrument to music recorder to musical instrument. By listening to the history of the phonograph, and by examining the desires and experiences of phonograph users, students will perceive more generally the complex relationships that exist between a technology and the people who produce, consume, and transform it.
title: In the Groove: Technology and Music in American History, From Edison to the iPod

otherinfo: The course should be of interest to graduate students in mathematics and physics as well as advanced undergraduates. Class participation 10%.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Weekly problem sets.
prereqs: MAT325 and MAT335 or equivalent..
descrip: The course covers the essentials of the first eleven chapters of the textbook, "Analysis" by Lieb and Loss. Topics include Lebesque integrals, Measure Theory, L^p Spaces, Fourier Transforms, Distributions, Potential Theory, and some illustrative examples of applications of these topics.
title: Advanced Analysis

evals: Definitely take it. You'll take away so many great skills from the course and get to participate in lively discussion every week without fail.
Jack is amazing, take a course with him, but only take this course if you like primary sources and are OK with lots of great questions, but not many answers.
grading: Papers - 75%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
descrip: The goal of this seminar will be to introduce students to some of the most important ideas and debates surrounding the two major religious revolutions of Late Antiquity: the triumph of Christianity and the subsequent emergence and world conquests of Islam. The course will focus on extensive reading in both primary and secondary literature and students will be introduced to and trained in using major instrumenta studiorum for this period; texts may also be read in Greek, Syriac, and Arabic. No prior knowledge of Late Antiquity, Christianity, or Islam will be assumed.
title: Monotheism and Society from Constantine to Harun al-Rashid

evals: Attend the lectures!
Class is very easy but soft and boring. Pretty much everything can be made up on the spot
Easy departmental, won't get much out of it

Meet with Professor Bhatt, she is lovely to talk to and the material is interesting so it should be easy to be engaged. The theory lectures are not too important to go to, however go to every discussion lecture as you can be called on at any time.

Professor Bhatt is a great professor. While her lectures sometimes are not the most effective, she genuinely cares about the content and that her students understand. She is genuinely invested in teaching the material to her students. The course started off a bit slow but really became good quickly.

Professor Bhatt really cares about her students and her field. The readings she assigns and the corresponding in-class discussions make these points clear. Take this course for a thoughtful look into modern digital life.
Read the case studies so you can participate in the discussion
Recommend starting the final paper earlier and engaging in class discussions as much as possible.

Take it. You learn a surprising amount of things, not just about Economics but also about the digital media industry in general. The final paper is great preparation for your JP and Professor Bhatt is a dedicated and friendly lecturer.
Take this course! It is fun and you will learn a lot

This course is very interesting. As a non-quantitative econ course, I felt like I learned something very interesting and unique about social spheres within an economic context. It wasn't that difficult, and the more you put in to it the more you get out.
take it.
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: 50 pages.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Using applied microeconomic theory and case studies, this course examines the impact of digital communications technology (DCT) on markets. DCT has enabled connections between markets, so that information is instantly, continuously and ubiquitously available. We will study the economics of networked markets, whose drivers are connectivity and big data. Is the Internet eliminating intermediaries? Is there more granularity of economic agents? Has the concept of time changed? Topics will include social networks, privacy, security and innovation.
title: Economics of the Internet: The Digital Revolution

evals: If you have any interest in taking this class (i.e. if you are even reading this) sign up! It's a really fun course and Tikya (Teacher) Hannah is a great instructor.
Take this class if you speak Twi or if you want to learn a fun African language.
otherinfo: No credit is given for TWI 101 unless it is followed by TWI 102.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Weekly language lessons, including reading, audio practice, conversation, role-plays, and written exercises. Quizzes and presentations. Other assignments will account for 15% of the final grade.
descrip: An introduction to Twi language and culture of the Akan-Twi-speaking people of West Africa. The course is taught in Twi and focuses on acquiring novice-level skills to perform basic communication functions in the culture of Akan-Twi speakers of West Africa. Students will be introduced to basic grammar, communicative skills and cultural activities that will be reinforced through role plays, conversations, dialogues and songs. By the end of the course, students will have acquired basic grammar competence to perform in everyday situations with an understanding and appreciation of the culture of the Akan people in Ghana, West Africa.
title: Elementary Twi I

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Weekly language lessons, including reading and writing exercises, audio practice, conversation and role-plays, oral and written drills, language lab assignments, quizzes and class presentations. Other includes other assignments (15%) and an individual or group project (15%).
prereqs: TWI 101 and TWI 102 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is a continuation of TWI 102. It builds on the basic Twi structures acquired in TWI 101 and TWI 102 through oral and listening activities. Students will continue to build on their vocabulary through readings of short stories. It continues to focus on communicative skills and cultural awareness. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Intermediate Low and Intermediate Mid.
title: Intermediate Twi I

evals: Definitely take this course. Fauzia is a wonderful professor who goes the extra mile in ensuring her students get the required language experience and is a warm and approachable instructor.
It's great learning Hindi-Urdu with Fauzia. She possesses a wealth of knowledge of both languages.
Professor Farooqui is awesome! And this class teaches you a lot despite not being a high time commitment
otherinfo: Grading: Other, 30% = homework
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 15%, Take Home Final Exam - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Reading assignments will consist of selected literary materials. Writing assignments will focus on comprehension, interpretation, analysis and critique of literary texts with occasional scope for creative writing.
prereqs: Intermediate Hindi/Intermediate Urdu or equivalent proficiency..
descrip: We will read selected Hindi/Urdu literary materials including fiction, poetry, and literary essays while also focusing on historical and literary contexts. Materials will represent a range of genres, topics, and trends. Literary texts will be supplemented with additional materials including film and documentary selections, author interviews, etc. Reading and writing assignments will be provided in both Hindi and Urdu. Class time will be devoted to in-depth discussion and analysis of materials.
title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: For first-year Philosophy graduate students only..
descrip: A seminar for first-year graduate students in philosophy. Issues discussed will vary from year to year.
title: First Year Philosophy Graduate Student Seminar - Classic Papers in Analytic Philosophy

evals: Take it if you want to hear stories about Guy's incredible career.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%
assgts: Students will produce a midterm paper and in the second half of the term will work in groups of 2 or 3 to study the existing climate change and adaptation situation and plans in one of 4 US cities: Seattle WA, Houston TX, Miami FL and Providence RI. Each team will lead class discussions and presentations on their research including provision of readings in advance of their class. Each student will also be responsible for an individual final paper based on their group's research.
descrip: Climate change adaptation is a pressing and difficult challenge to urban design, ecological and engineering planning theory and practice. It is clear that architects, planners, engineers and designers have an important role to help cities contend with climate adaptation. This seminar reviews the general state of science and practice of climate change and adaptation with a primary focus on the United States. It looks to the work of Frederick Law Olmsted for some of the theoretical basis of developing an approach to climate adaptation that is democratic and progressive and evaluate the impediments which restrict change.
title: Climate Change, Adaptation and Urban Design

evals: Feel like this might be different from Carmona or Sircar's version. But I feel like this is an excellent combination of qualitative and quantitative components. You get to read very influential papers! And Professor Lautier is very charming.

I don't this course will be taught by Professor Lautier again because she is a visiting professor. But if it is, I would recommend it. She was a good lecturer and I can honestly say I have a deep understanding of the functioning of energy and commodities markets.
I'd recommend to take this course if you are interested in energy and commodity markets and you want to know more of the economic functions of the markets.
Take this if you are an ORFE major and at all interested in commodities. It would be good to have already taken ORF 335 before this, but not necessary I guess.

The professor is visiting so it's very likely that the class will be very different in the future. Psets were harshly graded, especially given that she hardly provided any actual examples in class and then expected us to know how to carry out the calculations and how to comment on papers. Very non-transparent grading. Mostly Master of Finance students, with a minority of ORFE undergrads. Professor wasn't very helpful during office hours.
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Problem set(s) - 35%
assgts: 4-5 homeworks, occasional readings
prereqs: ORF335 or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course is an introduction to commodities markets (energy, metals, agricultural products) and issues related to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power, and carbon emissions. Energy and other commodities represent an increasingly important asset class, in addition to significantly impacting the economy and policy decisions. Emphasis will be on the term structure of commodity prices: behavior, models and empirical issues
title: Energy and Commodities Markets

evals: Take it, and talk to Forrest as much as possible. You will get more out of it by engaging with him because he is so generous with his time and knowledge.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course will build a discourse encompassing the many aspects of building function to try to rediscover the best role of the architect. We will attempt to discover what level of functional system knowledge is appropriate for the architect today. A palette of potentially complex topics will be provided to explore building function, but to avoid the seminar becoming overly technical, it will be grounded in the basic elements of function that one might imagine: Aristotle's Air, Fire, Earth, and Water. Air: space and comfort; Fire: energy and operation; Earth: materials and construction; Water: flow and systems
title: Elemental Building Function

evals: Take the course and try to do the best that you can given the poor circumstances.
You will get out what you put in...probably. Liz and Jaffer will do their best to challenge you and help you, but you have to have an agenda that they can support.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Open to students in the final year of the M.Arch. program.
descrip: This course will support students in the development of a broad range of thesis topics optimized to the faculty of the SoA. A series of exercises will guide students to identify the primary questions that currently structure the discipline and those extra-disciplinary concerns which architecture must engaged today. Throughout the work, analyses of these issues will be linked to contemporary architectural production. All work will be conducted by small teams and will harness the dynamic feedback between specifically architectural problematics and the general logic of contemporary culture in preparation for future thesis work.
title: M.Arch. Thesis Seminar

evals: Highly recommend for student interseted in semiconductor devices, such as solar cells, LED. The course covers almost all kinds od solar cells, materials, designs, etc. Prof. Rand is very nice. Wo not take long time to finish the assgnments.
I would highly recommend this course for all who are interested in solar technology.

This course provides a nice, comprehensive overview of solar cells and how different devices operate. Moreover, it provides an introduction to research efforts being made for future solar cells. A previous class on semiconductor devices is helpful, but not necessary as Prof. Rand will work with you outside of class to get you caught up. Class expectations (homework, lab, etc.) are very relevant in solidifying your understanding of the concepts, and are a good use of your time.
otherinfo: This course is open to undergraduate students with knowledge of semiconductor fundamentals. Timing may be modified to accommodate scheduling conflicts.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Lab Reports - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Problem set(s) - 20%
descrip: Photovoltaic materials & devices discussed. Topics: solar flux distribution & spectra, photovoltaic parameters, loss mechanisms, Shockley-Queisser detailed balance approach, stability, light management, module design & various solar cell technologies, drawing distinctions between heterojunction and homojunction devices including crystalline Si and III-V & thin film cells such as CIGS, CdTe, dye sensitized, & organic. In-dept treatment of organic solar cells, including lab to fabricate & analyze an organic solar cell. Finally, we present methods to go beyond classical limits, such as intermediate band solar cells & multijunction devices.
title: Solar Cells: Physics, Materials, and Technology

otherinfo: This course is co-taught by Professor Lee Mitchell and graduate student Brian Gingrich through the Collaborative Teaching Initiative.
