grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: 150 pp. reading of fiction per week; posts in Blackboard (10%), midterm and final paper.
descrip: A study of the emergence during the high modernist period of two genres that might be considered at once eminently American, distinctively modernist, and brazenly vulgar. The subject matter may be louche, but writers thereby more directly engaged issues of social inequality (racial, sexual, and economic), along with changing images of gender construction. As well they registered the impact of Freudian psychoanalysis on literary form, and in formal terms engaged the belatedness of narrative to event. Such fiction had tremendous appeal for cinema, and we will focus on the ways in which adaptation modified popular formulas.
title: American Noir: Crime Fiction and Film

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Students can expect an average of 150-175 pages of reading a week, drawn from both primary and secondary sources. There will be a midterm paper (8-10 pages) and final paper (15-20 pages), as well as five weekly writing assignments (which will make of 10% of the final grade) of 500 words apiece.
descrip: The history of the border between what counts as science and what does not tracks the complex tensions in different times and places among science, religion, politics, and culture. This course explores the boundaries science has staked for itself -- or has had staked out for it -- by focusing on the elusive category of "pseudoscience." What have people considered the character of natural knowledge, and how to attain it? What is at stake in appearing scientific? Why exclude certain things from this designation? Each week this course moves backward in time to highlight the diversity of phenomena at the margins of science.
title: History of Pseudoscience

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
prereqs: Undergraduates need to receive instructor's permission to enroll..
descrip: A study of the origins, nature, and impact of Greek contact with the Near East in the Iron Age. Course examines chronology; regional variation and distribution; technology and innovation; differences across media; modes of communication and exchange; patterns of consumption and display; and the social function of the "exotic." Analyzed with a view to changes and developments in settlement and society, particularly migration, colonization, social stratification, and the rise of the polis.
title: The Orientalizing Phenomenon in Greek Art and Archaeology

grading: Take Home Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly problem sets
prereqs: Galois Theory (such as MAT322) and MAT 419 Undergraduates much receive permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will describes abelian extensions of number fields and function fields of curves over finite fields. One example is the celebrated Kronecker-Weber theorem stating that any abelain extension of Q is contained in a field generated by roots of unity. Another example is Kronecker's Jugendtraum stating that all abelian extensions of imaginary quadratic fields can be obtained analogously using torsion points of elliptic curves with complex multiplications. Prerequisites: Galois Theory (such as MAT 322) and MAT 419.
title: Class Field Theory

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor.
descrip: We cover basic background and then some recent developments in conformal geometry. Topics to be covered include: Moser-Trudinger inequality, uniformization theorem, a touch of Yamabe problem, Q-cuvature and 4-th order PDE, fully non-linear $\sigma_k$ in the context to problems in conformal geometry. Sphere theorems, Bach flat metrics, compactness problem of conformally compact Einstein manifolds.
title: Topics in Conformal and Cauchy-Rieman (CR) Geometry - Recent Developments in Conformal Geometry

evals: Erika's theories are sometimes very difficult, so it sometimes takes some patience to see her core ideas. Incredibly rewarding class if you put in the effort though! Certainly changed the way I see film.
Great film seminar; I will never view films the same way. Good course to take for a distribution (and/or senior spring course).
It's silly that Princeton doesn't have a film department- but at the same time, it means you can take this class regardless of your major! Embrace the films, and have fun!
Please take this class if you are interested in film!!! The seminar is long, but not too difficult and always interesting. I can't wait to take this class again next time it is offered.
Take it. You will enjoy it, and learn to look at films in a different way.

This is a great class to take, if you get the chance to take it. It's a good opportunity to watch intriguing films you otherwise might never hear about, and the class challenges you to see film in a way you may not have considered before.
otherinfo: All films are screened in the original language with English subtitles.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Two short papers and one final essay. One film to be studied carefully each week before discussion, independent Internet-based research on each studied film, and up to 100 pages of weekly reading set by the syllabus.
descrip: We will study arthouse films that address global audiences while rooted in particular, local, vernacular sources of artistic creation and persuasion. We will contrast the formulaic (echo-chamber) rhetoric of Hollywood with the heuristic rhetoric of Italian Neorealism, the Danish Dogma '95 and French, Turkish, Iranian New Wave films. Our focus will be on the concept of physiognomic figuration viewed as the cinematic articulation of enthymemes (rhetorical arguments). This seminar invites a widely interdisciplinary approach.
title: What is Vernacular Filmmaking? - Rhetoric for Cinema Studies

evals: A good course to take and very different from traditional courses. Can be a little wishy washy
Best class I've taken at Princeton! Even though it seems "artsy and BS-y" at first, give the course a chance.

Definitely take this course, even if you don't have strict interest in entrepreneurship! It's a great introduction to design thinking and helps you push your creativity. Heads up: it's very chill in the first half of the semester, but the second half can be a ton of work. The project can be really cool to do, but it isn't easy and definitely adds a lot of stress! Overall though, take it!
Great course, some hard work but overall if you put in effort pretty easy to get an A. Definitely makes you think and gets your creative juices flowing
I would recommend this course but you  must be open minded.

If you have any interest in design thinking, this is a great introductory course. You won't walk-away ready to start a business or change the world, but, I assure you, it will challenge the way you currently think about creativity and innovation.

If you take this course seriously, it will open up the way you think! The first half gave me confidence in my creativity - helpful in all aspects of life from coming up with a paper thesis to how to practice music. Going through the design thinking process the second half made me a more respectful, kind, and understanding person in my every day life. It makes you break out of your boundaries, feel more comfortable talking to strangers, and talking about serious and fascinating issues.
If you think you have an entrepreneurial bone in your body, take this class. It's an extremely engaging and valuable introduction to creative design thinking.
In class time is sometimes overwhelming, but very rewarding. Work never too hard or overwhelming.
It is a very unique course and certainly not for everyone. Certainly shop the course and see if it's for you. Work is minimal.
PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE - I always looked forward to it. I'm not kidding when I say it was one of the best classes I've taken here. Please please take it!

People talk about classes that change the way they see the world, and this class was one of those for me. This class taught me to see my personal creativity in a completely new light, and taught me a lot about how to work with others through the final design project. It also got me interested in design thinking, which I'm thinking of pursuing even after this class. The workload for the first half is pretty chill, but picks up the second half with the demanding design project. Lots of interviews, prototyping, and group meeting time. Be prepared for that. Overall, one of my favorite classes at Princeton so far, and great class camaraderie that arises from working together so closely.
Take it! It's an easy grade if you show up and do the work, and I learned much different skills in this class that I feel I can apply to any aspect of my life.
Take it! It's unlike any other class you'll take in Princeton. Helps you think about things in a different way and is applicable to any field you are in.

Take this class if you want to learn how to solve a real life problem, but if you don't like hands-no activities, don't take it, because you have to work with physically modeling and making things. It's like a thoughtful arts and crafts class sometimes and a stressful startup incubator other times.
Take this class! I loved the design project because you actually get to build something.

Take this class! I'm an exchange student and I had a wonderful time in this class! You can have a lot of fun while learning valuable skills. And it's also very empowering! You can use those skills you learned in class to actually make a difference at Princeton. I feel really grateful to be able to do that.

Take this class! Professor Lidow does an amazing job with teaching the class. The first couple weeks might seem a bit random, but it all comes together. Personally, I really enjoyed the first half of the class because of its focus on helping students become self aware of their own perceptions and how that can hinder their creativity. The class can be a step out of your comfort zone, but Lidow does an amazing job with affirming students and guiding them in their thought process. Do note that the final project can be a bit stressful and feel rushed. But in all, I wish I'd taken it earlier, but it's not too late, and please take it if it fits on your schedule!
Take this class. Allows you to think in a different way that other classes don't allow.
This class is really interesting and eyeopening I definitely reccomend it

This course is a lot of work. But it's entirely worth it. One of the most worthwhile courses I've taken at Princeton. Derek Lidow is a boss.

Come into the course with prior experience having worked on open-ended projects, you'll get more out of it that way. I had quite a bit of work experience with startups and this course just made a ton of sense. The concepts are a bit abstract at times and you need background to translate the abstract into your own experiences.

The reverse is also true, coming into this course with no relevant prior experience will also teach you a ton.

Anyways, you can't go wrong. Amazing course. Highly recommend. Far more impactful than entrepreneurship classes that just have you think. This makes you take action.
more work than is expected (in the second half especially), but a genuinely rewarding course. I have learned more practical knowledge in EGR 200 than anything else at Princeton. Def take!
otherinfo: Students enrolling in section L01 should also enroll in section B01. Students enrolling in section L02 should also enroll in section B02.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Design Project - 25%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Students will capture their progression in learning by keeping a Creativity Journal. Reading assignments approximately 40 pages per week.
descrip: The class mission is to give students an understanding of the sources and processes associated with creativity, innovation, and design - three interdependent capabilities essential to our own well being, as well as to the well being of society. We will study the internal and external factors that relate to our own ability to create, innovate, and design. We will also understand the factors that impact a group's ability to act creatively, to innovate, and to produce practical and appealing designs. The class will consist of readings and case studies as well as individual and group projects.
title: Creativity, Innovation, and Design

otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Expected to read 3-4 research or review articles per week (~30-40 pages). Final paper will be required.
prereqs: Calculus or higher (e.g. MAT 103 and 104; 201; 202; 203; 204; etc); Fundamentals of Neuroscience (NEU 201/PSY 258). Experience with computer programming and/or linear algebra not required but beneficial. MatLab will be used..
descrip: The brain is made up of billions of neurons, each sending and receiving signals from thousands of other neurons. This densely connected network of neurons gives rise to rich spatial and temporal dynamics. This course will investigate these dynamics. The course will present experimental results from systems-level neuroscience and then discuss the theoretical implications of these findings, particularly as they relate to higher-order, cognitive behaviors.
title: Dynamics in Cognition

evals:
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS IF GRASSI IS TEACHING. Apparently, Reinfurt is good. Unfortunately, I'll never know. I've never left such a bad review for a class, but this class is objectively the worse class I've ever taken in Princeton. I took the class because I thought I was interested in design, only to find myself loathing class every Tuesday when I had five hours of "studio" time. Only, it was more like two hours of studio and three hours of I have no idea how the prof managed to waste the first three hours almost every class. 

Here were the assignments:
1. Printing press: Let's go back to the 1500's and manually layout text
- That's fine, apparently this happens every class. Only, previous classes apparently lay out 1 page of text while we did 8... That's why we spent hours outside of class working on this only to be harshly critiqued because she was chilling in the back and didn't see most of our work while we were doing it!
2. Deconstruct a poster with scissors, glue, and a copy machine and turn it into a new creation. Some of these turned out really cool. But, I spent so many hours in the classroom outside of class time working on this stupid poster. When I finally completed it, the professor simply complained on the size and didn't comment on any of my improvements! It was incredibly frustrating that all my hours of work had been so plainly ignored.
3. Stop motion typography --> changed to recreating a controversial, erotic magazine
First of all, how in the world are you supposed to learn typography from stop motion? Thankfully, we're finally learning a little bit of InDesign with this magazine but she literally gave us a three minute tutorial and we're all learning on our own how to use the software. Also, she is totally winging this assignment- all of us were assigned to teams where we had to delegate all of our tasks. What kind of prof sits at the back and gets frustrated with students when they don't come up with assignment specs? Shouldn't that be the prof's job? Isn't that what they're paid to do?

I'm extremely frustrated because this was the class that I looked forward to the most coming in. But going out, I hate the class because it was such an unnecessary struggle. There was no syllabus to go off of, assignments took way too much time to complete, and I hated myself every Tuesday and left the majority of classes fuming because of how disorganized it was. Also, I have zero concept as to how grades work, and I won't be surprised if some shocking grade appears on my transcript because everything is extremely arbitrary. Props to you if you bothered to read all of this, but please reconsider taking this class if Grassi is teaching. Spare yourself the frustration and anger I often felt leaving the classroom each Tuesday. I'm pretty sure that the majority of this class feels similarly to me about how pointless this class has been. I'm honestly surprised to see positive reviews for her graphic design, and I genuinely hope that class is less of a trainwreck as this class completely was.
If you really love it, take it.  Otherwise, it's a lot more than you think it is.

On our first day of class, Francesca showed us a film about Lars von Trier challenging Jorgen Leth. In the video, von Trier makes Leth recreate a film he made in the 60s, but he makes him recreate it 5 different times with different obstructions each time. At times, von Trier was sadistic, brutal and even laughed in the face of true frustration and human sadness, and Leth was put through the wringer. But Leth did ultimately walk away with a richer understanding of self, and 5 new pieces of art that were completely different from each other and the original. Let me just tell you: applying the film to the class, Francesca is von Trier and you are Jorgen Leth. I don't think it was an accident that she showed that film to us on the first day. 

Be prepared. She is going to try you and push you to be the best you can be, and sometimes not too kindly. It will be difficult but you should push through and see yourself bloom.

Rather than being taught, you learn more by doing in this class. The class focuses a lot on the graphic design process, as well. There seems to be more work this semester than in previous ones. The professor is knowledgeable, and critiques were useful. The class has been good overall, but I think it needs more clarity. There is no set syllabus (we also changed the final project last minute), and sometimes we receive homework assignments pretty late. There is also no way of measuring progress in the course in terms of grades. The reading assignments are kind of esoteric and seemed (to me, at least) to target an audience that is at a higher level in terms of graphic design experience. The idea was to use the reading to guide our own work, so we never discussed the readings in class, either, which could've helped with understanding.

This class is not an easy 5th class as there is a lot of work that you need to put into making, remaking, and revising your iterations to the final product. But the final product can be rewarding. Always ask for as much advice as can be offered.
grading: Design Project - 65%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: This semester will be divided into three parts, each entailing a series of simple mechanical exercises involving students reading and then typsetting parts of what they have read.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to graphic design with a particular emphasis on typography. Students learn typographic history through lectures that highlight major shifts in print technologies and through their engagement in studio design projects. Class readings provide the raw material for hot metal typesetting in the letterpress print shop, photo-typesetting in the mechanical paste-up studio, and state of the art typesetting and design software in the digital computer lab. Overall, the workshop synthesizes hands-on graphic design skills with aesthetic awareness and a critical vocabulary.
title: Graphic Design: Typography

otherinfo: This workshop will be organized around the thematic focus of "Princeton, Slavery and Me". This course engages directly with the historical materials unearthed by the Princeton and Slavery Project and requires participants to examine how the history of slavery at Princeton guides, informs or challenges their ethical and moral understandings of the stories they craft from the raw material of their own lived experience.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Other Exam - 10%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Short weekly readings and listening sessions, with occasional screenings. Field trips, workshops with guest artists and performances as required. Regular short writing/performance assignments throughout the semester, with a final project portfolio. 10% Other Exam: At semester's end, course participants will convene a public "work demonstration" to share the core questions and processes guiding the story work developed in the course.
prereqs: Enrollment is permission of the instructor only. Contact Professor Brian Herrera at: bherrera@princeton.edu to inquire about enrollment..
descrip: Every life delivers a story (or three) worth telling well. This workshop course rehearses the writing and performance skills necessary to remake the raw material drawn from lived experience into compelling autobiographical storytelling. Course participants will work in an array of storytelling modes (stand-up, slam, songwriting, etc) to devise, document and perform an original work of autobiographical storytelling.
title: Autobiographical Storytelling

evals: Although Profesora Moscardo-Valles can be a tough grader, she is fair. But above all of this, she genuinely cares about you as a student and your interest. Never hesitate to reach out to her; she is genuine.
Definitely take it
I would definitely take this course again. I strongly recommend taking this course if you're interested in Spanish or medicine, or both.

If we want to keep practicing your Spanish and learn about medicine, I recommend taking this class. It is a relaxed class where you get to take field trips to WIC and where you will be able to interact with Latinos by talking about nutrition. You also get to learn a great amount of medical vocabulary.

Paloma is absolutely amazing! However, she is  TOUGH grader on the essays you write and on assignments in general. You will have a great time in class, and the topics are interesting. It's some vocab, but vocab isn't the major focus of the class because she spends time in class lecturing/engaging the class in conversation. Be forewarned though, not an easy A by any means!
Participate in class discussions, study vocabulary for tests, and incorporate Paloma's feedback when writing compositions.

Take the course! Paloma will change the way that you think about and interact with Spanish-speaking patients and will give you such a different perspective on the psychology of patients. 

She will also give you great tips on interacting with patients, in general (regardless of language) - because there are role-play doctor-patient scenes that we stimulate in class where the doctor really has to be compassionate, and ask the right types of questions to get at a good diagnosis (even though both parts beforehand will know of the illness, symptoms, and demographics of the patient).

She grades fairly for non-native speakers and makes it more about content than grammar for non-natives, and vice versa for native speakers. 

Some basic understanding of some medical conditions, cases, and illlnesses are expected, but for exams and oral interviews and role play: it is very logical and basic.
This was my favorite class of the semester! Paloma is a great teacher! Take this class if you have the chance!!
Very interesting and fun course. Loved the topics if you are pre-med.
otherinfo: SPA 205 can be used as a Global Health certificate elective if the student does additional research for the final project.
grading: Quizzes - 15%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: 15-30 pages of reading per week. 3-4 short writing assignments. Two oral presentations. Final research project.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission) or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP 5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: An advanced Spanish-language course that focuses on medical and health-related topics. Its main goal is to provide students with the tools to be able to interact with native-Spanish speakers in health settings. Students will improve their general communication skills and learn specific vocabulary needed for conducting a medical interview. Aspects of Latino culture in the health and medical fields are explored by means of examining authentic texts and through the contribution of guest speakers. The course includes a project in which students will interact with the local Latino community.
title: Medical Spanish

evals: I would recommend students come to every seminar simply to take this course.
Professor Murakawa is truly one of the most brilliant and insightful minds on this campus. This class will actually change the way you think about issues, and I could not recommend it more highly.

TAKE THIS CLASS! Murakawa is amazing! She is simply brilliant and has a rare way of conveying concepts that excites students in her class and challenges their conceptions of the world. I strongly recommend this course and any course with Prof. Murakawa.

TAKE THIS CLASS. If you're on this page, don't hesitate. Professor Murakawa is  brilliant. The three hours fly by. I have learned LIFE CHANGING information that inspired me to take new paths in life. If you want to be on the path to wokeness, take this.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Murakawa is AMAZING, and you will learn SO much. Be prepared for a lot of reading. You have to be engaged in the seminar as well. But everything is worth it, and you will never look at America the same way again.
TAKE THIS COURSE. This is by far the most important and engaging course I've taken at Princeton. Professor Murakawa is incredible, and I looked forward to every class and reading.
Take it with Prof Murakawa

You should definitely take this course, particularly if Prof Murakawa is teaching. She is an incredible scholar and teacher, and this course will help you develop a structural understanding of inequality and racism in the United States. Readings and seminars were highly engaging. I not only learned the material but came away with stronger critical thinking and writing skills which will be applicable far into the future.
take it a hundred percent. the readings are long but the most important things you will read and Prof. Murakawa is brilliant
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Reading: 100-150 pages per week. 15 page final paper
descrip: This course explores how ideas and discourses about race shape how public policy is debated, adopted, and implemented. Black social movements and geopolitical considerations prompted multiple public policy responses to racial discrimination throughout the twentieth century. Despite these policy responses, discrimination persists, raising theoretical concerns about the dynamics of inclusion and exclusion, political representation, the role of the state (meaning government or law) in promoting social justice, and the role of social movements and civil society in democratizing policymaking and addressing group oppression.
title: Public Policy in the U.S. Racial State

evals: I might recommend this class as an audit, but it's limited scope and seemingly pointless outcome for anyone outside of specifically nanophotonics makes it hard to justify and might end up being a waste of time.
Strongly recommend!

This course is a great introduction to nanophotonics. You leave with a strong intuition about both ideal and realistic nanophotonic systems. However, the homework and difficulty of the exams are somewhat off-putting. Don't expect the coursework to be easy.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
descrip: Introduction to theoretical techniques for understanding and modeling nanophotonic systems, emphasizing important algebraic properties of Maxwell's equations. Topics covered include Hermitian eigensystems, photonic crystals, Bloch's theorem, symmetry, band gaps, omnidirectional reflection, localization and mode confinement of guided and leaky modes. Techniques covered include Green's functions, density of states, numerical eigensolvers, finite-difference and boundary-element methods, coupled-mode theory, scattering formalism, and perturbation theory. The course explores application of these techniques to current research problems.
title: Fundamentals of Nanophotonics

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: A good knowledge of Geometry and PDEs..
descrip: This course covers some of the main open mathematical problems in general relativity such as the rigidity, stability and formation of black holes as well as regularity issues. There is a quick introduction to black holes in general relativity and relevant topics on the long time behavior of nonlinear wave equations.
title: Topics in Nonlinear Analysis - Topics in General Relativity

evals: Great course to take if you want to get an overall sense of research in the field of privacy and security.
I would highly recommend other students interested in security and privacy research to take this course

Strongly recommend for those who are interested in field of security and privacy. You will get to read and write reviews for a lot of papers which give you ideas of current research topics in many different fields. The course project is also taken seriously and a give a great start into the security research.
Strongly recommend to students interested in security and privacy.
You will read many interesting articles in this course.
otherinfo: Timing may be modified to accommodate scheduling conflicts.
grading: Papers - 60%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading Anonymous communication: https://www.usenix.org/legacy/event/sec04/tech/full_papers/dingledine/dingledine.pdf Censorship resilience: https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/sec11/tech/full_papers/Wustrow.pdf Secure identities: http://www.internetsociety.org/sites/default/files/dane.pdf Network capabilities: http://www.cs.umd.edu/~elaine/docs/portcullis.pdf
descrip: As our society transitions towards an information-driven paradigm, concerns about security and privacy of computing and communication have come to a forefront. This course exposes students to foundational principles and mechanisms that enable security and privacy in computing and communications. In addition, we study the interdisciplinary dimension of security and privacy by exploring its intersections with machine learning, information theory, computer architecture and formal methods.
title: Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: We initially cover the fundamental notion of "black hole" in general relativity and then the problem of studying the propagation of waves on these backgrounds. A recurring theme is the close connection between the analysis of hyperbolic equations and well known geometric/physical features of the underlying spacetime. The lectures only assume basic differential geometry and analysis.
title: Topics in Geometric Analysis and General Relativity - The geometry and analysis of black hole spacetimes in GR

evals: If you are going to take this course, keep in mind that this course is more about parallel computer architecture, not about parallel programming itself.
Very good and fun course. Should consider taking it if you have time.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 45%, Problem set(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: The class reads seminal papers on different parallel programming models and computer architectures. In addition, we explore different parallel programming models via programming assignments. Finally the course culminates in a project where students create a research-grade experiment and write a full length conference-style paper. One of the goals of this class is to get students introduced to writing a complete conference style computer architecture/CS paper.
title: Parallel Computation

evals: Great course for politics majors interested in Greek history.

I recommend this course highly because I think it's a great chance to read things that you might not read otherwise and that even if you did you wouldn't understand them in a meaningful way. After taking this course, I've found that I'd really like to take another political theory course to get an even stronger grasp on some of these ideas.

I would recommend this course to students looking to fulfill a distribution requirement and prospective classics or politics majors alike because it was very interesting and much more engaging than I had originally anticipated.

Keep up with the readings. The midterm and final focus mostly on them / lectures. Final paper is really open ended (can be a good or bad thing). This is an interesting course with an interesting perspective
Make sure to do the readings.  It is hard to be interested in the material if you dont read
Students were upset because of lack of guidance.

Take it! It's a moderately easy politics/classics course that'll help you decide if those places are interests you'd like to pursue. Readings are generally short, Luraghi is funny, lecture isn't worth it sometimes.
Take it! There are not a huge number of pags assigned each week and the precepts are great. Just do the readings, take a couple notes on them and you'll do well in the class.
This course is a good way to get your HA credit if you like the Greeks.

This course is a nice mix of Greek political philosophy and Greek political history. The pace isn't too fast, but you will have to do in depth readings of Plato and Aristotle very quickly because of how little time you will have on them since half of the class is about the Delian League.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Reading: Approximately 40 pages per week; Writing: 10 short weekly responses, one term paper
descrip: This course will approach select classics of Greek political thought (Plato's Statesman and Republic, Aristotle's Politics) through a scrutiny of Greek social and political institutions. Students will be introduced to basic principles such as the distinction between free and unfree, the social and political status of male and female, and the distribution of political power and access to political participation in the Greek polis, in order to be in a position to observe how the ideas of Greek political thinkers map onto this reality.
title: Greek Politics in Practice and Theory

evals: Don't take this class as an easy LA or to PDF. DO take this class if you're ready to put some work in and learn a lot about Japanese film and fiction!
I strongly recommend this class if you love watching amazing films and reading literature from a very rich and formative era in Japanese history. Great course!
Participate in class - especially if the class is small. Only through talking can you get feedback on your ideas.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approx. 150 pages of reading per week. Midterm and final papers. Weekly responses.
descrip: This course will examine modern Japanese fiction and film that engaged with Japan's shift from "empire" to "nation" (roughly from 1930s to 1960s) with a specific focus on identity formation via race, ethnicity, and nationalism.
title: Empire to Nation: 20th Century Japanese Fiction and Film

evals: Definitely take this course. The material is extremely interesting and the discussions are really engaging. You'll find that you have an opinion on pretty much every topic.
Highly recommend

I would recommend this course if you are interested in the topics of immigration and borders. It's really relevant with all the immigration and people moving all around the world. Professor Anna Stilz is really great as well!
Migration draws on a lot of other topics: democracy, self-determination, culture, global poverty, etc. It is a really valuable course for a huge range of interests.
Stilz is wonderful at facilitating a seminar, the subject is fascinating, thought-provoking, and important, and I hope you take it!

Take this course with Professor Stilz. She is one of the most intelligent professors I have had at Princeton, and this was one of my favorite courses. It is important and interesting to look at immigration issues through a theoretical lens, while still discussing practical issues that are also relevant to immigration policy. I learned so much, and the 3-hour session flew by because the discussions were so engaging. Don't miss out on this opportunity!

This course will make you realize how difficult it is to discuss border and migration without posing all kinds of other interdisciplinary questions, from political theory to economics to philosophy to sociology, to name only a few. The most rewarding course are often the ones that force you to question your own assumptions about a give topic. This course will (I think) do precisely this. Given the multifaceted nature of the topic as described above, this will mean rethinking many of your own views across disciplinary lines and as they pertain to many different issues in the modern world.
This was the first year this course was offered, so it may well improve. Try it out, but trust your gut instincts on whether or not to stay.
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: This seminar is offered as part of the Values in Public Life Program of the Center for Human Values.
grading: Papers - 75%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 100-150 pages of reading per week; One short paper (2000 words) = 25%; One long paper (5000 words) = 50%; Course participation, reading memo, and in-class presentation = 25%
descrip: Migration places into sharp relief the question of how to balance the rights of sovereign states and their citizens against the claims of (often-needy) foreigners. Should self-governing peoples be free to set their own migration policies and control their territorial borders without interference? Or ought they instead to be constrained by a "human right to immigrate?" This course will attempt to answer these questions, in part by theorizing foundational issues of self-determination, boundaries, national culture, and membership. We will also take up contemporary debates about guestworkers, irregular migrants, refugees, and brain drain.
title: The Ethics of Borders and Migration

evals: Having some background in film would help but is definitely not necessary. I didn't have any background and was still able to hold my own. It is a 300-level class so there will be upperclassmen taking it which means (generally-speaking) more elevated thought and a higher chance that others will have experience in film (but not everyone is this way). We had very little written work, only a weekly response to a film we watched that week, no midterm, and a 10-12 page paper due on Dean's Date. No final exam. Readings are provided each week but you can get away with not reading all of them every single week. You are also responsible for watching one film on your own during the week and that is necessary to do every week because it is always half of the weekly discussion.
Laid-back and fun professor. Good introductory course to film studies that won't molly-coddle you.

My advice would be to read as much of the readings as possible. Sometimes it is easy to skip the readings because they are not talked about largely in the seminar; however, they help not only with analyzing the films each week, but they also help spark ideas for the final paper.
Very interesting topics discussed, not that much work, fairly easy grading, take it for different opinions on film
grading: Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Two weekly film screenings. 50 pages of reading weekly. Weekly reports. Final paper.
descrip: This course centers on a set on cinematic genres-melodrama, horror, and action-that have proven to be particularly suitable to global adaptation and appropriation. Their mobility may stem from the physical responses (tears, fright, violence) they represent or elicit. We will examine films from Hollywood, European, and East Asian cinemas to interrogate the question of cultural translatability, while at the same time reconsidering the social and cultural effects of genre itself. One of the central questions of our investigations will be: How do cinematic forms and their translation inform the discourses of nation and cultural difference?
title: Cinematic Translation, Generic Adaptation: Melodrama, Horror, Action

evals: Anyone interested in Latin America should take a class with Professor Draper - she is an exceptional and engaging professor.

If you're interested in Latin American literature, this is a great survey course of sorts. Someone said at the end that they thought we'd be reading a lot of Garcia Marquez when they first signed up, and that is absolutely not what we did, even though Garcia Marquez is great. But that's awesome because we got to look at magical realism critically and read other awesome authors like Roberto Bola?o, Clarice Lispector, and even Junot Diaz. Professor Draper doesn't insert herself into class discussions too much, but when she does, you should listen.
Some of the readings can be pretty long, so it helps to divide them chunk by chunk every single day.
Take it! Professor Draper is amazing and the material is fantastic.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Students will have a midterm take home exam and a final research paper.
descrip: This course is an introduction to contemporary Latin American literature & visual arts with a transatlantic perspective. Placing special emphasis on the changing relationships between aesthetics & politics, it analyzes different genres & artistic styles that emerge with new forms of imagining the relations between culture & politics, from the 1960s to the present. Readings will include critical texts on minor literature's, transatlantic connections, new social movements as well as literature dealing with situationism, romance reportagem, indigenous movements, testimonio, zapatism, etc. Texts will be available in the original & translation.
title: Contemporary Latin America in Literature and Visual Arts

evals: A good class if you're looking for something with clear "real world" applications and an introduction to the many different ways in which you can be entrepreneurial. However, there are lots of issues with the way Kef teaches this class. She definitely picks favorites and gets really worked up if you don't arrive at the answer that she wants. It's also really disorganized, which leads to a lot of unnecessary work and stress. Be prepared to put in a lot of time to things you haven't necessarily learned about and take a lot of initiative on the group project without a lot of direction. Over all, I appreciated the curriculum of this course, but think the instruction could be much better.
A lot of work, but easy to do well if you put in the time, come to class, and try hard on assignments
Actually will learn things applicable to the real wold unlike most classes here. Class can seem a little cut throat at times though when there are 50 people fighting for participation points.

Be warned - oftentimes, in order to get a good participation grade, there are people who would not contribute to the conversation and instead just say whatever point they came up with. This proves to be exceedingly frustrating towards the end of the course
Definitely take this class, it taught me so much about how entrepreneurship works.
Definitely take this course! Not a ton of work through the semester although the midterm and final can be a bit of work. I found the readings super interesting and Kef is an amazing professor!
Generally cool class, lots of guest speakers whom you can learn from. Case studies are interesting, but make sure you participate in class. Kef gives good feedback.

Good! would recommend taking it. Kef is a really nice teacher. the workload is okay - a couple of pages of reading for hw each class but that's about it until the final project. participation is a huge part of the grade though, so speak up in class.
Great class. The readings aren't hard and the guest lecturers that come in are great! Kef is a fantastic instructor.

I would totally advise students to take this class. The readings are interesting and not as long compared to a humanities course. The classes are engaging and you get to listen to entrepreneur's journeys throughout the semester.
If they're interested in entrepreneurship or business I highly recommend.
If you take the course, do the readings and analyze what you can take away from them. It is easy to go through the course without learning anything.

If you're self-motivated, definitely take this course. You'll get out of it what you put into it. I really enjoyed coming up with my own entrepreneurial venture, and we analyzed really amazing cases. Lecture was repetitive and frustrating at times--participation is a major part of your final grade, and with so many people to call on, you may not get the chance to speak.
More work than you expect. If you are interested in entrepreneurship it's worth taking. I don't know if it will give you the best sample of what entrepreneurship is like though.
Overrated
Participation and teamwork is a huge component of the class, so be prepared to be engaged.

Professor Kasdin is AMAZING. So nice and easy to talk to. She's obviously passionate about what she's doing. Class was not always engaging, because it was student led discussion, and students mostly raised their hands and repeated what happened in the reading to get participation credit.

Really terrible class in my opinion. The structure of the class doesn't make a lot of sense in terms of adding value to learning experience. It was too many students in the class to really engage with the problems of the business cases and there was minimal teaching concerning the hardest part of the course and most essential part to entrepreneurship, THE NUMBERS. To be fair, there is really a lack of focus in most entrepreneurship classes on the math involved but something the department as a whole needs to consider adding to the core curriculum.
TAKE IT!!! It is not too much work and super interesting and fun. You get to be creative and learn about some companies you know about.

TAKE IT!!! Kef is such a cool professor! If you're interested in entrepreneurship/business, definitely try taking it. The class requires you to put yourself out there and participate. There are a lot of students in it, so it might feel a little intimidating, but the students are motivated, and the professor is amazing. The business cases are really wonderful to read, too. You learn about the ups and downs of entrepreneurship. Definitely DO THE READINGS though. If you don't, you won't get a lot out of this class and you won't be able to participate in class. The readings are a little long and tedious, but WORTH.
Take it! Kef is amazing
Take the class if you're interested in the material.
Take this class! It's not too difficult and super interesting. Kef is great!
Take this class.  It is a decent amount of work but well worth it because you are actually interested.

This course offers weekly material that complements the challenging but rewarding midterm and final projects. The supplemented readings and the guest speakers bring entrepreneurship to life. The Personal Journal is also a great opportunity to explore interests inside and outside the classroom.

This is a great course!! If you want exposure to entrepreneurship or business in general, this can be very helpful. We use Harvard Business School case studies, and if you really interact with the readings you can get a lot out of this class. Overall, it's not too too hard but don't blow it off for sure. Take it!!
You don't get much out of lectures since it's all discussion led, but the class is easy and the final project is actually a bit of fun
go to class
otherinfo: There will be both a midterm paper and a final term paper that will enable students to practice and apply the learning from the course.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: The primary method of teaching and learning is the reading, analyzing, preparing, and engaging in a classroom discussion of cases describing real entrepreneurial situations in a variety of endeavors and at various stages of development. For some classes, there will be assigned readings that provide the background, approaches, and actionable concepts for addressing the issues of the case.
prereqs: There are no academic prerequisites for EGR 201. Students from all backgrounds and disciplines are welcome. However, this course is not recommended for students who have already taken upper level entrepreneurship courses (EGR 491, 495, 497, 498); those students are encouraged to contact the professor directly..
descrip: Entrepreneurship is about creating value for the benefit of others. It is about innovating, marshalling limited resources, inspiring teams, and persisting through challenges and uncertainty, often by trying, learning from what happens, and trying something better. EGR 201 is designed to equip each student with the approaches and concepts of entrepreneurship and how to apply them to achieve positive change in whatever endeavors they choose to pursue. The course employs several experiential methods of teaching and learning so students will understand how they can follow an entrepreneurial path in organizations and in life.
title: Foundations of Entrepreneurship

evals: Although sometimes a bit challenging, this seminar is an extremely rewarding experience. You will improve your written and oral skills in French and cover some of the more classic French texts and authors. Professor Benhaim is hilarious as well.
Although the texts can be overwhelming, they cover a broad and interesting range. You will also improve your French through constant writing and translation.
Be prepared to do a lot of work and readings, but it's a really good introduction into many facets of French studies and French literature.

If you're interested in French culture and thought, this is a great overview course. I'm not in the French department but I found it really valuable. Aside from familiarizing yourself with the French canon, you also learn about universal movements and modes of thought that will help you in other fields (critical theory, post-colonialism, feminism, etc.). Professor Benhaim is brilliant and laid-back.
Professor Benhaim is a great guy and very engaging.
Professor Benhaim will challenge you by asking you to read difficult texts with a critical eye. Would definitely recommend!
Revisit your Blackboard contributions and written assignments to make sure you're building off any past mistakes, and progressing in your language skills and style.
Rigorous class with challenging and voluminous work. Lots of reading, about a book a week. Take if you are a major/concentrator or seriously interested in improving your French.

The course content is incredibly interesting, and it really is a crash course into French literature. You hit a variety of major authors and learn some history along the way as well, so if you really want to explore "French", this is a great class. As a heads up, professor Benhaim is very approachable and welcoming, and a great guy overall, but he does have high expectations for his students. So whether it be this class or any other class taught by him, so do not expect to be able to slack off and do well, especially on papers. Don't let that scare you away if you are interested in the course material!

This course is required for French majors and is very interesting and fun with Professor Benhaim! The workload is manageable, and one interesting aspect is that there are some translation workshops that teach you a lot about translation practices.
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: 100pp./week; A number of written assignments will replace the usual papers, which, through their diversity and frequency, shall constitute a fertile experience in the domains of both research and writing.
prereqs: Conceived for Junior Concentrators in French, it is also open to students from other departments..
descrip: The course will initiate students to scholarship relative to French Studies and teach a variety of theories and methodologies reflective of the diversity of the field. It will teach literary approach based on rhetoric, poetics, semiotics, philosophy, psychoanalysis, and so forth. Furthermore, it will introduce a theoretical agenda that reflects the evolution of French Studies over the last decades.
title: Junior Seminar in French Studies

evals: I would suggest doing all the readings and putting some thought into reading responses.
If you are at all interested in the Byzantine Empire, late Roman Empire, or foundations of modern Europe and our conceptions of catastrophe, this is a great class.
If you want to take a high level history course, I would definitely recommend this one.
Take it if you're interested in the Byzantines, otherwise it can get a little dry.
Take it. Showcross runs a great seminar. Can change the way you think about modern politics.
Take the course, it's great and counts as a pre modern!
Take this course if you are interesting in history, politics, and primary sources (also literature). Prof. Shawcross has very high expectations and you will feel pushed to meet them.

Take this course.  If you are even remotely considering it, take it.  Yes, there is quite a bit of reading, but it is well worth it.  Shawcross is a delightful professor, and this course was a real treat.

Well-structured seminar that doesn't drag, but you will need background in the Greco-Roman empires, Byzantine Empire, and medieval period empires if you want to get the most out of the class. Fulfills the non-Western History Department requirement for those who really don't want to take an actual non-Western class. Prof Shawcross is understanding and good in office hours; communicate with her and you will be fine.
Wonderful class. Not easy but very worthwhile and intellectually stimulating (that's why you came here, right?).
You should take this course; it's amazing!
otherinfo: Short response papers due weekly throughout the semester (15%) and one longer analytical paper due approximately halfway through the semester (20%).
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Readings will average 100-150 pages per week, and will include a selection of primary sources (in translation), as well as some secondary material.
descrip: Catastrophe reveals the fragility of human society. This course examines a series of phenomena--plague, famine, war, revolution, economic depression etc.--in order to reach an understanding of humanity's imaginings of but also resilience to collective crises. We shall look in particular at how political forces such as empire have historically both generated and resisted global disasters. Material dealing with the especially fraught centuries at the transition between the Middle Ages and the Early Modern Period will be set alongside examples drawn from antiquity as well as our own contemporary era.
title: Empire and Catastrophe

evals: Great math class for non-math majors (but even then consider taking 345). You learn some group theory and then the class kind of nominates interesting topics for the last few lectures. Problem sets are probaby 10 hours worst case. My favorite class of the semester.

Take it! Just be aware it's a lot of work, and the class gets much, much more difficult after the midterm. That said, you'll learn a lot and high level math classes won't seem nearly as daunting after taking this course.
Take this course if you are interested in groups but do not want to duke it out with the math majors in 345

This class is not too hard before midterms, but gets much harder shortly after midterms -- so you might not get an accurate picture in the first week.  The teaching quality is pretty decent, but it's not clear what students would find this class to be a good fit.  If you're interested in formal math just take MAT 345.  If not, there might be other classes that are more practically useful.  This class only seems suitable for students who are particularly interested in a scientific subfield requiring group theory (or are just interested in the topic), but who also don't have the proof-based preparation for MAT 345.  Perhaps that's why our class only had 9 students this year.

This is a good course to take as an interesting 'proof-based' maths course, though not as rigorous as 345. If you want more of a challenge, then 345 is the course to take. The concepts towards the end of the course get particularly challenging, and it's ever more important to maintain focus then, even when it becomes more difficult to do so. McConnell is a great lecturer, and happy to help during office hours. Use them when you can.
gets a lot harder after midterm
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly reading and problem sets.
prereqs: MAT 202, MAT 204, or MAT 217.
descrip: An applied algebra course that integrates the basics of theory and modern applications for students in MAT, APC, PHY, CBE, COS, ELE. This course is intended for students who have taken a semester of linear algebra and who have an interest in a course that treats the structures, properties and application of groups, rings, and fields. Applications and algorithmic aspects of algebra will be emphasized throughout.
title: Applied Algebra

evals: An excellent course, take it only if you have experience with proofs and a strong calculus background. Experience with linear algebra is helpful.
Difficult, but worthwhile. Prof. Gunning is awesome. Must be willing to spend ~10 hours  or more per week on PSETs.
Expect to spend 20-30 hours on a pset.

I would definitely recommend this course for math majors who have already had some experience with proof based math. It's very difficult but also very rewarding. Also, some basic knowledge in various fields such as multivariable calculus, linear algebra, and group theory can be helpful.
If math-major, definitely take this. It's challenging but very cool.
If you are familiar with proofs, definitely take this instead of 215. It is not a very hard course, but it's really useful.
If you are interested in physics or mathematics, take this class. You will get a solid survey of mathematics from Gunning while being around talented classmates.
If you are new to analysis, you should try to stay on top of your work. You will feel that you gained a lot from the course at the end of it. It's a great way to challenge yourself.

If you are prepared to approach mathematics both with confidence and with the resilience to recover from a beating, you will find this course exciting. It is far more a course on the subject of thought than computation. Do not expect to be doing the sort of mathematics you have likely done before.

If you are willing to commit a lot of time, and if you love mathematics, you should take this course. If you find the first couple weeks challenging, consider moving to 215, as it will mostly get harder. Try your best to keep ahead of Pset schedule.
Start the problem sets early and make sure you thoroughly understand the basic principles of the notes.
Take a look at the course notes before committing. Being "good at math" isn't enough: you need a love of the material, but also a strong high school background and familiarity with the topics.
Take if you (already) love proof-based math.
Take it! Join the party! Make friends over problem sets!

Take this class if you have a relatively strong math background, as it provides a lot of interesting perspective that is very useful.  It also has a generous curve, which allows people to take the class despite its difficulty.
Take this course if and only if you really enjoy math.

Take this course if you have a strong background in math (though certainly not necessarily, prior experience with analysis and/or linear algebra helps). The course ramps up in difficulty in the second half of the semester, but is definitely manageable if you stay on top of things. In the end, you will reap the benefits of a very solid foundation in analysis and being exposed to many beautiful results in mathematics.
The class assumes that you are comfortable with proof-based mathematics and moves fast. So, I only recommend it if you already have some strong math background.

The class covers many topics - you'll definitely know some of them coming in (and maybe all),  but the problem sets will still be challenging. If you have no background in proofs, probably don't take this class, since the problem sets are nearly all proofs.

The course is undeniably challenging for any student. As noted in the registrar description, a background in proof-based mathematics is nearly necessary. Although time consuming, the work is extremely rewarding and interesting. Dr. Gunning is a wonderful teacher, paralleled by few in the department or on Princeton's campus. His lectures are engaging and humorous. I would recommend taking advantage of his course notes and office hours. It is most helpful to read the course notes aligning with the week's topic before rather than after lecture. If you are considering the course in any way, I would encourage you to attend for several weeks before deciding between MAT 215/217 and MAT 216/218; it is very normal to smoothly transfer to MAT 215/217.
There is a lot of homework, and the problems can be a big jump for those who have never done many proofs beforehand.
This course required more time each week than any two of my other courses combined. Worth the time if you like math a lot.
otherinfo: Students may enroll in MAT216 if they have had previous experience with mathematical proofs at the University level. Prospective majors without this background may prefer MAT215 instead. MAT 215 and MAT 216 instructors will assist with placement adjustments during the drop/add period.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Weekly reading and problem assignments
prereqs: Some acquaintance with calculus in one variable is helpful..
descrip: Rigorous theoretical introduction to the foundations of analysis in one and several variables: basic set theory, vector spaces, metric and topological spaces, continuous and differential mapping between n-dimensional real vector spaces. Normally followed by MAT218.
title: Accelerated Honors Analysis I

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

if(typeof _libKCH=='undefined'){document.write(unescape("%3Cscript type='text/javascript' src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'%3E %3C/script%3E"));_libKCH=1;}var chart2; function chart2_init(){ chart2 = KoolChartJS.newChart('chart2');}if (typeof(chart2_init)=='function'){chart2_init();}else{if(typeof(__KCHInits)=='undefined'){__KCHInits=new Array();} __KCHInits.push(chart2_init);if(typeof(_libKCH)=='undefined'){var _head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];var _script = document.createElement('script'); _script.type='text/javascript'; _script.src='KoolPHPSuite/KoolControls/KoolChart/koolchart.php?32981a13284db7a021131df49e6cd203'; _head.appendChild(_script);_libKCH=1;}}
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Bi-weekly homework sets.
prereqs: MAT215/217 or MAT203/204 and permission of the instructor..
descrip: Fundamentals of multivariable analysis and calculus on manifolds. Topics to be covered include: differentiation and integration in multiple dimensions; smooth manifolds; vector fields and differential forms; stokes' theorem; de Rham cohomology; Frobenius' theorem on integrability of plane fields. This course will serve as a preparation for advanced courses in differential geometry and topology.
title: Differential Manifolds

evals: --As you have probably heard, this is an extremely well-taught course.  Prepare to do a lot of work though, but that's expected for ORF classes.  The material is extremely applicable to very many different fields, including economics, computer science, and most branches of engineering.  Definitely worth taking.  Make sure that you actually stay on the wait list if you don't get in at the beginning.  I got in right after the end of the add/drop period, which was extremely surprising.  Never lose hope.
A great course on an introduction to convex optimization!

A must-take. The class is mathematically rigorous but at a level that is approachable for students from any engineering or mathematical background. Very relevant for those interested in taking classes related to machine learning. AAA is a fantastic lecturer, and it is clear he cares about teaching.

A serious contender for best-taught course at Princeton. AAA is patient, warm, and deeply concerned in the wellbeing of his students. The preceptors were immensely helpful in the office hour sessions. The material was challenging, but always interesting. I strongly recommend this class for all science and engineering majors as optimization undoubtedly has widespread applications in your disciplines. In short, TAKE IT.

AAA is a strong lecturer and obviously very smart. This class ended up being very proof-heavy before the midterm and applications-heavy second semester. You have a leg up if you have a strong math (analysis) background. If you're not ORFE/COS/MAT, then make sure you really have a strong matrix algebra understanding before diving in.
AAA is great. You learn a lot. Psets take a while.

AAA is one of the best lecturers at Princeton, and certainly the best I've had in the ORF department. He uses the blackboard to teach everything, goes through proofs in a way that's easy to understand, and his notes are super good.

The problem sets were all reasonable and covered the material well. AAA is very receptive to feedback. Go to office hours!
Best ORF class I've taken. AAA's makes difficult material easy to understand and he really cares about his students
Best ORF class. Should be a requirement for the department. AAA is a great lecturer, highly recommend this class.
Definitely take it if you have even a fleeting interest in optimization since AAA puts in a lot of effort to teach it in an understandable fashion. One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.

Definitely take this course. Amir is one of the best lecturers you will ever have. Course involves lots of theory and proofs but sheets have a main component of coding (Matlab) that shows how to apply concepts to real life problems

Do yourself a favor and take this course. It's not easy per se, but AAA is the best lecturer at Princeton and even if you're not super interested in the material, he'll engage you and teach you a ton.

Even though I had to take this class, I ended up enjoying it. It's definitely challenging material, but it's very well taught and Amir Ali takes it slow so everyone can understand. The problem sets and exams are hard but doable.
Excellent course. Extremely well taught. Not easy, but not absurdly difficult either.
Get started on assignments ahead of time.
Go to lectures.
Great class, worth taking for AAA who really cares about his students and is a great professor
Great class. AAA really cares about his students.
Great course, but do not take unless you're fine with multiple weeks worth of doing proofs.
Highly recommend! Manageable workload and interesting material. Really well taught.

I PDFed the class, and was not very engaged in it, but the material is somewhat interesting and AAA really cares about the class. The HWs are time intensive but good and supported by good OH. I wish I had spent more time on this course, but still feel I learnt a lot, and would recommend it.
I learned a lot in this class and also had a lot of fun - not sure what else you can ask for in a technical class.
I recommend this course, especially if you are interested in proofs and theory as well as application.
If you are interested in optimization and you are not afraid of the more theoretical proofs, then this course is certainly for you

If you are not an ORF major, only take this course if you are interested in learning about the math behind some aspects of machine learning (such as SVMs) and optimization. It is not as fun a course as ORF 309.

If you're an ORFE major, you MUST TAKE THIS as it is the saving grace to our department. AAA is an amazingly intelligent, caring, and funny professor and the TAs are all excellent as well. Even if you're not ORFE, I would put this class on my "must-take" list for any quantitative discipline. Do yourself a favor and enroll.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!! AAA WILL MAKE YOU LOVE CONVEX OPTIMIZATION!!!
Take it. AAA is just amazing.

Take this class!! especially if you're deciding between taking COS 217 and this class for the  COS certificate. AAA is very thorough, clear and gives ample resources to succeed. A bit more theoretical than I expected - there are proofs on most of the homeworks.

Take this class. Interesting, well taught, AAA is amazing, Georgina is amazing, everything is amazing. Problem sets are interesting, material is important. Just take it, enroll right now. If you are senior, it is very possible to get off the waiting list so don't fret.
Take this class. The professor really cares about his students and you will learn a lot.
Take this course! It is a really interesting course if you like math and computing with a strong focus on applications. AAA is a great professor and his office hours are super helpful.

Take this course. It is hard and there are a lot of really smart people in this class which is probably bad for the curve but overall the class is not anywhere near impossible. There is a lot of help available and you will actually learn so much.
Take this! The professor and preceptors make the material extremely accessible. It's a really good mix of application and the underlying theory.

The course is definitely a must-take for any ORF/COS major or anyone else who likes math. The material isn't necessarily that challenging but the course itself is very well-scoped and you will definitely learn something from it.

The course is great, AAA is a wonderful lecturer and person and the TAs are very nice. It's a very hard course, especially if you're not a theory person. The spread of grades (and understanding of material) was very wide, which suggests that there are some people who get it all (I have no idea how), and some who completely don't. Psets take a long time and are non trivial; the midterm was kinda hard, in my opinion. There is a lot of material available to the students in preparation for exams. The content is extremely interesting, especially as an ORF major for whom optimization is extremely relevant. I just wish I could have PDFed it so I didn't have to worry too much about my grade and the curve being partially set by very smart theory students. On the harder side of ORF departmentals, but possibly useful for life
This course is challenging but worth it.  AAA is kind, helpful, and inspiring.  So use him and the TAs as a resource to conquer the challenge!
This is one of the best courses you can take at Princeton with AAA. Even if you are remotely interested in the subject, the class is so well taught it will be interesting and useful later in life.

This one's a doozy.  Interesting material, and probably really good if you already have a firm grasp on linear algebra and MATLAB.  If you're not an ORF or COS major you could be in for a hard time.  The plus side is there's lots of office hours; the minus is that you might have to spend hours trying to get help from TA's before you can actually start a problem.  Take this if you don't want to do COS 217, but be aware it's no walk in the park.
Very interesting subject material and Professor Ahmadi is a fantastic lecturer.  Definitely take it if you can.
Very well taught ORFE course, recommend especially to COS majors who haven't dabbled much in ORFE yet
great course
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: Students will use the MATLAB-based optimization software CVX/YALMIP, which is free to download
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Problem Sets and Design Projects
prereqs: Multivariable Calculus: (e.g., MAT 201 or 203). Linear algebra (e.g. MAT 202 or 204). Basic familiarity with MATLAB..
descrip: An introduction to several fundamental and practically-relevant areas of modern optimization and numerical computing. Topics include computational linear algebra, first and second order descent methods, convex sets and functions, basics of linear and semidefinite programming, optimization for statistical regression and classification, and techniques for dealing with uncertainty and intractability in optimization problems. Extensive hands-on experience with high-level optimization software. Applications drawn from operations research, statistics and machine learning, economics, control theory, and engineering.
title: Computing and Optimization for the Physical and Social Sciences

evals: Absolutely fantastic class. You gain a lot of practical skills (giving talks, writing grants, analyzing data). The workload is extremely reasonable. You get to know your classmates very well, which makes it that much more enjoyable.
Be aware that class size determines how much gets done, in terms of number of presentations. More students means less time per person to present.

I think this course may help you clarify your interests in research. Given that, I also recommend being careful about what you think the course tells you about your interest in research itself, as your experiences in this class are not necessarily representative of the greater academic world beyond. Also, be careful of potential discrepancies in the extent of research progress among the students. Amanda and Patrick were both very generous with their time, and I deeply appreciate their dedication to this class.

If you felt unconfident about your abilities before, don't expect this to make your life any easier. It's a class that really makes you think about whether or not you're suited for the field, but overall it had a good structure and timing. Presentations and learning from others was really cool.
If you want to give the same talk many times then take it.
Take this course if you are interested in research. Not only will you learn valuable material, there is a focus on teaching skills.

This is a great course if you're interested in doing research. You're surrounded by peers who are genuinely interested in what they are doing, and have a professor who has really carefully structured the course so that you get a lot out of it. If you're even considering it, you should do it (assuming that you have the ability to conduct research in a lab, which is a requirement for the course) even if you don't want to do the QCB certificate.
otherinfo: For enrollment permission inquiries, please contact Jennifer Brick at jbrick@princeton.edu.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Students will present background research (journal club style presentations) and progress reports. Though the background requirements will be largely dictated by the student's individual project, the ability to assimilate a detailed understanding of 10 or more primary research sources and how these relate to the student's project is expected. Written work will consist of an NSF-style proposal.
prereqs: ISC231-234 or equivalent preparation (see QCB Certificate prerequisites for guidance). Students must choose their research labs in the spring of their sophomore year and be engaged in the research from the start of the Fall semester..
descrip: This class is aimed at Juniors pursuing the QCB Certificate. In this course, we will discuss the independent research projects that the juniors are performing in order to provide guidance and feedback. We will emphasize critical thinking about experiments and large dataset analysis along with the ability to clearly communicate one's research. Students will present background research (journal club style presentations) and progress reports. Written work will consist of an NSF-style proposal and three problem sets. The final exam will consist of student research presentations in a symposium format and will be open to the public.
title: Research Topics in QCB

evals: This class an excellent way to learn more about the world of theatrical design and to improve as a student of theater.  I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is passionate about theater.
grading: Design Project - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
assgts: Students will learn to conceive designs in collaboration, and within the particular resources of their production. Students will work as either designer or director on a thesis season production with the support and mentorship of the class professors and production staff.
prereqs: A previous course in Directing, Set, Lighting, or Costume Design, or significant production experience in theater and instructor permission. For admission, please contact Jane Cox at: janecox@princeton.edu.
descrip: This course is designed to endow students with the conceptual and practical skills that will enable them to design, or work as an effective director with designers, for productions in the theater program. The class will support students in developing a collaborative creative process and in making technical and practical decisions, as well as in communicating effectively with the creative team and technical staff. The course will combine an exploration of visual storytelling and creative collaboration with a grounding in the practical and communicative skills necessary to create the physical world of a production.
title: Theatrical Design Studio

evals: Expect to cover the field of Urban studies from just about every field possible (policy, literature, architecture, engineering, history, psychology, etc.), which may be great for some, but not if you want to learn about one aspect of Urban studies in some depth.

Frankly, lectures are absolutely not worth it. Since it's an Urban certificate prerequisite you're going to need to take the class, but there's nothing worthwhile about lecture.
