The books, on the other hand, are marvelous, and if the class wasn't required for Urban I'd just recommend reading all 11 (yup, eleven) books and getting a good understanding instead of slumming it through lectures.
Horrible class, Professor Massey is so boring and although material is interesting, the books required are dull. Little help is given and overall not rewarding in any way.

I assume they'll improve this course over time. As of fall 2016, it's trying to cover way too much and so you end up talking about everything and nothing all at once. Lectures were super boring as Professor Massey would just read slides, and he himself didn't seem interested in a lot of what he was teaching. Exams were hard to prepare for because a lot of things were just completely conceptual and abstract, and Massey enjoyed the "what are THE 5 aspects of this conceptual framework that we never applied to anything" type questions. There's little to no direction for the paper. It can be about anything--some of you might enjoy this, others might find it frustrating like I did.
If you're doing it for a distribution, there are better ones out there that are more interesting and don't have a midterm, final, and final paper.
Make sure you stay on top of readings and take active notes during lecture.
Not the easiest SA as it was a lot of work (mostly reading), but gives you a really good overview of the fundamentals of urban studies so take if you're interested in the topic.
The material covered is interesting.  It is not much weekly work, so if you are interested in cities take it.
The material holds promise, but the execution lets it down. Lectures are tedious, and there's a lot of work for an introductory course. Take only if you're really interested in the subject.

Took this class as an Urban Studies certificate requirement, but wish I'd taken URB 201 in the spring instead. Prof Massey often reads lecture notes right from the slides and changes the pace of reading very fast (we focused on one book for the first few weeks and then shifted gears without warning). That being said, not a lot of work, pretty good preceptor, and decent reading list.  Don't take this class unless you have to/already have a standing interest in urban studies.
either go to lecture or do all the readings because pace of lecture and reading is really fast
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Students will read each of the above books and prepare short written answers to specific questions on each book for presentation in precept. In addition, students will write a term paper describing and evaluating an issue in urbanism or urban policy of their choosing.
descrip: Introduces students to social scientific thinking on cities and urbanism and then builds on this base to consider and evaluate various approaches to urban policy.
title: Urbanism and Urban Policy

evals: Do your readings and responses, and you'll easily stay on top of the material!
Don't take this if you aren't a major or ethnographic studies minor. If you are, buckle down--this is not a particularly smooth, interesting, or worthwhile class, but you still have to do it.
Go to office hours because it really helps... Professor Johnson is super helpful and always willing to chat. And his dog, Lucy, is the best!
I would advise any student with an interest in exploring various areas of anthropology to consider taking this class.
This is a good introduction to the discipline of anthropology. Professor Johnson is engaging and assigns a fair amount of reading--not too much.
otherinfo: For administrative reasons, there are two ways of enrolling in ANT300A/B. ANT 300A is for all students other than juniors in the Anthropology major. ANT 300B is reserved for juniors in the Anthropology major, as it includes enrollment in the Junior Seminar (the ANT 300B "Lab" section). ANT 300A and B are otherwise the same, and meet together.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 75-100 pp/week. Oral: participation in class and on Blackboard in the form of discussions of the assigned reading and of students' field journals (30% of the course grade). Written: weekly one-paragraph abstracts and discussion questions (10% of grade); weekly 250-500 word journal entries (first half of journal due at midterm for 15% of the course grade, second half due last day of class for 20% of the course grade). Final Dean's Date paper: 3000 words (25% of course grade).
prereqs: This course assumes basic knowledge of sociocultural anthropology or another ethnographic tradition. Students lacking such preparation may take any concurrent 200-level anthropology course, or consult the instructor for advice. ANT301 (the spring term fieldwork methods course) and ANT300 may be taken separately and in different academic years. However, the two courses do complement one another and together prepare students for Independent Work involving ethnographic fieldwork in the US and abroad..
descrip: This course connects ethnographic theory (e.g., about culture, relationality, context, and interpretation) to everyday experience and vice versa. Readings from academic and media sources align with weekly journal writing to cultivate students' ethnographic awareness of their own and others' embodied knowledge and the ethics, politics, and ritual dimensions of relationships, language, and more. Throughout we scrutinize how "experience" becomes ethnographic "evidence" and how the immediacies of participant-observation fieldwork bear on wide-angle questions about power/value hierarchies, historical and cultural contexts, and societal dynamics.
title: Ethnography, Evidence and Experience

evals: Do the work, and engage as much as you can.  It's worth it.
I encourage people from other departments that are working on bio-related projects to take the course.
I highly recommend this course.
Please spend adequate time on this course. The more time you spend, the more knowledge you gain.
absolutely be prepared to thoroughly discuss the assigned readings in class
otherinfo: MOL seniors may enroll in this course with permission of instructor.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 37%, Take Home Final Exam - 38%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
descrip: Advanced-level discussions of selected topics in prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular biology. Emphasis is placed on original research papers and extensive reading together with critical thinking is required. Topics include the genetic code, mutagenesis, chromosome and chromatin structures, mechanisms of DNA replication, recombination, repair, and transposition, gene structure and function and mechanisms of gene regulation. Examples from bacteriophage, bacteria, lower and higher eukaryotes will be used to illustrate these different areas of molecular biology.
title: Molecular Biology

evals: Beware of dolls, texts, and discussions that may exceed the stated class time... but if the topic interests you, it will be well worth it!

Do not hesitate to ask Professor Guerrero for any extra time you might need outside the classroom in case you cannot follow the rhythm of the course. Philosophical readings can be very difficult sometimes, but Professor Guerrero is well aware of this and will be always able to work with you on advancing your understanding of the material.
I would certainly recommend this course and professor to other students.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
descrip: Dolls are human creations whose "disgrace" is their birth itself. They are not born according to the principles of sexual reproduction and biological identity: motherless, they form outside of the uterus. Dolls are different from other artificial matters in their close relationship to childhood. But the even more definitive distinction is that they have been assigned to a sex: they are female bodies. This seminar proposes to explore the specificity of these synthetic lives, considering dolls in their relationships with toys, monsters, mannequins, automatons, puppets, virgins, and mommies, through the work of diverse contemporary artists.
title: Synthetic Skin

otherinfo: This course is an option to fulfill the department's independent work/thesis requirement. One hour class meetings will be scheduled as needed. Students are encourage to attend. Requirements/Grading for Final Paper: 50% of grade is Advisor; 25% of grade is Reader.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 75%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
assgts: Written report and poster session due at end of semester.
descrip: Senior independent work is the culminating experience for the mechanical and aerospace engineering programs. Students select a subject and adviser, define the problem to be studied and propose a work plan. Projects include elements of engineering design, defined as devising a system, component, or process to meet desired needs. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Students must submit a written final report and present their results to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests.
title: Senior Independent Work

evals: A very good class as an introduction to graduate quantum mechanics. The course is probably too hard to be a first course in quantum, but was still quite valuable even as a third class in quantum. The examples and problem sets had a more condensed matter focus, which is complementary to the way my undergrad taught it, with more of a particle physics perspective.
Attend all the lectures.
It's a lot of work if you didn't have quantum before

Steve is a good teacher and made class fun, so I would recommend the course. If you've already seen a lot of quantum mechanics (~2 semesters or something), however, I think this class will be mostly review (unless they change the structure), and you should maybe consider a different option.
Study regularly and practice all the materials provided. Class was very helpful, should attend all of them.

The first half is a quick review of what you've learned in undergrad, and the second half moves very quickly through a lot of numerical approaches and approximations that are very interesting and easy to understand but can be a little overwhelming at times.
otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
otherinfo: Background in quantum mechanics at an undergraduate level will be useful, but not required.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 45%, Problem set(s) - 25%
prereqs: ELE 342 or PHY 305 or equivalent or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers the principles of quantum mechanics, including applications of relevance to students in applied physics, materials science and engineering. Topics include the concept of Hilbert Spaces, Schrodinger and Heisenberg Representations, Bound State and scattering problems in one, two and three dimensions, consequences of symmetry, Angular momentum algebra, Approximation methods for stationary states, Many-body systems, Quantum statistics and applications in solid state and quantum optics. Time dependent Perturbation Theory and/or Second Quantization and Electromagnetic Field will be covered if time permits.
title: Quantum Mechanics with Applications

evals: I would recommend this course if you are interested more in the theory behind neutron studies of materials, not just actually using them.
I would recommend those who are interested in material science in general and particularly those who are interested in learning advanced experimental techniques to consider the course
I would take it. The material is tricky, but the workload isn't higher than it needs to be and the class itself is very interesting.
If you don't have prior experience with these techniques it would be helpful to do some reading on them before the lectures so you can follow the lectures more easily.
It is a good introduction to synchrotron techniques.
Just audit.
Reading the textbook material before lectures was very helpful to understanding the lecture material in class.
Spend time on the labs; they'll teach you a lot.  Lectures will be a little confusing if you have little background in advanced physics/chemistry.
Take the course if you are interested/or will be doing work with scattering/diffraction experiments.

This course is probably the best way to get exposure to synchrotron and neutron based techniques which are immensely powerful for addressing a broad range of research questions.  The class (in particular the lab component) is a serious time commitment.
This is a very good primer course on x-ray and neutron topics. Definitely give it a try.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 15%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%
descrip: Topics include an introduction to radiation generation at synchrotron and neutron facilities, elastic scattering techniques, inelastic scattering techniques, imaging and spectroscopy. Specific techniques include X-ray and neutron diffraction, small-angle scattering, inelastic neutron scattering, reflectometry, tomography, microscopy, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy. Emphasis is placed on data analysis and use of Fourier transforms to relate structure/dynamics to experiment data. Example materials covered include energy storage devices, sustainable concrete, CO2 storage, magnetic materials, mesostructured materials and nanoparticles.
title: Synchrotron and Neutron Techniques for Energy Materials

evals: Definitely take if you want to learn about economic inequality, or about the methods to incorporate inequality in your potential research papers.
Go over the lecture material briefly after class to ask questions in precept.
Not too difficult and problem sets only take about an hour each week.

Prof. K is an amazing lecturer and keeps the 3 hours very engaging! However, this was definitely one of my most challenging courses in the Econ department and Princeton in general, so a lot of time is required to do well.

Professor Kuziemko is amazing - she cares so much about her students and the class. Even though the 3 hour lectures were long, it was worth it. She's one of the only professors in the entire economics department that is a legitimately enjoyable teacher.
The material is interesting and eye-opening and not terribly difficult. However, 3 hour night lecture can be brutal.

Topic is interesting. The structure of the course presents an overview not just of inequality, but also of the various econometric methods that economists use to try and answer questions. An excellent overview of how research can be done, by looking at all the research that has been done on inequality.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: One problem set per week. Students expected to read approximately 50 pages per week.
prereqs: Must have previously taken ECO 300 or ECO 310 AND must have previously taken ECO 302 or ECO 312..
descrip: In the US and many other developed countries, economic inequality has risen to historic levels in recent decades. What are the causes of this trend -- "natural" market forces (e.g., globalization?) or changes in public policy (e.g., erosion of the minimum wage)? Are measures currently proposed to counteract inequality and poverty -- e.g, progressive taxation, transfer programs to low-income families, public insurance programs such as Medicare -- effective? An emphasis is placed on understanding what basic microeconomic theory as well as empirical evidence can (and cannot) tell us about these questions.
title: Economic Inequality and the Role of Government

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: Please see website
title: The World of Noir

otherinfo: RCR for graduate students only.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
prereqs: For second-year graduate students..
descrip: This course is for second-year graduate students to help them develop their writing and speaking skills for communicating mathematics in a wide variety of settings, including teaching, grant applications, teaching statement, research statement, talks aimed at a general mathematical audience, and seminars, etc. In addition, responsible conduct in research (RCR) training is an integral part of this course.
title: Effective Mathematical Communication

evals: If you are interested in the topic, you will come away with a thorough insight of it following Professor's tutelage.
Misreadings are rewarded with comments, either to clarify or expand. The difficulty of the material is offset by Spyros's enthusiasm and willingness to decipher.
Strongly recommend - if not out of interest or curiosity, then to experience Prof. Papapetros's "bible study" style classes.
Take a class with this professor
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Reading 200 to 300 pages per week and active participation in the seminar. Final research paper: 15-20 pages for doctoral students, 10-12 pages for Masters students including preliminary abstract and bibliography.
descrip: An in depth survey of Gottfried Semper's theoretical writings, including a close reading of his Style in the Technical and Tectonic Arts or Practical Aesthetics, as well as the architect's writings on the basic elements of architecture, ornament, industrial arts, and his general theory of form. Semper's texts are set in context by readings in philosophy, anthropology, natural science, and political theory by authors from Semper's circle and implemented by an analysis of recent texts on aesthetics, tectonics, materiality, and theories of the object
title: Aesthetics, Tectonics, and Materiality in Semper's Theoretical Writings

grading: Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
descrip: This course explores the changing aesthetics of Japanese documentary media as the foundation for reconsidering the geopolitics of visuality. We inquire into the dynamic theoretical and practical contours of works of Japanese film, literature, and photography from the postwar to the contemporary period. The course charts the provocative horizons of thought and expanded aesthetics of documentary practices that interrogated the changing urban environments and media ecologies wrought by the Cold War and its aftermath in Japan.
title: Japanese Film and Media Studies - Dispossession, Documentary, and the Geopolitics of Image Media

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
descrip: Materialism has returned to the forefront of humanistic speculation, as scholars rethink how to be human in the face of environmental change. Today, who counts as a historical and/or environmental agent depends largely on what one thinks a material is. This course mines the history of architecture and its allied engineering for technical and philosophical perspectives on this material turn. We alternate seminar discussions (on themes such as solidity, invisibility, aggregation, operability, wires) and workshops (where guest scientists, historians, practitioners lead us in experiments in thinking and making).
title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - What is a material? History, Architecture, Environment

evals: Hand in the response papers on time!
I strongly recommend this course to other students.
Think if you are really interested in medieval history before making a decision.
n/a
grading: Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: The littoral of the Great Sea has long been viewed as a major place of contact, conflict and exchange for groups belonging to the three Abrahamic religions: Judaism, Christianity and Islam. This course approaches the encounters of different religions and ethnicities in such a manner as to introduce students not only to the classic historiography on the subject, but also to the main controversies and debates now current in scholarship. Our analysis and evaluation of the connections that developed between individuals and communities will focus on the High Middle Ages.
title: Cross-Cultural Encounters in the Medieval Mediterranean

evals: ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS COURSE IF IT'S BEING OFFERED. Professor Lew-Williams is phenomenal--absolutely the best lecturer I've ever had here, and the course is meticulously well-organized and consistently thought-provoking and eye-opening. (Bonus points for a fun field trip and the time and effort Professor Lew-Williams actually spends talking with students, getting to know them, and actively getting feedback on the course.) Don't let the identity politics scare you off--there's so much real history here, and this course is as much about the creation and study of history as it is about the Asian-American experience. This course kept me alive and dragging my miserable self to class during a truly dreadful semester, it's that good. I will yell about it from the mountaintops until the day I die. TAKE THIS CLASS. I don't care if you don't like history and if reading books literally gives you hives. (Incidentally, the reading load is very manageable.) TAKE THIS CLASS. I don't care if you're literally two monkeys in a trenchcoat disguised as a human being. TAKE THIS CLASS. I don't care if you're a spirit astrally projected from an alternate dimension who decided to go on TigerHub and read course evaluations for no good reason. TAKE THIS CLASS.
Absolutely take this class!
Absolutely take this course. Brilliantly taught and extremely engaging. Reading can be a lot, but not undoable.

Absolutely take this course. You'll learn about US History from a different perspective that is not taught in high school. Prof. Lew-Williams is a wonderful and engaging lecturer and the assignments are manageable.

Amazing class - would highly recommend!! Professor Beth Lew-Williams gives amazing lectures, and never once was I bored in class. This class urged me to critically think about Asian Americans and their role in US history- something that I've never thought deeply about before. Papers and grading are extremely fair.
Definitely take the class! Not too much work and very interesting material.
Definitely take this class! Professor Lew-Williams is excellent, and you will learn about a wide range of topics relating to Asian-American history and American history in general.
GO TO LECTURES!!!!
Go to lecture- very interesting!

Great HA. 
Took it as PDF, but could have taken it as a grade and gotten a solid A or at least A- without it, though I heard other students midterm results weren't that great (?)
Really interesting to learn American history in light of Asian Americans and how events shaped their emergence and identity.
TAKE THIS COURSE! you will learn so much, esp those people who aren't Asian American but Asians from other countries
Great class. Interesting material, awesome professor. Workload may be a little much at times, but there is no need to analyze and deeply read everything. Grading is fair too.
Great course to take, especially if you're Asian American! Some great readings-- will teach you the background and vocabulary to better talk about Asian race issues in the United States.

Great course. It was my first history course at Princeton, and although I typically don't like history, I really enjoyed this class. Definitely offers a new perspective on American history that isn't taught in high school for sure, and probably not at most universities either. Prof. Lew-Williams is a very good lecturer. A super valuable course that more students should take.

I LOVED this course, particularly Professor Lew-Williams' lectures and the readings! One of my favorite and most memorable courses I've taken at Princeton. I really hope that this course continues to be offered in years to come. It was such an invaluable way to explore the history of the United States.

I highly recommend this course! Absolutely manageable, and Professor Lew-Williams is phenomenal. Super interesting lectures, and she is also a great preceptor. Only thing I didn't like too much was that we had to write a Dean's Date paper based on an oral history, in addition to completing a take-home exam. That was a bit much, but the rest of the semester was good. Try not to get behind on reading, especially for the midterm.

I really enjoyed this course and would highly recommend it to anyone interested in American history! Professor Lew-Williams is an engaging lecturer and her precept is great. Although there are a lot of students who are more interested in the course as Asian Americans than as historians, I think the class does an incredible job at teaching students how to make good historical arguments. 

Take the time to speak with Prof BLW outside of class! She is really nice and receptive to feedback. I never went to her non-office hours, but I really regret it.

I would definitely recommend this course for anyone interested in Asian American history! It's really the only course in Princeton (sadly) that offers this kind of education and it really taught me a lot. It is quite a few writing assignments and a nontrivial amount of reading if you want to keep up, but if you don't mind those things definitely recommend!
I would recommend a different history course if you are not a history major and looking for an intriguing subject. I would not recommend my preceptor either.

I would recommend doing the readings before class. A lot of them aren't conventional history readings and really help to give a unique perspective on a history this is still in the process of being explored.

If you are thinking of taking this class, hesitate no more! It will be very worth your while, whether you are Asian American or not. It will teach you to look at US and world history from a completely different perspective. The readings and assignments are manageable for students from any major, and you can do a lot with the oral history project if you put in the effort. Only caveat is that the class has a take-home midterm (1500 words), final project (7-8 pages), and take-home final (1500 words again). But don't let those deter you. Seriously, take it. You will feel like you're genuinely learning, and Professor Lew-Williams is so approachable and offers coffee chats with students outside of normal office hours!

If you have any interest in Asian American history - or just want to have a broader view about American history and American minorities - take the course! Beth is an amazing lecturer and the readings are very engaging. Although some can take some time, this course overall is not too work-heavy; take it as a fifth if you will.

If you're interested in Asian-American history, take this class. PDF is probably the best option because there's both a Dean's Date assignment AND a final exam, and there's also a lot of reading assigned for the course. Regardless, you'll get a lot out of it.
Interesting if you like the subject matter, but I also found the grading to be very subjective/varied..
Please consider taking this class. The professor is passionate and does a wonderful job on the topic. You will enjoy going to lecture!
Please take this class! Coming from an Asian American, this course will forever change the way you view society and I will even go as far to say that it will definitely change your life in some way.

Pretty good history class. If you really want to learn about Asian American History, it's not a terrible class and you might be more engaged in it than I was. Otherwise, this might be a good/interesting pdf course.

Really interesting topic, would highly recommend taking this course because you will probably never have the chance to learn about Asian American history in as rich a way as how Prof. Lew William's teaches it. A good amount of reading but worth it, especially if just PDFing.

TAKE IT! I was worried I would be buried in readings every week by taking a history course here but this class was never overwhelming and always extremely interesting and manageable. Professor Lew-Williams is a great lecturer, too.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I have zero regrets. If there were an Asian American History class part 2, I would take it too.
Take it if you are looking for an HA. The subject is not well covered in other history classes, and it is now more relevant than ever.
Take it!
Take it! Grading is a bit tough, but you learn a ton about subjects that you may have never even heard of before.

Take it! Really well taught and fascinating material. Even if you're not Asian, I think that studying marginalized narratives helps to understand causality of historical events in a way that you don't get from just taking a regular history course.
Take it. You won't regret it.
Take this class - professor lew williams is fantastic and this is a great PDF

Take this class if you are at all interested in the material. The lecturer is great, the preceptors care about you and want you to do well, and you can gain a lot from the class if you just put in some effort.

Take this class! Asian American History is rarely a focus in US history classes and this class provides the opportunity to learn. Professor Lew-Williams is fantastic, as a lecturer and a preceptor, and I highly recommend trying to take her precept. The class will challenge your understanding of American history and what it means to be an Asian American.
Take this class! Prof Lew-Williams is engaging and pushes you to think critically. I did not know much of what was covered before so I gained a lot!
Take this class!! It might not be the easiest but it's extremely relevant and interesting.

Take this class!!!!! Professor Lew-Williams is a gift. This is a history class that is meant for everyone. Not a huge workload and it really makes you rethink the place of Asian Americans in history and today.
Take this course if you want to learn more about asian american history!! However, do keep in mind that this course does have a lot of reading (as it is an HA).
Take this course!! You learn so much about Asian American history, and the course puts it in context to give you a new perspective on current events and present-day racial dynamics

The class teaches you a lot and it's a very interesting history of Asian Americans. I wouldn't take it as a PDF course though--there are a lot of unneeded assignments in this class--specifically precept during the week of the midterm and a take-home final (basically two 3-page papers) after turning in a long Dean's Date assignment. Otherwise, I thought the course was interesting, lectures taught me a lot about a subject I didn't know much about, and the precepts were normally engaging.

The course is interesting and really takes a look at the Asian American experience. Professor Lew-Williams really knows her subjects and it is obvious that she is also passionate about what she is teaching. The readings can get tedious at times, but are not necessary to always complete.
The course material itself and the lectures are really interesting, but the precept and the exams are not great.
The readings and lectures are extremely insightful. Attend all the lectures and complete all the readings. You can learn so much about the history of Asians and Asian Americans through this course.

This class is great for people of all majors! I took this class as an engineer, and thoroughly enjoyed the lectures and readings. I could have skipped lectures, but I ended up attending almost all of them because they were engaging and inspiring.
This class is very enjoyable to take as an Asian American student or for anyone interested in the topic.

This class is wonderful and really important, especially if you want to study history! It really helped me develop a new perspective on race in America. The lectures are super interesting, and Prof. Lew-Williams is awesome.

This course might be tied for my favorite course that I've taken at Princeton. This is not just because of some sense of personal connection that I have as an Asian-American, but because a lot of the larger topics of discussion in the course (What makes someone foreign, what are the racial dynamics in the U.S., what is the history of immigration like, what does affirmative action do) are important topics that are relevant to all of American history. In getting a better understanding of these concepts, I felt that I gained a lot.
This is a great course to take if you are interested in Asian American History.
This is a really great course with a reasonable amount of work. Really gets you thinking about race and immigration in America through the lens of the Asian American community.
This is a solid class. It invites you to dig deeper and read between the lines of the contentious issues of race relations in America. If you're interested in the course description, take it.

This is an absolutely life-changing course, especially if you are Asian American or want to learn about Asian American history. The professor is phenomenal and does an amazing job - I really hope this course is offered again the future. I am telling all my friends to take it!

This is my favorite class ever. I haven't missed a single lecture, and not because I'm a star student. Teachers like Professor Lew-Williams are what makes Princeton students drag themselves out of bed in the morning. Discussions are nuanced, captivating, and profound.  Imo, every student should take this class before graduating.
Very interesting to learn about things like Asian American immigration story and college admissions
great PDF, did no reading, probably pretty easy to do well in too

it's ok material is not challenging tbh didn't find it interesting and regretted taking as a PDF because it has so much extra work like take home final, midterm, paper, transcription etc.

pretty good class. tdlr take it if youre asian.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 5%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 150-200 pages of reading per week; take-home midterm; take-home final; 8-10 page research paper
prereqs: P/D/F option not available for History concentrators.
descrip: This course introduces students to the multiple and varied experiences of people of Asian heritage in the United States from the 19th century to the present day. It focuses on three major questions: (1) What brought Asians to the United States? (2) How did Asian Americans come to be viewed as a race? (3) How does Asian American experience transform our understanding of U.S. history? Using newspapers, novels, government reports, and films, this course will cover major topics in Asian American history, including Chinese Exclusion, Japanese internment, transnational adoption, and the model minority stereotype.
title: Asian American History

evals: As a freshman, I was initially intimidated and unsure as to whether I would be able to handle the material or grasp the concepts. However, the discussions were enriching and engaging. Professor B is a very dynamic, entertaining and passionate lecturer whose enthusiasm for this subject matter transfers to her students. Would strongly recommend.
Be ready to read a lot and participate frequently.

I highly recommend this course. Professor Benjamin is as good as I'm sure all the other reviews say she is. Do the readings, write the memo, sit back, discuss)
I would highly recommend taking this course, but you definitely need to be able to fully dedicate yourself to the seminar and the work that is required.

I would make sure to keep on top of the readings: there are a lot and it is very hard to catch up if you miss them. They are also very important to understanding the class and writing successful papers.
Professor Benjamin is an incredible instructor. Every class is like being at a TED Talk. Take this (or any class) with her.
Take it - it's a lot of work though, keep in mind that it's some dense readings you've got to get through.
Take it if you have the time.
Take it!
Take it! Do the reading! Don't be afraid to use your imagination!
Take it! Professor Benjamin is amazing! The material is stimulating. Stay on top of the readings and you won't regret it!

Take this course, regardless of major, but particularly if you are someone interested in both science and race. Ruha Benjamin is a force of nature, and you would be missing out on a truly special experience if you didn't take this course. Don't be that person.

This course is awesome- you become very educated in the intersection of African-Americans and technology. It is a lot of work though- there are many readings, which you have to do because you write a weekly memo.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Design Project - 20%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approx 150 pgs reading/week; 1-page reflection memos (20%), 10-12 pg final essay
prereqs: Please contact the instructor if you have taken no prior social science course related to race-ethnicity..
descrip: Designer Babies. Ancestry Tests. Organ Regeneration. Biometric Surveillance. These and more comprise our 21st century landscape. This interdisciplinary course examines the values and politics that shape science, medicine, and technology, asking who bears the risk and who reaps the benefit of innovations? Social inequality is legitimized, in part, by myths about human difference. And while course participants grapple with past and present stories that shape science and technology, we also apply a sociological imagination to the future, exploring how contemporary hopes and fears may give rise to "real utopias" that are more equitable and just.
title: Black to the Future: Science, Fiction, and Society

evals: I would encourage every student to complete all the readings and to participate in class. This was definitely a very fun class for me, but it was only fun because each student was very involved and participated during discussions.
I would say go on with an open mind. Everyone has something interesting to offer.
If you love comedy, this is for you.
It's interesting but the reading is absolutely impossible to cover, the grading is harsh, and honestly you should probably just watch stand up in your free time instead
TAKE THIS COURSE! It's fun and intellectual at the same time!
Take this course! You won't be disappointed.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 15%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 200 pages of reading per week. Short response papers focusing on key concepts from readings. Oral presentation analyzing a comic routine. Term paper on a humorist or comedian of the student's choice.
descrip: What's so funny? is a question that could be turned around to ask: Who's laughing? Comedian Dave Chappelle might say it's a question about who gets the joke, and who doesn't. This survey of African American humor is an introduction to getting the joke. We study the technical artistry of black humorists and comedians and reflect on the audiences for whom they write and perform. We examine a range of cultural expression, from the dozens to stand-up comedy. In our critical and creative work, we assess how past forms and strategies can be adapted to the project of African American humor today.
title: What's So Funny? Forms of African American Humor

evals: I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in policy and African American history! Professor Taylor is brilliant and the workload is totally bearable.
One of the best classes I've taken; very interesting and important topic.  Take it!
Really delve into the readings and take the time to read the extra articles Prof. Taylor and other students recommend.

Take it Take it Take it. The material makes you think critically and shows up frequently in casual conversation. Professor Taylor is a genius who can be both intimidating and warm. Best of both worlds in one professor.
Take this class if you want to know why residential segregation still exists today
Take this class. It is interesting and the professor is very knowledgeable and personable!
Take this course if you have interest in Urban Studies or Housing.
Take this course! Very eye opening, political, and important material.

Take this course!!! You will learn so much new information about race and housing in the United States. Professor Taylor is very smart and will encourage you to develop your own ideas and questions about housing. The workload is very doable and not demanding at all. The assignments actually help you do better in the class. There is no reason why you should not take this class!

This course is super interesting and teaches you a lot about the history of housing in the US and all the ways that the housing industry was influenced by racially prejudiced policies as well as the barriers that African-Americans faced in trying to attain a middle-class lifestyle. There is a lot of reading, but the books are so well-written, you just might forget they're for a class. The main participation grade (I think) comes from your oral presentation, so prepare well for that.
Very interesting class, probably easier with some background of AAS, AMS, or POL classes
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 5%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: This class will require weekly reading assignments between 100 to 150 pages of reading a week; class participation including posting weekly questions to the class via BlackBoard; a formal presentation to the class based on one of the assigned texts; and finally two ten-paged papers will be required, one at the midterm and one as a final.
descrip: This class examines the history of urban and suburban housing in the twentieth century US. We will examine the relationship between postwar suburban development as a corollary to the "underdevelopment" of American cities contributing to what scholars have described as the "urban crisis" of the 1960s. Housing choice and location were largely shaped by discriminatory practices in the real estate market, thus, the course explores the consequences of the relationship between public policy and private institutions in shaping the metropolitan area including after the passage of federal anti-housing discrimination legislation in the late 1960s.
title: Rats, Riots, and Revolution: Housing in the Metropolitan United States

evals: Great class overall! Really interesting material, a friendly and knowledgeable professor who is enthusiastic about the material, and you'll learn a lot. Plus, no exams and not a lot of work outside of class are extra bonuses!
Great course for those interested in sustainability and clean tech.
Take the course. Very interesting subject matter. Overall engaging. The labs were cool too.

The class is well organized and each lecture is  well explained. This class is particularly helpful for students who are interested in understanding how real word contexts affect scientific research and vice versa. It is very helpful to understand the societal factors which drive the kinds of research questions that need to be investigated.
There was improvised lab sessions, so this should be STL in the future.
This is an interesting upper level CBE course that has a reasonable amount of work.
otherinfo: Interested graduate students should contact the professor.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 80%
assgts: The instructor will provide reading assignments in class. Three short lab reports will be required (40% of grade) and a final oral presentation project (40% of grade).
prereqs: Organic Chemistry or Biochemistry or Molecular Biology or equivalent..
descrip: What are biofuels, and why are we making them? What are 1st, 2nd, and 3rd generation biofuels? What is the controversy surrounding the food versus fuel debate? Will thermocatalysis or genetic engineering improve biofuel production? Can we make biofuels directly from light or electricity? These are some of the questions we will answer through engaging discussions, primary literature readings, and hands-on experience in making biofuels. In precept we will make bioethanol from corn (beer) or molasses (wine), biodiesel from cooking oil, and oil from algae. Grades are based on participation, an oral presentation, and three short lab reports.
title: Fundamentals of Biofuels

evals: Definitely take if you are interested in the subject. Material is for the most part interesting and the workload is not too heavy.

I really enjoyed this course! It's great as a fifth class. The readings and lectures are interesting, and I like there it doesn't feel like there is a lot of pressure. You are just learning to increase your general knowledge, and if you seeking a JDS certificate, this is a good, general survey class. Prof. Levy does want your comments to be of substance, though- don't be surprised if she openly disagrees with something you say!

I would strongly recommend this course for anyone interested in the topic matter. It provides you with many new ways of approaching the topic across time and space. Even though the course doesn't expect pre-existing knowledge, it still gives a really interesting and comprehensive approach to the subject of Jewish cultures.

Prof. Levy is great. Her lectures are interesting and her knowledge of the topic matter is impeccable.
Levy will go to the ends of the world to help you with your papers. Make sure to take her up on her offer and you'll be set. A good class to take if you're interested in the material!
Take the course, particularly if you have no background in the topic. The worst that can happen is you learn something.

This is a great course.  Professor Levy is excellent and really knows her stuff- you will learn a lot from her.  The class is taught in a way that is welcoming to students who come from Jewish backgrounds and those who do not, and does not assume much prior knowledge of Judaism/Jewish history/Jewish culture.  Even though I came from a Jewish background, I still learned so much in this course.  Definitely recommend it!
take it if it is in your area of interest. I learned a ton of new interesting information about Jewish culture and history in general.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Preparation for each class will total about 50-70 pp reading or viewing of a 1.5-2 hr film (occasionally supplemented with brief readings). Writing assignments: two 5 pp papers, each on a single week's topic (one due any week before the mid-semester break and the second due any week in the second half of the semester, at the student's discretion) and one final paper in reading period, 8-10 pp.
descrip: This introductory course focuses on the global diversity and the cultural syncretism of Jewish experience from the Bible to the present. It examines how Jewish culture has emerged through the interaction of Jews and non-Jews, engaging a wide spectrum of cultures throughout the Jewish world, and following representations of key issues such as sexuality, suffering, or mystical experience in different contexts and eras. Topics include Bible and Talmud, kabbalah, Zionism, Jewish cinema, music, food, modern literature, and comics. All readings and films are in English.
title: Introduction to Jewish Cultures

Jenny and Kat are both great people who do an excellent job of explaining history and getting you to think about history in different ways. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in science and needs to take a history course.

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: One short paper in lieu of a midterm. One longer term paper, submitted for Dean's Date. Five "thinkpieces" based on weekly readings, to be submitted via email in advance and discussed in precept (Week 1 excepted). These, together with participation in class discussion, will contribute towards the class participation grade.
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators.
descrip: Something "happened" to science between 1450-1750. The sun replaced the earth at the center of the cosmos, Europeans encountered new worlds and new peoples, and heaven and earth shook to the impact of new technologies like telescopes and heavy artillery. Yet how much was really new? Did all these changes merge into one phenomenon that we can call "the scientific revolution"? And were there many such revolutions or could the very idea be a modern invention? From optics and anatomy to alchemy and magic, this course will ask exactly how natural knowledge was shaped, challenged and exploited between the late Middle Ages and the Enlightenment.
title: What is the Scientific Revolution?

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Other Exam - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Additional readings from the primary scientific literature will be assigned weekly, and will be discussed during precepts.
descrip: This course will provide an introduction to the scientific study of sensation and perception, the biological and psychological processes by which we perceive and interpret the world around us. We will undertake a detailed study of the major senses (vision, audition, touch, smell, taste), using insights from a variety of disciplines (philosophy, physics, computer science, neuroscience, psychology) to examine how these senses work and why. We will begin with physical bases for perceptual information (e.g., light, sound waves) and proceed to an investigation of the structures, circuits, and mechanisms by which the brain forms sensory percepts.
title: Sensation and Perception

grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: The first part of the course, ergodic theorems, systems with discrete spectrums, and entropy are discussed. In the second part, applications of all these notions to dynamics are considered.
title: Topics in Ergodic Theory - Ergodic Theory and Dynamical Systems

otherinfo: This course will meet from 9/1/2017 to 12/15/2017. MUS 510 is for students who are pursuing educationally valid activities outside the University. Students should enroll only if they are pursuing an approved activity, and only after discussing the matter with their DGS.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: MUS510 is for students in the department who wish to gain experience of central importance to their area of study by working outside of the University capacity. For composition students, this might include working with theater companies, dance troupes, or other relevant organizations. For musicology students this might include archival research or performance. Course objectives and content are determined by student's adviser in consultation with the external institution. Students submit monthly progress reports including goals and progress to date, and any evaluations received from host institution or published reviews of the final product.
title: Extramural Research Internship

evals: Take this class exclusively if you are fully convinced by the premise of the need to introduce scientific thinking in the design process. There is not much room left for speculation around it during the class.

The experiment is quite challenging. Begin gathering data as soon as possible, because you will likely encounter difficulty. The amount of effort for the experiment is more than a history and theory paper as much of it is outside of the usual skill set of M.Arch students. I recommend the class as it has yielded an interesting tangent of research for my thesis.
take it. it will change the way you think.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Development of a publication level research paper throughout the course with an initial proposal due at the beginning of the course, a first draft due for the midterm and final paper of 4000 words due at the end of the course.
descrip: The pro seminar is offered to incoming PhD students in the PhD track in Computation, Energy, building Technology in the School of Architecture (open to other interested graduate students as well) and is organized as a research seminar to introduce the participants to scientific research methods in the context of design in Architecture and science in engineering. It is structured as a series of introductory presentations of exemplary methods based on case studies and a number of guest presentations from collaborating disciplines.
title: Pro Seminar: Computation, Energy, Technology in Architecture

evals: My recommendation is high and unreserved. Prof. Thompson will push you forward as a scholar.
Recommended.
This course comes highly recommended. Professor Thompson leads a productive and comfortable seminar, and the readings challenged me to think differently about US history.

This course is a survey of American technology as it ranges from the arrival of the Brits to present day. It has a considerable amount of reading, but the conversations in class will always be thoughtful as a result.

This is a wonderful and somewhat unique course, and Emily Thompson is a brilliant professor. I think considering the history of technology can offer crucial insights into a constellation of sub-disciplinary studies, and this course is well worth taking.
otherinfo: The course may serve as the basis for a minor field examine in History of American Technology, or in History of Modern Technology (with slight additions and revisions).
grading: Papers - 35%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 35%
prereqs: A small number of students from other departments may be admitted with the Professor's approval. These students must meet with the Professor prior to the first class meeting to review their qualifications..
descrip: This reading course introduces History Dept. graduate students to historical literature on American technology from the Colonial Era through the Twentieth Century. A chronological survey of technological development highlights the variety of ways scholars have understood technology and its interactions with society and culture from a historical perspective.
title: American Technological History

grading: Papers - 70%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%
descrip: This course covers selected ancient and medieval political theory texts in depth, beginning in ancient Greece and ending in the early Renaissance. Authors to be covered include Thucydides, Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Augustine, Aquinas, and Marsilius. Secondary sources as well as primary readings are discussed.
title: Texts in Ancient and Medieval Political Theory

otherinfo: In addition to select readings, this seminar also includes film and other visual materials as primary texts.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
descrip: From the invention of microscope, X-rays, to psychoanalysis and cinema, the world is increasingly mediated and constituted by visual technologies and new forms of visualities that collapse the boundaries between visibility and invisibility. This seminar explores visual representations of the "interior" and their mediating roles in the historical and social processes of colonialism, infrastructural revolution, (post-)socialism, and global capitalism in the East Asian and global context. Readings intersect cinema and media studies, globalization and urban studies, science studies, and Marxist feminism.
title: Seeing the Interior: Cinema, Media, Inverse Visuality

evals: I would recommend students familiarize themselves with the topic beforehand. Sometimes conversations in class were limited by some students being far more familiar with the material than others.
Take the class! Tarek is a really fun professor, and the readings are interesting.
Take this course. Tarek is an amazing Arabic teacher and you get to work with articles and videos and more practical sources than in other Arabic courses.

Tarek is a wonderful teacher, and I always feel like my Arabic improves greatly when I'm in his classes. He makes learning, practicing, and speaking Arabic a fun and exciting experience that will translate well to use outside of the classroom. I would recommend taking any class he teaches!
Ustaadh Tarek is not an experience to miss. This class is also essential for anybody who wants to understand contemporary Islamism
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Students will read no more than 50 pages per week in Arabic.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 302 or the permission of the Arabic Program..
descrip: Through readings drawn from the era of Nahda, students will develop their skills in listening, speaking, writing and reading via the reading and discussion, in Arabic, of a variety of texts, including works on history, autobiography, politics, religion and the social sciences. Analytical and compositional skills will be honed, and students will be expected to prepare an individual final reading and writing project for the course.
title: Topics in Arabic Language and Culture - Reading Arab Authors from the Age of the Arab Renaissance

otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
otherinfo: For administrative reasons, there are two ways of enrolling in ANT 390A/B. ANT 390A is for all students other than seniors in the Anthropology major. ANT 390B is reserved for seniors in the Anthropology major, as it includes enrollment in the Senior Seminar (the ANT 390B "Lab" section). ANT 390A and B are otherwise the same, and meet together.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading: approx 100 pages per week. Papers: 2 short papers at 20% each.
descrip: The course surveys the development of social anthropology by examining the concepts and models used by anthropologists to analyze human diversity and universals, social stability and change, and the relationship between the individual and the group. We explore theoretical debates (evolution, exchange, function, structure, culture, agency, subjectivity, history, power, and globalization) in terms of their capacity to understand human behavior, the social world and modernity.
title: History of Anthropological Theory

evals: Great
Take it if you have any interest at all.

Take it! Lazaridi is not only a smiling positive presence but she also knows her stuff. She'll point out great television and help us pick it apart to know why they are so good, and then use that to guide our own writing. I developed my television series idea really well and am excited to pursue it further. This class also kicked off my senior creative thesis!

Take this class with Professor Lazaridi. The assignments are manageable and fun to work on. She gives incredible advice and establishes a collaborative and creative dynamic in the workshops. The TV shows we watched are really good quality. (Note: this class mainly focuses on mini-series, or at least it did Spring '17).

This class is a LOT of work. Only take this if you are SUPER interested in screenwriting (probably someone who's absolutely sure they're going to get a screenwriting certificate), and be prepared to write like 50 pages and watch entire seasons of TV shows on your own time.
Would definitely recommend- Professor Lazaridi is the best!
grading: Papers - 80%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly writing assignments. 60 pages of reading per week
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they would like to take the course and optionally a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Please note this course CANNOT be audited. A prerequisite of 2 prior CWR courses. Application deadline is April 17, 2017. Accepted students will be able to enroll in Tiger Hub May 22nd to 26th..
descrip: Students in this advanced screenwriting course will work both independently and in small groups to learn how to develop, pitch, outline, and draft an original television show. We will read and watch television shows, pitch ideas, work in writers' rooms, and by the end of the semester have a complete draft of a television pilot in hand (50-60 pages). There will be weekly reading, viewing, and writing assignments - everything from conceptualizing ideas to writing outlines and character profiles. Given that television is a collaborative medium, students should feel comfortable working in small groups.
title: Advanced Screenwriting: Writing for Television

evals: I recommend this course even if you are not a student who is comfortable with classes that are primarily writing based. The workload is definitely manageable and you don't need a background in film analysis or Japanese culture/history to be able to get something out of the class.
Take this course if you're really interested in the course. It is an awesome class.
This course helped me view media differently. Though the material was challenging, Professor Prichard leads the seminars in a way that you slowly understand the overarching theme of the course.

Try to do the readings and watch the films. Thats the bulk of the class, and you will certainly fall behind if you do not do them. Take notes on key concepts in the readings. You'll be fine. The papers are weekly, but manageable.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings of up to 100 pages, weekly response papers, midterm and final papers.
descrip: Study of contemporary Japan through major works of film, photography, and visual culture. The course will explore defining transformations in urban and media ecologies, experiences of development and disaster, and the contentious environmental histories that inform contemporary Japan. The course will foster critical skills in interdisciplinary methods and transnational approaches to the study of film and visual media from Japan in regional and global contexts.
title: Japanese Film & Media Studies
