New way to think about social media and how connected we are

Professor Chung is one of the most interesting professors I've had at Princeton so far. I would strongly recommend taking this course even if you have little to no experience with media studies, since it's a great survey course with a highly manageable workload.

Recommend it for sure! If you have any interest in EAS or media (film, music, etc.) definitely take it! Also, Professor Chung is one of the nicest, most knowledgable, and chillest teachers I've ever met!
TAKE IT! It's so much fun. You would be surprised by how much you learn. Professor Chung is also such a cool professor with so many interesting stories and things to say. ^.^
TAKE THIS COURSE. DROP WHATEVER YOU HAVE TO DROP, EVEN IF IT'S A DEPARTMENTAL--DO NOT MISS YOUR CHANCE TO TAKE THIS COURSE.

There wasn't much work to do throughout the semester aside from the weekly responses and one group presentation. I would suggest meeting with Professor Chung to discuss final paper topics pretty early on during reading week.
This is an interesting course, I would recommend. Just make sure you come to class with questions so you can be ready to participate.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Other Exam - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly short critical responses. A shorter mid-term essay (5-7 pages) and a longer final essay (12-15 pages).
descrip: Whether we look at its speed, connectivity and convergence, the geographic reach of its exports, or the contradictions that characterize its relationship to social reality, contemporary Korean media poses provocative questions about conditions of life in Korea and the mechanisms of communications and cultural technologies globally. Through examination of a range of practices across the mediascape (TV dramas, music, webtoons, films, advertisements, etc.) and phenomenon that have arisen from them (the Korean Wave, the rise of national sports heroes, etc.) the class will consider the force of contemporary media in shaping the very idea of Korea.
title: Contemporary Korean Media Cultures

evals: Awesome class! Professor Riehl is a great lecturer and super approachable. Ask questions during the mid-class break. The lecture material is super engaging, too!
Counts for CBE bio track. A generally fun, interesting course and not too much work. Final and exam paper though which was a bummer.

Definitely take this course if you are an EEB major. If you are not, and are looking for an STN or an interesting course in general, this would be a good choice. Manageable coureload, interesting lectures, doable exams.

Do all of the readings and be prepared to memorize small facts and details as well as the big concepts from lecture. Also, don't be afraid to seek help from the preceptors for all of the written assignments.
Don't miss a lecture! They are super interesting! You should take this class even if you are not an EEB major!
Fantastic Course. Professor Riehl is literally the most amazing person ever. Her research is incredibly interesting.
Fantastic, highly recommend.
Go to lecture and pay attention.
Go to lecture and pay attention. Book reading isn't really necessary unless Riehl says.

Great class. Professor Riehl is a great lecturer and the topic is very interesting. You leave with a better understanding of animal behavior and lots of fun anecdotes. Also, she gives cookies during break and tries to learn students' names, which is always appreciated. Not too much work, but does take time.

Great course! I would definitely recommend it to others, especially if they are interested in EEB or even if they just want to learn cool things about animals and their behaviors. I took it without taking EEB 211 first, and while I've heard there is overlap and taking 211 would be an advantage, it was not necessary.

Great! Definitely should take if you need an interesting no lab class or departmental. Even if you are not all the familiar with EEB, the professor and preceptor definitely break it down for those willing to learn. There were even snacks!

I would highly recommend this course, whether you're an EEB major or not. Lectures were fascinating, full of interesting information. Christie is dynamic and excited and knows a huge amount, and whatever she might not know she is eager to learn along with the students. She takes a personal interest in getting to know all of the students, which is remarkable for a lecture of this size. Along with Amanda, she helps students learn for themselves how to think about behavioral ecology, and develop their own sense of how to conduct research and experimentation.

If you're on the fence, I would definitely say take this course! It was honestly one of the my favorites - Prof Riehl is so passionate about the subject and her and the TA Amanda were amazing at answering any questions. And all the lectures were really well organized and were full of exciting examples!
Loved this course! I learned so much and Professor Riehl is great. Make sure you understand the psets.
Pay very close attention to the details.

Probably one of the best EEB departmentals you can take right now! Professor Riehl is one of the nicest, and she is always willing to help students understand concepts from lecture outside of class. You will have a significantly better understanding of concepts you learned from EEB 211 (i.e. mating strategies, life history) through this course. Exams are very fair too.
Professor Riehl is great! This class covers many interesting concepts and examples and has a light workload.
Professor Riehl is wonderful. You'll lean lots of really fun animal facts! Take the p.sets and other assignments seriously. They're not that hard to do well in and they count for quite a lot.
Really great class. Take if you can!
Take it! Such a good course with great instruction
Take this course! Lectures are very interesting and Professor Riehl is a great lecturer
Take this course! Professor Riehl is an awesome lecturer, and the subject is fascinating. I hadn't taken a single EEB course before this, anyone can take this class and get an A, and really enjoy it.
This course is amazing! A great course for EEB majors. If you're not an EEB major it's still a great course if you want to learn a lot of cool facts about animals!

This is a fantastic course - the best I've taken so far at Princeton. Just one word of warning: Don't be lulled into a false sense of security if you find the concepts very easy to understand - there's a lot of theory that you need to make time to memorize.

This was a great class and I highly recommend it to anyone with an interest in animals or understanding how evolution and behavior are related. The most important thing to keep in mind if you want to do well in this class is that you need to pay attention in lecture and do the precept readings.
Very similar to Professor Gould's class but Professor Riehl is great.  You will definitely enjoy the class.
Well taught, interesting but with a fair amount of work if you want to do well.
You will do well if you try your best and put in sufficient effort into the assignments. Ask the professor or preceptor if you have any difficulties.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 25%, Quizzes - 8%, Lab Reports - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 4%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 2%, Problem set(s) - 6%
assgts: Weekly precept readings will consist of 2-3 articles from the primary literature. Weekly lecture readings will consist of approx. one textbook chapter (~30 pages). Writing assignments will include two short (approx. 3 pages each) essays and one ten-page term paper.
prereqs: EEB 211 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: How does a swarm of honeybees collectively decide on a new site for their hive? When a mother mouse protects her young, are her behaviors genetically determined? Why do ravens share food with each other? This course is an introduction to behavioral ecology, which asks why animals act the way they do, how their behaviors have been shaped by natural selection, and how these behaviors influence their surroundings. We will first discuss behaviors at the individual level, then move to reproductive behaviors. The final section of the course will focus on social evolution, the origins of cooperation, and human behavioral ecology.
title: Behavioral Ecology

otherinfo: Successful completion of the introductory Sanskrit sequence (through SAN 107) will satisfy the foreign language requirement for A.B. students.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Daily readings. Written homework. Weekly quizzes.
prereqs: SAN 102 must be taken to receive credit for SAN 101. No prerequisites..
descrip: An introduction to classical Sanskrit grammar and vocabulary, as well as Devanagari script, pronunciation, and phonological change (sandhi). Students will begin to read simple Sanskrit prose and verse.
title: Elementary Sanskrit I

otherinfo: Successful completion of the introductory Sanskrit sequence (through SAN 107) will satisfy the foreign language requirement for A.B. students.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Written homework; reading selected excerpts; short quizzes.
prereqs: SAN 102 or permission from the instructor..
descrip: Strengthens classical Sanskrit grammar and vocabulary and builds knowledge of South Asian religion and culture through reading selections from Sanskrit Epics and Puranas. Requires SAN102 or permission from the instructor.
title: Intermediate Sanskrit I

evals: There aren't a lot of machine learning courses at Princeton. This is one of them. Don't expect to learn anything from the lectures - they're pretty disorganized and unclear. The book is your friend, but also kind of unclear. That being said, you'll definitely feel like you have a better understanding of Kernel-based methods.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Lab Reports - 15%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: 20 pages of reading per week.
prereqs: Some prior exposure to linear algebra, statistical theory, and convex optimization..
descrip: With foundation built upon statistical and algebraic learning theory, this course offers an in-depth learning experience on machine learning for (big) data analysis for senior and graduate students in electrical engineering, computer science, and applied statistics - with some exposure to algebra and statistics. It covers various kernel-based unsupervised and supervised learning models and provides an integrated understanding of the mathematical theory and their potential applications. With the accompanied software learning laboratories. It also demonstrates how kernel learning models work for pattern recognition and data analysis.
title: Kernel-Based Machine Learning

evals: A must take, even with no prior knowledge. Topics covered are diverse and fascinating and the assignments are useful and interesting.

Biased opinion because I went into it wanting to learn about this material from Searchinger in particular and therefore am happy about it. Even though they made this exact criticism, the course doesn't help much in terms of not "treating all of Africa as a country". Do all the readings or you will let yourself skate by and not get much out of it.
Do the readings, pay attention and discuss! Also choose a good topic for the presentations.

Great course if you are interested in African agriculture and sustainability!  It gives a good overview of the environmental, social, legal, and political issues surrounding the question of hunger in Africa.

If you're interested in international development and environmental sustainability, I would recommend this course. Prof. Searchinger and Prof. Estes are great people and it's obvious they care a lot about their work in Africa and they are invested in their students too.
Pretty interesting course. Almost no work during the semester, but really intense dean's date assignment.
Take it! It's very seminar-heavy and tries to structure itself around class-discussions. You'll become better at evaluating agricultural policies.
Take this class if you're interested in environmental science and African development.

Take this course to learn about a highly interesting and important topic that doesn't get enough play in environmental discourse often. Professor Searchinger is a world expert on many of the food policy questions at hand and Professor Estes is great as well. The course is more of a survey course of many different topics so you don't get any one deep topic. Know that the final assignment is a 40 page partner project which is very intensive and accounts for the central part of the grade.

The course is interesting if you are looking for a relaxed seminar. The readings are not overwhelming. You receive a general overview of problems in Africa, but do not focus on one specific item, which makes it difficult to really get a true understanding of Africa's challenges.

This is a relatively easy course that does not have much reading. You will gain cursory knowledge of environmental and food issues but will not have a sophisticated grasp of either. If you want a laid back course this is a good option, but do not take if looking to learn a lot.
Wasn't my favorite class -- felt like one big cost-benefit analysis with overviews of topics and no real depth of study.  We listed contingencies of the issue and that was about it.
otherinfo: Course open to 20 sophomores, juniors and seniors. The course is intended to give students some basic understanding of agronomy, population growth, hunger, savanna ecology, and agricultural development issues while students explore one issue more deeply in a major final presentation and paper. The course will balance instruction, guest lectures and presentations by students.
grading: Other Exam - 15%, Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Readings of 60-80 pages per week will be from science and policy papers, journalism and book chapters. Final papers will be roughly 4000 words, and students may agree to work in teams of 2 with double the length. There will be an in-class exam after week seven.
descrip: This course will explore the economic, environmental, and social challenges of meeting growing food needs in sub-Saharan Africa. The region today has the lowest crop yields, the highest percentage of hungry people, and the highest population growth rates, and relies heavily on firewood for energy. The region also has vast areas of environmentally valuable forests and savannas. It has technical opportunities to produce food better but faces challenges from high rainfall variability and climate change.
title: Africa's Food and Conservation Challenge

evals: ISC 335 is nothing to take lightly. If you are coming in as an average MOL major (AP Bio, Chem 201/202, MOL 214, some math), expect to have to work hard to achieve any measure of success. Also, be prepared to be in a class with kids who took ISC as freshman, or ORF and PHY seniors taking the class "for fun". A lot of times you are expected to have prior knowledge of concepts, which these people do, making it difficult to keep up. Also, the quantitative aspect of the course is understated in the description. You will get a lot out of this course if you put in the time. Also, there is much support available from both the lecturers and preceptors, so even though you may feel lost in lecture, you can make up ground easily. Overall, it is a very good class that will put you ahead of the game for biochem and molecular biology in general, but buyer beware.

Make sure you fulfill the prerequisites. This course has a strong quantitative focus, so make sure you have the necessary skills. Also necessary to know MatLab coming into the course. Really interesting, in-depth class, but it is fast-moving and very easy to fall behind. Every little detail/concept is important to understand, as this course is very cumulative.  Course staff is really good and really tries to help the students learn/succeed.

Only take the class if you're interested in a more computational/mathematical approach to organic chemistry and not because you want to skip the traditional orgo sequence - this is not an "easy" alternative, and will in fact be much harder if you don't know how to code/are not comfortable with math. Prof Rabinowitz demands active participation from all students, so go to class and keep up with the material to prevent embarrassing yourself. It's a really fun class though, and I would recommend it even (maybe especially) for non-MOL majors!
Take this if you want to learn organic chemistry will a functional biological emphasis!

This class is an excellent choice for MOL majors who are not premed. The class is challenging, but the material is very interesting. From what I could tell the class moved a little faster than the normal orgo sequence but was not substantially harder and definitely took up less time. I would definitely recommend the class.

You probably want to come into this with some working knowledge of bio and basic chem if you want to do well. I didn't really know what I was doing, but learned a lot in the process. Workload was more substantial then I expected.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Reading and problem sets totaling 5-8 hours each week will be assigned.
prereqs: ISC231-234 or equivalent preparation: CHM 201/202 or equivalent; any one of the following: PHY103/104, MAT201 or MOL215; and at least a small amount of computer programming or use of Matlab, or equivalent..
descrip: A rigorous one-semester introduction to the organic chemical reactions of greatest biological importance, taught through the lens of metabolism. Covers organic mechanisms underlying fundamental enzyme-catalyzed reactions and quantitative analysis of enzyme kinetics and metabolic networks. For quantitatively-inclined students interested in biology, this course is an alternative to the standard two-semester organic chemistry sequence (CHM303/304). Does not replace CHM303/304 for Chemistry majors. Satisfies the organic chemistry requirement for Molecular Biology majors and provides appropriate preparation for subsequent studies in Biochemistry.
title: Organic Chemistry of Metabolism

evals: 4 hours is long and classes weren't always well planned, but if you need an STL and like art its a good pick. Field trip to Kansas City was awesome.
Definitely take this course
If you have the prereqs, this is a MUST take class. Joe is awesome
Interesting course unlike any other course offered at Princeton.

Not amazing if you have never done woodshop before, as it was in my case. Joe and Sigrid are understanding though and will work with you to help you do the best you can. This class will be time intensive, especially if you have never worked with wood before. Better than taking an actual STL in my case though!
TAKE THIS CLASS
This class is as much as you put into it-- would definitely recommend, but also suggest that you take the time to explore with the materials instead of finding ways to complete assignments quickly.
otherinfo: Grading: 10% Other = Field Trip/Visiting Artists
grading: Design Project - 50%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Bi-weekly readings and/or visiting experts to be discussed. Four studio assignments, three short (two weeks) and one long (six to twelve weeks) in duration, chosen by each student or team of students.
prereqs: Any 200-level VIS studio course OR any 200-level CEE course, PLUS any 200-level ARC, EGR, or MAE course OR 300-level VIS studio course..
descrip: This course investigates the processes through which the ordinary can be transformed into the extraordinary. Fall 2017 will focus on the strategic challenge of turning waste material into a viable consumer product. Working in teams, students will conceive, design, prototype, redesign, brand, package, and display a hanging light fixture for aesthetic enjoyment and domestic consumption. The object will be made entirely from ash wood due to the devastation of Agrilus planipennis, an invasive beetle that has destroyed 20 million+ ash trees in the United States. Readings, labs, and visiting artists will support in-class research and development.
title: Extraordinary Processes

evals: I highly recommend this class for anyone who wants to have some understanding of the ever-growing field of security. Prof. Lee is very knowledgeable in this field. She takes the time to make sure everyone has the same basic knowledge and explains fundamental crypto methods in an easy to understand manner. Highly recommend her book for anyone interested in reading up on crypto!
I think most of them think it is a good course.
Information Security in the COS department covers a lot of the same material. The final project is an interesting way to dig deep into security though.

The material taught is, on a conceptual level, very educative and interesting. Lectures run a bit long but more or less engaging. The final project (which might have to be revised in future semesters) was given with absurd expectations and no guidance whatsoever. It is very hard to know what is expected of you in this class. Bottom line, take it if you have no prior exposure to security and want to learn a ton but aren't worried about your grade.

This was one of my least favorite classes I have taken at Princeton. I originally overlooked the professor's poor reviews in other classes because of the interesting class description, but it became evident that the class simply reused a lot of the same material with a short section on smartphones tacked on. The professor often misunderstood questions in class, which led to some confusion. This misunderstanding also affected our final project, which ended up taking a disproportionate amount of time. My partner and I were unable to get her to clarify what would be enough, and the professor seemed to greatly underestimate the amount of time required to build the system we proposed. I was very disillusioned with the class by the end.

We mostly went over very general security principals and smartphone architecture. If you have never taken a security course before, then this might interest you. Otherwise, you will find this to be rather repetitive and lacking substance with regards to architecture.
otherinfo: Graduate students also welcome.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Students are expected to do the readings before class.
prereqs: ELE 375 or ELE 206 and COS 126, or equivalent computer knowledge. Security basics will be covered in class, so no prior security knowledge required..
descrip: Smartphones are the de-facto computing and communications devices of tomorrow. They can access any information in cyberspace and perform any computations through cloud computing and locally. We study smartphone design and security through an architectural perspective. Topics include smartphone system architecture; System-on-Chip design; heterogeneous and multicore processors; sensors, multimedia, communications and storage subsystems; basic security concepts; hardware and software security in smartphones; security vulnerabilities; use and abuse of built-in sensors; associated wearables and Internet-of-Things; and security improvements.
title: Smartphone Security and Architecture

evals: Definitely worth your while if you are a history student, study South/Southeast Asia, and work in the post-WWII time period.

I would advise students with interests in Europe and the United States to take this course, particularly in order to give them perspective on the importance of imperial decline back in the 'metropole.'
If you are interested in this period of time, or simply if you are interested in working with Professor Prakash, I thoroughly recommend it.
Particularly recommended for Lit students seeking to fill some historical gaps.
Prof. Prakash does not pressure or intimidate students to do their work, which means he treats them like adults. Students have to be self-motivated and independently willing to engage. Do your job.
grading: Term Paper(s) - 75%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
descrip: This graduate seminar explores the postcolonial world in the aftermath of World War II, a period convulsed by the aftereffects of wartime upheavals, nationalist insurgencies, imperial retreat, and the onset of the Cold War. Focusing on the period from the end of World War II to Bandung and treating it as a distinct and bounded historical conjuncture, we examine decolonization as a global phenomenon, caught between the no longer and not yet, and sparking changes in imperial and anticolonial projects.
title: After Empire

grading: Papers - 100%
prereqs: Students must prepare a written plan for research and submit copies to the supervising faculty member and DGS for approval before enrolling in the course..
descrip: Under the supervision of a faculty member, students carryout research on a directed topic and present results. Students must identify a supervising faculty member and submit a written plan for research and evaluation which must be approved by the supervising faculty member and director of graduate studies.
title: Directed Research

evals: Bialek is a very good lecturer and the classes were a lot of fun. It was a relaxed course, there were no formal requirements to follow it, some people attended only a few lectures, some stayed until the end and everything was fine. Be aware that you will have to set your own pace.
Easy class to PDF, but put work into the class to get something out of it. Lectures are excellent because Bialek.

Great class to take if you are a physics or biology student (some math background needed) and want to get some insights into a topic in biophysics. Definitely choose based on what the topic for the given semester is.

It is always a pleasure to learn from Prof. Bialek as his presentation of the topics is organized and well transmitted. Definitely recommend for anyone who is interested in sampling and reading through foundational papers in biophysics.
It's a minimal effort class, and if you can keep attention in class, you might actually learn a lot. It's Bialek, he's one of the best lecturers out there.
Super chill. You have one presentation you need to prepare well for, but that is it :)
otherinfo: Readings will be from lectures notes and selected research articles, with topics varying from year to year (example provided). Some background will often be found in Biophysics: Searching for Principles (Princeton University Press, 2012).
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
descrip: Analysis of recent work on quantitative, theoretically grounded approaches to the phenomena of life. Topics rotate from year to year, spanning all levels of biological organization, including (as examples) initial events in photosynthesis, early embryonic development, evolution of protein families, coding and computation in the brain, collective behavior in animal groups. Assumes knowledge of relevant physics and applicable mathematics at advanced undergraduate level, with tutorials on more advanced topics. Combination of lectures with student discussion of recent and classic papers.
title: Topics in Biophysics and Quantitative Biology - Statistical Mechanics for Real Biological Networks

evals: Course is required

Pick a proposal topic that you are already somewhat familiar with. Students who picked topics that they were completely unfamiliar with greatly struggled when coming up with an original research idea because there was way too much new literature for them to cover.
Read papers related to your proposal topic.
This is a great introduction to the research and people in the department, as well as structure and best practices for proposal writing.
none
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: A seminar course designed to acquaint first-year graduate students with the different research areas represented by the CBE department, as well as to train these students in the methodologies and practices used in chemical engineering research. Students learn how to read and evaluate the literature, and the techniques for formulating and developing an original research problem in the field. Each lecture is given by a different member of the CBE faculty (or associated faculty), who will review his or her field of research and discuss open questions for future investigation.
title: Research Topics in Chemical & Biological Engineering

evals: Adrian is a legend. Surely a must-take.

Adrian is amazing and will keep you engaged throughout. This is THE class to take on Cuba, you're guaranteed to learn at least a little bit of everything from Cuba's first inhabitants to the revolution and its recent opening to the US.
Don't take this course. Professor never stops talking for 3 WHOLE HOURS. Readings are useless without discussion.
Easiest class ever
Great class! I would highly recommend taking it!
If you are considering a LAS certificate definitely take this course! Adrian is great and the material is super interesting!

If you don't mind getting no feedback on your grade until the end of the semester and are incredibly self-motivated, take it! The professor is an AMAZING person and knows so much. The material is incredible. The problem is the class is pretty disorganized, so it can be hard to get a lot out of it.
Make sure to keep up with the topics.

Student engagement was low, and class conversation almost non-existant. Written work and project grades were not returned in a timely fashion. Professor was however engaging one-on-one, readings were well-picked and interesting.
Take it! Not too much work, interesting material. Professor Lopez-Denis is fun to listen to and he knows what he's talking about
Take it, just make sure there aren't 18 students enrolled like this year (should be like max 12)

Take this course if you have a burning passion for Cuba and if you are one of those people that is ok with not really knowing your grade in the class until the final paper, since that was our (only?) major assignment.
Take this course! Adrian is great and it's not hard at all.
The readings can get a bit overwhelming if not paced properly and you must be ready to discuss extensively in class. Make sure you are at least remotely interested in the material.

This "seminar" = a huge group of people crowded around a table listening to Adrian talk for three hours a week. Great readings, but you'll get caught up in the rest of your work and probably not do them, then freak out when you have to write the final paper. Not recommended unless you're crazy about Cuba (in which case you should probably just do the abroad program).
Very chill class. You don't need to do the readings very thoroughly to get through it, but the class is MUCH more meaningful if you do them and stay engaged in class discussions.
You get out what you put in in this class. If you're thinking of pdf-ing, n.b. that you will have no idea what your grade is at any point during the semester.
otherinfo: Use of electronic devices in the classroom requires the approval of the instructor.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%
assgts: In preparation for class, students are expected to read an average of 100 pages per week. Oral presentations on selected readings will represent 30% of the final grade. Written assignments will include weekly answers to study questions representing another 30%. A final essay (10-15 pages) is due on Dean's Date. This essay will represent 40% of the final grade. Detailed instructions for all written assignments will be available on Blackboard.
descrip: This seminar constitutes an introduction to the study of Cuba from a historical perspective. During the first half of the semester the course follows a chronological approach, covering the political and socioeconomic development of the country from the sixteenth century to the present. In the second half of the semester, it examines a series of sociocultural issues that are central to the life of contemporary Cubans, on the island and abroad. At the core of the class lies an interrogation of the relevance of the Cuban case for larger discussions on colonialism, modernity, socialism and development.
title: Cuban History, Politics and Culture

evals: 3 hours of hearing the professor speak. If you're looking for a chill class, this is it.
Do the readings and pay attention in class. There are a lot of interesting things to cover.
I would suggest speaking with Professor Lopez-Denis in office hours. He is very helpful.
Stay on top of the readings and definitely participate in class. It is fun for you and it helps you learn.

Take the course based on if you find the reading list interesting, since that's what you'll spend most of the time on this class. Not super difficult at all and gave interesting perspectives on the topic of public health

The class feels dry at times but you learn a lot! Professor Lopez-Denis knows A LOT and is so knowledgeable about so many topics. He is also hilarious and a really nice person to talk to. I really regret not going to office hours to get to know him better. The final paper was a bit of a challenge.
There isn't very much structure, but Adrian is extremely knowledgable and you can learn a lot if you want to.
You get what you put in. If you do the readings you'll learn a lot.
otherinfo: Use of electronic devices in the classroom requires the approval of the instructor. If using this course to pursue a certificate in Spanish, students will be required to complete all written assignments in Spanish.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%
assgts: In preparation for class, students are expected to read an average of 100 pages per week. Oral presentations on selected readings will represent 30% of the final grade. Written assignments will include weekly answers to study questions representing another 30%. A final essay (10-15 pages) is due on Dean's Date. This essay will represent 40% of the final grade. Detailed instructions for all written assignments will be available on Blackboard.
descrip: This seminar explores the impact of transatlantic exchanges between Europe, Africa and the Americas on the development of the environmental, political and sociocultural trends that affect our health and our ability to heal today. During the first half of the semester we will reconstruct the interconnected histories of the medicalization of the West and the westernization of the Rest, from the Renaissance to the end of the twentieth century. In the second half of the semester we will explore the contemporary consequences of these historical developments.
title: Public Health and Private Healing in the Atlantic World

evals: A big emphasis on the interdisciplinary, so if you're not interested in doing readings from a wide range of disciplines, don't take it.  I personally liked the exposure, and for me it made it a unique class.  Aaron and Bruno themselves are great instructors.

Awesome class that teaches you about different methods on writing an urban studies research paper. Aaron and Bruno are pretty chill and I think they work pretty well with each other. Amount of readings was a lot for me but pretty standard for a seminar class I think. Bruno is one of the most inspiring people I know, so if he's teaching, definitely take it! Also, if you will need to write a research paper on an urban studies subject this class would be very helpful. I had very limited urban studies knowledge prior to this class so don't be intimidated if you haven't taken any URB classes.
Bruno is an excellent professor and makes the course stimulating and interesting. Beware this class has a ton of reading! Learned a lot though.
Do not take this class

Do take it, but please participate. One of the weaknesses of the course was that only a few students contributed regularly to discussion. Also, try to focus on the research methods while doing the readings rather than getting caught up in content; that's what you're really there to learn.
I would recommend this course for anyone remotely interested in urbanism. I highly enjoyed it.

If you're interested in Urban Studies, this is a must take. Not every week will be fantastic, but this is probably the seminar in which the time has passed the fastest for me each week! which goes to show how engaging it is (or was for me, at least)
Take this course to learn more about Urban Studies and applicability to various disciplines. The readings are engaging and help you begin to think more about how you make claims in writing.

The seminar requires one to read a lot, but not an unusual amount considering Princeton standards. The course is rewarding for anyone engaging in independent research, regardless of one's major. Because one can find the urban in nearly any topic, do not be dissuaded if you are neither an Urban Studies certificate student nor affiliated with Bruno or Aaron's departments (SPO and ARC). The course is infinitely more thorough at analyzing research methods than Freshman year's Writing Sem is ever capable of. Do consider this course if you hope to develop your command of research methods and research styles. One of the most unique courses at Princeton where you get to talk once a week for 3 hours with students from a broad range of departments: Architecture, Anthropology, Economics, Independent Concentration, Politics, etc.
otherinfo: 20% Other: Research Proposal (proposal for paper). Optional capstone class that is strongly recommended for certificate students in either their junior or senior years (or anyone else who anticipates writing a JP or thesis on an urban theme).
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Students will complete a synthetic essay analyzing the scholarship on their chosen research topic. The remainder of the course will focus on expanding ongoing student research projects based on themes and research questions in urban studies.
prereqs: Students must be working on a junior paper, senior thesis, or larger independent research project..
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar introduces research methods in urban studies. We will focus on some of the ways in which researchers make sense of cities, including various aspects of urban experience, culture, history, theory, form, and policy. Students will use the analytical frameworks covered in the course to develop their own research projects with the goal of developing more dynamic junior papers and senior theses.
title: Urban Studies Research Seminar

evals: Decent course. Lectures are ehh, but every 2 weeks you write long op-eds that allow you to learn about things that you read in the WSJ and Economist, but aren't exactly sure what they are (like Onshore vs Offshore RMB).

If you're interested in learning more about China's financial system, do it! You should be aware that the grading is somewhat arbitrary (based on a handful of written homeworks, where most of the answers come straight from the lecture slides, and a final paper) but it is a great way to learn. If not an ECO major would be a very solid PDF.  Also, bring caffeine. The 7:30-10:30pm lecture time kind of sucks but it's the only time Professor Duan can teach because of her work schedule.
Take if you are interested in China and want a fairly easy course.
The class is what you make of it - if you do the readings, stay engaged during class, ask questions, and write thoughtful papers, it can be a very productive course.

The homeworks are long, so be prepared. However, you will be able to have conversations on China's Financial System on a very high level. Wei Xiong is fantastic, so I recommend meeting with him one-on-one at least once.

This is a great course to come in with no knowledge about. I went from 0 knowledge about China and its economy to knowing so much I can be elected party leader. Very well taught, excellent readings, and excellent lecture slides. My only negative is that the presentation was difficult because we had little idea on how we were graded and what the standards were. Future students should really focus on figuring out what to do for the presentation.
This is an interesting class if you're interested in China's stock and bond markets! Lectures can be dry, but the readings are great. It is an essay heavy class.
otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Problem sets, readings from books and journals, term paper.
prereqs: ECO 100 (Intro Micro), ECO 101 (Intro Macro).
descrip: With its rapid economic growth in the past three decades, China already has the world's second largest economy. Meanwhile its financial markets are also being quickly liberalized and integrated with the rest of the world. As the current trend continues, there are growing interests to learn and understand the workings of China's financial and monetary systems. This course aims to serve this objective with a particular emphasis on understanding the role provided by the financial system in facilitating China's economic development, in addition to the investment opportunities and risk presented by the system to the outside world.
title: Chinese Financial and Monetary Systems

evals: Other than the Friday morning start time, this class was a lot of fun. Prof. Luijendijk is an awesome person, and the readings were always super interesting. Discussions were a lot of fun and a/b meaningful things. Also just a good way to get to know the other Religion peeps.
This class is only available to Juniors in the Religion department, but it was awesome and helped me contemplate a lot of questions I need to ask myself as a religion scholar.

Well it's required for religion majors! Look it's kind of a filler class. You read interesting works in the religion field, then you guys talk about it. It's very chill, a bit fun, and you get kind of close with the others in the room. Especially if you have Luijendijk, who makes a fun environment. But...I didn't really learn much. It definitely felt like a filler class that you only take because you have to.
otherinfo: JP proposal and short assignments will constitute Other 60% of grade
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 60%
assgts: In addition to short assignments throughout the term that prepare majors to research and write a junior paper (JP), students are expected to produce a five to seven-page JP proposal.
descrip: First semester junior majors participate in a non-credit colloquium with a member or members of the faculty. In addition to short assignments throughout the term that prepare majors to research and write a junior paper (JP), students are expected to produce a five to seven-page JP proposal. The grade for the colloquium is factored into the final grade for the junior independent work.
title: Junior Colloquium (Non-credit)

evals: Great class overall. You'll learn a lot. Very accessible even for students without much finance background.
N/A
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: Problem sets, readings from books and journals, term paper
descrip: With its rapid economic growth in the past three decades, China already has the world's second largest economy. Meanwhile its financial markets are also being quickly liberalized and integrated with the rest of the world. As the current trend continues, there are growing interests to learn and understand the workings of China's financial and monetary systems. This course aims to serve this objective with a particular emphasis on understanding the role provided by the financial system in facilitating China's economic development, in addition to the investment opportunities and risk presented by the system to the outside world.
title: Chinese Financial and Monetary Systems

otherinfo: Grading: Weekly preparation 80% (attendance, completion of assignments between classes, application during class time), Studio masterclass 20%.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: The specific content of this course will be tailored to the individual needs and musical aspirations of the students. An effort will be made to balance the interests of the student with a foundation in the core repertoire and new music. There will be one studio masterclass in which students of same or similar instruments will gather to play for and critique each other under guidance of the instructor.
prereqs: Open to Music concentrators and Musical Performance certificate students only. Students must complete MUS 298 (Fall) and MUS 299 (Spring) in the same academic year to receive one course unit of credit. Please note that MUS 299 will be graded with a letter grade and will conclude with a jury exam before the performance faculty, which will require preparation throughout the academic year..
descrip: Independent instruction in voice or instrument is an intensive immersion in all aspects of recreating music for performance. Lessons are geared towards the development and embedding of solid technique, and the application of this technique to proper style and musical expression. Issues explored include but are not limited to interpretation, stylistic appropriateness, historical context, theoretical/syntactical underpinnings, audition and performance strategies, and career planning.
title: Independent Instruction in Voice or Instrument (Non-credit)

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

assgts: See syllabus
descrip: See website
title: State of the Earth: Shifts and Cycles

otherreq: Open to Juniors, Seniors, and Graduate Students Only.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly field notes; Two short papers; Class participation; Final Paper.
descrip: Students will be introduced to the practice of doing ethnographic fieldwork in the local community and to the reflective process of writing ethnography. Students will select a local field site within reach of their daily lives, engage in fieldwork and participant observation, write field notes, experiment with interpreting their data and discover their research question. In the readings and in class discussions we will talk about social explanation and interpretation, and focus on field notes and the process of writing ethnography. Field notes will be turned in weekly. A final paper based on field research is due at the end of the semester.
title: Studying Local, Writing Ethnography

evals: Strongly recommend. I suppose there is some tension for M. Arch I students interested in auditing the course-- since it is very interesting material on its own. I enjoyed, however, that it's intended to foster a very meaningful kind of class/cohort relationship and identity.

The course varies greatly depending on who is teaching it, but Stan's version was fantastic. Weeks alternated between looking at the early work of key architects and more self-reflective exercises to help each student identify their positions and place within the contemporary field.
This course is smooth and organized. At the same time work and presentations is new, relevenat and will expand your understanding about the dicipline of architecture.
great course, they should take their time to do their presentations
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Open to Incoming students of the post-professional M.Arch. program..
descrip: A series of exercises guide students to identify the primary questions that currently structure the discipline and extra-disciplinary concerns which architecture must engaged today. Analyses of these issues are linked to contemporary architectural production. Each week students present from the format list. The focus in the formats and their connections substitute buildings analysis or close readings of texts as isolated arguments, and should help discern the diversity of threads they open. Our goal is to describe value systems and discursive paths used not only to evaluate but also reconstitute architectural practice.
title: Proseminar for Post-Professional M.Arch.

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course
