otherinfo: For information on enrolling in this course and WWS course offerings for this term, please go to the WWS website (www.wws.princeton.edu).
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course is limited to students participating in the Scholars in the Nation's Service Initiative (SINSI), the Richard H. Ullman Fellowship, or an approved MPA middle year out. Enrolled students participate in one or more internships with a federal, state, or local government agency, non-governmental organization, or multilateral institution in the U.S. or overseas. The purpose is to provide a learning environment for students to use/develop quantitative and qualitative analytical skills in an active public policy setting, with oversight from Princeton University faculty and staff.
title: Extramural Public Policy Fellowship

otherinfo: The main goal of the course is to demonstrate how interplay between measurements and a hierarchy of models (that starts with highly idealized and gradually becomes more elaborate) can lead to an understanding of very complex phenomena such as weather and climate.
grading: Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Readings from texts and journals. Biweekly problem sets. Graduate Students will attend the same lectures as GEO 361 but will have more quantitative and challenging homework based on the same material.
prereqs: MAT 201, PHY 104 or equivalent.
descrip: This course discusses the processes that control Earth's climate - and as such the habitability of Earth - with a focus on the atmosphere and the global hydrological cycle. The course balances overview lectures (also covering topics that have high media coverage like the "Ozone hole" and "Global warming," and the impact of volcanoes on climate) with selected in-depth analyses. The lectures are complemented with homework based on real data, demonstrating basic data analysis techniques employed in climate sciences.
title: Earth's Atmosphere

evals: The continuation of PHY 557, although I take it before PHY 557. Totally recommended if you're thinking of doing experimental physics.
This course is useful as a low-work 5th class that actually is still academically useful.

This course teaches you the details of electronics as well as a "back of the napkin" approach to design problems. You will get the most of this course if you do the readings and ask lots of questions.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This is a laboratory course that provides hands-on experience designing, building and testing digital logic circuits. The course meets for one three hour session each week and has weekly reading assignments. Topics covered include combinatorial and sequential logic devices, A/D and D/A converters, PLLs and microcontrollers. Grading is in P/D/F format as is based on solutions of several "design problems" assigned throughout the semester. Students are assumedto have some familiarity programming in a procedural language ( C, Pascal, FORTRAN, Java, etc.) This course complements PHY557 which concentrates on analog electronics.
title: Electronic Methods in Experimental Physics II

evals: Strongly recommend for students interested in computing engineering.
Worthwhile for getting a feel for professors and their research areas.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course will introduce first year graduate students to the research of the faculty in the area of Computer Engineering and Information Sciences and Systems. It will help first year graduate students find a research advisor.
title: Selected Topics in Computer Engineering and Information Sciences and Systems

grading: Papers - 65%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
descrip: This course examines the political implications of ethnic diversity across contexts. We will discuss questions such as: How and when do ethnic identities shape political behavior and political cleavages? What explains ethnic conflict? How are ethnic minorities incorporated into politics? Readings will cover advanced democracies (with a focus on the US and Europe) as well as economically and politically developing countries.
title: Comparative Ethnic Politics

evals: I strongly recommend Daniel Barber as a professor, no matter what kind of seminar he's involved with
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 40%
assgts: Students are expected to attend all scheduled seminars, complete all assigned readings, participate in seminar discussions, lead a seminar presentation, and develop a semester long research project culminating in a presentation and final paper.
prereqs: Open to Graduate Students Only.
descrip: Architects have long been concerned with the relationship of a building to its climate. Focused on the period surrounding World War II, right before mechanical HVAC systems were widespread, this seminar explores the archive of methodological experiments, media systems, and technological devices that were intended to understand and refine the thermal interior. Many of these explorations took place at Princeton, in architecture and elsewhere. We also explore the conceptual frameworks that allow us to consider architectural-climatic experiments in light of the historiographic and epistemological challenges posed by climate change.
title: Architecture, Media, and Climate

evals: A great course to take as a fifth class or to PDF. There's not too much work (two short papers throughout semester, midterm, and final) and Prof. Bendixen is very engaging and knowledgable. The readings are classics that I've been wanting to read anyway, so I thought this was a great way to get a more academic approach.
Bendixen is fantastic, he's sort of a toned down Nunokawa. If you like sci-fi and/or need an LA, definitely take! The class is very fair.
Bendixen's great! If you like the class topic, you'll like the course. I learned a lot!

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS.
AMAZING.
One of the best classes I have taken here, as auditors from the community will agree.
Do the readings, you'll get way more out of the course. And go to lecture, since bendixen is a great lecturer
Do the readings.
Do the readings. They are very doable because they are enjoyable. Don't make this class harder than it has to be. You will have fun if you know what you're talking about.
Fantastic course (especially for engineers looking for an easy distributional). Engaging lecturer, fun readings, open-ended and flexible assignments.
Fun class, great readings, pretty chill grading.

Good class to PDF. Not bad to take for a grade if you're not amazing at essays. If you go to lecture and just write 3 essays, 2 short stories and 1 more or less throwaway essay you can probably get a solid grade.

Great PDF. Great reading-- I took it to have an excuse to read Watchmen. You can choose to turn in 2-4 papers and you can choose when to turn them in. One of them can also be a short story. Fantastic readings  and not too much work. Get to know Bendixen also, he's very smart and well-read.
Great class, excellent lectures! I found it hard to keep up with a novel a week, especially when we got to the thicker ones, but if you PDF, this is a great LA!
Great course - interesting lectures and readings, flexible paper prompts and due dates, and no dean's date paper!
Great course for an LA. Readings are really interesting and the lectures and precepts are a lot of fun to learn more about science fiction.
Great course with a great trio of instructors, reading lists, and assignments, which is rare. Great LA.
Great readings, lectures can get boring but they are not the worst. Professor Bendixen is very nice and enthusiastic about the topic.
I would recommend keeping up with the reading. I got behind working on my thesis in the second half of the semester and had to read a ton of books before the final.
I would recommend taking it, this was a pretty good class.
I would recommend this class if you're interested in science fiction.
I would strongly suggest taking this course if you have even the slightest interest in science fiction. Not only are the readings excellent, but the analysis is equally good.

If science fiction or the books on the reading list appeal to you, take it. I used this course's readings to procrastinate on my other classes' work, and I really enjoyed the class. Bendixen's lectures and jokes can get repetitive towards the end, but he's a good lecturer.

If you are interested in reading more science fiction, or gaining more perspective on science fiction you've previously read, this is an excellent class to take. Workload is fair, readings are very enjoyable, and lectures are reasonably interesting.
If you have any interest in sci-fi, take it! Just make sure to not procrastinate on the papers.
If you're interested in Science Fiction, take this course. It's not necessarily an 'easy' A, but it's definitely an easy P if you do all the readings
Interesting and fairly fun class. Great PDF.
It's a good class to take, the workload is not that bad and novels are assigned over the weekend, which is really nice. Professor is great and engaging.

Lots of fun, little effort - I gained a lot from this class without having to stress about it. Awesome reading list. Bendixen's lectures can wander sometimes, but as long as you pay attention to the parts of the books he emphasizes, you'll ace the exams.
Make sure to do all of the readings. They are really enjoyable and normally fairly light reading. Turn in essays early.
Not too much reading and very manageable work load for an English class. Take if you have interest in science fiction!

Probably my favorite course so far at Princeton. Prof. Bendixen is such an interesting lecturer and really makes you read science fiction (and literature in general) in ways you never thought of before. And the readings are excellent, you won't want to do the rest of your work because the readings are so engaging and overall a lot of fun.
Reading list is fun
Stay on top of the readings. Get the books from the library earlyish if you don't wanna buy them, better than reading online copies.

Students who are taking this course should make sure to attend all lectures, as these will provide the main discussion points of precept. If one does the readings, attends precept, and attends lectures, it is not difficult to do well in the course. In fact, I think that I would have liked to attend the lectures and the precepts even if they were not required because they were quite interesting.

TAKE IT! Professor Bendixen is an interesting lecturer and the topic and readings themselves are way more interesting than a lot of other english classes out there. Also, the grading for the class is definitely fair and forgiving as the exams are definitely reasonable if you pay attention in class, which you should definitely do because it is just interesting in general!
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! Although I had never read many science fictions coming into the course, I really liked it. Professor Bendixen's lectures are phenomenal and are very interesting!
Take it if you like sci fi and don't mind quite a bit of reading every week (you actually do have to do the reading by the time you take the exam). Professor was great!
Take it out of interest in the subject matter. Lots of fun, not too heavy of a work load

Take it! This class was both very interesting and fairly laid back. You may not like every book discussed, but you are guaranteed to thoroughly enjoy at least a couple of them. I found the novels all very interesting and the lectures very enjoyable.
Take it!! Prof. Bendixen is a really interesting lecturer, not too difficult of a course, and the preceptors are great. Very good readings too
Take it.

Take it. It's a great class and will open your mind to things you have never seen or thought before. If you like Sci-Fi already, this will change the way you read it for the better and will only make you like it more. If you don't like Sci-Fi, it will certainly show you the merits of the genre.
Take this class
Take this class if you like Sci-Fi. you will probably have read most of the books. Lectures are funny but also insightful. Just take it
Take this class!
Take this class! Definitely one of the funnest class I've taken at Princeton.
Take this class! Very fun, good lectures...or, at least, entertaining ones. Not very hard, but very rewarding.

Take this course! It's a great way to fulfill the LA requirement and is a really interesting class even if you don't need to do so. Keep up with the readings, the midterm and final are primarily identifying quotes from each text.

Take this if you want to do all the reading. As long as you do all the reading, even if you don't go to lecture, you will have no trouble with the assignments/exams. If you like the reading list and need an LA, definitely take this class.
Take this!!!! So fun and not hard at all as long as you do the reading (which is all really fun)... You get to read the hunger games for homework!

The readings for this class are really fun, so think of reading them as study breaks and keep up with them throughout the semester. Also, if there's still the "short story" paper option, I'd really suggest giving it a shot; it's fun to do more creative writing for a change of pace (also tends to be graded more forgivingly).
The readings for this course were entertaining and interesting, and Professor Bendixen does a great job of identifying the main themes and meaning. Relatively light course load.
This is a really fun class and the reading is great.
Unparalleled. May be my favorite class I have taken thus far
Very fun class I wouldnt hesitate to reccomend
Worth taking if you're interested in the reading list.
Yay. But be weary if you want more diversity.
You'll do well in this course if you do the readings and attend the lectures. If you don't at least read, there's not really a point to being in the course.
great class
read the books, they are fun
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Reading approximately 200-250 pages per week. Two short papers (each 1,000-1,500 words.)
descrip: An exploration of the ideas, issues, and aesthetic values that mark the development of science fiction from the 18th century to the present, with particular attention to the ways specific texts confront the philosophical questions underlying scientific inquiry and invention, travel in time and space, the creation of life, robots and robotics. The ways in which this genre reframes the basic question of what it means to be human will be the foundation of our analysis of contemporary short stories and representative novels.
title: Introduction to Science Fiction

evals: Professor Deem is an angel. She is ridiculously intelligent, well-read, and is so kind. I loved having lecture with her.
Take it if you want to sit through a pretty low commitment class. You may not discuss the readings but do them anyways because they are interesting.
Take it!
This class is not a good class.  With no clear direction, I felt as though I spent an entire semester not doing very much except for an independent research project.
otherinfo: Most meetings will be divided between critical engagement with the assigned theoretical/critical texts and the use of strategies gleamed from these texts to critically engage public discourses ranging from film, television, newspapers, magazines and new media that are important for the understanding of the discursive conditions of media spectacles.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 25%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 35%
assgts: Students will be expected to participate in weekly discussions of readings, present a case study on a media spectacle or scandal, and participate in a semester long research project which includes workshops, formal drafts, and culminates in a presentation and final paper.
descrip: Our contemporary mediascape is saturated with spectacle and scandal. In this class, we take this observation and examine, not only the logics that undergird these discursive events, but also the intimate connection between media spectacles and scandals and the regulation of non-normative bodies and speech. This class will examine the manner in which non-normative subjects and practices are hyperembodied, surveilled, stigmatized and disciplined through practices that often cast them as outside of a democratic ethos. Spectacles that might be examined include The Women's March, Trigger Warnings, Black Lives Matter, and Travel Bans.
title: Media Spectacles, Scandalous Citizens and Democratic Possibilities

evals: Amazing course with an incredible professor about a really fascinating time and place.
Keep up with the readings and take extensive notes and quotes. It will save you grief when you go to make study guides.

Prof. Bell is a good lecturer and very clear, but sometimes a bit dry. He is also very helpful when writing papers or reviewing for exams, and takes a clear interest in actually making sure the material is getting through effectively and people are keeping up with the course.
Really great professor and very interesting material. Great HA for anyone interested in French culture and I'm sure it's a great course for regular History students too.

Take it!! This class is on a very interesting subject and is very well-organized. I think that the topics (the Wars of Religion, Enlightenment, French Rev.) and readings are very worthwhile to know about. The professor is great and makes everything interesting. I highly recommend it!!
This is a fascinating course and Professor Bell is an amazing teacher.
otherinfo: If there is enough interest, one precept will be conducted in French. Please email Prof. Bell (dabell@princeton.edu) if you are interested in that precept.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 35%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 150-200 pages of reading per week; a 6-8 page paper; a mid-term in-class exam; and a final exam
descrip: A survey of France and its colonial empire during centuries in which this country dominated the Western world. Major topics include the sixteenth-century Wars of Religion, the absolute monarchy, colonization and slavery in North America and the Caribbean, the Enlightenment, eighteenth-century social and cultural change, the French Revolution and the Terror, the Haitian Revolution, and the Napoleonic Empire.
title: France and its Empire from the Renaissance to Napoleon, 1500-1815

otherinfo: Seminar weekly presentations (20%); Seminar reading discussion (20%) Final oral presentation (30%); Final paper (30%)
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Each student will select one Italian city to follow in its evolution from the Roman age to the Renaissance, and through a series of oral reports will discuss how it developed its own civic institutions and responded to larger scale historical developments. Class discussions will center on the analysis of contemporary sources in translation. Reading assignments (including narrative and sources) will total about 60 pages per week. There will be a final paper about 20 pages in length.
descrip: In the Middle Ages, dozens of city-states in Italy were governed by citizens elected by the populace (limited to men of property, as was the American republic in its early years). These communes grew out of the anarchy following the dissolution of the Roman Empire in the West and flourished by playing off the German emperors to the north against the papacy. In the course of the later Middle Ages, many of these cities became autocracies, but some remained republics well into the modern era. Each student will follow the history of a single city, using documents, coins, and art works from Princeton collections.
title: Medieval Democracy: Italian City States of the Middle Ages

evals: A terrible course. Pillow is a terrible lecturer and tried to cover way too many concepts (linear algabra, python, neuroscience). Problem sets are ridiculously hard and draw on material far above what they teach you. If you have to take it, try to get Nick as a TA. He's super heplful
Definitely doable with the help from the TAs and other students.

Do not take this class without being already comfortable with linear algebra and probability, and be prepared for some coding so you probably want to have taken at least COS 126 or equivalent. If youre not comfortable with the math, lecture is utterly useless, you won't understand or learn anything. Problem sets are also unreasonable but the TAs were very helpful (I know Alex and Nick are great, haven't heard great things about Anqi but idk), and most importantly having a study group. Worst class I've taken in Princeton, very frustrating, it shouldn't be a departmental the way it is structured right now. If you have to take it, go to labs and office hours and find a good study group.
Great introduction to programming, and a solid class in computational neuroscience

Having previous experience with statistics, probability, and programming would definitely be helpful for this course. Don't fret if you don't though; Dr. Pillow and the preceptors are very patient and encouraging of questions.
I would highly suggest that students considering taking this course have at least some experience with coding.

I would suggest taking a coding course or linear algebra course before this one. I spent at least 60% of my homework time on this class and was lucky my other classes weren't too stressful. The problem sets are difficult so definitely ask questions in lab and go to office hours.

I wouldn't take this course if you don't have to take it, unless you have a solid foundation in linear algebra, probability/statistics, and dynamics. The link to neuroscience isn't huge, but may be interesting for those who don't know much about the neuroscience related to some of of those computational concepts.

If you already know linear algebra and probability and think this class will teach you some interesting neuroscience, DO NOT TAKE IT. This is a math course, not a neuroscience course. I also think that you would be better off taking MAT 202 and a course on probability, since this course didn't even cover the math topics well. I would say take this course if you are a neuro major or if you want to learn Python.
If you don't have any python or linear algebra experience this class is gonna be really hard. But if your'e a neuro major you don't have a choice so, good luck.

Only take if you a requirement or you have background and a lot of interest in linear algebra and Python coding. Be prepared to put in time and effort. Great professor and very nice/helpful professor and TAs!
Some assignments may be a little difficult but the skills you learned in this course are so valuable if you are considering neuro or a related field

Start working on psets early and get
help from the TAs. They were all very
kind and helpful
Take advantage of the help the instructors offer in lab, office hours and Piazza!
Take it. Pillow is a great lecturer, and the TAs are super helpful.
Take this class if you have not done linear algebra before. It's also a nice way to learn introductory python.

The 'mathematical tools' portion of the class is kind of overstated in my opinion. We spent a lot of time on what essentially was linear algebra 101 and I assumed anyone interested in taking this class already had a working knowledge of basic stuff like that (+ ODEs, probability) and didn't need to re-learn it. Coding assignments were good however, I think using Python was a smart decision in retrospect. Anyway take it if the title sounds interesting to you, but be prepared for 20% neuroscience stuff and 80% freshman math stuff.

This class is a great intro to linear algebra, probability, and linear dynamics, if you haven't had any of those topics already. Very reasonable pace and workload, friendly and accommodating course instructors. Covers knowledge essential for anyone doing science and especially neuroscience.

This class is certainly a bonding experience with other students, as working through problem sets can often be a long and somewhat frustrating process. However, instructors are helpful if you seek advice.

This course was tricky. Do the lecture readings. The teacher knows the material too well, and thus expects the students to understand what are actually very tricky concepts. Not as easy as he describes it to be. The quizzes caught me off guard.
This is a tough class, but you will learn
Would be difficult for someone who has never coded before, since you're just told to Google how to code things, but overall a good course.
take it even if you're obtaining the neuro certificate; tools learned in this class are very useful
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: Problem sets will include programming.
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Problem set(s) - 70%
assgts: No reading or writing assignments. All assignments will involve paper and pencil mathematics or computer programming.
prereqs: Calculus is a prerequisite. Previous programming experience is not required..
descrip: This lecture course will introduce students to the mathematical, statistical, and computational tools necessary to analyze, model, and manipulate biological data sets. A primary goal of the course will be to introduce students to key concepts from linear algebra, dynamical systems, and probability, with an emphasis on practical implementations via programming. Lectures on each topic will develop relevant mathematical background, derivation of basic results, and examples of applications. The course will include problem sets based on the Python language. No prior programming experience is required.
title: Mathematical Tools for Neuroscience

evals: Class gets boring, is poorly organized. Professor gets frustrated often and does not respond well.
Good to force yourself to take ArcGIS, but Princeton has plenty of better seminars to take.
Interesting material, but even the professor felt the lack of enthusiasm for discussing gentrification near the end of the class. Glad I got to learn some new mapping software though.

Take it for the ARC GIS
Take it for Aaron too
Take the course if you are interested in mapping and gentrification, but it's a good bit of dense reading. The more you put in, the more you'll get out of the course.

This is a good introduction to gentrification. It's a great class to go along with an urban studies certificate or an elective to learn about how you (as a Princeton graduate) may impact the city where you eventually live and work.
otherinfo: Previous experience in GIS is not required.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Design Project - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Two maps, one created using data collected in the field and the other using preexisting datasets, both to be completed in groups; two papers providing a critique of each map and an analysis of how it supports or conflicts with existing theories of gentrification.
descrip: This seminar introduces the study of gentrification, with a focus on mapping projects using GIS (Geographic Information Systems) software. Readings, films, and site visits will situate the topic, as the course examines how racial landscapes of gentrification, culture and politics have been influenced by and helped drive urban change. Tutorials in ArcGIS will allow students to convert observations of urban life into fresh data and work with existing datasets. Learn to read maps critically, undertake multifaceted spatial analysis, and master new cartographic practices associated with emerging scholarship in the Digital and Urban Humanities.
title: Mapping Gentrification

evals: A lot of work towards the end of the semester, but manageable. Professor Huang was extremely flexible with office hours and offering extra guidance on problem sets and projects. She was very engaged and motivated to help her students
A nice intro to statistics and data science just be prepared to look at the slides

Awful. Not hard, but awful, and you will feel like you are wasting your time at every moment. Lectures were awful (literally the worst lectures I have ever encountered in my 14  years in school), precepts were awful, psets and projects were easy but felt like wastes of time, course organization and communication was awful. If you have any desire to actually learn statistics or data science, take something else. If you want to get the MOL quantitative requirement out of the way and never want to touch a computer again in your life, I guess take this, but make sure not to skip lectures because you'll miss those shitty quizzes and you'll be stuck with a bad grade that doesn't actually reflect your understanding (my mistake).

Be prepared to do some learning on your own and for some dry lectures. Daisy is very helpful, but much of this course is also dependent on your ability to look information up from notes and other resources. A very useful class nonetheless because you do end up learning how to do cool analyses with data.

COS126 isn't a prerequisite but I feel like a little bit of coding background proved to be extremely helpful...just in the way one approaches a coding problem and the basics of all computer languages. Also I would wait until the course becomes more organized and established.
Daisy (the lecturer) is great.

Daisy is receptive to feedback, which was nice, but honestly very disorganized and I feel like I learned little from the course. Hopefully should be better next semester, but if not just switch into another stats course, like the econ one.
Do not take this course. It is not worth the effort you will put in. This was definitely the worst course I took this year.
Do not take unless you absolutely have to.
Don't do it unless you need to.
Don't take it.
Don't take this class unless you have to, "Data Science" is just a trendier term for statistics, and there are stats classes here at Princeton that are much better taught than this one.
Don't take this course. R sucks, if you've ever done any statistics its useless, you could learn the entire course in a weekend.

Having taken ORF245, I really did not learn much data science or statistics from this course. It felt more like a semester-long R-bootcamp than a data science course, but perhaps it felt differently for people without substantial statistics backgrounds. The lecturer clearly knows her stuff and tries hard to lecture well and stay on top of students' concerns. However, she ran into a few hiccups at the beginning of the semester, probably due to her not having much experience lecturing before. She got much better as the semester progressed, however, and will probably be great next fall.

I didn't have any coding experience, but this course was still fine-- as long as you read the lecture notes, understand the concepts along the way, and go to office hours, you'll be able to do the problem sets and projects.

I think this course would have been a lot easier if the lectures were better structured and better taught. The class is pretty disorganized and difficult to follow. There are probably better stats classes out there.

I would take this course. It is very nice because there are no exams, so assignments compose your grade and you can get help from the professors and preceptors on them. They are vey approachable and helpful in answering questions.

If you don't know statistics, R or both, you should definitely take this course: you'l learn a lot of  statistical concepts by directly working with them with R.
So it's a practical-focused course.

If you already know stats and R, then probably you should take other course with more advanced econometrics.
If you have not already taken statistics, be ready to set aside some time to understand the theory.
If you want to learn either statistics or R extensively, this is not necessarily the course to do so. However, you will get good foundations in both.

It can be very dry, but Daisy is a complete darling. The course can be a bit confusing and in order to really learn anything, you probably need to put in a bit extra effort beyond just attending lecture and doing the problem set and projects, but it is a pretty good introduction to R and statistics.
It's a good course and the ability to work with partners makes it a lot easier. However, CHOOSE THE RIGHT PEOPLE TO WORK WITH.

Lectures are difficult to sit through, but Daisy is incredibly helpful, kind, and passionate.  She was always willing to help and constantly extended office hours. I learned a tremendous amount from this course and feel prepared now to do my own research. Daisy knows so much about data science, and this was particularly evident in lectures--it was often difficult to understand some of the very complex statistical concepts. I think she did a great job balancing teaching R coding and statistical theory. Be prepared to ask for help if you have never coded before!
Like a weird, watered-down version of ORF 245. Less work than ORF 245 but you may literally learn nothing about statistics in this course. You'll at least know how to mess around in R by the end.
Liked this course better than COS126, yet it is a little disorganized so beware
Make sure you understand the basics of R coding and R markdown presented in the beginning of the course; it speeds up doing the psets by a lot.
No no no no no no. Absolute waste of time. You will learn zero coding in R and the statistics is at a middle school level.
Not a great class-poorly structured an uninteresting lectures. Daisy is really nice though
Not hard to do well, but be prepared to not really learn anything unless you teach yourself on the side. Very disorganized staff too.

Please don't take this course. Especially if you don't know r or have a basic knowledge of stats. You will end up Googling everything and gain nothing from the lectures. I honestly hope that Princeton either stops offering this course or revamps it entirely; it was horrible.
Pretty chill course. I took it for fun and I think it's helpful for exploring various things you can do with R. Easy 5th class.
Review the precept examples
Simple material but the professor made it interesting. It's important to understand the statistical concepts to be able to code well in R.
Start assignments early! Go to office hours.
Take another course if you can, but again this is a requirement for some majors. (mol)

Take this stats class!!!! Especially if you're a science major. There is no midterm and final. Only problem sets and projects, in which you can work with partners. The material isn't too hard to grasp and the professor is so willing to help you with anything. Not a hard class to get a good grade in.

The course has very interesting material and the instructor is very nice and very approachable. However, the course is currently very poorly organized and it is hard to get much out of it. I am sure you can take the course, enjoy it, and get a lot of it, but you will need to do a lot of work on your own, go to a lot of office hours, and do more than should be expected of a student on their own. There is no syllabus, the schedule changes constantly, and no one knows when the problem sets and projects will be due until they are assigned a week or two beforehand. If you need to take the class, go for it, you'll survive, but expect to be frustrated throughout the semester quite a bit because of this class. The course has the potential to be really good and interesting, so wait until it is restructured if you can before you take it.

The professor cares about the course, which is good. The logistics (especially in grading homework) were fairly poor in the beginning of the semester but improved near the end. Students came in from a variety of different backgrounds, which could be good or bad, depending on if you know how to write scripts in R already or not.

This class is good for introductory statistics and starting to learn R, you don't get to the more fancy data analysis tools in this class. 

There are a lot of resources for this class- lecture, precept, office hours, piazza, and the instructor and preceptors were very accessible.
This class is not particularly hard but it's time consuming around projects. I didn't really learn anything from it but it wasn't difficult.

This class is poorly taught. If you want to learn R, the assignments will force you to learn, but do not take this class if your intention is to actually learn statistics-- you won't. Pro is that this class is graded entirely on assignments and there are no exams.
This class tried to teach us to code in R and to learn basic stats.... I didn't walk out knowing either....

This course has changed drastically from the version last year, and was not a good introduction to R. If you have some R background or previous coding knowledge, you will have a much easier time than others.
This course has hard projects, but office hours are extremely helpful!

This course isn't too difficult, even if you don't have experience with statistics or computer science (although background in either of these areas would definitely help). For the most part, lectures and precepts prepare you for the problem sets and projects, but don't expect to gain a great understanding of either stats or R from the course.

This course may be useful if you have zero knowledge of coding or statistics. Otherwise, though, it is a waste of your time - lectures are boring and confusing, as are problem sets. Easy PDF, but don't expect to gain anything from the course beyond a course credit.

This course was useful for me in learning R, although it was often very difficult to make myself pay attention to lecture. Overall, it's not that stressful, and I would definitely prefer it to other stat classes like ORF245
This course wasn't too much work, but also wasn't very interesting.

This was somewhat disorganized. Please make sure to stay on top of the material and do not let yourself fall behind. If there is ever a concept that you do not FULLY understand,  be proactive and go to office hours. You will thank yourself once the final project comes around.

Though many seem to have issues with her, I found Daisy to be a great lecturer and incredibly interested in helping individuals grasp concepts/get through her class. Definitely take this course if you have the chance!
Very interesting subject material but maybe take it with a different professor.

You may need to do some extra reading/work to learn the basics of R because they kind of jump right into it in this class. After you get the hang of R the class is pretty easy-going. If you've never coded before, do not fear it's not as bad as you think. I actually enjoy using R now and I had never used it before this class!
You'll learn the basics of R but don't expect to learn many statistical concepts beyond your standard stats class.
ok
stats is not the most interesting thing in the world, but this class was ok

take this course!! not a significant time commitment, and Daisy is very understanding about the amount of work that gets assigned and the timeline for due dates. you'll get a great foundation in statistics/modeling and R programming.
you don't need to know r, but it helps for the first couple weeks. after that you'll catch up and be just fine.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Design Project - 45%, Quizzes - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 40%
assgts: There will be three data analysis and/or programming projects and five problem sets due over the course of the semester. There will be primary and supplementary reading assigned by the instructor.
descrip: Introduction to Data Science provides a practical introduction to the burgeoning field of data science. The course introduces students to the essential tools for conducting data-driven research, including the fundamentals of programming techniques and essentials of statistics. Students learn to work with real-world datasets from various domains, such as writing computer code to manipulate, explore, and analyze data; using basic data analysis techniques from statistics and machine learning; drawing conclusions using sound statistical reasoning; and producing scientific reports. No prior knowledge in programming or statistics is required.
title: Introduction to Data Science

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course
