grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Problem set(s) - 25%
descrip: This course provides a unified presentation of stochastic optimization, cutting across classical fields including dynamic programming (including Markov decision processes), stochastic programming, (discrete time) stochastic control, model predictive control, stochastic search, and robust/risk averse optimization, as well as related fields such as reinforcement learning and approximate dynamic programming. Also covered are both offline and online learning problems. Considerable emphasis is placed on modeling and computation.
title: Stochastic Optimization

evals: Be prepared to work a lot and don't be afraid to ask for help.
Be sure to devote at least 15 hours each fortnight. Also, this course complements, but doesn't substitute course ast551, at least the first semester of that course.

Good introduction to the mathematics behind astrophysical plasma analysis. Broad in scope but involved in calculation. Would recommend to anyone wishing to gain a better understanding of plasma systems.
The tools of plasma physics play an increasingly important role in astrophysics research. No budding theorist should go without the lessons provided in this course.
can be difficult at times but worth taking
work hard! its worth it
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 25%, Problem set(s) - 75%
descrip: Introductory course to plasma physics, as it applies to space and astrophysical systems. Fundamental concepts are developed with mathematical rigor, and application to the physics of a wide variety of astrophysical systems are made. Topics include magnetohydrodynamics, kinetic theory, waves, instabilities, and turbulence. Applications to the physics of the solar wind and corona, the intracluster medium of galaxy clusters, the interstellar medium of galaxies, and a wide variety of accretion flows are given.
title: Introduction to Plasma Astrophysics

evals: Barber and Kitzinger are some of the finest minds in the field, they teach well.
Do not be afraid of asking questions, especially when you are unsure of the material or the significance of a piece.

I would recommend taking this course. Though medieval art sounds a bit intimidating for someone who doesn't know much about the time period (I definitely knew nothing going into this course), the course is taught in a way that emphasizes careful looking and formal analysis. In other words, you don't need to know lots about Christianity or Roman art in order to feel confident in the material. This class changed the way I see objects in relation to the body, to other objects - art in relation to place, to time period and medium. I appreciate how I was taught to think in this class.

Overall, you will learn interesting stuff in this course. It is dissimilar from other 200-level art history courses, however, as it doesn't provide you with a solid sense of the historical progression of medieval art. Instead, it feels more like case studies of often unrelated works. The professors do make a point to connect them thematically, but I don't feel like I got a comprehensive understanding of medieval art overall.

Take this course if you like medieval art or are looking to fulfill Group 2 requirement! It's super interesting and will make you feel like a true medievalist. Keep in mind, though, that it has a surprisingly difficult workload for a 200-level class. Also, you will probably get lost in some of the history discussed in lectures/precepts unless you have really heavy prior knowledge but you'll be okay--this probably won't affect you grade-wise.
This is a great course if you are interested in the material - but be prepared to really do all the reading.
Totally take this course if you are interested in art history, specifically from the middle ages, which will expose you to a lot of religious art and theology.
otherinfo: For department majors, satisfies Group 2 distribution requirement.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings, take-home midterm assignment, four short papers, final research paper due on Dean's Date.
descrip: In twelve weeks this course will examine major art works from the twelve centuries (300-1500 CE) that encompass the European Middle Ages. Presenting works from Europe and the Middle East, the course will introduce students to the art of Catholicism and Orthodoxy, Judaism and Islam; the great courts of the Eastern- and Holy Roman Empires, and the roving Vikings, Celts and Visigoths. Students will not only be invited to consider how art can represent and shape notions of sacred and secular power, but will also come to understand how the work of 'art' in this period is itself powerful and, sometimes, dangerous.
title: Art and Power in the Middle Ages

evals: It really helps to do all the readings and take notes on how one aspect affects another! Professor Chizhova is wonderfully elegant and is really great to talk to when you have questions about Korea!
Take it if you are interested in Korean history! It's a good class, and I really enjoyed it. It's also not an intense class.
Take this course! The material is fun and interesting. The professor is great.

Taking this course as a freshman, I was unsure what to expect and fairly nervous to study something entirely new to me. Professor Chizhova, however, makes the material accessible to everyone, no matter their background, and she is more than happy to meet with you outside of class or provide you with additional guidance if you are struggling to comprehend the readings. Class discussions are quite engaging, as are the vast majority of the texts you will discuss, and there is considerable flexibility with regards to the midterm and final papers. This is nice because you can compose an essay about the aspects of the class that most interest you, which makes the writing process more enjoyable. If I were to identify the biggest challenge I encountered, it would probably be the length of some of the texts. I am a slow reader, so I sometimes struggled to complete all of the readings thoroughly. Nonetheless, I would encourage you to take the course, especially if you are looking to try something you've never done before.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: In addition to weekly responses to the assigned readings, the students will write a midterm essay (5-7 pages) addressing the questions provided by the instructor. The final analytical paper (8-10 pages) will be written on the topic of the student's choice and will demonstrate the student's creative and informed reading of the primary materials. No additional research is required for the final paper.
descrip: This course is an introductory survey of the cultural history of premodern Korea-from early times until the turn of the twentieth century-focused on the primary sources. We will read various original materials (in English translation): myths, state histories, diaries, travelogues, and works of fiction, among others. Topics covered in this course include the imagination of the origins in myth, the idea of Confucian governance, everyday life and entertainment in Choson (1392-1910), and Korea's opening to the west in the late nineteenth century.
title: Writing and Culture of Premodern Korea

evals: Absolutely recommend taking this course!! Professor Stoddard is SO nice and is a really good lecturer.  She presents material clearly, and her enthusiasm for sensory ecology is contagious (I found the material fascinating!).  As a senior EEB major, this has been by far one of my favorites!

Absolutely take this, there is definitely a strong focus on the sensory systems of birds, which I did not think I would enjoy, but wound up being very interesting. Not difficult material at all, just a lot of memorization
Don't skip lecture and be engaging!

Great course, can't recommend it enough! Prof. Stoddard is a great lecturer and makes what is already very interesting material even more enjoyable to learn. Definitely the best departmental I have taken as an EEB major and one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton overall!
If you are at all interested in sensory ecology, take this course! Professor Stoddard is incredible.

If you have an interest in evolutionary biology or in the diversity of a wide array of different sensory systems that animals use to interact with the environment around them then I would definitely recommend taking this course. I would consider it a must-take for EEB majors in particular, but I also think that it is taught in a way that would make it enjoyable for non-science majors as well.
If you're interested in sensory ecology whatsoever, take this course as it is very rewarding and engaging! Professor Stoddard is a great lecturer who is so passionate about the subject.

Loved this course! There was never a dull moment and Professor Stoddard is so sweet and helpful. I learned so much and definitely see the world in a different way now. Make sure to remember everything that she presents in lecture. And definitely reach out if you need help!
Professor Stoddard is an amazing professor. Definitely recommend taking as an extra EEB departmental. Very interesting and well taught.
Take this course! You'll learn so much!
Take this!! Prof. Stoddard is amazing and you'll learn so much.

This class is a fine EEB departmental- I doubt you'll regret it. It is very similar to behavioral ecology (which I also took) and also Animal Behavior (so I hear) so if you're interested in those, this is fine (or if you want to retake one of those classes if you did well). Bunch of memorization. The class presentation was not that bad so don't let that push you away.
This course was a lot of work, but it is worth taking, and I'm sure Prof Stoddard will only improve the course with each year.

Very good class. Professor Stoddard is one of the better lecturers at Princeton. Despite being new here, she really blows a lot of other professors away. This class would probably be great to take even if you're not an EEB student..definitely way better than 211
take it - so good
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Students will be expected to read assigned textbook chapters and primary research articles before lectures and precepts. There will be several short assignments as well as a research paper (10-15 pages).
prereqs: EEB 211 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Sensory ecology investigates how animals extract information from the physical and social environment. All animals acquire and use information, but the sensory systems involved vary dramatically. Bats echolocate. Birds see ultraviolet colors. Electric eels shock their prey. Spiders communicate chemically. How do these processes work, and why did they evolve? In this course, we explore the mechanisms and functions of animal communication. We first review the different senses, emphasizing physiology and neurobiology. We then examine how animals use sensory information in foraging, mate choice, cooperation, anti-predator defense and mimicry.
title: Sensory Ecology

evals: Be Prepared to read. One author each week.
Everyone should take this one way or another

Great course. Jagmohan is friendly and passionate but he is not the best lecturer. Stick with it and you won't regret it. The reading list is amazing and the knowledge you have by the end of the course is invaluable.
I would highly, highly recommend this class to anybody, but, especially, people who want a more thorough understanding of American history in general.
I wouldn't take this course until the professor has had some more experience teaching.
It's a lot of reading, but it's a fantastic reading list and great lectures- if you're interested in African American politics, black political thought, or political theory take this course.
Keep on top of readings.
Only take this if you are excited about the readings because the readings are the course.

People: please take this class. For a political theory class, it is so so interesting and so relevant to how see the foundations of white supremacy that still shape America today.. Take it if youre into that

Prof. Jagmohan is a very knowledgeable individual with a passion for the material he is teaching. I would suggest being in his precept because he is able to foster an engaging and open dialogue. Take this class!!
Read the books carefully because it is not easy to get everything you need to understand the text through skimming. For the most of them, it is necessary to read between the lines.
Really great class! Professor Jagmohan is phenomenal - he gives great lectures and is very approachable. He is tough grade and expects a lot, but will make it worth your time.

TAKE THIS COURSE. It will change your life. If you've ever even thought about Black Lives Matter or slavery, you should take it. Princeton has great politics courses, but the reading lists are usually overwhelmingly white male (at least for the theory courses). The syllabus for this course is amazing, the professor is even more amazing (if that's possible), and I can't say enough good things about it. I literally talk about this course in daily conversation at least four times a week. Professor Jagmohan is a legend You should go to his office hours and get to know him even if you're not in his precept. You'll get even more from the readings and he's such a thoughtful person to talk to! He genuinely cares about his students and it truly shows.
Take this class! Prof. Jagmohan is super cool and interesting. Go to office hours and go to all the lectures and precepts and do all the readings! You can get so much out of it.
Take this class, especially if you're at all interested in POL or AAS. The books are amazing and the topics discussed are relevant to so many things!
Take this course!! You learn so much about the history of African American political thinkers and scholars. It really shaped how I view many current race related issues.

The course was interesting overall. It wasn't my favorite course but the reading list was fantastic and Professor Jagmohan is a fair professor. I actually really enjoyed the assignments (midterm, papers, final) because they were fair as long as I had completed the readings.

This class is probably one of the few classes that both challenges you and teaches you so much within the politics department at Princeton. Professor Jagmohan is a really great professor and is very attuned to how the readings relate to the present realities of the United States. If offered again, I would definitely recommend one take it - especially if you feel that you are a strong writer and would benefit from having a more diverse understanding of political theory (because Lord knows, some need that).
This course has a strong emphasis on political theory.

This is a must take a Princeton. Professor Jagmohan is one of the three best lecturers I've had here. If you're not particularly good at writing, I would suggest electing PDF. Ultimately, the subject matter is very pertinent to everyday life, and this course presents political philosophies that are often marginalized or overlooked. Please take.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: 125-175 pages of reading per week. Three 1000-word papers (10% each).
descrip: This course explores central themes and ideas in the history of African American political thought: slavery and freedom, solidarity and sovereignty, exclusion and citizenship, domination and democracy, inequality and equality, rights and respect. Readings will be drawn, primarily, from canonical authors, including Harriet Jacobs, Frederick Douglass, Martin Delany, Booker T. Washington, Anna Julia Cooper, Ida B. Wells, W. E. B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, Ralph Ellison, Kwame Ture and Charles Hamilton, and Martin Luther King, Jr. This is an introductory course, which emphasizes both thematic and historical approaches to political theory.
title: History of African American Political Thought

evals: A very well-done lecture class. Professor Lee was just recently a student, so she knows how to engage undergrads well. You'll learn a lot, and it's not that hard.
Attend all the lectures. Lectures are very important. Also, the grading is pretty unfair for this course. Probably because its new. They were really strict, so be prepared.
Awesome professor and awesome subject matter, but assignments and grading standards are sometimes unclear.
Definitely take it, it's a good mix of theory and actual cases which don't seem disconnected.

Great class to take if you're interested in IR, foreign policy, and/or military operations (or even if you aren't but want some exposure to super-relevant foreign policy topics)! Lectures were informative and relevant. Readings aren't too cumbersome.
I highly recommend this course to those with an interest in international conflict or diplomacy.
I would recommend this class to anybody who's interesting about learning post Cold War American intervention. The lecture's were incredible and an absolute must to go to.
I would recommend.

I'd definitely recommend this course. Professor Lee is a very kind, smart, and open teacher. The material itself is already more interesting on its face than some other POL classes I've taken, but the addition of Professor Lee makes this a must take for POL majors and a good choice for a non-departmental/PDF course.
I'd strongly recommend the course if you're interested in the subject matter
I'm neutral on recommending this course.

If I could go back in time, I wouldn't take this course again. Sure, the Politics department could benefit from more IR courses. But if you're an IR-track student looking for an IR course, you're better off spending your time on other courses than taking this one.
Keep up with the readings, don't procrastinate on the paper at the end of the term.
Professor Lee is an incredible professor, who teaches some very interesting material in an engaging way. I highly recommend

Really liked this class and would recommend! I didn't know much about interventions from recent U.S. history, and I feel like I came out of this class understanding not only what happened with our post-Cold War foreign policy, but also reasons for intervention, theoretical models, etc. The amount of work and reading is pretty average for a politics class. Lectures and precepts are both engaging!
Take it, absolutely fascinating.  Good for understanding the determinants of decision making within the government; very applicable for Woody Woo or politics majors (why is it not cross-listed?)
Take the class! You will learn a lot from it. Be ready to take extensive notes the entire 50 minutes of lectures. The exam is 40% of the grade, so keep that in mind.

Take this class!! I honestly came in not being able to tell the Afghanistan War from the Iraq War but I feel like I understand contemporary U.S. foreign policy so much better now. And Prof. Lee is great!
Take this course if you are an IR in POL. Prof. Lee is great and knows her stuff. A high benefit low cost class.
Take this course if you have an understanding of foreign policy going in. If you do, it will be very rewarding. Professor Lee is a very tough grader but she is brilliant.
Take this course if you have any interest in US military intervention abroad or how the decision-making process works when the US goes to war.
Take this course! Professor Lee is an amazing lecturer - make sure you go to lecture so that you'll be able to fully understand the readings of them. 10/10 would recommend.
Take this course! Very interesting. A lot of readings though.

The first half of the course is mostly theoretical while the second half focuses on cases of U.S. intervention. Be prepared to synthesize theories from the first half of the course with the material from the second half of the course.
The first half of the course was pretty dry because a lot of it was fairly intuitive if you think about it, the case studies were much more interesting. Really long readings

This course is fantastic if you want a framework to think about modern U.S. conflicts. It is also a nice PDF if you are a STEM major looking for an SA. Prof. Lee is an excellent lecturer, and every lecture is impeccably well-organized and well-argued. The workload is very manageable: a reasonable amount of reading per week and only one 8-10 page paper due before break. Highly highly recommend.
This course teaches you a lot, and there is a lot of material covered. Just be weary of Preceptors and try to get into Professor Lee's section. She's really incredible,
Well organized, interesting pol class
good class
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Students will complete one writing assignment. Reading assignments total approximately 150 pages per week.
descrip: This lecture course examines the politics of armed international intervention. Because the United States is uniquely positioned to intervene abroad militarily, the course approaches intervention primarily from an American lens. The aims of the course are threefold. First, we will discuss the domestic and international determinants of the decision to use force, as well as different justifications for intervention abroad. Second, we will assess the record of intervention in several post-Cold War cases. Third, we will consider the criteria for thinking about when the United States should intervene with military force.
title: International Intervention and the Use of Force

evals: Get ready for a great time with Jeff!

Take ANY class taught by Jeff Whetstone. Actually. Whether you are an established artist, or are thinking about taking your first art/photography class, Jeff will completely change the way you think about the world, and art,  and basically make you into a better person. Be prepared to work enough to make use of the incredible growth opportunities that you will be exposed to.
Take it

Take this course if you are dedicated to photography and are interested in thinking about portraiture as an artistic practice. Portraiture, representation, selfies, photography for the masses - all relevant issues in a world where cameras are everywhere and self-presentation is paramount. I think the issues that this class brings up are interesting, and it's worthwhile to think about how portraiture has evolved over time, and how it plays a role in our own lives. If you're interested in thinking about these things ? and most importantly, thinking through art ? definitely take it. Also, Jeff is an amazing professor - incredibly inspiring and uplifting to be around, intelligent, and passionate about photography.
otherinfo: Grading: Other 30% = Final Critique
grading: Design Project - 35%, Papers - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Students will lead and facilitate discussions for each lecture and be responsible for research and writing three response papers to the visiting artists and/or Museum exhibitions. These papers should relate the artists' work to class lectures, readings, and discussions. Students will write succinct artist statements for their projects. The focus of the students' endeavors will be three photographic projects culminating in a final portfolio.
prereqs: VIS 212 or VIS 213.
descrip: This course will examine the practical and theoretical issues of photographic portraiture. Photography's pervasiveness has described and defined notions of identity, race, and gender. We will explore the history of the photographic portraiture as well as work of contemporary artists working in a post-modern age where representation and identity are deconstructed. Students will learn technical skills such as large format camera use, studio lighting, and printing. Assignments will explore conceptual strategies, and students will exhibit their work for periodic critique.
title: Photographic Portraiture: The Practice of Representation

evals: I would encourage every student to take this course. It was incredible and was definitely one of my favorite classes at Princeton thus far.

If you're interested at all in Public Health, I recommend taking this course. Professor Gerwin is one of the most knowledgeable professors I've had at Princeton, especially regarding health in the United States, and she helps you to really think like a public health expert.

Interesting issues, not especially challenging. Readings can be skimmed and skipped, but they're the highlight of the course, so you'd be missing out. Professor Gerwin is very accessible, and cares a great deal about her students.

Keep up with the readings and make sure you visit with Professor Gerwin for office hours; she's very friendly! Do not be afraid to ask questions in seminar and take in all of the information that you can; it's all very interesting.
Professor Gerwin is a great professor, and she truly cares about all of her students---definitely take the course so you can get to know her!

Professor Gerwin is an awesome professor and she is really on your side and wants to see you learn, grow, engage, and keep in touch with her. She cares a lot about the public and a lot about health and the last class made me tear up. Though the seminars can feel long, the material is really interesting. Definitely recommend.

Professor Gerwin is great- get to know her! Be prepared for a lot of assignment shifts, and she goes on a lot of tangents which can be boring sometimes. Take the class if you are interested in domestic health policy issues.
Stay on top of the readings; participate in class; choose a topic for the final project that you are truly interested in.

This is a great, low-key course for the GHP certificate. Readings are manageable and fairly interesting and present information from a variety of perspectives. The workload is minimal but as engaging as you make it. A great fifth class, and Professor Gerwin has great stories.

This was a great course to have during the election and I wish I could continue it to the next semester, especially with the new administration. You learn about key stakeholders, policy debates, and how politics and conflicts impact policy.
Worthwhile course for students interested in public health - dynamic readings and discussions, knowledgeable professor, reasonable workload
not a bad class! you learn a lot, the prof is very knowledgeable. But the seminars can be hard to get through at times. I wish that it had been more discussion based. Very unstructured.
otherinfo: Reading assignments will include preparation for in-class exercises involving congressional testimony on mandatory vaccination laws; regulatory impact analysis of e-cigarettes; political desirability of emergency powers legislation; debate over legitimacy of government regulation of risky personal behavior; critical examination of whether America has a weight problem. PLEASE CONTACT jferszt@princeton.edu TO BE ADDED TO THE WAIT LIST.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 70-120 pp. reading per week. In-class exercises, mid-term, and final project. Group project will allow collaborative and creative analysis of a current public health issue.
descrip: The study of public health is an interdisciplinary inquiry involving issues of politics, policy, history, science, law, philosophy, ethics, geography, sociology, environmental studies, and economics, among others. Students will examine the government's role in assuring and promoting health, through the exploration of issues on America's "public health agenda," such as epidemic response, tobacco use, the impact of weight on health, mandatory vaccination, disease prevention, and violence. In doing so, they will consider the impact of race, income, gender, place and environment, education, capitalism and democracy on health outcomes.
title: Issues in American Public Health

evals: All the readings are really great, just try to engage with them and then bring some ideas to class so you have something to discuss.
Definitely take the course, speak to Laurel when you have a question and don't be afraid to speak up in class.
Don't take this course. It's a super easy class but painfully boring. Not worth your time.

HIGHLY recommend. Very important material to learn about--these issues are urgent. Opportunity to understand how injustice and violence, and their roots, are not always visible or obvious or immediate. Wonderful/inspiring professor who is very engaged in the course and organized and will gladly meet with you and for the final paper you can turn a rough draft in to go over in a writing workshop and one-on-one.

If the reading list appeals to you and the subject matter sounds interesting, take it! It offers a perspective and a critique of some of the systems in our society we often take for granted (like capitalism) that you don't get in many classes, and Professor Mei-Singh is passionate about the material and very easy to work with.
Readings are sufficient but manageable, a flexible and broad exploration of the way environment and geography are included in dynamics between capitalist world and indigenous, non-capitalist peoples.
Take this course if you want to be woke. One of the best I've taken at Princeton. It encompasses so many themes and it's so relevant to the real world.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 25%
assgts: Approximately 150 pp. of reading per week; weekly online written reflections (200-300 words); one 5-page midterm paper; one imaginative portrayal of disaster with an accompanying 2-page "artists statement" and presentation; one 10-page final paper.
descrip: In recent years, public discourse has stressed the urgency of impending environmental crisis. With the premise that "there's no such thing as a natural disaster," we will explore the social and political elements of environmental crisis. Our baseline definition of crisis will be: a moment when an existing set of relations is markedly upset. We will look at how war and capitalism precipitate environmental crises and how state and corporate institutions also benefit from these disasters. Our studies will begin with apocalyptic texts--which are reflections and exaggerations of existing realities--alongside environmental justice scholarship.
title: Environmental and Social Crisis

evals: Definitely take it if you can get in! It will change the way you think about your peers at Princeton.
TAKE THIS COURE! AYNSLEY IS AMAZING AND THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST COURSES YOU CAN TAKE AT PRINCETON.

Take this course! Is a great PDF and ends up being way more fun than you might think even if you aren't a dance person. Aynsley is so interesting, nice and most of all she is deeply caring of her students.
This class was as wonderful as the reviews said. I heard that it may be a bit similar to the other courses taught by Aynsley, but if you enjoyed those, you'll enjoy this!

This was my favorite course I have ever taken at Princeton and I am so thankful I took it senior spring. Aynsley created an environment in which 18 strangers became good friends, comfortable with being their authentic selves in front of each other.  It was amazing to see how the class became a conbination of physical and emotional therapy, and it has been such a gift. I STRONGLY recommend anyone vaguely interested in dance or movement to take a class with Aynsley -- you won't regret it!
otherinfo: This course is designed for all students, whether new to or experienced in dance and/or art making practices. It meets twice a week. Attendance in all classes and completion of all work required including: creative assignments, papers, and participation in final project is required to pass the course. There are seats reserved for each class year. All unused reserved seats will be released to all class years for further enrollment during the Add/Drop period.
grading: Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Ongoing creative and reflective assignments (approximately 2 hours outside class/ week); reading, viewing art and performances (approximately 2 hours outside class/week), several short response papers and a final project.
descrip: In this studio course open to anyone with a body, we will explore power, structure, and human bodies through personal, political, anatomical, kinesthetic, and aesthetic lenses. We will delve into these issues as artists do: by reading, thinking, talking, moving, and making performances, actions, sense, and change. Each day we will literally incorporate what we study by using tools from dance, somatic and creative practices. We will explore what it means to be an engaged intellectual. Readings include contemporary thinkers about race, gender, sexuality, disability, and performance. Students design final creative projects.
title: Power, Structure, and the Human Body

evals: A lot of reading, but she throughly discusses all of it in class and is eager to accept questions.
Best class I've ever taken at Princeton. Learned actual life skills. I think everyone should have to take this class.
Great! Highly Recommend

Prof Hamera is the most wonderful professor! She is sooo knowledgable and is great at leading and directing seminar. I learned a lot about a topic that I didn't really consider "academic" before, but know I use many of the tools learned in class to analyze the world around me and how bodies are relevant factors to almost all situations.
TAKE IT. Do not be deterred by the 3 hour time, it goes by amazingly fast and we end up wishing we had more time

TAKE THIS COURSE.  Professor Hamera is amazing and genuinely cares about her students and their ideas.  The class is so interesting, and this is the only opportunity (as I write this) at Princeton to take a course in fat studies, an emerging field that combines gender studies, sociology, politics, and performance studies.  This is the best class I've taken at Princeton, and I highly highly suggest it.
Take it! Even if size activism isn't of interest to you, we learned an important framework and a new vocabulary for thinking about daily interactions

This was probably my favorite course I have taken at Princeton. Prof. Hamera is an incredible instructor, and the material is very engaging and relevant. Granted, I was particularly interested in the content coming into it, but I still could not recommend this course enough to anyone considering it. The readings can be long but they're easy to get through (and interesting) and if you have to just skim it it's not hard to still be part of the discussion.
otherinfo: Grading: Other 20% = Performance
grading: Papers - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Three short papers, group performance, seminar paper, and class participation. Short papers: an ethnography of the normative Princeton body, a close reading of the ways fat works in a specific example, and a research-informed creative point of view assignment. Group performance investigates relationship between fat and performative elements of public life. Seminar paper uses performance studies methods to analyze an artifact or example.
prereqs: No prior dance experience is necessary..
descrip: This seminar investigates discourses and politics around the fat body from a performance studies perspective. How does this "f-word" discipline and regulate bodies in /as public? How do dancers reveal these politics with special clarity? How might fat be a liberating counterperformance? We will examine the changing history, aesthetics, politics, and meanings of fatness using dance, performance, and media texts as key case studies. Intersectional dimensions of the fat body are central to the course. Emphasis primarily on the US. Assignments include written work and group performances. No dance experience necessary.
title: FAT: The F-Word and the Public Body

evals: If you are looking for a class to strengthen your technique, this is not the course for you. I enjoyed this course simply as a cathartic outlet to relieve stress and move the body. As a prior competition dancer, the style and repertory embodied a more experimental and nonconventional method of movement. I was able to learn more about modern dance. However, I'm not sure if it really improved my dance ability.
TAKE THIS CLASS PDF IS SO FUN
TINA FEHLANDT IS A BEAUTIFUL HUMAN BEING
Tina is awesome! She does a great job of teaching material at a good pace and gaging the dynamic of the class/students.
Tina is so so wonderful.
otherinfo: Students will perform in the Princeton Dance Festival at the Berlind Theater, December 1-3, 2017 (mandatory). Preparations require four additional rehearsals, several costume fittings, as well as a final technical and dress rehearsal the week of the performance.
grading: Design Project - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Several reflective written assignments, reading, viewing live and videotaped performances (approx. 2 hours outside class/week). Grading: 30% Other = Creative Assignments.
prereqs: DAN 213/219/220 or equivalent. Mandatory placement class on Tuesday, September 12 at 3:00 p.m., location tbd. This course MUST be taken in conjunction, in the same semester, with DAN 319A, DAN 320A, DAN 419A or DAN 420A (Choreography Workshop courses, one additional 2-hour class weekly). Placement in one of these "A" (Choreography Workshop) courses is by interview only. To secure your place in the appropriate "A" section, email Prof. Lazier (rlazier@) between April 10-21, 2017 and list previous composition experience at Princeton..
descrip: Technique and repertory course that focuses on developing technical expertise, expressive range, and stylistic clarity. In technique, students will examine concepts such as skeletal support, sequential movement, rhythm, and momentum to emphasize efficiency in motion. In repertory, students will learn and perform dances that represent diverse approaches to dance-making either through collaboration with faculty or by learning significant dances from modern and contemporary choreographers. The course encourages rich, subtle, and stylistically accurate renditions of choreography and engages students in collaborative learning.
title: Dance Performance Workshop: Repertory I

evals: Take it!
Zvi is a great teacher, who obviously sees his dancers as individual artists. He creates a very comfortable atmosphere for his dancers.
otherinfo: Students will perform in the Princeton Dance Festival at the Berlind Theater, December 1-3, 2017 (mandatory). Preparations require four additional rehearsals, several costume fittings, as well as a final technical and dress rehearsal the week of the performance.
grading: Design Project - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%

title: Dance Performance Workshop: Repertory II

evals: I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the dance department. Any class the Olivier teaches will be a lot of fun because that's the feeling he emits. His laughter is very contagious!
If you ever get the chance to work with Olivier, or even just to perform in PDF with the Dance Department definitely take advantage of that opportunity. It's incredible!!
otherinfo: Students will perform in the Princeton Dance Festival at the Berlind Theater, December 1-3, 2017 (mandatory). Preparations require four additional rehearsals, several costume fittings, as well as a final technical and dress rehearsal the week of the performance.

evals: I love Stuart.
Take this for your certificate!
This class is great and any dance class with Stuart is amazing!
otherinfo: Students will perform in the Princeton Dance Festival at the Berlind Theater, December 1-3, 2017 (mandatory). Preparations require four additional rehearsals, several costume fittings, as well as a final technical and dress rehearsal the week of the performance.

evals: I think the class will depend on your other students. I learned alot from my peers.
otherinfo: Grading: 10% Other = Prompt arrival and attendance in class
grading: Design Project - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 65%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: An individual research based project TBP at the end of the semester. A presentation of a case study of a research related art project. Five short assignments exploring forms of research, document, and artifact
prereqs: Any 200-level course offered by ART, CWR, DAN, MUS, THR, or VIS.
descrip: Over the past fifty years, many visual artists have taken up the process and methods of academic research as an impetus for works of art. Through readings, discussions, case studies, and studio projects, students in this class will engage the immediate context of the University as source material for their artworks, and as a means of exploring the effect that research and knowledge production might have on contemporary artistic practice. How does art produce knowledge? How does the knowledge it produces differ from that of other disciplines? In what ways do artists and researchers use similar source material to different ends?
title: Art As Research

evals: I'd recommend this to people who wish to explore some new materials from Latin America and the Iberian peninsula in a relatively unstructured setting.
If you enjoy doing close readings you will enjoy this course, if not I wouldn't recommend it.

If you want a wide-ranging sample of different texts and experiences relating to the Spanish/Portuguese worlds, take this; if you'd like a more concentrated look at something in particular, don't. Christina and Pedro are a delight.
It is not going to help you write your JP.
Make sure to ask questions when you have them! Both professors are extremely helpful and super nice!

Not sure what this course is going to look like next year given the feedback we gave Pedro and Christina at the end of the semester, but for the first go-round, this class was kind of messy. Seminar to seminar there didn't seem to be much of a thematic connection, readings varied wildly in length, and we only brought up our individual JPs twice. If you're looking for a course to workshop your JP and learn more about how to conduct research, this course probably won't help with that (at least in its current iteration!).
Probably too disorganized at this point to recommend. Not a methodology course so don't expect that. Very intelligent professors, but not the most exciting of classes, as structured.
Very good seminar. Christina and Pedro are great. They have differing opinions which is very helpful in discussions. Learned a lot in the class.
otherinfo: This class will participate in the Community-Based Learning Initiative (CBLI) and involves some fieldwork off campus. Students who complete SPA 330/POR 330 will be eligible to join the departmental field trip over the winter intersession. For more information, contact the departmental manager (Karen González, kareng@princeton.edu) or the instructors.
grading: Papers - 70%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Readings average 50-100 pages per week, and will be available in English, Spanish and/or Portuguese. Classes will be taught in English. Four required papers: two papers of approximately 1000 words (15% each); and two papers of approximately 1500 words each (20% each).
descrip: The junior seminar discusses major challenges to the study of culture, literature and society in Portuguese and Spanish-speaking countries. Focusing on text and audiovisual materials, students will acquire methodological tools to develop their own independent research projects. Topics may include: identity, memory, democracy, visual arts, health, race, gender, migration, global cities, sustainability, climate change, citizenship, and digital humanities. It is co-taught in English, with sources in English, Spanish and Portuguese. Students are welcome to use any of the three languages in their written work.
title: Junior Seminar: Spanish and Portuguese-Speaking Worlds

evals: Definitely take this class! The subject matter is really fascinating and the instructors do a really good job.
Do not take if you're not a comp lit major. Class is very boring, books are very dull, and you will find yourself not interested at all.

Fun class! Good variety of books, though be aware that nearly all come out of Europe. This is the only class I've taken in the English or Comp Lit departments, so I have no clue how it stacks up in terms of easy grading. Workload is fairly light.
I would recommend that anyone taking this class should do all of the readings, as they are worth it, and attend lectures, because they help add depth to the texts.
I would recommend this course to literally anyone.  You'll read books you'll never encounter in other classes.  Workload is very fair and manageable and the books are great.

Take this course, especially if you love to read! If you're going to take it, really commit to reading the books. I found it to be a wonderful selection of novels, none of which I would have picked up on my own. Liesl and Professor Bellos are both very knowledgable on the topic of world literature and fantastic lecturers and precept discussion leaders.
Take this course, it was super enjoyable and all the other students are pretty much there because they are interested too!
This course is a good comp. lit. course. There is no secondary literature, so you have to be prepared to do the readings and the thinking on your own.

This is a great course and the readings are interesting and varied. Anybody considering this course should focus on construction of the text, like structure of the passages and narrative techniques in addition to thematic content. Students should also focus on connections between the texts.

Unfortunately, this course may turn out to be a one-time deal, but if it is ever taught again, definitely take it! The books are really great (I'm keeping them all) and not a burden to read each week time-wise. Professor Bellos is of course an expert in many fields and brings a lot to the class. Professor Yamaguchi, if you're lucky enough to catch her teaching this again, brings a whole different perspective to the same novels. The back and forth conversational lectures between the two and the clashing between their analyses framed by their very different backgrounds make this an exciting course.
otherinfo: 20% of the student's grade will be for participation in weekly posts to Blackboard.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading: Approx. 10 short novels to read over the entire course, plus 20-25 pages secondary material each week. Writing: short weekly posts; mid-term paper of 10 pages; term paper of 20 pages.
descrip: For historical reasons most books that come into English are translated from just a few languages, creating a misleading impression of the spread of literature itself. This course provides an opportunity to discover literary works from languages with small reading populations which rarely attract academic attention in the USA. It also offers tools to reflect critically on the networks of selection that determine which books reach English-language readers; the role of literature in the maintenance of national identities; the role of translation; and the concept of "world literature" in Comparative Literary Studies.
title: Great Books from Little Languages

evals: Decent systems departmental but would not have taken otherwise.

Disappointing. Thought it would be a nice continuation of Operating Systems but was very much let down by the course structure. Professors Freedman and Jamieson put in the minimum level of effort into this class. The assignments were unnecessarily confusing and frustrating. While there are many interesting topics in distributed systems, they were presented haphazardly. I recommend staying away until this course gets revamped.

Distributed systems is a highly relevant topic today, so it's a shame that this class wasn't taught better. During the lectures the professors pretty much just went over a laundry list of algorithms without really synthesizing the core concepts behind distributed systems. Some of the assignment policies were very bad (in particular the staff changed their minds at the last minute, which is never nice), but since this was the first time this class was offered, I'm sure the policies will be better in the future. If you are good at learning on your own, then this class isn't that bad. The lectures covered a good range of topics and gave a solid "scaffolding" for understanding distributed systems. However in order to truly understand the subject (which I don't after taking this class) I feel that you need to use this course in conjunction with other materials / your own analysis.

Distributed systems is one of the most exciting, relevant topics in modern computer science. This was the first iteration of what I think is going to be a very successful CS course at Princeton.
The course overall was very informative, and engrained in me a new way of thinking about computer systems (i.e. reasoning about consistency, fault-tolerance, and scalability tradeoffs). It is also a great introduction to CS systems research, via its assigned papers (Raft, Chord, Dynamo, Spanner), and a must take for anyone interested in 1) doing research in the area, or 2) backend/infrastructure software engineering.
Don't take it until it has been offered a few times and perfected.

Great course overall, especially if you're interested in the content! The assignments were very light (except for the 4th one), and as a result didn't cover much of the lecture's content. Since almost everyone gets perfect scores on the assignments, the material in the lectures is what you'll primarily be graded on.
I will only recommend this class if you believe the lectures are easy to follow and the slides (or other readings) good for your learning style.
Interesting material although it would be better if given within a comprehensive framework. Lectures are ok, assignments not too bad.

Interesting material, but I would strongly recommend against this class if you are not COS. The material is not always intuitive, and the class is dominated by impressive COS students. The assignments are in golang, and there is little documentation but often lot of bugs.

It was kind of difficult to follow along with what was going on in class if you missed a few classes. Since almost all material is covered in only lectures, you can fall behind quickly (no textbook). This class does introduce you to Go and systems programming, which is valuable asset to have. The assignments are brutal if you do not have a good understanding of Go.

Pretty interesting course. Was pretty eye-opening for me. Learned a lot about distributed systems. Consistency, consensus, fault-tolerance, transparency, etc.

Learning and programming in Golang was fun too (when my programs worked). :^)

Probably a lower course load than other 400-level COS classes. Reading the papers is surprisingly helpful. The lectures go very fast, so you'll probably have to spend time on your own understanding the material.

Probably worth taking if you like systems stuff. It isn't too difficult if you have taken OS and networks already. There are a lot of cool ideas in lecture. The assignments can be difficult to debug because there is a lot of concurrency, but this class gives you way more experience writing concurrent code than any other (318 is a better introduction to currency though). You also get a lot of practice using Go. Since this was the first time the course was offered, I assume that it will be better next time.

Subject material isn't particularly difficult, although there are some pretty nuanced invariants about concurrent systems that make the exams feel probabilistic (i.e. because it felt impossible to get all the True/False questions right). The assignments are also pretty tough, especially if you don't have much experience writing in Go or thinking about concurrency issues (i.e. deadlock, race conditions, locking, etc). Don't expect much help from teaching staff on programming.
Take it if you're interested in distributed systems. It's not necessarily a must-take but it's good if you're interested. The workload isn't that bad.
Take this class only if you are interested. Read the papers! The exams depend on it.
Take this course! A valuable and interesting systems course!

The course covered some key ideas and many ancillary ideas in the field. However, there was a lack of precision in the presentation. And precision is very important to a subtle field like distributed systems. Only take the course if you are okay with getting a blurred overview of a subtle subject.

The course needs a lot of work. The lectures are the only place to learn the material, and they are very high level and gloss over many of the intricacies of the problems at hand. There isn't a textbook, which I really would have appreciated in studying for the midterm (the only place to learn about many of the relevant algorithms was the lecture slides). The problem sets are graded extremely leniently (the average score is >100%) which puts too much pressure on students to do well on exams in order to distinguish themselves.

The course overall isn't much work, most of the time you spend will be debugging concurrency issues in assignments (if you aren't careful when writing your code like me). Tests can be frustrating as they often test very specific details that you may not even think to study, but overall the course is very interesting and the topic is an important one for a COS major. Also a good way to learn Go.

This course covers a lot of interesting topics, and the applications are always obvious. It's a nice systems course in that it doesn't dive too deep into low-level programming, but instead focuses on concepts.
This course was a nice follow up to Operating Systems. Most of the small kinks should be worked by the next time they teach it. Recommended.

This is a new distributed systems course, and while it has some rough edges, I think it has potential in future semesters. Around 2/3 of the course is spent on foundational concepts and algorithms, and the remaining 1/3 focuses on a survey of various applications. Each lecture was well-taught, but all of the content put together felt a bit overwhelming at times, especially when it came to exams. The programming assignments are based in Go and can be tedious to debug, but are graded fairly. I think this is a class worth at least trying out if you've ever wondered what was up with distributed systems.

Very interesting subject matter, but this was its first year so it was very rough around the edges. If you can, I would suggest waiting until the 3rd year it is offered (aka not fall 2017 but fall 2018), as I bet things will be more smoothed out by then.

I'm a computer science major and I found the assignments were standard and the tests were a little more annoying/arbitrary than usual.

We learn a lot of interesting things, so I'd recommend it for that. The concepts in distributed systems are really important in real-world applications, even if you don't work directly with developing these systems. But the lectures aren't super interesting, even if they do communicate key ideas.
Will only get better, I took it the first time it was taught. Interesting topics and with more structure definitely a great course to take!
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 30%, Programming Assignments - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%
assgts: 4 programming assignments. Prior knowledge of Go or other system programming experience would be useful, but not required.
prereqs: COS 217 required. COS318 and/or COS 333 recommended.
descrip: This course covers the design and implementation of distributed systems. Students will gain an understanding of the principles and techniques behind the design of modern, reliable, and high-performance distributed systems. Topics include server design, network programming, naming, concurrency and locking, consistency models and techniques, security, and fault tolerance. Modern techniques and systems employed at some of the largest Internet sites (e.g., Google, Facebook, Amazon) will also be covered. Through programming assignments, students will gain practical experience designing, implementing, and debugging real distributed systems.
title: Distributed Systems

evals: Don't take this if you want to go in depth into entrepreneurship. It's much more of a breadth class, and focuses more on personal development. I learned a lot about myself and about how I relate with entrepreneurship through the group project. Also, don't pick your group based on the idea they propose because this semester everyone's radically changed by the end. Rather, choose people you will work well with.

If you're interested in entrepreneurship at all; if you care about changing the world for the better and want to weigh nonprofits vs. public sector vs. entrepreneurship as ways to impart that change; if you want to explore social entrepreneurship with not just naive inspiration but with REALISM and with the goal of creating a rigorous and sustainable business, take this course. Homework is minimal, but the readings & TED talks are very interesting and relevant. Lectures and class discussions are engaging, and often include guest speakers who are very relatable and inspiring and easy to talk to. Clinic (lab) is very self-driven and completely project-based, which is refreshing and fun! Professor Danner and Rosie are amazing and have so much wisdom and guidance to offer. All in all, great classmates, great topic, and a well-run class, that will leave you with a great capstone project that will give you a lot of great challenges & a final product to be proud of.
TAKE IT! Teaches you a lot about the basics of entrepreneurship in the context of social impact.

Take it! Doesn't matter what you study or what career you're planning to pursue, you should take this class because it opens a whole new world of possible paths for your future. The world needs more talented and dedicated students to resolve pressing issues in a sustainable and innovative fashion.
Take it. its a cool course

Take this course if you're at all interested in entrepreneurship, social entrepreneurship, big social problems, or non-profits. Take it if you want to learn how to work in teams better, if you want to better understand how your own organizations work. Take this class and you will be inspired to make the world a better place.

This course is a great introduction to entrepreneurship and provides you with a safe environment to consider different models to address UN SDGs. Unfortunately, there are limitations to what you can do within a clinic setting and the course can at times feel a bit too abstract and broad. And often a "create something out of nothing" type of feel.

This was a great class and you learn about a lot of different topics including social entrepreneurship, sustainable development goals (SDGs), developing economies, cultures, team dynamics, and much more. 

The lab component was helpful for the group projects and getting feedback on our ideas.
take this, just do it.
otherreq: EGR 488 not allowed if EGR 498, Ventures to Address Global Challenges topic taken.
otherinfo: Students who took EGR 498 "Special Topics in Social Entrepreneurship: Ventures to Address Global Challenges" are not eligible.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Other Exam - 20%, Design Project - 15%, Quizzes - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: There will be one written essay-style test that will cover excerpts from some readings; and several shorter pop quizzes on that week's reading. Students are required to keep a "Semester's Journal" in which to record your questions about the issues we are considering, and your ideas and/or reflections about those issues. Team 4-minute YouTube Video summarizing a venture idea of your own and explaining why it's a promising and sustainable idea.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course other than a curiosity about its focus and a willingness to engage actively in class discussions and assignments. Students from across the campus are welcome..
descrip: This course offers an interdisciplinary, hands-on, immersive opportunity to design services, technologies, products and ventures addressing the UN's 17 new Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through a diverse portfolio of high-impact solo and team-based projects. Our course will weave together three strands of analysis and action: in-classroom exposure to entrepreneurship/social venture development and exploration of selected SDGs, plus a weekly design clinic to give students a chance to develop their own venture and solution ideas.
title: Designing Ventures To Change the World

evals: Attend class and be engaged! It's not too hard and Professor Fleischer really cares about his students.
Take this class!! It's not a very hard ELE class, but it is rewarding and it is very interesting.
This course caters to the person that really has an interest in the topic.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Formal homework assignments, with an expected time commitment of six to ten hours per week. A final oral presentation will be given, which requires written slides.
descrip: This course gives a general introduction to biological and biomedical imaging. Topics covered include basic imaging theory, microscopy, tomography, and imaging through tissue. Both physical and computational imaging will be covered, across a variety of different modalities (including visible light, x-ray, MRI, and ultrasound). The gaps between current technology and limits suggested by information theory will be discussed.
title: Biomedical Imaging

evals: A cool course to get a bit more transparency from the University on their overall and day-to-day approach to sustainability. Be prepared to be in a class with some people who are pretty intense on sustainability though

Absolutely take this course. Its by far the best environmental seminar i've taken and perhaps one of my favorite classes in general. Its a unique opportunity to speak to the people generally in charge of sustainability and environmental decision making at Princeton and it lets you see how practical change is actually  made  and applied from research which is something class doesnt often offer. Aside from that even Professor Weber is just generally a very kind ad talented professor and the workload is absolutely manageable.
Be sure to start your paper sooner and don't treat the blog's as irrelevant to your paper but use them as the foundation for your research!
Fun class with a light workload but the 3 hour seminar can feel long at times

I would definitely recommend this course - it's such a fantastic opportunity to get to understand our own Princeton community and the systems that exist that support and work toward sustainability. It also works to get you thinking in a solution-driven manner towards environmental problems on a larger scale. The workload is not unmanageable at all, you get to make recommendations to the University, and overall I think it's a really important course for all students to take!
If sustainability is your thing then you MUST take this class!!
Recommend. Very self-driven & directed course.
Take it! It's a pretty chill environment with lots of room to explore your own interests.
Take it! It's extremely easy considering it fulfills the EM requirement and the topic is pretty interesting. Very light and overall the workload is extremely manageable.
Take it! Really opened my eyes to environmental issues, and the specific challenges that Princeton faces as an institution regarding environmental sustainability.
Take this course if you have any interest in the environment, and you learn a lot about campus!
The guest speakers are the real highlight in this class - get to speak with some cool people from the University. Get started on paper research early - besides this one paper, not that much work.
otherinfo: Students will have the opportunity to study various sustainability-related topics while benefiting from class visits from University staff and administrators, as well as expert faculty. The course is designed to apply critical thinking to a number of applied sustainability challenges from various disciplinary perspectives, and to do so within the context of both technological and behavioral solutions. Other = 20% Peer review of writings and 20% Reflection logs
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Readings of 60-80 pages per week will be from book chapters, ethics, natural and behavioral science papers, classmate writings, and University documents. Writing assignments will include blog entries, final paper drafts, and a final paper.
prereqs: Students who completed ENV ST05 in fall 2015 are not eligible to enroll in ENV 327 due to the overlapping course material.
descrip: Achieving sustained human and environmental health is a global priority given increasingly disruptive economic, social and environmental conditions. Evidence suggests that humanity is capable of producing sustainable technological and social solutions, but must do so between now and mid-century. This course explores social/ethical dimensions of the sustainability challenge through an evaluation of related ethics and psychology of social norms literature, and includes an exercise in proposing evidence-based solutions toward cultivating an ethos of sustainability on the Princeton campus as a demonstration-scale system.
title: Investigating an Ethos of Sustainability at Princeton

evals: Climate of the Earth provides a high-level survey and introduction to climate dynamics, examining what controls the structure of the atmosphere and ocean and what processes lead to climate variability in the past, present, and projections of the future. This course provides physically-based reasoning (e.g. radiative equilibrium) as well as a qualitative ?taxonomy? of observed climate phenomena (e.g. El Nino Southern Oscillation).

For those who have been interested in the oceans and the atmosphere and would like to see how the two are linked, take this class. Problem sets are quite reasonable, and both instructors are willing to stay after class and offer guidance. The instructors also have great insights from being in their respective fields for many years, and it will be difficult to learn these concepts from other places!
Pay attention in class, ask questions, review your notes after class as soon as possible, read the Marshall and Plumb and Wallace and Hobbs textbooks, and start the problem sets early.

This is a really good course to take if you are interested in general climate, even if you are not specifically working in this field. I found most of the information was good background knowledge to just have, even if I don't use it on a daily basis.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: Bi-weekly papers and homework
prereqs: MAT 201, GEO 361 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The goal of the course is to provide students with an introductory overview of the broad factors that determine our current climate, as well as past and future climates. We first build a foundation for understanding the principal features of today's climate. This includes examining the Earth's energy and water cycles, the processes determining the principal atmospheric and ocean circulation features, climate feedback processes, and dominant modes of variability. We then use this framework to interpret observational records of past climates, including ice age cycles, and to examine projections of future climate change.
title: Fundamentals of the Earth's Climate System

evals: Be prepared to have unresolved thoughts and comments after seminar, but talk about those with your friends and classmates after class! There is so much material to cover and so little time that it's difficult to feel satisfied, but just opening those cans of worms in an academic setting is a great feeling. Anne can be a little disorganized at times because she wants to include everyone's opinions in the discussion, but she is a wonderful and fascinating person and definitely someone you want to get to know.
Give readings and blog posts the time they deserve!

Give yourself time to not just read over the readings, but reflect on them as well. While the amount of material covered each week can seem overwhelming, the discussions are excellent and accessible, even if you don't have any previous experience in a GSS course. Highly recommend!
Go to all the classes! Participate in all discussions! And whatever you do, don't miss this course!

I usually hate when people say that a class is the best they've taken at Princeton, but this was TRULY THE BEST CLASS I'VE TAKEN AT PRINCETON. If I could take this class every semester, I would. You will not be disappointed. Also, it is a bit self-selective because only girls (or feminist men) want to take this class, but if you are neither and are even remotely considering taking this class, do it. It will (I truly believe) make you a better, or at least more understanding, person. TAAAAAKEEEEE ITTTTTTTTTT
Loved this course. Professor McClintock is an incredible and inspiring professor. Definitely take if you are interested in these topics!

McClintock is an amazing professor. She will talk about issues like sexual assault and sex workers in concrete terms. She is not afraid to delve into taboo topics. She is very kind and understanding about work. She is clearly on the forefront of thinking about intersectional race and gender ideology. We spoke in very broad terms in this class and very specific. It was a fair class with a decent amount of work but very doable! Put time into class and you will get a lot out of it

Please, for you and for the rest of us, take this course or something analogous to it. Talking openly about our issues is the quickest path to change. I think that something analogous to this course should be required by the University.

Take any course with Anne McClintock if you are a humanities-oriented, social justice advocate interested in talking about the "unmentionable" in an academic forum! It is the only class I've taken at Princeton that turns an eye to popular culture and validates it as an area worth studying.
Take anything with Professor McClintock!

This class was the first time I actually talked about things that people are normally afraid to mention. Brilliant teacher. Brilliant subject.  

This class should be mandatory for all students (especially males).

This was a really great class that I would recommend to anyone who wants to get a better understanding of our society in general and the issues that are central to our contemporary culture like gender and race.
This was a very good class for people who want to learn about gender studies. It was very inclusive and set in modern times. Professor McClintock is a very involved and intelligent professor.
otherinfo: Group Projects: The class will be divided into small groups. Each group will choose a theme for a collaborative project. Project themes can be wide-ranging, creative and inventive, but should relate to the themes of the course. Each group will give a class presentation on their project, using the resources of the new media: films, photographs, images, music, regular research. Group presentations should be as creative, inventive, compelling, original and informative as possible.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Approximately 100-200 pages of reading a week, depending on whether we are reading a book, or individual articles. Participants will submit two papers (one of which may be creative): one mid-term (about 8 pages), one final (about 12-15 pages). Participants will submit a journal entry every week for the whole class to read. We will also divide into collaborative group projects for class presentations.
descrip: Pleasure Power and Profit explores the intimate ways that sexualities and race are entwined in contemporary culture, historically, and in our own lives. Why are questions about sexuality and race some of the most controversial, compelling, yet often taboo issues of our time? Exploring films, popular culture, novels, social media, and theory, we engage themes like: race, gender and empire; fetishism, Barbie, vampires and zombies; sex work and pornography; marriage and monogamy; queer sexualities; and strategies for social empowerment such as: Black Lives Matter, the new campus feminism, and global movements against sexual and gender violence.
title: Pleasure, Power and Profit: Race and Sexualities in a Global Era

evals: Definitely take it
Definitely take this course! Prof. Fauzia is amazing and you'll love getting to know her.
Just take this course - you'll never look back and regret not signing up for Fauzia earlier.
Must take class if you are interested in South Asia.
Take it! Fauzia is an excellent professor, and this class gives you an excellent idea of the broader themes of South Asian literature.

Take this course! The poems we read changed the way I see the world and opened me up to ways of thinking in different cultural contexts. Professor Farooqui is amazingly insightful and encourages collaboration and discussion. Class is fun and I looked forward to it every time. The readings take less than an hour for each class, and the work load is light.

The readings and writing assignments are very reasonable. As long as you do read the stories/poems and come willing to share whatever observations you have (even if you don't fully understand the material), you will do fine. 10/10 would recommend.
This is a fantastic class, would highly recommend. Fauziaji is an extremely understanding and empathizing professor and this is just pure enjoyment and barely any work

This is a really great course if you're interested in the subject. Fauzia knows a lot and is super willing to bend the syllabus to address what her students are interested in. Would definitely recommend this course as a nice and relatively easy course to add to your courseload.

We covered a very broad range of South Asian literature and Fauzia did a very good job giving a broad survey of the South Asian literary tradition. The discussion based style of the class where we broke out into small groups to discuss the readings and then came together as a class to discuss was refreshing in Princeton's academic scene. Feedback on written assignments is not given, though. Very reasonable amount of work.
Wonderful course. Professor Farooqui is not only a wonderful person, but an engaging professor and the class as a whole is a really great learning experience.
definitely take as a fun elective
take every class taught by this woman. she's great
otherinfo: While materials from various regional South Asian languages will be included, the primary focus will be on texts originally written in Hindi, Urdu, and English. Students do not need to know any South Asian languages as all course materials including literary texts will be presented in English. Grading: Other = 20% short writing assignments
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading assignments will consist of selected literary materials. Writing assignments will focus on the interpretation, analysis and critique of literary texts with occasional scope for creative writing.
descrip: This course introduces students to the richness and diversity of South Asian literature produced in vernacular languages and in English. Texts represent major themes and popular trends in the 20th and 21st century; and we discuss them in historical and literary contexts. Topics include cultural renaissance and nationalism; progressive- Marxist literary movement; modernist and experimental literature; feminist, dalit (oppressed castes), and diaspora literature; and various postmodern and contemporary literary trends.
title: Popular Trends in South Asian Literature

evals: Consider your reasons for taking this course, as it is more committed than past language courses I have taken.
Highly recommend this course for people who are interested in learning more Korean!
TAKE THIS CLASS. ? ??? is a great professor and you'll learn a lot in this class
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Quizzes - 20%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Vocabulary list and Reading text. Short sentence writing. One 2-3 page paper.
prereqs: KOR 108, 302 or permission of instructor..
descrip: The fourth-year Korean is designed to promote students' proficiency to the advanced-mid level and to enhance their continued development of literacy skills in Korean. Various authentic reading materials are reviewed in class discussion, presentation skills are emphasized, and a wider range of formal vocabulary is introduced.
title: Integrative Korean I

otherinfo: Readings are primarily in Arabic, and therefore this course is intended for students with interests in the intellectual, cultural, and political history of the postwar Arab world, or for students who would like to gain experience in working with Arabic-language sources.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 100-200 pages of reading, not all of which is in Arabic; weekly reading responses (in English, ~ 2 pp.); critical review essay; final paper
prereqs: Reading knowledge of Arabic.
descrip: A reading course that focuses on how Syrian intellectuals and literary writers have engaged with problems of ideology, aesthetics, and politics, among other topics. We will consider a wide range of sources including works of philosophy, political essays, cultural criticism, and novels.The course is open to both undergraduates and graduate students, and the course material may be adapted to suit student interest and ability.
title: Topics in the History of Modern Syria - Intellectual History and Arabic Literature

evals: I can't speak for the singers in the course because I was one of the accompanists, but I would say that if you're an accompanist, make sure to stay on top of the music - you'll be assigned a lot of it! Also, be prepared to rehearse outside of class with the singers - this adds an extra time commitment.
If you can really sing, this is a great class.
Incredible class! Definitely take it. Not very difficult in terms of workload, but an incredible experience. Even just auditioning is worth it!
The class really focused on the performance, really great opportunity to perform on a stage and sing with an orchestra! Not a huge time commitment.
take this class!!!
