otherinfo: Class includes 6 hours of formal instruction time per week, but each enrolled student will only be required to attend 3 hours of formal class time to be approved by instructor.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 60%, Other (See Instructor) - 40%
assgts: Reading and preparing opera scores for musical and staging rehearsals.
prereqs: Students are admitted by audition only.
descrip: Vocal and instrumental students will rehearse and perform complete operas or evenings of select opera scenes in Richardson Auditorium with full orchestra.
title: Opera Performance

evals: A great introduction to issues in philosophy, psychology, and neuroscience. Not too difficult of a workload and a great opportunity to do some interdisciplinary studies.

Be prepared to write a lot of papers. The freedom you get in choosing the topic allows you to write about something interesting, every time. It's a very rewarding course. You feel accomplished. Grace Helton was amazing.
Good class if you are interested in philosophy or cognition! Grace and Mark are both really great!
I recommend this course as an introductory philosophy course. The professor is great at answering questions and providing extra help. There are several long essays assigned.

I would take this course if you like philosophy and writing. This course is not science based, so although we look at different social experiments, it's more from a philosophical perspective, to see whether or not the results support an argument or not. This is something to keep in mind.

If you like logical arguments and have an interest in psychology, definitely take this course.  The readings are chill (as philosophy readings go), and lectures are very comprehensive yet easy to follow.
Yes, for sure.

give this course a shot. I learned a lot and felt as though it really gave a comprehensive introduction to relatively basic topics in philosophy. Grace Helton is engaging and approachable and if you make use of office hours, you will be successful in your papers. Do the readings.
grading: Papers - 60%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Before most lectures, students will be asked to read two-to-three article-length readings. Coursework will consist of: 3 short papers, 1 longer term paper based on one of the short papers, and participation. Total number of pages the Student is expected to read per week: 30-40
prereqs: A first course in philosophy or psychology is recommended but not required..
descrip: Introduces students to theoretical issues that arise in the scientific study of the mind: 1) evaluate the computationalist approach to studying the mind 2) consider several issues in cognition, including the proper characterization of inference and the issue of how judgments are formed and regulated 3) explore several debates in perception, including the question of whether perception can be influenced by desires and the issue of which kinds of features we can perceive 4) we will review three major theories of emotion--cognitive theories, feeling theories, and perceptual theories -- and evaluate these in light of recent empirical results.
title: Introduction to Philosophy of Cognitive Science

evals: Absolutely take this course if you are interested in film and the Portuguese language. Professora Cooney is such a wonderful woman and professor, and the films we watched were interesting

Be sure to start your two-pagers early. Though they're short biweekly assignments, they have a way of sneaking up on you. Beyond that, don't be afraid to contribute. Often, what seem like the craziest ideas are often the most provocative!
Great class! The work load is very light, and classes are very interesting.
Great class, amazing teacher!
I would recommend this class. If you are interested in Portuguese-language cinema and musings on saudade/nostalgia, this is the class for you!

If you are looking to improve your Portuguese skills and are interesting in Portuguese film, this is a great course. Nicola is one of my favorite professors, and her class discussions are always great because they're so open and engaging. Strongly recommend (but only if you are interested in analyzing and writing about films).
Nicola is a great teacher, class was dynamic, take if you're interested in luso culture and film.
Professora Cooney is great! And this course was really interesting as a look into Portuguese culture.
Take it! Nicola is the best.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: The course will meet twice weekly and will be discussion-based. Each class a student will be responsible for briefly presenting on a topic to the rest of the group. Students will write six short response papers (two pages, double-spaced in Portuguese) during the term on topics of the students' choosing and one longer final paper (10 pages) in lieu of exam.
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course will explore the supposedly "untranslatable" concept of saudade from a number of angles. We will examine the political, economic, cultural and aesthetic manifestations of saudade and its myriad social implications through analysis of literary and sociology texts, music, cinema, and more from across the lusophone world. Particular attention will be paid to the prevalence of saudosismo in pop culture where classical texts and forms often make surprising appearances.
title: Screening Saudade

evals: A decently taught stats course. There is a bit more emphasis on the programming (R) compared to statistical concepts. It may help to know some R, but I was fine without knowing any R.

A great course. From what I've heard, much better taught than the other introductory statistics courses. Besides that, this course will leave you with a good working knowledge of R, which will be extremely helpful in future research (e.g. JP's and Theses) and potentially even your career.

A painless way to get a QR or fulfill the stats prerequisite for WWS. You get to work with real datasets that are relevant to politics/sociology which is pretty cool, plus the assignments are a piece of cake.
Although the learning curve for R is pretty steep, I would recommend this for anyone who wants a healthy challenge (but not like COS 126).

As a person who has never taken a COS or statistics or calculus class, I found this course challenging, but doable and ultimately rewarding. There are many supporting resources available and all the instructors are engaging, enthusiastic and encouraging. You will also be pleased with the valuable skills that you'll have gained from this course.

Be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to this class outside outside of lecture/precept (especially if computer programming is not something that does not come naturally to you). That being said, it is a good class and I have learned more in this class than in any other I have taken at Princeton (both in terms of statistics and in terms of coding in R)
Be prepared to work hard!
Be prepared to work hard.  This course is extremely challenging.  Try not to get behind.
Challenging but worth it!
Definitely take - a really important skill taught by very engaging and caring professors. You will work hard but you will not regret it.
Definitely take this class if you want to satisfy the Woody Woo stats requirement or have a general interest in learning R.
Definitely take this instead of Woody Wu stats if you're going to do Woody Wu. The lectures are a little disorganized, but Kosuke and Maggie are both great. Get Hannah for precept, she is amazing!
Don't take it if you can avoid it, if you must take it, balance your schedule accordingly and take a class in R beforehand.
Easy course if you are quantitative and have coding experience.
Go to all the lectures. You never know what may be helpful.
Good class. I learned a decent amount.
Good course, gives you an insight into the social side of stats as a COS major.
Good stats course, be prepared to do the readings. Course is a LOT of work, have to be willing to commit.

I definitely would recommend this course if you have to take a stats class at Princeton. It was well taught, there were a lot of opportunities for help, and I feel like I really know how to code in R now. That being said, it still required a ton of time (6-10 hours outside of class/precept time each week) and was still difficult.

I only took this course because I had to and it made me consider changing my major so that I could drop it. Lectures are unnecessary. You can skip all of them, read the textbook, go to precept and be fine. It's ridiculous that this is supposed to be an intro course yet there's a final exam due before winter break and a final project due on Dean's Date. They need to pick one. There's a combination of people with coding experience and people who have never done anything like this before in the class and they make no distinction between the two. They basically expect you to know R by the second or third week. Making this a required course was the cruelest thing my department has ever done to me.

I think they oversold the difficulty of the course, but any programming experience or prior stats knowledge is very helpful. From what I've heard from my friends in other departments, it's one of the best stats classes.

I took this as a statistics course to fulfill medical school requirements, and I loved the book, the instructors, and the interesting assignments. It took a significant amount of work a week, but if you read the book before class and do the swirls, it can be awesome! I did come into the class with some basic coding knowledge (which really helped with the R) and with some statistics knowledge (which helped with the statistics content), so for me sometimes this class went a little slowly. However, I think on the whole it was reasonably paced for most people and had many opportunities to get help and tutoring, which I appreciated.

I took this to fulfill the POL analytic requirement but I would recommend it to anyone interested in getting a better foundation in statistics or learning how to use R for social science. The course is very organized and it's satisfying to make progress over the skills taught.
I was scared of taking this course because I was worried about how hard it was but TAKE IT. It's actually very reasonable and SO worth taking.

I would recommend taking this course only if you are very concerned about finding the most comprehensive way to learn R and use statistics. If you are just filling your distribution requirement, do not subject yourself to the endless purgatory that is POL 345. The course book is simply a draft that is hard to follow and has many holes in it. There are no secondary readings. The teaching is unbelievably poor, to the point where I would feel less confident coming out of lectures than going into them. Communication is poor, and instructions on problem sets, finals, and projects are vague.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who wants to get better at data manipulation and analysis, or wants to become familiar with R. To really succeed, a student needs to put in some of their own time to get familiar with R. Without an understanding of R functions, problem sets and exams become much more challenging and time-consuming.

If you have to take a stats class, POL 345 is a great way to go! I am a very left-brain thinker and had never coded before, but I really appreciated the many resources this course provides to help you understand, learn and deeply engage with the material. If stats might be a struggle for you, this is a fantastic course in which to learn stats/data analysis/coding.
If you're in this class you're probably being forced to so just read the textbook and start the psets/exams early and you'll be fine.

If you're new to coding and stats, as I was, be prepared to work your ass off.  I'm glad I took the class for my departmental, but it took an insane amount of dedication to get by.  Take advantage of office hours, extra credit, compass workshops, McGraw, tutoring, and your friends. Be prepared to spend a ton of hours on this course.
If you're taking a stats course or are interested in coding in r, do it.
If you're taking the course to fulfill a requirement, you are taking a well-taught, graciously graded, only somewhat difficult course. You won't love it, but it'll be fine, and helpful down the road.
If you're taking this course it's probably a requirement for your major. It's a good way to learn R, but it requires a lot of time.
If you've never worked with R/coding software before, this course is tough and moves fast, but work hard on your psets/ask questions and you will survive.
Interesting course with real-world applications, good option to fill requirement. Take advantage of office hours.
It is an OK statistics course. There is considerable focus on coding, so the coverage of statistical concepts is weaker.
It's a good course for stat if you do all the work which involves teaching yourself  decent amount, not an impossible task
Keep up with the readings and if you haven't coded before make sure to become comfortable with R early on.

Not the most fun course, but it's bearable if you actually put in time to read the textbook and PRACTICE code. You should know that they cover a lot all at once. They expect you to be able to learn coding, statistical concepts and an understanding of math/calculus is low key helpful for understanding the stats.
Not too hard but extremely frustrating. The problem sets are very time consuming as are the exams. Lectures are pretty boring.
Of all the stats classes I have heard that this is one of the better ones, but still be aware when you sign up that it isn't that great.

Okay course. If you need to take a stats class but want to stay out of the true "math-y" stats classes, this is a good choice. Be warned, however, that this class involves a ton of coding which can be hard to grasp at first. Hard to get much better than a B.
Only take it if you have to. Even then, equip yourself with a background in Stats and some intro to R. Work hard as hell from day one; you'll certainly wish you had at the end.

Only take this class if you are required to for a major/certificate. The class presents a very wide introduction to R, and if you are not familiar with coding this class is like learning a whole new language in a semester. Prepare to dedicate quite a bit of time to the workload.
Take it for an easy stats class.
Take it if you have to or are interested in social statistics.
Take it if you want to learn R!
Take it! Really useful and intersting.
Take it, a useful statistics course can be really helpful to understanding data
Take this course if you're planning to be involved in the field of Politics, Economics, or any kind of humanities.

Take this course to get a QR out of the way. Even if you aren't a super quantitative oriented person, you can do well and succeed if you put in a bit of effort and actually do the assignments. This is one of the most "fair" courses I think I've ever taken because they prepare you for what you'll be tested on very well and pointedly. Also R is really cool to learn as a person with no background in coding. It's a bit of a steep learning curve, but once you get it (there's a lot of help available) it's really not that bad. The professors also want you to succeed which is a great part of this course.

Take this course!  It will eat up a lot of time, but is in the end invaluable if you want to understand basic statistics and how to code using R. Chances are you're taking this as a requirement. If your non-Politics department accepts Pol/Soc Stats, take this instead of your department's option! Prof Imai and Prof Frye are awesome!
Take this if you have to. Keep up with the swirl activities and try to actually read the textbook. It'll be helpful for understanding lecture.
The best of any of the stats classes, way better than econ stats, orf stats, woody woo stats, etc. You learn R which is very helpful. Kosuke is great. Really recommend this if you need a stats.

The class did teach you things overall and even though it had its tough moments, I would recommend it.  You can get as much help as needed on the problem sets and the exams are similar to the problem sets so you could good practice throughout the year.  I'd recommend taking advantage of every opportunity they provide, be it going to workshops or meeting with your preceptor before the final project.  Be careful about a quiz that happens around thanksgiving though, as it's an actual math-type quiz thats worth 10%.  Other than that, so long as you make sure to do the readings and try your hardest, you'll have the opportunity to do well in the class overall.  In other words, make sure you try throughout the semester.

The key to succeeding in the Problem Sets, I feel, is going to McGraw and collaborating with other students. Check with one another and if you don't know what you're doing wrong, ASK. In lectures, SPEAK UP! It's important to slow the lecturer down if he/she is going to quickly, and no one will mind at all (because half the class is not paying attention and the lecturer is always so nice). I would absolutely take this course - one final piece of advice, though: DO YOUR SOCRATIC SWIRLS ON TIME. Sometimes, they can sneak up on you but they literally take like fifteen minutes, on average.
There is both a final project and final exam so keep that in mind. Coding experience is definitely  recommended prior to enrolling in the course, but you can survive without it.

This class is very challenging but you learn a lot. It will definitely take up a lot of time for psets and the take homes but you will learn a lot. Go to lecture and do the readings so you are prepared.

This class is very coding-heavy: there is substantial stats content but you'll spend at least half your time figuring out R. If you want a more theoretical/mathy experience, take another class. That said it is good preparation for the sorts of things you'll need to do for most quant independent work in the social sciences, so it's worth taking if you're a POL/SOC concentrator.

This class is very confusing and not the best taught.  Do not take it if you are a freshman, unless you have extensive statistics background.  If you do take it, go to office hours and make extra efforts to understand - otherwise you will find yourself stuck in the second semester.  The coding is not the problem; the complex statistics and equations is.  Would not recommend.
This course teaches you important skills. It is not too much work. Not too engaging day to day.
This is a good introduction to statistics. The intersections with politics and sociology made it much more interesting.
This is a great course. Highly recommend it if you plan to do research in the future.

This is a very well organized and well taught class about a very interesting and useful subject. I struggled quite a bit with it, but at the end, I felt like I had learned a lot. If you need to take a statistics class, this is the one you should go with. Don't even try WWS200 unless you have to - trust me. Also, don't be scared about learning R. I had zero coding experience, but I caught on pretty easily and there are always resources to help you out.
This is class is time-consuming and difficult. However, it is definitely worth it. Get a head start on the PSETS!

This is definitely one of the better statistics courses at Princeton. Read the book! If you don't, you will be lost at sea. The course is designed so that you teach yourself and fill in the holes during lecture and precept; that being said, you need to commit to learning the concepts and how to code! Go to workshops and McGraw.

Took this course for QR and WWS pre-req requirements. Definitely recommend over WWS stats, but it's a difficult course. Caused me quite a bit of anxiety over the course of the semester, but grading was a lot better than expected (ex: I usually got 60% of points on exams, which equated to a B), and probably could have done better if I had kept up with assignments and readings. Definitely go to tutoring sessions, do P Sets with classmates, and go to extra credit sessions. Teaching could be better -- I feel like I know how to do each concept only one way (in the context of the example with which we were taught), but cannot do it independently.
Very difficult at the beginning but once you learn R things finally made sense. Piazza was very helpful, so take advantage of it.
Well taught, but difficult.

You'll come out with it and you'll feel like you can do some real stats and you have real-world relevant skills. The class itself can feel pretty unsatisfying while you do it but I think it'll be quite good for you to take if you think you could be working with data at any point in your life.
You'll have to work hard to do well in this course but is it SO worth it. The skills you are so relevant and applicable. Get Adeline as a preceptor.
all stats class suck, in this one you will learn R, which is pretty hard without any coding experience.
do not take it unless you have to.
not the greatest Princeton has to offer but much better than ECO stats (I took both)
take it if you have to, good intro to R course but don't take to learn actual stats
otherinfo: This course satisfies a requirement for Politics, Sociology, and WWS majors. It also satisfies the foundations of statistics requirement for the Certificate Program on Statistics and Machine Learning. NOTE: Precepts will meet for 80 minutes, once a week.
grading: Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Programming Assignments - 10%, Quizzes - 10%, Lab Reports - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 10%
assgts: Weekly problem sets that include both analytical questions and computer programming. This course requires students to keep up with materials each week through frequent problem sets and quizzes.
prereqs: (1) High School algebra. Familiarity with elementary probability theory and computer programming is useful, but not required. (2) The course also serves as the prerequisite for students who wish to learn more about statistics in POL 346..
descrip: Would universal health insurance improve the health of the poor? Do patterns of arrests in US cities show evidence of racial profiling? What accounts for who votes and their choice of candidates? This course will teach students how to address these and other social science questions by analyzing quantitative data. The course introduces basic principles of statistical inference and programming skills for data analysis. The goal is to provide students with the foundation necessary to analyze data in their own research and to become critical consumers of statistical claims made in the news media, in policy reports, and in academic research.
title: Introduction to Quantitative Social Science

otherinfo: This course will meet for 1.5 hours per week for the whole semester.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course is intended specifically for students who are currently conducting sociological fieldwork or writing up empirical papers on the basis of fieldwork. Students who are currently in the field are encouraged to participate remotely. Part one deals mainly with issues of writing.
title: Advanced Sociological Fieldwork I (Half-Term)

otherinfo: Requirements/Grading: "Other 20%" is homework assignment.
grading: Design Project - 30%, Take Home Final Exam - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 10-20 pages of reading (or equivalent) and/or 1 page of composition per week.
prereqs: JPN 402 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course emphasizes continued development of four skills used in academic or professional settings. Materials include novels, essays, reports, films, and documentaries. The goal of this course is "superior" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.
title: Contemporary Japanese Language and Culture I

evals: Awesome class - great exercise and will push you out of your comfort zone. Alexandra really cares about her students. It's a great way to set aside a few hours a week to not care about the other stresses of Princeton.
Great course! A lot of daily work for a DAN class, but really worthwhile. Fun, easy, and thought provoking.
It'll definitely feel like you're taking a contemporary dance class. Alexandra is a lot of fun but she can challenge you as well.

Really fun class - you dance both days each week, along with discussion and meditation. Alexandra is amazing and everyone in the class really bonded with her and with each other. The dancing is not too difficult but it does challenge you to perform, express emotion, and have fun with a new group of people. There are readings and small writing assignments each week, and a few choreographing assignments outside of class.
Relax and enjoy it!

TAKE THIS CLASS! Alexandra has taught me so much more than how to dance. This class was a comfortable space where I found myself and really took the time to de-stress from other classes and really let go. take it! I wish i could take it again!
TAKE THIS CLASS. Most fun class I've taken at Princeton. The class got really close to each other and Alexandra is a star.
Take the opportunity to learn about the movements you body can make, and the more you step up to try a phrase, the more comfortable with your body you will feel.
Take this class!

This was an incredible class! Unlike other dance classes some of my friends were in this semester, we were always on the move in this class. If you are looking for a class to get your heart rate up, this is a class to take. Alexandra did a great job of taking things slow when it came to teaching choreography, so even if you are a beginner it is pretty easy to get the hang of the moves. If you are an athlete, you may want to think hard about taking this class, I found practice a little more tiring on the days that I had dance before practice.
grading: Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Several reflective written assignments (approx. 2 hours outside class/week); reading, viewing live and videotaped performances (approx. 2 hours outside classes/week), several short response papers and a final project.
descrip: Designed for students with minimal dance experience who are curious about contemporary dance techniques and choreography. Perfect for students who have taken other intro level dance courses and who want to broaden their dance knowledge and deepen their physical skill and experience. Students will try on various identities within dance - mover, creator, performer, writer, historian - in an attempt to holistically learn about Contemporary Dance. Readings and viewings will inform the creation of choreographic studies and invite students to consider issues debated by today's dance artists.
title: Introduction to Contemporary Dance

evals: For undergraduates: If you've taken ELE 304, which really leads directly to this course, then you'll have a good idea of whether you would like to continue down this track. Make sure you know for fundamentals - device physics, single-ended, differential amplifiers, and time-constant analysis, because these are expanded upon in this course.
It is a good introductory course for students looking to work in the field of high-speed circuits.
Needs strong circuit background. Strongly recommended for students who are interested in RF/high-speed circuit designs.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 25%, Design Project - 30%, Problem set(s) - 25%
descrip: This course aims to cover the fundamentals of the wireless and high-speed integrated circuits for future wireless technology. We cover analysis and design of high-speed and wireless ICs that enables modern wireless communication across device-circuits-system level abstractions. The understanding of these fundamental concepts prepares students for a wide range of advanced topics from circuits and systems for communication to emerging areas of sensing and biomedical electronics.
title: Wireless and high speed integrated circuits and systems

evals: Definitely take this class. Celeste is an awesome person and an even better professor. Not much work and the psets and projects are straightforward. Definitely attend and pay attention in lecture as it will save you from wasting time on the problem sets
Great class to take if you are interested in the field of bioengineering. Celeste is a great professor and the work associated with this class is very manageable.

If you have any interest in the topics, definitely take this course! You don't have to be an engineer or aspiring one. The class was genuinely very interesting and fun for me. The work was very manageable and the exams were open notes which was extremely helpful and made the class even better for me because I didn't have to waste time memorizing facts (which is not my strong suit). Also, Professor Nelson was very open to adjusting the class discussion and topics if you informed her of something you were specifically interested in which I thought was awesome. A great STN too!
If you're interested in the topic, take the course, it's not too difficult.
Interesting materials and Professor Nelson is a fantastic lecturer. Highly recommended even if you are not CBE major.
It would be helpful to have taken biology and chemistry before the course. It will help with understanding different processes and concepts that are applied in technology.

It's an interesting class and is non-science major friendly!  The professor is very patient and open to questions!  Also, this class is very relevant and provides basic knowledge that maybe everyone should try to have some exposure to.

TAKE IT! You talk about really cool devices/solutions to problems affecting millions of people worldwide. And Celeste works really hard to make our discussions involve our own experiences/interactions. And her work in her lab is really interesting too! She has a very clear vision of what she wants this class to be and makes it really fun and recognizes that the material we learned this semester could totally be out of date in 10/20 years cause of how these advances/technologies are progressing
TAKE IT.
Take if you want to learn about basic biomedical engineering!

Take this class and don't be scared away if you're not an engineer or a science person! I learned a lot and fee like a developed a deeper appreciation for bioengineering. You really don't need to have a detailed understanding of biology/engineering at all ? the professor/preceptors are very supportive and do a great job of starting with the basics and breaking the material down so everyone can understand it! You will learn so many cool things ? I strongly recommend it!
Talk to Celeste- she's really sweet and likes talking to students. Just do the homeworks and projects and you'll do well.

The course mainly only covered material taught in high school biology/anatomy classes.  The grading of psets, projects, and exams was also very vague, so if you get overly concerned about your grade, do not take this class!

This course is interesting if you have not studied bioengineering before. The projects are engaging but the lectures are not very deep. Think a lot about what you want to get out of the course before taking it.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 20%, Design Project - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Reading: One-two chapters per week
descrip: Cloned cats. Genetically modified organisms. Pacemakers. Insulin pumps. Bioengineering is by nature an interdisciplinary field focused on understanding and improving the human condition. This course will provide a hands-on applications-based introduction to the field for both engineering and non-engineering students.
title: Fundamentals of Bioengineering

evals: A good theory course for both undergrad and grad students, especially if you have interest in software verification.
Definitely recommend
Do the readings and schedule meetings with the professor even if it's outside of office hours.
I think this course is a great introduction to many of the techniques/algorithms used in automated verification (with an emphasis on SAT/SMT based methods).
Interesting introduction to program verification that covers a lot of ground. A very manageable class to satisfy a Theory requirement.
Probably the most useful and applicable COS theory course (and accessible, if you don't like math). Highly recommend.
Take it! Great theory that doesn't demand a ton of time. Aarti is a great instructor.

Take the course as theory departmental if you are an undergrad. Professor Gupta is very reasonable, and really cares about you learning the material for the sake of learning and not for just making it hard. She really tries to teach her students and allows them to engage with the material in a manner that is reasonable and fair.
Take the course only if you're going into PL.
The assigned reading is very interesting and are very helpful when trying to study the subject.
The course contained a lot of material that I had not been exposed to during prior PL courses at another university. It's a good choice for fulfilling the theory requirement as CS PhD student.

This course gives a great overview of different techniques for automated reasoning and its use in practice. If you work on large software systems, sooner or later you will touch upon the techniques presented in the lecture. If you are not a theory person, I highly recommend this course for the theory requirement because it is very accessible.

This is a good course if you are looking to knock out your theory requirement for COS.  It is challenging but manageable, and Professor Gupta is great.  However I would not take this course unless you needed it to fulfill a theory- there are much better COS classes out there.
Yes

take it!!! probably one of the easier theory classes, and aarti is great. the class itself is not too theoretical because aarti likes emphasizing the practical, applicable side of software verification. it's also logic based, so it's more intuitive than math-y, which i liked.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Design Project - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 5%, Problem set(s) - 40%
prereqs: COS 226 and COS 326 (or equivalent programming experience).
descrip: An introduction to algorithmic techniques for reasoning about software. Basic concepts in logic-based techniques including model checking, invariant generation, symbolic execution, and syntax-guided synthesis; automatic decision procedures in modern solvers for Boolean Satisfiability (SAT) and Satisfiability Modulo Theory (SMT); and their applications in automated verification, analysis, and synthesis of software. Emphasis on algorithms and automatic tools.
title: Automated Reasoning about Software

evals: Definitely take this class! It's hard work, but worthwhile if you have any interest in Latino lit or culture and want to learn more.

I would recommend taking this course if you're really interested in BOTH Latino Studies and English. I took it because of the Latino Studies aspect, and I found the English part of the course made it a bit difficult to get through. Sometimes we would get caught up on discussing a single word in a reading and never get to discussing the actual ideas or arguments of the reading relating to Latino issues. Although I think there's a time and place for close readings like this, I think that Latino issues are much more important to focus on that this. That being said Professor Huerta is an absolutely amazing person.
TAKE THIS. TAKE IT TAKE IT. PROFESSOR HUERTA IS AN ANGEL ON THIS CAMPUS AND THE READINGS ARE MINDBLOWING.

Take it! Professor Huerta is a smart, wonderful professor-- one of the best I've had at Princeton. A course on Latino Literature was much-needed and this is an excellent one engaging texts from the 19th up to the 21st.
Take this course! Prof Huerta is brilliant and the workload is manageable - readings are great!

This class is so fun and still very doable for non-humanities people. Although if you are going to take this class, never leave the readings to do all in one night! It's worth spending your time with it.
otherinfo: Distribution: Diasporas
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Regular reading responses, three close readings (2-3 pages), final paper proposal, final paper (10 pages).
descrip: Latina/os have long been present in the story of the United States. Yet, contemporary media headlines often report an increasing, and often alarmist, "browning" of America. These headlines often rely upon stereotypes of Latina/os--morphing them into a static and falsely unified identity category. We will examine to Latina/o literature and art to note how such headlines leave out many stories. Looking at Latina/o narratives, we will consider the uniqueness of each piece in relation to place, history, and gender. Attention will be paid to how these aesthetic pieces perform modes of resistance.
title: An Introduction to Latino Literature and Culture - Latina/o Literary Worlds

evals: A fun and engaging class with a relatively light workload. Definitely take if you would like to look at some fascinating social issues while getting a taste of linguistics concepts.

Definitely take this class if you are interested in linguistics or just want to get a better sense of what linguistics is. Not too hard, so also good if you're trying to fulfill a distribution requirement.

Definitely take this class! Professor Kalin is so kind and wonderful and she always makes class fun! The topics are super interesting and really make you think about how linguistics shapes our lives. The readings for the class do not take too much time and are always interesting to learn about.
Definitely take this course!  Professor Kalin is amazing.  The lectures and readings are so interesting and the coursework is very manageable.
Enjoy! Prof. Kalin is the best. And this was only her first semester at Princeton -- wow!!

Even if you haven't taken any linguistics classes before, you should definitely go for this course! I took it as a distribution requirement initially, but got very engaged in class over time. Lectures and precepts are intellectually stimulating, and Professor Kalin is a genuinely nice and great lecturer.
Great course, definitely worth taking. Try your best to get Professor Kalin's precept, she's great.
Highly recommend. Professor Kalin is the best. She is a wonderful teacher and is so much fun to be in class with. Also, the class is pretty easy, and is very interesting!

I would whole-heartedly advise: Speak up! Don't be afraid to say what you're thinking in discussions and lectures. Do not worry about what other students may think of your ideas; if you make a faulty argument, you learn from it, and by actively discussing you learn how to be a better contributor. State your ideas aloud often, don't be shy--you may regret it if you don't, as I do.

If I could make any one course at Princeton required for every student, it would be this course.  It was incredible, eye-opening, and so FUN!  Take it!  You will learn so much about topics in language that you probably didn't realize were important, but will want to discuss with everyone once you learn their implications.  I had no background in linguistics or even much initial interest (it seemed like a fun distribution requirement), but this class changed the way I view language and now feel like I have to tell everyone about this cool thing:  sociolinguistics.
Interesting material that is covered well, despite the survey nature of the course. Great distribution requirement.
Take this course, it was great.
Take this course.

The best part of this course is Professor Kalin, who is great at encouraging everyone to participate and at actually listening to her students. I enjoyed the graded components of this course though the final paper is definitely much more challenging than all the earlier tasks. The topics are interesting and important and fun and this class lends itself to the precept model well. I like the flexibility with which the class was taught, letting us decide how long we spent on topics based on how much there was to talk about. I also like that Prof Kalin took our midsemester feedback into account truly for the second half. Recommend whether you are an experienced LIN student or new to LIN (may get slightly more out of it having taken at least 201 though).

This is a really interesting course that makes you consider a lot of language based biases that you may not have realized you had. It was also not a huge amount of work, and was a great course to take for a distribution requirement.
This is a very easy course. It might be basic if you know a thing or two about linguistics and language.

This is definitely an interesting and engaging class that is a great intro sociolinguistics class. There is a pretty low amount of work, yet it is interesting and will teach you about issues facing society and the role of language in them. Professor Kalin is a super supportive professor. Would be a great 5th class or just an interesting course to take whenever regardless of experience.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Papers - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 40-60 pp. reading per week. Take home midterm and paper in lieu of final exam.
descrip: This course investigates language in its social, cultural, political, and historical contexts. Does your native language influence your perception, your behavior, and your culture? How does your identity influence properties of your language? What happens when unrelated languages come into contact for prolonged periods? How are new languages born? Why isn't English the official language of the United States, and should it be? We will explore these questions (and more) by engaging with the often contradictory opinions of specialists and the public, as well as with the empirical realities behind these different language situations.
title: Language in Its Contexts

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 45%
assgts: 50-75 pages of reading per week; Final research paper.
prereqs: LIN 201 or LIN 301 strongly recommended or permission of the instructor in the absence of either..
descrip: What is intonation? How can we measure it, transcribe it, and analyze it? This class focuses on American English melodic patterns, addressing questions such as: What is the difference between Mandarin-style tone and English-style intonation? Do all questions have the same intonation? How do you pronounce a comma? What does it mean to stress a word? Students learn how to analyze prosodic data (intonation, phrasing, and prominence) using laboratory methods, computer software, and standard annotation conventions. After analyzing the American English intonational system, we compare it to melodic systems of other languages of the world.
title: Intonation: Melody in Language

evals: All ARC concentrators must take this course. This is the first year it has been counted as an actual course which is a nice reward compared to semesters past when students had to take 4 classes plus studio typically. Like any studio, the quality of the course depends on the instructor. I am not sure if Gia will teach again, but nonetheless I will offer short feedback on her. Her studio was really ambitious, and at times fell short of its aims. Despite this, I do feel as though my presentational skills were developed extensively and this was particularly useful as a first-year ARC undergrad.

Gia gives so much work, and expects you to know everything. However, I found this class to be extremely rewarding. Gia focused a lot about idea development as well as verbal and visual presentation, all which are very important in architecture and many other fields. There was also quite a bit of drawing incorporated in the class, so if you enjoy drawing and models, I hope you would enjoy this class as much as I did. Gia is tough, and you won't always come out of the class with a smile on your face, but I thought it was well worth it.

I would recommend this course to anyone willing to commit a significant amount of time and energy to developing and working out their ideas before physically bringing them to life. The more you put into this class, the more you will benefit from it.

If Gia teaches this course again, I would recommend it-- but with knowing what you are in for.  It is a LOT of work, more so than any other architecture studio I have taken and the other junior studio, with short turn around times between projects and high expectations. that being said, it is so rewarding, and I think I have grown so much as an architecture student just in this semester alone.
Jesse can create a very relaxed studio environment. Just make sure you consistently spend time on your design throughout the semester. Putting in a few hours each weekend really helped.
Make sure you have an idea in your head and be adamant about following through with it

Only take studio if you have to. You don't want to put yourself through it if you aren't required to. That said, if you are an architecture major, I highly recommend Gia's studio. You will learn so much and be so much more confident in your abilities when you come out.

This class is tough. If you want a studio that you can somewhat easily get an A or A- in, this is not that studio. Take Jesse's instead. However, if you actually want to learn in your studio, take Gia's. Be warned, if you want to get the most out of this studio, you have to make it your top priority. Gia expects a lot from her students every single class. The turnover for work is quick, and there will be many late nights, even in the first few weeks. But it is worth it in the end.

This course demands a lot of you. You must be prepared to work through your designs, take the time to commit to the work. Studio is a magical and hard place, you work hard on your projects. But in the process you grow close to your studio mates, and learn so much about what it means to make a visual argument.
This is definitely the course to take to fulfill your junior studio! Chair studio is a Princeton architecture staple.
otherinfo: Required for Junior ARC concentrators
grading: Design Project - 100%
assgts: N/A
prereqs: Successful completion of ARC 203/204; this studio is open only to ARC and CEE concentrators..
descrip: This course will focus on a number of specific design techniques in a highly regimented manner. The theme of this semester will be the relationship between geometry and matter in the development of a piece of furniture. We will explore the nature of these complex surfaces and the effects of a limited but continuous enclosed environment on human functions. We will elaborate our skills in model-building, with particular emphasis placed on the value of accurate representation both by fostering craft and by exploring novel techniques of fashioning and representing precise geometries.
title: Junior Studio

descrip: The Great Recession led to a transformational rethinking of Monetary Economics. This course covers the interaction between monetary policy and macro-prudential policy as well as spillover analysis and the implications for the international financial architecture. Goals are to learn about new research trends and contrast them with the established New Keynesian framework. The course introduces new advanced tools, including formal modeling, economic dynamical systems in continuous time, strategic interactions, asymmetric information, and modern welfare analysis.
title: Financial and Monetary Economics

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 20%, Design Project - 35%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Approximately 25 pages of reading per week
descrip: Analysis and design of digital integrated circuits using deep sub-micron CMOS technologies as well as emerging and post-CMOS technologies (Si finFETs, III-V, carbon). Emphasis on design, including synthesis, simulation, layout and post-layout verification. Analysis of energy, power, performance, area of logic-gates, interconnect and signaling structures.
title: Design of Very Large-Scale Integrated (VLSI) Systems

otherinfo: The course will meet from 09/13/17 to 10/27/17. This is a half-term course; it meets for 6 weeks.
grading: Papers - 100%
assgts: Reading sample proposals and writing weekly drafts.
prereqs: WRI 501 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Workshop on writing research proposals, especially for submission to funding agencies and/or departmental committees. Open to students in areas of quantitative research, including science, engineering, and social science. Topics include getting started, motivating research questions, developing specific aims, reviewing published research literature rigorously, justifying resources and budgets, revising effectively, giving and receiving feedback as well as academic integrity. Prerequisites: International graduate students may enroll only after completing WRI 501 or with permission of instructor.
title: Writing a Persuasive Proposal in Quantitative Disciplines (half-term)

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Other (See Instructor) - 50%
descrip: Open to graduate students from all disciplines who have already taught (or will teach during the seminar semester) at Princeton. The course engages in critical discussions of current scholarship in the fields of learning and pedagogy, with opportunities to apply new pedagogical approaches in their own teaching. Participants refine their understanding of teaching as they reflect meaningfully on the approaches and skills gained in their own disciplines as part of a liberal arts education.
title: Scholarly Approaches to Teaching

prereqs: WWS 508c - Econometrics and Public Policy: Advanced.
descrip: This course presents tools for designing, implementing, and analyzing impact evaluations from a practitioner's perspective. It explores real-world problems and practical limitations frequently encountered in conducting evaluations and methodological tools to address them. Topics include program operation rules and their implications for design choice, process and standards for assessing evidence, challenges to randomization, sample size determination, complex sample design, and construction of analytic and non response weights. Students practice addressing these issues through a series of case studies and analytic exercises.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Impact Evaluation Tools

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/28/2017.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course introduces basic concepts and methods in time series analysis with applications in macroeconomics. Emphasis is placed on developing an understanding of how the techniques work, and when they are most suitable for applications. The applications focus on fiscal and monetary policies, exchange rate regimes, international capital flows, and long-run growth.
title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Empirical Macroeconomics: Applied Time Series Analysis

evals: I deeply recomend the class if you want to understand the roots of the theme.
The class topics at times strayed from the syllabus, but Prof. Vidler is fantastic, and I would recommend taking any course with him.
if they are interested in plato, they should definitely take the class
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Other Exam - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%
descrip: This seminar investigates the consistent presence of utopian thought in architecture. The seminar provides an introduction to the traditional narratives of utopia in Plato, More, Bacon, Ledoux, Fourier, Saint-Simon, and the emergence of utopianism as a critical practice in the 1950s and 1960s including Lettrism, Situationism, Archizoom, Superstudio, Archigram, Utopie, and Metabolism. Readings include historical and contemporary theories of utopia, and complementary texts in political, psychoanalytical, social and cybernetic theory. Participants select one example for research and documentation.
title: Utopics: Utopias, Dystopias, Technotopias, and Heterotopias in Architecture and Urbanism, 1945-2001

otherinfo: No prerequisites. Freshmen welcome.
grading: Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Reading: average of 80-120 pages per week. Students will be asked to submit regular reading responses each week as well as a draft of their term paper.
descrip: This course is a survey of Islam in the Indian subcontinent. We begin with the earliest Muslim descriptions of India and the rise of Persian poetry to understand how Muslims negotiated life at the frontiers of the Islamic world. Next we trace patterns of patronage and production at the Mughal court and the development of Urdu as a vehicle of literary composition including a discussion of the Progressive Writer's Movement and the "Muslim Social" genre of Hindi cinema. The course concludes with an examination of contemporary novels from Bangladesh and Pakistan. Students will gain an informed perspective on Islam beyond the headlines.
title: Islam in South Asia: Literary Perspectives

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Quizzes - 30%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Reading: approx. 100 pages per week; Writing: 2 papers
descrip: The course explores major myths and narratives of Hindu India. Through mythology and visual art we will look at Indian culture at different historical stages, and at every stage we will observe how the insiders built their relationship with the world, how they understood their place in it, their moral and religious duties, and the right organization of society. We will consider connections between myths and religious practices, social structures, historical events, and psychological and aesthetic dimensions of Indian cultural life. Reading of mythic narratives will be accompanied by analysis from selected theoretical perspectives.
title: Mythology of Classical India

otherinfo: Course will meet from 11/06/17 to 12/15/17. To apply, visit http://writing.princeton.edu/wse/graduate-writing-courses/wri-501 .
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Two to three research articles will be assigned as readings each week. Writing assignments will include weekly informal responses of 2-3 pages and a 1200- to 1500-word literature review in the student's area of research.
prereqs: Course is open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.
title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half-term): Science & Engineering

otherinfo: Course will meet from 11/6/17 to 12/15/17. To apply, visit http://writing.princeton.edu/wse/graduate-writing-courses/wri-503 .
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
assgts: Each week, students will write a new section of a research article on their own work. Reading assignments will include examples of published research articles and drafts of articles composed by members of the class.
prereqs: Course is open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are preparing to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.
title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering

otherinfo: Materials provided by instructor.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Reading and writing texts in a graduate students field of research interests, including articles, summaries, conference proposals, essays.
prereqs: Open to Graduate Students only.
descrip: This course focuses instruction on skills required to perform in a Russian-speaking academic context across core subject areas of literary analysis and cultural studies. The targeted language skills - reading, writing, speaking, and listening - will be tied with the specific needs of students (e.g., reading and writing proposals, presentations for conferences, academic articles, and correspondence). In addition, students get acquainted with various academic sub-styles and genres as well as differences in academic standards (citation, bibliography). The course includes a comprehensive review of Russian grammar and syntax.
title: Russian for Academic Purposes I

evals: Easily one of my top three classes at Princeton, and the best statistics course by far that I have taken. Highly recommend for any student in the social sciences looking for rigorous training in statistics. DEFINITELY TAKE IT IF BRANDON IS TEACHING -- he is incredible.

MUST TAKE IF YOU LIKE MATH, STATS, POLITICS, SOCIOLOGY, AT ALL. It's an amazing course. Stay on top of the concepts and problem sets, it will be an amazing and challenging time! Brandon is awesome, and so are the preceptors.

This class is a lot of work! About 5 hours of class time in addition to about 5-10 hours each week on a problem set. If you want a better grasp on R and social science quantitative information it is comprehensive but also jam-packed and is technically a sociology graduate student required course.
Would highly recommend. You gain extremely valuable skills while working with some of the most intelligent and kindest people.
take it ! so much work but all very fair and worthwhile
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
grading: Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Problem set(s) - 70%
assgts: Weekly problem sets (including two which disallow collaboration) and a final exam.
prereqs: No formal prerequisites, but students will benefit from a background in basic calculus and linear algebra. Undergraduates interested in the course are advised to take an introductory statistics course first such as POL 345/SOC 305 or comparable courses in another department..
descrip: An introduction to basic concepts in probability and statistics with applications to social science research. We cover descriptive statistics, sampling distributions, statistical inference (including point estimation, confidence intervals and tests of hypotheses), the comparison of two or more groups, linear regression, and designs for causal inference. Throughout the course we use the open-source statistical package R to illustrate and apply the techniques. The course is intended to prepare students to take Advanced Social Statistics the following term.
title: Applied Social Statistics

evals: Absolutely take this course if Hanlon is teaching it! He is so passionate about urban economics. The material is very new, so you won't get it anywhere else. The 80-minute lectures flew by, and it was very interesting to learn about cities from an economics perspective! Start the problem sets early, go to lecture, and pay attention...but it's not too hard.
Highly recommend for a departmental that is not too quantitative.
Make sure you memorize the articles.
Really enjoyed the class. If you're interested in Economics research, its a great chance to be exposed to interesting topics. I'd recommend taking it as a junior: you might get some thesis ideas.
Solid econ departmental
Take it!

This was not a very hard economics course, and had fairly interesting and relevant content. Make sure you understand the reasoning behind the graphs the professor presents, and what causes shifts, and you should be fine.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: The course does not follow a single textbook. Students will be asked to read academic papers (approximately 50 pages per week) and do one problem set every two weeks.
prereqs: Students must have previously take Microeconomic Theory (ECO 300 or ECO 310) and Econometrics (ECO 302 or ECO 312)..
descrip: Cities play a central role in the economy. But why do they exist? Why do people and firms pay so much money in order to crowd closely together? What forces shape their structure, size, and long-run success? The goal of this course is to answer some of these questions by analyzing cities as economic systems using both theoretical and empirical tools. The theory side of the course covers a standard set of urban models describing both the structure of cities and how they interact as part of larger national economies. The empirical side of the course draws on recent academic papers to introduce some of the econometric tools used to study cities.
title: Urban Economics

otherinfo: Department Requirement: Modernity and Diasporas
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: 200 pages of reading per week. There will be 3 papers.
descrip: Bollywood generates more films each year than other global film industries, circulating films across Africa, Asia, and beyond. What are the dominant trends and genres of popular South Asian cinema since independence? We will assume a capacious meaning of "Bollywood" as a global phenomenon. Course topics include the recent resurgence of Pakistani film industry as well as "Third Cinema," against which the popular is often defined in studies of postcolonial cinema. Course topics include melodrama, the popular, translation, diaspora, migration, nationalism and affect. Some background in film or media theory will be helpful but not required.
title: Bollywood Cinema

evals: Definitely a course I'd recommend! Andy and David are awesome researchers and lecturers, and Talmo is a fun and awesome TA. The course is super interesting and engaging; problem sets are very hard, though, so be prepared!
I'd strongly recommend taking this course, it's a very awesome entry into high level brain data processing. Just brush up on your matlab a bit beforehand!

Profs. Tank & Leifer are fantastic leaders in their field (although at very different stages in the careers), and I learned a lot through this course. The problem sets were quite tough, and it's unclear how much work is actually expected of you. In addition, many thesising seniors just chose not to do the problem sets all together, which made things very strange.. The final project was an extension of a problem set, and the directions were very vague. Originally, undergrads were supposed to do a final problem set instead, but they changed their mind right at the end of the course -- thus, I would ask the professors about assignments early and hold them to accountable to the syllabus if needed.

Really fantastic, not only for the material (you really get a great sense of what's going on in systems neuroscience), but also for getting David Tank and Andy Leifer's perspectives on them. I really learned how to think about the relevance of current research and what I will do in the future!

This course is incredible and essential for anyone thinking about neuroscience research post-college. All-star teaching team and fascinating material on emerging methods in neuroscience make it a great class to be in. Make sure you get started on the psets asap, though, because they are massive and difficult but super fun and actually very instructive, too.

This is one of the best courses I've taken in my time at Princeton. From electrophysiology to ethology, this course covers the foundational methods and recent developments in neuroscience that anyone hoping to better understand the brain will unquestionably encounter.  The opportunity to study popular methods for the recording of large neural ensembles under Professor Leifer and Professor Tank should not be passed up. Both are leaders in the field and are more than willing to share their knowledge. Anyone interested in computational neuroscience, data analysis, or methods for large-scale neural recording should definitely take this course.
otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: A portion of the lectures will consist of student presentations. A final problem set, worth 10% of the final grade, will be due on Dean's Date.
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Problem set(s) - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: The course will be lecture and article based, with homework in MATLAB or Python.
prereqs: MAT 202 or NEU 314 or permission of instructor. Prior linear algebra experience and familiarity with a scientific programming environment such as MATLAB, R or Python is required..
descrip: This course explores methods for recording and analyzing neural activity from populations of neurons at cellular resolution, and the scientific discoveries that such methods have enabled. Topics include methods for electrical and optical recording of large populations of neurons, as well as their application to studying neural dynamics underlying animal behavior. The course will survey seminal journal articles in the field and will provide students with hands-on practice analyzing real neural population recording datasets.
title: Measurement and Analysis of Neural Circuit Dynamics

evals: Term Comparison: Results for Overall Quality of the Course

grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 90%
descrip: Over the last 20 years, the emerging field of social entrepreneurship has taken new approaches to problems in education, waste management and global public health. This course focuses on types and stages of different social enterprises (non-profits/hybrid organizations/for-profits), evaluates nature of capital available from grants to patient capital to market-return investments. Course seeks to equip students with a framework for understanding how: 1) social enterprise can complement traditional provision of public services and 2) new markets are being created that deliver clear social benefits while generating returns to investors.
title: Domestic Policy Analysis - Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation

otherinfo: Museum visits and firsthand examination of works of art and other types of images will be an integral part of this course. For department majors, satisfies the group 3 distribution requirement.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Weekly reading between 50-75 pages, plus short response assignments. 2 papers, final exam.
descrip: From the toppling of a statue of King George in New York in 1776 to the super PAC "For Freedoms" founded by artists in 2016, art and politics in America have gone hand in hand, and understanding the history of American art requires a deep dive into the history of American politics. With the current political landscape as both backdrop and incitement, this course considers the history of intersections between art and politics in the United States, from the revolutionary era to the present, and examines how artists have engaged the political sphere and produced political art in order to express critique, accommodation, resistance, and rage.
title: Rage against the Machine: Art and Politics in America

otherinfo: For department majors, this course satisfies the group 1 distribution requirement.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Readings will consist of book chapters and articles between 50-100 pages per week. Writing assignments include two catalogue entries of 500 words each on two Song paintings in the collection of PUAM and a term paper of 12 to 15 pages.
descrip: The Song Dynasty has long been considered the high point of Chinese painting, representing a classical period to which later artists consistently looked back.This seminar will explore the artistic qualities and development of landscape, figure, and flower-and-bird painting and will consider main issues concerning these genres. Such issues include the relative importance of different genres, the relationship between the natural and the human world, the roles of the court and literati in producing art, and the materiality and visuality of Song painting.
title: Song Dynasty Painting

otherinfo: Other 15% = Homework.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Quizzes - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 15%
assgts: Each week, students will write a 1.5-2 page response to the assigned reading(s). As a midterm paper, students will write an essay (4-5 pages) comparing two stages of Hebrew that have been discussed in class. For the final paper, students will write a paper (6-8 pages) on a topic related to the history of Hebrew; the final paper will need to incorporate 5-6 articles. Students will also be asked to present orally in class their research on the final paper.
prereqs: HEB 107 or the equivalent as determined by placement test and instructor..
descrip: This course consists of a survey of the Hebrew language from Biblical Hebrew to Modern Hebrew. The course will evaluate Biblical Hebrew, Rabbinic Hebrew, Hebrew of the Haskalah, Hebrew of Ben Yehuda, and the Hebrew of today. The course will examine Modern Hebrew as an amalgamation of the previous stages of Hebrew that preceded the emergence of Hebrew as a spoken language in the 19th century. The course will be conducted entirely in Hebrew and will strengthen the students' listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Students will also gain a greater grasp of literary Modern Hebrew because it is heavily based on earlier forms of Hebrew.
title: Hebrew Through the Ages

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%
assgts: 1. 3-page review essay of articles on The Jewish Book, published in AJS Review 34:2; 2. 3-page review essay of Grafton-Eisenstein-Johns exchange on the print revolution, published in the American Historical Review, vol. 107 (2002): 84-128; 3. Research paper, 12-15 pages, on a subject of Jewish book history, utilizing both primary and secondary sources.
descrip: This course explores the composition and publication of books, manuscripts, and other written material for and by Jews during the medieval and early modern periods (ca. 1000-1800). The course touches on: orality and literacy; scroll and codex; authors, readers, publishers, and scribes; manuscript and print; Jewish-Christian interaction in scriptoriums, artist workshops, and printing houses; censorship; illustration, illumination, and deluxe printing; and major printing centers. Students will consider how these objects drove Jewish societies and reflected larger cultural trends. They will also address the definition of a "Jewish" book.
title: History of the Jewish Book

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings; two policy memos (20%) and one final paper (30%).
descrip: Since the end of World War II the developing world has experienced numerous violent conflicts. These conflicts often pit government and allied forces against those of relatively small armed groups, often called "insurgents." This course will explore the roots of insurgency, the organization and tactics of insurgent groups (including the use of terrorism), counterinsurgency campaigns, and efforts at conflict resolution. It will focus on the conditions under which insurgents are most likely to prevail in their fight against better-resourced armed forces.
title: Insurgency and Counterinsurgency

otherinfo: Class conducted in Spanish. Students pursuing a Program in Latin American Studies certificate must write their final paper on a Latin American topic and provide a copy of the paper to PLAS in order to receive their program's credit.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly one-page (250 word) response papers on the readings. These short assignments will be graded on a 0-2 basis and are intended mainly to complement the class participation grade and to assess the student's preparation of the assigned readings. Weekly topics will be posted on Blackboard. Prompts/ questions will be provided for the midterm (4-5 pp.) and final (5-7 pp.) papers. 20-30 pp/wk readings on average.
prereqs: SPA 207 or SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Flotsam. Jetsam. Hunger. Nudity. Lone survivors washed ashore. What can tales of shipwreck tell us about the cultures, societies and technologies that produce them? We read narratives and watch films of disaster and survival from the sixteenth century to the present, with an eye to how these texts can challenge or reinforce the myths that empires and nation-states tell about themselves and others.
title: Of Shipwreck and Other Disasters

otherinfo: Course conducted in Spanish.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 45%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Weekly readings of 30-50 pages in Spanish or 50-100 pages in English. Three short essays (3 pages), and a final paper in Spanish (5-7 pages)
prereqs: SPA 207 or SPA 209 or instructor's permission.
descrip: What does it mean to be Latin American? Hispanic? Spanish? Peruvian? Latina/o/x? How are national and alternate identities constructed and why? How are ideas of belonging to the body politic defined in Spain, Latin America, and in Spanish-speaking communities in the United States from within and without? Our course will engage this question by surveying and analyzing literary, historical, and visual productions from the time of the foundation of the Spanish empire to the present time.
title: Identity in the Hispanic World

otherinfo: Final exam will consist of a project, involving the characterization of an instability or non-linear phenomena, illustrated by some numerical or experimental work, or a detailed analysis of the research literature; together with an oral presentation. Midterm exam will consist of a report on the topic chosen for the final project with an outline of the student's approach.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Other Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Problem sets and optional readings. Final exam will consist of a project.
prereqs: PHY 103-104 and MAT 201-202. MAE 305 (may be taken concurrently) or instructors permission..
descrip: This course describes natural patterns arising from instabilities in nature, and discusses their importance in the environment. We will analyze phenomena at various scales, as diverse as wave breaking at the ocean surface, internal mixing in the atmosphere and the ocean, volcanic plumes, convection cells in the atmosphere, the break-up of fluid ligaments or bubble bursting at an interface. The course will detail mathematical tools (linear and non-linear stability analysis, symmetry arguments, solutions to non-linear equations such as shocks and solitons), as well as present laboratory and numerical demonstrations of the instabilities.
title: Instabilities in Fluids: Linear and Non-linear Analysis of Waves and Patterns in the Environment

otherreq: ART First-Year and Second-Year Graduate Students Only.
otherinfo: This course is for all first and second year graduate students in Art & Archaeology only. In 2017-18, it will be taught as Art 502C for fall and Art 502D in the spring.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
descrip: This course is intended to ensure a continuing breadth of exposure to contemporary art-historical discourse and practices. It requires attendance and participation in the department lecture/seminar series. Students must take the course sequentially in each of their first four semesters and take the appropriate letter version of the course (A,B,C, or D) based on their semester of study. The course is taken in addition to the normal load of three courses per semester and is for first- and second-year graduate students only. Topics discussed cover all fields of Art History and address current questions and practices.
title: The Graduate Seminar

otherinfo: Course will be taught by Bernadette Perez of the Society of Fellows in the Liberal Arts.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Expected pages of reading/week: 250 pp; Class participation; 2 short critical response papers; Primary source analysis; Annotated bibliography; Final paper (12-15 pp.)
descrip: Moving from the colonial era to the present, and from the Caribbean to the Midwest and the Pacific, we will place sugar in the history of European colonialism, trans-Atlantic slavery, capitalism, American Empire, and global immigration restrictions. During this period, the United States built a sugar empire that relied upon differentially racialized laborers, who worked under a variety of coercive labor systems. We will explore how the production and consumption of sugar connected diverse people and places in unequal ways, focusing on themes such as labor, migration, race, gender, citizenship, identity, power, resistance, and the land.
title: Sugar: A Commodity History of the United States

otherinfo: ANT 309A & 309B meet together for lectures. Students in 309A will meet in precepts to collect and analyze social and environmental data pertaining to the physiological data studied by students in 309B lab. Collaborating as a team, the two groups of students will conduct integrated scientific and social science research, and plan and shape long term research by implementing a dataset that will continue to be studied and expanded after this course ends. See ANT 309B for more information.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Take Home Final Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Term Paper(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Weekly readings. In precept, collect and analyze social and environmental data pertaining to the subjects in a physiological dataset (from real-world individual subjects from Philadelphia) that students in ANT 309B lab will collect, interpret and curate in their developmental and physiological studies.
descrip: Forensic anthropology involves medico-legal cases where human remains have lost "personhood" (an individual cannot be identified due to decomposition or destruction of unique personal features). We will explore techniques of analysis that biological anthropologists apply to forensic cases. We will blend the sub-disciplines of social and biological anthropology by tracing the intertwined physiological and social factors that shape human variation and life experience in an urban setting.
