otherinfo: This class will meet from 9/13/2017 to 10/25/2017. This interdisciplinary course is co-taught with faculty from Humboldt University and draws on comparative politics, comparative constitutionalism, and political theory.
grading: Papers - 100%
assgts: Students are required to make at least one presentation in class and submit one 20-page paper or 3 8-page papers. Seminar will be followed by a workshop hosted by the Center for Human Values, where students are welcome (but not required) to present research papers/work in progress.
descrip: The course analyzes the problematic interplay between basic principles of the rule of law and democracy, set up in contemporary constitutions, and significant attempts at changing the character of these meta rules by "politicizing" them and making them an issue of day-to-day politics. Cases studied include Hungary, Poland, Turkey and Russia. Studying these cases closely might possibly also help in better understanding contemporary developments in the US, where the legitimacy of the judiciary has been contested by the President in unprecedented ways and the specter of authoritarianism is newly present.
title: The Rise of Authoritarian Constitutionalism (Half-Term)

otherinfo: This course will be taught by Tim Szetela, a leader in motion and data visualization design. http://timszetela.com
grading: Design Project - 40%, Programming Assignments - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: There will be no reading or writing assignments as this is a this visual computer design course. Grading: 10% Other = Prompt arrival to class, respectful treatment of equipment, consideration of others, adhering to lab rules.
prereqs: None.
descrip: This studio production class will engage in a variety of timed-based collage, composition, visualization, and storytelling techniques. Enrolled students will be taught the fundamental techniques of 2D animation production, acquire a working knowledge of digital animation software, utilize the basic technologies of audiovisual recording, editing, and composition, and explore the connective space between sound, image, and motion possible in animated film. In-class critiques, workshops, screenings, and discussions will relate student work to the history and practice of animation and to other media, art, and design forms.
title: Digital Animation

otherinfo: This course meets from 9/19/17 - 10/24/17. This is a six week course that will be taught during the first half of the semester. Non-Sociology graduate students wishing to receive a grade for this course must submit a completed Graduate Student Enrollment Change Form located at the following URL: https://gradschool.princeton.edu/sites/gradschool/files/Enrollment%20Form%20Revised_1.pdf
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 15%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: How can ethnography help us to understand analyze, and critique organizations? This course delves deeply into classic and contemporary examples of organizational ethnography, inquiring into their findings, methods and implications. How do these studies suggest we approach ethnographic work in the firm, the collective, or on the shop floor? What is the role of formal structures and informal cultures, how are power and identity practiced in the organization, and what are the implications for human action? Our goal is to generate a rich qualitative understanding of how and why to study organizations and their role in social life.
title: Organizational Ethnography (Half-Term)

grading: Design Project - 35%, Papers - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: Grading: 10% Papers: Students will maintain a personal journal of their observations and experiences in the class. 35% Design Projects: Weekly in-class assignments / exercises in acting and directing, plus more complex acting/ directing scene collaborations. 30% Other: Final Project.
prereqs: Interested students should visit the VIS Program website to apply to the course. http://arts.princeton.edu/courses/directing-and-acting-for-the-screen/.
descrip: This introductory course will provide a critical opportunity to explore the mutual craft of directing actors and acting for directors, with the goal of creating credible performances on screen. Working in-class as actors and directors, students will learn to interpret the subtext of the frame and learn to stage action for the camera. By critically focusing on professional practice, the nuances of performance and behavior in relation to storytelling will be explored. No prior technical experience is necessary to enroll. Students will, however, be required to engage in acting and directing in equal measure.
title: Directing and Acting for the Screen

otherinfo: Denys Turner is a leading scholar of Christian theology and contemporary philosophy of religion. His books include Darkness of God (1995), Faith, Reason and the Existence of God (2004), Julian of Norwich, Theologian (2011), and Thomas Aquinas, A Portrait (2013). A distinguished writer and inspiring teacher, he has taught at a number of British universities, and most recently, at Yale University.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Approximately 100-200 pages of reading per week; participation; reading reflection papers; final paper (15-20 pages) in lieu of a final exam.
descrip: The course is to serve as an introduction to the theology of one of the greatest minds in the Western Christian tradition, Thomas Aquinas (1224/5-1274). Based on his most systematic work, the Summa Theologiae as the main source, the course will cover some of the central themes of his theology, mainly through readings of the primary source itself, and some secondary readings. Thomas Aquinas has in recent decades become a source common to most of the mainstream Christian theological traditions. Aquinas is an essential resource for any who simply want to study a dominating intellectual force within the wider cultures of the Western middle ages.
title: The Theology of Thomas Aquinas

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
descrip: This course traces the history of the photographic medium from the introduction of the daguerreotype in 1839 to socially engaged documentary photography of the 1930s and beyond, questioning the notion of photography as a modernist artistic and documentary medium in Russia and the West. Central issues in the course are the role of authorship in photography and in the hybrid photo-textual spaces of print media, photography's politicization and instrumentation, and photography as a reflection of a shifting modernist vision.
title: Photographic Modernisms: Russia and the West

grading: Final Exam - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
descrip: Do feelings have history? How do they influence history? Do "natural" emotions exist? How do political regimes control the emotional sincerity of their subjects? What is the role of literature in cultivating certain emotional modes? How do people interpret and express their emotions in different periods? In this course, we apply these and similar questions to the emotional history of Russian culture considered within western contexts and theoretical frameworks offered by scholars of emotions. We also try to "resurrect" a number of emotions which played an important role in Russian cultural history.
title: History of Emotions: Russia and the West

otherreq: Statistical, design or other software use required
otherinfo: Open to graduate students.
grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Weekly reading responses, 4 homework assignments, midterm essay, and final project.
descrip: This course introduces students to the study of social processes using agent based models (ABMs)--computer simulations in which agents interact and generate social outcomes such as norms, culture, and inequality. In the first part of the course, we will discuss the theoretical foundations of ABMs, how to design models that explore empirical questions, and practice generating, visualizing, and analyzing results. The second part will focus on ABM applications in the social sciences and their substantive implications. Students will be encouraged to develop a critical appreciation of ABMs, and will produce their own model for the final project.
title: Simulating Social Processes: An Introduction to Agent Based Modeling

otherinfo: Students will also have the opportunity to write or arrange music for the ensemble with the guidance of the instructor. Weekly repertoire assignments will account for 70% of the final grade. Other 30% = Final Project (15%) and Final Performance (15%).
grading: Class/Precept Participation - 70%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: There will be repertoire assignments each week (i.e. pieces to learn and practice). Students will be required to submit a 3 page paper giving a short historical analysis of a Calypso artist of their choosing (with the guidance of the instructor). Final projects are due on Dean's Date.
prereqs: To apply to the course, interested students should email jquillen@princeton.edu to describe their interest in the course and their previous experience with reading music. Students are required to attend all rehearsals culminating in a final performance at the end of the semester (based on availability of the students and the venue). Students must have a basic level of music reading skills..
descrip: The PU Steel Band course will focus on the history and performance practice surrounding the steel drum band and its traditional musics from Trinidad and Tobago. The repertoire will be chosen from traditional music from the Caribbean (Calypso and Soca) as well as other contemporary works from the United States.
title: Princeton University Steel Band

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%
descrip: Music is a deeply material practice. From the human bodies that perform music and the instruments those bodies use to perform it, to the spaces in which music is experienced and the physical constitution of sound itself, music always involves material processes and things. This seminar examines music's materiality from a wide range of perspectives (Marxism, phenomenology, actor-network theory, etc.). Participants develop a thorough understanding of each of these approaches and evaluate their relative merits and limitations.
title: Music and Materiality

grading: Papers - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
descrip: This graduate seminar is meant as both an overview of Sasanian history as well as an introduction to its historiography. It is organized based on the study of sources and addresses the issue of the diversity of languages, types of evidence, and variety of approaches. It additionally aims at connecting Sasanian history to the greater issues of late antique and world history and emphasizes similarities and mutual influences with other late antique civilizations and entities.
title: Problems and Sources in the Study of Late Antique Iran: Sasanian History

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings, one midterm essay, one final essay.
descrip: HUM 302 explores illness, health, and the body using storytelling as an entry point. It examines how science, subjectivity, and social difference -- race, class, gender, and sexuality -- are articulated on a global scale. The 1920s construction of the New Soviet Man resonates with histories of medical discrimination in the US; early Soviet studies on biomechanics and the body-machine illuminate current debates on disability and health disparities; the Russian tradition of the Holy Fool jumpstarts a discussion of neurodiversity. Guest lecturers from across Sciences and Humanities will each teach a class in their own institutional space.
title: Medical Story-Worlds

grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Design Project - 20%, Problem set(s) - 20%
assgts: Problem sets and programming exercises.
prereqs: MAT 202 Linear Algebra COS 226: Algorithms and Data Structures Recommended: Multivariate Calculus, MAT 201 or a similar course Introductory course in Probability, ORF 309 or similar.
descrip: The course provides an introduction to machine learning. Topics covered: learning from examples and generalization. Empirical risk minimization and regularization. Introduction to convex analysis. Gradient-based learning. Implementation and analysis of learning algorithms for regression, binary classification, multiclass categorization, and ranking problems. Dimensionality reduction methods. Ensemble methods and boosting.
title: Introduction to Machine Learning

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: Weekly readings from books and anthropology journals (75-100 pages/week). Weekly written responses to readings (20%). Take-home midterm project (20%). Final term paper (30%)
descrip: Why are people committed to the "Paleo" diet in the 21st Century? Why do we apply the title "comfort" to certain foods? This class will use anthropology as a platform to explore how diverse health outcomes are connected to the foods we do (and do not) eat. While we will consider how food is implicated in individual health outcomes (such as malnutrition and chronic disease), we will also explore food and diet at an evolutionary scale. Shaping these explorations will be a sharp critical lens that considers how culture shapes our perceptions of food and health and how power intersects in our ability to so access those needs and preferences.
title: You Are What You Eat: Bio-Cultural Explorations of Food and Health

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: This course will be assessed on participation in seminar discussion, a midterm paper of 5-7pp, and a final paper of 10-14pp. Approximately 100-150pp of reading per week.
descrip: This seminar considers a part of English literary history that is often overlooked: the surge in satirical writing from 1500 to 1700. In it, we will discuss a range of texts--prose, poetry, and drama--that are funny, clever, angry, culturally omniverous, and often foul mouthed. In addition to enjoying ourselves, we will see that satire involves far more than calling out corruption in high places, or mocking the pretensions of snobs, lovers, bad writers, and those trying to make it big. It is also a provocation to laugh, and sometimes to wince, our way to a better understanding of what life and literature are supposed to be about.
title: Laughter, Vice and Delusion: Satire and Satirists, 1500-1700

otherinfo: After briefly introducing the modeling and algorithmic aspects (neural networks, back propagation, stochastic gradient decent), we discuss the accuracy and stability of deep learning models, and we analyze the efficiency of the algorithms using simple models.
grading: Other Exam - 50%, Programming Assignments - 25%, Problem set(s) - 25%
assgts: Weekly problem sets. Final (other exam) will be a take home project.
prereqs: Calculus, linear algebra, basic probability theory, basic numerical algorithms..
descrip: This course gives a mathematical introduction to machine learning. It is not about proving theorems in machine learning, but rather a unified understanding of the models and algorithms used in machine learning. It begins with a simple introduction to supervised and unsupervised learning, including regression, classification, density estimation, clustering, and dimension reduction. Simple models such as linear regression, support vector machines, and k-means will be introduced, followed by focus on deep learning.
title: Mathematical Introduction to Machine Learning

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: Students will read approximately 200 pages per week and write eight short weekly response papers (10%). There will be a take-home midterm essay and a final term paper.
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar examines the production of urban nature. Nature and the city are usually seen as separate, even antithetical, yet cities are now responsible for the majority of carbon emissions that cause climate change. Generating a creative politics of nature in and for the city is consequently a key component of contemporary environmentalism. Reading across fields such as architecture, geography, and postcolonial studies, we will explore the material and social infrastructures through which nature is metabolized in cities, as well as the representations (fictional and otherwise) through which urban nature is depicted.
title: The Nature of the City

grading: Papers - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 50 - 70 pages per week
descrip: Critical African Studies is a colloquium designed as a capstone course for African Studies Certificate students. The course is designed to introduce students to cutting-edge scholarship in African Studies. Students engage with African Studies scholars from Princeton University and beyond. In addition to attending the African Studies Lecture Series and Works-in-Progress series, students in Critical African Studies will workshop their junior or senior independent research. This capstone course is open to junior and senior certificate students and must be taken to fulfill the African Studies Certificate requirements.
title: Critical African Studies

grading: Problem set(s) - 100%
descrip: This course covers a selection of advanced topics in cryptography, including some or all of the following: fully homomorphic encryption, zero knowledge proofs, traitor tracing, identity-based encryption, private information retrieval, garbled circuits, secret sharing, multiparty computation, lattice-based cryptography, and elliptic curve-based cryptography.
title: Advanced Cryptography

grading: Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: 25-50 pages per week from the reading list
descrip: Heritage structures represent an important cultural legacy. First, this course identifies particularities relative to structural analysis of heritage structures; it correlates the space and time (where and when the structure was built, used, upgraded, damaged, repaired), with construction materials, techniques, and contemporary architectural forms. Second, the course presents the methods of structural analysis that take into account the identified particularities, that are efficient in finding solutions, and that are simple and intuitive in terms of application and interpretation.
title: Holistic Analysis of Heritage Structures

otherinfo: Emphasizing developments in the 19th and 20th centuries, with particular attention paid to the circum-Caribbean, this course focuses on the themes of emancipation, migration, and decolonization. Related topics include the Haitian Revolution, slave rebellions, marronage, and abolition; intra-regional and transnational migrations; labor organizing and militancy; nationalism and independence movements; the black radical tradition; and transnational feminisms.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 35%
descrip: This readings course considers the dispersals, political movements, cultural production, social bonds, and intellectual labors that together have constituted and continually re-configured the modern African diaspora, from the emergence and collapse of the Atlantic slave system through the late twentieth century. The course tracks the evolution of diaspora as an idea and analytical framework, highlighting its intersections with concepts of Pan-Africanism, black nationalism, cosmopolitanism, and citizenship.
title: Topics in African Diaspora History - Emancipation, Migration, Decolonization

otherinfo: Other 30% in Requirements/ Grading: Project which will consist of a written report and an oral presentation.
grading: Quizzes - 60%, Problem set(s) - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
descrip: Nonlinear control of dynamical systems, with an emphasis on the geometric approach. The course gives an introduction to differential geometry, nonlinear controllability and constructive controllability, nonlinear observability, state-space transformations and stability, followed by study of a selection of nonlinear control design methods, including techniques motivated by geometric mechanics.
title: Nonlinear Control

otherinfo: Final exam consists of a project. Projects consist of an analysis of an instability, based on an experimental or numerical work, including the mathematical analysis of the problem. The student presents the results as a lecture during the class.
grading: Mid Term Exam - 20%, Final Exam - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: Problem sets and optional reading.
prereqs: Physics or Math in freshman year..
descrip: This course describes natural patterns arising from instabilities in nature, and discusses their importance in the environment. We analyze phenomena at various scales, as diverse as wave breaking at the ocean surface, internal mixing in the atmosphere and the ocean, volcanic plumes, convection cells in the atmosphere, the break-up of fluid ligaments or bubble bursting at an interface. The course details mathematical tools (linear and non-linear stability analysis, symmetry arguments, solutions to non-linear equations such as shocks and solitons), as well as present laboratory and numerical demonstration of the instabilities.
title: Instabilities in Fluids: Linear and Non-Linear Analysis of Waves and Patterns in the Environment

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 60%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: Students will be assigned weekly readings of secondary materials to prepare for class and will read and discuss selected primary materials in class. Students will be asked to write four short (5-page) guided analyses during the course, in which they will apply insights from secondary readings and class discussions to additional primary materials.
prereqs: No knowledge of Yiddish required. All primary and secondary materials are in English..
descrip: This course examines the place of Yiddish in America from the late 19th century to the present and considers the dynamics of the language's significance in modern American Jewish life. Topics include immigrant Yiddish culture, press, political activism, theater, music, and literature at the turn of the 20th century; hybrid Yiddish-English cultural works of the interwar years, American Yiddish responses to the Holocaust; Yiddish in postwar Hasidic and yeshiva communities; and contemporary engagements with Yiddish by performing artists, queer activists, and postmodern intellectuals. All materials in English.
title: Yiddish in America

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 5%
assgts: Final paper will be a ten-page essay (double-spaced, Times New Roman 12). The subject of the paper is chosen by the student and can be the analysis of a text or problem addressed in class or of a text not discussed but appropriate to the course topic. Students must use at least four academic sources of critical bibliography on the text, author, or theme.
descrip: This course aims to introduce students to the role played by culture in developing different politics of memory and human rights in Latin American recent history, from the end of the last military dictatorships to the present. Looking at literature, testimony, film, photography, museums and sites of memory, the course analyzes how cultural works on memory and human rights have helped to create connections between past and present histories of both violence and resistance.
title: Memory and Human Rights Politics in Contemporary Latin American Cultures

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: A 5-page final paper, which will integrate all topics covered in class + critically analyzing new material will be due at Dean's Date.
descrip: Manipulating memories, mind reading, recording dreams, brain machine interfaces, mind control, creating machines that can think. These seemingly futuristic topics are being investigated by labs at the frontiers of neuroscience. Using films as a starting point, this seminar will evaluate critically advanced topics in neuroscience. Every two weeks we will watch a movie and use scientific papers to discuss the research topic portrayed cinematically, and the scientific and ethical questions posed by the film. Some of the movies may occasionally contain strong language and inappropriate behavior, students¿ discretion is advised.
title: Neurocinematics - Using Films to Explore Frontiers in Cognitive Neuroscience

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 10%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Students will complete assigned readings (75-100 pgs /wk) and actively participate in class discussions as well as submitting via email a one-paragraph (100-400 word) précis of one of the readings each week. Two long-form, take-home essays will be assigned at the midterm and at the end of the course. These will be capped at 2,000 words and 3,000 words, maximum, respectively
descrip: This course will examine the areas of the United States that went heavily for Donald Trump, and the factors behind the election of 2016. We will examine the decline of the working class, the Rust Belt, conspiracy theory, the post-fact world, and the social construction of whiteness.
title: Trumpland

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly, short (approximately two pp. each) critical response papers to some aspect of the readings for that week, due in advance of the meeting at which the readings are discussed. A 10-12 page final paper, due on Dean's Date January 16, 2018.
descrip: In this reading and writing intensive seminar, we will critically examine some of the fundamental ideas of modern political conservatism, as presented by some of its leading thinkers. We will attempt to better understand conservative thought, and develop a framework for assessing its strengths and weaknesses, with respect to a number of representative topics, including the following: distributive justice and the apparent tension between liberty and equality, criminal justice and the nature of crime, and social conservatism and the role of religion in society. Our authors will include philosophers, economists and social scientists.
title: Intellectual Foundations of Modern Conservatism

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Book reports and a final paper due on Deans date
descrip: This course will use a series of catastrophic encounters between humans and pathogens as starting points for the study of the development of global capitalism since the fourteenth century.
title: Epidemics in World History

otherinfo: Weekly Response Posts on Blackboard: 10% Seminar Journal: 20%
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%, Other (See Instructor) - 30%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: What does "sanctuary" mean? This term has become an often-controversial statement of activism. It also has a long history and a range of meanings. This seminar has two parts: 1) The exploration of concepts of sanctuary, refuge, supplication, intercession, and "welcoming the stranger" in a range of historical and cultural settings; and 2) Service/Civic Engagement in partnership with local organizations through the Community-Based Learning Initiative (CBLI).
title: Sanctuary

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: This seminar will explore the complex history of the fairy tale genre and address the many critical questions it raises. The readings will include the canonical texts by the Brothers Grimm and Charles Perrault but also many other, lesser-known versions, ranging from Ancient Rome to the Italian Renaissance and the French 18th century, as well as interpretations of these stories by historians, folklorists, psychoanalysts, and literary critics. The second half of the course will examine the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen and Oscar Wilde and conclude with contemporary Anglo-American retellings of the classical narratives.
title: Into the Woods! What Disney Didn't Tell You About Fairy Tales

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Students must read all assigned readings and come to class prepared to discuss them. Students will rotate leading class discussions of assigned primary sources.Two short written assignments (3-5 pages), due weeks 5 and 9.
descrip: How did the Middle East become Islamic? What did it mean, in the first 500 years after Muhammad lived, for a state or region to be Islamic? This seminar will examine how religion worked within early Islamic societies, focusing on relationships, exchanges, and boundaries between early and medieval Muslims (rulers, religious thinkers, and ordinary people) and the non-Muslims who lived among them. We will use Jewish and Christian conversion to Islam as a lens through which to consider how religious identity worked in the early Islamic Middle East and how its meaning changed over time.
title: Islam and Other Religions:The First 500 Years

otherreq: Open to Juniors and Seniors Only.
grading: Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 50%
assgts: Weekly problem sets and a final exam.
prereqs: PHY 208 and PHY 301.
descrip: A survey course concentrating mostly on quantum condensed matter physics. Topics include: Electrons in solids: bands, scattering, transport, semi-classical dynamics, metals, semiconductors, semimetals, insulators, superconductors. The structure of liquids, solids and crystals. Determining structure from scattering. Harmonic and anharmonic phonons in solids, thermal conduction. Magnetism and antiferromagnetism. Strong interactions between electrons: Hubbard models and Mott insulators. Quantum gases. Superfluidity and superconductivity.
title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly reading assignments; Listening-music;
descrip: Story, song and the written word share a common and ancient heritage in the Irish Tradition. In this seminar series we will explore the rich tapestry that comprises the written word in Irish Language Literature and Song and examine how oral forms of artistic expression continue to enrich a nation's literature and music to this very day. The series will explore the shared histories of Irish Language Poetry and the Sean Nós song tradition, how oral culture finds expression in Irish Theatre and how older oralities still find potent representation and viability in a wide span of contemporary Music Culture, from Opera to Traditional Music.
title: The Irish Oral Tradition

grading: Papers - 80%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Paper 1: 20%, Paper 2: 30%, Paper 3: 30%; Class Participation 20%.
descrip: Why did Donald Trump win the 2016 election? What does his victory tell us about the future of American politics? This course will take up American politics as a democratic process. Do elections work as familiar notions of democracy suggest they should? Why are interest groups so powerful in the policy process? The course asks students to develop their own answers to these questions. Possible paper topics: Why did the Tea Party and Occupy Wall Street movements disappear? How do organized interests get what they want even when large majorities of Americans disagree? How is globalization changing electoral politics in the U.S. and elsewhere?
title: American Politics in the Age of Donald Trump

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Primary reading/viewing/looking is around the work examined in each class; additional reading is background and context and will be expanded/refined. Four Short Papers: 10% each for 40%
descrip: Just as there is no single American imagination, there is no fixed American place. America is a vast and highly diverse landscape and it deserves to be examined from multiple perspectives. As an antidote to facile generalizations about American identity, the class will examine several cases. Buildings, paintings, gardens, literature, films, photographs and music, each one highly specific in time and place. Each class will focus on a single work, presented in a wider social and cultural context. Out of many examples, we will construct an idea of Americas collective sense of self as it has evolved and the contradictions it encompasses.
title: American Places: Architecture, Landscape and the American Imagination

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 4 Short Papers (5 pages each). Final Research Paper (15 pages)
descrip: This seminar will examine the role of Jews in German musical culture from the Enlightenment to the eve of the Holocaust. Through the works and writings of Jewish composers including Mendelssohn, Mahler, Schoenberg, and Weill, we will explore responses to Jewish and German identity: cultural, ethnic, and religious as well as the Jewish relationship to Richard Wagner, whose essay Judaism and Music forged the language of cultural and racial anti-Semitism. We will integrate these topics into both the broader historical context through the writings of Varnhagen, Heine, Schnitzler, and Mann and present day cultural and political context.
title: Before the Holocaust:Germans, Jews, Music, and Identity

grading: Final Exam - 30%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: 50 to 100 pages of reading a week. Students will be expected to contribute to class discussions in a way that shows they have studied the reading material for the week. Two 5-page papers will be assigned, in addition to a final exam.
descrip: This is a course in comparative political theory. Beginning with a study of classical and contemporary Western liberal and democratic theory, this course explores how modern Iranian political theorists and ideologues interpret or critique liberalism and democracy or offer theories of government that stand at odds with liberal and democratic theory. These Iranian authors draw from both religious and non-religious (including Marxist) perspectives. Throughout the course, students will be encouraged to put the diverse authors that they read into dialogue with one another.
title: Liberalism, Democracy, and Iranian Political Thought

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Final Exam - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 50 to 100 pages of reading a week. Students will be expected to contribute to class discussions in a way that shows they have studied the reading material for the week. Midterm, oral presentation, final exam.
descrip: This course surveys major themes in the history of modern Iranian politics and society beginning in the 19th century and ending in the present. Topics to be explored include national identity, imperialism and interaction with the West, Islamic government, monarchism, constitutionalism, revolution, gender, Shi'a religious culture, religious diversity and post-revolutionary reformist and conservative thought and politics. Though focusing on the Iranian context, the course addresses questions asked by thinkers across the Muslim world in the modern period, questions that concern their relationship with the West, with Islam, and with modernity.
title: Modern Iran

grading: Term Paper(s) - 80%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Four papers - 20% each
descrip: We study tissue engineering as a vehicle to improve critical thinking skills. Future scientists, doctors, and medical policy makers need tools to evaluate new technologies for their benefits and limitations, but we are often introduced to advances in science through print media, television, or on-line reporting, which may lack in-depth assessment. Four papers are assigned; emphasis changes from impressions of discussion topics to detailed analysis of hypotheses, claims, and results. The final meeting is a brainstorming session where we devise a strategy for organ regeneration. A basic understanding of chemistry and biology is required.
title: The Smart Band-Aid

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Papers - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%
assgts: Each week, students who are not leading the class discussion are required to upload a Reading Response Brief (1 page, double spaced) to the course Blackboard site by 9 AM on the meeting day. These will be based on the readings for that week and will raise key questions or issues you would like to discuss, as well as how these questions might further our understanding of the readings. Students will also be required to write a research paper (10-12 pages double spaced).
descrip: The course will introduce students to contemporary debates about the role of religion in modern legal systems through lenses of family law, gender, secularism, multiculturalism and human rights focusing on European, Asian, Middle Eastern and African jurisdictions.
title: Law, Religion, and Human Rights in Comparative Perspective

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 20%, Design Project - 10%, Quizzes - 10%, Papers - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: This seminar will expect students to read 70-85 pages per week. In addition to these readings, during the second half of the seminar, students will independently research their chosen social entrepreneur, his/her organization, and general sector. Where possible, Isles, Inc in Trenton (isles.org), and Andela (andela.org) will be used as case studies.
descrip: Private social entrepreneurs (SEs) are stepping up to tackle root causes of social and environmental problems that governments struggle to solve. Can we train effective SEs, and is their nature or nurture most important? This seminar explores these questions and the SE goals of students.They map complex social systems, discover best practices, and explore their own SE ideas and options. They interact with SEs nearby, and for a final project, explore diverse ways to strengthen the SE ecosystem at Princeton. Taught by Martin Johnson `81, Founder/CEO of Isles, a nonprofit group that arose from a Princeton seminar in 1981.
title: So, You Want To Change the World?

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 15%, Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%, Problem set(s) - 15%
assgts: There will be both group work and individual work. Individual work will consist of a mid-term, a final paper, and a few problem sets. Each paper will be on one topic. Every group will have at least one member who is making its topic the subject of his or her final paper.
descrip: This seminar is about thinking about our own future and the future of humanity. What will be important? What will be startling? Climate change will be our vehicle to understand what thinking about the future involves. Much of the analysis will be quantitative. Your essays will be inserted into four time capsules, to be dug up at your 5th, 10th, 25th, and 50th reunions. You will write in depth about new science that clarifies how the Earth works, as well as about specific technologies, their associated policies and how they engage human values. You will also predict your personal futures.
title: Time Capsules for Climate Change, to be Opened at Your Reunions

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 45%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Paper 1 (a 6-7 page paper): 30% Paper 2 (a 10 to 12 page paper due on Deans date): 45%
descrip: This freshman seminar will introduce students to the economics of the music industry, broadly defined. We will cover topics including: the economics of super stars; the influence of technological change, such as digitization, on the economics of the music industry; the economics of ticket pricing; the role of herd behavior in musical fads; and the tradeoffs involved in intellectual property rights protection. Lessons that can be drawn from the music industry for the rest of the economy will be emphasized, such as forces that are moving the U.S. economy toward a winner-take-all economy.
title: Rockonomics: The Economics of Music

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Papers - 35%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: 25% class participation 35% response papers 40% research paper (due on Deans Date)
descrip: In this class, we will trace the rise and fall of maritime piracy from the sixteenth to the eighteenth centuries. We will explore the history of real pirates and their roles in empire-building, state-formation, and cultural exchange, as well as the imaginative possibilities that piracy opened up to early modern thinkers: the miniature republics of pirate ships served as an enticing way to imagine other forms of political organization and social relations. We will also explore the strange literary afterlife of early modern piracy in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, and the persistence of piracy and other lawlessness at sea today.
title: Piracy in the Early Modern World

otherinfo: Other 20% = Book excerpts
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 15%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%, Other (See Instructor) - 20%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: We will read three original works and three novels which give voice to a character silenced in the original: "Beowulf" with Gardner's "Grendel"; Bronte's "Jane Eyre" with Rhys' "Wide Sargasso Sea" and Camus' "The Stranger" with Daoud's "The Meursault Investigation." What role does the hero or heroine play? Why is the antagonist not given a voice in the original? Why do these authors take up the story of the silenced ones? What are they saying about the "other" through these voices? What do these new novels bring that did not exist before and could they exist without their forbearers?
title: Silenced Voices

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 25%, Paper in lieu of Final - 35%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: One 10-15 minute student presentation during class on a selected deity or spirit; Occasional Blackboard Discussions; Short midterm paper (1200 words); Final term paper (2300-2600 words)
descrip: The most fascinating and best-known art objects from Africa primarily depict supernatural beings and were often used for religious and ritual activity. This course returns these objects to their original contexts; it helps us develop fuller appreciation of these art works, the different ways African societies used art and religion to enrich their experience of life and the afterlife, and introduces us to the many ways Africans imagined their world through religion, and also how art - objects, images, and performances - were/are used to articulate and make sense of the encounter of humans with a rich, exciting, frightening, bewildering world.
title: Gods, Spirits and Art in Africa

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 15%, Papers - 55%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: Paper 1: 20% Paper 2: 35% Final presentation: 15%
descrip: How can mathematical modeling help illuminate biological processes? This freshman seminar examines major topics in biology through the lens of mathematics, focusing on the role of models in scientific discovery. Students will learn how to build and analyze models using a variety of mathematical tools. Topics will be organized under three modules: I. Evolution and Behavior (major transitions; evolution of cooperation from bacteria to humans; self-organization and collective behavior; evolutionary game theory); II. Ecology (species interactions; networks; regular patterns); III. Virus Dynamics (spread and contagion; immune system; vaccination).
title: The Equations of Life

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 36%, Quizzes - 34%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: This course is designed to introduce first-year students to the exciting frontiers in quantum physics: from study of electrons in solids to ultra cold atomic gases and potential applications of these ideas for quantum computing.
title: Exotic Quantum States of Matter

grading: Mid Term Exam - 30%, Final Exam - 50%, Quizzes - 20%
prereqs: Students in the course must have taken and passed the Graduate School's Summer German Reading Course, or an equivalent course that covers the basic syntax features of German. In addition, students are expected to know the 600 most frequently used words in German, following Jones & Tschirner (2006), and are tested on these during the first weeks of the course; those without this basic vocabulary are expected to do remedial study on their own prior to the course..
descrip: The course is designed to promote functional comprehension of academic texts in German by combining targeted reading practice, high-frequency vocabulary learning, grammar review, and speaking/pronunciation activities. Texts used for practice are drawn from students' fields of study. Conducted in English, with a limited but critical portion of class conducted in German, to develop an internal sense of how the language works. Assessment is based on students' proficiency in reading/comprehending/summarizing academic texts of increasing length and complexity over the course of the semester.
title: Intermediate German for Academic Reading

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 30%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 15%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: While humans are not the only tool maker in the animal kingdom, they are the most sophisticated. Using perspectives from anthropology, evolutionary biology, human development, and neuroscience, we will explore: How is human tool making unique and how did it evolve? How did the brain adapt to reflect sophisticated tool making? Are the neural circuits subserving tool making related to other human-specific abilities? What happens when these circuits break? The course will include laboratories in which students build stone tools, compare motor behavior of non-human primates and young children, and perform a functional brain imaging experiment.
title: The Human Toolmaker

grading: Mid Term Exam - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%, Problem set(s) - 30%
assgts: See syllabus
descrip: You are at the college dining hall, faced with tens of options. How do choose? In this seminar, we will discuss how our every-day behavior is shaped through trial and error. We will take an integrative approach to phenomena that grew out of classic animal-learning paradigms such as classical conditioning, examining them through the lens of computational models of learning and current neuroscientific knowledge. We will answer questions such as: why do ads so often show a happy smiling family, how can we train a dog to do new tricks, why do we press the walk button more times when in a hurry, how does aberrant learning lead to addiction, etc.
title: Reinforcement Learning and Decision Making

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 40%, Take Home Mid term Exam - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 30%
descrip: This course examines how historians have employed the notion of crisis in the study of the past in particular and the seventeenth century in particular. While the majority of our readings emerge from scholarship on crisis in seventeenth-century Europe, we also look at examples from other times and places. What insights does the notion of crisis release into the historical study of the past? What insights does it inhibit?
title: The General Crisis of the Seventeenth Century

grading: Design Project - 30%, Papers - 50%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Required viewing of films every week in addition to required readings. Project on the general theme of mapping the city through cinema utilizing materials from films, urban texts, and readings
descrip: This course examines the relationship between two forms of mapping the city: cinematic representations of urban space and architectural representations of urban form. The seminar will focus on city imagery and architectural entertainments by examining different methods of framing the city through travel, in the theater, through the invention of traditions, at the museum, from the cinema, or through its architectural composition and spatial configuration.
title: Mapping the City: Cities and Cinema

otherinfo: This course is aimed at graduate students in History and other related disciplines who are interested in questions of regulation, capitalism, the growth of government, labor, trade, etc. It builds on interest in political history and in the history of capitalism, both of which are subjects of interest among emerging graduate students.
grading: Papers - 20%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 40%
prereqs: This course is suitable for early graduate students, those who are preparing for comprehensive exams, and those who are conceiving of possible dissertation topics. Students from all subfields as well as other disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The goal of the course is to familiarize students with the big questions of American political economy in the 20th century and how scholars have thought about them over the last half-century or so. We read a combination of classic and new works that explore the relationship between business and government in the modern era. Along with the list of books below, we also read seminal articles that helped to define new fields, raise new questions, or synthesize the literature.
title: Readings in Modern American Political Economy

otherinfo: Take-Home Exercise, 10%
grading: Oral Presentation(s) - 40%, Term Paper(s) - 40%, Class/Precept Participation - 10%, Other (See Instructor) - 10%
assgts: See Syllabus
descrip: This course is about ethical, social, and political issues arising from discoveries in neuroscience such as: can drugs make us happier, smarter or more lovable? How has neuroscience supported sexism and racism, at least in the past? What are the brain differences between males and females and between straight and gay people and their origins and relevance? Can thoughts and lies be imaged? How does neuroscience impact on legal responsibility? What types of experiments should be allowed on humans and animals? What happened to psychosurgery? To eugenics? How common is cheating in science?
title: Neuroethics

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Papers - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Reading: approx. 100-150 pages per week. Assignments: 3 short essays (2-3 pages), an oral presentation (12 minutes), final research paper (10 pages)
descrip: In this seminar, students examine the social and political context of urban education and examine current trends in U.S. school reform with the urban teacher at the center of our analysis. We start with an overview of U.S. education policy from the 1965 ESEA to the present. We then focus on daily life inside urban schools by reading qualitative studies mainly from sociology and anthropology. Additionally, we invite urban teachers to share stories of their experiences with the latest reforms. This class is designed for students considering urban teaching or with interests in the study of public schooling as a major contemporary social problem.
title: The Dreamkeepers: Education Reform and the Urban Teaching Experience

otherinfo: Course is open to other students with the permission of the instructor.
grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 50%
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in Asian religions. The course is designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays. Note: REL 527 (fall) and REL 528 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.
title: Asian Religions Workshop

otherinfo: This course meets for 1.5 hours per week for the entire semester so it counts as a 6 week course.
grading: Other (See Instructor) - 100%
prereqs: Open to sociology graduate students only. All others must request permission from instructor..
descrip: This course introduces sociology graduate students to the discipline of sociology and to departmental faculty. Student work is evaluated by class participation and attendance. There are no prerequisites.
title: Proseminar

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 25%, Quizzes - 25%, Term Paper(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: Our primary text will be the online course Reinventing the Piano, created here at Princeton and produced by Kadenze. Students in this course will need to enroll in the online course to view lectures, take quizzes, and share work. The course link is here: https://www.kadenze.com/courses/reinventing-the-piano/info
descrip: Musical instruments reside at the intersection of sound and acoustics, perception, embodiment, creativity, music theory, and social values. How has their design influenced the development of music and how might they be reinvented to spur new ideas? Through readings, analysis, and composition, we will explore the relationship between instrument design and creativity. Specific topics include: harmony and the keyboard; tuning and temperament; meter and machines; preparing the piano; acoustics and psychoacoustics. More generally, we will consider the productive tension between qualitative and quantitative understandings of musical concepts.
title: Musical Instruments, Sound, Perception, and Creativity

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Papers - 30%, Class/Precept Participation - 20%
assgts: Weekly homework assignments and a 10-to-12-page final research paper due on Dean's Date
descrip: Princeton and Princetonians have played foundational roles in creating the information technologies - computers, smart phones, and the Internet, for example - that help to define today's world. This seminar will both introduce students to some of the basics of information technologies and emphasize Princeton's role in the development of these technologies. The seminar will examine the contributions of pioneers such as Alan Turing, John Von Neuman, Claude Shannon, John Bardeen, and Robert Kahn, among others, to information technologies. The material will be presented at a level suitable for students with general backgrounds.
title: Princeton and the Dawn of the Information Age

grading: Mid Term Exam - 35%, Final Exam - 50%, Problem set(s) - 15%
prereqs: Prerequisite ELE441 or PHY405 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Electronic structure of solids. Electron dynamics and transport. Semiconductors and impurity states. Electron-electron, electron-phonon, and phonon-phonon interactions. Anharmonic effects in crystals. Dielectric properties of insulators. Magnetism. Superconductivity.
title: Solid State Physics II

grading: Paper in lieu of Final - 30%, Quizzes - 20%, Oral Presentation(s) - 25%, Class/Precept Participation - 25%
assgts: No more than 120 pages per week; Weekly short written responses; 5,000 words final research paper.
prereqs: No prerequisites. Previous knowledge of Latin American contemporary history is an asset..
descrip: This seminar introduces key debates related to human rights, transitional justice, and the politics of memory in Latin America. Special focus will lie on the Southern Cone (Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Brazil), exploring the history of the human rights movement and the complex and diverse attempts to deal with the legacies of the dictatorships. The course will examine the range of transitional justice mechanisms applied, paying special attention to truth seeking efforts (and the work of truth commissions), the role of national and international criminal prosecutions, and initiatives of symbolic reparations and commemoration.
title: Human Rights and Transitional Justice in Latin America

grading: Paper in Lieu of Mid Term - 20%, Paper in lieu of Final - 50%, Other Exam - 10%, Oral Presentation(s) - 20%
descrip: This seminar examines architectural, literary, and critical responses to war between the 1930s and the present. The theories and practices of Surrealism and Counter Surrealism will provide a foundation in the critical (Bataille) and psychoanalytical (Freud, Lacan) construction of, and influence on, post-atomic architectural practices from World War II to the present.
title: Architecture after the Rain: Theory and Design in the Post-Atomic Age 1940-2001
